text: I would recommend that you shell out $13 at the visitor's center and get the CD that is essentially an audio tour of the park. It helps tell the story and points out what you are seeing at most of the pull off places. Overall the views are impressive, especially Cadillace Mountain where you see green trees and blue water on almost all sides.

Ended up there on a sat., sun., was way to crowded. It is a wonderful view, did the 20 mile loop. Went to the top of Cadillac Mtn. and finally found a space to park on sat, returned on sun. and could not find any place to park. There is limited pull offs and in some areas, which are one way only, you can park in the right hand lane, which was also iffy to find a place to park if you have difficulty walking. I advise you to stop if you see a spot, because remember it is one way in certain areas so you can not turn around, you would need to re do part of the loop. Also, I stopped to get driving permit at one of the visitors centers which was like 54 steps to the top office, then learned that if you go out of the parking lot and turn right , there is a road that takes you to the top for handicapped access. There are different passes , for my car it was $25.00 for a week pass, For myself, I still prefer the Blue Ridge parkway, especially in the Smokey Mountains.

The park is full of beautiful sights just made for picture taking. The park loop road has many pull off where you can take pictures or visit the sights like the sand beach, bubble beach, thunder rocks, etc. I think the price was $25/car but I used my senior pass and got in free. Definitely a place to must see.

We stayed in midcoast Maine for a week, and drove to Acadia on Monday. It was pretty crowded for a Monday, we thought, until we realized (after circling for a space on Cadillac Mountain) that people had flocked there for the partial eclipse. We're still not sure why, as the viewing there isn't any better than anywhere else, but I guess to say you were on Cadillac during the eclipse. So, we were on Cadillac for the 2017 eclipse. lol. The scenery all through the park is gorgeous. If you can only go once, and you want to drive, take the Park Loop Road, and stop at all the places you can. If you want to take the loop only once, make sure you stop at Sand Beach, Thunder Hole, and all the others in the one-way section. We went back the following Friday, hiked up the Bubbles, visited Sand Beach, revisited Thunder Hole, and had a great time. If we go back some day, it would be great to take a carriage ride, maybe. The free shuttles from the Visitor Center are very convenient, although we didn't use them. The parking pass was $25, but it was good for a week, which is perfect for vacationers. Bar Harbor is 5 minutes away, with nice restaurants, shopping, etc. Great trip.

Our favorite moment on our three week trip in North-East US was the walk we made in this fantastic park. We walked the Pemetic walk, starting from Jordan pond, where we luckily found a place to park. You need a permit to drive in the park. There is only a one week option of 25$, which is a pitty when you're only there for 2 days, as in our case. Fantastic views. On our second and last evening we wanted to enjoy the sunset and arrived a good 20 minutes before it would happen on the foot. We weren't allowed to drive up Cadillac mountain as it was 'full'. The ranger blocking the road could have been more friendly or in any case communicative for us non-US citizens having questions about the road block. Still it didn't spoil our stay here as we saw the sun going down behind the tree line driving out of the park.

If you love history, this tour is definitely for you! After watching a short video about the Adams family, you board a trolley to see the house John Adams was born in, the house where his son John Quincy Adams was born in, and the "Crown Jewel" of the three Peacefield. The tour lasts about two hours and the park service tour guides are very knowledgeable. At Peacefield, you also tour the family library which contains over twelve thousand volumes. The cost is only ten dollars for the entire tour and they validate parking at the parking garage (plenty of spaces) just behind the visitors center. It is important to note that the tours start at the visitor's center and not at Peacefield it's self!

Go early in the day as a lot of people visit and the only way to see is by a "first come, first served" ranger tour with transportation by national park trolly. There are a limited number of participants on each hourly departure. Cost is $10 per adult, free for children. Free for national pass holders. The rangers were very good at each location. A young woman ranger--sorry we don't recall her name--was very good explaining John Adams and John Quincy Adams homes. Ranger Rick was excellent taking us to the magnificnet Adams library and Peace Field.
A beautiful place to visit. Lovely home and surrounding grounds. Be sure to use your National Parks Senior Pass. The guides are very knowledgeable and helpful.

Everything was right about this attraction. It was well organized, efficient, interesting and inexpensive. For $10 and free parking visitors are trollied to see three homes and a library of 2 Presidents, John Adams and John Quincy Adams. The guides are very well informed and move visitors through in 2 hours. We truly felt a great sense of early American history.

If you're visiting the Boston area, do not miss this! It costs $10 per adult and the trolley takes you to two different locations - the houses where John Adams was born and where he lived for awhile after he married. But the really interesting part is the house at Peace field. It is incredible how well preserved the house is and the original furnishings inside. It's a guided tour and I highly recommend this!

The Adams family homes located in Quincy are spread out a bit in the city so you'll have to either walk to the sites or board the trolley that runs every 15 minutes picking up and dropping off tourists to the visitor center, Peace Field, or the birthplace of both John and John Quincy Adams. The tours within the historic homes are extremely informative and led by visibly enthusiastic and knowledgeable National Park Service employees. Entrance fees to tour the sites are $10 per person, with children or students free. This experience can last all day or you can do it all in a couple hours.

I had read David McCullough's biography and because we were staying with family in a nearby town, I wanted to visit the birthplace and see the actual sites where John Adams lived. The price is very reasonable and because I work at a museum, they kindly gave me and my family free admission. It is only $10 for adults and kids are free. They validate parking if you park in the big parking structure behind the visitor center. We arrived in time to get a spot on the next shuttle but we had to wait about an hour, but during that time we were able to see the short film and visit the Adams crypt at the church close by. The crypt was amazing--with a volunteer guide you can get right into the small room with the tombs of John Adams and John Quincy Adams and their wives. It was such a special feeling to be right there with no barriers or distance. We went back to the visitor center when it was time to get on the shuttle bus and visit the two small houses that are the birthplaces of the two presidents and then the house at Peacefield where they lived later. They take you in small groups and at Peacefield you get to go all over the house and also visit the stone library. The family furniture and portraits are still in the house, including the desk where John Adams wrote his letters to Thomas Jefferson. Even for the rest of my family, who were not particularly interested in John Adams, it was an interesting tour and fun to ride on the trolley. The guides were very knowledgable and welcomed questions from the group.

We used our Golden age pass which saved us $10 each for the tour. There is a lot of construction in downtown Quincy so expect a little delay for the trolley. We enjoyed the introductory movie at the visitors center. The tour guides at each of the two stops were fascinating and they really knew their stuff The first stop arrived at the birthplaces of Presidents John Adams and John Quincy Adams. We proceeded to Peace Farm where 4 generations of the Adams famiy lived. The home is filled with original art and furnishings. We especially enjoyed the library ***Make sure to have your parking ticket validated for free parking!

I have been to Boston a number of times and love the freedom trail and all that Boston offers. However don't overlook this significant piece of history! Ok, so Adams is my favorite president (even though he was argumentative). Even so, seeing the three primary homes he lived in during his life was moving. On the tour ($10) you will see where he was born and where he died. In Peacefield, you will see the actual furniture he and Abigail decorated their home with, including the desk John used. In future visits with my grandkids, I will be sure to include this attraction on our itinerary!

See where John Adams and John Quincy Adams were both born and where John & Abigail spent their final days at Peace Field. You buy tickets at the park offices in Quincy Center and can ride the trolley to all the sights. It only cost $10 per person for the tickets, which includes the trolley and curated tours through the 3 buildings. The gardens are magnificent, the Stone library is quaint (1870 Victorian-era) and impressive with its 14000 books in 10 languages. It truly is an opportunity to walk back in time, and try to imaging Boston both before, during and after the Revolution and during the early years of newly organized United States of America. You'll also learn who else from the time used to come and visit the Adamses -- Thoreau, for example, and the leading abolitionists of the time. The family tomb is nearby and the Hancock Cemetary as well. You can also see the Adams Academy, started by John Adams in honor of his friends John Hancock and Josiah Quincy, who, like Adams, lived in the town of Quincy, Massachusetts. Only negative: the guide at the carriage house told us the park fee had to be paid in cash: not true! The main visitors' center takes credit cards, but one of the card swipes was malfunctioning on the day we visited. To be safe, bring both (cash/credit). Fun items for all ages in the gift shop.

We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to the Adams National Historical Site. Your visit starts at the Visitor's Center in Quincy, MA. This is where you buy your tickets (which are free if you have a National Park Visitor's Pass) and choose a tour time. The center has restrooms, a gift shop and a film to watch while you wait for your tour to begin. Although there is no food available at the Visitor Center, there is a small convenience store across the hallway from the center where you could buy some refreshments.

The National Park Service gives tours about John Adams and John Quincy Adams for $10.00 per person. They take you to the 2 birthplaces and Peace field which became their retirement home by trolley. It's a good 2 hours, and the Park Service was very knowledgeable. While you wait for your tour, you can watch a 26 min. video about 4 generations of the Adams family. They also have a gift shop. It is easy to reach by riding the Red line from Boston to Quincy. Take the one that says Braintree and get off at Quincy Center. After you exit, take a left and you see the 1250 Hancock Street Building. If you go the far left of the building, you will see the Visitor Center. The tour pushes you through pretty fast. I wish they gave us a little more time at each stop. No photographs are allowed inside but outside is OK. If you are a local, you can stop by anytime without a ticket and stroll through the gardens of the retirement home. We didn't have much time to do that. There is a tree at the retirement home that was planted by John Quincy Adams in 1826 and is still alive!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

If you're into history, you're really going to nerd out at the Adams National Historical Park. For $10 you take the trolley around to the three houses and get guided tours from NPS rangers at each one. All three tours were fantastic and very informational.

This site is great! There is an air conditioned trolley to take you from home to home and the park rangers are very well informed. They did a great job of answering questions and facilitating the tours. There is so much to see so I reccomend the paid tour which runs about $10 and gets you the trolley ride and admission to four different buildings. This is a must see for adults and children alike!

We've been traveling across the US for about 6 months and have been to lots of historical sites and national parks. This one ranks in the top 10 mostly due to the enthusiasm of the rangers and volunteers. Also one of the few National Parks that hasn't been sub-contracted out to a vendor which means your Senior Pass (or other national pass) actually means it is really free. That includes the parking which they validate for you in the Visitor's Center. A trolley takes you to the two sites of the Adams homes - we were so impressed that so much is original. What foresight the family had in keeping everything - even John Adam's chair and desk. The paintings of family members and friends give great insight into who the Adams' were and how they thought. What great contributions they made to our country and sacrifices they made to do so. The only down side was that there aren't too many places to eat near the Visitor's Center so you might want to grab a meal before you arrive if you go near lunchtime. You aren't allowed to take photos inside any of the buildings.

This tour is so highly organized and a bargain ($5). The tour guides offer so much detail as to the history of the family and the furnishings. The home is gorgeous and is packed with original furnishings. The garden is stunning in the summer. The presidential library is a book lovers paradise. I look forward to my 4th tour this summer.

The Park starts downtown where you have to sign up for a trolley to take you to the three houses on the tour. It cost $5 for adults to take the trolley to the houses. At the park office downtown, there is a very good film that is narrated by Tom Hanks and Laura Linney. It gives you a good background to prepare you for the tour. We had to wait about 30 minutes for the trolley. The trolley takes you to the first stop which are 2 houses - one where John Adams was born and grew up and the second house where John and Abigail lived and where John Quincy was born. After that tour, you get back on the trolley which takes you to the Peacefield, an estate which John and Abigail purchased and which remained in the Adams family until it became a park. It is beautiful and has most of the original furniture from the Adams family. The stand alone library is amazing. I must confess my 13 year old daughter did not enjoy the visit. Our visit took about 3 1/2 hours in all. A couple of tips - there is a parking garage behind the park office - take your ticket with you because the Park will validate it. Also, use the restrooms at the park office. There are no public restrooms at any of the houses.

A friend recommended the visit and said they liked it better than the JFK Library. I remember thinking, well I won't feel the same. But I became curious and decided to see for myself. This National Park is easily accessible from Boston by car. I will have to agree that this was an amazing historic site and at $5 one of the best values around. Start at the visitors center where you will see an excellent film and then take the bus. You will return here, so buy your souvenirs at the end. The journey takes about 2 hours and you will first see the John Adams and John Quincy Adams birthplaces. These two homes are just a few yards apart and now are on a busy thoroughfare in Quincy. The National Park Rangers were excellent docents and able to answer every odd question. At "Peace Field" which is the later Adams home, you will see "the first sofa" and "the first desk." You will also see the dining room table where President Monroe asked John Quincy Adams to be Secretary of State. You will also see John Adams favorite chair and the room where he died on July 4, 1826 exactly 50 years after Independence Day.

Thoroughly enjoyed the tours of the Adams homes, library, and garden. Transport by trolley was very convenient, tour guides were very knowledgeable, and price was right- $5 for about 3 hour tour. Well worth the stop. Visitor center was excellent, as well. Parking garbage was close by and Visitor Center validated the parking ticket for free parking.

Have lived in the area for 50+ years. Have driven by it dozens of times and never did the Adams tour. So one Saturday we decided to. Empty nesters now. When we arrived at what we though was the Adams homes, we discovered it was actually a trolley tour to multiple sites. Sounds great ! The park ranger was very helpful directly us. Cheap tour ! When we arrived at the birth houses, we split into two groups with two tour guides. Our guide was actually rude to a couple of teenagers (!) in our group. We were pleasantly surprised that kids were on the historical tour on their own. They were quiet, etc. But the guide kept singing them out to correct them. Created a very uncomfortable tour. Then when we went back to our original house, many of the rooms were roped off. We've been on a lot of historical tours before. This one barely touched on any of their presidential accomplishments. It was abut the houses, when they moved in/out, etc. Less about the men.

Great value! For $5 you ride the trolley to the birthplace of John and John Quincy Adams for a guided tour. The trolley takes you to Peacefield the family home. It was worth the price of admission by itself! TJ gave a great tour. 2 hours total. Worth every penny

I visited the Adams family homes with two teens this summer. As others have mentioned, the Visitors Center was difficult to find initially. I did not expect it to be located in an office building, but parking in the garage behind the center was ample and free. The tour itself is a bargin. Adults pay $5 and children 16 and under are free. Plan to spend about 3 hours. Tours leave every 30 minutes and the size of the tours are limited so on busy days you might need to wait awhile. We went on a Monday morning and had no trouble joining the next tour. There is a short film that plays continuously that you can watch while you are waiting. We were told there are no restrooms at the historic homes, and there are only two bathrooms at the Vistors' Center, so plan accordingly. There are some coffee shops, convenience store, and a Subway nearby for food if needed.

If you like your early American history, the Adams National Park is for you. The $5.00 entry fee not only gets you, a guided tour of all 3 homes, the visitor center and the Adams library, but transportation between them. The rangers are all knowledgeable, friendly and enthusiastic; they really seem to like what they do. The garden at Peace Field are beautiful with wonderful shade trees. It was just missing a couple of benches for lingering. With all the original pieces, you really feel like you're walking with history. The only warning I would give an out-of-town visitor is watch the afternoon Boston/South Shore traffic. After 3PM, it's a killer...The National Park staff is running this place right.

After finding where to park (garage behind center) 3rd level is public parking and visitor center validates your ticket. The rangers were very helpful and friendly. We took their provided free trolley to the birth homes ($5 for each of us)and since were short on time stayed on the trolley skipping the 3rd house.
Cheap ($10) tour includes a trolley ride to both sites (birthplace houses & mansion). Very informational and enjoyable tour for American History fans.

Although I live close by I had never done the "tour" and was so happy to take visitors from California. The history is wonderful, the Adams Presidential Library is beautiful and one of the most interesting. The house has so many artifacts and stories that it's worth visiting again. I would highly recommend this tour to anyone locally or from afar. It's very reasonable to visit national parks and with a Senior Pass which is available for purchase here you can enter any of our wonderful National Parks.

As a lifelong MA resident, I grew up less than 3 miles from these sites, driven by them daily and never visited. What a surprise to find out the tour for myself and 2 kids was only $5! The entire tour takes about 2 hours. There's an opportunity to watch a short film in the visitor's center if you arrive early enough. It was well done and worth watching, not to mention helpful while taking the tour. We then got on the trolley and visited the birthplaces of John Adams and John Quincy Adams. The Park Service broke up the visitors into 2 smaller, more manageable groups which works really well considering the small rooms we walked through. Loved Peace Field where John and Abigail lived. You could visualize the large extended family living under one roof. There's an impressive library out back, complete with Mendi Bible used for the inauguration of our current Governor. My 13 yr old son was on crutches for this tour and managed quite well as there was only one trip up a flight of stairs to a second floor. So glad I finally took the time to view our National treasures, right in my backyard!

This was an incredible experience. We opted for the trolley ride to each site and it definitely is the way to do it. Only $5 a person so it is not expensive by today's standards. The homes and the family library are impressive as great care is given to keep them 'original'. The rangers who spoke with us were well informed and interesting.

Absolutely wonderful! The Peace Field home of John and Abigail Adams is a great way to spend a couple of hours. For a $5 fee at the visitor center, a trolley picks you up and takes you to the birth places of both John Adams and John Quincy Adams, then on to the Adams home (Peace Field). The furniture and decor in the house are original to the home, including a 350-year-old grandfather clock that they received as a wedding gift. Definitely worth the trip. You can take the red line to the Quincy Center stop and walk less than two blocks to the visitor center. The only down side is that there are no photographs allowed inside the homes.

The hotel scoffed when we said we wanted to go to Quincy to see this park and suggested the harbor tour instead. She was wrong! We are a family of history and national park buffs, so this was perfect. The only problem is lack of signage. Even with nap and gps we had trouble finding the park headquarters (and starting place for the tours). The headquarters is on the first floor of an office building housing Quincy College and law offices. We expected a free standing facility and actually drove by the place several times. While there is parking in a garage behind this building, it is not easy to locate. If you manage to get there, take your parking ticket into headquarters and they will validate it for free parking.. It is a small headquarters with the obligatory movie (pretty good) and small gift shop. That is it. The tours begin at this site and you can not join at other spots. The cost was $5 pp. The group goes first to the two homes (adjacent to each other) which are the birth places of John and John Quincy Adams. You visit each on guided tours.You can not visit the sites individually or on your own. From there, you travel on the trolley to PeaceFields, a much larger home with beautiful gardens and separate library building that belonged to the former Presidents and their descendants. The guided tour there is about an hour. Each guide was very different, but knowledgeable in their individual ways. Unfortunately it rained at the last stop, so we could not enjoy the gardens.

This is the best $5 you will ever spend. You watch a film in the visitor's center, and then a trolley takes you to the birthplace and home of John Adams & John Quincy Adams. A wonderful glimpse at our countries history.

Best $5 we spent. Tour includes trolley ride and tours of birthhouse and retirement house. Definitely watch the HBO mini-series on John Adams based on the biography by David McCullough before you go. Also try to go to the church next to the Visitor Center that has the graves of John Adams, Abigail Adams, John Quincy Adams and his wife. Tours of the church are donation only

My favorite was John Adams' massive library and the desk where he composed his defense of the British soldiers in the Boston Massacre. The humble home where he was born and where Abigail meet with spies also made a deep impression. There are so many artifacts and pieces of original Adams furniture on display at Peacefield. Well worth the $5 price. Come early, though. It is first come, first served with a limited number of spaces.

This is a guided tour run by the National Park Service. The ticket is $10, but if you have your senior entrance card to all the National Parks, it is free. You can get one there for that amount. A trolley takes you from in front of the office where you get the tickets to the 3 Adams' houses where you visit the interiors with informative guides that give you historically accurate information and make the tour not only educational but really enjoyable. Your are reliving history. If you read McCollough's book ot saw the PBS documentary, this gives life to it. Don't miss visiting the church, practically next door, where John and Quincy Adams are buried with their wives. The entrance there is a $10 donation. In both places, not much walking for seniors, just a few stairs.

Make sure if you are in the Boston area that you take the time to go just a few miles South to the Adams National Historical Park. Go to the Visitors Center to get tickets. They are very cheap-$5. Kids under 16 were free. They will direct you to the Church where John Adams and John Quincy Adams are buried with their wives. We were greeted by Gary who gave us a quick tour of the church that the family belonged to as well as their graves. The trolley takes you to the birthplaces of both presidents as well as to Peacefield, the home of 4 generations of the Adams family. The house went directly from the family to the National Park System so it has not been changed and contains the original furnishings. Our guides were all interesting and informative. It is a must see and gives you a greater appreciation for the contributions that this family made to our nation. They were ahead of their time on many issues.

My daughter and I enjoyed our visit to Adams National Historical Park. Begin at the Visitor's Center in downtown Quincy. There is a parking garage behind the Center, though it's kind of confusing as a good deal of the spaces are marked "reserved" for local business employees. Head up to the third level for visitor parking. And take your garage ticket to the Visitor Center with you - they will stamp it so your parking will be free (otherwise, it will cost you $4-5 to park for the lengh of a tour.) The tour costs only $5 and starts at the Visitor's Center with a movie (about 15 minutes). A trolley picks you up from there and drives your group to the first two Adams homes, and then to another site where the third home is located. The homes are very interesting to see, and the tour guides - as the National Park Service rangers usually are - are wonderful and very knowledgeable. Allow about 2 hours for the tour, plus extra waiting time for the next tour to start (there is a gift shop in the Center to keep you busy). I believe the tours run every hour. The only negative thing I can say is that we weren't encouraged to walk around the gardens at Peacefield (the third home), though I believe you are allowed to if you want to. If you are looking for a meal or snack before or after your visit, I recommend Gunter Tootie's across the street from the Visitor's Center for a yummy sandwich, salad, or pastry.
This is located at the Visitor's Center and run by the Park's dept. Movie at the center, trolley ride to best historic homes and buildings in Quincy and only costs five dollars.

The NPS has a true set of treasures with the Adams National Historical Park consisting of three historic homes filled with tons of history and impressive art! Their guided tour lasts approximately 2 hours- touring through each of these houses, with a trolley shuttle between the sites. The NPS tour cost $5 and my son was free. The tour we took was fantastic!

I've lived in the Boston area for over 10 years now, but never even thought to look up John Adams' home until my father came to visit (a history buff). Using our National Parks Pass (costs $80 bucks and allows everyone in your party free entrance into any National Park), we were able to get on the Park's trolley which took us over to the visitor center in downtown Quincy. There, they have a short video which covers some of John Adams' life and a gift shop. The tour has an itinerary and runs according to a strict schedule. From the visitors center, the trolley takes you to the birthplaces (homes) of both John Adams and John Quincy Adams. The park rangers take you inside each residence and give you a quick back story on their lives in those homes. Next, they take you by trolley to the "Old House" where four generations of Adams eventually lived. The grounds here are beautiful and the National Park Service clearly puts in a lot of time and effort to maintain the land. I was very impressed, and can't believe it took me this long to come here!

After paying up to $25 at other presidential homes, I couldn't believe this was only $5. Free for me since I have a senior park pass. A trolley takes you to 3 homes. You must have a ticket to see the inside of the homes so be sure you have at least 2 hours. Parking tip: the garage is behind the visitor center and free on weekends.

Whether you've read David McCullough's John Adams or not, this is a site that you shouldn't miss. For $5, you get a guided tour of John and John Quincy's birthplace, the latter's library, and the home at Peace Field. The NPS annual pace can be used here in place of the fee.

Being a history buff I could not wait to finally take a tour of the homes of our 2nd and 6th president John Adams. We took a two hour tour of three of the home which was so informative. Peacefield was fabulous as the house is filled with original items of the Adams family. Would recommend this to anyone!! Might be a little long for younger children so I would wait till they are older. With so much original items in last home you have to be to careful to take little ones in. Price could not be beat. It was hard to find visitors center in Quincy even with the signs that were up.

A must-see for a trip to Boston! Quincy is easily accessible via the T (red line), and the tour begins across from the station. It's only $5 for adults, kids 16 and under free, and free for National Parks passholders. The 2 hour tour takes you by trolley to the birthplaces of John and John Quincy Adams and the post-presidential Adams mansion (with the 1st Presidential Library) and is conducted by extremely knowledgeable guides (ours were Bob and Dennis - both terrific!)

I guess because it is in Quincy, this doesn’t show up on many lists of what to do in Boston; in fact, I heard about it from a friend. It is super easy to get to Quincy; simply take the Red Line T to Quincy Center and walk across the street to the National Park visitor’s center. A shuttle is provided, and it runs approximately every 30 minutes. It is only $5 (free if you have an NP pass) for two full hours of informative history about our 2nd & 6th presidents – John Adams and John Quincy Adams. So here is the coolest piece of trivia – John Adams and Thomas Jefferson, both signers of the Declaration of Independence and 2 of 3 signers still alive to celebrate our countries 50th anniversary, both died on the same day – July 4th, 1826. How ironic! The tour includes the house that John was born in, the house John Quincy was born in, the Adams house post Europe diplomat tour, and the best of all, the Adams library. Follow this with a trip to see where John F. Kennedy was born.

For $5, we saw three historical sites that were incredibly interesting. The tour guides did a great job of providing historical background of the properties. My favorite part of the tour was the Adams' main house and John Quincy's library. We didin't have a car in Boston, but accessing the property via the train was very easy. I would definitely go on this tour again!

On a visit to my son and daughter-in-law I had a morning to kill. The tour of the Adams National Historical Park and the church where two Presidents and their wives are entombed was a great way to fill that time. Guides (Park Rangers?) at both sites on the trolley tour were passionate and informative about the history of the area and family. I purchased a years membership in the National Parks so only had to pay the $4 requested donation at the church for the whole experience. Buy a National Parks pass and use it close to home. It is one of the best entertainment deals going, and supports our heritage.
Read the book saw the places! Fantastic deal. $5.00, parking validated and a great tour all in one. Felt like I was there in 1776.

It took us awhile to find this place in Quincy, MA, due to unclear, or hidden, signs, so by the time you find it and then find a place to park you are a little frustrated. After we got to the Visitor's Center, the Park Ranger was terrific. He first validated our parking ticket and then set us up on the next tour, which was on a trolley. We saw birth homes for both John Adams and John Quincy Adams. These were just 2 houses sitting on a corner with no signs to tell anyone what they are. We then were taken to a home that held 4 generations of John Adam's family. During the last part of the tour in the library, we were crammed into a small space with lots of people and neither of us could move. It made this part of the tour painful and very uncomfortable for both my husband and me. The park rangers gave the tours and I would have prefered a tour with more information given on the family and less on the artifacts in the homes. I realized my lack of information on this family and wanted a book to tell me more about their lives. One of the rangers in the visitor's center helped me choose some books to buy. Overall, this was a good experience and helps visitors learn about this important part of our country's history. I would recommend it to anyone. If you are 62, or older, get a park pass for $10 and thereafter every visit to a National Park will be free of charge.

This is for history bufffs who want to see the actual Adams houses and learn the history behind them and the famous Adamses from Quincy. It's a trek from Boston, but if you've got a car, you can see Wollaston Beach and eat at fancy Marina Bay, also in Quincy. Marina Bay has a range of restaurants from $$ to $$$$ and I think all of them have a waterfront view. There's a boardwalk and ice cream and a sense of being off the beaten path. If you don't have a car, Quincy is definitely on the T and Quincy Center has some nice eateries if you're on foot.

We have been planning to go here for years and are so glad we made it! It's only $5 a person (or free with Parks pass) and the tour is interesting whether or not you saw the HBO series on John Adams. It covers both the birthplace homes of both presidents Adams as well as Peace Field where John retired and died. Original paintings, furnishings and even the wisteria Abigail Adams planted. We were transported!

The tour begins at the Visitors Center in the middle of town. The Visitors Center is actually in a large city building containing many shops and offices, but visible signage makes it fairly easy to find. You can park your vehicle in the building's parking garage and they will validate your ticket at the Center when you get your tour tickets so that the parking is free. After paying a reasonable cost for the tour of $5 per person, or using one of the National Park passes to eliminate the cost, you hop the next tour trolley right outside the Center. During the 2 hour tour you visit 2 homesteads, the first stop being the side by side early homes of the Adams family and then on to Peacefield. The rangers were outstanding at both locales, giving lots of interesting information and most willing to answer questions. The trolley then returns you to the Visitors Center where, if you have the time, you can take in the PBS John Adams film (not the HBO miniseries that is better known), walk to the Church where Abigal and John are interred in a basement crypt (an additional cost), visit a nearby Revolutionary War era cemetery, or stop at one of the several nearby restaurants before heading home. It was a most enjoyable day.

The Adams homestead and library are beautiful places to visit. The library next to the main house is unbelievable and very beautiful. The main house is decorated just the way it was originally. The tour is great and not to be missed. The Park Rangers do and excellent job of giving tours of the house and library. Since it is a National Park, seniors get free admission with the Park Pass.

I took the train from Boston for the first morning tour. I had it all to myself - a private tour! It's now closed for winter. But go in the Spring! You first go to the Visitor's Center across from the train stop in Quincy and buy your $5 ticket (great value!) From there you take a trolley to the boyhood homes of John Adams and John Q. Adams. They stand next to one another, preserved for posterity in a busy residential area. They have been restored to appear as they did during Adams' occupancy. Some furnishings are original as the homes remained in the family until donated to the Park Service. You tour each home, which takes less than 30 min. total. You then get back on the trolley to drive 10 min. to tour the home John Adams bought later in life and lived in until he died. This home is exquisite and contains numerous family furnishings. You get a real sense of how they lived. I highly recommend that you read David McCullough's Pulitzer Prize winning book "John Adams" before you visit, as it will offer great insight into one of our greatest Founding Fathers and most under-appreciated Presidents. John Adams arguably did as much or more to secure America's freedom as any man, including Washington. Unlike Washington and Jefferson, Adams was not born rich, but he was determined to gain independence. A great American! John Quincy's youth in Paris with his father during the Revolution inspired him to become President, too. The first father-son Presidents. Go see where it all started.

After seeing the Adams miniseries on HBO, we decided to pay a visit. We went on a very hot July day (midweek) and were able to get on the trolley right away. The birthplace and family homes are small and limited on what you can see, but portable A/C units made them bearable even on the very hot day. The guides are very knowledgeable and friendly. No internal photo's though. The tour of the library and of the Peacefield house are more comprehensive and again, knowledgeably led. Whole tour is about 2 hours, $5 (great deal), and very interesting for adults. I would leave kids at home though. Use bathrooms before leaving! They even validate parking for the lot behind the center.

I read the reviews, still had a bit of a time finding the Park Office! The building where the National Historic Park office is not well marked at all. It shares space with an office building/ parking garage with a restaurant and shopping. Do not forget to get your parking ticket validated at the National Park desk when you buy your admission ticket! We were with the first group of 10 for the first tour of the day at 9:15. Some other members of this group told me that availability of the tours is limited and tour groups take availability first. The others in our group had called the day before to check for an open tour time. I just showed up at 8:30 and sat on the Park Service doorstep and got lucky. My daughter (age 11) and I enjoyed the tour very much. Staff very knowledgeable. Plan on two hours. If you want to stay and walk around the grounds at Peace Field, you can, but must wait about 30 minutes for the next trolley. Adult ticket was $3.50, my daughter was free. Exceptional value for the three houses plus library.

The trolley and the three house tours only cost $5. I was visiting a friend that has lived near Quincy most of her life and had never before visited this treasure. Since I am a history buff it was definitely on my "want to do list" so my friend reluctantly tagged along with me. Both of us had a great time and were very impressed with how easy it was to get the trolley from the Visitor Center in town, and how knowledgeable the guides were at each location. The guides at both locations provided a lot of information, though the guide at Peacefield was outstanding and very personable. My friend is talking about going back again and taking more people there when they come to visit her. I recommend this tour to anyone visiting the greater Boston area.

It was easy to do this, once we found the visitor center in the red brick business building on Hancock St, near the United First Parish Church. Park in the garage, 3rd floor or above, attached to the building & have the vistor center stamp parking ticket & parking is free. Once you pay for the tour at the visitor center, $5/adult, under 16 yrs old - free, they provide the trolley to the sites of the three houses. Learned alot about the Adams family on this tour. The tour guides we had were very knowledgeable. As expected, they don't tell you much about the conflicts & problems the Adams' had in politics & other areas. but you do learn about many of the good things they accomplished. You spend about 1/2 hr each on the guided tour of the first 2 houses, see first floors only. & about 1 hr at the Old house, where you go thru 1st & 2nd floor of the 3 stories, plus the Library building. Take your pictures outside when you can, because they move you along rather quickly to the next tour or next trolley. The history alone in these houses, makes it worth while to vist all 3. We started at the visitor center about 9:15am & got back there at the end about 11:30am.

We purchased the Annual Adams National Historical Park Pass that is good for one year from date of purchase for $10 which admits cardholder and three adults…..a good deal considering if the two of us purchased a day pass it would have been $10! We had toured the Park a few years ago, but wanted to return after seeing the HBO Miniseries. Since it was late in the season, there was not much of a line and we were able to get onto the 9:45am tour, only getting there at 9:35am. There is free parking (on weekends) behind the Visitors Center, which includes some video as well as some other interesting Adams facts and a small gift shop.

This is a gem of a National Monument, well worth the drive if you're in the area. Having just come from Mt. Rushmore National Monument, with its $11 paid parking and thousands upon thousands of visitors, ice cream, t-shirts--well, this is an entirely different way to experience a National Monument: You and the park rangers, and a handful of other visitors. Not to take away from Gutzon Borglum's iconic sculpture, because that's cool in its own way, but that seems like the Disneyworld of the Park Service--show business. Agate Fossil beds is quiet, thoughtful, and a window into other times.

Great forest with plenty of hiking trails ranging from 2 miles to 12. Dogs are allowed on the trails and in the campgrounds on leash. Each trail has its own map, and maps are located at the start of the trails. Camping costs $12/night. It's easy to complete the form and drop the money off. Be sure to have cash.

I really enjoyed being at the càmpground, although the only 5 sites we were shown as being available didn't have much n the way of good flat tent camping sites. My boyfriend complained a lot about the old facilities, etc. He remembers the old days when the Forest Service ran the campgrounds rather than the concessionaires but I don't remember that well........and I thought the place was fine. We didn't cook at all for the two days we were there - ate at Bob's Trading Post and Westline Inn. That added up the $$$ a little - I would make more of an effort to cook ourselves next time. Day one we did a great 23 mile bicycle trip, partly using the snowmobile trail - and then the dirt Forest roads. Day two, we spent in inner tubes and swimming at the beach. There were some loud kids, but otherwise a very nice experience!

We stayed at site 34 a week before the busy end of summer holiday. The campground was packed. It was very hot this weekend (upper 80's with 100% humidity) We checked in on a Friday around 3pm, and were the only ones there, but by about 6pm the place was jumping with weekend campers. The hut when you pull in is very helpful, everything from wood, to boat rentals, to pricy sodas, they have it all. A somewhat large bundle of wood is 10$, to give you an idea, we spend about 50$ on wood for the whole weekend but had large fire most of the night to stay warm (after the sun goes down, it gets chilly there)

I took the island wildlife cruise at 9:30 a.m. with Island Packers for $38, but our boat stopped by Anacapa Island to drop off people who were doing the day trip ($59) or going camping for the night ($79). On our way to the island, we saw a few humpback whales and when we arrived to Anacapa, we also saw a cute little sea lion on the pier. We continued with the wildlife cruise after dropping off several passengers and we toured around East Anacapa where we saw the lighthouse and Arch Rock. There were many seals and sea lions hanging out by some rocks around that area. Next, we cruised to Middle Anacapa Island where we saw lots of caves and the areas where different shipwrecks occurred. Along the way to West Anacapa, we saw Keyhole Rock and Frenchys Cove as well. These were the highlights of the tour around Anacapa Island, but one of my favorite moments was on our way back to Oxnard Harbor. We saw a pod of dolphins swimming alongside our boat and hundreds of them just jumping out of the water. It was really unforgettable and I will be back to Anacapa for a day trip next time so that I can actually have the chance to get off the boat and explore/hike on the island. I recommend this cruise to anyone considering a visit to the beautiful Channel Islands!
Our fascinating trip started at 10 AM and we were back by 5 pm. The cost was $60 and well

I've lived in California for many years and have often thought of visiting the Channel Islands but just didn't know that much about it. Well I finally went with a friend and boy was it amazing. I booked a ticket on the Island Packers ferry. It's about an hour to Anacapa and $59 round trip. I really didn't know what to expect except I knew to bring a picnic lunch and there were no concessions on the island. When we arrived we saw so many sea gulls sitting on nests. The nests were scattered all over the island and in plain view as there are only low plants/shrubs. Each nest had 1-3 eggs. We saw one chick as it was hatching. Several had baby chicks. They were beautiful. It was fascinating to see so many sea gulls in one place. The views are amazing and Inspiration Point lives up to it's name. The gravel figure eight trail is about 2-1/2 miles round trip. It's an easy walk. There are some slight hills. When the boat docks you do have to walk up about 150 steps to the trail. Do not miss this. They say there are different times to go to the island - spring has the flower blooms, late May/June has the sea gulls. There are also sea lions and seals to watch as well. Fantastic day!!!

The ranger led tour of the Homestead was very informative. Andrew Johnson's family showed amazing strength during and after the Civil War. Be aware that the homestead will be undergoing a major renovation and may not be open. Tickets for the tour are issued at the Visitor's Center which is several blocks away. Also, the address given on the website lead us to the National Cemetery and not the Visitor's Center.

we spent one night at the table mountain campground during the labor day weekend. the sites are nicely spaced, not too crowded. the camp host was friendly. the cost was $20 per night. it was Saturday night, and they happened to have a "Miner vincent memorial &campfire" program. the stories were interesting. after that they played the movie Kung Fu Panda 3, which was nice for a family night. we haven't watched a movie under the stars for a loooong time! it was a very relaxing evening.

Quick and easy access to snow play areas, hiking, camping, or just a drive through the forest-lined windy roads up to Mt. Wilson for a peak at all of LA - all the way to Catalina and then some. Not bad for a $5 pass!

If you don't mind hopping rocks, walking across logs, and ducking branches to get to the falls, then try Switzer! This hike should be on everyone's bucket list. Located above La Canada on the Angeles Crest Highway (don't forget Adventure Pass), it's an easy drive to the Switzer Truck Trail. Get to trailhead early for premium parking at the BOTTOM of the fire road. Otherwise, it's an UPHILL walk to your car after the hike in the overflow lot!

Amazing beauty can be found in the canyons and mountains of Angeles National Forest, which can be reached in 30 minutes from Downtown LA. Angeles Crest Highway rises to 8000', with walks up to 10,000 foot mountains nearby. Mt. Wilson offers fantastic views of the LA Region, and on a clear day out to Catalina Island. Switzers, 20 minutes outside La Canada, provides a beautiful streamside walk, and a waterfall view, and stays cool even on hot summer days. The trail on the east side of JPL up the Arroyo is terrific. Be sure to purchase a Forest Adventure Pass for parking (available at Sport Chalet in La Canada and elsewhere). The park is laced with fire roads that are perfect for mountain biking, as well as hiking trails and backpacking camps. For overnight camping, drive an hour from La Canada out Angeles Crest. Don't miss it.

This review is specifically for Henninger Flats above Altadena. Started backpacking late Friday afternoon from the gate and arrived at the flats about and an hour forty minutes later. The uphill climb and afternoon sun made for a good work out! The campground offered nice, shady sites with clean restrooms nearby for our scouting group. With nightfall, came the million dollar view of the twinkling lights below....hard to believe we were only minutes from the city! Signs warn of rattlesnakes and should not be taken lightly as we saw a baby rattler camouflaged at the foot of a tree the next day. As far as things to do, you can take a hike up to Mt. Wilson (half our troop), work on a conservation project with the ranger (the other half), or read a book and watch squirrels scamper up and down trees (what I did), it's all good and it's all free! So whether you enjoy hiking, biking or backpacking the 2.7 miles, the view at the top is all the same, spectacular!

The Sturtevant Falls hike is beautiful. Very different from my normal Temescal Canyon hike because it has many types of tress, flowers, butterflies and birds. Best part is the actual waterfall which is unheard of in LA county. It's 3.6 miles roundtrip. If you're in good shape this is an easy hike. A lot of reviews will talk about the last 1/2 mile on the way back which is all uphill. It's a nice little butt workout and will get the heart moving but it was nice because the rest of the hike is pretty much flat. We went in the middle of the afternoon on a week day and the lot had a few spots open. You can also park on the street but no matter what, you MUST have an "Adventure Pass" to park. I think you can buy one at the general store near the trailhead but I bought one before at REI. I would do the hike again.

I love WWII history, but know very little about any other wars. A few years ago, we went to Yorktown Battlefield in Virginia, which was the last major battle of the Revolutionary War in 1791. We decided to use this vacation to learn about the Civil War. Thanks to a friend's recommendation , we went to Antietam Battlefield, located in Sharpsburg, MD. It's fairly small (compared to Gettysburg) , but was the bloodiest one day battle in American history. 23,000 soldiers were killed, wounded or missing after twelve hours of terrible combat on September 17, 1862. The Battle of Antietam ended the Confederate Army of Northern Virginia's first invasion into the North and led to Abraham Lincoln's issuance of the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation. The Park Ranger did an amazing job of telling the history of the battlefield. You could actually "feel" it. The grounds are incredibly beautiful and authentically preserved. We went there planning on spending a few hours, and we spent all day. Admission was free as we had our National Park card.

Start your tour at the Visitor Center - if your not familiar with the battle watch the short movie. There's a pass fee ($10 per vehicle or $5 individual) to tour the battlefield. My wife and I are hiking enthusiasts so we walked the trails. The land is beautiful, meticulously cared, and maintained. We spent close to 3 hours (mostly walking) touring the area however we didn't get to see every plaque, monument, or site.

So much different than visiting Gettysburg (which I also loved). Feels tucked away from main roads and it's just one rolling hill after another of preserved battlefield lands. The scenery is just beautiful and at odds with the bloody history. Great little museum and bookstore in the visitor center. Fabulous panoramic observation room and there was a nicely sized theater for the introductory movie. Wonderful articulate and knowledgeable guides from the National Park Servic and volunteers. A really nice day. Be prepared for walking!
We enjoyed getting another stamp in our Passports and touring around Antietam. Well maintained and a perfect afternoon spent exploring.

This trip is a 90 minute drive from home in Fairfax county. Perfect for a day trip. It is $10 per car to visit the modest museum, attend the Ranger talk and watch the movie. The Ranger talk is given twice a day and is a must do prior to driving the trails. The talk is given in the observation room on the second level where the Ranger points out all of the various advances and landmarks in order to describe the battle.

This is smaller than Gettysburg but just as neat. The visitor's center and museum (unlike Gettysburg) is run by the NPS and the National Park Pass is accepted here for both admission to the park and museum. There's nice relatively short auto tour and a few nice hikes. Be aware though, that despite what the NPS website says, you cannot rent the audio and guide for the auto tour. You have to buy it for $24.00 which we did not do as we would never use it again. However, there are apps you can download to use for free instead.

There is a film about the battle and a ranger presentation which points out the locations and movement of forces. It is heart wrenching to hear and then imagine the slaughter. Everything is extremely well preserved and marked. Their is an auto audio tour with booklet available in the gift shop for $24.00. I'm not sure I would buy it again - it was just ok. This is an experience that everyone should have.
It's an amazing experience being in a place where history was made. Absolutely breathtaking views. $10/carload.

We were headed home from a weekend in Washington DC when we stopped at the MD welcome center for a break. Inside the welcome center, a lady approached me and asked if I was a fan of history. Definitely. She asked if I knew that I was only 20 minutes away the Antietam Battlefield (I did not). So after talking for a few minutes about the details, I headed to the car to talk the possibility over with my wife, which was a formality because visiting the park had been on my to-do list, and, well, we were going. The park grounds were very nice, very close to how it would have been in the 1860's. The visitor center has a 27 minute movie detailing the overview of the park and battle, as well as a museum and gift shop. I encountered three employees here, two of which were very nice. You will have the option to walk the grounds for free or take a driving tour. The driving tour is 10 dollars per vehicle or 5 if you are flying solo. The driving tour (Recommended) is 11 stops and hits all the highlights. You have the option to do this at your own pace. There are several signs and monuments along the way for your enjoyment and education. Make sure to walk along 'Bloody Lane', climb the watchtower and learn about the Irish Brigade, and see Burnside's Bridge. If time allows, get out and walk around the National Cemetery at the end! You should allow 2 hours for a well-rounded visit or 4 hours + for a detailed and thorough one. Great stop on the way home. Watch out for ghosts! Bloody lane is said to be one of the most haunted battlefield locations of the civil war.

Yes it is a battlefield and that may not appeal to everyone, but that would be a mistake because this place offers a lot for everyone-including dogs are welcome on a leash!. From an historical perspective- it is the place where the bloodiest battle of the Civil War took place. To understand the events that occurred here- start your visit with the movie that is shown on the half/hour at the Visitor's Center. The movie does a good job in helping you put the events into order. Stop in the gift shop and pick up the audio driving guide. This will give you detailed information at each stop. The park rangers often give lectures and tours- so check their schedule. This is largely a driving tour. Each stop is well marked. At each stop you can get out and visit the site. Many of the sites have hiking trails that take you into the woods, fields or other places. These hiking trails range in length from short and easy to long and moderate. A list of hikes can be found on the National Antietam Park website page. Most people never ventured onto the hiking paths, and that is a mistake. The hikes are gorgeous. For those who are history buffs, they really help you gain an accurate perspective, for those into nature- the flowers, butterflies, deer and other animals make it exciting. The most disappointing part of the battlefield is the yet unfinished Burnside's Bridge. Because of the construction- which looks nowhere close to being finished- you can see the bridge, but you can not access it. On your way out of the park, stop in town at Nutter's Ice Cream for the best deal and best tasting ice cream around! The park is less visited than Gettysburg, and that is a huge PLUS- it gives the visitor a chance to reflect on the implications of the battle and to enjoy the beauty of nature without being surrounded by tons of people. The National Park Service does charge a fee- 10$/car which is good for several days.

Great gift shop too with many items on sale and wool keppies (the ones at Gettysburg are cotton for the same price the wool is way more authentic). Video and small informative museum, self guided driving tour also well laid out and informative, for people interested in civil war stops this was well done. Can walk through the bloody lane, and see the burnside bridge which, please note, is under construction so closed this summer so you can't walk over it like other times. Very affordable too ($5 adults, kids free)

The Visitor Center is minimalistic with a short walk near the center. The highlight is the Battlefield auto tour. If you can afford, buy the CD to take you along the trip. The auto tour is self paced and you can listen at your own speed. Several stops along the way to get out and learn about the history of the area. The auto tour does require a car pass or the Annual Pass.

At 62 I have grown up knowing the name Antietam. It is a name embedded in memories of most Northerners and Southerners. It is the site where more than 20,000 solders died We purchased the CD, Antietam Field Guide, in the Visitor's Center for $23. We found this to be an excellent way to tour the battlefield.

Being a Civil War "Nut", I have visited Antietam many times but it never ceases to amaze me. The battlefield is in pristine condition and features new attractions and guided tours every time my husband and I visit. This visit included a stop at the Pry House -- General McCellan's Headquarters during the battle -- which is now open and features a medical history of the Civil War era. In conjunction with the Civil War Museum of Medicine in Frederick, MD, we found the staff at the Pry House quite knowledgable and anxious to tell the story of the medical side of the Battle of Antietam (Sharpsburg). A suggested contribution of $5 per person is totally worth the money and offers a different focus on the battle. Burnside Bridge is now totally under re-construction so that part of the battlefield is definitely worth driving but obviously crossing the bridge is not going to be part of your trip for awhile. If you are ANYWHERE in the area of Sharpsburg, MD, do NOT miss this true American experience.

This park is both smaller and more expensive to visit than Gettysburg. The park demands a $10 fee to just drive the area. If you go, just drive yourself, or follow a tour group. It was interesting, but not really worth the drive to the remote location, in my opinion.

This is a must-see stop for anyone interested in the Civil War. They have a nice visitor center with a short film about the battle at Antietam and a very very small museum and gift shop. The actual battle grounds are about 12 sq. miles, so most people, actually everyone drives it. The weather was cold and rainy when we went, so there was no question about driving. They give you a map in the visitor center to help navigate the grounds. And there are places besides monuments to pull your car over and get out. The grounds are open until sunset and visitor center, closes at 5. And it's only a $10 fee per car! What can you get for $10 anymore? You can easily do this park in about 2 hours, compared to Gettysburg, which at least half a day.

Antietam National Battlefield boasts the powerful landscape of a tragic historical event from the Civil War. The Visitor's Center charges $10/adult through the National Park Service for a brief museum and film and literature that guides visitors to the 11 stops that chronicle the accounts of the fateful day in September 1862. At each stop, I recommend you park your car either on the side of the road or in parking spaces provided, so that you can get out and read the informational signs as well as get a feel for the crucial moments of the battle. The driving tour begins at Dunker Church, which was locked when my husband and I stopped there. The Cornfield stop enabled visitors to envision the Union army trampling through the field in a wave of fury. The most powerful stop on the driving tour was Bloody Lane. Snake rail fences line either side of the "sunken road" that is entrenched between it leading to the brick observation tower. The energies of the fallen are prevalent in this somber place as images of wounded and dying soldiers lay beaten and battered one on top of the other in the red-stained ditch. The Observation Tower gives a visitor the opportunity to embrace the number of soldiers engaged in this bloody battle. With the vastness of the fields sprawled in all directions, one can visualize Lee's 38,000 troops of greys and browns fighting for their lives with McClellan's 75,000 marching forward in navy blues through the haze of gunfire and smoke. Burnside's Bridge is a must-see stop along the battlefield trail as it emphasizes the rushing waters of Antietam Creek below. Hike along the trail that climbs high above the creek, where Georgians held off the Yankees on the bridge for many hours during the raging hours of the day.

Toured Gettysburg last week (5th trip) and did my 3rd Antietam tour this last weekend. You can get a good sense of the ebb and flow of battle just using the National Park brouchure. But this time I purchased the CD tour at the giftshop ($24) and felt it was money well spent. It is easy to navigate the battlefield as you are not "fighting" the crowd you get at Gettysburg. Each tour site has enough parking and there are many monuement and War Department markers explaining all aspects of the fight. The CD tour takes about 2.5 hrs, but if you make additional stops or walk the trails you can spend a full day here.

We arrived at the visitor's center in the morning and were greeted by the friendly and helpful staff. After spending some time in the gift shop and museum area, we heard an excellent outdoor lecture on the battle by one of the park rangers. The battlefield was immaculate and small enough to allow one to get a grasp of how the battle actually unfolded. We saw a film about the battle that was much better-produced than others we have seen. Upon leaving the theatre, we saw that there was already a large crowd waiting to get in, so it's good to get there early. We took the driving tour, consisting of private roads with well marked signs. Several of the stops allowed us an opportunity to walk around on the battlefield. Highlights included the Dunker Church, many memorials to the various regiments that fought here, the original or rebuilt farm houses, Bloody Lane, the cemetery and the Burnside bridge. The bridge is undergoing restoration but there is a pleasant little walk you can take down the path to get a better view. Private tours providing a more in-depth look at the battle are also available for $100. Antietam is one of the best battlefield sites we've been to, both in terms of preservation and presentation.
location: Great Neck, New York, United States

text: ...if you bother to go! If you're not a military buff, then the angle is history. I went because it's in my backyard and the cost is less than a tank of gas theoretically. If you are a novice, the battlefield museum is the place to begin your tour. For $5, you get a half-hour movie narrated by James Earl Jones, and access to museum artifacts that will acquaint you with the weaponry of the day, the logistical details of the battle, and of course the "who's who" of who was there or reasonably close by (like in Washington).

On September 17, 1862 this site saw one of the worst and bloodiest days of the American Civil War as Union and Confederate troops met in battle. Words really cannot express the depth of feeling one experiences walking these fields and seeing the places where so many men fought and killed each other for their respective causes. I've seen pictures and read about the battle but you have to experience it to really know it. The sunken road, the cornfield, the Dunkers Church, and Burnsides Bridge, when you actually stand there looking at them, all make the story so vivid and so terribly real. Admission is $5.00 per person or $10.00 per vehicle. You can walk the grounds or drive around on a self-guided tour with an informative map. The staff in the visitor's center are very helpful and there are many souvenirs available for purchase as well as restrooms. The souvenirs are all very nice. I was tempted to pick up a few bags of toy Civil War soldiers but, as my kids are all grown now, they'd only have sat in my attic. One of the other Trip Advisor writers has called Antietam "a historic gem" and I could not agree more. So glad I had the opportunity to visit.

Stopped at the visitor center and saw the film and museum. Purchased the car audio tape to drive around park. Very pleased with that decision. Had marked places to stop and talk about events and you can start and stop at your leisure. Remember if you are 62 or over you can buy a lifetime pass for all national parks for $10.00!! Best bargain ever.......

I live 40 minutes from this battlefield and have visited this historic site many times. Yesterday was a beautiful day and I took family who had never been before. I highly recommend planning your trip around a Ranger talk. You can call and ask what time the talks will be that day. Make sure you see the movie which runs every half hour first. We got lucky and had a private Ranger talk as no one else was there. The Ranger was informative and fascinating. I learn something new every time I go because each Ranger has their own take on the days events. We drove the tour and ended up at Burnside Bridge. They are currently repairing the bridge but don't skip that tour stop. You can still walk right up to the bridge and get some great pictures including the witness tree. The cost is 10 dollars for a carload and if you are a senior you can buy or use your senior pass which is a one time lifetime fee of 10 dollars.

Cost was $10 for seniors. They offer self-guided car tour or tour with personal guide(can't remember how much the guide cost). Viewed the film which is offered every 30 min. Was a good way to begin the visit. Looked at the exhibits then went to the top of bldg for the overlook of the battlefield. Was awesome. We enjoyed the self-guided car tour, which allows u to stop whenever u want to see something more closely. The Antietam Bridge was the best attraction for me. The site is overwhelming trying to take in all the lives that were lost that day. Definitely recommend when u are in area visiting Civil War sites.

I stopped here after having visited Gettysburg and it was definitely worth the stop. I took a couple of hours. It is quite beautiful and well maintained. I did not get to hear any of the ranger's talk but in passing and they seem quite knowledgeable. There are walking trails, which allow for a different perspective as they pass through the fields of battle. There is a small fee, but it is chump change compared to other places. I think I paid four dollars, but it was worth it, though, as I also know that this goes towards helping them maintain the battlefield. If you are a history buff, a Civil War buff....this should definitely be amongst your places to visit.

Went yesterday to the Antietam National Battlefield (April 28, 2015) and it was great as most of the National Parks are. When we arrived we asked to see if they provided a personal guide for the battlefield and for $95 they do. We got a man named Bill Sagle, and if you go there....GET THIS GUY!!!! I know that $95 sounds like a lot of money for a tour, but this guy shows you the passion and knowledge he has for this area and it is well worth every pennie. The tour takes about 3 hours, but he takes you to the spot right where the action took place or the picture was taken a 150 years ago. He explains whta everyone did and why. When your done, you know all the players and what took place at this battlefield. If you just drive yourself around the park and just read the plaques, you will never know what your missing not having a personal guide.

We spent a day here and saw a lot of history, without it being overwhelming. It is very reasonable - $6 for a car and the pass is good for 3 days. Make sure to watch the 25 minute video in the visitor center before setting off on the drive-yourself tour.

When you first go to the visitor center, go to the gift shop and inquire about a private guide. They are often available for either a 2 or 3 hour tour of the battlefield. They drive your vehicle, so make sure you have an extra seat available. The charge was $95 for the 3 hour and $65 for the two. The guides are very professional, extremely well versed about all aspects of the history, the war, the politics, and social implications. It is very difficult to understand the ebb and flow of the events of that one day battle; just understanding the geography and terrain is hard from driving and reading the roadside plaques (of which there is no shortage, literally hundreds). Our guide, Justin Mayhue, truly brought it alive for us!

If you know you are going here, make you you hire a "step-on guide". What I know about the Civil War could fit in a thimble. I wanted to give my children a look at a battlefield in this terrible war. I wasn't sure what to say or do to show them how senseless most war is, and how brave these men were who fought all those years ago. I will be forever grateful for the guide who we hired. He climbed into our minivan and drove the 6 of us around for a couple hours. He stopped at several places. We got out and he made us "feel" of the terror and bravery and courage of these men. It was awesome. Pay the money. Hire the guide. Go to the Antiedam website and call and book it. You will be glad you did. BTW 2 hours is plenty. They have a longer tour, but that should be for hard core war strategists or civil war buffs. My kids are 20, 18, 15, 13 and it was just the right amount of interesting stuff and serious discussion.

Another stop on the bucket list. In-shape Civil War buffs, give yourself a day to walk to all the numbered spots on the free guide. $20 gets you an audio guide that you can also drive along with. Bring your own food and drinks - the Rangers don't sell anything because it's "less to clean up!"

After touring Gettysburg, I found this battlefield park to be reasonably priced at $6.00 a car! The excellent movie alone was worth that price, but you could also take a guided walking tour of the battlefield. It is a beautiful tribute to the darkest battle in the history of the United States of America.

$6 per car load for a 3 day pass!!!! First we saw an informative film overview of the battle, then attended a ranger talk. After that we explored the battlefield with an easy to follow self-guided auto tour. The Fry Field museum was advertised as being open every day, but is actually closed on Tuesday's and Wednesday's. There are no on site food concessions so be prepared or ask for recommendations.

We went there on 7/26/14 to see the artillery firing demonstration! It's our first time, and definitely won't be the last! :) We have a wonderful experience. If you live in South Berkeley County or Jefferson County, WV area, it will be shorter distance to drive through Shepherdtown, WV, than to take I-81. You also can check their website for more information, especially schedules of events. It's $6 per car for entering the park. You can pay it @ Visitor Center. I am not sure if you have to. But we did it because those money will use for park operation. If you have children under 12, there are Junior Ranger Program. My 2 boys [age 5, and 3] love it. You can ask for the papers @ the visitor center or print it off their website. They have to fill in and answer questions on those papers. Once completed, they will earn a Ranger badge and certificate individually!

The visitors' center was wonderful. They have a small museum, a 26 min. movie you can watch and a nice gift shop. Rate was $6 per car. Best of all is the staff. So helpful and well versed in everything Civil War. The battlefield is very large. It is hard to imagine the death and suffering that happened there. A part of history that nobody should ever forget for sure.

There are several tours each day at the visitor's center given by uniformed park rangers. In addition, you can get a map and do-it-yourself instructions so you can drive around the battlefield yourself. Or, ultimately, hire a private guide at the visitor's center for $75. He will drive your car and spend nearly 3 hours discussing every aspect of the battle.

If you're interersted in history or the Civil War, this is a must. The battle here was much more significant and costly than many people realize, and a visit there was a great way to learn about it. The visitor's center has a nice movie, 30 minutes long, that gives great overview of the battle. Right when that ended, we were able to catch a 30-minute ranger talk up in the observation area, which really helped orient us. After that, a walk through the museum was the final way to get acquainted with the battle before going out on the self guided auto tour. I'm thinking a guided driving tour with a ranger would have been best. We've done that in Gettysburg and it's fantastic. But this time we purchased the CD for $20. A little bit steep, but considering HOW CHEAP it is to get in the center itself it was no biggie. It was only $6 for BOTH of us for three days. Insane. I almost wish they would charge more so they could maybe make some improvements. Sadly this place has not been given the attention it deserves like Gettysburg has, but I hope it does because it should. The museum could be much larger I think... Make sure to plan about three hours for the driving tour, not the 1.5 to 2 hours they recommend. We felt rushed. Generally I would recommend doing Antietam first and then Gettysburg, if you haven't been to either yet.

If you get a chance to hear the interpreter give a presentation, take it. The visitors center has a three sided view of the battlefield and our interpreter gave a very clear and moving presentation on what was going on. With the view of the entire battlefield before you, you can actually see the how the terrain would affect the battle. Pass on the film if you hear the interpreter. The film covers the same information.

It's $6 per carload, which does help the battlefield. I'm sure some just bypass the fee, but at only 6 bucks, be ashamed! Nice little movie narrated by James Earl Jones in the Visitor Center. Upstairs is the scenic view, where they told a the story of Clara Barton, who went on to found the American Red Cross. In the gift shop, you may purchase the Audio CD with mobile App for $20, which also includes a book. That will guide you through the battlefield and the stops along the way. We did drive it, but it would have been so much nicer on a bicycle. I live near Gettysburg, but I think this park is a little nicer and much less congested. After the tour, try Captain Bender's for lunch, on Main St. in Sharpsburg.

Take the self-guided 8 1/2 mile auto tour through the battlefield. The tour has 11 stops on it and is very informative,take time and go into the buildings and the tower to get a better look at the battle field.Well worth the $6.00 and a lot to see and read at all of the stops.

If you're in the are this should be on the list of things to do/see. Only had a couple hours so we did the museum, ranger talk (there are many and these guys know and love telling stories) and half hour movie cost? $6 and this was good for 3 days and a audio tour we didnt have time for. We will definitely to come back for the "lumina" in Dec.were they light 23,000 candles along the battlefield road for every soldier killed and the audio tour with the car.

I took my family here for the first time during the kids spring break. I have to state this was a wonderful experience. The NPS has done a very nice job in preserving and expanding this location. The cost of admission is only $6 per car and we chose to purchase the DVD/book for the self guided audio tour.

WE arrived at the visitor center just a few minutes before the 20 minute ranger talk. We then went to the 20 minute movie. WE bought the auto tour CD and booklet for our tour of the battle field.
