This is an inexpensive way to learn about Civil War history. Admission was $6 for the car loan. The CD / booklet were $20. I would suggest going to the ranger talk before the battlefield. You sit in a room with many windows and get a battle overview along with getting to see the lay of the land so you have some idea where each side set up and in general where the battles took place. The CD tour takes you to a number of stops. You can get out and walk a number of pathways around the park. WE mostly listened to the CD. The auto tour took us 2-3 hours. We had a great time.

Plenty of room on the battlefield for the RV weather towing or driving. $6 for vehicle or $4 per person on a bus to get in. Informative and driving tour layed out well. You could spend as little as 1 hour to 3-4 days depending on your level of interest. Well done. JR ranger stuff to do also.

We were staying in Harper's Ferry and decided to drive out to Antietam to see that battlefield. The price was extremely low at $3 an adult. We did the driving tour and it was really a lot of fun to just explore the battlefield on our own and read about the battle as it happened. The stillness of the day truly added to the somber feeling that the battlefield itself evokes. I felt very glad to be able to experience the battlefield on a day that really made you remember all the young men that passed away that day.

Antietam National Battlefield is an educational and interesting place to visit. There was a nice reception area with a decent tourist/book store, clean bathrooms and a place to watch a nice 30-minute introductory movie. We bought and used the auto tour CD. It has more information than expected. You can choose to walk the 8 1/2 mile path if you want. Military can get in free if you have the National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Pass. You can get one there, I think, if you haven't already gotten one. I would pay to see it again even if we didn't have the pass.

Our Young @ Heart senior group took a bus tour of Antietam Battlefield. Our tour guide, Gary Rohrer, was superb, making what could have been a long and boring morning really fascinating! To hear his stories, one would have thought he'd been there to experience the battle and all that led up to it. We felt like we were a part of the action. The visitor's center, where we first watched the introductory film, is beautiful, and watching the film first gave us insight into many of the stops along our tour. It was well worth visiting. Antietam is a National Park, so anyone who has a Golden NP Pass can visit free of charge.

Unfortunately, we did not have adequate time to really tour the battlefield on this visit, but we did take the narrated car tour, which skips some of the stops on the car tour. Hopefully, we will return sometime in the future. Because the car tour tries to illuminate too many general facts about the Civil War at each stop, it doesn't do a very good job of actual instruction about the battle. However, since I had read extensively about the battle, being there did help me better understand the geography of the battlefield. If you have time (at least half a day or more), I would advise skipping the CD (which, in itself, cost @ $20) or audio tape and simply getting out at each stop, reading the historical markers and walking the relevant parts of the battlefield. If you have time before going, I would read Shaara's Civil War Battlefields, for a brief (24-page) description or Sear's Landscape Turned Red for an extensive history of the Maryland campaign.

They have a nice informative film in the visitor center $6 per car. You also receive a drive thru map that is well marked with the stops in the national battlefield. Watch the film first, or look thru the museum area while waiting for the next film to begin, which is a reinactment of the battle in area that you will be driving thru. It appears you could just drive thru the battleground; but the film and map help to give you the history of what you are seeing. The park rangers were very friendly and helpful with any questions.

We came on a Sunday morning in October, just after the 150th anniversary of the battles here. The weather was perfect and we bought the Auto Tour CD from the gift shop to explain the highlights of the self-guided tour in the car. The cost was $20 and well worth it. There are ranger-guided tours and based on our experience in Gettysburg, they are worthwhile if you have the time.

Enjoyed the visit to the battlefield. Very well conserved. Purchased the $20 CD that gives you some additional audio as you do the self-guided driving tour of the battlefield. It gave quite a bit of additional info, but you could easily get a lot out of the visit without. Definitely worth visiting whether you're big into civil war history or not.

The Visitors Center and the film in it are very good, but the exterior- the actual battlefield - is poorly planned for visitors. The website said that there is a self-guided tour that can be taken by car and that an audio tape or CD can be rented for that purpose. But they had only a $20 CD for sale, nothing for rent. We bought the $20 CD but found that it was not possible to tell which of the tour stops (numbered on a map) each CD track was talking about, so we ended up not using the CD and wasting our $20. Also, the website said that they encourage people to walk or bike on the self-guided tour, but there is no walking/biking path - one has to walk or bike on the very narrow road used by cars, which would be dangerous ( We saw nobody walking or biking). Also, along the self-guided car tour, there are many roadside signs explaining what had gone on at that part of the battlefield, but these signs were far from the parking areas, and it would have been dangerous to walk on the narrow road from the parking area to the signs. The road was too narrow to park near the signs in order to read them - we would have blocked traffic if we had done so. Very poorly planned out site from the visitor point of view.

The battlefield is very well preserved and work is on-going to return parts of the battlefield to the condition it was in during the battle. At the visitor's center you can view a short video that depicts the events plus get your map, visit the bookstore, etc. The park itself has a number of walking trails that wind throughout. There are also numerous unit markers, memorials, and stands that explain the battle. I suggest doing a little reading before hand to get a full picture of the events, or use one of the many audio tours available. Markers are quite as good as Gettysburg, but plenty of explanation and identification of units. The map lays out a pretty good driving route from North to South. Be sure to step out into the cornfield as well as the sunken road and Burnside Bridge (all must see areas). You can probably drive around in an hour if in a hurry. I wandered for 3 hours and didn't see everything. Admission is free for active military.

We arrived to find $6 got 2 people admission for three days. Awesome. We only stayed about an hour and a half due to a bad storm that moved in and pour rain down. While it was still dry we managed to see some of the monuments on the left side of the visitor center and the Dunker Church (which I swear is haunted!). We also witnessed a cannon firing demonstration before the rain hit. WE WILL BE BACK!!!! Hopefully better weather next time.

On our stops of great battlefields we decided Antietam was a must see. Arrived at the Park and the ranger provided us with a brief, but complete synopsis of what led to the battle, the players involved and the battle details. Great orientation (included in the $6 we payed for family of 4). We then watched a 20 min. movie, which corresponded with the orientation and is also included with the entrance fee. They have a very small, but cool museum. Did the driving tour and in the opinion of the whole family, it was far more enjoyable than Gettysburg, which we had just visited a couple of days earlier. Don't get me wrong, Gettysburg is an awesome experience, but it has gotten to be very commercial. Antietam however is not, yet it is also a must see for historical battlefields in the area.

Other reviewers have said it well. This place is smaller, more compact, nothing like Gettysburg's tourist congestion. Antietam is only about an hour south of Gettysburg in miles, but light years from it in quiet, understated historical impact. Early Sunday morning, we were nearly the only people there. The Visitors' Center is well done, as is the gift store. Our grandsons became Junior Rangers and the Park Ranger made the 'ceremony' quite nice by really checking their work, administering an 'oath', presenting certificates and badges, and giving congratulatory handshakes. We, too, were initially dismayed at the admission fee, but in retrospect, decided it was more token monetary support to the upkeep of the battlefield than any true financial hardship. At $10 a car, you really can't complain. There was a small demonstration of the way infantry troops advance presented at the center. And while there were only four soldiers, they did a nice job showing troop movement. The movie was quite informative. The small exhibition area was well done and the artifacts well chosen. Presentation was staightforward and effective.

I have visited many civil war battlefield sites, and for what occurred at this site this was a very disappointing visit. The small visitor center is half bookstore. I recently saw numerous photographs that were taken of Antietam immediately following the battle, but I didn't see any of these photographs at Antietam, and never knew they existed. The battlefield is a large area where there really needs to be a bus tour. You can tour the field in your own car, but it is hard to visualize what happened. It seems to me that not a sufficient amount of dollars has been invested in this great historic site that would make it a great experience.

This is a great battlefield to experience by walking. I stopped here on my way to Gettysburg. After learning more about Antietam while there, I wished I would have included Harper's Ferry first, then Antietam, then Gettysburg. If you're going to Antietam, first stop should be the Visitor's Center. They have a film to watch and a nice bookstore. If you want to walk some of the battlefield, go to the bookstore and pick up their $2 booklets for each segment of the battle. The booklets are walking tours of the events of the day; the cornfield, the bloody lane, the bridge, and more. It's good to do the driving tour, but there's something special about actually walking the cornfield and bloody lane that can't be experienced in a car. It was a full afternoon trip to cover the battlefield, so I stayed at the Hagerstown Hotel and Convention Center before heading up to Gettysburg. But, if you have time, go to Harpers Ferry in the morning, then to Antietam. Harpers Ferry is less than 20 miles away from Antietam and it is part of the "story" since Confederate troops occupied Harper's Ferry and then made a rush 17 mile foot march to Antietam just in time to provide reinforcement. One other tip, do the Ranger orientation that they conduct at the Visitor's Center. It's only a few times a day, but worth hanging around to listen to the Ranger provide insight.
Had to purchase audio guide for $20; no rentals. It was good but rather lengthy.

Whenever I visit these civil war battlefields, I question the reason for these wars and why humanity never learns its lessons. The cost to visit is reasonable at $6 per carload. There is a nice gift shop with some cool items. We watched the film in the visitor center which basically reviews the mechanics of the battle and you are given a map. The stops on the map take you step by step in order of the events as they took place. It is very hard to envision what it may have looked like as a battlefield from the serene cornfields now present. There is a observation tower. You will not find all the monuments and glamour present at Gettysburg, but instead a somber mood prevails. But I can't help but think..why? And I ponder of all the contributions that these individuals could have made for the benefit of society had their lives been not cut short and people had resolved their issues peacefully.
The CD audio guide, which you can purchase for about $15, is well worth it. It is available at the visitors' center where you purchase tickets and pick up a map.

My friends and I stayed in Gettysburg and decided to take a day trip to Sharpsburg to see Antietam Battlefield. We are all big Civil War buffs and were told it was a must see. We decided to hire a private guide for $50.00 which was definately worth it! He came with us in our car and basically went over the whole battle from beginning to end. This took about 2 1/2 hours. I have to say that was one of the most unbelievable tours I ever took. The tour guide was amazing! He went over everything with us and painted the most clearest pictures in our heads. He was patient and answered any questions we might have. He even took pictures of us at Burnside's Bridge. Even thought this battlefield is not as big as Gettysburg it is a must see. Standing on that battlefield especially near Bloody Lane just gives you chills. Its very quiet and peaceful here with no crowds and the views are magnificent! I definately recommend this battlefield to any one who enjoys Civil War history. Tip: Get the private tour guide! Its worth the time and money!!

We went here to check out the ice caves. It was the coldest day of the year, but even with all that, I am so glad we went! It was absolutely beautiful. We went at sunrise, parked in the lot at the beach for $3, and made it there very easily. It certainly can be very slick right up by the caves, but the rest of the walk is not too slippery. The wind is brutal. You definitely need to wear stuff to cover your face. Your cameras and batteries will freeze very quickly!

Went to see the ice formations. We went on a Tuesday so it wouldn't be crowded. Arrived at 6 AM and was the 5th car there. They have a lot of porta johns set up to handle the big crowds so bathroom availability should be good even with a big crowd. It is a long walk. The path over the lake was well packed and easy to walk over but it was cold the day I was there so no slush. Did find a really soft wet spot on the ice (only in one spot) so watch where you walk. As others have said it'll be about 3-4 hours. The website said there was a $3 parking fee but there wasn't anyone there when I was there to take money. When we left cars were starting to line down the road as the parking lot was full. I stayed in Ashland.

We had three very full days at the Apostle Islands. Day 1: we took our bikes to Madeleine Island on the ferry and rode to the state park, which is a pleasant ride with a worthy payoff. The park has a scenic area on the water, next to sea caves. Day 2: We took cruises to Stockton Island and Raspberry Island, so we could see other islands. The islands have wonderful beaches with clear water. Raspberry Island has a historic lighthouse and a ranger gives a good tour. You can also take a short hike. Day 3: We had a pre-arranged kayak tour with Living Adventures, a local kayak tour company. For $99, they drive you to Myers Beach, give you a demonstration, and the group with two guides kayaks along the shore, in and out of sea caves. It was an experience I'll never forget. It happened to be foggy and eerie - all the better. At noon-ish, we stopped for lunch on the beach, and the guides set up a table with delicious wrap sandwiches, drinks, cookies - very tasty. Then we headed back to Myers Beach. It was a full and busy trip. Be prepared - weather can change instantly, although we traveled during a hot spell. If you like kayaking, hiking and biking, you can do all of these at the Apostle Islands. We have not been to Pictured Rocks in Michigan UP - that's probably next.

02/03: Yes, I did it and survived. We drove my trusty Toyota Corolla down the ramp at Bayfield and out accross lake Superior toward Madeline Island.I learned it's best to drive something a little higher off the the road. Then, just head out and keep moving, fast. Timid me, scooting along slooowly got stuck and tried to turn around and got more stuck. But with some rocking and pushing we were back on our way, this time back toward the shoreline - fast.For $5.00 we could have taken the big air sled. But then we would have missed the excitement.Also walked along the frozen beach fron to the under water caves.

First hint: get there early so you can park on Meyers Road ($3 fee but worth not having to walk further). It was cold (about 7 degrees) with the wind blowing. Just bundle up like you are going skiing in a blizzard and you'll be fine. We found having those heating packets you stick in your gloves and boots to be really helpful. Be sure to have a good set (my cheap ones didn't even make it out of the parking lot) of strap-on crampons/cleats for your boots. They really help when walking on the ice or on the packed down snow. They are more a safety factor ( I can attest to this) than you might think. Also, ski or trekking poles are also helpful. We also had ski goggles that were really helpful when we had to walk back with the wind in our face. Full face masks helped as well.

Historic site of General Lee's surrender. Park was in excellent shape, visitor center, staff, buildings, exhibits all first rate. Enjoyed the visit, our tax dollars well spent. Not crowded on Labor Day. Quite a learning experience, even for those of us with a southern inheritance.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: If you like American history this is for you. Even if you are lukewarm it's a really pretty place. Well done exhibits, gives a great understanding of the effects of the civil war through individual stories. There is a good short movie in the visitors center (the air conditioning is a nice respite.) Informative. Feeds the inner history nerd. And it's all free!
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: This quaint village in a rural setting marks an important milestone in U.S. Civil War history. My wife, two sons (11 yrs, 9 yrs), and I came here (30 min. drive from Lynchburg) for a quick stop on our family road trip from Charlottesville to Greensboro, NC (and Raleigh-Durham). Admission to the park is free. First, I would strongly recommend the 15 minute orientation video on the 2nd floor of the Visitor Center to learn more about the importance of this site.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: If you're a Civil War or history enthusiast, you should plan sometime to visit here. It's $10 a car to get in. There are Park Rangers that narrate the history of the surrendering and can answer your questions. There is some walking/reading, but well worth it to see where peace was signed between the North and South.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: We visited the Appomattox Court House Park on a Saturday in August 2016. A fee of $10 per car is charged at the entrance. Parking is plentiful and there are handicapped spaces towards the front of the park. I thought I saw the Park Service provide a wheelchair to a guest. We were a group of adults, teens and some youngsters and started at the visitors center. We toured that as it has many historical artifacts, watched a short film and then listened (outside) to a Park Service Guide (Carl) for 40 about 30 - 40 minutes. Carl painted a picture of the events that led up to April of 1865 and really put you there. It was about 95 degrees on the day we visited so I believe we were only there for 1.5 hrs. Had it been cooler, we could have spent about 3 - 4 hours. I did not notice a place to purchase drinks (or food) and there are no stores in the immediate area so I highly recommend packing a lunch/drinks and having a picnic. There is a lot of open space. It is really an excellent example of the quality of our National Park Service. Not to be missed if you are into American History. Have fun and let me know if I was helpful.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: The Park Service has done its usual good job at this site, interpreting Lee's surrender to Grant. The staff here is both amiable and knowledgeable. Costumed interpreters enhance the experience. We were particularly impressed by the young lady portraying the innkeeper's daughter. A number of structures furnished with period pieces are available for touring. The highlight is the Wilmer McLean home, where the surrender took place.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: We made a quick stop here about 30 minutes before closing as we drive through Virginia. You don't have to pay if you enter after 430 (maybe even after 4) so we lucked out here though entry fees were "by car" and reasonably priced (maybe $10 I think?). We watched the video (15-20 minutes) and took a quick peek at the exhibits just outside the theater. This is all in the actual courthouse which is to your right as you're walking up the main entryway. After that, we went to the McLean house where the actual surrender terms were written and accepted. This is just ahead and to your left as you're leaving the courthouse. The interpreter inside was well informed and full of information. We didn't have time to see the other buildings, but they are all mostly reproductions of the town buildings that once stood during this time period and we were just hitting the highlights, which this quick stop did. You'll definitely want more time here if you're a civil war buff. Otherwise, this was sufficient.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: I spent several days at Appomattox for the 150th Anniversary of Lee's surrender. The site itself is small compared to other well known civil war battlefields. However if you expect to get the most out of your visit you will need a minimum of a full day, but would recommend two days to take everything in. There normally is a $10 fee per vehicle, however was free when I was there due to the special events. Like most other parks I'm sure the receipt is good for several days.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: $10/car entrance fee was a bargain. We saw a number of buildings, some original, some reproductions. A Living History re-enactor gave his rather rambling version of the Civil War and its disastrous effect on the town, which was eventually abandoned and rebuilt by the rail line 3 miles away. Interiors are beautifully furnished in period style, right down to the wallpaper. The courthouse/visitor's center contains many Civil War photographs, ephemera and artifacts, plus an upstairs movie theatre showing a rather simplistic film about the surrender. The General Store, an original structure, was packed with period merchandise. There is also a park ranger tour. The "town" covers a large area and there is a fair amount of walking involved on gravel paths. Even though it was the middle of October, it was plenty hot. Be sure to wear good walking shoes, sunscreen and a hat. Other buildings include the tavern and a munchkin-sized law office The sobering three story jail has a jarringly loud recording emanating from a cell of a "prisoner" speaking in a Southern accent so thick it was unintelligible. There is an underwhelming book and gift shop. Welcome picnic tables, paid for by a private foundation provide a nice place to eat lunch. Bring your own food, there is no concession. We saw most everything and were there for over three hours. A must see for Civil War, Americana and Victorian-era buffs.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
location: Great Neck, New York, United States

text: For $10.00 per carload you are granted entry to the site of the signing of Lee's surrender. This property is a sprawling and beautiful slice of Virginia. The highlight is the program offered by the costumed tour guide. They describe their life leading up to and including the day of surrender. Maybe you will listen to a southern soilder, maybe Union, or perhaps a store clerk. Their description of events is fascinating. Do not ask them if you can take a selfie with them. They will not know what you are talking about as they remain in character. Plan two or three hours here.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: The original Appomattox courthouse burned in the 1890's. When it was rebuilt they located it in the town of Appomattox, about 2-3 miles away from the park. Nevertheless, this stop is worthwhile. Accept the free narration which gives you a wonderful picture of life at the time of the Civil War. The narrators stay in character so as to enhance your experience. Plan to spend at least two hours in order to get a feel for the place. Hint: entry fee is $10 per car but if you are 62 or older you can ask for a senior pass for the same price that covers everyone in your car, has no expiration date and works at other national parks.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: This is a very nice small national park attraction I got in free with my national park pass because I am over 62 but its a small fee maybe $8.00 but very interesting.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: Every American should visit this park, northerners and southerners alike. The Civil War divided this country in so many ways, and it was here where healing could begin. It only costs $10 per vehicle to enter the park, a very small price to pay for what you can experience inside. Everyone we encountered was friendly, helpful, and enthusiastically knowledgeable. The setting is beautiful and bucolic; very conducive to imagining what exactly happened here. We were introduced to Mr. Coleman, who lived and worked on his farm, a short distance away, and joined the famous northern Virginia army when Virginia joined the Confederacy. He stood in front of a small group of us, comfortably seated outside, and described, often with great emotion, his experience of battle, of losing loved ones & friends, the assassination of President Lincoln. I realized, with great clarity, that he probably was typical of most Confederate soldiers, simply defending their farms, homes, & families... not slavery.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: I wish we'd had much more time in summery, cicada-buzzing Appomattox Court House NHP. (Full disclosure: son is interning at the Park for the summer, so we were especially excited to visit.) $10 per vehicle. DO NOT MISS THE MOVIE UPSTAIRS IN THE VISITOR CENTER which is especially well done. Enjoy the historical character actors (who included a period physician, a soldier, and a reporter on the day we visited). Catch a few ranger talks, and don't forget to pop into the Clover Hill Tavern to obtain your printed parole pass so that you may go home. The McClean House (site of Lee's capitulation), the Lynchburg-Richmond Road...it's a whole little village, perfect for strolling and soberly considering our nation's history. Lots of opportunity for engaging knowledgeable, attentive, enthusiastic staff about much more than a battle and a meeting of two generals. This historical installation gets it right, with a nice balance of sitting, strolling, listening, seeing, and space for contemplating. Saw an intern shepherding a young person in a wheelchair, sharing a binder with interior pictures where the wheelchair could not go. Separate from the Park, just up the road, and also worth a brief stop, is a small mostly confederate graveyard (18/19), maintained separately by the United Daughters of the Confederacy. (Also adding a plug for the nearby Babcock House B&B in nearby Appomattox Station, where we stayed--charming, hospitable, excellent breakfast, nice value.) This is an out-of-the-way National Park, and folks who come here typically have a good reason to have made the trip. Sure glad we did.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: The park is a bit off the beaten path, but well worth the time and effort! There is an admission charge, unless you have a Park pass. If you are a senior, it is well worth the $10 for admission to all national parks! The area is gorgeous. The village is nicely done and there is a lot of information available to visitors! Start at the Visitor Center, see the movie and the displays, then walk the grounds. You have the option of some living history in that there are talks by folks in character. Or you can do the self-guided tour on your own. Visit the McLean house where the actual surrender took place, hear about the family who owned the house. There are several rangers around who are happy to share knowledge with visitors. We enjoyed our visit here tremendously. Plan to spend about 2 hours.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: This place is a step back in time. It looks exactly like it did 150 years ago, on the day Robert E. Lee surrendered the Confederate Army to U.S. Grant. Enactors on the grounds give informative talks as characters that were at that historic event. Interns and staff give hourly talks on the history of the place and the war. Everyone is warm and welcoming. This is a DO NOT MISS spot if you are in western VA.(We arrived 45 minutes before closing and they let us in for free. If you are 62 or older, get the National Parks Pass. It's only $10, good for a lifetime, and lets 4 people in any national park for free.)
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: This was an excellent stop. The entrance fee was $10. Well worth it. They offer a walking tour with a park guide or you can self guide using a map provided in the visitor center. We did the self guide tour and had a great time visiting the buildings and sites located in the park. We visited the site on an over cast day, slightly misty. Lucky us because we were on site for about two hours. My suggestion is that you should make sure to take water with you since it can be hot and you do a lot of walking. I recommend this as a stop for everyone. I great way to discover history.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: Give yourself about 3 hours, in order not to be rushed. Also attend the live history talks and also the ranger talk, which gives you a good overview of what went on that day--there's far more than what you learned in school. The National Park Service does a very good job here; the environment encourages leisurely learning. Also check out the souvenir house--great selection of items, including books. You can also get your National Park passport stamp here. The woman running the souvenir house is utterly delightful, and it's air conditioned. This is a must-see attraction, especially since it's only $5 entrance fee, per car. Make sure you bring a hat, sunglasses; water would also be beneficial, although you can buy that at the bookstore.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: My husband and I were very impressed with the Park. Beautiful setting, well maintained, and staffed with friendly park workers who know their history. Entrance fee was $5 per car. We arrived late in the day, so the Park was closing an hour after we arrived, and daylight was fading. Look forward to visiting again when we have more time next time we get to VA.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: anyone with an interest in history should visit. There are no bells and whistles but you visit this village and can almost feel the ghosts that fought so long ago. The houses look as they did in the 1800's. There are several guides but try and go with the historic interactive guides. They take on a character that was actually there and answer and act as the time they lived in. A small museum inside the visitor center. The cost is very small. After summer it is $3 a person or $5 a car,
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park
location: Avon by the Sea, New Jersey

text: This site is where Lee signed his surrender to Grant. The buildings are all kept in great shape with reenactors on site giving an interpretation of the time and what living there was like. It cost a few dollars to get onsite, payable prior to parking.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: I have always wanted to see the McLean House at the Appomatox Court House. What I didn't realize was that several houses in the town have also been saved. We went in September on a beautiful fall like day and walked all over the place. The paths are very easy and well maintained for easy walking. This is an area that is inspiring even if you are just walking outside and not entering the buildings. We were just on a day trip but I heard there were some really nice camping sites close by. There is a small fee but if you are 62 or older, get the Golden Eagle pass, it's a one time payment of $10 and you get into any National Park free from then on out.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: We used our Inter-agency National Parks Pass to get in "free", there is a small fee for others.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: We were able to find the park with no problem. Checked in at the toll both ($4.00 per adult or $10 per car). Parking was plentiful on a Saturday. We started with watching a short movie at the visitor center (which is the courthouse). Then we joined the living history presentation where we were introduced to our tour guide who was dressed in period costume and he took us over to the front porch of the tavern. He was really good at presenting his portion of what happened there. We then went into the tavern and watched a guide demonstrate the operation of the printing press. Afterwards, we walked up to the cemetery and then toured the McLean house where the generals Grant and Lee conducted the terms of surrender. We also toured the jailhouse and walked to the other end of the village where there was a battle fought. Very interesting place. The paths (road) in the village is pea-gravel. The visitor center and the book store are the only buildings that are air-conditioned. There are stairs for all of the buildings except the bookstore. There is bottled water for sale at the book store as well as lots of books, magnets, patches, toys, pins, etc.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: We had not considered this one, but had made the detour to the National D-Day Memorial and were close.... so we detoured again. And we're glad we did. There is a modest fee but Seniors (62+) can get a lifetime pass to all national parks & monuments for only $10.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: We went to the Appomattox Court House National Historical Park today and as luck would have it the National Park Service Senior Lifetime Access Pass is accepted so basically free entry. In high school I learned that the surrender took place at the Appomattox Court House but today I learned that Appomattox Court House is the name of the village and the terms of surrender was signed at the McLean house in the village and not at the Courthouse which is currently used as the visitor center. Turns out many county seats in Virginia are referred to as Court House (two words) and the actual Courthouse is spelled as one word. The museum is in the courthouse as well as many other artifacts but make sure you walk over to the McLean house to see the room and furnishings of the surrender. A young lady dressed in period dress and in character told us what it was like to be the daughter of the owner of the Clover Hill Tavern and having a brother as a Confederate soldier that left healthy in 1861 and returned barely recognizable in 1865. She did a great job of depicting the era through dress and dialog. I highly recommend a visit to this sacred spot where our nation came back together.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: I've always wanted to come here so on our way to Richmond we stopped. It was late in the day so the tours had stopped but we still enjoyed walking around ourselves. The courthouse is also the visitors center and small museum with a wealth of information. Don't know if they still do but when we were there they had a paper for 5 dollars that explained in newspaper form each month of the war. If your really interested in the Civil war put your money down, it's money well spent. Many other buildings to explore including the McLean house were the war ended. Great experience!
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: We were impressed by the beauty of the setting. Our main focus was seeing where Lee and Grant met on the famous Palm Sunday, 1865. We enjoyed looking at the many buildings on the site. The bookstore, located in the old tavern, was very nice. If there was any bottled water or sodas on the site, we did not see them. It was very hot for early May. I would recommend that visitors at least have fluids with them in their cars. The admission, for 2 of us (seniors), was $5. We got our receipt in the visitor's center and handed it to the person who was in the McLean House (the surrender site). While there were some exhibits in the visitor center, we went to the Museum of The Confederacy about a mile down the road to get better information.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: Today was a gorgeous Fall day to walk the beautiful grounds at the Appomattox Courthouse Village and the connecting trails between the "last-stand" camps of Lee & Grant. Many of the buildings, including the famed McLean House where the actual surrender documents were signed, have been reconstructed based on historical documents and photographs. Only $3 per person or $5 per car is a great value to see and learn about one of the most crucial turning points in our country's history.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: GPS brought us a very round-about way to Appomattox Court House. It enabled us to see some of the nicest views of the rolling hills of Virginia that we would have missed on the highway, but there were no services along the back-country roads. Thus our disappointment when we arrived at the park to find there are no snacks available. It was a very cold, windy day and we were unable to enjoy walking through the park, so I'm sure our discomfort is the reason I would only rate Appomattox Court House "average". The unheated buildings were very cold, and the museum was so dark we could barely see the exhibits. The films were informative, but very old. I hope the National Park Service is able to update this important part of American history. Appomattox Court House has a great story to tell. Admission is free if you have a National Park senior pass.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: Appomattox court house was a nice peaceful visit. It's onl $5:00 for all of the park, you just walk at your leisure and spend all the time you want.very informative.the guides are great and helpful. We especially loved the provost as he talked with us, never leaving his character.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: The grounds are beautiful, and it is awe-inspiring to stand where Grant and Lee met. There was a very knowledgable ranger named Ernie Price working the McLean House -- he was full of all manner of information and insight, so bravo to him.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: This is an outstanding way to learn about our countries history. At $3 per adult, 15 and younger free or $5 per vehicle, this is a great value.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: We stopped on our way to Richmond,Virginia as part of our Civil War Tour. It was a little out of the way but a scenic drive, and worth the trip. Inexpensive at $5 a car. Certainly worth the trip for Civil War buffs.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: We stopped here with only an hour and a half until closing. We wished we had another hour or two to really explore the park. The $5.00 per vehicle admission is good for 7 days if you have time to come back within the week. The area had more to offer than we realized. There are a number of buildings you can tour on our own and there are a few cemeteries within the park. We enjoy photography and the setting sun cast a wonderful light for photos. The park rangers were knowledgable. Would definitely stop again.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: A significant moment in US history. You can see it in an hour or explore it for an afternoon. Grounds and buildings are well maintained and the US Park Service volunteers are friendly and enthusiastic about the material and their jobs. The visitor center has 2 slide shows, 15 minutes each, and interesting exhibits. The site of the actual surrender is a reproduction but very well done and accurate. You can spend more time touring more buildings or the grounds. Entry fee is $5. If you like civil war history or US history, this is a must see site.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: This was a really great stop while we were on our way to Lynchburg. The 'park' comprises a few buildings including the Courthouse which has since been changed to a museum, giving a taste of what this town was like back in the 1800's. There are a few other buildings including a tavern, lawyers office, and the house where Lee met with Grant to surrender his troops. This was a really good history lesson and the highlight was having the opportunity to chat with the three period actors who sat on the tavern porch. They were delightful and humorous telling stories of life 'back in the day' and commenting on the strange outfits that we tourists were wearing. Just up the street you can stop to see a small cemetery and a couple of other memorials. You can easily go through this area in about an hour to hour and a half. Definitely worth a stop if you're in the area. Bring your National Park Passport Book if you have one and get it stamped in the bookstore. Other things to see while you're here... about 35 minutes away is Lynchburg where yo can see Poplar Forest, Point of Honor, and the old Lynchburg Cemetery. All worthwhile!
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: I loved visiting this historical site! It was so lovely it was hard to remember that the Civil War ended here. The place was well marked so we had no trouble finding it. Lots of parking near the site. The staff were warm, funny and very knowledgeable. The site was well maintained and the boys were able to move around freely. The price was right too - we payed $5.00 for the family. I suggest you bring lunch because it's kind of rural, but it's a beautiful place for a picnic. We spent about 3.5 hours there and honestly could have spent more. There is some walking but it's not difficult.
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: Rated above average because I think that there is more of a story to tell than the one that is quite sparsly presented. This view of mine does not spoil the experience. The site itself will move anyone. The small city center that has been perserved/restored is precious. You can imagine people on horseback and horse drawn carriage arriving to this "bustling" town 150 years ago. And to think that in April of 1865, the bloodiest war ever fought by Americans came to an end in someone's living room. Please don't miss this if you are anywhere within a two hour drive!!
park: Appomattox Court House National Historical Park

text: $25/car and gives you access for seven days! Really wonderful experience!!! Make sure you bring water with you!
I've lived in Utah for 40 years and have never been here before. Shame on me. WILL BE BACK. Get the GyPSy Tour app for $3.99 for your iPhone or Android. Best way to visit the park. Just Beautiful!!!

Probably Moab. This place is like Westworld or something alien but whatever it's like it's really unlike anyplace you've been to or will go to. If you like hiking, deserts, crazy rock formations and amazing scenery this is your destination. $25 per car per 7 weeks but if you go on veterans day it's free ninety free all day.

Entry fee of $25 per vehicle, no fee with NPS Senior Pass. Highly recommend arriving in the morning upon opening before it gets too crowded. Currently some minor road construction ongoing in the park but not a big issue. also there are no restaurants in the park so you must bring your own food and drink. The overlooks and scenic views are just awesome. This is definitely a must see and we will return again when in the area. TIP: The Devil's Garden section seems to draws very large crowds so plan accordingly.

Just outside of Moab, this gem of a park awaits your visit. Easy to drive through the entire park, with many stopping points for photos or hiking opportunities. It was much bigger than I was expecting! Consider buying an annual National Park Pass if you’re going to tour a few like we did.
I recently acquired a Senior Pass for the National Parks and I have been taking advantage of this wonderful card!!

If you are in to adventure this is a must. You get to see 2 different parks. Off road can get bumpy but awesome. Can't find words to describe the feeling of being in the canyon, in the middle of it all. Would do this again if I go back. Hunter was an awesome guide. Price is well worth experience. Awesome, Awesome & Awesome.

I was passing this area on my way to Arizona, and detoured to drive through. I didn't have time to do any hikes, but it was worth just driving the loop to see the majestic beauty here. Luckily, I was here on Labor Day, and the park entrance was unmanned, so no visitor fee was required. Which is awesome, because apparently the entrance fee has raised from $10 to $25 per car. $25 would have seemed a bit steep just for me. Absolutely beautiful area, though -so worth seeing.

Visited here on two partial days in August 27 and 28. On the first day, we arrived around 4 pm. It wasn't crowded so we were able to see all the overlooks/turnouts in two hours with lots of photos. Unfortunately, the Window section of the park is closed for road construction until early September. The park itself closed at 7 pm to 7am from Sunday through Thursday. The visitor's center now has reduced hours from 9am to 4 pm for the rest of the season, starting on August 27. We arrived shortly before 7am on the second day. The weather had been 102 degrees on the first day that we were there so we wanted to arrive early to beat the heat. The park opened up at 7 am. It appeared that only one line had formed but when the park was opened, they let two lines go in. I would recommend forming a second line if there is only one line formed. Then, the attendants waved all the cars through without checking for national park passes or requesting payment, evidently to avoid congestion. The first thing that we did was to hike to Delicate Arch which took us 2.5 hours total trip. Best to do it first thing in the morning before the temperature soared. It went up almost ten degrees during that time frame. Wonderful park!
So much to see! Great hikes. The staff at the bistro center was great. With the $25 per car admission.

We had one day to travel around Arches National Park. Park entrance fee is $25. We stopped at the Visitors Center. It has bathrooms and places to get water. You can learn about the rock formations and how arches form before heading to the actual arches. There are many arches to hike to and some that you can view from the road. We only had one day so we picked a few to go see:

Traveling south after visiting dead horse park you can't miss this national park (seniors over 62 pay $10 and get a card that gets you in all USA national parks FOREVER! They do check your ID so no pretending to be older than you are).,.
For $10 you can't go wrong, even for $80 it's a great deal. Arches and all the parks are a beautiful part of our national treasures. All people in your vehicle gets in on your pass.

Worth every penny of the $25 entry fee. You will climb up through incredible rock walls and formations that just take your breath away. Good for about an hour and half just touring. Longer if you get out and take some of the numerous paths to view these sites up close.

The park costs $25 per vehicle for entry, and we spent most of our times that afternoon hiking to the Delicate Arch. That was because two of the sites along our way to the Arch was closed that day. It was about 45 minutes one way. About 1/3 the way there, the slope got stepper. Once you got over that steep part about 15 minutes depending on your physical condition, the rest got easy again. The Delicate Arch came into view and looked wonderful. Some folks hiked down below the Arch for a better view pointing their camera up. Although the sign said everyone should leave the park before 7PM; a large number of people started their hike up to the Arches after 6:30PM that day. If you do want to stay late, I would recommend bringing head lamp or torch light for seeing your way down after sunset.
Pay attention to the signs that say most people need 1 gallon water per day in hot weather. Also keep your brain cool: hat, sprtizing, wet handkerchief around your neck.

We spent 1 1/2 days here to get our fill of hikes and photos. Glad we didn't shorten the visit. The park is notoriously busy in summer, wonderfully quiet in winter. We visited in snow which was magical, a lovely contrast to the red sandstone, and easy to walk in IF YOU WORE YAKTRAX. These are cheap spikes for your boots, sold at the visitors' center for $11/pair and necessary when trails get icy (snow melts in day's sun then freezes at night). If you're visiting in high season, Google for the webcam at the entrance station that will show you how may cars are on the entrance road - this can help you judge your arrival time. Try for a variety of hikes/viewpoints when there. Yes, the Delicate Arch trail is terrific, but so is Park Avenue (a little canyon) with different views. And the Sand Dune arch is a short, cool sandpit for all ages.

In our somewhat limited time in Moab it was hard to pick and choose which hikes to do in Arches. One trail we did was the Delicate Arch trail. Mildly strenuous, it was worth every step. Was a longish line at the arch for photos, but provided an opportunity to rest, drink water, and meet new people. Also really enjoyed easy hike to Landscape Arch. Be sure to take brief side trip off main trail to Tunnel Arch and Pine Tree Arch. Pine Tree was a hidden gem - beautiful arch, could go right under it, secluded with very few people so could really take time to enjoy it, rest a moment, and get great pictures. We stopped at most scenic overlooks and were never disappointed. Feel like we just got a taste of the beauty of Arches and are eager to return!
This park is worth visiting -- amazingly scenic. $25.00 per car ($10.00 per person bike/foot $15.00 per motorcycle). Tons of wonderful sites and geological formations.

Moab, and Arches in particular, are now among my favorite places on the planet. Words can't describe the beauty of this area of the country. Take your time. There is much to see. Windows and Park Avenue are my two favorite areas of this park, but it's all incredibly beautiful. I also think you can see the park just fine on your own - no tour needed. Recommend going when it isn't full-up visitation season, or it could get very frustrating. Also, if you're touring consider buying an Annual Pass for $80. We did Arches, Canyonlands, Bryce, and several areas of Zion, and it more than paid for itself.

We had one morning to see the park before heading out in the remainder of our trip, so got to the park at 8:05. There were almost 100 cars in line already at this time and had to wait another 15 minutes to pay our $25 to enter the park. We thought this was a bit much to get in until we entered the park and hit the to if the first hill. Wow.

Arches National Park is unique and amazing. "Delicate Arch" -- the iconic arch seen in so many Utah travel promotions -- is really wondrous to behold, although (and the park warns you of this), to get to the arch by foot, you have to walk a rather arduous course that includes a path that is bordered on one side with a cliff (and no fence is there for safety). Tip: if you plan on seeing many national parks during a twelve-month period, buy an "America the Beautiful" national park pass for $80. The price of national parks adds up quickly and the park pass is a good value if you plan on visiting many national parks within that one-year period. There is another great national parks pass deal for seniors (62+): $10 for lifetime.

Why go to Moab if not to see Arches? Start early if you can. So many beautiful sites. Currently some construction at entrance and Devil's Garden causing closures to DG area. Loved balanced Rock, N,S Windows. Passed on hike to Delicate Arch but brought binoculars and got good view from the Viewpoint.

Arches is amazing- just breath taking. The only reason it's not earning a 5 star rating is that we waited 50 min to even get into the park on Memorial Day Weekend. They really need a separate line for NP Pass holders. Go early if you're visiting over a busy weekend- and know that once you're in the park the crowd quickly spreads out.

Plan at least 3 hours to drive through the park and stop at the viewing sites. We hiked to the Delicate Arch which is a rigorous undertaking, but well worth the effort. Getting there is basically uphill. We were able to take outstanding pictures of the arch. If you are a senior citizen, buy the Senior Pass for access to all National Parks for free once you pay for the pass.

Took a back country jeep ride one night and went back the next day to see the park from the front. Truly an amazing place to visit. We had senior(age 62) National Park Passes (which we paid $20 for that are going up to $80) that got us into all National Parks for free! A definite must see place on everyone's bucket list!
Shocked at $25 per car fee for viewing nature that probably has minimal costs to support but oh well

Some people travel to Utah as a destination. Some are just traveling through. If you are in the latter category, you need to pull off I-70 and get up close to what you've been seeing in the distance - those magnificent red rock formations. Once you turn south on US-191 at Crescent Junction, it's about 30 minutes to the park entrance, depending on traffic. By luck, we arrived around 4 p.m. and did not even have to pay an entrance fee. Be prepared, though, for a $25.00 cost per car, which I would have happily paid to support our national parks. Although still crowded, people are fewer at this time of day and the late afternoon light makes for striking photographs. This is a park you drive through, stopping or not stopping at viewing points along the way. There are plenty of hiking trails as well if you have the time. The Delicate Arch, the most famous of the park's structures is pretty far away from the viewpoint. To get closer requires a moderate half hour hike. To get really close involves a three mile strenuous hike. Regardless of the length of your stay, it's hard not to be awed by the wild beauty of this area.

I cannot imagine anyone rating Arches National Park lower than Excellent. Natural elements and diversity demand your full attention. While there are many arches and they are dramatic, the other 95% of the park are geological sights only to be seen and experienced; 220+ million year-old eroded, fascinating, all different rock, petrified and tree formations. A two-day visit (that is 3 nights) is my suggested minimum. April is a good month to be there with cool nights and mild days; great for walking and being in the fresh air. Seniors, get a lifetime pass for all national parks and monuments, $10, at the gate or online. Cars, Bikes, Motorhomes and Motorcycles are all welcome and well accommodated.

Be advised...you must hike to most of the arches. This is NOT a national park that you can merely drive thru. If you want to see the arches, you have to get out of your car and walk. The easiest one for me was the Sand dune arc. Also, call ahead for info. I was looking forward to visiting after dark only to find out the parked closed at 7 pm. $25 to enter seems a bit steep.

The drive through Arches National Park alone is worth the $25 admission fee. But you'll regret not hiking the 3 mile round-trip hike to Delicate Arch. This beautiful arch is captured on Utah license tags for good reason; it is awe-inspiring to see. The 1.5 mile hike to the arch is moderate to difficult but well-worth the effort. You won't be disappointed.

We arrived at the park in the early afternoon and waited in line to use my "Senior Pass" for the first time. What a deal. Lifetime entry for $10! Not just to Arches but to any National park or monument. If you are old enough (65), get yours before the price goes up. We enjoyed the drive and many of the pullout and trails, selecting ones that the park brochure described as "easy". It was a tiring and satisfying day. We are heading back tomorrow.

What more can be said? This is a breathtaking park. The views are beyond compare. Worth every bit of the $25 entrance fee. Did get a bit crowded at some of the lots, but not too bad. Was able to get a good overview of the park driving, took about 4 hours. Must see!!

This place is absolutely breath taking. It cost $25 to get in but it's totally worth it. There's so much to see. We spent an entire day out here and just scratched the surface. It's a must if you love the outdoors.

I absolutely loved this park. It's $25 to get in, but I had the $80 unlimited pass so over a span of 3 days I saw the whole park that's accessible by car. It's a MUST see. Take your time at every stop, walk around and enjoy the view. We came during the "off" season and it was empty. If you come back at night , the view of the sky is amazing. Don't pass it up!
$25 entry is well worth it if you take your time and explore each arch and take in the views. February is a great month to go when dry and warm.

Unbelievable formations and views, definitely take plenty of water, healthy snacks and wear comfortable hiking clothing and shoes. Would recommend allowing two days of time spent at the park as the price of $25 is a bit steep for one day and you really need two days to truly experience all the park. Did a 10 mile hike on my 58th birthday there and I am not a hiker. The magnificent views prod even less athletic people like me to keep going just to see what is around the bend. Be sure to take your phone or camera for photos you will always treasure. Hope to return again and do more hiking and spend a couple of days there and at nearby Canyonlands. Check out the Senior Discount Rates available for National Parks. Be sure to watch the quick video at the Visitor Center to get a good overview of the park at the start of your visit. Can't wait for a return visit. Would research a bit more before next visit to make best use of my time.

We chose do hike the overlook of Delicate Arch instead of the longer hike. The view is still good but you need a long lens for good pictures. Windows arches were worth the hike. Feet were tired but effort was worthwhile. Wonderful park!
Could not have had a better time. Hiked to Delicate Arch about 1.5 hours up and back. Loved balancing Rock. $25 for a week is cheap, we just kept going back.

You can ride to each arch most of the way and then take a short hike 1/4 mile to the arches. I think it would be wheelchair accessible for several of the arches. You can also do some 3 hour hikes if you want. No light at night so the stars are very visible. Cost $25 dollars for a week.

I spent 3 nights here. It was not enough. I would recommend at least 5 unless you are one of those young fit speedy Gonzales. The view points alone will take a day and there are so many trials to hike. Many of the trials involves rock climbing so you have to be at some level of fitness to tackle them. I would strongly recommend staying at the campsite (Devil's Garden). It cost $25 a night and if you have a senior card, $12.50. Have the right change as the host does not carry change. It is a walk- in only campsite which is great because it would be fully booked all the time otherwise. Best time to check in is around 8 to 9 because I notice that most people check out early if they were leaving. The campsite alone is a great place to hike. There is an arch by the amphitheater and a trail and rock formation within the campsite itself. A herd of 6 deer roamed through my site one morning. The campsite is in Devil's Garden which has a few trails and arches and that would take a day of hiking. The other popular trails are Delicate Arch (an icon), total 6 miles to and from the parking lot, Fiery Furnace (require permit), Klondike Bluff (about 4 mile drive on a dirt road to the trail head) and many others. Just driving around the park on the paved road give you some great views of the various rock formations in the park. It took me 2 days to drive from my home to the park but the trip was definitely worth it.

Arches National Park is very popular because of the dramatic red rock formations and famous arches. It's only 27 miles from I-70, and compared to other parks, you can see a lot of interesting and exciting sights and desert scenery within a relatively small area. The scenic drive access road to all the features is only about 53 miles round trip. The park can get very crowded and parking spaces fill up. It is best to try to get to the park early and visit the most popular areas first. Try to avoid weekends and holidays. This strategy worked for us; we visited the last week of August and arrived at the park at sunrise. We drove all the way through to Devil's Garden and took a short hike, then stopped at all the features on our way back out. It was starting to get crowded and tour buses were appearing by about 9:30-10:00. We had been to the park before and didn't need a permit for anything, so we waited to stop at the visitor center on our way out. You can get a map with basic geological information about the park at the entrance kiosk where you pay the admission ($25/car, accepts NPS passes). Allow about half a day to see everything - longer if you are going to do some hikes. If you don't have a lot of time, I suggest visiting "Park Avenue" and "The Windows" as you can see some amazing sights near the road/parking without long hikes. People who use wheelchairs or have serious mobility limitations will not be able to access many of the trails, but fortunately some features can be seen from a car or viewpoint so it's still worth visiting. There is no lodge or restaurant at this park, but it is located just outside the town of Moab, which has all the services you will need. Just bring along some snacks and water. There's a campground in the park at Devil's Garden, visit the park website for information about that. I highly recommend that you take the time to visit Canyonlands National Park as well while you're in the area, and take a scenic drive along the Colorado River on UT128 for more amazing scenery.

We visited Arches for the first time and were fascinated by its beauty! The landscape is unique. Visiting the Visitor's Center first and watching a video is a good way to start your exploring. We bought an audio tour which we found very helpful. It was only $10 at the Visitor's Center. If you return it, you get $5 back; either way, we thought it was a great deal! We really enjoyed seeing the rock formations and arches. We plan on returning.

This park is so unique and a real treasure, which explains why it is so popular, even mid-week in October. The hikes are well marked and you can easily judge their degree of difficulty. Go to the Visitors Center (only real bathrooms!) and see the short film.to get a quick understanding of the arches. Climbed the hike to Delicate Arch and saw so many miserable babies and toddlers being hauled up the hill with their parents. I don't recommend this for young kids. Government needs to pump some funds into this place so it can better handle crowds, especially at the entry/payment point.

Amazing, fantastic, incredible, awe inspiring… any of these adjectives plus any others that mean the same thing can be used interchangeably for this state park. A must see at least once in a lifetime. To enter the state park there is a $25 fee, but the ticket can be used for 7 days. And in order to see the whole park that's how much time you could use, and some! People can hike, bike, dirt bike and four wheel. Beautiful area…

Don't miss this park if you are in Moab. You can make the drive through the park without stopping and see enough to make the trip worth your while. If you are more adventurous, take one of the many hikes. We love the hike to Delicate Arch. It is a 3.2 mile round trip with a pretty steep incline the last half but it is well worth the views at the summit. Get to the park early (we arrived a little before eight and avoided the 20 minute entry line we saw when we left. There is a $25 fee per car, worth every penny.

Enjoyed this park tremendously. So many options for hiking, both in terms of length and difficulty. Visited the park twice, but so much more we would like to see. Can't imagine getting tired of this park. Husband and I agreed it was one of the prettiest we had ever seen. Entry fee is $25. Senior passes to national parks available at age 62 and are a great deal. Moab is nearby and a convenient stay to the park.

The Delicate Arch is the famous arch to see, so if you are able hike to it! Some people struggled on the hike that we saw passing by, but it's definitely doable! Take water and don't hike during the hottest time of the day (which is what we did). It cost $25 for our car to drive in, and it's good for 7 days. After we left we parked by the entrance sign where people take pictures and gave someone our pass so they could get in for free.
What can you say? Absolutely amazing! Be sure and stop at the visitors center and rent the park's cd ($5) It give lots of interesting information about the park.

Loved seeing this impressive park. The evening sun allows you to see the glow on the rocks and adds a depth that's a treat to the eyes. I find sunrise rise and sunset the best times to go. We have the annual national park pass and find that it's worth it --$80 if you're visiting several parks where as a single visit is $20 or more ( for 7days). Bring plenty of water and a picnic as there are no services available in the park except at front visitors center there is a water faucet. Also there are bathrooms (which are really covered portables) throughout the park to use. Plan on wearing layers as the temperature can vary and change quickly and the wind can be chilly. Don't forget your sunglasses either!

The Arches National Park is a picturesque detour worth taking if you have a few hours to spend seeing the spectacular wonders that nature has carved from the sandstone mountains in the area. There are plenty of turn outs along the roadway to allow you to step out and take photos, and it is well worth stopping at them. We visited the park in mid September and the temperatures were tolerable. I am told we should avoid the hot summer months, especially if planning a hike or two. Still, we enjoyed the beauty of the park and are very thankful that it is a National Park protected from developers. The scenes of red rock and formations remind me of something you might expect to see on Mars! I highly recommend visiting Arches National Park. One tip: If you plan on visiting any of the 5 great national parks in Utah and perhaps the Grand Canyon in Arizona in the same year, by all means purchase the National Park Pass ANNUAL PASS. For only $80.00, it will get you into ANY National Park in the United States. It has already paid for itself after a visit to the Grand Canyon, Arches and Canyon lands National Parks. After that, they are all FREE.
Beautiful views. Lots of pull outs for photography. Must see if your in the area. 25 dollar fee for the park

Being in our 60's I have an 'America the Beautiful' senior national park card, so we got in free(if you're old enough get one, $10.00 lifetime card). Arches is fantastic. Beautiful drive through the park. We were in awe of the double arch. For delicate arch we choose the shorter 'view' trail rather then the 3 mile hike to get up close and personal. The view trail was okay, but you are way to far away to appreciate the arch. That one trail and the disappointing view is the only reason I didn't give it 5 stars.

Just hard to comprehend all the beauty in this park. It changes at every curve. Overlooks are marked real well. Hiking was fantastic. This is truly Gods beauty at its best! Park entrance for a vehicle is $25 so be prepared for that. Truly loved this National Park!

A great start to our sunny Labor Day visit was expedited entry for us, as Golden Age Pass holders. Friendly rangers, good facilities, clean restrooms. So much to see! Good information, displays & maps. A fully enjoyable day viewing arches, balanced rocks, cliffs, formations & so much scenery!

This I our 3rd visit to the park and each time we go back the park is busier and less enjoyable. The park is just not set up for the numbers visiting. There is insufficient parking to view the many fabulous features. The toilets are disgusting and need solar recirculating fans. There are insufficient picnic places. There is certainly not enough parking to cater for the walkers to Delicate Arch (the trail to the arch is badly marked). It would be sensible if a Ranger checked out walkers when they set out for adequate footwear and water and also advised walkers that those descending should give preference to those going up. Finally - why are there no seats along the sides of the tracks and near the features so that older visitors can enjoy the park and sometimes wait for the younger members of their group. I am sue that the Park is underfunded but it is too cheap - why not a $2 surcharge per head over the park fee to allow some of the essential works to be put in place.

I'm on a month long solo road trip and I wanted to check out the national parks. I've never been to Arches and it was on my way so I checked it out. I arrived early 7:30 am and there was no one at the check in, but I have my yearly national pass which is a godsend. Highly recommend paying the $80 for the yearly pass which gets you into 99% of the National Parks (Mt Rushmore you still need to pay for parking). After leaving the Visitor Center I drove up the with switch backs and checked out a number of viewing places. What a cool park with interesting rock formations which resemble people, animals and objects.

To get into the national park you have to pay $25 which goes to preserving the park. The view was so beautiful! We went on a hike to see the delicate arch and that hike is not a joke. It was all uphill, no shade, and the air was still. It was 3 miles round trip and was extremely miserable but the view of the arch was SO worth it.

Entrance fee for private vehicle $25. Less if you have park pass, military, on bicycle or access pass. Fee is good for 7 days. Go to visitors center first to see a film and get info about hikes and fill your water bottles. You can drive the whole park in a day and do some short hikes or stop at scenic spots, but to really enjoy the park, visit for several days. Great stops to walk around are Windows, Delicate Arches and Devils garden. No pets are allowed on trails. Devils Garden is the longest trail. Bring food or snacks as there are no restaurants or gas stations. Wear a hat and use sunscreen. The earlier you start a hike you avoid the brutal sun! Spectacular views, well worth it!

This is our second trip to Arches in 12 months. There is so much to do! The most important advice that I can share is to wear closed toed sneakers or hiking boots with good traction. Most trails, even the easy ones, have uneven surfaces. There are several drive up quick walks, but to get up close to the arches you need to put in effort. We returned to the park in order to take the Fiery Furnace hike. The Fiery furnace tour is great for older families. You MUST be in shape, as there is rock scrambling to do. I am 50+ and was able to do this hike with little difficulty. Tickets must be reserved 6 months in advance through the park service. There were 2 private companies doing tours while we were there, so this might be an option if you can't get on a ranger tour This is a unique experience in the park. We also came in early for a sunrise and returned for a sunset on the same day. Bring picnic foods and LOTS of water. Finally go as early in the day as you can. It gets crowded.

National Parks require a fee to be paid. This park was $35.00 for a car load. If you are visiting multiple parks, purchase the annual park pass for $80.00. It is good at all National Parks and will save you money. Arches NP has over 2000 arches and windows to explore. We hiked the 3 mile trail tot he Delicate Arch and it was worth it! You must carry an drink at least a gallon of water and stop to hydrate often with the high temperatures and low humidity environment. Stop in the visitors center for park information and maps. The history of the park is very interesting to see and experience. There are cafe to have lunch at in the park. Give yourself a day to hike and drive to all you wish to see. Be vigilant of the weather and do not get caught on a trail during a storm, if this happens, seek shelter or get to your car.

This was our first time to Arches and it is just amazing. We stopped there on our way to Denver! It costs about $25 to enter the park. You can spend as much time or as little time as you want in the park. They give you a map and information to give you sample itineraries on what sites to see based on how much time you have, which was very helpful. We stopped at the visitor center and viewed their video introduction which is a great video on the background of the arches. Then you can walk through the little museum before you head out to the various sites. We visited the windows, balanced rock, and Delicate Arch. You can drive by the sites or you can park and hike up to them and view their magnificence up close and personal! If you do that, be aware it is a lot of walking so definitely wear your tennis shoes, wear your hats, and apply your sunscreen. We went in the heat of summer in July and it was hot, with of course, no shade. We are in-shape people, but our legs were still sore the next day as we spent about 3 hours there! Arches is definitely a must-see! We stayed at a hotel in Grand Junction, which is about 1 1/2 hours away, which is a great place to stay over if you're heading toward Denver!

What a beautiful place. This is one of the most beautiful parks we visited in the last two years we've traveled in our RV. One thing you need to know if your over 62 is that you can buy a senior pass for 10 dollars which will get you and your spouse regardless of their age into any national park for free and it never expires until you do. Most parks charge about 25 dollars each day you visit so this is a must buy.

We decided to explore Arches while passing through Utah from Colorado because it was only 27 miles from highway 70. It was after 6 pm and the visitors center was closed but the park is open 24 hours a day. It cost $25 to enter but apparently after 6 pm they don't collect the fee. After 4pm or early in the morning is the best time to visit because its the desert and it's hot! Bring a hat, sun screen, and plenty of water. We were able to drive about 30 minutes into the park so I advise that you go about 4 pm to really explore and take fabulous sunset pictures.
went to arches park on arrival ranger at booth suggested senoir pass good at all national parks for lifetime 10$.best deal in along time.can be used with car full of people.
Feels like being on another planet. Absolutely breath taking, and it just goes on and on. If you haven't seen the south part of Utah, you haven't seen some of the most beautiful country in the USA!!

Arrived in Moab in the afternoon and headed straight out to the park to catch Delicate Arch at Sunset. Hike is tough, but manageable. Came back the next day to finish off the park. It could all be done in one day, but fishing off the day with a hike up to delicate arch after hiking everything else would be a little strenuous. Fee is only $20 per vehicle.
Do not miss this park!! Gorgeous! Subscribe to the app and listen as you tour the park. It's only $3.99 but definitely worth it with step by step commentary.

Unbelievable! Better than the Grand Canyon, because you are right in the middle of the skyward-pointing arches that zoom upward at every turn. It’s so popular we had a 20-minute line to get to entrance. We had our senior lifetime Parks pass so didn't have to pay the $25 entry. Limited facilities for potty breaks, though visitors center just inside park does have great toilets. Clue: Go before you go! There are literally too many photo opportunities. The more you drive into the park, the more impressed you will be. Give it a few hours and take your time. We were a bit rushed because of commitments up the road. Two hours was not enough time. Our most impressive sight was Balanced Rock. See it to believe it. Or look at my photos. It is still unbelievable.

Road Trip from CA. The Mesa's are beautiful and picturesque but All of the Arches requires a trek into the dessert area. ( as Senior's , over 70 ) We got to see 3 Arches because the rest were too far to walk, especially in mid-July. You have to have a Hat, Water, and Hiking boots to traverse the terrain, some up to miles ( one was a 1.6 mile hike in dessert sand, no thanks ). This would be a great Park if you were under 40 and visit the Park in Spring & Fall but not in the Winter or Summer. We were looking for a better outcome. Seniors, do not forget to get your 'Senior Pass' ( at the ticket booth ) which allows you to get into any National Park that charges ( for "Free" ). The Arches charges $30 / car, we got in for Free....

My husband and I thought this place was just stunning. One must not just drive around but get out and climb to really experience nature's handiwork. The Window Arches were out favorite. It is an easy climb to see them up close. We went in April and thought this was the perfect time because the weather was perfect 60's-70's and the crowds were small. Be sure to get your Lifetime Senior Pass if you are 62 and older for $10. It lasts forever and you get in any national park free.

We have been to Arches several times,but this trip we went in only as members of a privately guided tour to the Fiery Furnace area. Our guide was great and the hike in the FF was excellent, but we were surprised and disappointed with our interaction with the park rangers. The two rangers we spoke to were rude and sullen, almost bordering on hostile. Not sure what that was all about. We had a free late afternoon during our stay and decided to go back to Arches for a few hours but changed our minds when we saw the entrance fee is now $25. If we had the chance to visit multiple times for that fee, that wouldn't have been a problem, but seemed high for the limited time we had. I wish that there was a reduced price half-day option available.
