Believe me when I say, that had my wife and myself not seen the film, we would have left the park later that day with more questions than answers. The film is free, so you might as well sit back and relax for twenty minutes, while you absorb the enigmatic background of Bryce Canyon. There are two different experiences you can take while driving through the park. A drive to Bryce Point and back is about four miles both ways. A drive to Rainbow Point and back (passing other major view points) is about seventeen miles both ways. When we got to Bryce Point, a Stellar's Jay (which we seen during the film) landed in a tree only about a couple of feet from where we were standing. We were able to get some really nice close-ups. We then walked the trail to one of the most scenic vistas anywhere, Bryce Point. I cannot even find words to explain it, other than unimaginable. At Bryce Point alone there are an incredible amount of different types of formations, but the biggest one is the amphitheater. Bryce Point is one of the highest points in the park at 8300 feet. Next, we continued to Paria View. Again, amazing formations mixed with a light snow made this the ultimate experience. We stopped by the Bryce Canyon Lodge which is currently packing everything up for the winter season. It will reopen in April. Not only was the scenery the most beautiful in our opinions, but the week before the lodge closes up is probably the most desolate time to visit the park. You pretty much have the park to yourselves. That doesn't happen during the Spring, Summer, and early Fall (especially May-August). We saw an abundance of Mule deer as well. Our last stop was Fairyland Canyon. This is where that famous scene of a balancing rock above all other formations can be seen in person. We liked everything about our trip to Bryce. I would recommend it to anyone and everyone. It doesn't matter whether you're an outdoor person or not, you absolutely have to see Bryce Canyon National Park!

While we only had a day to visit the park, it was well worth it. It costs $25 per car to enter the park for 7 days, or $30 for a yearlong pass. The crowds in the park when my wife and I went (June 2011) were very little, and it was so beautiful to see. Right after we entered we viewed the visitor center, which looked fairly new and had a wonderful exhibit as well.

One day was not enough! NOTE: If you don't have a National Park pass, consider getting one! My Senior pass @ $10 when I was 62 has been the best buy ever for access of 4-6 people as I take family & friends into parks like this and save $25 or more each time.

Our trip 's purpose was to visit 7 National Parks. Bryce was #7. We didn't know it, but we did save the best til last. The park can be appreciated from the numerous pull-off and view points with very little effort. Unlike Zion or Arches National Parks where hikers have the clear advantage. Bryce is breathtaking. We traveled in our own vehicle but later in the season a shuttle is used to get around in the park. We have the Senior life time National Park Pass ($10)

This park may be busy in summer, but it's so big you can probably find some quiet even then. In winter snow, check that the main road is plowed (the Arches visitors center will know), wear yaktrax for traction in snow (can buy at Arches visitors center for $11/pair) and enjoy the solitude. Try to see the different areas of the park (multiple canyons!): Mesa Arch trail (easy loop with arch that "frames" the landscape behind), Shafer viewpoint (mini hoodoos), Grand View Point (red sandstone), Upheaval Dome (overlooking sunken yellow canyon).

Lots of canyons and great views. Many places to pull over and enjoy the view or take a hike. There are spots one can pitch a tent or a small camper and spend the evening with a campfire and a great view. I have sent a photo of one such spot. It is good to have so many National Parks in the United States to enjoy, also glad I got a Senior Pass several years ago at a cost of $10,00 which allows for free entry to all the National Parks.

We toured the Islands in the Sky Section and this is not to be missed. Entry fee of $25 per vehicle, no charge with NPS Senior Pass. We did a self-guided driving and walking tour and the Upheaval Dome, Green River Overlook and Grandview Point Overlook are a must see with exceptional views. No restaurants in the park so you must plan accordingly.

This is a 1/2 day visit in my opinion. Spend an entire day in arches if you can. You do not have to hike very much but for sure take time to hike to mesa arch it was incredible, And i found a money tree! well it was a bush and there was only a dollar in it hahahahahaha
lots of turn outs, lots of trails, beautiful landscapes. It is a NP so you do have to pay an entrance fee. the NEW fee for seniors for a life time pass has gone from $10 to $80

My family and I visited Island in the Sky (the northern part of the park) at Canyonlands National Park in early October. To see the other two entrances, plan on driving several hours. The area is an hour drive from Moab but because it isn’t as close to Moab as Arches NP, it sees far less traffic. The park didn’t charge us an entry fee which is nice considering many national parks want to charge $70 per vehicle. The visitor center is smaller than in most other parks but has the same amenities. There are limited facilities available in the north part of the park and no lodging, fuel or restaurants near the park so come prepared. The park has both hiking trails as well as 4WD trails of various degrees of difficulty which should appeal to most people. There are some wonderful views of the canyons in the valley below which are must see. The northern entrance is near Dead Horse State Park which I would recommend visiting at the same time as Island in the Sky. Depending on the amount of hiking or 4WD you plan on doing, 1/2 day is adequate for Island in the Sky. The park is appropriate for people of all ages and abilities.
Stunning views make this a must if you like to be immersed in nature. The deep canyons are enthralling. It is well worth the $25 entrance fee.

We spent about 1/2 day at the Island in the Sky portion of this park. It is very pretty and we enjoyed our time there. There is no food sold in the park, so plan accordingly. If you plan to visit multiple national parks, be sure to get the America the Beautiful pass. It is $80 and covers admission to national parks and monuments for 1 year.

While seemingly not as well known as nearby Arches N.P., Canyonlands N.P. offers extraordinary views that seem to go on and on forever without the often overwhelming crowds like at Arches. The primary attraction is the unbelievable views of the canyons carved by the Colorado River but with 360 degrees of fabulous vistas there is plenty else to see. Pay attention to the map and hit all of the pull outs and overlooks and you will enjoy a great half day at the park. Add in some hiking and you will have a fabulous full day. No matter what your plan be sure to bring your own water and plenty of sunscreen.

This park had BRAND NEW ROADS throughout the entire park, along with brand new bathrooms. I appreciate seeing my tax dollars at work. This park is beautiful! Better than the Grand Canyon. Many overlooks and hikes. We hiked to the Mesa Arch and it was incredible. Not too many people there but everyone was respectful of each other wanting to take pictures and no one interfered. We were in the Islands in the Sky region.

Canyonlands is about 30 miles from Moab, entrance fee is $25. The views are just amazing with photo opportunities around every corner. In some spots you can see over 100 miles in any direction, beautiful canyons. You can hike, picnic and really spend the day in this wonderful place.

Drove along Shafer Trail. Awesome views. Not a difficult 4x4 trail, but if you are leery of heights, you may want to reconsider. Trail is wide enough, but there are some edges with sheer drops. Beautiful and Uncrowded. If you start the trail from Potash road, it is free. If you start from Canyonlands, there is a $25 entrance fee that supports the National Park system and there is a very informative Park Ranger there that will provide you with some maps and tips. Had a wonderful time.

Since we were going to Arches, we made a quick detour to see Canyonlands and let our daughter get her National Park Passport stamped. We only went to the Island in the Sky section. It is really beautiful. You can stop at a few of the overlooks and really get a great view. Worth the short drive when you are in the area anyway.

You can enjoy this park by car or by foot but don't miss it. The views of the canyon carved by the Colorado rival the Grand Canyon. There are lots of hiking and biking options, or you can just drive the excellent roads and take in the sights from your car. There is a $25 fee per car to enter.

After stopping at Dead Horse Point State Park we drove just up the road to Canyonlands. There are three separate parks of which all have their own separate entrances. So you cannot got to one and just go over a bridge to the next. The one closest to town is the Eye in the sky. Which is the only one that we made it to. We spent about 4 or so hours driving around and stopping at all the sites. We were there around late afternoon and most the attractions had around 10 or so people there. The cost to get in was $25 for our car.

Entry fee of $10 per vehicle, no charge with NPS Senior Pass. The drive in from Moab along Route 24 had terrific scenic views. We did a self-guided driving (~10 miles) and walking tour along Scenic Drive and the views were just awesome. We were not planning on visiting here but we sure are glad we did as this is a hidden gem. Also a visit to the Gifford House Store & Museum is a must see for nostalgia.

This was park number three on our 5 park tour. What an unextexpected pleasure. Much less crowded than arches, Bryce or Zion. The drive into the canyon was spectacular. And viewing the petroglyphs was interesting. A pie at the Gifford house was a nice break and reminded us of Acadia and getting popovers. An entire pie was only 6 dollar ( in a pot pie size tin). Finally the chimney rock trail while a little close to edges. Provided great views.

The park has a narrow paved road in and out, plus a packed dirt road about 15 miles in for the more adventurous. Hiking trails and scenic views. Pay attention while driving, and use the pull outs and viewing areas to photograph the area. Traveling by motorcycle, I had to pay attention to the road. And I thought the views on the way out were even more beautiful on the way out. I went just after sunrise, and before the roads started to get busy by 10 am. Enjoy!

This is a unique park, that not only has spectacular natural views, but also some settlement history of the small Mormon community of Fruitas. Part of the park is actually accessible for free along Highway 24, but there is also a great scenic drive accessed from the Visitor Center for a mere $5. Definitely a stop you should make if you are touring the great National Parks of Southern Utah.

If there wasn't a sign, you wouldn't know this was a National Park. There's no Park entrance or payment. There was a restaurant nearby that said it was in the middle of nowhere and that's the way they like it. That sums up a visit to this Park - its great if it's nowhere you want. If you are in the area, or have to do The Big 5 like us, plan on a "drive-through". If you make this a destination and have high expectations, you will be disappointed. Lots of pretty rock formations, a couple of historic areas and that's that. Didn't do the scenic drive because we it was boring. Try going later in the day - shadows don't make good photos. The famous "small" homemade apple pies at the farmhouse/museum were $6 and I swear they were delivered from a bakery in Torrey UT down the road. I guess there's a reason this is the least visited of the Big 5.

We enjoyed Capitol Reef National Park very much. The petroglyphs (ancient rock carvings) were incredible to see. Be sure and take the scenic loop before you exit the park as this is the most incredible part of the entire area. The scenery is unbelievable and well worth the $10 for the 20 mile drive.

This is probably a park a lot of people skip in favor of Arches, Zion and Bryce. It has more rock layers are more variety of colors in the scenery than any of those places. It is also nice to be in a small park without entrance lines and crowds. The payment is at a little honesty booth on a side route scenic drive. The capitol gorge trail was different and a fairly easy walk. Check it out.

I have loved Capitol Reef since before it was a national park. In 1969 my parents brought us on a family road trip to Utah. As a 12 year old, I was totally mesmorized by this place, which was a national monument then. Almost 5 decades later, Capitol Reef holds the same magic and majesty for me; it remains my favorite park in Utah. Why? It has both tremendous raw beauty with its massive fiery red formations and it has a lovely cultural history with the Mormon lives spent there and the beautiful orchards they left behind still tended by the NPS. During our September visit we enjoyed the 1.8 mile round trip hike to Hickman Natural Bridge and also took the capitol gorge gravel road to its end and hiked the easy, level mile Capitol Gorge Trail to see an amazing petroglyph panel and a pioneer register with several hundred historic signatures. The campground was full all 3 days so we stayed at an RV park in Torrey where having a reservation is a good idea. We enjoyed picking apples and pears for $1.00/lb, with a scale, picking equipment and self pay station offered by the NPS. We took an AWESOME ride around the park, on the Burr Trail, starting in Torrey on Highway 12 and then turning onto Burr Trail at Boulder. We had great coffee and dessert at an eclectic coffee and gift shop in Boulder. The road winds through Grand Staircase Escalante Natl Monument for a time, providing spectacular views. The last part of the road, after the steep switchbacks, was very washboard-ey even in our Jeep. With a car though, you could easily go up to the switchbacks and turn around because the gravel is good from Boulder to the switchbacks. Don't miss Capitol Reef when in Utah. For us, it beats all the other Utah parks in scenery, cultural history and hiking opportunities.

My 11 year old granddaughter and I did a trip through the Utah National Parks plus the Grand Canyon and this was one of our favorite parks. Yes it's free unless you do the scenic drive which I think is $10 a car. There is a self pay station at the beginning of it. We had a park pass so we didn't need to pay but it would have been worth it. The end turns to a dirt road which was really cool driving through this canyon area. I will include a picture.

We went out of our way on a trip from Phoenix to Wyoming to visit Capitol Reef. . . and we are so happy that we did! We traveled to Arches and Canyonlands National Parks last year and we live in Arizona, home to Sedona and the Grand Canyon. We were still impressed with Capitol Reef! The geological history that is evident on the rock formations is fascinating as well as beautiful. The historical elements of the pioneers and fruit orchards are also interesting. Definitely recommend spending time in Fruita to pick from the orchards if one of their fruits is in season. We went during apricot season and were astounded by the numbers of apricots on the trees. Visitors may eat as many fresh, organic fruits from the trees as they like. The park even provides fruit pickers for visitors to use for hard-to-reach fruit. Any fruit that you would like to take with you is only $1.00/pound. A dollar per pound for you-pick organic fruit?! Unbelievable!

Mom and I visited all the other mighty five and finally got around to Capitol Reef, not really expecting it to be that impressive. We were SO wrong! Capitol Reef is AMAZING! We were sunburned, and worn out from the previous day at Bryce, and short on time so I didn't do much hiking. but it looked like there were plenty of options for great hiking. We took the short scenic drive.(all the drive in and around Capitol Reef is technically a scenic drive!) Stopped for Pie and Ice Cream at the little homestead house. and were blown away by this unheralded gem. We got the little two dollar scenic drive map at the great Visitors center and mom read off the info as we drove through. Very special Park here! I will remember forever, driving through Capitol Reef with my Mom, listening to the Highway Men. Great moment in my life!

We spent 2 1/2+ hours, but it could easily be longer. Many cars passed us, as they were in a hurry. They were not collecting a fee. There should be a $25-50 fee per car. This place is special. Mostly foreigners. Lots of the drive in the attraction is paved, two way and fairly narrow. The speed limit is 10-25 mph, but often ignored and unsafe. Eventually, the road is unpaved, bumpy and narrow. Several places are hard to pass. This road was busy, but only a fraction of the visitors make this part of the area. Again the speed limits are 10-25 MPH, but often ignored to cause many close calls and dirt skids. Eventually you get to a parking area. From here there is a mile or so hike to the pots. We tried to make this hike, but my hip was not able. We hiked the river bottom, about 1/3 mile, but the footing in small boulders and holes, not an easy stroll. Great views and picture opportunites throughout this Park. Some people likely stayed over 3 hours.

Our first trip to Capitol Reef National Park was eye-opening -- to say the least. We drove the automobile tour, and every stop had splendid vistas. The highlight of our tour was the Hickman Natural Bridge. Some of it is moderately strenuous, with the 400-foot increase in elevation adding to the challenge. Worth the time and effort. Another interesting feature of the park were the orchards -- artifacts of 19th century settlers in the area. While we were there (in September), apples were on many trees. Visitors were welcome to pick the fruit. Any that they ate in the orchard was free. Any that they took was priced at $1/pound. Finally, the petroglyphs are a must-see.

The park can be accessed along Hwy 24, and unless you take the Scenic Drive heading south from the visitor center, the park is free. Be sure to stop at the orchards to pick some fruit. $1/lb self pick. Different fruits according to the season. Be careful of the orchard being flooded and muddy though.

The park is worth the trip. I like the remote location. The scenic drive was easy to do. We did hike the Grand Wash trail which was easy. The Petroglyph panel was interesting to see along with new graffiti. Would have attended the star grazing event but felt the cliffs would get in the way. We did our star grazing at Panorama Point (outstanding views in the day time too) along with several other cars. Left the park heading east to Moab and terrain was quite different and very unique but a word of caution, no services along the way. The entrance fee was $10 and you place your money in an envelope before entering the scenic drive. I would like to come back and do hiking around the area.

This is the second time we went here and it's such a peaceful place. We took the Hickman Bridge hike and enjoyed it. It is a hot hike during the summer so go during the cooler time of day. You are only by the water at the beginning of the hike then you walk up for most of the trip to the bridge. We went to the Gifford house for pie and took it to the picnic area to eat it while watching deer. The pie is $6 for a small tin that's more than enough for a person. The rhubarb with strawberries was some of the best pie I've eaten. The scenery is some of the best in Utah without the crowds of Bryce and Zion.

Capital Reef is a wonderful place to spend a day or two. There are wonderful viewpoints, interesting historical buildings and orchards, and a scenic drive. It was nice to be able to roam the park without the crowds we experienced at Zion and Bryce Canyon. Make sure to pick the fruit in the orchards and try out a pie at the Gifford House Store and Museum. If you're really adventurous, get up before dawn and see the sunrise through Hickman Bridge. There is also a variety of hikes that can take you through the canyon or up to the rim. Since Hwy 24 goes through the park, you only pay a fee if you do the scenic drive ($10/vehicle) which is so worth it!

I didn't even know this national park existed until I was mapping out our route from Bryce Canyon to Moab. We spent the night nearby and drove the Capitol Reef park in late afternoon taking advantage of the best light to view the park. We stopped at the visitor center and purchased a guide to the geology of the park for $2 which really add a lot of additional insight into what we saw.

We can't believe we've always lived in Utah but have never visited here. It's breathtaking and stunning nature. Most of the park can be seen for free by staying on highway 24. Our favorite spots were Fruita, including the baked goods at the Gifford House and Capitol Gorge. We chose to take the scenic drive and do a family hike at the south end of the park, so we paid the bargain $5 fee and enjoyed a day together in Capitol Gorge. Even though my research told me this would be the busiest time to visit, the park is huge and crowds weren't a problem except for getting a spot at the campground in Fruita. Highly recommend this park. We are excited to go back.

We only had a couple of hours to spend in the park, but it was fantastic! It's also a bargain for those who don't have a National Parks pass because the entrance fee is only $5.00. The drive through Capital and Grand Gorges is a must see!

We didn't know what to expect at this park and we were very pleasantly surprised with all that we found. It's beautiful with amazing landscape you expect to see in Utah with lots of hiking options. Beyond that, there's lots more amazing landscapes and things to see around there, in that part of Utah, that are within a semi-short drive away....like Goblin Valley and Robbers Roost. The biggest surprise was that the visitor center and part of the park is set in the Fruita Historic District. There are historic buildings and fruit orchards to pick your own apples, pears and peaches (we didn't see peaches but I think they have those). The fruit is delicious! Whatever you eat in the orchard is free and any you take out is only $1.25 per pound. There's a beautiful park that's perfect for hanging out or for a picnic. The Gifford House is a tiny historic house that's now a museum and store. They sell lots of yummy, locally made jams, jellies and more. And, they sell fresh baked pies and Scottish scones. Go early as they can sell out! They're delicious! You'll see deer roaming through the park all the time and even some wild turkeys. The campground is first come/first serve, only $10 per night and very nice. The visitor center is small but nice. We attended one of the nighttime sky talks conducted by a visiting astronomer with a telescope. It was fascinating and we learned so much! We loved visiting this park and plan to go back. Peaceful, beautiful, amazing! A side note....if you're staying a while....bring all the food you'll need as grocery options are very slim in the town of Torrey. Restaurant choices are slim too...and expensive! You will, however, have no problem finding gas. Torrey is a VERY small town.
Rates up there with more well known parks. Has lots of history and is easy to explore. Don't pass this one by.
Amazing place, we took the scenic road, and it was well worth the $5. (Side note, We left Bryce Canyon an took Hwy 12 to Capital reef, a must for anyone who has the time.)

If you are a drive through person who thinks that you can see it all from the road then you will definitely be disappointed in this park. Its best beauty is seen only off the road, hiking or walking, or at sunrises and sunsets. This is a place that you need to take time to savor and look. Keep bad reviews coming please as it will make this Nat'l park less crowded for the rest of us. The campground is a rare jewel in desert country admidst green grass and trees and orchards. In fall the deer with huge racks in the orchards are amazing to see. It takes a National park Pass.

We spent an afternoon and evening and the next day visiting this park and felt it was enough time. Rt. 12 goes right through the northern section of this park; there really is no “entrance.” or “exit.” Arriving at 3PM, we spent time at the Visitors’ Center (be sure to see the film “Watermark”) , headed back to Torrey for a bite of dinner, then headed back to Panorama Point (right off Rt. 12) to watch sundown. The skies were threatening, with rain afar, and we got some awesome pictures of rainbows. The next day we visited Frutia, a restored Mormon settlement, very near Rt. 12. Get there early to have a selection of the homemade pie. You can pick apples, on the honor-system for payment, in the orchards that are still maintained there. There is also a hike that starts there, following the Fremont River. Frutia gives you a feeling of peace; it’s very peaceful there. A short distance east of Frutia on Rt. 12 we visited the petroglyphs and the School House. We got lucky and joined a Ranger-led group and saw petroglyphs we otherwise may have missed. The Scenic Drive is a 16-mile round trip drive that goes south from Frutia and it is breathtakingly beautiful! The second night we returned to Panorama Point (we were the only ones left at nightfall, a bit spooky) to view the stars. Capitol Reef has some of the best naturally dark night sky viewing of the western national parks. It was a clear night and the stars and the Milky Way in the dark night sky were amazing! You could also just use some of the turnoffs off Rt. 12 for this night sky viewing.

Having not ever heard of Capitol Reef NP before our recent trip, I have to agree with the many fans who have reviewed it. We had incredibly good luck in that we arrived on the first sunny, rain-free day they'd had in a long time. Besides the amazing rock formations and long, beautiful vistas, there is the opportunity to pick fruit at Fruita (apples and pears in mid--September), free to eat there or $1/lb to take with you. We also hiked along the river and then as far up the side of a cliff as we felt comfortable. The day was warm, but as we gained elevation, there was a strong, cool breeze. There were a few other people hiking, and a fair amount of traffic along the scenic route, but it never seemed crowded, and you could tell from the way the other travelers were soaking in the beauty that they were as charmed by this park as we were. We also stopped to see the petroglyphs, and drove far enough along the drive past Capitol Dome to see a tiny historic cabin. If you want a great overlook for an amazing view of this area, there are some not to be missed along Utah Highway 12. We arrived in the area via this road after dark, but backtracked to see the overlooks after exploring Capitol Reef. Definitely worth the twenty-minute back track, which was much faster when not dodging cows on the road in the dark! Reading some of the other reviews, there were enough things we missed that I would definitely return to this park again, and hope for another stroke of luck weather wise!

While the key attraction at Capitol Reef and the reason this area was set aside as a national park is the beautiful geology, this park also offers many other reasons to visit including Fremont Indian petroglyphs, pioneer history, preserved remains of a Mormon frontier town with pick-your-own orchards, Wild-West history, such as a Butch Cassidy hideout, and backcountry adventures. Much of this is accessible along Rt 24 at no cost but even the scenic drive and access to some of the better hikes is only $5. Capitol Reef is named for geology; Capitol for the sandstone domes that look like a capitol dome and Reef for the fold in the Earth known as a monocline, named the Waterpocket Fold, which was a barrier to travel like a reef at sea. The Waterpocket Fold got its name for the pockets eroded in the monocline fold that hold water year round. Highlights of the visit for us were the scenic drive and the Notom-Bullfrog road which provided different perspectives of the Waterpocket Fold; our two favorite hikes, the Cassidy Arch trail and Capitol Gorge trail; the remains of Fruita with the flowering orchards during our spring visit and the Gifford Homestead with the wonderful homemade fruit pies; and, for the kids, the Junior Geology badge. If one has a high clearance 4x4 vehicle, one can visit the backcountry Cathedral Valley section with its famous monoliths and true solitude. This often overlooked national park is very worthwhile for visits of half a day to several days depending upon one’s time and interests.

Don't let the $5 entrance fee fool you, THIS IS NO "LESSER" PARK. I would say this one of big 4 (along with Bryce, Zion and Arches). It doesn't get promoted as much, but it is really spectacular and has some really amazing hikes. It's rainbow of colorful rocks. Visitor's center is fabulous. Some hikes were closed due to rock fall, but no problem as there are lots of options. Even just driving around is amazing.

Some parks charge $10 for the audio tour on CD. At Capitol Reef it's a value at $4. It's like having your own tour guide as you go through the park. Don't miss the left turn off Scenic Drive into Grand Wash; our favorite part of the park with the narrows, Pioneer Register, possibility of seeing big horn sheep, and seeing one of Butch Cassidy's alleged hiding areas.

Capitol Reef is part of a 100 mile area that was created some 65 million years ago when dinosaurs roamed the landscape. The "Waterpocket Fold" defines the landscape with it's bulging uplifts, rainbow-hued sandstone reefs and canyons. Entrance to the park is free. There is a visitor's center which is open 8-4:30 and has geology, natural science abd cultural displays. A short orientation video is also given. As with all National Parks, Rangers will assist you in planning an itinerary for the duration of your stay. The highlights of Capitol Reef are the Fremont petroglyphs, the Mormon Homestead, the school house, blacksmith shop, Ripple Rock Nature Center. the Fruita (orchard) and the 16 mile Scenic Drive and backcountry. There are two dirt roads off the Scenic Drive which take you to Cathedral Valley where you walk between vertical cliffs. The Scenic Drive ends in a loop where you turn-around and head back to the visitor's center. The Scenic Drive costs $15 dollars but is free with a Senior Lifetime Pass or other National Park Pass. The Fruita grows apple, peach, cherry, pear, and apricots. Pies and other baked goods are available during the harvest season. Eat what you like for free. If you want to pick and take home there is a minimal fee. They have historic and heirloom varieties. Off of Scenic Highway 24 westbound and about a 1/2 mile from the visitor's center you will find the old school house and Fremont (700 AD-1250 AD) petroglyphs. Capitol Reef and the Hickman Bridge are just down the road on Highway 24. I wish I was there for the fruit harvest. I would have given the park a 5 star rating.

We spent 5 days at Capitol Reef. We camped in the Fruita campground. We loved the family-freindliness of this campground. It is grass--which is nice for the kids to play on. The campground is paved-perfect for bikes. There is a trail that goes along the campground that the kids can ride their bikes on (and dogs are allowed on--a rarity in National Parks). The Gifford house is fun for $1 ice cream and pies. The orchard is fun to play in.

I have to admit that we had never heard of Capitol Reef until we decided to spend a month exploring SW Utah. Although all of the Utah national parks relate to the geology of the Colorado Plateau, each one has been preserved because it is different. Capitol Reef is newer (1971) than its national park siblings in the state and, by comparison, suffers from the fact that it is huge and doesn't have as many well marked vistas that you can drive to and take a picture at. Not that it doesn't have absolutely stunning views, but they aren't the great amphitheaters of Bryce or the temples of Zion. The majesty of Capitol Reef is the fact that it is literally a hundred miles long! Some tour guides mention that it is better appreciated from the air than at ground level. Although many people probably just stop at the visitor center and then continue across the park on Route 24, you won't appreciate the geology nearly as much unless you drive on at least a portion of the scenic drive. It's only from the drive that you can truly see the extent of the cliffs that are the primary feature of the park. If time is limited you don't have to drive the entire distance; it's only a $5 fee so it's not a big expense even for a shorter drive. When you do drive across on Rt24 be sure to stop at the petroglyphs; they are the easiest to get to ones we've found anywhere in the SW.

We added this national park into our tour from Canyonlands and Arches and were pleasantly delightfully surprised by the views, vistas and visit to the Mormon homestead, Giffords. At the Giffords House you can see old kitchen and bedroom set up and buy terrific home made ice cream for $1. I had a chocolate cup sitting on the hand made bench outside watching the ponies and other picnickers and it was just lovely. We also drove to the end of the paved road and took way too many photos of every mountain, point, butte, point etc., as if we hadn't see enough all ready. But the views are quite different and the feeling is more intimate in this park. Make sure you bring water and stop at the Visitor Info ctr for bathrooming and maps. The rangers there answer any questions you have about the formations and why they are colored the way they are. We also watched the movie which was helpful.
Capitol Reef is by far one of the best parks in Utah. Very reasonable lodging. Camping as well in designated camp areas. I recommend paying for a cabin, prices run about $35 - $85 per night.

Our plan was to walk along the Fremont River trail. It was rather overgrown and buggy, but kids had fun petting the horses in the field and looking in the pioneer farmhouse. We stopped to pick apricots in the orchard - as many as you can eat for free and $1 per pound if you take them away. To the kids delight, the horses stuck their head over the fence and were loving to be fed the rotten apricots. I think we had more fun doing that than eating them ourselves!!

Entry fee of $6 per person, no charge with NPS Senior Pass. We took a self-guided driving tour of this national monument. This is a small version of Bryce Canyon and there are no crowds to deal with. The overlooks Chessman Bridge, Sunset View & Point Supreme should not be missed.
The trails offer different elevations, so the flora changes as your elevation changes. There are very photogenic rock formations as well as amazing trees. Your National Park Pass works here.

Drove up the mountain from Cedar City and stopped here after it was recommended to us. We are glad to come to it. Rangers are on duty, one gives a very informative talk, there are trails, and it is a beautiful sight to see. Cost is minimal compared to other NPS locations. It is worth it. easy parking. Beautiful location and you will enjoy the mountain meadow you drive through. Road down the mountain west toward Bryce Canyon is well kept. Easy and beautiful drive with lots to see.
If you are anywhere near, this is a must see. It is a National Monument, so is free to holders of the Park Pass. There are great trails and a nice picnic area.

It was beautiful and fascinating! We did have to get a parking pass which was good for the whole park. Kids under 16 enter at no cost adults were $5. We just stayed right there by the visitors center and hiked around. The sites from there were awesome though! Worth the stop for sure for the view! Keep a hold of the little ones though there are some places the trails get close to the very steep drop offs!! I even got nervous and my kids are 10 and 12. Just a mom thing! It is fenced behind the gift shop but the other trail was not. They also had a few ranger activities for younger kids and talked about the volcanic history of the area.

This is not a terribly large park, but the views are great. We unfortunately didn't have the time to hike some of the trails but would have love to have spent more time there. It's well worth the $5 per person entry fee.

This beautiful National Monument really resembles Bryce Canyon National Park in color and rock formations. It has colorful hoodoos sitting in an equally colorful amphitheater. It is, however, much smaller and located even higher up in elevation. We went there in June and there was still snow in some shaded areas. The place wasn't overly crowded either so that was a bonus. Definitely stop by the visitor's center and pay your fees ($5 per person) at the entrance kiosk, and you could listen to the rangers explain the history of this place. There were a few hiking trails in the park. The Rampart Trail from the visitor's center to Spectra Point had spectacular view of the amphitheater. We saw marmots near the visitor's center. Take into consideration of the elevation when hiking. Most of Cedar Breaks is above 10,000 ft in elevation and may cause altitude sickness.

We were staying in Kanab and decided to add this to our National Park tour. Our kids are 7 and 11 and had done The Narrows and Bryce earlier in the week. It was a beautiful drive up. We visited the Visitor Center and got our NP Passport stamped. The temp dropped from 100 in Kanab to 65 in Cedar Break. We ate a picnic lunch and the headed out on the 2 mile hike right next to the Visitor Center.

This is worth a little side trip if you are on your way to Bryce from Cedar City- however, make sure you pay at the ranger station- only $5 and it is worth every penny. We went on a Saturday in July and had the entire view to ourselves-- wonderful moment!

This is a beautiful vista that is easily accessable. It's a bit cold as it's at 10,000 feet, but worth the drive. Most of it can be seen right off the road. There is a fee to go to the main overlook, but it's only $5 per person and a short walk.

We stopped by Cedar Breaks to see what it was all about. We decided not to pay the $5 admission and went down a little further and there are several overlooks that are absolutely gorgeous. It was over 10,000 feet, wind was blowing and it was cold but worth it. There are some great picture taking opportunities.

Passing thru from Los Angeles to Moab. We stopped in Cedar City to spend the night and have dinner. Drove up the Cedar Breaks for sunset. Views were wonderful. The drive was easy and parking was ample. Paths were short and easy to walk to viewing vistas.
Fantastic views and good hiking trails. Cheaper than the National Parks in the area but an equally good experience.

Same scenery as the surrounding country in the area. The difference is the Federal Government marked off 6 miles of the 50 we travelled and charges $5.00 per adult to go through it. A place to pitch a tent is $18.00. Give it back to the forest service or the State of Utah and quit gouging citizens. Sure, it is pretty but so is the 10 miles before Cedar Breaks and the 10 miles after which is free and just as well maintained. The cost of running it as a national monument is heavier than a national forest but requires more manpower and tax dollars for the same scenery maintained all around it by the forest service. Love the southern Utah scenery but feel National Monument status is a waste of taxpayer money.

MINI GRAND CANYON!! Don't miss it, really gorgeous. Also up in the mountains and always 15020 degrees cooler than Cedar City. We visit and re-visit EVERY year. One of nature's magnificent spots. If you have Natl Parks Pass, you can enter for free!

Cedar Breaks is very high, at around 10,000 ft. In addition to the cooler temps. you will get spectacular views!! You can also see Bristlecone Pines, the longest living tree on earth. There is an entrance fee, but if you are in southern Utah, it's worth getting the Interagency Parks Pass with all the other amazing national parks nearby. If you are 62 and a US citizen, get the Senior Pass for only $10.

We figured to stop by Cedar Breaks National Monument before heading to Bryce Canyon. We drove from St George, about 90 miles North to Cedar Breaks. We got there early, around 9:30am, paid $4 per person at the entrance. If you have the National Parks Pass, you can get in for free. There were about 5 overlooks that you can drive your car to. Higher elevation so it was a bit cooler (high 50's-low 60's). It was great coz no one was there so photo ops was perfect. Stopping at the five overlooks gives you different perspective of the views. It was spectacular & we were glad to have stopped. I think there was a hiking trail right at the entrance.

This was my second visit and it's worth a return visit. The entry fee is $4 but I bought the yearly pass from the park services. The weather here was much cooler than Zion with temperatures in the 60's in the morning. I took the trail along the canyon overlook and enjoyed expansive views of this beautiful canyon. Wildflowers were in bloom and I took my time navigating the trail. I spent about two hours here on my way to Moab. The Cedar Breaks canyon is very similar to Bryce Canyon and not as overrun either. I went into Brian Head for Lunch.

If you are in the Panguitch or Beaver areas or driving along I-15 this park is worth a visit. The drive up Hwy 143 is amazing. While there are not as many overlooks as in some places there is enough to satisfy one's appetite. There are a number of 2 mile and 1 mile self guided trails free of charge. Park access if you head all the way up is only $4 per person 16+. The highest point is at the Chessmen Overlook, 10,460 ft. Definitely add it to your list. The only distractor is that restrooms are not as plentiful as you will find elsewhere and there is no place to pick up water so be prepared.

We were staying in Brian Head so it was just down the road, but I would have drove further to see it. It is beautiful, its not very big as some parks but its beauty makes up for it. There are several stops along the way so you can get pictures from all angles. We stopped in the gift shop so I could get my Passport book stamped and the people working in the store were very nice and very knowledgeable about the area and told us about the other parks in the area. And don't forget to drive to the top of Brian Head elevation 11,307 feet the view is awesome.

Cedar Breaks has some incredibly beautiful views but not much else. In terms of restaurants, hiking trails, etc; they are rather sparse however, the gorgeous vistas make up for it. Park Fees are $4 for 7 days or you may use your America the Beautiful Pass. It's a great place to visit from nearby tourist locations like Brian Head but, in my opinion, one day touring the vistas by car is adequate.

It is one of the smaller monuments. Really only a small building and a place to pay to get in. I think it was $4 each to go in. They had some Native Americans dancing - that was fun, and the view was terrific. It is high up in the mountains. It was August but it hailed while we were there and it was a little chilly. You may need a jacket.

Beautiful scenery, less crowded than Bryce (and cheaper, if you don't happen to hit a public lands day). Aspen were yellow on the rim with spires of red rock at the "breaks." Not a lot of hiking trails in the immediate park. $4 fee for a week more than reasonable.

Stayed with friends at Brian Head and used this as a base to explore Zion, Bryce Canyon and the area. Little did we realize that just up the hill from us, only a few miles away, was Cedar Breaks National Monument. Passing through it each day caused us to allocate some time to visit it the day after we returned from Bryce.

Stayed in Panguitch Lake and stopped at Cedar Breaks on the advice of a friend- well worth it- the wildflowers were spectacular- from Aspen bluebells to white columbine. Saw no flowers in or near Bryce or Zion. The park rangers have a telescope set up so you can see the arch you might otherwise miss in the overwhelming beauty of the canyon. Unlike Bryce and Zion, which were crowded, even on the 4th of July there were always parking spots available at the overlooks at Cedar Breaks. If pressed for time, you can see a lot in an hour. At 10,000 feet, the cool air was a refeshing change from the heat of the other parks. Coming from the East Coast, the drive down to Cedar Creek was a bit of a white knuckle ride- would not attempt it in off weather but the views were literally breathtaking. If you're going to do several parks, buy the annual National Park Service pass for $80, which also gets you into national monuments like Cedar Breaks.

If you are anywhere near Brian Head or Cedar City, this is a MUST see. It is only 6 miles from Brian Head. We went in Mid-July. At 10,000 feet, the weather was wonderful and cool. There are only four viewpoints at this destination, but they are spectacular!! It cost $4/person entry fee. There are bathrooms and water bottle refill stations at the Visitor's Center. There are a few hiking trails and a campground. The viewpoints are only a few short steps from where you park your car, so most people should be able to enjoy this destination without worrying too much about disabilities. It's called a National Monument because it was designated by a president of the United States. There is no real "monument" per se, just an AMAZING, breathtaking canyon that you drive along and stop at 4 different viewpoints of the same canyon.
Long winding, scenic drive into this park. $4 entry fee. Lots of scenic stops along the way- high elevation, a bit cooler up here. Very pleasant 2 hour photo detour on my way from Bryce to Zion.

My husband and I wanted to escape the 100 degrees of Vegas so we traveled 3 1/2 hours North to Cedar Breaks just East of Cedar City by 20 miles. We found an offer on-line for Cedar Breaks Lodge and Spa for under $100 a night. It included a small kitchen with microwave and refrigerator so you can fix a meal. We hiked in the Park the first afternoon and the next morning before heading South. We also went out after 10pm to see the stars, which were very bright at an elevation of 10,000 ft. The colors were bright yellow with some reds and lots of evergreens. Rock formations were also amazing . It was a perfect get away.
1. Much smaller than Bryce but worthwhile; admission only $4 compared to $25 at bryce

It had been a lot of years since I had been through Cedar Breaks, so we drove through on our way out of town. It is as beautiful as I remember! Not crowded at all at any of the 4 stops or overlook areas. Charge was $5.00 per person if you want to stop and look, if you just want to drive through they said you could do that without paying. We enjoyed the drive and stopping at the overlooks. You'll get a MUCH better view if you stop, it's worth it.

Last time I visited Cedar Breaks was nearly 4 decades ago! Following a camping experience we decided to drive there for a visit. The park was beautiful and the vistas unearthly. We paid the entrance fee and later upgraded to an annual National Parks pass. I strongly encourage visitors coming to Utah to visit our National Parks, purchase the annual pass. You will not regret it. The best $80 you will spend. The hike to the campground is misleading since it doesn't actually take you to the camping area. That entrance is several yards/meters down the road. Be sure to bring a jacket regardless of time of year. The park overlooks sit at over 10,000 ft and it is chilly since the wind blows up from the red hoodoos below. Dogs are allowed on paved trails and must be on a short leash, 6' longest. Mid-July the wild flowers were exploding with yellows, reds, purples, and orange blossoms. Get here, don't wait four decades!

A very good tribute to a civil rights icon. We happened on this as we were traveling toward Barstow, CA. Admission is free. Friendly staff. Lots of photos of the farm worker struggles as well as Cesar Chavez's early life and family. Well designed and laid out. Good, small gift store, but a little pricey. Visitors can also visit his gravesite and well as his recently added wife's gravesite. She died in June 2016. The grounds are beautifully designed and one can smell the "sweet" aroma of flowers in the landscaping. A great pause on a long road trip.

If you love archaeology, history, the American Southwest, and learning about indigenous peoples, this park has beautifully preserved ancient ruins that are accessible to those who are physically able to walk about a half-mile or more with slight elevation. I am 62, very overweight, have a recently sprained ankle, and a knee with osteoarthritis. However, I was able, with plenty of water and my walking stick, to hike up and around most of the sites in the park. My husband is very fit, so after I got tired, I had him hike in alone to one of the sites while I chilled in the car. I recommend going in cool weather. Pay attention to the road conditions, and plan enough time for travel in and out of the park. If it has been raining or snowing, I would call the park HQ for information about road conditions. Here was our experience driving into the location in a Honda Pilot SUV, about two days after rain: about 12 minutes of paved road; followed by 18 minutes of rough, corrugated surface; followed by 24 minutes of terrible road with many ruts and potholes, and a few places where we had to get on the other side of the road because our side was washed out. Reverse that for the way out. One of the rangers told me that he drives the road in a Honda Fit! (He doesn't leave that often, but still...) For a sixty-something couple who both love Ancient Puebloan ruins (also see Mesa Verde and Canyon de Chelly if you have similar interests), this was a worthwhile side trip, and I wish we'd had a day or more to devote to this site. It might be hard for a young family to handle the jarring time in and out, and the lack of colorful things for the kids to see. Also, I know my preschool grandsons would be eager to climb on the ruins, which is the only attraction here, but which is not allowed in order to preserve the ruins.

We visited for two nights camping. Very much enjoyed several hikes. One was 7.5 miles to see some remote ruins. We had the trail to ourselves. It was extremely hot.reccommend coming spring or fall. They have an astronomy program some evenings 9-11 pm. The night sky is amazing! They have little booklets for each ruin site for 75cents. Very helpful to learn what you are seeing. Best tent site is #30. Has privacy and some shade. Because it take so long to drive in from anywhere, it's worth it to stay overnight. Then you can see the night sky. Nice visitor air conditioned center with a nice film and books. They are some snacks in the shop, soda machine, and ice for $5. Nothing at the campground. BUt bathrooms and sink to wash dishes. Great petroglyphs on the petroglyphs trail.

It is really a misnomer to call these sites by the name of "ruins". They are very much alive for the descendants of these ancient pueblo people. They come to visit their ancestor's spirits regularly to keep them alive. The largest pueblo structures are found at this site. Also the most numerous. There are guided tours, but you can also do a drive through or a walk through on your own with a handbook available from the Ranger's Station. This attraction was free today as part of National Park Week. Also consider buying a lifetime pass to the National Park System for $10.One of the most fascinating things to us was the highway system which the Chacoans engineered between various pueblos in the area. After you visit this site, you will be anxious to see the many other sites of the ancients in the area, especially Mesa Verde,

Chaco Canyon is home to several Puebloan Indian settlement sites dating from 850 A.D. to around 1200 A.D. It is not only part of the National Park Service, but is also registered by the United Nations as a World Heritage site. A nine mile loop paved road allows visitors easy walking access to each settlement. The site is located in northwestern New Mexico about 2.5 hours north of Albuquerque. Be aware this location is out in the middle of nowhere so plan accordingly. There is a small visitor center, but no place close by to purchase food or water. The entrance fee is $16.00 per vehicle. Hiking trails are everywhere and the pristine canyon itself, with all the original settlements scattered about, is truly breathtaking and is awe inspiring. All of the settlements are archaeological treasures and most are still being uncovered. The night sky in this part of the state is crystal clear and is a bonus for astronomy buffs and other star gazers. Be aware the last 12 miles into the park is over rutted gravel covered dirt roads, and the last 3 miles or so are extremely rough and rutty consisting of dirt with an average safe speed of 15 mph or less. Not for the faint of heart or anyone driving low profiled vehicles. Worth a visit for those who enjoy Indian history and exploring archaeological sites. Truly a very spiritual experience.

As stated, we never got to the Park. The road in was horrible - it starts out paved, but without warning it goes to gravel, then to less than that and graded terrible. We were in a 4-wheel drive vehicle and about got shook to death! I called and spoke to the Visitor Center to make sure we were on the right road and they are aware of the road issues, but are not the ones to make repairs. (And DO NOT attempt this after a rain - I can practically guarantee the road will be impassible.) And don't rely on road signs - there are maybe three that we counted, two of which were almost impossible to see. After over a half an hour of that, we get to the entrance where it says that - after getting our vehicle pounded - it will cost us $8 each. No thank you. As we turned around we saw other vehicles (sedans, not 4-wheel vehicles) turning around and giving up as well. We talked to the rangers over at the El Malpais Monument Visitor Center, and they said we were on the GOOD road in. Too bad - again, another national park that was disappointing on this trip.

This place has been on my bucket list for almost ten years, and it did not remotely disappoint. I was there on Saturday/Sunday of Easter weekend 2015, toured all ruins on the main road and hiked to two on the mesa above. Hardly saw any other people, especially on the hikes. The campground is small and quiet and mornings and evenings in the park seem practically deserted. I drove the (dry) road in my very low-clearance Honda Fit, and had no problems (took it very, very slow in the last five miles before the park). I got to the visitor center just before it closed and picked up self-touring guides for all of the ruins I wanted to see - well worth it at about $5 for the whole set. Self-toured Pueblo Bonita and Chetro Ketl late that afternoon and had the sites practically to myself, as it really clears out late in the day. Similarly, on a five-mile hike around on the mesa top the next morning, I saw no one at all. If you like solitude, this park has got it! Campground was also quiet and very dark. Just a lovely weekend.

We spent a night recently at Chaco canyon in the Gallo campground in the park. This used to be entirely first come/first serve but now is mostly by advance reservation thru the park Website. ($15 for a campsite for up to 6 persons). There are grills for fires...bring your own wood...but really?

Not much to do, and the road getting here is brutal on your vehicle. Few ruins that are in stages of dilapidation, kinda cool but there are others in the southwest that are easier to get to. Welcome center isn't much, but is the only modern thing they have in this park. Decent clean bathrooms, but that's about it for the amenities. Cost is $8 per car, bring cash!

As a native New Mexican, we are very proud of our National Parks. The Chaco Canyon is no exception. What a fantastic history.I had not been here since I was six or seven and worried about the roads, after reading the posts here. The road isn't that bad. What was bad was the fact that we stayed on road 7900 for 20 miles in the wrong direction. There is not a HUGE sign marking the park. I attached photographs to show you the stop sign where road 7900 connects to 7950. This is the turn off! Do NOT cross over the cattle guard. Turn right onto 7950 and you will see a large sign for the campground. Continue on for endless miles...lol...(you will hear plenty of "are we there yet!". Finally you will see the visitors center (now closed due to the government shutdown) but it has great bathroom facilities. Visit the small musuem there. Then drive onto the sites. This is a trip well worth it. They have wonderful visitor phamplets so bring about $4 in quarters if you would like to purchase them (about .50c each or .75). If you want to, return them for no charge. Bring a picnic lunch, walking shoes, blanket to sit on and water). There are decent bathroom facilities at the sites and a picnic table. Bring your camera! Do NOT stay at the close cities unless you can make a reservation at any of the bed and breakfasts. Do stay longer than one day if possible. The campground looks bare but has minimal facilities. If you want to stay in a nice motel/hotel go to Bloomfield, Farmington, Los Alamos or Santa Fe or Jemez Mountains. Bloomfield is by the Cumbres Railyard (steam train). Worth the money and the time. Enjoy your trip!

First off--very rough road--I clocked the unpaved portion at 12 miles. We got a few miles down it and hit a super rough portion and decided to turn around even though we were driving a rental. I told my wife that had it been my own car I would turn back--so we did. We got about a half mile back towards the highway when a local guy came cruising by in his pickup. I asked him about the road and he said it was another 10 miles to reach the park and the paved road- but that he sees people in rentals driving in all the time--we were in a Nissan Sentra. So upon hearing that we said let's just go for it-so we turned around again and found some grooves in the road and arrived. We had stopped in Aztec earlier in the day so by the time we arrived it was 4:45--a bit late no doubt. With dark clouds rapidly approaching and knowing of the low lying flood plains in several spots along the road we did a quick tour of the main ruins. It was spectacular and well worth the drive. Wish we had arrived earlier or could have stayed longer but those dark clouds had us a bit nervous--for good reason as it turned out. As we were driving the rain arrived at first a few sprinkles but steadily it increased until we were in a pretty good downpour--not quite a monsoon though. The road became super slick and now the reason for the washboarding of the road became our best friend as it provided traction in the ever increasing slipperiness of the road. There is a very fine clay-like soil covering the road and in the rain it becomes a slip-like substance making for nerve wracking driving. There were a couple of spots where traction became an issue but from having driven in snow many times I knew the main thing was to keep moving--if you stop you get stuck. There was one small hill we almost didn't make and I think had we been 10 minutes later we would have gotten stuck. I figured someone would come by sooner or later and for a few dollars would give a tow but who want to so through that? Anyways the bottom line is definitely go; leave early in the day to give yourself plenty of time to explore and then leave about 4 to avoid the late afternoon summer storm. Conversely you can camp at Chaco overnight which we considered. Depending on the direction you're heading--we were headed to Arizonz--you can take a "shortcut" dirt road to get you closer to US 40 but in our situation we deemed that unadvisable since we'd already done the 12 mile dirt road and barely made it. If you do end up going out the way you came as we did--book a room in Farmington not Gallup as we did--it was another 3 or 4 hours after getting back on the 550. A little adventure for us late 50's folks. Thanks for reading. Enjoy your travels.

Chaco Canyon has been on my bucket list for a very long time. We finally made the day trip out there from Albuquerque - about 3 hours one way. Best to go I-25 north to US 550 northwest, and then south on CR 7900 (just like they suggest). BUT . . . that dirt road at the end was brutal. I called in advance just to check if my Toyota Sienna minivan could make the trip. The woman who answered at the Visitor's Center told me she makes the trip in her Nissan Sentra. So we gave it a go. I would NOT do that again in our vehicle. I would make sure you go in a 4x4 or in something with superior suspension/shocks. The grading on the dirt road (the final 13 miles before entering the park) is so awful that it nearly rattled the teeth out of my skull. At times I could only go 5MPH because of the continuous, tiny bumps. I'm not exaggerating. The bumpiness was so bad that it rattled the DVD right off the ceiling of our car! So . . . getting past that, Chaco Culture Park is simply amazing. If you're into history, architecture, ancient culture, etc. then you MUST see Chaco Culture. $8 park entrance fee for one vehicle, good for a week. We brought our 3 very young kids and they had a blast. It's mostly safe for them to run around, especially within the maze-like complex itself. But keep an eye on the little ones because there are some spots where they could have a serious fall if they take the wrong step. I guess that advice is true for adults, too. I didn't realize it until after, but this could make for a fun overnight camping trip, too. Check with the visitor center for availability and price, but there are several camping spots available. You park inside the park and pitch your tent right there. There are toilets and running water, but nothing else. So be prepared to pack in your own food. To sum it up, Chaco Culture National Historic Park is amazing and we are so glad we finally made it.

While my husband and I were vacationing around Grants, NM, we stopped at the Northwest New Mexico Visitor Center. We ask a ranger about the south route/road conditions into Chaco Canyon. He said the road (57/14) had just been graded so it should be in good condition. Not so. The dirt road was very wash board and had thick sand in many places. The 19 miles of dirt road took about 90 minutes in my 4x4 truck. Once there, the park was awesome. We saw six of the main ruins in 6 hours and they were all close (1/2 mile or less) from the parking lots. The six main ruins are Una Vida (ruins and petroglyphs), Hungo Pavi (ruins), Cheltro Keti (has the largest Kiva I have ever seen, ruins and petroglyphs), Pueblo Bonito (very large ruins), Pueblo del Arroyo (ruins) and Casa Rinconada (ruins). My husband and I have toured many Indian ruins across a few states and I have to say these are the best. The weather was perfect (about 75 degrees) the last weekend in May.Cost $8 per vehicle.

This is a national park that has some of the best historical sites and ruins in the USA. We did it in a day trip out of Albuquerque, so we left at 6 a.m. and were there before 10 a.m. It is a beautiful drive, and if you get going early, you can easily spend 6 hours at the park exploring the sites and be back in Albuquerque by sunset. It was a wonderful day of sight seeing, and the ruins are truly stunning. There are examples of different brick patterns, and the circular buildings are amazing. There are picnic tables nearby, where you can enjoy a lunch (bring your own food and beverages), and there are bathroom facilities. The interior park is paved, but there is a 10 to 15 mile stretch of unpaved road you have to drive, so an SUV, or higher off the ground vehicle, is the preferred means of transport. You can maneuver it in a car, but you will have to drive very slow to dodge all the ruts.....and you can't dodge them completely. It does feel like you are driving on a washboard. But do not let that stop you from going, as that part of the trip is very short compared to the payoff when you see the sites. There are many trails, and if you stay longer, you can hike to the top and get a cliff view of the ruins. We saw lots of lizards and birds. It is very remote, so do not plan on cell phone reception. I also recommend taking pleny of sunscreen, as even when it is cool, the sun is closer and burning down. We went in Spring, and I can't image going at the height of the summer as I bet the temperatures get extremely hot. The winds can also be strong, so if you can, it is best to go on a nice day, especially since the unpaved road section can be problematic with rain, etc. Chaco Canyon is totally worth the trek, and it is one of the few places in the USA where you can find important ruins from over 1000 years ago. It cost $8 per car for our visit and was quite the bargain!

We'd been to Chaco Canyon 40 years ago when our children were small and we did the grand tour of the West. It was magic then and even more magical now as we were able to indulge only our own interest. Because it's such a long trip in off the main road, I couldn't imagine not extending our stay by camping in the canyon which we did for two nights. I know lots of people do an in and out in one day but there's so much more to see and learn than that kind of schedule permits. The walking tours from the Visitor Center are a terrific way to get acclimated. Then you can take off on your own, stepping out of time to be with those who came before. The architecture, for me, was the compelling element and a two dollar poster we picked up at the Visitor Center now reminds us of the mystery every time we go up and down our stairs.

I had been wanting to visit Chaco Canyon and Pueblo Bonito ever since I saw them featured in Kevin Costner's Native American documentary series, "500 Nations." In late August I finally got the opportunity when I visited the Four Corners region with my 83-year-old father. I was not disappointed. Pueblo Bonito, as well as two similar sites located nearby, are a fascinating "must-see" for anyone interested in Pre-Columbian Native American culture. Unfortunately, 16 miles of the 21-mile long county road on which one must travel to reach the site is unpaved and very jarring due to the road's washboard effect! Make sure your car is up to it before you head out. Thankfully, the road inside the park is paved and all the major sites, including Pueblo Bonito, are located only a short walk from a parking lot! The Park Service staff, who are presently housed in a temporary yurt-like structure while a permanent visitors center is being built, were very helpful and there were plenty of interesting books and other items for sale. I advise reading up on Ancestral Pueblo culture before arriving however, in order to better understand and get the most out of your visit.

Joined ranger-led tour of Pueblo Bonito at 10 am, followed by hike along petroglyph trail to Chetro Ketl, another great house. Drove to Pueblo del Arroyo and Pueblo Rinconada. All very impressive. Be sure to pck up a copy of the explanatory brochures at the entrance to each house – either buy them for $1 each or read and return them at the conclusion of each visit. Be sure to stop at visitor center for brief orientation by a ranger, and visit again at the end to see the movie.
If you are into the National Park System this is a fabulous stop- you can get a stamp in you NP Passport:). Lots of history, beautiful setting, right next to the Mississippi River.

This is where the actual battle of New Orleans was fought and the little museum is very informative and interactive. If you come, come the 2nd week in January when they have the reenactments. That is amazing! Best part, the museum is free. (However, a fun way to visit the museum is to take the Natchez Riverboat tour from the French Quarter, it's about $15 a person but you can get groupons from time to time.)

We visited this Historical park for two reasons. We wanted to get a stamp in our National Parks Passport book but I just had to visit the place that Johnny Horton's song was all about. I was raised on that song and know all of the words. It is located not far from New Orleans and appears to be a place that not many know about. It was mostly empty the day we visited. It has a very small visitor center and is mostly just open fields that were the battlegrounds. The final battle of the War of 1812 was fought on this property. There is a Creole style house on the property but I don't remember the history of it. It was privately owned. You can drive around the perimeter of the battlefields and there is an audio tour you can do on your cellphone. Next to the battlefields is a National Cemetery where 4 graves are from War of 1812 soldiers, a section for African-Americans, and many from the Civil War. Overall, visiting this Historical Park was laid back and quiet allowing for imagining the battle that truly ended the Revolutionary War and the final defeat of the British.

We took the Creole Queen paddle boat tour to the Chalmette Battlefield. The trip lasted about 2.5 hours. It cost $27 round trip. Be sure to look for a $5 off per person coupon available on line. The narrator on the boat was articulate and gave detailed information about all the points of interest along the river bank. There is no additional fee at the site. The narrator at the battlefield was knowledgeable and dressed in costume. This added to the experience. There is a museum there and a small gift shop. The grounds are beautiful complete with an unfurnished plantation house. My only criticism with this trip is they do not allow enough time to really explore the site. We were only given approx. 45 minutes once we arrived to see the battlefield, house and museum.

This 55 acre site right on the US/Mexico border is free, grounds are open daily 7 AM-10 PM and cultural center was open daily 10 AM-5PM when I was there. Outdoors there are lots of walking paths (accessible and level with places to sit) throughout the entire area with a stage for special events, picnic tables and restrooms, the actual historic boundary and monument, a courtyard with a fountain and gardens, and landscaping showcasing native vegetation of the Chihuahuan Desert. As beautiful and interesting as the grounds were, it was the Cultural Center that was the highlight for me. As you approach the complex you will see the colorful 18' x 120' "Our Heritage" outdoor mural by Carlos Flores (part of a series of murals in El Paso) recognizing the differences and similarities between cultures. Once inside there are a short introductory film and exhibits explaining in detail how the "Chamizal Problem" which started during the presidency of Lincoln and was resolved in 1963 was peacefully settled. It was the exhibit "Costumes of Mexico", a collection of 32 dolls (one from each state in Mexico) and the free Companion Guide (in both English and Spanish) that was of greatest interest to me. The guide explained in detail the history, culture, and interesting information on each state. Until August 31, 2017 there is a special photography exhibit "Photo Walk El Paso" in the Franklin G Smith Gallery next door to the Cultural Center. It is a part of a Global Photo Walk taking place simultaneously around the world and features photos of El Paso and the Chichuahuan Desert.
Easy to find, park rangers were friendly. Its a place to get a stamp if you like the Passport books that the National Park does.

We decided to make a stop at Chamizal partially because my 4 year old son has a National Parks Passport we like to collect stamps for. We stopped by early on a Saturday morning. You'd never know it was there, hidden behind a residential area off the highway you'd usually have no need to go that far on, unless heading into Mexico. After we found our way through the road construction, we drove back to the main parking area and were greeted by a quiet, peaceful place. The grounds are a good size, with nice walking paths. They don't really go anywhere in particular - just a few crisscrossing loops. A few picnic areas are available. You can see across the border and watch traffic next door going across one of the main bridges into Mexico. Inside, there is a nice display of the historical meaning of the memorial. I had no idea the history behind it and found it quite interesting that this conflict over the land lasted for so long. Like many national parks, some of the displays are in dire need of an overhaul. Many of the "interactive" displays were broken. The videos are quite old and getting fuzzy. But the information and knowledge is great. There was one older gentleman working there that was so friendly and excited to see us. (There was only one other couple there, in addition to our group of 5.) He asked where we were from, offered a sticker to my son and even helped us out in the gift shop before we left as well. You can tell he loves his job and is proud of the memorial.

This was the highlight of our day of plantation tours. Better by far vs Magnolia Gardens Plantation where we paid about $70 for 2 seniors. Park Ranger played a video for us about Pinckney and his family and history relating to our Revolution and the drafting of the Constitution. Grounds well kept and lovely.

We paid a visit to this site where Pinckney once had his home. Now there is a restored home built somewhat later on the foundation of the old Pinckney home. Admission is free and the volunteers are very helpful and informative.

This was a nice surprise. House, grounds, historic film, picnic area and parking- FREE. Pinckney was a creator of the US Consitution. This is "your tax dollars ar work".. so go and enjoy- and pack a picnic there is a nice shelter and restrooms. Also a short "nature trail" to take the kids on.

We decided to go here for free instead of across the street for $40. Not a cheapskate, just prefer real historical sites. This small site delivered information we never knew. Glad it was saved for future generations to learn and enjoy.

I'll admit, I may not have stopped it is wasn't part of the National Park system, but I'm so glad I did. This homesite is a piece of our past, and charming! You can spend a little time, or a lot here. Be sure to have your National Passport stamped here!

If your trip includes Anchorage, don't skip a visit to Cugach State Park. You don't even have to leave the highway to enjoy this beautiful park. There are many easy walking trails right off the road. Pay a $5.00 fee at one of the lots and park and hike all day. The trails are not paved and some are steep in places, but the views of Turnagain Arm are spectacular. If you have more time venture into the park proper.

Amazing views overlooking anchorage,great outdoor stairmaster!my family went all the way to the top I went as fas as where the steps end so it's a great hike for almost everyone.Saw moose at the park entrance and found some wild blueberries in a pasture.If you dont have much time in anchorage it's a great quick excursion and it's free (except $5.00 parking fee)

I'm lucky enough to have this National Forest virtually in my backyard. I haven't hiked all it's trails, but have done several of them, over the years. I've done the Resurrection Pass trail in a day twice, although at the age I am and in the condition I am in I wouldn't try it now, and have done it in five days, using cabins reserved ahead of time, with my wife and her eldest sister and her husband. But it's a great place to hike, and I recommend it highly!

We love this area. We hiked several trails in the area and visited a nature reserve and had a great time. We loved the Crow Pass Trail but it can get a bit treacherous at stream crossings and along some of the ridges but worth it. We will be back again.

2nd largest national forest in the nation, so don't expect to see it all. but what we saw was mag-by-god-nificent! Homer was our favorite city, followed by Seward and Anchorage. Best drive was up to Hatcher Pass out of Palmer. More fishing than you can shake a rod at, if you're so inclined.

The hiking trails host the most amazing views. We hiked Pipeline Pass and then went towards Hidden Lake which is tucked away in between two mountain tops. Currently iced over. We did see a bear and Dahl goats off on the distance. Wear you're bear bell and spray. A lot of people bring their dogs to guide them and scare off wild life that may be too close. Bring binoculars and water. These hikes are long and the altitude does wear you out a little if you're not used to it. Wear you best hiking gear and don't forget to smile!

We drove over 2 hours from Phoenix to visit Sedona. It was such an incredibly beautiful place. We wanted to hike Soldier Pass, but the parking lot off of Soldier Pass Rd. was very small and full, so we drove to Jordan Rd. where there was more parking. The restroom facility was not good--smelly and no way to wash or sanitize hands. However, we hit the Jordan Trail with the intention to connect to Soldier Pass. We double-backed a few times on the trail because we were not familiar with the area, and the maps / trail markers were not clear. After all that, we ended up not being able to go on Soldier Pass Trail. That aside, the views were beautiful, and we are glad to have had the opportunity to hike the trails. There is a fee for parking there, but we used the Every Kid in a Park pass which is for families with 4th graders and were able to hike for free.
Passing through Sedona AZ is a remarkable site filled with amazing mountains. Be prepared for the photo shoot of a lifetime. The hikes and shops are fantastic.

If travelling (as a tourist) between Phoenix and Flagstaff, DO NOT miss the opportunity to pass through a portion of the Coconino Nat'l Forest, winding through the Red Rock Scenic Byway and Oak Canyon Byway. The drive is slower than the highway, allowing your eyes to take in the beauty of the red rocks, the monuments (eg, Bell rock), and the painted desert, then passing through densely forested areas. Yes, there are brief periods of higher elevation and curves, but the pace is generally very comfortable, and extremely worthwhile. Take a little extra time to stop for a snack in Sedona or Oak Creek. Parking areas require fees (usually @ $5), but I'm not sure how well that is enforced.

Most of the hikes in Sedona are nice but this brings you to a vortex. Went there with our grandkids and we all enjoyed it. Please respect others with your silence or quiet talking. We had to ask a group to discuss their Las Vegas trip a little quieter. Wonderful area to enjoy the quiet of the Sedona outdoors. There is a vortex there. Get a map from your hotel or the visitor center. You may have to Pay $5 for parking but it's well worth it.

This is a basic and pretty little campground outside of Flagstaff. It was quiet and the bathrooms were very clean and had flush toilets, sinks, but no hand towels or power.
