Crater Lake National Park is THE National Park in Oregon. You can stay and relax at the lodge for an amazing experience if you book well in advance, or you can camp in the park. (We camped.) But don't be afraid to just make it a day trip. It is definitely possible as a day trip from Bend, Grants Pass or the like. Even transiting on I-5, taking a few extra hours out of your route to see the lake is worth it. While the full loop is nice, you can get a lot just by driving the north-south route that borders the lake. Visit the lodge area, and a few turnouts, then be on your way as you need. As well, if you have the time, schedule and take the lake boat tour. It is about 2 hours on a boat, touring around the lake and seeing things you cannot see from the crater wall. The hike to the boat is not easy - 1.1 miles, 700+ feet elevation. Think of climbing the stairs in a 65 story building. But take it slow if you need to. But if you do have the time, there is a lot to be seen on trials and it would be easy to spend several days soaking up the place. Any time the road to the lodge is open, it is worth seeing.
The park fee is very reasonable at $10 a car. Many many stops and parking for picture taking. The weather on July 7 was 72 degrees while the metro areas nearby were 99 degrees or more!

This should be on everyone's "Bucket List!" One of the prettiest places I've ever been. Breathtaking views. Take a picnic and stop at one of the viewing areas to soak in the scenery. If you have time and want to spend the extra $40, take the boat tour around the lake. We did not have time this trip but I'd love to do that if we go again. The east side was not open all the way, but you can still see all of the lake from the viewing areas along the west. Don't miss this one!

Crater Lake is not just a "lake.". It is impossible to describe to anyone who has never been. Just GO, but save your trip to late August or early September, the perfect time is just after Labor Day when kids are back in school if you want less crowds (it will still be crowded.). Most people don't stay here long because it seems there is nothing to "do", meaning this is not a lake resort, it is a visual and sensory spectacular event, a place to return to yourself, if you give yourself the time to slow down and discover the area. If you want the best, stay in the Crater Lake Lodge, but you'll need to reserve far in advance to get a lake view room (the only kind worth the $$$, it isn't cheap.). Stay on the top floor in one of the claw foot bathtub rooms. A warning- no TV, nothing but the view. They do have wi-fi now, but if you have an iPhone, no service- Verizon usually works. But the idea is to unplug! Take the hike to the top of the ranger station at Hillman Peak. Drive down to the Pinnacles. Drive the rim drive and stop along the way. Take the boat tour only if you are in good physical condition - the hike back up is very challenging. The same with the boat ride and optional hike up to the top of Wizard Island. For your first time, do it all- the ranger talks, etc. Even if you are not staying at the lodge, wander into the fireplace lounge early and grab a seat by the fireplace or on a sofa. After 3pm they serve drinks and food there, and you can curl up and read for hours. Or weather permitting, go out on the veranda and snap up one of the coveted rockers to view the lake and hang out- again, they will serve you there after 3pm. The lodge staff are from many different countries and many of them are friendly and great stories abound. Dinner or lunch at the lodge is also a treat in the dining room, but call in advance to make reservations for dinner as it is very popular. This need intensifies as the summer months go on. Really, the lake is only in tourable mode between mid-July and mid-September. I was just ther in early June and there was 6 feet of snow and at times you couldn't see the lake, it was snowing so much. Ther are a number of places to stay within 30 minutes, just outside of the lake, but choose carefully, as many places capitalize on the lake as a destination and aren't as they claim.

Nowhere in the U.S. (or perhaps the world) one would see water bluer than at Crater Lake. That's because of its altitude and the way its water is kept. In most other lakes, we were told, you usually would see below water surface up to say 100 ft. But, at Crater Lake, you see much, much deeper below surface. The air is also so fresh. Add a sky as backdrop, with some white clouds, hmmmmm. For vacation purposes, there is no place better than some spot in the U.S., esp. the national parks. No place where it's so well-equipped, humanly and naturally, and bargain basement costs (a mere few dollars entrance fee). Come as one, as family, a grand time is guaranteed for all if the outdoors is your cup of tea.

Even in July, there was snow around, adding to the splendor of our nation's deepest lake. It's waters, viewed from the rim of the giant caldera--an island in the middle is actually a stillborn volcano--looks both Alaskan and Caribbean. As part of our cross country drive, it was the next stop (2 days later) after Yellowstone. Crater Lake is also a national park ($10 fee to enter, but we had the Nat'l park pass) that was like dessert compared to its far larger Wyoming neighbor, but it holds up to anything there in terms of its sheer beauty. At one point, jays, chipmunks and ground squirrels approached us as we looked out across the lake, and you couldn't help but look for a lost peanut on the floor of your minivan.

This was our second visit to Crater Lake. Before we did a quick rim drive and left. This time we stayed at the Whispering Pines Motel, a great value at $55, 25 minutes from the rim. We spent 2 days exploring Crater Lake more thoroughly, and still felt like we missed so much. Take the rim drive slowly, stop at all the pull-offs. Each angle is a different view and brings new surprises, even just 25 yards further along the rim. Get out of the car. Soak in the amazing geological history. We took the time to hike down Cleetwood trail and take the 2 hour boat trip around the lake. The climb is not easy, but we are middle aged and took our time. It is well worth it. The views from the lake level give a whole new view of the geology. The US National Park Service Guide was a fountain of knowledge and taught us fascinating things about the Crater and its history. She pointed out many formations and explained their meaning. Next time we will explore some of the trails to wonders surrounding the caldera. There are many short hikes to amazing places....next time.

This was my third time to see this lake. It is the most beautiful lake I've ever seen, and I don't think I'd ever tire of seeing it. The views are spectacular. If you have time, (and Money) take the boat trip out to Wizard Island. We didn't this time, instead, just enjoyed the shoreline views of the blue blue water. If you are a senior (62 or over) be sure and buy a $10 lifetime pass for the National Parks in the United States. Hold on to it, because they don't keep records of your card...and if lost, you'll have to replace it. It's good for admittance to ANY national park....the daily entrance is usually $10/day, so once you've paid for it, you're in! This includes everyone in your vehicles as well!

This is a beautiful place. We did the boat tour in the lake. It takes about an hour to drive to the place once you get to the park, so allow plenty of time. We were rushed. Once you get there, you need to walk down a hugh hill. Going down isn't a problem. The boat tour is good, but not great. There is a ranger on the boat that tells you all about he lake. You could get the same thing from the tour up top, and it would take 2 hours. The hike up afterwards is very challenging. I think that it is worth doing if you are in shape and not in a rush. I think it was about $29 per person.
We drove through the park and stopped to hike at spots along the way. The most beautiful lake I have ever seen. Definitely worth the $10.00 park fee!

This place is gorgeous and of course one of the 7 wonders of oregon. I came from the bay area to do a trolly tour and Irene was selling the tickets and was the rudest person I encountered. Aside from that the gift shop was great and fee to enter park was $15.

I was visiting someone in Grant's Pass Oregon. Two of us drove to Crater Lake. It was the end of May and still there was snow on the ground the higher we went. (Take along cold weather gear, higher elevation) Stop at the Ranger's station and see the video and look at the exhibits or buy books or cards. When we got to the Lake, was a very clear day. We could only go so far on the road that goes around the lake, because it was still snowed in. If you want to drive all the way around and walk the trails, check for best time of year to go to avoid snow. Great visit for photos. A must see Park.

A friend and I spent one night in Oyster Point Campground. While well off the beaten path, this US Forest Service campground in Croatan Natl Forest was very convenient to our hiking trail. We met the campground hosts, Tonia, Will and Max (puppy). They were nice, helpful and apparently took great care of the area, it was very clean and seemed well maintained. There are only 10 or so sites, all primitive, fairly large, several located on the river with a path from the site to the waters edge. Wooded, dirt road, couple of large clean privies. Each site has a picnic table, fire pit, concrete pad, and hanging hook. The daily rate is $8, max stay is 14 days. We enjoyed our stay and will use the campground again when in the area.

I have the Passport stamp book and visited several National Park Sites..... This one was VERY difficult to find!. The signage and directions lead us down several creepy roads! We were lost on the opposite side of the park and just happened on a road that ended up at the Visitor Center! The Ranger was very helpful once we got to the center! I did get my stamp!!

Between the Wilderness Road Heritage Highway and the East Tennessee Crossing National Scenic Byway, this park has a very nice visitor's center, outstanding overlook and great camping. Camping with electric was $10 with the National Parks Senior Pass. Campsites were nice and nice restrooms with showers. As several have mention, this covers three states.

Cumberland Gap National Park has a nice visitor center, museum and gift shop. There are several hikes from 1 mile to many miles. We took the Tri-state peak trail. It was up hill but not too steep and the path was mostly shaded. The monument of the three states were very interesting but the views were lacking, too over grown and ugly electric lines present. The Pinnacle Overlook was very scenic and easy to get to.It is also ADA accessible. If you want to go to the Hensley Settlement you need to make a reservation ahead of time. The tour leaves at 9;30 and last about 3 hours I was told. You could actually walk to the settlement but expect a nine mile round trip if you do. There are several informational signs throughout the park at the pull outs and along the trails about the history and geology of the area. This is a good place for hiking, history buffs and nature lovers. I actually had a relative who crossed over the gap with Daniel Boone so it was a special visit for me. Everything is free here except the tour and it is $10 per adult.

Visited this park this past weekend. Weather was less than perfect, but there is a wonderful visitor's center with great exhibits, and 2 wonderful films. The rangers were very helpful with maps and suggestions for trails. They still had room for the Gap Cave tour (only 15 people per tour), but we did not have the time to attend. (only $8 per person). Also, they have a tour to Hensley settlement, but it closed for the winter 10/31. There is no entrance fee, but nominal charges for the ranger led tours. The view from the pinnacle overlook is outstanding, and you can drive there. There are also several civil war cannons in this park. Would love to go back and see more of this great park.

Visited Cumberland Gap National Park. I recommend stopping by the Visitor Center and learning about the history of the Gap. Sign up for the Gap Cave tour led by park rangers($8/adult) which last 2-2 1/2 hours. The tour starts with an easy half mile hike to the cave entrance. You spend about 1 1/2- 2 hours inside the cave. There are 183 stairs inside the cave. Got to see a bat pretty close up. There is another hiking trail which leads you to a nice waterfall. Also take a four mile drive up to the Pinnacle overlook and see a panoramic view of Tennessee, Kentucky and Virginia.

The gap cave tour is definitely worth it. While not a large cave - it has lots of interesting formations , pools, large rooms , and history. You make your reservation over at the park's visitor center , then meet at the parking lot over in Cumberland gap, tenn . It is about six tenths of a mile hike to cave. The tour takes a little more than an hour . There is some ducking low in places and several steps to navigate on the tour also. We had a great guide ( Lucas). , and the experience was definitely worth the $ 8 admission fee !

I've been to the park several times and always enjoy driving to the top of Pinnacle Overlook. My recent visit included the tour of the Hensley Settlement. The tour is led by a park ranger in one of their 12-passenger vans. The tour price is $10 per person. Reservations can be made one month in advance and are highly recommended. Take the tour. It was informative, it was fun, and Ranger Matt, was the best tour guide I have ever listened to. We all enjoyed ourselves and came away facinated at everything we had seen and heard. The tour lasts approximately 4 hrs., so plan ahead. You won't be sorry.

The park is a beautiful place, especially when the autumn leaves are colorful. Lots of hiking and neat things to do. The best thing we found was a ranger-guided tour of the Hensley Settlement, located on a mountain top and occupied in the late 1800's through the early 1950's by several Hensley families. The tour location takes about an hour to reach by NPS van, and once there, it's about a two-hour walking tour through the Hensley farm lands, their service buildings, and one of their homes. The scenery is beautiful, and our ranger-guide, Sharon, did an exceptional job of keeping us informed about the Hensley family and how they survived in this remote location. It gives one great appreciation of the hardships some of the early pioneers endured just to survive. The tour costs $10 ($5 with a Golden Eagle pass), but it was well worth the time and effort. Check the web site for Cumberland Gap National Historic Park and make a reservation for this tour, as it fills up quickly and is very limited.

We took a daytrip to Cumberland Gap National Historic Park driving Hwy 58 from Kingsport TN to the park which was gorgeous. There was little traffic and it was an easy drive with beautiful views. The park visitor center is not to be missed - see the film (about 20 minutes) which is free and explains the history especially involving Daniel Boone. There are other exhibits in the visitor center along with a gift shop. Very helpful attendants too. Make sure to do the drive to Pinnacle View - it is only about 4 miles from the visitor center and though there are some hairpin turns, it is not too scary. There is a short walk (about 200 yards) from the view's parking lot - all paved nicely. You are in KY and VA on the walk to the view and then can see stunning vistas of Virginia, Tennessee, and Kentucky. There are lots of hiking trails in the park though we didn't do any besides the Pinnacle. Admission to the park is free. A wonderful short trip for us, going home by way of Hwy 25 and then 11E. We stopped at Morristown for lunch at the Java Garden. A nice day trip.

We took the 4 hour tour to the homestead near the park.It is well worth it and only$10/ person.It is a trip for the whole family so the kids can see the one room school house and sit in the desk and imagine what life was like there on the mountain.

A highlight of our three days in Cleveland visiting my husband's family was a visit to the Cuyahoga Valley National Park. I've been going to Cleveland for close to 40 years and I had never visited until now. The park features a 20-mile towpath trail that follows the Ohio and Erie canals which is great for biking or walking. We had brought bikes with us so, after having lunch on the patio of Foster's, a pub in the cute little town, we biked from Peninsula to the Canal Visitor's Center which was about 10-miles. It was a flat, comfortable trail with lots to see along the way including herons and a small furry animal which I couldn't identify. There were two museums that we stopped at along the trail, one in Boston focused on the boats that plied the canal, and the second at the visitor's center explored the canals in general. Both were definitely worth a stop. A passenger train runs along the path and because we were short on time and the timing was right we took it on the way back from the visitor's center to where we parked our cars in Peninsula. It was fun--volunteers are dressed as conductors and they take your fare which is just a couple of dollars--while other staff load your bikes. I would love to explore this park more the next time I'm in Cleveland since we only did a portion of the trail and there are lots of hiking trails as well.

On our visit to CV National Park, we drove down to the Botzum parking lot, by the train station early on a Saturday morning in Sept, rode our bikes 20+ miles on the Towpath Trail to the Rockside station on a very nice (hard packed stone, occasionally blacktop surface- would not recommend rode bikes) for about 2 hours, then hopped on the CV train for $ 3 to take us back to our car. If you hike, bike or run the Towpath trail the train for you is only $3! The train ride took a bit over an hour, we relaxed, got a beer on board and really enjoyed the scenery. The east side of the train definitely will have a better view as you follow the water on that side, rather than just views of trees. Just so you know, the regular riders on the train, in all the front cars have really cold air conditioned cars, so if you get hot during the ride like I did, just take a walk to one of those cars as the car in the back for the bikers was hot on our Sept day. ON the Towpath trail itself, we saw bluebird, turtles, heron, beaver damns, even a small snake yikes, and some cute towns that we would have stopped in if we weren't in a hurry to complete our journey as we did not want to miss the train ride back. When boarding the train as a biker, you don't pay your fare until onboard the train, and you get on the train at the corner of the Rockside parking lot nearest to the train tracks, you will see a sign there for "bike aboard", so don't sit in the train station with the regular riders. If you want to take a more relaxed route, you might want to ride the train first, then bike back, so you don't have to worry about missing your train. The second day in the park we hiked to the Beaver Marsh (where a National Park employee will explain what you see there) Brandywine Falls, Blue Hen Falls, Oak Hill hiking (which was the only really quiet place we explored, and much enjoyed) and the highlight was the "Ledges area", really awesome hike, but many stairs. Everett Road has a nice covered bridge. Riverview Rd was quite busy with traffic on our day, and the parking lots at some stops were almost full so we picked the more popular stops to do first (Ledges). No, this isn't like your typical park out west, but for anyone in the Midwest or East this is surely worth the drive in IF you like to bike, hike or even jog. Would be an excellent marathon training run, and you will see plenty others to inspire you along. We got lucky enough to see a visiting steam engine as well this weekend, train lovers paradise.

We biked from the Boston visitor center to the North Akron train station. And enjoyed the relative ease of the ride on crushed stone and enjoyed the pictorial historical markers that tell the story of the Towpath Trail. It was quiet and uncrowded on the weekday. After rain for the last 6 miles, we opted to return by train; one can take their bike for just $3.

We visited Cuyahoga Valley NP for the first time with the idea of riding the train from one end of the park to the other and biking back. For only $3.00 you can load your bike on the Cuyahoga RR and travel whatever distance you would like and then ride the Towpath Trail back. The bike trail is a combination of gravel and paved asphalt with numerous places to stop and explore. There are key visitors centers at Boston Mills and The Canal Exploration Center. I recommend going to the visitor center first. We also visited Brandywine Falls which is very nice. The whole park is very historic with much to learn about the Ohio and Erie Canal. There was also lots of wildlife, especially birds to look for and enjoy watching. This was was of the nicest biking experiences I have done and highly recommend it to everyone that likes to ride the rails to trails circuit.

Have visited this park many times and it always pleases. Great for biking bring your own or rent one from Century Cycles in the park. Ride as much as you like and ride the train with your bike for $3 one way! Hike the trails visit the Ledges area for an incredible hike. Just took the Grand kids on a Ledges hike and they loved it!

We are collectors of national parks. So on our way to Cleveland, we stopped for half a day here - a day brings you to most of the park attractions. The park ranger at the Boston Store Visitor Center was very knowledgeable and sent us to the major sites. In half a day, we had plenty of time to walk to Brandywine Falls and the Ledges area. Accommodations near by are difficult and expensive. A local B&B quoted us $250 a night. The Inn at Brandywine was nearly as expensive and very musty.

Cuyahoga Valley National Park is one of the fifty-eight national parks, and the only national park in the state of Ohio. I have been fortunate enough to have visited eight of these parks and while Cuyahoga Valley is certainly not as striking as places like Arches national park it does have plenty to offer. My favorite activity is the “hike aboard” where you can ride your bike down a portion of the trail following the lake Erie Canal and the take the Cuyahoga valley scenic train bike down to you where you parked for only $3.00.

I just love Brandywine Falls in the Cuyahoga Valley National Park. The falls are so beautiful and relaxing. I know there are hiking trails there but I prefer to just take in the beauty of the falls. In the fall, the colors are so pretty there. It really surprises me how many visitors there are from out of state, as it is a just a 10 minute drive for me. Feel blessed I live so close!

We cycled our road bicycles from Massillon to Barberton one day; Barberton to Peninsula the next. Well, actually we took the Cuyahoga train from Akron to Peninsula. Our total mileage was 35 the first day, 23 the second day. The train ride was $3 for self and bicycle. The staff is very helpful; and the transition to get your bike on or off is efficient. The bike path is probably more suited for a hybrid bike. There is so much more to do at the park like hiking, fishing, canoeing or kayaking.

If you are planning a trip to this park think again.Compared to other national parks of USA this park looks at most like a forest preserve.If you are planning scenic route train raid RUN.Its not worth dollar.There is no difference between drivng along a highway and travelling in this train.

We rode our bikes most of the tow-path{bike path}. This path follows close to the cuyahoga river. It is mostly shaded-wooded path.There are lots of unique shops and a few restaurants along the path. You can ride your bike as far as you would like,then take the train back to your car for 3.00 dollars. We had a great time!

We drove to the Brecksville train station which was not hard to find. Get the address for the Cuyahoga Valley RR website. We parked the car and then hopped on board the train with the Ride Aboard program. It was $3.00 for the train ride. It runs Wed- Sunday through Oct 26th. The guy did have change but it was easiest to have the money. They also sold concession on the train. The train ride itself was a bit chilly. We rode down to Botzum and got off the train. Our bikes were already off and waiting for us. The ride back to Brecksville was about 14 miles. We passed so many locks , I was afraid we wouldn't see any.... Lots of herons, turtles, deer, etc... We rode over a beautiful wetland area that was filled with lily pads. We went right by Szalays and also an ice cream store. We could have stopped for lunch in Peninsula if we had wanted to. This was a wonderful day and I can't wait to ride again.

Travel along miles of varied scenery on the towpath and when you get tired, hop the train back to your original station for just $3. From historic locks to wetlands to wonderful side hiking. The Ledges area is exceptional!

This park is a bicyclists and hiker's dream. What less inspired visitors seem to miss is the unique terrain, in between the Appalachian mountains and the prairies of the midwest and the up close access that the park development provides. Add the fascinating Indian culture as well as the New England Western Reserve settlers' history and architecture and the rich learning experience is there for the taking. The 100 mile towpath trail provides a close up view of the canal that opened the unsettled interior of our young nation and connected it directly by water to the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico. Bicyclists who explore the towpath trail in between the river and canal can return on the historic railroad for just $2. Yes, this is not a "grand western park" but you will not find such a large amount of beauty this accessible anywhere in America. You will surely be impressed whether your visit is for 1/2 hour or days long.

We had road bikes and were worried about riding the towpath - with the exception of a few short muddy paths, the path was well packed tailings fine for any bike. We parked at the north end of the park off Rockside road and headed south to the Canal Visitor center (closed for renovations). Round trip was about 10 miles. You hit lock #39 about a mile from the parking lot (headed south) - in pretty bad shape. You pass a couple of other canal historical markers along the way before you get to the visitors center where there is a lock with what looks like working gates. The visitors center is just a couple of blocks from the train stop (trains run several times a day - riders can catch the train one way for $3, runners $9 - schedule at http://www.cvsr.com). There is also an extensive paved bike path system that looks terrific - we hope to get back and explore more!

We spent a long weekend exploring Cuyahoga National Park (between Cleveland and Akron). This is the first National Park I've visited where you hear a lot of road noise. Major highways run over and around the park. Consistently travelled local roads run through the Park. In the beginning, this was a turnoff but after a few hours I didn't seem to notice as much. The Park has beautiful trails for hiking and biking. This is the first National Park I've visited where dogs are welcome on the trails -- I wished I'd known that ahead of time. There is an excellent option where bike riders with their bikes can hop the CVSR train for $2 and get dropped off at a distant train stop to ride the trail back to their cars. Interesting history on the Ohio canal. Cool waterfalls. The Farmers Market at Howe Meadow on Saturday morning was the BEST market I visited this year. We brought home apples, potatoes, zucchini, squash, raspberries, tomatoes, and goat's cheese. Yum! Yum! Yum! Overall, a nice place to visit for a long weekend.

This was a nice weekend getaway for us, One of the two national parks near the East coast, and where we could drive to without losing the entire day. Of course, this is probably the most underwhelming of all the national parks in the country (mind you, I have been to only two and just seen pictures of the rest !). Still, it provides some nice hikes (the Ledges trail is a must do here), and a wonderful biking route following the Cuyahoga river. If you have your own bike, you can ride as far as you wish and then take the scenic railroad back (tickets are $2 if you have a bike, $17 if you do not !!). If you rent, on the other hand,as we did, then you have to meticulously plan your schedule to catch the train. Otherwise, you can end up paying quite a bit since rentals are $9/hr. There are a couple of quaint little towns here, and we happened to run into an enjoyable farmer's market in Peninsula, OH on a beautiful day. Also, it is really close to Cleveland. So, if you get a little bored, you can easily go spend some time in the city. Overall, a really nice getaway for a day or two.

This National Park Site includes much more than the Visitor Center and the Original Wright Brothers Bicycle Shop. You can stamp your Parks Passport at seven locations including two Visitors Centers: The Wright-Dunbar Interpretive Center at 16 South Williams Street and the Huffman Prairie Flying Field Interpretive Center. Do not miss visiting the Huffman site. Recommend this site and we will return! Too much to see on just one visit.
park: Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park
location: Los Ranchos de Albuquerque, New Mexico

text: After reading McCullough's biography on the Wright Brothers in advance of a trip to The Outer Banks, we decided we wanted to come to Dayton as well and see as much as we could about Wilbur and Orville Wright. This was one of the stops. It was our third Museum on the Wrights, so maybe it suffered from the fact we saw a lot of duplication, but we did prefer the Carillon Park visit and the museum on the Air Force base. The field is worth a stop and Hawthorn Hill definitely was worth the 2 hours and $12.
park: Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park

text: We were in Dayton for the weekend and our main adventure was going to be the Air Force museum but since we love National Parks and the kids love getting the stamps in their National Park Passports, we had to check this out. We only were able to get to the Wright Visitor Center and see the Wright memorial and the overlook to the Huffman Flying Field but that was enough to learn a lot. We saw the 30 minute movie which gave all the history of the Wrights and then got to fly a simulator of their 1909 plane which was awesome. From up on the bluff you can see the fields where they did all of their test flights. Definitely worth a stop!
park: Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park

text: Many sites make up this Historical Park. All are good. They have a Passport Stamp program here, visit 7 sites, and you get a "Wilbear." We had fun doing this. Lots to see and some good walking.
park: Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park

text: I knew Denali would be the highlight of my trip to Alaska, but I wasn't prepared for exactly how breathtaking the park is. I saw plenty of wildlife, and the mountain was out for 3 of the 4 days I was there. No pictures can possibly do the park justice. My favorite area was Polychrome Pass, but there is really no bad spot in the park. The term "vast, untamed wilderness" is the best I can do at describing the wilderness of Denali. It was truly incredible!

You can only drive 15 miles into the park. If you want to go farther you need a permit or get on a Green Bus Tour. Tickets can be purchased at the Wilderness Access Center. Three tours are available. I thought the tour was a great value. We saw lots of wildlife and spectacular scenery. This park is so vast, makes Yellowstone look like a city park. A picture is waiting around every turn.

Quite simply one of the most amazing places on earth. Because it is a wilderness area you cannot drive in more than 15 miles. The park provides buses and, in my view, very affordable tours - $50 for 8 hours (for the shuttle) -- where, depending on the tour you can get off the bus and hike or just chill briefly and get back on. Our driver, Wayne, was informative without being intrusive (the official tour buses undoubtedly have more narration) and had a great eye for spotting wildlife. We saw bears (black and brown) eating blueberries, moose, caribou, sheep, artic squirrels and even a wolverine! It is life-changing to see how the earth was before we got to it. The park is a wonderful gift that the U.S. government has given us -- Carter added 4 million acres to the original 2 million in 1980, so it is huge. We happened to be there when Obama was there and officially ditching "Mt. McKinley" and renaming the mountain, Denali. Alaskans were, universally, thrilled with this and his visit.

My husband and I stayed at Riley Creek Campground in mid-August. The sites were spacious with enough shrubs/trees in-between for privacy. The shuttle buses were conveniently located and had several pickup times throughout the day. Campfire wood was expensive at $10 per bundle so I would buy it outside the park if you can. There was construction near the campground which; unfortunately, started about 4:00 a.m. every day. I ended up having to use earplugs in an attempt to reduce the beeping and slamming of the heavy equipment. We had reserved tickets for the Kantishna tour a couple of weeks prior to our arrival but we noticed there was still availability the day prior. Maybe it was a slower part of the tourist season. The tour took us to the end of the park road. Round trip was about 12 hours. We rode in a bus similar to school buses, we were comfortable enough. There were several stops for restroom breaks. We saw several grizzlies, caribou and Dall sheep, most were at a considerable distance so I would suggest binoculars. The driver was knowlegable and gave the group plenty of time to take pictures of wildlife. Overall, we were pleased with the tour. We also took a ranger guided hike from the visitor center to the sled dog demonstration which we really enjoyed. It was leisurely paced, about 2.5 miles in length. Much of it was up hill and I considered it moderately strenuous at times. The ranger was very friendly and seemed to enjoy answering our questions and sharing her knowledge. We would stay here again and would recommend this campground, the tour and a ranger guided hike. Hopefully the noisy construction will be completed soon.

I went for a day to the park - had made advanced reservations for the park shuttle to wonder lake (11hr day). The day we went the buses were delayed and the road after Tolkat was closed due to large amounts of snow. The tickets were $48 per person. Because the road was closed, the park refunded the difference. I would have liked to go further into the park based on what I saw up until Tolkat. The landscape was absolutely beautiful going from big huge snow covered mountains to trees to color ranging terrain. We road on school buses as at least half the road is gravel. We got to see a number of bears, caribou, different types of birds - but the wildlife depends on the day and the timing of when you are passing through. The bus drivers are very informatIve as you drive through and will stop for any wildlife sightings along the way. There are rest breaks every so often with outhouses. You must dress in layers and bring enough snacks and water for the day.

Denali National Park is beautiful, awe inspiring, fun, and just an amazing place to visit. We spent 2 full days and enjoyed everything very much. Booked the shuttle to take the road up to view Mt. McKinley and totally enjoyed that day. Saw plenty of wildlife along the way and views were spectacular. Will probably do a review specifically on this activity and will go into more detail there, but in short, do not miss the ride up the mountain! As far as the park, we were impressed with the organization of all activities and the many activities that were at no cost (dog sled demo, lectures - we listened to one about wolves - ranger led trail hikes, the beautiful visitor center with lots to see and read about, the film at the front of the visitor center.) All this for a $10 entrance fee per person, and that covers 7 days. And I believe 15 and under are free. Parking is laid out well and the areas around the buildings are beautiful. Everywhere people are happy and enjoying this great outdoor experience. People from all over the world are visiting this gem of a park and I was so proud to see how well it is showcased. There is a huge commitment to keeping this area pristine. Staff is well-informed, professional and friendly. Just a most wonderful experience.

There is no denying that Denali National part is beautiful, and the park service and rangers do a nice job maintaining the park and making it accessible to visitors. But the small Denali village where most people stay, especially those on cruise tours, is terribly overpriced. It is easy to spend $40 for breakfast for two, and that is at the cheaper places with a modest breakfast. Lunch and dinner goes up from there. I understand the argument that the season is short and the restaurant, hotel, and shop owners must take advantage of it, but it genuinely feels like tourists are taken advantage of in a big way. We don't have to buy in the shops, and he didn't, but we have to eat, and it is nearly impossible to do so on any kind of a budget. In addition, tours are overpriced, not to mention the "dinner shows" the hotels put on. The one we saw barely let us finish our meal before they took the food away (the woman at the table across from me still had a plate of food) so they could start the show, and the show was limited in interest, although the singers were talented. Overall, don't miss Denali National Park, but do as little in the village as you can get away with.

We went to Denali on our Alcan road trip. We didn't have much time to tour the entire park, but were told that we could drive into the park for 15 miles and enjoy the nature and wildlife. So we drove into the park and decided to stop by the visitor center (which we don't always do). At the visitor center we saw the price information: $10 per person to enter the park. We paid $20 and drove to look for the park entrance. We drove for quite awhile. Didn't see any wildlife or any special scenery, except for beautiful Mt. McKinley in the distance. Finally, we saw a bridge and another ranger. We thought we finally got to the park. But the ranger on the bridge told us that we passed 15 mile mark and had to turn back. Most people who drove that way didn't even stop at the visitor center and never paid any entrance fees. They didn't know. If we didn't stop, we wouldn't pay too. It's OK for me to pay the money for something good. I am sure this money will be used to our all benefit. But... I don't like when things are done unfair. Either we all pay, or no one pays. Out of all cars traveling to the park on that day, there were only two cars that we saw at the visitor center that stopped by and paid the fees. The rest were just driving. They didn't try to avoid paying, they simply did NOT know about it! So, I wrote it, you read it. The rest is up to you.

Our day in Denali was the cherry on top of our Alaskan Cruise and 4-day trip into the interior. We had a beautiful day with a gorgeous view of Mt. McKinley on July 14. We saw six grizzlies; something we have never seen on our two trips to Yellowstone. We saw all kinds of animals on the Tundra Wilderness Tour through Aramark. Our driver, Chris, was an interesting guy who drove the bus with one hand. He talked a lot and it seemed he was making stuff up...but that made the trip more interesting! We were very blessed with a beautiful day and lots of wonderful memories. This post-cruise trip was arrange through Alaska Tour and Travel, and I cannot recommend them highly enough! A negative note: we felt held hostage at Denali. Prices are way too high at the hotel (McKinley Lodge) and the food is overpriced as well. We split a dinner meal, which was fine because we were full of cruise food. But really, prices are way too high unless you are a rich person. I feel sorry for visiting families.

We had a voucher for the included Natural History bus tour provided by our cruise line, Princess cruises. I had read that the farther yo go on the road inside Denali, the better your chances of seeing wildlife. So I opted for the $60.00 upgrade to the Tundra Wilderness Tour. It was well worth it! We saw a bunch of caribou, a moose and a new born baby, several Dall sheep, a porcupine, several Ptarmigan and the coup de grais a momma grizzly with her 2 baby grizzly cubs! It was why we're were there and exactly what I was hoping for! They do provide a box "lunch"- cheese, crackers, applesauce and some bottled water. The tour goes out to Mile 53 (currently-will go out to about mile 90 later in the summer) so the tour can last anywhere from 7 to 9 hours. I would bring something more to eat next time. Oh and the naturalist/bus driver was very knowledgeable and did a great job!

Yeah, yeah, yeah it's expensive paying $50 for a school bus trip of 92 miles into the park, but you won't be disappointed if you like wildlife and fantastic scenery. We saw 5 adult grizzlies plus 2 cubs, along with caribou, moose and dall sheep. You won't see these animals in their natural surrounding anywhere else in that volume. You'll get closer than in a zoo. You probably won't want to go to a zoo ever again. Don't miss it.

This tour was wonderful and more affordable then many showing up on the Internet. We were there the second week of May 2013 and saw the mountain all three days. What a wonderful place to camp and enjoy the scenery. Lots of animal sightings and and beautiful trails, plenty to do and lots of people on bikes. Fees for camping and activities all affordable if done through the park services, staff was very helpfully and friendly camp sights roomy. One thing we found interesting is that there are no fish in Denali so don't go there planning to catch any.

My wife and I went on a cruise that included 7 days on a Nowegian ship with 6 more days on land . There were so many high points that it's not easy to be brief. The inside passage included so many great sites, Ketchikan, Juneau, Skagway, and Whittier. Glacier Bay, the Hubbard Glacier, at the stop in Skagway, we rode the train up Chillkoot Pass, retracing the trail that the many prospectors took on the way to the gold fields in the gold rush of 1898, 99. The crown jewel of the six days that we were on the land part of the tour was, for me Denali Park. What an immense park it is, and if one is fortunate, a view of Denali itself, capps a 60 mile ride into this absolute jewel. 30 percent of the visitors to the park get to see this huge mountain. Denali is the largest mountain on earth. Everest is taller as everyone knows, but in terms of mass, Denali is the biggest mountain on this planet.

If you ever are to visit Alaska, this is a MUST SEE. The park limits private vehicles from entering in to the park completely (I think you can only go 15 miles in). You need to take a tour bus into the park which I highly recommend because many of the guides have spent time hiking, camping, etc in the park. Our guide Peter is a sub teacher in his other job but does this during the tourist season. He was well versed in the eco system, the animals, the history of the park and all that have traveled through the park since the early 1900s. You have the option of a 6-8 hr trip or a longer one. We chose the 6-8 hr because we do have an 8 yr old. We were even leery that he would hang on for 6-8 hr but let me tell you, he did and loved every minute of it. Part of the draw to this trip is that everyone on the bus participates in eyeballing animals. On our trip, we saw a momma bear and her 2 cubs whom gave chase to a male bear, caribou & their little ones, moose, porcupine, sheep and some birds. They film what you see on your trip and you can purchase that for $35-which they send to you via mail after editing. The mountains that you see throughout this great park are spectacular. They will take you to a spot to see Mt McKinley (aka Denali). This is hard to see in its entirety because of the clouds but we were able to see quite a bit. There isn't a bad Kodak moment and well worth the effort for the early rise. We did the early AM trip and when I say early..I mean..EARLY. They pick up at various large hotels in Denali starting at 530AM so be forewarned. Don't worry to doll up-no one will care at least I don't think so because I am sure I may have scared a few bear with my morning hair. The tour bus (which is a school bus configuration) we took included a light snack (reindeer sausage, cheese, bread, & bottled water). We opted to have our hotel pack us a lunch as kids aren't so thrilled with the bus snack option. They do make potty break stops often. Great trip for all ages.

Denali, the mountain, finally started to appear, just as we needed to board the bus to Talkeetna and the train. The station is a small building on a long paved roadway about 1 hour away. We waited for the train about 55 minutes. We would have preferred to wait on the deck of the lodge and the beautiful vista than along a roadway with bus fumes. Boarding the train was easy as seats were already assigned. Had to show a photo ID to board. Drink service was at your seats. Meal service by appointment was downstairs. Live commentary for the entire trip by Helen. She had fun stories to tell. They did not allow the large camera bag on board with a couple of other larger rollies. They stowed them in a small compartment right by the door. We had Chena Club car – Row 16 ABCD. The car was actually Holland’s car, not Princess. So far the left side, seats AB, were the better side for sites along the river. The windows are large and you can see views from either side. The ride was fairly smooth and quiet with a large comfortable area for your legs and feet. There was the ability to climb over the person sitting next to you without disturbing them. We did notice that towards the back of the car it was nosier with plate/meal service noise. And towards the front the blender noise for mixed drinks was prominent. Abby was our drink server. Smoothies were $4.75 and very good. There is a total of 22 rows, 4 across.

This was my 4th trip. The 8.5 hours went fast, it is beautiful. But they shortened the time at the stops and increased the price, $43.50, significantly. The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars. I would plan on taking the next bus to enhance your visit and have time to experience everything at the different stops. So take backpacks so you can catch different buses. Take bug spray and food and water. There is a water station at Eielson. A must do if you can get there. Will need to spend the night so you can get an early bus. Lots of great info on the Denali Park site.

Drove from Fairbanks, I would find a place closer to the park. We were exhausted after the drive there, then the bus ride, and the trip back. Road construction was going on, there was not a lot of waiting. Took the green bus, we had 4 of us on there which was wonderful. It was a hot day and the bus has no ac but we didn't need it with the windows open. Bring your snack and drinks. Potty breaks are provided along the way. We saw moose, caribou and dall sheep. The road is narrow and scary at times especially when passing another bus. We were afraid to get off the bus as we weren't sure what to do. Feel confident, to get off check out the sites, hike whatever. Green buses go by about every 15-30 min. You flag them down and they stop and pick you up. We had a great view of McKinnley.

Six million acres, highest mountain on the continent, spectacular scenery, snow covered peaks, glaciers, fast running rivers, waterfalls, mile wide gravel river beds with braided rivers twisting through them, an Alaskan wildlife preserve, ancient trees that are stunted due to short growth seasons, beautiful wildflowers, this National Park is vast and breathtaking. It takes a commitment to get there, but it is so worth the drive, train ride and tour bus on the single gravel road. This may seem odd, but the tour busses on only one road is what keeps the wilderness wild. The Alaskan and Outer ranges are majestic even if you aren't one of the lucky ones who gets to see Denali. Polychrome Pass is named for its multicolor hues. We saw moose, dall sheep, rock squirrels, the state bird willow ptarmigan plus other birds, snow hares, caribou and grizzly bears with cubs. The Denali Visitor center is very nice, a large multi building center. I hope this review gives you a sense of what we experienced.

Do yourself a favor and spend time in the amazing Deschutes Forest. We are blessed to live within a day's drive and camp here at least once a year. One of our favorite spots is Davis Lake - with about 18-20 campsites @$12 per night. Great fishing, beautiful scenery.

We traveled through the Deschutes National Forest throughout our week long stay in the Sunriver area South of Bend, Oregon. We crossed from West to East over the Willamette Pass and traveled from Chiloquin in the South to Sisters and over the Santiam pass in the North. The entire area contains several mountain passes; many, many lakes and streams; lots of trees and mountains to view and visit. Pine forests abound and mountain views are different every time you turn your head.
Many options for what to do and all for only a $5 day use pass. lots of trails and lakes for all sorts of activities

Take Paulina Lakes road, pay your 5 dollars (well worth it) and hike to the Falls. So easy an 80+ year old who is healthy could and did do it. Don't miss the Obssydian Flow either, it is a wonderful 1 mile loop (maybe less) and it is gorgeous. (Don't wear flip flops though, OUCH). Take a Camera.
Relatively easy hike to see two spectacular falls. Fun drive from Sisters, OR on Route 242 over the MacKenzie Pass and lava fields.

I was expecting a small place with a few bones and that's about it. Boy was I ever wrong! This location is one of the better locations that has an outstanding exhibit of the past. One starts with the introductory film at the visitors center, then jump on the tram out to the exhibit building. Handicap accessible...one can drive up through gated access to the exhibit hall. One recommendation is to spend the $1 on the auto tour and venture out into the NP. It was one of the better ancillary pieces of the NP that was great. You can take your time driving and reading through the booklet (I think around 15 stops) at your leisure. It is out of the way but well worth the trip.

Quick drive from Vernal. Excellent visitor center with short movie about the national park and very friendly and helpful rangers. Shuttle from the center to the Quarry Building. There are hikes that can be taken to discover more fossils. Can be hot and will need water. Quarry Building is modern design and air conditioned for very pleasant visit. And inside is the remainder of the wall of fossils found here in the Morrison Formation. This was a "jamb" of fossils following an unusual event. Awesome wall of rock with the fossils still intact and showing how they were found. This is a portion of the total wall originally found and since recovered for the many dinosaurs. Great exhibit with detailed explanations and you can touch fossils on the wall. Following the Quarry Exhibit we left the Visitor Center and drove on the road for the auto tour into the park. Guide available for $1 at the beginning of the road. Petroglyphs, views, rock formations, camping, hikes, picnic areas and the homestead for Josie Morris at the end of the road. She was a woman homesteading alone with cabins, livestock, gardens, orchard and much more. Fascinating and worth the drive. Mostly paved but the last part gravel but well maintained and easily driven. Recommended.

I mostly wanted to drive to Harper's Corner to photograph the unusual and stunning landscape, but I want to get Senior Pass for $10 to enter the park. The ranger at the Dinosaur, Colorado, entrance said that they were only available at the Jensen, Utah, entrance (the bone quarry). So, I continued "way over there" to get a pass.

Dinosaur NM is split into two parts. Only the part with the entrance off US 40 in Utah has dinosaur fossils. (Actually the entrance to the NM is in Jensen 13 miles east of Vernal). The part with the entrance off US 40 in Colorado has canyon and views but no fossils. There is a rest area and tourist info center at the turn off to the UT Dinosaur NM. It's about 7 miles to the entrance. Right after the tool booth you turn left into the visitor center parking lot. You board a tram to take you up the hill to the quarry building. The tram leaves every 15 minutes and only takes a few minutes. When you exit the tram you walk up a ramp to the second floor of the building, One whole wall of the building is raw cliff which has dozens of large dinosaur bone fossils still embedded in the rock. The rock wall is two stories high so after studying the top of the wall you can go downstairs to get a closer look and even touch the fossils. There is a map available for $1 that shows which bone goes with which dinosaur. (there are also several interactive displays that identify the bones.) The opposite wall has murals and replica skeletons of some of the dinosaurs found in the quarry. There is a fascinating 7 minute black and white video made back when the quarry was first being worked that shows how the bones were dug up, covered in plaster, crated and shipped back east where they were cleaned and studied and assembled into full skeletons.

We all enjoyed the monument. We took the self guided auto tour and enjoyed the scenery and petroglyphs. The quarry with the wall of fossils was amazing. Be sure to spend $1 for the auto tour pamphlet just past the quarry turn off.

Very cheap at $10 per vehicle. You start at the visitor center, where you get on a short but fun tram ride that takes you up the mountain to the quarry. Once you arrive at the quarry you are able to see dinosaur bones still in the earth and partially uncovered. In addition they allow you to touch many of the real dinosaur bones, which adds to the excitement. After you finish at the quarry you can take the tram back OR you can hike back on the fossil trail, WHICH I RECOMMEND. It is a 1.2 miles rocky but easy hike (about 30-60 mins) around the mountain where you are able to discover even more dinosaur fossils. Many people do not do this hike but I highly recommend you doing it for extra fun.

I only visited the Utah side of the monument. This side has the fossils and petroglyphs. The visitor's center s small, but has interesting information. There is also an auto tour guide for only $1. The fossil quarry hall is a short distance from there. Plenty of well preserved fossils. There is also many petroglyphs along the auto route, as well as an old ranch at the end of the road. One could easily spend a few hours here. Worth a visit.

Excellent park to visit. We went to the Utah side and went to the Dinosaur Quarry which was fantastic. There are so many bones and fossils to see there plus the building is built around the quarry. Inside the building it was air conditioned which was great when we went. It was very hot out. The whole family will enjoy it there. The rangers were very friendly and helped point out what kinds of dinosaurs were there and answered any questions you had. It was cheap to get into the park. Only $10 for a seven day pass. After the quarry we went on the fossil hike which is about a mile long. Within the trail there are stops that they have that show you where other fossils and dinosaur bones are. That was really cool. We rode the tram up to the quarry and took the trail down back to the visitors center. Bring lots of water if you plan to hike and it is hot out. They have many hikes you can go on.

My husband and I found this by accident. LOVED it! We had a great day looking at the dino bones and the beautiful scenery. The park is full of petroglyphs and they give you a brochure with information and corresponding numbers to find points of interest. It's only $10 to get into the park for as long as you want. We had a very enjoyable time finding the petroglyphs. It was kind of like Where's Waldo. Very interesting history.

Our family of 4 with a 14 yr old boy and an 11 yr old boy, really enjoyed the fossil quarry. While this is something I can cross off my bucket list, the quarry is not a full-day experience. Be sure to visit other parts of the park as well... there are petroglyphs from the Fremont people in several areas and a canyon overlook - but the overlook is quite a drive from the quarry, but worth the sights. The fee was $10 for our family in a car to get into the park.

This is really an amazing treasure. We. Old have looked all day. My 9 year old and myself were mesmerized trying to imagine all of the dinosaurs and how the bones linked. The child activity and badge were great to have the kids process a bit more as well. Incredible to have such an amazing treasure so close to home. Would go again! Also if you have a 4th grader download the free state park pass and present at the pay booth so they get a prize and free entrance. If not it is $20 but good for 7 days. Truly incredible!
For $10 a carload, you can actually touch a real dinosaur fossil, many of them really, on the quarry wall. Most places have only castings of fossils, but here you can touch the real thing!

We are fans of National Park Service exhibits - well designed, fair and balanced, accessible, and excellently interpreted. Dinosaur National Monument validated our opinion of the NPS. Roads are, for the most part, easily navigated, well-signed and self-narrated from a $1 booklet available at the gift shop.

We're not into dinosaurs but we already had a National Park Pass and were driving that way. If it's not crowded, you can see the main exhibit and be back on the road within an hour. The kids liked the tram/bus from the visitor center to the main exhibition hall. Dino lovers can take some trails and see more .

We visited the Quarry Visitor Center and the rangers there were very helpful in suggesting sites that would fit our interests, since we had limited time there. We took the shuttle, which runs every 15 minutes, to the 2-story Quarry Exhibit Hall. Ramps led from one level to another--nice for those with limited mobility. We learned a great deal about dinosaurs by viewing their bones and the many exhibits. We camped at Green River nearby. We had picked up a $1.00 auto guidebook at the Visitor Center entitled "Tour of the Tilted Rocks" and refereed to it as we drove down Cub Creek Road to view petroglyphs and pictographs from 1,000 years ago near the road. Toward the end of the road it was unpaved, but we were able to make it to the Josie Morris Ranch and log cabin in our RV. It was shady with picnic tables, and paths leading to good areas to listen to bird songs. It was difficult to actually see them because they stayed high in the treetops. There's a lot to see at Dinosaur, and I'm glad we made that a part of our trip to Colorao.

We purchased the $1 tour book that takes you to multiple numbered points along the road from the Visitor's Center to Josie's Cabin. I'd recommend the book even if you skip reading all of the points, there are a number of petroglyphs & pictographs along the route that you don't want to miss. Some take a bit of uphill hiking which is refreshing when you are doing a lot of driving. At Josie's Cabin, the road ends and you will find an outhouse (whew) and two side trails up canyons where she ran her livestock. We hiked both canyons and would recommend them especially if it is hot...cool places to end up.

We were traveling from Moab to Wyoming & wanted to check out Dinosaur Nat'l Monument. We had stayed in Vernal & that was only 12 miles from it. 1st stop was the Quarry Visitors Center where you pay a fee of $10 or use the Senior Pass. Got some info, watched the movie & looked at the exhibits. Then we did the Ranger tour over to Quarry Exhibit Hall with Ranger Tiffany from Sheboygan, WI. She was very helpful & made the experience more interesting. The exhibit hall has a very interesting cliff wall with hundreds of bones partially visible. Next we did the Cub Creek Rd. Tour of the Tilted Rocks with 15 points of interested covered in a brochure. At Pt. 14, hubby hiked up to see additional petroglyphs. I could see the lizard & flute player petroglyphs from the parking lot but couldn't do the hike due to a sore knee. The last Pt. is the Jossie Bassett cabin & a 20 minute easy hike on the Box Canyon Trail. We spent half a day here but you could easily spend much more time in this area. There's another section of Dinosaur Nat'l Monument on the Colorado side that we didn't get to this trip. Hope we get back to finish what we started.

It is up to date starting with the visitor's center. air-conditioned with interesting exhibits and a nice gift shop with educational materials. The paved parking lot is large enough to accommodate cars and busses and is a allows for a short walk to the visitor's center. The Quarry Exhibit Hall located in the back of the visitor's center can be approached by shuttle every 15 minutes in the summer, walked although it is steep but a short distance or as I did in the Fall drive up with your car. The Quarry Exhibit Hall is an excavation site that has 1,400 fossils. They are Late Jurassic. There are exhibits along the side wall and an upper and lower viewing area for the fossils encased in the wall. For one dollar you can purchase an activity book to further explain the fossils in the wall. Electronic information boards are spaced all along the viewing area and really add to your knowledge of what you are seeing. There are ranger lead hikes along the Fossil Trail or you can go it alone. Some of the steeper inclines have very interesting fossils. After you leave the Quarry Exhibit Hall, you might want to take the 11 stop Auto Drive Tour. Most stops are a short walk to the exhibits. For $1 you can buy a booklet which explains what each stop offers and how much of a hike it is. There are petroglyphs, ancient settlements and history and geology exhibits. It's a national park so any passes you have will be honored. I have the senior pass and used it. It can be an all day event or an hour but either way it's a wonderful experience for all ages.

We mostly were stopping because it was a halfway point between our destinations, Pinedale, Wy to Grand Junction,Co and we were looking for something fun to do to stretch our legs. This was exactly the ticket! Really cool and unique Monument. I imagine if you were into Dinosaurs or have youngsters that are this would be unparalleled. We also really enjoyed the rangers, clearly people who enjoy their work. So refreshing to see people having fun in life! P.S. Like any Nationally funded area, this park accepts the "National parks Senior Pass" If you have it, you already know. If you don't and your a senior who likes to travel, please inquire at any National park. Its really the best deal going! My Mom and I have been able to enjoy SO much because of this wonderful pass!

The National Monument has 2 Visitor Centers; the one near Dinosaur, Colorado is open seasonally and has NO dinosaur fossils. If you want to see one of the richest fossil beds open to the public in North America, visit the Quarry Visitor Center accessible from Vernal or Jensen, Utah. The Quarry is generally open year round; fossils were deposited in the rock layer about 150 million years ago. You can actually touch some of the fossils, a feature children seem to especially enjoy. A reconstruction of an Allosaur is on the first floor of the quarry. If you have only half a day, a visit to the quarry is a must. If you have more time, try to participate in one or more of the ranger led short hikes and/or some of the volunteer programs. When I was there one volunteer had a special telescope allowing us to view spots and prominences on the sun. At a night program (you can access these at night without having to stay at the camping areas) a knowledgeable volunteer provided telescopes and views of the spectacular night sky. There is also a road tour (maps at the visitor center) which can take a couple of hours depending on how many of the short hikes to petroglyph areas you might take from the overlooks. Camping is also available at 2 areas and will allow you to explore the area's ecosystems. This is a great park to visit for half a day to several days depending on your time and interests. There is a $10 per car entry fee unless you have a Golden Age Passport (62 and older).

We traveled to Vernal (not much of a town with little to no charm) to go see the bones at the Quarry. I think you need a full day on the Utah side to see everything. We took the ranger lead hike; there is only one a day in the summer at 10:00am. You can do this hike on your own, but Barb was very informative and willing to answer all questions. The hike lasts about 90 minutes. It starts above at the quarry and returns you to the visitor center below. Then we took the drive along Cub Creek. We bought the dollar pamphlet that explained each numbered stop. The petroglyphs along the way are not to be missed. There is some short hiking to reach them but well worth it. At Josie's cabin at the end, there are two hikes you can take. The landscape is beautiful all along the way. Be sure to pack a picnic lunch because there is no where to get food. We went to Smith's in Vernal before going to the monument. After the drive we went back to the quarry to see the wall of dinosaur bones. It is amazing. There are so many that it is hard to know where to look first. We arrived around 9:45am and did not leave the monument until 3:45pm. We were tired from the hiking in the heat, but so glad we had the time to see everything. That is the Utah side.

At the quarry you can see many dinosaur fossils, they are very impressive; you visit will take between an hour and no longer than two. As you arrive at the visitor center you can take a free shuttle to the quarry, about a mile away There is a trail from the quarry to the visitor center, about 1.2 miles, very easy and beautiful surrounding and you can explore some fossils at some rock walls, use the trail from Quarry to the Visitor Center.; the other way around is a steep incline. Park entrance is $10.00

This was my second trip to Dinosaur National Monument and loved it as much as my first visit about 30 years ago with my children. It was the first time I had been up close and personal with dinosaurs and found it to be an awesome thing. There were a few changes since that first visit. They now have a shuttle near the entrance of the park that takes you to the quarry site because the upper parking lot is not large enough to accommodate all the visitors and the gift shop is located at the park entrance also. I don't remember the price of the entrance fee for the park, but we opted to purchase the senior pass for $10 which allows entrance to all the national parks for a lifetime. A very good deal if you are 62 or older..

This place is a little far from everything in vernal, UT, but its worth the drive if your kids love dinosaurs. We took a trip out to Vernal UT last June 2012 when we attended a family reunion. We stayed in Provo, UT and we decided that we wanted to check this place out. Vernal is less than 200 miles away from Provo, but the scenery is awesome on the way there. Other than the the fossils on the side of the mountain, you can do other things while you are there. They have a hiking trail or you can camp on the colororado side. We went to the utah side where the monument is at. There is a $10.00 fee for the national park entrance. Thinking of doing this again this year. Vernal has a museum that houses dinosaurs.

While vacationing in Vernal, my family went to the Dinosaur National Monument because it's one of the few things to do in Vernal. I wasn't overly impressed but that might be because I'm not a huge fan of dinosaurs. We had to pay a $10 fee to enter the park.

There is a surprisingly large amount of stuff to do here even though you'd assume it's all about dinosaurs. The visitor's center and quarry buildings were beautiful, and there was a shuttle every 15 minutes to take visitors to the quarry. The wall of bones is gigantic and cool, and there were a few hikes you could go on. Definitely purchase the guidebook ($1) for the Tour of the Tilted Rocks drive. It was a neat way to see the park, and includes three petroglyph sites and Josie's cabin, which was a neat oasis at the end of the road. The last 2 miles are unpaved, but my sedan did just fine. Geology buffs will love this place.

Imagine hiking through a semi-arid region and see a skeleton of a Dinosaur. An archaeologist did just that. Modern visitors center. Reasonable admission charge, $20.00/car, and free shuttle to the Quarry Exhibit Hall. The Quarry Hall is an long two story building with 1,500 fossils and a ton of info about the area and exhibit. Take a driving tour and see where the Green River cut through a mountain, beautiful scenery and petroglyphs still visible on the walls of the mountain. Many rangers available for answers to questions. Would recommend this national monument if in the area. Accessible from Utah and Dinosaur, CO.

This place, and its history, are hidden gems. It is a “must visit”, in my opinion. The dinosaur fossils in this area represent the congregation of the creatures in this water-rich area during a period of drought where the dinosaurs ultimately died, settled in the riverbed; were then covered by sand and preserved. That’s the current theory of why the creatures are so prolific there. The Visitor Center, while desolate, is modern and easy to reach. It is where you stop to pay the $20 per vehicle user fee and get park insights from the staff. Then you drive <1km to the new building that houses the enclosed fossil-rich river bed, now nearly vertical given the earth’s movements over thousands of years, where you can view hundreds and hundreds of fossils that were preserved. If you have questions, the staff has answers. To get a different perspective, visit the upstairs too. This national monument is a perfect venue to teach children about the dinosaurs and archeology. It was an enriching visit; and utterly fascinating.

Posey Lake camping was to be our base camp for the rest if our byway 12 adventure. To get to Posey there is a turnoff in the town of Escalante. It takes about a half hour or so to get there and is a beautiful drive. The road turns from pavement to groomed gravel as you leave the desert scape of Grand Staircase to the aspen and pine of Dixie National Forest. It was absolutely beautiful. It was at the very top of the mountain and we were I the clouds. The campground was well maintained, they had grills, a fire pit with a removable grill as well, a table, tent area and a bear box. If not familiar, a bear box are becoming more common. They are large steal box with a door that you put all things "smelly". Everything from food to toothpaste. Anything else, locked in your car to the very least. Bear are prevelent in the tops of mountains but will keep there distance unless they smell an easy meal. As a sidenote, several years ago a boy lost his life( not in Dixie) when a bear smelled fragrant shampoo.) Get my point? Anyway, the odds are slim to nil you'll see bears or cougars or the like. I did not, had I I'd want to know where the kids are, how to handle a confrontation( I do) and find my camera! We did see dear, birds of prey and when we walked over to the lake and were greeted with a slap of a beaver's tail on the water near the small boat dock. Other that some unique looking water fowl, the fish jumping , Mr. Beaver and the few other campers that couldn't be seen from our camp( bonus) it was as if we had the whole place to ourselves. After setting up we went with hot dogs over the fire then I was going dutch over cooking from morning to night from fish I was planning to catch to a roast with veggies to pineapple upside down cake not to mention the egg, bacon and country potato's for breakfast. But alas it was all for not. We retired for the evening only to awake to 4 INCHES of snow!!!!! It was gorgeus but....1,2,3,4!!!!! Four inches! In short, it altered our trip. We packed up, said goodbye to Mr. Beaver, (who was no doubt comfortably warm and dry in his mansion of a dam) and abandoned our $35 tent. Our plan when we weren't at camp was to do the Hell's Backbone trail which starts near camp. This is not a hike, it is a small occasionally groomed 30 mile jagged road that is OK for our little car unless churned up by 4 wheelers after inclement weather. At the end is the town of Boulder, the home of the renowned restaurant, Hell' s Backbone grill.( look for my review on that). So after dodging the looming rain for the first 3/days, we not only got snow instead but had no place to stay but under the clouded over stars. We ended back the way we came, back on byway 12 and thru Escalante, passed Calf Creek Falls( see my review on that) and up and over what's called the Hog's Back. Top of a bald mountain, certain death on both sides of the road with snow turned rain and fog. Mine you this was Byway 12 again so it was awesome but would have been nice to see the vastness of both Grand Staircase on one side and Dixie N. F. on the other side of the Hog. We eventually made it to our next stop Hell"s Backbone Grill and the Anasazi National Monument( see review on this).

We stumbled across this national forest and just loved the scenery throughout our drive through it. We came across so many trees and stunning vistas that it's hard to pick just one. Walking and hiking trails are all over the place. A beautiful and serene area, just what you need to relax. We were lucky to have gone in early April before the heat and before the crowds. I'm not sure about the fee as we used our National Park Pass to go to Zion National Park and Bryce Canyon, both of which are in the Dixie National Park.

We are glad we saw it. You can't imagine how vast it is. It was very easy to see by driving through and stopping at the various viewpoints. You can do as little or much hiking as you prefer. It was a sight to behold. Since we only did a little hiking, it only took less than half day to see. It cost $25 per car to enter the park but the pass was good for 7 days. We did notice several shuttles driving through, but we thought driving our own car let us have more control of our time. There were 2 or three restroom stops. You can eat at the lodge just inside the entrance if you get hungry.
We took the ferry to Dry Tortugas National Park. The tickets were on sale during November, so for $99.00 each, we couldn't pass it up.

The most remote and yet the most beautiful place that you have to go see! Combine history with beauty and wildlife and this is a “must do” once in a lifetime trip. Pricey - yes, worth it - YES! So very glad we went. The only down side is the price for the ferry ride and the long ride there and back. But, we met some nice people and had a great chat with them.

We took the ferry and even though it is a long ride (2.5 hrs), they do what they can to make it enjoyable. Breakfast and lunch were served, snacks and drinks (alcohol, sodas, etc are available for $$). For breakfast we had a choice of ham, boiled eggs, bagels (cream cheese, butter, jelly), cereal, yogurt, fresh fruit, juice, coffee, and milk. For lunch you are able to come onto the boat and fix a plate and they offered bread and sandwich fixings, tunafish, sliced veggies, fresh fruit, chips and cookies. There are nice bathrooms and changing rooms at the Fort. They provide snorkel equipment (we brought our own), they have dramamine for purchase, they pretty much have whatever you might need. The crew was excellent!

The $175 ticket price seemed high but so glad we did this. 2 1/2 hour boat ride out, enjoy breakfast on the way. Ham, boiled eggs, cereal, cheese and bagels. Water, coffee, and hot tea all day. 4 hours at the fort. Take a guided or self guided tour, then wrap up with great snorkeling. We saw barracudas, coral, and sting rays. Lunch is from 11-1 on the boat. Sandwiches, chips, fruit, cookies and sodas. On the way back they open the snack bar with burgers, pretzels, ice cream and beer. This costs extra but prices are reasonable. Beer is $3 each. Excellent value, great crew, they know what they are doing! Take a Dramamine before the boat ride if you're nervous, but it's a super easy ride. No one on our trip got sick. Well done Yankee Freedom!

We took a day trip here on the daily ferry. If you like history you will enjoy the stories concerning this Fort which took 30 years to build. The fort itself takes up most of the island. Great for walking around and exploring the interior. There are also 2 nice beaches on the island and snorkeling. Stingrays, barracuda, large jelly fish and other schools of fish have been seen. However, it is not like snorkeling in the Caribbean (at least near to shore it is not). There are also picnic areas and you can also camp there for $15 per night. It is a primitive camping area so come prepared. No restaurants, toilets are only open at certain times. Bring lots of sun block and you may also need insect repellent.. It is extremely hot so be sure to hydrate! The only way to get to the island is by ferry, seaplane, or private boat.
Who can afford this? $175 per person! Omg. Great place to visit, if you've got lots of money. And, there's no alternative way to visit we could find besides the ferry.

We loved this trip and we made the trek from Islamorada to get there by 7:15a. Well worth the time and even the money. The trip is pricey on the Yankee Freedom but if you can swing it the park is incredible. It is almost a 2 1/2 hour trip out into the Gulf of Mexico but once you get there the snorkeling and the touring of the fort will more than take up your time and when it is time to go you most likely won't be ready. Too many places to swim and too much fort to see. Great scenery, fascinating history and lots of relaxation, all you can ask for in a day trip. Park in the lot across from the terminal if you can. $14 for the day. I would also suggest getting seats up to and inside on the way back as you will have had enough sun most likely.

We took the ferry ride to Dry Tortugas and the staff was very good and highly aware of all travelers needs. Breakfast, lunch, beverages were included in price. The waters were rough so they made sure to have Dramamine available to all for $1.00 a packet. The park itself is beautiful. There are two beaches to swim and snorkeling. Snorkeling gear is free at the dock. We say hermit crabs, barracuda, etc. Fort Jefferson is fun to explore and has a great history so make sure to take time to learn about it. We really enjoyed our time at the park and recommend the trip.

To get here, need a boat or plane. I guess you can kayak out over 2 days from Key West. The Dry Tortugas have no water. Fort Jefferson is an interesting civil war era fort.
