Did see an alligator on land and got a few great pics, but we've seen alligators before, so not a big deal. Saw a few turtles in the water. Won't go back. After exploring the Rocky Mts in July, this was boring and a lot of nothing.

There are many airboat tours as you approach the National Park but we decided to take the tour sanctioned by the National Park Service. We chose the Mangrove Wilderness Tour. We embarked on our journey on a boat with seating for six people plus the tour guide. This tour was billed as visiting the swampy part of the Everglades and seeing native wildlife through a series of mangroves. It was an enjoyable way to spend a couple hours of the day (travel plus tour). While the cost may be a bit steep (approximately $42 per adult), there is not any other way to see large alligators up close and personal. Unfortunately, the manatees decided to not poke their bodies above water for our enjoyment. However, we did see an Ibis perched in a tree and several large Alligators. If you are looking for an enjoyable boat ride in the Everglades, then take the Mangrove Wilderness Tour.

We took the tram tour which was very nice. A little pricey $23 per person but the tour guide was very informative. The tower view (included) of the Everglades was amazing. Don't expect to see many animals during wet season I believe May- Oct.

Save the money, go to the visitor center then turn back! We stopped at the Alligator Farm on the way out and had so much run feeding alligator babies and riding an airboat! Back to the park- you pay the entrance fee, and basically drive about 40 miles through grass. Sure you can get out of your air conditioning and sweat in the humidity for a 1 mile hike through grass or jungle trees but it seems more like a school field trip than anything. Then you reach Flamingo at the end! Yay! You made it to a gas station where you can pay $5 per gallon and buy premade sandwiches, burgers, hotdogs, etc for outrageous prices because they are the only place for 40 miles! That is all. Then what? Turn around and go back. Unless you have a boat. If you take a boat on vacation, maybe you could try it and have a better time.

We rushed to catch an excursion boat on the Flamingo end of the park. Saw coots, two tiny 'gators and an ibis on the boat trip. Saw more at the plug and on the grounds after the boat excursion, including BIG 'gators and manatee. The best part was the Anhinga trail. This alone was worth the price of admission ($10 each). Many gators, and the best variety of birds we've ever seen on a trail ... ANYWHERE. The only negative was insensitive tourists from other countries who were loud and disruptive. They seemed to think they were at Disneyland, instead of a wildlife preserve, giggling, talking loudly and SCREAMING.

We came, we had a picnic lunch, we got our National Parks Passport stamped and we enjoyed the park (and we saw a couple of owls). They have trails and we saw lots of people with kayaks parked along the sides of the roads. We just enjoyed the drive through the park and some of the walkways and observation decks they have at various locations. At one area, Cindy spotted a momma owl and her chick sitting in a tree near the parking lot. Mom was sleeping but the fuzzy little chick seemed as interested in us as we were in him/her. I did get a good photo, and I'm posting it here as well.

The visitor center is staffed by volunteers who are very nice. The entrance fee is only $10.00 per car. There are many scenic walks where a person can get to within feet of wild alligators. It was really fun.

With only one day to experience the Everglades, we wanted to see as much and learn as much as possible. We chose the Shark Valley Tram Tours, and it was perfect. Park admission was $10. Tours were $21.49 (I think that was with a AAA or AARP discount). We had reserved a 2 p.m. tour, but when we arrived there were four spots left on the 1 p.m. tour (which can not be reserved ahead) so we took it. The tram consisted of two cars, with the guide in the front car but an excellent sound system so we heard everything just fine in the second car. Our guide was EXCELLENT. She was just bursting with knowledge and enthusiasm. I was surprised to find out at the end of the tour (1 1/2-2 hours) that she was not employed by the National Park Service but instead worked for tips, and she received many from the travelers on our tour. The Everglades themselves are a treasure that we all need to protect, especially from the invasive (and very large - so glad we didn't actually see one) snakes. Saw lots of alligators and birds. The park ranger inside the lodge was also very knowledgeable. We enjoyed the whole experience.

This was out first experience in Everglades National Park. We expected a lot of marshy, swampy terrain and instead saw miles of "sawgrass prairie". The National Park Service person at the Ernest Coe visitor center was extremely helpful and the visitor center had a very nice souvenir shop. We stopped at Anhinga trail and were very pleased with the short (less than a mile) trail where we were able to see dozens of alligators and many different types of birds. We then drove to the Flamingo Visitor Center and were very disappointed in the appearance and cleanliness of he buildings. We took a Back Country boat ride ride from the marina which was $32 per person and we saw little if any wildlife and the guide shared info about trees and snakes but little else. The best part of the Flamingo area were the manatees that reside in the boat basin and the osprey nest that was easily visible and the largest we've ever seen.

The park is low key, nice boat rides are offered from Everglades city for about 40$ per person. The mangrove ride was really neat and different with a wonderful knowledgeable guide. From the Everglades city side, take a day and go into all the little areas. Tops for birds and Alligators is the Anhinga trail, very close to the entry to the park. fantastic. We loved it all. The Flamingo restaurant and hotel were destroyed in a hurricane so bring snacks, they have a makeshift eatery. A very memorable place.
If you want to get outside, enjoy some amazing scenery and see some very cool animals up close, hit up the park! Only $10 to get in. Its fun!

While on vacation with my daughters, ages 16 and 10, I had a burning desire to cross a trip into the Everglades off my bucket list. The entry fee to the park was $10, so quite reasonable. My kids are as much outdoor enthusiasts as the next kid, which is a negative as well as a positive, but they are true adventurers at heart and this stop was a memory of a lifetime for them.

Said to be 1.5 million acres, should be 5 million. Unusual jungles, swamps, water ways, sawgrass even a sea of grass. You can go birding, bass fishing, swamp tour, airboat tour for alligators, new minus pythons, endangered Florida panther, bear, key deer, manatee, American crocodile, total 14 rare endangered spies.Most animals, reptiles, snakes , even plants can adapt to the climate It's a great day, or way of relaxation. Cost; $
Support protecting our environment by being an educated citizen. Did not have time to take a tour but the Visitor Center very informative. Highly recommend. $10 per car.

Maybe we were expecting more. It cost $25.00 to get into. Which, was fine since it goes to preservation. We live in central Florida and have always wanted to go through the everglades. It is just a road with side stops. There are tons and tons of mosquitoes. We were loaded with spray. We opened our car to get in there were approx. 50 in our car. . We saw a few crocodiles, mosquitoes, crows, nothing else. One lake had birds but you needed binoculars to see them. The only restrooms we found working were in the campground. All the rest of them were locked. Very disappointing.

We stayed at the Hyatt Regency, a 12-mile drive, and enjoyed this beach as well as the drive. The hotel is a completely different review - I would study hard before returning there - but this Fire Island National Seashore made the stay tolerable. The picturesque Lighthouse is a rarity, at least in my travels but it's beautiful! It was not even really a big deal of our 8-night stay in New York. It was just kind of added because it was our arrival day and close enough to get the tourism started! A must see for the Island Stayer. A lifeguard is on duty. $10 fee per adult - kids free was advertised but upon entry to the park the sign read "no charge". Unsure about why but we were going either way. We will return here if possible!
We enjoyed our visit to the beaches and then the stroll over to the lighthouse and adjacent museum. We did think the cost to park here was rather high ($10).

My family and I recently visited on a beautiful summer day. We arrived mid morning and the beach was already starting to fill up. I thought the parking charge was steep at $15 but the beach itself is very pretty. There are also lifeguards on duty so I guess I should not complain about the cost. There is a beach concession and restrooms & showers. One of the nicest surprises is the very moving and beautiful memorial to the victims of the TWA crash. The memorial is tasteful and beautiful.

Easy to get to, easy to park ($10), short walk to beach, beautiful white sandy beach, protected by attentive life guards, snack bar, free showers (cold), and rent umbrellas and chairs ($10 each for day). Love love love this beach.

It was our first beach trip with our 11 month old son, so we wanted to make sure it was a clean beach, not overly crowded, and comfortable to stay at. It only took us about 45 minutes from Queens, and we left early so that was great! Very easy to get to and very family friendly. There were visible lifeguards on duty, two on each bench. Flags everywhere letting visitors know where to swim, and just felt so much safer then other beaches, even police vehicles drove up a couple times. It was clean, the people that were there were clearly there to relax, and the service area for food and restrooms was convenient. Will definitely start going here vs. the other options for NY. By 5pm the winds changed, umbrellas starting flying off everywhere, and the water came up to our area. We had enough time to pack up and move farther back, but would have been nice to know! $10 parking fee.

Fire Island National Sea Shore is THE place to relax, enjoy summer, and thank our lucky stars for a day off to visit. The only thing about it is the $10.00 parking fee which NYS charges - no other state charges for beach admission and with Long Island taxes being the highest in the nation, limiting beach access to paying customers makes this fee appear what it is: just another fee to support excessive government.

I was traveling on business to Long Island and found myself with a few hours of free time in the afternoon and evening one day. I decided to visit the lighthouse and beach area at Fire Island National Seashore. It was a bit cool at around 50F and with the wind off the ocean it felt much colder. Wear a hoodie or a jacket when the temps are lower. During my brief visit I saw many different species of songbirds, lots of deer and a coyote. The walk to the lighthouse was not very long and the boardwalk made the trek very easy. A highly recommended diversion if you happen to be visiting Long Island. There is sometimes an $8/vehicle charge to enter the park but when I visited it was free.

Took a day trip to Davis Park, and the view to the Atlantic is quite spectacular. Very nice, soft, somewhat narrow fine sand beach. You're in walking distance to a casino restaurant, a bar with a good snack bar, and a grill, so don't worry about food. Be sure and keep good track of the ferry schedule. Ferry is very punctual and very smoothly run, it's 16 or $17 a person (depends on your age).

$5 fee to enter. There are some nice hikes. Some interesting petrified redwood stumps and fossil info in visitor center. Not one of my favorite National Parks visits. But I nice way to spend some time.

Museum was nice. We walked out to the first few fossilized trees. We were there in July and it was about 108 degrees. Because of the heat, we did not attempt the hike. The park was beautiful and I am sure it would have been nice. It is set up well for those that do not want to take the long walk. Make sure to purchase you America the Beautiful Park Pass, it is good for entry into most of the National Parks and Monuments

Great location if you are in the area. Upon arrival we got to see the mountain blue birds flying near the parking lot. Prices seemed reasonable but we used our National Park Annual pass for free entrance. The ranger gave us a small brief regarding the history of the area and we completed the 1 mile loop. He stated there are over 14 miles of hiking trails in the area. This loop had several of the petrified redwood stumps along the way. The trail is very easy and stroller friendly. There is good parking as well as an overflow parking...probably used for the upcoming summer season. There is an informative museum displaying many fossils found in the area as well as a small gift shop. There are some picnic areas near the parking lot with a great view of Pikes Peak. Recommend this location if you are in the area.

We just visited Florissant Fossil Beds National monument. They charge $5 for adults (good for one week admission) and no charge for kids. Plenty of room to hike and great park rangers on hand to teach the little ones about paleontology, geology, and Colorado ancient history. Kids have an area to dig up artifacts, bones,etc. There is a yurt full of artifacts, microscopes, etc with an informative ranger inside. Not only is there plenty of natural Colorado beauty but a great place for a hike through the petrified forest, etc. Hikes start and end at the visitors center and range from one mile to 3.8 miles. The visitors center will give you a map of the park and hiking trail map. The trails are self-guided but the nice thing is all plants and exhibits are clearly labeled. If you are visiting the Colorado Springs/ Pikes Peak region then this should be on your must see list. I would highly recommend a visit to Florissant Fossil Beds!

If you have extra time to stop by this one of a kind attraction, do so. Florissant Fossil Beds was built in1969 to preserve this world-class paleontological fossil deposits, dated at 34 million years ago. The Monument is covered with 15 miles of trails along with a well-maintained Visitors Center, Museum (exhibits of fossils), Vending machines & Gift/Bookstore. Parking & picnic tables on-site. Location, 15807 Teller County Rd. 1, Divide, CO 80816. The Monument was developed to help safe guard the petrified tress stumps & fossil deposits that are found here. Cost is $5 per person, 16 & under free. Hours, 8AM-6PM summers, 9AM-5PM winter & spring.

We were slightly disappointed to learn that there were not as many fossil beds as we had expected. They have a museum with fossils on display and did show a very educational movie about the history of the Monument. My kids were saddened to learn from the movie that one of the early archaeologist doing excavation took some of the fossils back to London! We walked the fossil and petrified forest trails which were easy to walk and just the right length. The entry fee was inexpensive - $5 if I recall correctly and they do accept the National Park pass which is free to fourth graders.

Excellent for families. My kids really enjoy walking through here when the weather is good. You can get an annual pass for $20 which is good for a full year and for all members of your family. It's nice and inexpensive and great for an educational field trip. I love coming here for a nice walk on the trails (some are quite long) during nice weather.

Being a retired Science teacher, i was really interested in this National Monument. There is a very nice Visitor's Center. We watched most of the video, looked at the fossil displays, paid our Senior Pass, then headed out on the hike. It was very interesting to see the petrified redwood stumps along the trail. There were also informational signs along the way. But, after finishing the trail, we were disappointed in not seeing any fossils. But, I guess most were taken before the area became protected. And I'm sure that there are plenty under the ground. Anyway, i enjoyed the stop, but the husband was a little bored. I'm glad the area is protected now. Beautiful country.

Yes, they are fascinating and a wonderment. But that is not all that is here. The Park Rangers all took a good amount of time explaining fossils and answering questions. This may not be the place for children or teenagers, but adults can certainly appreciate the history and preservation. We had the National Park Pass, so we didn't have to pay the entrance fee. The fossils are mostly vegetation and insects, and they are so well preserved, even I can identify what I am looking at.

This National Monument might not be as flashy as some but it is well worth a stop! There is a very nice modern Visitor Center with informative exhibits and a movie about the history of the landscape. You can view fossils that were found in the area. It also has restrooms and a gift shop. Right outside the Visitor Center there are stumps of petrified redwood trees. There are 15 miles of hiking trails at the Monument. The .5 mile Ponderosa Loop behind the Visitor Center is the easiest and is wheelchair accessible. The 1-mile Petrified Forest Loop is also easy and gives the best views of petrified redwood stumps. Six additional trails of varying lengths and degrees of difficulty give excellent opportunities to explore the beautiful alpine scenery and view wildlife. In the summer, there is a ranger-led tour of the Hornbek Homestead (1878) in the afternoon. The day we were there, a ranger had set up 3 telescopes on the patio behind the Visitor Center and was helping visitors view the sun. Check with the park service before you go for a detailed schedule of tours and programs at (719) 748-3253. There are some picnic areas but no food service or camping. Food and lodging are available nearby at the towns of Florissant, Woodland Park, and Cripple Creek. Camping is available at local state parks and national forests. The park is open 8am-6pm in the summer and 9am-5pm the rest of the year. It's located about an hour west of Colorado Springs via US24 west to Florissant, turn south on Teller County 1 for 2 miles (follow signs). Admission is $5/adult (16+) and they accept NPS passes. The Visitor Center has handicapped parking and accessible restrooms. NOTE: The park elevation is 8400', be alert for signs of altitude sickness and drink lots of water. The sun is intense at this altitude; go prepared for exposure and wear a hat, sunscreen and sunglasses. Storms are common on summer afternoons; stay alert and seek shelter from dangerous lightning. Pets are only allowed in the parking lot and picnic area and must be leashed.

We drove down from Denver to visit this site - beautiful drive from Colorado springs, so that right there was worth the trip. However, the site itself is also very nice. There is a fee to get in for anyone over 15 ($5 per person, I believe), but we felt it was worth supporting this site.

Visited Florissant Fossil Beds NM last weekend with spouse. Easy to find. At $3 per person it is a great bargain! There are many hiking trails that you can take enabling you to see not just the fossilized redwood tree stumps, but also to learn about the people who homesteaded the area and the early tourism and commercial activities in the area that led a group to push for preservation. The monument was designated in 1969.

The fee is $3 per person which you pay in the new and very nice visitor center. The visitor center has lots of fossils to look at. There are a couple of hiking trails one of them takes you past several petrified redwood stumps. Its a nice spot to spend a couple of hours at.

Went there in May. Several very nice easy hiking trails and a few fossilized trees. That's about it. A few interesting things to see in the Visitor Center but I thought there was a lot of wasted space. To be honest, I was not impressed. Fortunately I have a Senior Pass otherwise I don't think it's worth the price. Good for a one time, short, visit.

I'm a big fan of National parks, monuments, landmarks, etc and this did not disappoint. They are building a new visitors center (done by 2013?) but still have a make shift one. Be sure to watch the movie before wandering around. It is really baffling to think these petrified redwoods are from 35 millions years ago. Ranger Jeff gave a great walking tour of the visitor center area. Afterwards we walked the one mile loop to see more exhibits. There are miles and miles of trails. There's a picnic area right next to the parking lot. It's a mere $3.00 per person. What a deal. Hard to believe it could've been called a tourist trap!!

Although this is not the biggest park you will go to, it is very interesting. The rangers at this station make the trip fun. They are very welcoming and friendly. We watched video about the fossils and petrified red woods before we walked around the park. I think it is the best place to start so you know what you are looking at. To make it even more fun for the children, I highly recommend doing the Junior Ranger program which is free. The children have activities to complete while there after which they can earn their junior ranger badge. My kids loved it! The petrified red woods are interesting and the trail was easy. There was a wildfire nearby at our visit so several of the longer trails were closed. Currently they are having a new welcome center built so they are in a trailer, but I would not let that stop you from visiting. It made no difference to us. It is a very nice place to spend an hour or two. They also have a hut outback that opens after 1:00 where you can look at fossils under high powered microscopes which we all enjoyed looking at. The entrance fee for the park was $3 per person and children under a certain age were free.

We were only 10 miles away doing the Wolf Sanctuary tour and decided to take 10 minutes to drive a little further to see what the Florissant Fossil Bed N.M. was all about. They are in the processing of building a visitor's center which looks like it will be really nice when finished. We got there a little late so we missed the fossil education in the Yurt (over at 3pm). All the staff was extremely nice and had alot of information to share. I don't know that it was so much about the fossils but more about the petrified redwoods for us. Be sure to catch one of the ranger's presentations down in the pavillion. They give alot of history about the area and information on what happened to the redwoods. We almost didn't go down to the homestead but the kids forced me and it was worth it. The volunteer did a great job telling us he history of the homestead and pointing out little things that we missed. All in all I think this is probably an easily missed placed to visit but well worth it if you're in to fossils and VERY LARGE petrified redwoods. Fee is minimal....only $3 per person over age 16.

While in Colorado on Vacation we decide to head to the Florissant Fossil Beds, we have the National Park Passport Books, and our son wanted to head out to see the fossil beds, and to get a stamp in his book. We had read a review on the website, and were a little apprehensive, but went anyway with little expectation. What we found was a hidden treasure. Our 16 year old son loved it. No you don't get to see the fossils out on the trails through the park, but the visitor center does have fossils labeled in cases. The park rangers were extremely knowledgeable, and able to explain the elements of the park. Once outside on a trail, the trail ranger came over and talked to our son, and guided us to an area in the park that was very fascinating, and he had seen a heard of elk earlier in the day. I am so glad we headed on out to the park, it really was a great experience.

We stopped here on our way back from a rafting trip. The value for the money was great. In the visitor center you can watch a quick movie which has great production quality and provides the history of how the fossils came to be. Outside a ranger gives a talk about the park and has hands on demos of the fossils. It was a really nice experience and very affordable at only $3 per person (good for 1 week).

This was our first stop of the day. It's off Hwy 1 & we went in by way of Cripple Creek. It's $3 a person, which isn't an awful lot for what you can do & see there. I noticed some visitor reviews were underwhelmed. Well, the fossils aren't just laying around for you to pick up & put in your pocket. They are actively excavating right next to the VC! The VC is great! Modern with FLUSH toilets!! We watched the film & looked at the displays.

We visited this park with our teenage boys 15, 16 and 19, they could not believe we paid money to look at old tree stumps. My husband even made fun of me for suggesting this place. I would not waste time here. Pass it up.

The fort ruins are a 1 1/2 mile hike off the South Apache Pass road outside of Willcox, AZ. It's dirt road to get there but ok for cars. All-wheel drive would be nice to have. The scenery along the road is great. Be careful on the roads and stay right over blind hills on the dirt road. RV's go there too.

Do some minimum reading about what happened and how the history of southern Arizona was impacted by misunderstandings that started here. It can be well enjoyed without the preparation, but I'd encourage you to spend a few minutes researching "Apache Pass" and the "Bascom Affair" so that your walk into the fort can be best appreciated. This is really where the Apaches Wars began. There is a 1.5 mile hike into the fort from the parking lot where you'll find bathrooms. The fort path is an easy grade, well marked trail and you'll pass good historical signage that sketches out the significance of what you are seeing. Be sure to have some water. You'll come upon the ruins of the stage coach station where troops set up a defensive perimeter after attempting to hold the Apache leader Cochise for the kidnapping of a settler's child, an act that had actually been done by another tribe, but no matter, one Indian was as good as another. Members of Cochise's family were held as hostages when the warrior chief escaped. They were later hung in retaliation for the death of hostages held by the Apaches. Its not at all difficult to conjure up in your imagination hundreds of warriors on the ridge side and in the surrounding hillsides, looking down over the valley and its anxious soldiers. This is one of those rare battlefield sites that brings the events readily back to mind because of its uncorrupted condition. No commercial establishments or bill boards or telephone poles to be seen in any direction. My wife and I encountered a mounted ranger who commented that artifacts show up after every heavy rain. The sense of history is heavy and close. Walking to the fort you'll see the post cemetery and the location of a number of grave sites. One marks a medal of honor winner. Another marks a young child of Geronimo's who had been a favorite of the soldiers but died of sickness. The clear "Apache Spring" whose water made this site so vital for life still bubbles on. You're advised not to drink the water. The trek to the fort is uphill toward the last quarter mile. The original fort's ruins are to your right as you climb the last leg of the hill and provide a good vantage to look back over the valley trail. The more massive fort that served over decades of the latter years of the 19th century is directly in front of you, and there is a picturesque American flag flying from the flagstaff in the midst of the parade ground that you will spot from the trail. The fort is large and mostly in ruins. A small but appealing visitor center provides a shady spot to sit and drink. It also has first class bathrooms. When you leave, I'd suggest, if you're up to it, hiking back over the ridge trail that begins directly behind the visitor center. Its a steep and demanding initial push to get to the top, but from here you have one of the most impressive views of an Indian Wars landscape that will ever be your fortune to see. You are standing at the top of the Apache positions during the battle and there's a side trail to take you down to their view of the soldiers. If you turn 180 degrees and look east, you can see the flat plains across which came the stage coaches and freight carriers, headed for Apache Pass. The rest of the trail offer a series of switchbacks down to the valley floor and merges with the trail coming from the parking lot. This fort site and its southwest surroundings looks more like a movie location than an actual historic fort, but its authentic, down to the horned toad that stared me down on the trail. I kept listening for a bugle. Enjoy.

I’ve been here several times btwn 2008 – 2011, always enjoying the sites and the view. It was no different this time, I went in early May before the weather turned hot. The trip was part of a class project. We were lucky that at the beginning we were met by a Park ranger who gave a short history of the post, and its role in the Apache Wars. The walk itself was pleasant, there were plenty of stops with interpretation signs and information from our instructor. We saw where the Butterfield stage had its Apache Wells location, and if you looked hard enough you could still make out parts of the stage trail. There’s also the location of the spring which made the location so valuable to first the Apaches, the Butterfield stage and later the cavalry, along with the location of Tom Jeffords Trading Post. The fort itself is in ruins, however there’s still plenty to see. There are interpretations of locations of the original post hospital, armory, housing, etc. There’s a ranger/museum/bookstore bldg. at the fort, once you reach it. The bldg. also has a wraparound porch around the whole bldg. with benches to sit on. From the porch you have a nice view of the old fort, the surrounding mountains, and the hill that you can hike back to your car on. That trail offers a different view of the Battle of Apache Pass.

Driving from Willcox, AZ it will take about 8 miles of pretty good dirt road to reach the trail head. The hike is 1.5 miles each way on a great trail with little shade. There is an old cemetery on the way that is interesting. The fort is located in Apache Pass and is mostly ruins at this point. The visitor center is manned by a great interpretative ranger who has a very good command of the history of the fort and the area. There are a few other preserved sites on the trail including the remains of the old stage stop and some Indian artifacts. While there is water for sale at the visitor center there is none on the trail so bring plenty.

Fort Bowie National Historic Site is a treasure to those travelers that enjoy American history, especially during the period of the Indian wars in Arizona. The fort was an active military facility between 1862-1894. For travelers on Interstate 10 it is a short 13-mile drive or 40 miles from Willcox, Arizona to Apache Pass Road. This is a gravel road with a parking lot at the site where your walk-about begins.

There are two ways into the park, one is a 3mi round-trip hike with a 200ft elevation gain, or a handicapped accessible drive. We took the hike and it was worth it. Passing points along the way, we learned about the old Butterfield Stage that ran thru here, the fort itself, and some of its history. Staff was welcoming and friendly, but do note, technology is limited. Bring water, good shoes, and a willingness.

Reproduction of the original fort provides insight into the 4 month layover in Astoria for the Lewis and Clark expedition. Good historical presentation of the overview of the trek. Part of the National Parks for Golden Eagle Pass works, otherwise nominal $5 fee. I wouldn't go too far out of my way though but if you're headed down 101 is convenient. As for the question asked "is parking not available" in these surveys, I'm not sure what that means. Does NO mean is is available? Trip Advisor should rephrase to "is parking available". Simple LOL

Well, it's only $5 a person to get in, and I suppose that helps support the park, but it's really more recreational than educational, or informative. There's a lot to do if you want to hike, wander around the woods, and imagine what it was like when Lewis and Clark wintered here after their long expedition, but I was really disappointed with the lack of real artifacts, and real information. Heck, not even the Fort, itself, is real. It's a replica built from Lewis' notes. I guess it is kind of cool, but I didn't really feel like I was walking in the footsteps of history. Even the museum was weak. It was mostly filled with replicas, too. The troubling aspect of all this is that we drove 100 miles out of our way to go here because we were "in the neighborhood," and it just really didn't live up to expectations. Nonetheless, now we can say that we were there, and we've seen both ends of the journey of exploration.

This is a great place to learn about the entire Lewis & Clark Expedition. The museum has many great exhibits that depict the trials and tribulations of the 3 year journey of the expedition team. It was very educational and well worth the entrance fee. As a tip, purchase the 5 day pass that lets you explore other parks in the area, as it is only $10 and is well worth the cost. There are several trails in the park and the replica of the Fort is interesting to see as well. I would recommend this park for any "history buffs" who enjoy learning about American history.

Easy to park then inside to pay $5 per person. They have a fort outside that was interesting to walk around. Then inside a vey nice small museum and 2.movies. They also had a hiking trail that we enjoyed.

My husband and I spent about an hour at Fort Clatsop National Memorial. We toured the small museum in less than 10 minutes and saw a short interesting 10-15 minute movie as well. There are very nice restrooms at the museum. A reconstructed fort is just a 2 minute walk from the museum. We spent 10 minutes at the fort. There were other trails to take at the park but we were short on time. The cost was $5 each.

The park ranger walked us around and pointed out features of the twice-restored fort. There is much more to learn about Sacajawea here. It is lush and green. It is a beautiful little park. You can get your National Park Passport stamped in the gift shop.

If you like history and the outdoors this is a great place to go and see where Lewis and Clark stayed when they reached the pacific. You get to learn both sides of the story from Lewis and Clark's perspective and the Clatsop people's perspective. Admission is free to kids under 15 adults are five dollars.

If you love Lewis and Clark this is a fun cheap ($5/adult) spot for adults and kids alike. Museum, fort replica where they wintered on the coast, movie documentary on site, Native American games for kids, nature hike with guided forest service personnel, and demonstration of firing a flint lock. Really fun day.

One of the places I've always wanted to visit is Fort Clatsop where Lewis and Clark and company wintered in 1805. I've been to quite a few Lewis and Clark historical sites and I am always amazed as to what I can learn about these brave men. Fort Clatsop is an excellent place to visit. An excellent museum with lots of displays, some are interactive, a replica of the fort with guides (although the guide that day was less than enthusiastic), a movie, hiking trails, guides that did demonstrations and all for $5!

I was under the impression that it was five dollars to park to go to this venue. It was actually five dollars a person once you got inside to pay. There is a very small museum inside the visitor center and it doesn't take very long to look at the fort.
Worth the stop and the fee of 5 dollars. The kids had a great time and the exhibits where educational... Lots of detail and great story telling.

We only had time for a quick visit. There is a small fee - I think it was $5 each - to enter. They have bathrooms, information, and a history center with a movie at main entrance. The trails are great with a few wooden bridges. It was windy and cold when we went this September, so bring a jacket from this point forward. We enjoyed what we saw and would have liked to spend more time reading the information. It's a good way to enjoy the afternoon. We went during the weekday and there were not a lot of people. It was perfect.

The cost is $10 per person, but is worth it if you appreciate museum exhibits, and you definitely get your money's worth with all the offerings. The exhibit is thoroughly educational, including various videos and sometimes even a presentation provided by a local expert. Beyond the indoor exhibit is a life-size replica of Fort Clatsop, which is very cool and makes you appreciate, if that is even possible, the experiences of the Lewis and Clark expedition. There are miles and miles of trails to enjoy, plenty of benches for resting, and we appreciated the markers identifying local flora. The only thing that we had to overcome outdoors was the pungent smell of horse manure. We visited in April, so we do not know how prevalent this condition is during the rest of the year. As is typical with Oregon State Parks, the workers are always friendly and quite helpful.
Staff/Rangers do a wonderful job of engaging kids of all interest levels as well as their parents. Costumed demonstrations w everything from hides, ammunition, plant presses-all wonderfully done

Finally stopped here after years of passing by. A wise decision. This is a replica of the fort built by Lewis and Clark when they finished their 'cross country tour' of North America. Great site. Staff is wonderful, visitor center is laid out well, there is a small gift shop that is well stocked, and it is just an easy, short walk to the fort. Stop by to see how they spent their leisure time, and be sure to watch the demonstration on the Flintlock. The story telling is very entertaining. Free entrance with Nat'l Parks Pass, or $3 per person.

This national park only costs $3/person with kids 15 & under free. The Visitor Center is small, but it has a nice exhibit explaining about the Corp of Discovery mainly focusing on the winter that they spent in Oregon. It also gives information about the local Native Americans tribes of the time of Lewis & Clark's expedition.There is a movie giving a perspective of a local Native American girl about Lewis & Clark's time in Oregon. The gift shop is small but has nice items. There is a water filling station at the Visitor's Center. The Visitor's Center did not sell water, so be sure to bring your own water or your water bottle to be filled. Behind the Visitor's Center, there is a short path to a replica of the fort which Lewis and Clark and their men built to live in for the winter that they spent here. We then walked down the path (about 200 yards) to where the Corp of Discovery's canoes landed. It has a little bit of a grade but not too bad. We did not take the trail to the sea. The sign said it was 6.2 miles. There are nice covered picnic areas close to the Visitor's Center. The scenery on the drive into the park area (through Astoria) was beautiful. Overall a very nice park.
Doesn't take long to pay this National Park a short visit and the historical value is well worth the $3 entry. The film about Lewis and Clark was my favorite part.

This was a place I had been wanting to visit for along time. I guess my expectations were a bit high because I was kind of underwhelmed by the experience. Overall this places is nice and had great hiking paths that were dog friendly, which is always a bonus. I was happy to pay the $3 entry fee because our NPs need the revenue however one could just walk right in without paying and nobody would have noticed.

We are so glad we made the effort to visit. We hired a taxi (you need to call one in town) and it cost about $20 each way. The entrance fee is very low as it is a national park. The forest area was so natural and primitive making it a lovely adventure with many unique plants and trees. The fort is small, but very close in historical accuracy. Well done and nice staff. Just arrange for the taxi to pick you up or call and they will be there in 10-15 minutes. So glad we went!

This is a great stop, not only for the history but for the whole area event. Great walking trails (easy), great foliage, great staff, pet friendly if on a leash (please use the doggie bags). Get the kids outdoors and visit the beautiful views of the river. Great for meeting new and friendly people. For $3 it's well worth the cost and it helps out our National Parks. Stop an take a peek. While on the road to the Fort we saw a field with Elk-that was a bonus.
This was cool but it's not the original. If you like the history of Lewis and Clark then you should check it out. It's 3$ per person.

This park was a great place for those who want to know more about the Lewis and Clark expedition. The fort has been rebuilt as it was in 1806. The interpretive center and gift shop was very well done. It was 3 dollars per person. The camp is about on the exact place that they camped so it you are interested in the history of Lewis and Clark this place must be on your agenda.

Very nice Memorial that commemorates the journey of Lewis & Clark. There is a very informative display in the information center and they put on a short film that is historically comprehensive and interesting...we learned a lot! The outdoor replica fort that was their winter quarters near the mouth of the Columbia River was especially well done, with very informative talks given by volunteers in period costumes. A great educational resource! Since this is a National Memorial, those with a Golden Age Passport get free admission.

Nice museum with some really nice trails (short and long). Gail was a wealth of info. Also a replica of the original fort. Be sure and get a coastal pass ($10) good for about a dozen parks along the Oregon coast-well worth the money as many parks are $3-$7 to enter.
Our family stopped here on our way down the Oregon Coast. Assuming we were going to pay about $50 for our family to get in, we were amazed by the LOW COST of admission - less than $20??

I have visited Fort Clatsop many times in my life, and each time I do I come away with new information about this famous "end of the trail" camp of the Lewis and Clark expedition. The "fort" -- really just a simple stockade -- is a reproduction of the original winter camp of Lewis and Clark and is situated within yards of the original "fort". The setting, under the huge old-growth Douglas Fir trees, definitely gives the visitor the feel of what the Pacific Northwest would have looked like to those early explorers. Well maintained trails and an excellent gift shop and bookstore add to the enjoyment of this unique place, so important in the history of our country. If one is anywhere near Astoria and has a love of history, Fort Clatsop is a "must see" in my opinion, and the $3 entrance fee makes it affordable for everyone.

We enjoyed this stop. It was raining just like it was most of the time when Lewis and Clark Expedition stayed there. The rain let up enough for us to look at the rebuilt fort which was fun. The two movies in the visitors center were very good. We also liked the little gift shop, clean restrooms and the information the front desk shared with us. We got in at no additional charge using our Senior Park Pass. The Sacagawea statue was very nice as well. Allow a couple hours time to enjoy this excellent stop.

The location is a serene setting and the replica buildings are very impressing . It's a short walk through some huge trees from the visitors center. There is a charge of three dollars per person unless you have a golden age passport.

We area glad we stopped at this area but it is probably only a place to stop once. The fort was interesting to see, probably more interesting during interactive summer times. The museum area was not one of my favorite NP area but was still interestings. Ranger programs were fun for our daughter. $3 per person to enter.

Visited Fort Clatsop last week with my wife while on vacation. Very informative, educational, but laid out nice that will intrest everyone. Cheap price to enter and very educational for both children and adults.

We didn't know if we would visit Fort Clatsop when sightseeing down the Oregon Coast or not. My 12 year old and my 76 year old father love history along with myself, so we decided to stop for a little bit. We are so glad we did. We parked at the visitor's center, and my parents bought a Senior Citizen National Park card for $10 which got all of us in. (Which we later used it at the Grand Canyon, Montezuma's Castle and Yosemite! Definitely worth the cost) and we took a short walk to the fort. We arrived just in time for the 1:30 presentation on shooting the old musket. A nice presentation with a man in historical garb. My 8 year old enjoyed it along with us, but anyone much younger I noticed ended up leaving before it was over. Dad had to turn off his hearing aids for the shooting of the gun.

From downtown Astoria, it took just fifteen minutes to drive to Fort Clatsop. Because it was an uphill climb from the parking lot to the Visitor Center we got out the wheelchair for Louise, and upon reaching the entrance all three of us were allowed to enter the park free of charge based upon my National Park Senior Pass. I would heartily recommend obtaining this pass to anyone over the age of 62 who plans to travel even moderately. It cost a mere $10 and allows free entry into any National Park, Forest, Battlefield, etc., to the bearer and up to three other persons in his/her car. It is good for life.

We learned so much about Lewis and Clark! So much comes to life through the visitor center starting with a posting of the expedition’s journal entry from THAT very day, 211 years earlier. My seven-year-old was focused on completing the junior ranger activity book to earn a badge, after which my 14-yr-old wanted in on the action! There was a live demo of rendering of animal fat over an open fire to make candles. The rain and cold temperatures almost kept us away, but I’m very glad we stopped. Admission of $5 per adult was so worth it!

The audio tour is a mere three dollars a piece but well worth it. There is a lot of walking involved. It is easy walking but it does cover a lot of ground. So glad that it was preserved for future generations. Easy to imagine this is its' hay day. Don't miss it.

This whole site can be enjoyed at no charge but I paid $3.00 for a personal audio tour. It was a wonderful look back at how our ancestors endured this harsh climate. Ft. Laramie National Historic Site allows us a peck at how the enlisted men lived as well as the officers and their families. We can actually walk into their prison with its isolation area, barracks, bakery, bar, and much more.

Yet another well preserved and/or reconstructed gem in our National Parks system. Fascinating history, well preserved here. Staff was very pleasant, knowledgeable and helpful. The self guided tour with audio is well worth the few dollars it costs. For a western history buff this is a great place to visit and we highly recommend it, but plan on at least a few hours to absorb all of it. the gift shop's book selection is really comprehensive. .
Off the beaten path but well worth a visit. Be sure to purchase the audio tour which only costs $3. This is an American Automobile Association great experience for members recommendation.

Not sure what we were expecting to see (maybe wooden walls forming a rectangle around a small cavalry outpost with guard towers and a main gate...like you see in western movies), rather Fort Laramie is a sprawling site with the remains (restored ruins in some cases) of the military outpost here. It was a cavalry outpost in the early 1800's to help protect the travelers and traders that used the Oregon Trail (not far from here you can see another site where the actual Oregon Trail ran, and where the steel on the wagon wheels cut ruts in the rocks). The sprawling site contains many buildings that you can tour (barracks for enlisted, officers quarters, housing for commander and base doctor). It got its name from being on the Laramie river and you can walk down to the river. Not much in the way of food/shopping at the site itself but the town of Ft. Laramie is only 3 miles away. The site is run by the National Park Service and the cost to get in is $3. A nice look back into the history of the wayward west!

This place is amazing! A wonderful preservation of history. All the employees and volunteers were very thorough with explaining everything and it is a wonderful place to see history preserved. We spent at least two hours here and skimmed over some of it. We would go back again. They allow you to walk into the building and they have restored the buildings and room to how they use to look. The cost was $6. If you visit here go another half hour to see Register Cliff and the Oregon Trail ruts.

We spent about 3 hours here at this fort. There are a number of restored buildings, and several that are just bare bones because they were dismantled during the time the fort was owned privately. The audio tour, at $3 a person, is wonderful, telling many stories of life at the fort, and filling in a lot of history.

If you are a history buff, as my husband is, this is a must see. Very interesting to even someone who isn't that much into history, such as myself. A note, it is $3 per person and the booth was closed when we were there, so you had to "self pay" and take a receipt. Make sure you have the correct change.....

This may be the tiniest fort I have ever seen. The fort itself is only accessible by boat, and Hurricane Irma wrecked both park service boats and their dock, so we could only take pictures from across the river. There are nature trails to explore, and the visitor's center is open. I had just purchased a National Park Passport Book and was learning how and where to have the pages stamped, etc. The ranger was marvelously helpful. When he found out this was my birthday gift to myself, in addition to the regular dated stamp, he dug out their centennial celebration stamp and added that to my book!

We had a great time exploring the fort and learning the history of the area. We especially enjoyed it as we used our National Park Pass, so worth having. The views form the fort were beautiful and the cannon demo really brought the past to life. All the rangers and volunteers were so knowledgeable and nice.

It is a National Park and a chance to use your Federal Recreational Lands Pass. The condition of the Fort is exceptional and filled with displays of the life at the fort. Guides are livable to answer your questions and someone is available to give tours to groups of adults and children was impressed !
You can't visit St. Augustine without visiting the Fort. It's a must. If you're over 60 be sure to take your Park Pass or $$ savings.

I have visited the fort 2-3 times. I do wish there were guided tours.....maybe there is one and I'm just ill informed. If you're at Medicare age, buy a $10 National Park pass at the entry and take everyone along with you for free!

Woodland trail is mostly boardwalk, sheltered from wind. Dunes trail was more exposed. Costumed rangers very informative with props from the period of the fort. Early FL history (Spanish era). Very short film, minmal VC space. Gorgeous old live oaks with twisting, long branches that bed to be climbed. Picnic facilities, free Junior Ranger program (you don't have to be a kid to learn from that). Views of the Fort across the waterway. Free ferry to resume once the dock destroyed by hurricane Matthew is restored, and I heard the contract for that has been awarded. St Augustine is very near. If we could have visited the fort itself, rating would have been much higher.

We tend to visit a lot of forts, but this one was somewhat unique due to its age, history, and construction. The views were great. Since this site is a national monument, our National Park Golden Pass gave us free admission. There were short talks in several different areas of the fort and we enjoyed the narration. The fort is right opposite the Old Town and there is reasonable metered parking.

Historic area with fort, old schoolhouse, jail,etc waterfront park with beautiful views and setting. . Many shops, good food and desserts to choose from. Don't miss pizza from Pizza Time! Rated #2 in USA for a reason! Delicious!! Shops are unique with variety, and plenty for your liking.. Fun way to spend a day.

Fort Matanzas National Monument is a short drive from St. Augustine and is a nice place to stop for a bit. When you arrive there are some picnic tables and a nature trail (mostly boardwalk) near the parking lot. You can find tickets for the short boat trip in the Visitor Center as well as the gift shop (and your stamp for you National Parks Passport). There is a short video that explains the history of the area and the fort's role. Taking the short boat trip with the Park Ranger is quick and you will arrive just behind the fort. Once there the Ranger gives you a short informative talk about the fort and then you are free to explore until it is time for the boat to head back.

We walked the whole fort and found it to be very unique. It was very informative and has been well preserved. The views from the top of it was exceptional and well worth the climb up. If your over 62 you can buy a lifetime pass to all national parks for a one time fee of $10 and three of your guests get in free with you. Great deal!!!

All other great reviews about this place are true. We got there on Friday at 2pm and it was a little crowded. We didn't realize that the only way to see the fort is to take a ferry tour that levels every hour. Tickets for ferry are on first come first served bases. They ran out of tickets and we needed to wait for an hour. While waiting we took their nature walk which is a half mile long and a little creepy but beautiful. We seen gourges trees, flowers, plants and huge spiders. The ferry ride and tour was guided by very knowledgeable national park Ranger. You will find out a lot of very interesting information about the fort and its history. We enjoyed climbing through the fort but the opening that leads to the 3rd floor is a little too tight. My husband has a little claustrophobic and added to his issues with heights he had hard time climbing to the top. The tour is 45 minutes total. Kids loved climing and exploring the fort. Also they do have very intresting Jr. Ranger program that keeps kids focused on the fort and the tour. Worth this trip. No enterence fees. Definitely recommend.

We parked in the lot by the fort for 6 dollars, 4 hours, and headed to the fort! It's 10 dollars to enter the fort and walk around and is by the water! It's very pretty and the views from the fort and hills are awesome!! Semi crowded on the weekend but was well worth it! If you love history or awesome views of the water and city, go!!!

Tickets for the ferry are limited by the size of the ferry that you have to take to get to the island where the fort is located. You are required to be on a guided tour, so you're not allowed to take your own boat over to the fort.
Free for seniors with passes (Saved $20 a couple).

Admission is free and you take a pontoon boat ride across the river to access it. It takes about an hour, but you need to get tickets first at the Ranger office. You may need to wait for a later tour depending on when you arrive. The fort is small, but interesting and if you are fit enough you can climb the ladder to the top of the fort. See this fort before heading to St. Augustine.
Passed this going back and forth from Palm Coast to St Augustine. Very cool, small and FREE stop. Very smart and informative staff, a little bit off the tourist path but well worth the visit.
history buffs....a must. $10 entrance fee but covered if you have a National Parks or Senior Pass.....little bit of walking and climbing but great history and views of what the people defended

A great fort to visit! My teenagers enjoyed the tour. It was interesting, nicely done by the National Park Service. Can visit here for free with a National Park Pass. The rangers were friendly and were extremely helpful when a strong storm came through and we needed cover. A beautiful point to take pictures!

One thing you quickly learn when you visit FL is that NOTHING is ever free, even state parks and nature trails make you cough $4 to park so I was floored when we didn't have to spend one cent to park, take a boat and visit the fort.

I arrived and went to the gift shop to receive a Free Ticket to ride the boat over to the Fort. I had some time so I went down the nature walk. It was on an elevated walkway and was not more than a quarter mile to the end. Beautiful trees and shrubs that represent a Maritime Hammock. I enjoyed the boat ride to the Fort and information the guide shared. Very much worth the visit since the Fort was an integral part of the history of St. Augustine.

We loved the entire experience. The park was well kept. The information shared by the rangers was invaluable, we had no idea about the history of this fort and the surrounding area. Nice to see our tax dollars doing something beneficial to our society.

The Live Oaks surround you, as does the history of this quaint state park. The parking lot in itself is a delight. Pay a small fee and step onto the boat for a quick trip down the Intercoastal waterway, to the tiny fort that guarded the entrance on the inlet. Learn the history of the brave men who were stationed here, and watch as the tide goes in and out.
Beautifully maintained national park. You can take a free , short ride over to the island where the fort is located. Park rangers are knowledgeable and friendly. Nice to see our tax dollars at work!

Full disclosure - I didn't pay admission, so didn't get inside.so only walked around the fort. It's an amazing sight, the grounds are very walkable and the views of the river are fantastic. It was a warm sunny day and we arrived in early afternoon. Parking was a bit of a challenge because we were unable to park on the grounds, but we found a garage, a bit steep at $12 for the day, but within easy walking distance.

We've been going to St. Augustine for 15 years now. This was our first time to this Fort. What a treat! Wish we would have seen it sooner. The park rangers are very friendly and the ferry ride to the fort is quick and free - but you can give donations which I recommend at least a couple dollars. Very informative!

Fort Matanzas is a very well preserved national landmark. To reach the fort, you must take a short and easy ferry ride across the river. Tickets are free, and are handed out at the office. Check their website for ferry times. Tickets do go quickly, so be sure to pick up your ticket as soon as you arrive to the park. There is a small boardwalk trail you can walk that takes around 5-10 minutes, although that is not a main feature of the park. On the first Saturday of every month, there are reenactors at the fort that are dressed in period costumes and FIRE A CANNON from the fort. The cannon firing was so cool, really made the visit. You can climb into the different levels of the fort and see the living quarters as well. The entire tour takes around 90 minutes.
This national monument gives a quick, enjoyable history of this part of Florida. Short video, short boat ride, and good ranger explanation of the fort. Spend 60-90 minutes and no dollars!

We have been to the Fort many times. We go every year while we are in FL. The history is amazing! It is hard to imagine the hardships those men endured while there! Matanzas means "slaughter". Many men lost their lives here in the conflicts between the Feench and the Spanish. There is also a nice wooden walkway through the wooded area where you can read about the history of the area.

Toured the Fort, Both Park Rangers and Volunteer Interpreters were very knowledge about the forts history. Relaying many stories about the operation, construction, battles and life at the fort. Tours of the various rooms offered an explanation of what it meant to live there. Check out the views of the harbor from the top level of the fort. Make sure you view the short film which adds additional insights to fort life. Seniors can buy a park pass for $10.00 which good for admission to this attraction and other National Parks.

This is one of St Augustine's free attractions. It's a little south of town but it's a nice drive to get there. You will need to get a ticket for the short ferry ride. Tickets are free in the office. You can watch a short historical video about the fort before the ferry ride. Keep an eye out for dolphins on the ferry ride! The fort is small but it has a nice view from the top. Definitely a fun activity.

If you love history, don't miss this. It is a small fort with touring in and around the grounds. Be sure you arrive well before 5 as inside tours end at that time. $7.00 per person to go in. Walking the outside perimeter is free. Great views from the top of the fort.

We were staying close enough to walk to the park. We took advantage one morning and had a great time. The boat to the fort and the tour was fun and this unique piece of history in a beautiful setting was fun for all. You can see everything in about an hour and a half without rushing. The guides were great and the history lesson was very interesting. I love places like this. Tax dollars well spent.

Our visit to Fort Matanzas National Monument was a trip back in time. This is a National Park and a treasure for future generations. Is is a massive structure with many rooms to explore. We experienced the full loading and firing of a cannon as it would have been done in the 1600's. The top deck has a good view of the harbor. Take your camera and enjoy. Price for us was $10 per person.
This is a must see while in the area. It is worth the $7 that is for sure. Give yourself plenty of time.

We stopped at this National Monument to get another stamp in our National Parks Passport - a great way to see places that we may otherwise overlook! The free ferry runs every hour, on the hour - usually. We timed our arrival to make the 12:30 ferry, only to learn that it had been cancelled. We were briefly disappointed, but after a snack break we were revived enough for the kids (ages 9 &11) to begin the Jr. Ranger activities, including a walk along the .5 mile Nature trail. We returned just in time for the 1:30 ferry, and thoroughly enjoyed the ranger talk, and exploring the historic Fort. It was well worth the stop, and furthered our knowledge of the French and Spanish occupation of the south.

Wow, learned so much early American history here. Part of the USA National Parks so if you have a Parks Passport you can use it here otherwise the entry fee is very reasonable. Canon firing demonstration was exciting and the "character actors" were very informing. As someone said before a great break from the commercialism of St. Augustine.

My 9 year old son and I stopped to visit Fort Matanzas on our way up to St. Augustine from Ft. Lauderdale. It was very well worth it and I highly recommend to visit this national monument. The whole visit is free and it's great to see our federal tax dollars at work in such a valuable way.

I wanted to take a sight seeing cruise in St Augustine but couldn't swing $17 for all 9 our our group. So...we combined a fun free ferry "cruise" (5 min.) with a fun historical field trip while on vacation. We had a great time. There is an informational video before or after the short ferry ride over to rattlesnake island. The park rangers are friendly and informative even pointing out dolphins swimming by and green sea turtles poking their heads above water neat the fort. This was really fun on our vacation without breaking the bank. Even our older teens and young twenties kids had a great time! Thanks so much!

This tour is just a nice way to spend a nice day outdoors. It's free to go on the little boat ride over to the fort and you get an informational tour about its' history. It's just such a quiet and lovely location, even if you're not huge into history, I would still recommend this. You'll see lots of fish and little crabs on the shores! There are picnic tables and a walking trial here, as well as restrooms and vending machines. I think they have a gift shop but I can't fully remember, since we didn't go in. They do ask a recommended donation of $2.

My wife & I were staying in St.Augustine with our daughter & grandkids.Our daughter was there on business & we went along to babysit the grandboys.The first thing we did in the morning was visit Fort Matanzas.The price of admission was $7 for adults & children under 14 are admitted free.As I am a disabled vet,my wife & I were admitted free of charge.This was a pleasant surprise! We found the entire experience very interesting & a huge amount of fun.The tour was informative & interesting if one is interested in the past.Of course,the boys being boys, loved the shooting of the cannon.I recommend this experience,if you love history & a real bargain,over all the usual tourist trap attractions.

I went to see the fort years ago and there was nothing to see then. Well since its been quite a few years (16). We thought we would check it out again. Still nothing to see. A bunch of empty concrete rooms. It is a total rip off. They charge $7 per adult and you can come back anytime over the next 6 days. For what I wondered. To bore yourself to death a second time. This place is just ridiculous.

I've been to St. Augustine many times before but never visited this Fort. I was so happy I took the time this trip. It's only about a 20-30 minute drive from the historic district. When you get there you take a ferry to the fort (quick 5 minute ferry ride) and the tour guide tells you about the fort. The fort itself is actually pretty small and only takes about 30 minutes to explore and take pictures. It's also a free activity to do but I hightly recommend donating (at least a few dollars) to the Fort. It's definitely worth at least $10/person!

History buffs will love this small fort, really just an outpost, in the Matanzas Inlet. You need to take a boat from the main visitor center to the fort. This is a National Historic Park. More information on the park can be found on the National Park Service website at www.nps.gov If you have a National Park Passport Book you can get your passport stamped at the visitor center. There is a walking trail along the beach, a picnic area and rest room facilities near the visitor center that is located just off A1A a 20 minute drive from St. Augustine. It is open every day except Christmas from 9am to 5:30pm. There is no admission. The boat runs every hour beginning at 9:30 am so you may want to time your visit to catch the ferry. There is a short video about the fort at the visitor center. The boat trip affords you beautiful views of the Matanzas River, Rattlesnake and Anastasia Islands. The fort was built to protect St. Augustine from attack from the Matanzas inlet. The restored fort gives you a look at what it would have been like to be a soldier assigned to the fort. A national park service ranger gives an overview at the fort and then lets you roam around but is available to answer your questions. There are several cannons including two originals. If you are small enough to fit thru the opening you can climb a ladder to the obervation desk of the fort for beautiful sweeping views.
What a nice Place. All Ranger's & Volunteers are very knowledgeable. The Fort is accessible only by guided boat tours. Hiking trails are available on the barrier island. No Fee

This is your US tax dollars at work. No cost to go on a short boat ride out to the island where the fort is. If you went to the fort in St Augustine first, you may be disappointed in this. But this comes with a personal guide who is very informative and by his answers to the questions posed, you can tell he is quite the history buff.
Great value (free, your tax dollars have already paid). Guides are knowledgeable. Wonderful two hour diversion.

This site is awesome! The interpretor at the site was one of the best I have seen. Admission is free and includes a short boat ride. The nature trail us awesome too! Visit this site you won't be dissapointed!

Although Fort Matanzas is free most of the time. If you spring for an extra $5/person you can go on the night tour. You have to check at the visitor's center or the website for availability, they don't run all the time. On the night tour you get to watch a total of 4 cannon firings. 2 while you are on the ferry on the way over and 2 watching from behind the fort. Both are a unique and exciting experience. During the evening program the fort is fully staffed with living history interpreters, so you get to see what it really was like. The views of the river and the fort at sunset are the great. There is also a musket firing demonstration.

We were a group of 4 adults and were very pleased we included this visit in our trip to Baltimore. Parking was free and because we have the National Parks Pass we did not have to pay for admission to the Fort or any displays.

I took 3 of the kids to Ft. McHenry during our recent vacation, and I will say it was well worth the trip (especially in light of recent events). The intro movie was very good, and we even got to hold a replica flag of the same size and material as the original Star-Spangled Banner while the rangers provided some good history of the fort and its role. The history of the fort was very interesting...I learned a lot about its role in US history beyond the War of 1812. Good displays gave us an idea of life for the soldiers there as well. The price is $10 per adult over 16 (my daughter has an Access Pass so it was free for us) but I think it is worth it. I believe this is something all Americans should see if they have a chance, especially if you are visiting the DC/Baltimore area on vacation.

This was one of the stops for our vacation. It is a few miles from the inner harbor so we opted for an Uber to take us there. We had a National Park Pass so were able to enter with no troubles. You can walk in and around the Fort. The canons are impressive. We had some time after we left so opted to walk the Historical Trail back to the harbor. Nice walk, felt safe.

The cost of lifetime National Park passes for seniors is going up very soon from $10 to $80, and because we happened to be in Baltimore on other business, we decided to drop by the Fort McHenry National Monument to pick up the passes. While we were there, we took in the gift shop and the introductory movie that is shown in a small auditorium every half hour or so. The movie was excellent and explained exactly why our national anthem says what it says and the circumstances under which it was written. Every once in a while there's a movement to change our national anthem to something more gentle and peaceful, like "America the Beautiful," but I think it's important to remember that our struggling nation was not only born under fire but grew up under fire and must be willing to fight under fire to sustain itself, because we will always have enemies wishing to defeat us. Because we were in a bit of a rush and because I'd been to Fort McHenry before, we thought that we would return another time to walk around and take in the other aspects of the fort itself, which I highly recommend to all Americans.

We made the mistake of walking from Inner Harbor. Fortunately, I had read other reviews that suggested we see the free stuff and forego the $10 self-tour of the fort. Good advice. More good advice - catch the free water taxi from UnderArmor of the free Charm City Bus at the stop right outside the park premises.

Every year for my husband's birthday, we visit a different battlefield or historical site that has some military history significance. This year, he elected to visit Fort McHenry, a site I have lived near my entire life, but never visited. What an awesome experience! We arrived prior to the gates opening at 9am and were one of the first cars in. The parking is convenient, free, and immediately in front of the visitor's center. The visitor's center was nicely designed with a brief movie and small museum with interactive features that will interest children and adults alike. We took our National Park Passport Book and stamped it and enjoyed the small gift shop as well. From the visitor's center, there is a paved path leading up to the Fort. There are great views of both the Fort and the harbor from the park surrounding the Fort. The park is free and is an popular place for joggers and families to explore. If you want to go into the fort, the price was $10 per person and they give you a sticker to wear. If you have never been, I would highly recommend going into the fort and getting there in time for the flag raising. The Park Rangers encourage visitor participation in raising the flag. It is a pretty awesome experience to be park of American history in that way. We did not bring a picnic lunch, but you could and it would be very nice. The Fort is about a mile's walk from some good local restaurants. If you plan to do an Inner Harbor Cruise, you can also catch it from the dock there. It was a really amazing experience. Shortly after our visit, we were at a ball game and hearing our National Anthem had an entirely new meaning to me. Thanks to this visit, I am able to appreciate it even more!

Th is is a great little national park. Filled with history, but it doesn't take all day to see, You can be in and out in less than an hour if you want to. It is only 15 minutes from BWI airport, so it is a great place to take visitors on their way to or from the airport. Tickets are $10 each (parking is free). But if you have a Senior with you, they can buy one $10 ticket, and take up to 4 guests in for free, which is a bargain. Be sure to catch the 5 or 10 minute video inside the Visitors Center before touring the fort. Don't feel obligated to investigate every building inside the fort; the interiors are only medium-interesting.

A must for all patriots and American history lovers!!! Starts with an informative video about the War of 1812. Breathtaking view of our nation's beautiful flag. A step back in time touring the fort and surrounding grounds. Reasonably priced at $10 per person.

Had out of town guests and we were looking for something to do. For just a couple dollars, go learn all they have to offer! Our history made real. The park rangers were knowledgeable and shared so much information that I had never learned in school. We will definitely bring more guests with us to this national treasure!

We visited on flag day, and boy was it good. The cost of admission is only $10, the video presentations on-site were excellent, the exhibit areas are really well done in the visitor's center, and the Fort is a treat. There were reenactors at the Ft on flag day from multiple historic eras that existed across its use. A band also made an appearance and that was wonderful. Going up and seeing the cannons and everything else hands on was totally worth it. Just a note, there is no restrooms up at the Fort, so do your business before heading up. Also take the water taxi, you have to take it from the innner harbor in order to get a ride back out.

Every once in a blue moon you get a nice surprise. I purchased my entry ticket to Fort McHenry for $10. Being 62 or older and a US citizen entitled me to a free lifetime pass to US National Parks etc. which means the passengers in my vehicle also enter free! There are perks for military, disabled, so it pays to do a little research before you come. If you enjoy American history then this is a must on your list. A 10 minute introductory film greets the guest, after that explore on your own. Remember you'll be walking on over 200 year old brick pavers, wear comfortable shoes. Up to the ramparts where there are no railings so be cognizant of your surroundings and pay attention to where you step.

We were quite surprised when we arrived by Water Taxi, went into the Visitor's Center, and found out it was National Parks Weekend, and admission was free (Normally $10 for adults). The movie was educational and well done, and the entire place gives a great sense of reverence and awe. My father was a History professor, and I still learned some things about Francis Scott Key, and the writing of "The Star Spangled Banner". Highly recommend!
If you are a history buff- you shouldn't miss this. Well worth the ten dollars to get in. Plan on spending a couple hours.

I was really surprised by how nice it was here! Video short to start the tour, a few nice exhibits and a lot of information inside. We had a great guide for the outside stroll, and he was very, very good. Interesting stories! Beautiful day and great weather. Banner line on the bus takes you right there from the Harbor area for free! I would recommend a trip for sure if you're in the area. The history here is far more interesting and extensive than I had originally imagined. Tour is free but to get into the Fort itself is $10. Water taxi will only take you out from the Ft. if you've ridden it before that day-no one ways from Ft. McHenry stop according to their rules just in case you were thinking of using it for a return trip instead of the bus.

My wife and I took the water taxi ($14/ person) to Fort McHenry ($10/ person), on a beautiful spring day. It's been many years since I've been as a young boy myself. Upon arrival, I got to witness a young man get sworn in as a Junour Ranger. What a proud moment to see for a dad and his son. There is always something new to learn. Even with the recent freezing weather we had in the Baltimore area, the Cherry Blossoms were gorgeous. See pics.

The visitor's center is beautiful. There are walking paths all around it and joggers we're doing their diligent workouts while we strolled gently along the path down to the water's edge. You can pay just $10 to tour the Fort. We didn't go in to do the tour this day due to my sore foot, but we'll return again later in the year to do the entire thing. We did however watch the movie presentation about Francis Scott Key and the writing of our national anthem. It made my heart swell with pride and I cried because of the triumphant story. I am blessed to have known a direct descendent of Francis Scott Key. My father rode motorcycles with him when I was just a young girl. Both parents knew him and were invited many times to attend events with him, but only declined because they didn't want to fly in a single engine airplane. I wish they had let me go! I also am blessed to know a direct descendant of General George Armistead. He shares his name and is also quite an amazing, highly intelligent person. This is a beautiful part of our culture that I hope people appreciate. As the daughter of a career military officer I can say unabashedly that it is worth the trip!
