I saw this on TripAdvisor and decided to visit. This is run by the National Park Service and is not as popular as many other Parks, but should be put on your "must do list"! This is the best $10.00 you could spend and we spent about 2 hours walking around the grounds. There is a great 10 minute movie that gives you an overview of events at the park. We were fortunate to get a tour by several volunteers that further explained the war and events as well as the buildings. They really made the visit more interesting. I'm so glad I decided to visit!

I have to admit that I'm not the biggest history fan, and I've visited my share of so called historical sites that seemed little more than an excuse to get a few dollars from me; well Fort McHenry is not one of those places. From the moment that my friends and I arrived at Fort McHenry, I could tell that there was something different in the air. Theres a certain calm and peace that emannates from this place, almost forcing you to stand in deep reverence of the blood, sweat and tears that went into building this great nation. As you tour the fort and look out into the ocean its almost like you've transported to the great battles that were once fought at this place. The effort and detail that has gone into preserving and trying to stay true to the reality of bygone days is clearly evident in every room that you enter. Here you can let your imagination run wild; one moment you're the forlorn prisoner held in a tiny cell, your only link to the outside world the sliver of sunshine that manages to peak in through the bars on your window.The next moment you're a mighty general drafting out your battle plan, ready for whatever tomorrow may bring.

When in big cities on a business trip, it can be refreshing to escape to a wide-open green space to relax. Fort McHenry is an easy 3 mile walk from the Baltimore Convention Center. The fort is on the bay waterfront and is surrounded by a large park with a paved walking path lined with frequent benches for resting. There was no charge for accessing the park, but there is a small fee for touring the actual fort buildings, which include historical artifacts, and audio/visual explanations of fort life, history, and battles fought. This fort played a key role in repelling the British during the war of 1812. I learned a lot from my visit. Several school buses of grade school children seemed to be enjoying their visit of the fort on one of the days I was there. I would definitely recommend visiting the fort if in the area. If you are a senior and have a National Park Pass, use it for free entrance.

We had a great visit on the Thursday of Fleet Week- no crowds, lots of ships, and a 3 hour practice flyover with incredible aerial manuevers by the Blue Angels- centered around the fort! Magnificent! The old fort still stands, with its star spangled banner, overlooking the Baltimore Harbor. Don't miss the video at the visitor's center- there is an emotional surprise ending that is quite memorable. The park ranger walked us from the center to the fort, and filled us in with a great deal of information- much of which I did not know. The greatest surprise? President Lincoln suspended habeas corpus during the civil war, and many of Baltimore's greatest men were imprisoned at the fort - legislators (so they could not sign a bill of secession) and other leaders who refused to sign a loyalty oath to the union. One of them was a newspaper editor- the grandson of Francis Scott Key! The "Land of the Free" was a bit tarnished at this time, but it was definitely still the "Home of the Brave!" Free entry with a National Parks "America the Beautiful" $10 lifetime senior pass. One of the best bargains out there.

Loved this place! The Water Taxi doesn't drop you off at the monument in the fall so I hopped off at Locust Point and walked the mile or so to the fort. It rained on my way there but I could have ducked into one of the little coffee shop/restaurants along the route if I needed to take a break. When I was buying my ticket, the friendly ranger behind the counter asked for ID with my credit card so I gave him my driver's license. He noted I was over 65 and convinced me to shell out $10 to be able to get in free to any U.S. national park--and so I did. The visitors center has a great video production and really good displays that give you a good sense of how The Star Spangled Banner came to be--and what Francis Scott Keys must have seen during the battle in the War of 1812. But what caught me by surprise was that as the video ended with the national anthem starting to play, the screen went up and we found ourselves looking at the current flag flying over the fort. It was pretty awesome--and whether you stand when you hear it or kneel, you realize that the anthem and the flag have great importance for us as Americans and stand for so much. The fort is a self-tour and it's worth walking around to get a sense of what the garrison must have been facing from the English navy. Ft. McHenry is a quiet piece of history you shouldn't miss.

We took the free bus from the inner harbor, but be aware that it is a bit of a walk to the visitor center from the bus stop. Pay the $10 and take the tour. Very much worth the money! I would recommend getting there no later than 2 p.m. to give yourself plenty of time to explore and read all of the postings throughout the area. We learned a lot and agreed that this was one of the highlights of our visit to Baltimore.

The water taxi will take you over to the Fort, but the $14.00 you pay for the taxi does not include park admission. You'll pay extra for that. They put on a nice show, but that's about it. The rest of the Fort is pretty much like any other Fort of the period. Visit it for historic relevance, and be prepared to wait a while for the water taxi.

Been to several forts and you never know what you are getting when you enter. This one was very well done. Modern exhibits in museum and inside the fort buildings. Interesting ranger lead programs, even costumed guides. Ranger at the info booth could not have been nicer! Very glad I made the stop on the water taxi and spent a couple hours exploring. Note that museum entrance and video presentation as well as walk on the grounds around seawall is free. The $10 entrance is for the fort proper.

Several times a year they have special activities and re-enactments and this weekend it was Defenders Weekend. You stop in at the visitors center and pay $10 for adults (parking is free) and you can visit the museum and walk around and learn the history of the fort. It is right on the water so you can bring some food and picnic outside. You will spend about 2 hrs there.

Relating to the war of 1812, the fight against the British, and the true facts behind the American Flag. Took about two hours, and was well worth the $10 admission price! Learned a lot from the movies played inside the historic buildings. Really enjoyed our visit here. Arrived by water taxi (just about a 15 minute journey) from the Inner Harbor. A great way to spend a couple hours when in Baltimore!

We visited Fort McHenry with family visiting us from out of town with young kids. It was a beautiful summer day. I have visited Fort McHenry number of times. There is plenty of parking, never had issue find a parking spot. The tickets ($8 per adult) are needed if you want to see the fort from inside and the living quarters from 1800s. No tickets are required to visit the visitor center with number of interesting displays explaining fort's historical significance. A short movie at the visitor center about star spangle banner is very good and its free. I enjoyed learning about the war of 1812. The grounds around the fort are well maintained with many trees where one can find shade on a hot summer day. The young kids in our party had a great time running around and seeing all the cannons on display.

We recently went here on August 6th and they had lots going on. My family had been here in the past but this time was so much better. They were firing cannons and everyone was dressed for the part. Felt like we were in the middle of a battle. Learned so much from the live demonstrations. Joined for a year can't wait to go back. Only $40 for a family membership can't beat that. Great place to take the kids for a picnic.

We decided at the last minute to stop at Fort McHenry when traffic on I-95N stalled on our way to Philly. We got to the park right when they opened on a Saturday and it was great. It was not crowded at all. The entrance fee was $10 per adult and the kids under 12 were free. The park did not have an official tour, but because our group was small enough, the Park Rangers decided to give us an impromptu tour. The kids did the junior ranger activities, which gave them historical insights to the fort, the flag, Civil War era, and Francis Scott Key. We also got to participate in the flag exchange. The kids loved seeing how big the American flag was up close. The views around the harbor look gorgeous. They had a musket and canon demonstration, but they weren't able to fire it at the time of our visit. The crowds got bigger around 11a.m., but overall we enjoyed our stop at the Fort.
Good place to visit, but admission fees is really high $10 for a small fort. you can enjoy lovely views from the fort.

We took the time to visit the National Park and we are glad we did it. Cost $10 to enter the park but it was worth it. If you get a chance visit the small museum and stay for the short film prepared to give a brief history of the Fort. Stay to the very end of the film and you will not regret it. suffice to say it will move you to want to salute with American pride. We apparently got there when they were changing the flags so we along with other tourist were able to help put up the biggest flag I have ever seen. While there the rangers were very informative and conversant. The gift shop was small but had an adequate amount of souvenirs.

Fort McHenry was one of the highlights of my recent trip to Baltimore. The park costs $10.00 per person which is very reasonable. There is an exhibit in the visitors center with artifacts and descriptions that were very interesting for all ages. This exhibit also features a 10 minute clip about the battle and the national anthem. We decided to take the self guided tour. The whole park was clean and beautiful. The gift shop was fully stocked and had reasonable prices. I would highly recommend.

My teen daughter and I visited for a couple of hours. She was free. My fee was $10. She thought the reenactors were cute. The cannon firing was interesting. It was all very self-guided, so we didn't really follow to well. The movie in the museum was down...it probably would have helped the history lesson if we could have watched it.
We visited on an extremely hot day, but is was very informative on a piece of American History. Fee is only 10 dollars and is well worth it. We would definitely go back, but on a much cooler day

My family of 4 (2 adults, 2 kids-14, 12) really enjoyed visiting Fort McHenry. It is that piece of history that seems to get lost in its importance. They do charge $10 for adults, but the kids were free. I recommend starting in the museum and watching the 10-15 minute video and reading as much as you can before going out to the Fort. Also take advantage of the volunteers who are there to fill in the details. To not feel rushed, allow 1.5-2 hours of time. If you are in a hurry 1 hour will suffice, but allow the extra hour. Yes, this is worth your time!

A fantastic place to visit. Great history lesson on the little known about War of 1812. Very good museum and history of The Star Spangled Banner -- do YOU know what the word "spangled" means? A must see if in Baltimore. The walk in and around the fort is special. Seniors -- all Natl. Parks can be visited with the one-time pass you receive (at any park) for only $10

Take the Water Taxi from the Inner Harbor or Fell's Point for a pleasant ride. It's the only way to get there. The taxi is free for veterans with IDs, half price for seniors, $14 for others, and good all day. Last return is about 5 PM. Just one of the great historical sites of America on the War of 1812, although the fort was active for much longer. Inside the fort is a great video describing the 1812 battle in the area and the situation at the time with good illustrations of how it progressed. It's in a room off the inside square. We were honored to be surrounded by a group of Freedom Flight veterans from Kansas, helping appreciate even more the defenders of our country. A group of young Fife and Drum marchers played throughout. A wonderful place to visit on a nice day. Well preserved, beautiful site, and nicely maintained. Be sure to stop at the Visitor Center on the way up to the fort to get your admission ticket in order to avoid the walk back down before going in. Cost is $10 unless you have a National Park Pass. Note: If you are going or coming on a Cruise Ship you get a great view of the fort!

What a historical place to visit. I have never felt so patriotic when I visited Fort McHenry. It is so amazing to see where so many brave men fought during the battle of 1812. To get to the fort you can take either your car, free shuttle service from the inner harbor, or uber. I walked it once from the inner harbor and I do not recommend doing it again. Once you walk into the visitor center you are greeted by a friendly park ranger. Admission was $10 per person and worth every penny. Once you pay there is a tiny museum and an amazing video to give you a better historical perspective as to what happened at the fort. The video will give you chills! Once the video concludes take some time to explore the grounds around the fort. Inside the fort you will be able to go into different buildings to learn what they were used for and other historical items about the fort. If you are luck enough to be there at dusk you can take part in the changing of the flag. Volunteers are needed to help lower the flag and raise another for the evening. The stars and stripes will always be raised over Ft. McHenry. God Bless America

I've only seen the fort from the water. It is very worthwhile to ride a water taxi over and spend some time walking around this historic site. Plus, if you are 62 or over, you pay $10 and get a lifetime admission to national parks! We enjoyed our afternoon. The cannons are huge!
Really enjoyed learning more about the history of our national anthem. It does not cost to enjoy the history center but it does cost a few dollars to go up to the fort section.

It's a nice place with a decent but small visitor center. The video they show was good. The grounds are well-kept. You have to pay $10 to walk the grounds. I walked around and saw all there was to see in about an hour. I took the water taxi, which was a nice way to get there, but plan about 30-40 minutes for that trip each way. I would not go out of my way to visit this park, but if you happen to be in the area...

Three miles southeast of Baltimore's Inner Harbor and just off of I-95, Fort McHenry is part of the National Park System. From I-95 southbound move to right as you approach For McHenry Tunnel because you will be exiting almost immediately. Follow the brown Fort McHenry signs which are highly visible and for the most part adequately spaced. The road leads you first to the Visitor Center parking lot. The Visitor Center is handicapped accessible. There is a gift shop, restrooms, information/ ticket purchasing desk, some exhibits and a theater. The theater shows a short 10 minute closed captioned orientation video. The film is shown at the top of the hour and at half-hour intervals from 9:30 to 5:30. Tickets are 16 years + ($10), 15 and under free and with my senior NPS Pass free. It's a self guided tour and there is a path to Star Fort which is about 200 yards from the Visitor Center. There is a 9:30 and 4:30 flag change, as well as, at 10:30, 1:30 and 3 PM Ranger lead Flag Talk just outside the Visitor Center. Exhibits include historical and military memorabilia. Electric battle map, restored barracks, commander's and enliste3d men's quarters, guard house and powder magazine storage building are some of the restored areas. The experience has newly interactive exhibits and seasonally it becomes a living history. The living history in the fort occurs on the weekends and the fort McHenry Guard performs drills, and musket and artillery demonstrations. They have a Junior Ranger Program which includes an activity booklet which once completed entitles the child to a Junior Ranger certificate and badge. As an adult it was a learning experience generated by reading information boards, listening to the Ranger led Flag Talk and orientation video. The pamphlets which are available at the ticket desk are also highly informative. Special event days like Memorial Day, National Flag Day and Star Spangled Banner Weekend are when all the stops are let out with services, mass, musket salute and wreath laying.

We visited this historic fort on a day trip to Baltimore with our young boys. We read on the website that the flag raising was at 9:30AM and they ask for volunteers to assist them so we made sure to get to the park when it opened at 9:00AM. There was a tour group of middle school aged children there that were asked to raise the large flag, but our two boys were asked to help with lowering and folding the night time flag. The boys were thrilled to help and made for an even more memorable experience. The boys loved walking around the old buildings, climbing the interior fort walls, and looking at the cannons. The fort provides a beautiful view of the river. There is a trail around the fort that served as a path for runners and bikers. The grounds around the fort are free, but there is a $10 admission fee to the fort for adults.

I take all of my out of town company here. There is a senior pass available for all federal parks for $10 and allows you 3 guests. The film about the National anthem is not to be missed. The living quarters of the soldiers is so authentic.

I won't go into details about the fort and history - lot's of reviews on that. It ranks up there as one of the best deals for what you get. I think it was $10 for people over 16. You have to see the movie at the visitor center before you go to the fort itself. If you go in the morning - not sure what time, you can help them raise the huge flag. But the most hidden little secret is you can buy a flag there (or bring your own) and the rangers will help you raise your flag in the same location that the flag was when Francis Scott Key wrote the words to the Start Spangled Banner. Very cool experience. Probably my favorite thing to see\do in Baltimore.

Admission is $10 for adults 16 and over. 15 and under are free. This is the birthplace of our National Anthem - The Star Spangled Banner. I felt very proud watching the video about the battle that was fought and won here.
We have a Senior Park Pass and we rode the free Banner Blue Line Bus out to Fort McHenry to spend an afternoon. What a wonderful experience.

Fort Mc Henry is one of the points of defense for the birth place of our beloved east coast of which these United States began . Take a trip back in time with a visit to the historical fort , and for an add experience visit on the Fourth of July an watch all the added bonuses the will have for you ! Feel The Fire Works From The Fort

This is a place with an amazing history. This fort actually was instrumental in withstanding the British attack and saving Baltimore from being destroyed by the English. The superiority of American design and the longer range of the American guns actually won the day. Walking through the place is almost like walking down the history of those times. Most of the fort is well preserved and there are plenty of doors to walk through and relive history. The entire area is also a great place for pictures. An interesting bit of history is the preservation of this monument and not being destroyed by development. I-95 was supposed to go over it. Then the citizens protested and it was saved and the tunnel was developed instead. It is certainly an inspiring place to visit. We loved the visit and aim to go back. Because we had a senior with us with a senior pass, our entire family got to see the place for free. There would have been a $10 per person charge otherwise to see the fort - not sure if we would have felt the same at that price :-)

I visited in mid November. Taking the free bus from the inner harbor by the Information Center was easy and convenient (they run every 15 minutes). The history and restoration of the entire site is fantastic. I was surprised how big the entire park is. Lots of families on a walk along the seawall trail or having a picnic, and a ton of joggers running along the open pathways. Of course the number of tourists were low on a Friday morning in November. I imagine it is a bustling place in the summer. The only drawback for me was there was not much in the way of Ranger guided programs because of the low tourist volume. Definitely would have been more fun if I had been able to bring my family. The visitor center displays are good and the 10 minute video is well done. The gift shop was very disappointing. It is full of "disposable" tourist stuff and not much of what I look for. I wanted a momento to keep, not a paperback book, or 2 dollar magnet.
I am a National Park Passport holder and drove down from Delaware to visit the National Monument and to get my book stamped. There's an short film shown and guided tours and self-guided tours.

I never expected to appreciate this site as much as I did. We all sing (or hum) the Star Spangled Banner on many different occasions. But I learned more than I remember from learning in school. To see the size of the site and learn about the fortitude of the men defending the city of Baltimore was just fantastic. I have a National Parks Passport and that made the visit just that much better.

Wonderful place to visit if you love American history-it's the birthplace of the national anthem. Operated by the National Park Service, there is a visitor center at the front of the park. The visitor center museum details two important events in U.S. history: the War of 1812 and the battle that inspired the "Star Spangled Banner" by Francis Scott Key. The grounds are free, but admission to Ft. McHenry is $10 per adult. NPS discount passes are available for purchase at the main desk. Restrooms are clean and accessible at the front of the visitor center. Park rangers are on hand to give historical talks about the fort. (Consult the web site for specific times for the ranger talks, which are extremely well done.) The fort's reconstructed buildings contain extensive exhibits about military life and the history of Ft. McHenry. There are beautiful views of Baltimore Harbor, the Key Bridge (I-695), and the Patapsco River from anyplace on the grounds. A great activity is the flag-lowering/raising of the evening flag in the center of the fort, which was held at 4:30 p.m. when we visited. Several people are needed to help with the flag lowering at the direction of the NPS ranger. It was truly an inspiring sight to see the flag once you appreciate the history of this place! Highly recommend for the history and the beautiful views!

Pretty good overall. The visitors center has some good exhibits and information. The $10 fee per adult is reasonable. The Fort itself is not particularly unique and is like several others that I've been to but as an important part of our history, it still has value.

Watch a short film and then the guide had you unfurl a flag and ask questions about the film we watched. I learned a lot. Did you know in 1814 there were 15 stars and 15 stripes and why there are only 13 stripes now! Seeing the original cannons gave me a how did we win but then you look from the top of the mounds and know we could see every British Ship as it tried to get into Baltimore Harbour. It was very interesting and I think younger children would enjoy living history. It helped put meaning into our National Anthem. I used National Pass .

Fort McHenry is a must see spot while in Baltimore. When you first go into the building you watch a short video clip which tells the history of the fort. There is a museum with artifacts from the British raid. It was interesting to see the weapons which were used at this time. The video and museum are free. However there is a $10 fee to walk through the exhibit area. It was well worth this amount to see all of the history made by our fore fathers. You saw how the soldiers lived, slept, and ate as a family.

We visited Fort McHenry on September 16th in the middle of the afternoon. It was a perfect time to visit on a spectacular day weather-wise. Since schools had opened, there were fewer families touring and no school tours were their either, so moving about the fort was easy. Our group consisted of family members (some of whom are in their 70s). The entire attraction is easy to navigate, with few, if any, stairs to negotiate. We saw several visitors with walkers and/or wheelchairs that seemingly were enjoying themselves. All the Park Rangers we encountered were extremely helpful and thoroughly knowledgeable of the events of the War of 1812 and the origins of the Star Spangled Banner. The visitors center includes a great display in museum format that sets the stage for walking the grounds. There is also a short movie to view in the visitors center. When we were there, the primary theater area was closed for emergency maintenance of the projection system; however, the staff had arranged for an alternative viewing area using a laptop computer and a smaller screen. Consequently, the malfunctions didn't affect our visit in any way. Visitors planning on arriving in the fall of 2015 should be aware that, at the present time, the only restrooms are in the visitors center. The restrooms in the fort itself are being refurbished - I don't know when they are due to re-open. The staffers are very good about letting everyone know about the restroom situation. The cost is $10 per person unless one has a senior citizen pass. I would allow at least 2 hours for a visit, although the time would depend on the touring style of the individual visitor. There is a water taxi service from the Baltimore Inner Harbor, but I am not able to comment on it since we drove to the fort. I recommend that potential visitors check the website (enter web via "nps.gov") prior to making the trip to the fort. I also recommend this attraction to all Americans - it is a most meaningful few hours (about 2 hours should do it).

This site is full of history. As a native, I have only been there twice in my 46 years. This is a place you should join and become a member for 1 year. You get to admit 4 adults anytime you go there. When you have guests in town make this one of the stops for them. Membership only $30usd a year. What a bargain!!!!!! Beautiful grounds and a fantastic place for a lovely picnic of homemade food or tasty crabcakes from Faidleys or G&M. What a huge flag. The films they show are very interesting for those who didn't pay attention in social studies during school.

Start with the introductory film. Very informative and emotional. Seniors can purchase a $10 dollar pass good for ALL national parks for life. We were fortunate to be there during Defenders weekend celebration. Lots of re-enactments. Very informative park rangers. Highly recommended if you enjoy American history. Lovely grounds to stroll.

We lucked out! Came in behind a gentleman buying a senior pass which gave him 3 extra tickets he didn't need and he gave them to us! Otherwise, $10 pp for those over age 12 years. Visitor's center is having a little work done, nothing too intrusive. Honor flight had about 20 veterans from Arizona there so we got to help them open up and then role the flag. It was very cool, very moving experience. The grounds are well maintained and the rangers all very nice and helpful.

Most of the “things to do”in Baltimore involve outdoor activities but this one is indoor & outdoor. The temps are brisk this week, but we decided to see the fort as it’s our third trip to Baltimore and we hadn’t seen it yet. We are so glad we did. Take the time to view the movie in the visitors center (free) and visit the gift shop. It’s $10 to get in to the fort, but it’s worth it. The buildings up at the fort are heated and there’s a modern bathroom. Great history, wonderful exhibits, really well done.

we took the water taxi over to the museum we watched a 20 or so minute movie about the history of the battle and the writing of the star spangled banner and toured the museum then we paid the 10$ each to get in to the fort. you can walk all over the fort on top of the ramparts and tour were the soldiers stayed. it was well worth the money and admission is good for 7 days. plus you can walk around the water front and enjoy the park for free.

This was a very interesting site to visit. We watched the film first, then a fort ranger led the group outside where he had the group unfurl a giant flag, then fold it back up again. Everyone in the group participated in the team effort, and it was a very large flag so all hands were needed. Then we took a self-guided tour around and inside the fort. Beautiful waterside view. We drove there and parked and with our $10 lifetime Senior National Parks Pass our party of 5 was admitted without any fees. Great bargain. We were 4 adults and 1 teenager.

We went on Memorial Day weekend and they were charging around $10- a head. Definitely not worth the paid admission. However, it has a great history and is well worth visiting if you go when it is free. Which from what I am told, is most of the time.

I used the water taxi to get there($14) Cost to roam around inside is about $7. A lot of cannons and there were tour guides around telling you the history. Some actors pro-acting the activities of the time.

There is a small enclosed building with information about the War of 1812 and Ft. McHenry before and after that time, including some Civil War information. Definitely plan to view the fort when it's not raining or snowing because it's all outdoors. Since it was summer, it was delightful to be outside. One of the rangers gave a great talk about the American flag, complete with everyone holding a part of a replica of the giant flag that hung above the fort at the end of the battle when Francis Scott Key wrote what later became our anthem. He had an amusing and informational patter about the flag and the history surrounding it and the fort. The fort itself has a few small rooms that you can enter to learn about what went on there, like the jail, and a few other exhibits concerning the fort's history. The visit would be a bit difficult for someone who had trouble walking, but otherwise is available and worthwhile for the whole family. As this is a National Park, if you are over 60, get a pass that gets you in free to all national parks, along with up to 3 guests; the pass doesn't expire. When we bought one, it was only $10 and may still be the same--the best bargain ever, as it includes places like the Grand Canyon which are otherwise reasonably expensive.

US citizens know that this was the location for the creation of our National Anthem and that is the best motivation to visit. It is in a central location to protect the Baltimore Harbor. It is maybe 10 minutes from I-95, but it is far from the center of Baltimore, maybe 20 to 25 minutes. The 200 year old Fort has a number of displays of soldier uniforms, weapons, and flags. Visitors can stand on the ramparts and imagine that they were watching a naval battle. It is old and please be careful walking around the star-shaped main area. There is a lot of walking, but it is worth it. There is a small fee, about $7.00 per person.
You need to take a water taxi service to the site. Cost a few dollars but you can also add other stops along the tour. Service comes and goes all day. We toured this site and the 4th of July
We generally visit this National Park because we have Senior Pass for All the U.S. National Parks. It has so much history and it is so beautiful. The grounds are well kept and so scenic.

A must see if you're in Baltimore. Took the Water Taxi over from the Inner Harbor ($14/adult for all day unlimited rides), but you can also drive and park for free. There's an informative video and display about the War of 1812 in the Visitor's Center. Then allow 40-60 mins to explore the grounds. You can help participate in the flag ceremony if you are there at the beginning and end of the day.

The Fort is well-kept and the inner part is interesting, well worth the $7 admission. We arrived on the water taxi from Fells Point. Only complaint was parents allowing their children to climb on places that signs clearly said they were not allowed.

A wonderful visit to a national monument and gives a lot of history. The film was very good and nice gift shop. From downtown Baltimore, take the Charm City Circulator bus for free. A bus stop is across from the visitor center at the Inner Harbor and lets you out at the entrance to Ft. McHenry. We almost paid $12 each for a water taxi and saved money.

I visited this National Monument for the first time and was impressed. You have to pay for a boat trip to the Monument. I believe the round trip fare was $7.50. The ferry is not run by the park service. I had a Park Service senior pass so my son and I did not have tp pay for admission. This is a must see for any student of U. S. history. There is ample room for children to run and play.
Take the Water Taxi to see where our National Anthem was written. The tour will take 1-2 hours, and is $7/person, well worth it. See the orientation before you begin.

We took a tour of Fort McHenry while we were in town for the weekend. If you're over 65 you can get a lifetime pass for 4 people to any national park for only $10. How can you beat that? We purchased one and spent the next few hours soaking up the history of the fort and its defenders. The fort itself was a great site to visit. You can walk around at your own pace and see as much or as little as you want. There were staff members giving demonstrations on the use of the canons and well as a Fife and Drum unit who added a nice touch to the tour. If you are at all interested in history this is a tour you must take when you are in Baltimore.

This is an attraction you must see while visiting Baltimore. For two people the price is only $14.00. The visitors center plays a short film about Fort McHenry, Francis Scott Key and how our National Anthem was born. You can also see the original Star Spangled Banner as it was initially written. I would recommend watching the short film, Once outside, you can tour Fort McHenry. Great exhibits and views.

This is a stunning historic site that that details the story we have all heard about the writing of our National Anthem as well as a courageous battle fought against all odds and won. The Park Service guides and other well informed individuals are on hand to answer all questions and tell the stories of Fort McHenry. We were unexpectedly treated to a hands on lowering and raising of the flag that flies over the fort. There are several sizes of flags that are used depending on weather conditions and time of day. A storm was in the forecast when we arrived and about 20 people were conscripted to help in the lowering of the very large flag that was currently being used. Then, 10 additional people were asked to help raise a smaller flag. It was a very emotional moment for all of us involved and a once in a lifetime experience. Anyone who comes to the Baltimore area should put this National treasure on their "must do" list. By the way, a Senior National Park Pass (one of the best deals ever) will admit the holder plus 3 additional.

While this National Park does charge admission ($7 per adult), unlike most other National Parks, it was well worth it. The site is extremely well preserved and presents an opportunity to learn about the historical significance of the site.
We paid $ 7.00 each and roamed all around the fort and grounds, it was well worth the price. There are interactive exhibits and films as well as rooms that are open, set up as they were in the past.

Birth of the Star Spangled Banner during the War of 1812. Small museum with introductory film of the history of the Fort. Grandchildren enjoyed the tour of the Fort even with the cold weather. Note to self, go in late spring or summer on next trip. Very good value for families small children since under 15 are free. Seniors (over 65) can also present (or purchase) a Senior Pass which admits a total of 4 persons over 16. Very Enjoyable Experience but should have gone a day later when it was a little warmer.

Perhaps one of the most outstanding and well preserved and maintained historic sites administered by the NPS. Ironically when I-95 was initially planned it was to cross over and have damaging affects on Ft. McHenry. Fortunately for all of us, the overwhelming public outcry quashed the initial plan resulting in the Baltimore Harbor Tunnel. You will find a new visitors center that offers a short film depicting the events which resulted in this fort's permanent page in American history. After the film and viewing the exhibits you walk a short distance to the fort. Be sure to visit the interiors of the open structures. If you do not have a car there is free transportation on the Purple Bus that runs about every 10 minutes. The water taxi offers transportation as well, however it's seasonal and was closed. The entrance fee is $7 for adults. Allow 2 to 3 hours for your visit.

While I have been fortunate to see my share of Forts in the Southern United States and Puerto Rico, there are few I am aware of this far north and with such history. It's hard to imagine shells flying through the air today or actually being stationed here, but it is a treasure close to Baltimore and worth a stop while you are in the area. The museum inside provides the bulk of the history and is where I would spend some time before visiting the fort itself. While the fort allows you to walk around and see some of the guns and fortifications. There isn't much shelter in the fort area from the sun and heat, so if it's a hot day, like the one i visited, you may be a little pink, or at least a little damp when you leave. For $7, the price of admission i was on the fence if it was worth it, but now am glad I went. I spent about an hour in the museum and an hour in the fort.

The battle that resulted in the Star Spangled Banner was fought here, and history buffs will enjoy the visitor center (free) and the actual fort ($7). I spent four hours total...but I am a retired history teacher. I found the history to be decently balanced...patriotic but it does provide accurate information as to the causes of the war and the events of the battle. A Must See if you come to Baltimore.

Went to see the fort but they had an air show that weekend also. Admission was free. Air show was great. If it was just the fort, I am not sure if we would have stayed that long. Not many things to look at compared to other forts.

We were lucky to visit here during the 200th anniversary celebration of the Fort's successful defense against British colony invaders and there was a lot going on. It was also a nice warm, sunny day with beautiful, blue skies, big puffy clouds, and just a hint of a breeze. A delightful day to spend outdoors. Security was unusually tight that day, with "uniforms" all over the place, from the usual park rangers all the way to a heavily armed TSA agent that I saw driving his golf cart around the edge of the Fort near the water and looking very stern. This weekend there were also many foreign tall ships visiting in the harbor, which we didn't get to visit. Maybe that was the reason for so much police presence. Anyway, the Blue Angels did a demonstration for us along with air rescue demos by other military craft, but the Angels by far stole the show. I tried to get lots of pics of their many super tight formations with my little "idiot proof" camera and I look forward to enlarging them and seeing what I captured. They moved so fast, up to 1000 mph, that if you blinked, you'd miss half of the maneuvers overhead. Of course, the Fort had programs, demonstrations and costumed re-enactors all over too, but the Angels were definitely "last but not least" that day. Also, the Fort suspended their usual $7 admission for the day which was nice.

We visited over Labor Day weekend and got the full fort Mchenry experience. At 11 Am and 2 pm they shoot off one of the cannons which is pretty cool to see. Also the park rangers were very passionate and knowledgable. If you are in Baltimore for more than a couple days your receipt is good for seven days. For only $7 it's a very worthwhile experience
Very pleasantly surprised by the amount of history presented at this inspiration for the Star Spangled Banner. Low entry cost ($7) and easy access from water taxis in the harbor.

Fort McHenry should not be missed by local residents or visitors! I have been several times and the movie in the Visitor's Center makes grown men cry at the end. The grounds and the fort are great for kids to run around and even fly a kite. The walk around the point (or run or bike) gives the best views of the Baltimore waterfront. In our family we say all our Federal tax dollars go toward maintaining the grounds at the Fort and it is so worth it. If only they stayed open a little later in the summer!

We have been to Fort McHenry before, but this was the first time with our granddaughters. This being the 200 year anniversary of the Battle of Baltimore and the writing of the Star Spangled Banner, it is a great history lesson. The entrance fee is so reasonable. $7.00 for adults and children under 15, free. You are encouraged to take a seat in the small theater they have where a well produced short film about the history of the Fort and our National Anthem is presented. After, we just wandered the grounds of the fort ourselves. We were there for the morning raising of the flag, which the park rangers actively rounded up all willing guests to participate in. This was very special, the kids really appreciated it. You are welcome to tour the buildings within the fort, (the barracks, the offices, the brig, the powder storage bunkers, etc) as well as all the pathways in and out, including up on the ramparts. Beautiful views to be had over the water to Baltimore and the harbor. Signs are present everywhere explaining the history and importance of the various points of interest. There is a very nice gift shop in the visitors center (where you purchase your tickets to the park) where the items for sale have a direct relationship to the park itself (not stupid junk that has nothing to do with the fort). There is lots of parking which is free. You just cannot go wrong with a visit to Fort McHenry.

The dramatic presentation that some talked about with the movie was down when we visited--broken projector. We saw the movie in another room. My kids were really into climbing in and out of the various rooms in the Fort. And I appreciated all the moments for learning in all those rooms. We went on a gorgeous, cool summer day. The park itself is also lovely. Only adults pay to get in, I think it was $7 each. There are ranger talks and various other opportunities. Plenty of parking. There is a bathroom up at the fort, as well as one down at the visitor center.

I took a trip here with my 3 kids. It was easy to get to. You do have to take 695 and 95, but if you time it around rush hours it is fine. It was easy to get back to highway when leaving. I can't say the same thing for everything in Baltimore! Staff was really nice. Film had some great info in a short amount of time. The fort has been maintained well. The view being on the water is great. There is a path to walk along the water, so you could pack a lunch or snack. We went to do the NPS Junior Ranger program. It was a good book with a good amount of work, but it had 3 different levels for different ages. Fee is $7 per adult (over 16) so it is very reasonable compare to other activities. Parking is free.

Great history, very good reenactments and the facilities are what you would expect with big federal dollars in a big city. They have a great trail and lots of room for the kids to act like animals. I can get to be a little redundant, they tell the story 5 different ways, but it is all good stuff and takes a little bit for me to fully understand all the intricacies of the story.

Fort McHenry isn't on the Inner Harbor. It's a little peninsula off the Inner Harbor. I would not walk there because it's like way out there. Thankfully they have the Water Taxi (their last shuttle for the fort leaves Harborplace at 3 PM) and the Charm City Circulator (they have a route that runs all day to the fort)! It's about a 10 minute ride to the fort. My boyfriend and I spend about 2 hours there and I found it amazing! Most of the buildings are closed off but they have facts about the fort all around and you get an amazing view from the upper walls! To get in, there is a 7 dollar fee but all the proceeds go to the fort for upkeep. The fort is also only open till 6PM on the weekends but it is a very interesting and historic!

A must see to appreciate the history of our country. Well presented history of the fort by the park ranger. Strolling fife and drum corps added music and excitement to the day. Lots of nooks and crannies to explore and an unparalleled view of the harbor. Take the water taxi to get there to get the best experience. It is a bit crowded, plan on practicing patience to get into the tight places! Definitely wear comfortable shoes as you will be walking narrow walls, step steps, and uneven surfaces. There are vending machines to purchase water and soda. Or better yet, bring your own drinking bottle, there is a free water fountain on the front right side of the welcome center! The admission to the fort is $7 for adults, however, the grounds around the fort are free! So, if you dont want to explore the fort, you can still get the great views of the harbor and see the film in the visitors center without cost!

The home of the Star Spangled Banner and a beautiful spot for a picnic with fantastic views. We were fortunate during our visit that a Fife and Drum Tattoo was being held and much to my surprise and enjoyment the Army's Elite Old Guard was on hand for a performance. Well with the $7.00 admission.

Nice, historical, clean area. We took the water taxi from the inner harbor for 12 bucks roundtrip on an all day pass. The water taxi stops in Fells Point first and you have to transfer. Then, you go fells point to ft mchenry. When you get there, you walk up to the tourist center and pay them $7 each and you can walk anywhere in the park site. It is a well maintained park with scenic views of the water, bridge and passing boats. There are no food or drink vendors but there are a couple of soda machines next to the tourist center.

We took the water taxi from the Harborfront and changed at Fell's Point so took a while to get there but the taxi was $12. (valid all day) Once on the Island/land you can walk around the parkland for free. The Visitor Center and Fort are $7pp. The line/ticket area was chaotic. Not enough space, and the line albeit short was blocking the gift shop and entrance to the inside exhibit. Once inside the exhibit (and to be fair they said you could do that bit and pay on the way out) you should definately watch the short movie. Very interesting not only in regards to the war of 1812 but the writing of The Star Spangled Banner and the history of the US Flag. Afterwards it's just a short walk to the actual monument. You can walk around the lower fort level and up on the battlement. There are inside exhibits of how things were inside the buildings and plenty of plaques telling you the info. I would say 90 minutes is plenty long enough.

We paid $7.00 a person to visit the fort and see the movie. The place was not busy and allowed you to take your time and see what you wanted. Be prepared to walk and climb stairs. Offers you a great view of the waterway.

First time visiting here and this is a definitely see for any American who visits Baltimore. The fort is rebuilt and has many rooms that you can go into and step back to the 1800's. The cannons still function and they shot one while we were there, Wow! The storyboards bring it all to life and put it into perspective. This was a historic battle and turning point soon after Washington DC fell and was burned. Shows the resiliency of the American spirit and why our great country will never be invaded or taken over! 2014 is the 200th anniversary of this epic battle and there will be a lot of attention and additional exhibits/entertainment throughout the summer wrapping up in September. I don't think I'll brave the huge crowds expected, but would be great to see the British Navy in the harbor and the US Navy and Army standing with their guns at the ready! The entrance fee is well worth the money for history and non-history buffs, $7 per person helps keep these kinds of places open and refurbished. Those who complain are the same people who complain about taxes too, you can't have all of these great historic landmarks for nothing! Pick a sunny day, pack a picnic lunch, tour the fort and have a family fun day.

The day we visited was pretty cold but we were determined to see it during our short time in town! I am a big history buff so I love to check out these types of things and was not disappointed. Very nice movie that is shown and very good displays speaking about the history of the Fort. The Fort itself is well maintained and some interesting things to see as well as the locations is very beautiful looking out over the harbor and trying to visualize what it must have been like back in 1812. We paid the $7 to tour the inside of the Fort and it was worth it to see things from back in that day plus I feel the money is reinvested in the monument so I will always pay. For others that aren't that interested in history, you may be ok to skip it. It doesn't take a lot of time to go thru so if you don't have much time, this is something you can easily fit in during a quick 60 to 90 minutes that is either free or little cost!

This national treasure is a must see for anyone. Our country has forgotten the War of 1812 and this monument and park helps our nation to remember a war that many never knew about. The visitor's center is wonderfully done. the museum and artifacts are well presented and educational as well as interesting. We were visiting on a field trip for my 7 yo who is home schooled. The use of multi-sensory exhibits in the museum impressed me and held my daughter's attention while learning. If you do not know about the Junior Ranger program, definitely look into it for any kid who is visiting. It is a great way to teach them some history while "on a mission." Complete the booklet which is FREE (usually there is a nominal cost at other National Parks) and receive a pin and certificate of your accomplishment as a Junior Ranger. The museum is great for adults as well. a wonderful history of the flag and Francis Scott Key as well as interactive exhibits on the anthem. The fort area is massive- could spend all day exploring here - and all the rangers and volunteers we encountered were friendly and knowledgeable. Definitely a place for an all day visit if you are interested in history. For families, restrooms were clean, the gift shop was reasonable (many items for kids under $10), the history well-presented and the staff informed and helpful. Fort McHenry is everything you look for in a national park. We had a picnic here but be forewarned the only way to reach the picnic area is to walk and it is a bit of a long stroll while carrying a cooler and other food stuffs. We preferred to open the hatch of our SUV and picnic in the parking lot of the visitor's center, overlooking the harbor. Either way it was a nice day and a highly recommended stopping place for history buffs and those non-informed-citizens : ) alike!

If you love American and military history it is worth visiting. My son and I enjoyed learning some new things as well as seeing things that we already had learned about. There are multiple building of the fort you can go into and learn. The staff was very friendly and the cost to go in was very reasonable for me and my son who is a teenager was free making it nice on my budget. Even the gift shop was extremely reasonable my son was able to pick out 4 cool things for himself (he is a military history fanatic), a magnet as we collect them from places we have gone, and brought back something for his history teacher and grandfather as well and spent only around $20! Most places make things so expensive he is lucky to pic out one thing! If you are into history it is well worth a visit!

We went to Fort McHenry in very cold weather, but it was worth it. The film and exhibits were topnotch, accurate, informative and thorough. It was particularly moving when the screen lifted at the end of the film and revealed Fort McHenry. The Fort itself was easy to navigate, had very good information in each section. Some sections were closed for updating exhibits, but will open soon. We had enough opportunity to explore each section that is open anyway. The gift shop had very good gifts at very reasonable prices. The docents were very knowledgeable and answered all our questions. The fee was reasonable, free if you have your Senior Pass for National Parks. There is free transportation to and from the Fort via Baltimore Transit, but we're glad we opted for a taxi. It is, of course, in an older section of the city which seems to be experiencing revitalization, however.

What a delight, getting to all about the star spangled Banner, the end of the war of 1812, with a fantastic view of the Inner Harbour. We arrived early and actively participated in the morning flag raising. A great value since I had a Senior Pass.

You can get here for $12 via the water taxi if visiting between 1Apr-30Sept. Also you can take anytime of year the free Charm City Circulator Banner Route. For free you can tour the museum, watch the overview video and walk the grounds of the fort all the way around the waterfront perimeter of the fort. You can pay $7 to go into the fort building itself. I would wait a few months before doing so because when I went all but 2 of the fort buildings were under construction and therefore the exhibits in them were closed. The trip out here is still worth it however for the free aspects of the property. And of course as has always been my experience at sites operated by the National Park Service the rangers are very helpful and nice if you have any questions.

My family and I walked out from the Inner Harbor (3 miles - one way) to see the fort. It is a nice park like setting with a nice interpretative center ($7). A great view of the harbor and nice bit of history connected to the war of 1812 and Francis Scott Key's writing of the national anthem. A great walk but nothing spectacular

Great place to visit. the displays were very nice, the grounds were taken care of. 7 dollars to get in we would have like to explore the hole place. There were chained areas, that they opened after we were done touring.we have been to other forts owned by the national park service that were done better.

Very nice place, used the free shuttle but from hotel to the fort, only issue there is the bus will leave you off outside the entrance and it is a short (1/2MIle?) walk to the visitor's center. I would not biother to pay the 7.00 dollars to see the fort, not much there but then again it is only seven dollars. Had a good time

We have been to many forts and this was one of the best. The buildings are pristine and the landscaping on the grounds is gorgeous. Take the $10 boat tour. The story of the Star Spangled Banner and the battle will warm your heart.

We've been to a lot of forts. Too many. But this one is the best one. Its only $7 for adults, 16 yrs and under are free. Parking is free. Go to the visitor center first. Theres a great movie that explains how the song got its title. Very patriotic. Then walk outside up to the fort. The fort has diff buildings that depict what the life style was like. You can then walk up and around the fort and get a great view. Best money spent in Baltimore.

FANTASTIC! If you have the time I would definitely recommend this tour. The price is right, $7 for adults, kids are free, parking is free. We have 3 kids under 12 and they each participated in the scavenger hunt for a Jr Ranger badge. It was very educational for them and fun, I'm glad they were able to learn about the history here. Give that task 2 hours. Also, we made it in time for the flag raising ceremony which I would also recommend. We were fortunate enough to be there during a special weekend so they were setting off the canons every hour. After you walk through the first exhibit inside the building, make sure you stay for the movie, I think it runs about every 30 minutes-stay to the end, it was totally worth it! A very moving experience. If you're trying to plan, we actually spent 4 hours start to finish at the Fort. The Park staff were very entertaining, hospitable, and helpful at every point. Again, a must see!
location: Royal Palm Beach, Florida, United States

text: It was instructive to learn more about the War of 1812 and the writing of the Star Spangled Banner. There is a short video, and at the end, the Star Spangled Banner is played and sung. I had to hold back emotional tears as the screen lifted, and we saw the flag flying over the fort. Just visiting to hear Francis Scott Key's song reverberate at this place, is worth the trip. Park Rangers offer talks, and we went on one that centered on the Civil War. We learned about the fort's significance in various times of American history. Though the day was a scorcher, there was a breeze from the bay and the visitor's center is air- conditioned. We were very glad that we took a detour to visit. Since the fort is under the auspices of the National Park Service, a senior interagency pass is accepted, and one can enter without a fee. Otherwise, the cost is $7 per adult..

Taking the water taxi on a recent trip to Baltimore, my group visited Fort McHenry and had a great time! Being the birthplace of The Star-Spangled Banner, standing on ground with such historical significant was introspective. Walking around the fort offers lovely water views and a neat perspective looking back towards the city. Make sure and watch the cannons going off as you enter the fort (done every 30 minutes or so). Plus, there is a nice video playing inside one of the buildings demonstrating how the British tried to overtake Baltimore and failed. Take food or beverage with you -- the vending machines charge $3 for a bottle of water or PowerAde.

Fort McHenry should be on the top of every visitors list. It is worth the $7 per person to actually go inside and tour the fort. For budget minded folks, the visitors center, including a short historical movie, and grounds are free. When our children were younger, we would ave a picnic there, watching the boats and playing ball. There are a number of local restaurants on the way to pick up food for an easy picnic. We have stopped at Harborque, Royal Farms (yummy fried chicken) and Quiznos. There is plenty of free (!) parking. You can also arrive by water taxi or the free Charm City Circulator. Well worth the visit.

We drove to the Fort from our hotel as we did not have time to take the water taxi, although it is the best way to get to the fort. It is an easy drive from downtown. The fort was great. $7 admission and you can walk where you want or stop and listen to the docents tell their story. It is a large fort and at a beautiful point in the harbor. A must see for all ages.

This is a really great trip by water taxi to the fort. Brick bombproofs, cannons, and of course our flag flying high above the fort. Our national anthem was inspired by the events at this fort. There is a charge for admission, which we were not aware of. Not the end of the word though, $7 admission. If you are into American History, this is a definite must see.

My wife and I were headed to Annapolis after several days visiting Baltimore. We decided last minute to stop at the Fort McHenry National Monument. (We had seen the actual Fort McHenry flag in the Smithsonian Museum in Washington the day before on a day-trip from Baltimore). It was a beautiful day and we thoroughly enjoyed the experience. Every one of the U.S. Park employees we encountered was very knowledgeable and very willing to share information. The fort is beautifully restored and films, exhibits and plaques thoroughly and effectively depict the battle in the War of 1812 and the importance of the fort. The "sentries" in period costumes were a nice touch. Coincidently there was some sort of "band camp" for drummers and fife corps going on for young men while we were there. It was interesting. The National Monument is a little out of the way, south of Baltimore, but is well worth a stop. My National Parks "Senior Pass" got us in free. We were able to access I-95 leaving the park to head to Annapolis.

This is a great place for Americans to visit. Guests from other countries who enjoy learning about American history will enjoy it, as well. The admission price is $7 and parking was free in the spacious parking lot (at the time this review was written). The Visitor's Center shows a film that explains the Battle of Baltimore and the birth of America’s National Anthem, The Star Spangled Banner. All of the volunteers and rangers were extremely friendly and knowledgeable. I highly recommend asking them questions about the fort and flags. They are more than happy to share their knowledge. Check the rangers to find out if/when the Garrison Flag is being raised (the large 30’ x 42’ Star Spangled Banner) as the times on the nps.gov website were not correct for the day we visited and we missed the flag changing ceremony. Also make sure you listen to the “Flag Talk” about the American Flag given by the Rangers.

Did you know the War of 1812 was in 1814, that it is the birthplace of the Star Spangled Banner, that townspeople, Army and Navy turned back the much larger British force on land and sea? It is all there and more. And seniors, for $10 you can get a US Park lifetime pass good at any US park. And what a wonderful place for a stroll, a picnic and just watching boats and ships in the surrounding water

This is a site which has great historical significantance to this country. I know that this site is accessible by public transport via the MTA buses but these buses run but any thing but on schedule. Beyond that it is a great site, though the $7 fee could be though of as a little steep but worth it. It some time to explore the whole fort not just the canons and display areas at the entry.

Exceptionally well staged and presented National museum and park for only $7. Probably one of the prominent War of 1812 landmarks provides a vital history of this forgotten conflict as the high school history lessons awaken in your mind. Check out the fort, the exhibit and movie inside and stroll the grounds or have a picnic outside. A memory to forever reside in the American heart the next time you hear the Star Spangled Banner.

My husband is really into history so I knew I had to take him to Fort McHenry when we planned to go to Baltimore. It was $7 per person to be able to see the fort. They start you off with a short video - it's about 10 mins long shown on the hour and every half hour. You definitely don't want to miss it - it gives a short explanation and it is very inspiring. We were blessed with beautiful sunny, 70 degree weather and it was perfect for this. The fort itself was very interesting and you can also walk around the perimeter which is a nice walk. I'd definitely recommend it. My husband, the history buff, loved it. There is no place to eat so you can bring food and have a picnic.

Great visitor center with displays that are not overwhelming. This is free if you have a Sr Citizen National Parks Card (one time fee of $10), can also bring a friend free. Great place to walk, lounge on the grass, read or picnic (no charge for grounds outside visitor center). Clean restrooms, little gift shop. Lots of history here, plus a lovely spot in good weather.

Fort McHenry in Baltimore, Maryland is the home of the Star Spangled Banner and the flag the remained flying during the War of 1812. This is a great place for families and friends to experience the history of the U.S.A. and the story of the National Anthem. The location is expansive and clearly shows the area around the fort and the water at the entrance to Baltimore Harbor. Also, for those who are interested in the National Park Passport Cancellation Stamps the Visitor Center is your place to get yours.
Moving presentation of the 1812 battle in the harbor and the writing of the Star Spangled Banner. Well done! $7 charge for adults.

Must see!! $7.00 per person to tour the fort... National parks offer military a free park pass... It's a large fort, different rooms to tour, view of the water and large ships. There is also a museum, video to watch, and a gift shop. It's the birthplace of the star spangled banner. Also the fortr is shaped like a star... of course you could see it better from above... there are pictures you can look at of it... and if you pay attention and look closely you can see some of the shape as you walk around the outside of the fort. Staff was very friendly... just make sure you pay before you go tour the fort they will be looking to make sure you have a sticker and if you don't they will turn you around and make you pay

I had a thoroughly enjoyable visit to Fort McHenry. I took the free Charm City Circulator (Banner Route) and easily spent 2 hours here. The visitors center is modern and informative, and there are plenty of informative signs all around the fort itself. The fort itself is the reason for the $7 charge; the visitors center is free. I learned a lot about Fort McHenry’s past – I sometimes forget that it was used even after the War of 1812 – and being able to see everything really brought history to life, after the history nerd in me went on a brief hiatus. I visited on a beautiful day and the view out over the water was fantastic. There were lots of people picnicking or just reading in the grass; if/when I come back I will be sure to do the same.

When traveling north or south on I 95 a stop at Fort McHenry is a good place to stretch the legs and enjoy the History, Only Takes about a hour or so to walk the whole Fort, It is very well staffed and maintained by the National Park service. Ample parking reasonable priced gift shop. Small theater for Movie on events that took place here, Flag they have is replica, Real one is in smithsonian. Only food or beverages I Noticed was a small outdoor stand, They do various Reenactments, You would have to check the schedule. Price of seven dollars is reasonable, they have good deals on season passes that are good for all National parks. Three of us used that and the cost was only Ten Dollars
Great place to bring the family and feel like you are part of history. Costumed guides are an added bonus with musket fire making it a full sensory experience.
Husband a marine and was excited to see the fort.educational.cost is $7 to walk around,old barracks,cannons nice view

This is an inexpensive day for a family where a little history lessen can be combined with a picnic and some kite flying. There is lots of open ground outside the fort where you can bring a lunch, play frisbie, watch the boats go by. The for not too much $ you can go inside the fort and take a tour.

Went to Fort McHenry for the first time since 1976 and what a pleasant surprise. The new visitor center is quite impressive with many interactive displays. Although I did find that some were not working and upon checking found they had been inoperable for many months. That was a disappointment! I also found out that if you are 62 or older, you can get a lifetime pass good for any national park for only $10, which gets you and 4 other adults into a park for free! What a bargain. Inside the fort it appears they are getting prepared for the bicentennial in 2014. I also had the good fortune to be there when a volunteer gave a flag talk and used the big 30'X42' flag. What a monster it is. No wonder Key was able to see it. If you have the opportunity, be sure to visit Fort McHenry!
The 100+ plus heat didn't take one ounce away from this experience. Please note the park itself is free along with the visitor center but the fort itself has a fee (currently $7).

The visitor center gives the history of the Fort, so make sure you see the movie first. Costumed docents make the times come alive. The circulator brings you within walking distance, free, so it's an easy commute from the Inner Harbor.

We took the Water Taxi from Inner Harbor to see Fort McHenry. Sat down to see a bit of history .....Story of Francis Scott Key's witness to the 25 hour bombardment of Fort McHenry by the British troopships. It inspired him to write the "Star Spangled Banner". At the end of the film everyone sang the song and I don't think there was a dry eye in the place Very interesting Fort, with very basic living quarters, and lots of Cannons. Don't forget your camera. Very nice gift shop with quite a few affordable gifts. Bought a Fort McHenry hat for only $8.99! Fee for Fort is $7. National Park Membership only $10.

This monument is one of Baltimore's great claims to history, since there wasn't much going on here in either the Revolution or the Civil War. But the Battle of Baltimore during the War of 1812 was arguably the turning point in that war. Visitors who come to the recently-renovated Visitors' Center can get an overview into the story behind Francis Scott Key's composition. You can tour most of the grounds for free--in fact, many people come down to picnic or walk along the seawall--but if you want to get into the Fort itself and take that tour (worth it!), it's currently $7.00 for people 16 and up (15 and under are free). That fee actually gives you free entrance to the Fort for a week, though you won't need more than a couple of hours altogether. The Interagency Annual Pass, which can be used to get into many national parks and monuments, is honored here. Pets are welcome on the grounds but not in the Fort area.

This June (2012) marks the beginning of a two year Bicentennary celebration of the War of 1812 (-15). The newly refurbished visitor's center readies the visitor for a truly stirring historical lesson of the events leading up to and following the composition of the American national anthem. Original documents and artifacts capture what might be just another story of the political sqabblings between jealous "cousins" so many years ago. But the story unfolds in the small amphitheater on a wide screen . . . and, as it lifts, you hear the words sung so beautifully with the flag (15 stars and stripes) flying over the fort. I am drawn each time I'm in Baltimore to this place as it reminds me that all citizens, regardless of their political leanings or disaffections, can renew the conviction that we share in the bounty of a long tradition of idealists willing to give limb and treasure for the rights that should be the birthright of all humans. Take a free shuttle (Charm City Circulator, Blue Line) to the park, entry Fee $7 for non-senior adults, and tour the ramparts , etc.

We recently visited Fort McHenry and found it to be very interesting. The guides were all very informative. When you enter the park you enter through a single archway. The stop sign is almost directly at the entrance. Upon leaving via the same arch, again the stop sign is directly at the entrance making the single lane difficult for ingress and egress. As we left, a car was coming in so we stopped farther back from the sign. once the car passed, we made our way through the arch. We were immediately stopped by a park ranger who clearly was parked on the other side of the arch waiting to ticket people. She was not an asset to the park with her surly attitude, and even though my husband hadn't had a ticket for over 20 years, we were issued a federal citation with a total charge of $115.00, being told that they take their stop signs very seriously. Obviously they do...figuring on 10 hours of park operation and 4 citations per hour they are pulling in about $5000.00 a day in stop sign violations. If the entrance was laid out better I wouldn't be so angry but it is very confusing and of course you can fight the ticket, but it costs you more than paying it if you are out of state. So do yourself a favor and stop at the signs at the gate where it is safe and where the signs actually are posted to save yourself money and aggravation.

The free exhibits were very well designed, including more technology (touch screen displays, audio, etc) than most national parks. Topics covered included the War of 1812, the Star Spangled Banner, and the fort. Entry to the fort itself is $7 per person but worth a look into the past and the war. The guided tour by the park rangers was very well thought out and enlightening but if you get Vince don't listen to his assertion that the tour will run for 30 minutes because he is full of information and ran way long while we were there. In addition to the cool history at the fort there is a decent view of the river as well.

This is the one place in Baltimore that I make sure to bring any visitors. The initial exibit movie is inspirational and when the curtains pull back to see the actual fort, it is very moving. Check out the Rangers as several were in the reenactment portrayed in the film. Check the website and go on a day when there are living history guides. There are lots of volunteers who dress in period costume and are fantastic at answering questions. I learned "How do you sit in a hoop skirt?". Admission is $7, but with a $40 membership, you can bring guests for free.

We have been here before, but wanted to come back during our visit for the Sailabration to see the new visitor's center, which is greatly improved. Be sure to see the film--which plays every 30 minutes--that ends with the playing of the National Anthem with the Star-Spangled Banner flying in the background at the fort. It will give you goosebumps. Exhibits are good, though viewing area is small and gets cramped if large crowd. The $7 entry fee is good for two days, so you can view the visitor's center one day, then come back and tour the fort the next day.

Lovely fort with great views over the water. They had knowledgable costumed curators and people dressed up as soldiers of the period, complete with guns. The exhibit about archeology done in the area was particularly interesting. Surrounded by a large public park, I commented to my husband as we left that I would picnic there every weekend if we lived in Baltimore. Had a great time and I reccomend it. The gift shop had a lot of nice knickknacks and I confess I have been playing with the little silver cannon I bought. As a bonus for those who are staying in the area longer, your $7 admission fee is good for 7 days. So you can come back to enjoy more history!

I enjoyed a hour and half visit to Fort McHenry. As I did not have a car I took the water taxi from Fell's Point which goes directly to and from Fort McHenry which was nice. The water taxi is $12 for the entire day so you can use it to take to other locations. There were plenty of park rangers and volunteers on the Fort's grounds to answer questions and make you feel welcome. The signage and displays were very interesting and informative. A wonderful experience that made history come alive and definitely worth your time for a visit. I arrived at noon and left at 1:30 p.m. on an April Saturday afternoon and the grounds did not feel crowded. I noticed a lot more people coming onto the grounds of the Fort as I was leaving. The National Park Service waived the normal entrance fee on the day I was there as it was National Parks Week - nice!

Lovely day to visit the fort. GPS did its own thing and getting there was not that smooth. Lack of street direction signs. Detour problems. Two unnecessary trips across a toll bridge ($3ea), with unpleasant money takers.

Amazing place! Incredible views. Great history lesson. Well maintained (although the movie projector wasn't working when we went). Great access to the grounds and buildings. Cheap entrance fee (free if you're or someone you're with is handicapped--they just need to sign an affidavit and will receive a card which can be used at any monument or historic site throughout the country). Free parking. Short drive from Baltimore Harbor. Friendly staff and rangers.
I have been to much more dynamic and interesting historical buildings, but it was pleasant and open. Not much to really see but the price is right--$10 entrance fee.

Wonderful site and film is very well done. Provides not only the history of the Star Spangled Banner but also of the use of the Fort and site in the subsequent years. Pay particular attention to the photos spread throughout the Fort. The Fort also provides a nice place to walk and view downtown from across the harbor.

The Visitors' Center should be your beginning point. Check out the displays and the film depicting the War of 1812 battle which led to Francis Scott Key writing our national anthem in 1814. Be prepared for a "lump in your throat" feeling when the film ends, the screen reels up into the ceiling, the Star Spangled Banner begins playing, and you're actually looking out at our national flag being flown at Fort McHenry itself. Feel free to stroll the beautiful, well-maintained grounds on the way to the Fort. Although the upper level of the fort is not really wheelchair-accessible, the grounds and the Visitors' Center are fully accessible. My elderly father who uses a wheelchair thoroughly enjoyed the visit. We visited on Memorial Day and were able to view the flag-raising of a replica 1814 national flag over the fort. The whole experience made one proud of our country. And, be sure to visit the gift shop in the Visitors' Center.
We visited the fort on a saturday morning. We took the water taxi over from Fells Point ($10 to ride it all day). It wasn't too crowded.
If you have any interest in history at all, this is a must see. The vistor center exhibits and short movie are FREE; admission to the Fort itself is $7 and well worth it.

My fiance and I visited Baltimore over the 4th of July specifically to visit Fort McHenry, birthplace of Francis Scott Key's “The Star Spangled Banner”. We chose to watch the short film in the visitor's center before touring the fort and we are so glad that we did. It is so moving and powerful. They did an incredible job with the film and the way it is presented. Especially the end (but we're not giving the end away here!). The visitor's center and film are free and the fort entrance fee is only $7 per adult. A “cheap date” at less then the cost of a movie and so much more fun.

Ft. McHenry is located on the outskirts of the Inner Harbor, just past Federal Hill in Baltimore.
