You could walk it if you are staying in the Inner Harbor but there is plenty of parking at the fort and no fee for parking. As of 9/7/09, the entrance fee into the park was $9/person (kids are free) and there is no military discount (although there was one for seniors). The visit starts with a 15-minute film giving you the history of the fort. I think the film runs every 30 minutes or so. And then it is a self-guided tour around the fort. There are plenty of information plaques located in strategic places explaining the battle. There are also cannons and cannon balls still located on the grounds. They ask that you not climb the bunkers but there are paths on top that you can walk. It is a very well-maintained park with lush green grass on the earthworks and beautiful brick paving. They even have motion-detected audio guides that activate when you walk into one of the rooms and gives you a short history of the room. We spent about 2 leisurely hours at the fort. There is also a gift store and restrooms on the grounds. For me, it was similar to Ft. Sumpter.

Me and my wife visited this place on Labor Day weekend. You can drive to this place or you can take Ed Kane's Water Taxi from Inner Harbor (or from Harbor East). Its a 20-25 minutes relaxed water taxi ride to the fort. There is a 7$ entry fee (if you want to enter in the fort). If you just want to explore the park surrounding the fort, you can do that for free. There is a 20 minutes (I think) video that shows the history of the fort and there are few exhibits too in the Visitor Center. We skipped that and purchased 2 tickets to visit the fort. I am no history buff but I absolutely loved the fort, especially the various barracks, weapons and uniform displays. We were able to spend good 3 hrs. The outdoor area surrounding the fort is a great place to sit and relax. We saw many locals jogging and spending there afternoon in the park.

Fort McHenry is an absolute must if you are in or around Baltimore. We visited specifically to go to this piece of history, and we were so glad we did. It is located in a beautiful setting, and don't miss the video. Pay the entrance fee as the tour is informative and inside the fort is interesting. Allow enough time; we were there over two hours because we took the time to read the exhibits and watch the videos. One of the best parts: you can actually purchase a flag in the gift shop and have it flown over Fort McHenry. We bought the 15-star flag (like the original star-spangled banner) and they gave us dated, printed certificate and ribbon certifying it had been flown over the fort. They prepared the certificate in the visitor's center while a ranger walked out with us to fly the flag. My husband got to fly the flag himself (with the help of the ranger). This is not something that is widely publicized, so ask in the gift shop. It was an awesome souvenir for $50, one we will display proudly.

We took the water taxi to Ft. McHenry 6/1/09 and it was very convenient, although extremely windy and cold at 10 a.m. on the boat. See the movie first so you get an overview of the story of the fort---the end is a very moving experience. If you have a Senior Pass for the National Parks you and 3 people can get in for free. It doesn't take long to walk around, maybe an hour. We didn't see any place to buy lunch and noticed kids on school trips brought their own food to eat. If you need a refresher course in the history of the U.S. and renew your patriotism, this is a great place to visit!

Visited Fort McHenry in mid November 2008. The fort is well preserved. But more importantly, the park rangers and exhibits do an excellent job of telling the story of the battle. The scale model of the fort in the visitor's center was invaluable in helping understand the battle, the direction of the British attack and where Francis Scott Key was witness to the bombardment. I recommend that you start your tour at the visitor center scale model before heading up to the ramparts and guns. Ft. McHenry was Union occupied throughout the civil war and stood guard over some Confederate POWs and a pro Confederate city of Baltimore. Many civil war cannons are also on display. The fort is a very long walk or a short cab ride from the Inner Harbor. We chose the cab ride. $9 plus tip each way. In addition, a water taxi services Ft McHenry during the warmer months. Be a better American, visit Fort McHenry and understand our unique American History.

Right off of I-95 it's a nice break for a long road trip. I thought the $7 admission was ridiculous though, and with a bit of research beforehand (wikipedia) you can get the same experience walking around the fort and save the money. You won't be missing much inside.

If you are in the area, you must see Fort McHenry!! A treasure to learn how our National Anthem, the Star Spangled Banner, came to be. It's value priced at $7.00/per person. Well worth it. Stop first at the Visitor's Center to see the introductory film about the Fort. There is a surprise at the end!! Inside the fort, you can go into the buildings and learn more about the daily lives of the soldiers. The very best time to go is later in the afternoon. The last water taxi leaves for the fort at 3:00 p.m. You can also drive there. We got to participate in the experience of lowering the flag, which they do around 4:00 The park ranger was very informative as we helped with this honor.

I was only planning to listen to the movie in the visitor center and walk the perimeter path . . but I paid my $7.00 and toured the fort. As a Naval Veteran this place made me proud. The only bad thing is that people watching the movie did not stand for the National Anthem at the end of the movie. My fellow sailors and I stood and saluted. . . what a great American Icon.

I've lived in the Baltimore area for 20 years and recently visited Ft McHenry for the first time. The visitors center is very nice - the movie is very moving and a must see. We really enjoyed touring the fort and learned a lot of neat facts by reading the informational signs posted everywhere. It costs $7 for adults to enter the fort, but is money well spent.

This place is really cool. They have tried to preserve it the best they can. It's really cool to see almost all three sites of this fort. They have the star shaped earthen fort the one closer to the mountains that you can see but cannot get to I'm almost certain it's on private property and then the ruins you can walk through. You have part of the Santa Fe trail that runs through here in a couple of spots I can imagine stopping here after a long bumpy ride on a wagon. I do wish they would do a audio tour for the times when you have no rangers do tours that could be accessed by phone or tablet or by paying a few dollars to rent an audio device to get a better overview but really it's awesome to see & I'm glad we have saved it. Just a side note all roads to this location are paved. The path might work for walking it's crunchy gravel so no wheelchairs are stroller at least I wouldn't think you would use them. If I ever make it back here I would go again.

I visited early on a weekday morning which is an excellent time to go-cooler and no traffic. I enjoyed the eight mile drive on Hwy 161(Interstate-25 exit 366) to the site. The colorful and variety of flowers blooming rivaled the Hill Country in Texas when the bluebonnets are in bloom (ranger said because of all the rain the area had this Spring, flowers are blooming that they have not seen in years). I drove with my window down and could hear the meadowlarks singing as they sat on fence posts. Several pronghorn antelope were also out. In the distance snow-capped mountains were visible. It was a spectacular drive with interpretive signs along the way including some for the ruts left by travelers on the Sante Fe Trail which are the most visible of any along the trail and are easily accessible. The eastbound travelers had to decide here whether to take the Cimarron Route (most did) which was shorter and quicker but was hotter and water was scarce or take the Mountain Route over Raton Pass which had more water but was subject to Indian raids and was treacherous.

We were attracted to Fort Union from I-25 near Watrous, NM by the sign that indicated that Wagon Wheel Ruts from the westward journeying wagon trains could still be seen here. They alone were worth stopping for. Eight miles further west along a well kept road lies the fort itself. At first it's quite distant and one had the feeling of how it must have been for the men of the day arriving there. There is a very nice Visitors Center with ample parking, picnic grounds, a gift shop and theater where an historical film can be viewed. And clean, well kept restrooms. And then one is free to wander the grounds. Fort Union was historically significant because it was located far enough away from the city (Santa Fe) to keep the men from wandering, and close enough to the Indians. In 1862, the Army and the Fort's location were instrumental in halting a Confederate Army invasion at the battle of Glorieta Pass.

The visitor center has a 15 minute film with a brief history of Fort Union narrated in an engaging manner. By all means watch this film first! Self-guided walking tour with a long and short version. Some of the best photo ops are in the Mechanics Corral (toward the rear of the complex) old wagons and wagon wheels stand inside the corral. The is a $3 per person entrance fee unless you have a National Parks pass. When driving north on I-25 you are on top of the Fort Union exit before you know it. (yes. . . we missed the exit, had to use the "official use only" cut-thru to turn around) After exiting, it is 8 miles to the Fort.

While the ruins are relatively new, the look like remnants of a distant era and they are. American history is so dynamic…. At some point, more than 4000 soldiers and civilians lived here, and now it is a ghost town. The location is spectacular. The view are astounding. A pleasant walk of 1.6 miles allows to "take the place in" and it is really worth it. $3/person, free to National Park pass holders. So glad to have seen it. A well kept place, and a memorable experience.

The visitors center was very nice and featured much interesting information. The rangers were very knowledgable and friendly. We bought a National Park Passport booklet and have started seeing National Park sites already. Adding stamps is fun and educational. We loved walking around the old fort and hospital along with the walking tours.

Ft Washington Park is a great place to spend a day. For kids there are plenty of options to keep them busy. Be it learning a piece of history, fun games in sprawling grounds, fishing, biking, stunning vistas of the river, this place has everything to spend a whole day. Entry fee of 5$ per vehicle and valid for 3 days.

It's hard to complain about a park. You go for some nature, relaxation, hikes. I don't really know how you could go to a park and be disappointed. This park might disappoint some on the historical aspect. I guess. I'm not a history buff but the fort was pretty cool to wander around. Unlike some places for the most part this was very open. Allowing you to get good views of the nooks and crannies. I was there on a Thursday and there weren't many people at all walking around. As a matter of fact, I felt alone there most of the time. It was cool and fun. After checking out the fort there's a lighthouse down by the river edge. Some people were fishing on the banks. Plenty of spots to crash and have a nice picnic lunch. I decided to hike the river trail. It's a pretty easy hike. Although there were one or two steep hills and at one point a fallen tree was blocking the trail. I had to climb over it. Pretty good hike through some dense woods. Again, there was no one around this day so was really a nice hike. All in all if you're in the area and wanna chill out by the river you can't do much better. I got dropped off and the fee was $3 to enter. I think it's $5 if you drive in.

During peak months it costs only $5 for a parking pass, which is good for 3 days, to enter the park. This is super cheap entertainment! (off season there is no charge at all for parking, so it is free!) We bring our 2 kids, ages 6 and 2 years old, and usually pack a picnic lunch. The kids love running around the old fort, visiting the small museum, running around the Potomac River and just burning some energy. This is a great place to fly a kite too, as it is almost always windy! Check out their website for activities. We showed up one day and got to see volunteers dressed up in full uniform, and they were giving out snacks!
If you're in the area this is a must see! Cheap $5 per car. Magnificent views from a very impressive old stone fort on the river! Go there'bn
By far the best fort we saw in the DC area. So glad we stopped by. Rolling hills and free to explore. Well worth the $5.00 car full fee.

This National Park showcases the historic Fort with its unusual moat, drawbridge, high stone walls, and cannons, built by the new American nation for protection against a British invasion and used intermittently by the military until World War II. The scenery of the Potomac River shoreline is beautiful, with views across the River to Mount Vernon, Va. and northward to downtown D.C. in the distance. The park has a circular, flat roadway excellent for hiking, skating, or bicycling. There are picnic areas, fishing, a lighthouse, a small playground and basketball court. Improvements were recently made to the shoreline hiking trail (which few people know about) which follows the River from the lighthouse southward. There is a tiny bookstore and museum open limited hours. Admission is free after 5:00 until sundown, and at most times in winter. Otherwise an admission fee.

After checking out Fossil Safari (or if you don't go to Fossil Safari go here anyway), make sure you head over to Fossil Butte National Monument. It is a small museum, but they have terrific fossils that were found right around the area. They had some plates of fish catastrophes (lots of dead fish) that were amazing. They also had some fossil ferns that looked like art (note, we saw a similar size fern fossil in Park City and it was listed at $88,000). The rangers were incredibly friendly and engaging. It is definitely worth the extra fifteen minute drive.

George Rogers Clark's brave and clever troop movements in the Revolutionary War saved the Midwest for the new United States. The video in the visitor center gives the inspirational story. Rangers will take you on a half-hour tour of the amazing monument which was built just before the Great Depression and was dedicated by FDR in 1933. No one could afford to build such a monument today (inlaid marble floors, murals, statues). It would take almost a billion dollars today.
park: George Rogers Clark National Historical Park

text: It is an interesting place but there is not much there unless you go when they are having an reenactment. Then you can spend the whole day they have earphones that you ware that are like a guided tour of the place and history. They have a flea market but that was to expensive to go in at $ 7.00 and is very small I passed on it, But the rest is worth the trip there
park: George Rogers Clark National Historical Park

text: My wife and I stay in Silver City NM in a AirBnb. This was March 7. We woke up and had breakfast and went to Diane's Bakery to pick up sandwiches for our lunch. We wanted the freedom to be able to stop when ever/where ever we wanted to have lunch as we traveled to Gila Cliff Dwellings. We took 15 out of Silver City starting at 9am. The road was in great condition. There was also very little traffic. Great views. We pulled off at most of the view points that posted. Took lots of photos. There was just a little bit of snow visible on the hill sides at times. We eventually got to the visitor center for the Cliff Dwellings. They showed a short, helpful video of the area and the history story. The rangers behind the desk were very helpful as well. It costs $10 per car to visit the dwellings. You don't pay at the visitor center, you pay right at the parking spot by the dwellings. There is a metal box to put your money in. As we drove from the visitor center to the cliff dwelling parking lot (only a few miles, we decided to pull off at picnic area along the road. They had nice cement picnic tables. With great views of the area. Lovely spot. Birds singing, deep blue skies. Temps were still cool probably around 60. We then drove the rest of the way to dwellings. Park our car and walk up to the small ranger staging area. Payed our 10 dollars and listened to a short talk from the ranger. Guidelines about walking the trails etc. My wife and I then began the walk. Very nice trails to walk on. Sometimes a little steep. We are both mid 50's in age. Decent health. We did not have any problems on the hike to the cliff dwellings. We had took advantage of the ranger lady who was stationed up in the dwellings. She was very knowledgeable and friendly. Greatly increased our overall experience. The whole hike experience took just over and hour and half. But we took our time taking photos. I would highly recommend this site and overall road trip. We came back by way of 35 to 61 which took us to the City of Rock State Park. It is a fascinating spot. Of this massive standing stone out in the middle of no where. Very cool. We then caught 180 back to Silver City. Total trip was from 9am to 6pm.

The Gila Cliff Dwellings has been a National Monument since 1907. About 1 1/2 hours north of Silver City, NM, either up a winding Rt 15 or perhaps 30 minutes more via Rt 35 through an interesting valley. Well informed National Park Service rangers and volunteers. Occupied in the late 1200's AD. Well-stocked book store and visitor center, ample parking, many campsites. Nearby is a trading post for lunch and relaxing hot springs - $5 each person.

I won't say put it on your bucket list, but I will say that if you are traveling in this area then it is a must see. I have been here twice now. Once when a girlfriend and I stumbled on it and then again when I took my family to explore it with me. We were on a road trip and I knew it was something I wanted my kids to experience. This is a very historical place loaded with a wealth of information. It is a small hike up, nothing strenuous in my opinion. The dwellings are great. You have to listen to the guide and try to imagine what it was like. It is beautiful to see from the ground and from the top. Give yourself enough time to explore on the walk up and at the dwellings. I think it is great that they have a place to leave your dog in at the information booth. It gets hot and since I had been there before I knew to make sure I had sunblock on, bug spray and good walking shoes before locking car doors. You need cash to enter, as you put your payment into an envelope and slip it in the box if no one is around. The drive up to the cliffs area is amazing, a definite wow factor.

Our experience at the monument was great. The 1/2 mile hike through the dwellings is worth the drive to the monument. The volunteers were so helpful. We really appreciated the free dog kennels available at the trail head. There is a $3 fee per person fee but with a Senior Pass myself and 2 other adults were free.

The cliff dwellings are very nice. The walk is easy, and the small natural history museum is very informative. During the summer months, the cliff dwellings may close when lightning is in the area. For this reason, it is best to get there early in the morning, before the afternoon rains. The road (15) to there is very wlnding, and takes about two hours to travel the 39 miles from Silver City, but the scenery is beautiful. A really good place to stay and camp is Gila Hot Springs-approximately 4 miles before the cliff dwellings. There are 3 well maintained pools, tables, drinking water, and an outhouse. Trash cans are not available at the hot springs or at the cliff dwellings. Pack it in, pack it out. The camp fees at the springs are; at this time; $5.00 a night per person, $4.00 per person for a day soak. Check their website for more information. There is small store nearby that sells ice, basic supplies, gifts, and homemade ice cream. This is a nice place to stay and unwind if you are wanting more than a day trip to the Gila Cliff Dwellings. Motor homes, and large rigs are not recommended for S.R. 15, as it is narrow and very twisty. S.R. 35 to 15 avoids some, but not all, of these turns. These attractions are best done in a car. Tent camping in all camp grounds off S.R. 15 is recommended. Have fun, and take plenty of time to enjoy this lovely and historic part of New Mexico.

First a word of warning: flooding in January 2010 washed out the approach to the bridge that carries you between the visitors center and the trailhead. Thus, until the road is repaired, you must park next to the stables and walk the last mile along the road to the begining of the trail. That means a three mile walk instead of a one mile walk. The walk along the road is flat and easy and should not present too much difficulty to most people. Just thought you should know. (While the bridge is out of service, they are waiving the $3 entry fee.)

Very interesting historical site and well worth the mile hike. My wife and I are both 66 and not in great shape, but we made it. The history is fascinating and the rangers do a great job with details and making it even more interesting. Be sure to visit the Visitor Center first. If you are over 62, ask about the lifetime National Park pass for only $10, which is the same priced as entrance to the Cliffs. If you are in the area, this is a just do, but plan an hour and half to make the 44 mile drive from Silver City; the road is very curvy and mountainous.

I didn't give this park a fair shot. It was a terrible day and I had no desire to be outside for the guided tour, so we dashed out to the last tie, snapped a photo, and dashed back in. Learn from my mistake and take the time to read the available materials, watch the video, and listen to the tour guide. We saved our visit by getting the $2 driving tour guide, which we thoroughly enjoyed. Everything on it is either visible from the road or just a few steps away from your car - a lifesaver for a couple of Floridians who weren't dressed for the weather.

This is about 30 minutes off the highway and well worth the trip. You can also stop to see the ATK rocket display as well on the way. Fee based, good displays and while the engines weren't at the monument at the time we were able to go see them at the maintenance facility just 1/4 mile away. While most of us know the history and the story it is still a good feeling to see this part of our nations history, to be there and drink it all in.

Huge Hell on Wheels fan (Netflix) and this made seeing this site a must. We were not disappointed! Go during the summer for two times daily reenactments. 7 dollars per car to enter. Very informative. Very small gift shop with a movie and lots of artifacts. This site is not close to civilization, but that's okay! Just do it!

The east and west finally united and California becomes the biggest state in a country that start on the east coast. At 10 am two steam engines appear, one burning coal and the other burning wood. Don't miss one of the first movies ever made, "The Great Train Robbery", it is short and historical for being made in 1920+-. The drive is also interesting and in the middle of just about nowhere, but well worth reliving history. Senior citizens and their whole crew get in free with a National Park Pass.

Wasn't expecting much out of this place, since its title is literally just about the final nail hammered in to the tracks to join the US transcontinental railroad, but I was so happy we made the stop from SLC! The staff was extremely helpful, answering all of our questions, giving great in-depth details of what we were experiencing. If you go, definitely make sure you take the auto tour, it's like an hour drive, but you actually get to drive on the original railroad grade built back in 1869! Just be sure to pick up a map guide at the visitor center ($2). It's also cool to experience if you've seen the AMC show "Hell on Wheels" since it's like living history! They even have reenactments in the summer. Worth the drive!

Golden Spike really is out in the middle of nowhere, but worth the drive. My boys loved the trains and loved it when they blew the whistles. We were able to watch the reenactment that they do every Saturday and holiday and enjoyed it very much. The visitors center had a lot of information and my boys found some souvenirs they couldn't leave without. It is only $7 a car load, but we were able to use my 4th graders free national parks pass. I would definitely recommend this for people, especially those with kids, and kids learning Utah history, makes history more fun when you can see where events happened.

What a great time we had at this National Historic Site. It's only $7.00 per car so it's a great deal. It's just a few minutes off the interstate and you can see something right out of history. We got there early in the morning as the train from the east was pulling up. The train was shiny, the smoke was billowy, and the whistle was loud. What more could you ask for? We got to see the spot where the two trains met and we heard the behind-the-scenes scuttle that we consider could only happen in the 21st century on Entertainment Tonight. Did you know there was more than one spike? And where are the spikes now? Our daughter bought a spike replica and it is one of her prized possessions. Our national history is something everyone should know about and this is one very important part of our history

A fun and educational place to visit in northern Utah. Only $5 for the whole family, Ranger Chuck was a treasure. The trains were incredible. Be sure to watch the 20 min movie on the railroads and how they finally came together. The junior ranger program is an excellent (and free) way to keep young children learning and they get a badge once they fill out there packet.

Drove out to the remote site and was glad we did. Extremely interesting to relive a great moment of history. Very remote location and hardly anyone was there. That only added to the ambiance of the experience! Only problem was the park ranger. He was talking to someone so I had to wait for some time to show him my National Park Pass so we could enter. Later when I asked about seeing the steam engines he said there was a tour in 10 minutes and proceeded to say "it's not really a tour. You drive to the site and a ranger will meet you and talk for 10 minutes and then you can either look around or leave." I asked him where we should drive to and he said "just down the road you came in on." Well we drove down that road and there was absolutely nothing. I honestly think he didn't give us the full instructions because he didn't want to be bothered with meeting us to do a tour. Very disappointing as all other US Park Rangers have always been so helpful as they have a passion for what they do.

This is one of those national historical sites that is definitely in the middle of nowhere. The typical visitor center with video gallery combined with a very knowledgeable ranger led tour combined to make this a very pleasant stop. Several in our group of six senior ladies were skeptical of whether this sideroad off of the interstate would be worthy of our time. It definitely was. We came in just before closing and at a perfect time to see them put the trains to bed for the night. The wood fired engines were ear-splitting to say the least. We only did the visitor center and not the auto loop. By showing one America the Beautiful Senior Pass per carload we got in free. We also stopped at the ATK Thiokol rocket garden along highway 83 so we got two attractions in our detour.

This is such an important site in the history of the United States that it is worth the 86 mile drive from Salt Lake City to the north side of The Great Salt Lake and Promontory Summit. If you are using a GPS be careful with programming - best results will usually occur if you enter "Golden Spike National Historic Site" and watch for signs as you get close. Other entries including "Promontory" "Promontory Point" "Corinne Utah" may not take you to the site itself. Stop by the visitor center for maps and program information. The main presentation of the replica steam locomotives Jupiter from the Central Pacific and the Union Pacific usually occurs around 10am along with a brief ranger led program. This site is on the original roadbed where the rails were joined on May 10, 1869. A museum, movie presentation and gift shop is available at the Visitor's Center as are restrooms. It appeared to be wheelchair accessible, but check with the site first to be sure. They also offer a reenactment of the Golden Spike Ceremony but that schedule varies. There are 2 auto tour roads: a West Grade Auto Tour which follows the Central Pacific Grade and the East Grade Auto tour which follows the Union Pacific Grade. The West Grade road was pretty rough and actually partially closed off due to flooding when I was there in August 2014. I would recommend the East Grade Tour - it is a dirt road but reasonably well maintained and heads back towards Salt Lake City. It is about 3 miles long and passes the Last Cut area and The Chinese Arch, two short hiking trails which children can easily manage. The views out onto The Great Salt Lake flood plain are magnificent. There was a $10.00 per car fee for entry, however if a visitor is 62, a citizen or a permanent resident of the USA that visitor can obtain a "Golden Age Passport" for $10.00 which is a LIFETIME Admission permit to almost all Federal recreation areas for no additional entry fees for that visitor and all guests within the private vehicle. I visit a lot of National Parks, Historic Sites, etc. and just show my pass for entry. From Salt Lake City, plan on about half a day: 2 to 3 hours at the site depending on what you do and about 3 hours RT drive time. Info: Golden Spike NHS, PO Box 897, Brigham City, Utah 84302; 435-471-2209; www.nps.gov/gosp

We took our children ranging from infant to 12 yrs. to the Steam Festival. The infamous 119 steam engine was there and we were able to tour it and see it in motion. Really a beautiful machine! We also got to ride the hand-cart and ride on a little motorized cart on up and down the tracks. There is a little museum with a interesting movie about the history of the Golden Spike. We all really enjoyed ourselves, all the employees were very friendly and informative. I think it was only $5.00 for our carload, so a real inexpensive family friendly activity. They have several events throughout the year.

We enjoyed the Site and found the staff helpful. I enjoy learning the history of America and you will find it here. Plus the open views around the sit are beautiful. Prices in the gift shop were reasonable too.

I had a free afternoon while visiting Salt Lake City, and decided to check this out. It was in the middle of nowhere, but relatively easy to get to. It costs $7 per car, but it's only collected when you enter the visitor's center so theoretically you can probably get on the driving trails for free as long as you know where you're going.

Just a short drive north of Salt Lake City this National Historic site is a must see. Go on a Saturday and they have the 2 trains roll down the tracks and re-enact the ceremony of when East and West railroads came together. Free with a National Parks Pass!

Wonderful way to see the Canyon. Tour takes about 45 minutes and is breathtaking. You'll never get more excitement for your $159!! The aircraft was marked "Papillon Airlines" and held 16 passengers. Large windows, high wings, so a terrific view. Flew from the Grand Canyon airport on the South Rim.
park: Grand Canyon Airlines - Grand Canyon National Park

text: We decided to do this vs standing on the edge of the Grand Canyon like Clark Griswold. The cost was $159 per person vs. +$200 for a shorter helicopter flight that wasn't as extensive. This tour covers most of the GC, is safe and there is a narrated voice over to listen to along the journey. Requested both of us have window seats which will cost you an additional $10 per person, but they were nice enough and waived the fee. The seating is 1 x 2 configuration with the exception of row 7, which is 1 x 1 with no 'B' seat, this is where we sat. Only downside was the tour was supposed to be 40 - 50 minutes, we were back at the terminal around 33 minutes.
park: Grand Canyon Airlines - Grand Canyon National Park

text: We had a great time at the Canyon, but only wish, that out of a 9-hour tour, we could have had more than 1.5 hours at the Canyon itself. We were told to be ready at 4:40 for our hotel pick-up, and finally arrived at the air terminal around an hour later, after numerous hotel stops and one shuttle bus change. If we had driven our own rental car, we could have shaved about 35 minutes off that portion and gained another half-hour of much-needed sleep, LOL! The flight was beautiful, and we both got window seats. Note: the views and light in the morning are much nicer on the left side of the aircraft. Once at Grand Canyon airport, we were efficiently shuttled into a huge bus (very roomy, but about 3x bigger than our group of 15 actually needed). The driver was friendly and personable, and even went back to pick up stragglers from our first stop after delivering us to the second one. But, at 45 minutes for each of 2 stops, it was nowhere near enough time at the park. If we had flown back right away after driving back to the airport it would have been one thing, but we were made to wait about an hour and a half before our flight back -- which is time I would rather have spent at the park itself. To top it all off, we found it was the same tour we could have booked through Scenic for about a hundred dollars less; the only reason we booked through this company instead is that they actually explained the plane configuration and guaranteed one of us would get a window seat (Scenic told us it would be totally random whether we would get one or not).
park: Grand Canyon Airlines - Grand Canyon National Park

text: i found a coupn on the internet for buy one get one so that was nice call to make a reservatin and was charge and additional $50 FOR TAXES AND FEES, seemed a little pricey questioned represntatative about the additional $50 Iwas just told it was taxes and fees but not what kind
park: Grand Canyon Airlines - Grand Canyon National Park

text: We booked this trip (Grand Canyon Scenic Tour) months in advance as recommended as it is quite popular. Now I know why. Our breakfast (and I know one of the reviewers felt she didn't have enough food--??) consisted of a large muffin, yogurt, orange juice, coffee, an apple, and a granola bar. The pilots gave us an overview of what we were to encounter and how to stay safe on the plane. The headsets provided a narration and classical music for what we saw from above. They also had 4 other languages available. There are two seats together and one individual across the tiny aisle. I read that you can pay an extra $10.00 for a window seat. But not to worry--the planes are outfitted with panoramic windows. It was a smooth ride and a view from every window. Well, worth the money.
park: Grand Canyon Airlines - Grand Canyon National Park

text: We had originally booked a mule ride, but that was canceled because of a controlled burn. Wanting to replace it, we chose to fly over the canyon for $7 per person more. This was such a fun experience. I will warn that the ride can be bumpy, especially with wind. A couple people in our group were very nauseated. The pilots were so fun and friendly, which really added to the experience. Although I was bummed about not going on the mule ride, I am glad we got to do this.
park: Grand Canyon Airlines - Grand Canyon National Park

text: My Wife and I took a trip on the EuroCopter helicopter used in the Majestic tour and it was fantastic! We wore headphones and could talk to the pilot the entire time!. I know it cost more but we wish we had taken the Grand Kingdom tour which is $50 more/person. I took so many pictures. We didn't take the next tour up not because of cost, but because the earliest reservation we could get was at 1 PM PT. All the staff was friendly and professional. Our tour was with two other couples who were from the Netherlands and France! It was an international flight. We will definitely take the longest tour the next time!
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: My husband and I booked the 40-50 minute Eco tour with Papillon for May 29th at 0800. We were directed to come 30 minutes early and when we called the day prior we're told many get lost on the way so we left early from Williams. There are no directions on the confirmation email and so had to call again when we arrived at the airport to find our location. However, we arrived at 0700. Everyone was very pleasant at the counter and we had our request in for both of us to be seated in the front of the helicopter. We understood that due to weight balance that we would be notified if we were selected (in addition we had a comfort seat for me as I am over their weight limit). At 0800 we were told that we would both be in the front and were charged $100. As this was my first time ever seeing the canyon, I was so excited (my husband has been before).
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: Cannot compare this to other tour providers since this is my only experience here. Was pricey but they provided everything they said they would. Everything first class. I did the King of Canyons Tour. I paid $50 for priority seating.....front seat. I am a photography enthusiast. The truth is that it was very difficult to get consistently good photos because the glass, while clean, has a slight curvature which tends to cause reflections most of the time. Best photos were taken on the ground when we landed in the canyon. I took the mid-day flight. I am sure the morning and evening flights are beautiful. However, either one of those will have you looking into the sun 50% of the time as the route is generally east-west. Anyway, it's money well spent. Highly recommended.
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: Beautiful flight, smooth ride,, awe inspiring scenery ( of course)! Pay extra for the front seats if you can, it's worth it!
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: The scenery was wow--it was incredible! Seeing the Grand Canyon from the vantage point of a helicopter was a once in a lifetime experience--one I would do again but not with this company-- This was an optional excursion as part of our guided tour--since we reserved our ride the tour company told us that prices were not fixed at the time and the price was now $301- per person for the 45 min. ride (an increase of $26 per person more than what we budgeted for). That is a lot of money for us but.... it's a once in a life time.....so we went--I felt like the pilot was phoning it in--he played music and felt like he was just reciting from a script--then asked for tips before we exited from the helicopter. Then to really annoy me--we were prevented from taking any photos. The pre-flight video specifically told when and where photos could be taken but the "professional" photographer was aggressively preventing people from taking a photo even in the safe area away from the aircraft-- based on these actions we refused to even view our 'professional' photo and did not tip the pilot. fyi you will be weighed pre-flight but no one other than the employee sees that number and does not repeat that number aloud.
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: We have to echo MJBs review of this company. We booked a 9:00 a.m. morning flight for our family of four and paid for a 'front seat upgrade' three months in advance. They require prepayment of bookings, 100%. We paid. We called 24 hours in advance as requested to confirm. We arrived 1/2 hour early at the terminal as requested. We wanted the 9:00 a.m. flight as we were told that this was the best 'light' in the canyon for photography and filming. We wanted the front seat upgrade for the same reason. We paid for the upgrade at the check in desk and were confirmed as having received it. We then waited in the check in area and were issued the 'life vests' and watched the pre flight videos. We were given the little yellow boarding passes. And then we waited. 9:05 a.m. No one called our name. 9:10 a.m. No one called our name. 9:15 a.m. No one called our name. 9:25 a.m. - I went to the check in desk and said "What is going on?" Have you forgotten us?" The front desk man said, "I don't know you need to ask the folks that issued you the boarding passes." We then asked the Indian woman at the boarding pass area what was going on and she said, and I quote, "Oh, we somehow forgot your family." I said, "Okay, so when do we get to fly?" She said, "I will need to check to see when we can get another helicopter for you." I called the 800 number and was on hold for ten minutes when we were finally told to board. It was now 9:50 a.m. The front seat upgrade I paid $50 was NOT honored. We were refunded the $50 when we demanded to have this refunded as it was not honored. Bottom line - the ground crew of this company are very disorganized and inefficient. They absolutely do NOT care about your experience being enjoyable. You will pay BIG money to be disappointed. And one has to wonder if they are this disorganized on the front end of the experience, what is going on behind the scenes with the pilots and maintenance of the helicopters. Great ride, too late in the morning for good light. Fun for my kids. But very disorganized and stressful to get on the bird. And the front desk guy is totally unconcerned with your satisfaction.
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: We took the Grand Kingdom Helicopter tour of the Grand Canyon about a week ago and I would never spend $500 per couple for the experience again! We took a wonderful helicopter ride last year in Hawaii and the difference was night and day. First of all, they were very insistant about us getting there a half hour early, yet they kept us waiting an additional 30 minutes with no explanation whatsoever as to what the hold up was. The pilot was not informative at all and just played a tape that explained everything. The views were good but I thought we would be dropped into the canyon or at least get closer to the river. Very disappointing!!!
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: Got delayed 4 1/2 hours due to cloudy weather. Many people canceled and those of us that waited it out finally got a ride. The two seats in the middle in the back had poor views and were not able to take photos. Nothing friendly about the staff or the ground crew. Tried to take a photo of my wife and the copter but were rushed back inside to find that they had a photo of us waiting for the $20 they wanted. Should have been free considering the $600 flight charge and the 4 1/2 hours we had to wait.
park: Grand Canyon Helicopters - Grand Canyon National Park

text: You pay 30 dollars per vehicle but it has an awesome structure inside, several restaurants to choose from, several parking lots, a shuttle going from all the points and awesome view points. They give you information on what to do and how to do it and they have signs, almost impossible to get lost.

Take a drive to from Boulder City UT to Escalante UT through the Grand Staircase, well worth the time. Beautiful Beautiful Beautiful! In the Town of Escalante pretty good food for a small town! A town that time forgot! Fun little town to see! You can also stop by the Petrified Forest and the pretty lake there for lunch! Fees there!
Be sure to stop by Escalante Outfitters for Pizza, camping, $45.00 cabins, coffee, beer and amazing people.

Going to the Tetons in September seemed like the perfect idea. A float down the Snake river was in order! The weather changed our plans as it rained and then snowed! It was the second week of September! We were so disappointed not to share that river trip! Feeling like this vacation was ‘on the ropes’, I went to the visitors center at Colter Bay and met a native artist named DG House! After a wonderful tour of her incredible art, did I mention her famous blue bears? We had a delightful conversation! She said how lucky we were to see the Tetons in the snow! Most visitors to the park never see the park that way! I felt suddenly so fortunate! She was so right! The next day we went on a very cold exhilarating boat ride across Jackson Lake to the foot of the Grand Teton. We were told again how only a small % of visitors to see the mountains this up close and personal! The snow made our visit so memorable. Also the animals are easier to see! Next time we will go in October!

We went to this park entering from the south entrance of Yellowstone. We bought a $50 pass that gave us access to both Yellowstone and Grand Tetons, well worth it! The mountains were capped with beautiful snow. The weather is a very crisp 30-40 degrees at the last week of September 2017. The trees are in full Fall color. The river was beautiful, Jackson Lake was gorgeous! We did not see animals as we were there when it was overcast and too cold. I highly suggest the Plains and Panorama loop that last 1.5 hours, but you see a LOT! Pick up a map and follow the loop. Highlight for me was the Chapel of the Transfiguration located at the Jackson end of the loop. Very spiritual and beautiful frame of the Grand Tetons at the pulpit. Ate at Sheffields Restaurant at John D Rockefeller Memorial Parkway at Flagg Ranch. They had the best food we ate our entire week trip. They close at 2:30 for a break before reopening at dinner. There was nothing that was not interesting in the Tetons!

1Really enjoyed hiking to inspiration point. You walk around Jenny Lake and ascend to beautiful point. All along the way there are various falls and gorgeous lake views. So glad we got there VERY early. There is lots of parking and a large visitor center. So, unless you want to have lots of company, go early! For those wanting to shorten their hike, you can take a boat across the lake or take the boat back to the parking area. $9.00 each way.

Beautiful place on a clear day. It was a bit hazy when we drove through but still great views. We were briefly only there on the way to Yellowstone. You can actually see much of the Tetons without paying when driving north from Jackson WY. It costs $50 to enter both Yellowstone and Grand Teton (one fee). That has gone up dramatically over the years which is why I give it 4 stars. It's not really a big place compared to Yellowstone but the mountains are spectacular. If you are already paying for Yellowstone it's worth checking out.

The Tetons are the kind of mountains you draw when you are a child,a row of cones rising straight out of flat ground. So majestic and beautiful with snow tops and glaciers. We just loved driving through the park over and over again. Our favorite sights were Jenny Lake, JAckson lake, Signal mountain, willow flats and the beautiful Oxbow Bend, a vision of green, water and peace. We floated down the snake river with solitude and enjoyed every moment in GTNP. We stayed in Teton Village which is just outside the park gate. Best of all since I am 62 I bought a LIFETIME park pass for $10 good for every national park in the USA! Ten Bucks for Life!!!!!

Grand Teton National Park scores pretty high in the beauty scale. It has grand mountains, crystal clear lakes and prairie lands. Some of the roads around Moose,Wyoming are only open in the summer with good reason- we thought our mini-van may fall apart on the rocks and bumps. They had a sign up that they were going to be fixing the roads and that road closures were coming. If you are looking for a moose, Grand Teton is the place. We were told by a ranger that years ago during a wildfire in Yellowstone - the moose all migrated to the Grand Tetons and never returned North. We were lucky enough to see a bull on those back bumpy roads near Moose, WY. The Jenny Lake Visitor Center is under construction - it was very crowded while we were there. If you are looking to rent a boat on any of the lakes - there is a 2 hours minimum for all boats including kayaks. Kayak rental is about $22 and hour. Be sure to go to the dam area ... that is were you can take those great mountain pics. Definitely a national park that needs to be on your list of places to see!

Grand Teton National Park is one of the smaller parks in the park system, but it is one of the most recognizable in the world. Checking in at about 480 square miles it is a little larger than Rocky Mountain National Park (415), but tiny compared to its neighbor, Yellowstone (3,462). What makes Teton such an attractive destination is the amazing scenery that is so accessible. And Wyoming has done an excellent job creating an infrastructure around the park that is cowboy rustic with the availability of all the luxury any one could possibly want. I can safely say that you can go into any restaurant wearing just about anything you want and fit right in. You are accepted for who you are and how you like to enjoy yourself. Sure, there are limits, good taste and common sense, but I think you know what I mean. There is no “Gentlemen must wear a jacket” nonsense. It is casual and relaxed throughout Jackson Hole. So don’t worry about that. I say this because there are some tremendous places to dine in Jackson Hole and the scenery outside the dining room is unlike anything, anywhere else in the world. So, Teton offers everything from slogging through wetlands looking for moose, hanging off rock faces from ropes or your fingers, crashing through rapids, floating through forests, hiking trails, riding horses, flying in helicopters and eating anywhere from a smoky campfire by a lake to 5 star, seven course cuisine in an historic lodge. You name it, you can probably do it. The trick to doing the Tetons right is to learn everything you can about the place, identify what you want to do, learn about that, and then book early. Grand Teton National Park is suffering the same influx of tourists as everywhere else. Cheap gas and an improving economy has more people than ever exploring the national parks. Not quite loving them to death, but certainly making their presence known. So with all the vacationers out there, you want to plan and book way ahead so you don’t have any panic attacks while you are in such a beautiful place. Lodging options are varied. There are many choices to explore including Jenny Lake Lodge ($$$$$$), Jackson Lake Lodge ($$$$$) Signal Mountain ($$$$) and Colter Bay ($$$). There are several camping and RV options within the park too. Outside the park there are hundreds of options from the obscenely expensive to downright economical. My choice, Colter Bay Cabins inside the park on the shores of Jackson Lake. I will say it again, BOOK YOUR LODGING EARLY. One more time: “BOOK EARLY!!!” Dining is another aspect of the trip that you may need to address in advance. If you want to do the fine dining in the Mural Room or Jenny Lake Lodge, book early. Get that out of the way. You will be disappointed if you try to book the day of. Most of the other dining options in Colter Bay and Signal Mountain and even Jackson Lake Lodge are less of a challenge. And check out the chuck wagon breakfasts and dinners where you ride a horse to your dining location or take a boat to a secluded island. Start at the activity desk. There’s even a chuck wagon barbeque at Dornans in Moose as well as a rockin’ pizza joint. So, what is there to do in Teton? If you are at one of the fine lodges, it’s not bad just hanging out in the great rooms relaxing or sitting out on the patio and watch Mother Nature strut her stuff in front of you. Activities are unlimited and you can go to any recreation activity desk and book things to do. All the lodges have brochure stands and you can book your own, or the lodges have their own guides and you can book with the guide. There is hiking that takes you to amazing OMG locations. Some of the hikes involve a ferry ride across Jenny Lake to the trail head. Any hike you take is surrounded by beautiful mountain peaks thrusting up out of the earth as well as dense forests on the lower mountain sides and the beautiful lakes and meadows left over from the glaciers of the last ice age. All you need is a desire to see nature up close and personal and a sturdy pair of footwear. Oh, and carry a can of bear spray. Bears know what the red can means and when they see it, they will usually go the other way. If you get tired or don’t want to walk. Ride a bicycle. Or go for a horseback ride. The float trips are amazing. Some floats are a few hours, others take all day with a picnic in the middle. If you don’t want to float, take a whitewater trip through class 5 rapids. Nasty canyons are nearby. Name your rafting preference, you can find it in Jackson Hole. Teton is also a driving park. You can drive the roads and stop at the dozens and dozens of pullouts to marvel at the scenery. You can drive to the top of Signal Mountain for a panoramic view of the valley. See if you can figure out where Ansel Adams parked his wagon when he took his photo from the Snake River Overlook. You can drive down to the trail that takes you to the beaver ponds at Schwabacher Landing and watch the otters during the day and the beaver at night. You can drive all the roads in the park in less than a day. Don’t forget to drive out the road to Gros Ventre. It is a beautiful valley that is not in the park. There are moose, elk, deer and bison. Well worth the time and miles to see it. Teton is a small park with a big backcountry. If you like expedition hiking, then this is the place for you. You will need to plan early so you can get all your permits and campsites ahead of time, then you strike off into the backcountry for a wilderness adventure. The back country is filled with world class climbing. If you want to try it, there are mountain schools and guides that will take you out and show you the ropes. You will be at altitude and climbing is strenuous, so make sure you are fit for what you want to try. If you are going to go it alone, check the climbing ranch for preparation and permits. If you are a photographer then you are in heaven when you get to Teton. Shoot RAW files as well as JPG. If you don’t know what RAW is, one day you will and you will thank me. The picture taking starts a couple of hours before sunrise and continues well into the night after the sun goes down. There are so many iconic places to take the National Geographic shot that I can’t name them all. If you want to be shown, sign up for a photo expedition with a guide and you will see things most people don’t. Or, you can get out and explore the park and find your own favorite locations. The park has an abundance of fauna and flora. The meadows explode with wild flowers during the spring. Hiking up mountain trails you see flowers all summer long next to the streams and pools. There is a huge variety of trees, so autumn is especially beautiful (Check out the historic barns on Mormon Row in late Septmeber). And the furry animals will be plentiful including bear, deer, elk, moose, bison, coyotes, wolves, ground squirrels, chipmunks and marmots. And there are dozens of birds including owls, hawks, golden and bald eagles, magpies, jays, etc. If you like standing around, getting wet and teasing fish, then the lakes, pools, rivers and streams will not disappoint. You can study up on where you want to go or hire a fishing guide. Lures and flies are standard stuff. Lots of people fish below Jackson Lake Dam (because there are a lot of fish there) but get out and explore the other rivers. If you get a good catch, the chef at your lodge will probably cook them for you. Just ask. One day in Teton is not enough. It will just make your realize that you needed more time and will have to come back. I would say two full days is the minimum stay as a survey vacation with some activities (meaning you will come back). And you could stay a week and never get bored. Remember, it is all in the planning. I know that lots of people are concerned about connectivity. Cell service in the park is fairly good, but can get spotty up on the hill. All the lodges have wifi in the great rooms, but probably not in the bed room. So if you need to stay connected, you can do that with a little effort. It’s kind of hard to review Grand Teton National Park just because it is such an amazing place. There is something for everyone and the park and outfitters have made every attempt to make the park as accessible and enjoyable as possible. So plan your trip early and you will not be disappointed.

While we enjoyed the views, it was definitely not as impressive as Yellowstone. We had and Access Pass so we get in free to National Parks. While Yellowstone would have been worth $30, we would not wanted to have paid the extra $20 to drive through the Tetons.

This was our 1st stop on our Yellowstone & surrounding area. The Mt. range is amazing. Unfortunately the skys were a bit clouded w/the smoke from the fires out west, but despite it photos still show the depth & perspective. The visitors center is quite informant & a cool looking building as well. There is a huge wall of windows lokking out to the Tetons & the floor is marked w/the Mts. you're viewing. Took the 5 mile hike around Jenny Lake up to Hidden Falls & took the boat back to the visitors center, which has a $9 fee. A nice start to our day.

Grand Teton is a beautiful national park. We stayed there for 2 days and did a lot of hiking there. Do your research before your trip to see what kind of trails you'd like to do. Come with the right clothes, take a small bagpack for rain jacket and water. It rained for 2 days but with the rain jackets we did the trails with no problem. Trail shoes are highly recommended (especially when it rains). We did buy a bear spray for $45, non refundable. Don't be a hero, buy one, most people do.

Breath taking scenery of nature at it's best. We stayed in Dubois, WY which is 56 miles from the park, less than an easy hours drive on some beautiful roads. We could not get a room in the park in the second week of September. When we go again, we'll try to book a room in the park. That would give us more time to explore. We spent 2 days in the park. Walking the trails, taking lots of photos. Some trails are not marked too well once you start out. Many are long so staying in the park would help. If you are 2+ years old you can get a senior pass from any National Park for $10. This is a life time pass and gets you into all NP's for free. Grand Teton is worth the $30 fee, but even better with a senior pass.

We saw lots of bears on this trip and my teenage son really was impacted by getting out in nature. We drove in from the gate bear Teton Village and headed to Jenny Lake. We hiked the path from the Jenny Lake visitor center to the water-very accessible to people of all physical copies ditions as the lake is just a few feet from the trail. We took some amazing photos. Charge to get into the park is $35 per car and the pass lasts for 7 days.

Visited in August. Weather during our trip was perfect. 70s during the day, and sunny so shorts were perfect attire. Had a senior with us so we got a senior pass from the visitor center. Saved us a lot of money as a senior pass is $10 for a lifetime pass and a typical carload charge can be upwards of $50. So make sure to get your park pass. Well worth it. Pays for itself in 1 visit. Lots to do here from the Jackson Lake Dam to Jenny Lake crossing by boat (NOT ACCESSIBLE so bear that in mind if you take the shuttle boat across). Set aside a whole day. If you plan to hike you probably need a couple of days. Don't miss at least a drive through this beautiful place.

The Grand Tetons are a wonderful place to visit. The scenery is beautiful. The mountains remind me of the Swiss Alps, but there are far less of them. The lakes are wonderful to look at especially if you can get a photo with a reflection of the mountains. Lots of animals to see. The Snake River adds to the enjoyment. This is MUCH smaller than Yellowstone. The park can be toured in about a day. If you want to add some activities like a float trip or white water trip, add another day or two. Restaurants in the area are generally average to above average with a few exceptions (both ways). Prices are above average.

Spectacular mountains and lakes. We saw the Grand Tetons on the way from Jackson Hole to Yellowstone. We decided the scenery was fantastic and returned the next day and actually entered the park. We were not dissappointed. If you are 62 or over you can get a senior pass for $10 that is a lifetime pass good for all the national parks. They do check your ID and the pass is good for all people in the vehicle, so your spouse or children, friends etc do not need a pass. Otherwise a 7 day pass is $30 or $50 for both the Grand Tetons and Yellowstone. If you are in the area I would recommend getting both passes.

We had spent the Memorial Day holiday in Yellowstone National Park, which was incredible. We are so very glad that we drove the extra miles to stay at the Grand Teton Lodge and see Lake Jenny as well. The vistas (the Cathedral mountains-7 sisters) are absolutely breathtaking, especially at sunset! They are not to be missed. The boat tour on Lake Jenny is well worth the modest expense. We also hiked the area and enjoyed waterfalls, overlooks, and even a snowball fight. In the area we saw a brown bear, elk, moose, and plenty of buffalo. We did not see any grizzly bears on our trip. Binoculars and a good SLR camera are essential to take all of this in, but my iPad took some great pictures and allowed me to upload them to facebook to share with my friends. Be prepared to get out on foot and climb the hills, a moderate feat, but if you need to be dressed for the elements and climbing moderate terrain. We spent two days at the Grand Teton Lodge. The Wi-Fi was very good. However, we felt, coming from West Yellowstone, that in comparison, the food was expensive and the portions could have been more generous, but, we did not feel as if we were "ripped off" since it was only two of us, but I'd be concerned if we had brought our family of five/ The formal dining area was lovely, and we had a wonderful view of the Grand Tetons at sunset, but once again, very expensive. The accommodations at the Lodge were acceptable, they were clean and slept well, but for $225.00, I have had much better rooms. However, on the second day, we had toilet problems as the Lodge had just opened that weekend and toilets had not been used that winter, so their were explosions as clogged toilets were stressed. The maintenance team could not quickly rectify the problem so they suggested that we move. We requested and received another room. The staff was efficient and friendly. The gift shops in the Grand Teton Lodge had some lovely items, it was well stocked. The artwork was well beyond our budget as tourists, but glorious to behold. We had the opportunity to travel into Jackson Hole, WY from this location for a day trip, which was a great deal of fun. We really enjoyed our stay. God's masterpiece is on display in the snow capped Grand Tetons in May-June!

The Tetons are something that you must see at least once in your lifetime! We visited everyday while we were there (7 days). The rangers were super friendly and helpful. A real treat for us was that because I was over 62, I could purchase a lifetime pass to all National Parks for $10. Normally it costs $25 for a 7 day access. If you qualify- get in on it! You've made it, so you might as well enjoy it!!!

Can't beat it. Pure nature and civilization combine to make this one of the best places on earth. Jackson is a great city with anything one would need. Prices are high though what you'd expect from a seasonal town.

Most phenomenal mountains I've ever seen. Still snow capped Memorial Day weekend, although we had 80 degree weather. Jenny Lake is not to be missed (west side of main road; small sign directs). Pronghorn, their young, moose, elk, coyotes, grizzly and brown bear, wolves, fresh pine scent abounds. At peace with nature. Not so crowded this time of year, and accommodation rates are quite reasonable ($65-80/hs). Didn't have time to hike, since park adjacent to Yellowstone, which we also saw in 2 days, but that would have been fabulous, as well as camping for outdoor lovers. After a winter of 500" of snow, waterfalls were spectacular as well. Jackson has everything you need (gas, restaurants, shops) in the evening.

This is a MUST SEE! Absolutely stunning area. There is a bicycle trail that you can do that has the Teton as you're backdrop and it is breathtaking. You pay $25 to get in but that includes entrance to Yellowstone as well. You have 7-day usage to see both parks! Worth staying a whole week then some to truly take in the total experience. It is worth buying out time for to see such stunning and beautiful landscape.
We didn't have time to hike. Just rode through. Fortunately we were not on our motorcycle, because we got caught on the Pass in a fierce storm! Was still a beautiful ride!

We are 2 adults, 2 kids, 10 and 11. We visited Grand Teton NP, Jackson Hole, WY and found a place for $100/nt at the Hostel in Teton Village, saved alot by staying there. We arranged to eat our breakfast at the hostel (an old ski lodge-from Olympic trials or? .. it seems), and ate dinner we prepared there. Saved alot of money, saw incredible animals, did alot of hiking, went to top of Jackson Hole Ski Resort (a little spendy but well worth it). the Hostel was pretty sparse, it had small bathrooms, the rooms were narrow, dark, with only one window, might be some dust in the corners, no desks or swimming pool here, but they were comfy. It had bunk beds, the floors creak --creaks alot, a large rec room in basement with a large frig for all to keep their groceries (all were labelled) and rec room included a toaster, a microwave, lots of tables and a tv, a ping pong table, and more games that i can imagine, a table just for checkers and chess. OK..it wasn't the Marriott, but neither were the prices. Alot of younger college age kids working at the place, my kids made friends with some at the front desk, and they liked their dog Cinch. I saw quite a few families, and older couples who look like they were in good shape and maybe retired but saving money while visiting the area, also saw plenty of Foreigners who know how to stay in hostels. Grand Teton NP is just up the road from the hostel, as well as Jackson Hole which has a cute historic downtown- our kids did a stagecoach ride, short and sweet for $4/each, and check out the Million Dollar Cowboy Bar, too. We did alot of hiking in Grand Teton, ate lots of PBnJ sandwiches, baby carrots, string cheese, beefsticks, and always brought our own water bottles. Loved this area!!

We're hiking the top 20 National Park hikes, and this one was in Grand Teton. Take the Jenney Lake ferry from the east to west side. It's $12 per person, but saves 2 miles of hiking around the lake (free for military!). Hike .7 miles to the waterfall, and then another .3 miles to Inspiration Point. Many people turn around here, but don't! It's another 6 miles up Cascade Canyon to Lake Solitude, but well worth the moderate hike. We saw bear, moose, marmots, etc. along the way, all the while enjoying countless waterfalls and rushing water from the melting glaciers.

The views are SO beautiful and amazing!!! We took so many pictures so we can remember our trip forever. We left Jackson, Wyoming heading for Yellowstone and went to the Grand Teton Park. We had lunch in our car beside the National Elk Refuge and sat and watched wildlife. It seemed like we turned the corner in our car, and there were the mountains..... We just were speechless. They are so tall, and gorgeous. Breathtaking. We stopped at Jackson Lake for great pics along the drive. It was gorgeous. They have a $25 entrance fee which is also good for Yellowstone. Glad we were there and have this memory, everyone should see it.

I recently did a 3 night backpack trip at the Grand Tetons National Park. I parked at the Leigh Lake Trailhead and hiked up the Paintbrush Canyon Trail the first day. A challenging but worthwhile hike. I saw a big black bear midway up the canyon eating in a raspberry field next to the trail. I set up camp just below the end of the upper paintbrush camp zone. A beautiful view all around. The next day, I went over the Paintbrush divide and also summited the peak to the north of the divide. 10820 ft. Great view and easy climb. Then down to Lake Solitude. This area is full of flowers and the lake is wonderful. I continued down and saw the largest moose I have every saw. It had 8 points but another 10-12 points that were about to complete. A sight. The South fork Cascade was fully of waterfalls and cliffs. Going to the end and climbing Hurricane Pass is well worth it to see the perfect view of the 3 Tetons and the valley where the South Fork Trail runs. I stayed two days in this area. Well work it. Lastly, I hiked down early the last morning down Cascade Trail. A very easy slow decline. I will go back.

You can't help but be in awe of these beautiful mountains. We spent 2 days enjoying the park and were delighted to see to a black bear and her cub, a mama moose and her baby, pronghorns and a bull moose. The mountains even treated us to an amazing thunderstorm. Nothing like a clap of thunder in the mountains. Take your time to visit the little chapel and make sure to visit the visitor center. We stayed on the Idaho side of the Tetons and driving the Teton Pass was amazing. Take your time to enjoy these stunning mountains.
The Aerial Tramway Ride in Grand Teton Village was fantastic! The cost was $29.00 per person.
Majestic. Great weather. Fantastic animal sights. Prices reasonable for the food and lodging.

It is very frustrating to pay $$$ to our national parks, only to find out that there are strict regulations on where you can have a pet. For the most part it is within 6 ft off the roadway. There are no shady places to park where the pet would be cool. So you end up driving through the park and seeing only what you can from the car. I should have done more research on the regulations of our parks before driving over 2000 miles.
My family and I traveled out west from Illinois...By Car, with gas prices over $4.00/gallon.

There are trails, lots of wildlife, a gift shop, Visitor's Center, and sites to see. I also recommend anyone visiting several sites in this area to purchase the National Parks Annual Pass for $80. It is good for a year and grants you free entrance at the National Park/Monument Sites. This place will take your breath away.

Absolutely grand! We camped in the park so had easy access as well as about 13 miles out of Jackson Hole. We had rain, snow, and cold but did not deter from the experience. According to locals June is a rainy month but we did have some days when it was warm enough to wear shorts. Lots of hiking, biking and just about anything else. A photographers dream with mountains, snow and wild flowers. We stayed 6 days and didn't want to leave. Something new about the mountains every day. It's a national park so there is a fee. If you are a senior (65) the life time pass is $10.00

We thoroughly enjoyed this beautiful national park while on our trip out west this past July. The Teton mountain range is simply breathtaking and even pictures don't do it justice. We stayed in Jackson for three nights, and spent two full days driving through the park. One of the major highlights of this park is taking the boat across Jenny Lake. It costs $30.00 for two adults for a round trip across the lake. After the boat docked, we hiked to Hidden Falls and Inspiration Point and the views were awesome. We were told you could also take a one-way trip across the lake and then hike about 2 and one half miles back to the visitor center. We had a couple of really good lunches at Signal Lodge while in the park. i would also recommend visiting the Chapel of the Transfiguration and joining the ranger for an informative session about the history of the park. We were told the best chances for seeing wildlife was either at Oxbow Bend or at Antelope flats, where we did see bison. Of course, the best chance to see animals is either early morning or toward dusk. If you are planning on visiting Yellowstone, make sure you allow yourself enough time to visit the beautiful Tetons as well.

This is my favorite national park. The views are incredible, the summer weather cool and refreshing. There is wildlife evrywhere; bears (be careful), elk, deer, and more down to the cutest chipmunks. Great for all ages. Camping and lodges available. Food store and restaurant. Be aware that showers are $4.50. The crowds are way less than Yellostone. You can go for walks or serious hikes, view Jackson Lake or take a scenic drive. Ranger led programs are plentiful. Its a win win for nature lovers.

We recently spent two days in the Grand Teton National Park. The Grand Teton mountain range is simply beautiful! One of the highlights of visiting this park is the boat ride across Jenny Lake. It costs $30.00 for two adults for a round trip across the lake and back. After crossing the lake you can hike up to waterfalls and to Inspiration Point. We did it and thought the views were incredible! We had a great lunch two days while in the park at the Signal Lodge. We also visited the Chapel of the Transfiguration and joined a tour with a park ranger about the history of the park, which was really interesting. The only disappointment was at Teton Village where we had planned to take the tram up the mountain, but decided against it when we saw it was $70.00 a couple. We thought that was a bit of a rip-off. Also, we were told the best chance of seeing animals was at Oxbow Bend and Antelope Flats, where we did see bison. There is a national elk refuge right outside of Jackson, but when we stopped at the visitor's center, the ranger told us you won't see the elk until November. I highly recommend seeing both Yellowstone and the Grand Teton national parks if planning a trip to Wyoming.

If you are travelling to Wyoming to visit Jackson or go to Yellowstone National Park, make sure you allow time in your schedule to visit the Grand Teton National Park. It is so beautiful and the mountains are just breath taking. There are great trails to hike, very scenic photos to take and wildlife to see. We paid $25 for a 7 day permit/pass that will allow us in to both this park and Yellowstone National Park. The mountains here are quite incredible and we spent time near Jenny Lake to see both the waterfall as well as to hike up to Inspiration Point and afterwards to hike around the lake back to the area that our car was parked in. This park is so worth the time and effort to visit.

We spent 6 nights camping at Colter Bay June 5-11. It was a GREAT time to go...no crowds, very comfortable temps (high 30's overnight; 70 during the day). Highly recommend Colter Bay Campground. We have a pop-up camper. There are sights with full hook-up, but we opted for none. The sites without hook-ups were much better. Full hook-ups were basically on an asphalt slab...not our idea of camping. There were clean restrooms (flush toilets only) near camping sites. You could shower for $3.75 at the laundrette in Colter Bay.

We visited Grand Teton National Park in June of 2015 and it is one of the most beautiful parks I have ever visited. The mountains are fabulous and still had snow on them in June. The Jenny Lake area is wonderful for hiking. You can purchase a round trip ticket for $15 on the ferry to get you to the other side of the lake or there are trails that take you around it too. Once on the other side of Jenny Lake you are in the wilderness. They drop you off and there are plenty of trails to explore. Hidden Falls in about .5 miles from the boat landing site and Inspiration point is about 1.5 miles up the mountain. It's a little tough, so wear good hiking boots and socks, but well worth the trip up the mountain to see the view. You can hike 3.3 miles once on top to Cascade Canyon for breathtaking views. It's a flat walk, so not too bad.

My sisters and I made a quick trip to visit 3 Natioanl Parks in The area. We visited Great Basin first. We stayed the night at a house rental in Baker and drove the few miles into the park the next morning. We knew it was going to be a good day when we saw 2 bald eagles sitting on telephone poles on the road into the park. We had a tour scheduled for Lehman Cave for the morning. We were greeted by the park folks and got our Park Passport stamp as we waited for the tour. It was a great tour made better by the fact that there were only 6 of us on the tour. Our guide was very knowledgeable and the cave was very interesting. On our drive out of the park we spotted several more bald eagles and possibly a golden eagle. It was a wonderful cost and I'd definitely go in the winter again. It was cold and many of the trails were closed to hiking but we saw a few hearty individuals camping and enjoying what there was available. The snow made it all the more beautiful!

One of the smaller national parks I've ever been in, but worth a stop - some interesting hiking trails - take plenty of water and plan appropriately for the very hot, dry climate. The drive out from Ely to the park is scenic - quite a few spots near the summit to take good pictures. Go to the visitor center near the Lehman caves and sign up for the cave tours (small fee to take the tour) - the caves are the highlight of the park and well worth spending a day to see. There is a restaurant and gift shop that is open in the summer months, but you should plan to gas up and take food and water with you to the park. There is very little in the way of facilities within 50 miles of the park. NO fees to enter the park, but the ranger-guided cave tours have a $10 cost (well worth it to see these amazing caves)!

I had wanted to visit Great Basin National Park for a long time. In my mind, I expected to see something like Death Valley. I could not have been more wrong! The scenic drive left me breathless with its beauty as we drove from desert scrub to lush forests and aspen groves. This park has it all. While eating our lunch at 10,000 ft., my husband decided he wants to train to climb Wheeler Peak which is 13,000+ ft. The view looking down to the valley from the top of the drive is truly spectacular!!! While at the park, be sure to take a tour of Lehman Cave. They only take 20 people per tour, so buy your ticket ahead of time. It is well worth the $8 for an hour tour or $10 for the 1.5 hour tour.

Went to Great Basin last week, the aspens were at there peak in golden colors. The park is remote, about 3 hours from Cedar Springs Utah on some pretty desolite roads. There is no admission to the park but the Lehman cave tours is $8 for an hour tour. Caves are interesting, call in advance to book a cave tour, they sell out.
