I went in mid-May when only part of the Wheeler Peak Scenic Drive was open. This is not my favorite national park, it was OK- it got me a stamp in my National Park Passport, but I'm not sure I'd make the detour off of the Loneliest Road in America again.

Great Basin national park is really just an amazing place... We went there for 3 days, and wish we were able to stay longer!! We camped at the upper lehman creek campgrounds which are around 7200 elevation. The second highest one, the highest is wheeler peak at over 10,000 elevation. There are wonderful hikes. From small simple nature hikes to extremely strenuous complete day trips! No matter what your age or skill level this place is spectacular. I really recommend taking a hike up to see the glacier before it is completely melted. It's abt a 6 mile round trip hike, and you gain around 300 feet. We took our children and they did fine with it! Packed a picnic lunch an trash bags to slide down the glacier! If you have time be sure to go in the lehman caves.. Truly an amazing place! Tickets are $10-15 ea, and totally worth it! But get them early, we arrived on fri morning, and they were already sold out all of Friday, all of Saturday, and most of Sunday!

I loved this place. I came here on a Saturday and there was a handful of people but you easily could find your own little spot away from everyone and be at peace. The fee to enter is $15 (I was alone so not sure if they charge by carful or by person.) Good info at welcome center. There's a small creek you have to cross and I assume at different times of the year it can be wider or deeper. I was here in late October and it was barely an inch deep. Sure it was cold but not so much so that you couldn't walk through it in barefoot. Probably a good idea to bring a towel if you're gonna go barefoot so you can dry your feet if ya wanna put shoes back on. After that it's just a free for all - there's giant mound of sand with various peeks and valleys in front of you so just pick your way and go. Some people bring boards and sleds to ride down the dunes. There's a shop right before you get to the park gates called Oasis where you can rent. I just worked my way up the dunes and ultimately just found a nice quiet spot away from anyone else and just say and enjoyed the view. Of course I couldn't resist taking a tumble down the dunes. I arrived with pants on cause the temp was about mid 40s but I brought shorts as well and once I got to the park I changed into them. Glad I did cause once I started hiking up the dunes it was getting warm. I really loved this place. I could've stayed all day had I not had to return to Colorado Springs for work. Would go back in a heartbeat.

We headed out from Denver last weekend for some camping, sledding, and hiking at Great Sand Dunes National Park. So how COOL is it that you can sled or board the dunes. This was and incredible experience. I recommend renting at OASIS - right outside the park ($20 per sled/board).

We took a family trip out here and had a blast! Unfortunately, my grandma had a hard time getting around and the rental wheelchairs aren't much help. My husband, nephew and I enjoyed boarding down the dunes after a hefty walk out to them though. Luckily the creek was still running, so my mom, grandma and niece splashed around while waiting for us to return. I'd recommend renting boards from Great Sand Dunes Oasis (you'll see it on your way into the dunes) for $20 each and stopping at the visitor center for fun souvenirs!

The view of the dunes is beautiful both inside and outside the park (and don't miss Zapata Falls just 5 minutes outside the park (see reviews)). If you plan to sand sled, rent them just outside the park at the Oasis for $20 each, or in Alamosa (a 30 minute drive) for $18 each. But be warned: the trek to the first dune to slide on is about 1/2 mile through rocky sand, and then just sand, and is quite tiring. Sliding is fun but sorta hard to get the hang of it. We spent about 2 hours sledding and were totally exhausted (it was about 75 deg. that day). And the sand starts getting really hot, so you've got to have shoes. I'd suggest tennis shoes or boots, and not Keen-type, which we wore and were sorry. Hiking to the very highest dune you can see from the visitor center yields a view of more dunes, and not far-off landscape. Bring some food and water with you, as there are no food facilities there, or the Oasis has a cafe and supplies.

You can't go wrong with a national park/preserve. It's beautiful, and clean and has a impressive visitors center. The roads through the park are minimal. There are are areas for off road vehicles, for more exploration of the park. Kite flying, hiking, and sledding down the dunes are options for recreation suggested by the park rangers. Sledding works best during the dry season. We tried using plastic snow sleds with minimal success. Wooden sleds rented by the one store near the park are around 25$ for the day. Our kids used the sleds a couple of times, and then tired of climbing up the dunes. There is a stream(seasonal) that you cross before you get to the dunes that is fun to explore as well. Camping sites are available to reserve. Not sure about RV sites. That being said the park is in the middle of nowhere. There are a couple of options for lodging, a unassuming looking restaurant with decent food and a small store all on the east side of the park. NO wi fi. No close towns with any decent amenities. Fill up gas tank when you can find a gas station.

This is a small National Park. You'll only need one day here, but plan to sand board! There is a campground / store on the right about a mile before the entrance to the park where you can rent boards and sleds for $20/day. Although you can rent them for a full day, you'll probably only be able to last for half. Try to go as soon as they open (8am) so you can get an early start before the mid-day sun beats down on the dunes. Most people took their shoes off to walk in the sand but then your feet burn like crazy. I kept having to stand on my board to give my feet a break from the 115 degree sand. When you are done riding the dunes, you can lay down in the stream that is near the parking lot. It is really mostly mud, but non-the-less, refreshing after being on the dunes. Bring bug repellent because the mosquitos by the water are vicious.

1st we stopped at the little shop just before the entrance to the park & rented the sleds for the dunes. ($20 each. Sometimes they worked, sometimes they didn't) Some of the dunes were incredibly tall & if you could stay on, the ride down was awesome. We had only been there for a couple of hours when a storm blew in, the temperature dropped really fast, the wind picked up & we were in our 1st ever sand storm. We literally took a beating & had to leave. It took a while to get out & it was miserable, so check the weather before you go. The creek that runs in front wasn't very full but the water was really cold & felt great. (on the way in) Also, the visitors center was pretty cool.

I've lived in Colorado for over 20 years and this was the summer to see things, like the Sand Dunes, that I've never seen. My friend and I brought our kids, age range 9-16, to visit the Sand Dunes. We used the 4th Grade National Park passes to get in free, which saved $30 between the two cars. Rent sleds at a place called Oasis, which is about 3 miles before you reach the park entrance. They are about $20 each. The visitor center is nice. Wear shoes - not sandals or flip flops. Sand is VERY hot. We were there midday - would probably be better early or late. The stream cooled our feet. Bring towels and lots of water. There were people that even brought chairs and shelter, which is probably not a bad idea if you're spending a few hours there. There are outdoor showers to rinse off feet/hair/body parts covered in sand. The sand sticks like crazy! The tallest dunes are tall! I didn't climb them but watching my 16 year old freaked me out! We only stayed a couple of hours. We did not check out anything other than the dunes and visitor center. Glad to have seen it but probably won't rush back for another visit!

If you are coming on a hot day it is not worth is to rent the sand boards from Oasis to slide down the dunes. We paid $40 and the sand was really too hot for this activity for it to be safe. We felt like they should have warned us, not just taken our money. Be prepared with closed toed shoes for the walk to the dunes. I had to turn back in my flip flop type shoes because it was so hot the soles of my feet were burning. If you bring a dog and it is hot don't leave it in your car and don't try to hike to the dunes with it. Just stay in the shallow creek and let your dog cool off. We saw several people make this mistake. Kids will love it. Such amazing views and a cool site. Well worth the stop and trip.

We rented a sled from oasis, $20. We arrived at 8:30 or so and it wasn't very crowded or too hot. Tons of mosquitos in parking lot and shrub near medano creek. The far side of creek is less buggy and none on dunes. Prepare to walk out a ways. If you have kids under 5 or so, it could be rough. Walking in dunes is hard work, sledding is fun. Don't hold the handles like they say you should, more likely to wipe out. Hubby took an impressive tumble until he figured out you trail your hands behind you to keep you straight. Nice that dogs are allowed up to the dunes. Had fun in the creek with him. Little snow on mountains in the background. Imagine in early June is it spectacular with the snow. When we left at 10:30 it was warming up and getting crowded.

I normally don't review the parks themselves but this one requires some info that I wished I'd known about. To get to the dunes you have to cross Medano creek. Late summer it's a trickle, when we went 6-8" deep in spots. We got across fine but we would have worn different footwear had we known. June to late July is mosquito season. We arrived at peak and were driven off. Fortunately the Visitor center sells a non deet citronella like repellent. Worked as good as the stuff we left at the hotel not realizing we would need it so badly. Go early, the sand gets hot -really hot. If you rent a sand board $20 from the store just outside the park, gloves might be a good thing to bring along.The hike up is tough, but worth it. There are no trail markers but usually there's a path of footsteps to follow.

Beautiful views and amazing experience. So very unique! We enjoyed our visit. Be prepared to wade across Medano Creek, which levels may vary. It is a unique stream as it surges, similarly to the small waves on a lakeshore. The dunes are a short walk beyond the stream. We rented sand sleds and a sand board. They are very expensive to rent, and they really aren't worth the $20 per day in my opinion. You also need to pay attention to the wind. It was quite breezy our visit and we were completely sand blasted in less than an hour. I'm glad we went, but definitely not a repeat.

We rented sand boards at the Oasis, which is located just a couple miles from the park entrance. The boards were $20 each for the whole day. The dunes were astonishing!! We live near the Indiana Dunes which are nice, but these dunes were monstrous in size. My sons loved walking up and sand boarding down the hills. The flowing creek is nice, which we crossed in order to get to the dunes. Make sure to watch the short movie in the visitor center - it is very informative. The only thing that could be improved with this park is the lack of trail signs. We had a very difficult time locating the Dunes Overlook trail and the Sand Ramp trail. Evidently these trail heads are located in the actual campground.

Location checked off our bucket list. We arrived early at 8am during Memorial Weekend. Knowing how crowded it would be, we arrived early on Friday. But we first stopped at the Oasis store, near the park entrance, to rent sand boards. They are 20 dollars a day. We parked at the parking lot passed the visitor center. The creek to the sand dunes are feet away. If you park at the Visitor Center, it will be a good long hike to the dunes. I advise to arrive early has parking gets full by at least 9/10am. If not, come with your patience and you may have to park along the entrance road. We did notice the wind was calmer early in the morning until it picked up a few hours later. Due to the wind (small children) we didn't get to hike further up the dunes but we enjoyed the early sledding. The sand does get hotter further up. We spent most of our time cooling off by walking through the Medrano Creek. It's very cold but warms up as time goes by. We did see people picnic outside their vehicles, but there are at least 4 picnics tables across the parking lot. There are also restrooms and outdoor showers to rinse all the sand off. We spent most of the day there, but we will definitely plan again. The running creek is seasonal, so you will have to plan around that if you want to see it at full. Great visitor center with a gift shop and small museum. No near café or restaurants so don't forget your food and water during your visit, if not, you will fight for parking when if you return back.

We traveled there with two children (ages 5 and 7) and spent HOURS having fun. The dunes are high (highest dunes in North America according to the National Park) so lots of great exercise. We went in late April and the weather was great. Little cool temperature but the bright sun made it short sleeve weather in mid-day (morning and evening had to wear jackets). We had to cross a wet area to get the dunes and saw experienced visitors with waterproof shoes or taking them off to cross. Would definitely recommend renting the boards, or bringing your own, to slide down before entering the park. We saw large pieces of cardboard and personal snowboards waxed well) being used with great results. Renting the wood boards was $20 per board with return by 3:30. Bring sun block and water!!! Just a great time and would definitely visit again.

You can spend an hour or half a day here, that's the nice thing about this place. It is a minimal charge to get in, I think it was $5. There is a very nice visitors center upon arrival, it has restrooms, a short movie to watch and many hands on activities. There is a wonderful place out back to get a large span photo shot of the Dunes. After the visitors center head to the dunes. Make sure you pack water and sandals, you can plan on your feet getting wet when you have to cross the creek to get to the dunes. If you want to slide down the dunes, I would suggest renting a sled from the visitor center. Regular sleds DO NOT work as there is too much friction with the sand. There is alot of territory to cover if you're going to climb all the way to the top, good luck!

There is the "Medano Pass Primitive Road", an about 11 mile road that took us about two hours to cross, plus another hour or so to reach US 160, on our way to Taos. We drove a Toyota 4Runner that was powerful and high enough to handle this road. Even though the standard recommendation is to lower tire pressure through soft-sand spots, this was not an option for us because we did not carry an air-pump. A very helpful Park Ranger suggested that I should drive a bit fast on those tricky but short stretches, and we crossed them fine. The rest of the road, which reaches 10,000 feet elevation, was one of the most fun/adventurous drives that we have ever made. We constantly had to set the highest 4WD option and drive 5mph or slower, but the views and experiences were just fantastic. If everything goes well, then this is not-to-miss. If a car breakdown, then it's long walk back to the Visitors Center - we did not find any car coming or going on Nov-01-16. BTW, we briefly got AT&T reception at the high end of the road, which helped us to get to US 160.

My family has talked about going here for awhile so we finally made the trip. The park is really in the middle of no where but the dunes are impressive. They are really quite beautiful. You can hike anywhere you want on the dunes. Getting up to the hire ridges will take about an hour and a half. If you want to sled you have to rent special sleds OUTSIDE the park. They go for about $20. Normal sleds will not work.

Great Sand Dunes National Park is a great place for the kid in all of us to play. It is one big sandbox. Hike, play, camp and learn. The visitor center will teach you about dune formation, plant and animal life one the dunes. The campground has great views of the dunes. Camp in the backcountry on Medano Pass, a 4 wheel drive route or of the park.

Once we were able to get to the sand dunes, it was fun sliding down them. Long drive to the park and long walk to the dunes. When your done on the dunes, there is a small creek that you can dip your feet in or play in the water. Beautiful seeing the flat grasslands, then the dunes and then the mountains. Kids did the Junior Ranger activity. After they complete their Junior Ranger activities, for a $1 donation to their special sand wheelchair program, the kids received both their badge and patch. The rangers were really nice and helpful.

I visited the national park with my wife and 2.5 year old. We had an amazing experience. The sand dunes provided by beautiful scenic photography opportunities. We had rented a board from the oasis shop before entry into the national park. Board cost was around $21 including tax for a 24 hour rental. The park entry was $15 and valid for 7 days. We entered the park around 4:00 pm. The park is part of the national park network and if you have the $80 annual America the beautiful pass you can use it here. After we entered the park we stopped by the visitor center. I knocked down 0.5 points in my rating due to the cold reception at the visitor center. When I asked for details the women at the reception just told me to use the map with no additional details. The park would be better served by hiring people who are more passionate about their job. We then proceeded to the sand dunes, parked at the entrance and made our way in. We had assumed the sand dunes would be near where we parked our car but it is a good 0.5 mile walk from the parking lot to the start of the dunes. I knocked down 0.5 points in my rating due to this bringing my overall rating to a 4 out of 5. Once we got to the dunes it was really amazing and we had a blast sliding down the dunes. Walking through the dunes is extremely tiring and we made it across two of them but could see people climbing across many more dunes to greater and greater heights. We were tired after 2 hours and made our way back through the 0.5 miles to the parking lot. On the way out I saw a couple of deers and took some photographs. Overall a very enjoyable experience albeit a bit tiring and wonderful photo opportunities.
Was great to visit! Beautiful views! Cost $15 to get in for a family vehicle, if active duty you get in free and thanked for your service! I would come again for sure.

We visited this National Park for the very first time over Labor Day weekend. As an area resident and National Park fan, it was high time to go! We lucked out with the weather. The gate is $15/car, valid for 7 days. Our first day in the park, the temperatures stayed around 75 and recent rains helped to keep the sand dunes comfortable. The warnings at the entrance to the dunes remind visitors that the sand may reach temperatures up to 150 degrees and that shoes (not sandals) are a safety requirement. The paws of animals are also at risk on most days. But our trip was special - we were comfortable bare foot in the sand as were most of the visitors that day.

Our family visited Great Sand Dunes National Park for 2 days in August. Shortly after entering the park on Hwy 150, you will see the sand dunes come into view. Stop at one of the pull outs on the road to take a panoramic picture. If you want to rent a sand sled, pull over at Oasis (convenience store & gas station), to pick one up. They are $20/calendar day. We hiked in the late afternoon our first day and took advantage of the late sun & shadows to take some pics. That evening, we were treated to a pink sunset behind the dunes as we watched from our campground at Pinyon Flats.

Great Sand Dunes made quite an impression on my family. It was otherworldly. Hiking out on the dunes was like hiking on Tatooine but with the 14k Sangre De Christos as a back drop. We hiked on the dunes until sand in all our crevices drove us out. Then my kids dug a deep hole in the creek bed. They were a mess but had a blast. Camping was good but there were plentiful mosquitos in the evening and morning. But that is part of camping. Also, there is a camp store in the NP campground which actually has a better selection of food and supplies than the store right outside the gate. We didn't rent a sand sled because it didn't seem worth the $40 for two which you then had to return before closing time.

Super hot sand in the summer, but very comfortable once the sun goes down. Mosquitos are vicious everywhere but on the dunes, although they seemed to stay away without having to use DEET bug spray. Be sure to rent a sandboard outside the park at least once. The 11 mile Medano Pass trail was interesting. Download the Medano Pass guide on the NPS website so you know kinda of where you are on the trail and what to look for.

What a surprise to find sand dunes at the base of mountains! There's plenty of parking. BUT, there are lots and lots of mosquitos!! Bring your bug spray! If you visit in the springtime or early summer, you will be able to wade in the running water from the mountains. Bring the appropriate footwear as some of the sandy areas have small sharp rocks. Be sure to rent a board to go sand boarding (about $18/ day). Rent them from in town. Walking in the sand is labor intense, so be prepared. The scenery is amazing. It is the highest sand dunes in the USA.

This was along the route we took through Colorado...and the kids had seen You tube videos of sand dune sledding....so we couldn't really pass it by. If you go with the intent to sled the dunes....MAKE SURE YOU STOP AT THE OASIS STORE BEFORE YOU ENTER THE PARK!!! They are the only ones with the sleds to rent. You cannot rent them in the park, and from what I saw, the plastic sleds/sheets of cardboard, etc. that others were trying to use simply did not work. It's a bit pricey IMO, ($20 a pop), but we rented 2 of them for our family of 7 and just took turns.
Take a backpack with plenty of water, a hat and a rain jacket if there's any chance of rain. Sand boards are available for rent in the visitor center. Park entrance fee is $15.

So, to start my review, I'm issuing a warning...when traveling to the Great Sand Dunes, DO NOT go over the MEDANO PASS if you are not FULLY EQUIPPED to do so. Basically, Jeep or other very high raised 4 wheel drive vehicle is ESSENTIAL to get through sand, rocks, and water. My friends GPS took us this way to get to the Great Sand Dunes. NOT A GOOD IDEA! we had no idea how treacherous it was until it was too late for us to turn around, so do yourself a favor, if you are traveling to the Dunes, take CO 160 from Walsenburg. The Dunes are worth the drive, but NOT over the Medano Pass. Best time to go would be early May, though. The snowmelt will produce a higher level of water to float on. Review the website before visiting for the most up to date info on conditions at the park. We visited in late June and there was only about 3-4 inches of snowmelt to play in. Lower water level was good for the toddler in the group and very refreshing to play in, but the mosquitoes were insane!!! The water is a breeding ground for the stinging pests! Bring repellent and SUNSCREEN! The Dunes get REALLY HOT but are so amazing to see and climb! Bring lots of water, and boots or shoes with high socks are the best ways to keep the hot sand out off of your ankles.

The sand dunes are a must see if you're traveling in the area. We went early morning and we were glad we did! By noon it was getting busy and the sand was getting very hot. We did rent a sand sled at the Oasis store right before you enter the park. The cost was $20 per sled and you had it for the day. I am an adult with married children and I had a blast sledding down the dunes! Of course after you go down you have the walk back up. It quickly gets exhausting but it's fun!

On Sunday, June 26th, 2016 we arrived about 9:30am after spending 15 minutes tied up in cow traffic. We literally drove a walking speed for more than half a mile with atvs and trucks herding cattle up the only road towards the park. I was concerned about lots of visitors on a Sunday, and we were third in line to pay the $15/car admission, but the line was 15 cars deep when we left at 11:15.

To photograph the dunes, it's best just before sunrise or 90 minutes before sunset. We chose to hike to the "High Dune" before sunrise. The air temperature was perfect, we avoided the heat of the day & the crowds. We crossed the creek barefoot and with our trekking poles. Then we put on our hiking boots. Once we started climbing the dunes, we found our trekking poles helpful. The photography was spectacular. On top of High Dune, we captured the beauty of the surrounding area. Unfortunately, due to a long, lingering winter, the upper reaches of Medano Pass Road was closed so we were unable to hike in that area. Zapata Falls was inaccessible as well...Zapata Creek was too cold and water flow dangerously high. Be prepared, lots of people hike this trail!

Spent the morning sledding the dunes with a sand sled rented at the Oasis gas station down the road for $20. I had heard typical snow sleds won't work and when I saw someone try it, it indeed did not! When we tired of sledding we spent some time on the river trying to raft. The water wasn't quite high enough to get far but we still had a good time. Small children had a blast just playing in the water. I would imagine camping on site would be a fun experience as we were in the hotel down the road.

Totally loving our National Park Pass. We came here about 8am on the Saturday of Memorial Day and so glad we came early!! According to all the signs the sand can get scorching hot (unlike White Sands, NM) so come early and wear proper shoes! You can hike all over the sand dunes, just be prepared because it can take quite some time.

We took our Boy Scout Troop to the Sand Dunes for Memorial Day weekend. They had a blast! The boys ranged in age from 12-16. The Dunes are beautiful and majestic, an amazing sight to see. I had been several years ago in the middle of the summer, but at this time of the year Medano Creek is flowing adding even more to explore! Several of the boys were interested in sand boarding on the dunes (rented from Sand Dunes Oasis - $20/board/day includes wax). Many of them were quite proficient by the end of the day! Other boys were happy to play "Dune Soccer" and still others had a blast playing in the creek. The deepest areas of the creek that we saw was about a foot to a foot and a half, more than enough to play in! The parents had a great time as well. The visitors center is a great place to learn about how the Dunes formed. I would highly recommend this trip to anyone who has not been - and a return trip for those that have! When hiking the dunes be sure to have either closed shoes (hiking boots, sneakers, etc) NOT sandals, or at least a pair of socks. The sand gets VERY HOT. Bring sunscreen, sunglasses, a hat, and a wind breaker. And as a couple of our scouts can tell you....swim trunks and a towel or at least a change of clothes is a good idea in case you decide to play in the creek!

After experiencing the sand dunes at Kitty Hawk in the Outer Banks and the Coral Pink Sand Dunes State Park in Utah, we knew that we did not want to miss any opportunity to experience the dunes at the Great Sand Dunes National Park when we visited Colorado this past week. Driving down the long road that approaches the park only wetted our appetite for the experience with beautiful views of the dunes and surrounding mountains. While we were there, we hiked the trail from the visitors center down to the dunes. Then, through the shallow creek and across the sand flats. Looking upwards, we saw others trudging up the "Chilkoot Pass" and decided we wanted to see the view from the top. We hiked up to one of the taller dunes with our 9 year old daughter. It was challenging but the view was incredible. After enjoying the view and catching our breath, we headed back down. My daughter completed all the activities needed to earn her Junior Ranger Badge. While everyone may not be fit enough to hike to the top of the dunes, there is defiantly a lot to see and do at this park for people of all ages and physical abilities.

I took my kids in our AWD Toyota RAV4 for a day at the Dunes and they loved it. It costs about $15 but you have a week to enjoy the park. We got there at 1pm to the visitors center. We were on the hot dunes by 1:20pm. It was a beautiful site but bring good tennis shoes so you can enjoy the dunes more. I was wearing sandals which were filling with small rocks and hot sand. You can rent boards to surf the dunes for a fee. Don't bring your dogs as the sand is too hot for their paws; unless, you just want to avoid the dunes and stay in the creek. The creek is only about 2 -5 inches deep at most but is fairly cool water. There is a hiking trail closer to the visitors center but we did not check it out. When we left aroun 4pm the mosquitoes at the parking lot were swarming! The area is desolate but beautiful if you like mountains,etc. There is also great camp sites with bear proof trash cans. Plenty of deer tracks were noted in the sand and off road area. The elevation is around 6900-7500 feet and the dunes rise up about 700 feet. The wind is blowing at a pretty good pace so you are going to feel the prevailing winds blasting you with sand. Depending on where you are on the dunes you might feel the wind and sand more. The drive there and back was stunning along US 160. There are gas stations and small town at Fort Garland but not much else so bring a cooler of drinks, sandwiches,etc. We are planning on going back this fall.

A neat view from a distance, but once we passed the Visitor's Center we were eaten up by mosquitos. They swarmed the car by the hundreds. We could not walk out on the Dunes because of this. We were out of the car about 8 minutes & received multiple bites. We went back to the Visitor's Center & they were out of insect repellant. I asked the ranger at the Visitor's Center why they didn't tell us that we needed insect repellant at the entrance gate & he just laughed & said " They don't bother you from here." The little store restaurant outside the entrance gate was charging $9 a can, so make sure that you buy some prior to getting to the area. Interesting to read about how the sand dunes are formed at the Visitor's Center. You can rent sleds at the little store right outside the park entrance so that you can sleigh ride down the sand. We would have tried this, if the mosquitos hadn't been so bad . This may have been a seasonal occurrence, but it was bad!

The store just outside the park rents sandboards for $20 a day. Grab one and hike up the dunes (tiring, but worth it). The boards go faster than you'd think, and as a result it's more fun than you'd think.

In September there isn't a lot of water flowing at the bottom of the dunes, but the weather is great for hiking the dunes and the trails. Mosca Pass has great views of the dunes. Take the time to rent a sled from Oasis, right outside the the entrance, we got 2 for 5 adults($45). Plan about 4-6 hours for a great family outing. Definitely stop at the visitor center to get your national parks passport stamped!!

I'm surprised the Sand dunes don't have more ratings. I'd rate this at the top of my list of favorite places to visit. We paid a small entrance fee at the gate, rented boards for $10 at the convenience store and hit the dunes. They look big from afar, but they're even bigger up close. Running up and riding down the dunes is exhausting fun. My only regret is that I didn't have more time here.

The park gets you immediately out of the metropolis that is Pigeon Forge. Deep and green, no commercial vehicles allowed in the park roads, it's a haven. We did the road to Cades Cove and the road across Newfound Gap. Yes, it's twisty and can be steep, but drive like a sane person and you'll be fine. The farm museum at Cades Cove, the John Oliver Place and the Mountain Farm Museum near Cherokee let you know what it was like for the settlers who were here. Views on the Newfound Gap Road are not as numerous as on Skyline Drive, but they are great. It's free to get in - you can add a dollar to all your park purchases or join the GSM Association that runs the concessions. Odds are you will see elk, bears, turkeys and more. Take it slow, make the time here last. Above all, be picky about time spent outside the park - Pigeon Forge is as thick as Orlando and mostly missable.

No matter how many times I go to the Smokies it's always an amazing time. The views are breathtaking and there is so much to do in the park. I love going to the Visitors Centers and picking up the $1 guide books for the things we are going to do for a little more in depth information. They made both the Roaring Fork Motor Trail and Cades Cove more enjoyable. I love that they really run the gristmill at Cades Cove and the Mingus Mill. Laurel Falls is a gorgeous hike and definitely worth the walk to see the double drop falls. Clingmans dome is breathtaking on a clear day, but if it is foggy it isn't worth the "pain" of hiking up there. I can't say enough about how much I love this National Park!!!

Our family had not visited here in over 20 years. It was crowded to say the least. In my opinion this being a national park, they need to do something about the traffic. It is nightmarish. If they would just charge $5.00 per car, a lot could be done to make it great. There is much beauty here, but with the amount of people it is difficult to enjoy it or find a place without 1000 other folks.

The Great Smoky Mountains Park is a great place to visit during the summer and the fall. It is especially nice during fall when the leaves peak. We got there a little too soon this year and the trees were turning but had not peaked. It was still beautiful. There is something very peaceful about a drive through the mountains. If you are staying in Gatlinburg you can take the trolley route through part of the mountains. The Tan route will take you up into the smpkey mountains to Sugarland visitor center and to the parking lot at Laurel Falls. The trip lasts about 1.5 hours and it only costs $2. The tan trolley runs until the end of October. A great way up the mountain if you are like me and not too keen on driving. If you are looking to go farther up in the mountains you will need to drive.

This is actually a nice campground right in the suburbs and not far from urban DC. Clean adequate rest room facilities. Nice wooded campground. Some flat and some sloped sites. Friendly ranger staff. Buy wood at the supermarket before you get here. We came in mid October, still lots of leaves and a decent number of people. I recommend it if you are new to camping, don't want to go too far or don't want t spend $400 a night for a DC hotel.

Randomly came here for one day of camping. There were plenty of sites far enough away from everyone to give some privacy, but close enough so that you feel safe. They had a self registration and payment envelope we used. This is dry camping, so there are not electrical outlets or water hooks ups, but they have water points and bathrooms. Each site has a fire pit, a parking slot and a tent pad. You cannot beat it for only $16. We stayed overnight and left the next day.

wonderful location for dc sightseeing time for a complete makeover and I am sure the n p s is not up for the task!! please consider outsourceing to private enterprise and save this asset for the camper. not to mention the tax dollars saved!!

Our family camped here for two nights during spring break. Only 10 min to Greenbelt Metro station. Park police station at park entrance, it does take a few minutes to get back to the campground. None of the sites have electric or water, which we knew, so it was ok, as long as your prepared. Not all restrooms have a shower, the "B" loop had one shower. They were not very clean and the park was quite empty while we were there. I attempted a hot shower and got about 2 min of warm water, but it was shortly after somone else took a quick shower. Our two dogs did fine there as well. Overall we had a nice experience, just know your not getting first class restrooms. The park seemed to have nice walking trails, but we did not have time to enjoy. $16 dollars a night that close to DC and all those free museums, it definately worth it.

We chose this campground because it was so cheap and very close to the College Park Metro station, a 3 min. drive away. We took the train into the city to the zoo and museums every day, between 25-30 min ride each way. Parking at the station is FREE on weekends too, so you save a lot by camping here and using the train. Considering the train tickets were about $4.00 round trip, this is incredible compared to paying for $20/hour parking in the city, IF you can find parking near the attractions at all.

The best little secret in D.C.....dry camping at it's best....16 miles from the capital....2 miles from the metro....very good site/ ok showers and facilities...all for $16/night....would return in a heart beat....for a few days......beautiful park.....
Cheap RV and tent spots! Another example of government charging a super low price since the park is supported by your federal tax dollars already.

My family (husband, myself, and 3 kids ranging in age from 1 to 11) stayed 2 nights at Greenbelt recently. We were amazed how few people were at the park. The campground host was friendly and helpful. Our campsite was flat and close to the access trail to walk to catch the metro at College Park station. We felt safe, comfortable, and enjoyed the convenience of easy access (1/2 hour walk) to the metro for day trips into DC. For $16 a night, it was quite a bargain! We highly recommend Greenbelt.

We camped here for 10 days while visiting family and sites in the D.C. Area. It was beautiful and very well located. At $10 a night with a Senior Pass it is unbeatable in the area. The camp area and restrooms are in need of updates including energy efficiency, but they were adequate. Some sites are not so level, but the natural area and hiking paths made up for it. It is secure ate the end of a long road with the Park Police substation at the entrance. All conveniences were nearby.

Arrived at the Visitor Center around 11:00am on a Sunday. Rangers were very nice and informative. Entrance fee for park is $5 per person. There is a 12 minute slide show that is played upon request, a few exhibits, a small gift store and bathrooms. A sign said that the trailhead parking was full, but we drove the 1/3 mile to it anyway and did find a parking spot - otherwise, you can leave your car at the Visitor Center and walk to the trail head. By the trailhead there is a small campground and there are restrooms and a water bottle filling station. We did the Devil's Hall Trail which is 4.2 miles total out and back. This is not a strenuous hike, though there are some elevation changes as well as some rock scrambling. We spent 4 hours on this hike, but we take lots of pictures, are not fast hikers, and we found a nice spot to sit and eat lunch during the hike. We passed several other day hikers, but it was not crowded and everyone we met was very friendly. Take plenty of water. There is a lot of shade on this trail and we had a nice breeze. Trailhead is shared with other trails, but the junctions are well marked. Most of this trail follows a gully - this is where the rock scrambling is and in many places there is no clear trail -- just pick the best path through the gully. The trail ends at a slot canyon called Devil's Hall marked with a sign. Return the way you came. While we did not see any, another hiker did warn us that they had seen a rattlesnake. Note that the park is in the Mountain Time zone, but you are so close to Central that your cell phones may display Central time. By the Visitor's Center, we also took the short (0.6 miles) Pinery Trail to the Butterfield Stage Station Ruins. The ruins were two rock walls, so not particularly interesting. But, there were some displays along the way about the vegetation and the history of the Station. There is also a small parking lot just east of the Visitor's Center that is a closer walk to the ruins/history displays.
If you go to the Caverns might as well travel another 45 miles and get your Passport stamped. Great view of the mountains.

This is a small park but was just south of the Carlsbad Caverns, so we stopped for a visit. The visitor center had impressive displays for such a small park. Not much else to offer at the park except hiking. We took a trail from the McKlintock(?) Canyon trail head, past an old homestead, up through pretty boring scenery to a waterfall oasis. That was beautiful, but being the only 2 people on the trail the entire time was creepy, considering the wildlife possibilities. It was long rough hike on rough uneven stones and quite an incline, although it was listed just as a moderate hike. I didn't care for it. People also warned us about driving through the Guadalupe Pass because of strong winds and possibility of flash flooding. We did not go that far, but wanted to pass along the heads up.

My wife and I visited Guadalupe Mountains National Park two times in 2015. Available at the park are RV campsites, tent campsites, 10 backcountry tent campgrounds, and miles upon miles of hiking trails, most quite well marked. In early May 2015 we camped for one night in the Pine Springs Campground and climbed the trail to Guadalupe Peak the next day. There were quite a few RVs in the RV section of the campground but we easily found a space for our camper. The Guadalupe Mountains official website states there are 19 RV spaces. Restroom facilities, potable water supply, and pay phone are available at the RV campground. Fee is $8.00 per night for RV campers. Fee for hiking in the mountains is $5.00 for a 7 day pass. The trail to Guadalupe Peak is easy to follow. The climb is very strenuous for the first mile and a half. Guadalupe Peak is the high point of Texas (8,749 feet) and the summit is approximately 4.3 miles from the Pine Springs campground. From the summit the views are great as you look out over the floor of the Chihuahuan Desert below to the east, south, and west; to the north you see Shumard Peak and Bush Mountain. At the summit it was quite windy and cool. Numerous people were on the trail either ascending or descending. In November 2015, we camped two nights in the Pine Springs Campground. There were a number of RV campers, but still there were empty spaces available for others. I hiked the Tejas and Bush Mountain Trails on this trip. I hiked up Tejas Trail, which is quite well marked, for approximately 3.6 miles to the junction of the Tejas and Bush Mountain trails and then 2.3 miles to the summit of Bush Mountain, the second highest mountain in Texas. (8,631 feet). Views into Pine Spring Canyon from Tejas Trail at this time of year are spectacular, to say the least. Numerous maple trees in the canyon were blazing red and other trees' leaves were bright yellow. The Bush Mountain trail is not nearly so well maintained. It leads to Bush Mountain--obviously enough--2.3 miles to the west of the junction of trails. Total distance covered in the Bush Mountain hike was slightly under 12 miles. This hike is very strenuous. It was quite windy all of the way--going and returning. I did not see another person all day long. If you like solitude and a very strenuous hike this will fill the bill. Guadalupe Mountains National Park is a great place to visit, but be aware that it is rather remote and the nearest city of any size, Carlsbad, New Mexico is approximately 50 miles distant.

Guadalupe National Park is a pleasant surprise in western Texas. The park rangers were wonderful - they were so friendly in helping us to explore the park. We stayed in the RV park - quite a value at $4/night with a Senior Pass. What a spectacular view from our campsite. We did several hikes including a night time walk with a ranger. Be sure to hike early - it can get extremely hot in the summer. The park has an excellent Junior Ranger program for kids - our grandchildren loved it.
The Black Canyons of the Gunnison is impressive black rocks with bursts of diamonds(silica) in them that really glitter when the sun strikes them. It costs $15 or you need a National Park pass.
Nice forest really beautiful, would like to see in the fall. Monarch Pass is a really nice pass to drive and very scenic

Enjoyed dispersed camping in the Taylor Park area for two weeks. Surprised at the large number of dual sports, dirt bikes and ATVs/UTVs -- we wondered if we had stumbled into a convention or reunion or a meetup of some kind. Great roads nearby for all skill levels of riders. All riders we saw were polite, respectful and safety-conscious; very family-friendly. Rumors of great fishing in the Taylor Reservoir and area streams and rivers. Dump station nearby for RVs for $6; potable water available at nearby Taylor trading post, as well as basic groceries and non-ethanol fuel. Restaurant at trading post, but we did not eat there. Horseback riding at nearby Harmel's Ranch Resort an extra plus. Hiking available locally, as well.

This year the trip over Ohio and Kebler Passes was delayed by clouds and rain. Finally on day 4 the sun appeared and I took wonderful photos. The Aspen trees had more red showing this year too. Had a scary experience on the narrow road over Ohio Pass. It had snowed the previous day and the road was in poor condition. Almost got stuck in the ice on top of mud incline near the top. No traction and had to back down to a wide spot to get back to Gunnison. I prayed that I wouldn't go over the cliff and fortunately another photographer helped me to settle my nerves. Probably should have tried 4 wheel drive but was too upset to think of it. Photos were worth it though !

We traveled from Aspen to New Mexico (by car) thru Macclure Pass and Gunnison National Forest k at end of 2014 / beginning 2015. Was unbelievable beautiful. A LOT of snow and one place most beautiful than other.

Ohio and Kebler Passes are a yearly trek for me in the fall for the Aspens. Even with the drought this year, the colors were fabulous ! I also got to see snow on the peaks alongside the Castles for the first time. Breathtaking ! John Denver's lyric Almost heaven West Virginia should have been Colorado. Oh well, this is a true Rocky Mountain High destination. Around every bend you will say WOW !
This is a fabulous area to visit in the fall in Colorado! Road trips over Ohio and Kebler Passes are breathtaking. Crested Butte,Black Canyon and Taylor Park Reservoir are just a short drive away.

We are constantly in search of good camping spots in Colorado. This spot is about a 3.5 to 4 hour drive from Denver. If it's good weather, make sure to take Cottonwood Pass from Buena Vista instead of going all the way down through Gunnison. It saves about 45 minutes of driving, but the road is pretty rough.

You need reservations for the sunrise at the park, so make them early...it only cost $1.50, bring your National Park Pass. Plan to get there 45-1hour before sunrise for a good viewing spot. Dress for 30 degree temperatures, check there is no rain in the forecast. Enjoy!

We had a last minute idea to see the sunrise. Discovered that now one has to book the reservation for sunrise entry from 3-7 am ahead of time on recreation.gov. It only cost a $1.50. Dress warm. The park is gorgeous, the views are spectacular. We have not made a reservation and had to wait till 7am. I think we have missed the most beautiful part of sunrise. Still worth it.

Recently drove up Haleakala to view the sunrise. You must make reservations ($1.50 per vehicle), with the National Park Service first, as only 150 vehicles are allowed for each sunrise. No reservation, no entry, between the hours of 3:00am and 7:00am, no reservation needed after 7:00am but you still have to pay the $25.00 per vehicle fee.

Absolutely amazing sunset from the top. Don’t spend the $120-150 on the dinner tours, cheaper to hire a car and drive up yourself!! If you’ve had experience driving around bends in your home country you should have no problem with this drive. I also hear the sunset is nowhere near as busy as the sunrise. And a lot cheaper!!

This is a definite must see while on Maui. The road up the Volcano has beautiful views of the Island on your way up. There might be a few clouds to deal with on the way up, but it's usually clears as you get futher up. There is a $25 park fee to pay since it is a national park, but well worth it. The visitor center staff was very helpful in directing you to what you might want to see or do. Once at the top the view is awesome, there are many different spots to get different views from. If feel energetic you can hike down into the crator, or higher up the montain. I highly recommend this for all ages.

The park was beautiful . I recommend checking if the 7 sacred pools are open prior to making the entire trek from Hana . There is a $25 fee for the car and it can be very disappointing . We arrived around three and the pools were closed . It was too late to do the hike to the 2 waterfalls and it was over 30 minutes from Hana . The park was beautiful and right on the ocean . The fee will let you in the crater as well .

We decided not to come at sunrise. You need a reservation - preferably weeks or months in advance. You might want to get your National Park Pass in advance of your journey. The road to Haleakala is long and windy and you shouldn't be speeding. Enjoy the view along the way.

Can not actually comment on Haleakala Crater from our own experience. Others have strongly recommended it though, along with people that we met while vacationing on Maui. What I'm writing about regards the Haleakala sunrise tour. You most likely will want to schedule this in advance! We had heard so much about seeing the sunrise from atop Mt. Haleakala; how beautiful it is, and with its moonscape type setting, you just don't want to miss this. Unfortunately; there is very limited parking, and the National Park Service limits the amount of parking passes during the 3:00am-7:00am time frame. You can schedule this in advance on line; if you're successful, there is $1.50 charge. We were on Maui for ten days; I tried daily, and was unsuccessful (actually, there was one day open, i think it was for the next day, and we already had something scheduled). I don't believe that the next opening wasn't available for about a month away. A park ranger suggested that I try daily, as they may open up some passes at, or after 4:00pm.

The view from 10,000 feet is amazing, as the sun streaks through the clouds below. Many people pay the $25 entrance fee to see sunrise (which, we assume, also must be awesome), though we chose to go an hour before sunset to avoid the crowds and the bikes hauling down the road. The switchbacks and steep dropoffs just a few feet from the road surface will challenge those whose stomachs get unsettled easily but, for most, this is a relatively easy drive up and down (even in the dark, on the way down). This drive is far easier than The Road to Hana (itself very nice). Don't miss this.

Check the weather first, maybe when you're at the bottom. But don't let mid level clouds fool you - that will only make the sunset more spectacular! Absolutely amazing! We were able to find a parking space at the summit, but there were plenty of cars that came in a tad late and made their own spaces. Truly remarkable views and colors. A once in a lifetime MUST experience. We did not hike at all. Pathway to the summit and viewing platform were a number of steps; the other side of the platform is where you'll watch the sunset from and it's an easy walk to a dirt area or very small climb along a dirt path along the lava rocks. Make sure you have a blanket even for sunset - into the low 50's in June. It's an hour drive from the very bottom, a full 1/2 hour to the summit from the place where you buy your $25 park pass. You can use your National Park Pass from other locations, too - check that out online. Note that if you're going for sunrise, you do need reservations.

A must see, if you want to know the history of volcanoes in Hawaii. Great views. You will see so many interesting things as you climb up the crater or you can just enjoy the spectacular views from the summit area. It takes about an hour to drive from the bottom and about a half hour to reach the summit. If you have a National Park Pass, you can use it here too.

Our family loves visiting national park service sites and Haleakala National Park was no different. We visited the Kipahula district first and saw the 7 sacred pools (Ohe'o Gulch) and hiked the Pippiwai trail through the bamboo forest to Waimoku Falls. Admission to the park is $20 but it is good for 3 days so we also visited the main section of the park two days later to take in the sunset. We got there early and hiked into the crater on the Sliding Sands trail which was fantastic. The headquarters visitors center closes at 3:45 which I hadn't checked and we just barely made it to stamp our passport.

Glad we woke at 2 to leave at 3am. Recommended from Wailea/Kihei area. Must make a reservation as soon as 2 months in advance, some available two days prior online as well. It is chilly, but the shelter helps shield the wind. I'm always cold but was fine with a cami, tshirt, sweater, hoodie and socks over my hands. No need to pack a parka for Hawaii. Many has blankets and beach towels. Go early in the vacation before you adjust to Hawaiian time. I wouldn't recommend doing the bike trip. National park no longer allows tour companies to bike from the top after 3 fatal accidents a few years ago. Vans aren't allowed into the summit parking lot any longer so you might as well reserve online for $1.50, and pay $20 upon arrival per car. Credit card preferred. Bikers can start further down the mountain. It looked dangerous. No really large bike lanes.

Got up at 3 am to drive 2 hours to the top of this Crater.You must make a reservation for $1.25 ahead of time online just to ensure your entry, we made ours a month in advance. It was $20 per car to enter the bottom of the Park.You don't realize that you are on this narrow road driving up above the clouds because it is dark..... So many twists and turns ,it goes on and on and finally you are in the parking lot .You layer on the warm clothes because it's about 35 degrees up there in the dark. We waited with 70 or more other visitors all cramming up against the railing to get he best view. We listened to the sunrise prayer/chant and watched the glorious sun slowly rise above the clouds. Everyone clapped and cheered. Took a bunch of photos. It looks like t=what the moon would look like when the sun comes out.. Very exciting.

We made a reservation for $1.5 ahead of time online one month ago. Wake up at 3:00am and drive 2 hours to the top from Kihei. We have National Park pass, so we do not need pay the ticket at door. The top is cold and windy, but all worth for the Sunrise. It was incredible amazing beautiful watching.

Advisory: you cannot go into the park for sunrise without a prior reservation. The park service had to limit the number allowed up daily for safety reasons. You can make your reservation online through the national park service. Take a printed copy with you, just in case. The reservation is $1.50, but admittance to the National Park is $20, which gives you a 3 Day pass. They can accept a credit card at the gate, but best to take cash, in case of a WiFi failure. The summit is about 10k feet.

This is a remote location to really get in touch with nature and leave the world behind. You will feel like it's a whole separate world once you take the drive from Hana. It's a must spend the night. The crashing of the waves was so enticing, we left our van open. Very safe. There is no running water at the camp area, but there is up at the visitors center. If you're looking for a relaxing place and twenty dollars gets you three nights camp. Cannot express the beauty of this place.

We went up for the sunrise from the summit. Make sure you make a reservation ahead of time on their website (it costs $1.50 but there are only so many spots). We got up to the summit early at 3.30am and watched some stars. We got to see the most amazing shooting star. We fell asleep in our car and woke up at 5.30 about 45 minutes before the sunrise and the sky was already getting light and the summit viewing area was getting crowded, but it was really pretty. We were way above the clouds at over 10,000 ft above sea level. If I went back a second time, I would go for sunset to get a different experience. After the sunrise we spent some time looking around on the summit and then hiked partway into the crater on the sliding sands trail. It's like being on Mars! My only regret it not hiking further into the crater. The Sliding sands trail starts at the visitor center near the summit, so if you park your car up there then you have to hike back up (which we did). What they recommend it parking your car at the bottom visitor center and hitching a ride up to the top visitor center in the morning so you can hike your way all the way down. There are lots of other trails in the this park that can take you a few hours to a few days. Either way the crater is a must see!

Beautiful sunrise above the clouds. Being above the clouds was a real treat! And hiking in the crater is surreal and unique. Feels like you're on the moon. And it is the quietest place I've ever been to. A must visit if you're in Maui!

Initially this was not on our list of things to see on our visit to Maui, but a friend of mine who had lived in Hawaii convinced us to go. The only time we had available was the afternoon/evening of our first night on Maui. The sunset was beautiful and I believe less crowded than sunrise. As others have said, make sure you bring warm clothes. It was about 55 F the day we were there. My kids have never gotten car sick before, but after the hour long drive down the mountain in the darkness, one of them got sick at the end of the trip. If you have the National Park Access Pass for disabled people, just be advised that the payment gate is automated now and so there is no way know if you are allowed to enter for free. Based on other reviews here I downloaded the Gypsy app and it was worth every penny.
Highly recommended, a must-see while in Hawaii. Wear adequate clothing, its cold & windy. Costs $20 per car to enter the park.

I went to the park website in advance and reserved 3 different days during our trip. It was $1.50 per day to do this. If you want to go for the sunrise at the summit, you need this to get into the park. We picked what sounded like the best day for this journey and left our condo in Lahaina at 2:15am. We were there early enough to get one of the parking spots at the top but many cars beat us there. Park Rangers are there to ask you to move if you park anywhere that is not a designated parking spot. We brought warm clothing and even our beach towels to wrap around us. It was cold up there and the wind made it very cold! There is a shelter that you can stand in to get out of the wind and wait for the sunrise. We talked to someone who was up there for the 3rd time. There were clouds on his other two trips so this was the day he got to see all the beauty of the sunrise! It is a long journey and we felt very lucky to have gone on the right day. So much color and it all seems so much closer when you are up there. On the drive back down we saw a rainbow that was also beautiful. If you can handle getting up in the middle of the night, the long drive and the cold you will really enjoy this! We were very happy that we were able to see the sunrise!

You are now required to make reservations (they cost $1.50 on the NPS website) to go up for sunrise and will be turned back if you don't. It's a long and arduous drive up to near the summit but it is totally worth it. Believe those who say it is COLD and wear everything warm you have including gloves and hat (they don't take up much room in your suitcase) because you want to be there about 45 minutes before sunrise to see the glow and the change as the sun rises. It takes about 2 hours to get there for West Maui and you can get delayed at the reservation checkpoint and the NPS booth so leave early. You won't regret it!

First let me say you MUCT get there early and beginning Feb 2017 you must make a reservation ($5) if you want to park at the top - and that is the BEST location. It is cold and windy so dress warm. Time lapse photography is amazing if you have the ability. Take a thermos of something warm to drink but drink cautiously because there is no bathroom at the top! There are bathrooms at the visitor center a little lower - cute little gift shop with great views of volcanic rock is worth stopping for, even if you don't need the bathroom :)

Go and watch the sunrise but pack a sweatshirt because it can be cold up there. A beautiful national park to spend a few hours and see nature. Don't forget to bring your US National Park's Passport Book to get stamped!

This park encompasses a vast area of land. There are camping areas, hiking trails and of course the Haleakala summit. Admission is $20/car, less for motorcycle, pass is good for 3 days and is good both here and Kipahulu. After the booth is closed for the day it is on the honor system via credit cards. When we went to watch the sunset, I must say there are few honorable people left. There were 4 cars infront of us and not one stopped to pay. Both the lower and upper visitor centers were closed by the time we arrived. A lot to see and do here, least of which is the SUNRISE or SUNSET over the crater. Be advised though, the weather dictates the experience.

Wow! This took some effort as it was a 2 hour drive from the Westin Maui. We left the resort at 2:30 a.m. and arrived at the entrance at 4:00a.m. After paying $20 for the entrance fee you're driving another half an hour to the viewing point. I'd say the first 45 minutes were fairly tame curvy road wise but after that it's all curves and switchbacks. I'm not sure if it was better not to see how close you were to the edge of the road or not! No guard rails. Just pay attention, mind the speed limits and caution signs and you'll be fine. When we arrived, we were probably about the tenth car with plenty of parking spaces available. Took an hour or so nap in the car and woke up to a completely packed lot with people already standing by the rails to get the best view of the sunrise. It was really cold outside (47 degrees with gusty winds) so I viewed the sunset from the inside of the visitor's center. Worth the wait as you see the clouds illuminated by the morning light - brillant. I was told that you could hear chanting/song if you stayed outside. I'm sorry I missed that. Bring a jacket or hoodie to keep you warm. You'll need them. Leaving the park was fairly easy traffic wise. The visitor center does not have snacks or beverages so make sure you bring your own. The restrooms are clean and fairly nice. Enjoy, we sure did!

It cost $20 to enter the park and it's credit card only. The pass is good for 3 days though so keep your receipt. In the park you have Haleakala Crater and 7 sacred pools on the southern end. Two very good attractions. Park has restroom facilities.

An experience you do not want to miss. Sunset is just as cold as sunrise at the top. We bought blankets at Costco, but needed warmer clothes like hats, gloves, and scarves too. But, the view was absolutely magical. We liked it better than the sunrise!

I have been a lot of places in this world and seen a lot of things, and Haleakala is one of the most unique. I have a National Park Pass, so we didn't have to pay for our car. Driving up the cone is an experience in itself as you climb higher and higher and steeper and steeper to reach the visitor's center at 9740 foot elevation. Plant to spend time here to take in the huge expanse of the muti-colored crater with dozens of small cones rising up from the floor. A review of the park description will tell you about all the different parts of the volcano and what you see from the lookout. There's a lot more than can be discussed here, so plan to spend the day at the park. There is a model of the park and a guide will explain all the areas of the park. This presentation was well worth the time. There are several more lookouts than can be reached by car, and they are well worth the effort to get there. There is a part of the park that I will not address here that is at the south shore of the island near the town of Hana, and it is also a great destination.

The drive up to the 10000 ft summit is kind of long but it is only 1 lane each side so if you are a slowwwww drivers then please find a good place on your right side of the lane to let cars from behind to pass you, most appreciated, specially I saw a lot of international tourists came there maybe they are not used to drive in US. Along the roast there are a lot of restrooms from visitor centers so use those before to get to the summit since I did not see any restroom there. The air is thin at 10,000 ft so prepare yourselves if you want to challenge yourselves with biking up there, if you make it to the summit then it is a big accomplishment. We got in on a free pass day for 100th anniversary of national parks otherwise it is $20 for single car. Enjoy, we had fun and the view of beaches and colored Valley are perfectly beautiful.

After visiting the Maui Winery, we decide to make the drive to the top of Haleakala. What a drive it was! this is not a drive for the faint of heart. The road is fairly narrow and there are lots of hairpin turns. The cost to drive to the top is $20 per car. You should also know that you need to get reservations for entering the park to see the sunrise on your own.

We had high hopes for this adventure. We got up at 2:30 a.m. and drove up the mountain - getting there at 4:30, which gave us a good parking spot. However, we had to wait for sunrise in the car because it was so cold and windy. It was 28 degrees with 34 mph winds. Then the tour company buses and hoards of people arrived, all jostling you for a place at the rail. People were loud and most were complaining about the cold. It was not the way we wanted to experience the sunrise. We actually could not wait for it to be over and go down the mountain. As we were going down a bike tour van kept honking at us because we weren't going fast enough and then passed us on a curve.. Crazy! I am so glad we got down before all the bikers started. I think the park is beautiful and we met people who went during the day and had a wonderful time, good views and no crowds. One good tip: if you have it, bring your Senior Park Pass for admission.

Sunrise at Haleakala is freezing. Everyone should tell you this but for real it snows. Bring shoes and socks and wear straight up winter gear. Also, unless you're active duty military (who get in free to any National Park, I think) you're gonna pay $10 a person to get into the park. (Or $20 a car, I wasn't sure which.)

WOW! So glad we got up! Book 30 days in advance to reserve your opportunity to get to the top of the mountain to enjoy the sunrise. It will cost you $1.50 to book online and $25 at the guard gate. If memory serves, they DO NOT accept cash. Make sure you fill your gas tank the night before and bring a hot beverage. The mountain opens at 3am and there is nothing open near the mountain that early.

Plan a trip EARLY in your vacation to Hawaii since you will be waking up early anyway. Fantastic sunrise and beautiful skies. Plan on 2 hour minimum drive time to get to the top and you MUST make a reservation now at recreation.gov. Otherwise they wont let you in. They started this in March to limit the number of vehicles and allow for parking. Cost is $1.50 per car, so not much.

The only way you can see the sunrise is making a reservation on the National Parks website. It cost $1.50. MAKE YOUR RESERVATION EARLY! It sells out weeks in advance. You CANNOT get into the park before 7am without it. If you don't need to see the sunrise, come after 7am no problem. IF you get a reservation, they have your name at the gate so when you show up just have and ID on hand. You still have to pay park admission separately-$25.

We actually went in May 2015. I just took too long to post a review. Drive to Haleakala state park. The switchback ramps are really incredible by themselves. Look out for bikers coming down. You drive up to the top of the mountain, then you can park and walk down into the valley. Wear sneakers because its a long walk but the view is so beautiful that you always want to walk farther. Bring fully charged camera devices, wear pants and hiking boots (or sneakers) and light shirt with a sweater. Go early (after sunrise, about 8am). There's a $10 for National Park fee but so worth it. Go early because there's less people.

Incredible views worth the 2:30am wake up effort! You can drive your car in (even if the reservations are sold out--) There are 40 tickets that are released at 4pm everyday 48 hours ahead of time. You must make the rez on the national park website and it's $1.50, then it's $25 to get into the park. It beats paying $200 for a tour...and then having the tour bus leave before the sky opened up and the most amazing otherworldly views I've ever experienced. (This happened to a few people staying in my hotel.) I drove and stayed until 8am just soaking it in! It was AMAZING.

Just like everyone mentioned, you can make the dollar $1.50 reservation online up to two months in advance and they do sell out. We had been in the park the day before at the end of the road to Hana and height so we already had a pass to get in even though they do take your name at the gate.

Driving up to see the sunrise from the top of Mt. Haleakala is definitely worth it. We were staying in Lahaina so we left around 2:30 in the morning. The weather was iffy the entire way but the drive gets you above the clouds and the sight is magnificent. The nice part about the drive up is that you don't have to see how terrifying the view down is if fear of heights gets to you. You can stop at the first parking lot and hike up(literally like 5 minutes and my father in law that uses a cane to walk did it) to the top of the crater edge. Tons of people stand at the level of the parking lot so hike up to get away from them. You can also continue on the road to watch from the summit but the view seemed better from the crater edge. We drove up to the Summit afterwards. The fee to get in was $20 but that pass was good for 3 days, we used it again to enter the park on the other side of the mountain near the Seven Sacred Pools. It is cold up there so bring something, my dad just grabbed the comforter off his bed. I wore jeans and a rain jacket and was fine. You are at 10,000 feet so its way colder. The photo is mine and we drove through very questionable weather and clouds so you can see that its worth it to push on through.

The Haleakala Crater section of the park involves a drive up the volcano from sea level to 10,000 feet in about 20 miles, so the roads are steep and winding. The scenery changes as you ascend from lush tropical plants to the silverswords on the summit. We watched the sunrise on one morning - bring warm clothes. On our return another day, the mountain was in a thick cloud and we could not see the crater. Hosmer Grove near the park entrance was fantastic for seeing many native endangered bird species. Don't forget to visit the coastal section of the park past Hana. There are wonderful hikes including the 2 mile Pīpīwai Trail ending at the 400-foot Waimoku Falls. Along the hike you pass through a variety of forests including an eerie bamboo forest where you walk on boardwalks. This trail is moderately strenuous with an 800-foot elevation change each way. You pay one entrance fee which allows you to enter the park for 3 days. Or better yet, for $25, you can purchase a Hawaii Tri-Park pass which gives you annual entrance to this park as well as the Volcano National Park on the Big Island.

We took the sunrise tour with Temptation Tours. Our guide, Scott Ferguson was outstanding. His explanations of what to expect to see and how to prepare for it were invaluable. He got us to the viewing point quite early which was the correct thing to do. We had a "front row" view of the sunrise. With his prior experience, he even suggested what our camera setting should be for the best photos. He enhanced our visit manifold over what we could have encountered on our own. The excursion was worth every dollar spent. His preparation for the cold weather included bringing extra garments for those who were not totally prepared for 28 degree temperature and 35 m.p.h. winds. (Very thoughtful). We highly recommend this tour and the company, Temptation Tours. Carolyn & Dave Horn

We decided to drive up to Haleakala during the day as we were older and didn't want to drive the road at night time. It was a good trip about half a day if you are planning to make it from Lahaina. A little scary driving through the clouds, but once on top it was breathtaking!! They did charge $25 to go into the park during the day. And, you must pay by credit card as they do NOT accept cash.

Again I set out for the peak of Haleakala at Haleakala National Park. Friend from Maui drove their car and a relative who enjoyed their first glimpse of Hawaii started out from Kahalui. The Maui friend with previous heart failure stayed behind as all persons with significant heart and lung disease should not go above 8000 feet without oxygen. Gas from Costco first as 66 cents less than anywhere else in Maui ,climb the many hair pin curves up the mountain and then we showed our senior US National Park card for free entrance of our carload. Clouds had hidden the peak of Halleakala until about 3/4 of the drive.

Each Visit i return to the crater. The trip from Kaanapali is a couple of hours by car so at 4:30 ( cant sleep the first two days anyways) head up to the road to the airport, and follow Rt 36 then 37 to the crater. Beware the police prey on lost tourists,so watch your speed. The best tiem is for sunrise , but check the weather. Cost for the nat'l park is $15 and sunrise is breathtaking. temp is around 40 and breezy so no beach wear, there is great hiking here but at 10,000 feet it isnt for the casual hiker. Big sell on biking down the hill but that wasn't for me, and is over sold. Loved the sunrise it as usual.

The price for this is a bit steep at around $100. I would feel much better about it if they provided the transport from their meet up point. However, I did very much enjoy the tour. A friend decided to join at the last minute, when we arrived we found she had booked with the competing company that offers this tour. So, she went with that company and I went with mine. Both provide warm clothes for you at the top and a chance to see the stars through high quality telescopes. However, my super enthusiastic lady also provided snacks and viewing the sunset from the upper viewing area. My friend’s tour did have a better telescope/filters and maybe better commentary on what you were seeing. The sunset and stars are also fully accessible without the tour. The tours offer warm clothes and the telescopes

$15 gets you through the gate and adventures begin. I'd like to suggest doing the hike to the waterfall first where you will go through the bamboos forest. The head to seven sacred pools and swim to cool down.

What can you say about a place that is so Beautiful other than WOW. This place is so awesome with so many things to do. It's a must stop if you got the time. I only wish I had more time explore more. The Fee is good for a few days. Another gift from the gods. I also been to Mount Olympus in Greece both are truely amazing.

We drove up to the top of Haleakala starting around 9:30 AM one morning. The drive is beautiful with steep sides and many places have no guardrails. Once you get into the park, there is no charge if you have a National Parks senior pass, otherwise I believe it is a $10-15 per carload cost to get into the park.

2016 will mark Haleakala's NP Centennial. We were there on a very blustery, chilly day. It's hard to describe the view. Park Ranger inside the visitors center was very informative. Great displays inside. Over 10,000 feet to the summit. A 37 mile drive up from sea level. A must visit when on the island of Maui! We had a National Park Pass which covered everyone in the car.

Worth it in ever regard! Views, family time and forever memories. $15 to get in exact cash or credit. Ask your hotel about blankets to bring or at least sit on. With my jacket and all my clothes we were cold. We got there a little over and hour before sunrise and watched shooting stars and got front row seats on the wall. No camera can do it justice.
Drive the road to hana! Hike the 2 mile hike to the waterfall. Pass by the sign and go swim in the waterfall! Cliff dive into the 7 sacred pools! You won't regret it!

A LONG drive of winding roads to get to the park. About 20 minutes past Hana. $10 admission per car. We first went to Ohe'o Gulch. Beautiful waterfalls, and pools. A easy walk to see from the parking lot. We walked the Pipiwai Trail. Much longer and harder than suggested. It was hot and more miles than 2 each way. The bamboo forest was lovely. The falls at the end, nice, but I will not do this again.

We went for the sunrise this morning and it was beautiful. We stayed in Wailea and it took us about an hour and a half from our condo to the summit. It is amazing how many people are on their way up the mountain that early in the morning! Everyone seemed to drive at a reasonable speed, not too fast or slow. It is a little bit of a wait when you get to the ranger station to pay and it costs $10 per car. There are two different parking areas and places to view. The first one we were told has a lady that tells a story as the sun is rising, but we decided to go the little extra way up to the summit instead. There is a little viewing area that is enclosed and covered to help with the cold. Remember to bring warm clothes with you becuase it is very cold up there. It's an amazing sight to see that everyone should experience in their lifetime. Even with the low clouds it's still stunning and worth the trip!

Great value at $10 for a wonderful drive up the mountain. Great views but you might have to wait for the clouds to shift, which they seem to do every 15 minutes or so. Saw some interesting wildlife too!

Many people come to witness the sunrise from the summit of the volcano high above the clouds. If you come for that, plan to arrive at least an hour before sunrise, preferably 2; the parking lots will fill up. Plan time for the long, winding drive and for traffic. Dress VERY warmly.
