Temperatures at the summit may be below freezing with heavy winds. There are restrooms but no food or beverage outlets. Sunset is a nice option; beautiful, much warmer, and FAR less crowded. $10 admission to the park. Use low gear going back down.

Included with your $10 park pass to the top of the crater is three nights of camping in the park. Hosmer Grove has a grassy area for setting up your tent, fire pits, picnic tables, potable water and permanent outhouses. (If you really want a flush toilet you can drive down the road 2 minutes to the interpretive center). It gets cool at night (10C range), but it is quiet and you have a million dollar view of the sky. There is also some nice hiking trails int he park.

We drove the Hana highway and stopped at Kipahulu. After paying $10 we found out the visitor center was closed, the bathrooms were closed, there was no running water and the pools below the waterfall were only stagnent pools of water due to low rainfall. What was worth $10?

There are two entrances to the national park, one to the crater, and on the Kipahulu side for Pipiwai trail and the pools trail. Do not let clouds keep you away from the crater. We visited here around 1pm. $10 entrance fee is good for three days. To check out both entrances split it into two days as the drive to Kipahulu from crater taken another hour to hour and a half one-way.

We were lucky to have a beautiful morning with stunning views of Maui. We did a little hike, beware that even a short hike can be strenuous with the altitude, which I knew, but, did not really appreciate until I tried it! Apparently, the entry fee is going to increase by $5 increments over the next few years, which is unfortunate, so enjoy now.

We started this trip at the Ocean Vodka distillery, which if you like organic products or Vodka, you should pay the $10 fee and take the tour. Then, at 2 PM, we began the drive up to the top in our rented 4 cylinder Bucik Verano. You'll begin in farmland, travel through woods and pastures, before reaching the park entrance ($10 for the car). .The two lane road was in good condition but could have used more guard rails at the shoulders. There are many hairpin turns and most all accommodate more than one car in each direction. Some passengers will get motion sickness, but not as bad as on the road to Hana. The downhill bicycles are the most dangerous part of your adventure.There are many scenic view pullovers to stop at, but until you're well above the clouds, the main reason to stop is to get acclimated to the thinning atmosphere. You may first notice the symptoms at the popular park roadside stop where you can look down into the crater and observe how the mountain can block clouds from proceeding. The final two stops are very close together and the view is what you see from an airplane. You'll be way above the clouds looking down at their tops. Once you make it to the summit, you'll see all the Slversword plants you want. The view is like a Martian or lunarscape. Bare rocky terrain and panoramic views as far as your eyes can see. The temperature in early September was 89 degrees F. at the bottom and 53 degrees at the top. We wore shorts (we're from the northeast) and while it was a bit chilly, it was a welcome relief from the heat and humidity at the bottom. If you have an interest in science or geology,, you'll appreciate all this a bit more. Since most of us are never going to scale Mt. Everest, we can do this and know we saw something unique and memorable. Make sure you have a full tank of gas and bring a sweatshirt, some snacks, and a thermos of hot coffee. The park will provide you with water and restrooms. Take some time to enjoy the view.

Maybe if we had gone to see the sunrise or sunset it would have been prettier but I thought it was just ok..Maybe on the day we went the visability was not great but I didn't think it was worth the time and trouble to get there. make sure you bring warm clothes we brought sweatshirts for 65 dollars which i thought was too high but when we got to the top we did not need them..Plus there were little bugs flying around everywhere and biting. If you are on maui for a few weeks maybe this would be good but not for a week or two vacation

We started our journey to the National Park super early to experience the sunrise (which is an absolute must on this trip). There is beautiful scenic lookouts and spots to hike. It is only $10/car for park entrance for a 3 day pass. The way back down just have to be careful due to bike tours.

Visited on May 6, 2014 with my wife. The sunrise views are highly recommended though expect some company. Entrance fee is $10 (cash accepted, credit card preferred). Arrive early as parking was not commensurate with the amount of people there. Arriving early will also guarantee that you won't be stuck viewing the sunrise from behind a row of people. The drive up can be slow when there are many cars driving up at the same time (such as sunrise). I also did some hiking down towards the creator and thought that it was well worth the trek.

Haleakala National Park is not just a sunrise. First, it has two components 1) The summit 2) Kipahulu coast. Check out both if you parts if you can. The two areas however, are not connected so will likely require too different days to explore. The summit is great to see the variety of climates/scenery on Maui. It changes dramatically green pastures to panoramas that are more reminiscent of a martian landscape. I would recommend taking some time to explore the sliding sands trail that starts from the upper visitors center. It was amazing! On the Kipahulu coast, definitely take the Pipiwai trail up to see the Waimoku falls and the bamboo forest. This was also a must do in Maui. Once you get down from the hike, take a short hike to the O'heo gulch and cool off and go swimming in the freshwater pools fed by small series of waterfalls. The park has a lot to offer, definitely check it out! Oh, and save your entry receipt because the $10 entry gets you into both sections on different days.

Enjoyed the trip up the hill for a great sunrise. Had a nice warm cup of coffee from the Coffee Cart on the way up. Worth a chat with the nice guy who runs it each morning. Parked at the crater (not the summit) and enjoyed great colors and receding shadows as the sun came up. Bring a warm jacket or dress in lots of layers. Then hiked the trail around the rim of the crater for a bit. Then drove up to the summit (only a few hundred feet higher) and enjoyed the view. You can see four other islands including the Big Island. Then made our way down the hill for a nice breakfast at Kula Bistro (Lower Kula Road). Passed tons of bikers on the way down (looked like fun) but glad we were warm in the car. It was a great experience for sure!

The drive is a very long and winding road, be sure that you have filled up the tank and pack some water and snacks. The drive is beautiful and there are a ton of places to stop and take pictures of the view and many waterfalls along the way. If you get car sick easily, be sure to make the necessary preparations, because you will get car sick. Once you arrive at the national park and have paid you $10 park admission, drive up to the main parking area and park. You can enter the gift shop and get maps and ask any questions you may have. There are 2 paths, the shorter path leads to the lower pools, and the longer path lead to the 200 foot waterfall and bamboo forest. I strongly suggest taking the longer path first. The lower pools are nice, but the other path is by far the best. Be sure to pack waters. This hike is long and considered difficult by some, so again if you have health issues, be careful. Honestly, as we got about 2/3rds of the way through, I was getting skeptical, even considered stopping. I am so thankful that we didn't. The bamboo forests was like something out of a fairy tale, and then as you walk out of the bamboo forest and continue about 75 yard, you get to see this amazing 200' waterfall. You can walk up to it and stand beneath and feel the exhilaration rain down on your head. It is simply one of the most memorable moments you will ever have. Don't pass up this opportunity. I'm sure that it will not be long before they regulate how close you can get to the bottom of the falls, and I am sure üit's just a matter of time. Anyhow, this was one of the best thing to see in Maui. A definite must see.

I think it was $10 entry fee - good parking and restrooms. We did a Pipiwai Trail (took about 2 hours) and had a picnic lunch at one of the tables onsite. Wish the shop had drinks or snacks of some sort but it did have some great views.

The winding turning road to the Haleakala National Park was like being on the flying turns whirl ride at Ohio's Euclid Beach (amusement park) when I was a little child. Half the fun was getting there. I remembered my National Park Passport book and warm clothes for the cooler temps and the higher winds I might encounter. Haleakalā is Hawaiian for "house of the sun." This is a must see location when on Maui. The visitor's center had an incredible view. I just enjoyed the chance to see this once in a lifetime visual miracle. You have to see it to believe it. The ride down the volcano in a big tour bus was another thrill....especially sitting the the back seat..............I knew it was the last place on Earth I would see if the bus went rolling down the side of the mountain. I felt better that my life insurance premiums were paid up but was also glad when the bus came to a stop at the end of the road. I would do this again if I return to the island. I might like to ride down the hills on a bicycle but not up for sure. I was halfway to heaven while on top.

$10 to get in. Was amazing! We called it the road to heaven. We did a light hike with the park ranger, Honey Girl. She was amazing. We learned a lot about the birds and plants. Call and ask about times. The last one was 2pm on the day we went. Hiked around and saw the sunset at the peak. Absolutely gorgeous! Bring a jacket, pants, and a blanket! But totally worth it! The drive is SCARY! so bring someone who is comfortable with driving.

Go ahead and get up early to watch the sunrise. It was a wonderful experience. Such a great trip up and make sure you start about 3-4 ish so that you don't almost miss it like we did. It's a bit of a drive with curves so you don't want to rush. It was so pretty being above the clouds. Got some great shots. Loved it. I think it was $10 to get into the park?

There are a number of trails at the park and some ranging from 1/2 a mile up to as long as 3 days worth of walking trails. This is a huge wilderness area with over 30 miles of trails. There is plenty of parking and restrooms are available.$10 per car

After driving upto Hana, we went onto the Haleakala National park and were awed by the scenic natural splendor and beauty. Make sure to save your $10 entry ticket as you can use the same ticket within a 3 day window to re-enter the park at the base or even the top. Spend time to enjoy the natural beauty!

No other place like it on earth, you get to drive up to 10,000 feet and have an awe inspiring view of a dormant volcano. The drive is winding but worth it just be sure to be respectful of the plants and animals within the park as many of them are endangered. If you have time and you brought warm clothes I suggest walking down into the crater a ways so you get the pleasure of hearing absolute silence. The sunset is also amazing if it is clear. Just 10 dollars to get into the park for 3 days, which is also good to get into the other national parks on the island, like the seven sacred pools after Hana.

We drove to Haleakala; the drive from Wailea is about 2 hours. I'm glad that I read about this adventure before we went. We purchased the GyPSy Guide and put it on our IPAD. For $9.99 ( for all of Maui,) you can have a GPS/audio tour in the privacy of your own car. if you plan on hiking at the summit, layer/bring warm clothes. It was 75 at the beach and 47F at 10,000 feet. They had had snow flurries 3 days prior to our trip. Bring your snacks/camera/ and a camelbak if you're planning on hiking for awhile. The vistas are truly amazing and become moreso the further you go. We started on the Slippery Sands Trail. Pace yourself as the hike back is much harder than going down; for moderately in shape mid 50 year olds, we felt it on the way back. This was one of the highlights of our trip to Maui. We also learned via the GyPSy guide that one entrance fee is good for 3 days to Haleakala Natioanl Park as long as you save our receipt; we used it on one day during our trip to Hana and the next day at Haleakala.

Others have described the beauty and splendor of the sunrise over Haleakala far better than I could; it's truly a must-see for folks visiting Maui who have interests beyond the beach. To ensure the best experience possible, make your reservation online for the sunrise entry 60 days in advance ($1.50 fee is more than worth it), bring plenty of layers (it can be cold and windy at 10,000 feet), and aim to arrive at the summit around an 1 to 1.5 hours before sunrise. While the sunrise is beautiful, star gazing at that altitude, with so little light pollution, is otherworldly.

Harper's Ferry is a small town, but worth a day trip. In the historical area there is very limited parking - on Potomac Street, which is one street over on the left as you come down High Street towards the bottom of the hill. But the better way to visit is to pay the $10 per car and go to the National Historical Park where you can take a bus. The park visitors’ center has very little in it, but the folks offer helpful information. The buses leave from there. The bus has 2 stops, one at Bolivar Heights Battlefield, where there are often live displays, firing a cannon, etc. That is where you will learn about the battle itself. Next stop is in town at the bottom of the hill - the historic area. I ride my bike here weekly from Brunswick, MD. I am surprised to see so few people go into some of the exhibits. I think many people wonder if they are open, but if you are there during normal hours they are usually open. Open the door and go in! Admission is free. Many of them are quite interesting. Visit the 1896 St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church that sits up above the historic area. Stone steps lead up to it from High Street and it is beautiful inside - open to the public. Nice view from there. Facing the church, to the right is a road/path that leads another 100 yards to Jefferson Rock. As you walk up, you will actually be on the Appalachian Trail. Back at the bottom, be sure to walk under the train tracks and take a look down the river - a great view. The Potomac is to the left and the Shenandoah joins it from the right. Thereafter, it is the Potomac. A footbridge parallels the railroad tracks were you can get frequent up close views of passing trains as they enter/exit the short tunnel. Across the river to the left there is a hike up the mountain to Maryland Heights. From below, you can see people up there most days. It is about 1 ½ mile hike up to the outcrop you see (3 miles round trip). It’s a fairly easy hike, but allow a couple hours round trip. Also, on the far side of the river from Harper’s Ferry, if you turn right you can walk the C&O Tow Path, which at this point is also part of the Appalachian Trail, with close up views of the river. Many people walk ½ mile down and back. On the river in the summer you may see hundreds of people on inflated tubes and rafts floating downstream. It's a lot of fun - $29 and up per person. Their location is about 1/4 mile west of the National Historical Park entrance. They will drop you off up the Potomac River and pick you up about 2 miles down the river. In Harper's Ferry, there are several restaurants on High Street and the next street over on Potomac Street. Nothing fancy. For cold drinks and snacks, visit High Street Market, adjacent to Coach House Bar & Grill on High Street. On that same block is True Treats Historic Candy. Worth stopping in and be sure to talk to the owner. She is a historian on Candy and will be glad to share information with you. As you head back to the bus, you might opt to take the path from the point where the rivers meet, to the right and down the steps. It is an alternate path back to the bus with views of the Shenandoah River and a few historical markers.

Our adult son was interested in checking it out so when we went to visit him we went and are glad we did! Just seeing the old houses and church was awesome enough but the history is a plus. Make sure you visit the John Brown museum & wax museum. I guarantee you'll learn a thing or two. There are a great many gift shops to visit plus several great restaurants and coffee shops. (must try Battlegrounds Coffee. New and delicious!) You do have to pay a $10 to park and enter the park but it is well worth it. And visit Jefferson rock. Small hike up some steps and past the church but well worth it.

Harpers Ferry offers something for many people. It turns into a mini melting pot for the variety of visitors it attracts: history buffs, train enthusiasts, hikers, walkers, outdoor enthusiasts. People of all ages appear to find something appealing about being here. A little planning before arriving does make for a more enjoyable and less stressful visit. As other reviewers have noted, parking and traffic can be an issue during the busy summer season (come in the winter for a different experience). The NPS does a great job in running a fairly efficient shuttle bus system which loops around from the Main visitor center off Hwy 340, to lower Harpers Ferry (in town near the NHP sites), and back to the Main visitor center. It appears that the NPS does not encourage it, but there are two small parking areas besides the Main visitor center: one is at the old train station along Potomac Street; the other lot is about 0.8 miles west of the town center near where Shenandoah Street meets Hwy 340. There is also parking at the Bolivar Heights section part of the NHP. No matter where you park, you are still required to pay the $10 admission fee (per vehicle); there are pay stations at the two aforementioned lots. As is expected, the small lots fill up very quickly during the weekends and on any nice day during tourist season. If you end up parking at the lot on Shenandoah Street, the walk into town is pleasant, level (but on an unpaved trail alongside the road; there are additional "parallel" trails on Virginius Island into town), and only took us about 15 minutes. All of Harpers Ferry is a great walker's town, albeit many of the worthwhile points to visit require steep ascents and decsents. So, moderate physical ability is helpful. But much can be enjoyed on the level areas! Walk across the railroad bridge for some great views of the town and rivers. The rail line is active so you may see an Amtrak or freight train. You also may see kayaker and rafters float down either river. The events that occurred here in 1859 put Harpers Ferry into the spotlight. The NPS has done a nice job in recreating the historical atmosphere. There are many hiking trails merging at this point, most notably the AT; Harpers Ferry is the approximate midpoint of the trail and location for the ATC headquarters. If you love to hike and explore, a visit to Harpers Ferry will not disappoint. After your wanderings, there are some small bars, restaurants, and ice cream shops to cool off and relax.

We were there on a weekday in June and were surprised at how empty everything was. You pay $10to park by the visitors center. There is not much to see there but there is a free shuttle down to the town. We chose to walk which was a beautiful 1.6 mile path. There is a lot of down hill on maris stone steps at the beginning of the walk so it's not for anyone with problems waking and I wouldn't want to try it when the stones are wet. The town itself is a lot of old buildings from roughly 1870. All are well maintained. There are lovely nature views and walks as well. The NPS does a wonderful job maintaining and presenting it all and their staff members are eager to help. A few things wee closed when we were there. Altogether the NPS part takes maybe half a day but there are also shops and restaurants in town and the Wax Museum ($$).

Not much time was spent at the visitor center. The three staff members or U.S. Park Rangers were polite, helpful & friendly. Large parking lots with the largest vehicles having plenty of room. Parking is $10.00, however if a visitor is a senior & having a senior pass they will be waved by. A shuttle bus will transport visitor to the village. The shuttle runs 9:00 to 4:30. To know which bus belongs to the Park, look for a bus with a blue strip & white body.

We parked at the Visitor Center and took the convenient shuttle into the town. Only $10 to park, and plenty of spaces. We had fun walking all over Harpers Ferry and reading about its historical significance.

This place is amazing! The stone work and the architecture are worth the trip. The rail bridge is a must to cross. You can feel you are walking through history while you are here. It is definitely worth the $10 fee to enter the state park and take the shuttle down into the town.

I was in Harpers Ferry and was looking for something to do. I decided to go to the national park. $10 at the gate and took the bus back in time to the old town. Once there it was amazing history. The people there were very knowledgeable and the old time feeling was still there. My advise is to take your time and see everything. Great place to go.

The views are amazing and the people are nice. PARK at the visitors center and take the shuttle over for $3. You will thank me as there is no parking in the town and you will get towed off and fined. The shops are cool and old and the views by the river are great. If you have time hike the trails by the water.

Was in DC during Women's march week and wanted to avoid the crowd; therefore, got in my car to take a trip out here. It was less than an hour drive from my hotel and it was $10 to park at off-site parking lot and take the shuttle to town. It used to be that you could park right in the town itself but not anymore. There is a limited, smaller parking lot with self-serve pay kiosk; it is closer to town than off-site parking but it's still about a mile walk to town and the shuttle does not stop there.

We stayed nearby in a rental house and went into Harper's Ferry one day. Parking was horrendous and not well communicated by area signs. We drove around the two little streets in town and then ended up following a line of cars over by the train station. Multiple cars were waiting for parking at the train station, so we followed others down to the end of the street. On both sides of the street cars had driven over the curb and parked on the sidewalks/grass/dirt on the roadside. No one had parking tickets, and there were no clear signs saying you could not park there, so we saw an open space and parked in it. After lunch we came back to everyone (about 30 cars) with parking tickets on their windshield for $50 that must be paid within 48 hours. Looks like the police have a system set up to let all the unclear parking fill up around meal times, write all the tickets at once, and then probably repeat.

Parked at the national park and took a bus down to the town. $5 to park and bus was included, there was played a little history about the location while on the bus ride and dropped us off in the heart of the town. Adorable town with lots of history. Went to the visitor center to get a map and we walked along the trail tracks to the hike starting point. Really cool train area because it's still in use. Hike is very steep and almost entirely uphill, took us about an hour and a half to get to the top but the view was worth it. Easy hike back down, overall took us about 2 1/2-3 hours. We went on a weekday and it wasn't very crowded. Gorgeous view, worth the trek.

You don't need more that an hour or so to see the park if you are not a hiker. There are a few historical buildings to visit, and then many restaurants and and stores and exhibits that charge an additional fee ( $7.50 for John Brown's wax museum) I thought it would be a bit more like Gettysburg. Beautiful viewing the mountains and rivers .

I've wanted to get out to Harpers Ferry for years but somehow never got to, until now. The town is an easy hour and a half or so drive from DC - very accessible by car, and apparently you can get out there by train, too. Last weekend the leaves were just starting to turn, and the Shenandoah and Potomac Rivers were really a stunning sight from the moment we drove up. The historic town is located at the point of confluence of these two rivers, and parking is a few miles away at a visitors center. The entry fee is $10 per car, or $5 per person - this is the only fixed cost of the trip. Shuttles from the lot to the town are provided and run quite frequently, we stood in line a bit both in and out of town but it wasn't long at all.

no unpaid parking that isn't a mile walk one way. Very disappointing to have to pay $10 to park and then ride a shuttle bus into the town - felt like herding cattle. The little town itself was cute and quaint - but obviously just another tourist trap trying to get every dime they can out of you - i.e., cheapest burger in town was $12.99. Look at the pictures online - no need to waste the time or money visiting.

We parked at the Harpers Ferry NP visitors center ($10 fee) and took the bus to the "lower town" - less than 10 min. The town in really cute with a lot of museums (self-guided), shops, and restaurants! You can walk near the water and talk the foot bridge over to Maryland and the C&O trail. We decided to walk back to the visitors center since it was only a 2 mile walk. The end of the walk goes through a steep part of the woods, but it isn't a long segment (.3 miles).

Harpers Ferry is located in a beautiful spot at the convergence of two rivers. The town itself and the National Park are one in the same. If you drive, you pay $10 to park up near the visitors center and can take the free shuttle bus into town. We opted to visit by bike and parked our car about six miles away and then rode on a flat path that winds along the Potomac until we reached Harpers Ferry. We left our bikes at a rack and then walked over the bridge into the town.

Visited here today. Well worth 10 dollars park admission. You get free shuttle bus down to the town. Some very quaint shops and eateries. The museums are well worth seeing if you are interested in the civil war

I would suggest you begin your day at Harper's Ferry at the National Park site since parking in the town can be a predicament. There is plenty of free parking, but a $10 National Park fee for entrance. There is a shuttle bus which passes every 10-20 minutes which will take you to Bolivar Heights for spectacular views and/or to the town itself. There you can wander at leisure (be prepared to walk up and down hills/steps). There are museums, gift shops, eateries, and hiking options. Hiking up to Jefferson Rock takes some stamina, but you get good views of the valleys. This is a recommended visit for history buffs.

Harpers Ferry National Park is beautiful and if you are a hiker well worth it. But if you are going primarily to see the historical section and learn about John Brown, it is so-so and unless you are eating lunch there you would be hard pressed to spend 2 hours there.The thing we found most interesting where the exhibit about the slaves and the one about the black college that was once there. Other than that most places you either can't go in or are so poorly lit that you really don't see much. There are a couple of shops, the best is the book store the other are 5 minute diversions. There are 2 restaurants there. Both claim outdoor seating which is true but all you look at are a parking lot and a train stations. The food at both is standard tourist area burgers and such. We chose not to eat there but to go into town to the Anvil which was recommended at the tourist information center. While it is free to get in if you have a national park pass, parking is $10. You can't bring your car into the historical center but park run buses make the 2 mile transit every 10-15 minutes so very convenient.

This was really cool! It costs $10/carload entrance fee. When you get in, you catch a bus to Lower Town which overlooks the Shanendoah River. Several of the old stores and houses have either shops or exhibits you can go in. You are also able to go in the Roman Catholic Church and walk over the river beside the train track. This was definitely worthwhile.

So first off, dont bother trying to save the $10 parking fee that the park charges by parking near the historic sites and walking...it's a good 3/4 mile from the free parking to the closest part of the town. the park provides a shuttle ride to and from the visitors center. you can drive through town but you must have a permit to park anywhere.

We spent half a day in this park while returning from Washington DC.... Parking a car was 10$ and the environment was good.... worth a visit if you traveling around virigina/wv area....... One of the place where two rivers meet and three states merge......

My wife and I are on our annual trip to anywhere.....and decided to stop in on this location. Entry to the park cost $10......but that gave you access to anywhere......and you could ride a shuttle all the way North......and all the way south to lower town. There is no parking in the lower town.....so don't even try it. The shuttles run every ten minutes or so.....and the park rangers are above and beyond in being helpful...just great staff there at the park. July is a good time to visit......no lines anywhere....shuttles were half full all day......mosquitos were large and plentiful......they spent most of the day carrying off medium to larger mammals....so if you have a relative that you are not particularly fond of........take them along.....August is your month. Be sure to see John Brown's fort......walk the section of the Appalachian trail along the rail tracks......That's perhaps a half mile....easy to do. Great visit.....and great views of the meeting of the rivers.

While traveling to Lancaster, PA (Amish Country), we took a side trip off I-81 to visit Harpers Ferry National Historic Park. So glad we did. We only had about 4 hours, but needed at least 4 more to do all we wanted to do. I can't add any more information to what has already been mentioned in other reviews (especially the review from NikkeByrd), except to allow one whole day for a visit. I said free. Parking is $10.00, unless you have a National Park Pass which I do. Many restaurants adjacent to the Historic Section. Park at the visitor center, take the bus and enjoy the day. There are two films in the historic section, be sure to see both to understand the history of the park.

You do have the option of stopping at the visitor center and riding the shuttle bus to various points or driving into town. Driving into town can be hard to find a spot to park though. The visitor center does require either the annual pass or a carload payment of $10. Still a good investment. You can walk into town too rather than ride the bus. Shuttles run about every 15 minutes in the summer. Just depends upon how much time you have. Once in town there are a number of sites to visit. The rangers are extremely helpful in talking about the history. Be sure to spend some time on the Appalachian Trail. Jefferson Rock is a short but medium walk up the hill. Great view of the surrounding area. At a minimum, give yourself 2 hours to walk around and visit. 3 hours is about average. Since the park and the community are there together, plenty of places to eat in town. Some shops.

Too bad almost everyone working at the center or at private businesses in town is so unhelpful and poorly trained. 6 park service employees who won't move when we said excuse me blocking doorways while staring at one showing off his marching - 4 behind a counter yukking it up with 3 friends they knew by name and never replying when we said excuse me 3 tomes - don't take your kids in the candy shop everything is mimimum$6.95 and not marked - good history hidden in dark rooms with no one around to answer questions. Just a big disappointment for such an historically important place.

This is a little gem. It has a lovely collection of civil war buildings- and the cannons placed on the hills surrounding the valleys helps you to understand the strife that people experienced during the war. It is the place where Thomas Jefferson was inspired to send out Lewis and Clark., It is the location of the incident of John Brown. Attempting to understand the history on your own is pretty difficult. It is best to take a park ranger tour (free) or hire a guide or do the Ghost Tour the night before. Not all of the buildings are open- but many are and you can go in and see living history at a variety of places such as the sheriff's office, mercantile, etc. There are quaint shops and restaurants in the town as well. Parking is located at the visitor center- with a free shuttle to the lower town or a hiking trail. There is limited parking in the town, train station and one parking lot by the river. There are a number of hiking trails that are breathtaking. Maryland Heights is one of the most challenging- especially if you go all the way to the forts. You can see some of the old lochs from the Ohio Canal. If you are just doing the town area- you should allow about 3 hours- if you plan on doing some of the hikes you make a full day or several days out of this location. There is a 10$ fee to park your car that is valid over several days at the visitor center. Parking at the train station is priced differently as it is not run by the park service. Be sure to check how to pay to avoid getting a ticket.

I really liked the first stop and the volunteer telling us some of the history about Harpers Ferry. She did a great job! Once we arrived to the town we though we would walk to the top of the town first. You have to like the old homes:) But it's a steep road to the top and you will feel it on a hot day:( But, you have a few shops to step into and grab some air:) The vendors were nice and receiving:) They have a beautiful old church in the town, wish it had been open:( Still trying to figure out the Jefferson rock:( Feels like a long walk even though it isn't, just another steep hill on a hot day:( It'sssssssssssssssssssss rock with an average view. The shops are nothing that great, nothing I haven't seen at any other tourism trap:( Loved the peeks into the old store fronts:) Stopped for lunch, it was less than average:(:( Did not even try to go to the backside of the town by the train depot:( construction and not customer friendly:( So, what did I miss as I got back on the bus? I must of missed something because I saw little:( p.s- I would say, if your a hiker, this place could be greatttttttttttttttt

We only got to do the lower town area but we will go back! Park and staff are excellent. $10.00 to park and ride shuttle buses for three days is a great deal. The museums all close at 5:00 PM so that is a bit of a drawback. The bathrooms on the street level needed a good cleaning. All in all a great place to visit. We intend to go back to explore the battlefields.

Paying the entry fee (if you do not have a pass) to the National Park is well worth the investment! Shuttle buses run every 20 minutes between the visitor center, lower downtown area and Bolivar heights. The rangers were very informative and gave great talks about the history of Harpers Ferry including the civil war involvement.

We spen 3+ hours here. The Ranger David gave an exhaustive lecture on John Brown's Raid and its aftermath. We also learned about the Niagara Movement that started at Storrer College and evolved into the NAACP. Volunteer Bob gave us a good overview of the importance of Harper's Ferry before and during the Civil War. I like how we had to take the shuttle to Bolivar Heights and Lower Town. The little museums were interesting. Age 60 or over get the Adventure Pass. It's good at all the National Parks & monuments for life.

We went for a hiking today[7/2/16]. It's our first time hiking at this national park with our 3 young kids [10, 7, 5]. We live 30 minutes away from the national park. It's conveniently located off route 340, which is about 2.5 hours away from Washington, DC [45 minutes - 1 hour drive from Leesburg, VA]. Once you are on route 340, you will see the sign of the national park. Following that sign will lead you to the visitor center, parking lot, and some hiking trail. Old Town Harper Ferry is on another side. The admission fee is $10 per car. However, we have America The Beautiful Pass, which is $80 annually and give us an access to 2000+ national parks in US all year round. That saves us much money.

My daughter and I spent a day trip in Harpers Ferry. Easy drive from DC (mostly going against the traffic). We paid the $10 to park in the NP lot, but skipped the bus into town: we hiked the trail instead. It is a more challenging hike, but you go down, when you go into town. Be sure to wear good, sturdy hiking boots or footwear that grips the trails and/or keeps you from slipping on the rock "steps" along the way. We saw lots of wildlife: 3 blue herons, several turtles, we think some snake heads, wood ducks, and a yearling. Arrived in town, headed for lunch - then took in many of the historic buildings, complimentary mini-movies, exhibits, and walked across the trestle to see a CSX train literally fly thru the 1931 tunnel for destinations north/west. We took the bus back to our parked car after spending about 4 hours seeing the sights. You can try parking in town for free - it just depends on how many visitors are there, and how close you can get. Seems better to support the park and rest your feet after tackling the cobbled streets. "3 states, two rivers, and one National Park" plus three trails converge at Harpers Ferry: the AT, the C&O and the Potomac Heritage National Trail. Try to find the sign painted on Maryland Heights around 1903-06 -- it reads "Mennen's Borated Talcum Toilet Powder"! Plus you'll learn that Lewis & Clark started their journey at the Arsenal before heading west~

I just spent three days and two nights exploring Harpers Ferry and it was fantastic. I've been there before as a kid and as an adult with my family, but this trip was solo and a great return to a beautiful and interesting area. I'm mostly interested in natural parks with scenic features and plant/tree life, but Harpers Ferry goes beyond that and offers so much interesting history. From it's beginnings as a ferry crossing to water-powered industrialization, the C&O canal, the Civil War, and the Civil Rights Movement, Harpers Ferry is full of many compelling stories. And they are well interpreted in the Lower Town and throughout the park. I spent my first day exploring Lower Town and all the buildings and museums, plus I walked the Virginius Island - Hall's Island trails along the Shenandoah River. The second day I hiked the Maryland Heights trails and then hiked the Murphy Farm trails. Then on the third day, I hiked the Loundoun Heights trails. The heights are challenging, but so worth the effort. Do bring plenty of water, a hat, and a bandanna since it gets pretty hot in the summer. It can get a little buggy, but no biting insects that I encountered. And some good trail shoes is important since the trails are rocky and with exposed tree roots. I would recommend starting at the Visitor Center located just off Rt 340, about 2 miles from the historic district. It's pretty congested in the historic district on weekends and there's limited parking. It's so nice to just ride the shuttle bus in. On the third day, I did park at the lot off of Shenandoah Street, close to where Rt 340 crosses the Shenandoah River. I was able to pick up the Appalachian Trail crossing from there and proceed to Loudoun Heights. But that was a Tuesday, and I think the lot fills up early on weekends. There is a fee for entering the park, which is $10 per vehicle per day. I went ahead and got an annual pass, which is $30, since I would spend the same amount for the daily fees. And I definitely want to come back. I live about an hour north, so it's an easy trip for me. I highly recommend it.

I have been here a number of times, and am always in awe at the history and beauty of this area. For 10 dollars you can park, and use the shuttle numerous times over 3 days. Amazing views, restaurants and hiking.

The little town that is part of the National Park is so cute. Thee kept the original buildings and turned them into shops and restaurants. You can pick up the Appalachian trail and hike for as long as you like. You walk over a bridge to enter the trail. It costs $10 per vehicle to enter the park. I would come back again to visit.

We parked on the hill ($10 per car) and took the shuttle down to historic old town Harpers Ferry. There is much to learn - apparently the town changed hands eight times, between the union soldiers and confederates, and much history happened here. Whether you take in the various museums (small scale), historic houses with displays, or just ambled along the Potomac and/or Shenandoah Rivers, you can truly soak in the unique atmosphere. Don't miss climbing up to Jefferson's Lookout - you will get a nice vista of the area.

The historic park is absolutely packed with things to see and do. We spent two afternoons and an evening wandering through the lower town, browsing the exhibits, shopping, and a few short hikes on the closer battlefields. We could have easily spent another day on the other battlefields without running out of stuff to see and do. The beauty of the natural area combined with the charm of the historic area means there is a photo op every few feet. The exhibits are set up so that short-attention span kids and adults can glance through and quickly see if they want to invest more time, and those who are plaque readers will find tons of interesting information and thought provoking questions. I was amazed at all that was offered for only $10 for the four of us.

It does cost $10 to enter the park but it is well worth it. We parked at the visitor center and took the shuttle down to the lower city, then walked all over. Everywhere you look there is something that draws your attention. We hiked up some of the AT here, saw a beautiful old church, took so many pics, and completely was enthralled with the history.

For an enjoyable visit to Harper's Ferry, take the bus! It's $10 per car to easily park near shuttle, nice air conditioned/comfortable busses arrive every few minutes, drop you off/pick you up all day downtown with friendly driver and a nice recording with history along the way! A must for seeing Harper's Ferry!

We spent a good half-day in Harpers Ferry (including hiking the Maryland Heights trail) and saw, read, and learned quite a bit. We parked at the visitor center (it costs $10, or it's free if you have something like an America the Beautiful Pass) and took the shuttle into town. From there, we just poked around, went into different historic buildings, walked along the riverfront, and hiked one of the nearby hills (which offered a wonderful view of the town). Enjoyable experience all around.
easily accessed by national park transportation (included in park entrance fee $10) it is easily walked with some stairs to climb up to the church...do not miss the graveyard...

So much to see and do! We’re in our mid-60s and used our National Park Pass for free admission. We got there right when the park opened at 9 am and started with 40 minute Murphy-Chambers Farm Loop Hike from the Visitors Center. The hike is easy and includes historical markers and river views. After that we took free shuttle to lower town. Walked stone steps to Jefferson Rock and old cemetery, walked across the Potomac Bridge and walked a bit on the Maryland portion of the Appalachian Trail. Definitely recommend all that! Had some snacks and checked out some of the museums including our favorite, the John Brown Museum. There were lots of boisterous, exuberant school kids there that day and the indoor venues were crowded and noisy so we walked to the AT Conservancy building. That was about a half mile uphill but interesting to see. It was a beautiful fall day and we saw a lot in about 5 hours. I’m sure there’s more to learn at the different museums but it was just too pretty a day to be indoors!

This was a great place to visit. We started in the park ($10 per vehicle to get in) and went for a short hike to the John Brown Fort foundation, overlook, Earthworks & Murphy House. We then returned to the visitor center and caught the free shuttle to the lower town which is composed of old restored buildings and various museums including one for John Brown. The town is a mixture of part historical and part commercial with most of the buildings either restored or built to fit in with the time period. The bookshop (the National Park shop) carries lots of items for adults and kids, and the museums were interesting with free admission. The overlook where the Potomac & Shenandoah River converge to form the Potomac is beautiful, and you get to see the train bridge going across to the Maryland Heights that is still in use. In fact, we saw an Amtrak train using the train station and bridge while we were there. This is a great place to visit for all ages.

We parked at the entrance and took the free shuttle into the town of Harper's Ferry. There are a few visitor's parking right by the town; however if you are visiting during a busy time of year, the chances of you finding parking right by the town are slim. The shuttle runs very frequently, I believe every 15 minutes and can sit quite a few people. It costs $10 a car to get into the park.

The $10 admission fee (or your $20 all parks senior pass) gets you a free shuttle bus ride down to the park, a film, a volunteer guided tour and carte blanche to wander in and out of the many musty old buildings set up like mini-museums. This was not the original layout of the town, which was periodically devastated by floods. The film, a history of Harper's Ferry, was quite good. The tour guide was knowledgeable, engaging and enthusiastic, but ran on too long. We visited a reconstruction of the firehouse where John Brown holed up with his hostages, a habadasher, a clockmaker, military headquarters, a dry goods store, a pastry shop, a boardinghouse, a gun making shop, an urban archaeology site, a Confederate museum, a museum of Harper's Ferry during the Civil War, an African-American museum and one devoted exclusively to John Brown. The latter had an exhibit devoted to free speech. A photo of a Nazi demonstration in NY during the 1930's was inexplicably mixed in with photos of Civil Rights, abortion, labor, suffragette and anti-war activists. As a Jew, I was both alarmed and offended at this validation and plan to notify my congressman. There is a very extensive book and gift shop with many nice items. The scenery, being at the confluence of the Potomac and the Shendoah Rivers is spectacular, and you can hike along one of the old canal towpaths and see the old railroad tracks. Up the block are food and gift concessions that are technically outside the park. We spent about three hours and felt it was worthwhile.
location: Great Neck, New York, United States

text: Parents. Do not bring a stroller if walking through downtown in this gorgeous national park. The sidewalks are narrow like they are sized for those smaller framed folks of 100s of years ago and you will be forcing people into traffic like a jerk if you bring one or waiting for crowds to pass to get by. Not sure why they allow traffic down the main street anyway. While you're at it if you are downtown do not bring nana or grampa if they can't navigate steep stony stairs very very well. The shuttle is very convenient and not a hassle to ride in my opinion and the afternoon was enjoyable (though i was either wrangling my 30lb son or draggin my empty stroller for all of it). The views are gorgeous and there truly is fun (and shopping) for all ages. Also don't take young children to the John Brown Wax Museum, to quote my husband to my 8 month old "Look son, John Brown is murdering the *&#$% outta that man. He's murdering him real good". And the docent "I've had people come up here as adults to process what they saw here as children"

This is an awesome national Park. Don't waste time trying to find a spot in the town. Use the national parks parking lot and for $10 you get a great ride into town with some stops at the storage places along the way. Once in the town make sure you hike up to Jeffersons rock. The views of the converging rivers are breathtaking. And you can even hike along the Appalachian Trail. I didn't hike the trail that crosses the river and up the bluff but the views from there looks spectacular. It's a cute little town to with plenty of nice restaurants and a few historical buildings. Again well worth the trip and I look forward to going back soon.

Parking here used to be free. Now they charge an exorbitant rate. You also have to pay via an app which is hard to access because Wi-Fi connectivity is spotty. After we sorted that all out we paid for 3 hours and went on a hike up to the Maryland Heights. It was a nice hike and the overlook is quite spectacular. When we got back down it had been 3 hours and 9 minutes - and we had a $50 parking ticket. We had planned to eat at one of the restaurants in Harpers Ferry but the ticket ruined our appetite so we left and ate at a wonderful Irish Pub (Paddy's) in Charlestown. The authorities in Harpers Ferry obviously have a racket going and are out to gouge visitors for as much as they can. We won't be back.

This was not on our initial travelling itinerary but we are sure happy we got to visit this historic and beautiful place. It was pretty cold for us with the winds blowing through the Shenandoah and Potomac rivers. I couldn't believe how pretty this place is. Good for biking and hiking. We saw people way up on a ridge where the view must be awesome. I'm not a hiker and neither is wifee. We paid the $10/car fee and took the tram down to the site. They have an audio narration on the way. Later we drove around and through the place. You don't have to park up at the visitor center as they have a small parking lot down closer to the river, but good luck finding parking there.

Not too far for a day trip, Harper's Ferry is 45 minutes NE of Leesburg, VA. Such a historic site, and geographically beautiful site to visit. $10 to park your car in the park, but you get a free bus ride down into the historic town (return trip included). There is plenty to see and read. The more time you spend in this quiet little town nestled away in West VA mountains, the more you are intrigued about how such a small town, "so far away" could play such a significant role in the history of the Civil War and this Great Country of ours. I especially enjoyed visiting the old, but still active railway station! ESX commercial train, MARC commuter, and Amtrack train whistles occasionally pierce the silence of the serene atmosphere of the valley. I enjoyed our time there, and I am no history buff! Worth the time and trip, for sure. Next time I will bring my hiking boots! Lots of trails to explore and we didn't get out to any of the battlefields due to my small children being tired from all the walking around town, and hike up to Jefferson's Rock.

Maybe I do not fully agree with Thomas Jefferson's claim that Harpers Ferry is worth a trip across the Atlantic but it certainly is a great day trip from anywhere in the DC area. Lots of history and beautiful scenery. Do the smart thing and park at the National Park Service visitors center - only $10 per car and free shuttle right downtown. Finding parking downtown is a nightmare

If you like John Brown, you'll love this. His story is told over and over again on the placards and videos in each of the old buildings. You pay $10 to park your car and then you can walk around all day visiting the sites. Imagine a smaller version of Williamsburg Virginia without anyone telling you anything. The best part of the trip was the place where they showed you how they discovered how to make guns on an assembly line. But there's no one there to tell you anything or to make it exciting. Just a video. Shame on West Virginia for not investing the money to attract tourists and make this the attraction it can really be. It's not well organized. There are only a few places to get food, and those were crowded & chaotic. We were there on a Friday morning. There was no one available to give us change of a $20 so we could pay the $10 fee for parking. Ridiculous! We drove around to the stores and shops and they weren't open yet. I would have bought an ice cream at 9:00am just to get the change. Nope. We ALMOST missed out on parking as by the time we got the change at the gift shop in the bed/breakfast (where I purchased a lovely blueberry preserves) up the street the parking lot was almost full. Just go there prepared. Go early. Have a $10 bill handy and good walking shoes. Bring your own water and maybe some snacks. And something to fan yourself with will be helpful. Its nice to read and learn the history, It's a shame they don't care.

Don't even waste your time driving into town and trying to find parking; there are very few spots and they fill up quickly. Make your way to the Shuttle right off the major road, pay your $10 and avoid the aggravation. Harper's Ferry is smaller than I had imagined, but there is a lot of history to explore. Keep in mind, this town is not modern; the sidewalks and most attractions are not set up for those that have difficulty getting around or may be physically handicapped. There is a clean restroom available, which is nice. One thing you will notices is that there are a lot of small "museums"; individually, they are not much, but after taking them all in, you will get a good picture of what happened during John Brown's Raid. My only real issue was the musty smell in almost every place I visited; my guess is the town has fallen victim to flooding more than once over the years. Go to Harper's Ferry, but make plans for something to do later in the day; perhaps take in a trip down the river with one of the may outfitters nearby.

The National Park Service has a wonderful attraction and is well organized to offer it to the visitors. While Harpers Ferry is a real life functioning town, the historical exhibits are seamlessly integrated. The Park Service website is very good and offers good information to organize your visit. The $10 fee per vehicle covers parking and shuttle bus service to the town. There are ample maps and signage to get around. And the walking trails over access to some of the most beautiful vistas on the east coast.
Beautiful historic area, very reasonably priced ($10 per car), need to wear comfortable shoes as there is a lot of walking. Free shuttle bus provides quick access from the visitors center into town.

In 1785, Thomas Jefferson stated the view of "the passage of the Potomac through the Blue Ridge is perhaps one of the most stupendous scenes in Nature" and "worth the voyage across the Atlantic." This was pretty telling description considering it took months to cross the Atlantic in the late 1700s. In the age of the automobile, it is a little easier to get to Harpers Ferry, but parking can sometimes be as challenging as a voyage across the ocean in the late 1700s. Thus, it is best to park at the National Park Visitor's Center, pay $10 per car load and take a shuttle bus to lower Harpers Ferry. The shuttle also stops at Bolivar Heights (the site of the second largest surrender of American troops in the history of the United States.) You can experience first hand where John Brown's raid served as a rallying cry for abolitionists and what many historians consider the spark of the Civil War and visit areas where subsequent battles of the War took place. For the more adventurous, you can hike up Maryland Heights (about 1 1/2 hours) to see Harpers Ferry from a high. While the trek can be tiring, the view at the end is worth it. The C&O Canal runs right through Harpers Ferry and provides a gentler hike. Also the Appalachian Trail goes through Harpers Ferry. If Thomas Jefferson thought Harpers Ferry was worth the trip across the Atlantic in the late 1700s, then surely it is worth a visit using more modern transportations means of the 21st century.

Very cute and quaint little town, so much history. There's a lot to see and do here, if you do come make sure you wear your walking shoes as there is a lot of walking. There's a lot of hills too!! Would highly recommend going to see!!! There's is parking at the visitors center and it costs $10 per car to enter the park.

What an amazing place Harpers Ferry is and has been for a very long time. I am a Civil War follower and have wanted to go to Harpers Ferry for years. After reading so much and anticipating this visit for so long, one would think it might be a let down once you've gotten there. Not True at all! What a truly captivating, beautiful, compelling, provocative place to be. The park and the town are impeccably kept. It is $10 a car to go about through the tours and shuttles and ranger talks. Everyone that works there is helpful and courteous and mostly all smile. This is a trip I will replicate ASAP. This place is one of a kind that wreaks of compelling history and rich tradition.I do have to say that , for the most part, several of the bar/restaurants have to step it up ALOT. You need to see this beautiful place!

We visited Harper's Ferry several times while living in WV in the eighties. This was our first time back since then. It was impressive then, and it's even better now, perhaps because the National Park Service administers it. Be aware, I am talking about the historic town of HF, not the spot across the highway when you arrive. You can park at the Visitor's Center and take a shuttle in, but be aware that this will limit you to dining options in the historic town. Prices are high and it's crowded. If you get lucky and find a place to park (there are a couple of lots near The Point), get out and walk down to the spot where the Shenandoah and Potomac Rivers come together. You will see right away why the area changed hands several times during the Civil War. Plus, it's a beautiful view, especially on a bright day. You can walk a short portion of the Appalachian Trail, as the park sits almost exactly in the middle. Cross the footbridge and walk down to the old canal towpath for a close view of the rivers. Believe it or not, skip the stores in favor of The Point and a simple walk through the town. Be aware, though: there are steep hills.

My visit was on a Sunday afternoon. It was a side trip that was spur of the moment so I didn't have much time to learn more about the visit beforehand. The NP fee of $10 is really for the frequent shuttle they provide from their parking area. You don't need to pay anything if you just came in your car and was able to find a parking spot - but note that parking is very, very limited. The shuttle does allow you a good view of the river, canal, and other features on the way to the town. I realized that more time was needed for a complete visit - allow a full day. I was able to see most of the exhibits in the various buildings. It was warm the day I went - there are multiple spots to get ice cream, all in a row! I did visit a few stores but noted that many were closed or spaces were for rent. I was conveniently in the NP bookstore during an afternoon downpour - a very nice collection of books there. Trains rattle by all the time. With the river and canal, one is reminded how important this location was with the Civil War. I hope to visit again. Good shoes are needed for all the walking and stair climbing. Bring a rain jacket or umbrella as well as a bottle of water.

It was a beautiful day, so we decided to do a spur of the moment trip. Took about an hour and fifteen to get there from DC. Parking is tight at the park and they leave an envelope on your car for you to pay the $10 entrance fee. There are lots of cute shops on the main street and a surprising amount of history. Bring good shoes because there are lots of trails to walk.

My only complaint is that we ran out of time! Beautiful location, layers of history, knowledgeable Rangers and volunteers-- a small (very small) town with a National Park in its heart. The Junior Ranger program wasn't very easy for the older group-- but do-able in just a couple of hours, very nice museum exhibits in several historical buildings, wonderful ranger talk! Beautiful!! Plan to spend 5+ hours so you don't have to rush-- it's worth it. (Get the National Parks Annual Pass-- it saves so much money! And visit www.findyourpark.com)

We were on a road trip to visit family in the area and passed the sign for this park right before Christmas. I decided to stop on the cold, rainy and foggy day. We knew little about the park, but had a couple of free hours and I was curious. I have a national park pass so we did not pay the $10 entrance fee per person. I probably would not have paid the fee due to the bad weather otherwise. There is a shuttle bus that takes you to the town from the visitor's center off route 340, according to the bus operator it was a 6 minute ride. We only spent about 2 hours in the town itself due to the poor weather and no visibility, and we were really not prepared for the weather, my daughter was very cold. I will definitely return in better weather as the short visit certainly peaked my interest. We did enjoy the small museums in the town and had an early lunch in the business area of town, but unfortunately many of the shops and pubs were closed when we were there right before the holidays. As we will go that way again in the future, this is a park that I will definitely return to in better weather.

This is a great place to visit. Fall is a beautiful time of year, West Virginia foliage does not disappoint! Lots of great restaurants and quaint shops. Not to mention, the park is full of history. There is a parking fee of $10/car. The pass is good for three days and really is a nominal fee to help preserve the park.

We were lucky enough to be in Harpers Ferry this past weekend. There is something for everyone; there is quite a bit of walking, so you may want to consider that before going. Wear good shoes. The entry fee into the park is $10 for cars, but its worth it. From the park, you can take a free bus ride to the town. Parking in the town is VERY limited, so it's not recommended. We took the bus from the visitor's center at the park and did all the site seeing on foot. The Appalachian trail runs right through the town, so you will see some very interesting people with hefty looking back packs and walking sticks! The scenery is breath taking. You can visit many of the historic sites within a short walking distance, but we walked up High Street to the Appalachian Conservatory office, which may be a mile or two from the center of town. It's very cool. Over all, the people are very friendly, the food is good, and there is plenty of shopping for those that like to shop.

I hadn't been to Harpers Ferry in more than 40 years and it hadn't changed a bit. There's a good three hours of walking around despite a small area. First, the trains come by regularly so if you're an enthusiast you can stand on the platform and watch them roar by from just feet away. Second, if you're a hiker, the Appalachian Trail passes right through the town and over the bridge. Third, if you're a Civil War buff there's a battle and plenty of old stores to see. Fourth, photographers love the town and nature shots. Fifth, you can watch the river and mountains for hours. Sixth, there are some shops and restaurants. The only downsides: if you have trouble walking it can be challenging. Parking is also challenging on weekends. Try the train station. It cost $10. Otherwise, it's a pretty cool place.

While I couldn't help myself from playing John Denver's "Take me home, Country roads" while I visited, I found this park a little less than one of my highlights. There is a shuttle that takes you down to the historic sites, this just seems like a waist in my mind but maybe it wasn't as crowded as it can get while I was there. If I were to do it again, I would drive down or as close as I could get and skip the bus. The entrance was $10 which was fine, there are plenty of old buildings, some of which are being restored. You can walk through them and along the river. It is scenic and a nice place to stop and break up a drive or enjoy a picnic. There were plenty of people in tubes soaking their way down the river and a few people in white water rafts. I felt these people probably had the best way to take in this park! Be sure to drive up to Bolivar heights and take in the view, would be great in the fall.

We needed a quick get-away, so we got up late one Sunday morning and drove to Harpers Ferry West Virginia. It is this thick with American history, it is a gorgeous town to see and hike, it is only hours away from Harrisburg PA, DC, Baltimore, and many other major cities but people fail to take advantage of it. First the negatives. We visited in September and parked in the tiny parking lot that also supports the train station. There is a second lot, which is 1.5 miles out of town and involves a vigorous hike to get back to down town historic area. They will charge you $10.00 for a 3 consecutive day pass to park. If you visit any summer weekend, be prepared to hike. The exercise and hiking is probably the best reason to go there. If you are not in good health, cannot walk up steep hills and trails, this is NOT THE PLACE FOR YOU.

Harpers Ferry National Historical Park is AMAZING!!! Our National Park system keeps this area & the shops- from yesterday year, WONDERFULLY!! I ate great food @ the restaurants, who by the way is doggie friendly on the patio... shops were doggie friendly too!! I LOVE history.. I can't believe how great this area is preserved!! Many famous explorers used this armory & ferry crossing!!! Come see!!! No fee $$$ walking next to the river!!

Neat place to stop and see. Many historical things to see. Be prepared to do a lot of walking to see individual places. Park at the Historical Park for $10 and take the bus to town. Neat shops and restaurants. Historic place that is worth to see and experience.

The park is a national park site, so entry is only $10 per vehicle...you can enter the park, walk the trails & tak the shuttle to town to walk around & see the sites---you only need a day--2 MAX if you're an avid biker/hiker.

We rode the Park bus free (we have a free Senior National Park Pass) from the Park Center to the town area of Harper's Ferry where we strolled around the picturesque area. We took photos of the Shenandoah River & the Potomac River, the track tracks entering the tunnel (the Appalachian Trail runs alongside the tracks crossing the Shenandoah River), the hillside where the town is perched--all quite scenic. It only takes about an hour & a half to meander around & really enjoy this pretty spot. There are a handful of shops but not many, some restaurants, & we believe a few bed & breakfast places. The parking is at a minimum, which is why it's a good idea to park at the Park Center & ride the bus.
Beautiful setting. $10 per car load admission. My teenaged boys and I took a 90 minute guided tour that gave an excellent overview of the importance of this site. Terrific scenery and enjoyable!

Went with family for day trip. $ 10 to park in the National Park lot. Walked down trail to lower town from parking lot. Small steep trail. Saw some large turtles in the Canal and pond. Walked by old ruins of a factory then along the Shenandoah River. Upon entering town we explored a bit. There are folks dressed in period clothing. Both young and older kids enjoyed playing period games with hoops and a stick as well as a ring tossing game. There is an informative Horse carriage ride where you can learn about the industrial history (a fee). Tickets are purchased in the bookstore. the walk in houses with displays were quite informative about the civil war period, John Brown, and the early industry. We hiked up to the Jefferson Stone/ overlook for a great view. No problem with a 4 year old along these walks. Several quaint with average food lunch places. We stopped at one of two nice ice cream shops and took an air conditioned bus back up the hill to the Park parking lot (free). If one wished, you could hook up with a portion of the Appalachian Trail or hike on dozens of other trails. The town is well done. Great views, nature, and significant history in a day trip from DC or Baltimore. Highly recommend for an inexpensive day laid back day with many options.

Harpers Ferry, WV, has a small historic district which presents a real parking challenge. The Park Service provides a great shuttle from the Visitors Center, on the top of the hill a mile or two away from the historic district, right into the heart of things and on a continuous loop. The shuttle buses have a 2-bike rack on the front, so that my husband and I were able to ride from parking ($10/day) at the Visitors Center down into town. We were told we weren't allowed to ride bikes down the hill on the main road into town (?? don't know why??). But it was a good way to go as we would not have wanted to ride up that hill to return to our car at the end of the day! The main street of the town was all museums--well done and lots of rangers and park people to help and answer questions. Also park employees dressed up in period costumes to help present the period of Harpers Ferry's important years in our country's history. The side streets going up the hill have lots of shops and, cafes and ice cream places.

My husband, dog and I go to Harpers Ferry about six times a year; winter, spring, summer and Fall. Rather we go to see the living history presentations or just hike 5 on the C & O Canal, we love it! By the way, pay the $10.00 to the National Park Service to park. Not paying may end up costing you more. We saw lots of tickets on cars this past Saturday.

Spent two wonderful days at delightful Harpers Ferry. However, you could get a good feel of the history and the place in one day. Lower Town has all the exhibits and history - it is located at the bottom of a steep hill. If you can get there before 9AM you can park at the train station. There is limited parking as this is the only lot and it fills up quickly. If you are traveling with dogs then this is the lot you would want. If the lot is full then the alternative is the big lot up at the National Park Entrance a couple of miles away. That lot is quite accommodating with an information center. You pay $10/car which is good for three days. The shuttle leaves every 15mtes and an audio relates history of the place along the way. Sit on the side of the bus doors to have good views of the old canal and all the turtles sunning themselves on the branches. The shuttle will let you off right at the Lower Town. My suggestion is to go into the first building to see the film on Harpers Ferry called "A Place in Time". Then walk a few doors down to the Information Center to see what special events are scheduled for that day so you can plan your time to partake in them.

We spent one day of a holiday weekend at this location. They had soldiers dressed in uniform from different wars. they had guns that were used from the different wars, and a special presentation from each of these soldiers of how they were used and they shot them as well. My ten year old loved this. The historical buildings were so authentic and we learned so much from the life that was lived so long ago. It cost us $10.00 to park and a bus took us to and from the town, the only other money spent was on lunch and trinkets. What a great day to enjoy with the family, and learn so much of our past for such a small amount of money. The parks department crew was wonderful!

Harpers Ferry is so quaint, all snuggled in between the Potomac and Shenandoah Rivers with mountains on either side. Read in other reviews that parking is impossible and that is true so I wouldn't even try. Entering town along the Shenandoah there is a very small parking lot you can use but then you have to walk a ways to the town. Do yourself a favor and just pay the $10 and go the park a few miles down. There is a visitor center, bathrooms, and a shuttle bus that will take you into town. We barely had to wait and there was a short audio about Harpers Ferry to listen to. Once you are in town you can go in and out of the "museums" (all free). You will learn about John Brown and the fate of Harpers Ferry in the Civil War and floods. When you begin to walk up the street there are some cute shops and restaurants/ice cream places. We really loved the whole area. If you have no walking problems make sure you go to Jefferson's Rock and walk along the Appalachian Trail a little. (very very steep steps up to them but I think you can drive but not sure how you got there with a car). Harpers Ferry must be gorgeous in the Fall with the leaves turning!

This is a venue for any type of physical abilities. You can drive to different locations and park and hike, although there is limited parking. If you are a civil war buff have at it. OR Take the tram (bus) from the park headquarters back and forth from the park to the town proper of Harpers Ferry. At Harper's Ferry a short walk from the bus drop off, see the the town as it was way back when. . . Walk along the Potomac River for some views, or over the river bridge to head up for some serious hiking. The town has lots of eating places, a few trinket shops, a wax museum, free entry to churches, old mansions etc. The hikes across the bridge are serious. The hike to look out Rock, which gives you view over Harpers Ferry is a favorite. It is 2.8 miles and lots of ups and downs, although it is mostly flat for walking. Good for all age groups, but you should be in pretty good shape and take water. The overlook, lets you look down on the reg. railroad tracks, and the passenger train track as well as the town. Parking is a rare commodity at Harpers although you can drive through it, but there is no place to park, so it only makes sense to go to the park headquarters to take the shuttle bus. The only cost is to get into the park for a cost of $10.00 which is good for 3 days. There was wheel chair access on the bus's. That is cool for the handicapped. This area is great for biking, since bikes can park anyplace.

This park has exhibits as well as shops and restaurants, but all are small. We toured the entire park in half of a day, even looking at all of the exhibits and going in to all of the shops. One other thing- parking is horrible and if you go on the weekend expect to pay $10 for a tiny parking space up on a hill.

This park is beautiful, especially in the fall. With white water rafting, swimming, tubing and the Appalachian Trail running through it and restaurants nearby. There is always something to do. There is limited parking in the lower part of the park for $10 or you can go back up the hill to the visitor center and park for $10 and ride the shuttle down for free. If you arrive late in the day on a Saturday be prepared to park free at the visitors center, but know that many attractions close before 5pm and the last shuttle goes back up to the visitors center at 6:45pm. So be prepared to walk back to your car on a dirt path, or watch the clock and get on that shuttle. Be sure to walk out towards the water and visit shops with many unique gifts and find many restaurants and ice cream shops. We will definitely be back, although I really wish that at least during the summer months, everything should stay open and running later.

We walked the trail through the park into town and rode the bus back at the end of the day. The bus to and from town is free if you pay to park at the visitor's center. With very limited to virtually no parking in old town, parking at the visitor's center seemed the best way to go. It costs $10 per car. The hiking trail has a number of steps, but if you have no mobility problems it is a relaxing short walk to town. There is a little gurgling stream that runs along part of the trail and you pass by some of the old canals as you get near town. Along the way we saw bluebirds, cranes, deer, ducks and turtles sunning themselves. It made for a fun relaxing dayall around.

We visted with 2 friends who had been here several times in the past. It was $10 a car to get into the park and there is a vistor's center with lots of info and people who will answer any questions you may have. There are shuttle buses right at the Vistor's Center that will take you up to Bolivar Heights where you can walk around and read about events that occurred there, and then they also take you to lower downtown Harper's Ferry. When we were there I'd say busses (air conditioned thankfully) came by every 12-15 minutes.

First time taking my family here. I loved coming back with them since visiting with my parents 25 years ago. The $10/car cost to visit is well worth the price. Start at the visitor center and catch a shuttle to the Lower Town. Plan on at least 6+ hours to really see and experience all their is to see and hike. If you have Children be sure to stop at the information center and ask about the Jr. Park Ranger program that is available at every national Park for little or no fee. It really helps kids of all ages to understand why the park is important. It also gives you a good idea of what to see and do while there.

Not much there. John Brown's Fort remains, but all the other buildings are just the stone outline of the foundations. There is an admission charge of $10. There is signage to tell you about what happened there. Vistor center is very small, with no services like were available at the other parks I visited on this trip.

Harpers Ferry is wonderful to visit for many different reasons. Parking at the Park Service welcome center is super easy and inexpensive ($10/car). There's a restroom and welcome station where a staff member will tell you all you need to know. From there you take a 5 minute ride down to the historic town and there is a brief introduction to the history of the town to listen to.

Harper's Ferry is a great place to visit. It is a beautiful and educational place with tons of history with little museums throughout the town. There is a very visible church on top of the hill that is lovely. We weren't able to go in, however. There are some nice shops and decent places to eat. We went into several stores, but there was a pottery store that had some really gorgeous pottery at fairly reasonable prices that we loved. If you are military you can get the National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Pass and get in free. I would do this again even if I had to pay the regular $10 entrance fee.

Going to Harpers Ferry make sure you have 3 hours to hike the Maryland Heights Trail!
