You can park your car at Train Station (very limited spaces available with a $10 fee), cross the bridge (take pictures of that view), walk the Appalachian Trail (take pictures on the poles that have the AT symbol for your memories), cross the C&O canal and start hiking up the mountain. The overlook trail is the short one and have attonishing views of Harpers Ferry and the confluence of the two rivers: Potomac and Shennandoah. If you have more time and energy go ahead till the end of the trail and enjoy more views and nature.

Our family went on a day trip to Harper's Ferry. From Southern New Jersey, it was only about a 2 3/4 hour drive. We love historical places, especially the areas that had involvement with the Civil War era. The town of Harper's Ferry is a must see. Great little town with a lot of history behind it. The location is beautiful, sitting between two rivers and tall mountains. We paid $10.00 to park our car and took the "Top to Bottom" tour of Harper's Ferry. It was so interesting and the park guides were awesome!!! This is a must do if you are going to the town. The tour runs once a day at 11:00 am, and lasts about 90 minutes. Great little restaurants and shops are also scattered throughout the town. .

This is a great side trip if you're into scenery, shops, history and hiking. The Maryland Heights Trail is fun, with a spectacular view at the summit, but it is strenuous, so you have to be in decent shape. The John Brown Wax Museum was "ok", but overpriced,and not included in the park fee. It's short , and interesting . Some of the wax figures have darkened through the ages. The park fee is $10.00 and good for three days so that came in handy as we stopped by the next day on our way home, to walk another trail. There are also flat trail options there. The restaurant there in town, Hannah's, was very good.

With this being a national park, there is a lot of land that is a part of it with sights that are both natural and man-made. The first thing to do on the visit is to pay $10 at the entrance if you are arriving by car ($5 per person arriving by foot or bicycle) and from there, you're free to walk around the park. There are a lot of different types of attractions within this one park, and it is a must-see for many different types of travelers, whether it be hikers (any nature-oriented travelers really), history buffs, or travelers looking for leisure. My visit primarily focused on historical sights in the town, although I also enjoyed some nice scenic views, and I recommend visiting Jefferson's Rock for the beautiful view of the hills (but prepare to walk up a LOT of steps!).

This is worth a stop, just be prepared for the tourist hordes. Take the shuttle bus down to the Lower Town as there are many things to do and see. There are also several places to shop and eat within the site. I highly recommend the old-fashioned candy store for some history and tasty treats. There is a $10 fee to enter the park.

Excellent tour given by National Park Service volunteers, Jim and Howard. Park entrance was $10, we then took a free shuttle to the town of Bolivar where the tour began. For the next hour and a half we walked down hill to Harpers Ferry all the while listening to a well presented historical presentation. Then lunch in Hapers Ferry and a shuttle bus back to the park Visitors Center. Thank you Jim and Howard.

The first stop was at the Visitors Center which actually cost $6 to enter. Once we got there we realized there was actually nothing there. They had a map of the lower town, which I believe you can get online, and you can get your passport stamped. Otherwise, there's not much going on. From the Visitors Center, however, you can take a shuttle to the Lower Town instead of driving there and parking yourself. I don't know that either one is preferable. It's just something you can do. The shuttle's last trip back to the Visitor Center is at 5:45.

Travelled to Harpers Ferry on a whim and with no information about the area except what we learned in elementary school. First stop (logically) was the National Park Visitors Center. After paying $10 to park we went to the Visitors Center building. It was tiny and the long winded park ranger was in the midst of giving his dissertation to a group of 4 visitors and didn't acknowledge us. After 10 minutes of waiting we left to try to figure it out.

We were here two weeks ago. If you go in the off season, you may be able to find parking, but in the busy season, you can take a shuttle from the visitor's center which runs every 15 minutes. There is a place in the town where you can watch a movie of the history of the town. There is a church which was closed when we were there. You can hike to Jefferson Rock which gives a lookout of the valley below. There are also various shops and some restaurants. Very quaint. From what I recall, the fee was about $6 per family.

My husband and I visited Harpers Ferry National Park this weekend and we loved it. It's $6 to get into the park and a bus shuttles you from the visitors center down to the lower town so you don't have to walk. The park is set up like a little town and you can go into the different buildings and learn about life in Harpers Ferry before, during and after the civil war. There's also a lot of information about John Brown's raid. You can go into some of the homes and even visit the Catholic Church in the town that still holds mass every Sunday. Make sure to go up to Jefferson's Rock where the view from the top of the mountain is absolutely amazing. You can see where the Potamac and Shenandoah Rivers meet. When we were there, the Shenandoah was an emerald green...so beautiful! You should also walk across the footbridge over the Potomac (i think it's part of the C&O Trail) and get more scenic views looking back at Harpers Ferry. Make sure you also walk along the river and check out Virginius Island. You can walk right up the river and there are old ruins on the island.

Been to Harpers Ferry on different occasions but this is first time in 10 years. First the parking, cannot remember where I parked in the past but this time I did not want to take the Shuttle from the external parking sites, so parked at the Amtrak train station which turns out to be the same price $6 as the external sites that require a shuttle. The Amtrak station is at the base of Harpers Ferry so no extra walking needed. My favorite spots are Jefferson Rock and then the walk over the Railroad bridge into Maryland Heights. If you enjoy hiking, hiking on the Maryland side is interesting.

Harpers Ferry National Historical Park is uniquely situated at the tip of West Virginia. From Harpers Ferry, you can see and easily hike into Maryland (via the foot bridge) and Virginia (via the pedestrian path on Route 340). The park rangers are friendly and extremely helpful if you are not sure where you are trying to go. We parked at the Harpers Ferry historic train station, where you pay a $6 park entrance fee, which is good for 3 days from the date of purchase. My Dad was visiting and we enjoyed the park and area in general so much that we came back two days later to spend more time walking around the town of Harper's Ferry and Virginius Island. From my understanding, the town largely rolls up shop from Christmas to March, but you can still find places to eat and a few shops doing business. One of the main draws of the park and the town is the rich slice of American history, much of which is well preserved. This area is friendly to hikers, history buffs, families, and even dogs. If you plan to be in the vicinity or live within a 2-3 hour's drive, I highly recommend checking out this park and town.

Had a great and enjoyable visit to Harpers Ferry National Historical Park this past weekend. I was very confused by the previous post stating that it is "very expensive" to park at Harpers Ferry. The cost is only $6 per vehicle to park at the park entrance area and take a quick shuttle ride to the Lower Town. The entrance fee is good for three days and is a bargain for an entire family! This past weekend was a fee free weekend in honor of Veteran's Day so there was no charge at all!

We visited Harpers Ferry with a tour bus group of about 50 (mostly seniors) and began with a stop at the Visitors Center. There we paid a $150 fee and proceeded into town where we met up with Rick Garland's "O Be Joyefull" tour as we were instructed. It was an excellent and informative tour, but when our bus came to pick us up, an NPS ranger advised our driver he couldn't come up High Street as planned. The group had to walk back down the hill to the depot, catch a shuttle bus back to the Visitor Center, then meet our coach there. On the way, one of our guests was confronted by a NPS ranger and treated rather rudely...very disappointing and quite the opposite of my other experiences with these usually very friendly and informative folks. Bottom line is that we would have enjoyed our visit much more if folks had given us better information and if the rangers had not been so cold to their guests.

Visited here on my way home from the casino (not worth it), and am very glad I stopped. The view is gorgeous and the guides are very helpful. It only cost $6 for the entire car of people. There is a shuttle bus there that takes you into the small town for more sight seeing that is included with the price of admission to the park. Everything was clean, including the bus, and everyone in town was very nice and helpful.The history surrounding the park is also fascinating. I would go back again.

We stopped at Harpers Ferry on our trip from NY to Atlanta. Thought we would just grab a bite for lunch and move onto the Skyline Drive. Once we found out that there was no parking in town, and that you had to take a shuttle bus from visitors parking, we almost left. That would have been a mistake. Fantastic views of nature combined with quaint village and historical sight. If you are ever in this area, don't drive past here. Best part was we got in for $10 since I was able to buy a lifetime senior pass (age 62) for national parks.

Ten dollars gets you three days of parking and entrance to all the National Park buildings. We really enjoyed that alot of the buildings were not overtly staffed so you didn't have someone hovering and "making sure" you weren't touching anything. Tons of information, clean bathrooms and guided tours that you can join or leave at your leisure. Very nice set-up.

Your first stop will be the visitor center. After paying $6 for the carload to enter the parking area, me (25 yr old male), my older brother and my parents, decided to start things off with a little picnic. On the side of the parking area are a few picnic tables, just be warned, there are a lot of gnats! Otherwise it was peaceful. Then we went to the visitor center which is mainly just a small building with materials on the town itself and some items for sale. Then we all jumped on the shuttle bus (comfortable and air conditioned) where we headed to the town of Harpers Ferry.

I have been to Harper's Ferry many times. Its a terrific little town where the Potomac and Shenendoah Rivers connect with alot of history, ranging from John Brown's Raid to the Civil War to the floods that have frequently ravaged the town. There are wonderful videos to watch, great river views, hiking trails, a CSX rail bridge that you can stand next to and feel the power of a locomotive, ruins to explore. They charge $5 per car to park outside ot town and then the NPS shuttles you to the town. During the week, it is possible to park in the town but I don't think its encouraged.

I was in Harpers Ferry National Historical Park for four hours mid-August 2010. Getting to the park from the south was delayed because of construction. The entrance fee was $6. Parking was easy, and the ranger at the visitor center was very friendly and helpful, as this was my first visit. I took the shuttle to the Lower Town. It then started to rain and rained the rest of the day! I walked the quick Virginius Island trail. There are good restrooms in Lower Town next to the bookstore. The short 2:00 pm ranger talk was helpful in placing Harpers Ferry in history. I then walked around the historical buildings. It reminded me very much of Greenfield Village in Dearborn, Michigan! The walking bridge across the river was fun, and the walk up to the Jefferson Rock was easier than expected. The Bolivar Heights area was isolated. When I go again, I will walk the Maryland Heights and C&O Towpath trails and do a float trip!

We had just a few hours to spend at this historic park, and that was plenty on a rainy day. We did enjoy the park, but probably would have really loved all the hiking opportunities on a day that wasn't a mixture of rain and snow. There is a junior ranger program with an opportunity to earn 3 badges. The booklet does cost $1.50. We have been to over 20 national parks and this is the first time I have seen an associated fee for junior ranger, maybe a new trend?

It costs $25 per car to enter the park. We did the roughly-two hour Kilauea'Iki trail hike into, through and back out of the volcanic crater. It starts off as the Crater Rim Trail and then turns down into the crater. It's a great moderate hike. Recommend entering at the trailhead for Crater Rim Trail off of Crater Rim Road and exiting across from Thurston Lava tube....this direction is the best. This hike really gives you a good feel for the terrain and what the park is about. We also had dinner at The Rim restaurant which gave us great views of the glowing active volcano. The Chain of Craters Rd is also a nice drive to the ocean.

First of all, if you think you'll go to any other National Park during the next year, I recommend just getting a National Park Pass. It's 25$ to get in per car, and if you get the pass you can feel less pressure and even come back another day.

Wow. Great to see. Takes about 2 hours from kona. Back a lunch and snack. There is very limited options along the way! You go thru long stretches of no town or gas. Part is well laid out. Good but small visitor center. Stop in for advice on where to see best views. Lots of hiking and biking options. $25 for car entry. Give yourself lots of time to explore. 1 restaurant volcano house onsite

I suggest going in your own car so you can take as much time as you want. The fee entrance is $25 USD, save the receipt it is good for 3 days. It is a whole day tour since there are many stops. You will see craters, lava tube, destruction path of the volcano and lots of lava rocks.
For us, HVNP was best seen over three slower days vs one rushed day. The $25 entrance fee is good for a week.

We specifically stayed in Volcano, so as to have easy access for several days in the park. For $25, you can get a week's pass for access; if you have a national parks pass, entry is free, but you will have to show it and your ID each time. We rarely had to wait in line and when we did, it was under 10 minutes. If you only have 1-2 hours, we highly recommend the Chain of Craters drive down to the ocean. If you have more time, as we did, there are quite a few options. Here's everything we did and the approximate amount of time we spent, including our impressions:

Started at visitor center to a short walk with ranger who spoke on the volcano history, Hawaiian lore, and the flora and fauna of the area. Continued hike through the Lava Tunnel, about 4.5 round trip, lots of vista points and very well marked trail. steep in areas but not too bad. This is a National park and is expansive need more than a day to see it all. The parts we touched on were fabulous, and left us wanting to come back at another time. If you are a senior and have a lifetime pass entrance fee is free otherwise $25 per car, not matter what it is worth a visit.

We rented a car in Hilo after getting off the Pride of America for an easy drive to the Volcano National Park. It was a rainy, cloudy day so the sights were not the best. After listening to a ranger describe the various places to visit in the visitor center - we set off for the drive around the park. Jaggar Museum was packed with people from several tour busses. The museum was an interesting place for a history on the island volcanoes. Be sure and hike to the lava tube during your drive around the park. Entrance fee was $25 per car but we used our golden age pass for free admittance.

We visited Hawaii Volcanoes National Park on Tuesday November 21, 2017. Our goal: to see lava! We got there early (7:30am) to do the Kilauea Iki Trail around the old lava lake (go early to beat the tour buses ). This was really cool. Wear tennis shoes (open toed shoes are not recommended), lava rock grips well but is very jagged. Make sure to do the extra part of the hike through the lava tube! Make sure to do it clockwise and the book for $2 dollars that can be purchased at the beginning of the trail right when you leave the parking lot on the right, was definitely worth the $2. The hike took us 2 hours and we’re pretty fast hikers! After that we headed to the visitor center. We asked about where we could go to see lava.... well usually you can hike up to and around Kilauea Caldera but due to the amount of fumes it is currently expelling it is closed and you can’t go near it. You can also usually go down and see lava flowing right by the water, but recently that has stopped. You can see steam vents and those are neat, but without lava flowing and lots of the park closed we were able to finish all the sights in a 1/2 day. In summary: double and triple check that you can actually view lava before going. Plan on a much shorter day if parts of the park are closed and go early to beat the crowds. Side note- there is very little to do in this part of the island aside from see the parks. The town is tiny and just a handful of restaurants/ a food truck.

We spent 2 days here, $25 fee good for a week. Make sure to go to the visitor center and watch the 20 min movie that plays every half hour. It was very informative. We did a couple of hikes. The best one was the 4 miler through the “bathtub” of the lava flow. The rest are very short and very crowded. Lots of tour buses. We also liked the view from jagger museum, tried to come back at night to see the red glow but the rain come in and fogged out the entire thing. Too bad. Stop into the volcano house and have a mai tai if you have time, amazing view.

Why would you go to the big island if not for the volcano? It's a must see!!!! Definitely go in the evening because you have to be there for sunset. As the sun goes down the volcano starts to glow. The darker it gets the more fascinating the volcano effects. It's only $25 a car to get into the park which gives you a week's entrances. To see the volcano from the ocean requires a boat ride that is very pricey, $200 a person. Amazingly these tours are often sold out so don't wait until the day before to book. There is a 2 hour hike to go to the ocean view by land, 2 hours in and 2 hours out. Most leave at 3:30 pm to be there for the evening viewing of the lava flowing into the ocean.

I have been a few times to the park, but it has been several years. Plus, I was bringing my travel buddy, who had never been to the Big Island, and this is one of the activities we had definitely planned to do. If you are driving from the Kona side of the island, plan to take 1.5-2 hours to drive at the Park. Also, when entering the Park, remember there is a $25 fee.

We visited the park with our 6 year old son this week and used the "Shaka Big Isle" app as our tour guide. The best $3.99 I have ever spent! Download the information on wifi before you go and the app will tell you stories at the park using the GPS. We learned about the differ st lava flows and many stories of Hawaiian culture. The whole family loved it. It was like having a tour guide with you but you could go at your own pace and use your own car.

There are very few places in the world where you can get right up to an active volcano. Plan to spend the whole day here, including early evening.. If you own an iPhone or iPad, download the app "Big Island Volcanoes GPS Driving Tour - Hawaii Audio Guid" by Shaka $4. It's a great GPS based audio guide playing from your device for getting directions, stories, and tip around the park.

Went to see what I could see from both ends of the flow. Just the steam through the park and it is a 5 mile walk each way and end up a half mile away. They could get you a half mile closer if the wanted. From the Hilo side and highway 130 you get to 4 miles away and have 3 options to get within a half mile. Bike almost all the way, lots of vendors and bike prices available from $10 and up. Most about $25. Take ahold personal mini van half way a bike the rest for $40 or the van and walk the rest for $30. You can walk the 4 miles also for free. At the end of the road you can go down about 100 yards over lava to see the fresh flow into the ocean. It was amazing. What struck me was how quiet people were, just watching nature in action. You can go up towards the pail 1.5 miles over lava to possibly see flows much closer. The road is crushed basalt and not hard walking, if you are doing the long lava walk do it during the daylight, injuries every day there.

Look, I get it: Hawaii = volcanoes. And while there is still some activity at Kilauea Caldera, you can't see it from the park -- everything is blocked off from very far away -- so all you get is smoke. No surface flows. Parking is $25/car. If you take Chain of Craters Rd all the way down, you see some great views, but it's a 5+ mile hike each way to get to the lava flowing into the ocean (which we didn't do, so I can't actually comment whether you can get right up to it or not.) I wish we had done a helicopter tour instead; may have actually been able to peak into Kilauea and see everything in under an hour.

We stayed at the Kilauea Military Camp inside the park. The rooms were priced well and though old, were nice. We went to the lava tube, the lights were out so they required you to have flash lights. Parking is very limited at this attraction, so you may have to hike some. After we went to the lave tree state monument and to see the lave flow into the ocean..The tress were a quick stop. The lava flow coming from outside the park is a 4.5 mile each way hike. Most of it was on a dirt/rock county road, the last few 100 so yards is on the old lave flow (it is rough wear good shoes). We went at dusk/night to try and get a good show. We were disappointed to only see some glow and not the actual lava. You may want to be at the sight at sunset so plan accordingly and not walk it all at night. It is very dark. The local have bike rentals and rides available at $20-30. After we got back we went back to the park to see the crater at night. We got some good pictures of the glow off the lava lake. We did everything self paced and guided.

Where else can you go walk up to lava? Only here on the Big Island. Hawaii Volcanoes National Park requires an entire day to fully appreciate. There is so much to see, so much information to learn. They accept National Park Pass, so no fee for parking if you have one of those.

Of course, you must visit this park. The price has gone up from $5 to $25 dollars a car load, so be prepared for that, and right now, you can't see the lava flow from this location. You have to drive close to an hour away and walk or rent a bike or shuttle for four mile each way to see lava hitting the water. But this is still a cool park to visit. It took us a couple of hours to hike to the Thurston Lava tube and do the drive of the crater rim drive. The drive is good if people don't want to hike. We also went to the visitor's center and watched the film which was very informative and good for my kids to see. I think somehow we missed the hike through the crater though. I forgot to do this. Will have to go back I guess!

This is not the easiest experience to plan. Of course we wanted to see the lava flowing into the ocean from the Kilaua Caldera. Everybody says to go after dark; that's good advice, but unfortunately it didn't work for us. We went to the visitor center first, but the staff, despite their best efforts, was overwhelmed by the crowd, and it was hard to get a good orientation. Since we were hungry we had lunch there, and were very impressed by the quality of the restaurants. We ate at Volcano House across the road from the visitor center, and were astounded by the view of the caldera offered from our table. We decided to drive the Chain of Craters Road to approach the lava flow from the west. It was a nice drive, but ended at a point from which one had to hike ten miles against a strong wind to get to the viewing area. We decided to try again the next day. The following day we approached from Highway 130 from the east. We were told the viewing area didn't open until after 3:00 pm, but this turned out to be inaccurate. At the end of the road, we were able to rent two bikes for about $50 to ride the last 4 miles to the viewing area. The rental company told us they were open from 3:00 am, and that early morning was actually the best time to go. The shuttles don't start running until after 3:00 pm, and perhaps that's what they were talking about. The shuttles will take you close to the viewing area, and you can walk or take your bike on the shuttle to ride from there. We arrived at the viewing area, and we could see the smoke from where the lava entered the ocean, but could barely see the actual glow from the lava. We followed the trail from there onto the hardened lava flow because we were told if we went 40 minutes in, we could get close enough to touch hot lava with a stick. We stayed close to the rope advising visitors not to venture any closer until we came to the point where the trail went up the hill toward vents of steam. We followed that trail for a while until we could smell sulphurous gases and the ground became hot, but we turned back before encountering lava. If I could do it again, I would have continued further up the hill. Instead, we went back and continued to follow the perimeter ropes until we reached the terminus of the road from the west, about a two-hour hike. Had we walked the ten miles from the other side, we would have reached a viewing point which was no better than the one from the east. While it was disappointing not to be able to get a better, closer, view, it was still amazing to hike over miles of congealed lava which looked like someone had emptied a huge bowl of cake batter. It was a day of strenuous activity, so we were happy to be able to get water and hotdogs when we got back to the bike rental area.

We stayed at Mauna Lani and drove over 2.5 hours to get here. It was raining like crazy in Hilo but was just drizzling at the park. We had lost our seniors pass to all the national parks so we're able to get another for $10 before the price goes up to $80 later this month. Get yours now seniors! Anyway, it was a good trip and saw a little lava bubbling up but mainly just steam coming out of a big hole. Still glad we did it. Bring a windbreaker or long sleeved shirt because it's chilly there.

The lifetime pass to national parks for seniors will increase in August, from $10.00 to $80.00. This is an easy pass to purchase at the park entrance before the rate increase, just show id with age and residence. It only took a minute and gives seniors free entry to all national parks. It's a great deal!

As we all know, this is a must see on the island. Make sure you stop at the visitor center once you pay for $25 at the entrance. They have a couple "info sessions" and simple events going on during the day. It could be very informative. We went to see the Jaggar museum and you can literally spot live lava from distance. We stopped by at lava tube, then hiked on Kīlauea Iki trial. It was amazing! We picked the easier route, which we hiked for a solid 20 mins then stepped on the bottom of crater floor, and turned back. You also have an option to hike for 4 miles doing a loop. I strongly recommend you to walk down to the bottom. The view was simply stunning. I was informed that people do stay overnight at park lodging places and drive plus hike all the way to the coast, where you can get closer to the lava. Make sure you plan ahead! It sounds super fun!!

If you are spending time on the Big Island, make the trip to Hawaii Volcanoes National Park. Admission is $25 per car and ticket is good for several days, which you can easily spend in this expansive place. The park is designed for you to drive your car from point to point. They do have days where admission is free so be sure to check their website prior to your visit. Only have a few hours to spend there? I recommend visiting the Visitor Center for a general overview and geological understanding, Sulphur Banks, Jagger Museum for a view of the famous Kilauea Caldera, Thurston Lava Tube for a quick stroll, and Kilauea Iki Overlook. Have some more time? Do the Kilauea Iki Trail hike--a four mile loop that guides you down into and through a hardened lake of lava. Bring water and wear sneakers! Have an entire day to spend? Do all the above mentioned sites plus the 13-mile Craters Drive where you can stop along the way to look at petroglyphs, crater, view the smoke from the active lava flowing into the ocean, and observe a natural sea arch at the bottom. Have lots of time AND energy? You can hike from the sea arch to observe actual lava but be aware that the journey will be 8 miles round trip. Want to see a spectacular lava light show without the hike?! Time your visit to coincide with sunset--you can view the steam and lava splash in Kilauea Caldera from the Jaggar Museum, best viewed in its spectacular pink glow in the evening. Bring a sweater; it gets cold at night! Enjoy your trip!

The prices doubled to $25 per car and the sights were lacking. The Thurston Lava Tube was minimal. It was done in five minutes though the parking took 25 minutes. The steam vents were just okay. The Museum was interesting but there were screaming kids running through the place and no one (especially their parents) were stopping them. Overpriced for the quality.

First of all, this place is huge. You pay $25 to get in, and then you could be here for days driving around or hiking around to see everything. That $25 will get you in and out of the park for 7 days. For some people who were unimpressed, this is nature, and volcanoes don't blow like a theme park. The steam vents were great to be near, the views of the Rim from the Museum as well as just the regular views inside the park were very neat. We heard from a lady next to us at the viewpoint, that they had seen the volcano blow the day before, and came back an extra day because they enjoyed the park so much. If we had had more time, we would have hiked the 4 miles down to the Rim and 4 miles back. Maybe not the 9 miles to a cabin, but that would be for more hard core hikers. Totally worth it.

If you come to the big Island of Hawaii you must come here. This is a beautiful park with many great things to see and experience. The best time to arrive is around 3:30pm and make sure you stay until dark evening so you can see the glow of the lava creator. The fee is around $25 per car and is worth every penny. Highly recommended.

Visiting the Kalapana Lava Flow is truly excellent and a great way to spend half a day. Skip the visitor centre at the park headquarters because they don't really have a lot of information that will help you (though the nearby lodge has an excellent gift shop, it's not really worth the $25 park gate fee). If you aren't interested in what's on Chain of Craters Road and the like, and just want to see the lava meet the water, head for the free East Entrance.

There are endless hikes and overviews. The ranger station is nice with pamphlets and maps and some info as well as a nice gift store. Nice bathroom that are not available everywhere. Parking is the best here and the entrance fee is $25 per car.

Watching lava exploding upward from the crater was super cool at night, although it was crowded at the Jagger Visitor Center and hard to get a good pictures with all the people in the way. Bring binoculars to see volcanic explosions. The visitor center was informative and had some cool volcano merchandise to purchase. The Jagger museum has daily operational hours but you can look at the lava from the outlook point 24/7. Entrance to Volcanos National Park is free after 7 pm. During the days its $25 per car.

Bring hiking shoes as this is many miles to hike and lots of water. This park is huge. Lots to see. I would recommend night time to see the sunken lava pit glowing. Very surreal. Also it has a $25 per car entry fee so be prepared.

To view the volcanoes you enter Volcanoes National Park - about a 45 minute ride from Hilo and tack on another 1.5-2 hours if you are on the Kona side of the island. We made a day of it from our lodging in Waikola - we stopped first at Mauna Kea and then we headed over to Hilo and on to Volcanoes National Park, arriving around 3:00. The entrance fee was pretty steep - $25 for the car which is good for a week I believe (very reasonable compared to the cost of all other activities, but a little steep for a National Park. I think there is a program that allows you to pay $25 to gain admission to all 4 national parks on the island. I read about it after we paid to get in to 3 of them, this being the third). In any case, it was well worth it! We hit up the visitor center first so we could lay out where we were going, we listened to one of the rangers give a brief talk and then we watched the videos of the Volcanoes. We had our 9 and 13 year olds with us and wanted to go where they could see the earth in action. We didn't have a lot of time, about 2 hours, and I would say you really should plan on spending at least 3-4 to really explore. We stopped at the steam vents, then the Jagger Museum. It had been raining and cloudy since we left Mauna Kea and we weren't expecting to see too much. But, just as we parked at the Jagger Museum, the sun popped out and it cleared up for a few minutes. We had a glorious view of a full rainbow off to the left and an incredible view of the Kailua crater off to our right, venting steam. It lasted for all of 10 minutes and the rain and clouds came back and you couldn't see anything other than the outline of the crater. We stopped at a few other sites on our way to the lava tubes but couldn't see much. We did the lava tubes (steep walk down and back up, but can do the whole walk to/from the lava tubes in 10-20 mins). By the time we were done there, we were soaked from the rain and called it a day before heading back to Kona via Hilo once again. Kids loved it, we loved it. Highly recommend to see it when you are on the Big Island.
This is a notional park and there is a $25 entry or a annual park pass. Don't forget to get the park map at the gate. There were none at the visitor's center.

Well worth spending a few days to explore this very unique national park. If possible, make it at least 3-4 days. There are sights you won't see anywhere else in the world. We arrived just as visitors were gathering for the early afternoon ranger walk. So glad we joined them. It was a very good way to get an intro to the park -- the land, location and info about key features, plants, and the history of the people and their relationship with the volcano fire goddess Pele. Our guide, Education Ranger Michael, grew up nearby, so the national park was his childhood playgrounds. He was very knowledgeable and personable, he pointed out interesting things that we would have missed on our own, and he shared stories about what it's like living with an active volcano. This national park is open 24/7, so you can go to the viewing area in front of the Jaggar Center at night to see the beautiful bubbling, sputtering orange light show of the active Halema'uma'u Crater below. It is said that this is the home of Pele. Check with the visitor center about other lava viewing options. Along the road to the Jaggar Center, there are some places to view the giant Kilauea caldera and some interesting thermal features, such as steam vents. Also, allow a day to drive Chain of Craters Road, which starts near the visitor center and runs down to the sea. Very varied, very scenic. The Thurston Lava Tube is near the start. Once a conduit for lava flows. A very interesting quick stop/walk. There are so many places to check out on the way that we ran out of time before we got to the place at the end of the road where we could walk down to see lava rolling into the sea. But, the views all along the way are "something else". We were impressed by the size of the lava "shields" (fields) and intrigued by the different forms of lavas. We enjoyed seeing the petroglyphs. The petroglyph trail is .7miles each way. For this and any other hiking, be sure to wear sturdy laced walking shoes, sunscreen and sunhat. Bring plenty of water and a lunch. There is a small "visitor center" at the end of the road. We didn't stop there so, sorry, we can't tell you about that. Even if you can't do the final walk, there are some great outlook views along the way. The park is ever-changing because of the active volcano. Be aware of signs warning of places closed/dangerous due to hazards. This is serious stuff. We didn't have time to do any hikes, except for the petroglyph trail, but it looks like there are some great opportunities to see stunning scenery. To take full advantage of the park, we recommend that you go online to check out lodging in nearby Volcano. Also, there is a lodge in the park that overlooks the caldera. We stayed in a darling, very private cottage. The town is small, with limited services, so buy groceries before you get there. We found the book "Hawaii, the Big Island Revealed" to be very helpful. The park is open 24/7; there is a nominal entrance fee. It's free if you have the National Park's senior pass. If you're 62+ and don't have the senior pass, ask. Currently, you pay the $10 entrance fee and that pays for the pass which is good for your lifetime.

Of course a must see when visiting the island. It's $25 per car for entrance and I believe that was a 7 day pass. We had about 75 minutes for the stop. It was very cold and rainy. We did not get to see the parts of the lava flow as it was light and we did not have the time to hike and see the certain areas of better viewing. ( our ship did take us pass the path of the flowing lava into the ocean). There are a few stores, camping, etc along the way.

The entrance is 20$ and gives you one week pass. Pack camera, a poncho, snack and water. Wear your hiking shoes and just enjoy your day. The lava tube was interesting. If you go to the visitor center, ask for the ranger walk. We did it qith a wonderful young lady who taught us a lot about ferns, the pele Goddess, the babysitter plant, amd variety of ginger which grow in the forest. It was very informative. The sudden rain made our walk more exciting.
Great park, well organized. The visitor center has rangers everywhere trying to help. $20 a day gets you in and out for a week.

Even on a short notice Volcanoes is worth a stop. If you have someone in your party of a certain age that has a Golden Pass, or on free day like we had; no charge. But even if you need to pay the pass it is worth doing. The Lava Tube is a nice walk, going out to the viewing center is interesting; particularly if you chance into a day where the Lava Lake forms up a bit. But take the time to drive out to the Arch. Nice way to gain perspective of the Park. However; do not plan to walk out to the Fire-hose lava from there. You will be downwind and likely stopped by the sulfur even if you can walk that far. Go to the other side and rent a Bike to get most of the way.

This was our second time in a few years to visit this park. It is an experience walking the lava trails. If you are eligible, I suggest you buy the National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands Pass at the entrance. For 62+ seniors, pay $10 and you have a lifetime pass to the parks. Since you can use it to the other national parks, you already get your money's worth.

Amazing sights, no matter what the weather. I did the Twilight Volcanoes tour with Hawaii Forest and Trail. I would highly recommend them as their tour guides are super knowledgeable. Not only about volcanoes and lava flows but the vegetation, natural history of Hawaii, astronomy and many other topics. The park was awesome and I'm so glad I saw what I did over several hours. This park is open 24/7 and when you pay $20 to get your car in, it's good for a week. I didn't do any of the long hikes but I hear that they are amazing. As someone said, " When are you ever going to see a volcano at home or what a volcano can do?". So, don't skip this attraction.

This park is full of amazing experiences! It costs $20 per car to get in but so worth it! First visit the visitors center to get all the up to date info on the lava. Then go to Jagger museum to see the caldera. The lava lake was bubbling up to see, but normally you can only see steam during the day and have to wait for the evening to see the orange lava. Thurston lava tube is a quick way to walk through an old lava tube and very cool! The hike out to actually see the lava by the Holei sea arch was long, hot, and not worth it in my opinion. We didn't see any lava actually oozing. If you do decide to do this hike it is no joke! Bring water and tons of sunscreen. The black lava gets really hot and reflects the sun! We stayed through the evening to eat dinner and see the caldera at night. We found the two hour drive back to Kona not too bad and doable.
Why would you visit the Big island without going here? $20 per vehicle entrance fee good for 7 days. Plan for at least one full day to see everything - two is better. Sunset is amazing...

This park is a great way to learn a lot about the volcanoes without having to spend the hundreds of dollars per person for a helicopter or boat tour. Lots of information in several areas of the park and an opportunity to see from a distance but not too far the lava boiling in the lake and the steam rising up out of many fissures in different locations throughout the park.

We started the day at the visitors center where the Park Rangers give you information about the current status of the lava flow. We saw exploding lava at the lava lake from the lookout at the Jaeger Museum both during the day and at night. The park is open 24 hours a day. We then decided to drive out of the park and west to Rte. 130 south. Arriving at the end of the road on Highway 130, you come to at least a half dozen bike rental companies. Rent a bike from anywhere from $15 to $40. They wereally all a flat rate, no hourly rates. At least one vendor was on site 24 hours a day but our company required the bikes to be back by 8:30pm. You ride 4 miles one way to ground lava flow and to where the lava enters the ocean. At the end of the gravel bike road (and some people walked), we walked another 25 minutes onto old volcanic rock and arrIved at active lava flows. You literally felt the heat. It was an awesome experience. Without leaving the national park, you can get to the same spot but there is no option for bikes. The park service says it's an 11 mile round-trip walk and the bike portion of our journey was 3.8 one way. You can also see the glow of the lava in the steam plume as it enters the ocean at this same spot. This experience was the highlight of our Hawaii trip.

The 8-mile round trip trail that begins at the end of 130 was closed due to current lava activity. A disappointment after walking 3.5 miles towards the plume. Some people ignored the warning signs and forged ahead, while others hiked down through the lava field to the ocean within the safe zone. I wouldn't recommend hiking through the lava fields unless you're in good physical condition. 1-gallon of water per person is highly recommended for the trip. The black lava makes the trek extremely hot. Start early in the morning if you can. At the start of the trail, there are bikes you can rent. There is also a shuttle that takes you 1.5 on the trail, then you can walk or bike the rest of the way. The shuttle was $20 round trip. Bicycle rentals were $25-30. The views are amazing!

Beautiful day trip . Worth the once in a lifetime visit ! Go towards evening so you can see the volcano during the day and then also at night when you can see the orange glow of lava flowing at night ! Take warm clothes , it gets very cold up there ! Charge your call phone camera !

Second visit to the volcanoes national park. This time we went down to see the lava flow into the ocean at sunset. It was a do not miss experience. I went in from the east or Hilo side through kalapana area. This way was supposed to be shorter and easier than the west side entry. It was easy to get to and well organized. The gravel road leading to the lava was an easy walk with sturdy shoes on. Many rented bikes at the entry for a small fee which seems like a good idea. I opted to take a golf cart shuttle for $25 which I enjoyed. Then we hiked for another two mikes maybe to get to the lava flow area.

As one of the most active volcanos in the United States, this can be a real learning experience. The indoor museum exhibit is very interesting and informative. A tour of the road around the crater is interesting, but there is not of "action" to be seen. From the observation point, you MAY be able to see "fountaining" of lava in the crater, but there is not pattern that is predictable. The best way to view the highly publicized lava entering the ocean is from a helicopter. These rides are readily available in the Hilo area and run $150-200, but are definitely worth the expense.

This place was my main reason for booking a trip on the Big Island and I was not disappointed. The $20 fee to enter the park is worth it and good for a week of entrance. I started my hiking at the Kilauea Iki Trail that takes you around and through the crater. Humbling to walk through the crater and see bursts of steam and spots of trees/vegetation. As you round this trail you can stop off and see the Thurston Lava Tube. I attempted to hike the Destination Trail but it was currently closed less than .5miles down the trail labeled a hazard area. Stopped over to the Volcano Gallery for interesting finds/gifts. I paused for lunch at the Volcano House and more gift shopping. I parked at the Kilauea Visitor Center and hiked through the Steam Vents, down the Crater Rim Trail to Kilauea Overlook and on to the Jagger Museum to view the active lava view point at night. Walking back at night with a flashlight was unreal, the stars are a sight to behold. If you get the chance to visit this park take it! I can't wait to return.

Not much of a scenic drive. No stops for food or restrooms. $20 admission per vehicle. Areas can be very crowded. Film shown in visitor center old and boring. I felt confused about what to do and where to go. Visitor center could use a little update. Not a lot of parking when you visit the different spots on the volcano. Will have to be patient. I'm not into getting on tour buses but this is one place I would take a tour. This a tunnel but if you've walked through a tunnel or cave not worth trying to park or taking the 1/2 mile walk that they suggest from a near by parking lot. Nice walk to the tunnel. Not handicap accessible.

What a site to see! Volcano is very active and we enjoyed seeing it from both sides and during the day and night! Very spectacular during the night. We rented bikes to ride the 4 miles to the viewing site at night. Only $20 a bike , everything included (water, headlamps, flashlight, etc ). We would highly recommend it!

I went with a friend to the Park where the lava was going into the ocean. It was about a 1.5 hour trip from our hotel in the Kahlua area and the closest road got to about 5 miles from the lava flow. We rented two mountain bikes for $20 and took the ride to the attraction. I ride a road bike at home frequently and I can say that 10 round trip ride was one of the hardest rides I have taken. Its a gravel road with a lot of ups and downs and the mountain bikes were very uncomfortable. I would recommend that people not do this unless they are in very good shape. If you walk the 10 miles its a hike on the same gravel road. Take good shoes if your going to walk on the lava to get a better view.

We ended up going here twice and it is fantastic that one ticket at $20 for a car entrance is valid for 7 days so just one fee! First visit was all the shorter walks and sights. We spent four hours in the park walking to see various sites. Our second visit was a planned day. We took the challenge of doing the 11 mile round trip hike to see the lava flow to the ocean. It was so worth it. Make sure you have plenty of water and wear sun screen as you are fully exposed during your 4 hour hike! Also, first 3 miles are on even terrain but the last 1.5 miles is over volcanic lava so you need to climb, jump, etc. It is not hard but it is not for those with medical conditions or who are not particularly fit or able. Also stay for the evening and the dark to see the volcano eruptions at the summit. Spectacular and worth the wait. Little chilly on the summit so bring a sweater or jacket to wear.

It was torrential rain the day we visited. They have rain ponchos for sale $5. So we covered up and headed out from the visitors center. We followed the free map and saw all the amazing sites. Our favorite was walking through the lush rain forester to observation decks of the flowing Lava. We went during the day, but it was still exciting and red and glowing. We also hiked through a lava tube which the kids enjoyed a lot.
We did a driving tour of the park using a GPS. based tour on our smartphone made by Shaka Tours. The app is free, the tour cost $2.99! Best three bucks I have every spent. We didn't miss a thing.

When we visited the volcano we heard that you could take Hwy 130 to the end and then rent a bike to see the volcano pour lava into the sea. The trek to do this is not for the weak. It was a 8+ mile round trip on some pretty uncomfortable bike's. As my husband said, "I did not know this was on the bucket list!!!" This is worth the effort and the time. I suggest you leave in time to see the sunset, as the viewing of the lava is so much more visible, Walking can be done too, but definitely the bike ride makes the trip easier and if the weather is right really enjoyable. Bike rentals only $20 so go for it!

A one of a kind National Park unlike most. As you explore the exhibits in Volcano House and see the caldera, it's awe inspiring. No lava flow, just steam vents but still awesome to see. HINT - remember to bring your National Parks Passport Book and get stamped, it's be one you treasure and remember!

There aren't many places where you can go tour a volcano, this place is pretty neat. I was surprised at how inexpensive it was to get in, $20 a car and this last a week. We also drove the rim, which was nice. There are many areas that you can hike too. The people here are very passionate about their work. This makes for a nice learning experience. I would definitely recommend anyone to go, at least once.

Do your research and prepare! I'm still PO'd at hubs because I wanted to get an earlier start and he prevented us from doing so! We stayed in Waikola and its a 2 hour drive there. Allot plenty of time to be IN the park if you want to see alot or most of it as it takes time but SO worth it. $20 to drive in and you can cover alot of ground by car/scenic drive. Plenty of stops along the way to see myriad things. The bubbling lava flow (at crater and at sea) were spectacular. IF you want to see it at sea up close, it will take time to get to the bottom and then hours of hiking in so PLAN AND PREPARE based on what you want to experience--there are no disappointments here as long as you do so! HIGHLY recommend--best part of the trip!

My boyfriend and I spent half day in the Park, which was more than enough for us. We paid a $20 entrance fee (except for who has a pass), headed to the visitor center for more information and decided to drive to Holei Sea Arch. We spent around 1 hour to get there from the visitor center. During the drive, we had some stops in order to see some craters and take some pictures.

We started out at the top and watched the lava spouts in the caldera from the Jaggar Museum (need a 300mm lens minimum to get good pics). We then drove down chain of craters road and saw the lava tubes (very cool), the Petroglyphs ( a good walk but not too hard) which were also very cool, and then continued to the west side end of the road. We then drove back to the east side end of the road and rented bikes to ride out to the lava flow into the sea (spectacular). The road is a lot of gravel and not an easy ride but definitely worth the effort. Haggle for a max of $25 per bike and not by the hour. After that we drove back up to Jagger to see the lava spouts in the dark. Again, a real winner. We spent the whole day doing the volcano and did not regret a minute.

My wife and I took a weekend getaway to the Big Island. I'm retired military, so we stayed at Kīlauea Military Camp (KMC) located at Hawaii Volcanoes National Park. Entry to the park is $20 (per vehicle). The fee got us a pass that was good for seven days. However, park rangers are not at the gate after 6 p.m. So, if you're not planning to see any of the sites during the day, one doesn't need to buy a pass.

My husband and I wanted to see active lava hitting ocean and creating new land. The whole creation aspect was very exciting! We were staying on the Kona Airport side of the island so it was a 3 hour drive to the park. $20 to enter park and then a 20 miles drive to the end of the road. Then its a 10 mile roundtrip hike. Mile 1 on pavement. Mile 2-4 on loose gravel but straight. Mile 5 on old lava flow which is uneven and full of ankle breaking opportunities. You will be exhausted (we did it at 6pm to avoid sun and see lava at night). The most disappointing thing is that you don't get that close and when you get to the best place to view the lava hitting the ocean, after your grueling 5 mile hike, you have to trip over bicycles from all the tourists who rented a bike from the other side (outside the park) and biked 2 miles in to see the same thing. They had picnics, shared joints, wore flip flops and enjoyed the zen like moment. The hike back is 10 times worse and you won't walk for 2 days. Spend the 2 hours driving around the park and do the bike ride. Or spend $250 per person and get a boat tour. Or spend twice that and do the helicopter tour. If you want to do the hike because that's your thing and you want the patch - bring food and water because the wind dries you out. Bring hiking poles to help with the balance and save some ankle strain. Bring toilet paper. And take all the park warnings seriously. I highly recommend hiking it at night (with a headlamp) to avoid the majority of people and sun.

It's cold, so ck the hourly wx forecast and bring a couple of water bottles. Personally, I think the crater hike is better than the ridiculously early sunrise trip and bike ride down. Save the $ on the bike ride and spend it on a romantic sunset dinner at the Kula Lodge instead. Mountain location, beautiful gardens, ocean view. Wife had wood fired brick oven pizza. I had the salmon special. One of my BEST meals ever! The herbs on the salmon were excellent, but then the chef set it on a puffed pastry surrounded by a port wine sauce. Outstanding. Our waiter said the chef knows 402 sauces and his beef Wellington sells out very fast.

Someone told me you only need 1 day for the park. I scoffed and came for 3 days. It was too much. Did some hiking which was fun. Really wanted to hike to the ocean entry but 8 miles round trip in the heat was a bit much for my vacation time. A helicopter tour with doors off over the lava vent was awesome! Feeling the heat was a shock and thrill.

Our latest visit to Volcano National Park was highlighted by a visit to the Jagger Museum observation area above the rustlings of the Kilauea volcano at night. The beauty and pot6ential of the raw power of Kilauea was for all there to see. Our visit to the Sea Arch included seeing in the distance the steam clouds from lava entering the Pacific. In their hundredth year anniversary, National Parks are still one of the best uses of our tax dollars.

It is only a short turn off Highway 11, and only $10.00 for a Senior's Lifetime Pass good for all National Parks! And it's only a couple of miles drive and involves only a 200 foot walk to see the steam tunnels and territorial view of the steaming volcano (no red lava observed). Continue to the end of a road about two miles, and enjoy the free exhibits at the observation center. (A souvenir shop, as usual). But, this puts Hawaii in perspective and tells you something about Pele. You can almost imagine being an early Native Hawaiian. Must Do! Recommended.

When we went the lava was very active! They said that this is rare. It was really exciting to watch. It was very cold and I had to buy a sweatshirt in the gift shop. Which cost me $52. So bring a jacket just in case. It was only 62. But I still loved it! You can view a live webcam on the parks sight to see what the lava is doing.

A visit to the national volcanoes park is a must when you are on the big island. This park could take up to the entire day to see. When you enter the park the $20 fee is good for 1 week. There are a number of lava tubes to see, and active steam vents as well as a drive to the most current lava flows. I recommend to bring good hiking shoes and a back pack for food/snacks/water if you intend to do the lava flow hike as it is an 8 mile hike round trip. A definite must see!
A must see when visiting the Big Island. Easy to get around park. Rangers very knowledgeable. Fee covered 3 day admission - AWESOME!

As with all cruise port stops, you have a choice of what to do. Be sure you take a trip to Volcanoes National Park instead of visiting a beach, taking a boat excursion etc. this is a beautiful and amazing landscape you will find nowhere else in the USA. How lucky we were to be there when lava was flowing. While we could only see steam rising from the crater at the visitor center, it is still a remarkable site to see the results of an active volcano. Later that night, we were able to see the lava flow from the starboard side of the ship. Our group spent the entire stop with a private tour guide from Lavaland Hawaii we booked on our own and not through the cruise ship. Vince showed us more of the park and shared so much information and stories, we got so much more out of our visit than if we tried to do it on our own. You could definitely spend more than one day in this park, as we did years ago when staying at the Volcano House. Admittance is $20 per car but we always view it as a worthwhile investment in the national park system.

We have never seen an active volcano, even though we live in the "Ring of Fire." We didn't see a river of lava like my boys had hoped, but it was such an awesome sight. We recommend this to everyone. The best time to come and view the caldron is in the evening as it starts getting dark. Also we had to pay $20 for our car, but that ticket was valid for 7 days so we could come back again.

We came here during the afternoon around 5 pm and I think it was $20 to get in with a car. There was a visitor center down the road which had a map and information of the park. We decided to drive down the craters path. First we went to the lava tube cave (forgot the name) close by. It was damp but the walk was short and you could see just how large these lava tubes were. Next we drove down the road with all the craters. It very unbelievable seeing all those craters, something I've never seen before in my life. Finally we got to the bottom of the road near the ocean, and were able to see lava flowing in a distance. The drive there and back with quick stops was around two hours.

How many times in your life are you ever going to witness firsthand an active volcano. It's safe and fascinating to see nature at her most violent, yet being beautiful at the same time. If you're Active Duty or former active duty or a Disabled Vet, you can get a Lifetime Pass" for free. In our case, my pass got four of us into the park for free and that pass is honored by 2000 national parks.

Very interestint points, the steam holes, craters, lava tubes, petroglyph trails, crater trails, and scenic highlights. Pretty awesome! However be prepared to walk 8 miles (round trip) to see lava flowing into the ocean at the end of Crater Rim road. Easy drive if you have a car! $20 per car to enter park!

Park entrance fee = $20.00 per car (which gives you in /out privileges for the whole week) or a 3- park entrance fee for $25.00 that lets you into this and 2 others parks. (Please see Hawaii Volcanoes National Park website for more info. )

$20 entrance fee for the week, except we were staying in Captain Cook, so I long drive to go back. The Volcano is still active but difficult to view. Most view requires long hikes which was not good for a 2 yr old and a 7 month pregnant sister. We enjoyed more of the drive south of Hilo where the lava just reached the ocean. Didn't realize it was an 8.25 mile hike round trip and got there at sunset...so needless to say we made it halfway due to improper gear and the above reasons again. Not sure if a helicopter or boat ride is worth the money but enjoyed the walk in the dark more than anything.

Went down to Volcanoes National Park and was worth the visit. We did the short tour, so saw Jagger Museum, the steam vents and then hit up Thurston's Lava Tube. Was very cool and for about $20 you can get into the park multiple times. I would recommend going at night to see the lava glow-during the day you just see lots of steam.
The park is beautiful, we loved seeing an active volcano,even from a great distance.Hope the island stays safe but continues to grow! Bring you Park Pass!

I have done this park many times over the years. It is unique and beautiful. Plan to spend the day exploring. My favorite part is Devastation Trail. It is unique and shows the stark difference between lush forest and devastation of the lava flow. The forest area is a great place to see forest birds and orchids, it is a fairly easy walk and the look out of the crater is excellent. It is also a great place to get your National Park pass. It has Hawaiian design and if you are 62 and older you can purchase a life long pass for $10 if you show your ID.

Hawai'i Volcanoes National Park was the one thing that I wanted to check out during my first time visit to the Big Island and is a definite must do! I wanted to see the worlds 2 most active volcanoes; Kīlauea and Mauna Loa. It's not every day you get to see this natural wonder. About a 45 min drive from Hilo and I believe 2+ hours from Kona, the entrance fee is $20 per vehicle and the park is open 24 Hours a day 7 days a week even during holidays!
Absolutely worth the $20 entry fee per car. Absolutely a must see and do in Kona. There are multiple hiking paths that are easy and the views are gorgeous.
Great views, great hikes... an awesome way to spend a day or two exploring volcanos. There's nothing not to like! $20 entry fee good for seven days. Amazing and fun for the whole family.

The National Park is about a one hour drive south of Hilo (might as well add another 30 minutes and visit the Black Sands Beach and turtles, too), and the entrance fee for the two of us was $10 each. You can get a lot in a "short tour" of the area or you can stay in the Park lodging and see everything. We did the suggested short tour (we spent 1.5 hours) and saw the steam vents, the caldera by the museum, the lava tube, and did the approx 1 mile round trip Crater Rim hike. We were in awe of the magnitude of the effect of the volcanoes. We were also able to see red hot lava bubble up from the Kiluea crater (we observed from the museum viewing area. The lava tube was much like walking through a cave, but you come out at the end of it--and walk through a rainforest jungle. You really get a strong sense of the power of nature. We almost didn't include the Park in our plans--and someone told us of their visit and strongly suggested we go. Now we feel as if you can't come to the big island without coming to the Park.

Hawai'i Volcanoes National Park was AMAZING! The best part is that it won't cost you an arm and a leg. It's $20 per vehicle (that's right, they go by cars, not people) and your parking pass is valid for 7 days. We pretty much spent the entire day there. We left to get lunch but came back after dark so that we can see the lava glow.

There is so much to see and do. Remember though this is at elevation and it can be rain,y but usually warm, unless you are there at night for the viewing of the crater and then it can be windy, rainy and cold. If you are a senior be sure to use your senior pass and get one if you don't have one yet. It is then free entrance at any of the national parks. That will save you $20 alone at the mail volcano park.

There are several things to do no matter what your level of physical fitness is. There are plenty of hiking trails for the active, but you can also drive around the park in a car and get out to see things along the road as you see them. If you have a National Park Pass, make sure to bring it, otherwise be prepared for the $15 entry fee (per car). Make sure you stay until after dark!!! Kileaua is beautiful at night. The Jagger Museum is very informative. We went to see the Thurston Lava Tube at 7:45 in the morning, and there was NO ONE there! No other tourists in my pics!!! After going through the tube, we hiked the Kileaua Iki Crater (4 miles). I'm glad we hiked it in the early morning because by the time we were finishing up, the sun was reflecting on all that black lava rock. It was getting toasty.

It costs $15 for a 7 day parking pass. We went to a hula performance about pele. And we went to chain of craters drive. We did all the stops almost and a little hike through volcano to see it. It's absolutely amazing how it's all in one place. The lohi Trees are beautiful. The lava tubes were nice.

This was a great place to go. Just $15 for a car load and you can visit the park for seven days after your initial visit. This you want to do because conditions change with the weather and volcanic activity. The park rangers were very entertaining and passionate. Really liked this place.
Very interesting site. Very educational. Not worth spending hundreds of dollars to go on a bus trip, glad i did it on my own time. 20 dollars per car.

Within the park boundary you can see an active volcano, stay overnight in a hotel overlooking the active Volcano, hike in the rain forest, and explore waterfalls! The FREE talks by the Park Rangers are so informative and educational you will enjoy learning! Even if you are not the hiking kind, you can drive and take short walks to most of the attractions. The best part is it is practically FREE--admission is $15 per car for 7 full days! It beats the heck out of most other family friendly activities!

This is a National Park, and a spectacular one at that! It's a bit pricey to get in, $20 a car. But it's really worth it. It's decent to see during the day, but if you want to see the lava glowing you'll have to go after 6pm.

The park is absolutely beautiful! At the end of May at 8:00 in the morning we were FREEZING. It was misty and super foggy. Bring a poncho and a jacket just in case. We paid $15.00 for a week pass. We drove around at our own pace, and looked at some of the main attractions. Pretty sure it would take a week alone to go over all the areas of the Park, but we weren't dead set to spend an entire day there. We finished our tour in about two hours. All the museums were closed because we were so early. We got to see vents, the main active volcano, and the Thurman Lava Tube. Very interesting and worth the trip. :)

Volcanoes are literally the heart of the Hawaiian Islands. This Park is a must see for anyone visiting the Big Island! Walk through the lava tube, visit the museum for many educational displays. Stop by the steam vents for great photos. Walk on the lava field created from a 1974 flow. We wen on a smallish tour (8 of us). The full day was about $90 and included Rainbow Falls, the Hilo Candy Factory, the Mauna Loa macadamia nut farm, visiting a black sand beach, and finishing the day with a swim in thermal pools. It was a very full day and well wrath the price. Our company was Green Travel and Tours. Dexter was our very kind guide. They offer a smaller group at a lower price than booking through your cruise line if you are on a ship.

The fee to enter the park is about $15 for a 7 day pass (that's the only option, unless you are in a tour bus). If you have a car and like to drive around and explore the island like we do, this will come in handy. You will get to visit on different days at different hours so you will have the opportunity to see the park with different lighting scenarios. We went in on a rainy day and at night. There is very little walking and we found parking easily. The old road that goes all the way around the crater has been closed for some time and that's not highly publicised, so there is a huge are of the park you cannot see at this time. Depending on the time of day it can be very crowded depending on how may busses show up. The crater is pretty far off in the distance so bring binoculars if you have them. Park facilities are very clean and nice. There is one restaurant in the park which fills up fast. There are a couple of gift shops with snack options. It would be wise to bring your own food if you don't like lines. The park is about an hour or so out of Hilo with very little accommodations/ shops along the way. There is a small cute village immediately east of the park with limited lodging and food options best suited for adults.

The views are breathtaking. For those that have never seen a volcano before (that was us) the size and areas are immense. Park is open 24 hours so so back at night after the tour busses (after 7:30 pm ) and see the red glow. WOW continue driving on road and visit some other craters and lava fields Seniors bring your US National Parks Senior Pass
This is a "Must Do" on the Big Island...and $15 for a one week car pass is a deal!

$15 per car to get in. I think this is a great stop for anyone spending time on Hawaii. Just keep in mind that you CAN NOT SEE any lava. You have to do a helicopter tour for this. If you know this going in, you won't be disappointed. There is some great hiking in here, amazing history, and an all around great time for families. Figure absolute min time here is about 90 min. 3-4 hours is much better. A few days would be ideal!

Fascinating visit to see a phenomenon of mother nature. Recommend a full 2 days to see the key sights. $20 for 7 day park car admission but $10 lifetime pass available for any of your party that is age 62 or older. Arriving early to mid morning allows you to see what ranger guides or presentations are scheduled for that day out of the Visitors Center in addition to a status report of volcanic activity (also available online). Several video's play throughout the day in the auditorium. A great map that includes hiking options is available and can select basis difficulty. Recommend the Lava Tube and Iki Crater trail. However, you can stop at many of them and take in a great panoramic view without the hike. The Sulfur springs are really interesting and easily accessible from the Visitors Center. Driving down the road a few miles to the Jagger Observatory gives you the best view of the overall Kilauea Caldera and the smoking Halemaumau crater. You can see the glow at night but recommend arriving well after sunset to escape the massive crowds since parking is limited. Can be cold, windy, and rainy so recommend appropriate jackets and hat. Saw several unprepared visitors only wrapped in beach towels. Also a small but interesting museum there. Lastly, a drive down Chain of Craters road to the ocean is very cool and you will see a lot of lava landscape, Sea Arch, and historic petroglyphs. Restrooms available at the end of the road. The ranger on staff there has a lot of interesting things to say.

It costs 15 dollars per car for entrance fee but that is fine because it helps pay to run the park which is a good thing. And they give you a pass so you can go to the park for 7 days so you can visit more than once.

Rented a Jeep on Hawaii. Had a lovely drive from Captain Cook to the park. Stopped at the black sand beach for awhile, then continued on. Took our time at the park, stopping at each lookout on the map. Everything is much close in reality, as the map makes each stop look far apart. Enjoyed listening to the volunteer ranger at the museum. The busiest stop was the lava tubes. $15 gets you a 7 day pass. What a deal!

This was an outstanding national park and we thoroughly enjoyed our visit. It cost $15 per car to get into the park, but you can show your receipt to get into the park for seven days and we did visit on several different days. To see the most from this park will require multiple days. We got our bearings at the visitors center. There are several suggested must sees depending on how long you have for your visit. The steam vents, sulfur trail, Puu Pauli overlook, and jeagar museum were short easy visits/trails. When we were there the lava was not high enough to see during the day. However we returned in the evening and the crater glowed from the heat. It was so cool. The devastation trail, lava tubes, and keanakakoi crater walk were slightly longer but interesting walks. The Kilauea Iki was the longest walk we took (two hours) but was also very interesting. The crater rim drive is also good to do and has many cool stops along the way.

My husband and I spent 3 days in the park (and evenings at Jagger) and still wish we'd had more time. Both the visitor center near the entrance and at Jagger are well worth some time! We went out to the rim at Jagger all 3 nights to watch the caldera - experienced a small quake and saw lava splash up on one night. Park Rangers and volunteers were very knowledgeable and helpful -- make sure to listen in if they're giving a talk! For a moderate hike, we really enjoyed the Kilauea iki Trail - be sure to do it the direction the park recommends otherwise you'll miss the great views on the way down and the welcome shade on the way up! And be sure to pick up a copy of the trail guide ($1 donation) at the start -- made the hike even more interesting!

As a group of 7 with 5 kids aged 11 to 18, this was a total success! They all found interesting things to see and do in this park, and we wished we had more time. The visitor centers are excellent. We did a short hike (4 miles) on the Kileaua Iki trail, which goes from the rim down to the crater and back up again. It's about 420 feet down and then back up - some of it on stairs, some through forest, and the rest across lava beds. This is a perfect hike for families. Lots to keep everyone interested (steam vents, lava formations). Bring LOTS of water if you are hiking. If you're driving Chain of Craters road, allow at least 2 hours. Kids loved these big craters. If you're visiting the Thurston Lava Tube, go late at night when there are no tour buses (bring headlamps or flash lights for access to the tube). This isn't a long but it's large inside. Stay late to see the glow from the eruption site. We couldn't see any lava flowing (none since 2013) but the glow from the "lake" in the crater is very cool! Best viewing at the Jagger museum. This is a bargain at only $15 admission!

My mother and I visited twice when we came for our visit. It is very accessible for wheel chairs, and those who have difficulty walking. Kilauea is fun to see during the day, but is a must see at night. The Jagger Museum was very interesting and is the best place to see the crater! Don't be discouraged by the crowds, if you wait 10 minutes or so, space will open up! Check for cultural activities! We were fortunate enough to be on the island during their monthly Hula presentation and it was phenomenal! If you're a birder there are many indigenous and non-indigenous birds to see, especially at the military camp. We went searching for Nenes, but no luck. We were told however that they do like to fly over Kilauea around 5pm, so keep those eyes open! Hidden gem alert: Tucked beside the main visitor's center there is the Volcano gallery, with local crafts and fine arts! Prices are very resonable!

We left our hotel in Waikoloa at 8 a.m. and did not get back until 10 p.m. so plan for a very long day to visit VNP. We went via Hilo which will allow you to stop and do Rainbow Falls before we headed to the park. We came home the Kona way and it is a much longer windy drive, much of it 25-35 mph so I would recommend returning the Hilo way too. The only good thing coming the Kona way home was that we drove past a McDonalds and had dinner for $18 – that is a bargain on an island that we had a hard time eating any meal for four for less than $100. Once we entered VNP, we got our national park books stamped at the visitor center. It was raining pretty hard so we went ahead and had lunch at Volcano House – it was decent food and good service and a great way to get out of the rain. We then drove the park including the chain of craters road and did all the stops along the way. By the time we got back from the craters road, the rain had stopped and we were able to do Pu’u Pua’i overlook and we knew right away we had to do the Kilauea Iki Trailhead (see separate review on that). This hike is not to be missed. We did do the Petroglyphs trail too. To take advantage of the entire park and do all the suggested hikes, this really deserves a two day visit.

You really need a few days to truly explore the park and all of its wonders. We did the Kilauea Crater walk, it is about 4-5 miles but somehow we turned it into almost 6. Just amazing, like walking on the surface of another planet. We did the opposite of the way the trail is laid out. The first part of the way the hike is laid out is down a set of stairs cut into the lava and is about 0.6 miles. The end of the hike is up a fairly steep but not to bad 1.4 switchback trail. We found that by going the other way the last part, the steps were not to bad. It really is not an overly strenuous hike but one that is to be enjoyed. Oh, and by the $2.00 book so that you know what all the different spots that are maked with numbers are all about.

Entrance fee was $5 per car and it's good for 7 days. We loved coming here. There was the Jagger Museum, different vantage points to see the crater, and steam vents all over the place. You can eat at the Volcano House. Food is delicious and not too expensive. Hint: there are two sides to the restaurant. One side of more luxurious than the other but the menu is exactly the same, just more expensive. There was lots to see at the park, the drive was smooth, and there were lots of photo opportunities. We came back to the crater around 7:30pm to see the lava, and it was fabulous to see the lava glowing under the stars.
