We went to the park for a whole day and we wish we had spent more time. There were a lot of things we didn't get to. However the things we did do were amazing. The park is open 24 hours a day but some of the museums close earlier. It is $15.00 per vehicle - 7 days $8.00 per individual or bicycle - 7 days $10.00 per motorcycle - 7 days $10.00 per motorcycle - 7 days $25.00 Hawai‘i Tri-park Annual Pass. We saw the Kilauea Iki Trail, the Nahuku - Thurston Lava Tube, the Holei Sea Arch, the Pu'u Loa Petroglyphs, the Jagger Museum, and the Kilauea Volcano. Our favorites were the Kilauea Iki Trail where we could see the smoke coming out of cracks and the Kilauea Volcano where we saw it glowing at night. Definitely come here.

Great place to visit on the island. Make sure you bring your own water they don't have any at the ranger station. They are trails and all different skill levels. We did a 6 mile hike across the ball Cano floor and along the rim. I would recommend walking sticks if you have an unsteady knee. The lava tube is worth the extra uhalf a mile so don't miss out on that! Parking is five dollars but alas for seven days. Most trails are not stroller compatible so keep that in mind if you have small children.

Volcanoes National Park is somewhere you should definitely plan on visiting if you are planning a visit to the Big Island. Entry fee was $15/car. If you wanted to do all the hikes and see everything, you could spend days here. We went expecting to spend about a half a day here, and ended up staying almost all day (left around 4:00 pm). Go early in the morning, as a lot of people & tour buses start showing up after noon.

This is an amazing park - so many great sights and many informative displays! But it was hard to enjoy some of the points of interest when the tour buses would unload - next to impossible to view anything when the crowds flooded in! And forget trying to take a picture with all the photo bombing!! So, try to arrive early so you can relax and really take it all in. Better yet, get off the beaten path and take some of the suggested hikes. BTW, the steam vents are really hot - if you're wearing shorts, Watch out!! It is a national park so if you have the pass it will work here as well :-) Although, $15 is an incredible small price for this park.

It was a 3-1/2 hour drive for us but we drove through the rain forest section of the island. Very affordable thing to do (for Hawaii) as it cost us $15 for a car to enter the National Park. Viewed the volcano by day, drove into the town of Volcano Village for a nice lunch at a little restaurant called O'helo. Drove back to the park (free in / out privileges) to drive down to the ocean side stopping to see Lava Tubes and Sea Arches. Then we made our way back to the Jagger Museum to watch the volcano glow at dusk to evening. We spent a good part of the day there as hiking is also very accessible. Also, I had a head cold, so breathing in the steam at one of the vents along the road was pretty cool and 'relieving'.

I must say this. You have to go see this. They have several different things to go and see. It was 15$ the pass was good for a week you had access the whole time. You just go see this active volcano. Words can not describe how amazing it is. At dusk when you go you can see the lava and the redness of it at the top of the chalet. Do yourself a favour and check it out!!!

If you have a senior in the group, go for the $10 life time membership as you drive in/check in. Look for the Nene as you drive in, they are friendly geese. Start out at the visitor center and take the 20 minute hike/loop. Lots of good info to read along the way. Walk through the lava tub. Stay until dark to see the red glow of the magma. Visit the area that was destroyed in the 50's = fascinating. If you have time to kill between your day time and night time visit, grab dinner ate the Thai Restaurant: 19-4084 Old Volcano Road

We drove over from Kona, arrived early afternoon, and only had a few hours to spend. We watched a movie at the visitor center, saw steam vents, the Jaggar Museum, the Kilauea crater and a second crater, and then did a short hike through the lava tube. We also made a stop at the black sand beach near Na'alehu on the way. Great way to spend a day. We were back by sunset. If you're over 62, do spend $10 on the Senior Pass ( good for any national park in the US).

We visited Dec 16, 2015. My father, who is over 62 years old, bought the $10 Lifetime Senior pass and it was good for all four of us in the vehicle to enter the park. We first went to the Visitor's Center, watched the 20 minute movie and picked up an information sheet on the park that includes maps. Bring a jacket or buy one from the Volcano House gift shop. At the higher elevation, it was too chilly for shorts. Then we had lunch at the Volcano house with a beautiful view of the caldera. Drive around the park on Crater Rim Drive to see different angles. There are many Points of Interest to pull over and stop. You can see smoke and steam from the ground. The only way we saw molten lava was from an airplane. We spent all day and still didn't see it all. I highly recommend seeing the steam vents, Jagger museum and the Thurston Lava tube. About half of Crater Rim Drive was closed due to high amounts of sulfer dioxide gas but we still saw and experienced plenty.

Second visit some 4 years after the first visit. Really like the National Park Service Welcome Center. Has excellent exhibits and explanations about the volcano as well as 2 short films in the theater. They also offer ranger guided tours which are well worth it. While the hot lava can't be seen from the road it is view-able via helicopter which we didn't do. There are a number of steam vents that are active and very visible. Also saw a number of the Ne Ne geese which are endangered. Used our senior national park pass to get 4 of us in. Pass really pays off.

Great family visit with group ranging in age from 9 to 77. There was no lava flowing, but it was still a trip highlight. We spent 4 hours making several stops Chain of Craters Road including a 1.5 mile round trip out to the pu'u loa petroglyphs. The park is laid out in a way that allows you to do a little walking or significant hikes. Great day! Car fee is $15 a day, free annual passes for all national parks for active duty and senior discounts.
Very interesting, frightening and amazing. Steam vents everywhere. Makes you feel very insignificant. This is very much worth the $$$ and the time.

You can see the glow of the lava at night. It can be quite cold during the day because of the elevation. I think it was $10 per car pass fee. Interesting place. We liked the steam holes because the air was warm and moist. We were under dressed so we headed to the west side of the island were its always warm and dry:)

VNP is a wonderful spectacular natural wonder to see up close. The $15 car permit is valid for 7 continuous day so whether you have one or several days to explore it's worthwhile. Trails are well maintained, many paved with ample parking. The impressive caldera, steam vents throughout the shield volcano areas, starkness of past volcano/lava paths offered a reminder of the power and beauty in God's and Mother Nature's creation. Our favorites included Kilauea Iki, Steaming Vents, Sulphur Banks, Crater Rim and Jaggar Museum. The NPS staff were so helpful, enthusiastic and of course knowledgeable. I did not realize rain forests surround the volcano so the black rock covered by green flora of trees, bushes and flowers was an unexpected pleasant picture worthy surprise. The nearby small town of Volcano Village offers great rustic simple cafes for lunch/dinner and nearby lodging like Aloha Junction B + B.

This was a FULL day tour from the west side of Hawaii. We left a bit after 8am (drove our rental car) and didn't arrive home until 10ish. It was an excellent day and we'd do it again. This is a US National Park and if you are a senior over 62, your carload is free. Pick up one of these IDs at any national park but make sure you have your ID with you when you use it. Saved us $15.

This was fascinating to us. We visited twice, first as part of a bus excursion and then later in a rental car. Rental car companies often have advisories about where you may not drive their cars, and we avoided those areas. The Chain of Craters Road is in surprisingly good condition, relatively smooth, and not crowded. There is a park entrance fee of $10 per vehicle, but the pass is good for three days. And if you have the NPS National Visitor's Pass, it will work here.
We went thru the park on our way to Hilo. We will probably go back again as there is lots to see and the ticket you pay for ($15) is good for 5 days.
The park is huge. We really benefited from a private tour with Warren Costa. He was knowledgable and fun to spend the day with. I am sure we would have missed so many things without his guidance

We had a wonderful full day in Volcanoes National Park. We drove from Waikola, leaving just before 9am (leave earlier!). We took the long north road for the views. Stopped at Rainbow Falls in Hilo, nice little stroll to the rocks on top of the falls, huge banyan trees, worth the quick stop. Even better, we had an iced coffee at the Rainbow Falls Café on the way out. The owner is a delightful friendly native Hawaiian, couldn't have been nicer. Her business is new, just a trailer across from the parking lot of the falls. She has iced coffee, great ice cream (coconut!), and is a sweetheart. She only charged me $1.00 for the small iced coffee (I gave her $2!). My husband jokingly asked her what she would do if he didn't have a dollar, and she said "I would give it to you for free!"...and I'm pretty sure she meant it. Hard to find people like that!

We greatly enjoyed several of the hikes; all were easy to use and had beautiful views. We particularly enjoyed the longer hikes through the rainforest parts. This is a unique place to experience and the rangers are most helpful with suggestions and maps. As suggested by the ranger we went back to the park in the late evening to see the active crater after most of the visitors left for the day, the views of the orange-hot crater and glowing steam above are most visible after sunset. Don't miss the steam vents along the road, they're just the thing to warm you to the bone on a cold rainy morning up in the elevations of the park. Admission is free if you have the "America the Beautiful" senior pass, you can buy a pass for $10 at the gate. Unfortunately, we had to leave the park after 2 days for our next stop on our schedule.

I discovered that you will not always be able to see the volcano glow. This all depends on weather and direction of the wind....if the smoke seems to be on the side of the thurston lava tube....make sure you get iver to th e jagar museum quickly because that is when you will be able to see clearly...definitely a breathtaking experience! You may also make the drive up to jagar museum at any time (ex. 2am). Watching the glow was one of the mosy incredible things I have seen.Alot of rain on my visit, make sure to pack a raincoat or purchase one at the visitor gift shop ($4 each). Steam vents throughout the the park were impressive, if driving down chain of craters road definitely stop at the thurston lava tube, beautiful short walk, through a diverse rainforest, to a spectacular lava tube that is well lit inside (artificial lighting). I will write a separate review on food, but just to mention, not the best and very basic.

This place is beautiful. It is amazing to see what can rise from the destruction. For the minimal park entry fee you can travel throughout the forest by foot or car to see some amazing views of the craters, lava fields, foliage, wildlife and the ocean. We hiked through one of the inactive craters, visited the petroglyphs, drove the devastation trail to the ocean and much more. There were many beautiful plants growing from the lave and many different birds to see in to the forest to include the Nene. Of course you cannot go near the active part of the volcano, but at night you can see the glow from the caldera from the lookouts or from the Volcano Hotel. Looking up from the ocean coast you can see where the massive lava flows from past eruptions have left what looks like giant lava rock water falls. If you expect to see flowing lava and eruptions this is not the place. Pay a ridiculous amount for the helicopter ride and hope the volcano is active. This is a place to breath the fresh air, view a different kind of beauty, smell the flowers, and enjoy the peace and quiet.

There are several Tour Co. that will take you to the Park, for a ticket purchase. It is a LOT LESS EXPENSIVE to Do It Yourself. Maps are provided by the Park Service and you can go to the same Volcano Talks given by the Park Ranger Service. There is an entrance fee, but if you have The Golden National Park Pass it is covered.

This park is amazing since you can visit volcanic activity, rainforest, desert, ocean and be on an archipelago all in one visit. I am in awe of this park. The Ranger station is the place to start. Our Ranger took us on a morning walk where she shared her knowledge of the land, birds, and sacred spirit of the island. In addition to taking a Ranger hike, I would recommend purchasing the trail book set. For $7.00 we then took 4 self guided trails over the course of 4 days. We also got up to experience sunrise over the active Caldera. Breathtaking! I would recommend a visit to Volcano National Park.

We left our rental house on Ali'i Drive at 8:30 and made our way. With a quick stop at a rest area along the way, we entered the park at 11:00. The $15 park entrance is so cheap considering what you can experience. We parked in front of the visitor center and went in to look around for a bit. Asked a few questions of the rangers and began our day-long adventure. We walked across the street to Volcano Hotel and stood along the main Kilauea Caldera. We could see volcanic gas raising out of the Halema'uma'u Crater. After taking some pics we went for a 2 mile walk through the Sulfur Banks and Teh Steam Vents. Awesome display of nature. The smell was very strong and the steam was very hot if too close. Many of the vents were within a foot or two from the walking paths. Many others 10-15 feet away, deep and spewing hot steam. After this 45-60 walk and visit to the area we had some lunch in the covered visitor area. Once lunch was done we filled up our water bottles with rainwater at the visitor center and made our way to the Thurston Lava Tube and and the Kilauea Iki Crater hike. The lava tube was fascinating. A 500 year old tube carved out by hot molten lava that cooled and created a tunnel. The hike through and back was about .8 miles. After we started the trek down 400 feet into the Kilauea Iki Crater. This 1.2 mile hike down a switchback trail was easy going down, motly in shade and cool. Once on the bottom, you stand on the solidified lava down 400 feet in the crater. Words cannot describe the feeling of being so small within the volcano. The crater walk is another mile across and then back and up hill. The entire look is 4 miles. Bring water, power bars, a hot, sunblock and your energy. The entire trip can go 2-3 hours. New life is growing on the lava cracks, beautiful flowers and plants. We took some great pics and the started up the trail. A lot more sweat and water consumed on way up but the switch backs come in handy going up. Even for this Ironman, it is a workout. If you are weak on your feet, a tough climb. Once on top of the 400 ft walk up, a quick break in our cars for AC, water and rest. We drove down a quick minute or two to the Pu'u Pua'i Overlook and Devastation Trail. The Overlook is fascinating as you can see down the 400 ft crater to the lava vents and the small little figures trekking across the lava beds. A little to the left is Devastation Trail, a 1 mile round trip walk. This walk showed us the absolute devastation the lava spewing upwards and forming cones of destruction. Many small bark-stripped trees were scattered a,ong the ground. The ground around us and trowards the cones were very unstable and closed to walking. We stayed on the trail and witessed the destruction and the new life forming all around. Beautiful flowers, plants and chnaged scenery within the forest. We decided to end out day and go to dinner and return a little after 7pm for the site that made the whole day. (We ate at Lava Rock Cafe in Volcano a 10 minute drive - awesome food, a must visit). We went back into the park at 7pm and witnessed something only seen in pics. At night, when the sun is gone, even in rain or fog, the Halema'uma'u Crater, that spews volcanic gases during the day glows red at night, all night, due to the lave bubbling hundreds of feet below. Wow and OMG is best I can say. No other words can explain the beauty of earth changing every second. We closed shop at 7:45 and headed back to Kona - another 2 hour drive back. Tired buy satisfied with our adventure. The day is busy and tough but good food, water and spirits make for an amazing adventure. Even the day after, the entire family talks about the best part of the day - the glowing red gas raising up from hundreds of feet below bubbling lava. What an amazing day. Feeling blessed.

If you are visiting the Big Island, this should be on your "to do" list. From the steam vents, to the sulfur rocks, to the amazing views of the crater, it's really breataking. When we went (June 2015), we couldn't see any of the active lava flows. You need to take a helicopter ride to see these (averaging $500 per person).

A trip to this park is a must if you are visiting the Big Island. How many times will you be able to get up close and personal with an active volcano? It is pretty busy with like tourists, but still worth the trip. It is actually best visited at night, when you can see the glow of the lava, you won't see during the day (bring a sweater-it cools down at night). There are a lot of options for hikes if you are interested, so allow time. There is a very long lava tunnel you can walk through, however I personally feel it has been very commercialized, with lights, cement etc... there are many other natural, less crowed lava tunnels you can visit on the island if you want a different experience. It is $15 to drive into the park, but if you go at night it is free as there is no one working the booth.

$15 entry fee per vehicle but you can re -enter! We did the lava tube which was great- not a big hike. You will need to drive to see the volcano, try to go on a clear night to see it glowing, it is great! lots of people but moves fast. Volcano, Hi does not have a lot going on so it is very dark if you are driving away.

If you only have a short time, see the crater from the Jagger Museum after dark. The glow of the lava field is amazing. The museum is informative but closes at 8 pm. The steam vents along the road let you know the energy underground. The walk through the lava tube was interesting. Plenty of hiking. $15 entrance fee per car good for 7 days.
Can't go to the big island without experiencing this. We flew over eruptions and flowing lava. Definitely worth the $$ to charter a plane. It's what Hawaii is all about...

When you visit the Big Island of Hawaii, be sure to visit the Hawaii Volcanoes National Park. Entry into the park is only $15 per car. A recommended first stop once you enter the park is the Kilauea Visitor Center, located across the Volcano House. At the Visitor Center you are able to get brochures, and a chance to talke one of the rangers there who can answer any question you have and recommend what you should see. They can tell you what the latest information is regarding the latest lava flow(s). Take some time to view a film on the Volcanoes National Park. At this time, however lava is currently not visible in the Halemaumau Crater Unfortunately, the part of the Chain of Craters Road nearest the active flow is closed so for a close view of the Halemaumau Crater, go to the Jaggar Museum where you can see plumes of smoke rising from the bottom of the crater. Take some time to visit the Jaggar Museum and look at the seismographs that are used to measure earthquakes on the Big Island of Hawaii and view the displays. Other major attractions along Crater Rim Drive and the Chain of Craters Road include the Kilauea Iki cinder cone and crater, the Thurston Lava Tube, and the Mauna Ulu eruption site. Along the Chain of Craters Road, there are many large and small craters where over the years numerous eruptions have occurred. Other attractions include the Steam Vents, and Sulphur Banks. Caution is advised for people with health issues in these areas. Do not enter the steam vents!

I guess it's worth seeing it , $15 to park ( good for 7 days ) plan your day visitor center has map what to do depends how many hrs planning to visit , some drizzle and light wind so bring light windbreaker , be aware some areas has strong sulphur smell , visit lava tube ( short hike ) too

Was hoping to see the volcano's lava flow, but access was closed because the fumes are dangerous. From the rim of the cauldron we could see the smoke rising about 2 miles away. You are permitted to walk in the cauldron at a distance from the lava. The ranger led walk on the rim is a must to appreciate the volcano and to learn about the vegetation along the rim. We have the Lifetime National Park Pass for seniors, so there was no fee. It costs $10 once and allows the senior and anyone in the car to enter all national parks free.

I really don't know where to start, this place is amazing. I guess what I would encourage the most is to get out an hike! There are a gazillion miles of hiking in the park and all are amazing. We parked near the Visitor's Bureau and walked through the forest, along the rim of a cauldron, and through the lava tube. Nice hike of a couple miles, each way. You can also walk along the crater floor with active steam vents! Park entry was only $5 as of June 2015, very reasonable for what you're getting.

Honestly, I thought we would just be looking at dried magma and nothingness. The rainforests, hiking trails and beautiful views were worth a day trip off the cruise ship. After renting a car for $50 at Hilo Airport, we paid $15 for our carload to get into the park. This was a much better value than the motor coach excursion through the cruise line for $300/four people.

My adult daughter and I visited this park late afternoon through nitefall and enjoyed it very much. $15 gets a pass for a vehicle to enter for a week. There are a few places to view the mountains, lava fields and the smouldering volcano. The gift shop and little display area is very nice with some local story tellers to boot.

Definitely not worth the drive. I'm from Hawaii but my gf wanted to see the Volcano. We drove almost 2 hours for a 30 min tour of the entire area. The price raised from $5 to $15. Save your money on this one.

It was somewhat crowed on the day we visited as the cruise ships were in port. The volcano was smoking but not flowing on this particular day. There had been lava flow earlier in the week. We read the information in the museum at the top and observed the craters. We stopped at different points to see other sights: lava field, lava chute, vegetation, etc. We used our National Park Pass and it was a free event for us.
Imagine seeing lava bubble to the surface in front of your eyes. The lava and steam created by the raiin was a real treat. There is a park entry fee but free for seniors with a Senior Parks Pass.
Perhaps the best way may be to spend the $300 plus dollars per person for a 40 minute tour over the area but driving is a viable option if you have a whole day to drive there from the Kona Coast.

I visited the park twice while on vacation, once with relatives I flew out with, and again later when my own family joined up with me. Both times the experience was beyond words!! Everyone we met in the park, staff as well as other visitors, was friendly! The entire experience was awe-inspiring! Even getting drenched in rain was not a deterent to our amazement at what we were viewing. We downloaded the GyPSy app for the volcano tour ($4.99), which gave us some information we would not have gotten anywhere else, and the narration kept us entertained, especially on the way back to Kona. The 2nd time I went to the park, our receipt blew out of our car when we opened the door to view the scenery, and my daughter could not catch it in time. We went out of the park for dinner, but wanted to go back in to catch a sunset. My daughter had bought something at the visitor center right before we left the park to eat, so we thought we'd show that to the person guarding the gate, and if we weren't let back in, oh well, our loss. Not only was the guard super friendly, she asked if we planned to come back another day (we weren't), as she'd do something else for us! The view of the rim as the sun went down turned out to be the highlight of our day!! So a big MAHALO to the entrance park rangers and everyone else working here!!!! Make sure you visit the volcano national park!!!!

So much to see and do. See steam vents, walk thru a lava tube, hike, smell sulfur fumes, drive, see petroglyphs, camp, learn something...on and on. There is an art gallery with local artists and all kinds of art for sale. The visitor center tells you things about volcanos, excellent gift store. Then there is the Jagger Museum with lots of knowledgeable park rangers giving talks and explaining what has been happening. This is an active volcano and the park is open 24/7...as the ranger said, "This is the 7 Eleven of National Parks. You get more than you paid for - price of admission is less than $20 for a car load!

I never thought I would like the Big Island or the volcanoes, hence, we waited until we had visited all of the other islands to visit this one. Since our first visit we have now been back many times and find it even more beautiful and fascinating with each new trip. The park is so interesting, starting with the visitor center. We also enjoy the art museum next to the visitor center within a short walking distance and will go browse through that building after the visitor center. If you are there for the day, take a stop at the Volcano House Restaurant and put your name in for a dinner there at sunset before you start your exploring for the day. Not only was the food delicious, the view of the crater at night from the window in the restaurant is fabulous. Ask to sit by the window if possible, but honestly even seated mid way in the room allowed us a very good view of the glowing red crater from a distance. Make time to relax and sit in the main room in the rocking chairs by the fire before your dinner. It is wonderful and warm by the fire in the lobby and we enjoyed doing that as well. It can be cold in the park, so bring long pants and a jacket in case you need them. Our first visit I had to buy a sweat jacket from the visitors center. Also, you'll want to make sure to go to the observatory right before it closes to read more about the history and to see a fabulous outside view of the crater. We've taken many of the trails in the park - usually one or two each trip, and they are all interesting in their own way. I'd also suggest packing a picnic so that you can sit in one of the areas in the park and enjoy the outdoors. We usually do the park in one day, starting early from Waikoloa, and getting back fairly late, but one day I'd love to stay at the Volcano House for the night -- if only it wasn't so expensive. When I checked it was upwards of $400. Definitely worth checking out if you are able to swing it for the night. If not, it can be done in one long day. Make the time to visit this park -- you'll be glad you did!

Our visit to the Kilauea Volcano at Hawaii's Volcano National Park was one of the most impressive stops we've ever made while traveling. The park is located about 30 miles southwest of Hilo. Since it is a National Park we were able to make use of my National Park Senior Pass which allowed our party of four to enter with no charge. That pass is

We enjoyed the Park. We got there early around 8 and there were little tourist. We didn't see any active Lava flow but seeing the devastation of past flows was really something. The visitor's center has some good info and a 3d map so make a stop there. It was $10 per vehicle to enter the park.

You don't have to be an avid hiker to enjoy this park. (You do need some mobility, however.) It is a must do if you are traveling to Hawaii. The Chain of Craters Road is fantastic, as are the steam vents and the Thurston Lava Tube. (Are there better lava tubes, yes, but this is the one to go to if you are in moderate - not excellent - health or have small children.) I recommend two days so that you can stay at night for the night view of the lava glow from Jaggar Museum. We thoroughly enjoyed our visit. For $10 for a week pass for the car, it is definitely worth it.

We got off of our cruise ship and rented a car. First went by the famous black sand beach, then back tracked slightly to get to the main objective, the national park. We drove in and to the right (only $10 per car) and stopped at a couple of steam vents. It is possible to hike in further at these points. We then drove to the end of this road to the Jagger museum and spent quality time (see my separate review). Then back tracked past park entrance to the lava tube site. There we encountered a very enthusiastic volunteer (Charlene) who was giving an introductory talk and then leading a 3 hour hike down in to the depressed area. She showed photos of the history of recent eruptions and explained how slowly the lava flows are here. There are several guided hikes, and even campsites and a volcano hotel. The area is a very interesting area of contrasts- both lush rain forests and very desolate dry moonscape terrain with steam vents, and cliffs galore. We may make future plans to return to Hawaii for this hiking in fact!

We came here to see the volcano and were not disappointed! Spectacular sunrise and sunset views and great hikes on hardened lava scross a crater. a nice drive thru old lava flows down to a sea arch was also fascinating. Rangers were infomatove and helpful. $10 pass gets you 7 days unlimited use. A real great adventure!

Driving from Holualoa to the Park was a long drive, but well worth it to visit the National Park. The entrance is $15 and good for seven days. The roads are in good condition and the signage is easy to follow. I did a driving tour along the Chain of Craters Road and all the way down to Jaggar Museum. Seeing steam vents, pahoehoe and a'a lava, hiking part of the Kilauea Iki Trail, walking the Lava Tube walk, driving through the old lava flows, seeing the Holei Arch, then a finale of the Halemaumau Crater was done within the day (at a moderate pace). Bring water and snacks as you tour! Great trip and a definite highlight of my short Island of Hawaii stay.

Great view of the volcano crater. It's still spewing lava.... You can also check out the lava tube in the park. But what I really appreciated was the entrance fee was $10 for the 1 vehicle and have access for the whole week which is awesome because there is a lot to see. You can also walk on a trail inside the actual crater of the volcano .do bring warm attire and proper shoe wear. NO SANDLES!!!

This is really cool park. There Are many fairly easy hikes to do and you will see all kinds of great volcano related things. Don't miss the lava tube or the Jagger museum. You don't need a tour guide , as there is ample info posted everywhere. Give yourself several hours to see it all. Be prepared for both warm and chilly conditions. Take snacks and drinks with you . $10 parking fee is good for a week.

Driving 2 hrs to Hilo from Kona has never been boring to me. Coming from Oahu , I'd say Big Island is huge! Scenic drive on the way comprises of lava rocks , plains and hills but while going up in elevation . The park itself is family friendly. $15 to a car to get in. Small hikes to see the crater. The lava tube is ok. The museum is worth it.

This has been and will continue to be a must stop on a trip to the Big Island. The hike around across and then back up the other side is a mild challenge but well worth the effort. It is a unique experience you wont forget. Take along water and a light jacket in case of rain. There is a $5 charge for the car load. One of the best values on the island. Worth the 2 hour drive from the Kohala coast.

It was raining lighting and 55 degrees on March 4, 2015 when we visited and we didn't have jackets or hoodies with us so we didn't linger! It was amazing to see at night but we just wished we had thrown a jacket in the car that morning when we started out. LESSON LEARNED! Admission is free if you have a Senior National Park Pass......

You need a minimum of six hours here to see everything! Only $10 per car entry fee . We started with the movie at the visitor center which was quite good and the gift shop was fabulous too. Then the steam vents, then to the Jaggar museum for a daytime view of the Kilauea Crater which was smoking; enjoyed a great ranger talk by the fabulously entertaining Dino! What a charming man :-). Then the rest of the day was spent going down chain of craters road - extremely windy at this time of year. Go straight to the end to the sea arch which is a spectacular 60 foot arch of lava that has been eroded by the waves! Toilets are available. Then slowly make your way back up chain of craters road - be sure to stop at the petroglyphs albeit a tough and very rocky 1.5 mile round trip walk. Don't miss the cinder cones, crater, various scenic lookouts, devastation trail, and especially the super cool Thurston lava tube (toilets there too). As the sun sets head back to the Jaggar museum to see the night glow of the lava in Kilauea - mind blowing and currently the only visible active lava in the park! What a day!!!!!

Great place to explore. Starting at the visitor's center with films, displays and park information, it only gets better. Sadly the weather wasn't the best when we went. It was raining much of the time and fog prevented us from seeing several interesting things. Walking through the lava tunnel was great. And driving to the shore line was unbelievable. There was lava as far as the eye could see. The longer we drove, the better it got. Be sure and get to the coastline with plenty of time before sunset. it is worth exploring. The fee per car to get in is only $10 and good for a week.

This is one of the most unique National Parks in the United States. It offers a first hand view of active and older volcanic activity. It represents an incredible learning opportunity and well worth the $10 per carload entrance fee. We really like the Volcano House for dining as well as you can view the caldera from the dining room.

This is an amazing place! From the steam vents to the overlook at the museum to the drive down chain of craters road to the arches! Stop at as many of the overlooks on chain of craters road as your time permits. Each one is different: different thicknesses of lava, different shades of gray depending on the age of the flow. The arches themselves are a testament to the power of nature. If you go during whale watching season, you may get an extra treat as you gaze out to sea by the arches. Tip to anyone over age 62: buy a national parks senior pass to get free or reduced admission to all of our national parks including volcanoes. Only $10 if bought at a park. What a bargain!

My daughter and I recently took a Circle Island Tour of the Big Island of Hawaii, through Roberts Tours (wonderful driver, Sun), with a short stop at Volcanoes National Park. The park ranger gave a very informative talk, and we learned that the wooden walkway we traversed nearly 40 years ago was no more--destroyed by an eruption. At the time of our first visit, Kilauea was inactive; since then it erupts regularly, though lava flows are slow-moving, with plenty of time for evacuations if necessary. That day, we saw just steam (no vog--combination of fog and volcanic ash lessen or prevent visibility) coming out of the volcano and had a clear view of the desolate landscape for miles around. I had not remembered how extensive the Park is (admission is $5 per car). Took us quite a while to reach the Visitors Center, which provides a great overview of volcanic activity. This particular volcano is currently the only active volcano in the Hawaiian Islands and has created new land over the years, continuing to make the Big Island the largest of the Hawaiian chain. One can stay the night for a glimpse of flowing lava when Kilauea is spouting, though we were just passing through. Wish we'd had more time...

So much to see there. And there is active visual lava in the caldera. The visitors center is nice and the road signage is well done. $20 per carload that is good for the week. This is one place you always go back to.

What can I say, it was pretty awesome to walk into lava tubes and see craters that could swallow a city all with the beauty of the Hawaiian vegetation! Only reason for 4 and not 5 stars this is a well funded state park. $10 per car that comes in and out plus all the tour busses, they do well...Clean your bathrooms! After hiking in the sun and being in and out of the car when you are hot and sweaty a clean bathroom would go a very long way! Other than that awesomely beautiful!

We had an afternoon and decided to take a drive up to see the volcanoes, especially since we heard that they have been active. It cost $10 to enter the park and once there we toured the park service building. We then drove in a ways and were able to see the crater with the steam coming from it as well as all of the steam vents in the area. The road around it is now closed due to the activity of the volcano, so we had to head back towards the visitor's center. We stopped and toured the lava tubes, which was amazing. Made you feel like you were in an Indiana Jones movie. Next time in Kona we do plan to head back to the park to do some more touring as we only saw a part of it and there appears to be quite a bit more to see and do. It was recommended by many others to go there after dark as you can see the lava flows.

This is one location you must visit twice. Day and night views are so different. During the day you see steam and smoke from the volcano and at night the steam is glowing red from the hot lava below. Lots of trails if you want to hike or lots to see, if you have limited mobility. There are steam vents you can drive right up to and actually hear the water below boiling. $10 admission for a car is good for 7 days. Thurston lava tub is also a must.

We drove into the park in the afternoon and stopped at the visitors center, the steam vents and Jagger Museum. We had an amazing afternoon view of the very active volcano and left the park for additional sight seeing and dinner. When you pay the $10 entrance fee, you can come and go as you please with no additional fee. We came back once it got dark to view the volcano again at night. The view was incredible and well worth the additional visit. Plan to bring warm clothes as it gets cold at night. It does take some time to get here from Kailua-Kona or Hilo, so plan accordingly.

I can honestly say, this probably the best ten dollars I've ever spent. The park has so much to offer: from driving the insanely scenic Chain of Crater road to the lava field where the road ends, to hiking the Kilauea Iki Crater trail, to the informative Jagger Museum, to the steam vents & lava tubes, to stargazing and ethereal glow of the Halema'uma'u crater after dark.

Fun and educational trip through the park. Many hiking trails or easy to drive to viewpoints if your group can't walk as far. The park is nicely maintained. The large crater, up close steam vents and lava tube are great to see. Mobility impaired folks may have trouble getting into the thurston lava tube. $10 per carload to enter the park.

Fascinating place if you are interested in volcanoes. Unlike Arenal volcano in Costa Rica, which blows out boulders the size of a city bus, you may get closer to Kilauea, which flows lava out, projecting the land mass into the ocean. In this park you can see steam vents, caldera, hiking trails, etc. About 1.5 hours drive from Kona, or 1 hour from Hilo. Bring water, snacks, hiking shoes, and camera.

See the world's most active volcano, but from a safe distance. The $10/car entry is a bargain, and even more so if you're a senior with a pass to get your group in free. The steam vents are readily visible from the Jagger Museum's outdoor lookout, the Volcano Inn dining room, or even on the road. Go back to the Jagger when it gets dark to view the red glow not visible during the day. We had a moderate and very fun hike down to the stark 1959 lava bed, and enjoyed an easy little hike to the Thurston lava tube. The lava tube is not nearly as impressive as Ape Cave in Washington, but it's lit up and a just short walk down. Dining options are very limited, but the Volcano Inn across from the visitors' center offers decent (but a little salty) meals for day visitors. The entire area had alerts for poor air quality, so asthma people may need their inhalers. Also, the weather forecasts let you know about the vog (volcanic fog/smog) readings daily. Still, it's a very worthwhile trip when in Hawaii.

For me, visiting the Volcanoes National Park was a must. We particularly enjoyed the 25 minute video at the visitor center which takes you through the formation of the Hawaiian Islands. The volunteer guides in general were very good, and the Jagger Museum is worthwhile. You won't see any active lava flows, unless you do a helicopter tour, which runs about $1,000 for two and can't guarantee you will see a spotable flow, so we passed on it. After that, the lava tube was good, longest I have been through, and there are so 'okay" photo opts if you take the long ride down to the sea. A lot of this latter looks basically the same, but the scale gives you a real sense of how long this has been going on, and how big. So generally interesting, but a very long ride if you are staying on the Kona side, and nothing that blows you away.

This is a must stop if you go to this island. Yes it is a drive but there is places to visit the whole drive there anyways. You can make a quick trip or all day out of it. The view from behind the lodge is spectacular. We also drove to the top and looked out and it was great. The kids loved the lava tube the most, being able to walk right through it was great but it is a hike and has elevation change and while not strenuous for most, those who have a hard time walking may not make it. The view to the tube through the trees is amazing. For the $10 to the park it is worth it.

We visited on 2 separate days and loved it each time!! The trails were wonderful! There is a Volkswalk offered in the park so we took the 6 mile walk. Great visitor center, very informative. Walked the Crater trail with numerous steam vents. Stayed after dark one night to see the steam light up over the crater! There is a $10 fee to enter park. It is good for 7 days so keep your receipt in case you want to re-enter.

If you are on the Big Island, a stop at Hawaii Volcanoes National Park is a must see. There are plenty of hiking options from easy to difficult. The main site is the crater which is easy to get to for anyone. There are many steam vents. I would suggest doing some hiking even if it is just along the crater as the views change. Should wear at least sneakers, no flip/flops. Bring water and a rain coat if you venture more than 5 minutes from your car. There is a $10 fee to enter the park.

This is one of the things in life you have to see to believe. There is literally miles and miles of Lava right down to the sea. You can hike, drive and send time. $10.00 gets you a pass that is good for a week.

Wife and I spent several days in the park. For the lack of funds that Congress gives them, we have to say that the park service does an excellent job with what they do get. $10 for a week was really cheap to get in compared to the Grand Canyon and well worth it, even if they increased it. The rangers were very friendly and gave great guidance. They had volunteers who did some cool presentations, and worked with other agencies to put on informative talks at night. The trails were very well maintained and fun to hike, and the views were great of the craters. If you're looking for the big flows of years past you might be disappointed, but that's not the fault of the park service. That depends on Pele and if she feels like showing the might of the volcano. You will see a lot and we highly recommend the hikes.

This is one of the most impressive national parks I have been to. If you like volcanoes or geology, this place is a must. You can see lava oceans from far and near and take great hikes. For just a $10 fee you can visit the park for a week. If you go through the Kilauea-iki trail you also pay $2 a person. It is well worth the money to go through the belly of this crater, which still is steaming in certain areas. The chain of craters and the lava tube also were impressive and educational.

Volcanoes National Park was our primary reason for choosing the Big Island. We had seen it almost 20 years ago, but when taking kids for the first time, we thought it would be great to allow them to see such a unique island. The park did not disappoint. The ranger guided activities were excellent as always, but it's the scenery that makes this so great. It's just a unique and wondrous place. Beauty everywhere. Definitely drive down chain of craters road. One of our favorite activities was to just stop at a random stop and walk along and hang out on the pillow lava rock. Just a great experience. There was no lava flowing when we were there that we could see, but we did return to Jagger museum at dusk where we could see the glow of the lava against the steam of the lava pool- a great way to end the evening. We also had to bypass the lava tubes on our way down to chain of craters because both parking areas were so busy. We caught it on our way up just before dusk and that proved to be a perfect time to stop. Don't forget the park is much cooler than the coast, so bring a jacket or two just in case- we were glad we had. All this for $10 per carload- what a great day!

There is so much to see here, you'll want at least one overnight and two days. It's $10/car to get in the park, but that lasts for a week of in and out. (See website for other fee options. Some holidays are free for a day.)

What a great way to spend four hours. From Hilo it took us a little over an hour to get to the park. $20 entry for the car and we went to the visitor center. Didn't need to spend much time there but get a map and see the suggested stops depending on the time you have. We went to Jagger Park, and had a great view of the erupting volcano. We then walked the Kilauea Iki Crater. This is a four mile walk, down 400 feet, then across the Iki crater and then back up the 400 feet. With steam vents on the crater floor and the lava frozen in time, it was an adventure that if you can you must do. Finally we walked the lava tube, it is a short and easy walk. Very interesting and worth the effort. This was the highlight of our trip.

The kind of park that reminds us of how wonderful the national park system can be. As a senior, I discovered that I can get a $ 10 pass for all national parks for me and my companions. The free ranger walks, talks, and their ready availability to answer questions--was remarkable and informative. Kilauea is in the process of changing dramatically the last few years, and getting some sense of those changes, and what they mean about the power of nature and the smallness of men, and the human spirit--of those who partied before the oncoming lava to their town, and prepared to move if they had to, to the rangers filled with a lifetime's passion for the geology of the volcano to the artists who respond in paint and stone and wood---all of this is worth being a part of. We enjoyed the lava tube hike, going to see "the glow" at night, seeing the steam vents and walking to the edge of craters. I wish we'd had the time (and that I had the energy) to take the hike into the crater, but we didn't.

This park should not be missed on a visit to the big island. The $10/car fee is well worth it. There are many amazing hikes for all time-frames and abilities. Many of the big sites are just off the road and can easily be reached by nearly everyone. For the more adventurous, there are many longer hikes, ranging from a couple hours to all day, that will take you deeper into the park. A full day is recommended to really be able to see the park. Be sure to drive Crater Rim Drive as well as Chain of Craters road. These both have many sites near the road and allow you to see much of the park. There are very few options (only Volcano House near the entrance/visitor's center) for food inside the park so either plan on packing a lunch or driving into the nearby town of Volcano.

It cost 10 dollars per car to enter the park. It is so worth the visit. Is about 3 hour drive from Waikoloa but so worth the drive. make sure to go to the ocean, Its a wonderful trip and inexpensive of you go on your own!. Make sure to stop and eat right before you go into the park. There are several really good diners and very inexpensive. Best food we had and 1/10 of prices at the resorts, allow at least 6 hours to really see and enjoy it all. If your a hiker plan to stay an entire day at least 12 hours.

We were in Kona and decided to drive around the island on day and stopped off at Volcano National Park. We didn't have a lot of time, but watched the video in the visitor's center and the took a walk down to the "steam vents" really incredible to watch, walked out to look at thr caldera And before we left, we stopped at the lava tube. Only spent about 2 and a half hours and it was well worth it. Can't wait to go back when we have more time. Only $5.00 per person. Ample parking at each site.

If you want to see nature continue to grow but also how much damage can happen then you won't want to miss this National Park! I never knew that there was so many types of "lava" that are formed just on this Island! The Park Rangers are very informative and "Dean" our Ranger was so fun! My husband and I just drove all over the area but chose not to go see the active lava since this area was where people were moving and losing their homes! The best way to see the the active lava is in a helicopter but the cost is about $200 per person!

This is a must stop place if you are visiting the Big Island of Hawaii. There is so much to see. Their is a $10 entrance fee, but that gets you access to the park for an entire week. The scenery is beautiful and there are all sorts of trails that one can hike. We hiked into an actual crater. We also drove down to the end of the park and hiked out to what used to be a road but is now covered in lava rock. Truly is beautiful and amazing. We only had about 1 day here and should have planned for more time. We didn't realize their would be so much to do that we had to sort of limit it to only a few highlights. Be sure to go back at night and see the crater as the effect at night is amazing. If you love to hike, there are plenty of trails to explore. Even if you don't; you won't be lacking for scenery just driving around.

The main reason we came to the Big Island was to go to the Volcano National Park. It was about a two hour drive for us from Kailau-Kona. Having four couples we rented two cars to drive there. Cheaper than renting one big vehicle. The first stop was at the Kilauea Visitor Center. The park ranger explained different option we could do. It was very helpful. One thing I would not do is watch the film in the visiting center. Very old and can put you to sleep quickly. Everything else was very impressive! We first did the spots along the Crater Rim Drive. Great views of the crater from different locations. Plenty displays with a lot of history. Afterwards we drove down the Chain of Craters Road to the ocean. Many spots to pullover and take pictures and walk on the lava formations. When you arrive at the ocean the road will end where the lava flowed over the road back in 2003. You can park and walk a mile to the spot and walk on the lava. If you walk further on the lava you can see the road Closed Road sign with lava all around it. Also, after parking your vehicle and

My husband and I visited Volcanoes National Park as part of our excursion around the Big Island. We actually visited two days in a row as the first day we went after going to Mahana Beach and didn't feel like we had enough time to see everything in the park we wanted to see. The entrance fee for a car is $10, but it's good for a week I think - maybe 10 days? So on our second day we didn't have to pay anything extra, just show our receipt.

Third time in the park, only time it did not rain. The first time was great (many years ago), we get to drive to the end of Chain of Craters road and was able to hike up very close to the lava flow and acutally saw steam from the ocean, rangers were every where to keep people away from the "danger zone". Second time (10 years ago), the road got a lot shorter and we were not able to see much activity, but we were able to see the lava flow via a telescope. This time, there were no rangers around to keep people away, we walk about half a mile and turn back, no new lava or what so ever, it was kind of disappointing. We went to the Jagger museum and saw a couple of huge steam craters, we were told by the information center that the glow is really nice at night, but we did not stay. The lava tube was interesting. BTW, Make sue to make many stops at the Chain of Craters Road, every stop presents a different view of the park. Check in with the informtion center, they are very helpful and will provide maps for the park. Food is limited inside the park and no gas. Like hiking, many trails available but dress warm and dry. There is a $10 entrance fee to the park.

We had a wonderful day in the Volcanoes National Park with Warren Costa from Native Guide Hawaii. Warren has an extensive knowledge of animals and vegetation in the park, the volcanoes and lava flows on the island and the history of Hawaii. We walked on trails that were amazing and off the beaten path -through different types of rain forest ( depending on altitude) over lava floes, through a lava tube, and down to the ocean to see a sea arch. He provided a delicious light lunch and great cookies when he dropped us at our hotel. Perfect day, Awesome experience. Thanks Warren.
Everything about this park is excellent. If you decide to hike some of the trails, be sure to stop at the visitor center and get the guide books -- only $2 each.

Hawai'i Volcanoes National Park is on the Hilo side of the Big Island, and is a two hour drive from the Kona side (western, and sunny side of the Big Island). Its obviously a much closer drive from Hilo. BTW, only $10/car entrance fee.

Amazing opportunity to witness an active volcano. Great educational trip for kids, to further understand how the islands were created. Must stops are the welcome center for maps, the lava tubes, and the lodge restaurant located across from the welcome center, which has fabulous volcano viewing. The gift shops are highly recommended, monies go to the National Park, who could use every dollar, and some great historical art prints and books available for purchase.

This makes for a great half or full day trip depending on your pace. It's a $10 entry fee for vehicles and $5 for walk-ins and motorcycles. I got there at around 8 and didn't leave until 12:30 PM. you should start at the Visitor's Center to get an update on the weather and grab yourself a more portable map. From there you can do a 0.3 mile hike to the Sulphur Banks, jump back in the your car and just drive counter-clockwise to the various hiking trails, craters, and view points shown on the map. The hike through the crater was very easy. It's a 4 mile loop, and only took about 1.5 hours (2-3 hours for a more normal pace). There's a long drive called the Chain of Craters you should definitely do that stops by each of the craters along the road. This takes about 1.5 - 3 hours depending on your pace and how frequently you stop. The last thing you could do is the Devastation Trail, which is only about 1 mile. Overall, definitely a must-see if you're on the east side of the island.

If you come prepared with rainjackets and decent walking shoes (sneakers are fine, flip flops not so good), you'll have a great day, or more than one! Only a $10 entrance fee! The guides at the visitor center helped us to plan our day, based on our time and what we liked and marked it all out on a map for us. We made an under one hour hike from the center to see the steam and sulfur markings - it was eerie and gorgeous! We filled out water bottles with the rainwater fountain at the visitor's center, then drove to the lava tube parking area and hiked to it - beautiful, easy trek through the rain forest and the tube, which is amazing to think about. The highlight was our trip from the lava tube parking lot down to and through the crater - again, amazing rain forest scenery the whole way. The path is an easy enough one and not dangerous, with some awesome views. The crater is out of this world - just can't be described - and there was a rainbow there! That was about 2 or so hrs of hiking down, exploring the miles of the crater, and hiking back up. We then drove the chain of craters road to the sea and wanted to visit the petroglyphs and see the dried lava on the road, but ran out of time. We did get to see the sunset at the stone ocean arch near the parking area. Then we headed back up to the visitor center and ate at the Volcano hotel, which had excellent, reasonably price food, though portions were humble. We headed over to the Jagger museum to see the lava at night and it wasn't a great view but none-the-less a once in a lifetime experience. Wish we could have gone again to see the museum by day and take more hikes etc., but that would have meant 4 more hours of driving and other sites beckoned. Don't miss this!

So much to see and do. $10 for the week to get in. We went to the visitors center, they have restrooms and rangers and info and a small gift store. A short 3/10 of a mile walk from the parking lot is the steam vents, then walk through there to across the street, about 7 10th of a mile to steam vents and walk back to the Volcano House, which is a restaurant, gift shop and overlook where you see the cauldron, really cool. We bought snacks in the store. Drove to Jagger Museum 1.3 miles up the road for a great photo op. Then took crater rim drive, to the Thurstson Lava Tubes, walk through a lava tube, so cool and then stopped along the way to see craters all over the place. We never did drive down to the ocean, we ran out of time and daylight. Great place and a must see. Last Eruption was 1983, its due to blow!

Presumably you can to the Big Island to see volcanoes and this is the place to do it. It costs $10 a car (good for a week) to get in, although after dark there was no one there to check. Stop by the Visitor's Center and get a map. There are plenty of trails to choose from. When we went part of the Crater Rim Drive and Crater Rim Trail were closed. Conditions change constantly so check the website to see where the lava is flowing and if any roads or trails opened or closed. The Visitor's Center had various films going on throughout the day. We came shortly before a special showing of the 1959 eruption at Kilauea Iki Crater. Very informative especially considering we were hiking it next.

It is a wonderful experience to be on a volcano that is active. Must be the safest volcano in the world. There is a lot to do. Could easily spend a full day here. There is a $10.00 fee per car. It takes about 2.5 to 3 hours to drive from Kailua-Kona, if you are coming from that side of the island as we were. There is some road construction going on this summer (2014), so be prepared to stop for one lane roads along the way. Just relax and enjoy the scenery. Also, be prepared for tour buses unloading a lot of people at the various stops throughout the park. If on a short visit, the Thomas A Jaggar Museum is worth the stop with lots of park and volcano information, as well as a seismograph of earthquakes and some lava samples you can touch. Best view in the park of the crater with steam coming out is from the outdoor observatory here. Anther must is a walk thru the Thurston Lava Tube. It is very large, so no fear if you are claustrophobic. There are some stairs and rough walking inside but it is lit. There are also pools of water in the floor and dripping water if it is raining or has been recently, so watch your step, but it's not dangerous if you're paying attention. We read that the best lava night viewing is from an area in the Puna district, but we did not do that this time.

I'll start this review by commenting on something my wife mentioned at the visitor's center. "this is a great use of our tax dollars." Excellent park with great rangers and volunteers. Probably a two day visit if you like the outdoors and hiking. Great history of the islands and the park. Lots of hiking, a huge number of trails. Only issue would be the time to reach the park if you are sleeping on the west side of the island. It is a beautiful drive, just longer than you want it to be.

We intended to spend two days in the park, but instead we spent one long day. The volcano's activity kept us from any up close viewing and the rainy nighttime sky was not optimal for viewing the glow at night. Nevertheless, we hiked the fabulous Kikeuea Iki trail, visited the Volcano House, walked through the Lava Tube, felt the steam vents and enjoyed the day for the $10 price of admission.

I would highly suggest splitting your trip to Volcanoes in half - go in late afternoon/early evening to see the glow of Halema'uma'u and check out the Jaggar Museum, stay overnight somewhere close, then come back the next day during daylight to see as much of the park as you wish. In my opinion there is just too much to see in one day, and if you stay late enough to see the glow the drive back to the other side of the island is just too much. And, if the weather is uncooperative one day it may be better the other! The $10 admittance is good for a week so you may as well take advantage of it.

This park is AMAZING!!! $10 gets you a wonderful educational experience and the opportunity to see the fierce, yet beautiful power of nature at its finest!! The movies outline the Hawaiian Islands, start to present. Interesting to think that these Islands are still forming and the lava is still reshaping the terrain today! The park also has a strong lesson on conservation and each individual's responsiblity to our planet. The park staff members were well versed and able to answer questions and share a wealth of information (appropriate for all ages). Their message is not "preachy", but it reminds us that we all need to do our part! I appreciated the park's beauty, the lessons, and the "friendly" reminders.

The Hawaii National Park Service does a great job. Entry into the Park is only $10 and that is valid for a week (I believe a huge piece of the rental car taxes goes directly to the HNPS). The Volcano House is the only on Park Site "Lodging" that I am aware of. Its very nice, a bit pricey but nice staff and great food. Camping (not my thing) I think is available at a number of spots around the State Park.

What a fantastic visit! We have visited the Hawaii Volcanoes National Park two other times, but stayed within three miles of the park this time, rather than drive back to Kona. What an enjoyable trip, and visiting the Jaggar Museum at night was definitely awe-inspiring. We hiked the Kilauea Iki Crater, the Thurston Lava Tube, and took the Crater Rim drive. Begin at the Visitor's Center, and plan as much as you can. All the maps, the ranger suggestions, and the information booklets are definitely worth the time and effort. Learn as much as you can and enjoy! (The $10 per car entry fee is good for a week, so you can return as frequently as you desire. We ate lunch out of the park, and enjoyed a dinner or two at the nearby Volcano Village.) Some attractions were wheelchair accessible, others not.

Great hiking. Unique, fantastic views of volcanoes. Interesting presentations. $10 for whole week! See my individual reviews for Kilauea Iki Crater Trail, Thurston Lava Tube, and Jaggar Museum Lava Overlook.

We decided to make the trip from Kona to VNP and back in one day and found it very doable. The road to and from has a lot of curves, so if you don’t like to drive curvy roads in the dark (coming back) I wouldn’t do it. We had no problems and still spent 6-7 hours in the park. Make sure you fill up the car before you leave, gas is limited and costly on this road. There is a $10 per car entrance fee into VNP, but we thought it was well worth the money paid. The park is laid out very well and the visitor center is a must stop. The park rangers were very helpful and shared the important places to visit. Here are the stops we made: Visitor Center, Volcano House, Jagger Museum, Steam vents, Thurston Lava Tube, Chain of Craters Road, ending our tour at the Jagger Museum. Plenty of stops along the way to take pictures of the beautiful scenery. The two highlights for us were the walk at the end of chain of craters road (over the lava flow) and the night-time viewing of Kilauea Crater (glowing red lava). While it was a fairly long day (11 hours) from the time we left Kona until we returned it was well worth the trip. Note: we also stopped at South Point and Punaluu County Beach Park (a black sand beach) on the way to VNP, so if you didn’t do that it would only be about 9.5 hours.

We spent over 3 hours in the park – quite a bargain for a fee of $10 per car! Most of our time was spent driving to different locations and viewing something or walking/hiking to see the sights. It would be easy to spend the whole day or several days in the park but with a 3 hour trip each way from Kona, we were simply tired of driving. It’s worth a stop at the Visitor’s Center for information and a short movie about Kilauea volcano. There is a restaurant in the park but we brought a picnic lunch and enjoyed sitting in the shade at one of the picnic tables while eating it. I would recommend staying on the Hilo side of the island for a couple of nights to be able to spend as much time as you want at the park.

Visited twice because came a bit close to dark ( around 5:30 ) and just miss some places to see. Hold your entrance receipt ($ 10/car) that good for 1 week in case you have to come back again, like we did because we miss the Thurston Lava Tube due to less information before we go (thought close due to dark after sunset and the Jaggar Museum closed at 7:30 PM ). The Thurston Lava Tube OPEN DAILY for 24 HOURS and don't worry there are lights inside the cave and bright enough for you to see in there. Make sure spent your time at least 4 hours to enjoy the Hawaii Volcanoes NP and go further more after see the Tube for another scenic drive to see another different world. We didn't see the entire HVNP even visited twice and will come back again someday.

Just amazing. Definitely recommended if you have not gone before. The average price to go there by tour (preferred) is from $350-$380. This includes the $250-$300 on airfare, transport from your hotel to airport and back, and all day guided tour. Meals are not included but the places they take you for lunch & dinner were priced reasonably. My favorite part was the steam vents and the Summit. Just amazing. Take lots of pictures.

It is very impressive to see the plumes of smoke and the view from the visitor's center. The visitor's center has a great deal of interesting information and there are park service rangers available to answer your questions. Do visit all the different buildings and drive through the park. We drove down from Kona for the day (several hour trip). I would have loved to have seen the lava flow, but the boat rides out of Hilo were the only realistic choice for me. We were on the opposite side of the island, so driving to Hilo was out of the question for us. The Lava Tubes are very impressive and are a comfortable walk. If you have the time, do stop by. We don't have anything like it in Pennsylvania. Just a note: if you are 62 or older be sure to get a National Park Senior Pass for $10. It's good for parks through out the United States for your lifetime. For more info on the pass, go to the National Park Service website.

One of the main reasons we wanted to visit the big island is to go to Volcano National park. The park has some rally amazing views. The crater rim road is partial closed but still can get to the Jagger Museum and the other side connects with the chain of craters road. If you take the chain of craters road all the way to the end the road stops because of the Lava flows. Along the way there are interesting stops and short walks and hikes. You can get some trails maps at the visitor center. If you can I would recommend that you get your own car so you can do things at your leisure and not be rushed. The island is big and to save a lot of driving I would also recommend staying on the Hilo side a few days the village of Volcano has a number of rentals to stay at. There is a lot to see and you get a sense of old Hawaii and you can eliminate a 3 hour drive just to get to the park. We actually went to the park a couple of days. Over a half day we did the crater rim area and see the sulfur springs, Thurston Lava Tube, devastation trail and the Jagger Museum. The next day we did the chain of craters road. There a number of short hikes we did enjoy the Kilauea Ike Trail which is about 4 miles to complete the loop. At the end of the day we had dinner in Volcano Village and then went back a dusk to see the glow from the Caldera. My kids really did enjoy the park the highlight was to see the glow at night. I think they would have liked to see some real lava flows but that takes a pretty long hike to go to that area a stop at the historic Volcano House is nice and they have a better gift store than the Visitor Center. Also the Volcano Art Gallery is a nice place to stop by and look around. I would recommend a specialty tour for that activity. The other ways to see the lava is to take a helicopter ride or a lava boat tour. If you do a full day trip to the park I would recommend getting cheap Styrofoam cooler at Wal-Mart for $9 so you can put some water, fruit and sandwiches. We picked up some subway sandwiches so we can have lunch in the park without having to leave. Not much to offer in the way for food or snacks in the park unless you pay for an expensive lunch or dinner at the Volcano House. My wife and I were here in the mid nineties and the whole crater rim road was open and the lava flows covered less of the road so we almost drove up to where the lava is entering the ocean. Today it is about a 7 mile hike. If you have time a drive down to Kalapana is cool and you can see the other part of the lava flow which is not in the national park. There are some tour offered from that side and since it is on private land they have the permits to take you to the ocean opening. It is shorter hike from that side. There was something different this time. The fact that the crater rim road was closed because of vog seemed weird since it was not really blowing on the road. I can see if it does but when it doesn't why not open it. The activity today is far less than it was before and the road was open before the government always trying to protect you. Also we noticed there were a lot of rangers milling around and really did not seem to interact with people like they did before. I tried to ask a few questions and I barely got an answer. Even with the changes it is worth a visit and try to plan your day so you can take a short hike or walk so that you get a better sense of the power that the volcano has and how it has shaped the islands.

We spent two days in Volcanoes and had some amazing experiences. The glow from the Halema`uma`u Crater at night from Jaggar Museum is great. Not as great as flowing lava, but nature doesn't always cooperate. The stars at night are unbelievable. Don't miss the Kilauea Iki trail, where you get to walk right through a volcanic crater where steam is still venting. There is a great and easily accessible lava tube that you can walk through. We also really loved the Pu u hulu hulu hike. We could see both of the current eruptions as well as most of Mauna Loa from one location. I recommend getting the trail guides for $2 at the start of the trails so that you learn a bit about the park while you're there.

if you want to see live lava running its hard to do unless you rent a helicopter, a boat, or are willing to hike 17 mi. one way over some pretty scorched terrain. The road the could take you there was taken OUT by some lave about 15 years earlier and while thats cool to see, it wont get you very close. There is some 'private' property you can cut through outside the park for about 2.5 mi. but apparently the property owners charge you $100 for privilege. There is opportunism at its best!

We rented a car from the port, we were on an Hawaiian cruise. Total time from port, shuttle to car rental agency, stop for snacks, to Park was approximately 1 hour. The admission fee was $10 per person. Stop at Jagger Museum first, the rangers gave us great planning ideas considering we only had a few hours. We drove the Chain off Craters road. We drove down to the ocean, where the lava had crossed the road during a previous eruption. We found this to be a wildly beautiful spot. High cliffs, with the ocean waves crashing off the cliffs. We then drove to Thurston Lava Tube and walked through the forest and then through the tube. Beautiful hike, short, easy to do. Then back to the visitors center to view the volcano. That was a little disappointing, it was drizzling rain, misty, just not much to see. For those of you seeing the park during a cruise ship excursion, I would recommend renting a car and doing this park on your own, as opposed to paying for a tour. It is easy to find, an easy drive, and more independent. I feel as if I saw everything I wanted to see.

Excellent place to learn about the volcanoes and everything that goes with them. LOTS to see (allow time). Wonderful place to learn about Pele. I will go back as I am sure there is much I missed. Be sure to take water and food (flashlight might be needed too as well as good walking shoes!). $10.00 National Park fee (good for 7 days)(per car).

So interesting and unique! I recommend going in the early morning in hopes of better weather. This is a rain Forrest and the weather changes in an instant. It seemed to be clearer in the mornings. We were lucky to catch the sights before the fog rolled in and left no visibility. Be aware of the sulphur gases in the air because they can give you a headache pretty quickly if its smoking a lot. Take your time and enjoy all the sights that aren't blocked off. Don't forget to hike to the lava tubes! Also there's a $10 admission per car but it was well worth it.

We stayed nearby in Volcano Village, which I highly recommend. Why? Because park admission for one car for an entire week is only $10 and we went back 3 times over 2 days and it was easy to drive back and forth from where we were saying. The first afternoon we arrived, it was rainy and foggy. We stopped at the visitor center which was busy and crowded, so we quickly left and went to the Jagger museum which is right at the edge of the crater. The museum is small but interesting. Unfortunately for us, the crater was socked in with clouds and we couldn't see a thing. So we drove down to the lava tube which is on the other side of the park. The tube is well-lit, easy to walk through and pretty impressive to see. We then continued to follow the park roads down toward the ocean and down to lower altitude where there was far better visibility and we could view the old lava fields all the way down to the ocean. It was spectacular.

Stopped by the VNP yesterday. $10 per car to enter. the view of the caldron is spectacular. There was lots of "Peles hair"...fine strands of glass...just like hair of lengths of 1 foot or more, being produced by the volcano. Huge plume of smoke! Near are the steam vents you can stand next to and feel the steam. It is very hot so be careful, if you like your hair thick and curly, and it wasn't before, standing next to the vents will get it done. We only had 2 hours so we also did the lava tube that is enormous and you walk through it, probably 300' long...amazing.

good trip, a lot of walking, so wear good shoes. Walked thru lava tube, saw a lot steam vents, craters, and lots of people. Still worth the trip. Cannot see lava flow from this side. $10 fee to get into park.

If you are on this side of the island, you need to go to the park. It is $10 per car, but that gets you a week of coming and going whenever you want. The park is open 24 hours. Go to the Jaggar museum overlook at night for an amazing sight. We missed seeing the lava flow, but the park was still one of our favorites.

From strange endemic plants and birds, to lush fern and ohia forests, to stark lava fields, to other-worldly volcanic craters (some with molten lava), to local art work, this place deserves five stars. Don't miss the hike around part of the crater on the crater rim trail, a hike at the Jurassic feeling Thurston Lava Tube, a hike on the Devastation Trail, a stay at the Volcano House on the edge of the crater, the Visitor Center (buy inexpensive pocket guides to the local plants and birds) and the nearby Volcano Art Center (check out the beautiful and dirt cheap signed prints by Dietrich Varez and other local art priced from less than 20 dollars to thousands), the ranger talk on the volcano at the Jagger Museum (very funny and informative), a drive down the chain of craters road including a walk to the petroglyphs near the coast, and a visit at night to see the glowing lava from near the Jagger Museum. This is a great introduction to volcanism before a hike or boat ride to the actual flow. I haven't hiked up to the summit of Mauna Kea or hiked across the main crater, so I have something new to do when I return! Arrive early for the crowded hikes and dress in layers as it can be cool and windy, or hot and still. The hotel and restaurant were being renovated when we visited in March, but they still sold sandwiches and other lunch fare at the hotel which we ate across the street near the visitor center.

Since most of the resorts on the big island are on the opposite side, it takes a long time to get there. We also had dinner plans back at the hotel that night so we were left with only about 2 hours at the park. The rangers at the visitor's center are super friendly and very helpful in planning your visit. The movie in the visitor center is good.
