You get to see the smoldering crater, but here is the bottom line: if you want to see glowing lava you have to go to the end of Chain of Craters Road or to Kalapana and still have something like a 3 mile hike one way, or you can take a helicopter tour at $200pp or a boat trip. I really wished we had time to take one of those options. If I come back, I will plan to stay at least one night closer to the volcano to do this place justice.

The gate attendant did not advise us that due to hi levels of methane gas, 3/4 of rim road was closed. Our $10 got us less than quarter mile, to only two viewing points and the visitors center. It's a long drive; we wasted a full day's vacation. Take food unless you like packaged white bread sandwiches.

To view Hawaii Volcanoes National Park, you need at least two or three days. But because we only had one day, my companions and I decided to focus on the highlights. We first stopped at the visitor’s center to pick up maps and trail guides ($2 each and very useful in determining what you are looking at during your hike) and ask about current lava viewing conditions before heading off to the Kilauea Iki trailhead. It’s good to go early while there’s still plenty of parking. I believe we got there around 9am and the lot was about half full. The hike itself is amazing and it was easy to see why it’s the most popular hike in the park. The rainforest makes you feel like you’re in Jurassic Park and walking the still steaming crater floor was like walking on Mars or another barren planet. We were even able to see a couple of nene geese waddling by. The hike is 4 miles long and normally takes 2 to three hours but we finished in 4 hours due to taking a few “detours” from the official path (not recommended as there's quite a bit of loose rock around). Since it’s a long hike, it’s a good idea to bring plenty of water and snacks, as well as sunscreen as there is very little shade on the crater floor. Near the end of the hike was the trail to the Thurston Lava Tube, basically a large, mostly underground, cavernous passage set amidst a tree fern forest. Because it rained the night before, it was an adventure trying to navigate around the water dripping from the ceiling and the numerous puddles on the floor. All in all, the walk took about 15 to 20 min. We spent more time exploring the rainforest outside the tube than the tube itself.

We loved Hawaii and want to see it again! The Ocean is the bluest Blue we have ever seen ! Volcano National Park gives you the Feeling of being in another World. Walking on black Lava ,looking at the odd Shapes and Swirls the Lava Flow left behind ,is amazing. There are Roads that are totally cut off . It was amazig to see pretty little Flowers and Trees peaking through the Mass of Lava. Entering huge Lava Tubes is cool. The rising Steam here and there had the potent smell of Sulpher.We took a Cruise with NCL and got to see all the Island. From Pearl Harbour to North Shore, there is so much to see. We visited ther 5 years ago!

Fantastic! Magnificent! Awe inspiring! A national treasure. And only costs $10/car. Don't bother with an outside tour guide. Park visitors center is filled with very knowledgeable Rangers that will provide ample guidance on how to see all the sites. Even advice on park hikes and durations. Throughout the day the Rangers give guided tours. Just join one for as long as you care. We took loads of pictures. Thoroughly enjoyed this National Park.

I spent two fantastic two days in the Volcano national park and 10$ one week pass is the excellent value. I visited the Jagaer museum during the day and than late evening to see the glowing lava from the museum viewing point, sulphate bank, Lilauea Iki hike, Thurstone Lava Tube, Devastation trail (the shortest trail at the park) and down to Pu’u Loa Petriglyphs and end of the road. You can do many different and long hikes in the park with a diverse landscape and scenery.

It was my first time visiting the Big Island and I had to see the volcanoes! I visited Kilauea Volcano where I went at night and got great pictures of the active Halema'uma'u Crater. If you listen closely, you could hear the pop and boom noises from the lava rock falling into the hot lava below. I went down the Chain of Craters Road and what an adventure I had walking over the different shapes of lava and looking at the different craters. I even had a chance to see the Hawaiian bird - Nene - walking among the lava rocks. I saw the Thurston Lava Tube, walked down the Kilauea Iki Crater and back up, and saw the Pu'u Loa Petroglyphs. If I returned again, I will definitely go back and see the Volcanoes again. There is still a lot more to explore. The entrance fee is $10 with a car for one week.

We rented a car and drove to the park, using our Senior Lifetime Pass to gain entrance. Although part of the scenic road was closed due to high sulfuric gas activity, we still were able to see quite a bit of the inside of the crater, steam vents all over the place, and were able to hike through an actual lava tube. We viewed a very informative film at the Visitor Center, and the souvenir shop had some quality items as well as the usual tourist souvenirs. We were able to go as far as the museum, an interesting place also. Quite a few observation outlooks made for quality photo ops. A little bit scary, since, after all, it is an active volcano, and could theoretically erupt at any time. Although the seismic measuring instruments would likely give plenty of warning, we were told that in a few instances, form was not followed by the volcano. Apparently the volcano has not read the book! All in all, a very interesting and informative activity in beautiful Hawaii.

This national park is simply amazing. Well, that's my opinion but I was just so impressed! The entrance fee is $10 and that's good for 7 days. Even if you only have one day, the fee is worth it. Start at the visitor center. There you can find out about current activity, ranger talks, get maps of the park and check out the gift shop. I would then take the Crater Rim Drive. This road currently only goes as far as the Jagger Museum due to the activity in Halema'uma'u Crater. Along the road there are several places to stop with great views of the Kilauea Caldera and some short hikes. The other drive is Chain of Craters. The map suggests a driving time of 3 hours and this is pretty accurate if you spend a short amount of time at all the pull offs. The road starts near the visitor center and winds up down at the coast. There are stops at a lava tube, Devastation Trail, petroglyphs, craters, old lava flows and the coast. You can walk to the end of the road where the 2003 lava flow went over. From this side you can also hike the 15 miles to the current flow activity or drive south of Hilo and take a shorter 2 mile hike in the afternoon. There are lots of longer hikes in the park and other roads up Mauna Loa. The thing I liked most about the park was the diversity of the landscape. You have tropical plants and barren lava flows, tall peaks and crashing waves. All this in one national park. There is a small store in the lodge that sells sandwiches and salads, but I would suggest eating in Volcano Village where you get more for the price. It was misty and cool in the park, but the sun peaked out at times and it was sunny and warm down at the end of the Craters Road. Prepare for a variety of weather and don't let it hamper your visit. The mist just adds to the scenery!

We picked the One Day Hawaii Volcano Evening Eco Tour from Maui tour. Accent on the "ALL DAY! Cost for two people $710. Only critism is the plane ride back routes through Honolulu adding about 2 hours to your day. Left from our hotel in Lahaina before 7 am, and 0n a Hawaiian Air plane from Maui by 9 am, in Hilo within 30 minutes, then picked up quickly by Jay our tour guide. From there it is a tour of a candy factory, a 2 & 1/2 mile deep pond, a Japanese Park, Rainbow Falls, then lunch at a not so great country club restaurant, (since we didn't take the tour to eat it wasn't a deal killer). From there we headed on a great drive to the park being enlightened by Jay along the way. He is funny and knowledgeable & made our time on the bus great. The Park is remarkable! You'll hike through a lava tube, over lava flows and fields, past and present. Then to dinner at a not so great park campground... Then to the museum and another hike around the park and explore steam vents. Then nightfall and the show starts with the glow of the lava. It is surreal and hypnotic! Then back on the bus to the airport, Honolulu, and then finally Maui. Back at our hotel at 11:40 pm.

Visiting Hawaii Volcanoes National Park was a very neat experience! $10 fee per car to enter the park. Although we didn't have the perfect timing to see lava, we saw lots of steam. Please see my photos to share in the experience. Nice walking paths, historical sites, panoramic views, learning to be had, and a fun family activity!

Few of us have come face-to-face with active Volcanoes. I have seen Arenal in Costa Rica, but looking up from the bottom, hearing and feeling an occasional boom, and seeing smoke rise in puffs isn't the same as looking down from above. My wife and I put Volcanoes National Park at the top of our list during our visit to the Big Island, and we were not disappointed.

Very cool to walk over the lava fields. They sound hollow, like you'd fall through. Thurston Lava Tube very cool. Don't miss the glow of the volcano at night. We toured the park with Warren Costa, Native Guide Hawaii. Definitely the way to go!

As usual in a national park, the Rangers were very helpful, knowledgeable, and friendly. As usual in a national park, there are a variety of excellent programs led by the Rangers. We spent some time at the visitors center, hiked a couple of trails, and drove down to the ocean in our rented black Charger. As darkness falls, the crowds gather at the visitor center to watch the increasing glow of the active volcano, and that's pretty cool.

We spent 6 hours in the park learning and viewing everything volcano's. We even did the Crater hike into the lava lake and up the rain forest. There are easy to advance hikes available. The steam vents, Crater ring and lava tubes are amazing and easy to access. The views of lava paths to shore lines are breath taking. A great was to spend a day with the family and learning something new at the same time! Plus its only $10.00 per car to enter and its good for a week of visits.

Ten dollars per carload for a week pass? What a great value. This is a fascinating place - go on the Kilauea Iki hike and the Chain of Craters Drive. One can easliy stay busy for 2 days if you are willing to do a couple of 2 to 4 mile hikes.

I share the joy and excitement of all the previous reviewers. Instead of repeating highlights already mentioned, I wanted to entail that the National Park is organized for self-exploration. I often heard tourists, including myself, inquiring about arranging paid tours of the park. There is no need. At least not while the lava is not actively and excessively flowing. The park rangers and the locals will tell you that you are just paying $100 plus dollars for someone to keep you company. Visitors are able to access all the same places as the tour operators.

If you are staying on this island don't miss this site. We loved it but we left our resort at 80+ degrees and froze in the park in our shorts and tank tops. We thought about buying sweatshirts in the gift shop / welcome center but they were $50 and ugly black. Our kids loved the incredible hikes. Bring lunch, snacks and water.

There's nothing earth-shattering to see here unless you've never been before, in which case it's probably worth the trip. I visited 6 years ago and since then the crater rim drive is half closed off, so there's less to do and see. The lava tube is cool. If you like hiking, then this trip is a must; lots more to do and see if you don't have a disinterested teenager with you. $10 park entrace fee. Bring food if you plan to stay!

If you want to see the power of the earth at work, this is the place. Although we didn't see any lava flows, we didn't expect the earth to perform on cue for just us. Seeing the miles and miles of craters and solidified lava areas is enough for one to grasp the devastation. The views are spectacular and the drive itself is awesome. Be sure to stop at the visitor center to the latest updates on what to see. The park roads are well maintained as areall of the stops along the way. $10 to get in is a pitifully small donation for all they do here. The steam vents area is surreal and worth the hike.

Very nice park with many things to do! Take the time to visit all of the attractions within the park. The sea arch was really neat and the closest one we were able to get pictures of during our stay. Stay after sunset and see the glow of the lava by the Jaggar Museum. It is amazing! Well worth the $10 to visit the park, walk the trails, and see the sites.

If you are cruising and arriving at the Port of Hilo, the must see attraction is the wonderful Hawaii Volcanoes National Park. While there are many excursions offered to the National Park, you will be in a large group and on the tour provider’s schedule which we find usually includes too much time shopping at a location they have a relationship with and not enough time at the sights of interest to us. Instead of taking the excursion, it is easy to see the park at your own pace and save a lot of money by renting a car. I simply reserved a rental car from a Hilo airport rental car agency several months ahead of the cruise. When we arrived in Hilo we disembarked and the all the agencies had shuttles right from the cruise ship dock to their location at the nearby Hilo airport. The National Park is about 45 minutes away and easy to find with few turns but for assistance I had brought my GPS from home along. After we were done with our day at the park, we returned to the airport, dropped of the car off and took the shuttle back to the dock. The whole process was surprisingly smooth and simple and the cost of the rental and entrance to the National Park ($10 per car full) for the four of us was about the same as the price for one adult excursion!

It was fun to walk thru lava tubes and then at night when it got dark you could see the red lava from the McJagger Museum in the park. There was a $10 entrance fee per car. It is definitely cold here- you should bring warm clothes, jackets, gloves and a blanket to keep warm.

You need a full 1.5-2 days (not including drive time) to really explore the park. It is only $10 for a weeks admission. The junior ranger program is great, as are all the ranger-led programs. It can be mighty rainy and cold, so bring long pants and shirts and a rain jacket. Sturdy shoes are also a must. A first aid kit is a good idea too especially if you have kids. The lava rocks are sharp. Be sure to check out the view from Jaggar museum in both the daytime and nighttime. The glow after dark is super cool. We loved the steam vents, the petroglyph trail, and the Kilauea Iku trail. The Kilauea Iku trail is my favorite hike. It takes 2 hours, but is totally worth it. You hike down to the floor of the Caldera. Our 7 and 9 year old children had no problem with the hike. Bring plenty of water and snacks.

Volcanoes National Park is a large park with a lot to see. The trick is to make certain that the sun is shining, or don't go at all. Our first day was typical of the area -- rain, rain, rain, nonstop rain. The locals told me it had been raining nonstop for 5 weeks. We finally got a break from the rain, though, on the second morning, but only for a few hours. If it's raining, go somewhere else. You can't see anything and it is very miserable since at 4000' it's cold, windy, and dreary in the rain (yes, even in Hawaii it can be cold). If the sun does shine, then you can see the caldera, take a few drives to the volcano tubes, or see the main steam vents near the observatory. I heard from others that they had enjoyed their helicopter flyover on a sunny day, and this was something I had wanted to do if we had had the time. The entrance fee is $12.00 per car, but for some reason there's always a wait to get into the park, longer than one might expect. Once you do get up to the gate, the entrance fee is good for about a week, so you keep your receipt. I wasn't all that impressed with the park and felt that the free Black Sand Beach just a little north of the park was a lot more interesting.

Though you pay $10 per vehicle to enter that fee is good for 7 days so hang on to that receipt. We went back two more times. We arrived in the afternoon and went through the visitors center and then down to the Jaegger Museum which overlooks the caldera but going back that evening was the really spectacular night glow. WoW! Then we went back the next morning to go the other way down the Road of Craters and that was great because at that time of day there are very few people around, it takes all morning for the tours to come over from Kailua so we basically had the place to ourselves all the way to the ocean. Staying the night in Volcano was really worth it.

We visited Volcanos National Park on the Big Island during our Honeymoon in June 2011. Entrance fee is $10 and is good for 7 days. The park is open 24/7. What can I say? It was absolutley amazing. Whether or not there is flowing lava, the sights are beautiful and aweinspiring. We just followed the road around the caldera, well as far we could anyways...the road was closed in sections because of high levels of noxious gases. This didn't matter however, as you could still access all the parks attractions. We walked around the Sulpher Banks which was interesting and stinky :) The view from the Jagger Museum is breathtaking, especially at night. We walked through the Thurston Lava Tube, down the Devastion Trail, and went to the many lookouts throughout the park...and I would recommend ALL of it, if you have the time. We also drove down Chain of Craters Road, which winds its way down from the Volcano Summit to the ocean. Truly amazing drive, it was one of the trips highlights.

I think most people would consider this a must-see on the big Island, and I agree. Allow plenty of time for the two visitor centers / museums. The drive to the coast is pretty, but long, and no lava viewing from this side. If you want to get to the active lava flow, it is an hour+ drive toward Hilo and in from the other side. That was also worth the trip, especially after dark. Note a visitor may not see the actual lava flowing from this side either, unless a special tour is arranged ($55 per person, I think, from a vendor set up at the end of Route 130).

The timing and amount of lava you will see is decided by Mother Nature. At the time of my visit, there was no flowing lava to be seen within the National Park. We also took a helpcopter ride and did see tiny amounts of orange lava, but mostly smoke and steam. It is interesting and something you can't do anywhere else, so I do recommend it but if you are expecting huge orange gushes you will be disappointed. $10 per car fee is valid for 7 days. Chain of Craters Road (easy drive and free) is very interesting and the sea arch at the end is beautiful. Jagger Museum is a great way to spend an hour or more.

Hidden gem off the beaten path. Well restored 17th/18th century iron manufacturing facilities including a barn, houses and other ancillary buildings. Small visitor center had a small museum with useful site specific history and artifacts. Has a large apple orchard where apples can be picked for $1/pound. Well worth a visit.

If you are a history buff, then Hopewell Furnace National Historic Site is a must. The site is nestled in the French Creek Park area and captures a part of our history. Run by the friendly folks of the National Parks Service (your tax dollars at work), the site is all about the early days of the industrial revolution. The Furnace, operating from 1771-1883, is an 848 acre iron plantation site that includes demonstration areas maned by a cadre of wonderful volunteers. On a recent trip we witnessed volunteers creating charcoal and others making molds and then casting them in iron. This kind of stuff is great for kids of all ages. Expect to spend at least two hours onsite and make sure you are wearing comfortable shoes. Don't forget to stop by the interesting General Store (Wed. - Sun.) and the farm area with horses, sheep and a couple of very lazy steers. Don't miss Hopewell Furnace, a great experience and it is free.

We brought the entire family (23+ pp ages 8-77). The area is very green but there is a lot of walking so I recommend bringing water bottles. We enjoyed some root beers from the old fashioned gift shop/general store. There was also a few people dressed in period clothes and one guy riding a wooden sled pulled by two horses. A few of the people in our group went apple picking for $1/lb. The apples were small and tart, but they had fun nonetheless.
Pros: cast demonstration, well preserved water wheel, apple picking ($1=1LB), nice rangers and no fee entrance.
Went for apple picking on October 5, 2012. Got some very nice apples for $1 a pound. It was fun picking my own apples. The National Park Service provides the containers and the picking pole.

We were heading to national parks in Texas and New Mexico and as this was not far off our travel route, we decided to spend two nights here and visit Hot Springs National Park. We "took the waters" of the springs at Quapaw Bathhouse, took The Grand Promenade Walk and drove the Mountain Tower Drive (the one way road up was closed due to construction so the one way road down was made a two way drive). We took the elevator up to the top to get a 360 degree view of the Hot Springs area. Bathhouse Row was mostly covered by foliage but there were a few scenic views to the west. The open top viewing area contained a number of wasps so if you are allergic to stings, be careful. The lower viewing area was enclosed, air conditioned and contained a history of Hot Springs. We received the senior national parks pass rate of $5 each otherwise it would have been $8 each. So we did all of what we wanted to do in this national park. There are other things for a family to do but my impression is that the bathhouses are for adults and not children. This national park is like no other we have visited, but we did visit it.

We loved this national park. The green space was beautiful as were the walking trails and promenade. Yes, many of the springs are hot. You can see steam coming off of them even in 90 degree heat.The Visitor's Center is a must see. This former bathhouse has been preserved and restored to the 1920s and is a show place. The gift shop a few doors down was also beautiful. The auto tour mountain drive & tower is nice as well. Make sure you buy an $8.95 glass jug for bottling some of the water. We got cold water from the Happy Hollow spring which I was told is 6,000 years old.

I thought it would be a hiking etc national park but it mainly consists of bath houses. The visitor center is a museum of a bath house..interesting to walk thru and see what it was like. The town itself is on the other side of the street consisting of clothing stores and shops. The park has some nice grounds you can walk around. We did go up to a spring display and the water was definetly hot. Then we drove to the tower on top of the mountain and went up...use your national park pass if you have one then it's 4 dollars apiece. It was a scenic drive up with switch backs for a lot of the way.
... Feel like we took a wrong turn and missed the park ? We found the national park campsite but that was it. Other than that could only find downtown hot springs ...

Hot Springs state park was a great place to explore. We stayed just on the outskirts of town and went over a holiday week end. It was a bit crowded but parking was free because it was a holiday week end. Definitely stop in the visitor center. There is a bathroom in there and we picked up some maps and other information on places we wanted to visit. Bath houses were fun and the kids were fascinated by the hot springs. If you stop in one of the Fordyce Bathhouse there are rangers from the national park who can help you if you want to hike. Since I was with my friends and her kids (one who is only 2) we opted only for the trails that were on a paved surface. Pay attention though. We totally missed the Hot Water Cascade. It is off to the left almost as soon as you pass through the two pillars with Eagles on top. Be careful if you let the kids touch the water because it is HOT. You could even feel the heat radiating off of the water in the summer. I would love to see it in the cooler weather when you see the steam coming off the water. We found a great place to picnic just outside the campground in the National Park. Plenty of shops and treasures up and down Central Avenue. I would also recommend a trip up to the Hot Springs Mountain Tower.

I loved this area and wished we would have stayed longer. We did do some of the scenic driving as well as hiked the town area. We also paid the 20 dollars per person to visit and participate in the quapaw bath house. That was well worth it. we wore suits and it was coed. it was super relaxing and I highly recommend the walk. Visit the city tourist center as well as the national park visitor centers for tons of information. Probably need 3 days and more like a week if you also do the state parks in the area. Don't forget to eat at McClards which has an amazing bbq.

March 13th this month, my husband & I rented two 2 bedroom condos at Sunbay Resort at 4810 Central Ave. in Hot Springs, AR. Friends of mine from grade school came from Mississippi (we from Texas) for a celebration of our reaching our 80th year on this earth. We were there until the 20th. We explored the area, drove up the mountain to the tower, walked all over the town, cooked some meals in the condo but ate out a lot! We spent a day at the Oaklawn Racetrack. Admission is free but I got us a boxseat. Went to the Crystal Mine & would have done zipline but chickened out. Some of the days were rainy but we didn't let that stop us & had a wonderful time exploring & remembering "when." Our condos overlooked an inlet of Lake Hamilton & great views of sunsets & rises over Lake Hamilton with balconies to sit on & enjoy these views. Plenty of places to walk, exercise room, activity center, etc.

We started out near Reserve and Central Avenue; walked on the Grand Promenade until picking up the Dead Chief Trail to the Peak Trail to the Tower. We got to the tower before 9 and it was closed; there was a small overlook we enjoyed (the tower was $7 to get in as well, which we probably wouldn’t have paid for). We then go back on the Peak Trail to the Hot Springs Mountain Trail to the Flora Trail to the Lower Dogwood Trail to the Arlington Trail. We didn’t know that the Arlington trail would actually take us into the Arlington hotel – that was certainly memorable. Make sure to take a trail map with you – you can mix and match and a number of different trails for a nice hike as long or short as you would like. Hot Springs isn’t the most exotic National Park, but certainly there is a lot of history. It was also nice to get out for a hike. We didn't find it necessary to spend more than a day...but there are other things to do in the area. Enjoy!

Agree w/ others that this National Park is not typical as it's in a completely urban setting. There is NO FEE to visit this park but do your part and leave at least $5/person to help it be charming for others after you. Touring the Fordyce Bath house, which IS the N.P. vis center, was fabulous as we caught a tour from a volunteer which enhanced our self tour. Restoration and history is fascinating. Realizing that these mineral baths were health cures of their time helps one understand a piece of history long gone since invention of penicillin. Charming and fun to spend a whole day on Bathhouse Row and then cross the street to the City area. V.C. desk staff had some very friendly people. The scenic drives are short, and the hikes interesting. The humidity is not enjoyable. Fascinating piece of history w/ gangsters, the wealthy, and the 'old days'. Glad that we tax payers are paying to upkeep this place. Worth the 4 days we spent in Hot Springs AR.

The town itself was not very impressive, however once you get to Bath House Row it all changes. Although most of the Bath Houses are empty there are a few that are open. If you stop by Fordyce Bath House you will find a few National Park Service Volunteers as well as Park Rangers and you can tour the House at your own pace. I highly recommend trying out the elevator at least once, although it does not work as it did back in the davit is still pretty cool. This Bath House has been restored to it's former glory and gives you a glance into the past. I loved this House you can see all the equipment they used, the baths themselves, changing rooms with actual clothing in them, courtyards, music room and even hotel like guest rooms, it is fantastic. A few steps away from that house you will find another 2 Houses that are actual Bath Houses although they are a bit modernized inside you still get the idea and maybe can indulge in a Hot Bath yourself. There is one that is used as a gift shop and you can get your National Park Passport stamped there. I loved this place and regret not partaking in a Bath, oh well maybe next time. FYI the cheapest Bath is $30 at one of the Bath Houses which is pretty economical. You may want to pass on the $7 to go up in the tower as it is not very impressive and does not give you a view of the Bath Houses, do go in the Arlington Hotel it's pretty neat!

You can't visit Hot Springs without going to the National Park. We went specifically for the baths and the hike to the mountain tower, all of which we enjoyed. The Peak Trail to the mountain tower will definitely get your heart pumping. Once there you can go up the tower for $7 (you can also drive to the tower). We of course saw Bathhouse Row as well. We didn't go into too many shops but there are some cool places to stop and have lunch or drinks. All in all, we enjoyed our trip to the park and it is definitely full of beautiful scenery and history.

I was VERY disappointed that this was closed as I had looked forward to going here specifically. I have a National Park Passport that I get stamped & buy stickers for when I'm at a National Park so didn't get to do that plus I was looking forward to seeing and reading the info in the Welcome Center.

We spent a couple of hours in Hot Springs National Park. Worthwhile if you're in Hot Springs, but I don't know that I'd make a special trip. The lookout tower is nothing special (but costs $7/person). There are some decent short hikes. We hiked down from the tower on the 0.6-mile Peak trail. Trail was mostly gravel, had some decent views, but nothing outstanding.

So let me say that before I visited Hot Springs National Park, I wasn't sure I'd enjoy it, but I'm glad I did. I think Hot Springs is rather unique in that not so long ago, it was actually still functioning not long ago. Also, it was initially built for profit unlike other National Parks such those that were nature-made. At any rate, when you make it to the downtown Hot Springs area, be sure to park in the free lot--as you exit toward the road, you'll find yourself almost directly in front of the park. You can tour one of the historic bathhouses that has 2 or 3 floors open for touring where you'll see changing areas for men and women, a gymnasium for fitness, and a massage parlor. If you participate in the NPS Passport program, be sure to get your stamp there at the Fordyce House and check out the park store in the Lamar Bathhouse, as they have a stamp there as well. You can purchase souvenirs there such as a embroidered towels, quartz specimens from the Arkansas mountains, and souvenior jugs and jars that you can use to fill with water from the hot springs at one of the nearby filling stations. As you walk the row, you'll notice other buildings that were once bathhouses--some still offer hot baths, while others have been converted to other things. Behind the row of bathhouses, there are areas to hike, and you can see the hot, steaming waters rushing through the aqueducts. Also, there are scenic mountain trails you can drive for those who are interested, though I didn't check any of them out. I really enjoyed this national park more than I thought I would given it's commercial beginnings. If you're in the area, why not check out what once made Hot Springs such a popular tourist destination? This park has no fees for those traveling on a budget. It's right in the heart of town with antique shops, stores, and restaurants, and you can spend as little as an hour or as many as you'd like. :)

If you've never been a customer in a bathhouse, plan on getting "the treatment" for about $80. We've done these in other places, but this looks like the real deal. And, the National Park ranger tour of one of the houses is fun an informative. Who knew they used to do "mercury rubs" to cure syphilis! Wonder if more died from the "cure" than the disease.

We have visited all of the National Parks but two. This is the most unusual and had me scratching my head. Approaching Hot Springs, you are routed through five miles of strip malls featuring every franchise brand known to man. Not too inspiring to say the least. Finally, you arrive at the historic Bathhouse Row, a mile or so of historic brick buildings sitting atop a series of hot springs. I wandered around wondering who I should present my Park Pass to - evidently, it is not that kind of National Park where you drive through the ranger station, pay your fees, and are soon presented with majestic vistas. Despite initial misgivings, I enjoyed our visit.
We drove into quaint Hot Springs and walked the Peak Trail up to the outlook. We didn't go up the tower because of the price ($8 pp), but we view was great from the outlook point.

Honestly, the best part about the “park” was visiting the Fordyce Bathhouse (aka the visitors center). This is the smallest National Park and truthfully one of the oddest and most unique parks. The town itself is part of the park. We drove up to the viewing tower and decided not to go up the tower ($8 for adults). We drove the little loop up the hill and got to see the hot spring capsules and the views of the city. That was about all that was up there. The little town was the best part. Definitely a unique National Park... unlike any others, that’s for sure. Overall, it was fun to go and see it but the self guided tour of the Fordyce Bathhouse was the best.

We came to Hovenweep from Cortez and it is an interesting drive to get there. Pay attention on the drive in so you don't hit any big ruts in the road where the asphalt is deteriorating. There is a nice welcome center and wheelchair accessible paths to some of the ruins with most of the ruins on rocky trails that go around the cliffs. Dogs are welcome on leashes. My kids enjoyed looking at the ruins and enjoyed the Junior Ranger program where you do activities at each national park and monument so you learn about the area and get a badge. It was getting hot on an 80+ day and the walk around the ruins is not necessarily easy, so bring water and good shoes. As others mentioned, there are easier and harder, shorter and longer paths so that you can tailor your visit to you. The towers on the cliffs are pretty impressive as you think about who used to live here and how they lived.

Because it's so remote and lightly visited, dogs are allowed on the trails, and perhaps this is also the reason why there is no admission charge. We would have happily paid $20 or more to see these really interesting ruins, some of which are perched artistically on top of large boulders. In addition to Little Ruin Canyon near the visitor center, it is worth it to take the dirt road to the Holly ruins. Just past the ruins is another short trail marked "petroglyph" which takes you to a very cool rock formation where the summer solstice sunset lights up a spiral carved in the rock.

A little known unit of the National Parks that has outstandingly preserved ruins and is well worth visiting! A new visitor's center has a 17 minute film that you should see before taking a walk to see the ruins. And there is no Entrance Fee :)

We spontaneously decided to visit Hovenweep on the way to Four Corners and are glad we did. You can walk the routes within an hour or so and view the ruins. We visited late May and the weather was beautiful....sunny, a nice breeze and pleasantly warm. The park ranger provides a map with the walking route around the ruins and the cost was $6/car. Very nice, easy walk with lots of ruins and picturesque views.

If in the area this is a must see. You can easily access it from 191 (half way between Blanding and Bluff Utah) on 262. Don't get discouraged as you drive along 262. There are really trashy looking houses and the road is littered with trash and empty beer and soda bottles. This hwy is nothing to write home about and makes it hard to beleive anything of interest could possibly lie ahead. But it does! The road is paved all the way albeit a little rough and any vehicle can make the drive. Once you arrive the canyon and ruins are visible. It is one beautiful canyon and quite different from the all so many red rock canyons of the area. It consists of large sandstone (I think) rocks but they are whiteish. Pinon pine and junipers cover the nearby terrain as well as the valley floor. The ruins look really unstable since many are on rock bed which is sliding down the hill. They are still amazing structures to look at. The National Park service has wonderful facilities and drinking water. They have a really nice network of paths which allow you to get up close to the ruins without disturbing them while keeping you safe and giving you the best views of the canyon. Warning. Stay on the trails and leave everything you come across alone. They have people disguised as tourist watching you and will gladly give you a $275 fine.

Park is great for mountain bikers and hikers in spring. In other seasons skiing and skating are available. Not so good for RVS only 7 electric only sites and 3 dry shelters in loop. Sites are close together and road narrow. Some of the sites would be very difficult to get into. No water, no dump site, and no trash at RV loop site.$14, we paid for 2 nights but only stayed 1 night. Beautiful vistas and nice day use areas along the road. Main loop for tents not open, office closed for season although person on phone said it was all open.

About 7.5 miles up the mountain you will find a snow board rental facility. Pay 5 dollars to the park near the flag pole and move to the sledding behind the rental facility. There are three runs to enjoy and we loved it.

Hyde memorial state park has great campsites which are inexpensive($7) and the area smells sweet as a forst should. But even more special was a wedding I attended in the lodge there and the atmosphere was great---not fancy or overdone, but foresty and just right for a young couple starting out.

We hiked here one morning while visiting Santa fe. It is not too far from the city center. There was a $5 charge for the park with plenty of parking. We enjoyed the 3.5 mile loop hike that had a nice climb with views at the top.

We are supposed to go to Ski Santa Fe and just dropped by to take pictures of the place, ended up here since kids wanted to try sledding and enjoyed it so much that we decided to just stay here. Another good thing is that you only pay for $5.00 parking fee.

We red reviews online for sledding here so loaded up and drove up here. The parking lot was full of vehicles which I later found out was people going in to rent skis/snowboards. There was lots of snow and a couple of little hills close to the road where there were already a couple of people sledding. I found the self serve pay area for parking and there was a sign hanging that said something like "tube run closed" but another person was paying their $5 so I went ahead and did it assuming there was another tubing area they were talking about. There wasn't anyone around to ask. We walked over to a little sledding area that was perfect for my little ones to try. After about 5 minutes a man came over and said that the area was closed due to lack of snow and that we would get a $200 fine from the park ranger when he drives by. So, we packed back up and drove further up the mountain. There were two other nice little areas up the mountain we found for sledding but I don't think they are considered part of Hyde Memorial. As we drove past the original spot by the ski rental shop, there were people sledding there again so I don't know if they will actually hand out fines or not. We drove past there 4 times the next day and there was always some people sledding there. There was plenty of sledding up the mountain further.

We've spent a lot of time at Hyde over the years. It is beautiful, quiet during the weeks, and the rangers are wonderful. While you won't see showers or flush toilets, it keeps things quiet and keeps the riff raff out. The park's infrastructure (site areas, fences, lean-tos, etc.) are impressive and well kept. The views from the West Circle trail are breathtaking, and it's a tough enough hike that you feel like you earned the views. I always hike from the Girl Scout Loop straight up rather than from the trailhead by the lodge up because you get the steep part over with in a mile's time. Compared with Santa Fe, the weather is nice and cool, especially if you're a Midwesterner like me. Bring warm clothes for the evenings and hope that there aren't fire bans so you can have a fire! The main campground loop has 29 sites and it costs $10 per vehicle to camp and $5 a vehicle for day use. It's a steal! Whenever we leave, we count the time until we get to return!

We were surprised how quickly we entered the mountains after leaving Santa Fe. The park is only a 10 min. drive out of downtown. Beautiful views overlooking the valley below if you continue on past the park a little ways. We plan to return to hike and camp in this area in the summer! $5 day use fee for park. If you want to sled for free drive just a little further to Tesque Campground. Our two year old enjoyed sledding. The scenery is worth the drive as well. It looks like this is a great place to check out fall foliage.

A great day hike very close to Santa Fe. Gorgeous views, beautiful woods and scenery. Some trails are a fairly easy walk, some require moderate stamina to climb, over a mile or so, 1000 vertical feet. That's not overwhelming, but if you're not used to the altitude, it can be a challenge! Although we went for just a few hours, many people were camping overnight. NOTE: there's a $5 fee to park, and you have to have exact change or write a check to put into a pay envelope.
We enjoyed the Images of Rocky Mountains National Park very much. My 12 yr old son purchased a 2017 calendar for around $20 and was really excited about all the pictures in it.
park: Images of Rocky Mountain National Park

text: Wish my Photos could be half as good as Eric's. His eye catching images were a bargain in his soft cover book (purchased first edition for $5).
park: Images of Rocky Mountain National Park

text: Hands down the most beautiful photographs of RMNP that we saw during our trip. The colors are so vivid in the photos and give them a life-like appearance. Only downside is that I'm not sure you could find anything under $500, with most photos being in the quadruple digits.
park: Images of Rocky Mountain National Park

text: The photographs at this shop are excellent. Eric is a very talented man! We purchased a photo and also his new book. Prices are definitely not cheap, but of great quality. A wonderful souvenir!
park: Images of Rocky Mountain National Park

text: The images on display are simply breathtaking. Erik is obviously a very skilled photographer and it shows in his work. Most of the images are breathtaking. We purchased three items and are anxiously awaiting their arrival. The customer service was excellent and the staff patiently answered all of our questions. I only wish we could have gotten to meet Erik. Typically, the images are mounted on plaques and are hung so they sit out slightly from the wall, helping to give it a 3-D effect. Spend over $200 and they will ship for free. Even if you don't purchase, you must make it by this shop. You'll be hard-pressed not to buy something.
park: Images of Rocky Mountain National Park

text: Nice shop, lots of options and the guy that was there was really helpful about climbs, recent local history (flood and fire) and not pushy at all! Wish we had saved some $$ to purchase something!! Next visit for sure!!
park: Images of Rocky Mountain National Park

text: We parked in the parking garage (which only takes credit cards as you exit) and came up right next to the visitor and information center. We had been here before, but it took a few minutes, a map and a "mighty nice staff member for us to get our bearings. Tickets to Independence Hall are available here....free but in demand. Also keep in mind that security is TIGHT at both the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall.

We visited Independence Hall, the Liberty Bell & then took the tour around Philly to other stops. The ranger we had for our tour was knowledgeable and fun. Tickets are timed and you must have a tour time to enter. I would get a tour time as soon as you arrive. We had a 2 hour wait till out time and we arrived at 10 am.

We arrived early but had no problem changing our tickets. Staff is super helpful. Visits are timed. There is airport type security. We did have to stand outside and wait - it was a cold and windy day. But so worth it. The Park Rangers as usual do not disappoint. Our tour guide brought history alive and included visiting children in the discussion. We were allowed to take as many pictures as we wanted. To be in the room that was the birthplace of our country is just surreal. You will recognize the room where the Declaration of Independence was signed because it is original and just like the pictures!!! You are invited to got to a second building to see a portion of the original Declaration of Independence. Parking is easy at the visitors center. Tickets are free at the visitors center. But you can get them online for $1.50 each.

The experience begins outside...First you learn about the President's House and the excavated slave quarters below. There are several TVs and plaques telling you about the actual slaves that lived there. Admission is free. Inside there are lots of artifacts, short videos, informational plaques--lots of great information and history to see and learn before getting to the Liberty Bell itself. And of course seeing the Bell in person gives you chills!

Everything is free. Unless you buy a timed ticket for $1.50 to see the Declaration itself. We were there for the Bruce Springsteen show on Friday 9/9. This entire area is run by the National Parks Service who, given that it was also 9-11 weekend, a Browns-Eagles game weekend handled the crowds admirably.

Independence Hall is home to some of the most historic events in US history. If you stop by the visitor center you can pick up free tickets. You can also reserve tickets at a cost of I believe $1.50 each. If you do that you have to pick up a couple hours prior to the visit. You are asked to arrive half an hour early to go through security. Security moves pretty quickly. When you get in there is a line that forms to the right for the Independence Hall tour. They let you in by the time on the ticket so the line doesn't mean a whole lot. If you have time there is a room on the other wing you can go in with a ranger there. They will give you some more information and answer questions. The tour is factual and provides you a history of Independence Hall and the formation of our country. You can also walk out to the front and take pictures.

The Independence Mall area & Hall are extremely busy and although admission is free for the day you go, if you want to save time and get tickets ahead, you need to pay $1.50 per person for a process fee. It does save wait time to have your tickets in advance especially for groups.

The foundation of the first Whitehouse, the Liberty Bell, the National Constitution Museum--this is the historic jewel in Philadelphia's crown. Lines move fast, though week-day visits are better still. I didn't see one tour bus on the weekday we went. *Note* there are Buddhist monks working the grounds. If you engage them, they will give you a wristband and prayer card--then hit you up for a donation. They don't want $5 or $10, they want $20 or $50. Do not engage them. If you do engage them, DO NOT let them hustle you out of $20 bucks. They got $8 out of me. Upside, you have the wristband so if you go back, show the monks the band and they'll leave you alone.

Recently visited the area during Independence Day weekend. The Independence Visitor Center is staffed with knowledge staff in regards to answering questions regarding nearby attractions. There's also a cafeteria inside with restrooms and souvenir shops. Tickets for the Independence Hall tour are obtained here but I recommend to pay a small fee to reserve online in advance since they go quickly. The tour is staffed by very knowledgeable park rangers explaining the foundation history and events of the country. The line to visit the Liberty Bell was a little long due to the holiday but the flow of people was well managed. The area is very well maintained despite many visitors and the age of the buildings. The park is very educational for someone who like to learn about early US History.
Brings to life the experience of 1776 and constitional congress. They have story tellers for young children and guided tours. Tickets are first come

Independence Hall is famous for housing the Liberty Bell. There was a short line to enter and once inside we noticed an assortment of informational displays about Philadelphia's history and the history of the Liberty Bell. They were very informative. The bell itself is situated in its own little area in the rear with windows around it. It was neat to see such an iconic artifact in person. Admission into the sight is free of charge. They allow you to take photos here. The building is surrounded by a small park area, which is nice.

I visited on 5/13/16 and arrived in the are early in the morning (8 am). I had no trouble finding parking in the Independence Visitor Center parking lot ($20.50 for all day parking). The park includes Independence and Congress Hall, the park area and the liberty bell. I got tickets (free) to the 9 am tour on Independence/Congress Hall. You do have to pass through security to enter. The Ranger was very informative. The tour of Independence Hall is about 20 minutes as is the tour of Congress Hall. During this tour you see the "courthouse" and then go to the room where the Declaration of Independence was drafted and signed. Following this tour you go to Congress Hall (again the volunteer was very informative). This is where John Adams was sworn in as president. You also get to go upstairs to see the original committee rooms and the senate chambers. After this tour I went to see the liberty bell. I got there at 10 am and was through the exhibit by 10:30. The line moved quickly. You do have to go through security. There are many exhibits to see within the area on the way to see the bell. The opportunity for picture taking with the bell was very good.

We are local and it was the first time I had been to Liberty bell, but not the first time I had been to entire park area. Clean as always, very touristy, even on a crappy weather day but that's ok. Admission to the main museum is expensive but it's something you should do once if you're in the area.

As part of our Spring Break Stay-cation, we visited Independence NHP. It was our first visit to the Park and wanted to see the highlights. We had requested free timed tickets to the Independence Hall. Other days during spring break were booked, so to assure we'd get the tour, we paid the $1.50 servicing fee per ticket. After a security checkpoint, we entered the square and were all pleased. The tour was about 30 minutes, and all my school aged kids got something from it. The ranger talk setting the tone for the revolution engaged my second grader quite a bit. I love when history becomes meaningful, and lessons can be understood.

There is a lot of great things to see here. There will most likely be lines because of security but it is a must see. The Liberty Bell itself takes one minute but there are articles to read. Independence Hall is where you need to do a tour to get the full effect. It really is cool to get to be right where the Declaration was signed. They have a original copy of the Declaration to view as well. Tours are free however if you want to buy tickets online it is $1.50 each. This reserves your ticket, otherwise you have to just show up the day of and hope to get a ticket. I would go back again.

This really is the birthplace of our nation. The park includes Independence Hall where the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution were signed and which was the seat of our government for its first 10 years. The Liberty Bell is housed just to the north of Independence Hall. The visitor center is located even further north. They have programs that delve into the history of the area. Tickets to Independence Hall are free but you have to get them at the visitors center. Get there early because they go quickly particularly on the weekends. Even farther north is the National Constitution Center which has everything you would want to know about the US Constitution.

Not to be missed while you're in Philadelphia. This is the place to see the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall across the street. Go on line the day before (or sooner) and reserve your ticket so you'll know when you can get in to Independence Hall, and won't have to wait around all day (there is a small ~$1.50 per person on-line service fee, but he ticket is no charge) ... and before your allotted time, leave a 1/2 hour or so to see the Liberty Bell ... amazing history!
Ease of entry (free) was not bad, but you did have to pass thru security. Tickets not required to view the bell.

They have done a fantastic job remodeling this, created a GREAT film that really helped us "see" the places and the people as it was. The park service people were helpful and took time to really give us a rundown of what we may enjoy. There were things for kids, for adults and good snacks, including healthy choices and even a few GF options. Liberty Bell in a separate covered building, get your tix inside the main building (depending on time of year). Pay attention to the interesting slave history and stories and tribal names as you wait to see the Liberty Bell. Great display inside that room too. Lovely restaurants in the area, and plenty of places for kids to run.

Since this was my first visit to Independence Hall and the Liberty bell in years, much has changed. The visitors center is very nice and much needed. Tickets are needed to visit Independence Hall so arrive early to get a good time. There are abbreviated tours between 5-7 and tickets are not needed. The Liberty Bell is in a different place from my last visit, but where it is now is more appropriate. Going through security could be a hassle and slow up you visit when it is very busy.

This National Park includes many venues: Independence Hall, Carpenter's Hall, Military Museum, Ben Franklin Square, Liberty Bell, Constitution Museum, Congress Hall, Christ First Church Burial Ground (Ben Franklin & other signers). Some sites are free, while others have an entrance fee for $3-8 per person.

With Independence Hall, Congress Hall, the Liberty Bell, a visitor's center, the National Constitution Center and much, much more nearby, this area is a jewel in the National Park crown and a gift to the American people. We are fortunate that these facilities have been preserved and protected and are available to we the people to tour and learn about what occurred here. We took a couple of days to tour this area. Tickets are needed, free though they be, to tour Independence Hall and are available in advance and on a limited basis at 8:30 am at the Visitor's Center.

Lots to see in the area...plan ahead and have a general idea of what you want to see before you go. I also recommend paying the online ticket fee of $1.50 a person to guarantee you get to see inside Independence Hall. Another tip...don't carry a lot of "stuff" or large bags and security lines will go quickly...this benefits you and the people behind you.

Very peace full. Go see some sites then sit and relax in the park if any thing to reflect on the history and plan the rest of your day. Don't forget to stop in at the T shirt shop on your walking tour after Christ Church. Prices are great.

The park is well maintained and easy to get around, The visitor center has all the information and gift store. The Liberty Bell is across the street, Parking available but if you have a van with a top storage it is too high to get in the lot, have to go across the street to other lot. Tickets for Independence hall here for free. Bought the PHLASH tickets here it is the purple bus and does the main tourist sites every 15 minutes, were able to get on and off very quickly and easily to the sites.

Learned about the Declaration of Independence and the constitution. The tour starts with you in 1 room sitting for a 5-7 minute background and then you get into 2 other rooms. After that you can see an early version of the Dec of Independence and Constitution. It's a national park and requires free tickets for the tour. You can reserve tickets online for a convenience fee of $1.50 each or get free tickets at the visitor center in the mornings. You take a chance on weekends to get them. They say pick up your tickets 45 minutes ahead of time to give you time to walk the block and go through security. Once inside you're asked to stand in line 30 minutes ahead of your time. They do that so if there is room available ahead of your scheduled time, you can get in on an earlier tour. We had a 1pm timeslot but got in at 12:30. The Liberty Bell is outside of the Independence Hall compound between the Visitor Center and Independence Hall. You can determine if the line is short enough to do the bell before or after your tour. There is a parking garage under the Visitor Center for a fee (paid $18 for 4 hours). Worth the proximity but I don't know what other lots charge.
This National Park is very well maintained and the Park Rangers are wonderful. Tickets are free, but they are timed, so get there early or order ahead. Wonderful place.

Excellent collection of buildings and artifacts that convey the stories of American history. Tickets for Independence Hall (Pennsylvania State House) tours are required : free for on-site walk up or reserved in advance for $1.50 per ticket--entry is by assigned time March through December. Hint: Advance reservations are highly recommended for peak tourist season or if you have a narrow visit window on a particular day. Arrive early in the day If you choose the walk-up option! There is much to see at Independence National Historical Park; give yourself plenty of time to visit.
Perfect for anyone and well worth the time and energy. Easy to get to. Park on 7th between Ranstead and Market for $7.

This 3-4 block area is chock full of historical landmarks. Plan on spending a day and see Independance hall, the liberty bell, franklins grave and much more. If it is a nice day (and it was on 12/27) I highly recomend one of the Carriage rides throughout the historic district it was only $45 for 1/2 hour and very informative
Admission is free and the bell is part of our history! Be sure to plan ahead due to the possibility of long lines.

I read the website wrong and as a result we weren't able to see the inside of Independence Hall. But we did see the Liberty Bell and Visitors Center. The line for the bell looked really long, but I'd estimate we were only in it about 30 minutes. Once you get in the door, you're kind of free to go at your own pace, and that was nice. The visitor's center had really nice rangers. They answered all of our questions and they gave the kids little Jr. Ranger booklets to fill out while we stood in line. They got a little badge at the end of the tour. There were a couple of people in period costumes and the whole square was very clean and easy to access. My only complaint is that the parking was a bit steep. It cost $20 for just over two hours. There might have been cheaper parking on the street, but we parked just under the visitors center.

Enjoyed all the history in this small area. We had to pay $36 for parking at our hotel so we just took off from the hotel and everything was right there, so much history in such a small area, it was fantastic!!!

Even if you have been here before it is well worth another visit to Independence Hall and to see the Liberty Bell. Run by the National Park Service I would recommend paying the $1.50 reservation fee and then picking up tickets at will call for the Independence Hall tour. It is a great to see where our country started and the passion and perseverance of our founding fathers. This sight sends chills up my spine each time I visit. Go!

You can reserve tickets for the tour of Independence Hall itself (the only part of Independence National Historical Park that requires a ticket) ahead of time at www.recreation.gov. There is a $1.50 surcharge, but it is well worth it, since timed tickets are distributed at the Visitor's Center on a first come, first served basis starting when it opens (8:30 a.m., I think) and apparently are often gone well before noon.
Our car got towed!! Deceiving signs !! Tow Trucks circling the block looking to tow out of towners cars, $250!! Security at exhibit very rude!! Long lines. Worth seeing once.

Right next to and across from Independence Hall. Lots of history and fact telling at this place. The grounds are beautiful and there are many groups giving tours in and around the place. Some of the buildings are free and some you must have tickets for. Tickets can be purchases at Independence Hall.

Check out the national park website ( siign up for a password to access and use in the future) for the "reservation, timed" tickets which lets you into the roped off cluster of buildings, access to the park itself and buildings, a ranger 30 min guided tour and access to the other buildings ( Congress hall, building where a copy of the Declaration and Constitution and inkwell are kept) ..all for a $1.50 each ticket reservation fee. Entrance is free, but you need this entrance ticket to the "park" itself or you can't get anywhere near the buildings , only can view from across Chestnut street or behind the guildings from the park. Getting the reserved tickets lets you choose when you will visit, and also saves you from waiting in what can be a huge line , especially if there are large groups of schoolchildren in the visitors Center. Note: The Visitors Center is about 2short blocks north ...all on Independence Mall. The rangers who lead the 30-person tours are informative and more than willing to answer questions, but you need to have done a bit of Americqn History homework to know what to ask. The tour of the Declaration House and congress house are not to be missed as the "plans" for the very existence of America were discussed, writtn and signed in the very rooms you stand in.

Birthplace of Liberty. Visit the actual buildings and streets where it all began. Feel the history as you walk amongst churches and buildings where our fore fathers walked. take in the reenactments and meet Ben (Franklin) and Thomas (Jefferson). see the Liberty Bell. (Free, timed tickets for entrance to to some attractions)

Took the tour last year and I'm glad I did, this place is the real deal, it happened here and if your an American, don't miss the chance to see the place our great country was born. If you don't get something out of a visit to Independence National Historical Park then something is wrong with you. It is all a lot smaller than I had envisioned, but happened here is really big, be sure and take a carriage ride the Historic District, the carriage drivers are very knowledgeable and it's worth the $'s all in all I would do it again, the Liberty Bell is also a great place to visit, it's right across the street.

Visiting the Liberty Bell is free but be prepared that you may have to wait in line outside with no shade - on a very hot day it can be brutal! Tickets for Independence Hall are free, but require pick-up at the visitor's center across the way. Again, perhaps it is my fault for not being prepared, but on a hot day it is brutal to have to walk back and forth trying to figure out how to get in to these places!

I think that Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell are places that every family should take time to see. Make sure that you reserve your tickets to go into Independence Hall. They only cost $1.50 each, and reserve you a timed entry ticket to get in. This can be done online. Make sure you get in line to see the Liberty Bell well before 5:00. They will close the doors, even whey people are in line. At 3:45 daily, in the park behind Independence Hall, there is an interesting reenactment that children love. Some kids are even asked to participate.

The tour is free but be warned, you must have tickets and they are distributed in the morning and are usually gone well before noon. We found this out our first day and opted to reserve online and pay $1.50 per ticket to select our time. We arrived at 10am, picked up our tickets and headed to the Liberty Bell. The line was short at this time but we noticed throughout the day, it was very long. It's definitely a must see thought! The tour of Independence Hall is well organized but a bit rushed. It was awe-inspiring to be in the same room that our founding fathers had debated and adopted the Declaration of Independence and Constitution. I must say that our guide, Ranger Eric Knight was the BEST guide that I have ever experienced. He truly made you think and appreciate the significance of what we were experiencing. Throughout the park, the park rangers have trading cards for the kids who answer historical questions. Great way to make learning fun. If in Philly, this must be on your to-do list!

If your visiting Philly you must visit the historical park. Start at the visitors center and sign your kids up for the jr ranger program. You then gravel around the park complete the workbook then at the end if the day they get sworn in and receive jr ranger badges for FREE. Tickets to independence hall can be reserved on line or just que up at the visitors center for a timed ticket. Make sure to leave time to tour Christ church were you'll find Ben franklins grave (bring pennies to make your wish) and Francis Hopkinson the designer of our flag. Wear comfortable shoes bring a backpack and water. It's a lot of walking !

There are many more things to see at the historical park other than Independence Hall and the Liberty Bell. There are the First and Second Banks of the United States, Carpenters' Hall where the first Continental Congress met, a few historical houses. All of the park itself is free but places place Christ Church Burial Ground costs around $2 per head to enter. All in all it is a great park with a lot of history.

The Liberty Bell exhibit is really good. Take the time to read the exhibits leading up to the actual bell. Independence Hall was great to see, but our tour guide was sort of lame. The guide at the Congressional Hall right next door was excellent, and we really enjoyed that tour! Don't miss the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution in a small building right next door. It's also nice to see some of the preserved houses nearby and to learn about what life was like back then. Great time, and I don't consider myself to be a history buff. Don't forget to book tix for Independence Hall in advance. There is just a $1.50 per ticket reservation fee, but otherwise it's free.
location: washington DC, District of Columbia, USA

text: went to the NPS visitor center early and got the first tour of independence hall. Very nice. So worth it. Tickets are free

A little advance planning will go a long way when visiting the park. Tickets are needed to visit Independence Hall and can be obtained (free) at the visitor center two blocks away. Get your tickets first before doing any other sightseeing, we couldn't visit the day we were there because the next available time was hours later.

Independence Historical Park is a MUST SEE for any American and for any tourist with the desire to tour essential American history. It is FREE, but touring Independence Hall requires a timed tour ticket. They can be reserved online for $1.50 a piece, but otherwise are free if you pick them up at the Visitor's Center.
I paid the $1.50 for the reserved tickets for the tours. The visitor center was air conditioned and was a welcome relief from the heat.

First, it's worth the effort to get tickets (just a few dollars) in advance through the national parks site! (http://www.recreation.gov). Second, it's worth planning an unusual time to visit in order to have smaller crowds, instead of just walking up. It happened that our party of 3 did a Sunday morning at 9:30 a.m. We were in line by 9 a.m. with our tickets, and the park ranger let us in early, because the 9 a.m. group wasn't full. We had an excellent guide and enjoyed the tour, which was about 30 minutes. We also came out at about 9:30 to find a very short line for the Liberty Bell at that hour. The guides were all helpful and knowledgable. One of the best parts of the experience was touring/ lining up with people from around the world to visit this World Heritage site. It's easy to take for granted what happened here. Puts it in perspective when you realize people from around the world find it noteworthy.
Enjoyed the tour. Make sure you get tickets ahead of time so you can choose your time for tour. Only $1.50 a ticket. http://www.nps.gov/inde/planyourvisit/feesandreservations.htm
You need to establish this as your headquarters in Philly. There is a parking garage, all day is $12, you can catch the subway from here, plus there is lots to see and do just by walking around.

If you come to Philadelphia, get off the big bus and walk around Independence Park, the Liberty Bell, the National Constitution Center. Soak up the stories that the Park actors tell you about our country's history. It's fun - and for the most part, free! The Constitution Center costs $, but is worth it.

I spend a few $ to book the tickets advance but I learned that It's not hard to get the tickets on the day for free. The guide I had was a young man doing this as a volunteer. He was very good and had passion about what he does. The tour itself was only 30 min but it was amazing to be in the same place where the history was made.
But I thoroughly enjoyed the presentation and tour of Independence Hall. The narrative was interesting and the delivery was excellent. Tickets were easily reserved in advance on-line.

Philadelphia is a city, and with common sense and comfy shoes, it is a safe and insightful place to be. We felt safe walking in this area. Street parking is scarce and limited, so plan to park in a parking garage and expect to pay $15-$25. Obvious stops include the Liberty Bell and Constitution Center and the US Mint (if it is open). But, get that free map and explore the easy to follow streets to get to other sites. Betsy Ross's house was fun ($5 pp) but small.(steps/close quarters). The 2nd National Bank is a gallery of portraits. The grand steps and columns are inviting. We didn't know many of the faces, but one portrait of a young girl is the inspiration for the American Girl doll Felicity's party dress. Ben Franklin is everywhere including statues and his grave.

By all means see the Liberty Bell. It is housed in its own building with a ton of information to see while you wait to see the bell. Tickets and reservations are NOT necessary. The bell is positioned so that when you take pictures of it, there is a clear glass wall which shows Independence Hall where it use to reside. Very inspiring. " Proclaim liberty throughout all the Land unto all the Inhabitants thereof \."

A visit to Independence Hall should be on every Philadelphia visitor's list of must-see attractions. Tickets are free and are available at the Visitor's Center. When you stand in line for tickets, there will be a sign that tells you what time the next available tour is--usually 2 hours ahead. For example, we arrived at 11:45 a.m. and they were giving out tickets for 1:45 p.m. and it was well worth the wait. You must go through security before entering--very similar to an airport screening. Also, you have to be there a half hour before your tour time. When the tour starts you are taken into a room where a park ranger gives you a talk. Afterwards, you follow him/her to other parts of the building where you see where the Declaration of Independence was signed and the Articles of Confederation were written. The last stop involves going to a room on the top floor that was once used as a ballroom.

NP Guides are terrific, exhibits are well done and the NP Guides go out of their way to ensure that when there is a "sold out" ticket situation if there is space people who don't have tickets can get in on a stand by basis. There's no charge for tickets it is just for crowd management. Nice job with our tax dollars! Money well-spent. So interesting to see all the non-US visitors who are so interested in our story of Independence.
Didn't like the fact that there were steep admission fees. The Liberty Bell was free to see. We even paid to see Ben Franklins grave site (but only $2).

We parked in a garage for $7 - 12 hours (Sunday) a block west of the visitor center, and roamed all around for about nine hours. Loved the visitor center (new since 1998 for me), both free movies (30 and 20 minutes), new(ish) Liberty Bell museum and exhibit, of course Independence Hall and Square tours, etc. Bummed it was $10 to enter Franklin Court museum but we spent a lot of time there and it was worth it, including the print shop demo. Per "award winning" advice, walked into Sonnys for authentic cheesesteak sandwiches (rather than driving to original locations further away), not disappointed. Good maps, flyers, signs, etc. A great place to spend a long day immersed in early American history, taking sit-down breaks for movies, food, etc.

Feeling the magnitude of time in this cave was one of the most rewarding and grounding experiences I have had in a while. We did the tour with the National Park Ranger, who was both entertaining and knowledgeable. Highly recommend checking Jewel Cave out!

Take the one hour and twenty minute "Scenic" tour. It'll cost you $12 but it's well worth it. You descend and climb over 700 steps so you're getting some much needed exercise after sitting on your butt in your car traveling around the Black Hills. As caves go, this isn't the most exciting but it is the third longest in the world.............bet, you didn't know that. Visit the cave and learn more amazing facts. Bring a jacket and wear boots if you got em.

The wild cave tour is only offered a few days a week and requires advance reservations and some serious prepping (ankle high boots, real elbow and knee pads, clothes that can be trashed...) but our group had a blast with the challenge and were glad we went. First you get to squeeze through the concrete block tube to make sure you'll fit through the narrow bits of the cave (8.5 x 24 inches), then you strap on a helmet with a headlight (provided) and hop in an elevator. The group size is limited to five people per tour, and it took us about 3 hours 15 minutes, plus clean up, but they allow up to four hours. Cost is $31 per person. You will come out covered in greasy black manganese, so plan to pitch your clothes. Heads up: this tour is not for everyone. You'll need some flexibility and confidence in your body, since you'll be army crawling and chimneying across crevasses and using knotted ropes to ascend inclines and slithering up and down slippery rock faces while lying completely flat on your belly. I'm a fifty year old lady, though, and my youngest daughter is 16, and we both loved the challenge. Also be aware that those with a fear of heights could struggle at times, something my other daughter didn't anticipate in a cave. Also, other tours better cover the history and geology of the cave; you will see rare formations, and have a real caving experience, but this is mostly about the physical challenge. If you love unique, small-group tours and a little adventure, you'll love this tour! Tips: don't skimp on the pads, get elasticised ones if you can, and don't worry about the chill, you will be working hard enough to be comfortable in a long-sleeve tee.

We were in the area primarily to spend a full day at Wind Cave National Park, but we got in early enough the afternoon before that we drove out to Jewel Cave and were able to go on the last cave tour of the day. Interesting history and formations inside. Would love to have explored the above-ground portion of the park as well but it was too late in the day. Note that the tour we took is usually $6 per person but if you have a National Park Annual Pass it is free (even though this is a Monument, not a Park).
We went out of our way to go to Jewel Cave, thinking we'd take advantage of our National Parks & Monuments Pass, only to find that they don't apply at this location.

Tickets are first come first serve and sell out fast I went at 9am and half the tours were already sold out. We got a 3:30 tour ended up stuck with a family reunion who would keep quit and made it hard to hear the guide which was upsetting him. He was very pushy on not taken pictures unless he said we could it felt very controlled and rushed but the gave was neat

The only way to see the cave is on a tour. You cannot buy tour tickets ahead of time, you must be at the on site ticket booth the day you want to do a tour. The 'Scenic tour' is 1.25 hours, $12 for adults. We arrived at 8:45am (ticket office opens at 8:00am), we got to the window at 9:45, the earliest ticket available was 4pm. So we bought tickets then left to see MT Rushmore, drive over Iron mountain Rd to Custer State Park, had lunch at the State Game lodge and easily returned by 3 for our 4 pm tour. 49 degrees in cave , have a jacket and closed toe shoes. Lots of metal stairs, very deep and dark. If you enjoy caves this one is impressive. This National Monument has a very detailed website regarding what to expect.

We had a bunch of little ones with us, so we were only able to do the "discovery tour." It's $4 for each adult and departs every couple hours. Make sure you get there a while before, as it is first come, first served. You can NOT make reservations.
