We got there and missed the tour, so we hung out at the visitor's center (which was interesting to learn about the cave!), and then hiked around on the trails behind the visitors center while we waited. You need to arrive for your tour 15 minutes before to meet with your guide. Then you go down an elevator for about 30 seconds into the cave. There are spotlights inside shining on some of the spectacular parts. The discovery tour keeps you right in the cavern you enter while the guide tells you all about the history of the cave and its discovery. He also passed around samples of limestone, stalagmite?, and another rock piece. When he shines the flashlight on different parts of the cave you can see them shimmer. I was in shorts/tshirt and while cool, was not cold. Though most people did have a sweatshirt with them to stay comfortable.

I was passing by this place on my way to Rapid City, SD via the scenic route and just had to stop and satisfy my curiosity. I will say it was worth the time spent, about an hour, though you can spend more, I was kind of in a rush. I had missed the longer tours of the day so had to settle for the shorter main chamber tour which gave an overview of how the cave was found and how they excavated it and created the visitor center eventually. If I had the time I would have returned the next day for the longer tour which takes you through several chambers but I had a schedule to keep, sigh. In any case the main chamber still shows many interesting geological examples of how caves form, and the ways the earths geological formations are made. If you give yourself a few hours you could take some short hikes around the visitor center and see the original opening to the cave and some other nice trails that are there, even do a picnic, great for families. The admission prices are quite reasonable, only needed if you do a tour, otherwise the visit is free, you can also make a donation (I threw in an extra $5). There is a small gift shop that has many neat things for the whole family but mostly for young ones, but I think they are the ones who get the most out of these experiences. So if you are ever passing through South Dakota, near Rapid City/Mt. Rushmore try to check out Jewel Cave it is an hour or three well spent!

This was a very cool thing to do while in South dakota! We did the 2hr tour and it was fairly cheap, only $12 per person i believe. We didn't have a problem getting a tour, we showed up about 15min before it started and got a spot just fine. It is cold down there so bring a jacket!!

We spent a half day at the Jewel Cave. Nice visitors center with exhibits about the history, geography and geology of the cave. We took the Scenic tour. One hour and twenty minutes. Cost $12.00. Quite a few stairs to negotiate. Very interesting Parks guide who provided lots of information about the cave and was very entertaining. Highly recommended.

Tickets go fast. If you're in any decent shape at all you won't have any problems. I did not go on the candle or wild cave tour. If you have problems with stairs or getting around this is probably not for you. Don't forget a lite jacket or maybe a wind breaker.

Get here early! Tickets go on sale at 8:00am. We arrived at 7:40am and there were about 20-25 people already lined up to purchase tickets. We were able to purchase tickets for the 9:00am Scenic Tour, which is about 1 hr. 15 min. and has over 700 stairs. Don't let the stairs scare you away! Many of the stairs go down and there are plenty of flat areas to walk on.

We spent a week in the Black Hills in June 2016 and went to both caves- Jewel and Wind. While they each offer a unique cave experience, Jewel cave was by far my favorite. Just trying to fathom the size is awe-inspiring. The ranger who led the tour was knowledgeable, funny, and friendly. As a bonus, our 4th graders had an 'Every Kid in a Park Pass' that got the entire family in for free! What a deal!

Discount for seniors with national park pass and military discount. Strenuous walking. I was having to pay attention to walking so much, it was difficult to enjoy the cave. Not as good as Carlsbad but nice to see on a rainy day.

We took the discovery tour which was about 1 hr and 30 minutes long. Our group had a range of ages from 7-73 and everyone had a blast. Our tour guide was amazing. But please note there are LOTS of stairs and while there are stops along the way if you can't climb stairs you should not do this tour. Price was great. Also, get there very early since you can't buy tickets ahead of time they sell out fast. We went there bought tickets for a later time and went back to see crazy horse and did lunch it worked out great!

We just did the initial cave entry 20 minutes. Ride and elevator down 23 stories and look around. This was free for our daughter and only $4 for the adult. The longer tours are only a little bit more. Worth the effort to get there.

We took the Discovery Tour - which included a ranger explaining the cave and showing the main room in the cave at the bottom of the elevator. We lucked out and had a personal tour with the ranger - which made it quite interesting. If you have the Senior Pass, this tour is free. Check the website for times that the tours are offered.

It's literally in the 40's on the cave tours, so dress accordingly. Tours are scheduled on a first come, first served basis so you have to plan and be prepared to wait. Getting there at opening time is your best bet. The cave formations (cave bacon!) and the briskly paced guided tour are well worth the time (just about an hour) and nominal fee ($12). There are a number of stairs to navigate but any reasonably mobile guest can maneuver them. This site provides an interesting contrast and different features than those found in Wind Cave NP. Teddy Roosevelt cared enough to secure this national treasure so we could all appreciate the grandeur of this enormous hidden frontier beneath the Black Hills!

I had never done a cave tour, so I was excited for this. We were not let down. Price is great, tour leader was very good, tour was interesting, and plenty of formations and cave aspects to see. Makes me want to do more cave tours. I'd you are interested in a cave tour I'd definitely say this is a good one. We did the longer scenic tour.

There are several tours offered but the most popular is the 1 1/2 hour ScenicTour for $12/Adult. You tale the elevator down and then walk up and down Aluminum steps through calcite crystals on all the walls in huge chambers. There are other crystal formations to see and the Ranger guides do an excellent job explaining the cave system to the visitors. The tour route is lighted but BRING YOUR OWN TORCH (flashlight) so you will be able to see the formations better as you walk by them. Also bring good shoes and a light jacket. The exhibits in the visitor center are very informative while you are waiting. There are also some hiking trails to enjoy the topside scenery. Hell's Canyon is one we hiked.

What a fun trip below the earth's surface to a maze of tunnels. This cave is amazing with miles and miles of tunnels but they have projected that less than 10% of the cave has been mapped. It is the 3rd largest cave in the WORLD! There are no self-guided tours here. In the summer, wait times between purchasing your tickets and your tour time can be over 4 hours so arrive early. Tours can fill up by 12 pm daily. Wear warm clothes because it is chilly (49 degrees) in the cave. Also, wear comfortable walking shoes (no flip flops!). They allow cameras but no camera cases or purses or walking sticks. We took the Scenic Tour (Adults $12, Youths $8 and Seniors $6) that went down an elevator and then went up and down walkways and stairs (750) so don't take this tour if you can't do stairs. My husband can't so he took the 20 minute Discovery Tour (free for Seniors and $4 for adults). Kids 5 and under not allowed.

We enjoyed our trip to Jewel Cave. We took the hour and half cave tour. Most of the walking was downhill on stairs and dark passageways. A small portion of the downhill descent was steep. Our tour guide was very knowledgeable and informative. The visitor center itself was a little unimpressive. I think you would definitely have to do one of the tours to truly appreciate the cave. There was some interesting formations, like the popular bacon formation, however, I think I expected more "jewels" with a name like Jewel Cave. There wasn't a lot of stalagmites or stalactites compared to other caves. I think it was well worth the $12/person admission. The tickets are available first-come first-serve. We arrived around 9:30 am and were able to get on a 10am tour without a problem.

Take a jacket, it's pretty cold down there. It's not the coolest cave we've been in but it was worth the price of admission (free with our National Park Pass). I wasn't expecting that many stairs, but it was manageable (most were heading "down")

We visited this during peak season. The caves are fun to see and the tour guides are great. The only draw back is they are really busy, and limit the tours to 30 people. We arrived before 9:00 am and most of the tours were sold out. They said people start lining up at 7:30 am to get tickets. Tickets are sold same day only, so keep this in mind when planning your visit.

Tickets are sold on a first come / first serve method with no reservations for the regular tours. We arrived at the park at 8 am and still didn't make the first tour at 9. Cave tour was excellent - 1 1/2 hours long and a very chilly 49 degrees, so bring a sweater. Also, no pets allowed and way too hot to leave in the car. Well worth the visit!

Visited Jewel cave midweek. Got there around 10:30 but tours were sold out until 3. A little drive to get there to find out you have to come back. Not sure if you can call ahead to make reservations, but that would be helpful. Be forewarned, the tours fill up fast in the morning even on what one might assume are slow days. Came back to a full tour. Here's one downside of the whole visit; Some tour groups get the Park Ranger and others get a volunteer leader. We got a volunteer and she was not very good. Needed a little more maturity to lead a group. Seemed like she stalled all along the trail with long periods of silence or babbling so as to extend the tour. You could see people were ready to move on and yet she just stood around. Sights were good and its a great tour if you have never been in a cave. It was their middle tour in regards to sights, time and activity. Worth the time and $'s. Need a jacket as it gets cool. Solid shoes as well, as some spots can get slippery. Seemed to be OK for kids. Unless you are REALLY claustrophobic, it should not be a problem.

Having visited Mammoth Cave, I was expecting more from this tour. Don't get me wrong, it was interesting (the Scenic Tour), but I was hoping to see more "jewels," which you only see on the 4-hour tour. Like many people stated, it's best to get there early. We arrived at 9:20 am and were the last 5 tickets for the 11:20 am tour (2 hours later and the next tour would have been noon). There isn't much to do while waiting (you could take a hike, but would need to make sure you're back in time for the tour). The nice thing is that they take only about 30 people on each tour (hence the quick sell outs), making it enjoyable. The price is reasonable (I think maybe $10-$11/person). Our volunteer tour guide was good and shared interesting information. Side note…apparently there was an awful forest fire back in 2000 (arson) that destroyed thousands of acres of forest in and around the park. Reforestation is taking place now and remarkably making progress.

Fantastic place to visit. A must if you are anywhere in the area. Tickets sold only “day of” so go early as they will sell out quickly. Amazing tour visiting a cave that’s a completely different experience than the Wind Cave (also a must). I must warn you that there are a lot of steps (723 to be exact)… mostly down, but some areas that you have to go up. A few elderly folks on our tour were not really up for it. At the end take an elevator to the top. VERY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED

We came to the cave on a rainy day of our vacation. While arriving early, the scenic tours were booked for several hours. Our kids convinced us to kill time on the lantern tour while we waited. This tour enters the original cave entrance and is lit only by oil lamps that you carry. It is not showy. Rather, it is a replication of what the first tours of this cave were like. It was awesome! Narrow passages, low ceilings, excitement. We were greatly disappointed with the scenic tour that followed. If I went again, I would only spend my $ on the lantern tour.

We toured this cave twice with different sets of relatives and both tour guides were absolutely stellar both in their knowledge of the cave and their enthusiasm. The "mini-museum" is not to be missed, either. We took the 90 minute tour both times and it was well worth the price of admission ($12 each). Even the giftshop was superior with it's wide selection of area books, learning materials and toys for every age level, toddler to adult.

We went on the short tour because I'm not able to walk down and up 732 steps to see the long tour...it was only $4 for short tour and FREE for us, because we have a Senior National Park Card...but, the short tour was not even worth FREE. We were taken down to the cave in an elevator and got out on a platform...the docent talked for fifteen minutes or so...but, we could not see anything except the cave room we were in and then taken back up in the elevator. I was really disappointed...They had a long jeep to take us WAY DOWN to the building ... there is MUCH construction in the parking lot. They have nice rest rooms and a snack building with machines...we were hungry, so hit the machines.

The scenic cave tour was amazing. Our tour guide was very knowledgable and genuinely enthusiastic about the cave and her job, and it showed. The scenic tour was well worth the $12. Make sure to get there about 30 minutes early to give time to take the shuttle to the visitors' center, since the parking lot is under construction.

As with every National Park or Monument I have ever visited, I have another rave review for this site. The rangers are always completely professional and knowledgeable, the sites are always in perfectly maintained condition, even the gift shop is nice--your tax dollars are well spent! We did the standard 1 1/2 hour tour which did involve some stair (and ramped area) climbing, but it is generally split up with only a few slightly strenuous areas. Most of our 60 or so age group had no problems (there are frequent breaks where the ranger will point out certain formations) but there was at least one man in our group who was a little too overweight and out of shape to manage the climbs very well--he was panting and sweating by the end--so do be aware of your physical abilities--it you can't do 2 flights of steps at once (and this only happens 1 or 2 times), do yourself a favor and just do the short visit to the great room. That said, there were many others over 60 and maybe even 70 who did fine. The cave itself is really cool--great lighting of the formations (of course they turn off the lights in one spot so you can see what total darkness is), the walkways are Trex with railings, damp in some spots but not wet or slippery like some caves, and the walkways are usually really large and well carved out, so claustrophobic people should not have problems either. And the cave itself is worth it--not many stalagmites or stalactites, it is filled with different cave formations, including a perfect strip of giant cave bacon! We missed Wind Cave, but I'm sure it is also a great site--a lot of people recommend seeing both, and I'm sure you wouldn't be disappointed there either! Please go to at least one of the caves!

Traffic and park phone issues took away from enjoying this trip as it took us two days to get in the cave. The tour was good and informative. You see a lot, but not a whole lot of color ( though more than Wind Cave). Price wise it is very reasonable.

During the winter months the rangers only offer two types of tours. There is a brief 20 minute tour offered at 9:05, 12:45 and 3:45. We took the hour and twenty minute scenic tour which is offered at 10 and 2 costing $8. I would call a head and confirm the tour times. The rangers were all very nice. Our guide was Kate who was very interesting and really knew all about the cave. This tour does have a lot of stairs but it's not strenuous. Since we were there in December, we were the only ones on the tour. I really like visiting National Parks during the winter months. They are less crowded and the rangers are more laid back without large crowds to deal with. Being winter, the 49 degrees in the cave was about the same temperature as outside. If you are visiting during the summer you may want to bring along a light jacket.

This was one of the highlights of our trip. It is almost an hour and a half long with a park ranger providing the running commentary. It was a fascinating tour, filled with interesting facts about the cave and the crystals inside. The fee of $12.00 is well worth it.

Great opportunity to visit the first national monument. Finding connecting caves causes this cave to cycle between the second and third longest cave ever discovered. We went on the most popular tour which was perfect for our entire family. They have various options depending on your desires to cave. Only down side is that tickets must be purchased in person at Jewel Cave. I called from Custer, SD and was told that there were 19 tickets remaining for the last tour, but I needed to head directly to Jewel Cave. They could not hold the tickets or take payment over the phone. We traveled from Custer to Jewel Cave to learn that there were only there remaining tickets when we arrived. We had a party of six and we all wanted to go....That was disappointing!!! The next morning we went there first thing and were able to get tickets no problem. Could be a problem for someone traveling farther that 20 minutes!! This is something that the NPS needs to address. Otherwise it was one of our highlights of a great family vacation!!

We read the descriptions of the available tours and decided to take the Lantern Tour. I can't believe it only cost $8. It was easily worth 10 times that much. Nicole, our tour guide did a great job and led us through the very dark and challenging caves to both the "Heavenly Room" and to the "Dungeon". If your guide only lets you choose one, the Dungeon adventure is really really amazing and memorable. Make sure that you do not being mind dark, tight places as it is both. You will need to be in pretty good shape with a sense of adventure. It is one of the coolest things I've ever done!

We had a great time touring Jewel cave this past weekend. We took the hour and twenty minute tour with our grandson. Tickets were on a first come first serve basis and we only waited about an hour for the next tour. Great guide, terrific tour, but not for the out of shape, the tour is only a half mile walk but also has 700 plus steps. We are senior citizens (in good walking shape) and our eight year old grandson toured with us. This is a do not pass attraction, total cost for two adults and one child, twenty dollars. Best bargain in all the Black Hills.

At only $8 an adult, this was a great tour. We went Oct 3rd and there was only 8 of us on the tour, we did not have to call ahead for reservations. With a small tour group we were able to go slower and learn more about the cave. Our tour guide, Melissa, was fun and knew her stuff. She tried to get everyone involved in the tour. The views in the cave are absolutely breathtaking.

It's a very large cave, so for those of you that are claustrophobic, I don't think you'll have an issue. I don't like enclosed spaces, but I didn't even really think too much about it when I was in there cause there's so much room around you, and it's well lit. The tour guide was awesome. Her name was Lydia, and she was extremeley knowledgable. She answered every question that was asked and spent a lot of time teaching and sharing personal caving experiences she has had. Great tour, only $8, tour groups leave often throughout the day. It lasts somewhere between an hour and an hour and twenty minutes. Jewel Cave is a little off the beaten path, but worth the trip :)

Awesome tour and a great price. It was just $20 for one adult, 3 kids over 6 and one under 6. This is one of the best bangs for your buck in the Black Hills area. We did the Scenic Tour which runs about an hour and a half.

I've never been to a cave before, but this one seemed to be quite professionally set up. We took the moderate tour and that lasted 1.5 hours. There are lots of steps. We took an elevator down 240 feet and then started the tour! Everyone in our family enjoyed this, there were about 30 people in our group and that did not seem to be too many people. We especially were happy to get out of the 100 degree heat. It is 50 degrees down there and close to 90% humidity. The trail is all aluminum no-slip steps, and rough concrete paths. I didnt see anyone fall or even come close to that. you do want to make sure you use the restroom facilities before going... checking that your kids do too!(our 8 year old was really, really wanting to get to the surface after about 1 hour!) Also, this is a very good deal when considering how much everything costs around here. This was only $8 per person, NOTHING else so far has been less than $10 in the black hills area.
Tickets completely sell out early in the day. Buy early if you plan on touring. Take a jacket on the tour, as cave temps are 49F.

You must make a reservations. Phone: 605-673-8300 8:30 and 4pm. They fill up quickly. They only have so many tours a day. Make sure you call ahead and make those reservations. The tour we took in the second largest cave in the world (JEWEL CAVE) was the scenic tour. It last about one hour and twenty minutes. Make sure you wear something warm. It is about 40 degrees in the cave. There are about 720 stairs you climb up and down. They do have plat forms that you can rest at. The trip is about 3/4 of a mile. Even though the trip is a little strenuous it is well worth it. You don't even notice the hour and twenty minutes going by. They have an elevator that that takes you down to the cave. Also, wear tennis shoes. The floor is slippery at certain points. Hold on tightly to the rails. Children five and up will love it. There is a fee of $8.00 per person. Not a bad price for what you get to see.

Tickets are sold out early in the morning and so we wound up securing ones for 3 hours after our arrival (first available). We visited Crazy Horse memorial in between...that worked out well but of course, it is extra driving. There were too many steps for me to attempt the scenic tour but my teeneage grandson said it was the best part of our trip to South Dakota. I went on the discovery tour so I could at least get into the cave. It was okay but could be expanded to at least 3 "rooms" even with small children, etc. Don't forget to use your Senior Natl Park pass for discounts and remember to not plan to eat there. Vending machines yield terrible food.

Stopped by Jewel Cave National Monument on our way to Mt. Rushmore; we're glad we did. Turns out Jewel Cave is the second longest mapped cave in the world. We took the Scenic Tour($8 each for adults); the tour is about 90 minutes long, with a park ranger as guide. Pretty amazing sights; would recommend

Had been to wind cave a few days earlier. This is a totally different experience. The cave has very large rooms and seemed a lot more open. Several different types of cave things to see. Cave bacon, popcorn, and eggs. Tour guide was great. Lasted about 1hr 20 minutes. Everyone had a great time and worth the $$$ to see this.

Take time to visit Jewel Cave, the 2nd longest cave in the world, if you are in the Black Hills area on vacation. Jewel Cave offers several different tours. The Scenic Tour (only $8 for adults) is one of the most popular and fills up quickly. You can call ahead to reserve/purchase tickets which I highly recommend. The scenic tour lasts about 1 1/2 hours and involves walking up and down 723 stair steps over a 1/2 mile loop, equal to about 40 flights of stairs. Some of the stairsteps are steep but overall it's very easy and not strenous. On this tour you'll see two types of calcite crystals, nailhead spar and dogtooth spar, which are the what Jewel Cave is known for. You'll also see formations of boxwork, flowstone, cave popcorn, draperies, stalactites, stalagmites and a long ribbon drapery that our guide referred to as cave bacon. Our guide was very knowledgeable so it made for an interesting tour. I would recommend this tour more for adults and older children. There were a few babies and young children on our tour and they became quite fussy and disturbed by the darkness shortly after the tour began.

We took the scenic tour which runs about an hour and a half. It was a great value for $20 for a family of 4. The tour was educational and fun for the whole family. Definitely call ahead to reserve tickets as the tours fill up quickly. I was worried about the 723 steps but it wasn't as bad as it sounds.

On a recent trip to South Dakota to see Mt. Rushmore and the Crazy Horse Memorial, we discovered the Jewel Cave. It is the second longest cave in the world (second to Mammoth Cave in Kentucy) and if it is ever completely explored may well be the longest. The half-mile tour (which includes the over 750 steps) shows many different features of the cave and is interesting for both children and adults. The Park Ranger we had really loved his job and loved the cave. It is not expensive ($8 for adults, less for children) and was a great way to spend part of a rainy day.

In the summer call ahead and reserve, I can't stress this enough! Jewel Cave is a great and cheap attraction in the Black Hills. The Scenic tour is only $8 for adults, a steal in the Black Hills as all the other attractions are a lot more. The cave tours regularly sell out so if you want to see the cave, call them before you head out to find out if there are tours still available and reserve a tour. It is so easy to do and you don't have sit around for hours waiting for your tour time, only 30 minutes. The cave is 53 miles from Rapid City but it takes a lot longer than you would think to get there. The tour itself is great, a lot of stairs but half of them are going down. And there flights are fairly spaced out so even if you can't do more than a 2 flights without getting wind you should be fine. They don't rush you through either. I've done many cave tours and this one is one of the best. The formations are interesting and you also get to see some box work which is what Wind Cave is mostly made of. If I had to pick between Jewel Cave and Wind Cave, I would pick Jewel.

Our family finally got around to seeing this and I must say I wish more attractions were worth the money paid such as this one. We also got to listen to a patio talk about the jasper wild fire which was very insightful about the damage to the local area. With five of us the price was just right at $28.

We've been in a lot of caves and this wasn't our favorite as it didn't really have anything special to it but it was nice and long and our guide made it worthwhile. He was excellent and definitely lively. we did the scenic tour in the morning (with reservations) at $8/ea.

We took the Jewel Cave Discovery Tour and it was a perfect match for two small children and a senior with walking issues. Twenty minutes down in one large room that was elevator-accessible. Very difficult getting reservations by phone--kept getting cut off and no one answered. Senior Access Pass got us tours free. Bookstore small, movie not very interesting for little ones. Not much else to do while waiting for your tour except go a little ways on trailheads. Bathrooms in small, separate building. Cave is cool--recommend jacket and jeans. We had young seasonal ranger who was very good with children, knowledgeable, and humorous. So close to Mt. Rushmore that you really need to go.

The 1.5 hour scenic tour was only $8 per person, which is a bargain in my book. Although a lot of the cave looks very similar, there are plenty of unique items throughout the cave that make the tour worthwhile. Two things to remember: 1) Its only 50 degrees F in the cave all the time, so wear pants and a jacket. 2) Call ahead to book your tickets. Only 30 people can go down per tour, so they sell out quick. If you arrive on a busy day, expect to wait several hours. There also is not a place to eat anywhere around here, so you may want to factor that in as well. The entire tour is on a paved trail, or metal walkway with railings. Very safe, even for smaller children.

Turns out you can easily travel east on US 26 from Hwy 97 in Redmond to the Painted Hills Unit, all in one day. Takes about 2 hours one way. Once you have lunch in Prineville it is an easy drive over the Ochoco Pass (4,722 ft elevation) & down into the small town of Mitchell & Painted Hills Unit.
park: John Day Fossil Beds National Monument

text: We already have a National Park Pass, so it cost us nothing to get into the museum. And the 4-hour guided bus tour was included. We were glad to make a donation to this wonderful tour, and the interesting and informative museum itself. The museum itself is worth at least an hour or two, and includes a great film. But be sure to sign up in advance for the tour, around the dam site, inside the Lodge of the Fish & Game Gang, into town, to the cemetary, etc. Only 12 passengers, and more than that tried to sign up. And if you're lucky, Nathan Koozer will be your guide ... he was extremely interesting and well-informed. Of course, other guides may be as good. Well worth the visit!

The Johnstown Flood National Memorial is about 20 minutes northeast of Johnsontown, PA It is located in South Fork, PA. Watch for the brown signage along the highway. The Memorial overlooks the old lake and you can drive or walk down to the old damn and the Grand Cemetery. We did not do either on our visit as it was 92 degrees that day. But would like to go back to visit the Cemetery. Be sure to watch the movie which plays every half hour. It gives a great explanation as to how and why the disaster happened and why the three warning were never delivered. On the lower level there is a wonderful electric map with narrative that helps to visualize how it all happened. (If you are a Senior you your National Parks Pass or purchase one there and use and have it for future National Parks and Memorials. .

I wanted to learn more about the Johnstown Flood and this was a great place to go to do that. They have a 30 minutes film they show, which is depressing, but gives a different perspective on the flood. There are a good many placards with information and displays to understand what all went on with the flood. The facility is very clean and well kept. It does have a small gift shop area also. There is a $5 fee for adults unless you have a National Park membership.

We did it backwards, having been to the Flood Museum in downtown Johnstown years ago. It's a great museum that mainly deals with the aftermath of the flood that killed 2200 people in the valley. This time we went to the Flood National Memorial, a National Park site that charges $5 admission. We have a Senior Pass allowing us free entry. There is plenty of parking just a few steps from the building. The Ranger will probably tell you to see the movie, and I would agree. Don't skip it! It tells the story of what led to the Johnstown Flood, which killed 2200 people in a very short time. The rest of the museum has displays which show you the topography of the land and other historical artifacts. You can also take about a 5 minute drive and see some buildings, including the clubhouse, that remain from the Flood days. Ask the Ranger for directions. We enjoyed our short visit to the Memorial and would encourage those interested to go to Johnstown and see the Museum downtown.
Tells the story of the 1889 Johnstown flood through pictures and a short 35 minute video. well worth the $5.00 admission charge. Plenty of parking available.

Fourth time here, visitor center is very impressive. They only take cash for the $5 entry fee, fortunately a member of our group had cash. The movie is depressing, the displays are interesting. It really is worth one visit only but I keep accompanying different ones that haven't been there. It is neat to walk to the overlook at the edges of where the dam was, I wish it was trimmed up a little better to see the valley floor. You don't need to pay the fee to see the overlooks and walk to the valley floor.

We accidentally stumbled upon the site of the Johnstown Memorial. We've toured the actual Flood Museum in downtown Johnstown, but never knew the actual site of the dam was still accessible for public view. Not only it is accessible, you can walk right out to the edge of where the dam broke! You will need daylight to visit this site. However, there is a Visitor's Center where you can watch a movie about the Club of the Pittsburgh well to do's, and how this tragedy could possibly have been avoided. There is a great view from the Center across the dam and down into the valley where the Clubhouse and some of the summer houses are still standing. The fee, if you're not a National Parks Passport holder is $5 cash or check! What shocked us is that they do not take credit cards at this Center. Which is a bummer because I'm sure it cuts down on the purchasing of their intriguing souvenirs and books! It was close to sunset when we found it, we are going to go back when we're in the area, and have more daylight to explore the dam site.

This park is off the beaten path but it's worth the effort to get to it. I knew about the Johnstown Flood but not as much as I learned here. There's a good film (if maybe a bit overwrought) you shouldn't miss. The displays in the center are very good. I thought the display showing the progess of the wave by using lights was especially helpful in understanding how quickly and how far the wave traveled. You can see remnants of the dam from the Center so you don't necessarily need to go anywhere but the Center but there are other vantage points around the lake for those wanting a closer look. One thing I was not happy to learn is the park's naturalist has advocated for letting the lake bed grow back vegetation so the valley will eventually look as it did before the dam was built. Apparently, this is the path the Park Service is taking, after years of cutting back brush so visitors can see the extent of the lake. I feel that once the valley has grown back there will be nothing to show visitors other than pictures. What would be the point of the Memorial after that? Why keep funding a Park site commemorating an event if the site no longer looks like it did at the time of the event? So if you're interested in learning about the flood and seeing what's left of the site after the flood you should go sooner rather than later. There is a fee of $8.00 if you enter the Visitor Center.

This venue memorializing the Johnstown Flood opened on the 100th Anniversary of the disaster. It was built by the National Park Service [seniors, your Golden Pass works here] who left the site pretty much as it was --and from the several lookouts, the disaster becomes very real. The show stopper, however, is the film in the main building. It is emotional, threatening to small children, but you'd swear it was filmed during the actual flood. A masterpiece in editing and sound --pieced from other flood films and at the same time accurate to the Johnstown event.

This memorial is about 10 miles north of Johnstown, overlooking the site of the dam that burst in May 1889, causing the deaths of over 2800 people. The dam is gone, replaced by an empty field. The indoor memorial has some pictures of the flood, audio testimony of a survivor, the names of all known victims, and a few other exhibits. It doesn't take long to walk through. There is also a film every hour on the 15, it lasts about half an hour. The film shows the real cause of the catastrophy; man's greed, and carelessness in building the dam. The film is a recreation, but very graphic, not for young children. Admission is only $4.

After our disappointing visit to the Johnstown Flood Museum, we drove several miles to the National Memorial. I told my husband that I'd just sit in the car while he went inside....since we had already wasted $15 at the museum. Turned out that since it was Veteran's Day, admission was free, so we both went inside.

Breathtaking views when you are among all unique rock formations and up high. Park entrance fee is $25, but they are going to raise the price to $75 sometime in 2018. We bought the annual pass at around $70 during our visit based on my sister in law's advice. It's good for other national parks as well. There are so many view points and hiking trails in this park. Great vistas, rocks formations and canyons everywhere and an incredible selection of hiking trails to choose from. Make sure to follow all the signs and parking rules as you may likely get a ticket if not. This is a 'must visit' National Park.

I went to Joshua Tree for the first time recently and it was great. It's a 17.5 mile drive from the west gate to Jumbo Rocks. It's like a lost world as you drive through the park. Such beauty. I setup camp and I had done a little research and knew that around 8:30 there was an event where you could look through telescopes. This would be great for anyone who is interested in space or had kids. I loved it. Got to see Saturn and the moon! Amazing. Camp was safe and they had a fire pit setup with a beach and even a small grill. Make sure to bring plenty of fire wood if you're like me. I love to have a large fire. If you're local they have a pass for a year that is 40 dollars. A one time visit is $25.

Visited this park from Washington State on May 2nd. This was much nicer than I expected. The Joshua trees and rock formations are incredible. My son went in January and was not too impressed because of the cold and snow. But April and May is a great time to visit. Wildflowers bloom in mid-April. I recommend going into the park at the Joshua Tree Visitor Center entrance on Park Blvd. off of I-62. Then follow Park Blvd. to Hidden Valley, Keys View, Sheep Pass, Skull Rock, Jumbo Rocks, and stay on Park Blvd. to the Oasis Visitor Center in 29 Palms, instead of exiting the park at Cottonwood Visitor Center. The drive to Cottonwood via Pinto Basin Road is long and tedious and not worth the views unless you want to exit to the south and maybe go to Palm Springs like we did. It makes for a long day though.

$25 entry for the car but we went on a free day, bonus! Plan your trip out before you go, know a little bit about it. We took about 6 hours to hit the basics there and take a lot of pictures of EVERYTHING. Bring water whenever you get out of the car to walk, even for a short time. If you use your phone for GPS, down the maps before you go into the park. If you get there while the visitor center is open, grab a map, it is very useful. The camping areas looked awesome. Everywhere was very clean. The picnic areas looked well maintained. The closable trash cans helped keep garbage from escaping and flying around.

Three couples set out from the Oasis visitor center, about 8 AM. Highly recommend getting there about 45 minutes to get in line for tickets to Keys Ranch. Only 25 per tour and only a few tours a day, but well worth the $5 or $10 per ticket. We stopped at most of the sites, took picnic lunch (no concessions in the park) and had an amazing experience! We hiked the loop to Barker Dam and spent 1.5 hrs. on the guided tour of Keys Ranch, with many of the structures and equipment still standing. The trip was topped off by the Cactus Garden and a beautiful display of flowers at the last area as we exited the park on the Indio side. Such a treat!

Many of the trees were beginning to bloom. We thought it would be fun to listen to U2 the Joshua Tree while driving through the Joshua Tree forest. So much beautiful scenery. I would love to go back one day and do some hiking/camping. $25 to get in per car.

Whenever we have visitors we make it a must to visit JTNP. OK, at my age I qualify for a BLM Senior Pass, so I can bring in a carload of people for free. If you come in the main gate at Twentynine Palms (recommended), stop at the Visitors Center to see the displays, find out about the plants and wildlife and pick up a free map. You can buy some souvenirs there, too.

Whether you have a few hours or a few days, the diversity of landscape and the incredible peace here are not to be missed! Although admission is $24 per car, it is well worth it. Don't forget to stop in the ranger station first for maps and advice although the rangers at the gatehouse can help as well. Several pullouts along the side of the road as well as dedicated parking lots for other areas make this park completely accessible. Don't forget to bring plenty of water and pay attention when hiking as it is easy to become disoriented. Joshua Tree is ethereal and not to be missed!

My wife and I made a one day road trip to JTNP from La Jolla, driving in through the West entrance, and exiting to the South. Stopped first at the NPS Visitor Center in Joshua Tree to buy our park pass and to get our bearings. I recommend buying your pass here so that you don't have to wait in a long line of cars to buy the pass at the park entrance itself. The Visitor Center has a café attached that sells box lunches and water (since there are no food or drink facilities in the park) but at $11 each it's pricey. I recommend stopping at the Subway counter at the Valero gas station across the highway and buying your sandwich, munchies, and drinks there instead. Once in the park we stopped at several of the pull-in exhibits along the way, and also walked around the Hidden Valley trail, Keys View, Cholla Cactus Garden, and Cottonwood Springs areas, and spending 4.5 -5 hours in the park itself. The sightseeing was wonderful, and it's interesting to see one desert filled with Joshua trees, and another filled with Cholla cacti right next door. I can see how some may get tired of seeing desert for hours on end, but I very much enjoyed the high desert and mountain scenery, and could just imagine John Wayne or Clint Eastwood riding a horse out in that landscape. Well worth the drive from San Diego!

While there's so much in Joshua Tree that you could spend a whole day exploring different parts of the merging deserts, sunrise is a particularly awe-inspiring time. If you're not camping in the park to take in the natural beauty, it's important to plan your route and commit to being there when sunrise hits - it will take you longer than you think. Decide which part of the park you want to be in for sunrise and plan to make it happen. We really wanted to see the part of the park with greater Joshua Tree viewing so we entered the west entrance from highway 62 and Park. The park entrance is unstaffed at that hour (but you'll pay on your way out) and a quick stop by McDonalds and/or Starbucks prior to entering the park will give you the essentials you need to witness the amazing desert transformation as the sun rises. Look at the projected sunrise estimate and plan on entering the park 15 minutes prior to that time to be in a scenic place to capture the moment (Quail Springs, Hidden Valley and Sheep's Pass are all great options). Not only is this an amazing time to see the park, you're first 2 -3 stops in the park will have minimal traffic compared to the volume of traffic over the rest of the day. Early risers are rewarded with a whole different experience. You can spend all day there but if you have kids, it's possible to have a great 4 hour experience before they lose steam and the heat of the day engulfs the desert.

Joshua Tree National Park is a massive protected area in southern California. It's characterized by rugged rock formations, stark desert landscapes, and the namesake twisted, bristled Joshua trees. There are 3 entrances, south, north and west. The park straddles the cactus-dotted Colorado Desert and the Mojave Desert, which is higher and cooler. The entrance fee is $25 per car, which is good for 7 days. There are many options for hiking and sightseeing. Please get out of your car and explore! You can pick up a map at the visitors center outside of the park or at the fee kiosk. The maps provided do not show distances between attractions and bathrooms in the park are not listed (they tend to be at large picnic areas). Also there are no facilities available inside the park to purchase food, water, or gas. Plan accordingly.

My wife and I drove through the park on a sunny afternoon in January 2017. We are senior citizens from the East coast, and we were tourists on vacation. We enjoyed seeing the Joshua trees, big and small, and the other vegetation of the desert. The various rock formations were nice to see. It's wonderful that these trees and this landscape are being preserved. However compared to the other scenery we encountered on our trip, such as the scenery in and around Palm Springs and San Diego, this scenery was underwhelming. While certainly beautiful, I would not say that the scenery is spectacular, but I would say that about the other areas I mentioned. Also as an example, if you have ever been to Garden of the Gods near Colorado Springs CO, a free city park featuring desert rock formations, cliffs and mountains, you would probably agree that its scenery is much better and much more noteworthy than here at Joshua Tree. I think that maybe this park is best enjoyed by hikers, but we didn't hike. At Joshua Tree I found something that was really fun, but it's something I am not supposed to do! It was the driving that I liked the best. As the driver and the husband, I greatly enjoyed the "driving experience" -- my rental car was powerful and handled well. The well-paved and well-designed twisty roads made for great sporty driving in the park. The speed limit is 25 or 35, but I enjoyed 55 a lot more. (Don't tell the police.) I was wishing I had a Porsche, but my rental car was only a Dodge Charger. We stopped the car in the park several times to take photos or look at exhibits. We also stopped into two visitor centers at the park or on the edge of the park. Not surprisingly in such a remote area, you should be aware that you will lose phone contact and internet service for approximately one hour as you drive through. However, on one of our phones, the Google Maps GPS kept working the entire time. As you drive, there are many pullovers with exhibits or signs explaining plants or natural history. There are multiple visitor centers. We suggest that instead of driving through the park for 2 hours, you might prefer to drive in for 20 minutes, turn around, and come back out. The things you will see will be just as good as seeing everything. Glad I visited once.

Famous for the Joshua Trees and the large boulder fields, this 800 thousand acre park is massive. There are 3 entrances, south, north and west. Entrance fee is $25 per car which is good for 7 days. Holders of National Park passes get in for free. Get a map at a visitor center. There are many trails and sights. Pick the ones that interest you the most. You cannot do it all in a day. Note--the maps do not show distances between sights and rest rooms in the park are not listed ( they tend to be at large picnic areas). Also there are no commercial places--no food, drinks, etc. available so make sure to bring your own, especially water.

Joshua Tree Park is so beautiful and rugged, with it's expansive landscape and hills of stacked boulders, dotted with Joshua trees and other desert vegetation. You can climb the rounded boulders, go on the numerous trails, or simply drive through stopping at different spots to enjoy this unique park. We found the best rock formations and trees along the Park boulevard from west entrance, going up to Keys Point, then through the Hidden Valley and Sheep Pass and Jumbo Rocks. We then went south on Wilson Canyon to the very pretty Cholla Cactus Garden that pops up suddenly on the barren landscape. We then came back up through the North entrance where the oasis are. You can also go out through south entrance. They are very friendly at the Visitor's center, and give you maps and point out best spots. This is a great park, just two hours from Los Angeles.

This very accessible park is just outside of 29 Palms. If you are 62 years old buy the lifetime pass for just $10 and enjoy the remaining NPS sites free of charge! Check out Skull Rock. Fill up your water bottles at the visitor center.

If you like desert topography, this park is for you! Lots of interesting markers, so be sure to stop and read! There are no stores or restaurants in the park, so plan ahead and bring what you will need in with you! At least water, water and some more water, with some food! It costs $20.00 to enter the park, so be prepared for the cost.

If you are a Senior buy the National Park Senior pass, which is $10 and is good for everyone in the car and at all National Parks. The video gave a great history and perspective about the park and the trees. We much more appreciated the "hidden valley" where the cattle rustlers kept the livestock. There are plenty of do-able hikes into the middle and around the rocks, some of which are better marked than others. We saw rock climbers, fun to watch them -some with and without equipment climbing up and scrambling over the rocks. The plant life was interesting and of course the Joshua trees are so unique, again the video added to our appreciation of these trees. The rock formations are jaw dropping, making you wonder how did certain rocks get into their current positions. It is easy to drive around to see most of the areas of the park. It is amazing how hot and dry it can be once you are on a trail - take water on your person when you start any of the hikes, hats, sunscreen, etc. It was easy for us to spend all day there, lots of great photo ops. Sadly the only night we had there was cloudy so we could not enjoy the stars!

What a fantastic national park! We loved our two days here. Your entrance fee ($20) is good for 7 days, so you can come and go as you please. Or, you can purchase an annual pass for $30. Our national park service is a bargain!

The family hiked the easy-going Cottonwood Trail and it was like being in a Flintstones cartoon - the topography here is unlike anything I've ever seen. We were lucky enough to visit when some of the cacti were in bloom (I would imagine that during other seasons it might be a bit bleak). Didn't see any animals (we really wanted to spot a ram) except for some lizards. Don't forget water and thick socks - that sand gets everywhere...and parking's kind of pricey ($20 - our tax dollars at work, I suppose).

I visited Joshua Tree National Park on a day trip with friends. I live in So Cal so it was an easy drive. The park is excellently maintained, clean, with information given to you as you enter the park. Plan to spend the day mostly driving the park... wear decent walking shoes, make sure you have food and water, and sunscreen. if you bring your dog, know the park regulations for pets. If you are a senior I'd recommend getting your senior pass for $10. before you go - otherwise there is a $20. entry fee. Regardless it's well worth the costs. It's protected land, and we all should be proud of it!
My wife and spent the day in the park, the views was great, we had fun walking the trails. The cost to enter is $20 a car in you don't have the membership.

Made the drive from downtown LA to come out here while I was visiting the West Coast. It was definitely worth the trip and so was the $20 entry fee. I was really looking forward to this part of the trip and it definitely lived up to the hype. There is so much to explore here and I can't wait to come back. Definitely drive up to Keys View and explore everything that you can.

This was my first, and hopefully not my last trip to Joshua Tree National Park. The best thing about it was there were not a lot of people in that part of the world on Christmas Day. We entered the Park in Joshua Tree and exited at 29 Palms. We paid the $20 Park entrance fee and headed toward a magnificent view called Keys View, elevation 5185 feet, where we could see Palm Springs and the Salton Sea. It was cold, so bundle up with a hat, warm jacket and gloves. We then decided to take a hike to Lost Horse Mine which is a Historical structure where 9,000 ounces of gold was mined up until 1936. The hike was moderate - about 4 miles, and not very steep. We also really enjoyed climbing on the rocks at Jumbo Rocks and it was fun to see Skeleton Rock. Great family time at Joshua Tree National Park!

We entered in from the west entrance and drove through the park exiting from the east entrance. It was a 38 mile ride and a $20 charge, which was worth it. The trails are well marked and there are a lot of climbers near the west entrance. Bring water, there is no place to purchase anything.

We entered via the Southern Entrance near the Cottonwood Visitor Center. Made our way to the Center, got our parking permit ($20). We knew our time was limited, so we opted for Mastadon Peak. It was an amazing hike, but we were a bit disappointed once we reached the peak, the sign stated "path not maintained" since it was a loop it was a bit upsetting not being to continue on. We saw some people who decided to brave it and did find their way around, we just didn't want to get caught out in the desert. We opted to backtrack the way we came.

We went to Joshua Tree National Park, as a little side trip on our vacation. I wasn't quite sure what to expect because I hadn't done much research before we went. This place was amazing though. It is quite large, so be prepared to do alot of driving. Make sure you take plenty of water too because it is hot and there is not much cellphone signal in most of the park. Many areas thoughout the park to pull over, take pictures, explore and hike. We arrived about 2:30pm and stayed till after sunset. The night sky is quite breathtaking, pitch black with just the moonlight and stars, no light pollution from city lights. We went back again the next day, since the $20 per car admission is good for 7 days. Definitely recommend this park!

Not having been there before, we decided to spend the weekend in Joshua Tree for my birthday. We rented an Air BNB and decided to do whatever trails we could in the 2 days we had. Wow. Just driving through the park is absolutely beautiful. We mostly used the west entrance and drove to the trails we wanted to hike. Don't miss Keys View at sunset. I also recommend the Skull Rock hike and the 49 Palms Oasis hike. Get started early if it's going to be hot out and you'll be fine. The park costs $20 for 7 days. If you're going to come back a lot or visit other national parks, get the $80 annual pass. We plan on going back to Joshua Tree time and again. Even if you're just visiting California, take the time to hit up Joshua Tree. There are plenty of places to stay and if you're into camping, there's plenty of that available in the park.

I love Jtree. It has to be my favorite place on earth. Where can someone who doesn't know how to climb start climbing boulders. There are many areas you can climb without gear. Pay attention to your surroundings and you might see a desert tortoise. Be sure to take the drive to cottonwood.

We spent the day in Joshua Tree National Park. We started our visit at the Oasis Visitor Center where two very friendly, helpful employees helped us to plan our day. They gave us a free park map and pointed out the best places to stop. We picked up some water (only $1 for a large bottle) and headed out on our adventure. The scenery was amazing. Be sure to take some of the short "day use only" side roads in order to get close to some of the amazing rock formations. Head down the road to Keys View overlook for a gorgeous view of desert, mountains and valley. We didn't do a great deal of walking in the park because the temperature was 103 degrees. We were somewhat concerned about visiting the park in the heat - would we be able to enjoy it? We found that short stops to get out, walk a little to see the sights, then back to the car for water and air conditioning worked well for us. There were a fair number of large interpretive informational signs at pull offs throughout the park, and I could read the signs without getting out of the car if I chose to. I would love to return during the cooler months and take some of the shorter hikes. But we really enjoyed our visit today. I highly recommend a visit to this park!

This place was amazing! It's $15 to get in the gate and that gives you access for seven days. If you plan to visit a lot of US National Parks over the year, spring for the $80 pass that gives you unlimited access to ALL parks in the US for the whole year. They have visitor's centers at each gate and a lot of the park has paved roads. I would have loved to hike more, but just had back surgery so was limited to doing small walks off of some popular pull of areas. Even those were a LITTLE strenuous, so keep this in mind. I'm also told that trails marked "moderate" are really a little more intense than that. We also returned at night to stargaze - I think it would have been amazing if not for the GLARING full moon. It was a wee cloudy, so that's also not great for stargazing. I'm willing to bet winter is the best time to see the Milky Way. But we saw a couple of planets, some popular stars and constellations, clear as day so it was worth it. The 7 year old even saw a shooting star.

There is a $15 fee per car to enter the park.which covers more than 800,000 acres in the California desert country. At various trailheads and road pullouts there are informational signs about that particular area. We stayed on the paved roads. Rock climbing seems to be a very popular activity in the park. We saw a lot of spectacular desert plants including Joshua trees, cacti, ocotillos, smoke trees, pinon pines and Mojave yuccas. Be sure to wear sunscreen and a hat and bring plenty of drinking water while you explore the park.

Joshua Tree is a beautiful place, but please don't be fooled and think that it is a hop skip and a jump from Palm Springs. It is a whole day affair..... Be sure to check the weather. We went when it was 55 degrees (in May) and it started sprinkling, and the wind was blowing so hard I couldn't even open my car door. That was a BUMMER. We went from the 10 freeway up the 62 and entered through the entrance at Park Avenue. We stopped at the visitor center and got a map and advice, and used the restrooms. There is a movie but we tired of it easily. There is affordable water sold there and very beautiful gifts, albeit a little pricey. There is a nice thrift shop next door, in case you need a jacket or just have a desire to browse for some other needed item. I bought a couple koozies to keep our waters cold and a sweatshirt because I was FREEZING! So we started driving through the park and at the first picnic stop, I didn't realize that you could drive around the back and there was a beautiful place to hike and eat and trash cans, etc. I learned that the second time when we went back during better weather. So we drove up to see the view, and it was so cold and windy I was SO HAPPY to get in the car I can't even tell you. So we just drove out of the park, but it takes a couple hours and then you are 30 miles north of where you started. So then we drove to Palm Springs and it took way over an hour to get where we were staying in Cathedral City. When we went back on that Sunday - you purchase a 7 day pass for $15 so why not go back... the park was beautiful. We took photos of trees and rocks and wildflowers and had a really nice time. It was a long drive back to LA that mothers day, but happy we went back. Have previously gone to Keyes Ranch and that was AWESOME. And of course we did take a photo of cap rock. I still don't see it, but apparently everyone else does. The camp sites looked nice but I am NOT a camper! Don't cheat yourself. Allow a full day to enjoy the park.

Drove two and a half hours from Los Angeles and glad we did! Stopped at the visitor center in the town before the park. The man there was extremely helpful and gave great tips. Stopped also at National Park entrance to purchase $15. ticket and received additional information, as well as the same places to stop, so we stopped at them. Hidden Valley was a great short trail. We spotted many rock climbers on the top of the huge granite rocks. It was amazing how varied the vegetation was along the trail. My son enjoyed climbing up many of the rocks to get a better view. We also stopped where you can look out across the desert to Palm Springs. The view was stunning. We then stopped at Skull Rock and hiked along the path as well. Give yourself plenty of time to enjoy the park, stop along the route and hike on trails. It takes about 1 1/2 hours to complete the loop, plus add in stops and hiking. We spent about 3.5 hours in the park and didn't do as much as we would have liked due to lack of time. The serenity of the park is refreshing in contrast to our crazy, hectic lives.

WOW, I was basically blown away by the boulders in this entire area. I love how they appeared to be placed carefully upon each other with each "pile" looking a bit different. I can't believe how many photos I took of rocks! They are much more impressive in person and this park with its paths and side roads make it easy to become one with the rocks. The picnic areas are clean and well kept, but they do need trash cans. I had been told about the location next to Cap Rock where the body of rock and roller Gram Parsons was burned and we found the location and it was quite weird standing where the fire had been. Super National Park. Glad my tax dollars are working so well.

If you are in Anaheim and have an extra day..take a break from the Amusement Parks and go to a National Park! Joshua Tree is about 2 hours away from Disneyland....and worth the drive. It was great to see all the beautiful scenery and wide open spaces, plus the climbing of the big rocks and hiking around. My husband saw a huge jack rabbit while he was taking a picture of a pretty cactus flower. There are some amazing rock formations besides all of the Joshua Trees and cacti. It is a great change from being around crowds. You can spend a lot of time there but we chose to leave a little early, like 3:30 (arriving there around 10:30am) so that we could get back and finish out last ticket to Disney. We bought a 3 day pass so we already spent a day in each park and now wanted to finish up anything we missed. If you go to the National Park, and plan on spending a lot of time there, bring bottled water and snacks or pack a picnic lunch..There are only a couple of bathrooms in the park along the way. We were so glad we went. Don't miss it. There is a $15.00 entry fee per car and it is good for a week.

I have been hearing about Joshua tree and so got curious how they look like for real. My husband and I explored this place for almost whole day. You will pay $15 for the entrance per car but that is already good for a week. I was so surprised how big is the place though I have read the infos. We went to split rock and we were both fascinated of all the beautiful rock formations. We hiked for about 2 hours and it was not really that hard, maybe because we hiked at around 9 am and not too hot. We went to Barker Dam but it was dried, the hike was one hour easy. The Keys view was awesome. One day is not enough to explore the place. We wanted to go to Keys Ranch tour, but I didn't know that you have to reserve months in advance. So please take note of that. But eventhough, we missed it, we have explored other places of the park. It is too big that you could still do other stuff. There were lots of campgrounds and they were all good. Oh, the bathrooms were clean eventhough they are portalets and no flush but they are all well maintained. That's a plus! Over-all, we enjoyed our 1 day trip here but one day is not enough to explore everything.

Allow yourself plenty of time and bring lots of water because we could not find a place to buy it once inside the park. We went on some of the shorter nature walks, but there is many hikes for different skill levels, so that is nice. Or you can just take a drive and enjoy the scenery. Many people brought a picnic lunch and there was a good selection of tables to use in the area where we were at. Also your $15.00 dollar entrance fee is good for seven days.

Feels like you are on the face of the moon to some extent. The trees are quite beautiful in this stark landscape. In parts of the park there are one or two tress here and there and in others there are hundreds (almost a forest). Drive up to the overlook where you can see the San Andreas fault for a beautiful vista. There is not much to see in the Visitor Center but you can get seeds to plant your own tree.

I have visited this park four times now, and I have been impressed each time. First, at $15 a car, entry is a bargain. Get there early, say before 11, to avoid long entry queues and full parking lots on busy days. We waited about 20 minutes just to pay the entry at the booth, but it is worth it. It was a very busy day, but it really doesn't detract from the beauty and other-worldly atmosphere of,this park. If you are willing to walk a bit, you can easily find parking near the busiest sights. We went on a gorgeous clear day. It was cool and breezy and the blue sky was dramatic as a backdrop to the amazing Joshua trees, boulders, dead wood, and brush we saw. There are no facilities in the park other than pit toilets and picnic benches, so bring plenty of food and water, especially on hot days. There are lots of places for hiking and photos. There were many people rock climbing, and in the town of Joshua Tree there are climbing outfitters. You should probably investigate that aspect before going to the park if you intend to rock climb. We drove to Key point to see the valley. People are constantly pulling in and out, so parking was easy. Great views from the overlook, but it is usually hazy so not great for photos. Having been to many national parks, I highly recommend Joshua Tree. It is totally unlike anywhere else in the world.

Wow, we entered the from the North just before sunset. I was anticipating a gorgeous display and I wasn't disappointed! It was chilly, glad we had our jackets. Even some patches of snow on the ground! The beautiful dessert sunset with it's vibrant blues, purples, and pinks with the Joshua Trees and rock formations standing as silhouetes....this should not be missed! We spent the night in TwentyNine Palms and will explore more tomorrow! Can't wait! The park pass is $15/car and is good for 7 days. We are going to drive through heading south.

The tour was informative, if a bit long. Much like other tours we've taken at other National Parks, there is a lot of standing around listening to the Ranger. Not that he wasn't interesting, it was just dang cold the morning we joined the tour. You must make reservations for this tour by calling the park and you must pay by credit card in advance with no refunds. But the cost is only $5 per person so it won't break the bank. Be sure to check the weather forecast to dress appropriately and cold or not, you do need sunscreen!

The Joshua Tree National Park is a place not to miss if you like nature tranquility and expectacular incredibles views. You can rock climbing and not need to be an expert to do it!!! You can rock climb a mountain relativetly easy really. The desert enviroment shows its colors at this place while you enjoy the relaxing of almost doesnt hear any sound of the modern life. Is a perfect spot to have a picnic they have plenty of areas to have a good picnic including BBQ areas. The admision fee is $15 per car reasonable for a 2/3 days pass. The rangers do their jobs so you feel secure and safe. You can see thousands of Josua Trees. My advise is to visit during the afternoon so you can enjoy the picture perfect dwan. Be preprared take water and snacks with you because you cant find anything to buy once you enter. Is a visit you never forget. The breath taking views are spectaculars. If you are a photographer amateur or professional you will love this National Park there are a lot of picture perfect spots. If you donrock climbing this is a spot you cant pass. I strongly suggest a visit

Admission to the park is very reasonable (especially if you're a senior) ... there with our adult sons and the scenery was beautiful and the trails were pretty flat. It would have been better to have some additional trail directions marked, along with mileage points, but overall it was very manageable. The temperature was in the 60s so perfect walking weather. We covered about 15 miles in trails and stayed hydrated so we had no soreness the next day. The drive to the canyon is also very scenic and easy to find.

Amazing that these rock piles were formed underground many years ago. Beautiful quirky plant life, I love the joshua trees. Quiet and peaceful park. Well kept. So glad we were able to go. We were short on time, but it worked well because we only stayed at Joshua Tree for about 2 1/2 - 3 hours. We stopped at Hidden Valley, Jumbo Rocks, Skull Rock, and Split Rock. We hiked at Hidden Valley the entire loop and walked in only a bit through Split Rock. $15. Bring water and snacks.

This relatively new National Park is best accessed through the West Entrance, about 40 minutes NW from Palm Springs. There is a $15 per car fee. The upper park has the Joshua trees to view, the lower 30 or so miles is more traditional desert. Plenty of opportunities for hardy hikers and eco tourists. For the desk-bound traveler, try the one mile hike at Hidden Valley, which was a Hole in the Wall for cattle rustlers in the 19th century. Take the 16 mile cutout to Keys View for a mile high look at the valley below.

A crew of us have made an annual camping trip to here in the last 5 years during the month of October. Is really a beautiful Park with numerous campgrounds to stay at and very reasonable. It's $15.00 to enter the park and it's good for 7 days, or if you have the Golden Age Passport it's free to get in and 1/2 price camping fees, which is just wonderful. Big beautiful rock formations and several great visitor centers to those you have never gone, is a must stop before entering. Summer can be a very deadly time to go, so I wouldn't suggest going during the summer months when the temperatures can soar well into the 100's +. Always have plenty of water, and if you get stuck, stay with your vehicle!! Always know your directions when hiking as it's very easy to get lost as everything looks the same. Be safe and you should have a great time!!
$15 entry fee good for seven days.

I'd wanted to go for a while, and a wedding finally brought me here. I had seen plenty of Joshua Trees driving through Arizona before, but this was something else, entirely. We only had a few hours to really explore the park, but the $15 fee was WELL worth the price. It's worth the drive through, if that's all you have time for (Key's view, and if you have a half hour or so, the easy hike at Barker Dam is totally worth it), but having done just that, i know i need to go back and take full advantage of the 7 day pass.

Very helpful park rangers staff the Visitor Centers, which are outside the park. Prices for water and mementos are reasonable, and you do want to have sufficient water for hikes because it is HOT. It was a long drive to get to the places we wanted to hike: Hidden Valley, the Oasis, and the Archway. Not many people were around, which added to the allure.

You won't see this anywhere else. Please spend at least a whole day here. Beautiful, unique sites to see. Joshua trees, rock formations, desert scenary, hiking, sight seeing.......there are tours that will bring you here from Palm Springs if you don't want to drive yourself. It is very hot in the summer, and can be very windy at times. Stop at a ranger station and get all the maps and info you need first. It's $15 per car. Have fun!

Use the west entrance and stop at the visitors center for maps and information. They also have restrooms and a small diner. From here you drive to the entrance . The fee is $15 per vehicle. There are camp grounds and hiking trail throughout the park. Some of the easier hikes are Barker dam 1.1mi., Cottonwood Spring 1mi., Hidden Valley 1mi., Keys View .25mi. Very good place for rock climbers.
Plan to spend at least five hours. Start your trip from visitor center to help with time planning. Ticket is good for a week.

Desert vegetation is nothing short of fascinating, not to mention the piles of great rocks which have a unique origin, formed under the ground and pushed up as they are. The best parts of the park are concentrated in the norther fork - though of course all the roads have interesting vistas. Watching climbers - will ropes, totally free climbing and on slack bands - oh my goodness. This park is definitely best during cooler seasons; heat and mid-day sun can be dangerous. Follow rangers' directions and caveats. Remember to use your 62+ $10 card to visit, if anyone in your party is in that age group. And the trails are friendly to seniors as well.

I had no idea what to expect, but this place was amazing. We found many areas to watch the rock climbers, take photos, enjoy the weather in November. We came from Colorado so the landscape was very different and so beautiful. There are many areas for photo ops and areas to hike. You can spend hours there! The $10/car fee is well worth it for entry. Plan to stay as long as you can, take in the vast expanse as you can see for miles. Awesome sunsets!

We were here last month on a visit with family. It took a little more than a couple hours to cover the park and drive through it with stops along the way. The Cottonwood Ranger station had some great Rangers who were very helpful and informative. If your lucky you'll see Tarantulas crossing the road. We looked but no luck. Great park. I love photography and this was a great place for pictures. We had a National Park Pass and got in free. Worth the visit!

While we went in August, the desert heat was not too unbearable. This popular destination perched on the crest of the Little San Bernardino Mountains is an impressive array of geologic rockpiles. It is a fascinating place to visit-with several nature trails and short walks available to explore. Camping is available as well.The park entrance fee is $15.00 per vehicle and the campgrounds are $15.00 per night. Ranger programs are available as well. This is a site worth visiting!

As a National Park this has well-marked roads and nature trails to navigate. We went in July with 110 degree temperatures, starting at the southern Cottonwood Springs entrance. After paying the "entrance" fee of $15 per car, we made stops along the way, getting out of the car to observe rock formations, exhibits, signs, and plants more closely. The signage is very informative about varieties of plants, rocks and desert changes. Paved road lead to northwestern entrance/exit with many more places to explore in the northwest and temperatures decreasing slightly. Two gallons of water per person per day is the quantity suggested by the park when hiking and exploring. Also plan for gas fill-up prior to approaching on southern side as exits on HWY 10 and available gas stations are few and far between. The plant life and rock formations are unique to various parts of the park.

Guess we just don't get it. We felt like driving through Joshua Tree National Park was like coming to see what the surface of the moon looks like. We drove up from south to north, and we were almost 2/3 through the park before we saw anything of interest--the cactus garden. Never did figure out what a real Joshua Tree was since even the displays at the Visitors' Center seems vague. Even the oasis we visited was just a group of palm trees that managed to come up through the rocks and sand. We were glad we had a National Park Pass so we didn't pay the $15 day pass to get through here.

My boyfriend and I were brought here while visiting family nearby, and it was definitely worth it. There is a $15 admission into the park, but it's per car not per person. The park is very beautiful, but it is definitely in the desert. The rock formations were my favourite part. They were stacked so intricately, it almost looked placed.

Exploring this park has been on my bucket list for a long time and it did not disappoint. I recommend you start at the West End Entrance Station after stopping at the Joshua Tree Visitors Center to get a map and advice from the park rangers. From there you can traverse the park as you wish, we exited at the bottom in Cottonwood so cut diagonally thru the place. I suspect many people do this in reverse, like many similar drives it will be a different experience depending on which direction you travel, next time I am there I will go in reverse staring from Cottonwood side. We hiked twice and stopped frequently and still it took us less than 5 hours to cover what we wanted to this visit. You should do the Hidden Valley Hike, Barker Dam hike, you absolutely need to drive up to Keys View for a stunning view of the whole valley. You will also pass "Skull Rock" at some point stop to check out this freak of nature! The Cholla Cactus gardens on the way to the Cottonwood Visitor Center is worth a look as well. As they tell you up front there is no food, no water and no gas in the park only restrooms so pack your own goods especially water. We were there in January so cool, in the summer this place is HOT and potentially dangerous so know what you are doing in that heat. Also while the hikes are not too hard physically, they are challenging in places going over rocks and uneven terrain, wear good foot great and if you have physical limitations know what you are getting into before you head off on trail. Even if you never left your car, the beauty is worth the trip. The Joshua Trees themselves are really neat and only found in the northern half of the park. If you have a senior pass to the National Parks you can use it here to avoid the $25 entrance fee.

On Dec. 10 flew topside with Makani Air and hiked both ways with bus tour at bottom. Trail was nearly impossible due to recent rains and mule traffic. Ankle-high mud holes at every step! Promised lunch was not provided because it was stuck on a plane on Oahu. NOTHING to eat or drink from arrival at 7:30 to departure at airport at 5:30. Taxi to beginning of trail was $33 each way, not $20, as indicated. Bus tour and Kalapaupa itself were worth it all, but Damien tours has zero spirit of Aloha.

As others have noted this takes some planning, but well worth it. We took a cab from Molokai Airport (Topside) ($30) to the Mule Barn to pick up our permits.
