Mule Barn does not open till 0745 so had to wait till then. Started our hike down at 0800 and it took us 1 hour and 45 minutes, finishing about 15 minutes before the mule riders. Hike was challenging but doable for my husband and I who are not hikers. We booked our tour of the settlement through the Mule Ride people even though we were not riding the mules because Damien Tours website indicated no tours available in late August (apparently they don't offer tours every day, so the owners of the Mule Ride have started their own tour, because without a tour of the settlement, no one would do the mule ride). Tour was about 3 hours, we were in a van with large windows, affording good visibility) and included a brown bag lunch. Incredible place. Van then dropped us off at the Kalaupapa airstrip where we took a Makani Kai plane to Topside. We would have been too tired to hike back up but those in better shape (and maybe younger!!) could do it.

We arraigned our tour of Kalaupapa with Damien Tours LLC, Makani Kai Airline, and Hele Mai Taxi, and were very pleased with the experience. We decided to hike down the Pali trail into the village and fly out of the settlement. This was a same day trip leaving Maui early in the morning and returning to Maui mid afternoon. If you hike down the trail be sure to wear good hiking shoes. We also had hiking sticks, purchased at Walmart 2 for $20, which were a life saver. The hike is strenuous, but doable. If the path is wet, as it was on our trip down, the rocks can be very slippery requiring close attention to every step made. Take a rain poncho with you, sure wish I had put one in the backpack. You definitely want to start on the path early, around 7:45, to stay ahead of the mules, and their additional droppings. Once you arrive in Kalaupapa you are struck by the beauty and serenity of the area. The 4 hour tour, provided by Damien Tours, was informative and heartbreaking. Damien's tours has retired the old yellow school bus and replaced it with a new van. The van is very comfortable but the side windows are obstructed which makes it nearly impossible to see anything as you ride. luckily you are in and out of the van at numerous spots. The mule riders had their own bus and tour. We would recommend a trip to Molokai and Kalaupapa to anyone visiting Hawaii. All aspects of this trip have to be planned and booked separately.

Kalaupapa has been a national park since the 1980's. It is funded and paid for by tax dollars and the trail was recently built by tax dollars (nearly half a million). However, one resident has cashed in and in order to view what your tax dollars are funding, you are required to pay $50 in cash to a resident who holds a monopoly on a "tour". While the tour is very interesting and could be worth the money, the requirement to pay $50 cash - which ironically is probably being under-reported and NOT being taxed - to enjoy what you are already paying for is very disheartening. I have been to over 100 national parks, historic places, and sites and this one is disgustingly run. Whereas there is certainly a beautiful history to this place, these residents are no longer "banished" here and they are being WELL taken care of by the government (our tax dollars are paying over 80 employees to benefit 8 people). The sense of entitlement is unreal.

Flew to topside Molokai for $20 more each person on a 1/2 hr comfortable flight vs the ferry (at $70 each way). Took a taxi to the Mule Barn at $30 each way--cheaper than renting a car that would be parked most of the day--reserved the taxi several days before arrival. Extremely nice taxi driver and service. Mule barn--terribly run down, nothing like the pictures--nothing to buy like the ad states. We preferred the 3.1 mile hike into Kalaupapa over the mule ride. Rained, overcast clouds, views limited, but nice. Trail is mostly steps (to help with drainage/erosion)-for hikers not a big deal going down, tougher coming up, but we made the 1600 foot climb back up the 26 switchbacks (which are numbered) in 1 3/4 hours, it would take longer on a hot day. Took the required tour (village of Hansen's disease patients & surrounding area) and were pleasantly surprised with what we learned. Only 4 stars because, first: the ferry leaves before the mule ride or hikers can get back (that's what they say)--so you have to stay over or fly. Couldn't the ferry service adjust the schedule to accommodate those who have one day to do the mule ride or hike.

We thoroughly enjoyed our visit to Kalaupapa. After reading reviews and trying to decide whether to hike, take the mules, or fly, we decided to hike down and fly out. This turned out to be a great option. We were able to set this up with Makani Kai Air Charters which offers routine service to/from topside Molokai and Kalaupapa, which is only a 10 minute flight. The permit, tour, lunch and flight out was $189 per person. We arranged a shuttle with Molokai Outdoors to meet us at the airport and take us to the trailhead, that way our rental car was waiting when we flew back to the main Molokai airport.

I agree with AmyWren in that there is not a lot of history provided. I had done a lot of research, so knew quite a bit, but hoped I would learn more about this fascinating place--I didn't. However, it was still fascinating. My one real regret is that there seems to be so little of the original colony's building left. There are few homes; you can't visit Bishop House; you can't visit many of the buildings, as a matter of fact, though they still make sure you visit the one existing store so you can spend your dollars.
The visit is free if you have a Senior Pass.

I honestly do not understand how this place has such good reviews. It was the worst $5 I have ever spent. It's like watching paint dry. The little trail tour has nothing to see. DON WAIST YOUR TIME. it's a rip off.

We stopped here on the way to the airport to get our National Parks "Passport" stamp,. A group was weaving things, which was interesting. Nice, quick, self-guided tour. Shop attendant was busy on the computer during our short visit. Didn't seen interested in bragging about the island's history.

We snorkeled in a few different bays and beaches during our stay on the Big Island and this was far and away the best spot we found. Pay the $5 to park in the national park area and then take the short walk down to two-step beach where the snorkeling is awesome and rewarding! There are two parts to the bay. The south part of the bay is shallower than the other side and you will see lots of marine life variety, including at least 2 different species of eel. The north side of the bay is deeper, which we were told is attractive to dolphins and can be seen if you're willing to snorkel in the deeper parts of the bay (we did not). We stuck the reef part of the north bay area and actually ran into some really cool fish and a really friendly sea turtle.

A visiting friend wanted a great pizza with a nice sunset view. Like I told my wife when she said let's go upstairs and make love, "Can't do both!" So came here after Big Island Pizza up by the Costco for the sunset. Just incredible. Park on the north side of the harbor (watch out, the gate is supposed to be locked at 6:30, so park outside the gate and walk along the harbor.

Its a free day, and you can make a nose flute, a water gourd and carrying net, palm hats or bracelet or bowls, and go paddle an outrigger canoe. Also make your own lei. After making a bracelet we saw them the next day at a store for $15. Exactly the same item. By the way the nose flute is just like a regular flute except designed to be blown with the nose. By local legend the mouth can be dirty, and thus the nose produces the purest air and thus the purest music. On a regular day the park is moderately interesting, but quite small. Good snorkeling beach just north of the park. There are two way to get into the park. The the road in from the south, off the belt highway is much better than the road in from the north. So much better it is worth skipping the north road when coming from the north, and do the extra miles on the highway. It will save brakes, time, and nerves.

Most everyone arriving at the Kaikua-Kona airport will drive by this park and probably miss it. It is on the road between the airport and Kona, across from Costco. At first sight, the park looks like a barren lava flow with little to see. This is where a nice park visitor center is located. I recommend stopping here first. It is definitely not the highlight of the park, but you get to see one of the more recent lava flows and some of the local flora. You have two options, take a hike down to the ocean (about a mile each way), or drive down to the beach area. To do this, you leave the park and drive to the Honokohau marina, stay on the right or North side of the marina and drive all the way to where the marina parking area ends. Park there and walk to the marked entrance of the park trail. It is a short walk to the ocean. There is a nice, thin beach with picnic area and a re-created Hawaiian huts. There is a shallow bay here that has good snorkeling and lots of turtles. In fact, the beach to the right along the ocean is full of turtles. Walk along the lava tide pool areas and they are usually eating the algae on the rocks in the water. There is a Hawaiian fish pond about 200 yards along the beach where there is some good bird watching. Look offshore and you may see dolphins and whales. Some of the locals are usually fishing along the beach. There are no services, so you need to bring everything in. There are small markets at the marina for food and drinks. Check out Bite Me at the Marina for fresh seafood and cold beer at a reasonable price.

The park is located between the airport and downtown Kona. It's free and definitely worth a look. First go to the visitors center for a quick orientation. From there you can drive to two other entrances. The first, by the large marina, leads to a short walk to a lovely beach with resident sea turtles. The second entrance is from the highway, near Hina Lina St by Costco. This three minute drive leads to one of the biggest ancient fish ponds in the state of Hawaii. The restoration of the immense fishpond walls is a sight to behold. It has a lovely shaded picnic area and a wetland with some interesting birds. This place is a secret little gem. It's a surprising and delightful place to spend an hour or a morning.

While driving down to Kona from Hilo we saw the National Park sign and decided to stop because we have one of the Passports were we get the stamps. The building seemed pretty new and a Ranged meet us immediately. He was very nice and after giving us a a brief history lesson, he told us about the beach with all the sea turtles. To get the beach we drove just down the road to the marina and then we took a short walk to the beach. There was a nice tree for shade and few people there. The area was great for snorkeling because there was an old breaker wall in the water that the Hawaiian used. As the tide began to come in more and more turtles can in. We must have seen 30 turtles. The best part was when we were snorkeling a turtle came up and swan right next to us.

Great way to see and learn about ancient Hawaiian culture. Excellent exhibits and self guided tour. Also located next to a very nice snorkel area. Admission to the park is free. Recommend a morning visit as it does get quite warm and there is minimal shade. Also, bring water and snacks as closest snack place is at least 15 minute drive away. Recommend combining this with a visit to Captain Cook Monument area and then continue south to Southern Most Point of the US.

Stopped here to stretch our legs before heading to Costco. Small visitors center, rocky trail leading through the lava field, past petroglyphs to a long beach (quicker access is from the marina at the south end). Lots of rocks though... tide pools were fun to explore. Be sure to bring drinking water as the wind & sun will dehydrate you more quickly than you think! Not a "must see" but was fun to explore & see the Honu.

Three reasons to stop here: (1) if you’re looking for the equivalent of a road side rest stop, this is a very good place to stretch and take care of business (2) you’re into Hawaiian culture and want to learn more (3) you’re into the National Park Service Passport program. Not a ‘knock your socks off’ kind of place, but nice nonetheless. This place has a modestly-sized interpretation center & souvenir shop, clean restrooms and informative park center personnel. There’s a 20 minute hike to the ocean, where along the way you can see remnants of Hawaiian culture and then get a nice view of a rocky shoreline and pounding surf. Nice beaches a short hike away. Best of all, if you’re into the National Park Passport stamps, you get two stamps here (Ala Kahakai trail & NHP). If your time is short in Kona, you may want to skip the park, but if you’ve got the time to explore you may find this place worthwhile. Visitor center is open 8:30 AM to 4 PM daily. Website link: [--]
It was fascinating to see the tidal pills that the ancients had used to collect fish. I saw several turtles. There's a $10000 fine for disturbing the turtles so be careful if the come near you.

We went there primarily for snorkeling. It is also called "2-step" because the main place to enter the water is a two-level rocky ledge about 8 feet wide. We were there on a very choppy day and getting in and out is a bit of a challenge. Not for little kids. The historical park is next to the beach. Entry is $5 at the official park or 5$ to park at the beach so it's the same. Beach is a little to the north of the historical park. The historical part is well documented and interesting, but we were there primarily for the snorkeling. There is no sandy beach to speak of, except for a small area, probably suitable for little kids away from the lava rocks.

We had upgraded our Holland America cruise on the Noordam to include a 10-hour daytrip that included a 6-hour cruise with lunch aboard a 95-foot Kenai Fjords Tours ship. The adult fare was $179.95 each.

We took a shuttle to the park and participated in the ranger guided hike to Exit Glacier. Know that you don't get super close or touch the glacier as it is roped off. That said, the ranger was informative, as they all are. There are longer hikes, but we knew our limitations given the time we had. On the shuttle back to Seward was a very fit younger man who did not make the longer, 8 hr hike to the Harding Ice Field. There is a Station in town as well as this station in the park. Both are small compared to larger parks, but the rangers are all informative. Well worth the $20 shuttle. Small kids, and older folks all could make this hike. FYI, this is the glacier President Obama visited in 2015.

We did a 5-6 hour cruise with Major Marine tours. $479 for 3 adults and came with amazing prime rib and Salmon BUFFET!! We saw lots of Humpback whales, several sea lions, seals, otters, and many birds. Our Captain John said it was one of his most special tours in 5 years because a Humpback kept breaching and playing around our boat. SO AWESOME!!
Very kind crew and captain, and we were able to see nice active glaciers, falls, spiral rock, whale. Spent about $180 but it was money worth. Good memory and great scenery.

We arrived in Seward by train and took a shuttle to the park ($10 roundtrip per person) At the visitor center we joined a group led by a ranger for the hike. She took her time, explained the history and science of the area and encouraged questions. Much of the hike is paved and it is an easy walk. People of all ages attended. The area is marked with dates to show how the glacier is retreating.

Our family group of 11 had a wonderful day touring in the Kenai Fjords National Park on a tour presented by Major Marine Tours. The service was personal, the captain excellent at spotting and calling to our attention the wildlife swimming in the fjords and the onboard salmon luncheon was outstanding --- having been declared superior to one the night before done on a beach for a cost of $35.00.
Don't plan on buying T-Shirts and Hoodies here - this is an information stop. Get maps, advice and your NP Passport stamped, but that is about it. The rangers are great, really nice folks.

The 1.5-mile Exit Glacier hike is an easy trek, and rewards the participant with stunning views of history! Longer hikes are available. You can avoid expensive bus tour trips with a guide by taking a cab from Seward ($35 round trip).

There are several hikes you can get to from Seward. The parking fee is $5 and you can take a few long beach hikes. The one at Exit Glacier is very easy and clearly marked. The visitor center at the Exit Glacier has great displays on how a glacier is formed and the wildlife and more. Great day.

We took the 6 hour catamaran from 11:30 to 5:30. $325 for two people. I was concerned that 6 hours would be too much, but it was perfect. We saw everything but Orca's and Clint Eastwood - a great day to see and learn about Alaska birds and sea life. Included lunch was good, although I would have preferred a bottle of cold water to a paper cup of tepid water. I'm sorry if you think that's snobbish, but for $175/person, you should get bottled water - it's just a great 75 cent business investment. This adventure is a must do if you're in Kenai.

We visited Kenai Fjords National Park on the water with Major Marine, and then the next day, we hiked to an accessible glacier within the park - Exit Glacier. An easy way to get to the park if you are traveling without a car is to use the Exit Glacier Guides service, located a short 15 minute walk from the train station or boat harbor. They only charge $10 per person, round trip, to get a ride to the Exit Glacier hike. All you need is a comfortable pair of shoes, a water bottle, and layered clothing to take this easy hike. There are many places within the hike for getting close to the glacier, as well as getting right up to the glacier to touch the ice! We did not climb on the ice field hike, as that requires a lot more time than we had.

Highly recommended. My wife and I went on the 8hr trip with the dinner stop at Fox Island. The Captain Tiffany and crew were very good. We saw sea otters, eagles, humpback and killer whales, porpoises, huge glaciers, puffins, harbor seals, stellar sea lions, etc, etc. Well worth your time & $.

We took a cruise with Kenai fjords tours. It was expensive, $162 per person and included a sandwich and snack. It was a hazy day and rained,so sadly the view was compromised, but still, we saw plenty of animals, and an up close view of the glacier. The 6 hour cruise did have at least 1 hour in choppy waters. It was very cold to stand outside, but we braved it for photo ops. The competition offers a salmon and prime rib buffet for $20 more. I don't know how I could eat that with the choppy waters...Suggest dramamine before just in case. They pick you up at the train station and drop you off afterwards wherever you need in town. Very friendly staff. Not sure if worth the cost. But, a fun day overall. They also offer 4, 5 and 7 hour cruises.

Took a 5 hour boat tour of Resurrection Bay and the Fjords. Most boring 5 hours of my life! Half the boat was laying across seats sleeping! I can only assume that the others who wrote glowing reviews for this would be excited at watching grass grow because this tour was in line with that! My 80 year old father my brother 49 son 21 and myself 53 all could not wait to get off that boring boat ride! They told us once we got on the boat you rarely see whales or other sea life. Instead of spending $70 on this tour send me $35 and I'll come over to your place and hit you up side the head with a 2x4!

We took the 6 hour tour to the Holgate Glacier on May 31, 2013. We had calm seas and dry weather. There was plenty of room and seating on our boat, the Alaskan Explorer. Well narrated tour with many wildlife sightings, orcas, humpback whales, porpoises, stellar sea lions, otters, mountain goats, puffins, and eagles. The boat was well run with no rush to see the highlights and had plenty of time for photo oportunities. The Holgate Glacier was great with the calving and with the engines turned off or idling quietly. On the return leg, they served a chicken ceasar wrap. Well worth the $144 price per ticket.

You know when the captain guarantees that you will see whales that you are in for a wonderful experience. We took the 6 hour tour of the park with Kenai Fjords National Park Tours. The catamaran is large and comfortable. Lots of seating. Seas were a bit rough due to some recent storms in the area and some people got sick, so definitely think about taking some seasickness meds if you are prone to this. The tour was amazing. We saw whales, otters, seals, mountain goats. Got close to a glacier and heard the eery sounds of it calving. We had some rain, which cleared toward the end of the trip, when the sun actually came out. It was pretty cold, too! So dress in layers if you go early in the season. All in all it was stupendous. I highly recommend. If you can use one of the coupon books (we did and saved $100) all the better. Some of the most beautiful scenery I have ever seen.

We took one of the 16 passenger boats for the captain's choice tour. We think it was probably a lot better than the larger boats. We saw lots of great bird like hundreds of puffins. The captain actively searched for birds, whales, animals, and good glacier views. It cost each of us more about $225 for the day, but it was worth it.

We did the 8.5 hour tour out of Seward. It was a beautiful day. This is the third time that I have done this trip. When we have friends come from out of state, they usually go on this trip. We saw humpback whales, porpoises, goats, puffins, glaciers, etc. It is a great way to see a lot of things in one day. The food is good, we always order the half pound of King crab with dinner for $12. This time it was cold, but was great crab. Great trip to take out of town friends coming up to visit on.

The "Costal Explorer" Captain and crew were GREAT. We saw Sea Otters, Dall Porpoises, Orca, Humpback Whales, Puffins, Stellar Seas and many other wildlife. Snack lunch. This ship captain worked hard to give great sightings and photographic opportunities. Ending the day with a good meal at Fox Island and a Park Ranger slide show and overview of area.

Visited on what I thought might be a nice Sunday with few visitors...was I mistaken. This park on nice weather weekends is a must go for the fitness crazed locals. It was packed and I had to park in the overflow lot even though I was visiting for the site. On weekends you cannot drive to the top of the mountain. Your choice is a $3 shuttle or a very strenuous hike up a Mountain. I took the shuttle as not up for a hike...only complaint the shuttle was playing a local radio station loudly...if I wanted music something more Civil War appropriate would have been more my style. Unfortunately the view was not as spectacular as it was sort of hazy, but on a clear day it must be magnificent. The park is only accessible be car in a few locations, but if you are into hiking trails, then this is the place to go. The museum was surprisingly good for the size.

I rode the shuttle to the top for $3. My family took the 1 mile hike up. I hiked down. It was a nice hike but it was crowded and hot. We had to park in overflow parking. Con: Hot. Recommend: go early in the day as possible. Pro: they had a shuttle to the top.

The park is picutesque, self-adventurous, and educational. You can picnic, hike up/ down the mountain or take the shuttle. Office personnel can advise you of different options, you decide to do all or some. Parking and hiking is free. Shuttle inexpensive ($1.50- 3.00).

The Kennesaw Mountain is very beautiful in any season. The museum, gift shop and center are filled with interesting items related to the battlefield. Surrounded by the battlefields and beautiful park grounds. The Kennesaw Mountain is a steep hike - luckily they have a tram you can pay $3 to take to get to the top. You can take it both up and down the mountain, but if you're up for it, ride up and walk down. There's a paved path and a path thru the woods. If you're sure-footed, take the path thru the woods. Great views of the city of Atlanta and you really get a feel for the military importance of the mountain during the civil war. LOTS of beautiful dogs on leashes being walked.

Passing through town I thought I would take the extra time and check out the battlefield. Often when I do this, I am rewarded, and this time was no different. The battlefield is easy to reach from the interstate, has an outstanding visitor center and provides top of the mountain access via the drive or hike. I choose to hike and it was just the pit stop I needed to stretch my legs. Yes, the history of the mountain is evident from the preserved field to the artifacts in the visitor center. Staff is available to share additional learnings and their knowledge. The gift shop provides what anyone interested could want and if you are hungry, town is a very short drive down the mountain. Enjoy

Key conflict in the critical Battle for Atlanta. Great visitors center with very good 30 minute movie overview. Start your tour at the Visitors Center, then drive up to the mountain top (free during week, $3 per person by bus on weekend). Be sure to visit the other battlefield sites from the conflict but if you have to pick just one, pick Cheatham Hill, and the Dead Angle.

I love this mountain which gives a peep into history and also a scenic place to have an aerial view of Atlanta ! It has a mini theater and museum where one can feel the last important war history ! Admission is free and on the week ends there is a bus ride up the hill !

This is a fab place to enjoy a picnic with your family. Nice park, many people with dogs, strollers and so on. I was pregnant at the time and took the shuttle up to the top ($2pp). Would definately do it again!

All that can be said is WOW !!! Come to this place and it is guaranteed you will be awe struck. Surround yourself in these redwood beauties and you will definitely forget where you are. As you stand in the trunk of one of the redwood giants it puts things into perspective of how long they have been around and just how big the trees are. The water level of the river and lake are sufficient to keep you entertained. We spent some time at bear claw falls which is truly worth the drive. It's really good to see how close to the falls you can get. The only draw back I had was paying the $30 per car to get into the park. I think $20 is more appropriate. Either way it's a great place to visit

After sixteen years of visiting Kings Canyon NP annually, I never get tired of this place. There's something about the majesty of the Giant Sequoia that quiets my soul and gives me pause. Over the years, the entrance fee has changed and is currently $20 per car unless there is someone in the car who is 62 and over and has an ID, or in the US military, etc. The pass is good for 7 days.

This guy from Florida can not begin to describe the majesty of the Sequoias. We drove in from the north, through King's Canyon first, and saw the General Grant tree, visitor center, and the grove where the tree is located. Very friendly to us out of shape flatlanders, but still a lot of walking on uneven surfaces. You can see a lot just from the car, but getting out and up close to the trees is incredible. Next we drove down to Sequoia, and by then the crowds were picking up. Parking fills up, but they provide speedy and frequent shuttles, like every five minutes. The General Sherman tree is billed as the largest in the world, and is down a half mile paved trail. I do not recommend this for anyone out of shape. It is pretty steep, and at 7000 feet, we were all out of breath. I left my wife and friend at the bottom, and retrieved the car, and drove down to get them. I think the bus will take you to the handicap entrance, where I picked them up. The trees line the road through the park, and there are other places to just pull off. $20 per car fee for the whole park.
Seniors (above 62 I believe, or perhaps 65) can buy a ‘forever’ pass at the gate for $10. Gets you into any National Park for free.
$18 per nite plus Park entry fee($20)

On a quest to get National Park Passport stamps, had to make a detour to see Kings Mountain. We were blown away with how great it was. Everything was beautifully done, down to the roads on the drive in. The museum has great interactive displays (it's designed to be like you are walking through the forrest) and the approximately 30 minute video is very informative.

This park was by far one of the most beautiful parks I've ever been in. The huge trees were amazing!! A lot of the trails were paved and just so beautiful and peaceful. This park was right up there with the Grand Canyon. What ever you do don't miss this National Park. And if your 62 years( young) by a senior pass for $10.00 it will get you and a guest in all the parks for free after that. We went to 5 Parks while vacationing. They were all beautiful in there own ways.
park: Lakes Trail in Sequoia National Park

text: There are too many giant trees in this park, the bus services is A+. Take the bus from Visalia $15 round trip. The bus stop almost at all main hotel. It will save your time, save your money ($20 for a car entrance fee).
park: Lakes Trail in Sequoia National Park

text: If you want to see the great Giants, you won't be disappointed. Plan on spending at least an entire day in the park if you are not camping there. With so many places to stop and explore, you may never get to everything! It does get cool when you get to the higher elevations, so bring a jacket if you are not used to colder climates. Being from Minnesota, that was not a problem for us! Take a picnic lunch and plenty of water. You will want to stop and have lunch in one of the numerous picnic areas. You will pay $20.00 to enter the park and your pass is good for seven days.
park: Lakes Trail in Sequoia National Park

text: Lava Beds is pretty much in the middle of nowhere. I enjoyed it quite a bit, but I think it’ll be appreciated most if you aren’t driving out there just for that. We were driving from Grants Pass to Lassen Volcano so it was in route.

We took a day trip from Klamath Falls to this out of the way attraction. From Klamath falls it is 39 miles to the entry (via highway 97 and California RT 161. it is another 9 miles to the visitor center. The cost for a vehicle is $15.bikes and hikers are less.

Enjoyed our day at Lava Beds. We saw Petroglyph Point, very interesting and lots of glyphs. Walked the inner circle of Captain Jack's Stronghold which was so interesting and informative, get the trail book for a $1.00. We got overheated though on this hot day. Visitor center was helpful and we explored multiple caves. Make sure and pick up before you get there: headlamp, flashlight, water and lunch/snacks. Recommend getting there earlier in the day so you have plenty of time.

There is a $15 per vehicle fee to enter Lava Beds National Monument or use your senior or other inter-agency pass for free or reduced fee entry. Because of the remote locations of the fee stations, credit and debit cards don't work here; cash or checks only. The Visitor Center, on the other hand, welcomes all forms of payment. Stop at the Visitor Center to see the video and get your cave permit stamped. If you have been in any cave east of the Rockies or in Europe the rangers will decontaminate your boots or shoes in order to protect the bats from white-nose syndrome. Your boots will be ready before the video is over.

We were really surprised at how much there was to see. There were so many caves to explore. Take really good flash lights. The visitors center will let you borrow them for free which surprised me but you had to have them back by 4:30. The views from the campgrounds were so beautiful. The campground itself was OK if you like being on top of one another. The fee was only $10. per night. Luckily we were there in the fall when most people weren't camping anymore. Make sure to go to the visitors center first and do the bat screening. Once we asked what it was about we found out how important it was. They ask a few questions and then depending upon if you have been in caves back east you will need to have your camera wiped down and your shoes. Millions of bats are dying from a disease. There was so much history about the Modoc Indian wars we didn't know about.

Tucked away at the top of California, near the Oregon border, Lava Beds is an interesting glance into time when active volcanoes dotted the landscape and lava flowed freely. Miles of frozen lava rivers and deep lava tube caves make this a worthwhile stop for whole family. Admission is $8 per carload, or if 62 plus you can buy a lifetime $10 golden pass that will get you and the kids into all national parks as many times as you like. The caves are not developed and cool, so dress appropriately with good hiking boots (rough floor) and bring a flashlight. If you forget, the rangers will lend you one in exchange for a copy of your driver's license. There are a lot of caves with varying degrees of difficulty, ask the ranger for a recommendation of the best ones for you. Also check out the nearby national wildlife refuge for the breeding ground of the white pelican. Area also was the site of a battle between horse soldiers and the local Indians.

My friend visited here with his wife and two sons all the way from Texas, so I went a long. The caves are amazing, and if you want to explore, bring proper gear and clothes, like gloves and long sleeved shirts, and flashlights. You can rent some of those goods at the visitor center, but it's better to bring your own. I hard hat is worthwhile too. The caves were exciting and nice to cool off in from the hot July sun. Went to the talk about the Modoc war in the evening which was very eye opening to the history of the area. The night sky is very beautiful and intense. The campsites are only $10 per night, which is a bargain in California. They are fairly spacious and have picnic tables, fire pits, a hand water pump adjacent, and clean latrines nearby. Very remote park with ancient beauty.

This place is Amazing! My Sat Nav didn't even show it, but some locals pointed us in the right direction. At a few points it felt to me like we were lost(I have a terrible sense of direction), but once we arrived it was beyond words. The admission gate was closed, it is typically $10 per car. We drove up to the visitor's center and paid there. You defo need more than one day to see it all. A must see is signal bridge. You can see actual Modok writing/pictures on the cave walls. I am humbled and in awe of that alone. The terrain is uneven and some is a bit harder to walk/climb than other parts but it is all so worth it. I will defo return!!! The gift shop has snack food for sale and a picnic area, but nothing substantial, so if you want a meal, eat ahead of time, or bring one. Also, at the time of my visit, it was a cash only operation.

Just got back from a fun weekend spent exploring caves at Lava Beds National Monument. The visitor center has great detailed maps with explanations for levels to each person can go at their own pace. I found that if we went into the challenging caves we just turned around and went back when it got to be too much for us. The visitor's center sells knee pads ($13) so if you plan on crawling I would bring your own or buy some before heading out. You can also purchase hard-hat type helmets there for around $7. We brought bike helmets which were more sturdy and stayed put. The best cave for the beginner is Sentinel cave because you can walk all the way through it, the path is really developed and they even have stairs in places. Skull Cave and Merrell Cave require a lot of stair climbing to get to the bottom so be prepared for the long climb up those same steps when you are coming back up.

This place is now one of my new favorite National Parks!! There is so much to explore and see, and most of it is underground!! I HIGHLY recommend visiting the Golden Dome Cave because of the golden, glowing bacteria on the ceiling! Its absolutely gorgeous (but not contagious, so don't worry!) You can borrow huge flashlights from the rangers, and even buy a bump hat for $8 (which I would recommend if you plan on going into the more challenging caves) Also, if you decide to visit the Painted Caves, go to the one that is farther back on the trail because that one has more obvious paintings on the wall. HAVE FUN!! I will definitely be back soon!

We camped at Lava Beds NM for one night over Memorial Day weekend. It was super cheap ($10 for tent camping and $8 for firewood). The highlights were the Golden Dome cave and an evening hike up Schonchin Butte. Skull Cave and Sentinel Cave were decent, but not as spectacular.

We had the chance to take a few days in Southern Indiana and Kentucky so made sure to include the birthplace in Kentucky and this Indiana Home. Very well maintained grounds here and a large visitor center. This site does have a $5 entrance fee so don't forget your senior pass or park pass if you have it. There is a short (15 minute) film providing background history and info that is worthwhile. There is a lot of information displayed in the welcome center on a self tour basis. A walkway leads to the American Flag behind which is the cemetery with the grave of Lincoln's mother. There is a living history type farm and other activities beyond the cemetery. Due to the excessive heat we didn't get to those because of the walk. You can drive back behind the cemetery but it's still a pretty good hike. It is worth the stop.

The memorial when you first come in is nicely air conditioned. They have a 15 minute movie they show which was informative. Some nice portraits and then some other things from Lincoln's period of time. The trails to the living farm are very wide and easy to walk. Costumed reenactors were helpful and offered up cool information. The setting is a lovely area.

We went to the lake side gated area ($7 for local $9 for out of state) and walked the trail for the little pigeon church which was nice. We ended up at the nature center which was not our intention but worked out. The trails could use a bit more signage. We had girls age 5-13 and they all liked visiting the nature center. We drove past the swim/beach and paddle boat area but were not prepared for swimming. We will return for that. We visited the amphitheater and had been to great programs there in the past. The areas were all very clean. We crossed the main road to the boyhood site (no charge) and walked the trail through the village and the 12 stones. Nice walk. The people in the village were informative and friendly. All together good relaxing time.

We stopped here on our way home from Holiday World. It is literally less than 5 miles away! We were greeted immediately upon entering the beautiful Memorial Building and given an overview of what the park had to offer. I should mention that they charge a fee of $5 per person or $10 a family. We were happy to contribute although some visitors seemed caught off guard. Our son really enjoyed participating in the Junior Ranger program and adding a stamp to his National Parks passport. There is a working farm on site with period dressed Park Rangers who interact with the visitors. It was really neat to see how Lincoln lived growing up and what his home and land were like. There is also a short hike taking you through the land to the site where President Lincoln's mother is buried. We definitely recommend stopping by for great education fun!

The museum itself is a no cost attraction which provides endless history in a beautiful presentation. If you actually want to see the Lincoln boyhood home, you'll have to pay $5 individually, or $10 for your family. This was an option for us as it is only 5-10 minutes from Holiday World Splash and Safari and it was completely packed that day so we had a history lesson instead. This is a national park if you're visiting as many of those as you can. Highly recommend this attraction.

We stopped in here while visiting Santa Claus and it was a very enjoyable stop. It only cost $10 for an entire family or $5 per person. They had a neat video and a lot of cool artifacts. It was raining pretty hard so we did not go walk the property and see the buildings, but heard they were very neat. Would definitely recommend visiting.

My family and friends spent about 3 hours here on a late July morning. We watched the video, did the Junior Ranger Program, hiked to the living farm, explored the interactive living farm, fed cows, hiked back on a different trail, and explored the visitor's center. The living farm is what sets this site apart for me. Our kids really enjoyed that and it such a nice touch compared to many of the other nationally ran sites. I have now been here twice and have enjoyed it on both occasions. The cost for our group of 7 was $10. Each group is a $10 fee and is it well worth it!

"There I grew up." I'm a Lincoln follower and this was a place I had to see; where he spent his formative years between the ages of 7 and 21. You may have to walk a little and deal with the elements (heat, mosquitoes) depending on the time of year, but it's sacred ground as far as I'm concerned. For $5 you can tour the grounds as well as go into the little museum. None of the building are originals, but they put up replicas where they were when the Lincolns lived there. You can also see his mother's grave and throw a Lincoln penny at it like hundreds of others have. :)

We really enjoyed this attraction. The museum wasn't the highlight but walking the grounds were. They do offer an active duty Military Discount (Free) so make sure to ask for it if you are. The museum was just ok, I was hoping for more however walking the trails to the historic farm was the best. There we met 2 gentlemen who were very friendly. 1 man explained to us the house and the grounds and answered all our questions and we had ALOT. The trail was nicely done and easy to walk. I would only suggest to put in working water fountains along the way as none of them worked.

Lincoln Boyhood National Memorial is made up of a Museum and a walking tour of the grounds where it is believed Lincoln spent 14 years of his life in Indiana. Lincoln's mother is reportedly burried on the grounds. The museum is probably the highlight of the grounds. There is a short film that is worth viewing and then many artifacts that are representative of his time in Indiana and his family. The gravesite of his mother is moving as well. There is a short walk to a working farm where the replica of Lincoln's cabin foundation is located. (on a side note..while it is known that this is only a replica, it unfortunately looks very fake. In light of the effort to make this a good representation, it appears work could be done on this particular part of the venue) We have visited this memorial twice. This time, July 2014, the folks working the farm were doing an excellent job engaging the guests. This is a self tour. There is a farming area and they were allowing guests to attempt to till the soil by working the two draft horses. It clearly showed the challenges those in that day had tilling their land. There are not too many buildings on the property to tour but the information is very interesting. I think this is a great short trip to take the family on and does provide younger children with a glimpse into the time Abe Lincoln spent in Indiana. This is a Federal park. There is a $5 per family fee to enter the museum. Walking the grounds is free.

This is the place where Abraham Lincoln "grew up as a young boy, and left as a young man." Saw a nice little 15 minute video in the museum. Also some nice pictures and good information about Lincoln and his family living in Indiana. Learned a bunch of new things about Lincoln and his relatives during his 14 years' time in Indiana. $3 admission fee or $5 per family.

This is a little out of the way , but if you like Lincoln history it is a must . You tour at your own pace , no push and shove. You need to walk the 12 rock trail too. Be sure to see the working farm too . If you have a Senior Pass for the National Park you get in free ,

We stopped here before going to Holiday World. This memorial is a good stop to get some Linciln history. Be sure and see the informative movie and exhibits in the memorial. The family price is only $5. Take the 1 mile hike to the working farm and pass by Lincoln's mothers grave. The first part of the hike is downhill but if you take the 12 stones path back, it doesn't seem so bad coming back uphill. The Park Rangers and farm workers are all very nice and informative.

It was only $5 for all of us. The small museum had tons of wonderful information and we were able to watch a small video about Ad Lincoln and the park. We also took a stroll through the woods to see Abs farms, what was left of his house and what it would of looked like. All three of the girls enjoyed the sites and the small farm animals.

What a nice surprise. We came across this memorial as we were in the area with some extra time. I was surprised how much of my Indiana History I had forgotten. This is a very interesting place to visit. Entrance fee was low, just $5 for two. Make sure you watch the 15 minute film. It puts everything in context.

The memorial building has nice carved murals on the outside, small gift shop inside. Historical artifacts are lacking, but what they have is interesting. Trails are well manicured. Pioneer cemetery marks resting place of Abe's mother and other settlers from the area. Bronze casting of the original cabin gives a nice feel for the historical significance of the spot. The park employee in period clothing at the recreated cabin was a wealth of information on the area of the time and the Lincoln family. Family pass was only $5. A definite must see if in the area.

The wife is a big Lincoln buff and we took our daughter to see this place. It is basically a visitors center (admission was $3 per or $5 family), the grave of Abe's mother, the site of their cabin, a spring, and a replica working farm with live animals. There are also some hiking trails (not terribly long or difficult) which I enjoyed the best. Especially the trail with 12 stones scattered throughout, marking events in Lincoln's life (e.g. an actual stone from the White House during Lincoln's time). I found the hike very interesting! There isn't that much to see in the Visitors Center and some may balk at the entrance fee, but I found the 14 minute movie quite interesting and worth it. I was not aware of how much time Lincoln spent in Indiana and that it was during a crucial part of his growing up helping define who he was as a man. If you have young kids, since this is a National Park (this goes for all National Parks) have them participate in the Junior Ranger program. It helps make the visit a fun learning experience and when they complete the book, they get a badge. My daughter has gotten quite a few of these over the years and displays them on a vest. A nice keepsake as she gets older to remember our trips. We spent about 3 hours total there.

We traveled to the Lincoln Boyhood National Monument in June 2008 while we were in the area visiting Holiday World and Splashin Safari. This National Park is very inexpensive as it was $5.00 for a family and that was good for 7 days if we wanted to go back. The main building was nicely done and had a good movie. We then toured the grounds which were well kept. It might be a tough walk in the heat and humidity of summer, but it wasn't too bad the morning we were there. The grounds contain a working farm with animals and actors who are dressed for the time period. One thing that was a little disappointing was the cabin that Lincoln built with his father is not there (anymore). However, there is an outline on the ground of where it stood. I know it has been a long time since Lincoln lived there, but it would have been neat to see the cabin. This, like many other attractions in the area, is isolated and is a little bit of a drive off the Interstate, but it is a good look at the early life of our 16th President.

Is it me or is there a little bit of interstate rivalry between Kentucky and Indiana on the matter of which state contributed most to Lincoln’s character? Lincoln Boyhood National Memorial, located in Lincoln City, Indiana, focuses on his boyhood and young adult years-- The admission for the museum and film is like $3.00 individual / 5.00 for families-- While I always enjoy and recommend an NPS, overall this place is pretty standard in terms of content, historical collections, education media, etc.

The Visitor Center was certainly a honor of Lincoln and his life. Allow ample time to browse through the exhibits. We paid the $10, but due to the hike from the parking area, the heat, and high humidity, my husband had to turn back before reaching the location of the original cabin, gravesites, and the historic farm. It would have been so much better if handicapped visitors and those with health concerns could have driven back to enjoy the full experience of the Memorial. There were stairs to the visitor center, but I would think there was a wheelchair ramp somewhere? Feel kinda ripped off of our money since we were unable to visit the areas you had to walk to.. Because of how well done the Visitor Center was done is the only reason I didn't give it 1 or 2 stars...

Our family loves visiting various National Park Service sites so we altered a road trip to stop by the Lincoln Boyhood National Memorial in Indiana. There isn't much around the site but it is only about 5 miles off of interstate 64 and very easy to find. The memorial building is the best place to stop first. The site charges $5 per individual or $10 per family and this can be paid there. There is a 15 minute film that plays every half hour that gives more context to the rest of the site. The building also has two rooms built to look like the period that Lincoln lived there. One is an auditorium room that is used for churches, weddings and meetings. The other is just a large room with a table and a painting. There is also an exhibit room that further illustrates his time spent in Indiana.

The Lincoln Boyhood National Memorial is one of the less impressive historic sites. It is a pay park. $10 per family. It consists of a small museum the with two wings and an outside park area where the cabin he lived in location is laid out.

I cannot believe they do not charge for this tour. Tickets are free from the visitor center which also has parking. Not to mention a pretty cool gift shop inside. Our tour guide was a girl. I can't remember her name. But she was good. It was amazing to go through history and hear the stories and see actual things he touched inside that house.

We decided to spend Thanksgiving in Springfield visiting Lincoln sites since he was the one to introduce the idea of dedicating a day to giving thanks as the Civil War was still raging. To see where Lincoln and his family lived before he became President was a bit overwhelming. Tickets are free and are collected at the visitor center. You do have to pay for parking, though, in a lot adjacent. At this time, it is 0.75 per half hour. Tours are available and run about every half hour.

This is the only home Abraham Lincoln owned, and this home is still filled with all the original furniture. This is a wonderful, FREE tour for you and your family. You must visit when you come to Springfield. The parking is $2 and they have a nice gift shop. The tour takes about 20 minutes (guided by expert) and is free.

This was our first stop in the "Lincoln Learning" tour & glad we did this first as it gave us a better understanding of what we would see & learn at other Lincoln venues here in Springfield. Our Park Ranger, Peter, was very informative, witty & knowledgeable. Many of the artifacts in the home are original. Do NOT park in the church parking lot ($15 fine)!! There is parking beyond the Visitors Center. You will need to stop in the Visitors Center to get a free ticket for the tour of the home. There is also a good movie available in the Visitors Center.
Park rangers give the tours. Quite informative. 4 block area set up where no cars allowed. Allows you to freely walk about and view from the outside the homes on the street. Admission is free.
Very good tour of the house the Lincolns spent before he became president. Feel like you have a peak into their lives before everything changed for them. Very friendly and knowledgeable tour guides.

The Lincoln House, the crown jewel of the National Historic Site in Springfield, is only a small two-floor frame house in a quiet residential neighborhood south of the downtown. Tickets to the house are purchased in an efficient park center that has museum pieces from the Lincoln family, an interactive Lincoln Walk from the neighborhood to the Old State House and a good-sized gift shop of Lincoln books and memorabilia.

Another Presidential home off our list. We toured the home of president Abraham Lincoln on our stop in the town of Springfield. The tour lasts about 20 minutes and is filled with information about the 16th president and is family and home life. The tours are free but a ticket is required for it. They are issued at the visitor center. The only cost was parking which was $1 an hour with a national park pass. Not sure if the full parking rate.

This is the only home Lincoln ever owned. The restoration and furnishings are very authentic. Being a National Park there is no admission fee, but tickets must be secured at the Visitors Center for the House Tour The four blocks around the house have also been restored and you get a feel of Abraham's neighbors. Parking though limited is available for $2.00 and is adjacent..

Tickets are free you just need a ticket to enter the Lincoln home. What a joy to stand in this beautifully restored home so exciting. They did a great job restoring the home md supporting it to last for generations. At least 50% of the contents are original which is amazing thinking about people not really saving items or things lost to history over the years but they received a lot of the original items back or had them on property. Very cool to walk through the same rooms and corridors Abe Lincoln and Mary did. Highly recommend this home on your visit. It had a great center to visit and learn more about the neighborhood and Lincoln himself up the street

We had a really lovely tour guide who was dressed in costume. Our tour guide, Kellie, knew tons of facts and details about the house and the Lincoln family. About 80% of the home is original to the Lincolns. Make sure to check out the rest of the neighborhood. The use of augmented reality via a phone app at the Jenkins lot is a really nice touch. Parking was all that we had to pay for ($2/hr). The tour itself lasts about 25 minutes and photography is allowed inside and outside the home. After the tour we were free to roam the neighborhood for as long as we liked.

A timed tour with a guide is required. Tickets are free and available at the Visitor Center a short walk away. It takes about 15 minutes to walk through. Very interesting to see how the Lincoln Family lived and very well worth the visit.

Easy parking, about $2 per hr. Expect to spend about 2 or more Houors. It is a National Park so If you have the National park card (life membership) which cost $10 now and expect to go up later this year, this vist is free

Seeing Lincoln's home helps a person understand his personal life. This is run by the National Park Service, so the guides are well informed and enthusiastic. The home has had a wonderful restoration job. The whole neighborhood is part of the park and has also been wonderfully restored. It is also amazing that visitors are admitted without any charge! This was what Lincoln's surviving son, Robert, wanted. However, the parking lot adjacent to the house costs $2/hour. It fills up quickly so it's a good idea to get there by mid-morning.

I recommend this historical site if you have the time. You will pay $2 per hour for parking, but you get to learn a lot of historical facts regarding our 16th president of these United States. There is a movie in the visitors center and a tour of his house. The historical site includes four city blocks restored to the time of 1860.

First, it is in a very safe, well maintained cordoned off area in downtown Springfield, Illinois. The adjacent streets are blocked off to vehicular traffic. Also, there is parking at the site but even if that is full, there is on-street parking too. Admission is free but you need to get there early to get a ticket and wait your turn to tour the house. While you wait, there are other houses in the area to see. If your wait is long enough, there is a brewery, bakery and restaurant right across the street. The President and Mrs Lincoln lived in the house from 1944 until he left for Washington DC in 1861 and how they kept house and expanded as their family grew will all be explained by the docent.

The Lincoln House was an excellent attraction that is very well maintained and presented by the Nation Parks Service. Tickets were gone the first day we went but got them easily the next day. It was truly a gift that the Lincoln family specified that they wanted the house to be open freely to the public.

Very informative video before touring Abraham Lincolns historic home. Rangers were so informative. Also very nice walk thru surrounding blocks to give one an idea of home it was in that time frame. If have national Park Pass- parking is free, building is free-will. Would go again.

Start with the visitors center. Parking is $2-4. I think everything else is free. If you're willing to wait for the guided tour, you can see the inside of the house (my family's fun meter was pegged at this point so we didn't see it). The neighborhood is cool. All the homes are restored and there are a lot of replicas of items reminiscent of the era. For the price and accessibility, it's a must see.

This requires a guide and a ticket. Tickets are free at visitor center. Waited in the Charles Arnold house for tour which was very interesting too. House has been restored to the time of Lincoln's residency. Guide was very worried about guests touching wall and getting off blue carpet. Should have been better protected to eliminate this constant reminder. Guide was very knowledgeable.

We were not able to get the free tickets to go inside Lincoln's home but we still enjoyed walking around the few blocks and seeing the home from the outside. There's a few blocks of old houses that are blocked off so cars can't drive there. You can walk around and feel like you stepped back in time. If you park in the Lincoln Home Visitor Cneter parking lot you have to pay $2 but we parked a block away in the neighborhood and didn't have to pay for parking. Lots of photo ops and some interesting signs with historical information. My son and I don't like history and we really enjoyed it.
What can I say that already hasn't been said for Lincoln's home? This is a nice historic site and grounds. The grounds are very well maintained. Parking is $2.00 but close to the house.

This was the purpose of our visit to Springfield. Absolutely love what the NPS has done with the neighborhood. Everything is well kept and you really get a feel for how it was back when Abraham Lincoln and his family lived here. Tickets for the house tour are free. Worth stopping if you like history.

Well worth visiting. It's a guided tour and fun and educational to see the historical setting as well as some household objects that were actually used by the Lincoln family. It is impressive to walk the street that has been turned into a period place with replicas of homes of the past. Feels like you are actually in the time period. Well worth seeing and experiencing

Had by far more original items than did the Lincoln museum. Interesting ranger led tour. Tickets are free and give the time of your tour to keep group size down. Tours were leaving every ten minutes when we were there. The guided tour was about thirty minutes but there is then more to see on you own. We were there about one and a half hours all together.

We took the tour that was offered and it was so interesting. Lincoln lived in a nice home. A lot of the original furniture has found its way back. Tour guide tells you about their struggles and way of life. Two dollars per hour to park. Allow yourself about 1.5 hours to park. No charge for touring home.

The Lincoln home is part of a well restored neighborhood where Lincoln lived with his family. Many of the furniture pieces are originals as are some of the wall paper. The tour itself is about 30 minutes but you can spend 1-2 hours viewing other homes and watching great movies in the visitor section. Tickets are free and you are scheduled to a certain viewing time. You can actually stand at Lincoln's desk where he wrote so many meaningful speeches on the way to the White House!

The Lincoln Home is a National Historic Site maintained by the National Park Service. Although tours are free, tickets must be obtained from the Visitor Center. Parking is available adjacent to the Visitor Center for $2 per hour (as of summer 2016). Restrooms, information desk, gift shop, and additional information is available in the Visitor Center, also.

The National Park Service took this over, and they are doing a great job. Apparently, when Robert Todd Lincoln sold the property (for $1), one of the stipulations was that visitors could tour for free! You walk the same floor that Lincoln walked (more or less), and hold on to the exact same handrail that he used. It's pretty small by modern standards, and very popular, so tours are short and quick (it's free, so you can always go back). Unlike most historic homes in America, they've also preserved a couple blocks of the neighborhood, which I think is great. The visitor center is nearby, but unobtrusive, and there's a nice video. Highly recommended.

We enjoyed our time here. They give tours every 10 minutes in groups of about 15. The house has many original items of the Lincoln's. Very informative. They have Lincoln and Mary Todd Lincoln in costume during the Living History days in the summertime. They also have a museum in a house of Lincoln's time there that shows how they restore the homes. Another museum was housed in an Lincoln-era home and contains more pieces of the Lincoln era and interesting info. The tour is free (you must have a free ticket from visitor center), but you do have to pay to park: $2/hr, and you have to pay for parking before you go in, so you have to estimate your time. It took us about 2 hours seeing everything, but we did not get to see the film in the visitor's center.

Quite a pleasant place among the busy city. The visitor center is a good place to start. There are two movies. Only had time to watch one as we had allotted 2 hours for the visit. It was very good. Wished we were able to spend more time. It was peaceful to walk the streets of the "neighborhood" as the weather was pleasant. Several of the homes are open for self-guided tours. Others are used as office space for federal agencies. Lincoln's home requires a guided tour. Free tickets are obtained in the visitor center. Tours were going off about every 20 to 30 minutes. Tour size appeared to be small (less than 20 people per tour). We didn't take the house tour so can't provide any information about the inside. The only negative is the paid parking. $2 per hour but there is a discount if you have a federal pass. This is the first place we've seen that actually accepts the federal pass for parking. Thank you!

Great tour, our guide was wonderful and very knowledgeable. Tickets are free at the visitors center on a first come first serve basis, so get there early. Be aware that they do activities and shows during the day, my children enjoyed learning about the period toys and games that Abe's children would have played with (and it was hands on, so the whole family had fun playing!).

Our guide Travis was great! He handled our talky guests very well and was very professional. The tour was short but very much info was given. It does get kind of cramped in the house so get comfy with your neighbors. Parking in the lot is $2 an hour parking on the street is a $1 an hour

You should visit the Lincoln home early in the day because they only give out so many tickets and sometimes run out. We managed to get on a 10:30 tour. The guide had some jokes but not a lot of info. She recited the standard things but no personal or interesting stories. Abe came to town on a borrowed mule and with no education. He taught himself to be a lawyer. Lincoln’s house is 177 years old and he paid $1500 for it. He added on to the house 5 times. Three of his boys were born in the back parlor that was a bedroom at that time. The wall paper is an exact replica of what was there when the Lincolns were in residence and a lot of the furniture pieces were original to them. Lincoln had a perchance for stray cats and adopted any that came to the house. He also did not believe in discipline and his boys were terrors! The Lincolns went through sixteen hired girls (nanny and housemaid) while they lived in Springfield. Mary did all the cooking and the stove in the home is original and her second one. Our group looked around the renovated 4 block area with histories on placards outside the gates.

If you like Abe and history --you will enjoy the tour of the mansion. It is free as well which makes one scratch their head..they do charge for parking at $2 an hour. The tour is 15 minutes tops and you go thru most of the rooms in his home. I do wish they would expound upon some of the history or have a more extensive tour including some of the other homes on the block the NPS has purchased.

We were eager to visit this historical site for the second time. There is a parking fee of $2 but the tour is free. They have a tour every 15 minutes. The tour guide explains all the details of the home and you'll be able to walk both floors of the home. You must purchase your free tour tickets in the visitor center across the home. There is also a gift shop and restrooms. This is a must for everyone go loves history and I highly recommend it for children of all ages. Strollers are not allowed inside the home. The home has air condition so you can be comfortable in hot days!!

Went in July around the 4th with my young daughter (6 yr.). We got there early to get a free tour ticket. We were able to get a tour to start within 15 minutes. There is parking available - it was $2/hr. when I was there (cash or card). I asked and was told that it should not take more than 3 hrs. to do everything - including the tour. Home has original Lincoln furniture and other items. You are able to take photos - even use your flash. You can't touch doors or walls, but none of the kids on our tour were fussed at once - just given a little reminder. The rangers were great and very knowledgeable. There were period actors there. Mary Todd was in the visitor's center. Some younger girls (12 and 14) were dressed in period clothing and reading period stories to children. They all were willing to answer questions - my daughter asked how many clothes they had on (answer - 7 layers total). We both had a great few hours learning a little more about Lincoln. Wear good walking shoes as there are a few blocks to explore. Bring clothing to walk around outdoors (light jacket or umbrella if needed, etc.)

Admission and tour was free but you do have t stop at the visitor center and get yourself scheduled as only 15 go in a group with a guide at one time. The guide was very knowledgable and friendly. The house is painstakingly taken care of and is filled with many of the Lincoln family's original belongings. They lived there for approximately 25 years so it truly was their home and not just some place they lived for a couple of years.

Timed Tickets for free House Tour are REQUIRED. The Lincoln Home has an excellent visitor's center 1 block from the house. Be sure to watch the two separate films at the Center. You have to have a free ticket for a timed tour, so you have to stop at the visitor's center. The streets are graveled so no cars in the immediate area. Look for street (free) parking. House tour guide was excellent. Also they have various re-enactors in the open lot across from the house. Visit the house next to the re-enactor's lot to see the different versions of the Lincoln Home as it was expanded over the years.

177 year old home still contains some of Lincoln's furniture and items. Be sure to visit. Tickets are free but you must visit the welcome center to obtain them. Tours start every 15 minutes or so. Parking was additional but inexpensive. I believe we paid $4 for 2 hours. You can walk to cafes and restaurants. Microbrewery is right away the corner if you can get in. Long wait times around lunch.

Paid a small fee to park, lots of room for kids to run and roam since several blocks are blocked from traffic and preserved. A very informative free tour is provided by park service. Tickets can be obtained inside visitor center at desk. Actual admittance to Lincoln house is timed and size of each tour is limited so check in first thing if you intend to take tour. House is very neat and well preserved.

We had an excellent tour in a small group. Tickets are free too. Go to the Visitor Center to be scheduled on a tour and be sure to take the time to see the movie. It is delightful to walk down the street and just imagine Lincoln and his family talking with neighbors in their front yard or Mr. Lincoln stepping from his horse. A step back in time.

I am still in awe of being in Lincoln's home. It is beautifully restored and easy to see just how they lived from day to day. I could imagine Mr. Lincoln walking home from the law office, stopping to talk to a neighbor, coming in the door, hanging his hat (yes, it's there) as his sons accosted him and smelling the scent of the evening meal wafting from the kitchen. Back of the home is the shed where the cow and the horse were kept and the out house, of course. It's still there. Walk through the neighborhood. All the homes in the 4-block area have been restored. People do not live there but you can get a sense of what it might have been like to live there. It was a thrilling experience that I relive in memory frequently. This is a national park and a ranger will give the tour. You may share it with school children as well as other adults. They are open every day of the year except Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's Day. Free with a ticket you get on site. $2 parking you pay for. There is a gift shop too.

I was here about 30 years ago and it has definitely improved. There are free tours about every 1.5hrs, with a movie on the location and history before the tour. However, I opted (time restraint) for the self guided tour. Parking is very close and abut $4.00 for 2 hours. There is a visitors center (where the sign up for the tour) and the movie theatre is in. I went walking and each home with the 2 block radius has a little sign with what it is and who lived there, There is a phone number that you can call and punch in the "house number" and the self guided tour will thoroughly explain the history of that house and how it relates to the Lincolns. You can walk in about half of them and there is some great reading and interesting original items for you to see inside. All the homes have been redone and preserved to the original look and size. Some you can walk around the back and see the barns and the gardens. It does look "new" as most of the completion was just finished within the past 10 years, but still very true to form of the time. The streets are as they were and there are some interesting wagons and artifacts to complete the feel of the time. I went alone, as I was killing some time before I head to head out of town and I was so glad I took the time to see this as an adult.

FREE admission, you only pay $2 per hour parking. Be aware that this place gets packed and you will likely have to wait 1-2 hours for the tour. You cannot go in alone and they give you set times to go into the home. They have a visitor's center where they show movies etc and you can walk around the "town" and see the homes of the neighbors and even go into some of them. Well worth the stop. We pulled a camper and there was bus parking available, a little tight to park, but doable.

Went to Springfield to learn more about President Lincoln and was not disappointed. Prior to the trip (all adults) I expected to enjoy the Presidential Museum and Library but wasn't sure about bothering with the Lincoln Home. So very glad we did go. The National Park Service does a great job here. Though there were loads of children and school groups, we were sheltered from the chaos as much as possible. Admission is free, under terms of Lincoln's son's gift of the homestead. In addition to the house itself, the entire street/neighborhood is tenderly preserved. Wandering the street feels like visiting Williamsburg.....but a century later. Informative and delightful.

Located in the historic area graduallly being restored, Lincoln' s home is a must see for anyone who knows anything about history. Tickets are available at the nearby visitor's center, they are free, but assign you a time for your tour.

Enjoyed my visit today at Lincoln's home. The docents did a nice job describing The Lincolns' life in Springfield. Learned some interesting facts that are not presented in history books. For example, Lincoln's favorite dessert was Almond cake and that you can google it and try it for yourself. This is a beautiful area to walk around in and read the signage that tells you who lived where. There are eateries near by including a coffee shop and microbrewery. Please note there is a parking lot at the visitor center and the cost starts at $2.00 for one hour. May be cheaper to park in garage near Lincoln library if you wish to spend extended time.

When we arrived at the site we were some of the few people there. You pay $2/hr for parking which is a great deal since everything else is free. The people working in the visitor center were extremely helpful and got us on a tour right away. We were the only two people on our tour which was actually really nice. It made for a more informative tour and all of our questions got answered. I only wish the weather had been a little nicer so we could have explored the site a little more. Also be sure to check out the gift shop because it had lots of great souveniers!

It was interesting to learn that President Lincoln's son Robert sold Abe's last home before the White House to the state of IL for only $1.00 with the condition that it remain free for future visitors. I really enjoyed the home, as it had some remaining artifacts that the Lincoln family possessed and we could see. You were also allowed to take pictures which is great, as some presidential sites do not allow you to take pictures. There was a visit center with a gift shop containing many books relating to Lincoln's life, bathrooms and theater inside that showed movies of Lincoln. The home itself appears well maintained and clean. The volunteer ranger we had was quite animated and friendly; he seemed to enjoy presenting this little slice of history. Even my children enjoyed the tour. I would highly recommend a visit to this place of any place regarding Lincoln in Springfield. We went on a Saturday and it was open. I would check the website ahead of time to make sure they are open for the hours and days you are looking for. For those who have physical limitations, there are stairs in the Lincoln home going up to the second floor. You have the option to stay on the first floor, as those stairs are steep. The visitor center is great though for anyone.

Run by the National Park Service and really done in a very professional way with very knowledgeable personnel. It's free but you must go to the visitor's center to get your free ticket and put on a tour at a certain time. There are 15 people per tour group to go thru the home so they get you scheduled in 10 minute increments. The parking isn't free ($2.00 per hour and you must use a machine to either use cash or credit card and then put the ticket in your car on the dashboard). There are meters on the street but you must plug those also and they have a time limit of 2 hours there also. The home was well worth the visit and don't forget to see the film in the visitor's center which has one theater where it runs on the quarter hour and one theater runs every half hour and it runs for 27 minutes of viewing time and well worth it! Very professionally done and you can really learn allot about how Lincoln came from obscure lawyer to President of the U.S. Very nice clean restrooms and there is a 4 square block of the restored homes and you can walk thru two other homes besides the Lincoln home. Those are self-guided tours. Didn't think at the beginning that this would be so neat but it really was great! We were there for a little over two hours and really took our time but you can go faster if you wish.

Tour of the home is free and parking close by was $2.00. The tour guide was knowledgeable of Lincoln, his wife, and his children. Our group had only four people which gave ease for taking pictures and asking questions.

We enjoyed our visit to the Lincoln Home National Historic Site. We arrived at 8:30 when the visitor center opened so was able to get on the first tour at 9:00. They take about 15 visitors per tour. Jim did an excellent job of taking us through the house and providing information, the tour lasted 30 minutes. If you arrive later you may have to wait for a tour, depends on how busy they are. You can walk around the Home Site area on your own, but need a timed ticket to tour the inside of the house. The visitor center has interesting exhibits. The only negative issue we have is the charge for parking, we paid $4 for 2 hours, it is an automated machine so you have to figure out how to use it and how long you think you will visit, then put the receipt in your car.

The Lincoln Home is fairly easy to get to coming from I55. If you do not have gps on your phone, there are signs posted throughout Springfield. The parking lot had plenty of room (I did visit on a weekday so unsure how crowded it is on the weekend). Parking is $2/hr and I ended up paying for extra time as I just left my vehicle parked in this lot and walked to the other downtown attractions in Springfield as I would rather have my money go to the NPS than a private lot owner.

Word to the wise: Get here early in the day. Tickets are given out first come first serve and though they are free, there is a long wait (3 hours) for a tour of Lincoln’s home if you wait until mid-day. We enjoyed walking the neighborhood and the carts with outdoor exhibits were interesting and entertaining. Our guide was a school teacher and she was very creative in how she gave her presentation. You could tell she loved the site and that made it even more interesting to us. We loved knowing that we were walking where Lincoln and his family walked and lived.
