The bathrooms were clean and well maintained and the gift shop full of interesting Lincoln memorabilia. The parking lot was easy to access, but working the parking ticket machine proved difficult.

This is the only national park in Illinois. They have 4 blocks of restored homes surrounding the Lincoln home that his family lived in for about 25 years prior to his election to the Presidency. Parking is $2/hour and tickets are free for a tour of the home. Bring your cell phone and earbuds to hear a talking tour, too. Be sure to catch the movies in the visitors center.

I am an avid walker, with a goal to walk in all the capital cities of the US. Since I was in Springfield IL, I thought it would be appropriate to visit the home of Abe Lincoln and I am so glad I did. The National Park Services offers a great tour of the home, as well as a lovely area that is cordoned off in the Lincoln neighborhood. I got to the Visitor Center just before 9 AM and got my ticket for the free tour to begin at 9. The guide takes you into the home, and this lasts about 20 minutes. When you come out, you can walk the rest of the neighborhood on your own. I am not into museums, but I do highly recommend this tour! It was awesome! There is also a video shown about Abraham Lincoln in the theater, inside the visitor center. The only cost is parking, in the lot adjacent to the center. Well worth $2 hr parking fee. You can also walk from this center to the state capitol building!

We took a little detour on our road trip so we could stop by the Lincoln Home. Unfortunately all of their tickets were gone for the rest of the day so we were unable to take a guided tour but we did get to walk up and down the street and go into the other homes/interpretive spaces. The exhibits were well done and enjoyable. Everything is free except for the parking but that was only a couple of dollars. I like how they have used the entire block to tell the story of Abe and Mary's life, their interactions with their neighbors and the time period. I highly recommend stopping here.

Not recommended for children who can not stay still during a guided tour. Very thorough and detailed. There is no touching and children are expected to behave with museum behavior. A must see in Springfield. Parking is $4 minimum. It is free to see the home because you pay for parking at the visitor center. Even disabled placard pays.

This was quite disappointing. The first problem being they had the wrong address in the visitor's info. It had us on 7th and south of the parking lot. Had to stop at a store to get directions. He did mention they have many visitors coming in as they can't find the home. He was very helpful. Finally got to the parking lot, where a 2 dollar fee was being charged. A big line at the machine to get a ticket for parking; we opted to into the visitors center and get ours there. Once inside a big sign saying all tours full for the day. I wonder how those people who just paid for parking felt. We were disgusted and just did not go there.

Our group of high school Girl Scouts really enjoyed our visit. Get your tour tickets when you first arrive. We arrived on a Monday about 2 p.m., and the next available tour was 4:15 p.m. We spent the time watching the movie in the Visitor Center and spending time looking at the other old homes on his street, which are part of the historic site. It was interesting hearing what stories were emphasized here and then hearing the stories in the Lincoln Museum. Parking in the lot is $2 per hour. Metered parking on the street is limited to 2 hours per day.

We love the Lincoln Memorial in DC and have visited it several times. The place gives you the unmistakable feeling of being in the presence of greatness (despite the constant noise and bustle from the hordes of daily visitors). It truly is a befitting monument to a giant among men. Driving down from Chicago to Springfield to visit the Lincoln Home, we were hoping to experience something similar, if not greater. And I have to say it was a tad underwhelming. The house and neighborhood have been beautifully preserved/restored. For a while, the surroundings transport you back to the mid-1800s when the Lincolns called this place home. But we found the constant chatter of the tour guide very irritating. I realize they're supposed to stick to the script on these tours, but we found it an unnecessary distraction. Every section of the house has a board in the middle explaining the contents of the room and how it was used. There really is no need for the tour guide to say anything (or even do anything except stand around and make sure people don't touch stuff). It would have been a better idea for them to just be quiet and let people soak in the moment. There is so much history here, so much detail in the house, the furniture and surroundings that all you want to do is walk around taking it all in, trying to imagine what the Lincolns' life must have been like back then. There was no opportunity to do that, which was a bit disappointing. They keep hustling you from one room to another because the next group is about to catch up. Still glad to have visited though, despite all these issues. On a side note - if you visit on a not-so-busy-day, it actually makes sense to park out on the street. Parking on site is limited and it's also $2/hour. If you really want to look around you'll surely be in there at least a couple of hours.

The rangers are excellent. They handle the crowd in tight quarters very well with history and humor! I learned so much about Lincoln and his wife during our time. Don't miss the moving in the visitor center. Then walk outside to join the tour. This is free if you have a Senior National Parks Pass card.

While not as detailed as the museum, it does show you his house, how he lived in Springfield, and a typical street. The tour takes about 25 minutes and it's free. There are a couple of other houses to walk through besides walking down the street itself. We spent about an hour and a half doing the tour and walking around the homes. I'd suggest getting there at least two hours before closing to get into a tour. The parking lot is not very big and costs $2 per hour. We had no problem mid week. But I'm sure at can be crowded on the weekends.

I had not been to the Lincoln Home since I was a young girl, so I did not realize that this was located in downtown among the other residential homes and/or businesses. Parking is $2 per hour at the visitor's center, but that is the only cost. You have to get a ticket within the visitor's center and with it being forth of July weekend, they were fairly busy. We arrived at 9:45 a.m. and we were not able to tour until 11:00 a.m. There are things to see within the visitor's center including a 25 minute video about the life of Lincoln. The neighborhood is blocked off from traffic and you can explore two homes near Lincoln's home. Both homes are more informational and have exhibits and displays rather than original furniture. Our kids enjoyed playing some 19th century games in the lawn adjacent to Lincoln's home. Since they were so busy, they had tours running every 5 minutes and they had different park rangers stationed in different rooms of Lincoln's home. On the first floor, it got a bit noisy when multiple guides were speaking at once. The tour was very informative and we learned a lot. We'll likely come back on a non-holiday weekend to get the full experience.

It was a very nice tour. You pay $2.00 to park at the visitors center and get your free tour ticket. We arrived at 8:15am and a line had started to form, but not huge. We were given tickets for the 9:20am tour. We went and saw a short movie and perused the gift shop. Our tour was very interesting and the view of Abraham Lincoln as a husband and parent was great. Afterwards there was period actors in dress showing children some of the games played during that time. We saw someone dressed as Mary Todd. Was a great experience. Our son absolutely enjoyed it and learned a little more about our 16th President.!

Tours are first-come, first-served (and free) - plan accordingly if going on a weekend. The official parking lot is $2/hour with a somewhat confusing payment system. Came back on another day to walk the neighborhood when it wasn't pouring down rain and found free street parking just south of the historical neighborhood block. The tour itself was very interesting - glad we took the time to do it.

This is a lovely representation of a comfortable middle class home in mid 19th century America. The fact that the head of this family was one of our most revered Presidents is almost secondary as this is such a typical cozy family place. The immediate neighborhood has also been preserved as it would have been in Lincoln's time with crushed stone paths and ample garden spaces. There is no charge for this site only a $4.00 parking fee for a spot in an adjacent lot. You must sign up for a tour of the house, our park ranger who led the tour was friendly and knowledgeable.

I came here with my mom to see the old Lincoln Home. What we saw was way more than expected. Parking costs just $2; you pay with cash or a card, then place the ticket (receipt) on the dash of your car. There is no fee to enter what is a two-block neighborhood where Lincoln lived before becoming President after his 24 years of living in Springfield. Tickets for guided tours are free but tend to go really fast. However, there is so much to walk around and see for yourself; give yourself at least an hour to appreciate how finely preserved this historic site is, taking you back to an era which helped shaped America and should never be forgotten. I'd say that this is a bucket list must that everyone should see. This site is the only National Park in the state of Illinois. The Park staff members are very knowledgeable and helpful. It feels like a "frozen" place in the middle of a more modern city that has grown and moved on through another century, but Lincoln's presence is--essentially--Lincoln's presence. Amazing place.

If you take a trip to Springfield, then you have to stop at the Lincoln home. The Park Rangers are so knowledgable and friendly. At 9:05 we had a 2 hour wait but it was worth it. Donation only and it's $2 per hour to park. Don't push the time on parking, you will get a ticket.

The house is in a restored area near the old and new capital buildings. The area is well maintained. I had 4 of my kids with. Ages 12, 7, 7, and 4. Tickets are free. I arrived and got tickets for 40 minutes later. So we watched a free movie about Lincoln and went on the twenty minute tour. My kids asked the park people a lot of questions and they were politely answered. All four liked it and asked me more questions later. It was a nice place to visit.

Visited on 2/27/15 and signed up for the 4:00 pm tour (the last tour of the day is 4:30 pm). Pick up a free ticket at the Visitor Center and choose a tour time. Parking is inexpensive ($2 worth of quarters in the Visitor Center parking lot). While waiting for your tour time, take the time to view the free movie available in the Visitor Center... very informative. The tour itself is quite humbling and gives a lot of insight into the Lincolns and their life once Mr. Lincoln became a successful lawyer and before he was elected President. Our tour guide was very knowledgeable and was able to answer all of our questions and also offered further information on the Lincolns and their life. Seeing the space where the Lincolns lived and being able to walk through their home is an experience that you can not get from a textbook or from pictures. I am glad we visited during a winter month as I expect this attraction is very busy during warmer months. There are also other historic homes nearby that can be visited. We did not do this as we wanted to view the film at the Visitor Center before it closed at 5 pm and it also happened to be a very cold day with temperatures in the low teens and wind.

Was on a mini vacation and came here for my first stop. Been coming here since I was a kid and still well kept up. Parking is 2 dollars an hour which is very reasonable considering how expensive Chicago is. The tickets are free though they are required to get into the house. For back then the house was big though it's kind of small compared to today's average home. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and answered all the questions people had she even took pictures for people at the end. It is always interesting to see how people lived back then without indoor plumbing or electricity.

I'm a single Mom of two kids, and I love to travel. I'm always looking for great deals. This is a place I have been before, and I wanted to share with my kids. It is FREE, so if you don't like it, you are only "out" your time, but it is a real treasure in my opinion. We parked in a nearby lot for $2 an hour. You have to go into the Visitor's Center to get your pass. It was a rainy day, so the Ranger who took us on the tour was kind to let us go into the house quickly. It is cool to see the furniture and decorations of the period. Many of the pieces were from the Lincoln's actual house. It is appropriate for all ages, but there are steps to get into the house (they probably have a ramp as an option), but I am not sure if they have a "lift" to get upstairs. All in all, a rare treat to see how Abe lived before he moved on to the White House.

Very interesting. I really didn't hold a lot of hope for being wowed with this visit, but I was pleasantly surprised. Really got a feel for how the Lincoln's lived and their day-to-day life. Part of it was because our tour guide was absolutely wonderful and you could tell that she took great pride in getting everything just right. I found it very fascinating to see their home, as they lived, and related some of the things (like the privy), to if I had lived at that time with my brothers. A must see for any history buff or Lincoln fan. I really enjoyed this more than I ever thought I would and another great thing about it is that it was free! You just need to get a ticket for the tour at the visitor's center and you are good to go. Thank you NPS and thank you to Robert Lincoln for selling the home back to Illinois for $1 and making them promise to you that there would never be a charge to enter this piece of history.
House was free. Parking was $2. Nice tour of the house. You could also see the other properties on the area but the house was the most interesting. Tour guide was informative

The Lincoln Home is beautifully laid out with original and period pieces. It is free to visit, but you will pay a small fee to park. We really felt the spirit of Lincoln and his family. The other historic homes nearby are also interesting to visit. Tickets are free, but you can only enter the Lincoln Home at the time indicated on your ticket. Entry is done by small groups led by a volunteer. We found this method to be very intimate. We were in a tour group of about 12.

Lincoln's home tour is free, just pay $2 a hour for parking. It was neat being in the same house where Lincoln once lived. The tour guides are very knowledgeable, and the tour was interesting. I suggest starting your Springfield tours here, learning about Lincoln and then on to the other museums and his Tomb.

It's an awesome feeling to say you where in Lincolns home. It's free to tour the house. The tour is lead by a smart and friendly park ranger who will answer all questions you might have. The tour lasted a good 20-30 mins also ask a ranger if Mary and Abe Lincoln are around they have actors who look like the real Mary and Abe and are truly stuck in the time period make sure you get a picture with them. Also feel free to look at the neighbors houses you cant tour the insides though. Also be aware in $2.00 an Hour to park your car.

The large parking lot for Lincoln Home National Historic Site had many available spaces when we arrived at 2:10pm on a Sunday. The pay station only allows maximum of one hour parking but displays that next tour will be in an hour. At that moment, we knew we needed over an hour parking. At the Visitor Center, our free tickets were issued by the Ranger for the 3pm tour as expected. It was a little inconvenient to go back and purchase another parking ticket to cover the time before the Lincoln 20 minute tour. The Lincoln House tour plus the other house exhibits easily takes over an hour. (Lincoln House is the only one requiring the free tickets.) I suggest free two hour street parking on corner of 8th and Edwards. Then you can walk directly onto the historic site property and ask for free tickets to Lincoln’s Home at the Visitor Center. If you wish, you can donate two dollars in the center to cover the parking revenue loss.

Run by the national park service and everything is free, except for a $2 parking fee if you use their lot (you can find 2 hour street parking). The park service bought up 4 city blocks to convert to the historic site, knocking down any modern building and renovating all remaining historic buildings that were there during the time Lincoln lived there. The actual home is mostly original, with many of Lincoln's furnishings as well. Plan to spend 2-3 hours touring the grounds and visitor center.

Loved being able to enter into Lincoln's "neighborhood" and feeling like you were being taken back in time. The National Park Service has acquired a lot of the area surrounding Lincoln's home (I believe it is about 4 blocks) and you can walk around and see many other homes and buildings as well. Admission is free but you must reserve a spot on the tour. Tour guides here as well as all of the historical attractions visited are very knowledgeable and interesting. Very impressed with the care taken to preserve and maintain this area. The only reason I did not rate it excellent is accessibility. While the first floor is accessible to a wheelchair user, my daughter had to view photos of the bedrooms on the second level. We also did not tour any other buildings because we were unsure of their accessibility.

We visited with our 5 and 7 year old daughters. The national park rangers and volunteers at the site were extremely friendly and helpful. The tour was very interesting and the movies at the visitors center were informative. If you enjoy presidential history, you can't beat this stop. The price is $2 to park, otherwise the tickets for the house tour, free!! It was pretty surreal to stand in the house that Lincoln lived in. You really feel like you are stepping back in time, the houses and streets around Lincoln's house are done in the same time period.

It's just as I remember it 30 years ago...nothing has changed, and that's a good thing. There is a small parking lot, I think it was $2 an hour...there are around 60 spots. We got there around 9:45 on a Sat. and went straight to the visitor center to get the tickets for the tour...they were for the 10:35 tour which gave use plenty of time to slowly walk the two historic blocks of very nicely restored houses...there are two or three that are open to the public, they all have signs describing who had lived there as Lincolns neighbors. The tour of Lincolns house was around twenty minutes start to finish, not real exciting...but a good tour none-the-less. If you're heading to Springfield it's really worth the time to stop and look around.

I have often visited the Lincoln Home National Historic Site and recently decided to just walk the neighborhood after hours. It is a step back into time. Feel the give of wooden sidewalks as you admire the architecture of Abraham’s neighborhood and read of his neighbors. Imagine him walking home from his office and his sons playing in the yard. Be sure to come back during the day to take in the movie and exhibits in the Visitors’ Center. As soon as you get there get your free ticket for the tour of the house. It will be for a specific time so get the ticket and then do your touring. Come, soak in the atmosphere and understand.

We were here bright and early. There's a parking lot beside the visitor center. We used the electronic machine to pay 2$ per hour for parking. You could pay with dollar bills or credit card, but not with coins. We went in the visitor center first and got our tickets which were free. Saw the 23 minute movie about Lincoln and then went to the meeting spot on the benches in the street for our tour. A national park ranger met us and explained that we had to hold small bags to the front of our bodies so they would not touch a wall. We made our way into the house. We were allowed to take all the pictures we wanted. The guide did a nice job of explaining about the house, what was actually the Lincoln's and what had been reproduced. We walked through the parlors, dining room, upstairs, and back down into the kitchen and the tour ended in the backyard. There were 2 additional homes of neighbors that we were permitted to tour too. We returned to the visitor center to visit their small gift shop. I was impressed by the Lincoln home, but I think my favorite was his museum. Also we were allowed to use the original handrail in the front stairway. (same handrail from when Lincoln was there).
The home is wonderfully restored as are many houses in the whole area. Walking through the neighborhood, history comes alive. The best part - it's all free (except for parking - $2.)

Admission to the Abraham Lincoln home is free, but by tour only in fairly small groups. If you're doing the trifecta -- Lincoln's home, Museum and tomb-- all in one day (easily done), strongly suggest you go to the Abraham Lincoln Visitor Center first (just one block from the home, 6 blocks from the museum) and secure a ticket for one of the timed tours. This is particularly important during prime tourist season. If it's a short wait, you can walk the surrounding historic neighborhood; there are two other homes adjacent to the Lincoln home that you can self-tour.

This was a great experience. Free tickets for the Lincoln Home tour are available at the Visitor Center, where there is a gift shop located. Parking is $2 and there is a lot on the grounds. Watch your step as you travel back in time to world of sidewalks made of wood boards and rough uneven streets. I recommend this attraction to anyone visiting and touring Springfield. It really is amazing and you may learn something you didn't know.

Feel at one with our 16th President when you step foot into his home in Springfield, Illinois. This place is as humble and modest as the man was brave and heroic. The tour guides are funny and informative, and the neighborhood is one big history lesson. Make this place a must-see in your lifetime.

We arrived in the lot and paid our $2 for parking and then waited about 10 minutes before we started our tour. Just amazed standing in the same house where Abe Lincoln once lived. Comparing how he lived to how we live today is just mind blowing. His office was just a desk in the corner of the family room, his family room had a couple chairs by the fireplace, the exact spot where Republicans offered him the Presidency. The upstairs is 5 bedrooms almost all connected. Just a great time and pictures are allowed.

In 1880 Robert Lincoln, son of Abraham and Mary Lincoln, sold this home to the city for $1 with the promise that it would be maintained and that visitors could always tour the home with no admission fee. Well, 134 years later, amazingly the home has been maintained correctly and there is still free admission.

My husband and I, along with some friends, took our kids to visit this place. We arrived and paid for parking. $2 for 2 hours of parking. Not too bad. Then we went in to get a tour. The tours are FREE. Nice to find something for free when everything is so pricey these days. You do have to go with a group though so you need to make sure to get a time for a tour. We got our time and met at the specified spot. The park rangers took us through a narrated tour. Pictures are okay to take but we were not allowed to touch anything. After the tour we wandered around the town for a while and visited some of the other houses.

see Lincoln's home exactly as it existed in 1860. Also, the entire 2 block area has been restored to mid-1800 vintage. Just like walking back in time. Priceless. No fee for touring the house and the entire historic site, because the Lincoln family stipulated that rule when the house was turned over to the public.

This is a highlight. Abe Lincolns' family home and the entire neighbourhood preserved and restored to reflect the way it was - is simply impressive and a must see if visiting Springfield Illinois. The tour is free and very informative - we would have paid $25 pp - to give indication of its' real value.

There is a parking lot across from the visitor's center for a small fee ($2/hr). There is metered street parking and a parking deck near the museum about 6 blocks away. Start at the visitor's center to reserve your tickets. Tours run every 30 minutes and are free. We arrived near opening time at 9AM. We heard tickets are reserved fast. If so, there is plenty to do in the area and return at a later time. There is a short movie to watch prior to tour about President Lincoln's life in Springfield. It is a guided tour by very knowledgeable a national park ranger. Tour takes about 20 minutes and plenty of time to ask questions.You can take pictures inside his home. Stay on the second floor's designated carpet because if you cross the line there are motion sensors that will alarm. It happened on our tour. lol quite embarrassing for that gentleman. The rooms are replicated to time with paint, wallpaper, carpet, and drapes. See the couch in the back parlor where Mr Lincoln was offered the nomination for president, see his desk, where he shaved and the kitchen where his favorite dessert was made....Almond cake. The ranger takes you back in time throughout the tour. There is wheelchair accessibility for first floor. All three generations of our group enjoyed the tour.

The NPS acquired about 4 blocks of the Lincoln home neighborhood. The actual home and furnishings can be seen on a free timed ticket. Two other homes can be seen at your own pace and have exhibits about the renovations the Lincolns did to the house. The visitor center has 2 films about Lincoln's early life and times. No admission but there is a $2 per hour parking fee which is half price with a NPS pass.

This house is part of the 4 blocks of historic area managed by National Park Service. The entrance to Lincoln Home is free. You need to pay for parking ($1/hr at NPS lot, but street metered parking is only 1 quarter per 30 minutes). Go to visitor and get a ticket for a free guided tour of the house (you are only allowed to enter with a guide in a tour group of 20). Tour lasts about 20 minutes. The guide (park ranger) will explains to you all the rooms, funitures inside the house, and Lincoln's family life before he became the President. Most funitures are still original. Photography is allowed. Allow 1 hr.

Visiting Lincoln's home and neighborhood was an amazing experience. The beautiful, quiet streets make you feel you are back in the nineteenth century. Costumed docents across the street and very knowledgeable national park ranger guides bring the house to life. Our guide was extremely friendly and well informed. Not really a tour for children; the children on our tour seemed very bored, Highly recommended for history/Presidential buffs or anyone who enjoys architecture.

Great step back in time tour. Our Park Ranger who gave us the tour was top notch and made the tour of the home both entertaining and educational. This is a don't miss stop when in Springfield. The entire home area is quite interesting and has many people there to tell you the history of each home in the area. Tickets for the house tour are free but get there early or tickets may be gone. My entire family enjoyed this greatly

In the interest of full disclosure,I am retired and don't have to work, but I have been working at Lincoln Home for the past 6 years as a Park Guide because I love the place. So here's something just to convey my impression of what visitors think of the site: You know how often you hear someone go off on the issue of wasteful and unnecessary government spending? Well, not once, never ever, has any one of the thousands of people I have interacted with at the Park said anything about the Lincoln Home National Historic Site being a waste of our tax dollars.

I took my daughter to see the Lincoln House and we both loved it. It is a National Park right in town. There are 4 blocks that you can walk through that are a step back in time. There is the Lincoln House and 2 of the neighbors homes that we got to explore. The guides encouraged picture taking which is rare. She also said be sure to use the hand rail going up the steps, not only for safety but because it is the original handrail that President Lincoln used himself. Very cool. Many things in the home are actual pieces the family owned. A must see for any American. There is also a gift shop and information center. The tour is free. There is a $2 per hour fee to park but you can get through everything at this site in about an hour. I would definately go back again.

This four-block neighborhood includes Lincoln's home that he bought in 1844 for $1,200 and lived in until he went to Washington in 1861. Lincoln's home has been restored to it's 1861 condition and many of the other homes in this neighborhood have also been restored (at least on the exterior). The visitor's center is excellent and there is a very interesting video on Lincoln's life that you should see before you tour the neighborhood.

The Lincoln Home is one of Springfield’s Premier attractions. I arrived shortly after the site opened and was greeted in the visitor’s center where I found the rangers and staff very helpful and knowledgeable about not only the Lincoln Home but other sites in the area. There are a limited number of parking spaces available in the lot adjacent to the visitor’s center. Payment for parking is done through a kiosk which takes cash or credit card. After a brief stop at the visitor’s center I was directed to the Arnold House where I was met by a Ranger who escorted our group on a very informative tour of the Lincoln Home. The guided tour of the home took about 45-minutes and our guide was quite knowledgeable and more than willing to answer the questions posed by the members of our group. I was very pleased to find out that photos inside of the Home are not only permitted but encouraged. Following the guided tour we were free to visit the other home and sites around the historic area. Admission to the Lincoln home is free, donations are accepted in the visitor’s center. The Lincoln Home is one of the must see attractions when visiting the Springfield area.

A very nice visitor's center greets you with some artifacts, info, gift shop, and two movies. It's all free, except parking, which is $2 an hour. Get your tickets as soon as you arrive for the tour. The tour is brief, but neat. There's plenty to fill 1.5 - 2 hours while you wait for your tour to begin.

The Lincoln Home is just a short walk from the Hilton Springfield and is a part of a preserved mid 1800's neighborhood. Get to the visitor's center first thing in the morning to pick up free tickets for a tour of the Lincoln Home. We neglected to do this on Friday and Saturday, but were advised to arrive there at 8:30 AM on Sunday morning ("while people are at church") to get tickets for the 9:00 AM tour, and we were able to do so with no problem. Tickets are free, but please make a contribution. Due to the sequestration, money is tight, and these folks do a great job giving the tours and providing this great resource. In the neighborhood, there are signs on each front lawn providing some history of the residents and their relationship to the Lincolns. There is also a telephone number posted that you can dial for an audio tour. The National Park rangers are friendly, helpful and have great suggestions for other places to go and things to see and do in Springfield. We went to the Lincoln House as the last thing we did before we left Springfield, and it just served to tie everything together. It's a wonderful feeling to be in the only home that Abraham and Mary owned during their marriage...just wish there was more time to linger in it, to read all of the captions, placards, etc. A National treasure!
Wonderful guides and beautiful restorations. Our grandson was full of questions which were encouraged by the period actors. Pay a visit if you can.

Great, but quick visit. Very informative, our guide was super. The tour was free, but there is a limit to group size. We had a 2 hour wait. (Parking is $2.00 an hour.) We toured the other lovely houses and walked across the street and had a wonderful lunch before returning for our tour. The guide was good at including our children in the conversation and pointed out what life was like for the Lincolns. Overall, we thought it was the most touching stops of our Springfield visit.

Admission is free because Robert Lincoln left this as a condition of his donating the property to the park service. There is a visitor's center where you can register for a tour of the homesite. There is also a small gift shop area and a brief movie on the life of Lincoln. Park guides will direct you through a tour of the home. There are not many original pieces in the home but there are a few, including Lincoln's original desk and reproductions of the wallpaper that was originally installed. If you love Lincoln, this site is a must see. You can also walk the streets of old springfield and learn a little bit about Lincoln's neighbors at the time. Very interesting.

Such a great house to see. The park rangers are very friendly and helpful. It is really interesting to see the place where the Lincoln's lived while in Springfield. Every room has a little piece of history for you to see and hear/read about. Love that it is free to see. You do need tickets, but those are free from the visitor center and they have a nice picture of the house on the back if you wanted a keepsake photo. We were early so we found parking easily on the street and only paid a dollar for 2 hours. We were able to take our time and really look around the little neighborhood, (several of the houses have self-guided exhibits inside them) and browse the gift shop afterward.

You are transported back in time when you step inside his home. On advice from others, we made this our 1st stop & glad we did. You need a free ticket to tour the home as they limited the number of people inside. We arrived at 11:30 on a Tuesday morning & our ticket time was at 1pm...they fill up fast. We had our kids take part in the Junior Ranger program, which kept them busy. We walked down a few blocks to the Old State Capitol. (Free inside self guided tour) by the time we were done & had lunch, we walked back & toured his home. We then did the museum & tomb the rest of the afternoon. Parking was $2 an hour...should've/could've found parking on the street for a $1 an hour.

The National Park service gives free guided tours of the Lincoln Home. Robert Todd Lincoln sold the home to the State for $1 on condition that no admission be charged to visitors. You must obtain a free ticket for the tour, which you get in the visitor center. The home has been beautifully restored, and most of the furniture is original. The Lincoln Home is a short 4 block walk from the Lincoln Presidential Library and Museum.

Get your free ticket to go inside Abraham Lincoln's house. Thanks to his son, Robert Lincoln, we can visit the home for free. In it are some of the original furnishings and decor.. The tour guides are very knowledgeable. Photos are encouraged. Fee for the parking lot. One of three excellent attractions (Lincoln tomb, Lincoln-Herndon Law Office and Lincoln home) in Springfield.

We spent about an hour and a half at this historic site. There is a great movie in the Visitor's Center about Abe's life and how he got to the White House. Several of the houses are open for self-guided tours and the tour of the Lincoln home is led by a very knowledgeable and friendly park ranger. It's a great field trip for those interested in Abraham Lincoln. The house tour tickets are free, but they do "sell out" early. We got there at 1:50 and had to wait until 3:30 for our house tour. The rest of the tours booked up very quickly after that and a "sold out" sign went up on the door. Parking was $2.00 and the rest was free. You could leave a donation after the house tour to help fund additional restoration projects. The gift shop was great too. It was filled with many books on Abraham & Mary Todd Lincoln along with other memorabilia.
Daily 8:30 to 5 PM 8th and Jackson Streets. Free Admission

I went there later on in the day and the tours were full, so set that up early. I still got to walk up the street there and see the neighborhood as it was in his day, even got to speak to honest Abe as I found him relaxing in his back yard. This area is blocked from general traffic and a couple houses in the area contain artifacts from his day. $2 for parking but you can walk around for free so well worth the 2 bucks! Next time I'm in the area I will be sure to go back to get the full tour!

This is another must see sight in Springfield, IL. The Lincoln House. It is very well maintained and you get an excellent half hour tour with a Park Ranger, but because it's free and because it is what it is, you are rushed through the house with another tour fast on your heels. I might suggest you do the tour first, and walk the street looking into the other "Unfurnished" houses, then go back again and tour the house a second time. It's worth it, and you'll probably get a different Park Ranger to guide you through. Parking costs about $2.00/hour, so plan to be there for about two to three hours.
location: Long Branch, New Jersey, United States

text: Excellent historical site - that is free! Make sure to get tickets in the morning so that you know what time you will be permitted into the home. Cancellation station here if you have the National Parks Passport book. My whole group learned a lot about Lincoln through the tour.

It's free, but there is a two dollar parking charge. They have restored the whole block you can stroll around and see the inside of three houses. The Lincoln house requires a guided tour. Very pleasant.
Sadly, we only gor to see the ouside. You must get there early! Tickets (which are free) go FAST!

We enjoyed this visit. You need to reserve free tickets for the home tour. This tour is free as a condition by Lincoln's heirs when the property was given away. There is a lot across the street which you pay at the pay box. If you have an America the Beautiful Pass, it discounts your parking. Tour guides great.

This is a great place to go and learn so much about Abraham Lincoln and his family. We got a personal tour, which with young children worked very nicely. We didnt stay long but was able to ask any questions and learned so much more about life back then. Beautiful! No fee to get in but you do need to pay for parking if you park in their lot. But even that is minimal. Only $2

My 7 yr old daughter really enjoyed this as did my husband and I. This is a National Park, and park rangers give a great tour. A lot to see here! I think we paid $3 to park and that was it. My daughter did a scavenger hunt they had to earn her Junior Park Ranger badge and really like that!

Great for young and old alike! Well worth the $12 admission. Bring your AAA card for $1 off admission. Park on the street behind the museum for 50c per hour. Walk around the area to see the historic downtown and be sure to step inside the historic railroad depot which has been restored. Beautiful!

There is a $2.00 parking fee, but tickets for the guided tour of the Lincoln's home is free. Suggest you allow 2 to 2 1/2 hours so you can walk the entire four block preserved area and read the historically information throughout the neighborhood. Also, don’t miss the short film in the visitor’s center.

This attraction does an excellent job of putting you back in Lincoln's time and place. Take the free Lincolns' neighborhood tour and learn about their neighbors. The home tour is free and the NPS visitor's center where you pick up the tickets has more information inside and a friendly staff. Ample $2. parking.

The Lincoln home feels like you're back in the 1850's. The national park consists of several buildings through which you can tour including the Lincoln Home. Lincoln's home is well worth an inside tour to see where he slept and ate and composed many of his speaches. Parking costs a few dollars but is easily accessible. A very enjoyable and educational experience.

After paying $2.00 to park and watching the video at the visitor's center, we headed over to the "gray house with the red fire hydrant", which was the meeting spot for all tours. We waited 10 minutes or so and then our tour guide lead us into the house. We saw all the rooms, took pictures and basically squeezed into each hot spot in order to get a glimpse of everything. We must've had about 20 people on our tour, annoying kids included. The one kid tried to climb onto Mrs. Lincoln's bed! I couldn't believe how irresponsible the parents were the whole time. In fact, this family ruined my experience.

Worth seeing if you are a huge Lincoln fan and are in the area for a couple of days. If you have to choose between this and the Lincoln Presidential Museum though, chose the Lincoln Presidential Museum instead. Onsight parking for $2.00. Tour will take about 45 minutes for everything.

Step back into time. Start at visitor center at 246 Market St. Parking is validated there. Park at 304 Dutton St. Use annual America the Beautiful pass for 1/2 off admission of Boott Cotton Mills Museum at 115 John St. ($3 instead of $6). Ask for ear plugs where you pay. When looms are running, very loud! Make sure to visit second floor for history. Must see Mill Girls and Immigrant Exhibit at 40 French St. Only open in afternoons but free. All area businesses either use old buildings or build to look old. Nice walk between buildings.

Really nice tour lead by nice guides. You ride the trolley and take a nice boat ride through a lock with a lot of interesting history along the way. Our 11 year old really liked it too! $12 for adults and $8 for children and lasts two hours.

The outdoor portion of the park is embarrassingly run down, The walking trails are poorly marked, have plaques missing (apparently stolen) that would explain the stops, and follow garbage filled canals that need to be cleaned out. In addition to trash, there are numerous bikes, lawn furniture, tires, etc. in there. Not sure why a superintendent would let the park get to this point of disrepair. There were numerous rangers and maintenance people around but the condition of the park does not reflect their attention. The gem of the park is the Boott cotton mills museum. The admission is $6 for adults but it is worth the price. You would not know it from the street but there is a lot in there. Teaches you how the mill functioned and what the town was like when the mill was in operation.

Lowell national park is a great city park showing the industrialization of this country in the 1800s into the 1900s. Lots to do and see. Some parts are free and fees are very reasonable. Recommend the canal boat tours highly! All ages will enjoy this tour. Also the canal walk ways that follow the canals are an interesting way to see the city. Get a map at the visitor center. Walk the part from the visitor center to the Boott Mill to the river and along the river. There are a lot of signs pointing out the sites along the way. Note: At the visitor center the parking is validated at the desk in the visitor center. Stop in there at the end of your visit. Discount at Boott Mill for National park pass holder.

We stopped by the Lowell Mill museums on our way home, so didn't have a lot of time. There is a lot to see. We were able to see the Boott Cotton Mills Museum- which had a large space filled with the vintage looms- all the belts were spinning but only a few at the end were producing fabric. You get an idea of the noise level in this workplace. Upstairs was a museum of photos, equipment etc detailing the process from raw cotton to finished material. There was a ranger up there to offer info. Of particular interest were video interviews of people who had worked in the mills not that long ago. There was also a free museum at the nearby boarding house for the girls. We did not have time to take the free trolley tour (free with museum admission I think-- admission for us was only $4 since we had the senior national park pass).

One of the 1st National Park Services Urban National Parks designed to preserve and protect the historic importance of the Industrial Revolution. Lowell, MA was one of the 1st US industrial centers. There are tours of the 1st cotton mills, a museum that follows the evolution of Lowell from the early 1800’s through the 21st century, a trolley ride, and the Canal Tours. The Canal Tours made be one of the least highlighted features of the Lowell Park Tours. The Canal Tour runs 1.5 hours, board the old trolley’s to the canal boat start point, step on to a 25 person uncovered boat, a Park Ranger does a narrated tour as you progress through 1800 century man made canals that take you to the Merrimack River. Be ready for trip there are no rest rooms after you leave the Visitors Center, bring water it is an uncovered boat and it will get hot. At $8 this canal boat tour is a bargain but hurry the canal tour only run from Memorial Day till September 1st.

My daughter and I arrived at the visitor's center in the late afternoon just in time to look around a little and take the canal boat tour. We boarded a trolley to take us the few blocks down to the boat dock for our tour. Cost for the canal tour was $8/person or $4/person if you have a National Parks annual pass. This tour was well worth the cost. Emily, our ranger, was very knowledgable about how the canals allowed Lowell to become one of the 1st big factory towns in the United States. She discussed how/why the canals were built as well as pointed out areas of interest along the way. We even disembarked upstream to get a close look at one of the locks. Originally, we had planned to spend an afternoon in Lowell. After taking the canal tour, we decided to come back for a second day to see the rest of the park.

I'm a Lowell native and I didn't take this tour until a couple of years ago while entertaining an out of town guest. I want to take everyone I know on it now! Our guide was not too keen on us (she must have been one of the stricter ones and we were just having a good time) which is why I gave it 4 instead of 5. I'm sure some of the guides are great though! Cheap and really educational - plus it's so nice to see Lowell from a boat!

The Evening Canal tour combines the history of Lowell's historic water-powered mills with a refreshing ride on the Merrimack River. They have preserved the historic flood gate (which has only been dropped to prevent massive flooding 2 times) and the locks to go through passing from canal to river. The guide mentioned that they are starting a bike tour of native american sites in the area, and a new ranger is starting to give bird-watching canal tours. A very nice way to spend the evening (they also have them during the day). $8 per person.
We paid $12 each for going through the museums and taking a 90 minute canal tour by boat. Very informative, well informed rangers, great museums. Well worth it!
We took a canal tour, part trolley and part boat. Interesting history of the town and its part in the industrial revolution. Need to reserve in advance. $8.00 each

We found the exhibits very informative and enjoyed the canal tour. With an apparent surplus of rangers in and out, we were never told that we could take the trolly to the mill. My wife was clearly using her cane to move slowly about the visitor center so one would expect to be informed of the alternative to the long walk. In the mill we were never given nor advised to use ear protection. The machines are VERY loud. It would also have been nice if some of the many rangers seen moving in and out could be stationed along the exhibit to answer questions or direct us. We also were surprised to learn our Senior Passes did not work and we had to pay a discounted fee.

My husband and I spent the afternoon walking around Lowell. We started our tour at the National Park Visitor Center, then we walked down the cobblestone roads to the New England Quilt Museum store, and from there we walked along the water canals/trolley tracks to the Boott Cotton Mills Museum. We went into this museum, which included a weave room, interactive exhibits, and video programs. After seeing the museum, we had a picnic lunch overlooking the Water Canal. In total, we spent less than $20.00 for museum tickets, lunch, and parking. We plan to go back to Lowell next year to take in the Engineering Innovation Boat Tour. This trip was stress free, easy walking distance, and low cost.

How many of you have driven through an old industrial city, over the ripped up railroad tracks and dirty canals, and wondered what it was like in its heyday? Well a trip up to the Lowell National Park in Lowell, MA, will help answer this question. The National Park offers a combined canal, trolly and mill tour, which is informative, fun and a great value. I worked in Lowell for years before going on this tour and am now sorry I waited so long. The canal tour takes you in a boat, through manual 100+ year old locks to the Great Francis Gate. Park Rangers and historical actors drive home the importance of this canal system to the industrial growth of Lowell. The trolley tour is fun and relaxing and you can even see an actual mill turbine in operation. All this in one tour for less than $10! A fun and informative visit for the family.

We visited last weekend on a rainy, cloudy day but it was the perfect solution to the dreary weather outside. First, we visited the visitors center and the ranger inside was extremely helpful in not only the history of the area but assisting in walking directions. Make sure to get your NPS Passport book stamped here, watch a documentary for free, learn a brief history of the mills, and touch and feel bobbins, thread, and clothing/textiles made in the mills. We then visited the house/mill where the mill girls would live and work (free). More rangers are inside to offer insights, stamp NPS Passport books, and give history lessons for those visiting. Make sure to walk along the canal to get there to see the water and the trains that would come into the area in the past. Lastly, we went to the Boott Cotton Museum (discounted price for students). Here is where they still make textiles today! It is loud inside on the first floor where the machines are (they offer ear plugs) and it was great to have a guide inside personally turn on/off a few machines and explain/show how they worked, were threaded, different styles they would weave and so on. The museum on the second floor was great and extremely interactive. Plus, outside there is a beautiful garden and gazebo to relax in and a trolley service! All of this is a few steps from a cute, main street type of setting with small restaurants, coffee shops, and bakeries.

We've been in the area several times and decided to finally take the time to visit. Beautiful ranch! Pay the entrance fee to take the ranger-guided tour of the house. Our guide was very well informed and kept the tour interesting. Make sure to stop along the self-guided drive to see the different sights and read about LBJ and his family. We learned a lot about LBJ and some about the Texas Hill Country.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Getting onto the property is free. It is a huge working ranch. The self guided driving tour covers the whole property and the life of LBJ. Him and his family are buried there, his childhood school, and the Texas White House are all part of the exhibit. The Texas White House has a private tour that is $3.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: This was our third or fourth visit, spanning times when we simply drove in through the river, just like the family, when we rode a tour bus with taped monologue, and, now, when we drove ourselves through considerably more of the ranch and stopped to go inside the house. The house, $3, had been off limits on previous visits.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Interesting, enjoyable and informative. It costs a few dollars to tour the Johnson home, and it is well worth it. Don't miss the cars in the old tool shop.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: We took a side trip here and are glad we did. The ranch is beautiful and I can see why LBJ loved it so much. It's a nice trip through history, and the house has been restored to look exactly as it did when LBJ was alive. Retro furniture, but of its time, and seeing it, you learn about the home's inhabitants' personal tastes.. The rangers know their stuff, and the groups are small enough that no one feels "closed in on" while taking the tour. The National Park Service has done a wonderful job, and I suggest buying the audio CD available at the gift shop. It's $7 and while you're driving through the park it not only tells you about what you are going to see, but has comments from LBJ's daughter and former employees.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: This is my 5th Presidential home to visit and no doubt the most interesting. What a wonderful 600 plus acres the Johnson's gave to America. It is FREE and the house tour costs $4 . . . quite interesting . .. you will depart relaxed, just as Lyndon did after every visit. It has something to do with the Pedernales River, the live oaks, the cattle, and grasses blowing in the Texas breeze.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: We visited here one other time and really enjoyed it. Our son was in school at that time, so since he had a free day, we decided to go back so he could see it. The initial place to stop is part Texas State Park/part National Park, but you get a driving permit for free to drive around the ranch and a map.. Signs direct you to the actual LBJ ranch where the Texas Whitehouse is located. Along the way, the Sauer-Beckmann farm is interesting; they make candles, soap and do home canning from the garden. Also along the way is LBJ's first schoolhouse; his birthplace home, (good restrooms behind the home), the cemetery where he and Lady Bird and other family members are buried, and his grandfather's home. After this comes the airplane hanger where LBJ's Air Force "1/2" plane sits. (So named because the airstrip at the ranch could not handle a full sized Air Force One jet.) Near the hangar is a building where you can buy tickets ($3.00 a person for adults, kids 17 and under free) for an inside tour of the Texas White House. For anyone with age on them, it is like going home again; very 60s vintage interior. There is also a building which houses old LBJ cars including the infamous blue amphicar which could be driven into a lake. Afterwards, we drove to Johnson city to eat and saw LBJ's boyhood home, the tour of which was excellent as well. Across from the boyhood home is a National Park Service center which had some history of LBJ and excellent restrooms and drinking fountains.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Much more interesting than I had anticipated. Very well done. The house tour, at $3, is well worth the price.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: We were staying in the New Braunfels area for several days and made a trip to LBJ Ranch. It is a little over an hour from there and we made a day trip out of it. LBJ Ranch had been recommended to us by friends who had visited it and it was NOT a disappointment. Johnson was a very hometown kind of guy and the tour through his home and the history of the his family are definitely worth the time. You can tour the ranch free but the tour through the house is only $3. There are also a couple of short movies that enlighten you about this historic president. Don't miss the display of his old cars in the building behind the visitors center. They don't make them like that anymore.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: After picking up a driving pass for the LBJ ranch at the visitors center, we drove through the ranch. We saw a few longhorn cattle, wild deer eating pecans, goats and hereford cattle. We stopped at the visitor center near the home and purchased tickets for the tour. Our National Park passes did not cover this tour, but it was only $3 per person. The guide gave detailed descriptions of the Johnson's life when they were living at the ranch. It was interesting to hear how LBJ worked while he was at the ranch. A private plane used by the president was also located near the home. It was interesting to hear about his experiences.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: On our way to Fredericksburg, TX, we saw this national park and decided to stop. It is free, except for the home tour which is $3.00 if you want to go through the house. The home tour was well worth it. Loved this stop, where the Johnsons are buried and where they lived. Nice little museum and gift shop to tour as well.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: If I had to compare the LBJ national historic site to any other NPS run establishment, it would be valley forge. If you're not familiar with that, let me explain. The property is huge and you need a car to get through the entire thing. The site has a ton of different things to see. We got there on a weekend and it wasn't crazy busy which was great. You drive to the visitor center to obtain a parking permit so you can stop along the various sites. You are given a map, and there is a small gift shop inside with a great selection of both LBJ and NPS merchandise. You then begin your trip to the several sights along the way, including the LBJ childhood home, family cemetery, school house, and finally the Texas White House. There is a second visitor center there where you can obtain tickets for the guided tour of the home, which runs $3 per person. The house itself is quaint and lovely, while the airplane outside is a very cool addition to the tour. There is a scenic view outside the home as well as a swing in the front yard. While we didn't have time to do the tour unfortunately, we did really enjoy ourselves. Word of advice, the short road to get to the house was closed so we drove the length of the park which happens to be an operating ranch. Cattle everywhere so stay in the vehicle if you're in the same situation. Worth the drive to see the home and very close to San Antonio if you want a quiet getaway from the busy atmosphere of the River Walk.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: So many parts to review! I did not know that Johnson came here to this schoolhouse sign the Education Act. The tour of the barn gave a realistic account of Johnson driving through the barn with his guests. The house tour ($3.00) brought back memories of my childhood with all the furnishings of the 50s and 60s. Well done!
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: What a gift the Johnsons left to America in the LBJ Ranch!Visiting the ranch and home of President Johnson was an absolute delight. I'm old enough to remember LBJ's presidency and the visit was relevant to my life. The ranch is really beautiful country. When you stop at the state park visitor center to get a permit to be on the ranch, pick up the $7.00 CD that narrates your drive on the paved road around the ranch. See a reconstruction of the LBJ's birthplace and hear about his childhood. See his grandparents home and listen to the stories of their influence on him. The elementary school LBJ attended is on the property. Hear about the ranch operations from the CD and the ranch hand at the show barn. Look inside the US airplane in the hangar on his property. It shuttled the president and his cabinet to Austin where he could take a larger plane to WA D.C. Yes, he had a runway right there on the ranch. See some of the vehicles he used. The highlight for me was visiting the first floor of LBJ's home "The Texas Whitehouse". Filled with actual furnishings and personal items like LBJ and Lady Bird's clothing, you get a real sense of the man and his life. Be careful not to hit the cattle grazing freely on the ranch as you ride along and soak in the scenery and history. An absolute must see for any history buff.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: We so enjoyed everything in this National Park. The ranch was beautifully restored to reflect when LBJ lived there and used it as the White House. You will see his office, main living room, dining room, kitchen and bed rooms. On the other areas of the ranch you will see a school house where he went to school, where he and Lady Byrd are buried, the hanger and much of his ranch where the cattle graze. The ranch tour costs $3 and everything else is free. Great experience.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Very interesting and informative. There is a gift shop at the headquarters and after getting free permit for car you can walk over to village to see how things were do in the past. There is also an area to see two longhorn steer and deer. When I went by the deer were outside the enclosure walking around. The main attraction is a car tour through the working ranch land with places to stop to see school building, cemetery and other interesting sites. Lots of cattle and other animals and fields. Then you come to the airforce one hanger and can see in the plane. The best part is the Texas White house which costs 3 dollars.to be guided through. Children I believe are free. It is really worth the visit.the guides are very knowledgable about LBJ and family back then.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Tours are $3 and leave every 30 minutes. Home of President and Mrs. Johnson during his presidency and is restored to that era. Found it very interesting. Home where he was born is on the ranch and the President's grave. Beautiful area of the State.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: I am so glad I went on this tour. It is very interesting. Carol our tour guide did an excellent job. She was very passionate. It was like she was talking about a beloved grandfather. She made it seem like we were there as it was happening. Great lesson that brings history to life. The ranch and house are about 14 miles outside of town. Once you get on the property you continue to drive a few more miles through the ranch. The visitor center and gift shop also have some history exhibits. Tour costs $3
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Our guide was excellent, he knew his facts. There is walking involved in touring the Texas White House but it's worth it. You are provided with a map to see LBJ's ranch. You get to see such things as the one room school house which he attended, his reconstructed birthplace, family cemetery, where LBJ is buried and a herd of Hereford cattle which descended from his original herd. The tour was very informative. You pay $3 for the Office Tour but everything else is free.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Go to the State Park office first and get the permit to drive through. Get tickets to see the house - it's worth it. The ranch is a nice drive, with things to see, but the tour, $3 per person, is well worth it. You get a rare personal view of LBJ. I was not a fan of him, but there's much I did not know, even though I lived through his Presidency. This glimpse of him as a human being was positive and informative. You learn about both his background and attitudes that shaped the things he did, not all of which are fully appreciated today. If you're in San Antonio or Austin, take the time to drive out there. The scenery on the way is beautiful as well, and there is a picnic area near the State Park offices.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Loved driving on the LBJ Ranch, lots of cows, bulls and beautiful views! LBJ and Lady Bird's private home, referred to as the Texas White House, preserved as it was when they lived there, was full of history. Well informed guides shared info and sometimes personal stories about the former President and First Lady. You get to see the entire 1st floor of the house including his office, their living room, kitchen, bedrooms and even closets with their clothes. You can also see his Presidential plane, antique cars (including the famous boat car). Stop first at the Visitor's Center to pick up a Free driving permit to drive onto the ranch. You can also stop by and tour his Boyhood Home and see the Johnson family cemetery where they are both buried (although you can't go beyond the gates). There is a $3.00 fee per person to see the Main House. Don't miss this great glimpse into history!
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: My husband and I decided to check out the LBJ Ranch on our way home from Fredericksburg and I'm so happy we did; it ended up being my favorite part of our little getaway! We didn't know what to expect when we showed up at the visitor center. The man gave us a map of the park, a vehicle sticker for our driving tour and information about what to see. We watched a short historical video featuring LBJ talking about the importance of his ranch and then drove on to see all the places he spoke about in the video. We stopped at the schoolhouse and then made our way to the Texas White House. LBJ was a character and we thoroughly enjoyed looking at his Air Force One-Half, his cars and his home! We paid $3 apiece to tour the inside of the Texas White House and our guide, Ann, was terrific!!!
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Went to visit the LBJ home place and was really amazed at what I did not know about LBJ. This shows his soft side and how he loved people and the land. Great place to visit and the tickets are cheap $3 to go in his and Lady Birds home. Well worth the trip.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Visiting friends in Austin and they took us to Hill Country and a visit to LBJ Ranch. What a piece of history here where LBJ spent over 450 days of his presidency. Large airstrip and his presidential plane on property and buildings house the cars LBJ's and Lady Bird drove in that era. If you visit be sure to tour the house. Cost is $4 and is the bighlight of any visit. Preserved in its 1960's decor, the home contains original furniture, paintings, dishes, photos, and wardrobes of clothing etc. The Park Service docent brought the house alive as we toured. Would do this trip again!
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Everyone, it seems, visits the LBJ Library in Austin, but really you should not miss this National Historical Park. Known as the Western White House, Stonewall, this ranch is about 30-40 miles outside Austin, and is just beautiful. The drive there through the hills outside of Austin is very different from the flat lands around Austin. That alone is gorgeous. However, the birthplace in Johnson City, and the ranch at Stonewall are so very interesting historically. Everything is so well presented. The tour of Stonewall includes a look into the Air Force 'One Half" Johnson's Air Force One, and his collection of cars. It is the best bargain in all of Texas ($3.00) next to the Capitol which is free. There are cute little towns on the way, such as Fredricksburg which are of German origin and very interesting as well. Great German food to be had. Get out of town for a day and do this, you won't regret it.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Only cost $3, it is very much worth it.... Coulding take pictures inside of house,, but it is amazing and there are post cards with pictures of the inside of the house, that you can purchase for like $3. for those of us that scrapbook
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Going to the LBJ National Historical Park in Johnson City, TX is well worth your drive. The ranch covers many acres and the drive through to the Texas White House was beautiful and relaxing. The guided tour of the Texas White House is $3. The NP ranger that guided our group was fun and informative. Having been a teenager when LBJ became president, it was quite a kick to see this house with colors and decor from the 50's and 60's. I didn't know he was such a hard worker. They said he worked sometimes 22 hours a day. He would have cabinet meetings in the beautiful swimming pool which is still maintained by the NPS, but nobody every gets in it. Not allowed to. There were two climate controlled garages, with old vehicles including Lincoln Continentals. There is also a plane on the property (Air Force One and a Half). Be sure to see the stones outside where visitors would "sign in" rather than signing in on a Guest Book.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: A charming spot to visit and a lot of history, great car touring and a little extra $ for a tour of the Western White House. I think a must place to visit if you are in the Fredericksburg area.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: We were on a back-roads tour of Texas Hill Country and saw the Johnson Museum set-up in Johnson City. There, staff informed us about the LBJ Ranch park and tour...about 10 miles down the road. You have to check in at the State Park Visitor Center to get a free driving permit; then you over the river and through cattle pastures; past barns and horse paddocks; interpretive panels explaining the ranch operations; landing field and plane hanger. You can stop at some of these locations. We rushed to make the last tour of the day at 4:30. The NP Visitor Center has free movies and you can walk around the grounds. $6.00 each got us a tour of the house; early pioneer stone to presidential additions. Each room has a guide to tell you about the room and how the family used it. Great tour - even if you are not a history buff. Grounds close promptly after the last tour.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: We had a short day today so we were able to visit this historic landmark. Visiting Johnsons home was memorable. Our ranger/guide was excellent. He gave us quite an insight of LBJ as president. For a mere $3 it was a deal.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Free park's pass required before entry. Long drive through working ranch past resident Herefords over many Texas Gates. $3 tour obtained at hangar. Vice President's Plane on view but not accessible. Tour guide luck of the draw ours lacked a sense of humour. Johnson's need for telephone access is in evidence even at the dinner table.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: If I were to have a ranch, it would look much like the Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park. About 2.5 sq.miles, private airport, Lockheed Jetstar, and a 28 room ranch house. You must stop at the visitor's center for a free permit to drive through the ranch. You can pay $6 for a DVD and CD that you can play during the drive to tell you about what you are seeing (recommended). Once you get to the ranch house, you can take a tour for $3/each. The tours run every 20 mins or so and are lead by a park ranger. Expect to be 1-1/2 hours there with light traffic.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: We weren’t really sure what to expect in visiting the LBJ National Historic Site/Ranch, but I had heard that the State Park portion had a herd of longhorn cattle that I wanted to see so we opted to visit. Upon getting the park permit (which is free, only $3 to get a guided tour of the Texas White House portion), the park ranger suggested 1.5-2 hours to visit the whole site. We didn’t even tour the White House and spent about 2 hours here enjoying the scenery and the other buildings including the schoolhouse, birthplace, show barn, and hangar (there is a real, retired Air Force 1 jet in residence here!). While we never saw the longhorn herd here, we found another portion of the LBJ National historic park in Johnson City that had two longhorn steers plus we got to see the prized registered Herefords on the LBJ ranch and in the showbarn where they were displaying a young bull, cow, and new calf. We highly recommend a visit to the LBJ National Historic Site and Ranch.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: You feel like you are stepping back in time as you visit the ranch. The Park Service has done an amazing job in all aspects of the property. Be sure to stop and visit the schoolhouse (the first building you'll see), pull up the little side drive and park around back. The family graveyard is down the road on the left, and the reconstructed birthplace home across the street. The home is in a beautiful setting, very nice. Drive all the way around through the ranch to the main home...it is amazing. At the visitors center, right in front of the retired Air Force jet that shuttled LBJ around, pay the few dollars for the tour, worth every cent. Plan easily on a couple to a few hours, take the time to soak in some history.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: My wife and I had toured the Johnson Ranch in 1968 or 1969 when I was in graduate school in Austin. LBJ was still president so the family home was not open and only portions of the ranch were accessible (LBJ's birthplace and family graveyard). Recently we were traveling from Fredericksburg to Austin with a little extra time and stopped to tour. This time you could tour much more of the ranch including a small, but interesting museum in the onsite airplane hangar. The family home, also known as the Texas White House was opened to the public in about 2007 and was VERY interesting. It has been restored to the 1970's style that existed when LBJ was president and spent many of his days as president there. The National Park ranger leading our tour was very good. The 500-year old oak in the front yard was very impressive. Anyone with an interest in history and especially the era around Kennedy and Johnson's terms would enjoy this tour. The house tour only took about 40 minutes and one starts every 15 minutes. There is some small fee but I'm not sure how much since we entered free with my National Park Senior Pass.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: We have visited Fredericksburg several times and never visited the LBJ ranch. We scheduled it into our itinerary for our latest trip to the hill country, and we wish we had visited sooner. We spent 5 hours between the two historic parks and would definitely go back. We learned so much, and enjoyed being outdoors amidst all this history. The house tour was a highlight, and the NPS has done a fantastic job keeping the house pristine and preserved. Would highly recommend. All but the house tour is free. (House tour is $3/person.)
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Driving through the ranch, seeing the cattle (some of whom are roaming free), and following the life of LBJ, in conjunction with the state historical park, was a real lesson in the history of our country and of the man. There are many things to see, but probably the most outstanding was the Texas White House. One could almost feel the presence of LBJ and Ladybird; for example, in the living room, I could see the fireplace and mantel and then look at a picture of LBJ standing in that very spot. There were two closets, one for LBJ and one for Ladybird, that contained their actual clothes, shoes, and accessories. The park ranger, who gave the tour of the Texas White House, was knowledgeable and told personal stories about the Johnsons which made me wish I had known them. After a day of learning about LBJ, I have much greater appreciation of our 36th president. It is free to drive through the ranch and costs $3 to tour the Texas White House. It was $3 well-spent.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: A self-drive around the ranch property until you get to the home. You can make stops at the family cemetery LBJ & Lady Bird are buried along with about 4 generations of the family. Across the road from the cemetery is a re-creation of the home LBJ was born in. Finally you get to the hangar (a plane & some cars are stored) and for $3 / person you can take a guided tour of the Texas White House.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: For $3 you will receive a high quality tour of the inside of the Texas White House. Our guide was informed and enthusiastic. The inside of the LBJ home is almost exactly as it was when the Johnson family lived there. Really, if you are at all interested in going then you should go because you wont find anything quite like this anywhere. You even have exposure to the former president's vehicles and airplane. Worth the trip from Austin or San Antonio. You wont be sorry.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: Take a nice day trip from Austin and visit the Texas White House in the Hill Country.Allow a full day for stopping to visit all the sites in the Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park. The only park fee is a modest $3 for touring the Texas White House, otherwise, there are not entrance fees. View the film at the visitor center, it is well worth the time and sets the context for the visit.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: This is just a fantastic trip, no matter what your age. What a wonderful bit of important American history. From seeing what the US was like just a little over 100 years ago when LBJ was born (and you can visit a working farm that was down the road from his birthplace), to the "Texas White House" it's a lovely way to spend a day. On top of that, if you DON'T go inside the Johnsons' home, it's FREE (and even to go into the home is a nominal $3/person fee). They give you a CD to pop into your car that is a guided tour as you drive around the ranch. The cars/airplane (Airforce one) were a big hit with our son - as was the working farm. All in all, a great way to spend a lovely day in the Hill Country. While you're there, take the drive on in to Fredericksburg - a jewel of a town with wonderful shops and places to eat. And there are all of these wineries on the road into Fredericksburg - so plenty to do.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: We never gave President Johnson much thought, but it turns out he’s a surprising and interesting person! He’s so much a product of his unusual upbringing. This park has two sites. Be sure to see both. There are no less than three videos between the two sites and a guided tour at each one. Everything is free except the tour of the Texas Whitehouse which is only two dollars each. There’s a nice walking trail where you may see Longhorn. And the CD for your driving tour of the LBJ ranch is quite informative. Check out all the animals at the living history farm. And visit the prize-winning and pampered Herdfords at the show barn. This is your National Park Service at its best: Interesting, affordable, and a lot of fun.
