Nor for the faint of heart but a great visit. You can also stop to see Spruce House from across the small canyon - it is closed for visits due to rock slides. There are also other areas to visit depending on your timeframe. We had about five hours and it was perfect timing to do these three areas. Don't miss this great Park

Mesa Verde was one of our major stops during a recent Fall family road trip through Colorado. There really is a lot to see and experience here, enough to fill at least 2 days if not 3. We bought tickets at the Visitor Center for the Balcony House tour (purchased our tickets at 8a earliest we could get was the 1p tour) and the Long House Tour (earliest we could get was next day at 9:30a). Tickets for these tours have to be bought in person either at the Visitor Center or at the Colorado Welcome Center in Cortez. You can buy tickets up to 2 days in advance I believe. And they do sell out as we discovered by trying to get same morning tickets on our first day (oops). When planning your tour schedule, keep in mind that the ruins are quite a ways from the park entrance (1 - 1.5 hour drive). Getting to Long House by 9:30a took some planning.

Entry fee of $20 per vehicle, no charge with NPS Senior Pass. Drove the Main Park Road, Mesa Top Loop and Cliff Palace Loop (~50 miles roundtrip) Disappointed with such a boring drive to get to an excellent finishing result seeing the Cliff Palace and Balcony House up close.

This is the only Pre-Colombian park in the US and worth a visit. Ranger tours are excellent ($10 pp). If you are somewhat physically fit, be sure to hike up to Cliff Palace. Indigenous cultures are explained well. The Far View Lodge is great for an overnight stay (15 miles inside the park) as well as a meal. Make sure you carry water with you; area is very dry and it is very easy to get dehydrated.

The drive is relatively long, and arduous at times, reaching elevations of over 8000 ft, but well worth the journey. Enroute to the cliff dwelling areas, you cannot help but notice the effect of wildfires over the past 20 years, changing the landscape as fires have likely done for millennia. While hiking is an essential component for many visitors, it is possible to see the Step House with <1 mile of walking (R/T), on smooth surface with only 100 ft change in altitude - nothing too steep or taxing, with places to rest along the way if needed. The Cliff Palace is visible, and easily appreciated, from a great vantage point at the at the visitor center. The lengths that this civilization, over 100's of years, went to in order to survive in this region, is incredible. There is a fee, but if you're >/= 62 yrs old, get a lifetime pass for $80, good at all national parks.

We only had one day to spend in Mesa Verde National Park on the day after Labor Day. I wanted to do all three of the guided tours-Long House, Balcony House, and Cliff Palace-in one day. I was told by the rangers that it would be difficult to do get tickets and to do all three tours. About 7 weeks in advance of our trip, I purchased the twilight tour of Cliff Palace for 6:45 PM at a cost of $20. The other two tours-Long House and Balcony House need to be purchased in person, either at the Colorado Welcome Center in Cortez or at the Mesa Verde Visitor and Research Center near the entrance of the park. These tickets can be purchased in person two days in advance for $5 each. I was concerned that the tickets may not be available when we arrived in Cortez around 5PM the day before we visited the park. I had called both places to ask about the possibility of getting two tickets for each tour (as the tours limit the number of people). I was told that there was a good possibility, but not a guarantee, as we were a smaller group. I was told that if there are larger groups, obtaining tickets would be more difficult. If you are staying at a B&B, it may be a possibility to ask your host to get tickets for you. I had also read on tripadvisor that on busier days, you may not be allowed to buy tickets to all three tours. Don't know if that happens or not. Anyway, we were able to get tickets at the Colorado Welcome Center for the tour times that I wanted. So, this is how our schedule went on the day that we visited. We entered the park at 7:20 AM. There was no one to take entrance fees at that time. We have a senior pass anyway. This happened had three other national parks that we visited this vacation which seems odd since the national parks need more revenue. We arrived at Wetherhill Mesa at 8:15 AM. So, it took us 55 minutes. The road is winding and we did not stop for viewpoints as it was hazy due to smoke from the Montana fires. We took the Long House guided tour at 9AM, returning to our starting point at 11:15 AM. We took a short rest break and did the self guided tour of Step House. Walking to and from the Step House and visiting it took only 35 minutes. We left Wetherhill Mesa and drove to Chapin Mesa which took 35 minutes. One ranger said that it could take 1.5 hours during a busy day to drive that same route. At Chapin Mesa, we ate lunch at the Spruce Tree House Restaurant, saw the 25 minute movie at the Archaeological Museum which runs on the half hour, and toured the rest of the museum. At the rear of the museum, you can view the Spruce Tree House dwelling but it is closed due to structural deficits. From 2:15-3:25 PM, we did the one-way Mesa Top Loop Road, stopping at nearly all of the dozen sites. Pick up a free brochure at the first stop, the Pithouse, which explains the Mesa Top Loop Drive sites. It provides information that will give the sites more meaning. It was the only place in the park that I saw that particular brochure. We had tickets for the Balcony House tour at 5PM which lasted until 6:10PM. Out of all the three tours, that was the tour that was most strenuous in terms of climbing 32 foot ladders to get into the house and then climbing four smaller ladders on the side of a cliff clutching onto metal rungs in the cliff between the ladders to get out of the house. Lastly, we did the 6:45 PM Twilight Cliff House Tour. That tour was suppose to last 1.5 hours but it lasted about half the time. It was disappointing as there was little information provided by our young ranger and we were free to leave after we had looked around. It was dark exciting the park so be careful as we saw wildlife on our way out.

This is a great park with very helpful staff. Love the access to the ruins, although there is a small $5 fee to some of the tours (Balcony House, Long House, Cliff Palace) but well worth it. Rangers are very knowledgeable. Spruce Tree House is closed for safety reasons. There are nice visitor's centers and restaurants within the park.

National Park Pass lets you in to drive the 26 miles of scenic highway. Overlooks allow viewing of cliff dwellings. Book a tour of one of the sites for a closer look and a ranger led tour. Climbing involved.

I loved Mesa Verde National Park. It was just so cool to see how the cliff dwellers lived. The rangers were awesome at the tours. You have to get tickets for the tours of The Long house, Balcony House and Cliff Palace. You can't book these online. You have to get them at the visitor center or in town. The problem is that they book up quickly and you may not get a tour or not at a convenient time. The tours are inexpensive at only $5 per person per tour. The views are amazing in the park!

It's best to go early. If it's been a while since you have been here, the visitor center is now located right off the highway and it is very nice. This is where you pick up your tickets if you want to take one of the highly recommended Ranger guided tours. We took lunch with us, there are plenty of tables to be found once you are in the park. Don't forget to purchase your National Park Pass, there are several National parks close by; Aztec Ruins, Canyonlands and Arches.

We hadn't visited Mesa Verde National Monument in over 40 years! It has tours now! What a great experience! The Visitor Center is so informative, and it is where you buy your tour tickets. They were $5/person for each tour, which is sooo reasonable!!!

Visited with my adult daughter. This place is awesome. There are so many cliff dwellings to see. Took the tour of the cliff palace. Visitor center opens at 7:30 am to buy tour tickets. $5 for a ranger tour that involves steps, going thru boulders, and ladder climbing. I wouldn't take children under 12 on this tour. I recommend this park to everyone.

This park offers the amazing opportunity to walk through the ancient cliff dwellings of the Pueblo natives that built the dwellings over 800 years ago. There are also several pit houses that are over 1000 years old within the park. There are three of the cliff dwellings that require tickets, so plan ahead. You can only buy the tickets at the park ($5) up to three days in advance. I arrived at the Visitor Center 20 minutes before it opened and was about 20th in line for tickets. The morning tickets go fast, but there were same day tickets available. I recommend buying tickets for the following day because the availability is much better. I highly recommend doing both the Cliff Palace and Balcony House, which can be done on the same day with a 2 hour gap between the tours.

We stayed at The Retro Inn in Cortez, CO and it is a very short drive to the park. We left the hotel early to try to avoid the heat that would come later in the day. We had no idea what to expect and we certainly didn’t expect to see what we saw. Time did not permit us to do a tour so we went to Cliff Palace and then did the Mesa Top Loop. We got to Cliff Palace just as a tour was lining up to go. One of the benefits of getting there early, before the tours start, is that we didn’t have tourists in our pictures of Cliff Palace. We walked down a set of stairs and were able get very clear views of Cliff Palace and the canyon. The views from Sun Temple are so incredible, well, every stop off had incredible views as did the drive in to the park itself. The museum at the park headquarters had good info. Not a good layout on a crowded day, but interesting. We spent about 4 hours in the park which is what they recommend on their website. That was just right on. The visitor center was very helpful and had a good store. Don’t forget to stamp your National Park Passport Book!

Go early. We didn’t and we couldn’t get in on any of the tours until 3pm. You have to take a tour of the three main sites. They are only $5/person. We toured Balcony House and it was fabulous. I wish that I could remember the tour guide’s name because he was outstanding. My son left his walking stick on the path and he even walked us down to get it after the tour. There are plenty of things to see in the distance and smaller sites to walk through if you are driving but the tours are the way to go.
One of our favorite parks but we were disappointed that virtually everything now requires tickets. The only significant free tour has been closed for three years due to rock slides. $$$$$

This is a beautiful National Park. I have always wanted to visit and am so glad I was finally able to. Start your visit at the visitors center and get tickets ($5.00 per person) for the ranger led tours. Do as many as possible. They are so informative and you can not see these areas without going on tours. After your tours drive around and see some of the other sites. So amazing to see these dwellings and know they are hundreds of years old. Wish I would have had another day to visit and explore

The cliff dwellings of Mesa Verde were everything I hoped they would be. Giving us a glimpse into a past culture, one can't help but wonder, "How did they make their chief so mad that he made them build their homes in the side of a cliff?" Your guess is as good as mine, or any of the experts for that matter . . . no one really knows. The dwellings are quite interesting and you know what???? - None of our buildings today will be around in 800 years for future generations to see. So the cliff dwellers have that going for them. You can take a driving tour to multiple locations for free and take photos of the dwellings from across a canyon, or you can pay $5 to go on a guided tour with a Park Ranger and actually climb up and down ladders and steps in the rock wall. Either way, I'm sure you will be fascinated.

This Park is a must-see. Be aware that at a 7,000-8,500 ft elevation, you might feel light-headed and/or require a jacket or sweater. 1. Plan on a full day there. The park ranger at the visitor center laughed when I asked for a 2 hour highlight tour recommendation. It's in a remote area of Colorado so you need to spend an hour or two to get to the Park entrance. Then another 30+ minute drive to get to the top of the Mesa and more time to drive the loops. It's such as beautiful place you'll want to take your time. 2. If you want to take a tour, book in advance. There aren't many and they were sold out when we got there. The one that looks interesting is the 700 Years Tour but it's 4 hours and pricey ($47 plus park fee), requires climbing and you're on a bus with other people. 3. If you're doing your own thing and pressed for time, skip the visitor center, grab a map at the pay booth, drive by the many overlooks and head to Chapin Mesa and listen to the 30 minute video on the people who lived in the cliff dwellings. Fascinating! There's a snack bar Spruce Terrace with affordable food, outdoor seating and a BBQ going that day. Pass on the ribs but everything else was tasty. View the Spruce Tree House from afar - the trail was closed and tours were suspended. 4. If it's overcast that day, go anyway. Your dwelling pictures will be better when the sun is behind the clouds as long as there's good indirect light. 5. Skip the Mesa Loop unless you have time to kill - you'll see dwellings from afar, the Sun Temple and some holes in the ground. 6. Don't miss the Cliff Palace loop and overlook. A short walk down will allow you to get reasonably close to the dwellings without a tour ticket and take great photos - pray for clouds. The other overlooks were nice but skip the Balcony House overlook - you can't see much without a tour ticket. 7. A stop at the Far View Lodge and Terrace Restaurant might be worthwhile. We didn't do it but the view is amazing. 8. Stay in Durango, CO - a great town with affordable lodging and restaurants but you may want to book in advance. All hotels were sold out Memorial Day weekend.

As you enter Mesa Verde you travel several miles to the top of the Mesa. The views from the road are outstanding and the higher you go, the better they are. The skies are 'Big' as one would expect in the west. The road forks off into several routes leading to historical destinations where ancient Anasassi Indians built cliff dwellings. You can climb many of them under the guidance of the ranger. Take a camera or cell phone camera. You will need it. P.S. If you are over 65, get a lifetime National Park Pass for only $10. This is good for free admission to hundreds of National Parks, Memorials and historical sites all over the country.

The drive up takes a while because it's 20 miles+ of winding roadway with many switchbacks, so count on 40 minutes past the welcome center. The cliff dwellings are very interesting. We did a self tour of the Step House, which is a mile hike down to the site on some fairly narrow and sometimes steep paths and stairs and next day did the Cliff palace tour which is $5 and worth it. You have to be dedicated to see something different and fascinating to make the drive but I highly recommend it. There are also some hiking trails to overlooks and many overlooks on the drive to the attractions.

We toured the park in mid-May and thoroughly enjoyed our visit. The Visitor Center is minimal, but nicely done. There are guide books available that offer information about several of the sites. We started out on Wetherill Mesa, where the museum is not. Step House is a self-guided tour, on a slightly less than a mile loop. Long House is a ranger-guided tour and requires purchase of a $5 ticket (per person) at the Visitor Center. Both narrow trails feature an elevation drop (what goes down must come back up) and switchbacks and stairways, so they are not handicapped accessible. Also note that the elevation here is around 7,000 feet; if one has breathing issues, you may wish to visit the area by driving the roads and viewing from the outlooks. Spruce Tree House is on the other mesa, behind the museum, and is worth a look from the viewpoint, even though one cannot currently walk down to it; there is rock fall danger that has the area closed off. In a previous visit, I drove the Mesa Top Loop Drive, which shows "the full range of architecture at Mesa Verde, from the earliest pit houses to the latest cliff dwellings." (Quoted from the Mesa Top pamphlet, available for a minimal charge at the Visitor Center). On this loop tour, you can see examples of dwellings dating from AD 1300s to AD 600. In any case, lots to see. You could easily spend two or three days or more taking the available tours, much less exploring the area. Or, as we did, try to hit the highlights in a day. Definitely no less than a day. Still a great experience. Food and rest rooms are available at selected locations in the park.

This national park is amazing! Do the Balcony House tour, it is $5/person and book it at the visitor's center when you get to the park. Also do the pertroglyph hiking loop. Do not book any tours through ARAMARK - they are expensive and will not take you into the pueblo sites.

I can't believe I have lived in the Boston area for over 40 years and this was my first visit to this wonderful National Park. The park is not far off Route 128. I went to the park to obtain my senior National Park Pass as it was something that had been on my to do list for way too long.(However, I believe this particular park will soon no longer sell the senior pass.) Another friend had gotten hers there a few days before I went, so that is why I went. It was such a beautiful day that after we got our passes, my friend and I decided to take a little walk. I was so impressed how beautiful it was along the paths and so enjoyed reading all the historical markers along the way. I definitely want to return to this park when I have more time to do the walk and read more of the historical markers. I would think it would be a great place to take children to get some exercise and get a history lesson at the same time.

Walk down the treed path, cross the bridge, and stop at the foot of the Minute Man Monument. Feel history whisper throughout the trees and the field. This is a wonderful, quiet spot and the history of the battle comes alive here. We used the audio tour that you can access from your phone (go to the visitors center in Lexington to grab information on it) all the way from Lexington to Concord. It was excellent.

LOVED the park and surrounding area. Had a great time in Lexington, loved the 25 minute movie of the April 19, 1775 battle at Lexington & Concord, but felt completely oppressed in the little town of Concord that is clearly a tourist destination. Was dying of thirst and inquiring everywhere if I could buy a bottle of water. (I don't drink soda, coffee, wine, beer, etc. Just water.) Finally a shop owner confided that a local ordinance spearheaded by one person made it ILLEGAL to sell bottled water! What do they do for people when it's hot?! There are no water fountains. And oddly, there are no trash or recycle bins. Concord, get real. Tourists, save your dollars (and thirst) for Lexington or the National Park areas where you are legally allowed to buy a bottle of water! Isn't this whole region trading on the concepts of LIBERTY and FREEDOM?

Just moved to New England two years ago from California and we ALWAYS take our visiting guests to Minute Man National Historical Park. The Road to Revolution multimedia theater program is fantastic and it is great to watch this program before you hit Boston's sites as it explains the relevance of many of the historic attractions. Costumed tour guides during the summertime are very informative and makes one feel they are back in time. And of course the Old North Bridge cannot be missed; you can even rent canoes and kayaks locally and boat the river flowing beneath the bridge. All in all a lovely morning / afternoon to spend living the history of the area.

Minute Man National Historical Park is a great place to brush up on your Revolutionary War history. If you like history of if your 7th grade history lesson is a bit fuzzy you definitely need to stop at this park. The National Park system has taken great care in restoring the buildings and landscape of area between Lexington and Concord. The park is laid out along the old battle road where the 1st shots of the Civil War were fired. The visitors center offers a great 20 minute video about the events of April 18-19, 1775 to refresh your memory then you can either walk the trail or you can drive the road that runs parallel to the park to visit the different areas and buildings. Costumed interpreters give you a day in the life explanation of everyday life and the events of that time. We witnessed the musket demonstration with was fun and informative. The park is not that large and can easily be done in a half day.

A dear friend built a super cub and put it on amphib floats, invited me to spend a week visiting Forest Service cabins, and we toured the Misty Fjords extensively. What beauty! The LeConte Glacier was beautiful, we saw whales, many sea lions. In fact, there were hundreds of sea lions and their babies floating on ice floes from the Glacier. For those who are coming by cruise ship I would encourage you to spend the $$ and take a flight out to the Misty Fjords.
What a beautiful place. If you can afford the few extra dollars, take a flightseeing tour. Loved it!

We were on an Alaskan Cruise and, upon reading all of the 5 star reviews on Trip Advisor, opted to go the Misty Fjords. Everyone in our 20-member family was terribly disappointed and felt like it was a complete waste of our entire afternoon and $4,180 (tickets were $209 each). The trip took FOUR AND A HALF hours! A very LONG boat ride to look at a few cliffs. They were pretty, but compared to all the lovely sites we've seen in AK, this was nothing! I've driven through canyons in CO that were more impressive! Ketchikan is the SALMON-FISHING CAPITAL OF THE WORLD people . . . and instead of going salmon or halibut fishing, or watching loggers compete, or just enjoying the quaint town, we were TRAPPED FOR 4.5 hours on a boat! The biggest regret of our entire 10-day cruise was the trip to Misty Fjords (all 20 agreed). If one is dying to see them, take a plane trip instead (1.5 hours and you get to see a volcano). I am frustrated with myself for not researching things a little better - but I came to trip advisor and read so many glowing reviews that I thought this was the way to go! DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME OR MONEY!

We paid some 200$/person for visiting this place via a boat but this place wasn't worth that much bucks. The place is overhyped.. We did not find anything extra ordinary. It is just a foggy places surrounded by mountains and few waterfalls. One can definitely skip this place.

During an Alaskan cruise we took a boat excursion into Misty Fjords. This was a different type of tour compared to the breathtaking glaciers and White Pass RR tour earlier in the week. This was more about viewing magnificent towering cliffs with rain forest growth at their base. The water is so still in the fjords that it looks like glass. From the purple hues of the cliffs to the bold greens of the trees and light greens of the cliff side moss, it was unlike anything else seen during the week. Time actually in the fjords was about an hour with the rest of the time taken by the outbound and return high speed boat ride. True to their name the fjords were accented by low hanging mists that did not obscure the views, but added to variety of the environment of this protected national monument. We enjoyed the excursion and we were glad we chose this for our Ketchikan stop.

I booked the HAL excursion. At first it was not too interesting, but once we got further into the Fjord the view was breathtakingly beautiful. Better eyes and cameras than I saw a bald eagle nest, the head of an eagle peeping out and eagles soaring overhead. Alas, I missed it. However, a young brown bear turned up along the water's edge. Loved Ketchikan, a cab ride from the docks to the Totem Museum was $5+tip. Vote the restrooms at the docks some of the cleanest I have seen!

Five of us flew into Misty Fjords on Pirate Air. The Dehavilland Beaver was equipped with floats so it was able to take off from the water at Ketchikan and land on an isolated lake. The views are magnificent; you can see so much more from the air-- snow-capped mountains, glaciers, lakes & rivers. It was typically cloudy & rainy (hence the name "Misty" Fjords) but not dangerously so. The pilot explained the technique of taking off and landing on floats which I found interesting. The flights are not inexpensive but you will not see any more spectacular scenery per $ than flying to Misty Fjords.

My husband and I took a June/July Alaska Cruise and booked the "Misty Fjords by Floatplane" Adventure through Holland America with TAQUAN AIR in Ketchikan. We were fortunate to have beautiful weather and clear, blue skies for our trip. We were most impressed with Taquan Air operations, safety and the pilot, who was very experienced and knowledgeable. The flight was spectacular ~ flying for two hours over the breathtakingly beautiful Misty Fjords National Park. We landed on the water in the park (exciting!), walked onto a fairly large dock where we were able to take gorgeous photos from that vantage point. You truly appreciate the beauty of Misty Fjords from the air. The cost was $250 per/person. We both felt it was worth the $$ and would recommend.

This was the highlight of our cruise to the Inside Passage of Alaska. It is breathtaking beauty and Michelle, the owner of Island Wings, makes the tour very interesting and very comfortable. If you are trying to decide whether or not to book this excursion, you can't go wrong with Island Wings! Everything it says on the website is true and more. Thank you, Michelle, for your professionalism and wealth of knowledge.

We went up on a Disney cruise and booked a floatplane on a sunny day from Ketchikan. It's certainly beautiful, but I agree with the other reviewer who said that it isn't all that different from the rest of the Inside Passage. I give the Inside Passage overall five stars, but IMO the floatplane didn't add a ton to the overall experience, especially for the price. It might be more magical on a misty/rainy day, but at noon on a sunny day in August, it looked mostly like a set of mountains covered in trees. I also find that I prefer viewing nature without looking through a pane of glass, and a cruise/boat in the open air is much more conducive to that experience. Loved the rest of Alaska-- I just think the floatplane wasn't my thing, especially after seeing the rest of Alaska.

I've posted a positive review under Promech Air's name regarding a combination float/fly trip. Many companies make trips to Misty Fjords. I found Promech to be a really quality provider. Feel free to look at review under their business.

The tour was simply incredible! Besides the stop in Glacier Bay, this made our trip memorable and worthwhile! By Googling the tour and booking it directly instead of using our cruise ships tours, we saved over $100.00. The cruise ship tours can usually be found online for so much less money. Since your tour will be with other who DID use the cruise ship to book their tour, you face no chance of being left behind if the tour was delayed for some reason. The views were spectacular and those who do not do this tour miss so very much indeed.

The cost of the 4.5hr trip was right about $175. We went at 7:30am and had purposely booked the tour on a good day. Having been in Ketchikan for about a week, we knew that you had to have a clear day to view the glorious majestic scenery. We were greeted by the staff in front of the Christmas Store in AK, and directed to the catamaran. All of the staff were super friendly and helpful. Throughout the tour, we were served several snacks: a delicious pastry, as well as a choice of chowder or chili later, and even samples of salmon and local jelly. There were hot beverages available also. The captain went beyond his duty of commanding the boat and assisted me multiple times throughout the tour. It was a wonderful and amazing trip. I would have loved to see more wildlife and waterfalls, but one can never predict wildlife viewings. We were too far away to see the eagles and seals up close, but one can make out the shapes if you tried hard enough. I really wanted to see a whale, but no luck that day. Unfortunately, it had been sunny for the past few days prior to my tour, so most of the waterfalls had dried up. Regardless, the fjord was breathtaking. It was definitely a worthwhile trip (despite the price tag)!

I have to say, by the time we hit Ketchikan on our Inside Passage cruise, we were truly on Beauty Overload! Nice town, nice people... the misty fjords by seaplane??? Extraordinary. We went out in a small plane, there were about six of us, besides the pilot and copilot. It was amazing. Again, saw open wild country, forests, glaciers, waterfalls, mountain goats outside the windows, and then? our pilot landed us in a fjord, and let us out onto the pontoon of the plane! It was still, it was silent, it was AMAZING. High sided cliffs above us, and the beautiful green water around us. It was an amazing wilderness experience, and worth every penny we paid to go. If we get back to Alaska, we will do it again!!! We booked this through the Cruise line... I have the name at home... if you need it, message me, and I will look it up. The office staff left something to be desired, but the pilot and copilot and tour? They were GREAT!

Our group on a Princess cruise took a shore excursion to Misty Fjords for 4.5 hours of my life that I will never get back. The tour is extremely expensive for what you get--rain and low clouds blocking most of the views. Maybe you get lucky a few times a year, but remember Ketchikan is one of the wettest places on Earth averaging 153 inches of rain and it rains 88% of the time. The boat was comfortable if you get on early and sit at a table. Otherwise, it's seats only for 4 hours. The crew had to pass out towels to clean the inside of the windows and they would have to constantly wipe down the outside of the windows each time the boat stopped to observe something. If I lived in Ketchikan, I would be suicidal. Charging $200/person is ludicrous. I would urge you to find a cruise itinerary that doesn't include Ketchikan.

A one hour $400 plan ride for two to Misty Fjords is not a good value. We had been in Alaska for 12 days when we took this trip and saw lots of wilderness, waterfalls and mountains and did not need to spend the money to see more. Save your money and use it for a good hamburger at the Burger Queen and a beer at the Asylum.

A few of us took a sea plane excursion to the Misty Fjords and it was breathtakingly beautiful. A little unreal even. It was a short jaunt to the park from Ketchikan and we flew over Tongass National Park (State Park?) on our way to Misty Fjords. The best part was landing on a pristine lake and being able to get out and stand on the floats of the plane. Pricey but worth it!

I took a 10 passenger seaplane into the Misty Fjords. The most beautiful and exciting adventure of all. Passing snow capped mountains and looking down into some of the most beautiful scenery I've ever seen. Being world traveled, I have never witnessed such beauty. Waterfalls and goats were plentiful. Landing on one of the lakes took my breath away. Smooth take offs and landings both times. We got to get out and stand on the pontoons to take pics and videos. Wow! Exhilarating and Spiritual all at the same time. We witnessed tons of jellyfish in the water. Mind blowingly peaceful. The reflection in the water of the natural beauty of the land rendered me misty. I must admit, everyone on that seaplane adventured agreed that they could now die in peace. That trip could not be topped. On top of all the adventure, two fellow travelers that I met on this tour live and work in the same small city as I live and work!!!! What are the chances?

We recently returned from an Alaskan Inside Passage Cruise. While in Ketchikan, we decided to take advantage of the seaplanes and booked a Misty Fjords flightseeing tour with Seawind Aviation. They are a small, family run business and their prices were much better than those offered by the cruise line. They even gave discounts for booking early and paying in cash. Lesley picked us up right by our ship and drove us to their office where Steve then took over with the flying. Misty Fjord was breathtaking and Steve gave a great tour on the area. I highly recommend seeing Misty Fjord but also Seawind Aviation. If we ever make it back, we'll be sure to book another tour with Steve and Lesley.

We arrived in Ketchikan on May 20th 2012. We did the Misty Fjords tour with the Allen company.... the cabins were heated and there were 2 restrooms. Our guide was a Native American from the 2 Finned Whale killer clan that told about her folkfore, the animals and sold beading work - our naturalist on the tour was Native American as well - she really talked about the Natives, how Ketchikan grew, the salmon industry and the wildlife. We saw alot of mother humpbacks and their calves, bald eagles and some bird rookeries. The scenery was outstanding - this trip was about 4 - 41/2 hours and was $189.00 from the Carnival Spirit cruise. We had complementary breakfast roll, cup of clam chowder/chili and smoked salmon. You could purchase food, beverages, souvenirs as well. We really enjoyed the ride and the beauty all around us. We saw several pictographs dating from 10000 yrs ago and learned of their rich history and culture. This was worth the time it was money well spent for such a great day.

After deciding to see the Misty Fjords Monument by floatplane I had to choose a company. I chose poorly - lured by their deceptive website and ignoring the absence of reviews. They advertise a 3 hour tour, reiterated by their receptionist and promise it to be oh so much better than the competition. At $371 per person compared to the $229 of others you do pay for it but they don't deliver. First they were late to pick us up at the dock. The ride to the plane is short and we were airborne soon. Lovely plane, pilot and scenery but we were down after 1hr. and 45 min. and a lot of that was a remote landing. What! Turns out the pilot worked for his own company, Misty Fjords Air, and only did what he was contracted to do. He disappeared and someone finally came to take us back to the boat. She didn't know anything either. This Bananof "owner" runs a restaurant and there is no tour office. He is simply a middle man taking a huge cut. Save yourself the money and book directly with a reputable company that owns the planes. Misty Fjords Air was great but the rest was a racket.

This was a cruise ship excursion on Norwegian while in Ketchikan. Not keen on a seaplane, we decided to take the catamaran. It was expensive, $220 per person, but all the Alaska excursions are pricey, some much more so. The boat was large and very comfortable and the crew friendly and knowledgeable. We didn't care for the part at the end where they tried to sell us items from locals, but the scenery was incredible and there were numerous breathtakingly beautiful sites. I do not think it would be nearly as good on a rainy day, we got lucky. Advice is to not book while on ship because you're stuck if it rains; book as soon as you get off the ship

We bought this excursion for our 22 year old grandson that was on an Alaskan cruise with us. He had not been to Alaska previously and never on a seaplane. We bought this excursion through Costco as it was longer and less expensive than one offered by the cruise line. Our grandson flew in the co-pilot's seat and thoroughly enjoyed the trip, although his headset had some problems and it was difficult to listen to the pilot. They didn't see a lot of wildlife but he thought the scenery was awesome. They did land during the trip and each passenger got out of the plane on a pontoon for a photo. Very happy we purchased this excursion.

The Well is a large sinkhole that is replenished with water that has taken thousands of years to percolate into the spring. Admission is free and the Ranger was friendly and informative. The path is less than a mile long and is an easy hike with information signs scattered along the way. There are cliff dwellings visible under the rim of the well and also at the bottom. The site at the bottom still shows advertising graffiti from 1878. It is interesting that no fish live in the water but there are water scorpions and leeches. We were able to watch ducks and muskrats feeding.

(our visit, April 5) We stopped at Montezuma’s Well on our way to Phoenix from Sedona. Admission is free. A nice size parking lot is the start of the trail head that leads to the ‘well’. It is a paved loop that ends in another section of the parking lot. Although the large cratered area looks more like a pond won over by the algae, don’t let that make you turn around. Admire the modest cliff dwelling, probably considered prime real-estate in its day, and then take the path of stairs leading down from the ridge and walk a very short path to the well itself. There is a small house like structure that contains the well. A different side path further along the paved pathway leads you down some more stairs to a shaded area where the water exits and the actual irrigation canal can be clearly seen. Even a leisurely stroll to all the stops along the way, shouldn’t take you more than an hour. I would not make this a destination in itself, but if anywhere in the area, it makes a wonderful stop to stretch your legs, learn some history, and dip your hands in the cool 76 degree water. There was a small building where I guess a ranger is normally stationed, but it was closed up tight when we were there.

Montezuma Well is something really special. Originally an underground cave - that is, after the even larger shallow lake that covered the whole area - the roof finally caved in and formed what we see today, a pond - actually a limestone sink - fed subterraneously, with a swallet thruogh which water keeps draining out into Beaver Creek. From the parking lot visiotrs walk upa short cemented trail to find themseves at the rim of the more or less cuircular pond with the vertical sides, into which cliff dweeelings were built by early native tribes - what a location: always enough water to keep the crops alive, shade, trees, and tranquility supreme. The short loop trail half way around the well - with a side trail down to the swallet and some if the cliff dwelling ruins, down to beaver creek past some more Pueblo-style ruins up above, and back to the parking lot is very easy to negotiate. It's an extremely pleasant and peaceful place to visit, not overrun by tourists. Admission is free, donations welcome. If you're in the area, this is very well worth your time for a brief stop.

Interesting geology/history to learn about for free (compared to other national monuments in the area which charge $10 per person). Beautiful setting in late fall, but it would probably be too hot to visit in the summer.

You can obviously enjoy the historical artifacts left behind by Washington and his troops during the revolutionary era, his Headquarter and Museum in town, the Wick Farmhouse and the site of winter encampment with recreated soldiers barracks at Jockey Hollow. The Visitor Center will do a wonderful job reminding what you already forgot from history courses. What most first time visitors would miss, because of time constraint or lack of preparation, are the wonderful hiking trails within easy reach at Jockey Hollow. If you enjoy the Eastern woods, please invest $1 to buy a trail map and choose your course(s), perhaps with a little help from the local rangers at the Visitor Center. Most trails are clearly marked and pretty obvious, even beginners couldn't get lost. Most are rated easy or moderate, depending on the elevation you might have to scale. Spring and Fall are best, even the summer should be comfortable enough with the canopy of tall trees providing shades. Dress according to weather and terrain, and bring plenty of water. I highly recommend the Grand Loop, which courses around the perimeter of the park, crossing streams and ponds besides the magnificent foliage, ca. 5.3 miles, and could be completed within 3 hours. Experienced hikers could do in much less time. History & Nature in one package, you can't ask for more in densely populated Jersey!
park: Morristown National Historical Park, Washington Headquarters and Museum

text: This is a national park and thus free with the National Park Pass. Jockey Hollow was the sight of the Continental Army's winter encampment of 1788-1789. A brutel winter tested the army's endurance. Center has an excellent short film describing the soldier's experience along with a reconstructed typical soldier's hut. Beautiful walking paths available as well as drive through roads.
park: Morristown National Historical Park, Washington Headquarters and Museum

text: Very interesting tour of the house where Washington spent the winters while his troops camped nearby. You need a the guide to tell the story otherwise you are just looking at old stuff. Well worth the $7 charge for the tour, museum is free. Allow 1 - 2 hours.
park: Morristown National Historical Park, Washington Headquarters and Museum

text: Well worth a visit. The museum/visitor center is staffed by courteous and knowledgeable crew of Park Service employees. The tour of the Ford Mansion normally costs $4.00 but on Independence Day the fee was waived. The tour was excellent. This is a great way to spend a couple of hours learning an integral part of the fight for life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.
park: Morristown National Historical Park, Washington Headquarters and Museum

text: Bring the kids, bring the grandparents - this site will have something to interest all. Small museum that won't overwhelm the kids - plus a film on Washington's encampment during the winter of 1779 to 1780. It was a brutal winter and the film presents a dramatic enactment of the poorly equipped and poorly clothed soldiers struggling through a record 20 plus snow storms and building huts at Jockey Hollow. Also included in price of admission ($4) is a tour of the Ford Mansion where Washington stayed for 6 months over that winter. Military on active duty and seniors (62 and over) get a national parks pass (any park attraction) for free which entitles them and their guests to attend parks for free. The Ford Mansion is enthralling. Most rooms are blocked off and you can peer in to see period furniture. See the rooms that Washington is reported to have used, see servant quarters, and see the two rooms where the widow Ford stayed with her children while Washington and aides were encamped there. The mansion once stood on 200 acres of property. Step back in history with this tour. Park tour guide was very knowledgeable and fielded many questions from our group. There are only a few mansion tours each day and attendance is limited. Be sure to get your ticket right away to avoid being shut out on the mansion tour. Follow up this visit with a trip to Jockey Hollow!
park: Morristown National Historical Park, Washington Headquarters and Museum

text: We went on the off chance and glad we did. This is a very easy visit and worth the $4.00 fee (free for Golden Age Pass).
park: Morristown National Historical Park, Washington Headquarters and Museum

text: A tour should begin at the Visitor's Center which has exhibits, a reenactment film, restrooms, and the National Parks Passport Cancellation Station in the bookstore/gift shop. It is where to buy a ticket for a ranger-led tour of Ford Mansion & Museum which became Washington’s Headquarters in Morristown.
park: Morristown National Historical Park, Washington Headquarters and Museum

text: I'm always amazed at how the winter quarters for the revolutionary army got so much hype and development, yet the sites where the actual battles took place have very little. This is a perfect example of that. Nothing really exciting happened here except that Washington and his men hunkered down for several really bad winters. Same thing as Valley Forge. Both of these sites have enourmous vistors centers that quite frankly aren't being used to the full potential. Then you take a place like The Battle of Princeton and there is no visitor's center except for a couple of plaques and monuments. The Battle of white Plains in New York has one small little commemorative stone in the corner of a city park. Anyway this site is ok to view a historic house that Washington lived in for 6 months. $4 for adults but free for children. The museum is free but only contained 3 exhibits that were just ok. There is also a half hour movie that is ree. We had a good time with family but agree that the Park Rangers could use a few lessons on customer relations. We had 22 people in our group but they would only allow 20 on the tour at one time "due to Fire codes". Are you kidding? so two of our group had to wait outside.
park: Morristown National Historical Park, Washington Headquarters and Museum

text: We visited Jacob Ford Mansion and was pleasantry surprised by the tour of General Washington's winter headquarters. Our National Parks Service's guide, a young Ms. Watts, was very informative. Thoroughly enjoyed it and the museum and surrounding area. We strongly recommend visiting it; it was $7 each well spent.
park: Morristown National Historical Park, Washington Headquarters and Museum

text: This was my first time visiting a National Park on the west coast. We had our National Park Passports with us so we could get the stamp as well. It's about a 2 hour drive from Seattle but well worth it. If you enter the Nisqually entrance, you'll be driving through the forest for a bit before you get to your first overlook area over the Nisqually River, but you keep seeing parts of the Mount Rainier along the way. If the Nisqually is dried up like it was when we were there, you can walk down into the riverbed and see the mountain in all its glory. Continue driving, and you'll reach the visitors center, different hikes (we did Comet Falls) as well as canyon and pretty wild cliffs along the way. Definitely well worth it!

I visited Mount Rainier National Park on a beautiful fall Sunday morning, and the views were amazing! Waterfalls and snow capped mountains were the highlight for me! We went to the Paradise Visitor Center where a short movie was shown about the history of the park and the activities that can be done such as snowshoeing, hiking, and mountain climbing. The park rangers were very helpful in answering any questions we had. A casual cafeteria style lunch was available at the visitor center. The entrance fee of $25 for a passenger car gives you access to the park for seven days. Money well spent to see the natural beauty that Mount Rainier offers.

We only had half a day to see the park or not see it at all. I'm so glad we opted to go anyway. It is possible to be blown out of your socks without hiking a foot of any trail or staying overnight. The park is beautifully laid out so that a drive through it will be more than worth it. If the weather is good (no clouds or fog), go for the drive. The views of the mountain and all the surrounding Cascades is breathtaking from multiple angles as you wend your way through. We entered from the southwest and exited out the east. I don't feel like we missed much. Be aware that all national parks charge a fee, but if you are a senior you can purchase a lifetime pass for any/all national parks for only $10!

We loaded up the car with the kids,dogs and a picnick lunch to go on a spur of the moment trip,It took us almost 3 hours to get up the mountain so we stopped in Elbe to see the trains they have there to use the rest stop bathroom that was very clean and tidy but busy,its a cute town with a tiny historical church. We finally got to Paradise Point got the kids and dogs out almost got to the trail and a park ranger stopped us and told us we couldn't have our dogs on any trails and they could only stay in the parking lots. There are no sign stating this anywhere. I was really upset because we had to pay $22 to get into the park and they seen my dogs in the car when we paid and said nothing to us,if they had told me that I would have turned around. We ended up having to leave because I wouldn't leave my dogs in the hot car as the park ranger suggested. The drive and park is beautiful just don't take your pets.

Google "best parks in America", and few will mention Mt. Rainer National. That's a shame, because Mt. Rainer National park is one of the best on the planet. Peak crowds will vary, as the mountain weather is so unpredictable. But if you can get there on a clear day, try just before lunch hour. There is a fee per car to enter, about $25, and the value is immense. The park takes hours to traverse, possibly days depending on your method of travel. For first time visitors, we recommend driving up to Paradise station, and stopping along the way at the other various lookouts and stations. My wife and I stopped SO MANY TIMES to take pictures and there are far to many lookouts to name here. The drive to Paradise Station is the one of the most beautiful we've experienced. It ends a little more than a third of the way up the foot of the mountain (almost 6000 feet), and that's where you'll find the bulk of the tourists. There's a lodge, café, bathrooms and other small exhibits labeling the parts of the mountain with various informational displays. Its pretty cool, actually, and certainly helps to offer a place for tourists to eat, rest, or wait out bad weather while on the mountain. Paradise also offers walkable paths directly towards the mountain, surrounded by wildflower fields and other flora. Even if the grounds are covered in snow, its an absolutely stunning sight. If you're anywhere near driving distance to Mt. Rainer National Park, this is an absolute must! Don't miss out!

Mount Rainier is a must see/visit especially for outdoor enthusiasts, campers, hikers, and mountaineering groups. Expect some long driving to get to popular places like the Paradise. You'll get a closer and better view of this majestic mountain if you can get to Sunrise at about 6,000' of elevation - worth your time for its breathtaking sceneries. Roads are well maintained but caution must be observed while driving its winding routes and sharp curves. Their trail system leads to some beautiful waterfalls and spectacular vistas. With bigger crowds, expect a long wait at Nisqually entrance on the weekends during the summer but a shorter wait if you have the National Park Pass and a photo ID to show. We've seen only a lone deer when it bolted in front of our truck to cross to the other side of the road and then pause momentarily for me to take a picture. No bear nor mountain goat sighting which was kind of disappointing. Overall, the park is a great place to visit for at least a few days and a national treasure to be enjoyed by all and future generations.

This was an add on from a trip to Alaska and it was worth the extra day and night. Beautiful, breathtaking park to spend at least a half day in. Only an hour and a half from Seattle where we spent the night. Don't miss this National Park if you are near Seattle. The cost was $25 per car, but worth every penny.

Awesome in view but a bit pricey, I thought. Great rangers at the entrance booth are most helpful. Wish one didn't have to drive, that there could be a small walking path along the road for those wishing to hike part way up to the summit or even to the summit. Workers do incredible diligence to maintain the roads. $2l7 for a single room at Paradise Inn plus meals plus minimum $25 entrance fee... all adds up to limiting access for all.

We love national parks! The girls do the activities to become Jr Rangers, we hike and absorb the majesty of these parks. Seniors, be sure to get you lifetime pass to all parks for a mere $25. Everyone in the car gets in free with you to all national parks!

We came in mid December and the drive up to paradise was already tough. The pass to get in lasts 7 days. You can rent everything you need down the mountain, but the shop at paradise carries rentals too - $15 for snowshoe. The views are incredible! Come here and enjoy the snow!
beautiful and relaxing depending on the trail you are on. nice amenities in the park - over priced - $20 now - going to $25 next year. Thank you Jay Inslee - why are we paying taxes ?

The national parks of the United States are not to be missed. Mount Rainier is no exception. Much of it is truly wild, and the hikes and views of the ancient volcano are spectacular. I've reviewed individual parts of the park separately, but any of them are wonderful. If you're a senior, be sure to buy a $10 lifetime pass that also gets a 50% discount on camping.

This was my second visit to Mt. Rainier, my kids' first. The first was in November 11 years ago and the second was this March. Both times there was tons of snow. Unfortunately, you couldn't even see Mt. Rainier this time around due to the weather, but the park was beautiful & amazing nonetheless. We drove to Paradise & bought a couple of sleds at the visitor's center (around $13 each for the small, round sleds, about twice that for the long ones) and the kids played for hours in the snow. On this trip, we went to Yosemite, Death Valley and the Grand Canyon and this was my kids' favorite park. Check road conditions on their website before you go. If snow chains are required, you can rent them at several shops in Ashford. Also, if you're looking for a place to stay, BaseCamp Cottages in Ashford is really nice. Check with the park rangers for free events. When we went, they had a free snowshoeing hike, but we didn't stay late enough to go. The gift shop also rents snowshoes and trekking poles, but if you sign up before the ranger's hike fills up you get to use theirs for free.

Come ready to hike! Lots of great trails and beautiful forests! Go to the top visitor center at Paradise. The road construction on the main road is annoying, but the new pavement is nice. The gift shop staff were very friendly. Bring lots of water bottles (or a Camelbak) for the lower trails and you can refill at the visitor center. Tons of opportunities for photographs! Be prepared for the $25 park entrance fee.

We were lucky to have absolutely beautiful weather when we visited in late July. We entered the park from the east, traveling west on Rt. 12, the White Pass Scenic Byway, a very beautiful alpine drive. We spent two nights at the National Park Inn; the first night we watched the sunset on the mountain from the porch, what a beautiful alpenglow view. Our full day in the park was driving the road to Paradise and back again to the Inn. The Ranger told us to get up to Paradise early, to get a parking spot; he was right, by the time we finished our hiking, the large lot was packed. We drove directly to Paradise, and did the vista pull-offs on the way back to the Inn. Highlights of the day included hiking at Paradise (there are many trails at Paradise, for all levels of skill), trail to Myrtle Falls (also at Paradise). The meadows were in full bloom, and you are hiking so very close to the mountain; it was simply beautiful! Be aware that you are hiking in high altitude; going up steep trails is exhausting; take plenty of water. Along the route back to the Inn, we to the trail to the foot of Narada Falls (there was a rainbow on the falls at the foot). We wanted to stop at Christine Falls, but there isn’t much parking there and we couldn’t stop, too crowded, sadly. As in any national park at high season, hiking early in the day, or later in the afternoon/evening is the best way to avoid the crowds.
We really enjoyed visiting Mt. Rushmore. Being late in the season, only the main visitor's center, shop and restrooms were open. Parking was only $10 and the pass was good for a week.

Saw this as a kid in the 80's. They've greatly improved the visitor's experience since then. Parking was a breeze. Tickets allow you to leave and come back. We came back for the evening lighting which was really cool. The trail now allows you to get some really good views that were not available when I was a kid. Really cool thing to see. Our ten-year old son loved it.

I think $10 to park is a little steep but it was cool to see this national memorial up close. I enjoyed taking the trail. Definitely worth going to see once but now that I've seen it there's no reason to go again really.

We loved it. I would put this on my bucket list if you haven't been there. Parking was in a covered parking garage. We paid $5 because we were seniors. I believe it would be $10 otherwise. There are exhibits of the building of Mt. Rushmore. We bought the DVD after seeing the movie which was free. They have elevators if you need them. The gift shop is the same at all National Parks expensive. They do have a pull off as you leave that will give you a profile of George Washington don't miss that photo-op. It is worth visiting. I'm so glad we did.

This is a magnificent carving of 4 of our presidents. On the drive up, we drove under it and looking up at it from our car just made the size of it that much more evident! As we went up the walkway we looked at the flags and information for each state, which included when each became a state. That information was actually very interesting and even though I'm sure we learned that in school, and it's available on the internet, it was much more thought provoking in that setting. The monument itself was awe inspiring and huge! How they did it back then is amazing. There is a $10 parking fee because the parking is managed by a contract company. It's an annual fee, which we didn't need, but if you want to go back, you can with no additional fee.

Parking was very easy. We got in with senior citizen discount for $5 per car, regular $10. Very nicely kept National Memorial with lots of information, films & history. You could spend quite a bit of time here looking at all the displays, but we spent a little over an hour. Visited the gift shop, but did not eat at the restaurant. Highly recommend.

OK, this is a Bucket List venue for sure. As we approached the site in our car,the sculture is impressive, but small in relation to it's surroundings. Of all the pictures I've seen of the Memorial the faces appear HUGE in nature. Not the case in real time. Since this is a National Memorial, you must pay to enter the grounds, either with cash or use your National Park Pass, (we used it at Devils Tower, too). However, if you do pay, you may leave and re-enter all day. The parking deck is located within easy walk to the main entrance. There were two Port-O-Potty's located on the top parking deck, but nice, government facilities are located a short three minute walk towards the Memorial. The walk up to the viewing area is impressive with all the States represented with columns, along with their state flags, on either side of the walkway. Now up close the Memorial is a site to behold from the viewing wall. Between you and the Memorial is the amphi-theatre featuring the nightly presentation of "light's out" and folding of the colors by our Vet's. Halfway in, along the walkway, is a concession area as well as a bountiful souvenir shop. Our hour and a half visit was enjoyable and a check mark placed in the box.

We did the evening program and the next morning went back to see it in daylight. If you can...go in the evening. So patriotic and moving. Well done and happy to be there with fellow Americans and enjoying the celebration. It cost $10 to park but it is good for a year. Daylight was another wonderful experience. Seeing the 4 presidents with the sunshine on them was spectacular. Everyone should go!

The entire memorial is well done. Suggest you get an audio phone for each person in your party, like $8 for two, well worth it. Take the presidents walk. not very long but you get closer.Food in restaurant cafeteria was good, very helpful service.

An amazing experience.. beautiful during the day... absolutely stunning & a must see all lit up at night. Plan some extra time for the museum. lots of great artifacts & such as well as a couple great movies on how the monument was built. The Memorial is free but there is a $10 parking fee (good for a week). There is a nice restaurant & gift shop as well. Some really good (interesting) Jerky at gift shop... Venison, Buffalo, elk & more

Outstanding display of the sculptures. Not to be missed. It does not take long to visit. Charge for cars - $10. $5 over 65. No other admission charge. Plan your trip around a clear day.Mt. Rushmore can be in the clouds when Keystone is not.

Great time of year to get in with minimal wait and smaller crowds. It is only $10.00 per vehicle to enter and see this, so the cost is well worth it for a family adventure. Nice and clean and many people to help answer questions, videos on the building of the monument, alot of pictures with descriptions as well, pamphlets to take, gift shop and places to sit right in front to take in view and people also hiking hills right in front of monument. Beautiful day and easy to enter and exit this park. Had a great family visit.

Great time just to see how and why it was built....The explanation of how and why they picked the president to be on there mountain.....A must to see....All you pay is a small parking fee of $10.00 for cars and rv and if your senior citizen is $5:00 less...Also that pass you buy is good all YEAR LONG but its only for the car you purchased in...I went back for the night lighting but all it was again a film on the historic of how it was built....I won't recommend it but you feel you need to it only during the month of August/September......How fun
This is my first trip to Rushmore and it didn't disappoint. It is beautiful in person. I recommend everyone go and see it. It's $10 to park.

As a photographer I found the light at dawn (on sunny days) to be remarkable. It's possible to come here very early in the morning. I think the gates open at 5;30 am. Their will be no shops or bathrooms open, but you can see the monument. Mount Rushmore is ONE OF THE PLACES I WOULD DEFINITELY STOP AT ON WAY TO YELLOWSTONE!!!! It's one of the coolest spots in South Dakota. It's possible to easily stay in Rapid City and come here. Rapid City is something like 20-30 minutes away. Don't make the same mistake we made by staying in Keystone. Keystone is an awful tourist trap (unless you like that sort of place). It's free to enter here, but $10 to park.
If you are in the area, this is a must see. $10 to park and you are good to go. Has a nice trail that gives many vantage points for unique views. There are a lot of stairs, so be aware.

Finally made it here! Road tripping through from Yellowstone we stopped here to see it for ourselves. It was astonishing. However, I was expecting it to be bigger. Even standing in front of it, it seemed small. The boardwalk pathway with stairs makes it hard on disabled people. Unless you only go up to the lookout area and leave. The little amphitheater also has ceremonies for the military. The facilities are very new and clean. Parking is $10. It is a parking structure.

Very clean and well maintained. The Museum is not to be missed. We were lucky to see the Turning on of the lights at night. IT starts at 8:00pm with a presentation by a park ranger as well as the lowering of the flag and singing of the National Anthem. IT was crowded the night we were there so not sure if it is always that way but get there early. The senior Park pass gets you a Discount on the $10 parking fee. It only cost us $5 good for a week and we returned the following day at no cost. Keep the card they give you as you can return just by showing it. The Gift shop is very nice up there and prices to go along with it.Also we got a ice cream at the ice cream shop. Good value for the amount and the ice cream was just OK. Not outstanding like the rest of the area. I highly suggest if you get an opportunity you go to Mt Rushmore. ITs awesome.

We have been quite a few times but Mount Rushmore just never gets old! First time or 10th time...it is an awesome sight! $10 to park but no other entrance fee. The movie was interesting and the gift shop is great.
I resisted this trip but am glad we came. You should see this in your lifetime. Free entrance but parking was $10.

One of our nations greatest monuments. You can easily spend 4 hours plus here. Lots of things to see along the presidential trail. Information through the hike towards the artist studio. Then back up too tour the muesum grab a bite to eat they have a wide selection of food. They have a little coffee shop also and a ice cream stand which is a must stop. ($5-6) for a big double scoop (you'll also learn the historical point of the ice cream stand while there) they have 3 gift shops located through out 2 ran by the national parks the other by Private company. $10 for a car to get in $5 for senior citizen and the pass is good for a whole year.

We arrived at a reasonably early hour. There already was a short line to get into parking, but nothing really drastic. As a senior, parking cost us $5.00; the normal rate is $10.00. Military retirees also can get discounted parking. Unless you buy something, parking is the only thing you have to pay for. Be aware there is a strict "No pets allowed" policy. One man complained to us about the "no pets" policy as we walked up the steps toward the monument.
Arived around 10:00 and the place was about half full. $5.00 parking for us with senior park pass. Not crowded walked right up to the viewing area & amphitheater . Good exibit on the lower level.

The parking fee is $10 which is very reasonable since it is good for a year. Because of this we were able to multiple times on this trip. We got in the area late in the afternoon so the sun wasn't quite right on the monument. We planned to return the next morning. We did and we decided to walk the presidential trail. It was a bit regroups, especially on the return up. Finally we went st night to see it illuminated. We got there around 8:30 and the huge crowd was leaving. The lighting ceremony was over so we basically had the place to ourselves once we got there.

Mount Rushmore was absolutely spectacular! The actual monument itself is very impressive, and the grounds are just as nice. There is a lot more information about the place than I had imagined, which is presented well in the museum, which also has short film. Parking is $10.

Very impressive! I went on a Globus tour through the state parks and was not only impressed with the sculpture but with the park itself with the trails, cleanliness, shops and amenities. The Park Service provides a good service to get us close to the site safely and with good information. I recommend you purchase the $35 membership even if you live far from Rushmore. That membership card paid for itself at the other national park restaurants and gift shops (15 percent discounts). More importantly it helps sustain our national parks.

Seeing the Presidents engraved in the mountain is really AMAZING! The sculpture is remarkable. The park is very clean and offers beautiful views. Walk the Presidents trail- it is an easy clockwise path and gives you interesting angles of the sculpture. The film gives you a fascinating inside perspective into its making. Gift shop had great variety of souvenirs. Skip the overpriced food. Parking is $10. The annual national parks pass isn't honored.

My wife and I rounded up our May whirlwind tour of Idaho, Wyoming, Montana and South Dakota by visiting Mt Rushmore. What a beautiful sight to behold. With a handicap placket, we were able to drive (pretty much) right up to the base of the monument. Well, we were a few hundred yards away, but from the pictures, you would think we were right there. I am limited on my range of walking, so I stayed back and just took in the scenery, but boy was it breathtaking. Not only looking up into the sky to view the monument, but if you turn around and look back, the view down off the mountain side into the valley below is fantastic. I don't remember the price, but I think it was less than $10/person and the pass (I believe) was good for a year. How can you beat that?

If you're in the Black Hills, Mount Rushmore is a must. Just driving to the monument through the Black Hills is breathtaking. It seems that every turn provides a different view of nature. The memorial itself is amazing as you stand and realize the magnitude of the sculpture. The walk through the Avenue of Flags to get to the observation deck is appropriate as all 56 states and territories are represented. There are two visitor centers, one near the parking center and one below the grand terrace, both including a bookstore and gift shop. You can also visit the Sculptor's Studio where Borglum worked on the model for Mount Rushmore. You can explore further with the half-mile walk with or without the audio tour $5. We were unable to take the self-guided tour because of the 422 stairs.

This is a lovely park and monument that speaks of the traits that America was founded upon. There is a fee to park here $10 if you are under age 62, and $5 if you are over 62. The parking pass is good through the end of the calendar year. There is a movie and other exhibits that provide information about the artist who designed this monument. There is an evening program with a movie and patriotic music. It concluded with a tribute to military personnel for their service to our country. Very nice!

Really, truly, this is such a beautiful monument. Viewing the heads is easy as there are so many places to see it well. The whole area is nicely done and is quite impressive. The gift shop had a wide variety of things. We ran out of time to walk thru the museum. It was $10 to park and I believe that pass is good for a year. We came back for the lighting ceremony. Somewhere I read it happened at 9pm however the night we went the program started earlier and the lighting of the heads was at 830, so we missed most of the program. I'd recommend checking on that the day you plan to attend if you want to see the evening program. My kids thought it was very cool!

A must see National Monument. There is no fee for the monument, but you must pay $10 to park ($5 for 62+ and military). Take the Presidential trail (really a boardwalk with rails and steps) for diverse close-up views of the monument and the sculptor’s studio. The studio contains the large model of the sculpture which was never quite completed on the mountain. The sculptors death and lack of funds prevented completion. Also be sure to see the film and museum documenting the people and processes that created this magnificent sculptor.

This wonderful Memorial is certainly worthy of every American's time and effort to go see and take in. We appreciated how easy this is accessed about 30-40 minutes off the highway depending on traffic. We went early in the am and made great time. The sculpture work is something to behold for sure and the granite entrance way lines with each state's colors is classic architecture. For better or worse, this is one of those check the box places as there really is not too much to actually do. You go. You see. You take photos. You leave. All for $10 parking - which was ample.
10$ for parking. You can use that pass for the year. There's an audio tour I didn't take. The hiking trail is well maintained. ABSOLUTLEY breathtaking view of the mountain.

They do have one of the best gift shops in the area! Please go to the lighting ceremony! A one time fee of $11.00 for a car load is an awesome deal when you have a large family! AND it's good for the whole year! Such a great experience for all!
Not much to say that hasn't been said. It is a must see for all Americans. Stay for the lighting ceremony. Feel free to ask a ranger a question- very friendly and full of knowledge.

I remember coming here when I was a kid and now I had the chance to take my daughters. They thought it was pretty cool and learned a little something. You have to pay $10.00 to park, but if you are close enough or want to spend more than one day the parking pass last all year so you wouldn't have to pay again.

If you go to South Dakota make sure you check out Mount Rushmore. It won't take long to see and pricing is affordable. Only have to pay for parking which is $10. If you have anyone older than 62 then the price is $5. You can do both Mount Rushmore and crazy horse in the same day since both are not that far apart. Make sure you plan other activities with this and not make this the only place to visit on a trip.

A famous attraction with enough to do to fill a couple hours for only $10…oh wait, that $10 you paid gets you in for an entire year. The Presidential Trail was busy, but not annoyingly packed. You get to see the sculpture from lots of awesome views, and the Sculpture’s Studio is very interesting.

You do not have to stop here to see Mt Rushmore but for a 10$ parking fee you can see the memorial up closer and visit the gift sho and learn more about the artist behind the memorial. It was very good. And believe it or not the things we bought at the gift shop were cheaper than the same things at gift shops in the surrounding towns!

We made sure a stop at Mount Rushmore was part of our family vacation across the U.S. this summer. It somehow seemed smaller to me with an adult's eyes, but no less impressive. The kids absolutely loved the memorial, much as I remembered being awed by it so many years ago when I was their age. There is no fee to enter, but there is a fee to park - currently $10 for a car. Your National Park pass will not help you here, although there is a discount if you have a senior over 62 in your vehicle. The visitor's center is small, but has a nice exhibit area and a nice short film. We spent about an hour here, and didn't find it to be crowded at all (a surprise since it was a Saturday afternoon during Sturgis). No trip to the Black Hills can be complete without a stop here.

This was a fun trip and enjoyed spending some time taking this place in. The effort and sacrifice put into to this by so many is awe inspiring. Craftsmanship is amazing and on such a grand level. Especially would recomend and don't fail to see the workshop. It will complete your visit. I havr one criticism, that is charging for parking is plain bull crap. Charge a entrance fee or don't. Don't treat people like idiots.

It's really stunning - if it's cloudy when you arrive you should wait for the sun to come out as it changes the intensity when the sun is beaming off the faces. $10 to get it and lasts for a year. Well worth the visit

We drove from Colorado to see the monument. It was a nice experience but not all what I hoped for or expected. There is a parking fee of $10. I knew that before we arrived, so I wasn't shocked. However I didn't think parking would be a hassle since I'd paid for it. The walkway with the flags was really nice. It has each state's flag and the year it was added to the union. The flags are alphabetical order by state name. They have walking recorded tours. There's a cost for those. I didn't walk them, but there appeared to be walking trails alongside the mountain. We went in the afternoon and left to come back for the lighting. We got there at 8 and it slowly started filling up around 8:30. The ceremony is just a ranger talking and a movie about the monument. It was not all it was hyped up to be. Although seeing the monument lit up at night was really nice. After the ceremony the traffic was crazy, which was to be expected. The history of the monument is all over the place. The monument is really nice and the history behind it as well. But I've been there, done that. No need to return.

Visiting on a roadtrip. There were 100k bikers in the area during my trip which was a bit of a pain. The monument was great. Not much wild life in the trails due to the rumblings of motorcycles. There's a museum and a few walking trails here. There's a $10 parking fee. Parking was readily available early in the day. On the drive out there are several photo ops.

No trip to the Black Hills would be complete without a stop at Mount Rushmore. It is absolutely beautiful and it only cost $11 to park so it's very cheap. There is a nice gift shop as well as s cafe that serves very yummy ice cream. Highly recommend stopping at Mount Rushmore if you are in western South Dakota!

Many National Parks and Monuments charge an admission fee, and that's fine. That's justified, and it's why I buy an annual $80 pass. But the pass wasn't accepted at the (only) "concession" parking area. (At other Parks and Monuments, parking is free.) I've been to this spectacular spot before, so I decided to try other ways to see it without paying the fee. (Yes, I travel on the cheap when I'm on my own.)

Parking was $5 for seniors, others $10 and no entry fee for the facility. This was a great site to see in person but once you've been here, there really is no reason to return as it should never change.
Parking is $10 a car unless you have a senior citizen in car it's $5. Go early to avoid the huge crowds. Definitely watch the 'shrine' video. Beautiful site.

I had been here twice, once for the Bicentennial celebration on July 4, 1976 and once in the late 80s with my husband. They definitely updated the experience since then. Parking structure is nice ($10 for a year pass), they serve breakfast, lunch and dinner with both indoor or outdoor seating. Nice trail around the face of the mountain (lots of stairs for those less agile).

If you are in the area Mt Rushmore is a must see, but don't make it the focus of your trip. Go early to avoid the crowds and be prepared to pay $10 to park! The Presidential Trail is OK. There's a small museum and gift shop. It's a good spot for photographs, but not much else.

If you are anywhere near the area, you should definitely stop in and see this gem. Parking is $10 but plenty of it and nice garage style with either stairs or elevator available. Awesome parade of flags list info about each state and US territory. Presidential trail is must do if able. Plenty of places to rest along the way if need be. Buy or bring your passport book for national parks. Three different stamps available here. Lighting ceremony in the evening was interesting with Ranger talk and video about some history. A real tribute to America!! Don't forget to try the Thomas Jefferson vanilla ice cream while there.
We stopped in the late morning and it is an inspiring stop! It's highly recommend. Even if it seems crowded to get in, it's worth it. Parking is $10 ($5 for Seniors)
