Mount Rushmore looks exactly like the pictures I have seen all my life but seeing it in person is impressive and left one in awe. I came back to see it lit up at night and it was amazing. I would recommend seeing it during the day and lit up in the evening. It is just incredible. There is a parking fee of $10 which is good for a year, so come back as many times as you like. The park is beautiful, clean and has so much history to offer.

We (mom, dad, 10 year old daughter) visited Mt. Rushmore three times in two days. You'll pay $10 for parking, but the permit last until the end of the year and there are no other entrance fees. (Note- a fourth grade National Park Pass does not work here.) We went in the late afternoon the first day, visited the gift shop, walked on the Presidential Trail which loops about a half-mile, taking you up closer to the monument. (There are many stairs! I do believe only the first part going to the left is wheel-chair accessible.) We also visited the sculptor's studio that had the scale model used by the carvers and other artifacts.

It had been 30 years since I have been to Mount Rushmore. Things were pretty much as I remembered. There did not seem to be many people there mid week. The price is worth it to see at least once in your lifetime. $10 per car, $5 if you have a senior driving. We had kids with us so opted for the the junior ranger booklet. We all learned a lot in the process. The under 12 was very easy to go through. The over 13 was more challenging. It was a fun scavenger hunt of questions. They had to go through all of the exhibits to get the answers. The movie seems like it was the same one I saw when I was a kid. Overall it was nice to revisit and spend the day.

This will likely be our last visit to Mt. Rushmore. The crowds and concrete parking garage (10$ to park) were a real disappointment to us. You don't need your national park pass to get in (just pay to park). Take the short hike around the bottom if you want?

Wonderful attraction. Loved watching the short film about Mount Rushmore & how it was built. There is plenty of sheltered parking. Parking fee is $10/vehicle, but it's good for the entire year! Loved the lighting ceremony at night!

Arrive early to this venue as it is crazy busy after 8:30 am. The venue opens at 5:30 am and Visitor's Center at 8 am. $10.00 parking and $5.00 for 62 year or older. Entrance fee is free. Beware as this is a crazy busy place and I suggest arriving before 8:30 am for the best pictures. See the 18 minute film as it's informative!!

We had never been to Mt. Rushmore so decided to make it our summer get-away. What an amazing sight as you approach it. Even the drive up to it as awesome. The history behind this and its sculpture is really neat. Only pay a $10 parking fee and you're IN! Go later in the day so you can catch the lighting ceremony plus the park isn't that full. Take the trails and get views from different angles. So glad we got to see this.

We had a great visit. They have a nice walkway around the base of the mountain. They had a gentleman in the gift shop who actually worked on it. He was having a book signing. Beware though there is a parking fee and your National Park Pass does not cover it. Everyone must pay.

This is a must do for families. It was a $10 parking fee and otherwise free. The trail around Rushmore was beautiful and well maintained. Also, best gift shop in the land- really! It was affordable with nice clothing and gifts.

After reading about the parking fee at Mount Rushmore, I wanted to add that the fee is waived for active-duty military and half off ($5) for seniors, but you have to let attendant know you are a senior. Well, worth it, however, I do not understand how a private company was allowed to have this arrangement. Hopefully, this will not occur at our other national parks.

I have been coming to Mount Rushmore since I was a young girl. It is always inspirational! The development of the park through the years has definitely enhanced the experience. The film and museum are so interesting and inspiring. So amazing, everyone needs to experience it. You only pay $10 per carload for one year for same vehicle and discounts for 60+ and Military.

Mt. Rushmore is so amazing - and be sure to watch the movie and visit the exhibit hall, also. If you are a senior citizen, you can park for only $5.00. What a bargain! The Market Cafe is an excellent place to eat while you are visiting.

Smaller than I thought it would be, but then again so was the Alamo. I guess history class always made things seem larger than life, still, this is breathtaking. We are so lucky to live in this country with so many beautiful places to visit and cool things to do. The parking is good, don't forget to mention you're military if you are because we didn't and that would have saved us about half on parking but $10 wasn't bad. Handicapped parking was not well marked but there are elevators so it worked. The gift shop is really nice - HUGE. Definitely worth the visit!!

We all enjoyed our stay. Parking is easy. $10 to get in and is good for a year in case you want to visit during the day and come back at night for the light show. We decided not to, we were exhausted from our day of traveling. Was easy to make your way around. We enjoyed the presidential trail-this is must do. You can get some amazing pictures.

My family appeased me to stop here while in the area but after our stop, they were glad we went. Even though you can see the sculptures from the road, it is worth the $10 parking fee to go to the site. A museum is included that does a great job of telling the story of how the site was carved. A 14 minute movie is worth the time too.

Enroute to Yellowstone NP, we stopped at Mt. Rushmore. It's free to get into, however there is a $10 parking fee. Traveling with a travel trailer, we were apprehensive about parking, but it was well laid out, and easy to get in and out of.

I thought it was cool, if you take the time to learn and respect the work that really went into it I think you'll enjoy it that much more. Big visitor center, many areas to view the Mt from whether your in a wheel chair or not. If you want to get up close but can't walk the stairs up, to the left is a paved trail. Get there before 10 if you can it gets busy, Lots of parking though so no worries ($10 to park) We spent 1.5hr there

We arrived too late to catch the light show, but we were still able to see Mt. Rushmore lit up. Went back the next afternoon to get daytime photos. One of the least expensive to visit - $10 per car, and you can use your parking ticket for a year! Didn't make it to the museum (son had no interest).

Mount Rushmore is an iconic American landmark and it is a Memorial that you won't regret visiting. You can go for a quick visit to take a picture or you can spend some time there, hiking the presidential trail, viewing a movie, or exploring and learning some history. The Memorial is free but the parking cost $10.

We came in through Custer State Park, a longer but much more scenic route, with several corkscrew turns and one lane bridges and tunnels. Our first view was afar was awesome!! We were able to take pictures as we got closer, but did not enter the memorial because of the immense amount of cars. The $10 fee is for parking, so National Park passes are not accepted.

This is a very cool National Monument. Everyone has seen pictures of Mt. Rushmore, but you can't experience the awe unless you actually stop here in person. We visited about 9am and beat most of the crowd. Beautiful weather on the day we visited, sunny with blue sky made for some great photo opportunities. A $10 parking fee for cars. Hike the President's Trail for a close view from the base of the mountain, but be warned lots of stairs.
The park only cost $10 to get in!

A great place to visit for all ages. No fee for admission, but $10 for parking for a motorcycle. They have an area for motorcycles to park which is nice. A lot of people, but the area is large so not much of a problem. The presidential trail is worth taking, but there are quite a few stairs. It is just amazing to see what was accomplished in that time period and with the equipment they had available.

Make sure you stop by at night to see the monument all lit up and then return the next day and purchase the audio tour, well worth the $5.00 and the walk around the monument. Very impressed with the new parking deck, what a change from our visit 20 years ago.

Visiting Mount Rushmore had been a lifelong dream and goal for myself. I absolutely loved it. I arrived at about six in the morning and though there was a sign that parking was $10 there was a note posted on the parking attendant booth to simply proceed without paying and enjoy Mount Rushmore. I am not sure if parking was free that whole day or they just get someone in the booth later on to collect the money during regular business hours. I greatly enjoyed the huge sculptures of famous American presidents and the path that wound through the ground and afforded differing views on the monument. This stop was one of the highlight of my trip out west. It may not have the same appeal to other folks but I thoroughly enjoyed every bit of it.

I've been so excited to visit here, that I actually got a little emotional just walking on the property. Admission is free, but there is a $10 fee for parking. We were asked at the gate if anyone in our car was a Veteran or Active Duty Service. We certainly appreciated the free parking and they thanked us very genuinely for our service. There's a multi level parking garage and there was an attendant directing us to the number level we should drive to. We arrived at around 5 pm, and while there were lots of people, parking was easy and we never felt over crowded.

The monument is easy to get to. The annual parking pass is $10.00 that is definitely worth it. There is a parking garage to protect against inclement weather. Lots of shops and three restrooms in three different locations. Typical gift shops and some stuff they offer is very reasonable.

It was some sort of special day so we only paid $5 for parking. Every inch of this monument is worth the time to walk around and read about how it was done and why. I will be back for the lighting another time. I missed it because of time.

Wonderful. We were there on a Saturday night in June. I thought it would be incredibly busy, but it was manageable. We went for the lighting at 9:30pm, as we arrived to the area around 9:15 and figured why not. There were no seats left in the amphitheater where they were showing a movie, but we could hear it and participated in singing the National Anthem at the end before they lit the Memorial. Our young boys enjoyed it, even though it was very late for them. We were pleased to find that there is no admittance fee and only an $11 fee for the parking pass, which is good for one year. So we returned the next morning as well. We loved seeing it both at night and in the daylight. We didn't have extra time for any hikes or anything; probably spent 20 minutes each visit, which was plenty. A great family memory we will share for years.

It was great to see such a famous national monument. It was a quick visit. Took pictures, walked around the path, and left. It was only $10 per car to park and no other fee. Worth it if taking a trip to the area, but not a whole day adventure. We were there for probably about 30 minutes. A good experience overall.

The carvings were larger and more majestic than I expected. Photographs don't do it justice. I'm not much for reading all the information sheets or touring the on-site museums, and I sure don't like site movies...but this was the exception. I thoroughly enjoyed the informative aspect of this site, and especially enjoyed the informative movie presentation! Go! Feel patriotic, and marvel at the accomplishment of those who worked on this monument.

So happy to have crossed this one off my bucket list! We stayed in Rapid City so it was a quick 25 minute ride to Rushmore. Get there early! We got there at around 9:30 and got a close parking space ($10 park fee) and had plenty of opportunities to take family pictures before the crowds came in. The Presidents Trail loop was great--I would recommend you take it clockwise as it's easier on the knees and a little easier to get through if you're not in the best of shape. Plenty of shade and benches to rest along the way and some great picture viewpoints that you can't get from the main viewing platform. Once you've completed your loop don't forget to pick up a cup or cone of Ice cream from Thomas Jefferson's recipe--the kids loved it--just be warned the portions are huge! You can also rent an audio guide at the entrance which you use at various stops along the route. What an amazing place to visit!

We went to see the evening lighting ceremony then returned the next morning to see the monument in the daylight. The evening ceremony was well done and brought feelings of extreme patriotism. During the day take the trail around the monument as it gives different perspectives at each overlook. Yes, there is a $10 parking fee but don't let that dictate whether you see this national treasure or not.

This has been on hubby and my bucket list for the past 3 years or so, and we were so happy that we were able to get there!!! To see this amazing sculpture and know that it was carved out of massive mountains. After viewing the monument time and again we went into the theater where they showed a film about the making of the monument. Be sure to watch it, as it was extremely informative. There are also lots of exhibits relating to how it was built and stories behind how each of the Presidents was carved. Parking was $10.00, but since we are senior citizens we got in for $5.00 and it's free to view the monument. As you walk toward it, you are in an area with flags of different states, and on the posts it has the names of the states, when they were admitted, and what number they are. Believe me, seeing this in person is nothing like seeing pictures of it. A must see!

This is a must see! For starters parking is only 10 dollars and the drive takes you through these majestic mountains. There are tons of things to do and see around the monument making this a great destination as well. Kids enjoyed eating ice cream at the little ice cream shop and all agree it was worth the stop!

We took a quick trip to Keystone just to see Mount Rushmore; it was worth the 7 Hour road trip. It's very reasonable...just $10 per vehicle. We went around 3:00 pm on a Saturday and it wasn't overly crowded. A must see in the Black Hills.

Easy to get in and park, its $10 per car unless senior or military and then its only $5 per car. The tkt is valid for the whole year so you can return. Park service offers wheel chairs if needed and an audio tour. The audio is $5 and not sure its really worth it. Monument is about 5 miles out of Keystone so if you stay there the night before its an easy up and out. Look at going back in the evening to see the monument lighted. Not a bad half days visit for $10
I love how Mount Rushmore is presented with a grandiose entry way with pillars of all US flags. The $10 is definitely worth the visit for a family! You can even take some trails to get a closer view.

Mount Rushmore is a must see. I had never been there. My husband had never been there. So, it was neat for us to be experiencing something for the first time alongside our kids. We went straight to the monument after arriving in the Black Hills, and it set the tone for the whole great trip. We returned again in the evening for the lighting ceremony. (It is worth noting that your $10 parking pass is valid for the rest of the year!)

My husband and I visited Mount Rushmore as children and together in the early 2000s and the place has transformed since then. The parking is $10 for the day (it's an annual pass!) in a multilevel parking ramp. The entrance to the facility is much more grand and stately. The park staff were all so friendly, welcoming, and helpful. And the addition of the Presidential Trail around the monument is tremendous. I'd suggest good walking shoes as the trail is a bit vigorous. A stop in the Sculptors Studio is well worth it to get a historical account of the monument from a Park Ranger. The surrounding landscape of rocky terrain and rugged trees is stunning. Altogether this is an impressive part of any vacation!

Great place to visit! Very well organized displays documenting the planning and sculpting of the monument. Great gift shops with a large variety of items. Park on the third level and you're on the same level Elma's the entrance. Parking costs $10 and there's no entrance fee.

My husband and I visited the Mount Rushmore Memorial while on vacation in South Dakota. As usual, the National Park Service does a wonderful job of presenting and maintaining these national treasures. I am disturbed by recent internet articles naming Mt. Rushmore as "a vacation spot not worth seeing." The vision and expertise that went into creating this Memorial is well worth the visit. In addition, it is set in the Black Hills National Forest, which I believe is one of the most beautiful areas of our country. There is no entry fee for the memorial, however, there is a $10 parking fee. A $5 discount is available for those with the national parks annual or lifetime pass.

My family and I recently visited Mount Rushmore during our trip to Rapid City. My family consisted of myself, my wife, and our 12 year old boy/girl twins. The monument is breathtaking, and full of history. Can't beat the price.....$10! We got to the monument early in the morning, and were able to beat the crowds! This is a must see for anyone in the area....would definitely recommend it!

This isn't an all day trip, but a good 2 hours. Nice museum, movie, trail. $10 to park (5 if you're over 62). Park rangers available. And of course, those faces! They were having a naturalization ceremony for a number of new citizens which was a special moment.

Anyone who rated this place as anything less than 4 stars is a liar. It's $10, easy to walk to, and has lots of other interesting things to view beside Mount Rushmore. The staff was friendly. The mount itself is magnificent and inspiring. The views of the surrounding black hills is beautiful as well. The gift shop is large and has several unique items. We brought our 9 month old daughter here and she liked it. It is not an all day thing, 1-2 hours tops, but is definitely worth the money and time.
Awesome. Great show at 9PM also and friendly people all over. First site of monument is inspiring. Charge is for parking and good for a year

I've heard it said that Mt. Rushmore is one of the most over-rated destinations in the US. I was prepared to prove that wrong but I found it to be true. The presidential portraits on the mountain are indeed impressive, but the site seems to be more about Gutzon Borglund, the artist, than the presidents depicted. The National Park Service has done their best to make this an impressive place, but there isn't all that much to work with. Parking was a mandatory $10, but because I was over 62, we got a discount on that. Very nice gift shops onsite. This is one of those things on people's bucket lists to say they've visited. So ... been there, done that, didn't buy a t-shirt.

This was one of our stops on a multiple stop trip out west. Mt. Rushmore is something you always see pictures of when they show the sites of the US. You should go see it in person. Pretty impressive. To learn how it was built and what it took for the people to build it is very interesting. There is a trail that you can walk around and get different views of the monument and then get to the base of the it. Definitely worth seeing!! Price of admission is very reasonable.

This national treasure is definitely worth seeing! There's several walking trails and all steps are paved to get a closer view of this granite monument. Photo opps at every turn. Best of all, admission of between $10-$12 is charged per private car only (not per person) so it makes this park affordable entertainment for the entire family. There's also a brief video on the history of the project. Weather can change within minutes so be prepared for possible showers. Lots of walking involved.

Mount Rushmore is very inspirational to visit. Parking is $10 per car but only $5 for Seniors 62 and older and is good for one year so we visited multiple times on our stay. The mornings are the best time for sun on the faces of the monument. There is a nice cafeteria on site which serves breakfast, lunch and dinner plus ice cream. The $5 ice cream is about 3 scoops so you might want to share. On the left side of monument the Presidentsl trail is mostly flat out to the monuments. We also enjoyed the sculptors studio and seeing the large models of the sculpture. The lighting ceremony at night was very patriotic and week done by the Rangers. Plenty of seating in the amphitheater.

Mount Rushmore is one of those must see places in the United States. The parking is $10 regardless of having a National Park Pass or not. The monument is not actually charging, it is the company that owns the parking structure. The price is not too bad for an hour or two of something to do. Once parked, you enter the monument. There is a walkway with all the flags from each state. It's a nice representation of the country. We took the Presidential Trail Hike. I suggest starting on the west end and looping around. You are going to have a steep incline either way that you have to go up but that way seemed a little easier. The Presidential Trail allowed you to get closer to the monument and get some nice pictures of the faces. The walk is nice and worth the time. There is a small museum at the end of the trail (or beginning if you are coming from the east) that we were able to take refuge from the hail storm that popped up.

My wife has been wanting to visit mount Rushmore for some time now and I was glad to finally take her. Even though the parking was $10 it's still an amazing sight and a testament to our great country. We were not able to walk the presidents trail due to weather but we are hoping to go back tomorrow and walk around more. The museum is small but nice. It does a great job explaining how and why the monument was built.

WOW! This place is amazing. Parking is only $10, but $5 if you are a senior. The memorial is beautiful, and they have a great lighting ceremony at 9 pm. The park stays open late. You get to learn about the history of the memorial and it is pretty impressive.

Let me start by saying START EARLY! This is a very popular place for good reason so be sure to get there no later than 8am (as the grounds opens at 5am). It will get busier as the day goes on and you will have much better photo opportunities and a bit more solitude the earlier you are there. There is no fee to visit except that you have to pay $10 for parking. No idea if you could actually walk or bike up and not have to still pay though. They have all the gift shops/restaurants and standard facilities as you might expect. I would suggest doing the Presidential Trail if you have time is it is a short distance and only a little bit of up and down on stairs (not wheelchair accessible). The monument itself is better than you might expect with incredible detail. Overall I was quite surprised and very pleased. I can finally check this one off of my list! Definitely a must see!

What an amazing memorial to see. We went three times to get different pictures based on the lighting. I am ready to go again. The cost is $10 for parking and that is good for the year. If possible go at night also for the lighting.

What can you say? It's Mount Rushmore. The views are incredible and you will be able to take photos that look just like a postcard. There is a movie in the Information Center, which was rather disappointing. However, the displays there were very interesting and informative. If you're interested in the process of carving the monument, it's a must see. If you take the Presidential Trail to see the monument closer up, I would recommend starting at the end (on the right as you face the monument). I read many reviews that said starting on the left involved less steps. However, that did not seem to be true. Plus, all the steps going that direction fall at the end when you're already tired. I rented the audio tour for $5 and thought it was well worth the price, although the rental process was pretty cumbersome and time consuming, even needing a copy of your driver's license! The Thomas Jefferson vanilla ice cream was delicious and the servings were pretty large. The food (cafeteria style) seemed overpriced so we didn't eat there except for the ice cream.
This is a must see if you are in the area & very well priced considering the $5 fee we paid (senior) gave us a one year's pass to come back.

Visiting Mt Rushmore was an extremely enjoyable experience. Recommend staying in Keystone, South Dakota as it is only 2 miles from the monument. The park requires $10 to park but the visit to the monument is free. The park rangers and employees were extremely friendly and helpful. The is a restaurant and ice cream shop in the park. There are great opportunities for photos. We visited in early May before Mothers Day. The park was not crowded. The tourist season begins on Mothers Day. Keystone is a great place to stay as there are many other attractions in the area.

I came here today with a friend on a friend's trip. This is a MUST while in Keystone. The drive up was scenic. Once there, expect to pay $10.00 a car. The walk up has a bunch of flags and pillars with the names of states and facts on them. Behind that is the monument. What a sight it is! We took the presidential walk also which gets you even closer to the monument. I would highly recommend this place !
The view is amazing. Price is reasonable. The movie was very helpful in understanding the monument. Gift shop had lots of local items to chose from.

I always said I wanted to visit Mt Rushmore - and this Spring weekend i did- I arrived in Rapid city by plane from Chicago- it was a one hour and 43 minute flight- as soon as I landed in Rapid city - the airport was clean and cozy - I rented a car with Enterprise - and set off to my hotel - then I hopped back into the car and drove the empty highways toward Mt. Rushmore- the drive was so calming - a big wide highway - and I drove through forests and hills - when I got to the entrance to the Memorial - I only paid $10 for a parking pass- that I could use over and over again to gain entrance for a year- the parking was indoor - then i proceeded to the walkway toward the memorial - of course I got distracted by the gift shop and bought the usual t-shirts and trinkets as souvenirs for friends and family- as I headed to the memorial the walkway had columns with each state's date of joining the Union- Delaware was the first state to join the Union and Illinois was the 21st in the year 1818- I am leaving the best for last - the sculpture on the mountain of presidents Washington- Jefferson- Roosevelt and Lincoln is just breathtaking - they look down at you with such dignity and wisdom - it is fantastic how out of a mountain in the middle of America comes this breathtaking image- the museum on site explains the history of this magnificent sight - the sculptor Borglum who had Danish roots wanted to set up this project in the Black Hills of South Dakota - he needed money so a man named Rushmore donated $5000 to help start this project - and that is why the mountain where the presidents visions are embedded is named Mt Rushmore- and this was in the 1940s - it is also worthy to note 3 million people visit Mt Rushmore a year

We visited in early May. The weather was just beautiful. The first time we visited was after 5 PM. The lighting on the memorial was just perfect with the sun. Many people back home told us they were disappointed with the memorial but we thought it was amazing. This has been on our bucket list for years and we were so excited to finally get to see it, even my daughter who is 20 enjoyed her visit here. She took tons of pictures (as did we)! The visitor center was closed by the time we arrived. We walked the Avenue of Flags and of course looked for our State. Then went out to the viewing veranda on the Grand View Terrace I for an excellent view of the president's heads. It is just amazing to us how anyone could carve such a great memorial onto a side of a mountain. We got a few pictures of the local white mountain goat. We then came back in the evening to see the memorial when it was lighted. Since we were there so early in the season the patriotic program was not yet going on. I do hear that it is very moving. I'm glad we went back in the evening to see the presidents lighted but a little disappointed - I guess I thought it would be brighter. The pictures at night seem a little grainy but maybe a better camera would take better pictures. I would go back to see the program if we visited in season. Since the visitors center was closed, I made my husband go back in the morning to get our National Park Passport stamped! On this visit, we got to see the movie and walk the path to the bottom of the monument. Being a first time visitor, we didn't realize that if you take the path (Presidential Trail) to the right looking at the monument, you will have to walk up over 400 steps but if you take the path to the left, it is so much easier with just a few steps and the path leads to the exact same place. So if you have trouble walking, have small children, or are in a hurry, take the left path. I wish we would have went left and then walked down the steps! The Sculptor's Studio was closed on our visit. There is a Cafe and Ice Cream Shop onsite but we didn't go there. After getting home, we found out that they use Thomas Jefferson's original recipe for the ice cream so this is on our next trip's list! They have pet exercise areas on both sides of the parking lots - we didn't take a pet but thought this would be useful information to share. There is a parking fee - the National Park Pass does not cover this fee. I thought the fee was like $8 but I think we only paid $1. Maybe because we arrived so late in the day or maybe because it was off season I don't know. I would definitely go back this way again.

Every red blooded American should see this monument - but you don't have to pay the extreme rates charged at the parking area to do it, if you know your way around. The area is crowded, condensed, and the stands charge nearly twice as much for refreshments as you would get anywhere else - so bring your own. The price in is by vehicle, so if you are going in a group use one vehicle, if you can do so safely and comfortably. For me to pay $11.00 for myself on a motorcycle was a bit rich for an hour viewing of the rock. Got good pictures, but you don't have to pay that price for the return. Once was enough for me.
Amazing! This national monument must be seen in person to appreciate. The kids had a great time on "presidents walk". Parking was only $10. No passes or discounts accepted.

The drive to the monument alone was absolutely beautiful, be sure to bring your camera! Also the price to get in was only $9 and good for an entire year, definitely a great deal. The monument is set up so that you always have a good view. I went around 3pm on a Wednesday so there weren't many people there however many cars started to pull up as it got closer to 5. Check it out!

Mount Rushmore is located about 30 minutes outside Rapid City, South Dakota. The drive up to the monument is less than inspiring in that it is a collection of some of the worst kind of tacky tourist traps. It's really quite awful. Then parking at the monument is a bit misleading in that most of the signs direct you to what turns out to be an expensive pay lot. Also, the National Park Pass was not honored because it was a private lot. That said, the monument itself is quite impressive and the adjoining plaza is well done. When you consider the size of the figure heads and the effort to scale the mountain and perform the work, it is really well done. There are good sites for photography, however the afternoon sun was not the best for shots, morning would have been better. There were decent crowds in July but not unmanageable. For a pleasant break, I recommend the ice cream shop; the flavors are named after the presidents. Overall it’s a piece of history that is good to see, but once in a lifetime should suffice. After that, your photo will do just fine!

We stopped to visit Mount Rushmore on an early morning in April. There were very few people and the weather was great. We paid $10 for parking but the memorial itself was free. We walked through the parade of flags and the presidential trail. There were lots of stairs but well worth it! Definitely recommend as a stop on a trip out west.
Ok so seeing this in person is a must do. Tips: $10 parking, no national park pass discount. Park on upper level of available furthest in to minimize walking. Go in the off season for low crowds.

This experience was better than we thought it would be. We traveled with two daughters (12 and 14). It was very chilly, but we all still had a good time. Unfortunately the path that winds down closer to the monument was closed. We would have loved to do that, too. Gift shops had nice options. We did the audio tour and we enjoyed that more than our girls (but I think they enjoyed some of that, too). Not too pricey. I think those were $5 per person.

I have wanted to see this for as long as I can remember. I finally got to see it. It was awesome and I highly recommend everyone see it. You drive pretty high up and the views up there are awesome. It only costs $10 per vehicle to park, and that pass is good for a year. They have adequate parking, and a gift shop.

I enjoyed visiting Mount Rushmore. We went at night first which is very cool to see and I highly recommend it. We came back the next morning and walked along the paths all along the front of the monuments which was very cool. I also noted some hiking trails in the area. The gallery area is lovely and accessible. Parking is ample. The monument is free but parking is $10 however parking is good for the year if you come back. Lots of cool history and information!

Very Impressive in Person...Have seen photos for years and none compare to seeing it right in front of you. Mount Rushmore was on our Bucket List. Went in May and was not crowded, which made parking and maneuvering the park a breeze. There is no admission fee, but parking is $10 per car, which is reduced to $5 for Senior Citizens over 62. The parking fee is good for 1-year for same vehicle. The park is pristine and easy to access. Don't miss the intro video, which tells how the idea was conceived and work was done. Still marveled as to how this was accomplished in 1927-1941 time frame. Suggest you take Iron Mountain Road to access as along the way you go through some man-made tunnels and one in particular provides a view of Mount Rushmore from the entry side. Very glad we did not miss this National Treasure!!!

We took our grandson & it's all he's been talking about doing. It's cool to see but as he said...he thought it would be bigger. Our thoughts too but worth $10 parking & no admission. It's just the kind of thing that if you are in the area you should see.

This is a monument that everyone should see. I just don't get a lot out of it. It is pretty impressive but it just doesn't do it for me. I think after traveling across South Dakota, you are looking for anything to break up the trip, so it is a good place to stop and stretch your legs. That said, it is a nice place to stop but would recommend moving on to Devils Tower or beyond. Usually very busy in the summer, as I have been here a few times now. Ten dollars to park but is good for a whole year. Thomas Jefferson's vanilla ice cream was very good!! Still recommend going there as a bucket list item but don't get your hopes up too high!!

Was not as big as I thought! But it was a sight to see and hear how it was carved. It cost $10 to park and go in to visitors center where you can read about who and how it was made. Glad I got to see it

I always wanted to see this place, ever since I was a kid. Growing up in Cebu, Philippines, I always pictured myself sitting on a big stone and just marvel at this great monument and just have my mind played that moment when they were making it. It was actually a pretty long drive since we drove all the way from Riverton, Wyoming. Anyways, the road to get to the parking lot was pretty nice. It has some great views and lakes around the road that leads you to the park entrance. You will never see the monument on your way there. Which was pretty smart of them, that way, people would actually get inside the park and pay just to see it. It was all but $10 entrance fee per car, and it was actually a season pass. Good for people who might have some relatives and friends they might take through out one season.

I've been to Mt Rushmore before and although I love it, I felt like I was done after about 30 minutes. We had a long road trip planned with many things to do and see so we decided to travel Needles Highway and Iron Mountain Highway before we decided if we needed to go back in to the actual memorial park. My spouse and I were just as happy with the views from the scenic drives without having to deal with the crowds and $20 parking that goes along with the Mt Rushmore. I will post pictures obtained from the scenic drives and you can decide for yourself-especially if you are just driving through.

Very impressive in person, absolutely a must-see. It's crowded and tourist-y, but still absolutely worth the trip. Free entrance, but parking is $11 and not covered by the National Park pass, unfortunately.

Mount Rushmore was exactly as I imagined it would be. A massive larger than life sculpture depicting the faces of four U.S. presidents, George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Abraham Lincoln and Theodore Roosevelt, was carved into the rock of a tall mountain. It took nearly 400 men (mostly miners) to carve the mountain and considerable amounts of dynamite over a span of 14 years from 1927 through 1941. More than 90% of the carvings were completed using dynamite. The details were completed with jackhammers and hand chisels by the workers climbing 506 steps to its top each day. Amazingly there were no casualties. Nearly all of the mountain was carved during the Great Depression at a cost of nearly $1 million. The height of the sculptures faces reach nearly 60 ft high. Their noses are approximately 20 feet long, their eyes are 11 feet wide, and their mouths are approximately 18 feet long.

It was my dream to visit the Mount Rushmore National Memorial - definitely one of my bucket list items. It is great place to bring your kids to show them American history! The parking is well organized and easily available. The entrance fee is $10 (per car) and valid for one year. Unfortunately, no pets are allowed (not even a tea cup Yorkie in the purse).

Photographs don't do a justice to this amazing place. Parking is $10 for a regular vehicle. You must stay in the right lane when driving up to Mt. Rushmore. It was stroller friendly. Great gift shop by the entrance. Great restaurant to eat or pick up a snack. They also have an i team shop which is a must try. Don't forget to do the trail walk. Don't for get your cameras. We met people from all over the world. They have benches so people can sit and relax and watch the amazing view. This place is perfect go families, couples or groups.

My husband and I had a great experience at Mount Rushmore. The whole park is beautiful and well-maintained. There is ample parking and it only cost $10 to get in. From the parking area, it's just a short walk and you're there at a beautiful observation area, overlooking Mount Rushmore. It's a great place for photos. If you're feeling up to it, there's also a trail you can walk, that brings you a little closer and gets you a different perspective on the faces carved into the mountain. I'm not an avid hiker by any means, and for me the trail was enjoyable, not too long or too strenuous. There's also a very well-presented museum that tells you about the history of the park. Definitely a must-do for your trip to South Dakota!

We went here to see something that you see in books and movies and think you know what it's going to be like when you see it in person but are not truly sure. We schedlued a tour with Globus which was going to bring us here (on the first day of the tour) but only in the day time. We heard about the night time lighting ceremony and decided to rent a car and come here a day early. As we were traveling from Rapid City toward Mt Rushmore on the highway, Mt Rushmore suddenly appeared in our view. We pulled over and took pictures. It was quite a sight. Mt Rushmore has a large parking deck which costs approximately $12 dollars. To enter the park is free. The Park is clean, has gift shops, cafes, information offices, museum, flags and individual stones for each state and the year they joined the union. The lighting ceremony starts with a brief introduction by a park ranger, video history of the four presidents, lighting the monument, and honoring all of the veterans in attendance on the stage. There are walking paths (for day time) down and around the monument. Very enjoyable.

We read up on the monument before going, great way to get the history. Viewing the monument is free but parking is $11 per vehicle. As we drove up the road and approached the monument there is a great place to pull over and take pictures before arriving at the parking lot. We did that and read the plaque about the sculptor, Danish-American Gutzon Borglum. The view was spectacular and we decided to skip the actual monument park, parking fee and gift shop. So glad we did! Right past the park we spotted a mountain goat and her two babies so close I could have touched them! There is another pull off a little further on where you can see a great view of Washington's profile. Great place for pictures! About 5 more min of driving gets you to a lake and another pull off. We then headed back past the monument and followed the Iron Mountain Road, US 16A. That was an awesome way to see the whole scope of the monument [there are many overlooks for picture taking], as well as beautiful scenery of the Black Hills. There are three one-lane tunnels and in at least one of them you can see Mt Rushmore from inside the tunnel, as you look out the other end. When you get to the end at Custer State Park you can pay and go thru the park or simply continue to hwy 79. Well worth the time to take this scenic drive!

We were impressed. Make sure you do everything available, walk the trails, see the theater presentation, visit the gift shop and explore. They have a self guided presentation available at the visitors center. You will learn how and why each president was chosen to appear on the mountain and how the men completed this amazing feat. Everyone should visit at least once to be reminded of how this great country was developed. The staff are wonderful and full of answers to all your questions. Walking around was easy, even the trails were not difficult. We came off season so the senior price for parking was only $5.00. Please note: pets are not allowed in the main areas, walkways, buildings but are allowed on the surrounding trails.
OK, so I was a little annoyed that my National Park Annual Pass was worthless here. It was a great presentation.

Everyone needs to go to Mount Rushmore once in their lifetimes and I am lucky to now done it twice. First time visitors should be advised to buy the audio tour to give a good background of what you are seeing. Take the Presidential walking tour and you will be blessed with many fine views of Mount Rushmore and you will be snapping pictures all along the way. Their gift shop is one of the best I have ever spent money in my time as a tourist. Carver's Restaurant not only gives you a view of the Memorial but offers many reasonably priced items for purchase. Keep in mind that the Memorial is free but you will be charged $11 to park in the ramp, which is just a short walk to the Memorial.

Loved our trip to Mt. Rushmore. Visiting during this insane election season really brings the comparison home as to the greatness of these past icons compared to some of the nuttier and inarticulate candidates who are trying to fill their shoes today. With that said, the park costs $11 per car for entry. That pass is good for a year. I would recommend visiting during the day and at night when they light up the faces- which is beautiful. Also, take the relatively short walk on the presidential trail which winds below the carvings and takes you to the artist's workshop.They only disappointment here was the film in the visitor's center. Not that interesting or informative - but it was free.

OK, first, the entire area surrounding Mt Rushmore might be one of the biggest tourist traps in the world. You and the kids can experience everything from reptiles to bears, Christmas villages to caves, zip-lines to sky trams. If you want skip all of the tourist trap sights and sounds, and just experience a key part of American history without the crowds, then November is a great time to go. The weather is crisp, so plan accordingly, but the hotels in Rapid City are inexpensive. There are no crowds at the monument, and you can drive through the area and experience it without being overwhelmed by all of the tourist activities. There is a $10 parking fee to get into the monument (your national park pass won't get you a discount), but this time of year you can park very close to everything (a 5 minute walk) and take your time getting some great photos of the area without having to fight the crowds for the perfect camera shot. Don't forget to experience the museum and drive around the monuments to get the profile photos from the backside. Dress comfortable, take along a good camera and some binoculars, pack a picnic lunch and enjoy!

Mt. Rushmore remains a fantastic place to visit. There is no admission fee because of all of the private money that financed the facilities. The only cost is for parking in the garages at $11.00 and the pass is good for the calendar year in which you purchase it. In addition to the obvious attraction, the carved faces, there is a museum, store and large restaurant to enjoy....oops, almost forgot the ice cream stand!

My family and I visited in July. The area surrounding Mt Rushmore is very nice. The monument itself was great. To see it in person was a awesome experience for me. My wife and kids were also really excited to be there. Its not a huge place and should only take a few hours to half a day to see. There was a $10 parking fee Otherwise its free. We enjoyed seeing the flags for all the US states and territories, when you first enter the monument. There is a path that leads around the entire area. The kids liked getting underneath the faces and see them from that angle. Although, there are more exciting national parks and monuments this is a must visit if you can get to it. The kids still talk about seeing this place as one of their favorites.

This is a most fascinating place to witness the carvings of famous Presidents such as George Washington and Abraham Lincoln. This was carved in the 1920s and have been enjoyed by many generations since then. This can be seen for many mines from the highway. There are also a visitor center featuring many refreshments, light meals plus information on how this exhibit is made possible. Located near Crazy Horse statue by Kevin Costner and Deadwood abandon village.

I had been to visit this site as a child, but now 50 years later, although I knew what it looked like, I can more appreciate the work that went into this project for all of us to see for many years to come. A very good movie of the project is available to watch in the museum. It shows every 20 minutes and is only 14 minutes long, but very informative, as is the rest of the museum area at the site. Although there is no admission fee to get to the museum and viewing area, there is an $11 dollar fee to park your car. You can see Mount Rushmore, from many other sites along Route 16A and the Iron Mountain Road, but not as close up. The information in the museum area is worth the $11 per automobile.

My mom and I opted to stay in Rapid City and drive ourselves to Mount Rushmore. It was an easy short 30 minute drive. People were extremely friendly and the cafe was great! The exhibit and the 14 minute movie were great and very informative. We had a fantastic time. The cost was $11.00 to park. No other entrance fees. The views on our way were fantastic.
You pay for parking - $11 and its an annual pass. Cashier told us the private company who upgraded the parking areas needs to recoup their investment. So the Senior pass isn't accepted.

Mount Rushmore is a must see and very hard to avoid when driving out there. We did not expect the $10 parking fee after spending $80 on the other Park card. The museum and film were very informative and nicely put together.
It was not crowded during this time. A few tourist buses but very pleasant. Lots of great pictures. It is always fun to go here. The parking was $11 but is good for a whole year, Jan - Dec.

I was very impressed with the Mt. Rushmore National Memorial. Very well laid out. Lots of interesting information about the four Presidents and the history of the United States. Great visitor information center. Interesting exhibits and movie about the history of the memorial. Don't miss it. Cafeteria and gift shop. Its free but you have to pay $11 to park your car.

Went late in the season at 8am when they opened and had the place to ourselves. Immediately greeted by a momma mountain goat and her two babies which was a treat. Of course the view is great and the Presidents Walk and museum were nice as well. However don't fall for the "ice cream" story $6 for Jefferson recipe???? Given it's scooped out of a Dean's ice cream container I highly doubt its the authentic recipe from Jefferson as claimed!

Mt. Rushmore didn't disappoint! Take the President's Trail to get up closer to the faces (take the trail counter-clockwise for a less strenuous walk). You probably only need 1.5 hours to see the whole place. The Park Service takes immaculate care of the Memorial which is so appreciated. It only costs $11 for a car and the rest is free.

Among the Black Hills of southwest South Dakota is one of the most popular American symbols, Mount Rushmore. Our family visited one summer weekday on vacation. Following the long twisty entrance road up and up we arrived at the traffic jam entering the lot. There is no cost to visit the monument but parking is $11 per vehicle. The entire area is beautifully designed with walkways and steps leading to the promenade of presidents. It’s easy to see the giant sculptures even from a distance peering at the huge crowds gathered in almost every direction. The display of flags alongside the walkway leading up to the mountain lends a feeling of patriotism. The actual presidential sculptures are simply awesome and we were busy taking photos and videos from many different perspectives. We were obliged to take some selfies even though the presidents in the background didn’t smile for us. The museum detailed the history of the sculpture from idea to prototype to supposed completion. There is a wooden trail that leads through the woods up through the mountain a bit closer to the monument. A gift center is on site too allowing all to search for that ideal South Dakota souvenir. We spent about an hour here shopping waiting out a thunderstorm with everyone else. Though there are only attractions pertaining to the actual memorial here, we still had an enjoyable few hours here. There is a nightly light show where colored lights are displayed on the sculptures faces as the National Anthem plays on loud speakers. Based on videos we saw we felt it wasn’t all that scenic and we left by late afternoon. Regardless of what you see around the area, it is definitely recommended to come visit historic and iconic Mount Rushmore National Memorial.

Sure, we aall have heard of Mount Rushmore. Yet you must see it up close to really appreciate its beauty and artistry. It is so much larger and awe inspiring up close. It is a testament not only to American history at its best but also to American tenacity, inventiveness and commitment at its best. I recommend seeing it twice: once in the evening when it is lighted and has a mystical ethereal appearance and once during the day to see its full artisitc power. Also visit the museum and walk down to the artists studio not only to understand the complications to carving that were overcome but also to see the sculptures very close. Do not fret over the $10 entry fee. It is good for a few days.

Really enjoyed the memorial. The feds vendor for parking is way too expensive. I don't need to pay $10 to park an auto for a couple of hours. Being good for a whole month is only helpful for residents. Gift shop prices were also too high. Feds letting vendors(Contractors) run amuck.
Loved this! Very majestic! There is an $11 fee. Paved walking paths to see at lots of different angles. Well kept and worth the money.

We travel FT in our RV and purchased the annual park pass which gets us into all of the national parks such as Yosemite, Grand Canyon, Yellowstone and then we came to this park expecting that we would have free admission. Nope!!!! They charge $11 for 'parking', we were absolutely stunned but paid because we wanted to go in and look around. On the drive up there, when you come around a corner you can see the 4 presidents, stop here, take your picture and skip the memorial. Compared to all of the other parks, I just wasn't impressed at all, maybe we've been spoilt by the other parks but this one didn't do it for me. There really isn't that much to do or see here, plan to spend maybe 1.5 and that's it. We brought our own lunch and ate outside which was nice.

It was a beautiful fall day...so clear that you could see the monument from the road! So if you do want to spend the $11.00 to park (you can use the admission as many times that you like...annual pass) you can see it from the road leading into the park, but you will miss out on an awesome experience!

During a recent cross country trip my husband and I decided to visit the Mt. Rushmore monument. Our expectations for this attraction were not that high but we were blown away with our visit! First we discovered you must visit the monument during the day and also in the evening for their lighting ceremony. There is no fee for visiting this monument but you must pay an $11.00 parking fee. The parking fee is good for a calendar year but appears to be linked to your vehicle. When you enter the monument you walk through the flags of the states and that brings you to the amphitheater and above that you see the monument. There is also a Visitors Center with a very good short film and display as well as gift shops and a small restaurant that is very popular for their ice cream (Thomas Jefferson's recipe). You can take a hike closer to the monument either by going to the left or right. The feedback was to take the left trail(closer to Washington) as there are less stairs and it was true there were less stairs but still quite a few stairs to bring you back to the main building. Along the way you can visit the sculptor's cottage and see what the original sculpture was supposed to look like...quite different from the finished project so that was quite interesting to see. It was also interesting to see all the rocks down the mountain front that came from the demolition while doing the sculpture. We came back in the evening for the lighting ceremony and it was very patriotic and moving. We got there about 7:15pm (lighting was 8pm) and the amphitheater was starting to fill up. It was packed by the time the ceremony started and we were told by a ranger that the seating area holds 2500 people. There were a lot of people in the standing area as well. A Park Ranger did a presentation then they called all the veterans from the audience to come to the stage and they retired the colors (flag). Then all the veterans got to give their names and branches of service. Lots of patriotic music! Then the lights go on! It is quite moving and well worth the return visit! When you visit it is worthwhile to learn why the sculptor chose these 4 men to be part of this monument. It is a good reminder about the foundation of our country.

Mt Rushmore is a monument that is truly a work of art. The monument is free to get in, however a fee of $11 is charged to park. The garage was built by a independent company, not affiliated with the park system. The faces are illuminated in the evening at approx. 830 pm. If you drive up the mtn to see the carvings illuminated, the staff will charge you $11 to park. We were coming back the following day. The management should have something in place to allow a night viewing in conjunction with a day pass. Awesome picture opportunities. A visitors center in on a lower level, along with a gift shop. Upper level also has shops and cafes.

Absolutely awe inspiring - we spent hours there. If you can climb steps, take the Presidential Trail to a vantage point below Mt. Rushmore to a closer view. So incredible! Then add the fact that it is only $11 parking fee, you can have Thomas Jefferson's original recipe vanilla ice cream (that was great - although $1 more than the other ice cream) and you can sit in the outdoor part of the restaurant and just marvel at the sight. Definitely add it to your bucket list!

Part of a 3-generation/bucket-list eliminating trip. Parking was high-$11, and the pass, while noted to be a "yearly pass" means it's only good for the year in which it was purchased. We visited in Sept 2016, so only good thru Dec, and there is no discussing with the agents ;-(. Entrance and Monument were quite impressive, and would recommend spending time in the visitor center and theater- very informative. If you're a photog and have time (since you can re-enter with the "yearly pass") would recommend visiting at different times of the day. Morning light hits the Faces more directly, while late afternoon is more oblique, with different and dramatic shadows. Kid is wheelchair bound, and most areas are easily wheelchair accessible, however only part of the walking path is. You do get fairly close (looking up their noses), but probably half (towards the artist studio etc) involves stairs, so don't know how it is. The dining room is buffet style (kinda hard to juggle wheelchair and tray, but am used to it), and tables are fairly close together, making it even more of a challenge to balance loaded tray and wc. No staff offered to assist by moving chairs. There is a water bottle refill station!!! Restrooms are plentiful and wheelchair accessible.

You know when you visit a place like the Grand Canyon and you get home and the pictures just don’t show the grandness of it all. Well Mt Rushmore isn’t like that. It is pretty cool to see it, but the pictures do a wonderful job of showing it all. It’s not so grand. I’m glad we stopped during our visit to the Dakotas so I can check it off my list. And you can leave your National Parks pass at home because there is no charge to get in. However, you do have to pay $11 to park!

If coming from the East on I-90 exit at the Bad Lands which comes out a Wall Drug. Wall Drug is a must stop and see. Mt Rushmore is beautiful and the night show is excellent. Take a drive through Custer State Park on the Wild Life Loop. You can see Turkeys, Burros, Antelope, Deer, Ground Hogs, Bison (Buffalo) and ohter animals. Then take US16A which is Iron Mountain Road from the South to the North towards Mt Rushmore, the monument can be seen in several of the tunnels. All the roads are good, but I like Iron Mountain the best. Stop in Keystone at Halley's Merchandise Store and Rushmore Saloon for a $5 Burger and Beer, on SR40 east of town.

Yes, there is a charge to park ($11), but no charge to enter the National Memorial. I was amazed by the beauty of the sculptures carved into the granite rock mountainside. No matter where I strolled around the memorial grounds, my eyes always ended up drawn to the 4 president's faces. Gift shop, snack shop, museum, etc. located centrally in the memorial. Great history lesson on how it was built, about the artist and the men who actually created the faces. A once in a lifetime sight. DO NOT let any nay-sayer's reviews keep you from visiting this piece of Americana.

I loved Monument and the story behind it. The only entrance fee is $11 for the parking. The monument itself is incredible but the films and the trails are pretty awesome as well. You must see it at night when it is lit up it is so cool. Singing our national anthem while it was lit up gave me goosebumps. The evening show starts at 9pm.

Mt. Rushmore really is a beautiful sight. The road winds through the black hills in front of and behind the mountain. We opted out of paying the $12 to park and got beautiful pictures that didn't include people or buildings at the base. Really is a great attraction for families.

Mt. Rushmore like the Grand Canyon is something most Americans want to see before they die. The actual visit was a little anticlimactic. It looks exactly like it does in the photos. You pay $11 per car to park. (I think RVs paid $50 - ouch). We spent between 30 and 45 minutes there. You do appreciate the size - but like I said in large part it just felt like one thing off my bucket list. The town is so commercialized with all the tourist traps of a miracle mile or Boardwalk - that was also a let down.

The parks department has done an amazing job of turing this monument into a must-see attraction. The amphitheater is amazing and affords a million dollar view of the monument. Plenty of signage, hiking and other amenities make this a great stop.

This is one memorial that is interesting and worth the visit. We had a cloudy day at first, but then there was a break in the weather and we we able to see the full effect of the memorial. There is also a short film at the visitor center, a Presidential trail, and lots of interesting side trips. There is an eleven dollar parking fee, but not an entrance fee. Haven't figured that one out yet. No passes for this monument. However, the parking fee is good for one year.

My boyfriend and I were able to make it just in time for the lighting ceremony. They played a short video that talked about each president, they're contributions to the United States, and why those 4 were chosen. This is something that should be on every American's bucket list. Very cool! Oh & btw there is a parking fee of $11 (even if you bought the National Park pass) but you are able to use it for the rest of the year so definitely a reasonable price.
I recommend the audio walking tour, very informative and worth the 10 dollars. The short movie about the park is very interesting.

Of course the monument looks just like it does in all the pictures, but seeing it in person is pretty awesome. The sheer magnitude of the undertaking is unbelievable, considering this was done all by hand. The $11 fee to get in is well worth it. (Someone asked us outside the park if it was worth it.) Yes you can see it from the road, but once you pay the fee it is good until the end of the year. You can go back and see the lighting at night. There is a nice view point from the road where you can see profile of Washington. Worth a look too.

You've got to go! Admission was $11 per car for parking. You can walk up closer and take some photos. There's not a whole lot here (sept). Looks like normally there's ice cream and a place for food but was closed when we were there (early morning)

You can see the mountain sculpture from a distance on the highway and there is a pull off to view it. It's worth the $11 to park your car and park entry is free. They have lots of parking for large RV's, buses, etc. and you follow a ranger in a golf cart to your parking. Otherwise you Self park in a garage. They have a really nice museum, trail and displays. Also a pretty good cafe, ice cream bar & gift shop. Don't miss this national treasure if you are in the area.

$11 for parking. This is pretty cool! There's actually a lot to do besides look at a rock carving. Lots of educational info inside. We got there early (around 10am) and it was raining all night and earlier that morning, so the fog can really cover up the view, i suggest waiting. by the time we were leaving around noon it was clear as day and quite amazing. I suggest going up Iron Mountain Road afterwards. There are some pitstop/scenic views you can park and see mount rushmore from there too.

Parking is only $11 per car. The park is open from 6AM - 11PM. Best lighting for pictures is in the morning but the views are incredible all day. I recommend also seeing the lighting ceremony at 8:30PM during the summer.

I loved the museum and the story of the Sculptor. The park pass doesn't work here. You pay for parking which is only $11. Great parking and the whole experience was great. You most definitely can do it in one day.

This was nothing short of spectacular. It's one of the must see sites. My husband and I both enjoyed it tremendously, even though we had to wait on a couple of rain showers to pass through. The rain left the most interesting marks on the faces of the Presidents. A gentleman who was standing beside me said he had photographed it many times, but had never seen that pattern left on the faces before. I would like to return before we leave the area and see it without the rain. The $11 to park was well worth it.

This is one of the reasons this is a great country. What a piece of art. Very affordable at $11 to park, admission is free. While standing and looking, going thru museum would be fine, spend an extra $5 per audio player and take the walking tour. This audio adds so much to the trip. Also make sure you attend lighting ceremony at night, very moving and another look at the sculpture. If you are a politician and running for a federal office this night time ceremony is a must, you will become focused on the job at hand. Overall worth the trip to get there. As I was leaving I kept turning around to get one last look. Go see.
What can I say that hasn't been said? Definitely worth the $11 parking fee. Prepare to walk and climb a few stairs if you really want to explore the grounds.

Viewing Mount Rushmore in person is hard to describe; it is an awesome sight. We spent $5 a person and got the audio tour. This is the way to go. The audio tape gives you so many details and interesting facts. The faces are so amazing and life-like, The way the eyes were carved make them come alive. We took our time along the presidential trial and enjoyed every minute of it. I highly recommend visiting this memorial and getting the audio tour.

I think if you have an appreciation for "wonders" that have been done, you will love seeing Mount Rushmore in person. It's unlike anything anywhere else in America - in my opinion. Aside from just looking at the monument, take the time to walk the Presidential trail (some steps included) and go see the short movie they have. I loved seeing the mountain before, during, and after. It really makes you understand how complicated it was to carve faces there. A truly genius undertaking. Just know, this is technically "free" but parking is around $11. They have nice bathrooms, food, snacks, and 3 gift shops too.

Awesome sight!!! Unbelievable talent to sculpt. The early morning sun and night lighting ceremony the best. There is no fee to get in but they charge $11 per car to park. Well worth the price for the spectacle!! Lots of gifts and exhibits to entertain.

Every American should see this beautiful park! It exceeded my expectations. Really lovely setting in the Black Hills, with this jewel of a monument. It's 4 miles from Keystone (we stayed at the Powder House Lodge in a cabin, highly recommended), very easy access for disabled folks. Admission is FREE, parking is $11. We parked in lot Lincoln 3 and we were literally 300 feet from the entrance. The park is lovely, clean, pine-scented, fresh and NO smoking! Clean restrooms, nice restaurant and ice cream shop, audio tours, bookstore. Very good for kids as there is a lot for them to do in the area: mini golf, dinosaur and reptile museums, tons of kids activities!

This is a very impressive memorial, especially after you watch a 14 minute film about its construction. Hordes of people! Charge $11 to park. The entry fee was waived in celebration of the US Park's Service 100th anniversary. The memorial is located 28 miles south of Rapid City, WY, in a town named Keystone. A visit to the museum is a must. Everything in the area of the memorial screams "TOURIST TRAP!" I felt that the impotance of the memorial had been degraded because of the "Almighty Buck!"

Take your time. Pay to park in the garage (although the sculptor never intended for anyone to have to pay to see his colossal work). Walk, look around at the exhibits. Get lots of pics. Look at their program schedule and go to one of their presentations in the evening. Feels very American. Recommend highly. Their is a narrow place to park as you are at the bottom of the hill on the right, and can first really see it; lots of bikes park there, but it is dicey sometimes, and the police will shoo you away. Makes an awesome group shot, if you can get it. Remember so much here is not level and off camber. Caution and again, take your time. If you continue past the parking garage and curve around on the hwy and back/west for a bit, you'll come onto a very easy to park in lot. Look up at the profile of Mr. Washington ...awesome shot. Easy to get back onto the hwy. You can continue on this back road and enjoy some easy twisties. GET A MAP before you travel in the Hills. Just saying. Enjoy!

It's $11. Why people are complaining about that I'll never know. It's good for a year. We went twice the week of our vacation. It's a must see in your lifetime. The kids were in awe we they saw the faces. Sure you can stop in the road to take a picture of the front and the profile. We did both and paid the $11 to park. Glad we did.

I know there are thousands of review on this national park but we had to say it again - it was a fantastic attraction. From the nice parking lot to the flag entrance to the rangers who give tours to the museum and nice walking paths, it is all first class. If you are anywhere near here, make it a stop. The park is free but you have to pay $11 for parking.

My husband and I took our two teenage children to see the monument. It was wonderful to finally get to see it in person. Admission is free if you already have a national park pass, although you have to pay for parking. Because of rain, we only walked part of the President's Trail, but what we saw was nice. There is a gift shop for souvenirs, which was quite crowded at the end of our visit, since the rain made most people rush for any shelter.
We only spent 40 minutes here and that was with walking around the presidential trail. Does not seem worth the $11 we had to pay to park.

This is a must see, especially for children. I was upset when a commercial company handles parking and the fee is $11/ motorcycle and more for each person. The area is built up looking like a Disney resort sharing your experiences, you're helping travelers make better choices and plan their dream trips. Thank you!

This is a wonder everyone should be able to experience at least once in life. Admission is by vehicle to cover parking, there is no individual fee. We arrived early to avoid higher temps later in the day and found an additional bonus of lighter crowds. Traffic to the monument was really picking up about 10:30 AM when we left. The terrain is easy to navigate and elevators are provided to move easily between levels. The parking permit indicates it is a non transferable annual pass.

I never dreamed I would actually visit this American treasure but I am sure thankful I did. Museum was great below and the views were amazing! Cost is $11 to park a car. Get maps inside and ask for the National Parks - Nationwide map. Great to plan future trips.

This monument was a highlight of our vacation. We drive the Iron Mountain Road to get there. Don't do it if you don't like challenging driving. It is really scary. You can get there from Custer, SD without going on scary roads. The memorial is done beautifully with all the state flags displayed as you approach the actual mountain carvings. There is a wonderful movie telling you all about how it came about and how it was accomplished. There is a fairly priced cafeteria and nice inside or outside seating. The parking did cost something... maybe about $10. Don't miss this amazing display.

My Wife and I are on our 8th. day of our trip and Mt. Rushmore is the reason we came to South Dakota. There isn't a whole lot that I can say that has not been said already. I thought the $11.00 parking charge was reasonable. I tried to use my Senior Lifetime Nat. Park Pass. Didn't work. There was a light rain but it didn't seem to bother the large crowd. My Wife and I are so glad we came and when you leave you just might realize that Yes,this is the Greatest Nation on the Planet. Steve & Deloris

Mount Rushmore really is interesting, in a way that I couldn't tear my eyes away. The work that went into that must have been phenomenal. This was my second visit, so I knew not to pay $20 for parking and just view the monument from the road (there are relatively safe places to pull over). I could visit this place again and again; it's fascinating every time!
It was very neat to finally see this up close rather than in pictures. I was surprised at the cost of $11.00 per bike to get in though.

Parking is $11, but park is free. National Park passes are not accepted for parking. Make sure you watch the film, narrated by Tom Brokaw. It is an amazing sight & well worth a visit, no matter how many pictures you have seen. We went to see Crazy Horse after this & interesting to compare something similar as a work in progress.

We were visiting for the Sturgis rally and this was on the must do list. It costs $11 to park, even for a motorcycle. It was very crowded when we were there. The drive to the park is beautiful. This is just something that you have to see in person. It's pretty amazing.

South Dakota is called the Mount Rushmore State for a reason. This is probably the best national memorial in America. They open at 5 AM. The entrance fee is $11/vehicle. Inside the visitor center, there is a restaurant and a 14 min video about Gutzon Borglum and the construction of the memorial. You can walk the Presidential Trail if you want to get up close to the mountain. There is a lighting ceremony at night. The atmosphere is very patriotic. A must do in South Dakota!

It costs $11 for car parking and you get a closer view of the monument, a museum, a huge gift shop and that's about it. If I had it to do over again I would just stick with taking pictures from the side of the road going up to the park entrance because all we got was closer. And it's easier to get the monument in your pictures with family when it's a little farther away. We had more fun shopping Keystone and then spent to much time at the monument and didn't have enough time left to take Custer State Park loop which we would have enjoyed more. The first picture was taken from the side of the road outside the park. The other pictures were taken inside the park. What we came out with after visiting Mount Rushmore: fewer dollars, less time, bragging rights. I'll only go back if bribed or coerced! :)

As a child, I have always seen this iconic emblem. I never had expected to go since I live so far away. But after finally planning my trip and taking two airplanes to visit keystone, I finally got a chance to visit this most cherished site. NO REGRETS!!!! Worth every penny I spent to make it there. It's simply awe inspiring to say the least. I can finally check this off my bucket list. In fact I would not be surprised if I returned. This is truly a magnificent site to behold. There is an $11 parking fee which I think is very reasonable and get this, you can return at night for the lighting of the faces and all you have to do is present the pass they give you!! (Don't throw it away or you will end up paying another $11). I will make a recommendation regarding the parking.....PARK ON THE 6TH FLOOR. It leads you right to the entrance of the memorial. The presidential trail is not that tiring as I thought it would be so you may want to do that as it lets you get closer to the faces. If you decide to return to see the lighting of the faces, keep in mind it is not instant. There is presenter in the amphitheater followed by an inspirational video all which run for about a total of a half hour. When you hear the national anthem, that's when the faces are lit. One last thing to mention regarding your visit to Mount Rushmore and this is regarding weather. If you can, take a pocket or mini umbrella or poncho with you, ESPECIALLY if you take the presidential trail. Believe it or not, when I started the trail, it was sunny. Upon reaching the Sculptors studio, the weather changed dramatically and it began to pour!!! Crazy!!! But true!!! I had to wait a while in the Sculptors Studio until it stopped. Then, 15 mins later or so, it was sunny again!!! No lie!! Those on the trail got soaked because there is no place to go.

First time at Rushmore was nice. It is very busy though. You pay 11 dollars per car to park but worth it. We visited there with 2 motorcycles and it cost 22 dollars. Kind of disappointed that even thought we only used one parking space we had to pay for two. I think they should change that! There were a lot of motorcycles there. We should get a break or have dedicated motorcycle parking. The park is nice and plenty of places to relax, take pictures, eat and shop

We got there when it was still light and walked the presidential trail. The trail has a lot of stairs, but is worth it. It takes you really close to the memorial and is great for pictures. The lighting ceremony is held in an outdoor stadium. A park ranger gives a small speech and shows a 20 min. video about the presidents. The Memorial is lighted and they called all the veterans down to the front to retire the flag for the night. Then the vets gave their name and branch of service. It was very moving. My family loved it. There was a parking fee of $11, but the rest was free.

Nice walk and stair climb on the presidential walkway. The drive from the south builds the anticipation of the presidents. $11 per car. Kids can complete the Junior ranger program which is a great way for them to learn about the park.
Drove by to see the monument lighted at night - next day, parked ($11) and walked a short, flat way up to really see it. We were so glad we did!

This is the very best thing to see in SD. If you are American and still have a sense of pride, this will not disappoint. I have not been more proud to be an American in a long time.
