They have multiple viewing points. They also have a couple museums and gift store. They charge $11 for parking but no admission fee.

wow, very impressive what was carved out of rock. parking fee $11. national park pass holders have to pay too. but there are a couple of road side dtops for free. bring your binoculars. recommended meutermedia

Go see this at night! We literally parked got in after it was lit, took pics were amazed and left all within 30 minutes. This is a must see, so breath taking it doesn't seem real. If I recall the fee for cars was $11.

A bargain at only $11 to park for the entire family. Don't worry about the traffic to park, since most people stay less than an hour admiring the monument there always is a place to park. My advice- after paying your $11 ( good for Parking until the end of the year) stay to the right and keep going until parking area 5 which is the roof of the parking garage- it is actually the same level as the entrance and has tons of room. Much better than the first few areas which are at the bottom and require stairs or an elevator to get to the main level. Leaving from the roof is direct to the exit as well! Thank me later for the advice by giving me a helpful vote!! The attached picture was taken from the roof of the Parking garage which is the main level of the monument entrance.

This is my second time here. It's certainly a must see. The updated visitor center and grounds is very well done. Be sure to bring water on hot days, especially if you hike the presidential trail (it's a must!!) The park is free but parking is $11, good for one year. It's worth the trip!
motorcycles are charged $11 to park, same as a car. Not right, we parked 3 bikes in one parking spot. Mount Rushmore is awesome and a definite must see!

A visit to Mt. Rushmore National Monument at least allows one to say you’ve done it and to check it off your list. We visited in July 2016. The monument can be seen from the sinuous parkway that threads through the Black Hills, and the sudden sighting from afar is arresting. Up close, after a parking rodeo ($) and a walk up a flag-lined concourse, you can view the Faces in all their mineral-veined detail. There is a pleasant walk through the woods at the base of the monument and a decent ranger-chat on the engineering aspects of the sculpture. There is a pretty expensive cafeteria and a gift shop, in which people seemed to spend about the same amount of time (or more) as they did looking at The Faces. In Washington, D.C., there are memorials to Washington, Jefferson, Lincoln, and Roosevelt (Roosevelt Island), which remind us in clear terms of their accomplishments. As a spectacle of engineering, Mt. Rushmore may do the same. Keystone SD , the town nearest to the Monument , is a tourist city of several blocks, with bars, restaurants, souvenir shops. With summer crowds, parking is difficult. We found no grocery stores, which seemed odd, since many of the tourists are staying in local cabins and RV parks – bring your own supplies, from Rapid City or Custer. In Keystone we were able to fuel the car and buy some hot dogs to microwave. Local restaurants may be okay, but we did not need to sit down and pay for another meal after the high-priced cafeteria at Mt. Rushmore.

You could see the mountain top from outside the park, but it is nice to get closer even though they have made it less rustic and more commercial.. Was surprised that they created a "parking fee" that replaced the traditional park fee, which would have been waived for senior pass holders.. Oh well, they invested substantial $$$ in updated parking structures.. Just hope this isn't a trend that will proliferate in all parks. Place is still very impressive and well worth the cost. Love seeing history close up.
Although there is no "entrance" fee, there is an $11 parking fee. It's worth it. Keep the parking pass (vehicle specific) if you might come back within a week.

4 days 3 nights, be warned cell phone/GPS may not work. Stayed in custer but tried to get hill city, certain days were booked and custer as $50 cheaper per day. Stay in hill city, custer or keystone, rapid city is too far.

We have been planning on seeing Mount Rushmore for many years and finally made it, well worth the trip. The drive to the entrance was filled with glimpses of the monument and spectacular views of the surrounding area. A short walk from parking, between the stone pillars, adorned with state flags and engraved with each states name, rank and when admitted to the union, to the balcony where you get a close up view of the monument and amphitheater at its base. There is a gift and ice cream shop and a restaurant, plus while we were there they had an artist selling art and signing books. Admission Free but small parking fee.

You cannot appreciate this monument thru pictures. This MUST be seen in person. Plan your visit so you get there about an hour before sunset, if possible. You will have time to take great pics of this masterpiece, visit the immense gift shop, & make ur way to outdoor amphitheatre, where they light up the monument after dark, for a totally different view. Only downside is it costs $11, per car, to park. I realize they have much to maintain. Just seemed a lil high.

Mt. Rushmore is a place everyone should experience! Although I have seen pictures many times, nothing compares to actually standing in front of the 60 foot faces. We arrived about 7:30am which was ideal. There were very few people in the park at that time. We were happily surprised to find out there is no admission fee to the park. Each vehicle must pay $11, which makes this visit incredibly reasonable. The shops do not open until 8:00, but you are able to park easily and beat the crowds to see the Monument. Make sure to take the short hike along the Presidential Trail. It is an easy hike through beautiful scenery, with several different views of the Presidents. Make sure to go to the night lighting ceremony! Wow! We arrived about an hour before dark and enjoyed the music and information about the Monument. At the end of the presentation, they call all military members, past and present, to come down to the stage and be recognized. Very touching!

This was my third visit to Mt. Rushmore and my first time to see the night time lighting ceremony. The night ceremony starts with a video and then the lighting of the monument. This is followed by the singing of the National Anthem and recognition of all veterans in attendance. I was glad I was able to attend the ceremony. We then returned the next morning to spend more time at the monument and walk the trail. A National Park pass does not work here, but an $11.00 parking pass will get you in for one year. It's well worth it.

This is why we came to SD. Our 4 and 6 year old wanted to see the Big Head's. They were not disappointed to say the least and nor were we. It was so clean, and well set up it. It reminds you that we live in the Good OLD US of A and we should be proud and appreciative of it every second. There is a cost for parking but $11.00 is nothing. The trail we took was excellent and the Museum at the end, so much information you could spend hours just there. It is amazing what they did so long ago with nothing when compared to what we have today. I strongly recommend this for anyone. It is a life time opportunity.

We've seen Mount Rushmore multiple times, the most recent being just this past week. It does cost $11 to park, but the pass is good until the end of that calendar year, so I recommend going once at night and once again during the day if your itinerary allows. The nighttime lighting ceremony is really something to see and I think it's more beautiful than during the daytime. They put on a very patriotic and historical program with video and also call up all armed forces active/veterans to the stage at the end, each getting chance to introduce themselves. I really enjoyed that. They deserve recognition and the great applause they receive. Take a picture just before you reach the flags - it looks really nice when you have the flags and the monument in one frame. A definite, must stop attraction in the Black Hills!

After having heard quite a few people say that Mount Rushmore was underwhelming, I wasn't very excited about seeing it. But when there was a last minute airfare deal to Rapid City, We decided it was time. Yes, it is just a giant statue carved into a mountain. Yes, you view it from a distance. Yes, it costs to get into the viewing areas ($11). But in spite of these things, it is breathtaking. Worth every penny of the entrance and flight to get there, and every minute of the drive from Rapid City.

My family of 5 stopped by here after seeing the Crazy Horse Memorial. Mount Rushmore was everything I had hoped it would be, and more! Stunning in person, everyone should visit here at least once! Large gift shop on site was packed! Parking was $11 in a covered garage and entrance to the Memorial is free.

You can't not visit Mt. Rushmore when visiting South Dakota. The park itself was very enjoyable. The cost of admission to the park is parking. The park has mostly covered parking and areas where it is not covered. I would highly recommend taking covered parking, just on the off chance that a storm creeps up. I've been told by locals that there has been a lot of hail storms recently. Cost of parking is $11 which is good for a year, so be sure to keep that pass if you plan on a future visit. The avenue of state flags as your walk toward the monument is very nice, and the Presidential Trail to the base of the mountain was a nice walk and gave you different vantage points of the mountain. There is a gift shop, ice cream shop (highly recommended) and dining hall at the park. Plan to spend up to 2 hours at park. There is a light show at night which we were unable to witness due to the storms later that evening. The park gave me greater insight into the history of Mt Rushmore and the people that built it. After visiting Mt Rushmore, I highly recommend seeing the Crazy Horse memorial (~20 minutes away) which stands to compete against Mt Rushmore. I was surprised the park is open till late at night. During our visit in July, the park is open until 10:30pm. So if you want to forgo the visit to late in the afternoon, go for it. Mt Rushmore is less than 45 minutes from the Rapid City Airport, pretty much a straight shot. The only gripe I have is the town of Keystone that appears to exploit the tourism of Mt Rushmore. If you are driving in from Rapid City, you will pass through Keystone which is chalked full of attractions, gift shops, and restaurants. Seeing this killed the nice vibe I was having driving through the black hill national forest to the monument. Other than that, Mt Rushmore is well worth visiting.

I can't visit Mount Rushmore enough. $11.00 a carload admission with parking garage for a week. Amazing sculptures, educational exhibits, theater, walking trail is a little difficult but not as strenuous as advertised. The evening lighting ceremony that is preceded by a retreat that honors veterans makes you proud to have served this great nation and is witnessed by so many foreign visitors they have to be impressed. Clean grounds, clean restrooms.
Easy parking, $11 parking, great walking trail to get close to monument. Serve beer $4 so that is always a great stress reliever.

Saw it when I was younger. They are having an anniversary year so lots of publicity convinced me I had to go see it again. Liked the history. Didn't take the path near it. Parking is $11 in a multi level parking lot. Elevators and ramps for handicapped. The avenue of flags was impressive. Each state is written on the pillars holding the flags in alphabetical order. Book store and snacks. Movie on how it was made. Lots of people there. It was overcast that day. You have seen all the pictures you don't need one more of mine.

I took my family to the memorial at Mount Rushmore and it didn't disappoint! It's quite a beautiful drive through the black hills and the crazy horse exhibit is nearby. The memorial is quite a site to behold with information inside on how it was built, equipment used, etc. Everything is free except parking which is $11. There are alot of visitors there from all over the world. We spent about 2 to 3 hours there checking everything out. This is very well thought out and laid out perfectly. As a American I really appreciate this memorial to our greatest Presidents! #Recommended

Cool place to visit - well done. Took a while to get to the parking area but all is within walking distance. The outside viewing area is very nice and well done. However, Could use some remodeling inside ie a larger museum area, better concession area, & more restrooms - the exhibit is extremely crowded and you could barely walk around. Needs updating. You have to go though - donate your $$ and taste some history!

Mount Rushmore is a must see. Lots of history, well laid out grounds with paths/trails, nice displays, etc. I think it is only $11 to park and free to enter the grounds. Well worth it. Also, it is in the middle of the Black Hills which is very scenic and many small towns to visit and wildlife to see. You can drive through in a day, but would be nice to spend 2 or 3 days in the area.

Easy parking, only $11 per car and that pass can be used all year. Easy to spend 1-2 hrs just walking. If museum and shops included it'll be 3-4hrs. Beautiful. Museum full of interesting stories from workers.

$11.00 to get in for concessionaire parking which includes admission for all in the vehicle. This is clearly a monument that you should see. For all ages, all nationalities. This is a good representation of American history. Built in a mere 14 yrs, the monument is incredibly over whelming

We absolutely loved visiting Mount Rushmore. $11 Per car and you get in for the rest of the year at no additional charge. The grounds are beautifully kept. We enjoyed walking the presidential trail and the sculptors studio. It will forever be a lifetime memory!

Just driving up to Mt. Rushmore is spectacular but once you are on the grounds it is just amazing. We got there early about 8:00 had plenty of places to park in the shade. The grounds weren't too crowded early in the morning so we had plenty of picture opportunities. You can take your dog up to but not past the entry column. The day we went was 107 degrees so we weren't able to take any of the trails but we are waiting for my next trip to finish my tour of this great memorial. It cost $11.00 for the car but it is good for a year. They do mark the color & make of the car so don't think you can go there with a different car

Loved the memorial! Truly a work of art. An audio tour or a guide is provided for a fee. $11.00 to park but entrance is free. A little off the main road but worth the trip. Beautiful and the presidential trail is nice.

This was neat to see. Prices were decent. Clean atmosphere. Staff was very nice. I think it's a great attraction to bring your kids to learn about our presidential history. Souvenir prices were a little pricy but over all its a great place to visit.

The entrance fee/parking permit for $11.00 is good for a year - a decent price. Parking is easy in the parking ramp. Views of the monument are fantastic wheelchair accessibility to most of the areas. Also, visited the Crazy Horse monument, currently under construction - can't wait to see that one finished!
We don't grow tired of the magnificence. You pay $11 per car load and get to return as many times as you'd like for a year. A must for every American to visit.

Road trip with granddaughters. This was our main attraction. Bucket list type attraction, but we had a great time. Short drive from Rapid City, parking fee $11, but no other $$ to visit. Short walk to visitor center and more walking if you want to. But great views from the center. I recommend taking the short walk up close. Only about a half mile and not too bad. There are stairs, and quite a few of them, but you are at your own pace with benches along the way. Sounds weird, but stop at the kids exploration area on the walk and listen to the stories told by the park Ranger. He is a native American and was outstanding. Decent food available and a don't miss ice cream shop. Of vourse lots of ways to spend money in the large gift shops.

Hadn't been in years, decided to visit with my kids. A lot has changed, they have a parking garage now and you pay to use it. $11 to park, would not take my National Parks card as it is for 'parking' although you can't get in otherwise (perhaps walking). We felt it a bit of a government scam, anyway, the memorial is beautiful as ever. Majestic and glowing on the mountain. Much more the tourist destination than it used to be with gift shops, food cafes, etc so very busy. I remember driving up to it closer, now it is a bit of a walk up the hill through all the distractions. Definitely worth a visit, my teens thought it was huge and appreciated the detail of it.

I really learned a lot from the audio tour and are definitely worth the $5. Otherwise all you do is gaze at the amazing sculpture without knowing all the background info. The guides who are of Lakota heritage were excellent telling personal stories.

On the drive to Mount Rushmore you can see the faces from the highway. A line to get into the Memorial took about 10 minutes and cost was $11. We arrived late morning and the for a summer day didn't find parking to be difficult at all.

The last time I was at Mount Rushmore was back in 1982 with my family when I was a young teenager. Me, My wife, my 3 teenagers visited here on July 4th. We arrived early, avoided the traffic and found close parking. The cost to enter the property was $10 per car. The experience was amazing. There are walking trails, restaurants, ice cream shop and a really neat outdoor auditorium. The views from numerous locations in the park are awesome (many spots to take the your best selfie or family picture). A nice touch was an area where a Native American played tribal music with several flutes and he told historical stories. No fireworks this year due to forest fire dangers. Mount Rushmore is an American Classic .

We have the opportunity to be in the Keystone area and of course once they are you need to visit Mount Rushmore. The access is very accessible the splendor and beauty is unmatched. Give yourself at least a couple of hours to walk through the many adjoining exhibits. Also if you're able take the presidents walk as close to the top of the hill as possible it is well worth the time or a lot of steps but if you can take it there a lot of benches along way to rest. The cost is only $11 and your pass is good for like four months so out of all the things to do in the area this is very reasonable don't miss this opportunity to see one of the wonders of the world

Costs $11 per vehicle. Annual National Park Card does not work here as they label the fee "parking". Someone recommended the night lighting ceremony. So we arranged to see it. It was not as spectacular as I was anticipating. The ranger spoke to the audience then showed a video on a large screen which gives the history of each of the four presidents and their contributions to America. Then they turn on spot lights on the monuments. Then they call down all service men/women for the lowering of the flag. The sculpture studio closes at 7. So me missed it. I would have rather come during the day to see the studio and skip the lighting ceremony. Also take the Presidential Hike. You can see the monument a little closer. Zoom in on the monument with binoculars or your camera. Detail is fascinating.

The minute you see Mount Rushmore you wonder how could this have been done. The realism is unbelievable. Since our last visit they have built a large Visitor Center complex with restaurants, gift shops and multiple theaters. There is a new trail, the Presidential Trail which leads to the base of the carvings. Much of the trail is handicapped accessible and the views of Washington and Lincoln are outstanding. Admission is free but it cost $11 to park in the new garage. Some people park at overlooks outside the Monument and walk in.

The entrance fee was $11 for a car. They had plenty of parking spots and it was easy to access. The Presidential Trail is definitely worth it, even my mom (age 70) didn't have a problem with this trail. You can see Native American tipis, the generators, and much more!

I was leery when my family voted to go see Mt. Rushmore. I wasn't sure if it would be worth it traveling all the way from Houston, TX. Well, it was more than worth it. First off, it only cost $11 to park, and the parking is good all year. I realize I'm not coming back anytime soon, but we did make it back that evening for the lighting ceremony, and it was nice not having to pay for parking again. The Presidential Trail and Sculptor's Museum is a must-do. Mt. Rushmore is majestic and awe-inspiring.

This was my first time to visit Mt Rushmore. I havae seen pitures of it, though. All I ana say nis WOW!! It was breath taking for me. I like the underground parking they had. I thoght having to pay for parking was a little much. They refused my Senir Pass to all the National Parks and Monuments. The food was a little pricey ad dothing to get excited ovwer. The souviners were what I expected. They had plenty of benches to sit on, but they could have had covers on them, to help protect you from the sun. I personally would liked to have seen misting fans. It was very hot there the day we visited. I will want to go back and see more of it. (I had lots of famaily with me)

The monument is spectacular and viewing it from the different vantage points along the walking trail is very cool. There is plenty of information about its construction and history along the way to get a good idea on how it was constructed. It is free to enter the park itself but you have to pay $11 for parking to get there. We were in a mobile home so it was pretty tight quarters for us but it appeared that there were several parking garages for regular vehicles. There's just something about being forced to pay for parking to visit a free national monument that doesn't seem right.

Glad we went, but it was extremely crowded in the restaurant, and not enough tables to handle large crowds. The presidential hike around the base of the mountain however, was fabulous. The trail was wide and brought you as close to the faces as you can get. I suggest going clockwise around the trail because there are more steps going up the other way. I also recommend seeing the short video about the making of the monument. Parking is only $11 per car and no entrance fee. We were there a couple of hours, including lunch and the hike.

Beautiful place. Nice gift shops. They have a ice cream shop. It'll cost you $5.00 for a cup or waffle cone. They had a cafeteria with a variety of foods from around $7.00 and up. They have a trail that goes up closer to the moment. Their is an easier way up. My hubby and girl's went up the hard way before they knew there was an easier way. I believe the easier was was up the left side. You might want to ask to be sure.

We made a brief stop in Keystone--got to see the lighting ceremony at 9:30 pm the night we arrived, then went back for a quick walk around the memorial park in the morning. We went early so parking was plentiful and the site was not crowded. It's so beautiful and impressive, and the location is stunning. I never knew the Black Hills were so picturesque. So glad we stopped. This is noted on the NPS website, but be advised that EVERYONE pays for the parking, even if you have a National Parks Annual Pass. It's $11.00 and the pass lasts till the end of the year, so it's not unreasonable.
This was super fun to see. One of our highlights. Seriously a marvel. Kids enjoyed it and enjoyed the ice cream and souvenirs there as well. Parking is $11 I believe. Worth it for us!

This attraction is free, but parking will cost you $11. Plenty of other options for spending money, like a gift shop, ice cream and a restaurant. The sculpture itself is, of course, amazing. The president's trail takes you up close and personal with the sculpture, which gives many photo ops and different perspectives on the carving. There is also a park service exhibit about the actual work on the sculpture, along with a scale model of what the completed sculpture was supposed to look like (it was never completed), which is fascinating. Rangers are on hand to tell the story and answer questions. This walk has quite a few steps and is not wheelchair accessible. However, the main viewing area is wheelchair accessible, and is well worth the effort. Gotta see it once!

We caught the night show the night before our visit. A few tears were shed...quite moving. The next day, we came back to explore. It's not an all day venue...can be done in a morning or afternoon. Parking is $11 and good for the rest of the year. Be prepared to climb stairs for additional views. We enjoyed ourselves. Junior ranger program is excellent for kids.

After reading so many wrong reviews on Mt. Rushmore let me tell you what it's all about. First...there is an $11 parking fee and no one will tell you this until you pay your money but the parking pass is good for the rest of the year until December and you can use it as many times in and out as you want. Second.....the park is FREE. There is no charge to enter the park. The monument is breathtaking and there is a museum about the construction, a couple of souvenir shops and a walkway to the foot of the monument. There is also a service at 9PM for lowering the flag and all veterans in the audience are invited up onto the stage to be acknowledged. The evening service is very impressive. If you have back problems get there about an hour early and sit in the back row. There is a wall you can lean on to support your back. This was the highlight of my trip.

We could see Mt. Rushmore from the road and for a moment considered not going in to the park. I am so glad we paid for parking $11 and went in. I found Mt. Rushmore to be very impressive on many different levels. It was interesting to learn about the history behind it and how it was made.

Wow! Takes your breath away. The pictures you've seen don't do it justice. Take the Presidential Trail hike and read about each. The staff that work there are friendly and helpful. Admission is free, HOWEVER you pay for parking. The good news is that your parking fee is good for a year, so you can visit again.
Most parking, covered, easy access, park is free, but you do have to pay $11 in parking, well worth, nice museum and movie to tell the history of the monument, great gift shop.

This Presidential shrine is MUCH more than 4 faces carved in stone. The drive through the Black Hills is full of splendor and when the faces come into view it is truly an awesome sight to see. $11 will get you an annual (non-transferable) parking pass. We saw it for the first time at sundown. Came the next day in the morning and went to the sculptors studio... At 9pm in an outdoor amphitheater with a perfect view of the monument, a park ranger gives an interesting 20min monologue about each of the 4 presidents and a short history of how the sculpture came to life. At the end of the presentation the ranger invited men and women who were serving or had served in the military to walk up and join her for the lowering of the American flag. About 75 people went to the stage and then the entire amphitheater of guests rose and heard the national anthem. (Goose Bumps) The flag was lowered and then each person was given the chance to say their name, where they are from, and the branch they served in. WOW they got a huge standing ovation. The faces are illuminated at 9:30. The profile view of George Washington (seen outside the park from the road) is also great at night. Giving 4 stars because this is a National Park and it should be FREE! The $11 is for a parking deck that is owned by a for-profit company. Bogus! Even Seniors that have a lifetime national park pass and active/retired military have to pay the $11. That is just ridiculous and should be corrected.

I believe it's $10 to park. I guess this is for the otherwise free attraction. I still recall when you could just drive up. The parking ramp can be quite an ordeal, though, if you have trouble walking distance or stairs.

Stopped here on trip across the country. It is quite a bit off of the interstate. There was road construction so that added additional time. There is a small town right below (a bit too touristy for my taste). You can see the memorial from the highway or pay $11 to park. We spent about one hour there and that included time in the gift shop. Was very hot that day and there was little shade. Not much to do other than take pictures and look at all the state flags.

Real nice facility except for the very nasty port-a-potties just outside the entrance. The facility, itself, was neat and clean an pleasant to visit. Had a nice bookstore, gift shop and exhibit area. Of course, the main attraction was the carved presidents, which were very impressive. The attraction is free, but there is an $11 parking fee which was good until the end of the year.

Of course, isn't this why you came? While the information center, gift shop and viewing area have changed many times over the years, the Presidents stand solid as ever. While it is free, parking is $11. I think we could have returned again for that, and wanted to get there for the evening lighting ceremony but ended up not having time. Always interesting to learn how they are maintaining this and digitally mapping it. And the Hall of Documents (or whatever) is a real thing (well the concept was real anyway.) Who knew!? Not just a Hollywood creation for the National Treasure movies.

I have waited my whole life to see this monument and it was worth it. It only costs $11 and that's just to park and it's good for a whole year, even better deal. The drive through the Black Hills was very beautiful also. Words cannot describe this you have to see it for yourself.
It's easy to go there a snap a photo and leave, but hang around to learn the story behind it. Know they charge you $11 to get in.

The memorial is free but you have to pay $11 to park. The parking pass is good for six months. We passed it on to another family at our hotel. It only took us a couple of hours or so to see it all, view the visitor's video, do the Presidential Walk and stay for the evening light up show and honoring of veterans. I don't think you could spend much more time here. But it is certainly worth seeing.

You are excited about going to see the monument and you wait and wait to get into to park, you fight the crowds to get in as close as possible, then you are THERE, you look and you leave, unless you want to fight the crowds in the gift shop. The attraction is free but you pay $11 for parking.

We walked the presidential trail and got to hear a park ranger recount the construction process of the memorial. I really love history and this was a part of history that I enjoyed learning about. Great areas for pictures and also very nice that we were able to purchase t-shirts (and opportunities for other souvenirs) for $5.

Go and see this! It is really amazing. Take the circle walk to see the faces from different view points. The parking garage is $11 and the national park pass does not count towards the cost. Everything is well maintained and beautiful. We spent about three hours here and that was enough time to see everything. Try not to go too early in the morning or you might just see fog. We had to wait awhile for the sun to warm the fog away.

We went to the memorial in the evening because we heard the lighting ceremony was a good thing to see. It was very easy to find (the roads are well marked). There is an $11 parking fee but it is good for the rest of the year if we were to return. The parking was very easy and accessing the monument wasn't a challenge for my 70 year old mother. The gift shop had a pretty good selection of memorabilia. The lighting ceremony itself was PACKED. I couldn't believe how many people were there. It all boiled down to a speech, a short movie and patriotic music that played when they flipped the switch to illuminate the monument. It was nice to see but kind of boring for little kids.
We loved touring the monument - go there for breakfast. It is very reasonable - $6.50 for a great breakfast, and can eat out on patio with Mt. Rushmore in background.

We enjoyed our time at Mt.Rushmore, immensely! The location is rather remote, but beautiful. Parking was easy in the garage, costing $11. National Park passes do not work for the parking fees. The whole area is so clean and inviting - from the garage, to the walkways approaching the monument, to the aisle of state flags, to the patio in the visitor's center that opens to the Mt. Rushmore vista. It is so impressive to walk up and see the carvings in the mountain. All services there are clean and inviting. We ate at "Carvers" enjoying a Buffalo burger and a chicken sandwich and a piece of yummy pie. We ate on the outdoor patio with the 4 Presidents overlooking our meal! The lighting ceremony was cut short due to higher winds causing the movie screen to not be stable. So that part was cancelled. The Park Ranger gave a little talk, we sang the National Anthem, the lights went on the Monument and then Veterans were invited down to the stage to be honored before the flag was taken down. Very patriotic and moving.

Four of our many outstanding Presidents are engraved on the side of the mountain. Do take your time to walk one of two trails and stop at all the sites within this NP. The main entrance is a sight to behold and the aisle is lined with all 50 State flags. There is no charge to get into MRNP but there is a parking fee ($10+/-). Enjoy browsing the souvenir shops or having a meal in the on site restaurant.

Our trip to Mount Rushmore was quick, but well worth it. We drove in from Denver (about 6 - 6.5 hours) and the weather was beautiful. The park is free to visit, but you have to pay for parking which is $11, but good for the whole year. I recommend taking the Presidential Trail once you are at the monument. It is an easy trail that gets you up close and is great for pictures. We will definitely be back to visit the surrounding areas.

Good value for a carload at $11 unlike Crazy Horse which is a ripoff. Be sure to walk the Presidential Trail to see all angles and get that much closer to a real treasure. So much history and out tweens even liked learning all about the history of Mt Rushmore. You just can't have a Black Hills vacation without visiting Rushmore.

We enjoyed the 1/2 mile Presidential Trail that went closer to the monument through lush forest and huge rocks. The trail itself is well groomed and trex decking much of the length. The models used to carve the mountain were on display in the sculptor's studio along with a lot of other photos showing the mountain in various stages of completion. There were gift shops with all manner of souvenirs. A short movie told the history of the monument. The day we visited, the mountain was completely socked in by fog but it cleared briefly while we were there. In retrospect, I think I would recommend doing this starting at about 7pm to be there at 9pm when the lighting ceremony occurs. Entrance is free but parking is $11 --good for a week.
Such an iconic image, it was wonderful to see it in person. Highly recommend the Presidential Trail (for those physically able). The parking fee ($11) is good for a year.

We really enjoyed visiting the Mount Rushmore National Memorial. Our family of 6 arrived in the morning about an hour after the park opened and parking was not an issue at all. We enjoyed finding the flags of those states that we've lived in and/or visited. Tons of photo opportunities. Two trails to walk, one a little longer than the other. I will say that we would have missed the museum underneath the theatre if I hadn't read before our trip that it existed. We had ice cream as a treat, and although we didn't eat a meal there the food we saw others with looked to be MUCH better quality than we would have expected from a tourist attraction. Large selection in the gift ship with expected prices, and a tent setup outside that day with $5 selections (t-shirts, mugs, bags, etc). The bookstore located inside the museum is run by the Mount Rushmore Society and had very knowledgeable staff, better quality books and better prices. We left midday and came back that evening for the closing ceremony and monument lighting. Afterwards, the park ranger asked the military personnel in the audience (past and present) to join her on the stage to take the American flag down. She then took the microphone to each of them and asked them to state their name and branch of service - very inspiring. So glad we were able to visit during the 100th anniversary of the founding of the US National Parks.

I live in Montana and this monument is practically in our backyard being located just 5-hours to the east. I can't believe I waited so long to go see this wonderful National Memorial. The visitors center was fabulous giving the history and background of this wonder. A nice little theater shows a film on how it was constructed and became a National Memorial. The rangers were very knowledgeable and the grounds were beautiful and clean. The gift shop was large with plenty of souvenirs to choose from and staff was helpful and friendly. Parking was eleven dollars which included entrance. This monument will give you a sense of American Pride!!

This is one of the best example of American grit. Teamwork and sheer determination is evident through the entire attraction. Organized and well attended by park personnel. Very helpful. Just pure fun. Discovery available thru all of your senses movies available,sound tour equipment available. Several small trails available to walk around mostly steps. Plenty of parking there is no fee for the exhibit but you pay for parking $11.00 for parking. A short drive from Rapid City South Dakota about 25 minutes site seeing along the way. Several attractions along the way Bear Country dive thru park. Our day started early we made a day of it by ourself so we started at Mt. Rushmore then we drove needles highway and then we stopped at the Blue Bell Lodge and had lunch we arrived early at 11:15 am after we drove thru the wildlife loop and then went back to Rapid City on Iron Mt Road a map was provide when we entered Custers Park entrance fee $20.00 fee for a 7 day pass. We saw wildlife on the Wildlife loop which included Buffalo,donkeys,deer. It was a blast. A great memory. Mostly driving all day it was raining the day we attended it was fine to be in the car but it would have been better if it wasn't rating so hard. We wore sweatshirts and glad we did it was low 50's and windy.

I've wanted to visit Mount Rushmore ever since seeing the movie North by Northwest when I was a kid. It's every bit as stunning in person as you'd expect it to be. You can get some great views before you even enter the park, and also an interesting profile view after you exit. We got to the park about 10:00 a.m., and it was crowded, but not prohibitively so. With some restless teenagers in our party, we didn't take the time to read every plaque, etc., but we did take the Presidential Trail, which I highly recommend. The number of stairs might be daunting if you have knee problems, but it's a boardwalk instead of rocky, uneven steps, so that helps. With only the $11 parking fee for our car of seven, this was a terrific value. Unfortunately, we were not able to go back at night for the lighting ceremony due to our car breaking down, so I can't comment on that part of the Rushmore experience.

Like virtually every National Park, Memorial, Monument, etc. this one was excellent. Well kept, polite, knowledgeable Rangers. Nice facilities. These places make me proud to be an American and show me that not all our government institutions are dysfunctional. There is no entry fee but there is a parking fee and no place to park except the onsite facility. It is only $11.00 a car so is quite minimal. The parking facility was built and is operated by the Mount Rushmore Society and was built without any federal funding. A very sensible way to make the federal dollars stretch and still provide excellent facilities. The mountain is spectacular and the story of it's construction amazing. The movie is definitely worth the 15 minutes it takes. A very nice gift shop and book store are on the premises. There is a place to eat although we did not eat there. Magnificent monument to America.

Definitely need to go see Mt Rushmore if in this part of SD. I feel worth the $11 to park for the up-close viewing, museum and Presidential walking trail to really see the mountain sculptures up close! There are many stairs so be prepared but they are broken up into manageable "chunks" (12-20 steps at a time) with decks & some seating available along the way. My husband, 15 yr old & I had a wonderful time. Ice cream shop & restaurant available for those showers that pop up in the afternoons!

It's $11 to get in and the ticket you put in your window lasts all year long or for 12 months..Either way, when you come back within a year you don't have to pay another Entrance Fee :) Win! Win!! We watched a short movie on the making of Mt.Rushmore and to find out it's not Completed! I didn't know that and I grew up in South Dakota! HaHa...Enjoy your time!
Although this is an amazing piece of artwork, it's a drive by attraction. $11 to park to stare at it when you can stare at it from the side of the road for free is excessive.

Well worth the drive, enjoyed by both adults and children. Clean, well developed. Exhibits very up to date and enjoyable. Restrooms clean and plentiful. Views amazing!!!!. Prices reasonable. Parking cheaper then Disney. Worth visiting multiple times. Good educational materials to purchase. Our cheapskate granddaughter actually spent some of her own money on educational information???

$11 to park a car but entry into Mt. Rushmore is free. Beautiful setting. The thing that we really noticed is almost all of the employees were foreign. Seemed a little strange to us. Ate a buffalo burger for lunch and ice cream for dessert. Nice gift shop.

Very impressive to see in person. A little aggravated that parking is $11 and NOT covered on the national park pass. The mountain is beautiful and the walk leading up to it is amazing! All the state flags and the columns with the states listed is a nice touch. Seeing it in person is just amazing! You don't have to spend a lot of time here. An hour is sufficient.

This is one of those places that you know exists you seen in books but you don't really get the impression of how real it is till you see it first hand. While there is a lot to do it is not an all day activity plan for other things for half the day. Be prepared to pay for parking ($11 calendar year in 2016) but the memorial itself is free.

This is everything you expect, from the moment you walk in you feel patriotic and that you are in a movie! We went for the night ceremony and it was beautiful. If you want to do the night ceremony get there at least 1 hr and 30 minutes before as sits fill up fast and take a light jacket as temperatures drop plus you can use them to save the seat. at $20 for the whole car this was a steal plus the pass is good for the WHOLE year.

Mount Rushmore is a once in a lifetime must for Americans. In June 2016, we enjoyed a one mile walk to the monument with plaques about the presidents, their bookstore, a 15 minute lecture about the artist's process in his work shop, and a half hour in the museum (with a video). Admission is free but parking is $11/car. If you want to get a photo in front of the monument without the fun extras previously mentioned, there is a pull-off on the road prior to the admission gates.

Even if you have a National Park Pass, you must pay the parking fee, oh well! It is worth a trip, the trail around the bottom of Mt Rushmore is great, signs say it is a hard trail, but I guess they mean, if you go down, you must climb back up! It is all paved and a must - do! The lighting ceremony at night is on your same parking (annual) ticket, so you may as well. While waiting for the lights, you listen to a speech and view a short movie. At the end, veterans are invited up to take down and fold the flag and then they are introduced, very nice. We had been there 30 years ago, but it was still worth it!

This was a repeat visit to MT Rushmore! As always it was very inspiring. We also did the short hike/walk around to get other views of this monument. It cost $11 to park which is good for the whole year.

Set in the beautiful Black Hills of S.Dakota, this monument is simply stunning. Please don't miss it when you are in the area. We didn't stay long, as I had a blistering migraine, but we were so impressed with this amazing monument that I know we will return. The stone pergola archways, fitted with flags from every state, frame the faces on the mountain as you approach the viewing area. There is an amphitheater below where there is a presentation about the monument in the evening, and we were sorry to miss that. Parking is somewhat limited and costs $11.
All Americans should go. It was amazing and our kids loved the lighting ceremony. We actually went two days since you $11 pass is good for a year (super cheap).

Beautiful National Monument, rich with history. Very well designed walking loop- lots of shade and not difficult. But lots of steps- not good for wheelchairs or strollers. We opted for the $5 audio tour- it is self paced- you carry a little remote control size device and listen at your own pace- really liked this- added depth to the experience, Kids (Teens) wished there was an app for their phone, so they could listen with their headsets, but otherwise they liked the audio info. So happy we went here- you won't be disappointed. Go early to avoid crowds- we got there around 9AM, and when we left at 1130-12- it was really getting crowded.

I was hoping to use my National Park Visitor pass for the first time to get in free, but alas, it was free. Parking cost - $11. The walk through the State flags up to the monument was very impressive. An added pleasure was the Navy band playing below. After you visit the monument, don't forget to look at the mountains and valley from the parking lot. Hopefully, you will have storm building over the far mountain - what a site.

The monument is visible from far away. It's $11 to park but free to take pictures by the roadside. I thought the sculpture was impressive but it was hard to miss the affluence and money that this "attraction, creates while it brings nothing to the Natives it was stolen from. The Black hills gold is blood gold.

Of course on our family road trip we had to see mt Rushmore. $11 parking fee, no entrance fee. Take the presidental trail for a closer look - lots of steps. total time needed there about 1 to 2 hours but do not miss the lighting of the monument in the evening - starts at dark (9 p.m.) We also ate in the restaurant - Carvers- which had great views of the monument.

Mount Rushmore has to be the hokiest National Park unit in the USA, and it's also in some ways one of the most commercial. You even have to pay a $11 parking fee, even if you have a National Park Senior Pass or Annual Pass. Worse, it's a notorious example of defiling natural beauty. It caters to the lowest common denominator of tourism.

We read reviews of the monument and saw a couple of videos, but it doesn't come close to seeing it in person. Our first view was through the trees on the highway. It didn't disappoint. The closer we got, the more impressive it was. Its an international symbol of democracy. Free to get into, parking is $11 per car.

Mt. Rushmore was really cool to see. Personally though if I were to do it again I would skip paying 15 dollars to park and just enjoy the view from Iron Mountain Road and from outside the parking area.

This was on the bucket life list of things to do and it was for sure a life time experience. You could really get close to the memorial and take really good photos. Parts of this are wheel chair accessible. There are park rangers to answer any of your questions. If you have not gotten your National Park Pass I would suggest you get one! It saves you money. Plus there is a map of all the National Parks and sites. You can also get your pass book signed at all National parks and memorials plus buy a sticker and this is a fantastic way to have a record of every National park you have visited. It's also a fun thing for the family to do together.

The entire experience is so much better. The surrounding tourist area is spectacular. The walk to the observation area is a pleasure to view. The gift shops, the restaurants, the handicap accessible parking make it so much better. The NPS did not detract from the view, they just made it better for everybody to witness this work of art. You only pay $11 for car parking that is good till the end of the year.

Mt. Rushmore National Monument, near the town of Keystone in the scenic Black Hills of South Dakota, is celebrating its 100th Birthday this year. It was built over 14 years, from 1927 to 1941, by Gutzon Borglum with his son Lincoln and 400 workers, at a cost of just under a million dollars. It's named after Charles Rushmore, a NYC attorney, who visited the area on business in 1885. The mountain was originally known as "The Six Grandfathers" by the Lakota Sioux.

We stopped by in the morning right around 8:00. It wasn't too busy. Disappointed that we have to pay $11 for parking at a free monument. The Rangers were extremely helpful and gave us a great plan for the rest of the day. Trying to find our state flag was fun for the kids. Interesting reading the history of it as well. We didn't do the hike because we were going to go on the scenic tours.

We only paid $11 to park and there were no other fees! This shocked me. We went to the left side in order to use the ramps to get closer to the monument. Much easier going down the stairs coming back. Make sure to go to the sculptors area, I learned quite a bit. Favorite thing to learn was about the area behind Lincoln's head that is used to store all of the documents associated with the carvings.
Always love coming here gift shop is to small should offer clothing and other items. Parking is a joke $11.00 for what it should have been free many years ago,

A must see while you are in South Dakota. Great history lesson for young and old alike. TIP: you can buy your national park pass at a reduced rate in advance of your trip to save time and money. If you are a senior, lifetime pass is $10 and covers entrance fees for others in your vehicle. I got mine at the local BLM office.

Mount Rushmore is absolutely spectacular. Do not miss it if you're in Rapid City. In the summer it opens at 5 AM and closes at 11:30 PM. The monument makes you proud to be American. Admission is free but the is a parking fee of $11.00.

Everyone knows what Mt. Rushmore looks like but seeing it up close is still fantastic. And they have a nice walk that takes you up even closer to the presidents so you can get gorgeous photographs from all angles. The visitor center staff was nice to warn us that it's easier to take this Presidential Path starting from the left going up the hill since you don't have as many steps to climb up that way.....though there were still quite a few coming back down after viewing the Studio where the model for the presidents is. But the road up to Mt. Rushmore is so beautiful and easy to drive......just gorgeous. You have to pay $11 to park.

We took the $100 per person heli ride around Mt Rushmore and then went to the 9 pm amphitheater show and 9:30 lighting held at Mt Rushmore. It was cooler then and it was a show worth attending. Parking can be tight during high tourists times, we found plenty of open parking in garage 6, but this is early June after Memorial day.

This is a spectacular place, one that is a must see if anywhere near it. The scope of the memorial is mind-boggling. Access is easy with a parking ramp ($11.00 for annual pass) adjacent. An amazing observation is that the foreign tourists seemed to vastly outnumber Americans. Bring your camera! This is a good place to spend a couple of hours enjoying the view and just plain people watching.

So different from when I came as a kid and there was only the mountain and a trail! Huge gift shop, cafè, indoor museum, film, etc.--very bustling. Helicopter tours fill the air. Be prepared to pay a concessioner $11 for parking! (WHat???) Take Level 3 or 6 to save on walking if you have mobility issues. It was still wonderful, but I'm glad I came when it was quieter back in the day.

My wife and I decided to take a day trip to see Mt. Rushmore and we were very pleased. It is only $11 for parking (good for a year) and everything else is free to visit and observe. I suggest watching the film on the history and to take the presidential trail for a great view.

We visited in late May, 2016 in the morning but was disappointed to see the clouds covered the sculptures. Fortunately it cleared in the late after noon and we revisited this place. It is a wounder how the artists worked on the mountain top to complete their work of art. A place every one must see and appreciate their workmanship. This place charges $ 11.00 for parking, but it is valid for one year. If you miss seeing the sculpture due to bad weather, you can return any time later but the parking is free.

I finally found my way to South Dakota to see Mt. Rushmore. Luckily, when I visited, it wasn't as crowded as I hear it can get during the summer peak. The work that was done is amazing. The fact that these four faces are carved into the mountain is awe inspiring, but at the same time, disappointing when you learn that it wasn't completed. I found the parking cost ($11) to be high since there were only two of us in the car; I would have preferred an admission fee if additional money needs to be made to cover the cost of upkeep. I would imagine that had I visited when there are thousands of people in the small visitor area, I would have been less happy with my experience.

Impressive monument, incredible location. It's a bit cheecky, that this place is not run by NP and we must pay $11 on top of our annual card. It is a NATIONAL memorial... It is worth it, though... Don't forget to take a Presidential Trail hike, very easy walk will lead you right under the mountain and the view are pretty incredible. Have a rain coat or umbrella ready, Black Hills weather is unpredictable.

Despite the very long trip, Mount Rushmore is so worth it. We went during the middle of May before the seasonal rush began. The weather was very nice and there were no crowds. Parking at the monument is $11 for an annual pass and admission to the park is free. I've seen photos of Mount Rushmore all my life but photos cannot begin to capture the grandure of this national treasure.

It was amazing to see and learn about the sculpture and how it was achieve. Gutzon Borglums was a brilliant man. I loved seeing the President's who founded this great nations. Loved everything about our visit. You pay 11 dollars to park but that is all. There is not an admission. It is well worth the time and money.

This monument is breathtaking! If you have time, take the trail around the base of the monument to see different perspectives. We visited during the day, then made a special trip back to see the monument at night with the lighting - this was a disappointment as the lights just seem to wash out all the features and make the stones look flat. Although when we came back at 10:00 pm (it's open until 11:00), there was no one at the gate so we could've parked for free (this was in early May). The park is free but there is an $11 charge for parking. Stop in the Artist's Studio to see a model of how the monument was intended to be finished (to President's waists instead of faces only).

The area has a lot to offer families but most of the attractions are only open for the summer. The monument is not visible from the road. They charge you to park for the whole year no matter how long you're staying. There is a reasonably priced gift shop on the plaza. I recommend eating before you come. The restaurant there is about $20 for a bowl of soup and not that great. The ice cream is a must even though it's expensive. The trail is only about a mile long. There are a lot of stairs. There is a free museum, but the staff was really rude. I would recommend it just for the experience.

I've been here several times and always marvel at the engineering feat of years gone by. Parking is $11.00 per vehicle and admission is free. Take the time to walk the trail to the base of the faces to really appreciate how huge they are.

Mount Rushmore exceeded all expectations. Be sure to rent the audio guide for $5; it gives basic and extended information as one walks the "Presidential Trail." From the guide and in the museum there is much info. on Gorglum who designed the statues an the men who made them. The Trail is not at all strenuous. Lunch at the cafe, on the terrace and looking at the 4 great figures is a great experience.

My wife and I have been wanting to see Mount Rushmore for over ten years! We finally made the trip out to Western South Dakota, wow somethings look amazing in pictures but some you just need,to see for yourself. This is one of those things. It costs $11 to park your car, there is no further admission to get in the park. The avenue of flags leading up to the monument is a very nice touch. If you have time and are in decent physical shape, I highly recommend walking the presidents trail. It was an overall humbling experience, glad we can finally cross it off our bucket list.

My husband has been wanting to see Mount Rushmore for several years. We decided to make the trip and take in the sights of South Dakota. Mount Rushmore was the first place we visited and we were not disappointed. The natural surroundings are awesome and the carved faces of the presidents were inspiring. Lots of good photo opportunities and information for history buffs. The Mount Rushmore area is beautifully maintained. It costs $11.00 for parking and that is a bargain for tourists. The gift shop was very nice and my husband came home with a Mount Rushmore T Shirt. Don't miss this attraction.

Wow! Where do I begin? The fact it took 14 years to make and it wasn't finished? That 90% of the monument was sculpted with dynamite? Or that the highest paid worker made $5 a day? If you see it in person you won't think about those things, no, you'll be wondering how this person with a giant sized vision made this amazing monument a reality. If my husband would have let me, I would have stayed half the day just staring at it! Truly every American should see this awesome tribute to our country's heritage! By the way parking was $11 but the viewing area, museum and the rest of the site was free.
This monument has been on my bucket list forever and it has been completed! Parking cost was way more than expected at 11 dollars. It was much smaller than I imagined but awe inspiring just the same!

This is a place Americans should really try and visit at least once in their life. Visitors should be sure to read the history of how this was sculpted as the story is fascinating. Be sure to walk around the park to afford yourself different views of the monument. Note the NPS does not charge admission however there is a charge for parking. Also, for those who collect NPS Passport Stamps, there are a couple located here.

This is a must do on a list of things to do. We enjoyed viewing Mount Rushmore very much. We see pictures of Mount Rushmore all the time however, they do not do it justice. This is one of those things that you must see in person to get the full effect of just how much work went into making Mount Rushmore and the size of it. This was an awesome stop to make. A Must Do. There is a parking fee of $10 that you pay to park and then you enter the viewing area from the parking lot.

We are grateful we got to see this majestic piece of our history. The film and exhibits really help you understand how hard it was to create. This is not expensive, only 11 dollars per car. The walk was not difficult

The price of admission is $11.00 and good for the rest of the year. Lots of great information in the museum down stairs, don't miss it! Certainly would come back, very impressive and humbling for the work involved to carve, and maintain a National treasure.

Mount Rushmore in Black Hills, South Dakota is an incredible monument that you absolutely must see at some point in your life. Me and my family (mom, dad, 3 young kids and 1 teen) packed up our minivan and drove all the way from Colorado Springs to see this historic monument. When we arrived, we had to pay a parking fee of $11 before parking in the lot and then taking the pathway up to the entrance. Dogs are not allowed but there is a small dog park outside the parking lot. Inside, there is a viewing area where you can look up at the carved faces, and pay binoculars that allow you to examine the mount more closely. There is a museum section of the downstairs building showing how the monument was built and a free 15 minute movie that you should make a point to see, as it gives lots of good history. There are two gift shops and a bookstore (the bookstore also sells collectible stamps and coins) and an ice cream shop and cafe. All in all, this national monument is a must see any time you are in South Dakota and was a great experience for my family.

Must see attraction! Take the President's trail after the viewing platform. The route to the left is flat and basically without stairs while the route from the right hand side is over 300 stairs...grueling to an average person probably but great exercise for us since we had already commmitted. But not for the out of shape. Great gift shop, too! Pay attention on the drive up for some pretty good camera shots and videos.

If you have a good telephoto lens you can pull off to the side of the road going up the hillabd get a good view and ppicture. The $11 for parking seemed awfully steep, considering we wrre there less than an hour. Also the wheelchair accessible restroom (ladies) had push-to-operate door controls that did NOT work, going in or coming out.

Since we went in April there were only a few people there. Nothing was open other than the park itself. It was $11 to park and it is good for the rest of the year. We took the presidential trail and got amazing pictures. There were 4 billy goats on the rocks which were very cool to see.

Be prepared to pay $11 for parking and a Senior Park pass does not count. But, the pass apparently is good for a calendar year. It was quite busy for a drizzly day - I can't imagine the crowds in season. Happy to say I actually did get to see this - even with the cost for parking.

The price for parking, and admission is high ($13). The flag entrance is neat. The food is overpriced. You will be able to view Mount Rushmore from the road before you actually get to the gates. My advice would be to save the money, pull over, & take a pic. Do not plan on actually getting close to it because you won't. You could easily see this & Crazy Horse in same day like us.

We came up for the Easter Sunrise service at the amphitheater in the Monument, as we were here the same time a couple of years ago, and had just missed it, didn't even know they had one. So we made it this year. It was a good service, and the cafe at the monument had an excellent Easter brunch afterwards, at a great price. And the food is excellent there in the Carvers Cafe. We had several meals as we liked their home cooking taste of the Yankee Pot Roast meal. Better than MY homemade. Great staff everywhere, and well, the Monument of course, speaks for itself. Admission is free, but you have a parking fee which is good for the calendar year issued. We plan on coming back again in late August, as many attractions in the area are still closed, and the Presidential Trail was closed this time too, because of the snow. So we would like to see the rest of the Mount Rushmore attractions that were seasonal, but the rest of the Memorial is open year round. And there are such great auto trips around. Beautiful countryside!

Read several reviews before our trip. Advised to see monument at night. They were right a "Must" see at night. Probably 20 people there and no charge to get into parking lot. Went back the next morning to see 100+ people. Admission was $20 to get into parking lot. Pretty impressive sight. Take the road west out of area go to back behind memorial to get a cool picture of Washington's side profile. Restrooms were clean. Souvenirs, food and drink were expensive, but expected.

Always wanted to visit and Mount Rushmore does not disappoint. The parking fee pass is good for the whole year so glad we went first day, we can go back all week on the same $11 parking pass. Sunny and crisp weather, and we went back that night to see it lit up. They have new LED lights that are lit from dusk to 11pm local time. Definitely dont miss the night view. Look up and enjoy a plethera of stars also!! Snowstorms recently left the Presidential Trail closed which is a bummer but we will try later this week.

My husband and I were taking a cross country trip and decided to make the most of it and visit Mt. Rushmore. I don't think I would visit if it weren't on our way as it seems to not be surrounded by much. However, it was a really great site to see! There is no admission fee but there is a parking fee of $11. Since we visited in December there weren't that many other guests which was perfect. It felt like we had the whole park to ourselves! The clerk at the gift shop said they typically are very busy from approx. July 3rd thru the Sturgis Motorcycle Rally.

We visited in March during the off season so we enjoyed the lighter crowds. The $11 parking was annoying, but we knew ahead of time so it was at least not unexpected. The whole family really enjoyed the mountain and the Presidential Loop. The video was informative and kept the kids' (6,6,9, & 15) interest. The younger kids loved doing the Junior Ranger program. The gift shop was a bit overpriced so I would grab your souvenirs elsewhere.

This is a must see for every American. The drive up to the park is as much fun as the monument itself. The walk through the visitor center is excellent and very moving. Your $11 parking pass is good for one year for the vehicle it is registered to. So we went early in the morning for pictures and early in the evening to see it lit up. Wonderful! We ate breakfast in the cafe where we ordered the special and had a pretty decent meal.

I figured, once you saw Mt. Rushmore, then what? But it was an amazing visit. We arrived late in the afternoon so we could experience Mt. Rushmore in both the daylight and at night when it was lit. What a moving place to visit and I recommend every American see this at least once in their life. And the ceremony at night was so moving and patriotic. At night, they show a 20 minute film on the United States and history of the monument and how they picked the faces for Mt. Rushmore. After the film, a park ranger invites all veterans on stage to help with the flag lowering at the national park. After the flag is lowered, the park ranger gives a microphone to each veteran or active duty soldier and they state their name and branch. It was so moving, both Mom and I were in tears. I just wish more people took it seriously because there were some kids running around like idiots and the parents did nothing to corral them. It was easy to get in and out, too, as there was an ample parking garage. The state flags as you entered were a nice touch, too. The whole place was just absolutely stunningly beautiful. There was a nice gift shop and also a sit down eatery. I loved this place and can't say enough about it. It cost $11 to park, however, that $11 gives you entrance in to Mt. Rushmore for the entire year. If I wasn't in Chicago, I'd visit again before year end. Great place; I loved it...but was disappointed I never saw Cary Grant climbing over the faces of Mt. Rushmore.

Obviously, being such an iconic monument this place is crawling with tourists. We went on a week day in at the end of August thinking it wouldn't be as crowed but that wasn't the case. It was exciting to see the monument in person and get a closer view. I got some good pictures, however, I'm not sure the experience lived up to the my expectations. I just imagined it be more majestic and awe inspiring. I think my husband pretty much summed it up saying we could have seen it from the road to Keystone for free (or the Iron Mountain Road). Also, you can't use a national park pass here. There is a $11 parking fee to enter the park. The parking pass is good for a year but we already have a national park pass which should be accepted here.

This is our 4th visit to Mount Rushmore National Memorial. In mid-October there are few visitors so the view is unobstructed by hoards of people. The Memorial is amazing and wonderful. We did not tour the cave or the sculpture's workroom this time - only visited the Memorial and the Visitor Center. The fee to park is $13. A National Park Pass is usually required however it was not necessary at this time of year.

It was great to visit this historic landmark with my kids. It is an impressive stone monument to some great presidents. You can get a free good look, if it's not foggy, from the historical marker commemorating the designer on the way to the monument. But, it is well worth the $11 to go in and get close to the monument and perhaps pickup a souvenir or two from the gift shop. You can also get a good view from the lookout in the National Forest south of the monument.

What a beautiful drive to reach Mount Rushmore. The landscape is amazing! Keep your eyes open for side views of George Washington. Mount Rushmore is an amazing sight. The flagged entrance to the Grand View Terrace is impressive. The cost to park is $11/car but totally worth it!

The walk way up with the flags was very nice. The pictures and movie were very informative and we learned alot about how the monument was built. The gift shop was very nice with a wide selection of items. The parking was $11 but you can come back the same day.

Our kids learned to much here. I think you could spend multiple days here and not absorb all of it. I think it was $11 and that is a pass for the entire year, and you really get your monies worth. We went during the day and then came back the following night, beautiful!
Like most things, Mt. Rushmore has to be seen to appreciate. You can get a good view from the road, but inside the park is definitely better and worth the $11 admission. Drive by at night too!

When entering the monument by car, you are charged an $11parking fee. The parking pass is good for several days (can't remember how many). The gate attendant took the money, but did NOT mention that the monument itself was not visible, due to low clouds! Be aware of the weather beforehand and plan accordingly. We did not have several days to wait for the weather to clear. On a positive note, the Badands, Black hills, Custer state park, and Deadwood were all wonderful.

My husband and I agree: we were more impressed than we expected! We had read about Gutzon Borglum's work, seen the PBS special. But when we rounded the bend and saw it for the first time, we were really impressed. It was a monumental undertaking. Pictures do not do it justice. Of course, the National Park Service does a fine job of interpretation. There were rangers available to answer questions; the museum and films are informative. We visited in the afternoon and walked the Trail. My husband has some difficulty so he only walked the first part while I continued. I took so many pictures because each view was amazing. We returned at night for the lighting and the salute to veterans. It was a very moving experience. There is no admission fee but there is $11 parking fee; that is a yearly fee so you can visit more than once as we did. It is well worth the small cost. Everyone should see this!

This is a must see, of course, if you are in this area. As others have said there is a parking fee of $11.00. The monument is beautiful and the museum is very informative. It is well worth a visit and does not take more than a couple of hours to see, even if you take the trail around the base (which we did). It was actually the main reason we traveled to this area and we were not disappointed! It was a cloudy, misty day but we were still able to see everything very clearly.

If this is a place you've always dreamed of visiting, then it might be worth the $11 required to park. There are exhibits to see, too. However, if I had to do it again, I would have just looked at it from the pull off just before the entrance and saved the $11 for something else.

It had been nearly 20 years since we visited Mount Rushmore and we don't think we paid $11 per person to park last time. We visited the sculptor's studio and walked the trails. The steps were a bit of a challenge for arthritic knees but elevators are available. We also discovered the "profile photo opportunity" of George Washington on the highway. Wow!

They have renovated the area since my last visit several years ago. It is nice, but parking is expensive. I believe it was $17...of course, you can save the tag and get in all year, like lots of tourists do that! The evening talk was worth staying for, but only if it fits into your schedule. We were disappointed in the "illumination".

Mt. Rushmore is an awesome sight. Wish they would remove the flags, as they break the mood of the sculpture. Did not like the $11 to park. Second time here and probably won't be back again. Seen it once, twice, and that's enough!!!

This national memorial is a must see. We visited 37 years ago and since then the visitor grounds have been totally reconstructed. The Avenue of Flags was added, and you get an awesome view of the monument looking through the flags to the mountain. The Museum and the Sculptors Studio provide great insight into the project. The evening lighting ceremony is a true patriotic event which should not be missed. The hiking trails are a challenge, as should probably be expected. If you haven't been there since 1998 when the remodel was completed, go back. You must pay for parking ($11 for our car), but the pass is good all year. We returned two days later for dinner.

Mount Rushmore was on my bucket list and was one of our major stops on our 5,000 plus mile road trip. This a national memorial so there is no entrance fee but there is a parking fee of $11 per car. It is good for the calendar year. Like most national memorials and parks there is a visitor center and introductory video. We arrived about 4:00pm, walked around, including the Presidential Trail, had dinner and then stayed for the evening lighting ceremony. I found the evening lighting ceremony to be very moving and should not be missed. Get to the lighting ceremony early and secure a seat in the last row so you have a back rest.
well worth the $11 parking fee, which is undercover if you have your dog with you. But, you can see it from the road too.

I'd rate the memorial as Excellent, but reduced the rating slightly because of what I consider the rip-off parking fee for the parking garage at the memorial. You have to pay $19. The admission to the Memorial is free (yay!). A national park pass does not waive the parking fee, however. You do get a parking permit that's valid for the rest of the calendar year (if you're returning).

I loved seeing Mount Rushmore. We arrived around 9am on a weekday in September, which was a great time to get there, before the crowds and tour buses roll in (which was starting as we were leaving). The parking was $11, but there's no actual entrance fee, and they have covered parking, which is great for those of us with pets in the car. Though dogs aren't allowed beyond the entrance gates, you can take them up to the gates and snap photos there, if you're so inclined. The gift shop was one of the better ones we visited on our cross-country trip.

There may be and $11 dollar parking fee, but who cares. I think that is a small price to pay for something that most people in the world and even our country don't ever get to see. Other parks cost a lot more money to get into so complaining about the small parking fee is ok with me.

Wonderful memorial. It is hard to top this one. The film, the work room of the sculptor was an added bonus. Everyone should visit the presidents. If one drives around the highway a mile or so from the monument you will see George"s profile. It took our breaths away. $11 per car to enter. Pays for parking g lot. A bucket list must for all Americans.

This is a must see for everyone. It really is an amazing feat to see these faces carved up there on the mountain. There is quite a bit of walking to do but there are planty of places to sit & rest. Be sure to check out the sculptor's studio. That's where you can learn how they actually did this. Very, very impressive. There is a place to eat & another to get ice cream. Pretty large gift shop of course!! It cost $11.00 to park.

The sculpture is magnificent and the story of its creation was fascinating. The buildings, the parking, the walkways are all very nice. Do take the walk that brings you to the foot of the mountain. It is a different perspective and worth seeing. We also saw a mountain goat with her baby freely wandering around. Go early to avoid crowds and get the $5 handheld audio tour.

We spend 3-4 hours here, walking, taking pictures, ate lunch, and watched a short video. The route TO Mt. R is a beautiful winding, tree-lined drive. Admission is free, but you pay $11 for the parking garage. They are obviously prepared for large crowds, so think "Disney meets The Presidents", in terms of big parking garages, big cafeteria style food venue, and gift shops.

The park is well kept and worth the visit. I didn't like that the National Parks admission pass was not honored. It seems like a scam to say entry is free but there is a mandatory parking fee of $11. Just the same, it is worth the price. Be sure to walk one of the trails.

First Class!! The Movie is not to be missed which tells about the project and the Sculptor. Pay $11 for parking and the rest is free. We spent two hours there and did not eat at the restaurant. We just took lots of photos and went to the interpretive center and also watched the 15 minute movie Two hours is minimum.

This is another one of those "must see" attractions. The faces are visible at many locations along the road but the walk along the Avenue of Flags is an emotional experience. There are many things to do while here: Ranger-led programs, the Sculptor's Studio, book stores, gift shop, cafe and ice cream shop. Rangers and staff are helpful. The entire area and restrooms are clean. This is my first year at paying an $11 parking fee to a free attraction. A snack of 2 coffees and a brownie cost $8. Still worth it!
An easy drive from rapid springs, easy parking, a $12 pass good till December.
