If you have never been here, you must go at least once. Pure Americana at it's best. Just the act of walking up to the viewing area invokes a sense of awe. Mount Rushmore is truly a marvel and tribute to the four great Presidents. You can always tell when something is inspirational because people tend to talk in hushed tones and so it is at Mount Rushmore. Admission is free but there is a fee for parking (currently $11) that is good for months. There is a gift shop, museum and restaurant. Go during the day and return in the evening for the lighting ceremony.

Pictures of Mount Rushmore don't do it justice (although I have a lot of them). There are trails to hike up right next to the monument and various places for pictures with state flags, stone descriptions or from the viewing deck. The ice cream shop hit the spot on a warm day for me. Definitely worth the $11 parking fee.

I read some of the reviews and don't understand them!! It was beautiful. This was on my bucket list and I enjoyed the experience. You do pay $11 to get into the park which isn't much at all. Watched the film about the building of the memorial and it was very interesting. Would highly recommend.

Mt Rushmore is one of those National Mounuments you have to see to believe. To learn about the lives of the men who spent 14 years risking their lives for $2 a day is amazing. My Aunt was a foster child of one of those men for a short while, Red Anderson. The presidential trail is a must just to get closer to the monument. Take your time and explore it all and enjoy the videos.

Beautiful place with awesome granite carvings of the presidents. No dogs allowed past the entrance gate unless they are service dogs. Plenty of parking. Get an audio tour for $5. There are three or four gift shops, a restaurant and and ice cream shop. There are elevators to the lower level for the museum and movie which are very interesting. Worth your time to visit. We loved it!

This is nicely done by the park service complete with small museum and a movie of the history. The entry is free but the parking was $11 good for one year which doesn't make sense. They put your car license number on the parking permit. Ours was a rental car, LOL. I have never been here so had to see it at least once. Not sure if I have a reason to ever come back.

Admission is free but parking is $11 and no passes are accepted. The area is well maintained and impressive with book store and dinning area. The observation platform is the spot where all the photographs of this you have ever seen of this were taken. There is a moderat walk around the lower part of the hill, not for wheelchairs or those who can't do a lot of stairs.

What an incredible place. Watch the movie, walk the presidents trail, stop and try to capture a photograph ...then stop again and again. It is truly a wonder to behold. Go back for the night lighting show, not just for the lighting, but for the part where they honor our troops. Only negative was "concession" parking fee, we had our National Parks Pass but had to pay anyway.
Angostura State Park is where we stayed. $25 night

So interesting to learn the history behind Mt. Rushmore. Very informative learning how it was carved. Definitely walk the 1/2 mile Presidential trail. There are a lot of stairs so if it's easier for you to go up for the majority of them instead of down then go towards the studio first (to the right when facing the monument). The only fee to get in is an $11 parking fee which is good for the rest of the year. There is a lighting ceremony at 8:00 pm.

Our visit to Rushmore was part of a road trip and it did not disappoint. The opening colonnade is stunning and highlights the facade beautifully. Parking is only $10, which makes for a bargain of a visit. The ice cream at the snack shop is delicious and the portions are huge.
Last time I was at Mount Rushmore was almost 30 years ago. A LOT has changed and I was very impressed. for $11 a carload, my Family of 3 got to see and do a lot.

The sculpture carved into the granite of Mt Rushmore is amazing to see up close. You should see it both day and especially at night when it is lit. There is a film about it in the theater and history throughout the complex. The only downfall is the parking, very crowded and cost $11.00 to park, but still a must see stop for the traveler. Highly recommended.

Words alone cannot describe the experience we had visiting Mount Rushmore. Walking down the avenue of flags while staring up at the presidents makes you swell up with pride of this great country. To see the heads of our fore fathers gives you chill bumps. I just could not get enough visual time to satisfy my desire. The park is tastefully done and large enough to accommodate a large crowd. The gift shops are well stocked with great gifts and the ice cream is a must. The park cost $15 and it is well worth it. TIP: Park on level 6 (top) to avoid stairs.

I have been to Mount Rushmore a few times in the last 25 years and the facilities have gotten bigger and better over time. My only complaint is the $11 parking fee that my annual NPS pass doesn't cover. I'm not sure why I had to pay to park for a national memorial. It would be nice if the NPS could explain this. Maybe then I'll up my rating to 'Excellent'.

I had not been to Rushmore in 40 years. New visitor center is very nice. Worth the ten dollars or so. The men on the mountain were great Americans. The visitor center is a fitting tribute to the hard work of the artist and the people on the monument. The ride there is a long one but this rare experience of nature and man is worth the trip if you are in the area.

Well worth the visit. See all here that is offered. The Memorial itself is amazing. Walk the path to the base. Hit the sculptors cabin and the exhibits. See the movies too. Best of all top it off with the lighting ceremony which starts at 8pm. It honors the Presidents but seeing this lit and hearing the national anthem is a real treat. Finishes off with all active and past military service personnel helping to low the flag. Unbelievable for only $12.

I was "in the neighborhood" and thought I would check out Mt Rushmore, being a great fan of the movie "North by Northwest." I didn't have a lot of time but wanted to make a quick tour of the visitors' center and stop at a viewpoint or two for a photo. Forget that. You cannot stop and take a quick snap of the full monument. There are no parking, no stopping, no blah blah blah signs exactly where any normal passer-by would want to stop, on penalty of fines. Instead the road funnels you into an expensive parking garage operated by concessionaires who charge $11 to park a car and FIFTY DOLLARS for an RV. If I had been operating an RV I would have been mighty unhappy about that. You cannot access the visitors' center otherwise. As it was I was so disgruntled I made them tell me how I could get out completely without visiting. The attendant tried to talk me into paying the money for the best experience, in her view. How is it this is a national monument and yet you cannot access it without paying a concessionaire? I actually already had a parks pass that would have admitted me to any other national parks site, but that was of zero use. I seem to be the only person online unhappy about this. Just be forewarned. Maybe if I had expected it and had time to get used to it I wouldn't have been so ornery. Or maybe I would have anyway.

Always been on my bucket list as a destination and I finally made it. The drive up is just gorgeous. Visited during bike week at Sturgis and they monument made special exceptions to bikers giving us our own garage level to park on. Only issue here was the trapped exhaust was overwhelming, they should have considered the top open air level. The restaurant at the monument had good food choice (cafeteria style) and the usual gift/souvenir stores. Cost to enter was nominal, walking not excessive.

It is one of those things you just have to see. We stopped at the official site and paid the $11 for parking. The site was amazing. We also chose to stop for cookies and cream ice cream -- really good. While driving around the area, there are also numerous sites to stop and take pictures from various angles. We would definitely recommend visiting Mount Rushmore!
Was more then I excepted. Only $15 and that was for parking. We rent the audio tour things at $5 a piece. Well worth it. Took around 2 hrs to do the whole audio and walking tour.

Good for younger children, a short hike to see the monument. A fun thing to see if you're in the area, but I wouldn't go out of my way to see it. Impressive because it took so much effort to put this monument into place, but almost disappointing in person. Good staff, very friendly and helpful. Free entrance, but $11 dollars for parking.

Yes, you can see this from nearby roads and save the $11 parking fee, but it really is amazing up close. Take the President's Trail--it gets you up very close It's not very long, but it does have a lot of steps, so if you're not in the best shape, prepare, take water, and take your time.

There are so many great photo ops there. Little disappointed in paying $11 to park , The parking structure was built with private money and maintained privately. It is the best way to get close enough to get great photos. It is definitely a must do attraction in every person's lifetime.

Recommend to both visit during the day and also to see the daily 8 pm lighting show in the amphitheater which features ranger presentation, 20 minute video and the lighting of the faces. I understand this is a National Memorial but was unaware it is a Veterans Memorial but that is for some reason the emphasis of the night time presentation. I wish the show could have focused more on the history of the carving. Admission to Mt Rushmore is free but a parking fee of $11 per vehicle which is valid throughout the calendar year purchased is required. The facilities and displays are clean, beautifully maintained and well worth the visit.

Originally I thought that Mount Rushmore would be a half hour experience and we would be off to explore other things. I visited here years ago, and was shocked at everything there was to do. $11 for parking makes this one of the cheapest things to do in the Black Hills area! We spent time in the various gift stores, ate a picnic lunch on the terrace outside the cafe, viewed the monument from the platform, saw the ranger at the youth station (interesting stuff there!), looked at the exhibits, and hiked the Presidential Trail. We ended up spending probably four hours here between two different visits. One thing that sticks out in my mind as a negative; in the bookstore is an elderly gentleman signing books. He, Nick Clifford, was a driller on Mount Rushmore and is the last one alive. We made the mistake of walking past his table and my son merely touched one of the books as he passed. We smiled at him and my husband asked what it was like to have worked on the monument. He grabbed the book away from my son, and snarled, "We were just glad to have a job." With this he just glared at us; it was such an awkward moment we didn't even know what to do. So we kept on walking. I was actually relieved to hear him snarl at someone else a few minutes later so I knew it wasn't just us. I really felt like his sour attitude detracted from our experience. Why have him there if he is a bitter, angry man? Really too bad--my husband and I shook our heads about him for days afterwards, and the fact that he gets so much space in my review exemplifies how much of a lasting impression he had. That one experience aside, it is a very humbling and wonderful experience. Don't miss the Iron Mountain scenic drive, catching a glimpse of the four heads framed perfectly through the last tunnel..... Beautiful.
While passing through South Dakota I would of course stop to see Mt. Rushmore. $11 gets you in to park but I'm told this covers you for up to a year should you decide to come back.

$11.00 for parking and you're in. They are strict about staying on the walking path. Other than that, it's great. When up as close as possible, the monument is awesome. I felt proud to be a American. Loved it.

Mount Rushmore is a wonderful memorial. Pay the $11. parking fee, See the Sculptures, they are an amazing sight. The museum is educational, they have a gift shop, and the restaurant is very good. When you leave, Rushmore cave is another chance to shop or eat. Since you are in your car, Horse Thief Lake is a nice drive.

My wife and I visited Mount Rushmore and were so impressed. It made me feel so proud. From the walk by the flags to the memorial viewing area to the presidential trail where you have a close up view of the memorial. What a great National memorial that we should all be proud of. With the parking pass of $11 which is good for a year we were able to return the next night for the lighting ceremony. An overview/story is read for each president followed by the lighting and tribute to those that have served. Get there early for a good seat. What a first class monument.

This is amazing every time. The view, the history and the work becomes so real. Don't miss the studio and the unique views of the Presidential Trail. Fee for parking which gives you parking for the remainder of the calendar year.

Drove out of our way to go to Mt Rushmore, and we weren't disappointed! Amazing memorial! The memorial is free, but it costs $11 to park a standard vehicle. Considering the cost of different memorials and parks, this is a great deal! The museum is excellent with a short film about the memorial as well as a large display of items and information regarding the memorial. I would highly recommend making the trip out to Mt Rushmore if you can! We stayed in Custer, and it was only a short drive from there.

FYI, you can't use your national park pass so you do pay the $11 parking fee. The grounds are beautiful and the displays are very informative. The movie is great for the history of Mount Rushmore. We walked the presidential trail which was great- lots of stairs! The sculptors studio was very interesting, especially the models. We went back in the evening for the lighting ceremony and it was very, very moving. All Americans should see!
Awesome, South Dakota must-see! Just as awe-inspiring as expected. Surrounded by so much natural beauty as well! One of the few remaining things you can do with your family on a budget ($11 per car).

Even though you have to pay the parking fee (National Park Pass doesn't cover it), the organized and large expanse of parking was worth it. It wasn't as busy as I expected, or the many lines to enter helped make it less of a wait.

Highlight of our trip. Price was reasonable and it encourages you to go back and see it again and again. Decided to go for the sunset lighting. It was patriotic and moving at the same time. I was worried that my 5 and 7 year olds would be bored but they were in awe. Of all the things we did on our vacation our 7 year old still will tell everyone it was her favorite thing. Our 5 year is still disappointed that George Washington didn't talk - but hey, you can't win them all over!! Can't wait to go back again soon!

We did not give ourselves enough time to walk around some and then find a seat to watch the end of the day ceremony and lighting. We arrived around 7:30 due to taking the Wildlife loop at Custer and then Needles highway and that took way longer than expected. Then the kids were starving so as soon as we arrived we hit the cafeteria and filled up. Ceremony started at 8 so we walked along the Presidents Trail and stood for the ceremony. DH is disabled so it was a little hard on him to stand that long. But it was worth the time and the $11 parking fee. We left just as they were honoring the veterans (husband is one but too hard for him to stand any longer). Got to our car and we're back in our hotel in Keystone in just a couple of minutes. Into wish we could have gotten there earlier so we could sit and watch it. Bring a jacket, it gets pretty chilly at night

The drive up to the memorial through Black Hills National Forest was beautiful. Parking was $11 for a reusable pass, but no charge for entrance to the actual memorial. It was a very nice, well kept walkway up to the viewing area. A definite must see if in the area or driving through.

I'm in awe of this magnificent National Park. What a beautiful place. I'm shocked at what a bargain it is for families. It's free admission into the park. The only fee is an $11.00 parking fee. We spent around 100.00 on souvenirs to help support the park. I can't wait to come again. The parking fee is good for the rest of the year. What a great deal!

We spent about 1.5 hours at the Memorial. We watched the movie at the lower level of the Grand View Terrace. Then we walked over to the Sculpture Studio - that had the scale model of the original vision for the monument. Then we took the Nature Trail back up to the are by the parking lots. You can get your National Park Passport stamped in the Information Center,

We arrived at 11 am. We decided to pay the $5 each to use the audio tour on our visit. It consists of a hand held device you put up to your ear to hear at your pace. If you like history it's interesting. We proceeded to walk up the avenue of flags, then stopped at the grand view terrace. Here you are looking straight at the Monument. Below you is an amphitheater and visitors center. We decided to continue around the presidential trailhead path, getting haIf way about 1145. The path which is accessible is wide and very easy to walk and stop on. This path at this half way point brings you right under the monument. From this point the path changes to stairs and is not accessible. Using a three wheeler, I rode back while my family went ahead on the stairs. When back to the view terrace, I took an elevator down to the visitors center and access to the outside amphitheater. I listened to the rest of the audio tour and my family got to me around 1230. They said the stairs were up and down; going both directions. As a group we went into the visitors center. Lots to do. Gift store, pictures on display, a 15 minute video & Rangers desk. We watched as kids answered questions for the Rangers and were then sworn in as Rangers; badge and all! We ate lunch in the large cafe located before the avenue of flags.Very reasonable! Another large Gift store close by. Ice cream shop too. We were out to our car by 2 pm. We returned that evening for the lighting of the monument. A must! $11 for parking all day.

This is a must see! It's a national monument, and the story behind it all is impressive! My kids loved becoming junior rangers by finishing the booklet and earning their badge! It's a great place to spend the afternoon and learn a little of our country's history! Free, but parking is $11- a bargain for an afternoon of exploring!

Went to the night time presentation. The screen lit up to show a video, it was hard to see from far away. At the end of the video they asked the audience to sing but it was hard to follow a speedy song. Then the lights just jumped on real quick, I expected it to slowly light up each president. I was disappointed. The gift shop was actually opened for us to visit. $3.75 for a simple drink.
I believe we only paid $11 for the whole family to visit this place. It was beautiful and well worth the trip.

I kept hearing how Mount Rushmore was just a giant rock in the middle of nowhere and wasn't that cool to look at. I still wanted to see it, so we made it the main purpose of our road trip. The first time we went was during the day. It was pretty amazing to A) Stare into a piece of history, and B) Reflect on the time and effort that went into creating such a piece of art. The exhibition hall was really interesting as well, tons of great, interactive exhibits outlining the creation of Mount Rushmore from beginning to end. I would have to say skip the gift shop, unless you're DYING for souvenirs. It was full of screaming children and the same tacky junk you can find at any other tourist trap. The ice cream however, was delicious. Definitely go for that. In the same trip we came back a second time to see the monument lit up at night. There is a photo in the gift shop of the big dipper over the monument and I thought maybe it was photoshopped to make it a little more spectacular. Turns out, it wasn't. The big dipper was actually visible over the monument at night. My only regret is not having a camera that would adequately capture the image in the dark. While it's definitely not an all day kind of stop, it's worth checking out on your way to somewhere else, or as one of many attractions to see on a vacation. Parking is $11 and the pass is good for a year. There is no other entrance fee.
Of course this is one of the stops you come to when coming to South Dakota. It was really neat to see this monument, but you are really not here for long, considering the $11 parking fee you pay.

I was here thirty years ago and this time around I brought my brother and his family. Much has changed in thirty years, but the sculpture is still impressive. The original parking lot has turned into a multi-story parking garage ($11 good for a whole year). The memorial is free. The entrance is much grander. The visitor's center is much nicer and the dining facilities are much improved. There's also an extensive gift shop. The Avenue of Flags is more impressive with stone pillars lining the walkway and holding the flags of each state and commonwealth (instead of posts and trees). We were at the memorial around 10:00 AM and it was already crowded. Everyone was posing for pictures or staring at the Presidents. We walked the Presidential Trail (review to come) and visited the Sculptor's Studio (read the history and see the model of Mt. Rushmore). We ate lunch at Carvers Cafe (reasonably good, a little more expensive than a typical family restaurant). We only regret not returning for the Evening Lighting Ceremony (we left around 1:00 PM).
We couldn't walk the steps since we have physical issues but it was worth the $11 parking just to go as close as we could.
I do not care about the parking charge - it's only $11.

When you come around the mountain and see this spectacle you will be in awe.. Great monument and family experience. Hefty parking fee of $11 but nice facility. Food and drink is pricey but hey your on vacation right? Lol. This is a must in your lifetime.

Check out both the Lincoln Borglum Visitor Center below the Amphitheater and the Sculptor's Studio - incredible history! There's also the Borglum Story Museum in Keystone if you're interested more in Gutzon Borglum (for those history lovers). Just a few handy mentionables: there are 2 pet exercise areas near the parking ramps, $11 parking fee that is a season pass, walking trail that goes slightly under the faces, excellent restaurant - good hardy food and worth the money, self guided audio tour, and lighting ceremony at night!

My daughter and I visited the Keystone area in July of 2015. We went to the nightly lighting of Mount Rushmore the first night we were there. Although the monument is an amazing man made sculpture carved in the side of a mountain we weren't impressed. You can see the monument from the city and honestly its not worth paying the $11 park admission.

$16 parking pass that's good for a week. The trail is pretty easy up until you hit the stairs. I wouldn't recommend going down to the house if you can't handle stairs. I also wouldn't recommend trying to haul coolers, but that's none of my business as Kermit would say.
Worth the time. Surprised it cost $11 to park there after I spent $80 on an annual park pass but I wouldn't have missed it.
It is amazing to see the monuments up close. They are huge. It cost $11 for the car and the ticket was good for the year so that was a good deal. There is restrooms, food and a gift shop.

Is all I can say is WOW. It was everything I though it would be. Thanks to the movie National Treasurs II which had some shots of Mt. Rushmore. We decided to make a full day and book a tour that included this as the first stop. Which you will enjoy the morning view better and if you decide to strike out on the trail as we did the cooler morning is better. There are plenty of places to take pictures of your own. But not to worrie if your thing is not a camera the gift shop has what you need. The have many different good quality prints. I chose several 8X10 plus several pictures I took with my own camera.Admission is free. But they get you for parking depends what you are driving. Remember I choose the tour bus so my price for parking was included in the tour fee.

The $11.00 parking fee is well worth the money! It is good until the end of the year! We went during the day and walked the presidential trail and took in the sculptors building. There are plenty of steps on the trail. If I could give any advice it would be to take the stairs to the left first and end on the other side. We came back at night to watch the lighting. I would say if you want to take in the story and all that get there early because there is NO give and take with people. We started to watch the movie of the story but people kept cutting in front of us so we gave up and just listened! It was a great experience. The weather was perfect for this too!

We enjoyed the whole Mount Rushmore experience. Can you beat an $11 annual entrance fee? The National Park Service does a great job here. I also recommend the audio tour available at the entrance, $20 for a family of 4. While my husband and I really liked all the audio information so did my son (9). He liked listening to it an every stop.
Did you know a president invented ice cream? Me either! A bit pricey but you'll be surprised how much ice cream you get for $5. The monument was amazeballs to.

There's not much to it - but there doesn't have to be. The memorial speaks for itself. Visiting the memorial is free, but there is an $11 fee to park. However, we visited very early in the morning and the parking attendants don't begin collecting fees until 8am. Gates were open since the memorial opens at 5am. None of the gift shops were open that early, but restrooms were open. The memorial is stunning from the very first glimpse of it through the gateway from the parking areas. Walking through the flags of every state, you see the president's faces ahead, looming larger and larger. It really does give a certain thrill and pride to see it. The observation area is clean and quite beautiful - very much worth the visit.

This is an absolute must see! Be prepared for the $11 parking fee. Mt Rushmore is absolutely breathtaking. Small children may get bored quickly because there isn't much to do, however there is a nice gift shop, snack bar in sight. Ice cream should work!!! Try to see it I the evening when the light is shining on the mountain.

The memorial is laid out beautifully, with the flag-lined walkway ushering visitors towards the monument with pride. The monument itself is beautiful and worth seeing. For $11 a carload for the entire year (seriously!), you can schedule a return visit if you're close enough or return the next day for more scrutiny. The visitor's center is fabulous and easy to navigate, particularly with the available option of downloading an app to guide you through the park. My children enjoyed earning their badges with the Junior Ranger's program and interacting with the rangers. We went on the Fourth of July weekend when the four featured presidents were available for photo meet-and-greets.

We were extremely impressed with our National park. It was $15 (? i think - for sure no more than $15) - and that is good for a full year. Beutifully kept park. Prices were very reasonable. I was surpised by the fact that they served alcohol, but it by no means a problem. If you do the hike around the trail, I suggest starting on the west (?)/left side and going round - not as many steps that way. Make sure to watch the night ceremony. It starts at 9:00 I would get there 8:30ish for a spot. It was full when we were there. Again - very proud of this park - it was an inexpensive day for us!

On a family vacation, we had the opportunity to visit Mount Rushmore. Arriving in Keystone, South Dakota, late afternoon, we decided to visit the Memorial that same day. Knowing that there was a nighttime presentation at Mount Rushmore, we were prepared to spend several hours at the memorial to try and see everything. We were impressed with the minimal amount of time that it took us to get through the gates, considering the volume of traffic was entering with us. This is not a national park where a senior citizen needs to use their card to get in, as everyone paid an $11.00 fee to park. We found several different venues inside Mount Rushmore that offered hot/cold food items that the prices were consistent with other major attraction prices. The grounds were extremely clean and well kept. It had been many years since my wife and I had been there and we were happy to see some of the trails had been developed and were easily navigated. The memorial was handicap accessible and there were plenty of personnel that were there to assist. Everything was self guided and well marked. The outdoor, nighttime presentation was pretty special. A park ranger was in charge of the presentation, which was delightfully entertaining and interesting. At the conclusion of the evening, members of the U.S. armed forces (active, retired) were asked to join the ranger on the stage in recognition of their service to our Country. It was very moving to see how many military personnel moved to the stage, under a rousing, thunder of applause from the audience. Each of the servicemen/women were given the opportunity to say their name and their branch of service, prior to the flag of the United States being retired for the evening. A large number of persons were moved to tears, as a result of this ceremony.
We had a wonderful time at the Mount Rushmore monuments. Parking cost $11 per car but the monuments are free to enter. Enjoyed looking at them and reading the history behind them.
For 15 dollars you see all of Custer park, wildlife loop, all the trails and you can see the Presidents while driving on those very same trails.

When you see those faces for the first time it is like seeing the Grand Canyon or the Eiffel Tower or Statue of Liberty for the first time. I highly recommend the self guided audio tour rental ($5.00) very informative and a little silly to go and not get it

We took our cousin to visit Mt. Rushmore since she was visiting from another country. It is definitely an "American" site to visit. It was a spectacular day, blue skies! It was surprising there were not very many people for the middle of July. We arrived around 10:30 a.m. We walked around the path, visitor center. There were even "deals" set up outside the gift shop. $5 t-shirts, bags, some magnets.

We love Mt. Rushmore or as my kids say "mt. mushmore." We had a short visit to SD this year and went twice to Mt. Rushmore. We love driving by it and walking through the flags. For $11 for a year pass you can't beat the price to see such an amazing treasure! There is a lot of history to read and a great trail to take to get closer to the monument. I hope to go yearly and take pictures of my kids.

We didn't make it to Mt. Rushmore in the daytime, so when we heard about the 9PM ceremony, we took it. Very poignant, as the vets in the amphitheater were recognized individually at the end, and it was a very special time. A park ranger talks about the monument and liberty, followed by an inspiring movie. The theater was pretty full, but we found seating. Lots of stairs. The event is free, but parking costs $11, and there was a long line to get into the parking lot. The heads of the Presidents are well lit for about 2 hours, and it's neat to see. I would highly recommend this.

Although we did not like the $11 parking fee for this park, the monument itself was very cool. The Presidents Trail was cool to walk on and gets you closer to the heads, although from a 'looking up the nose perspective:)'

We visited Mount Rushmore National Memorial during the day and again at night ~ it was really wonderful. There is no admission fee for the memorial but there is an $11 fee for the parking garage. I was told by the parking attendant that the parking pass was good for a week but read on the Mount Rushmore Info website that the pass was good for the entire year in which it is purchased.
We did not like the $11.00 parking charge,however we enjoyed everything else. The rangers working at the park were very helpful and polite. The kids loved it!

As far as national monuments go, its pretty cool. However unless you have time to go hiking there isn't much more to do. It was only $11 per car to go in (which wasn't bad) & wasn't overcrowded (went at 7:30p). Glad to mark this off the bucket list.

If you are in the mood to go through the museum stuff, go ahead and pay to park but if you want to save $11, you can look at it from an overview and get the same effect. It was nice and gorgeous to see. Even better was the Needles Highway getting there after that drive and seeing it from that vantage point, the actual memorial sight was a bit of an anti-climatic experience. Still, they can use the money for upkeep.

Mount Rushmore National Memorial is a wonderful place to visit. The only cost involved is parking. $11 for a year pass. There are great gift shops. There are great exhibits to learn about the making of the memorial. A Great photo opporturnity. Great of all ages.

Visiting Mt. Rushmore is definitely worth the $11 per car entrance fee (for parking). They have a visitor information center with movie, souvenirs, etc. as well as some nice trails to walk around the site. And the view of the president's faces is very neat to see.

Nothing like making the drive up the mountain, and making the curve to see your first glimpse of the Presidents. Amazing! Was able to meet, and purchase a signed book from one of the actual workers that help build the statues. Priceless! Would highly recommend the light show in the evening. We went back to watch and it was well worth it.

What an amazing place to visit. Parking was $11 for a year pass. There was plenty of parking on a Saturday in the summer. It is very clean with hiking trails that tell about each president. They had an area for children to color the presidents. They have rangers teaching about the carvings. So much to do at this place.

First - it cost $11 to park but the attraction itself is free. The movie and museum are very interesting and informative. You learn about the construction and the artist in detail. There are places to hike all around the monument. Don't miss the ice cream - the Thomas Jefferson vanilla was the best and is his recipe. Awesome!

I hadn't been to Mt. Rushmore since I was a kid, and it was even better than I remembered. I don't think the $11 it costs to park is that big of a deal. It allowed us to come back again at night for the lighting ceremony. The grounds are beautiful. It was fun to walk along the path and see Mt Rushmore from different angles. The video in the museum was very interesting and a must see.

This is our third trip to Mt Rushmore and we never tire of the beautiful monument, grounds, history and especially, the evening lighting ceremony. Take the time to walk the easy/moderate trail for an up close look. The staff are very helpful and people are generally courteous regarding photo opportunities. Be sure to check out the museum and short film. Hint: the evening program starts around 9:00 and ends at 9:45. Walk the lighted path afterward while everyone else is rushing to get away. $11 parking fee only.

Give yourself about hours to really enjoy this park. $11 to park per car. $5 per self guided audio tour. Do the audio tour, it's worth every cent. There are about 25 audio tour stops really detailing everything you might want to know along the 90 min walk around the base of the monument. Watch the movie in the museum (it's about 15 min).

Seeing Mount Rushmore in real life is amazing. Pictures, TV images, views from the road are not enough. They do not accept the National Park Passport and you pay $11 per car for parking. We were there pretty early so we were able to park close. As you're walking up from the parking structure you get your first closer view of the carved stone. There is a wonderful walkway with all the state flags and when they joined the union. A nice wall honoring all those that worked on Mount Rushmore. The restrooms were clean and well stocked. There's a main viewing area and tons of seating to just sit and reflect on the accomplishment of this mountain carving. I recommend taking the trail to see more views, see the sculpture studio and compressor. Mount Rushmore is amazing. I would recommend it to everyone - put it on your must do list and get there. We visited for about 2 hours.

Another one of those places that is a must see-where photos can't do it justice. Gotta see it in 3-D. This monument is such a large scale art project that it boggles the mind-how do you begin to sculpt a mountain? Amazing. The site itself is free, but there's an $11 parking fee. There is a nice trail, a beautiful viewing deck, food available, restrooms, gifts, ice-cream, seating. It's wheelchair friendly too. Lots of different viewpoints and educational information. The artist's studio is a short walk away, but lots of steps to it. Well worth the trip. You may wait in line for the fee booth for parking. Beautiful vistas in all directions.

While I figured the carvings would be worth the drive and price of admission, I was pleasantly surprised at the nice park around them. There's a good deal of parking, $11 for the vehicle then you're all paid up, not having to shell out more at a park entrance. Then you've got a beautiful avenue of flags, an amphitheater, clean restrooms and visitor center, and so on..

The views coming in were grand and the site itself well kept and maintained. This cost us $11 for our family to visit so very cost effective. The Avenue of Flags was very nice as was the Presidential Trail for an up closer walk which I highly recommend unless stairs are out for you. We took the way to the left of the memorial to the trail and it was mostly down stairs. When you get to the sculptor's studio you'll go up some stairs but it's not too bad. There's a film you can see that is about 15 minutes and worth watching. You can come back in the evening for a free lighting show. If you stay in Keystone it's worth coming back and especially for free with your pass. I think we spent maybe two hours here and that was perfect.

We went on the 4th of July, it was crowded but it did have actors portraying the four guys up there. That was very cool. We shook hands and took pictures. $11.00 to park but well worth the time and money. A must see!!!

If you don't like visiting Rushmore odds are you are un-American or just a grumpy person. The monument itself is awesome so I'll review the national park aspect of the place. The cost to get in is $11 a vehicle which gets you in all year if wanting to visit again. Parking is pretty close to the main attraction. The visitor center has a couple of videos and exhibits that are interesting. The cafe is ok if you don't mind paying $10 for a hamburger basket. (Maybe eat before or after visiting) I would suggest checking out the evening program that includes a ranger talk, video, monument lighting and honoring of veterans.
A must see once. $11 parking fee ( 2 motorcycles using the same space still pay $11 each) and the National Parks pass counts for nothing.

Spectacular carvings in beautiful setting. One doesn't have to go in to enjoy it as it can be seen from many vantage points. However, one should pay the $ and go to the visitor center. Watch the video and see the exhibits. You will get a better appreciation of the exhibit.

We absolutely loved being able to see Mount Rushmore in "real life". It really blew us all away, and to only pay a fee of $11 to get in and park the car, to us seemed like amazing value. Watching the documentary on the making of Mount Rushmore, when you get there, as well as going through the museum, I would truly recommend, it is absolutely amazing to see what these people did to build and sculpt the monument over a14 year period, considering the tools and access they would have had available to them during the 1930s and early 1940s. We walked up the many steps to get closer to the sculptures and I would really recommend this too, although if you are not a strong walker, like my mother in law, I wouldn't recommend this as it may be too much. If you do this on a hot day I would recommend you have a hat, sun cream and water if walking the many steps to get closer as it can get pretty hot. Something that we noticed was that we arrived at Mount Rushmore around 10.00am, and it was very busy getting into the monument parking, but when we left the monument at lunch time it was so much quieter getting into the car park,so you might want to consider the timing of your visit.....midday/early afternoon may be quieter (we were there on a Friday). The other thing I would want to let people know is that we came from the direction of Keystone, SD and when we got to a section of the 385, if it is busy going to the monument, you may think people are pulled over to take photos of Mount Rushmore but they are in fact in a long line of traffic to get into the parking. So you actually need to be in this lane of the 385 to get into the Monument. However, if you get stuck and are on the left hand side of this road and can't get back into the turning lane up further ahead near where the parking is you can do a u-turn, which is what we did, and we actually got into the parking area much faster than all the cars that were banked back in traffic.....I hope this makes sense. When you see it, it hopefully will.

This really is a must see. It's a great monument. The visitor center and exhibits are very well done and it is neatly kept. We went for the lighting ceremony- it was cool a little longer than necessary but cool. Go see do. Free admission but you pay 11$ to park.

Not much needs to be said about this amazing monument. It was my wife, 8 year old daughter, 3 year old son, and myself. It's only 11 dollars per caseload, so definitely worth admission price. The park is beautiful, and very clean. We walked the trail that gets you right up to the monument and sculpture workshop. Wonderful visit and the kids loved it. All I can say is get there early. We arrived at 8:30am and were right in, and there wasn't many people there. We left just after 10 and there was a whole lot more people in the entrance, and the line of cars waiting to get in was enormous. And that was on a Monday.
Awesome, with a great gift shop. Costs $11 to park and that's it. Great photo opportunity. Go see this National Monument!

A must see for those who appreciate history. Worth the $15 entrance fee. We were unable to use our National Park pass at this venue. The 'avenue of the flags' perfectly frames the monument and the museum and a film a must for history buffs.

What can be said about such a tribute that has not already been said. Definitely worth the stop. Not just for the awe inspiring monument, but also for the work that went into creating it. Small children may get bored quickly as they will not understand all that it took to do what has been done here. We came back for the evening lighting ceremony and it was worth the time. ( In my opinion and my wife disagreed, the ranger that was the MC of the 45 minute ceremony got a little preachy but not way overboard.) They brought all the veterans in the audience on stage and at the end had them introduce themselves, nice touch. There was a 20 minute video on the four presidents and why they were featured on the monument. If you are in the area and have at least a half hour, could be more if you like to read through the exhibits, it's worth your time. No entry fee but there is an $11 parking charge. Restrooms were clean and updated, as is the bulk of the entire facility.

The monument itself is awe inspiring and was well worth the price of admission. I HIGHLY recommend the audio tour for $5. It is informative and makes the tour of the place much more enjoyable. The gentleman that was working the audio tour booth told me about the Crazy Horse Volksmarch. I had been at Crazy Horse memorial earlier that morning. It was fun, but you could only get a profile view of the memorial from a very far distance. While at the monument I was disappointed that none of the staff told me about the Volksmarch. This piece of information was given to me by the Mount Rushmore booth staff member! He informed me that the next day you could walk up the mountain the next day for only 3 canned goods! I can not stress enough the life changing pictures I got the next day, the 2015 Volksmarch commemorative medal I purchased or the experience of walking up the Crazy Horse memorial. I wish I had taken down that gentleman's name, because he went above and beyond and should have been rewarded for that life changing experience I would have never had had he not told me about it. Best staff at a National Memorial ever.

We have been here several times over the years and it never fails to amaze me. It takes my breath away every time. All of the updated facilities made this experience much better than it was years ago and if you haven't been here in awhile it is worth the effort to come back. The Presidential Trail allows you to literally walk right under their noses and is one of the newer additions from the old days. Call it gaudy, cheesy, or a blight on the Black Hills... It still gives me goosebumps when I first see it! Only a parking fee to enter which was $11.

We read about people saying just to drive by on the road and snap a photo.....not me. I thought the experience of walking through the state flags, watching the 20 minute video of how the monument was constructed and my selfie with the Presidents in the back was more than worth the $11.00 parking fee.

This is really a special place. Be sure to visit it in the morning and late afternoon the view is different with the change in sun position. At night (9PM) there is a ceremony along with spotlights on the monument. There is no fee to visit the monument but you have to purchase a parking pass when you enter for $11, however it is good for THAT CAR ONLY (they record your plate number) until the end of the year. There is plenty of parking available.
Allow 2 hours for this stop. It was great to finally see Mount Rushmore and South Dakota. Parking is $11.00 for cars, turcks, and RVS.

The average rating is due to the fact that senior, veteran, and other park passes do not gain access to the memorial -- you have to pay the concessioner $11 to enter. The National Park Service needs to fix this. People on a fixed income who have senior passes, and vets, who have served and also have passes, should not have to pay. The memorial is an impressive site.

If you've never been to Mount Rushmore this is almost an obligatory stop. Everyone should visit once. Since we were in the area, we decided to make a second visit having been here once 20 years ago. You pay 11 dollars to park but otherwise visiting the site is free. We got an ice cream cone and walked along the flag line walkway. At the end is a viewing point where you can take your photos. There's an interesting visitor center and at night I understand there is a lighting ceremony. There's not a lot of reason to spend more than a couple of hours here. It is however, a fascinating couple of hours.

You really need to see this Monument in person to appreciate the grandness of the carvings. After viewing the sights be sure to take the Presidential trail around the area. Then check out the nice gift shop! It costs 11$ to park the car and the viewing is free. Take lots of pics! This makes for a nice way to spend a 1/2 day in the hills!
This is a must see if you are in the area. Inexpensive, $11 for a car load. And truly something that is a must see. Pictures don't do this justice.

My husband and I had never been to Mt Rushmore, so we decided to make it a quick vacation and went there on the 4th of July! I didn't know what to expect, and I was pleasantly surprised. It was only $11/car and there was covered parking. They have a really amazing walkway leading up to a viewing platform. The walkway has each state and when they were admitted to the union - great photo ops. There is also a walkway that makes a loop from the entrance area, up to the mountain and back. You can go either way (left or right) from the entrance area, and I recommend taking the left. This will allow you to walk down hundreds of stairs instead of up! We went around 5pm, and it was very crowded, but it was also a holiday. In the gift shop, we were able to meet one of the original drillers who actually worked on the memorial. He signed a book for my boys, and answered all of our questions. The day after we were there, was his 94th birthday! Overall, it was a great experience, and I'm glad that we were able to share this experience with our kids.

This is truly a sight to see for everyone. I would also highly recommend buying the audio tour for $5. Do be careful to check the weather. If it is cloudy, you will NOT be able to see anything. We got there one day and walked the Presidential Trail and listened to the audio tour but never got a chance to see the memorial. Luckily the next day was perfectly clear and we got to the park at 6:15AM to see the monument. Seeing those four familiar faces on that mountain is truly inspirational.

My trip was planned to specifically see Mt. Rushmore, Crazy Horse and go to either Jewell Cave or Wind Cave. The Black Hills of South Dakota are beautiful reminding me in parts of Colorado. We stayed about 4 miles beyond the Memorial so as we drove past it we were going away from it and didn't see it from the road. The next day as we were driving back west from our cabin, you could see the Presidents up on the mountain from the road. How beautiful it was for that first glimpse from a distance. Even though I have a National Park Pass, you still have to pay to park as the parking lot is owned privately rather than the Federal government. So a National Parks pass doesn't save you anything here as there is no admission to the actual park/memorial itself. It is $11 to park. Upon walking in and getting the closer view, you are just taken away by the magnificence of the sculpture. You walk along a large paved area that has posts on each side with the names of states and the date in which they became a state. There are flags of the states flying off each post . Of course, there are stores and the visitor center which you can buy your commemorative merchandise. There is also the Lincoln Borglum Visitor Center which shows a 14 minute film describing the methods used in carving the memorial. The BEST part of the Memorial is taking the President's Trail. This is an easy .6 mile walk, but there are 422 stairs. The most fascinating thing about this trail is there are stops along the way in which you can see only one sculpted President. It is a wonder to me as to how they planned this out, was it planned out when blasting and sculpting was going on or when the trail was being built was it just discovered you could stop at certain points and you would see only one of the four presidents. To see Washington by himself, it is a short walk through a cave (very short even for a claustrophobic person). At the end of the cave is an opening in which you peek through and there is Washington up close. When you get to the area where you see Teddy Roosevelt by himself, you are so close you even can see the sculpted glasses on his face. The details are amazing on each president.
Definitely a sight worth seeing at least once in your lifetime. Parking pass is good for a year and it's only $11! No other fees for the day unless you eat there.

fulfilled one item on my bucket list, one time charge of $11 per car for admission, good for re-admission for one year but not transferrable as your license plate is scanned and recorded on parking pass. A bit of an uphill walk- keeping in mind the high altitude and sun is taxing on all visitors. Breathtaking is all you feel. trails and information booths abound. Nice but a bit expensive food court offering all kinds of foods and ice creams. large gift shop, got to personally meet one of the original stone carvers who was signing his memoir. Can't wait to read this book.

I was able to enjoy the view of Mount Rushmore on a sunny cloudless day, and the view was spectacular. It really is a sight to be seen. I am glad to have checked it off the bucket list, but I do not think I would ever come back. Tip for those traveling up the mountain to go see it: if you're hitching anything be careful as it is quite a large mountain. Also, you can stop before the actual entrance and take a photo as Mt Rushmore is quite visible from 16A. Stop if you can, take a photo and turn around and avoid paying the $11 parking fee, as the view doesn't get much better close up as there are too many people also trying to take a photo.

Keystone is kinda centered in the area where all roads converge at Mount rushmore. So if you want to be close to everything stay here. We stayed in rapid city which was a 20 mile drive but a relatively easy one to get to mount rushmore. First you will pay a $15 "parking fee" which let's them say the monument is a free attraction but really its not. You then walk up some stairs or take an elevator from the parking lot to a long walkway lined with flags and a view of mount rushmore. There are lots of people so expect crowds. The best view and picture is at the end of the walkway sp just avoid the cluster of people and move forward. Then you can branch left or right for a mile loop that takes you near the base of the monument for some unique views. It's all a wood deck path but there are a bunch of stairs going back up. At the end of the loop is the sculptors house and a nice little exhibit and there are some bathrooms nearby. That's about it for this trip.
Recently visited the memorial. What a site to see that must be done in person. Be prepared for the parking cost of $11. A bit steep.

By far one of the coolest things I have seen. Just amazed.. And lots of info everywhere!! Must try the Theodore Roosevelt (I'm pretty sure that's who's it was) vanilla ice cream recipe!! It's worth the extra dollar.. By far the best vanilla I have ever had and I don't even like plain vanilla lol

Of course this is an awesome experience! This Memorial is very well kept and clean, nice stone walkway and Presidential Trail. Be sure to take in the short movie and visit the gift shop. $11.00 parking fee, but good until the end of 2015. The first morning we were there the fog had moved in and completely covered the faces. Went back the second time with full sun in the morning and what a sight those four faces are!! Plan to spend two hours there.

After you get past the $11 parking fee you are free to roam about one of the most magnificent shrines to Democracy available in the US. Words cannot do it justice to view it the first time. People that say they see it by the road to save the parking fee do not get the ability to get up close and personal. Take time to walk the presidential trail as well. Absolutely inspiring what these sculptors did between 1927-1941. This is a must see.

We just visited the Mount Rushmore monument which was an awe inspiring work of art that you must really see. Unfortunately the workers there were rude and ruined the moment.First when we paid the eleven dollars for parking the young woman in the booth clearly didn't like her job and was rude to me and even rolled her eyes at me.Nice! Then I bought some over priced souvenirs in the gift shop and when I went up to the counter she put the sign up that the register was closed with not even a sorry or an explanation so I waited in line in another counter.When she finally was ready she offered me no assistance and acted like she did nothing wrong. Thanks for the wonderful experience. Not!!! i would say skip the parking fee and the gift shop and take pictures on the way up then turn around.

The price to get in is $11 for parking only. No other admission price. The tag you get is good for one year! Reminder the tag is only good for the car you came in on, can't use it on a different car later. Wheelchair accessible. Great $5 prices on some tourist items under a canopy on your way up to the memorial. Other tourist stuff to see not worth it. Don't forget to get ice cream!!! One price and LOTS of ice cream, very good too.

We traveled from Philadelphia to the giant heads with our two kids and it was well worth the trip, Mount Rushmore was great as was the surrounding country side. The sculptor's work shop was nice the monument was impressive and there is so much do around the area a must see. We visited three times so we got the most out of our $11 parking pass.
Mt. Rushmore was our daughter's vacation choice this year and we were not disappointed. There is a $11 parking fee, but it's worth more just to visit this memorial.

It might seem touristy, but just like visiting the Statue of Liberty, this is a stop worth visiting. To gaze up at the carvings is really awe inspiring. A trail allows you to walk fairly close to the carvings, which allow for great photo ops. Visit the cafeteria (seen in North by Northwest) and grab a not too shabby meal, to just get some of Thomas Jefferson's ice cream. A nice gift shop on site. Don't forget to get your NPS Passport stamped.
After a long drive up the mountain you turn into the driveway to the parking booths.... you immediately see the presidents looking at you... $11 to park.... but that's not a problem at all....

Breath taking place to be. The $11 for parking is not bad and the ticket is valid until the end of this year (not that I'll be returning), but never know. A must see if you are within driving distance of Mount Rushmore. I thought I was just going to "take a look" and walk away; however, once there, you want to get closer and closer and marvel at the workmanship of such a project. The exhibits and very informative and for $5 you could "purchase" your personal audio tour. I highly recommend visiting this place.

What you see in pictures is real. However, the $11 parking fee is ridiculous! You can stop on the side of the road and get great shots! There is a museum of sorts inside, but we had already visited the Borghum Cultural Center in Keystone, so we didn't bother at the monument.

This is a fantastic place. The history of our country in summary is carved into the mountain. Washington to represent the founding of our nation, Jefferson to represent the expansion, Lincoln represents preservation of our union and Roosevelt represents the development. It is just a beautiful place---lots and lots of photo ops and walking trails. The admission is FREE, but parking costs $11 (at least in June of 2015 it is.) Definitely worth the stop!!!

During most of my life, I have seen videos, or movies, or read stories about the many places to visit in the western half of the United States. While spending all of my life in the south and southeast (currently I am retired in North Carolina), I have never been further west than Memphis, Tennessee with the exception of one lone trip to Vegas. I finally decided that if I were ever going to see those sites, I was just going to have to load up my car and drive there and stop making excuses about why I should not go "this year". During my 13 day self titled "2015 Bucket List Tour", I traveled over 6000 miles and visited sites or observed sites during my travels through 21 states. Mount Rushmore was my final destination before returning home. I was awe struck walking into the site and seeing Mount Rushmore for the first time. I kept thinking to myself..."It only took you 57 years to get here but that day has finally arrived!" To know some of the history of this location, and the men, the time, and materials needs to complete this monumental task, I was just truly overcome with an excitement I had not felt since waking up on Christmas morning as a five year old child. The trails are easy to walk and each closer view of Mount Rushmore was just breathtaking for me. Inside the park, there are some very nice places to eat a real meal, get some ice cream, and shop at the park. There are two movies showing inside the main building that detail the history of Mount Rushmore at no extra cost. One movie about the history of the making of Mount Rushmore only last eleven minutes and is worth watching. The entrance fee of $11.00 was a steal compared to the entrance fees to Yellowstone and the Grand Tetons. I even went back that night to see the Memorial as well. I think the best time to go is later in the afternoon/evening (around 6pm) was it is still light. You can then enjoy the evening and relax in the outdoor theatre and wait for the 9pm lighting and presentation. Awestruck!

If you have a national parks pass it will not work here since the park is free and they only charge for parking. It's only $11 and worth seeing and is way better than the disappointment that the crazy horse sculpture is.

What can be said that has not already been said in other 5 circle reviews? The place gives me goosebumps. Go there at 9:00p for the lighting ceremony and be awed by American pride and honor. Only $11.00 for parking and worth every penny. The visitor center and area are in pristine new condition and the staff are very helpful and knowledgeable. The walk of flags is a nice touch.

Not Just a National Park But a National Monument Unlike any Other. Entrance Free, Parking $11.00 per auto, Valid for Remaining Calendar Year. Views for W/C, Handicapped from Grand Terrace. Best Enjoyed by Walking "Presidential Trail". Spend an Hour or Spend the Day. Come after Dark For Spectacular Lighted Views. (Park Hours Vary Throughout the Year).

Mount Rushmore was interesting just because I can say I've been, but it's not worth the $11 parking fee to see it. The true gem is the town of Keystone itself. There are some wonderful little shops and eateries that line the street. Rushmore itself was crowded and some of the workers were rude. Don't get ice cream at the ice cream parlor. Most of the workers were rude and hurried. I felt like I was being herded along like cattle just so they could get me out of the way and serve the next person. Overall, go if you want to say you've seen it, but keep in mind it's a little underwhelming.

Only $11.00 to park & all the fantastic sights, displays, trails, movies & programs are free. You can spend 8 hours & not see everything here. Most is handicapped accessible except for a few trails which have steps to go up or down. The bookstore & gift store will have something for you to buy. I had a great time

I read the enrty from 2007 and thought that there must be something amiss, surely the "powers that be" would nit ruin a national monument by making sure no one sees this site for free and that those that do pay don't get a decent picture anyway because of this stupid granite "banner" standing above you blocking the ciew???? Well we paid our $15.00 to visit, which is good for a whole year not transferable to any other vehicle... Okay first issue, just how many times does one think they will travel to the site in a year? Now second issue no pets beyou the huge concrete monstrosity that blocks the view of Mt Rushmore.... Okay I get you don't want dogs all over but seriously they could extend the pets allowed to this point a little further. Now onto point three, is it really necessary to have commercialized the crap outta this site? I am going to go on a limb here and take a WILD guess that, oh say, 94% of the visitirs will not go into the bookstore or buy a book.... Further limb sitting here... I don't think that the VAST population that visit are going to stop in the icecreame shoppe either. Niw because I had been here WAY before it was spoiled with all the unnecessary parking structures, and granite structures EVERYWHERE, I chose to sit outside of the NO pets beyond point with our new rescue 6 pound dog while my husband went to see what there was to see. NIO one walked by with either an ice cream cone or a book!!!! Sometimes change is not a good thing!

Mount Rushmore is a very cool thing to see. The facilities are very nice. What is not cool at all is paying a fee to park for at most an hour! We have a national park yearly pass that we bought and paid $80.00 for. Of the 5 National Parks we have visited, our pass pays for using the roads AND parking, with this being the exception. It isn't right.
the monument is very nice and impressive. go early in the morning or in the early evening to avoid the crowds. the entrance fee is free, but the parking is $11.
if you are in the Rapid City area, every American must see Mount Rushmore. Check it off your bucket list. no seed to spend $11 for parking. go early (8:00 am) and drive by to take photos

Very beautiful, educational, and breath taking. This is a must see, parking for the year is $11(min.). Admission is free, can't ask for more they have a small cafe and ice cream shop on site and of course the gift shops. 2016 is also an anniversary year for them. Go see
This is always an amazing place to visit. But I don't get why your National park pass isn't accepted here. Get ready to pay a parking fee of $11.00 a vehicle. The attraction itself is free though.

This is a must see for anyone traveling to The Black Hills area. If not for the $11 parking I would have given this an excellent. If all you want is pictures and a look, park on the approach road and take pictures from there.
As National Parks go, this was well done. Nice paths. So glad they have an ice cream stand. Very disappointed that the National Park Pass we bought for this trip did NOT cover the $11 parking fee.

What a feat and work of art! Truly amazing! The grounds are beautiful. The studio and visitor center are very informative and educational. The food in the cafe is good and very reasonable. The night time show left us feeling so patriotic! We loved how all veterans present were asked to come up to help retire the colors and each told who they were, what branch they were in and where and how long they served. What a great way to show appreciation to them! We were also amazed that the entrance fee was only $11 for both of us and was good for a year!

If your an American (and maybe even if you're not) you cannot help but feel a sense of emotion seeing our nations leaders carved into the beautiful Black Hills. This is really a first rate National Monument. The grounds are beautiful, a large gift store and an educational exhibit that explains the creation of the monument along with its cultural significance. While we didn't eat there, there is a cafe (it smelled good) with reasonable prices. We did have the ice cream (yum!). The gift shop is reasonably priced to allow for a souvenir or two to remember the visit. The best part is walking the grounds, gazing at the sculptures and thinking of how lucky we are to live in this great country founded and guided by these great leaders! It couldn't but help to bring a tear to my eye. I read some complain about the $11 per vehicle parking fee. Really? Its worth every penny (Lincoln).

Got there about 7PM to see the night lighting ceremony at 9pm. Glad we got there early to see the sculpture and take pictures because at about 8pm the fog started to roll in and by 9pm you couldn't even see the mountain. So check the weather before you go. Also the ceremony is a little long on speeches by the park ranger along with a movie about the four presidents that was very boring. Just show a movie with scenes of America while patriotic songs play and light up the mountain and it would have been much better. $11 parking fee per car load of people is the only cost unless you buy food or gifts. Lots of neat free exhibits and films about how they carved the mountain are inside nice building near the viewing area.

they added a new building since the last time i was there over 10 years ago. Very interestig learning about how they built it and the videos. Rained when we went. Would like to go on the trail next time we can visit. this is a must see. also the parking ticket $11 last all year long too.

My husband and I were doing a cross country trip and decided to check out this national monument. We had our dog with us. We paid the $11 to park and selected a parking garage 4. (Not in the sun) At 85 degrees outside it was still way too hot and irresponsible to leave our dog in the car while we toured around.

Ever since I learned about Mt. Rushmore decades ago in grade school I wanted to see it. At the end of a trip to four national parks (Zion, Bryce, Grand Teton and Yellowstone) we drove across Wyoming and enjoyed the monument and learned the story of its construction. I was not disappointed! Astonishingly it was carved for <$1,000,000.

Unless you're interested in history of construction, you can see all you need to see from the highway. There is a commercially run parking lot that cost $11 to use. We could not find any free parking. Technically there is no fee for the monument, but the parking fee seems impossible to avoid.

We visited on 6/5, on the way to the Memorial we had to stop for some mountain goats in the road, it was a good start. The parking fee was $11 but there is no fee for the actual memorial. The cravings are amazing, be sure and walk up to the bottom of the mountain (240+ steps) for a better view. Presently part of the walk is closed so you need to go up and down the stairs to get to the platform.

We had never been here and I really wanted to see it. We brought our 14 year old granddaughter with us. Weather forecasts included rain, so we decided to go to Mt. Rushmore on our first night. It was June 1, a great time to go because crowds aren't bad. There's no entrance fee, but parking is $11 per car (the national park prepaid sticker won't work here). The parking garage had lots of space. We arrived around 6 and wandered around the park and marveled at the amount of work this took and also at the actual size! We ate in the Carver's Cafe (not great--see review), and then headed for the amphitheater for the lighting ceremony. Rain was threatening, but thankfully it held off until after the ceremony. The ranger in charge said they might have to speed up the ceremony if rain came. He spoke a lot about Lincoln, there was a 20 minute film that was interesting, the monument was lit (pictures of the lit monument looked like a blob of light), veterans went to the stage to take down the flag and introduced themselves, and we sang the National Anthem. It was a nice ceremony, although the Lincoln part seemed to go on too long, especially with threatening weather.

Parking is $11 and is good for one year (no other options) but everything else is free. Visitors center has a movie that explains the building of the monument. Be sure to come back for the night ceremony too but if you are visiting during the peak summer months arrive early or you will be standing.

We visited after the big May snows which may have affected crowd levels. Both the grand viewing deck and the presidential trail were very manageable as far as crowds were concerned. There are a lot of great photo opportunities on the trail (even more stairs!), so don't let the walk intimidate you. The sculptor's studio and some very photogenic mountain goats are found along the way. The visitor's center and film are not to be missed. There are several bookstores and gift shops on site. The main store had very neat items dedicated to each state: mini flags, pins, magnets, etc. There is a cafe which we did not try, but the attached ice cream shop was very good. All in all the monument is a great value. Parking costs ten dollars per vehicle, but the pass is good all season. Other than that, admission is free.

It is a little underwhelming while you are standing there viewing the memorial. However, this is a must see for all. And the story behind it is terrific. There is no entrance fee - only an $11 parking fee. There are gift shops and places to grab a bite to eat. There is also a little museum and a walking trail. There are also signs to Keep off of the rocks and stay on the trail which several families chose to ignore. I recommend this be built in to every family's summer vacation.

Clearly a lot of work went into its creation but I sort of felt underwhelmed. A tourist attraction in granite. Long drive, expensive parking, and when you arrive you find exactly what you have seen in a million photographs. It actually seems a little dated, and needs the additional perspective of including Native American leaders. No entrance fee, but there is an $11 parking fee, which seems high considering that you only need a couple of hours there, at the most.

By ‘enjoyment density’ I’m trying to gauge the amount of fun one can have relative to the time spent. Mt. Rushmore is a way cool artistic tribute to four great presidents, but if you add in the drive time + finding a parking spot + battling crowds, the result might be only “well, there it is.” Sure, take some pictures, and if you’re there near dusk, wait to see what the monument looks like lit up (not that amazing). Not to belittle the effort that was taken to create this attraction, but there is really not much to sink your teeth into here. BTW, parking is $11, which is not avoidable by having a National Park pass.

This is a very inspirational monument. Admission is free, but there is an $11 parking fee. Visiting on June 1 proved to be an excellent time as it was not crowded. It is advisable to view the video about the monument first as it will give you an understanding of its history. There are rangers at different points in the park offering talks about the monument. Information on times of these talks are posted on a board outside the main building on the right as you enter the grounds. I highly recommend the $5 ($4 if you ask if there is a senior discount) audio tour as it was extremely informative. It is to be used on the Presidential Trail, but you actually could rent it and just sit and listen to it to gain more information. If you listen to it all, it lasts about 2 hours. However, there are several opportunities to skip parts that expound on information already given. The left side of the Presidential Trail is closed for construction, so the route now is up the right side and then back down the same side. There are 225 steps, but the walkway and platforms in between help with the hike. There are some interactive displays in the museum for children. The last remaining living worker on the monument, Don "Nick" Clifford, is often in the gift shop selling his question/answer book. His wife was accompanying him when I was there. They both seem more talkative when you purchase the book which is $12. She pointed out that 400 people are listed as having worked on the monument. In actuality, there were only 137 people. The government insisted that all people who worked on the work programs set up by Franklin Roosevelt around the country were also listed on the plague commemorating the workers on Mt. Rushmore. Interesting. There is an obviously located ice cream shop onsite. Among the flavors is Thomas Jefferson's ice cream recipe. He was the first maker of ice cream. It is a rich, smooth, delicious vanilla flavor. I highly recommend trying it. Though I did not attend, there is a 30 minute patriotic program and lighting of the monument from 9:00-9:30 p.m. This is an amazing national park.

It is well worth going to keystone just to see this! Parking is $11. a car total ripoff. We decided not to pay it or go in. Driving up, we stopped at the turnoff and got some great pictures. Make sure you drive past the memorial, you will see washingtons profile. Well worth it.

I seem to go here about every 10 years and it is always an awe inspiring experience. The facilities are amazing compared to what was there 20-30 years ago, and while hiking one of the trails we saw a side trail to the "historic viewing area" which is what I remember from being there years ago. Well worth the $11 fee/car full to get in.

The view is amazing, you can also walk the Presidential Trail and get pretty close. A must see for everyone!! There is not a fee for the memorial but you do have to pay $11 for parking. Your parking permit lasts for the whole year, which was awesome because the day we visited there was so much fog you couldn't see anything. We went back in the morning and the weather was great.

It's so cool to see landmarks that you've heard about your whole life. The fog barely allowed us to see the presidents, but it was a worthwhile experience. Parking was $11. One of the original diggers was autographing books in the gift shop. While you are nearby, be sure to drive Needles Highway to see the presidents "framed" by the one lane bridges.

Words can't explain how awesome this memorial was to visit as it lit up at sunset. Haven't visited for 20 years and there have been lots of improvements to the park. Wonderful display of flags as you walk to see the monument, top rate restrooms, gift store and visitors center. Can Learn as much as you want about the history of the memorial, it's all good. Go when you can and enjoy this wonderful treasure of our nation. No fee for entry but you do need to pay for parking, we paid $11 for a yearly parking pass.
Dislike: $11 parking fee to go into a national park that is free!

WE had been to Rushmore years ago but you can't see it enough. Last time we actually went in to the park. This time when we got to the entrance it was $11 a car which was a little steep for the short period of time we would be there. Have since found that we can get a senior, lifetime pass, to National Parks and Federal recreation Lands for $10. But we got great pictures from the road and lots of sites to see on the way up. On the way back down the highway there is a turn out to get the profile view. It is an awesome site.

I had been told to have low expectations but I was very pleasantly surprised. I was more impressed by this smaller carving than I was by the larger Crazy Horse. It was nice that there were no crowds as we were there in the off season. Half of the Presidential Trail was closed but it was nice to get up close with the mountain. A great experience to see this in person after seeing it on so many other things. $11 seems a little steep for parking but the pass is good for the rest of the year (not that it does you good if you live out of town).

This was our first time to Mt. Rushmore, and we really enjoyed it. We went on the off season so the crowds were not too bad. The paid parking is not too expensive and is good for one full year. We paid the extra $5 for the audio tour and it was worth it to us. Be sure and walk the path up the the base of the monument...It is a little strenuous, but worth it. There are also food and gift shops on site as well. We spent about 4 hours there. Overall, a great way to spend some of your day.
