Mt. Rushmore in the Black Hills of S. Dakota is the home of the National Memorial comprised of 4 of our presidents. Although the attraction itself is free there is an $11.00 parking fee. At the info center and gift shop, one can rent a wheelchair as the walk to the memorial from there is a long one. A most fitting and beautiful memorial, it will be one worth remembering. The area is well kept up and clean and the museum is extensive. We spent a long time viewing all the displays. There is an informative movie on the creation of the memorial and the educational value is priceless. Personnel are visible and willing to answer all questions. Great learning experience for the children.
About 30 minute drive from interstate. We went on a dreary day. Only handful of cars in parking lot. Even though I had National Park Pass, still had to pay entrance fee. They called it a parking fee.

My last experience was 30+ years ago and the improvements they've made are impressive. Beautiful scenery. Pristine trails. Easy hike for non-hikers or just walk up the sidewalk (or wheelchair) to the observation area. We went in the off-season so we didn't encounter any traffic or accommodations concerns. It's out of the way for most of us, but worth the effort to get there. Even our teenagers were impressed. Parking was $11 and no other fees. the parking pass is good for a year so you could return in the evening to see it lit up.
location: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States

text: Late afternoon visit to see this inspiring sight. Love the majesty and natural settings. This never gets old. The faces and tribute to the Nation is great for all ages. Parking fee is the only drawback, no need to charge $11.00. Just trapping tourists.

Truly a magnificent sight to see in South Dakota. The parking fee is $11 per vehicle--the attendant let us know that it was valid for the rest of the year--we're from Texas so we will not be back unfortunately. Anyway, it is wheelchair accessible & they also rent out wheelchairs if necessary. There is a grand viewing terrace as well as two government visitor centers (US National Park Service), which close daily by 5:00pm. There is also a gift shop & restaurant/snack bar which is open until much later for visitors. We did the Presidential Trail (not wheelchair accessible), & it was classified as a strenuous but short hike. Lots of stairs/climbs. It was a nice alternative view of the monument. Overall, we were so happy to visit Mt. Rushmore & cross it off our to-do list.
Everyone should experience this monument and its history just fabulous $11.00 per car to get into the park

So Mt. Rushmore has been on my to do list for a few years. We finally made it. We went in February and the weather was very warm for the season. The high was 56degrees that day. It was an excellent day and because off season the park was practically empty. Parking was $10 and a parking tag they give you is good for the entrance the entire year. Self audios are available there was a cafe/giftshop. We continued to Crazy Horse which completed a very nice day trip. Mt. Rushmore was smaller than I imagined it would be.

I had been to Mount Rushmore many times the past 25 years. When I first went there you could walk right to the base of the mountain. The next time I went there was a gift shop and railing that kept you back. You used to be able to drive right into the park area and park your car (free) and walk around the area. When I went this year they now have a toll booth type admission area that charges a fee for entry. We had a National Park Pass but it was not good at this attraction because entry into the park is privately owned now so they can charge what they want. I don't mind paying a reasonable fee but it was quite steep for just wanting to spend an hour or so,

We took our child to Mt. Rushmore during summer 2014 and it was truly worth it to see this amazing masterpiece. It was the perfect second grade education. Just be prepared with comfortable shoes for the climb up and down along the paths. One thing to note is that while the attraction is free, parking is not. So even if you have a National Park Pass, you will still need to pay about $11 for parking.

The Federal government gave a parking contract to a private company to build and maintain the parking facility at Mt. Rushmore. The charge for parking is ridiculous. Get a good view from the road and carry on. It's a shame this national park has been taken over by the private sector making tens of millions of dollars a year on parking alone.

We visited the Memorial in January on a weekday, and had the good fortune to have the site basically to ourselves for a couple of hours after sunrise. Don't miss the Presidential Trail, for $5 bucks at the main entrance, you can rent a small recorder that gives you the historical background of the monument as you stop at different markers on the trail. We met a ranger downstairs in the theater area who gave us a personal information session that we really enjoyed. Very large gift shop in the main plaza. Entrance fee is $11 per vehicle and it's good for the entire year. It is lit up for a short time after dusk as well. Truly a gem and a must see!

the fee is $11 to get in per car, but you can see it just as good from the side of the road. Im far from cheap, but you see it coming all the way up the mountainous road and then you pay to get in, and you arent seeing anything you didnt already see. i looked at it and was ready to leave.not that impressive,but its something that you add to your "bucket list"

Pictures do not do the memorial justice. It was breath taking. There is an $11 entry fee (but you can get in all year long if you ever wanted to go back). Going in February was great. There was no crowds and the park rangers gave us great attention.

Mount Rushmore is the quintessential Black Hills tourist attraction as well as one of the most iconic memorials in the United States. It is virtually impossible to give this memorial anything less than an excellent review. Nestled in the sacred beauty of the Black Hills, the four heads of America's most famous and recognizable presidents stare over the vast landscape of one of the most beautiful places in the country. Photo opportunities are plentiful, and if you are lucky you may catch a glimpse of some of the local fauna such as the BigHorn Sheep or a Mountain Lion. The Park Rangers are knowledgable and willing to help and provide informative insight. There are several bookstores on sight to quench the thirst for history buffs and a decent sized gift shop. If you are traveling to the Black Hills this is the "must see" attraction. For frequent visitors, the $11 parking pass is good for the entire year so it's definitely worth it if you live within driving distance and visit the Hills a few times every year. I have been here four or five times now and it never gets old.

I wasn't real excited to go see this but my friend wanted to go, when we got there I was taken back at how stunning this is to see in real life. Was $11 per car to park had a gift shop and an auditorium stage below. Very neat in person.

Went through the area fairly quick as it was rather cold the day of our visit. Could count on one hand the number of people there visiting:) So off season was perfect! No vending open but store was for some souvenirs. Seems ample parking there and cost us $11 to get in (per car price)

We enjoyed another look at Mt. Rushmore, but I was not thrilled at the $10 parking fee since we have a senior national park pass. We hadn't had a look at the four presidents for many years, so it was a good stop as we were traveling back home.

Maybe we're just not monument people, but you can see Mt. Rushmore from the approach road, and I can't imagine the advantage of paying the outrageous entry fee when the surrounding area (Custer Park, etc.) is so spectacularly beautiful on its own. Save the time and the $$$ and get on some of the scenic drives instead!

It is inspiring to see this massive monument and contemplate the craftsmanship and determination that went into building it. The viewing amphitheater is impressive, and the visitors center is comprehensive and informative. It is unfortunate that the cash-strapped National Park Service decided to franchise out a parking garage for which they charge $10 to park your car. They like to point out that entry to Mt. Rushmore is free, and that the parking is for an annual pass (as if most tourists are going to be returning that year!). For those of us who purchased annual National Park passes, this feels like price-gouging.

When you visit the Black Hills, it is almost required that you go to Mount Rushmore. The monument itself is free, but now they charge you to park there (around $10 - good for a year for that car). There are a lot of people who pull off to the side of the road at take pictures (who doesn't???), but the monument has a lot of information available to actually learn about the history of the great faces. If you're into hiking, you can take the trails that take you off the main viewing area down the hills and then back up to under the Presidents. Oh, on your way out of the monument area, headed back toward Hill City (not toward Keystone for this), be sure to stop at the large parking area on the left where you can take a really cool picture of George Washington's profile. With the sapphire skies in the Black Hills, it's a really neat reminder of your visit.

Mt. Rushmore is one of those places that has to be seen to be believed. You might think that you can take a quick glimpse as you drive by (there is NO parking any where near the memorial unless you pay at the site!) but trust me - you really will have a completely different and much more rewarding experience if you suck it up and go in. There is an amazing interpretive center where the stories really capture your imagination and create a strong connection to the iconic place (although the film needs updating as some poor quality imagery!) and the opportunity to see the carvings up close and personal just can't be compared to the roadside. We didn't see the night lighting show (too cold and foggy) but the morning light as the sun moved over the heads was incredible. That all said - I did resent still having to pay $12 to park when I had a National Parks Pass, and am glad I went in the off season which was still busy enough!

Mount Rushmore has not changed in the past 30 years. The surroundings of the monument have been updated with restaurants and accessibility. Very disappointed to have to pay $11.00 to park, but that seems to be necessary for the popularity now. At least the pass was good for the year, even though it was our only visit. The veteran's recognition program during the evening amphitheater light show was very meaningful to my husband-a Navy veteran.

Very, very patriotic. The weather was crisp and lovely, and we had the place almost to ourselves. We thought the introductory film was interesting. Mt Rushmore is free to visit, but you do have to pay $11 for parking.

This was an awesome event. A must do!! $11.00 a car load gets you full access to the whole area. parking was easy. There is even covered parking. Plan on spending a good 2 hrs to see it all. Make sure you take the walking trail. It will put you right up next to the figure heads.

The 9 pm evening lighting ceremony is a majestic event as the four presidents carved in rock are transformed by the lighting into a emotional moment to remember. Even more emotional was the program that took place before the lighting. As a salute to all those that serviced the announcer asked all veterans in the audience to come forward and as they handled the flag their names and service were honored against the backdrop of Mount Rushmore. It was a moving gesture and reaffirming of our love of country and respect for those who gave so much to preserve our freedom. For me that was a highlight of my visit. Other highlights included seeing the New Jersey flag and the plaque that stated it was the 3rd state to enter the union, the view from the mezzanine of the four Presidents, The Presidential walk which gives you a closer and different view of the sculptures, the Gutzon Borglum Museum which was his workshop, the Rushmore museum below the mezzanine which is an interesting history lesson and eating ice cream that was made from Thomas Jefferson's original recipe. For an $11 parking fee you get a lifetime of soul fulfilling memories. Tip: if you come out of the Mount Rushmore parking area and turn right ,

When you come around the bend of the road to see it for the first time – you are very impressed. Here are those magnificent faces carved into the rock and you are finally about to see them from a much closer vantage point. The park itself looks and feels brand new. Parking is easy and you walk along a corridor as you approach the site. There is an amphitheater just in front of the park that they use for special events and the nighttime when they light the sculpture for approximately 30 minutes. Parking is essentially your fee for the attraction and it was $11 when we visited. Be sure to watch the video where they explain how the sculpture came to be. Take your binoculars too!
It's an amazing treasure, what more can I say? I was quite surprised to see that the total price tag was under $1 million. Can you imagine the cost today?

We took our 8 kids to see this marvelous creation of mankind. This was incredible to see in person I am 35 and only ever seen it in movies. It was a bit cold but we hung around for a little while. Parking was only $11 which helps preserve the mountain. A must see for all

What an awesome place! From the moment we come around the curve and get that first view, I am in awe. We parked in the first handicap area, since my mom needs a wheelchair. Everyone parks in this lot; keep on going to the one that is past the stairs to the monument. The cost is $11 for cars, and the pass is good for the remainder of the calendar year. (Note: it is not transferable to another vehicle.) The walk to the viewing area is a bit uphill, but we had no problem getting my mom there and back. I love all seeing all of the state flags that line the walkway. There are also several hiking paths around the monument for those adventurous types. This majestic work of art needs to be on everyone's bucket list!

At first I was a bit blaze about doing this. After all, its just a bunch of rock carved up into politicians. But my wife insisted and I must say, I loved the experience. I call it a "must do" if you are anywhere in the area. There is a bit of a gouge on parking cost; $15. Alas, it is good to have handicap access to the viewing area. Loved it.

It is amazing to view it both during the day and then go back at night for the lighting event. The visitor center is excellent, the story by film and exhibits on how it was made is amazing. No cost for admission but you will be charged $11 for parking but it is good for the year so we went back several times while being in the area. The 4 presidents look so different in the sunshine, rain and clouds. It was very moving, especially at night when they honored our veterans in the audience.

We visited Mt Rushmore during my husband's South Dakota marathon trip in early October. What a beautiful place. When you first arrive and see the sculpture for the first time, it just takes your breath away. We walked into the plaza and as you are passing through the columns of state flags, I just stopped and took it all in. I couldn't believe I was there. It made me very proud to be there and proud to be an American. The facility is nicely laid out, although at this time of year, the viewing veranda was extremely windy and cold, be sure to dress for that. And, be sure to to walk the Presidential Trail. It's an easy little hike with some stairs that gets you a great view of the monument from directly below. Best part of this mini hike is that there is no wind! And the views are just absolutely amazing. There is a nice restaurant (cafeteria style) on the property. Movie buffs will recognize it from the Hitchcock classic, North by Northwest! Food is average and a little pricey, but still okay. There is no entrance fee for Rushmore, but rather just a parking fee of $11....more than reasonable. Wonderful gift shop! I had a blast in there; it's very large and has everything you can imagine in there! Great place to go into to get out of the wind for a while. There is a beautiful museum and a film. I wish we had more time because I really didn't get to spend as much time looking at all the displays inside the building as I would have liked. There is also a Sculptor's Studio that I didn't get to see which I think would have been really interesting. We hope to go back some day and spend more time.

Since our first trip in 1995, they've done so much to beautify and to make Mt. Rushmore Memorial accessible. The welcome with state flags is so majestic, but it's the trail that leads around and around so every angle is breathtaking. They've made all rest areas and attractions within the memorial very intersting, and so many photo opportunities. The gift shops, museums, etc. are all well attended, and you have to go see the film about Borglum and building it. Thanks for the $5 tee shirts,, too. Some of us don't need expensive souvenirs. Amazing place. Awesome sights; fascinating history.

This is an engineering / Artistic marvel. Most of us know the basic story behind this attraction. It is not operated by the National Park Service and Parking is $11.00. The best part of the attraction was the Mountain Goats that we saw. A big Billy Goat, a Nanny, and a Kid. They were right beside the trail

This is a must see and has been on my bucket list for a long time. The best time to go is late afternoon, around 5-6 the sun is behind the mountain and you get the best light for pictures. We stayed for the evening and light show which is really beautiful. They ask everyone in the audience of several hundred people to come forward if you have ever served in the Military so you can be recognized, it was a very moving and patriotic show and at the end they light the heads on the mountain, so you get more photo ops. If your staying in the area you only have to pay once and can return as often as you would like, so you can make multiple visits. Also they honor the National Parks Senior Pass, so you only have to pay for parking!

This was the ONLY thing on my bucket list...I can't put into words how wonderful Mt. Rushmore is. You really need to see it -- to believe it. I think you will enjoy my photos. Don't miss going to Mt. Rushmore...It costs $11 to park -- but that is good for a year and we went back three times in five days. There is a gift shop, restaurant, ice cream, place to stamp your Passport for National Parks. I really can't describe how wonderful it is.

We had been here before about 15 or so years ago, but decided to make the stop again. You can plan to spend a half hour here - or several hours - it just depends on what you want to do. Do be aware that there is a fee to park - $11.00 for a calendar year pass associated with the license plate of the car. The fee is going to the concessionaire for the parking garage - not the NPS.

Yes, the faces of four great American Presidents sculpted, larger than life, into the face of a mountain is a spectacular sight to see. It is difficult to decide whether it is better to view the Monument in the daylight or when it is illuminated at night. If you have the chance, view it at both times. Be sure to see the informational film that tells how the Monument was carved: It was an amazing feat! There is an $11.00 fee for parking; however your parking pass is good for return visits for an entire year. This is the only fee. I'm thinking this is a pretty good deal for visiting one of the most iconic places in our nation.

I think that people who like to learn, like history, like walking around the outdoors, and have the ability to appreciate art or hard work will really enjoy this. I almost enjoyed this, but other visitors just ruined it for me. If people were not complaining about how they thought it would be bigger or the $11 parking fee, they were complaining about the price of food or about how many people were there. Loudly! And then there were the people that think that photobombs are still funny, and people that just don't care if they get in your picture or not. From the moment we got out of the car in the parking lot to the moment we got back in, we hear crying, arguing, and just all out crankiness from so many people that my group started to think that we were somehow being punked.

It was our first visit to Mount Rushmore and we enjoyed it very much. When we got to the park, I was prepared to pay the $11.00 for parking, I did not know that it would allow us to park for the entire year - that was nice surprise. We rented the audio tour and walked the complete circuit. It was very good and the information we got on the tour was very interesting. Walked through all the gift shops and displays and even got to meet an elderly gentleman who had worked on Mount Rushmore from 1938 to 1940. We had dinner in the park restaurant and then waited for the lighting ceremony. If you do go, plan on staying or coming back for the lighting ceremony it was well worth the wait.

We took the beautiful "Needles Drive" to Mt. Rushmore. I was disappointed at the $11 parking fee at first, but found the visit to be well worth it. It was a very touristy and crowded area, but there is plenty of room available and plenty to do. There is a film offered along with other information about how the park came to be. Quite a bit of walking and stairs involved to see some of the exhibits, but most are easy access.

The drive to the Memorial is curving road and a great view of the area. The facility is well maintained and the work done by the artist is amazing. You do have to walk a little distance to get to the visitor center but has great information. If you don't want to walk and just see Mt. Rushmore it can be viewed from numerous locations along the highway. Leaving the part we took the scenic route back to Custer, SD and it was the most curving road I have ever been on but very pretty. There are several tunnels on this route and if your going towards the Memorial every time you exit the tunnel the faces are right in front of you. Please be advised that the parking garage is privately owned and you do have to pay a $11.00 fee to park, if you park use the top level as it takes you right to the walk away to the visitor center.

I don't understand the "terrible" reviews that complain about the entrance/parking fee. We paid $11 total. The fee not only covered our entrance (2 adults), but allows us to visit again - for free - until the end of 2014. With all the site has to offer, how can an $11 charge *per vehicle* inspire such anger? This place is lovely and pristinely maintained. Such attention costs money. There's a trail to follow, the sculptor's studio to visit, and informational films and displays to enjoy. It's a fabulous, patriotic place to visit.

We travel to all of the national parks and have a life time pass. This is the only park we have visited that gets around that by charging $11 to park. There are no options, you pay to park or you leave. If you are like us and can't walk any distances, don't do this there are excellent areas on either side of the park to see the carving and take pictures. Just follow the highway that takes you there. As a matter of fact the NEEDLES HIGHWAY, a mile or so past the park, coming from Rapid City is a far better attraction for sights, rock formations, fantastic ride and beauty in general. If you had a choice of seeing NEEDLES HIGHWAY or MT Rushmore, easy decision. Skip Mt Rushmore!

The first view of the monument when you drive in from Keystone is breath taking! $11.00 per car. You may return anytime in a year. We returned for night illuminating service. The area is mountainous and remote. Check weather conditions before you go. Nice cafeteria and gift shop.

Our trip was planned around Mount Rushmore. And I will say that is a must see, but I was somewhat disappointed for several reasons: 1) While there was a free wheel chair, most of the complex is NOT handicapped accessible; 2) The other National Parks we have visited accepted our Senior Golden Passport. Here they claim there is no entry fee so you don't use the card BUT there is a $15 "Parking Fee"; 3) the exhibits around the complex were lacking in "wow" features. I am glad we visited the place, but am glad that we did other things in the area while we were there.

Famous presidents statues are impressive, if in the area a must see. $11 parking to get into the park, clean museum with parade of state flags and date of entrance to the union, typical artifacts from the carving and presidents history, I recommend the informative movies in the visitors center.
location: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States

text: Need to see it at least once.. we were awed.. car load fee is $11.00.. you can see this from the road but but the film and the flag walk was great.
Parking: ample, covered in parts roughly $10.

Have always wanted to see Mount Rushmore and finally made the long trip this summer. I could not stop looking at it. It is so impressive and so uniquely American. It made me feel a little guilty that I spend few travel dollars in the USA where there is so much to see.

I'm not particularly patriotic but this site does bring that to the surface in anyone who goes there. The site is well organized and very informative. $11 to park is a bit much but I guess they have to keep it up somehow. It's run by Xanterra.
Have had this on my bucket list for awhile. So glad I went - spectacular! Was an easy hike around the park and very educational as well. Highly recommend spending $5 to get the audio tour.

I personally don't care what you've heard about this place. It is fantastic. when looking at this in books or TV, the chips of rock at it's base look like they're inches wide. Not true, this thing is massive and was well worth the trip and the $11 parking fee.

Our whole family enjoyed it, especially since the kids have been learning about the presidents in school. Admission of $11 was very reasonable and no more mandatory fees inside. Concessions available (didn't use). Museum was perfectly sized (not overwhelming), two sets of restrooms and informative. Can't understand why they have quarter-operated viewing units for close-up views, but no way to break a bill or accept cards except way back at the entrance. We google'd a youtube on Mt Rushmore instead of renting the audio tour devices and that sufficed. I wish we gave the area two full days so we could visit more sites/activities, but 90 minutes at the monument is plenty unless you want to walk the trail to the base.

I've always had Mount Rushmore on my bucket list. Now that I've checked it off, I regret having put it on in the first place. This was disappointing. After paying $11 to park - someone has found a way to avoid the National Park Pass problem by charging for parking and not entry - we entered the grand plaza with all those flags obscuring my view of the mount, my first reaction was, "Wow! It's so small!" Moving closer to the amphitheater area, my next reaction was, "Look at all of the debris - like a rocky garbage dump."

Yep, $$$ to park... If you go take in all the information. Movie, museum, check out the book store. Food (Buffalo burgers) were all pre cooked, warmed up fries. Another attraction off the bucket list.

There is no charge to enter the memorial but there is a parking charge of $11 per car (and the National Park pass if not accepted). We stayed for the night lighting of the memorial that included a wonderful presentation by a park ranger and recognition of all veterns in attendence. All veterns were called to the stage for the lowering of the flag and then each one of them were ask to state their name and branch of service....very emotional experience.

If you've never been there, it's a must see! You can walk all around the base of the monument and see the Presidents from different angles. Make sure you drive around and see it from the road. The only problem I had was the admission was free but the parking was not, it was $11, that's good for the week but how many times are you going to go back, pretty steep price when you may only be there for a couple hours.

It was everything we thought it would be and more. To see this up close was just amazing. No wonder you can see them for miles they are huge. When you walk in with the state flags on the sides and look up and there they are - gave me chills. There are walking paths to get quite close - great for photography. Listening to some people along the way there were more stairs than expected. Lots of interesting displays and video on people and stages of completion. Cost $11.00 for our 4 door car which is a pass for a week. That is the only cost to get in.

We paid the $11 to go in but did not hike any trails. We went through the flags, took pictures, walked through the gift shops, stood in awe for a bit and left. It was worth it though. It's a beautiful place and worth the trip with the family. We were on our way out to Yellowstone so this wasn't the sole purpose of our trip, but if you are going just for this, stay longer and take in the views, read up on the history and I've heard there's a very special night show to come back for.

As we expected, the Park is awe-inspiring! Beautiful vistas of the monument from many places and beautifully well-kept. Rather restores one's faith in human beings (the feat and effort it took to accomplish this). Be aware that your Senior Park Pass does not relieve you of the $11.00 parking fee...the parking is privately run and there are no discounts. Once we got over being annoyed about the parking attendant's attitude when we quizzed her about the parking fee, we were never asked for admission fee to the park. Confusing that Mount Rushmore is called a "National Monument" but is staffed by National Park Service. Nevertheless, it does not take away from the beauty of the place. Oh, yes - and do not fail to get the ice cream! For $4.50, you get a huge-mongous amount of the good creamy treat!

Walk around the grounds and they have added a great trail to connect many of the sites at the facility. The ice cream shop was dishing up some huge cones of soft serve ice cream the day we were there. Great photo ops. I've been here a few times over the years and will be back again for the lighting ceremony which is supposed to be great. Don't fuss about the $11 parking as you can park under ground and have a cool car when you return. Also that is per car, so cheap for a family to spend a couple of hours. On the trail you can see the rocks which came off the mountain. Nice to see my grandfather in law up on the names of men who worked on this American icon of the midwest. Have fun!

We arrived early at the monument.....after spending about 2 hours in Keystone, visiting numerous shops. The parking is great (covered parking garage), with easy access to the monument. It had been over 20 years since I had been to the monument, and a lot of updating has been done at the visitor center. Very clean facilities, with several places to purchase food and souvenirs. We spent about 2 hours there, and really enjoyed this remarkable monument to our presidents. There is no fee to visit the monument, but you must pay $11 for parking if you drive......it would sure be hard to visit without a vehicle.

Where else can you get a year pass to $11. This was amazing to see what they were able to create. There are buildings to go through and see how it was created. The night show is a must seeing the faces light up and all the vets, very patriotic.

During my visit to the NATIONAL Park Service - I was a bit (understatement) disappointed to see how this national funded park is operated. I am not one to flaunt nor feel a sense of entitlement about my service to my country as a Army Combat Veteran from Iraq. As an disabled Army Veteran, one of my very few perks is my National Access Pass which provides Disabled Veterans with free National Park Entrance. I think it's a slap in the face to Veterans that our Access Pass is not accepted at this NPS as parking is owned and controlled by a for profit private company. What a disservice to our country's Veterans to ignore our service to our country by charging us access to a nationally funded park. Most unpatriotic place I have ever seen. Shoot even Home Depot honors us - Mt Rushmore bends you over. I will never visit again and spend my time in National Parks where my pass works.

We visited Mt. Rushmore on a weekend in August and the crowds were very manageable. Overall the park is well maintained, is attractive and presents very well. The facial profiles are not as big and they may seem in the picture, but the real uniqueness is the detail in the carvings. The history of the 4 Presidents and how it is presented is impressive. We stayed for the lighting ceremony. While that was nice and kind of neat, it was a tad bit on the side of being too much. They did ask all the veterans who have served to come down at the end for recognition, and they then went down the line and each person announced their name and line of service. While nice and not meant to be disrespectful, it could be abbreviated with the same significance without going to each and every person. You do have to pay $11 for car parking, but I don't mind paying a reasonable charge that goes for a good cause. The pass they give you is good for the full calendar year. Overall, this is a don't miss if you vacationing in the area.

Our family of 5 went to this park during our 4 day road trip from Illinois to Washington. and we are very glad we stopped, Must see to appreciate! parking was 11 dollars. Only disappointment was they do not allow dogs and it was a hot day and we could not leave here in the car so we had to go in shifts.

Make sure to stick around for the evening lights. It is better in the warmer months but we were able to catch the lights at night. $11 for parking to get in but that is for the year. NO charge to actually get to the Memorial. Great place to take the kids.

In reality, you can see this momument both coming and going for free, however once you pay your $$ to get in and park in their parking garage, I think that the fee is fair. I found the history of both the artist and the momument both very good. Did you know that Jefferson was originally supposed to be on the other side of GW? I think that everyone should see this momument and realize that it was done in a relatively short period of time and that it would probably never happen nowadays. I didn't care for the row of flags (too modern and in the way of the real reason why we're there). The gift shop is huge with a nice assortment of just about anything. I challenge you to find out why silicone caulk is so important. Go, just for the fact that everyone knows what Mt. Rushmore is and being able to say you've been there is awesome!

Loved Mount Rushmore, we rented the audio tour and it really enhanced our visit, especially the Presidential walk. The program in the evening was well worth the return trip and when they lite up Mount Rushmore it was the end to a perfect visit. Don't let the eleven dollar fee to park discourage you from going into the monument, viewing it from the road doesn't do it justice.

We spent a cold but sunny day at this beautiful memorial. We visited the second week of December and saw only a handful of people which made it very easy to get some great pictures. Walking through the flags left our family with such a feeling of pride for our country. The gentleman who took our payment was so welcoming, only wish the two women working the gift shop closest to the monument were the same. They seemed bothered that we were there. We skipped shopping and went in the store as you first enter where everyone was great.

So...four giant heads of presidents are carved into a mountain. You've seen the pictures, and it's so famous that you pretty much have to go. But don't overcook it in your imagination. It's four giant heads of presidents, and from the observation deck, they don't look as huge as they really are. But dig into the history of WHY those four were chosen. That's the hidden gem here. For example: Why Theodore Roosevelt? We know the other three, but why him? It's important. The memorial is free, but it costs $10 to park even a motorcycle. They have to raise money somehow. Ice cream shop serves Thomas Jefferson's personal ice cream recipe. Several buses of people dropped off and crammed into the line, so we didn't get to try it, but we heard it is good. Even with large numbers of people visiting the monument, you can get to the observation deck easily, and kind strangers will take your picture for you. Look, this is a "been there, done that" venue that you have to check off the list. It's pretty cool. Inside secret: If you drive nearby Iron Mountain Road (both ways), you will find at least two tunnels in the mountain that will frame Mt. Rushmore in the distance, and that's pretty cool. Plus, the road is twisty and fun.
$10 at the gate which I believe is good for that vehicle for one year.

This was my 4th and 5th visit to Mt Rushmore. It is awe-inspiring. There is a $11 parking pass that is good all year long- so make the best of it and visit multiple times during your time in the area! Stay for the evening closing ceremony. They call the past and present service men and women on stage to assist in taking down the flag. It gives me chills every time. You will not regret visiting!

This is one of those places you just have to stop if you're visiting South Dakota. It was also the least expensive of our stops. I think we paid $11 for parking, but everything beyond that (souvenirs, food, etc.) is up to you. This is an amazing piece of history that you truly have to see to fully appreciate. Pictures don't do it and the setting justice.
Loved the Memorial, not the mandatory 11 dollar parking charge which applies to EVERY CAR no exceptions. Get there early or expect to wait in line to get in.

Mount Rushmore is something to see. Was not expecting to have to pay to park, which was expensive. We paid $20 per car. There isn't much to do once you get in. You can walk around the base of the mountain and there are a few shops but nothing spectacular. We had an awesome view of the monument from the road leading up to it before you pull into the parking lot. If we had known we were going to have to pay to park, I would have just taken pictures for the road. Was great to see it but it's a one time thing.

This place is a symbol of American pride. Definitely worth visiting. Parking is $ 11 and is valid for return trips for up to an year. There are restrooms, the place is accessible for people on wheelchairs as well. The hike is easy and I saw several pregnant women. There were several who bought portable audio tours at the front.

We went early in the morning, not too many people yet. The view of Mt Rushmore is spectacular. Definitely go to the short film in the museum, it is concise and only 14 mins long. The grounds are beautiful and immaculate. Only $11 to park, no other charge.

The National Memorial allows you to learn as much or as little as you like. There's an educational video, lots of museum walking and reading of plaques... or simply take in the views. Sadly, the parking is unlike all other National parks and there is a charge of $10 per car.

Spent literally 20 minutes at the monument and paid $11 for parking. Honestly, I have to say this attraction is not worthwhile compared other landmarks in U.S. If you weren't drive pass by, it doesn't worth the money and time.

It seems a little expensive to have to pay $11.00 to park. There is a parking garage where you have to park and we couldn't find a parking space. Best not to go in the summer when everyone else wants to be there too. At least the $11.00 is good for more than one day. We went back in the evening thinking it wouldn't be as crowded, WRONG, even more people. We just drove back out content on seeing the memorial from a distance.

We arrived early in the morning to tour Mt. Rushmore. We last visited in the 1990's when the park was undergoing remodeling. What an improvement! I cannot say enough about the audio tour! Not many tourists were using the audio tour but it was so worth the $5 fee! There is a lot of walking if you take the Presidential Trail. My recommendation is to go to the left of the carvings so the stair climbing is less intense. If you use the audio tour, you will go this route. The film in the visitors' center is excellent to begin the tour. A private company operates the parking lot and there is a fee to park--about $15. We did not get to view the evening show due to weather but I wish we could have seen it. Perhaps next time? The cafeteria on the grounds was ok but sitting in the dining room with the view of Mt. Rushmore more than made up for the average lunch. Lastly, the employees at the Memorial (audio tour window, the gift shop and the cafeteria) were very friendly and helpful!
We hadn't been there since the parking, gift shop, etc was remodeled. Nice that the only payment needed is for parking.

I have been here several times during my life and it continues to be awe inspiring. Since my last visit in 1971, they have totally rebuilt the viewing area, and the visitor’s center and added a huge parking lot. The entrance fee for the monument if FREE, but you have to pay $11 to park. Walk around the visitor’s center and read everything then take the Presidential Trail walkway. This trail takes you to the bottom of the mountain for additional picture opportunities of different perspectives of the monument above. Very interesting. The trail is an easy walk but has some stairs up and down.

I haven't been to Rushmore since I was a teen. What they have done to make it a memorial is nothing short of superb. It's something every American should see and where it's located near Custer National park, Crazy Horse, the badlands, Wall South Dakota makes this a must see. The walk up is grand, the viewing balcony, sculptors studio and the 1/4 mile Presidential walk around loop is a must. You can get so close to the big stone sculpts now it's wonderful. And the informative talk in the sculptor studios is well done, not overly long and I learned things I had never known that is fascinating about Rushmore. I wish they would show a running loop of the movie about Rushmore in it's theater or museum. That would be awesome. Nothing showing when my niece and I were there for over 2 hours. The cafeteria is a rip off and the food is so-so at best. Stay away from the ice cream. Looks great, everyone has one, but for $5 bucks you wonder how you can screw up ice cream. I wouldn't eat there if you don't have too, but the dining area in view of Rushmore is just too tempting. Try to bring something and eat there. But go to Rushmore and see how great this country can do things when they want too.
The fee for parking is $11 and a parking garage is available. I miss the music It gave it a feeling of pride. Mount Rushmore is gorgeous, the facility clean but everything up there is overpriced.

A must see historical landmark! I would also recommend paying the extra $5 for the audio and walking tour, the history and knowledge you gain is definitely worth the price. All of the services-bathrooms, gift shops, snack bars, were clean and the staff was friendly. We weren't able to stay for the evening ceremony but the lodge we stayed at, did have a view of Washington's profile lit up and that was nice.
$11 to park, then free admission. The food there was cafeteria style, and okay in quality, but a little overpriced. But the view wasn't to be beat (Mt. Rushmore).

We enjoyed the Mt Rushmore monument. It was awe inspiring and you must attend the night lighting of the monument. The tribute to the veterans was also great. I would strongly suggest you arrive early. By 10:30 am the place was so crowded that it was hard to get around. You can see the place in a few hours. No cost to enter the monument but $11 to park. Well worth the drive and parking fee.

This was an amazing feature to see. I saw a show on the history channel and decided to pack the family and take them to see it. You do have to pay for parking, but it's only $11.00 per car. There are plenty of photo ops in numerous locations and they also have a gift shop with a vast array of items for everyone. I know you can see the pics on the internet and in books, but being there to see in person; no words. Even if you only do it once, it's a must. I only wished you could bring pets, but I understand why.
A must see and go to...worth the parking fee of $15 I think? easy to get to and gift shop was packed!

Mount Rushmore is one of those special spots in the U.S. that one should see before one dies. Allow at least one hour, but if you have two hours, hike the half-mile Presidential Trail which begins at the Grand View Terrace, traverses the base of the mountain for closer views of the sculpture, goes past the Sculptor's studio, then back up to the Grand View Terrace. The hike takes about 30 minutes. There is no admission fee...BUT there is a vehicle entrance fee ($11).

It is such an iconic place that we were glad to get to see it. The carvings and history behind them are very interesting. The parking garage seemed out of place for the area but I am not going to get my nose out of joint for the $11 fee. If it wasn't there would probably have to walk quite a way to get to monument. We ate in the cafeteria and the food was really not bad and not as over priced as I expected for a captive audience place. Was pretty crowded but it was July and that is to be expected so I was not surprised. We went back for the night show. The movie and program were good. The lighting of the sculpture was nice but I guess I was expecting a laser show like is done at Stone Mountain, another Borglum carving. It was really an out of the way drive for us but we discovered Wind Cave National Park on the way there which was beautiful and made the drive worth it.

You can't visit the Black Hills without visiting Mount Rushmore. See the monument. See the gift shop. See the museum. There is also a restaurant and an ice cream parlor. You definitely want to see the evening lighting of the monument. Very patriotic and moving. $11 gets you in for the year, so you can come more than once if you want.
Lots of fun and patriotism in this place. Go for the night show too. Liked $11 one year pass. Take the walking paths and go downstairs.

This is our third trip to Mt Rushmore, and this time we drove around enjoying the beautiful scenery in the area. By the way, it'll cost you $11 per vehicle, and no the national parks pass won't do, so you'll need to pony up $11 per ride. We were on motorcycles this time and decided to enjoy the beautiful scenery in the area (and in my opinion, unless you want to get a lot of information on the monument, you can see the monument without going in). We were on two motorcycles, so it would cost $11 per motorcycle, as the fees are per vehicle. It's a marvel of engineering. Awesome.

Visited on Saturday around 9am, it was less crowed. When we left at 12, it was way too crowed. Parking is $11 at the toll & valid till end of the year. The structure is impressive & gigantic. Take awesome photos. There's a amphitheater below. We checked out the museums, & saw a short documentary in a theater about the history of mt. Rushmore. Very informative, it was like 10mins long. Then you should definitely go on the presidential trail to get up close to the monument. The gift shops sell all sorts of clothing & souvenir.

You're driving to the National Park through the Black Hills & suddenly it's there! The sculpture itself is breathtaking & the history rich. $11/car load is very reasonable "parking" fee. Add the audio tour for $5 extra as you will get a lot more historic information than if you just read the few self-guided signs along the loop path. The history lesson is much more about the sculptor Gutzon Borglum & the how & why these four Presidents were chosen than the Presidents themselves. I was surprised to learn that several models of the sculpture were envisioned & Mt. Rushmore was not really carved but constructed by dynamite blasting, honeycombing & bumping. And the Presidents that we see are not really finished as originally intended. See, you really do need to get the audio tour! Another helpful hint is that there are MANY scenic opportunities to take unobstructed photos so you do not have to stop at the observation deck with all the other tourists.

Mount Rushmore has built up quite a bit since my last visit. The only fee is for parking ($11) for cars. There is a 3-level parking garage which does contain an elevator. Wheelchairs are available at the information desk located to the right before the Avenue of Flags. We ate at Carver's for lunch. The food is served buffet style. It is ok for a quick bite to eat. You should try the ice cream. It is very good. The large gift store contains a wide selection of souvenirs. On the downside, it can get very crowded. There was a tent located after the Avenue of Flags that sold Mount Rushmore t-shirts for $5. Plan to spend a minimum of 3 hours here - more if you plan to walk the Presidential Trail and eat.

We've all seen it in the movies and in print but until you go for yourself you haven't really seen it. This was my 2nd visit, the first being 30 years prior as a teen. Our daughter was excited to stop as well. The park is free. I read complaints about the $11 parking fee. Get over it. Everything is well maintained. $11 is nothing. Make sure to go downstairs or take the elevator. The display on how they made the sculpture is very worth your time. If history us not your thing just skip it.

It was good to finally see this monument in person. They have an extensive gift shop and the food in the restaurant is good. It cost us $26.00 for two buffalo burgers, a beer, a soda, and two bags of chips. The monument is free and parking is $10.00 but you can't use your national parks pass for the parking. It's easy access to the monument from Keystone. They've done a nice job building up the road infrastructure and the parking facilities at the monument.
My family visited Mount Rushmore National Memorial for the second time on July 6, 2014, the first time was back in 2007. What can I say, it's cool to see. Too bad they charge you $10 for parking.
There's nothing to really add about Mount Rushmore that hasn't been said many times previously. We thought the hand held informational "wands" were worth the $5.

Great experience. Great exhibits, enlightening and educational in regards to our GREAT country and the presidents that this memorial represents! Admission to the parking/memorial $11 which is good for 1 year. A must see! Along with seeing the evening presentation and the lighting of the presidents, starts at 9PM

Every American should go. We made our trip on July 4. Grounds are well maintained and there is a nice museum dedicated to the sculptor. Plenty of areas for great photos. There are gifts and food for sale as well. Parking is $12 though.
I have visited Mount Rushmore several times, but it's beauty is always worth it. $11 for parking isn't great, but their souvenirs are not that expensive when you get inside.

We are so happy with our experience at Mount Rushmore. It was a perfect day and we hiked all over the park getting great photos. However, it was July 3rd, and it was so crowded. We felt the $11 parking fee is nothing compared to the high quality walkways and benches with so many different angles available to see the monument. The historic references and sculptors memorials really made me feel like I was a part of a very important part of American history. It was patriotic, moving, and I can go back because my $11 parking fee is good for the year.

If you're in the Black Hills, Mount Rushmore is a must see. An $11 parking fee will get your entire group into the memorial. The setting is beautiful and the monument and surrounding grounds inspire patriotism. If you can, take the Presidential Trial to get closer to the monument for some different perspectives. The museum is great as well. Our whole family enjoyed the memorial, including our very young sons.

The mount carving is really beautiful. The sculptor studio is well maintained with the detailed history and the difficulties faced during the carving process. There is only parking fee of $11 for the place which can be utilized throughout year. If you have time, do the presidential trail to get different views of 4 presidents. We visited again the next day for lighting ceremony. It’s worth a visit.

Although you can see this monument from outside the park, its great to see it from dead center on the grant view terrace or even closer from different angles while strolling on the presidential trails. Don't forget to bring the binoculars or you will miss some of the surface features of the presidential heads. There are plenty of brochures about the monument as well as the ecosystem here on the ground so make sure you look stop at the visitor center. Audio tour which I think is the best way to go about the park is available for $5 and produced by the Mount Rushmore Society. There's a sample of audio and map of audio listening stops on their website. There are also various other ranger led talks and the night lighting ceremony so make sure to participate and you will learn about Mr. Borglum and the monument. For the bad news, the day we arrived, the place was packed. Lot of people stop here including tour buses so except lines at popular areas, presidential trails, sculpture studio, and Indian tent area. There was even a line to see the heads through the giant boulders so be forewarned.

Nothing special here. Nothing to do at the site, MAJOR tourist trap. Its as if all of the stereotypical Americans congregate here. Go to the Badlands or visit the city at the bottom of the mountain or go deep into the black hills instead. Only worth seeing if you're already in the area. The camping grounds surrounding the monument looked awesome.The drive up the mountain was better than Mt. Rushmore, 16A or 87 are great drives. $14 to park? No thanks, see if from the roads. If a concert (or event) was held here, it would be awesome. Then it would be worth the trip. Understanding this review could get some heat, it is a great American Monument. I'm saying it looks just as good on the history channel.

It was great to finally see this in person. I was not disappointed at all. The cost was either $11 or $15 for parking ( I'm getting all my parks confused) but worth it. You get some great photos inside the national memorial that you can't outside. There is a trail that you can walk to get different angles of view and photos. They do a night viewing also that was neat to see. Inside the main building you can watch a video about the sculptor and carving the monument which was very informative BUT if you stay for the night viewing they replay a video that is almost exact to it. Surprised by that but still great to read the information boards, watch the video, and see this awesome creation with my own eyes.

We have always wanted to see Mount Rushmore. We didn't expect to want to spend more than an hour there. See it and take a few pictures. We read that the monument was free but we had to pay $11 for parking. We were kind of disappointed in that since we didn't expect to stay long. While driving up 16A we saw Mount Rushmore from the side of the road and lots of people taking pictures. We pulled over and took some and enjoyed the view. It was very cool to see but we didn't expect it to be any different if we paid to go in and get closer. All three of us were ok with what we saw so we didn't go in to the park.

My third trip to Mount Rushmore was as moving and memorable as the other times. In fact, I erred on my first visit when I telephoned the Natianl Park Ranger and inquired about the best time to do photography. He told me that the morning light was the best light for good photography. So I scheduled a night's stay in a Rapid City hotel with the idea of doing a photo shoot the next morning and then moving on to my next appointment. Unforunately, it had rained heavily and when I drove to Mt. Rushmore just after sunrise, the mountain was fogged in! I could see nothing but gray clouds. On THAT trip I left disappointed and a wee bit frustrated. SO, plan on staying at least two nights, because I am not the only person who has never seen the sculpture because of fog in the mountains. Nevertheless, this recent visit was very special. The staff was cordial and the National Monument is neat, clean, well maintained, and well staffed. When I purchased an autographed book in the book store, the clerk thoughtfully advised me to go to the upper level gift shop where Mr. Clifford was greeting visitors and signing books. The 93-year-old man was one of the workers who "carved" Mount Rushmore. What a treasure he is and what a pleasure it was to meet one of the original workers on the very site where his contribution made a lasting, historic impact. My only reservation about visiting Fushmore had to do with extreme costs of hotels in Rapid City. The cost of overnight accomodations was nothing short of greedy businesses gouging visitors during peak season. Of course the winter months are subject to such harsh weather, business probably drops off dramatically. Clearly the summer months demand a high return to ensure a profitable year for all the businesses in Rapid City and surrounding areas. I am a huge proponent of capitalism, with supply and demand controlling prices, but $300 a night for a $120 room is gouging! To resolve the problem, we drove about an hour away and stayed at the Circle View Guest Ranch overlooking Badlands National Park. Mount Rushmore is a Mecca for American families in the summertime and it is an impressive monument honoring Roosevelt, Washington, Lincoln, and Jefferson. It is a grand, aesthetic feat in the Black Hills and one that should be experienced by every American who has a penchant for history. While it makes for a magnificent road trip, do your homework so that you are prepared for dreadfully inflated hotel prices that will break your bank unless you are well prepared for the cost ahead of time! Allow at least a full day to see the mountain, in the event that weather clouds your view.

If you are in the area, this is a site you don't want to miss. As you drive by, you can get a good view of the monument from the highway but don't let that stop you from visiting the monument. Parking is $11 valid for a year. The rest is free.

Well thought out traffic, parking, and facilities. Great entryway that showcases the state flages as you walk toward the monument. Guest appreciation day offered numerous tif items for 5$. We enjoyed seeing it again since our last visit was in 1978.

$11 to park but you get the pass for the rest of the year which is great unless you are in a rental. The associate it with the car not the person. It was a great place to stop with the kids but not as impressive as the many photos you see. I'm told that once Crazy Horse is done these four head will fit into his armpit.
I did not pay the $10.00 to park, but you can see the monument from the highway. This is a super cool section of South Dakota.

We stopped by here on a cross-country trek. I had never been, though my husband had visited as a child. It was beautiful to see Mount Rushmore at dusk and into the night. The mountains were beautiful at sunset. Once it is dark enough, there is a ceremony to light the mountain. There is a large visitor center and the lower floor plays a video about the presidents depicted and when they did/why they were chosen. As the video plays the mountain is gradually light and is beautiful! We took the back road to the attraction which was definitely worth the view and ate dinner in keystone. There was a small fudge shop with delicious chocolates! Glad we made the stop! The national parks annual pass is NOT valid here. There was an $11 fee for parking, no military discounts.

My family just visited Mount Rushmore with some close friends of ours and we thoroughly enjoyed our time here. With only paying $11 to park, it's actually a really great value. After we took our obligatory photographs, we decided to take the Presidential Trail to get a closer look. Right as we started down the path, a mountain goat walked out in front of us to fill up on some of the vegetation which made for a great photo opp and naturally our kiddos loved seeing some wildlife up close and personal. Making your way around the walking path gives you other opportunities to get closer to the monument and provides great opportunities for photographs if you're into photography. Otherwise, it's just a nice walk in nature somewhat away from the crowds. There are quite a few steps but it's well worth the time...plus then got to see the Compressor House and the Sculptor's Studio which was really interesting and full of great history. Lastly, the park rangers were super helpful and friendly. One of them gave us all a QR code which linked to a great app about Mount Rushmore that gives you some behind the scenes look at the memorial. All in all it was a great day and worth the trip!

We spent Independence Day learning about patriots. Go early, we went around 6 am and waived through without having to pay the $11 parking. We shared the park w a couple of families and had a terrific photo ops

Mt. Rushmore hasn't changed in 32 years but the environment in which it is displayed has, and not for the better. Of course, that probably was a necessity with all the tourists on the highway these days. Selling parking for a year at $11 per car is atrocious, when no one from out-of-state is likely to make a revisit within a year. Why not have a one time, or two-day, parking pass? Too sensible!?!

If you are from the U.S you have to at least see this once, considering it has some pretty honorable people carved into the side of a mountain. It's a pretty cool thing. I would suggest to do the Presidential trail because you get many different views of the monument while getting fresh air and seeing neat flora. Take your time here. There are some cool things to see and you will get a better experience if you see it all. I also like the fact that when you pay to get in you can use that pass for the rest of the year as long as you use the same car! Pretty neat for only $11.

You'll never forget this sight. And you will hardly believe how this carving in the mountain was achieved by such dedicated people before the days of computer tech etc. A fabulous daytime visit, good gift shop and some food/drink are available. While you can view for FREE, the parking is $11.00. Save the ticket stub and return for the evening 1 hr. prior to the night time illumination. The evening film and Ranger Presentation is stunning. The Visitor Center will also give you a perspective on the memorial as well. But don't miss the night illumination/presentation.

Pictures just don't do the drive up there and back or the scenery while at Mt. Rushmore justice. We actually went up there two days in a row. The first time was to see the "Lighting Ceremony" which was educational and enjoyable. Then we went back the next day to get better photos during the day. It cost $11 to park and that parking ticket is good for a year. There is no other cost to go there unless you buy soveniers or go to the resturant that is there. How ever many fit in your vehicle can go for a total of the parking pass.
Mt Rushmore is something to see. It's cheap....$11. Not a lot to do and not as impressive as crazy horse.

We visited Mount Rushmore National Monument when we were in the Black Hills. The setting in the hills was amazing. We paid our $11 (pass good till end of the year) and parked our car. We walked in, took some pictures, visited the museum, and watched the movie. It was a nice visit.

You can't be in the Black Hills area, and NOT go see Mt. Rushmore, and yet I have managed to do just that for years. Not this time though, we headed up on motorcycles, which was a pleasant little drive. Just a note, the parking fee is $11.00 per vehicle, so that can be an entire family of 8 in a mini-van for $11.00 (great value!), or just one, lone person on a motorcyle for $11.00 (not quite as great of a value). There were 5 of us, each on our own bike, so it cost us $55.00 for the group to visit the Faces.

It's awesome & it's something everyone should see if they can. We walked the trail (lots of steps) that runs along the bottom of the monument (& gives you different views of it) & takes you back to a studio where they keep the model that was used to make the actual carvings. I recommend watching the video they offer. (I think it runs about 15 or 20 minutes). There is a night time lighting ceremony which we didn't get to stay for but looked really cool in the pictures. There's also a $5 audio tour offered which we didn't do but a lot of people were doing. The rangers working in the museum part were very knowledgeable & had a lot of info. if you were willing to listen. Plan on spending 2-3 hours.

You would think this being a national monument and all that you should expect to stay a few hours. But really you pay the $11 to get in (per car), have a stranger take a couple of pictures (hint: ask a few different people because of picture taking skills or lack thereof), look in the gift shop and you're done. We were in and out in less than an hour and that was fine. It's still cool to look at and you've GOT to do it but don't stress out about needing to spend an afternoon or anything.

The last time I was here was in the late 1970s. It sure has changed a lot since then! The paved walkway is very nice, and the park is well maintained. If you take the walk on the Presidential Trail, note that whichever direction you go, you will have stairs! For $11, it was an excellent way to spend a few hours with the kids.

Yes, it is $11 to park your car, but after driving from Milwaukee to check out Mt. Rushmore, it certainly is breathtaking. However, the huge mountain you see pictured everywhere is just not as large as it really is. Though it was slightly disappointing, the overall effect and impressiveness was about the same. We returned at night to watch the short film and see the presidents lit up and this experience made the $11 parking fee seem worth it since it is good for 24 hours. While it may not be what you've always pictured, it is certainly worth seeing both during the day and at night! TIP: Arrive early at night to get a good seat for the evening program!

Truly a wonderful experience!!!! My family and I enjoyed the trail----watch the signs closely, it can be a strenuous hike for some, but it is beautiful. Don't miss the museum----very informative and interesting. The cost is very reasonable---$11.00 per car---you can't beat that!!!
Been here four times throughout my life, every visit seems to get better. There is a $11 vehicle fee that is good for the year. Walk the Presidential trail, it's a must.

While traveling around the Dakotas this summer, we had to make sure we saw Mt. Rushmore. Never would have lived it down if everyone knew we were there and did not see it. The sculptures themselves are pretty amazing when you take into account all the work that went into making them. A real engineering feat and the vision that was necessary was incredible. However, the day we were there it was very crowded and there is now a private parking concession. There is very little choice but to use the facility and it cost $11 to use it. We were not impressed that some private corporation is profiting off all visitors to a national memorial. We would not go back again just because of the parking situation.

Have a bucket list? Put Mt. Rushmore on it. During a six state summer vacation, we stopped off for about a week in the Black Hills area. Mt. Rushmore is an awesome place to visit. The museum has some really interesting history, pictures, and stories of this wonderful monument. I will tell you this though, in person it looked smaller than what we had imagined it to be based on photos you see of it. Take the little walking path. There are some great photo spots. If you have time, take the tour too. If you have younger children, there is a Junior Ranger activity that they can participate in (might take an hour or so) and at the end they receive a Junior Ranger badge and a "swearing in" ceremony. Our son loved that and it is something that he'll remember for a long time. The restaurant there is nice. Kind of cafeteria style. Not a great value for the money, but, if you are hungry, let's just say that it will fill the hole. Overall though, it is a wonderful place to visit and the history behind the monument is extremely interesting. While there is not an actual fee to visit Mt. Rushmore, it did cost us $11 to park. That $11 parking pass is good for a whole year, if I remember correctly, and it is per car, so, if you are there with other families, friends, family members, load up like a circus clown car and it will be less 'per person' to get it.

We came the second week of June and I think we beat a lot of the tourists. It was a lot less crowded than I had anticipated. The avenue of flags held my kids' attention as they searched for Illinois. The sculpture in the mountain is smaller than I had imagined, but still majestic. We ate in the cafeteria style food court. It was good, but overpriced since it's a tourist attraction. 7 bucks for a burger, without a side or a drink. The trail is what I enjoyed most. It's fun to view the presidents from all different angles. It really does give you a unique perspective. The ice cream shop was a hit after the trail. My son liked that there was a special Thomas Jefferson vanilla that you could order with his original recipe. It was 5 or 6 dollars for a large scoop. Be forewarned, it doesn't taste like your regular vanilla. It's almost a little eggy tasting. The gift shop was large and stocked with your average touristy stuff.

This was our first time seeing Mount Rushmore. The exhibit was very informative and gave a good history as to why these 4 presidents were chosen to be the carved heads on the mount. Seeing them was awe inspiring, rekindled a feeling of deep patriotism, and reminded us of how and why our country was born. There is no fee for the monument, but parking is on private property and costs $11.00 per vehicle so try to load everyone into one vehicle to save money. The parking pass is good for the year so pass it on to someone else to save on the parking fees. The monument is well worth the trip.

We somehow expected faces to be larger. The work was amazing, but the $11 parking fee was steep. Other than take some photos of the presidents, there wasn't much else to do. We spent less than an hour there. Glad we went to see it, but would not go back

In my opinion every American should visit this monument. The swell of national pride is indescribable. For our international friends and visitors, it is amazing to be able to have something like this to share. Visiting during the day gives great photo opportunity but, come back at night for the flag and illumination ceremonies. There is a film and a honoring of our veterans and current military personnel. Seeing the monument at different times of day with different lighting is really something. There is also a flag for every state and protectorate on display, a museum, a really nice gift shop, a book store and info center, a resteraunt, a snack bar and ice cream shop, and a bar. There are multiple viewing areas so, take your time and explore. The parking fee is $11 per vehicle, regardless of the number of passengers, and is good for one calendar year. This is the only fee. All other attractions and activities in the park are free, excluding food and shopping.

Mount Rushmore sounds like a hokey idea but again, on my second visit after many years, my husband and I found it to be spectacular. Of course it is crowded but the entry road and parking garages are extremely well done to handle the onslaught. The avenue leading up to the viewing platform is beautiful with plenty of places to sit. The Thomas Jefferson vanilla ice cream is wonderful too. So worth $11!

The drive getting to the park is beautiful! The park is easy to find and it was only $11 to park, which is good till the end of the year! We parked in the parking garage, in the shade, and had no trouble parking our truck. The views are spectacular! Even when you aren't looking at the monument! We got the usual pic of the monument and then walked the trail to get as close as we could. So glad we did! The trail is strenuous and not stroller friendly with all the steps! There were bathrooms, benches to rest, and places to get a drink if you needed it. When we left there we planned on going to the Crazy Horse which is just a few miles away. On the way there is a place to stop and get pics of Washington's profile! So glad we went that way! I'm 45 and this was my first visit. I'm so thankful I got the opportunity to see it!

We did not know what to expect from Mount Rushmore but this was a fun stop-off. Very patriotic. The view of the monument is spectacular. While it was kind of cold outside, we had fun getting out of the car for a while to get a good look. In the right light you can get some really dramatic photos. The countryside is scenic as well. We could not stay too long and we wish we could have viewed some of the events in the amphitheatre. Not very crowded at all but I believe we beat the peak season by a couple weeks. Parking was $11 and gives access all year long. I can imagine the parking lot fills up quickly in the summer.

Okay, so it's Mount Rushmore, and it's only $11 to park, but skip this stop if you want to have more time on the Custer State Park loop... Waaaaaayyy more fun to spend time at Sylvan Lake. Busy, overpriced gift shoppe and lots of wandering tourists oblivious to anyone other than themselves.

Had a wonderful time visiting Mount Rushmore. A really beautiful sight. Very fortunate to visit on a beautiful day. Not much of a crowd. The film and artifacts in the lower level was very informative. There are trails to walk around ( we didn't but saw many others doing that). There is no charge to see the monument but a charge to park. Ours was $ 11. Thought that was a little pricey. Had a wonderful time though at this must American landmark.

Only reason I'm giving this 4 instead of 5 stars is because of the parking fee....$11 is pricey especially considering they don't give you a discount with any of the park passes. They tell you it's good for a year, but can't imagine many people using it more than once. That being said, park is beautiful! Presidential loop trail is not accessible and if stairs aren't your friend, you will have difficulties.

Obviously you will have Mount Rushmore on your list of things to see and do while visiting the Black Hills. It really is an amazing sight to see. When you stop to think about how long ago this was done and HOW it was done, it is stunning. Yes, there is a fee of $11 to park. Pay it and go into the park. Don't do yourself a disservice and skip it because you don't want to pay the $11. There is a junior ranger program available and my girls LOVED it. Wonderful museum, sculptor's studio and gift shop. They have a place to get ice cream and treats. Every person we encountered that worked here was wonderful, particularly the park rangers. Your parking pass is good for six months after you purchase it, so you can go back again and again while in the area. We went around 4 in the afternoon on 6/11/14 and it was not busy at all. It is a great place in America, a must see!

The $11 parking fee was the best bargain of our two-week vacation as we made six trips to the memorial during our three-day stay in Keystone. Neither of us had ever been there so we really took advantage of our visit. We attended the lighting program on Memorial Day. Very impressive and moving with so many veterans in attendance. This is an amazing sculpture and you really need to walk the Presidential Trail to see it best. One of the original drillers happened to be in the gift shop on our last visit and since we had already purchased his book he was kind enough to sign it for us.

Stopped here on our out west to the Badlands...this is a MUST SEE for certain. It is only $11 per car & the pass is good for a years worth of visits too. It is truly so very grand and spectacular site to see. We walked the whole trail all around & back. We even visited the sculptors studio too. This is just a wonderful place to visit even if only once in a lifetime. Wow!

Parking/entrance fee is 11$ which would normally be just fine to see a national treasure by when we arrived to a cloud covered monument with no refunds available we were disappointed. But we hung around and took the hour presidential trail hike into the cloud covered forest ; which turned out to be quite a lot of fun. Upon returning to the viewing area we were delighted to find the cloud cover lifting and revealing the spectacular sight of Mt. Rushmore. What an amazingly awesome experience.

I really wanted to see this on our road trip. I felt like it would be unAmerican of me to be so close and not stop. I was told ahead of time that it's not as big as you see on tv so I was expecting that. There really isn't much to do though other than stare at faces on a rock. I actually asked my boyfriend how long we had to stay there. I read that the museum was nice but it was closed when we were there. We did looking at the state flags and guessing which one was which. I also expected the $11 charge and don't think it's something outrageous like other people have said.

My wife had always wanted to see Mt Rushmore so I drove an extra 600 miles on our trip so she could. The first big shock the Government needs to review is parking. It is a concession and costs $11.00. Way to much. The next thing they need to review is their poor compliance with ADA. It is a struggle on crutches or even in a wheel chair in places and the whole place is paved. The monument is what it is and has always been. A tourist attraction for South Dakota and nothing more. There are many gift shops with junk to treasures. Our highlight was the Buffalo we had at lunch. Well prepared by nice folks with a great place to eat, and it was the only thing that was not expensive. My wife who had wanted to come here for 30 years was terribly disappointed. I would not plan a trip just to see this.

This monument is a true national treasure everyone should see. It's difficult to believe that people were able to carve such life like faces into the side of the mountain. We were there on a cold and very windy day, so were not able to hike up any of the trails, but enjoyed the view from the cafeteria that had wonderful bison chile that day. It also may be the only place in the country you can still buy a postcard for $.35!

Words are hard to find to express the patriotic inspiration I felt while visiting our National Memorial.
