If you love this Country, this is one place you need to put on your bucket list to visit at least once in your lifetime. The four men memorialized here built this Country and the story behind Mount Rushmore is one to make some time for. The Park Rangers are great and there are a lot of things to do and see here. From the short, half-mile, Presidential Trail hike that gives photographers numerous views to the informative Visitor Center, gift shop and café, there are all sorts of activities. Although there is no charge to get into the Memorial, there is an $11.00 parking pass required which is good for the calendar year. We arrived at 6pm, spent a few hours taking pictures and going through the shops and then went to the lighting ceremony at 9pm. The evening festivities are well worth staying around for. Don't miss this part of our national heritage, this part of who we are...

This attraction is a must see for any western adventure but don't waste you $11 going inside the Park. Your national park pass does not get you in free & there are nice spots to photograph the attraction from the highway. My suggestion...pull over, snap your photo, and move on!

This is a great cheap must see for families. This was my first time back in 6 yrs and every time I go new interesting displays along the way. No fee to get in except for parking which was only $11 per car.
Things have changed here in the last 5 years.... You now have to pay ($11) to park and walk up to the monument... Not a huge issue just remember it when you could just park and walk on up..

Definitely one of those must see things! The monument is beautiful and the plaza seems nice. We went in early May around 7pm and we pretty much had the place to ourselves! The mountain goats that wander around we're great to see as well! Parking is $11 so not bad for the overall experience.

We showed up mid day and the fog covered the monument completely. We drove a whole day to see this so were disappointed. We paid the $11 to get in, which is good for a year! So we came back early evening and the fog cleared off and on during our visit.

Well, as much as I looked forward to this, just my 2 cents, I wasn't impressed. Could have stayed in the parking lot, the view is the same. If you're military, it's not free with your National Park/Monument Pass, but Badlands is. Family still liked it. My son was running around looking and pointing a lot. The cafe food area is, well ballpark food at best. Crazy horse is much better still in our family opinion. But, you should still see one of our National Monuments and at least I did.

My husband and I have been here before but this was a family trip and was a new experience for our 2 boys 6 & 8. Parking is on $11.00 and is good for the same vehicle for the rest of the year! They've increased parking and a spot was easy to find. Not more than 20 feet from our parking space were 2 mountain goats feeding on some grass. We were able to get within 5 feet and take some pictures!! Great start...then we walked up the stairs...we checked out the first visitor center..had some great info and we got our boys "Junior Ranger" books there. We continued up the walkway lined with flags...to the viewpoint. AWESOME! Then we went downstairs to the larger visitor center - watched the short 10 minute movie about creating Mount Rushmore and looked at the exhibits... Fascinating and wonderfully done. In addition, the Rangers were all super nice and informative. Our boys were able to finish the "duties" in the Junior Ranger books, took an oath to protect national parks and wildlife and received the badges!
I'm gonna preface this with saying $11 is a bit dumb for seeing what was intended to be free. That being said, any state park will charge!
It was on my bucket list, and well worth the drive. The only bad part was parking cost $11. That was a rip-off.

We were here in 1985 and too much has changed Even though considered a national park, parking concessions are private which $11.00 for a one year parking pass. More souvenir shops plus the faces on the mountain to us, were starting to fade

When visiting friends last August in Saskatchewan, we drove to Devil’s Tower en route to Rapid City. Macular surgery and other health issues prevented timely publishing this review, so don’t think the following photos are misplaced. Though this phenomenal national monument has no admission fee, there is a parking charge of $10, but you can get an annual pass for $11. I recommend the annual pass, and return several times if you’ll be in the area for a week or more. (National Park or Access Pass is not valid, as this is not NPS.) Walking along the Avenue of Flags to the first observation deck, I loudly asked my Canadian friend, “Which carving do think has the biggest schnozzle?” Brian considered for a bit too long, just as I had planned for hours. “Go ahead, Brian. Pick a nose.” He didn’t get it—even when people nearby guffawed.
Really cool and there is a ton of other attractions within 30 miles. I'm glade I stopped. I'll be coming coming back. The 11 dollar parking pass last all year.

There’s just something about this historic place. It truly makes you feel great to be an American. I didn't at all mind the $11 "parking fee". I believe in supporting our state and national parks and monuments! Everything was very well kept and clean. I WOULD have appreciated some plaques or reading materials outside the museum to clue us in to some of the history. A five star visit as it is one that everyone should do sometime and the day was just that perfect! Love this place! Plan on coming back next Christmas!

We visited in January so there were no crowds, in fact I would say it was exclusive for our visit. We talked with 2 different park rangers who were so helpful we felt like family, thank you. We were not sure what to expect but we were wowed by its awesomeness, really, what a great sight. The parking is a fantastic convenience, I didn't mind paying $11 as it was steps away from the gift shop and everything. The restaurant food was great even thou there were 4 people there at lunchtime, including us!

This was worth the drive from Kansas! Parking is about $11 but we went on Christmas eve (was open) and there was no parking fee :) The displays and exhibition rooms were worth it, if you are one to not just take the views but spend some time reading. Wheelchair accessible.

The Visitor Center is very informative on the history of the mountain, the art behind the mountain, and the history since then. If you are counting on getting in with the National Park Pass, think again. The parking has been contracted out, so there is a fee. Good news is that the fee works for multiple days. If you get the chance, get a cone of Thomas Jefferson's ice cream. The BEST ever!

Little foggy when we visited but still visible. Very impressive. Nice historic center and gift drop. Nice entrance and accessibility. Parking is easy and convenient. Easy wheelchair access. Parking $10 even with Sr pass.

Visiting Mt. Rushmore is always a very interesting and exciting event. The sculptures are fabulous and the museum is well worth the visit. Lots of good history for the children. Take many photos---it is a truly picturesque location. Entry is free, but the parking is $11---kind of an odd way to get revenue for the monument?

I visited Mount Rushmore in the 1950s as a child. I remember being fascinated with the faces of former presidents so high up a mountain. Going back in my 60s did not diminished the excitement of seeing this marvelous work of art. It was a beautfiul day with dark blue sky and white fluffy clouds. The national park's facilities were beautiful and modern. We enjoyed seeing the videos and visiting the museums about the making of Mount Rushmore. I enjoyed walking the trail loop to the foot of the mountain. Renting the $5.00 audio tour was worth it if you are doing the trail loop. Do note there are a lot of stairs leading to the scuptors cabin, but there were plenty of benches to rest.

Visited Mount Rushmore on our way out west the second week of September. We planned it so that we would get there a couple of hours before sunset - giving us time to look around and then see the light show after the sun went down. The drive to the Memorial was beautiful, the parking convenient and the area well-kept and clean. There was a bookstore and food on the site. The walk-way was easy for people with mobility issues. It led straight towards the mountain, giving you plenty of ways to set up your photos, and was lined with state flags. I would have liked to have seen it the way it was before they put in all the concrete, concessionaires and $11 parking fee (your national park pass is not honored). We didn't take the opportunity to do so, but I understand there is a trail that takes you closer to the monument. There is seating on an upper level over-looking an amphitheater below. After sunset, a park ranger came out on the amphitheater stage and began a video that was part history lesson, part flag-waving rah-rah. The video concluded and he droned on and on about how we must put aside our differences as a country and come together as one nation. Huh????? I didn't expect to be chastised on my vacation! What a downer! Finally, they turned on the "spotlights" so that we could dimly make-out the faces of the presidents. What a let-down! Not at all what I expected and not something that I'll visit again. The next day, as we were driving along the scenic roads in the area, we came across numerous viewpoints to take better photographs than we were able to get at the monument itself. If you've never seen it, go - but don't expect much.

Visiting Mount Rushmore is an inspiring experience. If you are traveling and get into town in the evening, go to visit for the ranger talk and the lighting of the monument. The sound in the amphitheater is crystal-clear. Like other national parks, the ranger talk is excellent. I suggest taking a basic pair of binoculars to help see the detail of the monument carving. We also went back the following day and did the walking tour in the morning daylight (the path isn't lit at night). Rent the audio guide for $5. It has over 20 stops and provides and incredible amount of information and is well worth the price. Admission to the monument is free, but there is a one-time fee for parking (we paid in the evening and just had to show our receipt the next day).

This was one of the places my friend and I had to stop on our cross-country trip! While the monument itself is free, the parking, which is managed by a contractor, is $11. The monument, exhibits, and overall presentation are excellent! I wish we could have stayed longer, but we had a schedule to keep. It is amazing that these were carved out of the rock, and are quite impressive. It is an American icon that everyone should see once in his or her lifetime!

I loved the entire monument, it was better than I imagined. It is beautifully designed and engineered, easy to get around, see and take photos. There is even a place for people to pull off and get a photo if they can't or don't want to pay the $11.00 per car to drive into the actual monument. We chose to go in and it was worth it. Bathroom facilities were easy to find.

I've wanted to see Mt. Rushmore since I was a kid and it definitely did not disappoint. An awesome sight and great setting. We did the $5 audio tour and would highly recommend it. Made the Presidential much more interesting and shared interesting tidbits of information. The evening lighting ceremony is emotional and patriotic. A definite must see for all.

The drive up is absolutely beautiful ... when you get there it is $11 for parking - which is very organized and seems very secure. Then a short walk up to the viewing area ... there are rangers everywhere to answer questions. You can view the sculpture from the viewing area - quite pretty or take the trail to the base of an even better view. Also you can go down to the artist studio for info on the making of the sculpture and models. The only draw back was the gift shop had a sign out that said "American Made" - we went in and there was only a very small section American Made

We visited this one late afternoon to seeing the evening lighting presentation. It was awesome. There is a nice amphitheater to sit or you could stand at the back. While we waited, we watched the sun go down and it was a very pretty sunset. They had a nice presentation and then slowly illuminated the memorial with a very nice musical score playing. We chatted with several people. We came back the next morning to walk through the sculptor's area and the walking tour. That was nice. While there is no entrance fee, it did cost $11 to park and there is no other place to park. However the parking fee was good until the end of the calendar year. Nice Visitor's Center.

A spectacular sight only experienced in books until this visit. Every American should visit and learn who built it, why, and the entire background of how it was sculpted. The $11 parking fee is very reasonable, since there is no entrance fee. Tip for parking - use the Lot 6 (not covered) on the top level as it is a very short walk from the entrance. Recommend the movie to help explain the memorial, and also do the Presidential Trail walk (only a bit strenuous on the uphill portion). The walk gives you views of Mount Rushmore that are not available from the viewing platform. Did not get to see the lighting ceremony (nightly at 8), but am told it is very impressive and patriotic. And one last tip - have the Thomas Jefferson ice cream (only vanilla) in snack building - his original recipe and it is great!

We saw Mt. Rushmore initially on a cloudy day. It didn't interfere with our pictures. But with your paid parking entry, you can enter the memorial for a year, so stop in again when it's sunny. On your parking pass ($11 USD) it prints out the make of your car and the state on the plate, so it is nontransferable.

Yes we paid $11 for the car. It was just me and my husband. Price is good for two people or a car of $20. So $11 isn't unreasonable to see such a patriotic grand memorial. We attended nighty lighting ceremony and then viewed it the next day as well. We were told our $11 pass was good until December. Only too bad we live in PA! Worth the price and don't miss out on side view when exiting monument.

at just $11 early bird special at the parking, you will see the marvels of men with none of the heavy equipment that todays contractor's have. what can I say that others have not, I do not know. there may be something that we may over look, the flag stations at the entrance o yes look for your state or the American territory where you live for a little bit of history.

When you visit South Dakota make sure that you pay a visit to Mt. Rushmore. Its a sight that you wont want to miss. A huge mountain with the 4 presidents faces in the granite side of the mountain located in the Black Hills of South Dakota.At the National Park there is a gift shop. restaurant etc. Also underground parking garage close to Mt. Rushmore. As you approach the mountain you walk under the avenue of flags which is very impressive.Free to visit the attraction but a $10.00 parking fee.

You might think you get a good enough view of the monument from outside on the highway. Think again. It is well worth the $11.00 parking fee, to go into the park and see all the extras. You even get to go back for the lighting ceremony on the same parking ticket.

This is one of the "must see" sites in America, particularly early in the morning or in the evening. No entrance fee, but $11.00 for parking, which is good for an annual pass, if you want to return another time in the year. Early morning light provides excellent shadows for photos, rather than the wash-out that occurs mid-day. With evening comes a lighted opportunity of the monument, adding artificial sparkle. Take time to visit the designer's studio to learn more about the history and fabrication efforts of the monument.

Mount Rushmore is one of those American attractions that everyone should see once in their lifetime. Set in the Black Hills the drive to the monument is just as incredible as the monument itself. It will cost you $11 to park but its worth it. We did not have much time to be there but I would recommend taking 2-3 hours to do the trails around the monument. You won't be disappointed.

This is one place you have to see. I've seen this place in advertisements, movies and photos but you have to see it in person to appreciate the amount of work involved and the Beauty of this landmark. $10 entry fee to park but its well worth it. Beautiful viewing area and good place for photo ops and a walkway that takes you right up to the base of the mountain. Very patriotic feeling when you are there. The monument is also lit up at night til 10 pm. Take binoculars to view the faces and you would be amazed how much detail and how finished the faces are. Park is well maintained and staff was friendly and helpful. You could tell they enjoyed their jobs.

Majority of reviewers cite the beauty of this Memorial as outstanding and it truly is. We usually use our Natl. Park Senior Pass but for Mt Rushmore you are charged $11.00 for parking and I concur, a small price to pay for a great day. We had the honor of meeting Mr. Don "Nick" Clifford at the visitors center gift shop. Mr. Clifford is the last living Mt Rushmore worker and at 92 years young, it was a pleasure to talk with him. Your parking pass allows you to return for the evening ceremony. With the faces lighted and a presentation by the Park Rangers, this is truly moving ceremony. As a veteran it was fun to be called onstage with my brothers and sisters to be recognized for our years of service. Both the day and night visit offered numerous opportunities to meet and talk with our guests from other countries, a great honor.

There's nothing I can say about this memorial and the area in general that hasn't been said a zillion times. You have to see it to believe it. The only thing that still bothers me and always will, is the FEE that they charge to park!!! It's supposed to be a FREE monument / memorial but you have to pay $11 (2013) to go there!! What a horrible political move that was. They were building the new plazas and parking ramp when I was working in the Badlands in 1995 and I wrote several letters to the superintendent at Mt. Rushmore about it and was told that the then $8 parking fee would be dropped once the ramp was paid off. Well, now it's $11 and there's no end in sight. I guarantee that Mr. Borglum is rolling in his grave at this travesty to charge people to go to a "free" memorial to the four Presidents he took the last 17 years of his life carving. The guy at the entrance said that our $11 parking pass would be good for ONE YEAR, but on the back it says that it expires at the end of the year. They really need to get their act together on this, for those of us who might actually be back more than once a year it's really bad PR for those who run this otherwise breathtaking and mind-blowing carving. You will not forget seeing this whether it's your first time or your hundredth time.

We found this attraction very interesting, although there was not a lot to see or do. A movie and museum (interesting on the history) were on the premises, as well as the standard gift shop and snack bar/restaurant. Parking ($25) was near, very convenient and plentiful. Other than the figurines, there was not much else to do or see. I believe you could see everything in less than an hour, if you so desire.

Ah, I always read the negative reviews and consider them. I took away the idea that the parking fee was unfair; the surrounding structures were garish, and the carving blocked from external viewing due to the money-grubbing erection of buildings to force your payment.

We arrived in the area late afternoon and before visiting the monument took some time to drive around the area. We booked a hotel in Hill City SD and it was about a 15 mile drive to the monument and Keystone SD. The towns were small and reminded me of movie sets at places. There are plenty of campgrounds and numerous hotels in the area. We visited the monument in the evening/night and then again in the morning. There was a parking fee of $11 but it was good for the same car until the end of the year.

Similar to the Grand Canyon, you most appreciate the accomplishment and atmosphere when visiting this memorial in person. Don't forget your camera and, if 62 years of age or older, your Golden Age Passport for free entry to this National Park.
Super busy place. It’s free to get in but parking is $ 11 and not really worth it for the 10 minutes you’re there. If you’re in the area you might as well stop but don’t make a special trip for it.

This was our first trip to Mount Rushmore and we loved it. Dress for the weather, wear your walking shoes & bring a camera (smartphone cameras work well). There's no entrance fee and parking is $11 per car. The lot was full but we found a great parking space near the entrance anyway. The monument is amazing, huge and a must-see! The area is pristine with trails, tall trees, lots of greenery (we're from Arizona), an educational center, amphitheater-like area, state flags and magnificent views. It's a photographer's dream. We learned so much about our history and each president, too. There is an Ice cream shop & cafe & a gift shop. Steps & an elevator, too. As we drove through town, there was a motorcycle event going on and it was an awesome sight. I would recommend this trip to everyone! This visit was on my bucket list. And, we did it all in about five hours! http://www.nps.gov/moru/planyourvisit/feesandreservations.htm

everyone should visit if they can possibly do so. While you can actually see the mountain carving from the road, you really should pay the $11 per car parking fee and visit the very informative visitor center.
We've been here 4 times and the newest renovation is wonderful. The parking garage is great even though they charge $11 per car which includes admission. The visitors center is very informative.

We really enjoyed our visit to Mt Rushmore especially the lighting ceremony. It made us proud to be Americans! A short film is shown before the ceremony begins highlighting the most significant events of each of the four president's terms. At the closing all veterans and active duty military are asked to come down and help with lowering the colors. Then each member gave his name and branch of service. Really glad we went! Only fee was a $11 parking fee. Stop if you get the chance, you won't be sorry!!

The $11 parking fee is a bargain. We spent several hours walking the grounds and learning about the carving process and history. The entire area is well designed for smooth flow of visitors. I would recommend avoiding the over-priced gift shop, restaurant and ice cream shop. We asked questions of several of the staff around the monument and they were extremely knowledgeable. Definitely a good visit.

...but the reality of the infrastructure they built around it is not for me. The model and talk about how it was created was pretty good, but the rest of the displays didn't really give you a good feel (updating the displays could do wonders). Parking was $11 and it doesn't matter if you have a parks pass or not. Truly fascinating that this could be made in the era it was, but not a little diminished by the buildings, etc. they've surrounded the cliff with.
This is an awesome place to view, a must see. Pictures do not do it justice, in person it is awe-inspiring. Go see it!! I think we paid $12 for a carload?

Your NPS pass does not work here. The parking is owned by a public benefit organization that is not part of the NPS. They charge $11 for parking your personal automobile. The parking structure is divided into 6 sections, section 3 is closest to the entrance to the venue.

Load your car full of people and pay the $11 to park! We left one car in Keystone and packed the whole group into one car. I see reviews about the parking fee, and it really could be worse--they could charge you to see the whole thing. There were 5 of us in the car, so really, it amounted to less than $3 a person. You can't beat that! It is something you are going to want to check out-- The sculpture is amazing, I love the entrance, it's beautiful and you get an overwhelming feeling of patriotism. We had fun finding our state along the pillars of flags, and loved the trail that gave you a different view of the sculpture. The gift shop was nice, and we had fun just hanging around and enjoying the scenery. Cough up the money for parking and check Mount Rushmore off your bucket list!

This was the reason for visiting South Dakota. We loved the monument, visitor's center and the hiking trail. Everyone must see the monument during the evening for the lighting ceremony. Made me proud to be an American. There is no fee except the $11 parking fee which is good for 7 days.

This place was on my bucket list. I was on a family vacation in Denver and decided to make the seven hour drive north to see it. It was worth the long drive. The monument is a beautiful site to be seen. Especially if you are an American History Buff like me. I love each and every one of the presidents depicted on the granite. There is an $11 parking fee but if you make the trip to this place it is more than worth it. There is no price for getting into the park. The park is beautiful! Also, there is a big gift shop that will sell you souvenirs (my recommendation is to get them elsewhere because they are expensive there) For those people that complain about souverniers not made in the US, then good luck finding any because everything has been outsourced by the US Corporations. The grounds have a great restaurant and great ice cream shop. There is a pathway to walk up and get really close to the faces. If you go to the right it is over 200 steps but if you choose the pat on the left it is an easy paved walk way. Like I stated before, an American Gem not to be missed. Loved every minute I spent on those grounds.

We arrived at our motel in Custer, SD, around 5:30 p.m., and decided to take in the evening program at Mt Rushmore National Memorial. While this is part of the National Park Service, many of the improvements to the memorial have been funded by donations to a non-profit support group and Xanterra. One of those improvements is a $17 million parking garage; so there is an admission charge for the parking garage of $11. There are no discounts for NPS annual passes, senior passes, etc. There are a number of exhibits and things to do, and a food court for meals. The evening program takes place in the amphitheater, includes a 20 minute movie that emphasizes the four presidents carved into the mountain side, lighting of the monument, and a special tribute to the veterans and active service members in attendance. While we didn't have time to do everything, we enjoyed the evening program.

You've seen pictures your whole life. Go and see it! We watch the film and went in the exhibit hall. expect to spend at least one hour. I think it was $10 for one car. Worth the time it took to fly and drive there. We drove from SLC and saw other sights. Expect lots of motorcycles if you go the first week in Aug,

By happenstance, we arrived in Rapid City to tour Mount Rushmore the same two days and my wife's cousin from Colorado. We toured together. We arrived early, around 8:30 AM, which was great since it was not yet too crowded. The day was absolutely beautiful - clear blue skies (after a storm with hail and a small tornado the day before!), The carving and the overall facility is spectacular. The artist's studio is very interesting as is the walkway of flags. Entry is free, but parking is $11 per car which interestingly is good for a full year! The parking ticket has the date and most of your car license plate number on it, so if you wish to return, maybe at a different time of day (or dusk) or another day, parking is free IF you save your initial ticket. Access and viewing is easy although there are a fair number of steps down (and back up!) to the studio, but it’s worth it. My only slight disappointment is that the actual carvings seemed a little smaller than I expected,, but yet it was spectacular and well worth the trip. I highly recommend it.

I guess I get the point of getting to see this and being proud of what it is, however I am sorely disappointed in the park itself. First if you buy an annual national park pass, this park does not honor that for entry. Their "claim" is that they don't charge for entry only parking and its an "independent company" that collects the parking money, so even though its a national park you will pay $11 to get in even if you have the annual park pass! While we were there it was packed!! The kids exploration area was closed, so we were not able to do that. And, without paying extra for the "tour" Most of what you could do it hike around and take pix. By the way .... You can see a GREAT view from a pull off on the road coming in to the park and there are a lot of free places to hike while driving around the parkway roads. The only reason I can even give this a two is that there is a little movie you can see telling about Mount Rushmore and I've heard if you go at night it's fun to watch the lights, however we were not going to be there at night, so we were not able to enjoy that.

My family and I arrived at Mount Rushmore in the morning, shortly after it opened. We got a great space in the parking garage. There is no fee to get into Mount Rushmore, but there was a fee to park ($11.00). From the entrance, we walked through the Avenue of Flags, which was quite nice, with Mt Rushmore as the backdrop. We visited the Visitor's Center, where my son got a booklet to fill out to become a Junior Park Ranger. As we walked around, we found answers to the questions in the booklet. He then filled in the answers and turned it in to the Park Ranger at the Visitor's Center information desk. My son was then given a certificate & a badge & sworn in as a Junior Park Ranger. He thought that was awesome! We all enjoyed the information and displays at the Visitor's Center. Also, we walked the Presidential Trail, about as close as you can get to the mountain. I got some great pictures! The trail has ALOT of steps. The Sculptor's Studio was nice as well. I was very happy that there was a vendor table set up when we were getting ready to leave the monument that wasn't there when we came. The table was set up as a "Guest Appreciation" day and all the items on the table were being sold for $5. So we were able to score some Mount Rushmore t-shirts & coffee mugs at a great price! We were at Mount Rushmore about 2 hrs and as we were leaving, people were pouring inside the entrance. We were happy to have beat the crowd and people were waiting to get our parking space!

One of our aims in taking a road trip to the western US was to see Mt. Rushmore at least once. We had a gorgeous, sunny day to view this spectacular icon of Americana! A person can just go and look and be satisfied or spend hours here. We went down to the sculptor's studio which involves going down and up several flights of stone stairs, but it is manageable for most. At the studio, a guide gives about a 15 minute talk on the history and making of the mountain. It is well done and not tedious. We then walked the trail that views the other side of the mountain (to get a better view of Lincoln's face). There are many vantage points from which to take pictures, both on and off the property. (I think my husband got them all!) There is an $11 fee which, when paid, is valid until the end of that year. This is a must-see if you are near the Rapid City area.

It's Mount Rushmore- everybody has to go just to say that they've seen it! Parking is $11 which is the only cost. Souvenir show had outside stand selling t-shirts for only $5...don't take a baby stroller on the presidential trail like I told my wife!

Many times places are overhyped. This place isn't. Once you get out of the tourist trap Keystone, the park and monument are wonderful. You pay an $11 parking fee (per car) but everything else is free. Don't miss the movie and museum. We walked the presidential trail and really enjoyed it although it does get a little strenuous.

This was my third trip to Mount Rushmore and every time it amazes me more and more! For the first time, my party did the walking - listening tour. For our party of 4 it was $15. (I was with 2 of my friends and my 14 year old and they let us do the family price! Very nice!) The audio tour was amazing and you learned so much more about the making of Mount Rushmore. Staff was very willing to answer any questions we had.

What more can be said? I went as a child and then took my 3 children. Parking is $11 (good for whole calendar year) and admission free. Nice museum with video on how it was made and about the workers. New trail leads you up the mountain for some awesome views. Very well laid out. It's about 2-3 hour deal.

A definite must do. We did the presidents tour which is a self guided tour. A must do. We also did the audio tour which cost $5, but gave a lot of insiteful information that I otherwise would not have received. Last time I was there was 20+ years ago. Allow at least 3 hours to complete if you are going for the full effect.

The site is quite inspiring. There is a State Flag lined, walk in, entrance-way.....that leads to the most common photo spot. A museum, sculptures, ice cream, outdoor eating and cafeteria style cafe is all available. It will be busy! Parking cost is about $11, National Parks Access cards are not valid as there is no entrance fee, only a parking fee. Visit....it's a chance of a life time.

The busts were smaller than I expected, they have a large parking garage they charge $11 for, the walk to the base of the mountain if free, if you want a self guided audio it is more, but they were out of them at the time
Really neat to see monument in person. Beautiful entrance lined with state flags; great viewing area, informative exhibits. However, parking is $11 and the site is crowded!!

We went up here on a Tuesday! Parking was 11 dollars but its good all year! It wasn't too crowded! Mount Rushmore looks a lot bigger in photographs! They have a bunch of flags as you walk in. They are doing some construction but it wasn't a hassle! We were told to come back at 730 for the light show at 930....That was a major disappointment! All it was the singing of star spangled banner, a video and then military persons came on stage, said there names, audience clapped for them, The light on mount rushmore turned on, and it was over!

This is a wonderful sight/site. The audio tour is very long but filled with information about the people and events surrounding the carving. Our brains couldn't handle all info. and so we skipped the last four chapters. Our 14 year old daughter was a little disappointed in the size - she thought it was going to be larger. The movie isn't necessary if doing the audio tour but a must see if not. For only $11 per car, you can not go wrong with this.

Stop and pay the $5 for the audio program. It gives so much more than the information posted along the way. You get American History, the history of the building of Mt Rushmore and short talks by people who helped build it. You spend hundreds or thousands of dollars to go there and you miss out on so much because you wanted to save $5.. Yes the parking is also $10 but that allows you to come back for the night lighting show either the same night or a different night. The Presidential Trail is fantastic but make sure you take water as it is over a mile with lots of steps. We spent almost four hours there to do the Trail, the Video and the Museum. Posted by grinandbrakeit.com

I have waited over 20 years to see Mount Rushmore and I'm so glad I got to see it with my little family. We walked the presidential trail and that was really cool. If you are going to walk the trail I will make a suggestion; when you are facing Mount Rushmore go to the left and start the trail that way. You are going to be climbing stairs and if you go to the left there is mostly climbing down stairs. If you start at the right when facing the Mountain you will be doing a lot of climbing up the stairs. Also, if you have small kids and are walking the presidential trail don't bring a stroller. You will end up carrying it up and down stairs which will suck for you. We saw a couple doing this and felt so bad for them. Stop in the Sculptor's Studio on the way back up. If you have one of those National Parks Passports there is a different stamp for the Sculptor's Studio. our kids (4 and 6) really enjoyed the Jr. Ranger Program there as well.

You needed a National Park pass (cost $10) and there was a $10 (I think) parking charge. Otherwise, entrance was free. I was happy that I brought binoculars--so we could all see the carvings close-up. It was awe-inspiring as you would expect. We returned the next night (used same parking pass--so it was free) to see a patriotic movie and the Presidents' faces lit. It was very worthwhile. And don't miss seeing the sculptor's original model in his studio--though it is a longish walk down (and then up) a lot of steps. A definite item for your bucket list.

Visiting Mount Rushmore will cost you $11 (per vehicle) and allows you to see some great American history and inginuity. There is a half mile wooden trail that leads you to view the presidents. There is a gift shop and a small restaurant/ice cream shop as well for those who are looking for a bite to eat. The views are great even though you are not allowed to get real close to the monument. Lots of good photo ops.

This is a free attraction, but $11 to park. It is well worth it. We watched the video, which was very informative about the building of the monument. We walked the Trail from left to right which appeared to be easier than the other way according to the people we passed. Check out the sculptor's museum. And of course they have a nice gift shop.

Mount Rushmore was on the tail end of our Yellowstone adventure. We decided since we were "up there," we had to drive over to Mount Rushmore so the kids can see. When we arrived, there is a $11 parking fee. We headed up, saw the mountain, oohed and awwed, snapped some family pictures and went into the museum downstairs. We probably spent a total of one hour viewing the mountain and touring the museum and headed out. It was a quick stop, we were tired and just ready to head home the next day. Maybe if it was the beginning of the trip we would have gone back to see it lit up and there was a trail of some sort off to the right that you could hike. I'm not sure where it leads, but it would have been fun if we weren't at our wits end by that point. We're glad the kids experienced it, though!

I went here as a small child, about hmm..25 years ago? So when we were passing through the area en route to Yellowstone/Tetons, I wanted to stop here. I assumed it was free, but as we were driving along I-90, I was doing some research on my phone only to find that they now have a giant parking ramp in the area and you need to pay $11 to see this.

Great family attraction. If you can, do the hike path its very scenic and enjoyable. only $11 for a car load and the pass lasts the entire season. The cheapest thing we did while in the Black Hills and one of the most memorable.
Just awesome. Go to the evening lighting also. Price included if you go during the day. Everybody should see this first hand. Beautiful park.

This was my second time here and it still remains a must stop. There has been considerable development/improvement since 1985, all necessary to handle the huge number of visitors. The facilities are clean, the food acceptable and the grounds clean and safe. Don't miss the introduction film and do walk the trail up the mountain to get a closer look...there are many steps but it is best approached from the sculptors display center. Spend time looking at all of the historical artifacts and displays as there is much history here besides the rock work. Yes, parking is $11 but that is a small price to pay to see a most impressive work dedicated to our country's patriotic past.

Cross country trip NYC to Seattle with kids, had to go to Mount Rushmore. it really is a must-see National treasure. Get the $5 audio tour. Bring a good camera. if you're American or American-friendly you'll enjoy. Great history for kids. The surrounding area is beautiful and cheesy, but no lack of things to do for whole touristy family. I've been three times, and though we didn't have the time to stay for the light show this time... plan your day around being there for the nighttime show.

Visited on July 5th - was crowded as expected but the place is organized to handle crowds so we never felt uncomfortable. Parking was ok. $11 parking fee is super reasonable for something this significant.

We visited Mount Rushmore on July 5. We planned on going on the 4th but the lines of cars were wrapped down the street and we figured it would be way too crowded. We didn't spend much time there, maybe an hour. I assumed it would take a lot longer than it did. After driving past it several times during our trip, I almost felt like I didn't need to actually go in and see it but it was pretty neat seeing it up close. The gift shop had some really nice items and when we were there, there were two drillers signing books. I also appreciated that they sold $5 t shirts, hats, bags and cups outside the gift shop under a big tent.

This memorial could be underwhelming for some. You stop, you look, you leave. We were worried this would be the memory our kids had so we paid the $15 for the audio tour. It gave us 4 listening devices. We took our time and enjoyed the tour. The parking is $11 and is a garage structure. if you have a topper on your car, they will make you park on the roof and you get no shade, something to consider if you have pets. They won't let you bring your pets into the park.
This is a must see if you are visiting America. It was very crowded when we went The parking price of $11 was reasonable. Also their was a sale of t shirts for $5 which was nice.

Even if you're not terribly patriotic, this HAS to be on your list of things to see and do! How they carved this monument in a mountain of granite is amazing! Make sure you take the time to go into the exhibits and museums and read about this. Totally PHENOMENAL!!!!! The sight itself is incredible and the drive in is one to be savored and enjoyed. It takes an effort to get there but more than worth it. For the $11 per carload entry fee, you can spend literally hours enjoying the spectacle. You should budget at least two hours to walk the 1/2 mile Presidential Trail and stop in the museums and exhibits. You can easily spend more but make sure you enjoy your time there. It is truly a wonder.

The park was great. There was a small fee to enter but that pass is good for a year. I won't be using it again but the $11 was worth it. We went to the movie before we walked around to the viewing points and it was nice to get a little background of how they built the monument. We did go back later in the evening for the light show which was inspiring. The July 4th holiday is a couple days away there were quite a few veterans around and the acknowledgment that was given to them by all of the people was amazing.

We went by Mt Rushmore on the way to Yellowstone and it is really neat to see it in person. Parking is $11. No other fees. We had to go because we were going right by there, but I won't feel a need to go back. Being there gives you a sense of being American with all the flags and celebration of presidents. We took a few photos and stayed about an hour. Did not really have time for much more, so I can't comment on the hike or audio tour. Gift shop is big and loaded with stuff.

Go for the evening show. I just went and the show was at 9 pm and lasted until about 9:40. Also see the movie and the exhibits on the sculptor. Be aware that entrance to this site is through a vendor, not the National Park Service. The vendor has constructed a parking structure, so there is an $11 charge per standard vehicle for parking at the site. I believe that allows you multiple entries on future days as well. If you have a NPS pass, it won't work here.

I know people complain about the $11 to park, but guess what? Unless you have an annual pass or a senior pass, you are going to pay to enter any national park. We spent about 2 hours at the park, taking photos of the faces, walking around the trail, exploring the sculptor's studio and going to the gift shop. I'm happy to spend the money to keep the upkeep of the park. If you don't want to spend the money, you can see the faces from Rt. 244, but I think it's totally worth going into the park. You can use the pass for up to 1 year, so if you decide to go back a few times during your stay, as long as your have your pass, you don't have to pay again. Something to keep in mind. Worth the money.

This is definitely something that everyone needs to see in their lifetime. We got here in the afternoon and surprisingly there wasn't a lot of people, we did not stay for the lighting ceremony that was held at 9pm. The price to get in was $11.00 per car I personally think this was cheap. There were trails, but we did not go on them.

What can I say that has not already been said about Mount Rushmore. This is something every American should see and experience at least once in their lives. From the mountain itself to the stories about building this great monument take the time to see everything while you are here. Listen to the stories told by the workers, read about each president, walk the presidents trail and truely enjoy this place. The cost to ge in is minimal. ($11 for parking and you are in) I have been here a couple times with my kids as they have grown up and we have all truely enjoyed it.

I have always wanted to see Mount Rushmore and it didn't disappoint. Pay the $5 to get the audio tour. It is full of historical information and details about the sculpting of the monument. It is certainly was an amazing feat. Take the few minutes to view a movie narrated by Tom Brokaw that runs every 15 minutes. Be sure to walk the Presidents Trail for a multiple view of the monuments. It's an easy 20 minute walk.

It is hard for something like Mount Rushmore to live up to expectations since you've already seen so many pictures and heard so much about it, but the carving of four great Presidents on a South Dakota mountain is awesome and inspiring. Here are a few tips. Parking is $11 but it's good for a year so if you are staying nearby come back a couple of times. We went during the day and came back for the evening lighting ceremony. Don't miss the Presidential Trail that will give you a very different view of the Presidents and leads to the Sculptor's Studio. The food at Carver's Café is better than you would expect. We met one of the original carvers in the gift shop selling a book. Take your time because there is a lot to enjoy. Hats off to the NPS for taking great care of this wonderful monument.

First, the entrance fee of eleven dollars per vehicle is quite reasonable considering the upkeep of the park. The parking garage is very user friendly, and the ice cream was quite tasty, and not much more than what you would expect for an ice cream chain. We did not try the food but the cafe had quite a selection, and there seemed to be plenty of seating considering it was a Saturday during lunchtime. The gift shop and bookstore have several interesting and possibly difficult to find selections, for fairly decent prices. The grounds and restrooms were clean and staff was friendly. We did not take the walking trail nor did we visit the Lincoln Borglum Museum as we were already beat from a busy day in Keystone, but we intend to head back up the mountain tomorrow at nine o'clock in the evening to see the Monument lighting ceremony. For just five dollars, you can partake in the audio tour and learn even more about everything.

I can't top the other wonderful reviews about this gem. It is really well organized and very impressive. Be sure to see the night time lighting ceremony. If you're able to handle steps, the Presidential Trail is an essential part of the visit. I also highly recommend the audio tour. Everything was top rate. No fee for the attraction, but $11 for parking.

Great experience to see one of our nation's historical landmarks; well maintained facility with a restaurant and gift shop, trail, etc. It seemed strange to go in for free but pay $11 to park. We drove by early in the day to visit and decided to come back later in the day for the lighting ceremony. Ranger presentation and video are interesting. Only disappointment was that the parking pass we purchased earlier in the day (which was still good) didn't allow you to get around the line getting into the place. Definitely a must see when in the Black Hills area.

Very impressive night program with the lighting ceremony, veterans dedication, film and talk by ranger. amphitheater full and expected problems getting out, but got out quickly. Well worth the night time visit. Program starts around 9 but get there before 8:30 for seats. Parking is $11 which is only fee and parking pass good for one year. We plan to go back today to hike the presidential trail.

We considered just viewing it from various places along the road rather than actually driving in and parking. I'm glad we paid the $11 parking and made the visit. We walked the Presidential Trail which offered some interesting viewing angles. The sculptor's shop was very interesting including the model and we got there at the right time to hear a Park Ranger give a 15 minute talk that was very informative. Driving the Mt. Rushmore road trip (local guide map) it was amazing how many different times we could view Mt Rushmore. I especially liked the long distance view from Norbecks's Overlook.

I have been to Mount Rushmore three times now, and it is does not get old. I especially love the first glimpse of the stone faces peeking through the trees as you wind your way up to the parking area. While the grounds have continued to be developed over the years and made more accessible, the efforts have only enhanced the visitor's experience. This visit was a quick stop en route back home, but it was the highlight even though the visit was short. Had we had more time, we likely would have grabbed a bite to eat and then stayed for the lighting ceremony. Instead, we took our time on the walking loop (both directions can be a bit strenuous with the steps, but we would recommend starting the trail by going to the right since stone steps seem steeper than the newer composite steps that you'll encounter the rest of the way), and then perused the large gift shop. Public parking fee was $11 per vehicle, but that is good for the year.

Mount Rushmore is an amazing sight. All cars must pay an $11 parking fee. Senior Pass is not good at the Park. However, there is no other "fee" once through the parking gate. You must really enter the Park to get a good sight of the four presidents and take good photos. Be sure to see the short theater film describing the sculpture and how the images were positioned and blasted from the rock. There is a path/walkway that winds around through the trees below the presidents and leads to the sculptor's work studio. We did not stay for the laser show at night, but we were told it is a great experience. This is one of those "must see" monuments for anyone residing in or visiting the USA.

Mount Rushmore lives up to its billing as a national treasure. You can't grasp the enormity of the monument unless you see it in person. There is no charge except for the $11 per car parking fee, which is good for several days if you want to return. You can see it for free at several spots on state Route 16. There is also a trail that runs close the mountain for a closer perspective. There is a lighting ceremony every night which is worth attending.

Why is it that a non-governmental entity charges $11.00 for the only parking near the National Memorial Mount Rushmore? That pretty much spoils the entire reason for having national parks. Private companies have no business controlling access to our national treasures.

The fee for this is to park. It's $11 for any vehicle, motorcycle, car, etc. No military discount, etc. Not so great, but there is a lot of maintenance involved in the monument. The viewing floor up top is very fancy from floor tiles to lights. Inside there are videos and displays with information about the making of the monument, each of the presidents, and the surrounding areas.

Mount Rushmore has always been on my bucket list, and it did not disappoint. The best thing about being in the area is that you can see these men everywhere. Take some time and view all the different areas in the park to see the figures. The lighting ceremony for me was a must. We went two nights and the better place to see is the seats above the auditorium by the elevators, just not the first row. The best place to hear is on the auditorium floor. We got there by 8 to get to our seats, the ceremony started at 9. We looked around a little while my husband saved us seats. The highlight of the lighting ceremony is the retiring of the flag with the veterans or current people serving in the armed forces. The lighting ceremony was very informative and patriotic. Make sure you view the movie, see the sculptors studio, and walk the presidential trail. If you have kids the must do is the Jr Ranger program, my 10 year old loved it. My fourteen year old also did it. You have to get the book from any ranger anywhere in the park, and when you complete it you take it back to any ranger. The ranger will ask them a few questions and then they take an oath of a ranger and get a badge to wear. A great program and it focuses the kids on learning something other than just looking and not learning! The park spends a lot of time on the making and history of Mount Rushmore, which is all centered around Borglum. As you make your way around the park and the exhibits you really start to feel the passion of Borglum and what he wanted to do. The park also has a great gift shop, one of the biggest and best in the area we saw. The ice cream shop was ice cream, nothing special. The food was good and not overly priced. Do the presidential trail had lots of steps but well worth it. Like my husband says you can always stop to rest! Parking was $11.

Took returned from a trip with the family to Mount Rushmore! I remember going when I was young with my parents and sisters and really enjoyed mine now! The whole atmosphere is still amazing that people carved this in the mountain! You can see Rushmore from the outside roads but well worth to pay $ to park and get up close!

I've grown up in SD and have traveled all over the US. We've gone to many National and State Parks. I still love Mount Rushmore. What a great piece of art - carved into hard rock. A great patriotic tribute to this wonderful nation that I love! I so glad to be an American. It is beautiful to walk the trail around and take so many photos. I like to take a blanket with the kids and get some ice cream. The gift shop is nice too but we don't always go in. We go here every time we are in the area. You pay for parking and it allows you to get in for the rest of the year. I think it is $11 per car.

So, I'd always wanted to see Mount Rushmore. It is AMAZING! We were so lucky that when we got there it was a little bit overcast. The faces are so defined and it is just an awesome piece of America. The park is really first class and the trail around the park is a nice way to spend some time at the park. The sculpter's studio is pretty interesting, but the real draw is the actual monument. We left and went back that night (the $11 entry fee per car is good for a whole year!) for the lighting ceremony. It was a very reverent and inspiring ceremony and especially cool that all past and present servicemen were invited to walk to the stage for the lowering of the colors. It was really great how respectful the huge audience was throughout the ceremony. It is a really beautiful monument, outdoor theater, park, etc.

This is one of the places you read about in your elementary history book. You think I will see it one day but you get side-lined and go to the beach. I finally made it to Mt. Rushmore and I'm so glad I did. When we first got there it was raining in the mountains so there was a lot of fog. We couldn't see anything and then when some of the clouds moved we snapped a couple of pictures. I also thought they did a good job with the museum that contained pictures and video explaining how the mountain was completed. Don't miss the museum and the film that tells the story of Mt. Rushmore. There is also a path that you can walk and see different angles of the president's heads. The gift shop had a Customer Appreciation day while we were there. I was able to get t-shirts and a coffee mug. The cost was $5.00 each! That is hard to beat.

National Park Pass not valid here - you'll pay to enter and park. Very good and affordable late dinner in the cafeteria. Moving lighting ceremony with all singing and honoring service men and women :)
What a great place to take our young kids. 11 and 12 years-old. We rented the audio tour and for $15 for 4 of us, it was worth it.

If you are just interested in seeing the president's faces in the stone, then save the $$$ for the parking fee and pull off the road as you approach the attraction from the town of Keystone and look at them there. Inside, there is a gift shop and lots of exhibits and a movie to watch and I don't know what else. W

After the disappointment and expense of tourist-trap (and waste of money) Crazy Horse monument, Mt Rushmore was great. I didn't want to leave. The park rangers even gave me the best route back to Missoula. Unlike Crazy Horse, it's possible to get very close to the actual carving for photo ops, and learn fine details of construction. $11 what a deal!

Haven't been here in over 20 years, the park service has done a great job with the facility. I just don't like spending $4.50 for a soft serve cone, seriously, the only advice is, eat before you come here, the vendors here charge way too much!

It had been almost 20 years since I had first visited Mount Rushmore. I’m sad I waited that long. It is truly breathtaking. The gift shop has a nice selection of souvenirs; I love the books on South Dakota history. We walked around the Presidential Trail, and on the back side is the sculptor’s studio. I bought some postcards, and the historian was helpful and answered all of our questions. I’m so glad I went back as an adult. There is a large parking lot that costs $11, but is good for a full year. Not too bad for a couple of hours of entertainment.

The National Monument itself is free to the public, but you pay $11 per car to park. This is good for that car for a year. After you have viewed this inspiring place and walked the trail to get different views, be sure to return at night. There is a half hour program followed by gradually increasing illumination of the mountain. At the end of the evening program, veterans were invited on stage to participate in the lowering of the flag. A must see if you are in the area.

I left Ohio and drove to South Dakota to see Mount Rushmore, something I have wanted to do for 20 years. It was worth every mile and every dollar I spent on this trip. It is an awesome sight and I made good use of my time while in the area and went back two days before I left the area. In the gift shop I met Don "Nick" Clifford, he worked on Mount Rushmore from 1938-1940 and he wrote a book with questions from people he met over the years and his response(s). Very nice touch to my visit. One other thing I loved about the area was it was not commercialized at all!!!

We first saw the figures from two miles away and my first thought was OK, we've seen this, now let's go somewhere else. But the family wanted to do the tour, so we paid the $11 parking fee and then rented the $5 audio tour - DO THIS! The $5 was very well spent, the audio tour gives you the history, the background, profiles of the people, and really makes the place come alive. This is not just four faces on a mountain: it is a monument to the qualities that make America great: freedom, justice and equality for all. This is time well spent.
Save the eleven dollars and view it from the road....we paid and parked to walk up the beautiful walkway and figured the money goes to a good cause of upkeep...

We stopped here on our way home from Yellowstone. It was so exciting to see the presidents faces as we were driving up the drive. It cost $11.00 per vehicle, which I thought was very reasonable. I was so awe struck at seeing Mt Rushmore in person after seeing it so many times in books and on tv. However, I was a bit surprised at the size....I imagined it to be larger. We spent about 2 hours there and my children earned their Junior Ranger badge. There was a video about the making of Mt Rushmore, which was very interesting. And there was also a museum with various exhibits that were interesting to our entire family. The gift shop was very big and had plenty of souvenirs to pick from. There were also trails available to explore, but we were limited on time. I think this is a must stop for every family!!!!

Mount Rushmore is definitely a place to be seen with your own eyes! You pay $11 for parking, but entrance to the monument is free and your parking pass is good for a year. Upon walking up to the monument viewing area, there are state flags lining the way. It gave me chills, seeing all the flags with the Presidents faces in the background, not to mention it is a great photo op. There is a walk around the grounds where you can get several different vantage points along the route. It is actually quite breathtaking to see in person. I didn't do the audio tour as I didn't realize that was an option when I was there. My only criticism is that there is not a film to view during the day. You have to go back at night to see the film at the lighting ceremony. I went to the lighting ceremony. When I got there, fog was completely covering the monument. For about an hour, it lifted right around the faces. A few minutes before the ceremony was to start, the fog covered it again. The ceremony began with a 20-minute film. Just as the National Anthem began, the fog lifted and the faces were lit up. It was spectacular and I highly recommend it, even if it is a foggy night! You never know what will happen.

Sure, we've all seen or read about Mount Rushmore but to actually be there in person was quite thrilling. Although we had a National Parks Pass that gets us into national parks for free, we did have to pay $11 for parking. We had our dog with us and since he couldn't accompany us to the actual monument, he had to stay in the car. I suggest parking in the lower level of the garage with the windows mostly open to keep your pet cool (leave fresh water for him too). My husband and I walked the trails around the monument and even a few trails outside of the official monument area where we saw mountain goats in the distance. At night, we returned for a special salute to veterans accompanied by video and the lighting of the monument at night. The park ranger asked all the veterans to come forward and selected 6 (my hubby included!) to retire Old Glory for the evening. It was an exciting day to be part of such iconic America.

You probably traveled to South Dakota in part to see Mt Rushmore - so don't get put off by the $11 parking fee 9 (Charged to pay for the new garage to accommodate all the visitors that they get in season). This is a major landmark in the USA and everyone who has a chance should see it at least once. The facilities have been recently rebuilt, and there is a beautiful stone walkway leading to a viewing platform for the monument. There is also a nature trail that takes you closer, as well as leads to the artists studio - be prepared for a bit of a hike, but it is worth it if you are able. If you are serious about taking perfect photos, get there before mid afternoon, before the shadows start to affect the monument.

Don't forget to do the Jr Ranger program! My girls 7 and 9 totally loved it! It allowed my husband to go read all the signs in the visitors center and I helped the kids do their booklets. The girls learned a lot and had fun earning their badges. And it's totally free, get your tax dollars back! ;)

First, you should know that parking fees at the monument ($11.00minimum) are mandatory...no senior free admission. The buildings up to the faces remind me of a grey, lifeless, concrete fortress and there are throngs of tourists. That being said, the faces themselves are true marvels of both art and technology and are a part of our heritage. Better, fewer tourist filled photographic shots of the monument are to be found on the wonderful road to Custer Park from Keystone. Frame the faces through the forest or through a stone car tunnel. Just keep your eye open on this auto tour and you will come home with great shots of Mount Rushmore and no shots of the tour bus crowd.

We stopped here on our way to Yellowstone. It is much like the Grand Canyon in that after you've seen it ... its time to go. We paid $11 to park and were in the park maybe 30 minutes. We met some folks from Indiana (always happens) and took a ton of pictures. Then we took off for the next site.

This was the reason we flew out from New York and it did not disappoint. No fee to get in, but you do have to pay to park. So very stirring and majestic. The audio tour was great and a bargain at only $5.00. The Presidential Trail was a bit of a hike with the warn weather- not that long (maybe a 1/2 mile) on a paved path, but the stairs did leave us huffing a bit... still well worth it. We came back at night for the closing ceremonies... so very stirring. Tip- come a bit early to get a seat.

Mt. Rushmore is a special place! Be sure to use the audio tour that is available. It is $5 per person and well worth it. If you are able to walk up and down numerous steps, take the full circle that gets you closer for even better views. Parking was $11, but the park is free. It can get real crowded in the mid morning and appeared to be less so in the early afternoon. Allow 3-4 hours for your time there. Be sure to see the 14 minute movie that details the history of the project. Great outing for the entire family!

Great Memorial, laid out beautifully. As you walk towards the sculpture down the aisle of flags the view is fantastic. No charge for entrance, but there is an $11 parking fee. Food is available in a very nice cafe style restaurant. If I go again, I would stay for the lighting ceremony, which everyone says is fantastic. There are two pet exercise areas either side of the parking lots, just in case you have your pet with you. You cannot take your pet inside the memorial.

I was amazed at the beauty of Mount Rushmore. Did not realize in our initial looking for attractions how much there would be to do and see. This is a great place to capture beauty and scenery. The kids enjoyed the hiking and the statues. The price to get into the park is only $11 and if I remember correctly it is good for the whole year.

We had a terrific time visiting Mount Rushmore. The facilities are fabulous, plenty parking and the amenities were clean and easy to access. We got great photos and in general had a lovelyrelaxing time. The snow was melting and we enjoyed the streaks on the faces of Mount Rushmore. The museum was interesting and the gift shop had something for everyone. It was well worth $10 for a car load. We had some disabled folks with us and everyone was comfortable going up the steps and hill. The flags were a nice finishing touch and educational!

Visited with my wife and Son, and we watched the movie and then took the path that leads closer to the monument and also goes to the sculptors cabin. What a great experience and a great place to go on the 4th of July. It was pretty crowded, but still worth the visit. The $11 parking fee wasn't too bad, and it's good for a year, so we are planning on coming back one more time before we go home.

Fun to see the monument which is a short walk from the parking lot. $11 for an annual pass is reasonable, but the weather is a bit hit or miss the first part of April so upon arrival it was clear, but after about 2 minutes the fog rolled in and you couldn't see anything. I would definitely do it again if I'm ever in the area. Very pretty.

I did not mind paying the fee to enter the park which was $11 because the structure is very big, beautiful and impressive. The park itself is very well taken care of and reverent with all the flags of the states leading to the area where you can see the sculptures very well and take very nice pictures. I like shopping for souvenirs from all these attractions around the world and they have a very large variety of items there. The good thing about going to Mount Rushmore is that Rapid City has a lot of things to do so it is not just seeing a big mountain with the faces of Presidents. I mean it: there is A LOT to to there. The sculptures themselves are very simple. The artist did not use of many traces to make his point. Reminds me of Egyptian sculpture actually. Their eyes impressed me the most. I could stay there for hours just starring at every trace carved in that mountain. I hope you go and have the same good impression I had. Don't be cheap. It is worth driving up there to the park. No, you cannot climb those heads. Just enjoy the view!

I never been here before, and while waiting to pick up a load on Monday we decided to visit Mt. Rushmore especially since learning it was 1/2 hour away and semis sans trailers could also park. We went in the off season so the town of Keystone looked like a ghost town, everything was closed. Nevertheless, it thought it was cute and I imagined it crowded in the summer. There is no fee for the park per se, but there is parking fee of $11, and I really loved that it also serves as an annual pass, that way one can visit again and again, that was a nice surprise. It is definitely amazing and inspiring just to imagine what it took to make this monument happen. One can't fathom such ingenuity and such desire to honor history-changing presidents. The park is well kept, it's informative, and accessible. I really liked that it's clean and well maintained, and I never though I could enjoy it as much as I did.

So finally we can take off this site on our bucket list. It was an awe experience being able to see it by yourself. We went there early march, so it's a little bit cold, bring jacket and prepare for layers. Parking is $11 but is for the whole year admission.

The Mount Rushmore National Memorial is a sculpture features the faces of four American presidents: George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Theodore Roosevelt, and Abraham Lincoln, sculpted by Gutzon Borglum and his son, Lincoln Borglum. The lighting program takes place at approximately 9 p.m. nightly (May-September) in the park's amphitheater. No entrance fee, but paid $11/car parking fee which entitles us unlimited entry to the memorial for the calendar year.

Mt. Rushmore is something everyone should see. It's truly stunning in person. The presidential trail that leads up to it is worth the walk. If you go right after walking down the walkway where the state flags are presented you will have to walk a lot stairs to get close to the base but if you go left there is a large ramp that leads up to the same area. Either way it is worth the walk. There is a platform area where you can take photos and Mt Rushmore is right above you. Plan on 1-2 hrs. There is a small museum that is included in the admission (it's $11 to enter the monument per car). Not much else to do here, but it's worth the drive and a must see while in South Dakota.

Mt. Rushmore is almost a duty to go and see for any American. It is a beautiful testament to the American dream. If you can get there close to the evening ceremonies in order to see it during the day and when they light it up at night I would say that's the best. The evening ceremony is touching. Parking is $11 but that is good for a full year. Otherwise, the rest of the memorial is free.

Pay for parking; not covered by Access Pass. Attraction itself is free. Avenue of flags is pretty nice. Be sure to watch the short video. Entire facility is accessible. Encourage you to walk the trail to the mount from left to right, as it is less strenuous as the other way. Plan to spend a couple hours there, plus the lighting ceremony.

Worth the trip and the $11 parking fee (bring cash as the credit card reader wasn't working at our entrance booth -- we read ahead of time they only took cash but that turned out not to be true, officially anyway). I heard from many sources that it was much smaller than they expected, so I expected it to be small and it was, then, larger than I had imagined. I wasn't disappointed at all. The Presidential Trail is a must too. It gets you much closer to the monument and boulder field and affords you a number of less-cliched photo opportunities. We arrived a little before 7:30 on July 15th which gave us plenty of daylight to walk the Trail and be in our seats by 8:25 for the 9pm night-lighting program. If you want a decent seat, get there by 8:30. Like a movie theater, the prime seats are in the middle and upper areas. You probably don't want to be right at the front, and that's what was left by 8:45. The program featured a brief talk by a ranger (including reciting the Gettysburg address), a video about the four presidents, the lighting of the monument and the retiring of the flag with the help of all the active and retired military members in the audience (which was a really nice touch). We bypassed the visitor center but spent a little time in the gift shop and restaurants and both were perfectly fine and exactly what you would expect. This is an iconic stop and must-do if in the area.

My first visit to Mt Rushmore was awe inspiring. I had seen photos of the mountain in books for 50 years, but nothing can prepare you to see it first hand. As you're driving up the mountain, you get a little peek of it up on the right side. If you have never been here before, its worth the visit. I walked around quite a bit and got some great exercise in the process. I enjoyed going reading all the material about how the mountain was carved, and all its history. There is a visitors center and a gift shop you can educate yourself and bring home a souvenir. I went on a weekday and apparently is the best time to go. It was not very crowded. There is no entrance fee but you do pay $11. to park. Be sure to drive around the side of the mountain where you will get a really cool side view of the monument. I have never seen a published shot before like that. See my photograph below.

I was really excited to see Mount Rushmore. I never got to travel as a kid, so I missed out telling all the good stories you did as a kid. My husband and I decided to make this a stop on our move from Alaska to Minnesota. It was a beautiful drive, but after getting there and realizing that parking was $11, we were a little bummed. We parked and walked up to the monument, got our pictures, saw the flags and went into a few stores then it was done. That's it. $11 to park when we could have taken the same kind of pictures from the road. It is quite an experience to see it up close though.

This is a piece of history and national recognized. Anything else you see in the Black Hills is good but not nationaly recognized always. You can say Mt Rushmore to anyone anywhere in the country or even workdwide and people know what you are talking about. My recomendation is to see Mt Rushmore before you see Crazy Horse. Crazy Horse is so much bigger that it takes away from the awesomeness of Mt Rushmore if you see Crazy Horse first. Parking is $11. Being a National Mounument would be nice if could get a discount if have the America the Beautiful Pass. We had 4 teenagers sho had not seen mount rushmore with us and they loved it. If trying to save money plan to eat before you go. The restraunt there is pretty high priced.

Absolutely amazing! The main reason we came up to the Black Hills area and it was well worth it. I highly recommend hitching on to one of their free ranger led programs. We followed one with the kids and it walked us down to right below the presidents (note: you can go there without a ranger program as well) but the material they presented was fascinating. Very informative and fun too. Parking seems a little steep at $11.00 per car, but you do have free reentry with it. We stopped by another time to see it at night as well so we did actually use our parking pass more than once. If we were in the area again we would definitely stop by and see it.

On October 22nd 2012 we drove from Colorado Springs-about 8 hrs with "potty Stops", to the Memorial. It was a very tedious ride..we listened to an audio book. It was worth the drive. Once again the National Parks have done a wonderful job. Anyhow there is a museum, a movie, a trail around the base of the sculpture, a very nice Cafe ( had a piece of the Berlin Wall on display) and of course the Monument of Mt Rushmore itself. The builders' workshop, and many other pertinent items are also on the grounds.( We were unable to see the lighting ceremony in the evening due to lack of time) You come away amazed at what this team of men accomplished. Probably the highlight for us was meeting a gentleman (92 yrs old) in the gift shop who had worked on the carving crew for Lincoln and Roosevelt. He was signing copies of his book. Of course we bought one. Only $10.00. It is wonderful to read about this project from his perspective. We spent about 3-4 hours and felt we had done about everything. Then off to "Crazy Horse".

I first saw Mount Rushmore in 1958 as a 13-year old on a family motor trip to the West. I was excited to return on my motorcycle trip to the same area. Long story shortened: it was better the first time. Then: a drive up a long road, park in a lot (free parking), a walk through some woods and there it was! Now: a drive up a long road, park in a parking garage and pay $11 for my motorcycle (same charge for a car), then a walk through an elaborate and (in my view) unnecessary granite-paved plaza, and there was the same mountain sculpture. The magic sure was gone, and feeling that I'd paid $11 to some entity (not into the Federal treasury) left a bitter taste.

This is truly an amazing feat of man. We origially saw it from needles highway as we came through a tunnel; but don't stop to take picture as you might cause a bad accident. Just go to the memorial. I had a senior pass to see this but was charged $10 parking fee which I was very unhappy about. I saw a lot of people taking pictures from the side of the road outside the park and basically saw what we saw. It is not the $ it is the principal. We saw a video while we were there and that helped ease the pain. LOL.
