Mt Rushmore was great,but could not walk on side trails due to snow. Keystone, the town at the base of the base of the mountain was closed except for a few small places which were closing the next week. Parking was $11.00

After a visit to Yellowstone we made the drive to Mount Rushmore, with an overnight stop in Deadwood along the way. Keystone is a small town but quite a few hotels. Headed to Mount Rushmore around 10am. There is no entrance fee but parking was $12, which is valid for the calendar year, so keep your parking pass for a followup visit in the evening. Parking was not a problem, albeit a little walking involved. The visitors center is nice and staffed by pleasent folks. As you approach through a walkway edged with each state flag the magnificant memorial comes into view. It is quite astounding and worthy of many photos. We took the Presidential trail, which is a nice walking trailing affording various views of the memorial, many photo opportunities along the way. Hint, take the trail in a clockwise direction for less uphill climbing. The walk is easy with many rest stop benches along the way and if taken in a clockwise direction you are doing more walking downstairs than up. Take the time to visit the artists studio towards the end of the walk.

People, stop traveling to Europe, start traveling the roads of America. This is one of the most amazing sights not to be missed. Take a guided tour with one of the many college students and be impressed with their knowledge and pride of being an American and love of country. For only $11 (parking fee) you get to enjoy the sights but they offer good food, a well stocked store and you get the opportunity to meet one of the men who worked on Mt. Rushmore. If your lucky you get to see a mountain goat.

Finally getting into Keystone, SD and checking into our room, we had a room with a view of Mt Rushmore. We drop off the bags and headed over tot he memorial as it was becoming dusk and at the memorial they have a lightning ceremony where as the sun sets and gets darker, they off lights and tell you the history of Mt Rushmore. As they finish up -they ask everyone to stand and join in with reciting the Pledge of Allegiance and then the monument is light up starting from the bottom. Visitors try to gather around the stone edge to look down into the amphitheater to see what is going on there. As much as this might be interesting, if you want good pictures, hang back a little for pictures. As for Carver's Cafe, if you want a snack then grab a bit here before it closes. Check with park as hours may vary. The cost to view the monument is $11 for car. If you have the opportunity, grab the opportunity.....

Four Virginia guys, average age 68.5, left VA on 8-22-2012 and traveled twenty one states in twenty four days on our Harley's. Indianapolis Speedway, Sand Hills, Deadwood, Black Hills, Spearfish, Sturgis Canyon, Custer State Park, Devil's Tower, Big Horn Park, Cody, Red Lodge, Bear Tooth Pass, Mt. Rushmore, Crazy Horse, Yellowstone, Jackson Hole, entertained at Bar 'J' Ranch, Rapid City, Durango, Red River Mountain, Durango, Four Corners, Albuquerque, Santa Fe, Madrid, Amarillo, then back east to ride The Dragon in Tennessee. What an exciting trip covering 6,789 miles!
$11 to get in. The museum was really neat, the view is unbelievable. My 6 & 4 years old had a wonderful time. They liked the Indian village, the museum and hiking the trail.

Three friends and I visited Mount Rushmore National Memorial in late July. I can't say I was disappointed, but at the same time I wasn't that impressed. There is a small charge to park at the monument ($11, for a car), but the actual admission is free. You can see the monument as you get closer to it while driving which kind of makes it less exciting when you arrive. The memorial looks just like you expect it to look. There is a nice easy to use walkway that circles the area with information about the monument and different view points, but you can't really get that close to the sculpture. We stayed for the lighting ceremony and while I thought the presentation was nice I was expecting much more. It was a cool sight to see, but once you've seen it I don't know if you'll ever need to go back (I know I won't). There is a cafe with typical cafeteria foods (burgers, chicken, etc.), drinks, an ice cream shop, and a gift shop. Everything is overpriced but that should be expected. If you really want to visit Mount Rushmore I recommend spending a few days in the region so you can visit other attractions.

This was AWESOME, AMAZING, and quite HUMBLING!!!!! The monument is just undescribable .... no matter how many different photos you look at of Mt Rushmore, you will never get the same effect as being here and seeing it with your own eyes!!! The park is very well maintained and clean, considering there is no fee to get in that is a testament to the dedication of the people who work there!!! There IS a fee for parking ($11) but once you pay it, your parking pass is good for the rest of the year....not too many places that can make that claim!!

This park is a must see for history buffs. The state flags and dates they entered the union are impressive along with the artist studio. Spend some time in the studio and ask questions. This place is very important. Catch a ranger doing art, take the path closer to the faces or just sit and admire. Great photos everywhere. We had the National Park Senior pass we bought for all park entry ($10) but be prepared to pay about $11 for parking.

When we last went to Mt. Rushmore almost 35 years ago, there wasn't anything more than a rudimentary parking lot and a gravel path to lead you to the base of the monument. As I recall, it was free, so the $11 annual parking fee was a bit of a shock on this return trip. And, because it is a (private) parking fee, our Senior National Park Pass would not cover it.

Active and retired members of the military were recognized during the lighting ceremony, bringing tears to my eyes. The carvings are magnificent, but the area was very crowded - much better and a little cooler when we went during the evening. $10 for an entire year admissin is such a huge bargain.

For $11.00/annual pass, you get to see this magnificent display and I actually got goosebumps walking up to it! There is a light show with ceremony apparently which we didn't get a chance to check out, but heard it was pretty cool! They have a museum as part of the exhibit and rooms with little 15 movie clips about the creation of Mount Rushmore, very fascinating. There was also an Artist Studio which housed a replica of what Mount Rushmore was suppose to look like if it was completed. A lot of historical facts, known and unknown to me!! Must see and you can't beat the price!!

After seeing photos of Mount Rushmore in history books all of your life, expect that the monument will seem smaller than you expect it to be! Don't get me wrong, it is still amazing and definitely worth a visit. On this trip we included the evening program at Mount Rushmore because we had heard that it was very beautiful with the monument lighting ceremony which was begun at 8 P.M. Actually, the entire ceremony lasted about 90 minutes. It started with a history talk by the ranger at the beginning, then the lighting ceremony & patriotic music, and lastly, a call for all veterans to come to the stage to be recognized by their name, rank, and service affiliation. As you can imagine, this took a long time. There were many families with young children & I think they were getting a little antsy by the conclusion - if you have young ones, I would recommend leaving before the vets portion of the program. The monument is free but the cost of parking is $11.00. Be sure to remember where you parked your vehicle - yes, it took us a while to find ours! If you go at night, I would recommend staying nearby in Keystone as it was about a 30 minute drive in the dark back to our Rapid City motel. Keep in mind that there are many deer nearby & in the roads at nightfall, so the drive can seem longer than it actually is!

We were passing through on our way back home and decided to stop here since we were so close. I am so glad we did. It was very easy to get to with lots of signs. It was a pretty drive to the park as well. We went in the early afternoon. The traffic was not bad getting into the park. They had a really nice little town before the park that was full of places to eat and buy souvaniers. It was $11.00 to park, not bad. The park was clean. Other than it being smaller that I had pictured it, it was really a very cool experience. When you see it on TV it looks like it is a massive mountain. But it is not quite as big as it appears on TV and in pictures. I am so glad we stopped here. A once in a lifetime experience....

I came here the first time 40yrs. ago. Parking was free and you had an unobstructed view of the monument. Well, the natural beauty of the surrounding area has been ruined by the greed of capitalism and for so many people who need to be "entertained" rather than just taking in the site itself. Flags and buildings hocking their wares obstruct the view. Parking was $11. It just diminished the whole experience for me. Husband, who had never been there in his 71yrs. was much impressed. And don't eat at their Carvers Cafe, it's worse than bad.
Its a great monument, but you will be charged $11 to park (even a motorcycle) - but your ticket is valid for the season. Expected more. The area is very scenic and the roads excellent
There is no admission for Mount Rushmore, but instead, an $11 per car parking fee.

They have done a very good job of laying out the park. Very easy to get around, and the .6 mile trail is well worth the effort. Admission is free, however to park costs $11 per car that is good for a year. Many fantastic photo opportunities. Be sure to rent an audio guide, its only $5 and you can easily skip to the section you want to listen to.

Just one of those amazing things in the world that you just have to see if you are anywhere in the neighborhood. Thought $11 to park seemed steep; however, we enjoyed visiting the monument and got some great photos.

We took the kids (age 11, 11, and 9) to Mt. Rushmore. Getting there is easy, as there is signage everywhere pointing the way. There is no fee to visit, but there is an $11 parking pass (which is good for the rest of the year).

I expected to drive into a parking lot and look up to see the Monument. However, there is a lovely entrance, promenade and viewing deck. Very nicely done. A grille for snacks, even breakfast and a nice gift shop. We had a pass from our hotel for parking but even so, it's only $11 for the car. Well worth it.

Of course most people who travel to the Black Hills in South Dakota stop by to see Mount Rushmore. But what they may not know is how educational it is, and how affordable! The cost is only $11 per car (cheapest attraction in the Black Hills!). They have also added so much more to the park since I was there last. (1996) My 8 and 10 year old children loved to read the facts about all the presidents on Mt Rushmore. We also enjoyed the museum and info about Gutzon Borglum, the sculptor. Very educational, beautiful and affordable.

We visited this site in July 2012 and it is just wonderful. The entrance has been updated and handicap friendly. There is no fee to get in so your senior pass for national paks is not needed but there is a $11.00 parking fee. When you get to the ampitheater stay left as the walk way is ramps, there are more steps if you go right. The views are just awesome.

National Landmark everyone should visit. $11 for parking gets everyone in. We thought this would be a quick stop, but ended up spending a few hours here. I recommend walking the path, but be prepared for lots of stairs. A little way into the path they have a teepee & artifacts, with employees there to answer questions & give information regarding the area. Clean restrooms & a large gift shop as you are walking up to view the monument closer. Our kids 5 & 8 really enjoyed it.

I am 45 years old and I giggled like a little kid the morning I woke up to drive to Mount Rushmore. After seeing this iconic sight so many times in movies, posters, tshirts, television - I was so intrigued to see it in person. I drove from Pierre, SD and stopped at Wall Drug. Then onto Rapid City and Keystone. The drive from Rapid City to Keystone wasn't bad at all. I took off early in the morning so there wasn't a lot of crazy traffic. As you're driving up the winding roads, all of a sudden BOOM there it is. Of course it looks smaller from this distance but everyone gets out and takes a picture. The smell of pine trees is wonderful. Then onto the Visitor Center. $11 entrance fee was well worth it. Lots of parking (several outdoor levels). Then a nice walk up to the main plaza. There's a very long row of flags for every state in the union. A great gift shop and cafe. And the sight of the presidents up close is truly breathtaking. Just the sheer human achievement of actually getting something that huge and detailed carved into a mountain side is truly awe-inspiring. I couldn't stop looking at them. Don't miss it. Then when you leave, follow the signs west into Black Hills National Forest and you'll see some fantastic roadside photo opps of George Washington in profile.
Did the Audio tour for $5 bucks best money I ever spent.

It is so amazing and cheap. Still can't believe that we only had to pay $11 to park! Would recommend doing the 30 minute walking tour. It is very interesting and our tour guide was very knowledgeable! If we had more time we would have visited it again and gone to the lighting ceremony at night!

This is an amazing place to visit. Just going through the pack was great but we spent the $5.00 for the audio tour. It gave a great deal of extra information and helped explain a lot. Make sure you arrive early to avoid huge crowds of people. We arrived not long after it opened and had no problems walking through the park. When we started to leave it was filling up and made it hard to walk around and enjoy. All the people we came in contact that worked at Mt. Rushmore were extremely friendly and helpful.

Although we've all seen pictures of Mt Rushmore from time to time, there's nothing like seeing it in person. The first view is an awesome sight and the size of it makes it all the more spectacular. I've visited the Black Hills four times during my life, and each time I've paid to visit Mt Rushmore. It's a national monument afterall...and a bargain at $11 a carload.

This has clean, modern buildings for a national park. You have to pay to park, $11.00, but your pass is good for your car for the calendar year. Great Design and this park made me want to linger. Mt Rushmore is a must see, but the way the park was designed makes it a nice place to spend some time.

Great must see spot. $11 parking pass lets you go for the calendar year. Went back for evening lighting - awesome. Take the trail to get close - start on the left for easy ramp or the right for lots of steep stairs! Great value for the price.

This is must see. I will make some suggestions. Find out what time the Ranger Tours are and go on one. You learn so much. Wear good shoes and take your time if you use the steps in front of the memorial. It is a long and tasking walk up and down steps but they have levels you can rest at. I would also suggest if you go in the summer to buy what is known as FROGG TOGGS. I found mine at Bed Bath and Beyond. Read how to prepare the cooling cloth. This is a neck wrap in a plastic bottle that you wet and wear when you get hot. It saved me from over heating and kept me cool. If you are older take the steps slowly and walk slowly and rest often. Take water and drink as you go. The walk in front of the memorial is worth it. The beauty of the landscape is unreal. You see pictures and movies of Mt. Rushmore but you just can't appreciate how huge and wonderful it is until you see it. You will pay for parking only and they have covered parking which we liked for keeping our vehicle cool. Cost around $11.00 for the day.

For the people who didn't do their research and planned a 2 day visit to Mt. Rushmore...don't. Mt. Rushmore is stunning as it is, but it is not a 2 day visit. It is 2 hours well spent though. We did not mind the $11 entrance fee. Go in the morning (8am is when it opens) to avoid the crowds and to take pictures without jostling for space.The visitor's center is really nice and informational, albeit a bit repetitive at times. We learnt a lot about the sculptor himself. The hike to the base of Mt. Rushmore was easy but pleasant. It was nice to soak in the atmosphere and reflect on the achievements of this nation.

Even during one of the busiest weeks of the year, we had an awesome time at Mount Rushmore. We were in the park on July 3 and got to participate in some of the Independence Day activities. Even though the park was full, parking was painless and access to bathroom facilities and concessions was easy with very little wait. While I wouldn't plan more than a few hours in the park, we had a great time going through the museums at the welcome center and hiked up to a view Rushmore from a different vantage point. We packed a picnic lunch and ate before we got to the park, but had AWESOME Raspberry soft serve ice cream cones. We didn't travel with kids, but saw many taking part in the awesome "Junior Ranger Program". Would definitely be fun for kids ages 6-11 or so. There was an $11 parking fee, but no fee to enter the park. I think they discouraged outside food and drink, but we each carried a bottle of water in without any problems.
Although it is free to get into Mount Rushmore, the parking is $11 per vehicle. Keep the receipt as it is good for a year.

My husband and I had been here about 12 years ago. For some reason we thought there was more to see. This time we did the presidential train and went into the museum. It took us about 3 hours to get through the entire thing. One thing we thought was cool was that they only charge for parking $11 for a car. The tag is good for the rest of the year. This allowed us to come back on a different day and watch the night time lighting and program.

This was our second trip to Mount Rushmore. I must say I felt the same awe seeing it again this time around as I did the first time. We decided to see it at night and arrived around 8:30 for the 9:00 lighting ceremony. Many others arrive for this as well, so plan ahead if you attend to see this. We didn't get there early enough to get a seat at the auditorium for the ceremony. The experience at night would be best if you get a seat to see the movie that accompanies the speaker. We did not and it made the speech harder to follow without seeing the screen, especially for younger children like our 5 year old. While it was nice to see the mountain at night, the detail of the faces is better appreciated by day. We came back the next day to take it all in completely. The walk at the base of the mountain is easy and gets you up a bit closer. Overall, its worth the stop, especially for only $11 for a year, and for me makes me feel all the more American. Its an American Icon that shouldn't be missed if in the area.
Can't beat it for the price. You all know what it is...the price is $11 for your car for the year! Everybody should see it once!

Went to Rushmore and had expectations that I was going to be dissappointed. We first rushed there to get there for the night lighting as we heard how great it was, and that's where we were dissappointed, as we found it overrated. Almost did not go back the next day, but we did, and really enjoyed it, as it exceeded our expectations. Went on brief Ranger walk and Artist studio, both worth the time. Daughers of 8, 10 and 14 really enjoyed it. (Regarding people "belly aching" about $11 dollar parking, don't listen to them, as its only $11-get over it)
Only $10 to get in for the whole year! Great value and very educational. I wouldn't recommend this for younger children though. My five year old was NOT impressed.

The 4 carved presidents are a must-see for any vacation to the north country, that is for sure. But, go here before you go to Crazy Horse. My wife and I went to Crazy Horse and then traveled to Mt. Rushmore... and we were not blown away... and we felt guilty about it. Take the audio tour if you want to know more about the making of the monument. The restaurant had decent food, but prices were high- I had a ham and cheese sandwich, a bag of chips, and a water, my wife had a salad and a water, and our bill for lunch was $28. My suggestion: go to Mt. Rushmore early in the morning, enjoy an hour with the presidents, then leave and eat lunch elsewhere. In the afternoon go see Crazy Horse to really get your socks knocked off!

We had a beautiful drive to Mt Rushmore the mountains were beautiful. It cost me $12 for my family to park and go into the monument. Parking was unbelievably convenient for accessing the monument. Inside everything was absolutely top drawer: clean, immaculately maintained, there was a real sense of reverence and the staff were extremely nice and polite. A truly great experience.
Fee: $11 parking fee - a national park pass does not circumvent this fee

You cannot go to the Black Hills without stopping at Mount Rushmore. It is amazing. Nice museum with information on the making of president's heads. Worth the stop. Free, but fee to park (I believe it was $11 this year.)

It could have been the long drive leading to our visit or the history lessons at every turn but the family didn't exactly enjoy the visit. New parking structure is paid for by a parking fee not covered by Golden Eagle Pass. The "light show" is not, it is a monument lighting show with a history lesson leading up to it.

The monument is free but there is an $11.00 parking fee. The visitors center is very informative and interesting. Make sure to catch the short documentary on the monument's construction. The amphitheater and porch behind it provide an unobstructed view.
I was blown away at the size of the carving! The memorial(no fee) and convenient parking ($11)

Mount Rushmore has been on my "bucket list" for many years and seeing this impressive sculpture on the mountain was well worth it! Plan to spend at least 2 hours to see everything. Take in the "Sculpture's Studio" which has detailed information about how the busts were carved. The museum has many interesting photos, actual artifacts - drills, bonsun seats, etc that were used in the actual carving. There is a nice restaurant and ice cream shop with plenty of indoor seating. Don't miss the bookstore which has many historical books, children's books and great postcard selection. We went back for the lighting ceremony at 9 pm and I was slightly disappointed. After watching a video presentation, all they do is shine a light on the monument faces and that's it. I expected something a little more flashy. Fee for parking is $11 but no entrance fee is charged.

We stayed in Custer during the week of June 25th and some of the days were getting a little warm so we picked the coolest day to visit Mount Rushmore. One thing I would recommend is to go early and have breakfast with the Presidents at the Carvers Restautant. They have an open air deck and you can sit outside & look straight up at the Presidents while you eat. When we were there, we were the only ones sitting outside and it was a beautiful morning. You get a really great breakfast for $5.99 (The Monumental Breakfast - eggs, bacon, sausage & gravy and potatoes) - can't beat this deal and it was good! My other tip is right inside the entrance you can rent a hand held device for $5 and hear all of the background information as you walk the Presidential Trail. Wow, this is really an awe enspiring sight to see. I was there as a child and I thoroughly enjoyed going back!!

First, I feel the parking fee is a little high. Second, should you go during the day save your money for the customer appreciation bargain souvenir table. For $5 you can purchase great t-shirts, ball caps, recycled shopping bags, coffee mugs, & other items.

We were able to view it both at night and during daylight. We weren't able to attend the lighting ceremony because it was cancelled due to very bad weather. We enjoyed both times of day. The entire facility is well done with a very patriotic feeling and the services that were provided. $11 parking fee but we didn't mind at all to help maintain such a nice place. The boardwalks with different views of the monument were great, they take guests around to different views of it. We enjoyed the videos and museum exhibits very much and spent quite a bit of time enjoying the history behind building the monument. We were there on a Saturday night and Sunday morning in early June and didn't find the crowds to be an issue at all. Cafeteria with typical options, there was also an outdoor grill set up with burgers and dogs. Overall we are very glad we made the stop.

At first, we were shocked at the $11 parking fee, but then we discovered that there was no admission fee. Our visit was also damped by a downpour, which limited our time at the site (we didn't do any of the hikes). The cafeteria food was ok. The presidential faces monument is an artistic achievement. There is also a museum.

We got lost getting there because you kinda can't read signs on the other side of your sign as you pass by.That part was kinda funny to us . Anyways...First of all with or with out The America the Beautiful pass it's $11 to park. When we first pulled up to the Memorial it looked so small but the more we kept on walking pass the flags to the end of the walk way it looked so big. The ice cream prices are so so for a scoop of ice cream and of course we had to get t-shirts and stuff which really wasn't to badly priced ($5) I thought hey why not. Lots of different people from all over the world are there. Which is cool! It's Really busy!

Well as I sat and looked at the work of art showing great presidents of the past. I was struck by how a post card or picture could not even begin to show you the beauty of our present and past. Just below me a professional photographer was snapping shot after shot. I asked him how it was going and he said exactly what I was thinking."Honestly I have gone up and down the coast and all over the west taking shots and I just can't seem to capture the feeling I get by seeing this in person". I smiled and told him I was thinking the same thing. Columns show the states first in our nation to the last. Delaware being the first and Hawaii being the last. You will have to go by to find out when your state became official. Don't miss this and Keystone is a lovely town you will want to stroll. The cost to enter I believe was $4.00 per car.

We have all seen pictures of Mt Rushmore. The pictures can't begin to show you how it feels to stand in front of the monument in person. Our kids participated in the junior ranger program and had a blast. We all walked the presidential loop. Lunch was very, very expensive and wasn't worth the money. The food wasn't bad, it just cost entirely too much. ($50 plus for a family with 4 small children - nothing fancy to eat. Hamburger or hot dog and a bag of chips with a coke). Overall, an awesome place to visit. The rangers are very knowledgeable and helpful. The view is incredible.

We enjoyed it very much. We had not been there for 25 years so there were alot of changes. I would suggest you get there earlier in the day to avoid the crowds. It costs $11 per car and the sticker is usable for a year. We were impressed with the avenue of flags and the path that goes below the momument. There was also a place near the path for children to go into tepees and touch all kinds of Indian artifacts. Definately, worth the trip. We camped at Custer State Park and that also is amazing. We were unable to attend the evening light ceremony.

I've always wanted to see Mt. Rushmore and it was worth the wait. We happened to visit on a gloriously beautiful day and the first glimpse of the memorial truly took my breath away. As you take the foot tour, be sure you wear good, solid sneakers - it's a trek but worth it. Food service is limited, but snacks are available. Actually, you don't go for the food - get over it. :-) The park rangers were very helpful and the onsite exhibits were exceptionally well done. Some "complain" about the parking garage, but given the location, a garage is the best way to get everyone in. $11 per car isn't bad for all you get to see. Plan for a 2-3 hour visit - there is a lot to see in addition to our forefather's heads. Outstanding and just break taking. Enjoy!

Very nice place to see. Paid $11 to drive in and park. Got there 4 hours before lighting so we snapped a few photos and enjoyed the beautiful scenery. This is a very cool attraction but once you see it not much to do unless you stick around for the lighting show. We made the mistake of not eating before going here as we assumed (bad move) that the food might be good. My wife and I ordered cheese burgers for $8 a piece. The first clue they were going to be bad was seeing them take the burgers out of some little heating box. Took one bite and wanted to puke. I'm not kidding. These were not even half as good as the ones they serve at school lunches. Anyway... it sucks paying that much for food that is just crap. We are from Nebraska so we know what a good burger tastes like. I'm fine with the price if the food is good. This was not the case!

It can be disappointing if your expectations were too high. I just went for the second time with my family (kids 11, 9 and 5). I had been once when single years ago. I enjoyed it more then. My wife, 11 year old and I were a bit disappointed this time. They had not seen it before, but had higher expectations. They still thought it was interesting, but there is not a lot when comparing against other major parks (Yellowstone, Grand Canyon, Yosemite, etc.). I remembered a better nighttime presentation. This one repeated a lot from the movie. They honor veterans during the presentation. We were all still glad we went, but we did not stay long. The National Park Pass is of no use. The Park is free, but parking is not. The pass is good for admission, but not parking. That is kind of lame. We got the junior ranger books, but we did not stay long enough for our kids to complete them. We were there for under two hours as we got there just before dark so we saw the monument in daylight and lighted.

Mount Rushmore is, no doubt, the primary objective for the vast majority of Black Hills tourists. No one should miss it. It is important. But, even though it is a national memorial and there is, therefore, no admission fee, be ready to pay substantially for your visit. Parking for an automobile has increased this year to $11 from $8 in the past. The Gift Shop prices are the highest in the Hills for popular items such as shirts, caps and baubles. The resturant, which we used to consider one of the Hill's best bargains has gone over the top with no improvement in quality. The site has instituted a "Bargain Tent" outside the main Gift Shop where all items are $5. which is truly wonderful if you are traveling with children. I hope that Tent is permanent!

Wow, what a view. The visitor complex provided an incredible setting for viewing this remarkable site. A walking trail provided additional opportunities to view the monument and get exceptional photos. Make sure to visit in the evening to hear a park ranger, watch a movie and see the lighting of the monument America The Beautiful in the outdoor amphitheater. One price ($11) for the car provides good for the year.
Took my son to Mount Rushmore for his 1st time. I had been 10 years earlier. Still a good place to visit. Was shocked by the amount to park , $11.00.

By the time we got to Mt. Rushmore, we'd been going all day, most recently spending a couple hours at Crazy Horse. Sadly, in comparison, not as impressive. In fact, as we waited at the stoplight, my son suggested we just look at it from the highway instead of paying to go in. Yes, at $11 a carload, it was cheaper than CH's $27 a carload......but MR is federally funded while CH is not. Either way, we saw it from the highway in front twice, and although it was nice, not quite the thrill the kids & I thought it would be.

It is very impressive to see Mount Rushmore in person, and worth the $11 IF you go for the lighting at night. The lighting ceremony was a very patriotic time and well worth the time spent. It lasts around 30 minutes before the statue is lit with a ranger coming out and talking, and then a 20 minute video (weather permitting) on the history behind the presidents chosen for the monument. My suggestion is if you have young kids who are attending, make sure to bring along something for them to do if they get bored and be there early to get good seats. We hadn't realized there would be a program prior to the lighting so we were unprepared, but we got through it with 4 kids under 8 years old and it was well worth the experience. It is in fact one of my personal highlights of the trip we took through SD and WY.

Don't forget your parking pass ($11) is an annual one with no entrance cost. Great price for a family or group. The evening patriotic program starts at 9 pm and the lights are projected onto the monument a half hour later. We went back the next morning and ate breakfast in the cafe to see the morning light on the faces and peruse the exhibits. Worth it!

We went twice, we saw the evening show which is at 9 pm and watch the video and the lighting in the rain. It was not a heavy rain, so bring a rain coat or umbrella. We wore jeans and then the next day we went to the monument and walk the less then mile trail near the monument the weather was 65 and sunny. The area is very nice, parking is easy and once you pay the $11 fee you can use the park for a year.

My 12th trip to this national memorial and it never gets old. Something I feel every American should visit once in their lifetime. I have been lucky enough to see it a dozen times. It's affordable at $11 for the whole year. Morning is the best time to shoot photos of the mountain. Didn't see any chipmunks or mountain goats this trip. Love the native American exhibit here with the teepees.

It's always a fun & afforadable place to visit with friends or family. It only cost $11 for parking. Bring your camera. It can be a short stop or longer depending on your time frame. Great for all ages. Must see.

The entrance is free but the parking is $11. Pull up to the entrance and ask if you can turn around. On the way out you can get a great view and pictures. I dont recommend getting out of your car since there is nowhere to pull off. But if theres no traffic you can get away with a few good pictures. I did.

Definitely a place to visit in order to capture the American Experience. When we visited in May we were fortunate there were no crowds and the weather was perfect a far cry from rainy Seattle and I might add the Rangers were friendly. The entrance fee is only $11 per car and the place far more organized and pleasant compared to Crazy Horse just a stones throw away. We are glad we visited Mt Rushmore.

The Mount Rushmore memorial is awesomely done. The Presidential trail gets you some great close up views of the memorial. Rent the audio for $5 it is worth it. The restaurant on site was very good, as well as, the ice cream shop next to it. The bookstores and gift shops were well stocked.
I wanted to see Mount Rushmore since it's an American landmark. I'm so glad I went! It was not very crowded when I went so parking was fine, and $11 is a bargain for a 6-month pass!

My boyfriend and I were floored to see that it was such a high cost to park at Mount Rushmore and that our National Parks Access Pass did not cover the fee; we almost kept driving and just looked at it from afar because we were so disappointed. We decided to buck up and pay. However, we had been camping nearby and happened to get on the road very early (about 5:30 or 6AM); when we reached the parking area, the gates were open and we were able to park for free and access all of the trails. None of the facilities were open, but we were able to see what we came for - Mt. Rushmore!

My family (wife, son, daughter-in-law, grandchildren ages 7,5,2) all visited Mt. Rushmore on May 5, 2012. I must admit I was a little disappointed at the cost ($11.00) for parking. That aside, the setting is beautiful, the layout of the walkway, visitors center, shop and restaurant, as well as the Flag Walk. One cannot help but be impressed with the work done, and the dedication to detail on the faces of the four presidents depicted. It was really inspiring. We decided to have the grandchildren participate in the Jr. Ranger Program. If you are not familiar with this program it is well worth the time (no cost) and the kids really learned about the site. I wish I had thought to take down the names of the Rangers we spoke with, who went over the kids booklets, gave a little pop quiz (our five year old grandson, when asked by the Ranger who was the president with the glasses, proudly answered "Teddy Roosevelt!" to the pleasant surprise of his mother). The Rangers we spoke with were pleasant and well versed in the information about the monument. The gift shop had lots and lots of items, although a few items that would be what a 2/3 year old would like, would have been helpful. Overall it was a fascinating and thoroughly enjoyable experience...and rather emotionally moving as well.

This trip was one of those, "always wanted to go see it" type of things. We flew into Rapid City, SD, rented a car and headed out early the next morning. It is only a short 20 to 25 minute drive out to the Monument from Rapid City. It is truly an impressive place to be. Parking was $11.00, but there is no fee for touring the monument, grounds, studio, and museum. Happy to pay to park as the entire place, including the parking was paved, clean, neat and user friendly. The only problem we encountered was that we were a few weeks early for the busy tourist season. Some of the area attractions and the sculptor studio at the monument were not open. We visited during the last week in April. Mount Rushmore is truly an attraction that everyone must see! Make a time and go see it! We went back out to the monument in the evening. The faces are lighted about 15 minutes after dusk and remain lit until about 9:00 pm. Wow, what an impressive place. We enjoyed every minute of our visit. Allow a few hours for the visit and wear good walking shoes so you can take the President's Trail. It is about a 1/4 mile walk with some steps to negotiate. It is worth the time and effort. It will put you right up under the faces for some uniqe photos. Nice lunch room and gift shop on the site. Over a million visitors a year. You should be one of them!

The monument is nothing short of breath taking. The surrounding area has a nice little nature trail, and the visitor center is clean and interesting! Show me something else you can do that is fun for 4 hours for $11/car, and I'll be impressed. FYI, a parking pass is valid for the entire calendar year that you visited in.

We have for years seen pictures of Mount Rushmore but the in person experience is the real deal! Wow! When you gaze at this awesome picture looking right at you you get a sense of America the Beautiful. You feel proud to be an American. We you take the closer walk up to the monument you look straight up at the magnitude of this structure and you wonder how did they do it? I would suggest you go during the day as well as return at night for the night lighting ceremony. We went to the night lighting the night we arrived in Rapid City as we would be taking an all day tour the next day which included Mount Rushmore. I high recommend this attraction to everyone. No cost to get in but you are charged $11 for parking. But do it... it's worth it.

We did not think we would be that impressed but it was great. Has a nice trail around it but be prepared there are a lot of stairs. Costs 11 dollars to park and free to see the monuments. There are bathrooms and gift shop and food. Good parking. Worth seeing.

I teach 4th grade United States regions. For as much as we have read about Mount Rushmore and seen pictures, nothing can prepare you for the real thing! It was a true work of ate! We were lucky enough to meet and get a book autographed by one of the original carvers of the monument. Our only disappointment was that our annual National Parks Pass did not cover the $11.00 parking fee, not sure why that is.

We went off season so not much to do after viewing. I am sure that summertime would be better as far as other options. There is no fee to enter the park but the parking fee is $11 per car and that is good for multiple visits for the same vehicle so you could go one day to view the monument by day and then return to see it by night another time without additional charge. Viewing by night is a must because the appearance changes according to the time of day.

For our girls' Spring Break we visited Mount Rushmore/Black Hills area. The Black Hills alone are beatiful and Mount Rushmore added to our pleasant experience. I heard that the area and faces were not in good shape but all of the faces seemed to be in very good shape. The various views among the Presidential Trail were very nice. The walk is just right. My 2 year old was able to hang in there and make it all the way around. The cafe onsite was a bit expensive so we did not eat there. Nice experience. Would recommend it. (Parking is $11 per car but that is the only $$ you are required to pay and the pass lasts for the rest of the year for the same vehicle. Not to your benefit if you rented a vehicle as we did.)

While in the Blackhills one has to go to Mt. Rushmore and we did. Felt strangely patriotic while there; not something that happens to me often, so that was nice. Was glad to have given my children the opportunity to see it. Both the drive in and out were delightfully beautiful (and sometimes scary while at the edge of a mountain). Unfortunately, they do charge to park - we were short on time and didn't take in any of the programming at the monument, so we did feel a bit robbed by paying $11 to park for 1/2 hour. Overall, I say go. It is a marvel.
Easy to get in and out. Parking fee is pretty high, 11 dollars, but it is valid all day. Recommend to go early in the morning for great pictures and attend to lighting ceremony in the evening.
I though that going to Mt. Rushmore would be a so-so event. It was very inspiring. We also saw mountain goats along the path. The $11 parking is good for the entire calendar year.

For some reason, I expected to Mount Rushmore to be enormous. In reality it is only 60 feet tall. Parking is $11, but you can get some descent views and pictures from the road. There are 4-5 different stops on the road as you go around the mountain. I'm glad I went, but once was enough.
Senior Pass, really not applicable here. $11 to park. The newer granite columns and entrance really was well thought out.

2 stops here...wasn't visible for 2 days because of weather....but worth the wait. First seen at the night lighting ceremony....breathtaking.....park service does an excellent job of presentation....honoring Vietnam Veterans that evening. Following day can be done on same car ticket one time $11....park is well managed and operated. Park in lot #6, closest to the promenade for handicap access. Wheelchairs are available on sign out. Daytime overflight by jet fighters...awesome display. Lots to see, must take the Presidential Trail to the viewing platform....go to the left...easier walk going down the stair cases (250 steps). Gift shop was infuriating....only a few items Made in America, the rest made in China. So we only bought items MIA, their loss. Would have spent a lot more. Ice Cream cone was $4.75 for the smallest, more than a pint...seemed like a quart...way too much price and quantity...enough to freeze your brain. Mount Rushmore is a symbol of our great nation and the tone here is of a sacred nature....too bad the gift shop hasn't gotten the message....this is one place for America only. Better get here before Obama either grinds his face over Lincoln's or he sells it to the Chinese who will probably grind up the rock and put it in our food.

It is something everyone should see. You hear about how big it is and what people had to do to create it, but seeing it all in person is a different story. They have tours there that I heard were good, but I injured my leg 2 days before the trip and couldn't do all the walking involved. We did look through all the museum-type attractions and it clearly details how the entire thing came about and all the people who endured very dangerous work conditions to get the job done. I would highly recommend this attraction. It's $10 or 11 to park and that is all you pay for.
So glad we worked this into our trip. We went in the afternoon and then back again for the lighting ceremony. The $11 parking fee is good for the entire year for the vehicle driven in.

This was our third trip to Mount Rush more and we are impressed every time. It was special this time as we met one of the original carvers that worked on the stones, Don "Nick" Clifford who is 90 years old and the only one surviving who worked on the monument. His wife, Carolyn, chatted with us for several minutes and her story was likewise as interesting.In the early morning hours there is a minimum group of people thus leaving a lot of the viewing space for just a few. Buses don't start arriving until mid morning. You will be charged $11.00 to park however the entrance to the monument is free. Fees of this type charged by concessionaires under contract with the National Park Service is slowing ruining the publics perception about the Park Service. The other concessions, such as the gift show , are also tun by large corporations determined to get your last dollar and many times providing a cheap , shoddy imported product as a souvenir. There is a gift shop and cafeteria on the grounds, plus a theater that will give you the story of the construction. The gift shop has numerous books about the monument and unless you just have to have the book at once, I find jotting down the name and ISNB number and waiting until I return home and make the purchase off of Amazon where I save 30 to 40 percent off the retail price. Plus I don't have to lug that book or books around for many more miles. The little town Keystone is located just down the road and there you can get a cup of coffee or maybe a sandwich. Fair warning---it is a tourist town with lots of cheap novelties. The traffic to and from the moment during the summer season can be a challenge, thus patience is a virtue.

The Mount Rushmore monument is beautiful and a value too! It was only $11 for a year long entrance pass. The outdoor areas are well thought-out. We took a walking tour with one of the park ranger, which was very fun and informative. We also returned for the night lighting ceremony, which was beautiful. It is well worth it!

While not overly convenient to the Interstate, Rushmore is well worth the visit. The monument itself is awesome, and the (relatively) new entrance adds to the splendor. We visited just before Labor Day and there were no crowds on a spectacular day. We had breakfast at the cafeteria on the site; food was surprisingly good for breakfast. When you go, notice the original viewing site adjacent to the current one. And go early or late in the day when the sun isn't directly overhead to get nice detail. The admission is $11 per car, there's a large parking structure, and the admission is much more reasonable than it is for Crazy Horse.
It is neat to see, but as usual the federal government charges a fee to see it. I did not find that it was worth the $11.00 fee to enter the park.

While on a road trip with friends I stopped by to see this monument. It is definitely something I recommend, especially for someone that appreciates history and culture. The monument is a bit underwhelming as it is very far away from the viewing platform and thus appears rather small off in the distance. Also, parking is for a fee (about $12), and was still difficult to find a parking space. My friends and I read all of the various plaques and information kiosks, took pictures of all of the state flags, and many pictures of the monument itself, and were still hard pressed to spend more than one hour here. There is a free show where a park guide describes the history of the monument, but this will be redundant to most people.

This is a site that is worth the drive. IT is funny that when we got our first look at the memorial there were four cars that had to pull off before they even got to the site. There is an $11 parking fee but the fee is good for a week.

If in the area or making a road trip, this must be visited. No entry fee as this is a National Memorial. The fee for parking was $11 for a car and was good for return visits at night or until the year's end. TIP: Renting the Audio Tour is worth the $5. Very easy to operate and gives information at numbered stops. .Wheelchairs cannot go on the walk around the Memorial due to the number of steps. We took the walk to get closer to the Memorial--long walk with many steps. But well worth the effort! At night they light the Momorial and worth the return tripENJOY!

Awesome attraction. Much more to see and do that I anticipated. However, I would highly recommend to eat before or after you go as the food is mediocre at best and a bit pricey. There is quite a bit of selection but the burgers are premade and wrapped in foil on a warmer. I did notice that they were chargrilling burgers/hot dogs outside so that is the way to go. I got a garden burger and it was just barely edible. Bottled beer is $5 a pop. Otherwise, a fantastic experience and the only fee for the attraction is for parking which is $11 per car.

We took our family to Mt. Rushmore in July with a seven and three year old. The junior ranger program was great for our seven year old to get and stay interested in the park. The visitor center had some really neat information but it was not geared towards little kids at all. We watched the movie and found it to be interesting and information without being too long. I do highly recommend the ranger tour because they give a lot of little neat facts that aren't widely known. It was very neat to see this site but there wasn't a lot of activities to stay for a while. The entrance was free but parking cost $12 but the pass is good for the year.

I hadn't been to Mt. Rushmore since I was a kid & WOW they've done a lot with the place! It's great! Def. make the stop if you're in the area! And it's free! Besides parking which is $11. However, whatever you do, even if you're dying of hunger DO NOT, I repeat, DO NOT get the Chicken Sandwich at Mt. Rushmore, it's the worst salt bomb I've ever had. Not sure how you can screw up a chicken sandwich but they did. Def. the worste $20 I've ever spent (2 Chicken Sandwiches, 2 Bags of Chips & 2 Cokes)

For $11 per car, you can come back as much as you like for a year. Its a quick visit, unless you go downstairs for the educational section. Go at night for the light show! Tip: when you leave the memorial, take a right. Just around the corner is a great profile shot of Washington! :)

If you plan on walking the trail then it might be a little more worth your time. We stopped by on our way home from vacation, paid the $10 fee, stayed for maybe an hour and left. The time that we were there was plenty to go up, admire the memorial and take some pictures, shop for a little souvenir and head on out. The flags lining the walkway are a nice addition, adds a lot of character.

Wow, not only is the monument impressive, the story behind it is even more so. Watch the video on how the monument was created - 90% via dynamite. The park is free, but there is an $11 parking fee for cars. The parking ramp is convenient and clean. We did not stay for the night lighting show. There are also hiking trails.

It is a sight that you have to stop by while you are in the area, but just be ready for lots of people. To miss the crowds go early in the morning. The lighting ceremony is ok, but I wouldn’t recommend waiting around for it, there are much better things in the area to see. We didn’t spend more than 1hr there in total taking pictures and looking at the gift shop. While there are no fees to enter the park, it costs $11 per car to park there… Make sure to look out for the mountain goats and other wildlife in the area.

We spent two full days in the area, devoting one day to Mount Rushmore, custer park and crazy horse and one day to the Badlands. Mount Rushmore, while one admires the original feat of carving it, is surprisingly dull. The area of shops at the entry are tacky, parking is expensive and there really is no payoff once you have walked out on to the viewing terrace. Photographs and postcards make it seem considerably more dramatic. Crazy Horse will, one day, have far more impact. It is far from completed however, and the $10 per person entry fee seemed more akin to a donation to the project. On the wildlife loop in Custer Park the few bison seemed bored and the miles and miles of road surrounded by empty grassland made us feel the same way.

Had a wonderful time and especially enjoyed the informative talk by Park Ranger Charles Dumond; most interesting and I highly recommend it along with the Presidential Walk and the second lecture in Borglum's studio, No cost to enter but parking is $11 CASH, no CC accepted but worth the money. The winds were 60 mph the day we were there but we were told this was unusual - bring a jacket and if it's windy, hold on to your hat!

My husband and I loved Mt. Rushmore! The $10 price for parking almost seemed low for the sight, especially after just leaving Crazy Horse and feeling completely ripped off! Words just cannot describe how incredible it is to stand in front of this beautiful carving. The grounds were well taken care of and although it was fairly busy, we still had a great time! Everyone should see this site!
Beautiful. Put's a lump in your throat. Beware parking is $10.00 Cash only, no credit or debit allowed.

Although I was aware of it, I got annoyed when I was forced to purchase a $10 "annual" parking permit (that was good for 6 months). The concessionaire took only cash which was also annoying (they did make change for a $20 bill, however). I wonder why they don't sell $100 "century" parking permits (that are good for say 2 years).

While there is a concessionaire fee to park, the National Memorial is free. Informative exhibit and top-of-the-line videos within visitor center make the story behind the creation of Mt. Rushmore personal. Do the President's walk too....start on the left as you face Mt. Rushmore....and it's a easy loop. When you come to stairs down to artist's studio...you can back track to the visitor center if you do not want to do 'stairs. Evening lighting ceremony (seasonal) is moving....and free too! (Pay once for parking and can return at night for the illumination.)

This was our second trip to Mt. Rushmore. There have been major improvements to the site, including an amphitheater, paved trails, better entrance, better parking, etc. Very reasonably priced to enter ($10/car). On the drive up the mountain, a mountain goat jumped out into the road in front of us!

What a dissapointment to see all the man-made stuff below a perfectly iconic American Monument. The awesome view was from the road, not the park. It cost $10 to park in a parking garage despite the fact that entrance to the park was free. This should be free to all visitors, but there is too much money invested in the avenue of flags, gift shops, and the multi-tiered garage to let you out of there for nothing. We went in June and it was quite hot, which also detracted from the enjoyment as all the rock pathways hold heat. Too many people. I suppose it would be nicer in the off season with fewer people. Still, the whole thing takes away from the majesty of the Monument itself. It was not the patriotic experience we had hoped for. We couldn't wait to leave!

Visisted July 20, 2009, with husband and kids (17 & 12). You just can't believe how large this is until you are actually there. The line to get in to park was a little ong but moved quickly. It is definately worth the $10 to park so that you can take the trail that leads right up under the monument. There are several picutre spots along the trail, but if your not up for hiking be sure to only take the easy part of the trail. We started on the easy side and then thought that the difficult side would be fine because it looked to be all downhill; however, it does climb again and can be difficult for some. We visisted the sculptures studio which was just OK. There is a rather large gift shop, but it looks to be crowded most of the time. We liked the trail the best and got some awesome pictures.

We went to Mt. Rushmore with our daughter and her almost 3 year old son. We drove in from Colorado. The scenary was beautiful ! I fell in love with South Dakota. I was thrilled we stayed in Keystone. It was only one mile from Mt. Rushmore. Definitely be sure to see the mountain lighting ceremony and pre-lighting movie. I think it happens around 9 for the program and 9:30 for the lighting. Also be sure to see it in daylight too. A one time 10 dollar parking fee lets you in for the year.... I really was proud of our country and the great leadership it used to have being at that Monument.

I haven't been to Mount Rushmore for the past 20 years and didn't know what to expect--I certainly didn't go with high expectations. From the minute we pulled into the park admissions area I was impressed. Only a $10 fee for parking, and that pass is valid the entire year! A great parking garage with ample parking left us knowing our belongings were safe--and we weren't hearded around. We got to the level of Mount Rushmore and saw that the entire obversatory area has been redone and it's magnificent. Very patriotic, very impressive. There is a new trail you can take and get really close to the mountain too! We did it all and it was one of our favorite parks of our South Dakota trip.

Learn how the site was selected & why the four presidents' faces were chosen. Be sure to plan enough time to see everything. Take a guided tour, spend time in the Indian site, walk the Presidential Trail, visit the sculptor's studio & have lunch. Early and mid morning times the best. Gets crowded in the afternoon. Parking is $10 and convenient. A camera is a must--get someone to take your group's picture with the Presidents' faces in the background. Walking shoes will make the trail easier to maneuver.

A very good bargain at $10 per car. Plenty of parking in a newer, well laid out parking structure. The hall of flags and viewing terrace were clean and well laid out. The presidential hiking trail allows an up-close view of the monument from the base of the rock pile. Take your time when hiking, as the return path can become strenuous. Definitely worth a look if you are in the area. Arrive in the morning to make sure the sun is directly on the faces. Excellent gift shop...don't forget to buy your 'four documents of freedom' reproductions.

Even for visiting on a Wednesday in mid-June there were a lot of people. BUT, the number of people did not distract from the visit in any way. The monument is, of course, awe-inspiring for its scale and the era in which it was completed. The main viewing area is wide and accessible, providing plenty of vantage points for the classic straight-on views for all the people visiting. I walked on the path closer to the monument, which was worth my time, getting closer and different views of the monument. The sculpture's building and accompanying ranger talk provide interesting history. A cafeteria on site had reasonable park-priced fare (I liked my buffalo burger) and plenty of seating (when I was there). $10 to park. I spent about 2 hours at the Memorial.
$10 to get in with 4 in the van, can't beat that. And we all got a t-shirt for $5 each...not a bad shirt .

Mount Rushmore was fabulous. We got there pretty early in the morning, so it wasn't crowded yet, which was nice. Make sure you bring cash, though, since parking is $10 and they only accept cash. The rest of the site is free. We were able to walk around a little of the Presidential Walk, which was well laid out. There were tee pees for the the kids to check out and a Ranger there talking about them. There are great signs to read about the presidents featured on the mountain. A great thing to see.

I couldn't believe that after 40 years of wanting to see this place, I finally took the time to visit. It was wonderful. It costs $10.00 to park but it's an annual pass so visit as often as you can. We got there fairly early (which I recommend during the summer rush) and found a parking place right away. We walked around and did the Presidential Walk, which gives you excellent views of the presidents. The lecture about buffalo skins and teepee making is the first top on the walk; it is also interesting. I was awestruck about the whole monument. To see it as you're walking up from the parking garage can only be described as breathtaking.

This was by far my favorite activity after a week in the Black Hills and we had to go three times to finally see it with a blue sky (or see it at all since the first time it was too foggy to see). This happened to be the cheapest thing we did while in South Dakota--everything else was much more expensive. And considering we went to the Lighting Ceremony another evening-we got our money's worth out of the $10 fee.

As you approach the park from either side-it's uphill. We went on July 3rd and had a terrible time with parking. The monument itself was awesome though. It's free to get in, we paid the $5 for the audio tour and really enjoyed that. The path and terrain to the monument is not difficult, but it's not short either. Be prepared to walk. There is a neat movie explaining the history (about 15 minutes) we also toured the studio. I'd say you could do it in half a day easily if you are an active person. We did not buy food in the park, although there is plenty of opportunity.
Mount Rushmore is worth the trip if you are in the area. The parking charge of $7 is a little steep, but that is the only fee to access the site.

It was a MUST STOP for us this past August, but I was surprised by the admission system. Coming from Washington, DC area (where the Washington Monument, Lincolm Memorial, Jefferson Memorial, and FDR Memorial can all be enjoyed for free) I was surprised to see that Mt. Rushmore is technically free, but there is an $8 parking fee...and no real way to visit without parking.

I envy people who got to see Mount Rushmore before the construction of the new visitor center. The memorial itself compliments the natural landscape surrounding it, as does the original Frank Lloyd Wright visitors' center. Now half the mountain is defaced by a gray granite monstrosity (gift shop, restaurant, ice cream shop, t-shirt shop, parking garage, etc.) and amphitheater that looks like an unholy combination of a suburban outlet mall and something out of a Nazi-propaganda film. If you want to see the faces of the presidents as they were probably intended to be seen, view them from one of the many overlooks in adjoining Custer State Park, where you can see them without Disneyland in the way. If you absolutely must go to the memorial itself, look in the other direction. The unobstructed view of the badlands and prairies stretching from the edge of the Black Hills, which is available from the top of the parking garage, is one of the best in the area. Oh, by the way, forget using your National Parks Pass, you're still going to get socked with a nice "parking fee."

We first stopped here in the evening and went to the lighting ceremony and watched the movie. Then went back in the morning and walked around more. It's good to go both times. If you're a veteran they recognize you at the night ceremony. The parking permit they give you ($10 at time we went) is good for the year.
Its what you expect full of people but worth the time.. Its 10 dollars a car for parking even if you have a senior citizen free park pass just an fyi

Our dream was to someday see Mt Rushmore. We were worried that we had such high expectations that we would be disappointed. We were awe struck. It was moving to see this piece of history. We were happy to pay the small parking fee of $10 to help with the cost. It was nice that you could walk the path and see it closer. I wished we stayed in Keystone because it looked so cute and closer so that we would have gone back to see the lighting ceremony. We stayed in Rapid City and it was about 25 minutes away so we didn't go back at night which I regret now.

This was awesome. We started our trip in Keystone and wound our way down route 16 into the Custer State Park (the $12 is totally worth it) and got a great view of Rushmore from afar. The journey through the park, along the Wilderness Loop and then on the Needles Highway is fantastic. We went to the Crazy Horse but for $20 admission did not go further than the end of the hill to turn around.

We arrived around 3pm from Devils Tower (WY) via 85/385/16/16A from Spearfish and wish we'd spent more time stopping along the way but it's a good way to get there rather than just going straight from RAP. Amazing to see in person and well worth whatever the NPS entry fee was--$10/car I think which holds over all day [including return for night]. Definitely walk around the wooden walkway and most people should be able to do the loop--maybe a mile [guess] when it's all said and done and mostly level so not really physically demanding; some stairs here and there so I think handicapped folks would be somewhat limited in making the entire loop. Get some good vantage points from nooks and crannies of the fellas on the hill and the trail leads you over to the small museum where there is a video of the construction and a mock up of some equipment. All told two adults can swing the whole thing in 90 minutes including taking pictures but do that stuff during the day. Come back later at night using same parking pass, grab some ice cream and bring it out for a good seat for the evening lighting ceremony. There was an excellent movie that last 20-30 minutes around dusk followed by some narrative from a ranger [and a song actually], and at least on our night the ranger asked veterans to stand and be recognized then come down to the platform for retiring the Colors. So you'll spend maybe 3 hours all day split between two visits but not bad for parking fee..excellent value actually.

Went to visit this site to check another place off in our National Park Passport. We didn't do a guided tour of either location but we explored the Melrose Plantation on our own. It was my first time visiting a Southern plantation but was everything I imagined it would be.

We only toured the Melrose Estate and found it very interesting and educational. The slavery display was simple but well done. The exterior of the house was under renovation, but it didn't diminish the experience. The fee to tour was minimal at $10 per adult and $5 per child. Credit cards are not accepted so bring cash.

Entry fee of $10 per vehicle, no charge with the NPS Senior Pass. This national monument is very clean and well kept. We drove the 9 mile Bridge View Drive loop and stopped at all overlooks for scenery views and of the 3 major natural bridges. It was quite the drive to get here but we were not disappointed.

Arrived just before sunset and set up camp before hitting a trail for a short hike. Nice, clean campsites. Easy late registration. $5 with Senior Pass. No food services nearby. Really enjoyed seeing my first and second natural arch. Awesome landscape.

Go to the visitors center first and learn about the bridges, grab a map and watch the short film. Cost for the park is $5pp, less for kids, senior pass and interagency pass. We did a loop hike parking our vehicle at Kachina parking lot. We started on the Mesa trail which is pretty level to the Sipapu trail which is steep and leads down to the Sipapu bridge by stairs, ladders then followed along the canyon/dry stream bed (not marked very well)to Kachina bridge. From there we climbed out of the canyon by stairs which are pretty steep. It is 5.6miles total. Or you can continue on to Owachina bridge for another 3 mi which we were too tired to do! We are not athletes or young so it took us 4 hrs. The views of the bridges from the bottom are impressive! Bring lots of water. If you prefer not to hike you can drive the park loop and stop at the viewpoints. Or hike up and down to each bridge. The park was not crowded and we saw no one else on the loop we did.

On a motorcycle trip I stopped by on a whim and since I have the Senior Pass it didn't really cost anything. I made it to all of the bridges view points except one and I couldn't physically make that one. Most of the walks to the view points were gentle. I did a couple with a 90 year old lady I met there who was traveling with her son. She made it to all of the view points that I did. BTW, the last bridge is the best.

Natural Bridges National Monument was the first monument in Utah - the land was set aside by Theodore Roosevelt. Three Natural bridges can be view on an easy 9 mile drive - there are trails to each for folks taking the time to really experience the Monument. A fine visitor center staffed by knowledgeable and accommodating members. Remember to use your Golden Age pass - and put a few bucks in the collection box. Those dollars stay at the Natural bridges National Monument.

This was the nicest, cleanest most well maintained park we visited while in Utah. I believe they had the cleanest bathrooms of anywhere we had been. The road was in good repair. The signage was good and the trails were well marked. It is a small park that is easily done in a couple hours. All the bridges can be seen with a short walk to a view point. The Indian ruins is a longer walk but worth the effort. We were there early in the morning and we had the park to ourselves. The rain form the night before left natural pools that reflected the sky adding a nice touch. The entrance fee was only $6.00. Well done National Park Service, the people in charge of this park need to be recognized for their work.

It is a ways off the highway but well worth the time to get there. The drive takes you to three different stops to see natural bridges. Not as spectacular as Arches National Park, but the geology is so interesting in every part of Utah. Make sure if you are a senior (older than 62) you get your forever National Park pass for $10. It's well worth it.

Natural Bridges National Monument was so great! We loved it! There were beautiful natural bridges and ancient Native American ruins. We hiked the short distance to see the Horsecollar Ruin. It was an easy hike with amazing views. There were several hikes in the monument, but we didn't have time to do them. We'd like to go back there and spend more time. The staff at the visitor's center were helpful and informative. Unlike the national parks, there were no signs prohibiting our dogs from going beyond the parking lots. Also, unlike the national parks, the fee was quite reasonable -- I think $6.50 (not sure because we had the National Parks annual pass, but heard her quote the price to another traveler.) This was a great experience!

In my opinion the campground at the Natural Bridges National Monument is a real gem. There are only 13 sites but there is so much space between them that my tent wasn’t visible to other campers. There were at least two other tent campers, van campers and RVs. I think the length of RVs is limited to 28 ft. The campground is spotless with very clean bathrooms. Maintenance people are there working all the time, making certain this campground remains presentable and appealing to every guest. No water available at the campground but you can get 5 gallon of water per day from the visitor center. Short path goes from the campground to the visitor center. From my tent I had a great view of Bear Ears. There are several areas with recycling bins and trash bins. Each site has a tent pad, grill and picnic bench. It is $10.00 or $5.00 with senior pass. The drive to the campground from Blending on route 95 is visually spectacular with many Indian Ruins and some of them are right off 95. The signs point to them so it is obvious where they are.

I went to this park on my stay in Blanding. A charge for the park is $6 per car. Not bad for what they have in park. I only like the third natural bridge in the park. The first two, I didn’t think was worth the hike so I only viewed from the parking lot site. However, the third natural bridge was worth the hike. Thank god the hike was only .5 mile. That was plus for me. I am not a fan of hiking but .5 mile was fine by me.

We had not planned to stop here before the owner of our motel in Monticello told us not to miss it. We arrived before the park opened and the rangers actually opened the Visitor’s Center early for us! We used our Senior National Park Pass so there was no entrance fee. The rangers were very friendly and helpful and actually gave us tips for our visit to Monument Valley and other places. We had been to Arches National Park the day before and wondered about the difference between arches and bridges. Natural bridges are formed by the erosive action of moving water. Arches are formed by other erosive actions such as frost action and seeping moisture.

The husband and I stopped here during a week-long road trip and were surprised by the splendor. The bridges are easily accessible from overlooks so one can just stop and view them, or you can go on several nice hikes to get closer to them. The scenery is beautiful and provides numerous stunning photography opportunities. There are some nice Native American ruins along one of the canyon walls to view (for this, I wish I had brought binoculars to get a better look). The landscape is pretty amazing and the park is peaceful as it does not get too crowded. The facilities are in excellent repair and the Park Ranger was very helpful and clearly enjoys his job. This park is definitely worth seeing and the entrance fee was cheap (about $7). We drove from the park toward Hite, UT, near Lake Powell, and the scenery was amazing.

I grew up in Utah and thought I knew all the parks -- state and national -- but this one was a map discovery. what a cool place! the gift shop has an excellent display and a fabulous selection of books -- a good place to buy the "old fart pass" to the parks for $10. The hike down to Owachomo arch was worth the effort -- word of warning -- you MUST have a wide angle or fisheye lens to do justice to the arch!

we came for the awesome history, we had some canoes on top soo our clearance made it so we could not fit into the parking garage, $2 to pay the metter, no feeding the metter, that is a $25 fine, with the meter man right there!!! No time to enjoy, wander, just a the stress of get on out, disaponting because the musem is wonderful & I wanted to see sooo much more, they need to amend the parking rule to accomidate ALL their visitors or provide sutable parking, this was also during the week NOT a weekend!!
park: New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park

text: Went to get the Passport Stamps. Ranger was very informative and the movie presentation gives a good base to see the rest of the National Park sites and related parks in New Bedford and the local area. Plus no fee at present.
park: New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park

text: We have a National Parks Passport so when I was in town for business, I knew I needed to stop in and get stamped. There was some outside rehab work going on. The rangers were friendly and the main visitors center was nicely done. They have me a walking map to help me find the various locations though I found it hard to really determine the location of the waterfront park (the map didn't show post 911 security changes as it is located by the ferries) so I had to loop around to get back. In hindsight, walking would have been easier. I THINK I found the waterfront center but no one was there. I am guessing it is much busier in the summer. A very nice diversion.
park: New Bedford Whaling National Historical Park

text: We attended the "Festival Of Stars 2017" and had a great time. Many activities for children, helicopter rides, many vendors selling different food items, live music and the evening concluded with fireworks..The festival admission price was free. However, VIP seating for headliner Aaron Tippin was $25 per person. We certainly enjoyed the show. The heat and humidity not so much. I have never experienced anything quite like that before. My clothes were dripping wet within minutes of exiting the car. I can not believe residents actually are accustomed to this weather. I could never live there because it was total misery. I found everyone to be very friendly and welcoming. This would be a nice area to visit during the winter season.
We only stopped here because it was in my Passport to the National Parks and on the way to where we were headed. We had never heard of it. Glad we stopped!!

If you are planning to visit this National Historic Site, please take a few minutes when you arrive to watch the short film found in the Visitor's Office where the park rangers offices are located. This puts everything into perspective and allows you to get a sense of the importance of this site in our American history. Another suggestion, bring your National Park Passport so it can be stamped at the front desk. (If you don't have one, get one at this office). The park is beautiful, clean and free (unless you care to leave a donation). We're so glad we took a few minutes to visit. Now I know why it was called Star Fort.

I thoroughly enjoyed Ninety Six NHS. Like most other Battlefields, it is more of a park with hiking trails. However, that being said, the Park Service did a great job with signs, silhouettes, and recreated buildings. I believe that one of the buildings is actually original. The visitor center had lots of information and as usual, a great movie that introduced you to the setting. One should watch the movie to understand what happened here. The paved path is only one mile long. There are signs everywhere stating what happened where. It's a wonderful location for a picnic lunch. I would definitely recommend going to Cowpens and Kings Mountain in conjunction with Ninety Six. Those two National Sites are about two hours away. Admission was free.

The North Unit of Theodore Roosevelt National Park is much less visited than the South Unit. Both units lie along the Little Missouri River, and are about 70 miles apart by car. The North Unit Visitor Center is located near the park entrance about 11 miles south of Watford City on US 85. A short film gives an overview of park history, geology, wildlife and things to see. Scenic Drive winds 28 miles (round trip) along the cliffs, outcrops, coulees and canyons formed by the Little Missouri cutting into colorful bands of rock.
