There are numerous pullouts to view the rugged landscape and rock formations. The cannonball concretions are particularly interesting, and are adjacent to the drive. Wildlife abounds, particularly early in the morning. There are numerous bison, elk, pronghorns, longhorn cattle, feral horses, mule deer, prairie dogs, and hundreds of bird species. Four trails, Achenbach, Buckhorn, Caprock Coulee and the Little Mo Nature Trail thread through the park. I enjoyed the Caprock Coulee Trail which starts in the bottomlands along Squaw Creek and ascends to the caprock plateau near River Bend Overlook. It traversed grasslands and forest habitats, and offered spectacular views of the badlands along the river. The Little Mo Nature Trail starts near Juniper Campground and the picnic area. It is the least strenuous of the four trails, and has interpretive information at numbered stops. Oxbow Overlook, at the end of Scenic Drive is the starting point for the north and south Achenbach trails. It rained during my visit, and the ancient volcanic ash layers became quite slick (like ice, only not so flat). If hiking, wear sturdy shoes, carry food and water, and be ready for sudden changes in weather. Bicycling along park roads is a great way to see wildlife. You can canoe, kayak or fish in the river. There is a $20 per car entrance fee (Senior Pass half price).

We rode motorcycles coming west on RT 200 from Devils Lake. It was an spectacular day that was only made better when we got to the badlands. The views look like the moon must look in many places and it was an unexpected surprise. We camped at Juniper and the park service was friendly. The camping site was $12 plus the entrance fee, but everything is cheaper if you have a Federal park Sr. Citizens pass. Campsite didn't have showers, but had everything else you'd expect. The little Missouri River is next to the campsite. We were thinking about fishing, but it was really muddy and apparently was geared towards catfish. The ride to the end of the trail is scenic and worth doing.

I visited the North Unit of Roosevelt National Park with family and was blown away by its rugged beauty and wildlife. The park offers a 14 mile stretch of paved roadway that takes you through the park. There are also many walking trails throughout the park. Definitely stop at the entrance before going in and pick up a map. Entrance fee is only 10$ per vehicle. The park has about 3-4 scenic overlooks where you can park and walk out to get great pictures and view wildlife. We were able to see several bison, a buffalo crossing the road, mule deer, and big-horned sheep. We drove about four hours from Minot to see the park. Definitely worth the long drive!

Beautiful surreal cliffs and plateaus occasionally with a buffalo standing atop a high plateau or maybe just ambling down the road. Park is lightly traveled on a September weekday. $20 per vehicle or use your National Park Pass. The north unit is near Watford City. Whatever detour you need to make it is worth it.

Our kids loved this place! They joined the Junior Ranger program here for like $3....so worth it; ask the any ranger about it. They have a film area, hand on things, and other great educational viewings here. Restrooms and all very close the geyser. Have fun here!
Beautiful center and gift shop! Stop and get your NP Passport stamped. Kids can also sign up for the Jr Ranger Program.

Make sure to park in front of the visitor center as you can walk right through it to Old Faithful. Running close to the estimated time? No problem you can view Old Faithful from the center. Souvenirs, junior ranger programs ($3) at the ranger stand, national park "passport" stamps, education and much more. This is one of the best stops in GTNP or YNP. Also check out Old Faithful Lodge next door, amazing piece of history and architecture.

The Center, like others in the park, are stocked with wonderful, helpful, friendly rangers. They are all so pleasant to speak with. Be sure to join the Yellowstone Association for as little as $35 for the year to save 15% on all purchase in the park stores not including rooms or the Xanterra restaurants, but including gift shops, book shops, general stores (not eat in food) and coffee shops.

You want to be sure and take the time to stop and get all the various $1 donation each brochures--Old Faithful, Fountain Paint Pot, Norris Geyser Basin, Canyon and Mammoth Hot Springs. They're well worth the donation. There were 4 park rangers there to answer questions and help you plan your tour.

Of course you are going to come see Old Faithful. Everyone does. The information center there is well worth exploring also. Many facts about geysers and the formations and sights found in Yellowstone. Pay no attention to the fact that you are sitting atop one of the worlds largest volcanos that could erupt at any second. Have a great time. The odds are way in your favor against such an event.

This is a great place - the building itself is beautiful. And it had a ton of great information. There is an information center where you can ask park rangers questions, get time predictions for the next big geysers to go off, and get brochures (they are $0.50 a piece but are well worth it as they have maps of all of the different geyser basins). There is also a gift shop/book store and the restrooms are really nice, so I would take advantage of those since a nice one can sometimes be hard to find!

Great Geyser viewing area. Lots of information and displays to help learn how it all works. Rangers are helpful and friendly. Prices are always ridiculous in parks so nothing new here, however, lots of books you may not find anywhere else. Junior Ranger program is great for kids 5 and up and the kids will love participating in completing their books to earn a badge! Can't wait to go back next year!

Our kids did both the Junior Ranger and Junior Scientist programs. Both programs require the kids to complete some activities that help them to understand what they are seeing and learn along the way. The programs are fun & the Ranger program especially kept our kids busy in the car while we were driving from one area to another. The Ranger program is $3 per kid and the Scientist program is $5. The Scientist program needs to be completed at the Old Faithful area and there is a backpack to check out for 3 hours. We didn't know until we did the Scientist program on the morning we left, but the Canyon area has a separate Scientist program that must be done at that location. My kids will treasure their badges, but hopefully they can remember something about the park due to these great programs.

I had limited time on my trip to western Wyoming, so after spending the bulk of my time in beautiful Grand Teton National Park, I decided to make the drive through Grand Teton north into Yellowstone. When you enter Grand Teton for a $20 fee per carload, Yellowstone is thrown in free. A two-for-one deal.

The Talimena Scenic Drive is a 50 mile drive along the ridge of the Winding Stair Mountains. In late October and early November the drive offers some of the best fall foliage in the south. Year round, the drive has RV and primitive camping, day use picnic areas, and a scenic turn-out almost every mile.For the more active, the Ouachita National Rereation Trail offers 225 miles of "easy to moderate" hiking between Talimena State Park in Oklahoma to Pinnacle Mountain State Park just west of Little Rock, Arkansas. Trailhead parking and primitive campsites are located about seven miles apart in the section of trail that follows the ridge of the Winding Stair Mountians. There is a $3 fee to camp, but you have free access to the showers in the adjoining RV parks. If you want to "loop" back to your car, you can take the equestrain trails down through the Holson Valley.Plan a stop at the Queen Wilhelmina State Park atop Rich Mountain in Arkansas. Just east of the Okla/Ark state line, this park has something for every member to your family or group. In addition to RV and tent camping, the lodge and restaurant offer food and accommodations, there are many children's activities, and several easy nature trails. Both the senic drive and the Ouachita Trail pass through this park. Reservations may be needed in the summer or fall. Call (800) 264-2477.Don't overlook this section of the country. You'll have to get off the d... interstate, and it may "cost" you a day, but it will be well worth it. After taking the drive, you may want to enjoy the local lakes, museums, and other attractions in the area.

I am convinced that my "post-40 hour plus per week" life, some people call it retirement, is a time to re-learn what we were taught in school. The 15 minute film is the place to start - concisely tells the manifest destiny mind set of President Polk and the Texas republic in contrast with the Mexican view of their land rights. Must take the walk across the prairie to see the lines of battle. A short 10 page history is for sale at the cost of $1.00. Really. Go in the spring before the heat sets in as there is no shade.
park: Palo Alto Battlefield National Historic Site

text: Palo Alto is not well-known, even among locals; however, this is a fantastic historic site that is well-run and does justice to the important events that occurred here. The museum is very informative and the staff are truly knowledgeable, friendly, and hard-working. They have done a nice job with the site. Expect it to get hot (very) in the summer. Pay particular attention to the fact you can use this site not only for history, but as a great way to see the local flora and fauna and even a dry bed Resaca (old distributary of the Rio Grande). The staff, which I have worked with professionally in the past, have done an excellent job of trying to recreate the look and "environmental feel" of the entire grounds. What a gem!
park: Palo Alto Battlefield National Historic Site

text: We visited the Battlefield during the week, and were the ones there at that time. We watched the little video that told the story of the battle - worth it. Then walked the trails to the Battle site. You can drive a little ways up, but you still have to walk a little to get to the main part of the battlefield. It wasn't a hard walk, pretty level paved paths, well marked with historical markers. Small gift store. We enjoyed our visit, and this Historic Site also has the Passport stamp if you participate in that program.
park: Palo Alto Battlefield National Historic Site

text: My special needs daughter and I were on a motorcycle trip. We were headed to South Padre when I saw a sign for Palo Alto Battlefield. I knew of the battle but not the park. I got into collecting stamps in my National Parks Passport Book when I achieved my Iron Butt Association Master Traveler National Parks Certificate. It requires at least 50 parks with at least one each in 25 states with in 12 months. Plus I am a history buff and Army Brat, so this was a required stop. We did not have time to do the walk but we did have a very long talk with the ranger in the visitor's center. He was a young guy, last name Hernandez, working on his master's degree in Mexican American History. He told us all about the battle and we discused many aspects of what it must have been like for both sides to exist in those conditions let alone fight a battle. If you are in the area this is a good history lesson which we all need to remember.
park: Palo Alto Battlefield National Historic Site

text: Born of molten lava which formed into Basalt, the Great Falls emerged 13,000 years ago after the last ice age. At 77 feet tall and 300 feet wide it is the second most powerful falls east of the Mississippi. The first being Niagra Falls. I have visited the falls many times but this past Sunday was truly spectacular. The Passaic River over flow has turned to cascade water and ice. There were many photographers present, I among them. If you are interested in photography this is a must. Views can be had from multiple positions including bridge footpath that takes you over the falls.
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: I am a National Park geek. I also love waterfalls and anything related to Alexander Hamilton. He created the town to harness the falls of the Passaic for industry. Some of the mill buildings still exist and have been repurposed. Take the drive that goes by these buildings. Only a few parts are totally accessible, but you can see the falls. There is a reasonable amount of walking so that you can see why Hamilton thought this would be a great place for new industry for a new country. The visitor center is small, but there is a National Parks passport station to get a stamp.
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: If you are looking for a unique combination of natural wonder and fascinating US history, do not miss the Great Falls National Historical Park in Paterson NJ. This is the birthplace of American domestic manufacturing in the very beginning of the 19th century. Founded by Alexander Hamilton, who visualize the potential for industrial power in the 77-foot Great Falls, planned by Pierre L'Enfant (who later drew the plans for Washington DC), paterson had a rich history as the site of factories that not only produced the highest quality silk in America (thus the city's nickname, "Silk City") but also Colt revolvers, the locomotives used to push Westward and dig the Panama Canal, the first working submarine and the engine that powered "The Spirit of St. Louis." The 19th century mill buildings, the remnants of the complex raceways that diverted the Passaic River to the water wheels that powered the mills, the geology of the chasm itself -- all worth a few hour's visit and tour. Don't miss Hinchliffe Stadium nearby, home to many of the Negro League baseball greats; also see the Paterson Museum, housed in one of the mill buildings, containing relics of the city's industrial history.
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: Growing up in Totowa, I have always loved visiting the Paterson Falls, but it has been 40 years since I have been back. The park has guides to answer questions, there are various levels to view the falls and a bridge to cross over the Passaic River at the top of the falls. There is a museum filled with the history of not only the falls, but Paterson and Alexander Hamilton and the beginnings of our country! A must see for young and old!!! Bring your camera!
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: The falls are beautiful and the park was recently renovated. Hard to believe Paterson has its own waterfalls. This is a must see if nearby. While the surrounding area is not so good, there are some interesting old buildings nearby in the historic district. Went to see the Lou Costello statue which is only a few blocks away in the middle of a small park.
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: The City of Paterson played a major part in the American Industrial Revolution....From the 1700's on, Paterson was home to manufacturers from silk to colt revolvers to locomotives and even submarines....so much manufacturing was done Paterson and mainly centered around the Great Falls and Passaic River....many immigrants arrived in Paterson and worked at one of the many textile mills or machine shops....Unfortunately, the city declined over the years, and this once beautiful area fell into disrepair and negligence....It has improved somewhat, but there is still a lot of graffiti, trash, etc in the area....the falls are beautiful, but the surrounding area is not....Hopefully the city will improve the area over time, after all, it is a national historical site....springtime or after heavy rainfalls would be the best time to see the falls because of increased water levels resulting in more water going over the dam....
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: Ok, so I grew up in NJ read that the falls of Paterson was now a National Park. I was like, ok - cool. Let's go see it. I went there and was very underwhelmed by what I saw. The falls are nice to look at, but this is a 15-30 minute trip at best. It's not worth going out of your way to see, unless you happen to be in Passaic County.
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: Great sight in the middle of Paterson. On our drive toward the falls it did seem like we were headed into a bad part of town (multiple liquor stores and rundown buildings) but my wife and I never felt unsafe or did we encounter anyone begging for money. Living in Bergen county all of my life I couldn't believe I've never heard of the falls and recently made the trek. The only mistake we made was seeing Niagara Falls just a few weeks prior to these. Walking through the mist from the Passaic river was a bit different than that of the Niagara Falls.
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: This falls was the focus of the new town, Paterson, that Alexander Hamilton helped found along te Passaic River. Its a real beauty, though the town of Paterson itself leaves much to be desired. There is a Burger King nearby and this has convenient coffee and food. AND a bathroom. If you love American history, tour the falls and surrounding factories. If it has rained recently, all the better.
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: Stopped here on our way from Tenafly to Basking Ridge. Plenty of water rushing over the falls. Beautiful. Small parking lot (signs encourage you to lock your car and hide valuables-area a little sketchy) and small free visitor center/museum across the street. The man staffing the building was a little much (didn't really answer questions so much as tell us that visitors aren't so smart and if they insist on asking questions they won't be able to listen to him talk). Needless to say, we couldn't get a word in during our 20 minute visit and instead of sitting down to watch the 15 minute film, we made a quick bathroom visit and escaped to the nearby Paterson Museum to learn more about the Falls and the use of the Passaic in .
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: The Great Falls aka The Passaic Falls is a marvel to behold. It just takes your breath away. The views are obscured a bit by urban fences and proximity to falls. The area around Lou Costello Park is a bit intimidating as it is a hangout for undesireables. Just be careful. Paterson's heyday was in the past. Urban decay has ravaged this city. If you still want to see the majestic Falls, add a few more sights so the trip is not a total waste of time. I suggest seeing Lambert's Castle, and the Paterson Post Office. Parking around the falls is limited to the lot near the info center.
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: The Great Falls National Historical Park encompasses the Great Falls overviews and park area, the visitor's center, the historical neighborhood and buildings and the Paterson Museum. Start at the Visitor's Center where you will find a video, graphic information and period photos of the Falls restrooms and a parking lot.. A ranger is at hand and tours are given on the weekends. Next, see the Falls from various viewpoints, Haines Overlook Park, Marry Ellen Park and the footbridge which gives you a view from above the Falls. There are also trails. Proceed down Spruce Street to view the location of the 1rst continuous roll paper mill (1812), Phoenix Mill (1813), Rodgers Locomotive Works (1832), Colt Revolver Factory(1837) and the USS Holland (ss-1) submarine (1898). One block from the Visitor's Center you will find the Paterson Museum. For a nominal fee $3 you will see artifacts from Paterson's Industrial History including an extensive collection of Colt Firearms. The Falls was formed by the last Glacial Period some 13,000 years ago It is 260' wide, 77' tall and is feed by the Passaic River. It was Alexander Hamilton's vision and political support that made the Great Falls the first planned industrial city in 1791. Sam Patch the Jersey Jumper jumped off the Falls in 1827, he also performed stunts at Niagara Falls. In season 1 episode 6 two mobsters throw a drug dealer over the Falls. The Great Falls became a National Park in 2009 under the Obama Administration. It is a work in Progress as more money is allocated to it's development.
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: You have the sense that you are visiting a work in progress when you come here. A tiny but friendly visitor's center, limited parking but a bigger space to open by Summer '18, a famous statue of the city's founder, Alexander Hamilton, hidden in a box to keep it safe while work is going on. The National HIstorical Park is just 6 years old, and there is much to be done. But worth visiting, even now as things are getting fixed up. Good videos in the center, helping you learn about the first planned industrial city in America, born of Hamilton's vision and powered by the Great Falls, about one of the last and greatest Negro League Baseball Fields to remain standing, part of our sad history of segregation and the gifted athletes who transcended it, and about the Falls themselves. The Passaic River has a seasonal ebb and flow, and if you catch it at the wrong time, the Falls are a dribble. But at the right time (and today was that) it has a magnificence that rivals Niagara, but in a smaller, enclosed space. Quite amazing and beautiful. The Park Service has made progress, in concert with the town, to try to clean it up, though you do still see some trash. So not pristine, but a complex interplay of major American industrial history, social history, and ecology, all in a wondrous waterfall. Hint: Try to arrange an interpretive Ranger tour, it will make the whole story come together much better. No fees or Park Passports are required.
park: Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park

text: Our visit to Pecos National Historical Park was without doubt one of the highlights of our recent trip to New Mexico. We had just missed the last guided Ranger tour but picked up the self-guided booklet for $2 and struck out on our own. It was an easily managed walk that is about a mile in length and the booklet and signage are very informative. We later picnicked at the tables near the administrative offices and the facilities were well-kept.

This park is about 35 minutes from Santa Fe, with great signage along the way. Admission is free, and there is a beautiful visitor center with a museum, gift shop, and theater with an introduction film. Staff was very friendly.

There are actually two different reasons to visit. First is an easy walk to visit the ruins of the Pueblo People of the Pecos. The second is you can visit that part of the park which was the site of the 1862 American Civil War Battle of Glorieta Pass. The Glorieta Pass trail is very well maintained and a little over 2 miles long with quite a few interpretive signs along the way. The only downside is that visibility is limited because the trees have grown back over the ensuing 150 years since the battle. We were unable to take any of the guided tours that are available from the park service.

If you are visiting the Santa Fe area, Pecos is an easy drive and offers some of the best historical perspective on the area. Life of the early pueblo inhabitants, Glorieta Pass, and the Santa Fe Trail are all showcased at one site. Like other historic treasures managed by the National Park Service, Pecos NHP is no exception--expertly done! The on-mile paved trail around the park makes the pueblo ruins and mission church accessible to everyone. Take time to view the exhibits at the visitor center then walk through the park. If you enjoy history, you won't be disappointed.

Pecos National Historical Park in Pecos, NM celebrates the 1200 year history of Pecos Indians inhabiting this enormous and strategically situated Pueblo. The strategic location below the Glorieta Pass and, on a height of land providing views to warn of approaching attack was ideal for habitation.

Pecos is definitely worth a stop if you are near Santa Fe. It had some great pueblo ruins and a fascinating large church. The trail is easy and fairly compact around the ruins area. There is also a Civil War battlefield trail you can take if you sign in at the visitors center. The views are very pretty as it is close to Glorieta Pass and the Sangre de Cristo mountains.

This site has a great paved trail that walks you through the Pecos Pueblo and highlighted by the Pecos Pueblo Mission Church. Be sure to inquire about the Glorieta Pass Battlefield at the visitor center.

If you are up to your eyes in great Santa Fe museums and sites, take a short drive over the pass on Interstate 25 to Pecos and follow the signs to this National Historic Park. Entrance is $7 per person and worth it. A great into movie at the Visitor Center, then an interesting 1.2 mile walk through the pueblo excavations and the two mission churches and convent type buildings. The staff is, as usual for a National Park service facility, friendly and great to deal with. The walk is informative. The views from the property magnificent. We picnicked near the 17th century church ruins before going to see the Civil War battlefield (separate review). This is a special place with great bathroom facilities, and great selection of gear and books and nice folks. We did not plan this at the start of our trip, but it really enhanced it.

This was a great national park. It really brings to life visions of the past culture of some native peoples. Don't miss the tour; we even did the off-site $2 tour. Our guide was Suzan and she was very knowledgable, friendly, and enthusiastic. Great! They definitely need more signage from the highway though; a sign saying, 'Visitor Center this way' would have saved us valuable minutes and a lot of stress. We had no idea what to do when we got to a big sign that said 'Welcome to Pecos National Historical Site' with no other direction and we were told GPS doesn't work! The ranger I called in desperation was so sweet she stayed on the phone with me, giving me directions as I drove. Kind of strange problem to have!

If you are interested in Puebloan history, this is a great place to explore. There is a small museum and a 13 minute video about the area. The former actress, Greer Garson, owned a small part of the land. There is a 1.2 mile trail around the old pueblo with plenty of signage explaining the different areas. The volunteer was very helpful and friendly. They do charge $3 to go through the area.

If you get the opportunity, take the Glorietta Pass tour with Roger Clark. He was so informative regarding this Civil War battle that took place in New Mexico. I am somewhat familiar with the details of this battle and Roger brought it to life for me. His detail regarding the personalities was phenomenal, including the ultimate demise of one of the main characters "the Slough (pronounced slow) death". If you are in the Santa Fe area, do not miss a chance to "experience" this little known battle.
The Ruins, especially the Church were amazing, and really enjoyed the tour of the Glorieta Pass Civil War Battle, and understanding an aspect of history we knew nothing about. Guide was great.

If you are traveling I-25 the Pecos National Park is a great stop. The Access is easy off and on I-25 traveling parallel so you lose no travel time. The Visitor Center has a great display and explanation of the Civil War Battle of Glorieta Pass and a the history of the Pueblo Indian and Spanish settlement.

About a half hour drive from Santa Fe on 25. The Visitors Center is a must first stop. Very helpful Ranger. Spend the 10 minutes to see the film, then another short visit to the museum. It gives you the whole historical context of what you are about to see. They give you a nice plasticized four page trail map explaining the well marked feature points, which you return when done. Very concise and helpful. Then you can either do a pleasant 1.2 mile walk from there, or if you have less time, a short drive to the park HQ lot,which puts you right next to the remains of the Spanish church. Then you do the loop, through the church and adjoining pueblo ruins in a little less than a mile. Great vistas of the area. The pueblo was built on a high point and existed as a trading point to the western plains for milleniums before the conquistadors showed up and undermined their world. This is not a pueblo site built into a cliff. This was a free-standing four story pueblo occupied by two thousand people. What is left are excavated remnants of foundations and rooms, and several well preserved underground kivas you can actually climb down into. Well marked paved trail with signs giving the history and details. The second church remains are the best preserved, albeit worn away by the weather, the first much larger church having been destroyed in the Pueblo Revolt of 1680. You look at the surrounding mountains and valley below and feel the history and the lives of those who lived it. A special place. Worth the trip. Ps. It only costs three dollars for an adult to visit.

We went right after Christmas 2013 just for a fun day out of doors. The park is located a short, easy drive from Santa Fe. The trail is well laid out and great for walking. As I recall, it's just over a mile in total, but it was not a difficult walk. If you can't walk the whole trail, there is a parking lot at the end of the trail (not near the visitors center). Pay your admission at the visitors center and then drive around to that parking lot. Most of the ruins are very near that lot. The Rangers and volunteers in the visitors center are very helpful and friendly. Here's the plus- your leashed dogs are allowed on the trail. We had a very nice hike in the sunshine with our furry family members. The ruins are beautiful and you can even enter the kiva (no dogs allowed there!) I know we will visit this park again with our next out of town visitors.

You simply must start with the Park film, or you won't have a historical perspective to appreciate these ruins and how these folks must have lived. The relationship of these early peoples to their neighbors, and later to the Spanish is important to understanding what otherwise might be just a few rock foundations still standing. Much of the old (second) mission church is still there, and at least one of the underground kivas has been rebuilt. There is another section of the park a few miles away at Glorieta Pass, where a crucial battle of the Civil War was fought, that ended the South's westward expansion. Again, you need to review the displays in the visitor center to appreciate that battle, because there isn't much out there to see otherwise. It still takes less than two hours to see the film, walk the self-guiding trail, and look through the visitor center.

The short film in the park center, really gives a good perspective of what one is about to see. The park rangers are extremely helpful as well. You can strike out on your own with a map, staying on the trails (watching for rattle snakes) or you can wait for a ranger-led tour. Imagine a village of Pueblo Indians living in harmony eventually being run over by other peoples, in the 1500's. The ruins tell the story very well. There is a $3 fee but we used our Golden Age passes good in any national park. Very well maintained.
For anyone interested in the history of the Southwest, as well as the Civil War (Glorieta Pass - the "Gettysburg of the West"), this is well worth visiting.

This large park has theruins of an Indian peublo that was built, destroyed, then built again in the 1700. There is a walking trail around the puebo and a very good guide. The visitors center is a beautiful building with a very good museum with artifacts that covers the history of the area. There is also an excellent video narrated by Greer Garson, the actress, who owned a large ranch in the area which was eventually donated to the National Park Service. This area had the Santa Fe Trail and pre 1937 Route 66 go through it. If you are interested in Civil War history they have directions, maps to the only battle in New Mexico, the Battle of Glorietta Pass. Ask for it at the visitors center--you will need the code to unlock the gate.

Here is a park in which you can learn about early American civilizations and how europeans changed them forever. Then you can learn about the civil war in the west. Make sure you make reservations ahead of time for the tours. We found the civil war tour of the Battle of Glorieta Pass to be outstanding since the guide took us by van to all of the important sites. Great for families who want to learn history the right way, by being where it happened!
This review deal strictly with the new unit of the Pecos National Historic Park, their Glorieta Pass Battlefield unit.

I visited, from Santa Fe, on Friday, July 23, 2010. I arrived just before 10am, just in time for the 90 minute guided tour. I paid my $3 admission (tour is included with admission) and joined Cathy, the Ranger/Teacher guide, along with several other visitors to the park. I have to say that this tour is very worthwhile. If at all possible, try to visit the park at a time when you can take the tour. Cathy really knew her stuff and opened up the history to the place. This was all the more important since much of the ruins have not been excavated. We needed the interpretation to bring it to life. (I think that they do have a written guide if you’re not visiting when a tour is on offer.) Visualizing the intense trading culture that would have characterized Pecos was pretty powerful. The most significant ruins in terms of physical presence, as elsewhere, were those of the mission church. (Very similar to Quarai at Salinas Pueblo Missions National Monument, yet different by virtue of the surrounding landscape and the specific history.) After the tour, I watched the 10 minute video in the visitor center, which had I arrived earlier would have been better before the tour. Still worthwhile. I also visited the museum which had a great historical pottery display along with excellent informational placards. (I felt that this visit complemented, rather than duplicated, a visit I made to Salinas Pueblo Missions National Monument.) Altogether I stayed a little over 2 hours.

This is a nice side trip from Santa Fe. It is a hike through old pueblo ruins. Really well preserved and nice views of the surrounding area. Opportunities to climb down into kivas and see an old church structure. Lots of good places for pictures and worthwhile to spend a few dollars to get the guide book in the welcome center. It's a pretty easy hike - well marked and easy to navigate.

Well worth making the easy drive from Santa Fe. Admission fee is nominal and the park is an easy walk. The scenery is beautiful. Be sure to purchase the informative booklet that details the park history at markers along the trail. There are picnic tables (3) at the main entrance and several more at a separate parking area.

We ended up going here as a bit of a last minute decision, while looking for some stops on our way home from Santa Fe. It is about 45 minutes from the city and definitely worth the drive. The scenery is gorgeous, and the site is very informative about the region, from the native Pueblo Indians to the Spanish settlers, and the economic and cultural dynamics of the region. There is also some interest for civil war buffs as the main New Mexican Civil war battle was in the area. The main trail will take you about 45 minutes to walk and sight see with the trail guide (and if you are like me, take a ton of photos). Entrance fees are only $2-3 per person. If you are looking for a easy affordable day trip from Santa Fe, this is worth checking out.

We were driving a scenic bypass and came across the Pecos National Historic Park in Las Vegas, New Mexico. This is a must see. The history of Pecocos NHP is anazing. Never knew a Civil War battle was fought in the area. The Visitor Center person was so knowledgeable and helpful. The musuem is great and has terrific exhibits. See the presentation on Pecos NHP in the Visitor Center. The trails are terrific and the Church is worth viewing. Small fee, free id you have a National Parks Senior Pass. The Pecos Indian artifacts are worth seeing.

$3 pp charge or national park pass. The visitor center has a nice movie about 12 min long, narrated by Greer Carson which gives some history of the ruins and the people who inhabited them. The trail through the ruins is fairly easy with some gradual incline. There are two kiva's, which you can descend into via ladders, that are very cool. The ruin of the mission is also incredible. We were here in the morning on a weekday in Sept. and there were only a few other people here. There is a small museum at the visitor center as well as nice restrooms and a gift shop area.

My family and I visited Pecos National Historic Park in early October 2014. The park is off the highway but well marked. The main portion of the park features a visitor's center which contained an informative video, and a very neat timeline. Once done here, the trail to see the ruins begins just out the back door. The trail is paved but uphill all the way to the ruins. There are several stops along the way, which correlate with a walking tour pamphlet provided at the visitor's center. The highlight of the ruins is the mission built on top of a destroyed mission. It was very neat to see, and read about. I would recommend visiting this park if interested in Spanish Rule, Native American History, New Mexican History, or just interested in the National Parks System. Admission to Pecos is also valid at Fort Union as well.

Entry fee of $20, no charge with NPS Senior Pass. Did a self-guided driving & walking tour starting at the Painted Desert Visitor Center thru to the Rainbow Forest Museum & Visitor Center via Petrified Forest Road (~28miles). Our favorites, beside the numerous pieces of petrified wood, were the petroglyphs still visible on the boulders and the 1932 Studebaker at the site of the old Route 66. Highly recommend watching the video at the visitor center.

The Petrified forest and the Painted Desert are grouped together on either side of I-40. If coming from the East when you exit the highway you will see the Painted Desert first then continue on the loop through and over the highway and onto the Petrified forest. This is about 28 miles until you get to the second visitors center at the petrified forest. If you are a senior don't forget your senior pass otherwise as with the other parks it is a $20 admission for a car of people. The roads are pretty straight forward and when you finally get to the petrified forest visitors center continue afterwards onwards to I-40 west without having to reverse your steps. From the west you get to the petrified forest first after a 20 mile ride through desert. then continue on to the painted desert before getting back onto I-40

This is another spot I haven't seen in many years. Really neat how the wood looks. If you come in the summer, come prepared. Lots of heat and little to no facilities in the park. If your a senior, get your Seniors Pass from the Parks Service for a big discount on admission.

Make sure that you watch the 20 minute video at the information center. $20 a car to get into park. We stopped at all the points of interest and I was not jumping for joy... If you only stop at one place you could skip most points and just head to Crystal Point. This is the only place that you really under stand the scientific process. The walking maps will tell you one distance and you should take it times 3 and that is the really distance. Walk the crystal path. There is a bathroom at a few stops so if you need to think about that please look at the map.

I would not make this a vacation destination, but a weekend getaway, ok. The painted hills were not very colorful or special, just ok, seen better for free. The road meandering through the park has many pull offs that are worth evening photographs though. The Blue Mesa trail was the best as far as photography and getting in the middle of it all. The Petrified Forest, part, which does not have standing trees, was a good hike through a lot of large petrified trees laying and broken on the ground. There is a remodeled ruin with petrified wood that was quite colorful. We can say weve been here, return, nope. No restrooms except at the visitor center/museum. Entry fee $20

I really enjoyed walking out among the petrified trees and reading about the history of this land. The admission price was $20, but a senior lifetime pass to all national parks was only $10 (going up soon to $80). The park includes ruins of Hopi villages and petroglyphs, which were interesting.

OK, so I read reviews where folks don't know what the big deal if about this place. Just stop a moment and think that first the trees that are now petrified came from someplace in Canada and the current land that the Petrified trees sit on was once down in Central America! Yes, that is how long ago all this happened and here it is for us to see in 2017. If you don't think you are such a minute part of this world than skip this. To me it was beautiful, absolute mind boggling and beyond comprehension. From the South entrance off the interstate near Hollbroke you actually start at the eye portion of a fish hook and then you will drive North to the hook portion for 28 miles. The entire place is a National Park and part of the original Rt 66! The Petrified Forest National Park is part of the Painted Desert so you actually pay only once ($20) and get to see both parks. Now here is a great tip I learned on this trip. You can combine all your National Parks entrance fees and get an annual pass which is $80!. I went through Lake Mead National Park, Grand Canyon and here and converted it all to an annual pass for any visit to ANY National Park for one year! SCORE! I took 6 hours to drive through here with my daughter because we like to hike all the trails and visit the visitor centers which were all very informative and helpful! The gift shops were amazing too! The colors of the landscape keep changing as the sun rises and sets. I think I took over 500 photos and still which I would have taken more. Get out of your car and hike. Bring Water as you are still in a desert! God I love this place!

This is a 28 mile loop road that includes the painted desert and the petrified forest. There are many overlooks and hikes. There is a $20 entrance fee or you can have a national park pass. It took us several hours. It was an amazing place. Make sure to walk the Painted Desert Rim, Blue Mesa, & Giant Logs. Pictures can do this place justice.

This was our second trip to the Petrified Forest/Painted Desert. Your $20 admission covers both. It is a 23-mile trip through both areas that is breathtaking. Seniors can get a $10 pass and active duty military are admitted free. It is highly recommended!

I don't know what we expected, but there is nothing here to see. You basically drive through the park with a few pull overs to get out. There is really nothing to see except in a few spots there are some petrified logs. My husband is a wood lover and even he was sorry we came. There is a $20 entry fee for this park and it is totally NOT worth it. Thank goodness, we have a senior pass, so we didn't have to pay.

Road Trip to CA on I40. We stopped by this National Park on our way west. The Petrified Forest was just OK but the Painted Desert was really nice. We took the 26 mile drive thru the desert and enjoyed seeing all of the sights ( took many Pics ). The cost for the drive is $20 per car but for seniors it is $10 when you sign up for the 'SENIOR PASS' which lets you in FREE at ALL National Parks that charge an entry fee, for Life (WOW). This saved us over $200 when we went to the other Parks.... .If you are heading West, Do not turn back,Take the 26 mi drive then exit the Park turn right on Hywy US180, go 20 mi drive to Holbrook, Az. If you are heading East just reverse these instructions. Saves you from back tracking.

Plan to spend at least a couple of hours to drive the loop through the park. Lots of pull-outs and short hikes to provide maximum viewing experience. Entry fee is $20 per vehicle. This includes driving through the Painted Desert.

The thing that really impressed me was how it got there. The forest now petrified grew in a seal-level semi-tropical environment when this land was at the latitude of Costa Rica.The moving continents made this place drift north to the latitude of Arizona is now and rise about 5,000 feet making the arid climate it is today. But it started out where Costa Rica is today. So does anyone suspect that the earth never changes just because it hasn't since you and your known ancestors have been alive? We're in a "quiet period" right now that won't last. Man made climate change is but a falling feather compared to an avalanche of what the earth can do without our "help."

As far as parks go, it was ok. For $20 (we have the pass but that is what it costs without it) I would have thought there would have been more bang for the buck. Don't get me wrong, it was nice .. reminds me of the badlands minus the petrified wood but if I wasn't in the area I probably wouldn't go out of my way to go here

Naturally there are Amazing views. Go in the Winter as there are no lines and no waiting to speak of. The views are the same in the summer only you're not melting while you are enjoying them. There are several opportunities to hike along paved pathways. If you plan on taking strolls along the pathways you need to allow for an all day excursion. Had not realized that the painted desert and the petrified forest are one and the same drive. Ask about purchasing a lift time National Park senior admittance pass if you're 62 and older. This deal can't be beat. We paid $10 each and were told the price will rise to $85 a piece later during this year.

First thing I noticed while driving this area was how close it is to I-40. People zoom by here every day and never see this kind of beauty, which is sad. The Painted Desert goes on forever. On a clear day you can see peaks in California!! The Petrified Forest was also pretty interesting. I also like the little spot where Route 66 is mentioned. Well worth the $20.
It is $20/vehicle to enter the park.

Only costs $1 to do the short trip and you can climb up a hill to get a view. Tough to discern what is old and new we saw a peace sign and some other graffiti. Some walks are not for people with balance problems or disabilities.

We went to Petroglyph National Monument to hike the Piedras Marcadas Canyon Trail, but couldn't find the trailhead (we found out later we were very close!). Instead, we went to the visitor center where there are no petroglyphs and talked with the friendly ranger. He suggested we visit Boca Negra Trail and gave us good directions to find it. Hiking would be too strong a word; you literally clamber over rocks to the top of the hill, but you see petroglyphs all along the way. They are fascinating and well worth a stop. The "trail" is a .5 mile loop, so fairly good for everyone except those with walking difficulties. Even then, there are a number of petroglyphs visible before you make the climb to the top. Costs $1 per car for parking.

Make sure to stop at the welcome center upon entering the Monument. The rangers are very friendly and helpful. There are several choices of trails all of which you will be able to see Petroglyphs. Based on your activity/ability there is a trail for you. Some are even paved! Watch the video at the welcome center as well for a good perspective on the Petroglyphs. You will drive to your choice of trail head and need to pay the whopping $1-2 for entry. The Petroglyphs are amazing and everywhere so keep your eyes peeled.

This is definitely worth the stop, and they only charge 1 or 2 dollars per car depending on the day you visit. The trail is a little steep and not easy to travel on so take caution. We had a great time looking around at the different petroglyphs and reading the signs. It was extremely hot however, so we didn't really take the time we normally would have. There was hardly anyone there (we got there around 8am), so I would recommend getting there early, it would be really hard to walk around people on the small trail.
Learned a lot today. Enjoyable afternoon strolling around the monument. Don't forget to have $1 ready for parking. Bring Walking shoes instead of flip flops or sandals.

Passing through Albuquerque, we decided to go to the National Monument. Glad we did. It's just a few miles off of Interstate 40. Unfortunately we were a bit late in the day to visit. We arrived at the Visitor's Center at about 4pm. They closed the park at 5pm. And closed the gates to Boca Negra petroglyph area at 4:30pm.
Best to go on a cool/cold day. Great place to explore the history of Petroglyph while getting plenty of exercise. There is an entrance fee of $2. There are bathrooms and covered picnic tables.

Entrance fee was $1 on a weekday. 2 small hiking areas to see the sights and a view of town. Informational signs were somewhat helpful. It was a little warm outside when we went in October around 930am. Take water!

This park is outdoors with walking trails that put you up close and personal with the petroglyphs. Entrance is $1 and there are trails, some at ground level and some that take you up the side of the hill, that showcase the various petroglyphs. Signs at locations throughout the park give you a glimpse into what we believe the various petroglyphs may mean

Fascinating petroglyphs. There are several areas, each with different degrees of difficulty. We stopped at the visitor center first and the ranger recommended the easiest area. It had some steep stairs, but there is a lot to see even if you skip the stairs. Free admission, just pay $1.00 to park. We were there for about an hour and a half, enough to get the flavor of it.

We went to Petroglyph National Monument and found it very interesting to know that these drawings date back 300-700 years. It's worthwhile to stop by the visitors center to get a brief explanation of the various sites and pay the $1 charge to get a booklet with a narrative describing what you'll see.

On a recent solo trip to Albuquerque, I did a stop at the Petroglyph National Monument on the outskirts of the city. It is a National Park Service location and is full of information, tours, and great knowledgeable folks. I was pressed for time so I did the "Boca Negra" trail. It takes under an hour and you can see hundreds of petroglyphs. What's a Petroglyph you ask? It's old art! It's drawings on black volcanic rocks made by Native folks hundreds, if not thousands, of years ago. The view from the top of the trail is also a wonderful vantage point to see a panorama of the city and surrounding hills. It's well worth the $1.00 parking fee too park at the base of the trail. Btw, when I say trail, I mean climb up the hill. You never loose sight of your car. Those that don't want to go far, don't worry!

We had a great morning exploring the petroglyphs on these trails. Head to the visitors' center first and go over your options with the staff. They will help you decide which trail to choose. We started at the Piedras Marcadas Canyon trail, which (I believe) gives the best opportunity to see the most petroglyphs, and you can get very close to them. It's also all sugar sand trails, so it's a good workout! After that, we tried the Boca Negra Canyon hike. That one is all uphill, but entirely paved. There were not as many petroglyphs, but there were still a lot! (This site is shared by the city, which maintains the parking lot, so you will have to pay $1 to park there.) I wish we'd had time to visit the third trail and go to the back of the canyon. Next time!

So, let me first start by saying Petroglyph National Monument is not for those who are handicapped. Wouldn't you know the day before my visit, I fell down the stairs, sprained my ankle, and scored myself a brace and a pair of crutches? I didn't want to miss out on the park, so I went anyway. I will say that if you're on single crutch, you can see a fair number of the petroglyphs. You won't be able to make it to the top of the Mesa Point trail in the Boca Negra Canyon, but you will be able to see most of the Macaw and Cliff Base Trails. The NPS estimates that it'll take about 50 minutes to see all of petroglyphs, and there is a picnic area with water fountains and restrooms in the area, though I'm sure you'll want to make sure you have plenty of water with you especially in the summer months. Petroglyph DOES participate in the NPS Passport program, so don't forget that and any parks passes you might have. If you forget, not to worry; Boca Negra is just $2 to park on the weekends, $1 on the weekdays. As for the other areas to include Rinconada Canyon, Piedras Marcadas Canyon, and the Volcano Day Use area, I can't comment on, as I simply was unable to hike much on foot. At any rate, my recommendation is that if you can't spend the whole day at Petroglyph, at least check out Boca Negra, take some photos, and drink often. You'll enjoy checking out historic and prehistoric imagines drawn in stone.

Enjoyed this outing with teen kids. Was not prepared for the hiking involved so be ready to climb. We made the mistake of going when it was too sunny so it was difficult to see the Petroglyphs. We found if you have shades on or use the lens from your camera or phone we could see the drawings. The $2 fee made this a priceless adventure. The views of the city below and mountains in the distance are nice.

We walked the Boca Negra Canyon which charges a dollar to park because it is a "shared?" park with the city. It is right in the edge of developments just 5 minutes off it I-40. Very nice visitors center. Trails have lots or volcanic rock and sand so wear good shoes. We were there before noon after overnight and morning showers so it was cloudy and cool but was headed to 94 that day. With no shade that hour to see Boca Negra was perfect.
This place is really neat and has various Trails with various levels of difficulty and lengths. Truely amazing. Bring some water and choose a trail you can easily do. The only cost is $2 for parking

We were there early in the morning and hiked a short trail (mesa point in Boca Negra Canyon) to see petroglyphs along the trail. It was not a difficult trail to hike. When we were there we did not find an envelop to put our $1 parking fee, but we put the bill into a slot. This national monument does not charge entrance fee.
Short drive from uptown area and well worth it. I went on a weekday and entrance fee was $1 cash. Honor system.

But not a great hiking experience if you are into that. It is a national park, so if you have the pass you won't have to pay the $1 or $2 parking fee. There are 3 "trails", one is 5mn long, the second 15mn, and the last one 30mn. You do see some nice petroglyphs and can enjoy a little stroll outdoors when you need a break from the city.

This is a "must do" visit to Albuquerque, especially for folks who do not live in the Southwest. You will find remarkable examples of petroglyps with signs that explain them. There's one tough climb to the top of the mesa, but three other small trails that are easily accessible to almost everyone. It costs a $1.00 to park, placed in an envelope when no attendance is in residence. There weren't any envelopes, so I just dumped some change in the slot. People behind me just drove through - geez, folks - it's only a dollar. Do you feel better having cheated? There are rangers on the property who love to answer questions. While there, we overheard two rangers talking "rattlesnake." I asked them if I had heard correctly. Yep, they moved it off the trail. They explained they are not dangerous. It takes a lot of energy to produce venom, and they do not like to waste it on something that is obviously not prey. We enjoyed this visit very much and encourage anyone visiting to stop by.

Hikes for everyone! There are petroglyphs everywhere! I have hiked and hiked just see a few but not here! Definitely worth the stop. You can stay 30 mins or all day. There are several hikes that you have to drive a few miles to start the different ones. Everything is marked and easy to find! Enjoy! It's $2 on the weekend and $1 during the week:)

What is cool about this national monument is that a lot of monuments and parks need a full days visit. Petroglyph's is one of those places where you can get in a worth while visit whether you visit for an hour or a full day. Some of the trial are long, but some are as brief as 15 minutes. If you have an hour to spare, stop by and take a look. It was only $2.00 to park. What a cheap price to pay to view some fabulous history.

I found the history of this area and the petroglyphs themselves extraordinarily interesting. The paths were well marked (might be too hard for little kids for anything away from the visitors' center) and the petroglyphs easy to see. There were three main viewing locations, and it was a short drive among them. The volcanoes were also in the monument area, and were a bit further of a drive. We tried to hike to the tops of these, but many of the trails were closed off for repairs, so that part was a bit of a bust. It's not a place to spend a great deal of time, but certainly is worth a look (and it is free - although some of the parking lots charge a nominal fee - $2).
We visited the monument on a bright sunny day for a walk amount the ancient petroglyphs. They are amazingly clear and well preserved, thanks to NPS. Admission is free with a parks pass.

Just outside ALBQ, Petroglyphs NM contains over 20,000 petroglyphs. At this time of year it was self-pay envelope system & I think it was $3. Our 1st stop was to their nice visitors center to get the scoop on the trails. Then we did the Boca Negra Canyon trails which only contains 4% of the petroglyphs but offers some nice examples. Macaw Trail & Cliff Base trail are easy with Mesa Point trail a bit more strenuous but not bad. Then we went to Rinconda Canyon for the 2.2 mile hike also pretty easy. Probably spent a couple hours there.

I found out about this through TripAdvisor and I enjoyed that it was different and unique to the area (I do a lot of traveling lately and some things all start to look alike). I hiked the three trails in Boca Negra. The first, and biggest, was up the side of a hill. Not difficult but definitely got my heart rate up and I wouldn't recommend it for somebody that doesn't like to hike. The other two were very easy with few steps. Overall, I am glad I went but also glad I didn't do the longer hikes. There was a $1 parking fee during the week and $2 dollars on the weekend. Go to the visitor center first and grab a map/pick a hike.

We drove out on a Sunday. There are three hiking trails, I believe, but they were not manned. There is a pleasant visitor center that sells tourism junk, and then people paid (on the honor system) $2 a piece to get in. To me, the volcanic structures were more interesting than the ancient rock art, but little information was available about that. Because of cultural taboos, the Park Service provides very little information about the petrogylphs themselves. Nice outing for people who want to get outside but not too far from the city.

We decided to check out the petroglyphs because they were a short drive from our hotel, and it's free! It is a day park open until five, so plan accordingly. We drove to the visitors center to pick up some maps and water, it's pretty cheap, around a dollar, and went to.Piedras Marcadas Canyon. We parked at the small neighborhood park on Tia Christina Dr NW., In just a short while, we found lots of petroglyphs, and few other visitors. It was beautiful. Just thinking about the people who took he time to leave this artwork which are more like information signs, made it sort of a spiritual experience. Be prepared to walk in sand, and gravel, so wearing good sturdy shoes would be helpful. The closest and easiest walk, not hike, was Boca Negra Canyon. But it might be crowded. We liked the view from the top of the Mesa Point Trail. The genuine petroglyphs are mixed in with a bit of graffiti,.but it's easy to tell the difference after seeing your first, I promise! The trails are asphalt mixed between the basalt rocks, with some cement steps and a few handrails, so it's mixing the ancient with modern! It is fun, quick, and probably close to your hotel, and will make for great dinner conversation later on!

Loved the petroglyphs!! Amazing to think that these rock pictures were done 400 - 700 years ago. And to see an actual Kokopelli was fantastic. We only did Boca Negra but would like to do more. Be sure to stop for the 20 minute video and directions at the Visitor Center. All of this for only $1 per car. My 12 year old granddaughter enjoyed the stop as well.

You see rocks everywhere, petroglyph's and some graffiti. This the closest I will get to rock climbing. We saw people of all ages making the climb to the top. At the top you are rewarded with a view of Albuquerque and the 5 volcanos. Worth the stop and the $1 (weekdays) or $2 (weekends) to get in.

We visited the Boca Negra Canyon area of the park. There is a parking fee of $2 to visit this area. The temperature was close to 100 degrees so we only walked a short way on each of the 2 trails. There are literally hundreds of petroglyphs on the rocks. It would be interesting to know what made the people to climb seemingly randomly to make these. There are information signs at some of the carvings explaining what they might mean. The trails can be rocky and steep, they go up the hillside. Watch where you put your hands, there are rattlesnakes around. Bring plenty of drinking water and wear a hat.

Right on the north side of the city of Albuquerque is an amazing concentration of Native American petroglyphs. It is a large scattered area, and the Visitor Center is nice, but it is not where you go to see the Petroglyphs. The most concentrated area of petroglyphs can be found in the northern most section of the park, the Piedras Marcadas Canyon area. There you can take a scenic 1.5 mile hike that has a great collection. Bring water and hiking shoes, as you may do a little climbing to see some of the petroglyphs close up. We were really impressed and spent over 2.5 hours on the trail. There are a variety of lizards and insects and jack rabbits in the trail area. Pay attention the directional signs are small. There is also a lot to see in Rinconada Canyon area on a slightly longer trail.

This monument was well worth the visit. It was $1.00 to get in during the week, $2.00 on the weekend. It has short trails with petroglyphs etched in rocks along the path. It was amazing to see etchings that were believed to be 800 years old!

Stop by the visitor's center first to get helpful information and decide what trails you want to hike. We chose two shorter ones that were easier for the kids to manage. Get there early in the summer to beat the heat and crowds. Only $1 entrance fee per vehicle! We stayed for about an hour and got great pics and listened to the cell phone audio tour for our trails. Will definitely visit again to tackle a longer trail!

While visiting New Mexico I read about the Petroglyph Monument in a travel book and thought it would make a great day trip. It was wonderful! Three separate trails ranging from easy to more strenuous trails makes it a perfect day trip for anyone. The two shorter trails have petroglyph's that are up close and easy to view. However, the longer trail requires binoculars or a zoom lens camera to see the "glyphs". Children have freedom to climb, run, and view past history like never before! At a meager $1.00, great experience.

Spent about an hour in this canyon exploring and trying to find the petrglyphs (100+) with two little girls (10 & 5). The first "30 minute walk" is a bit nerve wracking for an over-protective father - as the trail was steeper than expected and uneven for a 5 year old so I spent most of the time holding her hand asking her to be careful, so I did not enjoy it as much as my wife and daughters! The 5 & 15 minute walk were much more my speed, but in the end they were all very interesting for our children. If you can find the canyon - there is really no need to go to the visitors center unless you want a bit more history (you can watch a 20 minute movie and buy souvenirs). The only fee is a $2 parking fee at the canyon. Cheap and interesting way to spend a few hours away from the city (which is maybe 10-15 minutes away).

There are lots of choices here in terms of how far you'd like to hike. Check in at the Visitor's Center first to get a map and talk with a ranger. There are clean restrooms and picnic tables at the center, as well as a small gift shop with books, trinkets, food, and hats. After the Visitor Center you do have to drive to the other hiking spots. Keep your eyes out for rabbits and rattlesnakes throughout the area. We were there to see the cacti in bloom. Make sure to bring water - you will be in the sun for most of the hikes, and it was warm before noon when we visited in June. There is a parking fee - bring single dollar bills because you put the fee in an envelope and then drop it in a box. They do not make change.

We only stayed on the lower trails but the petroglyphs were few and far between and not very impressive. It was a nice drive out there and the hike and views were beautiful so still worth the $2 entrance fee

We enjoyed seeing the petroglyphs and there were plenty of them. The first hike was pretty uphill so we just went up a little way and came back due to our physical limitations. The second little trail is something we were able to walk the entire way and also the third one. It made us happy to be able to walk along and enjoy most of the trails. Nice signs to explain some key information. Fun to photograph along the trail. Price is right for a nice lesson in history.

Our time was limited (had to catch a plane) so we made a mad dash through the three trails We probably missed some of the petroglyphs, however, we were amazed at how many there were to see and felt like it was worth our time and the $2 entrance fee. Two trails are very short and easy; the longest trail involves a steep (but not terribly long) climb among the large boulders (which are from volcanic activity.) We were surprised to see that this is all in/near a residential area! (This would be cool backyard!) You might want to note that visitor center is 2 miles prior to the monument entrance.

Not sure what I expected, however I wasn't wowed! It was interesting to see some petroglyphs however, some of them didn't look ancient. The park was kept up nicely and it's only a dollar to park. We went on the basin trek as the other in the canyon was a high peak and was too much for us old folks and our small dog!

Went during March- Plan about 1 hour to climb a steep trail to top of the mountain, stopping along the way to look at the petroglyphs and then catching your breath at the top. Coming down much easier. Saw some jack rabbits along the way. Awesome view. $1.00 for parking makes this worth the visit. Great for teens.

Mother nature frowned on me the day I planned to come here-closed the road in the AM so I went elsewhere. After lunch I decided to try and make it before by 7:30 flight, so I only got to see a snippet, but what I saw was great. I went to Rinconada first. Free entry. Easy relatively flat walk on sand. It was snowing and wet so some of the petroglyphs were obscured but I still saw a bunch. The path is circular, with the second half walking through fields but I would recommend backtracking the way you came in. I did and saw a few symbols I had missed coming in. I went next to the visitor center. Chatted with the nice ranger. I think her name was Alison, but I am probably wrong since I am terrible at names. Got my passport book stamped and continued to Boca Negra Canyon. $1 entry. Unfortunately, this is not a place to go when it is raining/snowing as the trails are a kind of cement/blacktop that I found to be slippery. I started up the hill of the one trail-saw what was my favorite petroglyph-it looked like a weasel holding a lollipop-but even in hiking books felt a bit unsure about walking. There are several other trails by the restrooms and I was able to see several over there without climbing up anywhere. In good weather this would be a great place for an afternoon visit. I kind of liked seeing the residential neighborhood surrounding it-past and present intertwined.

Every thing is better when it's free or just a small fee. Here you pay a couple dollars to park. It's definitely worth the hike. I believe we hiked Boca Negra Canyon which is up a rock type mountain. Once you reach the top you can see the Albuquerque sky line, which is very nice.There is no mistaken that it once was an area of volcanic activity. Most all the petroglyphs are easy to see. There are many different trails and canyons, it was very hot so we didn't make it through all of them. The kids enjoyed it as much as the adults.

In order to view petroglyphs, you need not walk far. The park offers three separate locations for finding petroglyphs with differing trail lengths and difficulties. We stopped at the visitor center first where we received helpful information in which trail would suit our hiking ability. We then drove to the trail site and walked a very short distance and found many amazing petroglyphs with several information signs to aid in appreciation of their origin. The only cost was a $1 (senior) or $2 (adult) parking fee.

The Southwest is an artist's dream...great light; excellent subjects and a wonderful variety of landscapes. Apparently, the Ancient Ones agreed! Their "art" graced the boulders we now know at Petroglyph National Monument. These were not directional signals or simply graffiti...no, they appear to be the "canvas" they used to express their creativity. Whenever we host visitors, this place is a MUST see...all enjoy the hike and the fun of discovering petroglyphs others may have missed. A great place to teach children about ancient history and culture. The entrance fee ($1 per vehicle on weekdays; $2 on weekends) is very reasonable and worth the donation.

On our way to the airport we decided to take a quick 30 minute side trip to the park. We chose the location 2 miles north of the visitor's center. It was a $2 fee to get in and we walked most of the trails. Great seeing the petroglyphs but sad to also see graffiti also in the area. Don't know if we'd ever visit again, but definitely recommend if you've never been.

First off this isn't located in one spot, we arrived at the visitor center thinking we were at the monument, but that was not the case. After getting a map we had to drive to another canyon and pay $2 to park to see some of the petroglyph's. We had a National Park Pass so it was free to park. You could barely see the petroglyph's and it looked like a kid drew graffiti. We didn't stop at the other canyon park, we did drive to see the volcanoes, but there wasn't much to that and not even a sign off the road. We were killing time, would have done something else. I wouldn't waste my time w/this. And if you are interested then research it first so you don't waste time driving around to the visitor center then to the canyons.

I spent about 2 hours here, walking the trails and seeing the petroglyphs. The visitor's center is small, but you can get a brochure of the trails here. The Rinconada Canyon trail is a nice walk with several petroglyphs along the trail. The Boca Negra Canyon area is a much shorter walk, but also with nice petroglyphs along the trail. It is a $2 fee to visit this section, but free if you have any of the outdoor passes. Worth a visit is you are in the area.

We started at the visitor center to get directions to the Boca Negra site. We paid $1 to park there. The petroglyphs are mainly concentrated on a hill that is paved but may not be easy to climb for anyone with mobility issues. There are interpretive signs along the path. further down the parking area there are two more short trails. One is a macaw petroglyph and the other is a longer trail with more petroglyphs. Interesting to see such old things and wonder what they were trying to say. There is another site that is part of the monument but we didn't venture to it.

The ranger at the visitor center was really rude and NOT helpful at all in giving directions. Terrible waste of tax dollars. The main park has POORLY marked trails when you get to the end and you can wind up out in the desert not knowing how to get back. There are lots of secondary trails that people have made and the signs for the regular trails are worn away and hard to read so you don't know which way is correct. The park needs to repaint the trails and put in some new markers. Come on - people pay to go there. We ended up at the local playground instead of the parking lot on the way out because the trails were so poorly marked.

We visited Petroglyphs National Monument during our trip to New Mexico. It's easy to get to from downtown or Old Town Albuquerque. One way is to take Central Avenue west to Unser Boulevard and head north. Stop first at the Visitor's Center to get a map and chat with the park rangers who have a ton of information. After getting our map, we headed a little further north on Unser Blvd. till the turn-off for the Boca Negra Canyon section of the Monument. There is a $1.00 per car parking fee. There are three hikes here. The first will require a little bit of a hike up the volcanic outcroppings. You will see petroglyphs all along this trail. This is not strenuous but it is uphill. It's strange to see how close the housing developments are to this part of the Monument. From the top you get a wonderful view across the Rio Grande Valley. The second is a level hike through an arroyo (which also leads to the rest rooms). This is a short stroll on a sandy path. The third hike is a little longer, on the other side of the rest room building. You will see petroglyphs up-close. We saw lots of little lizards and many flowers were just coming into bloom. Very neat. We then drove into a residential section of town (north and east of Boca Negra) and found the parking area for Piedras Marcadas Canyon. Again, this was a stroll through sand and sagebrush to see more petroglyphs on the canyon walls. And again, you are quite near the housing development that abuts this part of the Monument. Because Rinconada Canyon trail was closed because of major damage from a storm in the fall of 2013, we drove north and west to the Volcanoes section of the Monument. There is no sign pointing you to this part of the Monument but it is very near the little airport that is across from this part of the Monument. There is paved road that leads to a parking area and rest rooms. You can see in front of you at least three very old volcanoes about a half mile walk across the grassy flatlands. You will be walking on some of the lava that spewed from these rift volcanoes about 150,000 years ago. We climbed close to the top of one of them for spectacular views of the Rio Grande Rift, the Sandia Mountains to the east, and the Rio Grande Valley directly in the middle. Awesome views! A great way to spend the day!

This was cool, only costs two dollars. Our dog had been cooped up in the camper so we thought we would bring him along for the hike. The ranger informed us no dogs allowed. Worth an hour of your day not to much else to do in albuquerque.

This place was really easy to get to, and surprisingly close to the city. At the visitor's center, there are guides, maps, displays, gifts, books and helpful staff to answer questions. You'll drive to a separate site about a mile away, where there is a $1 parking fee. There are self guided tours of the monument that you can link up your iphone to, which was really neat. The paths up to the top of the monument can be steep at points, and rocky and gravelly. I made the mistake of wearing flip flops, and going during a super hot time of the day, but that was my fault. Just have water, as there really is no shade at all. If you are interested in history, it's a neat way to spend a little bit of time. The petroglyphs are definitely pretty cool to see. It was very bright during the time that I went, which made it kind of hard to see many of the petroglyphs, so I decided to only hike one trail. There is a lot more to see. For me, it was just was a so-so experience, but I would definitely say it's worth visiting.

This was a highly worthwhile attraction on your trip through Albuquerque, New Mexico. The cost is nominal ($2 per person). You will get in some mild hiking while you see the petroglyphs. The site of the petroglyphs easily catapults one into antiquity from present day as one tries to decipher what each of the petroglyphs says. This is a good choice for an outside venue.

I enjoyed the hike. All real pictures are amazing, and fun to see. I saw a snake, coyote, millipedes, and birds of all types. Note: There are like 3 - 4 sites a few miles apart. The parking pass is $1.00 M-F or $2.00 sat-sun, and is good for all parking locations. You don't have to keep paying.

Take an hour or so out of your day and visit Petroglyph National Monument. The art work has stood the test of time and are very interesting to see. Cost is either $1 or $2 depending on weekend or weekday. Short walk up side of hill. Easily done. Other walk is along base of hillside, takes 10 minutes, if that. Worth the visit.

The visitor's center and Boca Negra Canyon are in the midst of residential neighborhoods, so it's a little odd. The rangers were very helpful in our decision of which trails to visit with two children (ages 8 and 12). We decided on Boca Negra based upon the fact that the trails were paved; however, only one of the three is truly paved. The other two have some paved stairs, but there is a lot of climbing on rocks. In fact, I would not recommend the trail up the "mountain" for small children or anyone with mobility issues, because you have to scramble over rocks. The view from the top was awesome, and there were several signs that told us what petroglyphs we were looking at, as well as more information about the volcanic rock. It gets pretty hot out there, and there's not much in the way of shelter. We did find some graffiti written on a rock; however, the ranger had already told us what was real art and what was not. All you have to do is ask! Our kids did the Junior Ranger program, which was easier than in other parks, and you get a badge, patch, and certificate, which is also more than some other parks. Admission to Boca Negra was $1. All in all, we spent about two hours, and it was well worth it.

If you love history, there are plenty of petroglyphs to be viewed. If you love hiking, it is beautiful with a great view of ABQ! First off - BRING WATER! I am always amazed at how many people bring kids but not water, or just don't bring water. The main loop is challenging if you have difficulty with mobility, many steps. The other two are less demanding. Morning is always best for temperature and lighting for photography. Parking is $1, and no other fee is assessed. It is easily the best spent dollar ever!
