We came here with our two small children. We only did the short hikes but it was very enjoyable. There were a lot of petroglyphs all along the trail. My kids liked climbing the "mountain." The ranger at the visitor was very friendly, knowledgable and helpful. And you can't beat the price- $1 for parking and that's it!

Petroglyph National Monument is right in the town of Albuquerque. You really should see it, as it’s so convenient and yet such a great window on the mysterious past of centuries ago. What did the artwork mean? First go to the very nice visitor center. Chat with the ranger and see the overview film on the touch screen. Ask the ranger for a trail that will suit your and your families level of energy and time. There are no trails at the visitor center, but the ranger will guide you to some excellent opportunities to see the petroglyphs up close. To get more out of your visit and to get an insight into the meaning of these etched pictures, get the little book Petroglyph National Monument by the Western National Parks Association for less than five dollars. It may not tell you what each figure in the rocks mean, but it gives you what clues we have. Plus it has great photos! Then get outside and enjoy your national park!

First, as in any other outdoor activity, go prepared. The hikes to the petroglyphs are easy, but good hiking boots, sunscreen, windbreakers, hats and water make for a much more comfortable experience. If you are not a walker, you probably won't like this attraction. Much of the trail is sandy which increases the effort required. Take a good camera, and be sure to stop at the visitors center, talk to the experts, and pick up a map and information sheet that describes the various glyphs. Kids LOVE this hike! Give yourself at least half a day and have fun. PS: $2 parking fee at trailheads.

Stopped by the visitor center, listened to a brief ranger presentation about the trails and petroglyphs, then headed to the trails of our choice. There are several trails available of varying lengtghs and difficulties. There is a trail for everyone - one was literally a total of about 30 yards while another was a 2 1/2 mile hike through the desert. All of the trails are interesting and you are virtually guaranteed to see petroglyphs at them all. It is very interesting to scan the rocks, locate the petroglyphs, and think about someone carving the figures in the volcanic rock long ago. It provided a pretty cool connection to the past and I thought it was well worth the visit. Be aware though that this is a fairly low-key activity and people with little to no interest in history may actually find it boring. The only cost is $1.00 per vehicle. As several others have noted, this exhibit is outside IN THE DESERT so it is usually HOT. Take some water, wear a hat and some sunscreen, and enjoy the petroglyphs and hikes.
This is on the West side of town and very easy to do. Kids will love it, but don't take rocks or you could get a $25,000 fine! ( you can get some volcanic rocks just outside of the park)

I have a National Park "Senior Pass," it is the best travel value in the USA. I stopped to get my National Parks PASSPORT stamped at the “Cancellation Station.” The Park Ranges at the Visitors’ Center were extremely helpful. The NM was well worth the efforts. The sky was blue it was before the afternoon rains; and the petroglyphs were easy to see as the paths were well marked and signed; it was great to see the messages from the ancient native peoples.

Drove over with my family of 4 (wife & 2 kids ages 7 & 8) to the Petroglyph National Monument on a Friday morning after breakfast. It's surprisingly close to the downtown area. Make sure to stop at the visitor center just off Unser Blvd on Western Trail. The Park Ranger in the visitor center will give you some great information on Petroglyph's and even recommend where to go. He recommended that we go to Boca Negra Canyon a few miles north of the visitor center. Parking was $1 and at the time we went there were plenty of parking spots. In Boca Negra there are 2 "mountains" with 1 main trail at the first stop then 1 main trail and 1 small one at the second stop. Both have parking so you can drive over after the first stop. Each trail only takes about 30 minutes max but you can spend more time searching out Petroglyph's if you like. You start by climbing the volcanic rock and looking for Petroglyph's, you actually acend upwards a decent height before you come back down the looping trail. The park service is trying to start a cell phone information line where you call a number and at different locations they give you interesting facts about what your looking at. I tried it and it was pretty cool but unfortunatley its still in a test phase, hopefully they'll improve on it as I rather enjoyed it. My kids had a great time and had no problem climbing the trails. Definately alot of fun for a few hours of exploring.

This would be a great excursion for the budget minded traveler. The visitor center is free and has a few things to see. Park service staff recommended that we hike Boca Negra Canyon since it was our first visit and we had limited time Cost is a mere $2 per vehicle parking fee. It takes about 1-2 hours to hike all of the trails at Boca Negra Canyon, but you can pack a picnic lunch and enjoy a 1/2 day out with the family at minimal expense. Take some time to learn about petroglyphs before you go and challenge the kids to find as many different ones as they can.

Did this in mid-July in the morning hrs. I think it would be too hot to do any later in the day during the summer. We did Boca Negra trail. Kids had a blast climbing up a small mountain (hill) strewn with vesicular basalt (volcanic) rocks. We saw a lot of petroglyhs on the approx 30 min hike to the top and back down. The trail is paved and certain areas have steps and handrails to assist your climb. There were restrooms and a water fountain, but take water with you while on the trail. At $2 per vehicle, you can't beat the price and it provided a couple hours of fun and history for our family. We didn't see any snakes, but there were signs warning you to beware. We did see rock squirrels (which looked like chipmunks), lizards and rabbits. We took a picnic lunch and ate at a shaded table in Boca Negra Canyon.

We began our late-September trip to Petroglyph National Monument at the Visitor’s Center. Our group spoke with a very friendly staff member who, after asking several questions regarding the goals of our visit, suggested we try the Boca Negra Canyon Trails. The Boca Negra Canyon Trails are three relatively short trails (5, 15 and 30 minutes) a quick drive away from the Visitor’s Center where you can quickly and easily see quite a few petroglyphs. We paid $1 to enter the Boca Negra Canyon Trails park and walked the 5-minute Macaw trail and the 15-minute Cliff Base trail. Due to very uneven terrain and the well-advertised possibility of snakes, it is recommended that visitors wear sturdy, closed-toe shoes.

We stopped here on our first RV trip, since it sounded interesting. It was kinda cool seeing the rock drawings, and the hikes were not bad at all, but people who have mobility problems might have difficulty. Our major gripe was that since we had an RV, we were not allowed to drive into the park, though we still had to pay the vehicle entrance fee ($1), and then walk to the trail entrances where everyone else was parked.

What a great place to go. Make sure to start at the visitor center. Great historic building. Ranger was very helpful and informative. Rocky paths fairly easy to navigate. Don't bypass the Gift shop (extremely reasonable) Bought some CD's for $5.00 less than anywhere else. The Petroglphs are amazing and it only cost $1.oo to park and they were not too far off the parking lot to see some of the closer ones! There are several different trails varied in length. Talk with the ranger to decide what meet your needs.

The best part of the monument trail does not allow dogs. You can't even leave them in the car! It was a cool drizzly day and my dog would have been fine in the car but they said no dogs. Unfortunately I was traveling with my dog at the time so I had no place I could leave her while I visited the park. I went to the part of the park that is open (on the NW side) but it requires a long hike to see the petroglyphs and I didn't want to leave my dog quite that long. Bottom line, I saw the visitor center and watched the video. I am collecting the Passport to National Parks stamps, and I have never been to an outdoor park that doesn't allow leashed dogs. Needless to say, I got my stamp but wasn't able to see much of anything. I will need to return another time.

My family visited Pinnacles this May for a hike to the Balconies Cave. We were drawn here solely because it's a national park. The trail was not terribly difficult but it was very hot: 93 degrees at the trailhead (yet only 59 when we returned to Monterey!). The cave was literally cool and we used one as a stop for a snack. Bring lots of water! The visitor's center was closed and fees ($15 for the carload) are left in a drop box.
I live close to the Pinnacles and go often. I never tire of it! It's great for all activity levels and the price is right. I bought a year pass for $20. Prices will change as the years go by.

Pinnacles National Park is a beautiful small National Park. Located just 1 1/2 hours from San Jose, it is the closest national park from the bay area. There are hikes for all ages and difficulty levels, although to get the main view, it requires about a 5 mile (3-5 hours) hike round trip. This park is easily done in a day trip from the bay area. The visitor center isn't very big at all. Come more prepared. This isn't the biggest of the national park, and only basic amenities are offered; so come prepared. Entrance fee is $15/car; you can pay with cash or credit. Hope you enjoy this park!

Pinnacles is America's newest national park - founded as a national monument in 1908 but inaugurated as a national park in 2013. We entered the park from the west just east of Soledad, California. Entrance fee is $10. There is also an east entrance, but you can not drive through the park from one to the other. The east end has 9 trails and the west end has 4.

There is a fee of $10 per vehicle, and the park rangers will give you a map when you pay. The east entrance visitor center sells snacks, drinks, ice creams, and souvenirs. Adjacent to the visitor center are restrooms and quarter-operated showers, as well as a nice little swimming pool.

Don't miss the nation's newest national park if you are in the area. We drove over from Monterey, about 90 minutes away, and we're so glad we did. The park fee of $10 is a steal, especially since we paid almost $40 a person to visit the Monterey Aquarium the day before. When you enter the park you must stop at the small visitor's center to pay the fee and get a map from the rangers. The rangers working when we were there were incredibly friendly and very helpful. They want to make sure everyone is safe on the trails so visitors can enjoy themselves. If you are prepared, you have a fantastic selection of trails to choose from, but if you want a nice starter trail, do Bear Cave and the Rim Trail. The park warns you need a flashlight for the cave, which is obviously great advice, but I used the flash from my camera to see since we didn't have a flashlight and we were okay. We didn't go deep into the cave as they were closed for the bats. This park is beautiful, but be prepared with water and food so you stay safe. Stop at the small camp store for ice cream as a reward after your hike. The store is attached to the visitor's center. Finally, be aware there is no connecting road between the east and west sides of the park, the east side has the visitor's center and store.

I was very excited to hear about this new national park so I had to check it out! The caves were very cool and it wasn't over crowded at all like you except these types of parks to be. Entrance fee was $10 instead of the usual $25 for California national parks. The do have a store with snacks and souvenirs. The only complaint I have about this place was that being a national park I thought they'd have a shuttle so my friends and I hiked a few hours to the other side of the park to be able to see everything, we encountered a worker there who laughed at us when we asked about a shuttle, which I found to be pretty rude. If it was past the cutoff time or there isn't one that simply could have been said! We had to turn around and hike all the way back without food or enough water so bring PLENTY of that, otherwise I would have given 5 stars if not for that encounter.

I enjoyed my first hike in Pinnacles National Park. The 2 mile cave hike I took was a bit tough on this 74 year old, but I survived. Next time I will take less camera equipment. The views are spectacular. The caves are fun but a bit tough on Senior Citizens. By the way, be sure you have your National Park Senior Pass. If you do admission is Free. Next time I will take the longer but flatter old Park trail.

We visited the east side of the park on a Saturday, we stopped at the Pinnacles visitor center to pay the entrance fee, $5 and told there was no parking and that we should park there and hike in. This is what we did, it was a 8 mile hike roundtrip to the Bear Gulch caves, we did manage to get there and experience the caves, it was very crowded, by the time we made it back to the vehicle we were exhausted. Sunday they do run a shuttle to the trailheads, which would definitely be the way to go. If you visit this park on the weekend be prepared for crowds of people, and lots of kids, not a place to go to escape from it all unless you hike away from the main attractions which are the caverns and the pinnacles themselves.

It’s the newest national park named last year. The entrance fee is only $5 per vehicle; it’s cheaper than a state park fee. It’s located 1.5 hours southeast of San Jose and half hour from Hollister off the East entrance. Since there is no lodging or restaurant in the park, it’s easy to take day trip from San Jose. You can pick up snacks, lunch or dinner on Rt. 25 when you go through Hollister. There are camp grounds with a swimming pool at the East entrance. If you coming from the north like San Jose, you’ll most likely take Rt. 25 and enter the park on the East entrance.

On a recent road trip through CA, I decided to add our nation's newest national park to my stops. I made a reservation at the campground (east side), and was pleasantly surprised to discover that the fee was $26/night instead of $35+up at most CA state parks. I went in mid-July, and a reservation was far from necessary. There were very few people there, and there are plenty of camping spots. However, sites range from small to large, from totally secluded to totally exposed and from totally private to neighbors in your pocket. Here are some thoughts:

We went to Pinnacles for a two night weekend trip in mid-July. We came from the East entrance and stayed at the camp site. The camp sites cost $23 a night and you pay a $5/car fee (valid for 7 days). Make sure you reserve your tent sites online before you go!

I had a day off from work and decided to go for a ride. Taking La Gloria Road from Gonzales over the Gabilan Mountains I turned South on Airline Highway and used our National Parks and Federal Recreation Lands Annual Pass at the Visitor's Center to cover the entry fee. After a little driving in the park I checked out the map and decided to park at the end of the road and take the Moses Spring Trail to the Bear Gulch Cave Trail. After going through the caves, I took Rim Trail back to the parking lot. Except for a small group of oblivious kids sitting on the trail eating their lunches, I had a good time. Remember to bring flashlights for the caves.

I stopped at West Pinnacles (near Soledad CA) during a road trip down 101. There are 2 entrances to the park, but you can only hike between them - not drive. The rock formations are beautiful. There are also caves to explore, but I didn't have a flashlight. The sunset glows off of the pinnacles - take a camera! Park entrance is $5 and is good for 7 days.
About an hour drive from Monterey CA. (we went on a rainy day) $5 admission which is totally worth it and supports the park so just do it.

We visited here on our way to Monterey on Saturday August 31st. We drove to the East side first and wasn't too impressed but then again we didn't hike the many trails as it was hot and not shaded. We then decided to drive to the West entrance where we saw more rock formations. We again didn't hike the many trails as it was in the mid afternoon and the weather was in the 90's. I hear the trails have some good sights to see but go early in the morning when it is cool. We only paid $5 and it was good for both sides.

Shut your house before heading back to South Carolina after two days in North Carolina we want to make one final stop and see some waterfalls and the national Forest. First one was clear waterfalls which is about 6 miles from the entrance off north of Brevard on Highway 276. You can walk down and take advantage of the water below the Falls to walk in or float if you'd like, the only problem is it's Rocky and a rough bottom to get out there period I would recommend some kind of water shoes to protect your feet and a good sense of balance period what are those called even though it was mid June. Access to the water is not a simple walk most of the lock slope down towards the river period but the waterfall is beautiful and great place to get a good picture and some Adventure. II waterfall was sliding rock which is about another mile and a half up the road away from Brevard. This is the recreation area and is a $2 charge per person to get in. The bathrooms and dressing rooms are available however there was electrical problem and they were closed during our visit. We walk down to the fall area and took a look at the Rocks while sloped and slippery they are certainly not smooth. Despite that I was intent on giving it a shot the only problem is the Wiz rain in the area and as soon as the lifeguards heard thunder The Falls are shut down for 30 minutes. The Thunder continued on for another 15-20 minutes so we decided to just get a picture of the falls head back to Brevard and wait out the Storm Passing. I must say the people who were doing the sliding we're having a good time and everybody all ages and sizes was involved so if you get the chance to visit the forest take the opportunity to see Sliding Rock at least and give it a shot sliding down into the little pond at the bottom of the falls. Just make sure you have a towel and some dry clothes and hopefully they have their electrical problems solved

What a great time on a hot summer day. Great fun sliding down the rock into a pool of cool water. Just enough supervision to keep things free and happy. Watching other people was a hoot! Just $2 per person for the day. Free parking. What could be better?

We found a couple of places to park and walked down into the creek. We walked all the way up to where Sliding Rock is. For a $2 fee you can park and slide down a very slick rock. We did that for about 25 minutes and it was very crowded. We had much more fun finding places on our own to sit in the water. Just make sure you park in a legal area. There are lots of signs telling you where you can't park!

I spent two wonderful days in this forest with my extended family of 14 (ages 10 to 70). First we climbed up to Fryingpan Mountain Lookout Tower, a 70-foot-tall structure built by the US Forest Service in 1941. The ascent was steep but short, and climbing the actual tower brought us to a splendid view of all the surrounding peaks. Later we drove down to Sliding Rock (which charges $2 per person), where the more adventurous of us loved the thrilling ride down the gently sloping waterfall into the cold pool. The next day we hiked up to Black Balsam Knob, perhaps everyone's favorite mountain hike ever because the trail allowed us to see the mountains all around us all the way to the top. It was cool (on a very hot day) and very windy, and the 360 degree views were spectacular. We carried sandwiches up with us and ate lunch at the grassy top of the bald mountain. Amazing and unforgettable!

I spent three days at Pisgah Forest with my teenage daughter and a couple of her friends. We stayed at the Mt. Pisgah Campgrounds. We had reserved a site since we knew we were getting in late. The only site left was a RV site on A loop. We were camping but it worked out well, Just be sure to keep your tents on the gravel or paved areas. The shower area is fairly new and kept cleaned. The only issue is that there is just 1 shower stall so at peak times you may wait awhile. At $19 a night it makes a trip very affordable,

We took a day trip from Asheville to Pisgah National Forest. It was a short ride and well worth it. My husband went down the Sliding Rock and we hiked with our dog. On the way back to the B & B we drove along the Blue Ridge Parkway and the scenery was spectacular. I recommend going to the Sliding Rock and paying the $2, especially if you have kids - it is well worth it.

Beautiful 5.1 mile loop. Rated moderate, but bring water and be prepared for some elevations. Trail is clean and well kept. Beautiful fields of daisy and Queen Anne's lace ( I later read were man made). Rododendroms were beginning to bloom, but were in full bloom on the drive up.

Ever wanted to swim up to the base of a waterfall? This is the place to go. Awesome waterfalls. We also did Slide Rock, so much fun for about $2 a person. Want to go back and explore more of this beautiful forest.

Just drove through the National Forest on way back to Indiana from Seneca, South Carolina. Early morning meant less traffic. Leaves were changing colors in the upper elevation. Clear blue skies allowed the sun to shine and reveal picturesque moments. Passed several cyclists riding up the mountains. I wish I could have joined them because the scenery was perfect for cycling. We did not actually go into the Pisgah National Forest via the park's main entrance. We just drove through on our way to the Blue Ridge Parkway.

We only spent a few hours in the Pisgah forest, but we could probably stay there for a month. The giant water slide rock was hours of fun for the kids and it only costs $1.00 to get in the park. It's worth the drive. We also spent some time in the Davis River fishing and swimming. It's an inexpensive way to spend a day out with the family. Next time we will probably try tubing.

This National Forest is beautiful! The waterfalls are very pretty and most are within a decent walking distance, if not pretty much off the road. Make sure you visit Sliding Rock! It's so much fun, but a little scary! Sliding rock is the only area with a fee...it's $1 for everyone over 5 years old. It's so worth it!

If you really want to enjoy all that Pisgah National Park has to offer I strongly suggest you stay at the Mount Pisgah Campground off of the Blue Ridge Parkway. It is just across from the Pisgah Inn were you can get a delicious meal. If you like high elevation and you really like peace and quiet then I suggest you stay at Mount Pisgah Campground. It is by far nicer than any campground that we have seen in the Great Smokies National Park or on the Blue Ridge Parkway. If you are a hiker then you got to hike the 1.5 mile trail to Mount Pisgah where Channel 13 TV tower is located, The trial is a little streunous at the end but we did see people from ages 4 to 70 up at the obervation tower. The view from the top of Mount Pisgah is incredible and worth the hike. Buck Springs trail is another trail worth checking out! Mr. Vanderbilt of the Biltmore House had a hunting lodge there in the early 1900's. We also went to the Crade of Forestry and were skeptical of the $5 per person fee but we spent the day there and thoroughly enjoyed it. You will learn so much about the history of forestry at the Cradle of Forestry. You will find plenty of things to do in Pisgah National Forest!

sliding rock was absolutely awesome. My husband and 9 yr old went while my 12 yr old and I filmed and took pictures. Couldn't talk my son into going in that cold water and my 9 yr old refused to go just 1 more time. My husband however, was all over it. Like a kid again. Loved it all. Can't beat it for $1.00 per person.

Sliding Rock in the Pisgah National Forest is the perfect natural water slide with a freezing cold pool at the bottom. We drove out of our way just to visit this again. This was my third time through here in the past 30 years and it has changed a lot. They now have lifeguards, a changing station and an admission fee (only $1.00/person though, so well worth it). You can get in line and go down as often as you wish. Also stopped at the nearby Looking Glass Falls which was beautiful.

Went to see the Waterfalls.... Awesome time even in the rain. We hiked and went to the trout hatchery. Feed the trout. Read all about the 3 types: rainbow, brook, and browning. Learned alot and enjoyed our time exploring.

This place used to be free in the 1980s and the statues didn’t have loin clothes then. But at $5 per car load, it is a bargain and that fee is nominal. There are some interesting heiaus (temples) here including a large one. This is the only city of refuge left in Hawaii. Condemned people who broke a kapu could swim here so they wouldn’t be put to death. The ranger gives an interesting talk with much information and he is very entertaining.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We visited this park four times over a two week period. It has a historical village and walking trails throughout the grounds to explore. There are picnic areas and beaches to enjoy. There is a great snorkeling spot just outside the gate. They also accept the National Park Senior Pass.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: "Place of refuge" well worth the $5.00 entrance fee. Easy to follow map and walking tour, but if you have the time the Ranger presentation is very insightful. Lots of interesting Hawaiian history facts and culture. Very enjoyable would do it again.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Part of National Parks, so if you have your pass handy, you get in for free. If not, $5 entry is good for reentry for 5 days. One of Hawaii's historic places, you can do a self-guided tour or catch a Ranger's talks and guided tour. See the protected turtles on its beach. You can also go snorkeling in a small area of the Park's property.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau, or the City of Refuge, is a historical preserve of an area set aside during the pre-modern monarchy of Hawaii. It was a place to come be cleansed from your breaking of kapu, or the law/taboos of the time, and a place to be protected from war or aggression. The ali'i and the commoners both stayed here for short times, and there are fish ponds and beautiful paths. It is very peaceful and they have preserved swellings and tiki carvings which are extremely photogenic. You can do this place in 30 minutes but it's better to just be here and contemplate ancient Hawaii. The entry has great introductory recordings and there is a 15 minute visitor movie that plays hourly. It's short, sweet, and pretty, and also inexpensive ($5 park entry fee per car).
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: we just loved this place, very good walk and sites to visit....costs 5 dollars per car and you can us it to go to two steps for snorkeling afterwards.........great historical location and meaningful site for Big Island history
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: I'm so glad we took the time to visit here. There was a lot of Hawaiian history provided in our short 1-2 hour visit here. We had bought the TriPark pass when we visited the Volcanoes National Park so admission was free, otherwise I think it is $5. They have a short presentation or you can just do the self-guided tour if you don't want to wait. We didn't have a lot of time, so we did the self-guided tour after asking the ranger a few history questions before beginning. There is a 2 mile trail to a little village, but we did not have time to do it. You could spend the whole day here between the hiking and then you can snorkel if you brought your own gear. It must have been good viewing since we saw a lot of people snorkeling here.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Peaceful area. Beautiful views. Informative presentation. Interesting artifacts/structures. $5 allows you to park and visit for a week. There is no food for sale at the park, but if you bring a picnic lunch you can drive down a road off the parking lot to a gorgeous quiet beach with picnic tables and enjoy your lunch under the palm trees.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Nice mix of cultural and historical info and the beach park nearby is nice also. I would say it is well worth the $5 per car to get in.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: The Great Wall, carvings of gods, and beautiful beach area are unforgettable. Only $5!!! Follow the map and the markers to truly appreciate the area. Stay for a ranger talk if you're able. I heard a woman say it was boring, but she's crazy! Ha!
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: For $5 you get to enter the park. Very pretty grounds. It's a self guided tour and you get a brochure when you enter. Neat little piece of history. There are park rangers scattered though out who are happy to talk further with you about the land and history. The grounds my not be accessible to all due to soft sand or uneven lava rock gravel. We walked it fine in flip flops though. Just be cautious. It's a ways out there so stop by 2 step beach for a snorkel, the painted church or a coffee farm.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: The is a popular place for both locals and tourists so it's best to arrive early. The parking is limited along the road however there is a parking lot for $5. It not big but if you can, park here to support the local church. The entry to the ocean is literally 2 steps in and pretty easy. It is well marked by folks getting in and out.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Fun place to walk around and do a self-guided tour. You can also snorkel and see lots of green turtles! It's $5 for parking and can go in and out and is also good for 7 days so if you wanted to come back another day. They have a ranger that gives a talk about the significance of the refuge which is interesting.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: The park is an easy 1/2 mile walk along the shore. There are brochures at the visitor center to describe the numbered sites. The walkways are well marked but are warn during the middle of the day. There are some very old and unusual totem poles along the walk. The park has a $5 parking fee. There are bathrooms, and a gift shop on site. If you have the time, many people leave their cars and walk to the nearby snorkeling area called Two-step. A beautiful spot with lots of coral gardens and fish, turtles and even some dolphins.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This historical site happened to be near where we were staying in Kona so we stopped in one morning for a visit and were glad we did. In the A.M. it was quiet and incredibly beautiful and the lighting was nice for photos. The park is relatively small and self guided but the walk is easy and sites are marked to match the info provided on their map. The $5 entry fee is also good for 7 days.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: When heading south on Hwy 11, just past mile marker 104, take a right on Keala O Keae Road. The post office is on your right side at this intersection. A few miles down the road you will see the park entrance on the left. There is a $5 fee per car and the pass is good at this park for one week (it is not good at the other National Parks on the island). There is a visitor's center next to the parking lot and you can walk through the park on a self-guided tour. The gate attendant gives you a brochure that has a map as well as an explanation of the different areas you can visit. As you walk through the park, certain areas have a number marked on a stake in the ground. The brochure you are given gives a brief explanation of what you are looking at. The construction of the area began in the 1500's. The tour gives a brief overview of the site and the way of life the islanders led during that time period. There are numerous tiki statues on the grounds, as well as reconstructed structures. The Park Service has a movie presentation they show several times a day, and there is a guy demonstrating traditional tools, etc. You could spend an hour or two waking around here. There is also a bay that was used for launching canoes. The sea turtles come in and lay on the beach here now. We found the park to be a worthwhile stop.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: As I was entering the park and paying my $5.00 admission fee, she told me that since I was a Senior Citizen, I could buy a lifetime free admission pass to National Parks for a one time $10.00 fee. At that point, I could get in for free. So, for an additional $5.00 I now have free lifetime admission to any National Park in the United States.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We spent two half days at the Park and the adjascent bay. Be aware that you cannot snorkel/paddleboard from the park itself, but you can park here and walk 5 minutes to Two-Step. We got the $25 annual pass that covered this park, Volcano, and Haleakela. Well worth it.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: It is a small .5mile loop explaining the City of Refuge. It is located right next to Two Step beach.. Bring water bottle. There is water fountain. There's no food or water sold here. Bathrooms are clean. We saw signs to keep away from turtles but we didn't see any turtles. Drive to the back and walk a short hike for secluded Coastal views. We used our National Park pass to get in. If you don't have a National Park pass , then cost is only $5 per vehicle.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This real gives you a feeling of what Hawaii was like in the past. Very serine and beautiful. Give yourself enough time to walk around then you can plan on snorkeling next to the park. Cost is $5. Per car
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This was very interesting and beautiful. It is easy to access off the highway and a leisurely walk around the park. The whole family will enjoy this stop. It is set up as a living village along a beautiful bay and the signs along the way explain the life of the kings and the people of Hawaii. You can easily see it in an hour or you can linger for a longer time if you want to. It is a National Park so if you are a senior citizen and have the park pass you won't have to pay. If you are a senior citizen and don't have the pass you need to get one because you will pay for it twice over on this trip to Hawaii. A one time price of $10 and for life you and everyone in your party gets in free to all of the National Parks.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We actually heard of this place from our snorkeling guide and were fascinated by the history behind it and so we returned later to check it our further. (There is a great snorkeling area adjacent to the park). There is a $5 per car admission fee. It takes maybe 45 minutes to an hour to leisurely walk through, reading the self-guided tour pamphlet. At one spot, a park employee, dressed in traditional native garb, was discussing fishing techniques and answering questions about the Hawaiians who inhabited the area in the past. I would not categorize this as a must see location by any means; however, if you are interested in the ancient culture, this is well worth the trip and the time.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: So glad we visited. Best $5 I spent all vacation. Used the written guide to describe what we were seeing. Fascinating insight into life of the islanders. A peaceful place, but so historically significant. The statues of course are stunning but so is the background story. Took time to stand and stare at the waters.....turtles and magnificent variety of fish all to see. The lava is amazing, creating many tide pools teeming with interesting animal life. Oh and then there's the game of Konane. When you get to the visitor center, ask for the instructions because it's fun to actually sit and play the game. Really interesting game of strategy. Combine all this with a stunning location ..... Have fun!
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Entrance is $5 per car. It's a nice place to wander on a nice day. We almost always see turtles and we did on this visit. I love the tikis.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: There is a nice road to get to this park. I think parts of it are recreations and parts of it are original. But it was the only place I saw while we were there that had the authentic tiki huts and totem poles you think of as being Hawaiian. We missed the informational video and didn't take any kind of guided tour. There were lots of turtles and I think it's a great snorkeling spot. It was $5 per car to get in.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Make sure to use your Senior Access Pass from the National Parks to get in for no charge. There is a visitor center with a gift shop, restrooms, and a film to watch. They also have beach wheelchairs. I recommend using one. I tried using my walker and it was exhausting because most of the pathways are sand or loose gravel. But it is well worth it!
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We first visited the park and wow, what a cool history. There is a entry fee of five dollars. Its completely worth it. The panels and the self guided walk were super interesting. Its a truly humbling and sacred site to visit. After the park, we grabbed out snorkle gear and walked down this road to Two-Step for some mind blowing snorkeling. Be prepared for a no beach snorkle experience. I found that having my beach shoes on to travel across the lava rock was key. Once you are out at the edge, there are a couple different spots you can enter the water. Mostly use the steps down in. There are no pokey urchins there and it can be a little tasking if the waves are rough. Sooooooo much sea life! Once you are out, there is no place to stand up. That took some adjustment on my part. This is not a first time snorkelers place. I would recommend some of the beach parks in Kona for first timers before they come here. This is the ultimate snorkeling experience.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: While planning our trip at home, I added this to our list of 'must sees'. Happily, we stumbled upon it while on a short drive. It's a quiet and for lack of a better word, a reverent place. We saw our first (and only) honus here along with oodles of fish and black crabs. Just wandering on the beautiful grounds was a treat, looking at structures and tikis that are hundreds of years old. Yes, it's a warm place, but there are a few places to seek shade. The sand/gravel is white, so that makes it much hotter. If you're traveling down the road and see a sign to this marvel, definitely take the fork in the road. We used our lifetime Natl Parks pass, although the entry is just $5.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Excellent historical information. Black lava is beautiful. Great place to go with children. Plan on going the morning because of the heat unless you are planning on going swimming. It is a National Park and is free for seniors if you have a National Park Pass.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We arrived at the same time a school field trip arrived which delayed the ranger talk a few minutes. The talk was worth the wait and helpful in explaining the basics of the parks historical significance. Very informative self-guided walking tour pamphlet let's you enjoy the area at your own pace. Lots of parking and clean restrooms. $5 charge per vehicle to enter. Well worth it to add a little education for the kids while on vacation.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This is an excellent combination of Hawaiian history and some beautiful scenery - you can learn something while enjoying a nice stretch of pacific coastline. Only $5 per car to enter and it takes about an hour to see it all at a leisurely pace. Just off the parking lot to the south is a beautiful picnic area right on the ocean.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This is a great place to visit especially if staying in Kona as this ia about a 15 minute drive from Ali dr. Its $5 to get in where you can explore a piece of hawaiis history, when your done you can walk next door for some easy access snorkeling (you can't snorkel at the park). This snorkel spot is usually calm, clear and is easy for a beginner snorkeler to access. Go in the morning as the clouds usually roll in around 1.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Pu'u O Honua is a site previously known as the Place of Refuge. It is a rebuild sanctuary and heiau. While they do offer a guided talk and tour every other hour, it is set up for a self guided tour. This is not an amusement park; it is an ancient structure and grounds that allow you to walk quietly and peacefully and allow your imagination of history to fill your mind. It is an easy path to walk that shows you hales (houses) as well as a variety of tiki style idols surround by a great wall that marked the grounds and the foundation of a heiau (temple). This truly is a place of refuge. Entrance fee is $5.00 a car load, or $3 per person. I highly recommend coming and walking this beautiful place and feel the peace and "mana" of the land. You won't get a full history lesson of this place and its history and culture, (I suggest you read up on it before or even after). Don't hesitate to ask any of the Park Rangers questions, everyone I spoke with was eager to answer all questions; they just were constantly in your face. This is a self guided tour that you do at your own pace. Your pass is good for the whole day; we toured the grounds, went swimming next door at Two Steps, drove around and then returned to the Park to watch a beautiful sunset. This time of the day seemed to bring about an almost spiritual feeling to the area.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: The historical presentation as well as the historical site are a great experience for visitors to Hawaii to learn about some of the history of the islands.The snorkeling just outside the park is phenomenal and just as good if not better than Captain Cook. Parking can be an issue if you only want to go to the snorkeling area but parking at the park is only five dollars and it is a short walk from there to the snorkeling area. The coral reefs on both sides of the bay are great, the currents are mild, there are a lot of fish, and on one day there we were able to swim out and swim next to a pod of dolphins. We also saw sea turtles there.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Fantastic snorkeling and very relaxed atmosphere. Lots of corral (for Hawaii) and abundant sea life including many turtles. Easy entry via two step (just look where everyone is entering). Street parking or there is a make shift lot for $5, which we did. A tiny bit of sand and few trees for shade. Bring your own food and drinks.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: It's part of the National Park System and represents the only preserved refuge site on the Hawaiian Islands. For $5 per vehicle you can gain entrance to this ancient culture. Start at the Visitor's Center where you should see the 30 minute video in the amphitheater which is a great overview of the park and it's ancient history. The park was once the sacred grounds where Kamehameka chieftains were buried and the great king Kamehameka was born. It's a sacred site so learn what you can and can not do on the property. It is also the place where refuge from war or refuge from death could be secured after Kapu sacred law was violated. If you could make it to the refuge before you were captured and killed for your crime, the high priest could grant you life and a second chance. The rangers give free talks at (10:30 and 2:30) and further explain this very interesting culture. While at the visitor's center pick up a free map which shows you the 16 sites to visit. Site 8 is the rebuilt temple. The 1871 Trail of Ki'ilae is 2 miles round trip and begins right behind the visitor's center. A guided tour is also available which is ranger led and lasts about 40 minutes. Kids can get a Junior Ranger Badge which will keep them occupied. You can also take a self-guided tour. When I visited there were green turtles laying on the beach. Actually they are not green, only their flesh is green from eating seaweed. They said pods of dolphins and sometimes humpback whales are visible from the shoreline but I did not see any. Tide pools are teaming with marine life and are worth investigating. They have a native Hawaiian demonstrator on site that does native crafts like dug out building. Tip: engage them because it will enrich your knowledge and experience. They are expected to engage visitor's so go for it. Once you establish a relationship they really begin to open up. This is not the easiest National Park to navigate but take my advise and follow the plan I laid out.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This is a great place to spend the day. Pay the $5 for the week pass because you will want to come back to Two Step Beach and park your vehicle here. Pack a picnic and drive to the picnic area and spend the day. You can snorkel in this area regardless of sign at gate. If you snorkel you can make your way around to Two Step Beach, just pay attention to surf. There is also some history to see here. Staff was very friendly!
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: There was a self-directed tour using your cell phone to move from one item to another. Difficult when you needed to move on to a new numbered site or repeat info. Sometimes the recording was difficult to even understand. I sense a desire to generate tourist dollars from a small segment of global history.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We loved this park. The history of the royal family and how the park was used is interesting. The lava beds and tide pools were beautiful. We saw two Hawaiian green turtles feeding in shallow tide pools. Definitely worth the five dollars and the chance to gain knowledge and see turtles. By the way, watch for "Harry" the wolf spider in the bathroom. He shared a stall with me and provided a nice shock when I turned around and saw him.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: I liked the peaceful feel of the place. I liked the turquoise water against the black lava rock. I liked the ranger who gave an entertaining lecture and could make beautiful insects from a blade of grass( or palm leave?). I liked that we could park in their lot with our Nat'l Park Pass, then walk down a few feet to TwoStep beach for beautiful snorkeling above coral and a tiny sandy beach and tidepools for the kids.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Yes, the snorkeling just a few hundred yards away is incredible, but don't cheat yourself by missing this site. Parking is only $5.00 and you can leave your car there while you snorkel. It took us about 30-45 minutes to walk the area. We were told that sea turtles sometimes come onto the beach there to sun themselves. We didn't see any, but did not leave disappointed. Overall, a good educational site for those who seek to learn more about Hawaiian culture.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: My husband and i were really looking forward to visiting this historic sight. We enjoyed our brief time there and marveled at the amazing wall, the sheer scale of which is mindboggling. My only beef with this otherwise beautiful park were the string barriers run with cloth/plastic strips to keep people from the water - it reduced the beauty and significance of the place dramatically. However, we still enjoyed our brief visit and for the $5 entry fee it was time and money well spent.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Good educational stop in the middle of Kona coffee country. We drove from Hilo to see Kona with a recommendation to see this park other than commercial sites. The time for the trip was worth doing to see old Hawaii before commercialization. While in Kona, it might be worth your while to stop by Costco for gas as the gas is about a dollar per gallon less than outside.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This park a good 20 mile drive south of Kona so take your time to get there and be careful of the fog and windy roads up in the hills. $5 entrance fee per car. We sat and listened to the 35 minute ranger talk prior to exploring - he was fantastic! Very funny and lots of great stories. You will be able to pronounce the name of the park by the time you are done! Lol.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: To Snorkel go just outside the park. The park will not let you snorkel but they will tell you that 20 feet from the park entry is a one way road where you can go to the beach. If you have a free senior citizen's pass to the National Park you can park there and walk to the beach in a minute or two or just drive down to the beach and look for parking there. The water is soooooooo clear. Lots and lots of fish. You can see down 20-40 feet in the crystal clear water. No fee for parking in the snorkeling area. It was the very best on the big island. The National Park does have a great picnic area where you can drive your car to the tables and to sights of the beach. There is a $5 entry fee if you don't have a free pass to the national park.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: It was a beautiful day but this attraction was almost empty and half closed. One gets the feeling it is spiraling downwards as it is need of repair from storm damage and there was little to see. Sure it only cost $5 per care but was the time to go there when there was little in the way of informative displays and not much to see.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This National Park holds a lot of history and is still a sacred place. Now as a National Park, there is an admission fee to enter. $5 per vehicle, or $3 per person walk in. Not too bad, the funds go towards upkeep of the attraction. Behind the visitor center is the road leading to a picnic area and beach, where we love to go with the family to relax. You can fire up the grill, do some shoreline fishing, or just stretch and enjoy the peacefullness. It is also a dog friendly beach, but your dog must be leashed and cleaned up after. No real restroom facilities- just portable bathrooms, with no running water.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Great place that has been really well preserved. Well worth the $5 entry fee. If you don't want to pay, park outside & walk in.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Haven't been in 30 years. Parking and $5.00 per person to walk into this place now. Beautiful and serene. Kept clean
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Visited this historical site on 9/2, parking is $5.00 and is good for one week, you can also drive down a separate road to the tide pools and picnic.. It was very hot that day, it was nice to cool before heading back out on our road trip. The actual site was amazing to learn about Hawaiian history and culture. The ocean view was amazingly beautiful. My children loved it. They also received Jr ranger stickers, the staff in the gift shop were great and made my 5 year old feel very special. Thank you
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: There are three national historical sites on the west coast of the Big Island, Pu'uhonua o Honaunau, Kaloko-Honokohau, and Pu'ukohola Heiau. Pu'uhonua o Honaunau is the southern most site and if you can only visit one of the three, pick this one. There are ancient stone piles with replica huts, stone walls, and a couple of fish ponds. It's a beautiful, serene place with it's palm trees and lava coast. The park does not allow you enter the ocean for snorkeling, but Honaunau Bay is within walking distance, just north of the park. $5 to enter.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Only $5 to get in, and they don't always have someone at the gate, so frequently free.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This is about 30 minutes from Kona, but well worth the drive. There is so much history here and the location is gorgeous. It would be great if they offered tours with a guide (maybe they do and we missed that somehow), but we followed the path/sites, fine on our own. Right across from the Park is a snorkeling spot-Two Step Beach, that you shouldn't skip. It offers some of the best snorkeling on the island. It is mostly lava rock (with a very small beach), but once you are in the water, you will see turtles, a ton of fish and other sea life. My 12 year old absolutely loved it here. We paid the $5 to park in the Historical Park's lot and then after visiting the Place of Refuge, we changed in their restrooms and walked the short distance to the snorkeling spot.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: If you have a National Parks pass, be sure to take it with you so that you don't have to pay the $5 per car entry fee. This is a self-guided walking tour that weaves around the City of Refuge and the Royal areas. It has an interesting history and there are audio and video areas that help explain the park.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Paul, the Concierge at the Marriott Waikoloa Beach Resort, recommended this location for the Hawaiian history and also as the second best snorkeling location on the island (the best snorkeling is taking a boat trip to Captain Cook’s Monument). Pu’uhonua O Honaunau beach assess is next to the National Historic Park (about 45 minutes South of Kailua-Kona). Pay the $5 entrance fee at the Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park and park your car in their lot, then walk the couple of blocks to the snorkel area via the beach access road (just outside the park entrance because parking at the beach is limited). Actually, there is no beach, just lava to walk across. So, take water shoes/sandals to walk on the lava. Entrance/exit into/out of the water to snorkel isn’t as hard as it looks and you will be rewarded with a spectacular view of coral and hundreds of fish! Then go back to the park (use the bathrooms to change, if needed) and take the Historic Park self-guided tour to see some amazing Hawaiian artifacts and history.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Before going to the Place of Refuge, take a little time to learn about old Hawaiian culture (pre-contact). It is especially helpful to learn about the class distinctions between the ali'i (royalty) and other people, and the kapu (or taboos). Then, visit Pu'uhonua O Honaunau and take in the serenity, beauty, and spiritual significance of the site. The crash of the waves, the palms growing in white sand, and the re-created village environment transports visitors to the Hawaiian past. Hawaiians who violated kapu and who were lucky enough to flee their villages alive would come to the city for refuge and absolution to be able to return to their homes. The air is thick with the spirit of the past, and it is so easy to imagine the ali'i living here and the terrified refugees seeking safety. There is a wonderful audio tour (via cell phone!) and sand-friendly wheelchairs to provide accessibility. I would absolutely bring children here - there is plenty to look at and enjoy, and, bring your National Parks Pass for entry. Take your time, and watch the beaches carefully for turtles. (Moving rocks? Yeah, they're turtles...) We combined our visit to the Place of Refuge with a snorkeling adventure at Two-Step (my favorite land-based snorkel site). But please, don't use the Place of Refuge as a launch site for the snorkel adventure. The two experiences are very, very different. There is road-side parking for snorkeling, and the restrooms at the Place of Refuge aren't changing rooms.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This is the real deal - unadorned as it must have been hundreds of years ago. History and culture exude from this Place of Refuge enclosed by a massive great wall. A must-visit if you want to glimpse traditional ancient Hawaiian culture. A trail takes you all around the park. Ki'i (carved wooden images) are found throughout the park. The cost is nominal at $5 per vehicle.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Place of refuge provides a look at early Hawaiian culture since the 1700's. It is a beautiful park were you can explore Hawaiian history. Park Entrance Fees: are
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This Historical National Park is a must see if you are at the Island of Hawaii. The place shows off the historical aspect of the culture and the Hawaiian people. The models of the churches, and the statues carved out the wood (Tiki) were awesome. Admittance was $5.00 per car and $3.00 per person (so take a car if >2 people)
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: When you check in to this historic park, you will be given a self guided tour map so you explore here at your own leisure. While were there a long boat canoe race was taking place and also a royal ceremony so we got to see something extra. There is a nice picnic area off to the side but you'll need to ask where it is and drive down a sand road to reach it. We thoroughly enjoyed seeing this historic site and it's well worth the $5/vehicle admission.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We really enjoyed visiting this historic site. There was a free audio tour with a map, which helped us navigate the site without missing the main items. From here, when we looked out to the honaunau bay,we could see schools of fishes since the water is so clear. It worked out well for us since the nearby honaunau bay is one of the best snorkel sites in the big island and we combined both these attractions.The entrance fee was only 5$ or so.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: The Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historic Park is unique mix with historic site, the Heiau, the tradition building/house, the totem pole, the coconut trees etc. The more exiting from this site is also place for snorkel lover with a lot of fish even you can see them from the lava rock with the wave calm and clear water. I saw the local fishing with the spear and the fish so pretty (so sad, the local call the fish is parrot fish, so colorful like the other fish ). Parking & entrance fee $ 5/car and they give you colorful flyer/map to the historic site for your guide.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Only about 20 miles east of downtown Kona it is well worth the drive. Well maintained and friendly helpful staff. A physically beautiful National Park. Great free guide books of historical features and native plants. Reconstructed huts and statuary. Fee of $5 per car more than reasonable.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Spent about an hour here walking around enjoying the views and the serenity while reading about the history of the Place of Refuge. The cost was five dollars per car. There was a nice visitor center and bathroom facilities. The tour is self guided. Interesting and beautiful.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Had never heard of this Park until someone at work told me about it. So glad we went. With the restorations, it was amazing to see the Heiau that housed the bones of past chiefs. There was also a wonderful outrigger on display that was made by a native craftsman who frequently is there working on one or another piece. It is hot there so bring water, wear good walking shoes. You can either take a self guided tour or start your time there with a guide who gives a short talk. What is significant about this "Place of Refuge" is that if you were on the losing side during a war, or refused to fight, or broke a sacred law, you got the death penalty. BUT if you could make it to this place, be absolved by a Hawaiian Priest, the death penalty was lifted and you were allowed to live. Would have liked to go to the beach next door but we were too tired out that day. For those who need a wheelchair, sand wheelchairs are available at no charge. The only fee is $5 for parking and there are handicapped spaces available.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: "The Place of Refuge" to ancient Hawaiians. Yes, it's mostly recreated, but it's done accurately. Rangers are on hand to give detailed explainations, and the view is not to be missed. It's worth the $5.00 park admission.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: White beaches with coconut palms, beautifully carved statues, lots of turtles, tidal pools...what a great value for $5. No snorkeling allowed but you can easily do that in the bay right before this site, within walking distance.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Visied here in the late afternoon. Cost was $ 5.00 for the car, which was reasonable, we really enjoyed this place, very peaceful, worth visiting if you are in the area.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: For a minimal entry fee of $6 per vehicle you can tour this National Park, either a self-guided tour or wait for one of the ranger lectures and learn more about the "Place of Refuge." The park brochure provides a good overview of the attractions, the historical items are numbered and labeled so you clearly know what you're viewing. I found the entire park very interesting, full of details on ancient Hawaiian culture, including how commoners were to interact/react when royalty was present. It was quite warm the day we visited and the black lava rock heats up quickly. The park does have a water fountain and restrooms.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Sacred ancient ruins where Hawaiian defeated warriors could find refuge after battle. A place of great history and beauty. Fish ponds, recreated temples, display of hand hewn canoes. A place worth the visit and $5.00 entry fee.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: I feel a trip to any Hawaiian island is incomplete if you're just going to the beaches, eating at the restaurants and seeing the attractions. It's important to learn about the history so you better understand the Hawaiian people and truly appreciate your remarkable location. The Big Island is one of the best for this and Place of Refuge (Puuhonua o Honaunau National Historical Park) is a great place to start. Very good visitor center and self-guided walk. Definitely worth the $5 per vehicle entrance fee.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Parking is $5 and it’s valid for one week. The site displays and preserves the ancient Hawaiian life on a natural scenic ocean front location. It has bathroom facility, drinking water fountain, but no shower. Right next to the historical site is the Two Steps, a well-known best snorkeling site by the local. It is not on any tourist map because it is not a park. It is a open public spot with no public facility. The land opposite the Two Steps is privately own. The owner charge $3 parking on its dirt lot and they have portable toilet. We brought our snorkeling gear, visited the historical site first. Left the car parked at the nicely paved historical site parking lot, then walked over to the Two Steps for snorkeling. Since the historical site parking is good for one week, you can go back and park at the historical site as many times as you want during the valid one week period, and snorkel at the Two Steps.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: As a part of the National Historical Park, Hawaii, this site is wonderful. I appreciated the landscape - the land that the volcano brought, what it means, the beauty, the palm trees, the hard work of previous generations....all wrapped up into one. The admission fee is $5.00 - I'd pay more.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: The City of refuge is located right next to a great place to snorkle. Pay for your parking and enjoy the National park walk and then snorkle after. Price for entry is around $5.00 and the walk through this historical site is very peaceful. Make sure you learn the history off this place so you can have a better understanding of its significance. Park employees are very knowlegable and provide a short presentation for you close to the park entrance.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: The second time I visited the park in 8 years. It's a magical place. Absolutely gorgeous grounds, one of the most beautiful places on earth for me now. Turtles can be seen regularly. Good visitor center. Best picnic spot next to grounds, overlooking lava field and ocean with best sunsets. Plus - one of the best snorkel spots on the island is right next to it. You can park in the lot for the park for $5, go visit it first and then snorkel, or the other way around. It couldn't be more fantastic.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: July 2007 - My kids and i went here late the afternoon.we arrived on the Big Ilsnad. The BIReavealed book gave us good directions. This is a really neat place to explore. There is a self guided tour you can do that covers the key areas in the park. Nothing spectaular until you realize that alot of this was put together in the 1500's. Its just a nice place to get a feel for the early Hawaiian islands and their culture. The cost is $5 - however when we got there no one was there to take the money. As you leave pay attention on you left is a turnout to go to the Painted Church. Its worth a stop as well.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: The park is only 5 dollars to enter and its ticket is good for admission for several days.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: We went there just to park so we could go snorkeling at what I would say is the "best spot to snorkel" on the big island. But found it very interesting. It gives you some history on what locals refered to as the "city of refuge". They have restrooms, snack bar & gift shop. It's only $5.00 to park on a watched parking lot and admittion to the National Park. So if you have a yearly "Park Pass" you have already paid for it. If not, save your receipt, it's good for the week. Ask the attendant at the parking lot for directions for the snorkeling. I swear, it's the best spot on the Big Island to snorkel. It's an easy walk to get to the snorkeling spot.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: This is such a beautiful park with so much historical significance. Parking is just $5 and well worth it. Take some time to walk around the beautiful park. Be aware that this is a very sacred place to the Hawaiian people and treat it with the respect it deserves.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: On the big island this is a Must See. The place itself is spiritual as the place of refuge and forgiveness from ancient times. Now there is a wealth of cultural education and they have added daily Ranger Talks like some of the other larger National Parks. The history and depth of culture here is unsurpassed. In ancient times people could come here to get their 'sins' forgiven. Now it is simply a peaceful place to walk and ponder. And somehow when here you too feel 'forgiven'. The tide pools are reported to have healing powers. They often times have turtles in them and as we know the turtles have mana-the Hawaiian word for spiritual power. It is not hard to understand how this place could be called the place of refuge. Cost- $5. Gift shop available. Water available for purchase and at the restrooms in the form of a drinking fountain. Parking-included in cost of entrance. They have special wheelchairs that can navigate the sand on the beach. Beach-protected by a 20 foot perimeter but has many sea turtles who go there to bask and feed. Call ahead for the special Ranger Talks, (808) 328-2326 well worth the time.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Ancient Hawaiian sacred place( The place of refuge) and royal grounds. Complete with tiki ,huts ,Hawaiian fish ponds, lava flow,and ocean. There is a picnic area, so bring your lunch.$5 a carload.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Prior to visiting this sacred location, I had coincidently read about the site's function and role in Hawai'ian society. By doing so, I was able to gain a greater appreciation of its historical and cultural value. A good source can be found at the National Park Service website since it is managed Federally (a $6 entry fee to the park).
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Well worth the $5 per car admission. Ranger talk is good. Beautiful scenery with Windy road to get there.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Been to this island several time and this was our first time to city of refuge. We bought the Parks dept 3 park annual pass when we went to the Volcano National Park. ($25 for one park, or 3 park pass for $30 and good for a year).
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: It's a smaller park, but there's a fair bit to see here. The interpretive signage is good, and the entrance fee is only $5. There's good snorkeling across the cove - you cannot snorkel in the park.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: I found this Nat'l Historic Park to be very interesting and there is a very nice visitor center with displays, information and a video (that tends to drag a bit). In my mind, however, it is unfortunate that the principle attraction at this site, the sacred site, cannot be accessed unless one is of a certain race and/or religious belief. For a nationally funded site supported by tax dollars, I find this offensive at the very least.

I ended up here after just seeing where the road from Kealakekua Bay would take me on my way back to the Hilo side. I have a National Parks Pass, so entry was free--not sure what the fee is if you don't have one. I did the cell phone tour around the different artifacts. There were Green Sea Turtles sunning on the beach and a few out in the tide pools. I was there near sunset and got some nice pictures of the place. Overall, a nifty little stop with some interesting Hawaiian history. I wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to see it, but if you have an hour or so to kill and you are in the area, go for it.

This easy hike starts at Swiftcurrent Pass. Most of the trail is pretty shady. After we reached Redrock Lake, we encountered a mama bear munching on berries while her cub was safely perched in the pine tree. She really didn't pay much attention to us...we took pictures and walked on by. On our return trip she was still munching but this time decided to follow us on the trail with cub in tow over to the lake. Again, lots of pictures while walking backwards so we didn't lose sight of her. Lots of fun watching them, but with bear spray in hand!
park: Red Rock Falls, Glacier National Park

text: This was an amazing hike. The hike begins at Swiftcurrent Pass in Many Glacier. The hike was one of our favorites. You go by two lakes before you come to the falls. We saw deer crossing the stream. We also saw sheep on this hike.
park: Red Rock Falls, Glacier National Park

text: You have a couple of choices at the trailhead, near the Swiftcurrent Motor Inn. You can go to Iceberg Lake or take the other trail towards Swiftcurrent Pass. We took the wrong turn and went towards Swiftcurrent Pass and it was only after about 2 miles that we figured it out. But this is also a great hike and you can go about 3 1/2 miles and arrive at Bullhead Lake. We saw a moose swim all across the lake! Once you get past the very popular Red Rock Falls, you will have very few fellow hikers.
park: Red Rock Falls, Glacier National Park

text: We traveled from Grant Pass OR to CA in late September which we covered all Redwood National Park. Redwood National Park is not just one park which is a combination of many state parks and there is no park entrance fee. The best way to explore this park not just only driving through it but also do some hiking. There are some short ( o.5 mile) to medium ( 2-3 miles) hikes which are not difficult to handle. To me the best part of Redwood is at Stout Grove (0.5 miles loop trail) which you can get to it from Cresent city or north entrance ( like us). But the road is narrow and with big holes. Do not forget to stop at visitor center which they will give you some ideal where to go. We drove through Newton B Duruy Park way ( you will see the biggest tree at this region) and went to Fern Canyon which you can do more hiking ( narrow road and curvy with big holes and string of water to get there also). At Prairie Creek ( before go to Fern Canyon) you will be able to see many many elks ( I saw at least 14 of them). At Humboldt Redwood you can drive through Ave of Giant. There are couple hiking trails. We hiked at the Chaney memorial Grove ( 2.4 miles) which is loved by local. At Ave of Giant you will able to see the tallest tree at this region.

This is a great activity if you like the out of doors. The trees are absolutely majestic. The open-air train ride is very relaxing. It doesn't take too long, nor is it too short. The weather was a little cool so be sure to bring a jacket. The employees we met were friendly. There weren't many there because there were parts of the site that weren't operating the day we were there. The bookstore/souvenir shop was open. Be sure to scratch the guard kitty under the neck when you check out. Prices in the store were normal souvenir prices, a little high. The food we purchased was tasty but expensive. The menu was more extensive than most places like this. You can wander around and look at the site at your leisure and there are plenty of photo opportunities available. Definitely worth the price, if you like this sort of activity.

I arrived at this park via the Redwood Highway from Grants Pass, OR down into Crescent City, CA. The drive was about three hours or so and it was very scenic. The Redwood Park is just into Northern CA, and there are many places to stop. The trees became larger and larger as we entered the area of the park. As a resident of the east coast, the size of the trees was surreal. I visited Stout Memorial Grove that was locally recommended and was located off the main road, down a dirt road and then eventually a parking lot emerged. It was so quiet and peaceful. The trees were so large I was in awe. It was beautiful!
Passing through, even beautiful at night! Would loved to seen it during the day but throughly enjoyed the nighttime drive. A must see!!!!

RNP works with a couple other state parks. RNP has one main visitors center that is small but fun to see stuff about animals. For those with young children, I recommend the prairie creek trail that starts at the visitors center and taking it to the big tree. Can take a stroller the whole way. We then we did the cathedral trail and you can't take a stroller on that but we did anyway and had to carry our baby and carry the stroller, as it has inclines and lots of tree roots and then it narrows. My fave was the prairie creek trail. We also went to fern canyon. $8 if you don't have a national parks pass. Worth it. Just go early cuz it was so crowded when we got back to the parking lot! Had our toddler walk that hike/walk. We did the lady bird johnson trail and it was ok. I wouldn't do that one again just cuz it wasn't as spectacular, but you could take a stroller.

Pictures cannot do justice to this beautiful forest. it requires people and cars in the pictures to realize how majestic these giant trees are. We took the road less traveled into the Jedidiah Smith State park and Redwood National park. The easy way is over a bridge off hwy 160 coming south from Grants Pass. There is a ranger outpost on the north side of the road where you can get directions to Douglas Park Dr and Howland Hill Rd. However, that bridge was under reconstruction and we entered off hwy 101. We visited the visitors center in Crescent City, CA and they directed us down a short distance to the Elk Valley Road that bends into the Howland Hill Rd. Once on this road you will wind your way through these giant redwoods spaced just far enough for a single vehicle to pass through. The road is dirt, dusty, and full of pot holes but that seems to add to the ambiance. After traveling about 5 miles, you enter a parking area with outhouses and trails through the forest as well as down to the Smith river that passes through. You need at least 2 full days to enjoy all that the expanded park has to offer. Unfortunately we only had one which means there is still a lot to see.

This is a great adventure. The National Parks are national treasures and many of them are bypassed for the masses in favor of the staples like Yellowstone and Yosemite. This is a gem of a park and I had the place almost to myself traveling in early June. This one you can just drive through and enjoy. Other national parks charge an entrance fee but for $80 you can get an annual pass to The National Parks and Federal Recreational Lands.

Our tax dollars did not go to waste in Orick! You could buy every dwelling and what is left of the businesses and they would not come close to the cost of the palatial Park Head Quarters in the middle of the small town. Really this thing is extravagantly huge. The problem is, it is not open to the public. You would think the thing would have a huge visitor center and theater inside. Nope. I have a friend that assumed he could stop and use the restroom. Echos of his own footsteps in the cavernous entry but no restroom. Lurch appeared as if magically summoned and ran him out though. There are a few visitor centers in the park, just south of Orick at the beach and to the north at Prairie Creek. Check out the Bull Elk embedded in a tree from probably a hundred years ago.
