Nice park set up...anyone can walk these trails and camping is available...driving there is another story...go the route 17 way...we went up a very narrow road and was only a one lane road at times...took forever to get there...coming down we stayed on bear claw blvd and it took half the time to get home to San Jose...Have fun...nice day trip...cost only $10 to park...
Its a nice place to spend 2 days.Gondola ride was fun but u can not see much on the top of the mountain. "Drive through tree" is just OK. I feel its expensive to spent $5 for such a small thing,,:(
Enter. Look....... around and up. Breath deeply. Relax. Smile. Feel the entire experience. Be awed at the grandeur and beauty of nature. Appreciate.

A visit to the Redwood National Park is a must. It brings all your senses back to reality after a visit to SF. It shows the grandure and grace of nature juxtaposed to the man made grandure of the Golden Gate Bridge and the vibrancy of San Francisco. If you arrive before 9:00 a.m. entrance is free. After 9:00 a.m., $7 for adults. Paths for easy strolls around the base of the redwoods and paths for hikes half way up and higher than the 300 foot giants. This is my second visit. Will go every time I'm in the area.

This is a gem of Northern California scenic places to visit. It was a labor day weekend, we 3 families stayed in one of Trinidad's vacation rental (Retro Retreat $900) for 3 nights, we planned for 2 but the minimum was 3, in fact it turned out to be good other wise it would have been a exhaustive trip. On Day one we just roam around Trinidad, beaches, light house, Paticks Point, once passing Patricks point there is an RV park and old school museum where they do have a community music band and free food (you can donate $$ for the food) on weekends, we had great burgers and coffee, then proceed to Gold Bluff's Beach. It's a 20-30 minutes drive through the woods, slight rough roads and small creeks you can drive through. You need to walk down to see the fern canyon and water falls which is a mind refreshing experience, I would suggest plan for an afternoon at this place. We didn't that much time so we spent some time at fern canyon and didn't reach to falls as it was farther and park hours are about to close for the day. We had a close encounter with Elks at this place. Day two we took south to visit shrine drive through tree as we didn't know there was another one in Klamath, so that we could visit drive through tree and trees of mystery in one trip.It turned out to be good as this place has few parking spots inside the park. Even though the tree is supported by the cables and it's leaned to one side. It's not a tall tree, it's a hollow tree vertically (been cut off) and horizontally where you drive through.They are saying that the trunk of the tree has been burned off and fall down ~100 ft from the level. Tree is still alive and it has leaves and branches as well. I visited the leget drive through tree as well, more or less you 'll get the same feeling as you drive through the tree, if you expecting for a fully sized tree from top to bottom, it's not what it is. We still had time to spent but not enough to reach Klamath for visiting trees of mystery. So we took a tour through avenue of gaints and swim at one of the river passing near by. You can drive in to river and park next to the water. The water was not that cold too. We spent some time playing with water, and refreshing swim. Then we visited the one of the beaches at Crescent, it was early evening and a bit cold but kids enjoyed it's fullest as the beach is more of sandy than muddy. On day 3 we went to visit trees of mystery at Klamath, we could have do both day 2 and 3 in one day if we went to Klamath on day 2. On our way back we took a stop at Carson Mansion which is a really great place to visit.

You really must visit these trees once in your lifetime. They should be ranked among the ranks of the Grand Canyon as a necessary visit in the United States. So many gorgeous campgrounds; so many gorgeous trails to explore. Stayed at the Elk Prairie campground - beautiful and serene with a mellow creek running through it. Bathroom facilities were topnotch: showers were extremely clean and water hot - there is a fee for the showers (25 cents per 2.5min). Also stayed at Mill Creek campground: further north with secluded campsites. Bathroom facilities older, showers not as clean, and varying prices for the showers. Viewed the Jedediah campground even further north - close to Stout grove, but no more special than the other two. Tons of hiking nearby; ocean always within 20m drive. Most of the park sites were free admission and parking, but $35 fee per night for the campsites.

The Redwood National and State Parks are absolutely amazing! I started the trip from the south on Hwy 101. The Avenue of the Giants is an incredible drive. Me being a forester from Louisiana, I was in complete awe of these giant trees. The trees here would fit underneath the first limb on most of these trees! The Lady Bird Johnson, Founders, and Stout Groves are home to some of the largest trees in the world, definetly check them out. The National Park is free, but the state parks require small entrance fees. There are some drive thru trees along highway 101, there are signs to them, and you can drive thru for a 5 dollar fee, kind of a tourist trap, but where else can you drive thru a tree? If you're ever in California don't miss this magnificent place, they will render you speechless!

I'm just going to point out some of the highlights of our trip in case it is helpful to anyone else. We stayed in the Ravenwood Motel in Klamath (& loved it but it is pretty isolated) then we spent a day travelling north & another day travelling south. Starting north on your park map & heading south: we would recommend the Howland Hill Rd. drive & the Stout Grove trail. You can walk over to the Battery Point Lighthouse but nearby is the Seal rescue center & you can walk around outside & see if they are re-habbing any animals & give them a donation for the awesome work they do. We liked the Yurok Loop trail and saw a bald eagle & we also did the Trees of Mystery. We drove the Newton Drury Pkwy & we did see some elk near the visitor center. We really liked the Fern Canyon trail (you can only hike it for a 1 mile loop if you want)--highly recommended but $8 per car load. We also liked the Trilium Falls Trail--we saw elk here too. These were our favorite things we did over 2 days. Good luck!

We visited the redwood forest as part of our California road trip. We had been to the Muir Woods Sequoia forest the day before so it was interesting to compare this experience to that. The weather was gorgeous that day, warm and sunny with really bright blue skies, but the limited parking areas were full by the time we got there, well before noon. We had to park about a mile or so on the road and walk back, but it was free. The entrance fee to the forest is $5.00 per person. After paying that you can visit the gift shop, eat, drink, go to the restroom or just proceed into the redwood area. There is a whole different atmosphere upon entering the forest. It is a humbling, almost hushed attitude that the visitors have while in it. I looked around while walking the several miles that we did that day and there were people visiting from several nations. I could hear snippets of german, korean, italian, french and some indian and arabic dialects being spoken around us. After a mile or so inside the forest, there is a clearing where one can sit on a bench, reflect, take pics, etc., and where a park ranger gives a 15 minute talk on the history of the forest and how very difficult it is to grow a majestic redwood to maturity. A tiny redwood seed must go through a gauntlet of issues before it has a hope of becoming a fully mature tree. This was fascinating stuff to me. The natural beauty and history of this forest, on the day that we were there, was pretty much perfect.

Our main reason for visiting was to purchase a senior National Parks Pass before the prices went up. Since this park is free, they did not have them. The ranger made certain that we knew which parks in Michigan might have them and also printed out a list of those in our home state. Awesome help!

If you are into revisionist history and are apologetic and ashamed of your American heritage then this is the place for you. The small museum was very nice and for the most part the staff was very pleasant. Everything was okay until we listened to the park guide give a discussion of the battle. He tried to convince us that the horrible Americans were stupid and were only there to conquer Canada. The American wounded deserved to be slaughtered by the Indians because all they did on the way there was burn their villages. They are even going to erect a "Peace" center as a way to apologize for having a dispute with them in the first place. Nice to see how our American dollars are being spent here. We die for a lack of knowledge here.

Came here today for a pre-Easter event and boy, oh boy...what a GREAT day! Kids did fun old-style games, there were snacks (cookies, donuts, juice, cider and coffee), staff/volunteers were so fun and friendly, a wreath raffle, and it was gorgeous out!! There is a gift shop inside with all different kinds of items from 35 cent pencils to $25 bb guns. Not a ton of parking but they have 2 lots, one next to the visitor center and the other one just down the driveway to the right. They also have a picnic/shelter area. There is a paved trail to bike or walk. Gorgeous scenery behind the center and water to view across the street that has a boardwalk/bridge. Def'ly looking forward to the next event :)

The NPS Staff at the River Raisin National Battlefield Park are exceptional. This is a wonderful addition to the Parks Service roster! Don't miss getting your stamp for your NPS Passport! Visit www.monroeinfo.com for details on the park and this beautiful community of Monroe.
Our family is attempting to visit every National Park in the country and get the stamps in our Passport book. This is listed as the only National Park in RI, though the name states Memorial.

The four Kaiser shipyards in Richmond produced 747 vessels, mainly Liberty and Victory cargo ships, for the war effort in the 40s - they were somewhat revolutionary in terms of applying prefabrication and assembly line techniques to mass produce cargo ships faster than the Axis powers could sink them. They were co-located with the large Ford Assembly Plant already on the Richmond waterfront that itself was converted to wartime production of jeeps and tanks. The visitor center for the complex is located in a corner of this latter facility. In addition to providing a starting point for seeing some of the sights at the shipyards, the SS Red Oak Victory that was built here and now is museum herself, and the extensive walking trail around the waterfront, there is a good sized museum with some artifacts from yard workers and some first person accounts telling their stories. There is a little movie theater as well, and apparently on some Fridays there are lectures by some of the original "Rosie the Riveters" who worked at the shipyards. Admission to the visitor center's displays, movies, etc. is free.
park: Rosie the Riveter/World War II Home Front National Historical Park

text: Museum interesting. MUST go on a day Betty Reid Suskin is lecturing at 2pm. Tickets given out at 1. Get there early (noonish) to get in line if crowded. Google her. She's 95, so go soon.
park: Rosie the Riveter/World War II Home Front National Historical Park

text: Used our Golden Eagle Pass to get in. A lot of the interactive exhibits were out of order and the more controversial aspects of the history were read-between-the-lines. BUT they have a lady there who lived through the era -- she was fascinating. The view of the Bay and the walking path along the shore is great, too.
park: Rosie the Riveter/World War II Home Front National Historical Park

text: So glad we did. Interesting and informative, and located in a great water setting. Fantastic view of the S.F. skyline. We spent about two hours; you could di it in as little as an hour, or perhaps up to three hours. Price: free. Bonus: the ability to actually chat with 90+ year old real "Rosie the Riveters". Be sure to stop by next door for lunch at Assemble (you can thank me later for that tip).
park: Rosie the Riveter/World War II Home Front National Historical Park

text: For the low price of $0, you get a well presented education on how WWII affected things here at home, as well as the opportunity to bike along the water. The visitor center is very well maintained, and there is a lot of info in a relatively small space. Be sure to take in at least one of the short movies in the theater...we saw the one titled The Home Front and Total War; well made and informative. Exhibits are good, and we enjoyed looking at all of the WWII ads on the walls. You can bike or walk along the San Francisco Bay Trail near the center, or for a longer ride you can follow that same trail in the opposite direction through a mixed use industrial area to get to the SS Red Oak Victory Ship for a tour. Be sure to check that tour's days/times of operation, as we were about 1/2 an hour too late to get on the ship. There is a suggested donation for the ship tour.
park: Rosie the Riveter/World War II Home Front National Historical Park

text: In Point Richmond there are a number of interesting historic attractions - the Rosie the Riveter Park, the Ford factory, the Rosie the Riveter Visitor Center (behind the Ford factory and not well marked) but the crown jewel is not listed on Tripadvisor. It is the SS Red Oak Victory - the last surviving Victory ship to be built during WW II at the Henry J. Kaiser Permanente Metals Corporation Shipyard number 1. Read about it here - http://www.ssredoakvictory.com/index.htm. The tour by the docents has an amazing amount of information, presented in a personal, warm manner and if you are lucky, you get to spend time with the ship's retiring chief - Bill Jackson, aged 94 (but you would never believe it). Bill was one of the first African-American chiefs in the U.S. Merchant Marine and his story will inspire you and your children. The admission is a suggested donation of $5 - I would have happily paid $25 for the tour.
park: Rosie the Riveter/World War II Home Front National Historical Park

text: Russell Cave National Monument is really in the middle of nowhere. The cave was very disappointing but we have a National Park Passport and wanted to check this Alabama site off the list. Glad we went for that reason, and since it was spring there were some beautiful flowers blooming. However, do not go expecting something like Mammoth Caves, etc.

A sleepy little stop--even the lady working the desk said she was ready for a nap. They show you a video and you can walk out to the cave to look around. It was raining so we watched the video, got our National Park Passport stamped and left. I probably wouldn't recommend going unless you needed your passport stamped.

We, too, visited the park because of the NPS Passport program and had an excellent time. The cave is large but you can only enter a small portion of it but the area is beautiful. The walkway made it easy for all members of our party to experience the cave and the ranger was very helpful and friendly.

Russell Cave National Monument is a bit out of the way, but worth a stop for those who like to enjoy nature while learning a bit about pre-Columbian natives in the Southeastern U.S. There is a small museum on site, adjoined by a small gift shop. The truly great feature is the Cave itself, which is located a short distance from the visitor center, down a beautiful wooden walkway. The site also offers demonstrations of primitive weapons some days, unfortunately this wasn't offered on the day of our visit due to a lack of staff. Admission is free and the site is beautiful;if you're in the Chattanooga or Huntsville area it's worth the drive.

This is a great visit if you are in the area or nearby. We live in Chattanooga, TN and so the trip was not too out of the way at 50 miles and we had already planned on visiting a state park that was about 30 miles from home so the 20 extra miles wasn't much. I don't think it would it is worth going out of your way for, unless like my husband and I you don't mind just getting out for a long relaxing drive. It is a beautiful area, visitor center is nice, the volunteer and ranger were extremely friendly and knowledgeable, but there is not much else to do but view the cave entrance, take the short hike and get your National Park Passport Book stamped. We arrived early morning on a Sunday morning and had the place to ourselves. We took the boardwalk to the cave entrance (this is wheel chair accessible) and snapped a few pictures. We were too early for the guided tour but I think it would have made it much more enjoyable to hearing the history while viewing the cave (tours offered at 11:00). After less than 10 minutes we were ready to head on.

Before leaving to go on a trip we order our Passports for the national parks... So we set out to search for this place... lots of back roads, but it gave my husband and I time to reconnect and the scenery was beautiful. Would have never know it was there. It has a lot of history and a great display. My daughter (2 1/2 at the time) was mad because we would allow her to take the baby!

We only had a short stop here, as we were on our way to another planned destination. But, since we were so close to a national monument, we had to stop. (Plus I got another stamp in my National Parks Passport book!). It was almost closing time for them, but we did get a chance to walk the trail to the cave and see that, as well as the informational boards along the way. It's always interesting to learn about how people lived so long ago, and this was no exception. There are additional trails aside from the main one to the cave, but we did not have time to walk them. The NPS staff was very helpful and informative. If we get back to that area, we will stop again so we can see more of the area.

I loved Saguaro National Park because it was out of the city and wasn’t crowded at all! We explored the west side of the park. There are two sides and the city of Tucson sits in between them (they are about an hour apart). We first went to the visitor center and paid our entrance fee. Although I’m sure many people completely pass over this and enter without paying, we wanted a couple souvenirs from inside and also paid when in there. It is $15 per car.

Having purchased a new travel trailer, we were anxious to give it a try and reserved a space at Cagle. Then it became apparent that if we were to follow through with our plans, we would be forced to sit in the camper for 3 straight days, as the entire are was pummeled with days and days of torrential rains. We determined there was no point, and cancelled our reservation 36 hours prior to our scheduled visit. NOW COMES THE GOOD PART, Cagle decided to retain $19 of our original reservation for the privilege of looking them up and reserving a spot ONLINE. They literally did nothing but read our email reservation, and our cancellation notice, 36 hours in advance, but determined they deserved $19 for their trouble. RIDICULOUS! STEER WELL CLEAR OF THIS PLACE!

My friend and I (in our 30s) spent a few hours hiking the Lonestar trail, a covered forest hike that had views of Lake Conroe for parts of the hike. To manage expectations, this was a nice hike (for this area), but you are not going to see a grand finale at the end (i.e. Waterfall, overlook, ridges, etc). The whole trail is a forested hike. Some tips...stay on the trail (poison ivy), find a stick to fend off spider webs (if you go first before your group), follow the gray marked on the trees (so you don't get lost), ranger station not open (11:30-12 as they are at lunch), park is free to get in (unless you go to Cagle camp site $5 = bathrooms, as the visitor center is under construction), bring bug spray and sunblock. Spider web stick...super important! Don't be a ninja fighting off spider webs in the air! :) have a good time! See my pictures to get the map and a feel for what the park is like.

RV camp sites book early, but we were able to renew our site the morning of, so I think they leave some sites available for that purpose. The only swimming hole in the park is nice, but it is a good distance from the camp sites. Plan to have bikes or a vehicle to get there (it would be a long walk!). They do have bathrooms and showers nearby. We rented a canoe for $15 for an hour. They do have life jackets readily available as well. The trails and fishing pier were also nice.

Just sent a week in two towns around the SJNF so much to do hiking and jeeping was our thing. The most amazing trails out there. The million dollar highway is worth a drive in its self. A lot of history out there, Ute Indian tribe, miners, railroad men, and the settlers of the early years.

Took this trip by jeep. Jeff Copeland was our guide. Amazing views and ride. It is however not for people with back problems. Wear something to protect your head from wind. It is after all an open air ride. Guide was super personalble and knowledgeable Bring water and good hiking shoes as the terrain is rocky and rough when you get out to walk to take a few pics. Well worth the $85.00/adult for half a day ride. Highly recommend it.

Backpacked the Vallecito Creek trail up to Hunchback Pass. Spent one night at the campground at the trail head near Vallecito Resevoir. 4 nights on the trail! Can't wait to go back & try other trails that connect.

We have been fortunate enough to have been through the San Juan National Forest county three times in the last 20 years. It keeps getting better, especially in the fall. Picture taking is a must. Take the highway from Telluride (62) west to Ridgway & turn south on 550 ( going north isn't a bad thing either) through the old mining areas of Oray, Silverton & Durango. The road is winding & often no guard rails but it is worth every mile you travel. Get ready for blue skies, sunshine, even snow at times, mountain peaks, plenty of gorgeous aspens in fall colors. Could not get enough, every bend in the road was a picture. You can see why they call it the Million Dollar Highway. From Durango take Hwy 160 & follow it east until you pass through Pagosa Springs where you climb up to 10,850 feet over Wolf Creek Pass. This car trip through southwestern Colorado truly makes you sit up and notice. Nothing like it all the western states. You can plan a month vacation here easily!
Don't miss the drive on US 550 over Red Mountain Pass otherwise known as The Million Dollar Highway. It's quite the adventure and many photo opportunities.

Been coming to Lake City. CO since eight years old. We have used a 4x4 to go over Red Mountain Pass to Ouray as well as snowmobiles. It is fascinating to see how they reproduced electricity in the mining days with a waterfall. The horse back riding is some of the best you will ever see anf Lake San Cristobal is gorgeous all through the year. There is so much to see if you appreciate nature & wildlife you will return time after time.
Gorgeous views everywhere on route 550. Took it all of the way to Ouray (Million dollar highway) and was wowed at every turn. A little scary at times but well worth the trip.

I have been hiking and enjoying the San Juan N F since 1968. I started back packing with the Boy Scouts on trails behind Vallecito Lake 17 miles east of Durango. There are two trail heads that make access easy. They are the Vallecito Trail Head and the Pine River Trail Head. You can also access the forest via the train into the Neddleton area. A trail there will take you up Chicago Basin and over Columbian Pass at a little over 12,000 ft. One piece of advice go into Durango and buy a good trail guide book, and read it before deciding where to enter. This simple act will make your trip that much better. Also, buy the forest service pass or a fishing pass, it is about $15.00. BUT if you get into trouble, the search and rescue with a helicopter wont' cost you a dime.

We have visited the Durango area many times and always spend some time up in the mountains. The scenery is spectacular and the opportunities for outdoor activities are unlimited. If you enjoy hiking, consider the Pass Creek trail. The trailhead is located very near the Coal Bank Pass rest area on highway 550. It is a high altitude and fairly steep trail (2300 feet in elavation gain) but after only about 2.6 miles you are near the base of Engineer Mountain and rewarded with amazing views in all directions. If you are more adventurous you can continue on a much steeper rocky trail to the summit of the mountain. We were there on Labor Day weekend so the trail was fairly busy but I imagine at other times (especially during the week) it is not very crowded. It is appropriate for older children who are used to hiking but not for younger ones. Please be aware that it is a strenuous hike at a high altitude so you should have a decent level of fitness before attempting it.

Totally different experience from more familiar deciduous forests, or from conifer forests at lower elevations. We were there during the Wolf Creek Pass fires, and the results of previous fires made very clear the effects on whole communities, not just the forest itself.

Whether you go the loop (1-2 days) or Durango to Ridgeway(few hrs), you won't be disappointed. The Million $ Hwy will take your breath away! Stop at Mola Pass and Red Mt. Pass and get your camera-WOW. Easy on those curves.

Do not miss this drive. We did the Durango-Silverton railroad the day before and were on our way to Ouray for the night. We followed the rr for a short time and then climbed high into the mountains. Different views than from the railroad car but spectacular. I am so glad we did both. It cost a million $$ to build this road in its time but worth every penny!!

We were fortunate to have personal tour guides in this national treasure since we have family that lives in Durango. The San Juan National forest is just beautiful. We made our way up to the Molas Pass Summit, clocking in at 10,910 feet. The views are breathtaking, you get some awesome photo ops, and the signs at the top of the summit give some great historical and geographic lessons about our country. This was great for adults, and would be even better for kids.

We were in the Durango area for 4 days and intended to hike the Engineer Mountain Trail (a poplar hike in the area) but by the time we arrived, there was no parking at the main lot or the overflow lot (lots are located near Coal Bank Pass, I believe). We were told by the parking lot attendant that you need to arrive by 8 or 9 am to get a parking spot. So we went up the road a bit until we saw a trail going up the mountainside. That turned out to be Coal Creek Trail. We parked at an overlook pull off and headed up the trail. You can't see the trailhead sign from the road -- just look for a trail as you are driving and pull off when you see it.

The hike up from the Coal Bank Pass trail parking to Engineer Basin made for a great outing with friends visiting from out of state. The wildflowers weren't in peak bloom but there were plenty to take in. The trail is relatively easy though steep at times, with an overall elevation change of about 1,200 feet. The views of the San Juans did not disappoint.

Wow, is all that can describe the Santa Monica NRA. The NRA is where the Santa Monica Mountains meet the Pacific Ocean with the Channel Islands and Malibu as its backdrop. We travel the country visiting and hiking America's Greatest NF, NRA, NP and NM's, so we are inclined to be excited when we get to stamp another page in our National Parks Service Passport Book. That said the Santa Monica Mountains NRA was a double whammy, because you are minutes from the Heart of LA yet you feel a hundreds of miles away. The Park has much to see and like its cousin, the Smokey Mountain NP in the east, the SMNRA is unique in that it is dotted with private property and homes. Not a problem though as this "array" of structures and facilities mostly adds to the stunning scenary. We really enjoyed the Semler Winery located right in the heart of the NRA on Molluhand Parkway. Open daily, we enjoyed a wine flight while sitting back and soaking in the stunning hils of vineyards. Hiking trails dot the area and every road is a scenic one. I suggest you start at the SMNRA visitors center accross the 101 in Thousand Oaks to orient yourself with the Park. The Visitors Center is located in the old City of Thousand Oaks City Hall, built in the Sixties, the City Hall in itself is a attraction. With so many stops to refer to, may I suggest Paramount Ranch. Bought by Paramount during the golden era of hollywood, this ranch was the backdrop for many classic pictures and the western town which remains was even the hometown for Dr. Quinn Medicin Woman. Nothing I can right here can fully describe the Santa Monican National Recreation Area, but rest assured if you are in search of something different in LA or just need a sense of peace this is where its at.
park: Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area

text: This was a pleasant surprise. We didn't expect anything so well organized and interesting. We started out watching the movie which gave a good overview. Then looked at the exhibits. The exhibit showing the movement of the British and American lines during various days was very interesting. We bought the CD (about $7) at the visitor's center that explained the battle and the 10 marked spots. A handout is also given that describes the various parts of the battlefield. Each spot had a nice parking lot and various markers telling about the action in that area. Almost all the stopping points had paved trails that you could walk on to see more of the view. And it is some view, especially overlooking the Hudson River. We especially like the second stop which was called the Neilson Farm. This tiny house was General Benedict Arnold's headquarters in September 1777. The guide at this stop, Diane, was just so much fun to talk to. She told us some information about the battle and the generals involved that had recently come "to light." The driving route is about 10 miles and takes you back to the visitors' center where you can use the bathroom and purchase books, toys, souvies at the very nice gift shop. Allow 2-3 hours for this visit if you are going to do the drive. There are also nice trails for hiking. So glad that we stopped. There is no admission charge, but there is a box by the door for donations. We had no trouble contributing as this place is a national treasure. The park is not well parked out from the small roads leading to it. That is the only "downer" I can give in this review.

Walked the Wilkinson Trail which was very well maintained - I think some areas could be soggy if it had rained recently - but I went when it was dry. Lots of birds and wildlife. Park fee was $5 and there is a small gift shop/information center with very knowledgable staff to make your visit worth it.

Begins in the Visitor's Center with a 20 minute film, highly recommended, and a room with an electronic map and some relics. Then pay $5 per car at the Visitor's Center for a self-drive around the battlefield using a brochure indicating the 10 stopping points. (Additional options available.) Great for bicycling or hiking. Would be absolutely beautiful during the fall. Not much to really "see".... some monuments, a few cannons, a house, fields, mountains, Hudson River, and lots of Poison Ivy. You need to use your imagination, and it really is amazing to think about. Great for history buffs. You can spend a couple hours or all day, it's up to you.
We get the $10 annual pass and walk here several times a month, whether on the tour road or the Wilkinson trail.

We enjoy history and my boys (11 and 13) enjoy battles so we arranged a private tour with Larry Arnold. It was $80 for 2 hours (although he really gave us over 3!) with him riding in our car and explaining the two battles that occurred. Without him it would have been very confusing. Mr Arnold, who is a former park ranger, did an excellent job explaining the battle tactics (without too much detail), the reasons, and the results while keeping all of us engaged. It was COMPLETELY worth the time and the money. (The Saratoga National Battlefield site has information for booking the tour.)

Not as much remains as at Civil War sites - but well worth it. Costumed volunteers were at several of the stops. Also many hiking trails. Learned about the actions of Benedict Arnold - who would have been considered one of our greatest heroes for his actions here - if he had died in the battle, before later turning traitor. Easy to drive through.

This is a great historic site for many reasons and one is that it is accessible to all. We opted to tour the visitor's center which had both great exhibits, knowledgeable rangers, and a very good (and short) movie. Then we took the 4 1/2 mile hike through the battlefield. The hike takes you through both fields and forest and has lots of historic signs marking what happen where. The trail is also marked very well. We also noticed shorter trails to the markers if you didn't want to do the full hike. After we hiked the grounds, we visited the small gift shop at the visitor's center which had lots of interesting items...don't miss the local food items (shrubs) and candles. They also have bottle water for sale if you go hiking. The last thing we did was drive the paved road through the battlefield, stopping at several of the sites...the rebuilt home also has a guide there who shared lots of great information and was able to answer all our questions. This site cost us a mere $5 per car and it was a great bargain for what we got in return.

The place is huge we were not aware their were 10 miles of driving through the national park. You pay $5.00 as an entrance fee, the ranger provides you with a map and information of all the different spots. We were only able view the 20 minute film they provide which by the way is very good, and walk the grounds behind the building.

Nice visitor center, knowledgeable rangers. we viewed the 15 minute movie to get a refresher on the events of this battle and all that took place here. We got our $5 car pass and went through all of the sites. Each site you can dial a cell # and it will give you a narrative of what happened there. Well laid out tour and beautifully kept battlefields. We loved that you parked your car at each site and got out to walk and see the points of interest. Recommend this for history buffs and for families, a poignant part of our history lies here!

While in the area, we went out to the battlefield. It is a bit of a drive from Saratoga Springs. I didn't know much about what has been come to be called THE pivotal battle in the American Revolution. The 10 mile park loop wasn't all that interesting as it is mostly just hills and fields. But the visitor center had an optical table that showed you the movement of the troops during the battle. And there was a movie that was informative. I could have spent longer there, but the kids were not so interested. It's $5 per car if you want to drive the loop, otherwise free. They have a cell phone tour of the loop if you are interested. We did not do it, but would have liked to if the kids were not there.

This was really amazing. This park is for everyone. You can walk, bike, hike, snowshoe, cross-country ski, ride horseback or drive through this National Park. $3 on foot or $5 per car. Ticket is good for 7 days. Seasonal passes are available. There is a Visitor Center with a gift shop at the west entrance where you can buy the tickets. We drove through the park and got out at each stop, ten in all. There is the reconstructed Neilson Cabin on the southern Patriot encampment. There is also the British encampment on the northern side. The walls of each redoubt on each side are marked by red or blue topped post. They have period canons. There is the famous Boot Monument where Benedict Arnold was shot in the leg. Also Barber's wheat field.

The revolutionary war battle in Saratoga in 1777 is considered among the most significant battles in world history. If you are in the area, this site is educational as well as being inexpensive entertainment ($5 per car when we visited).

This is a nice national park to visit to learn more about the Battles of Saratoga that took place in September and October of 1777. The park is run by the National Park Service.. The Visitors Center is free and has a wonderful exhibit and film. We went on the car tour which cost $5.00 per person. If you have the Golden Age pass it is free. There are a number of stops on the tour with explanations of the battle sites, including the home of the people who lived there at time. A re enactor was on site dressed in colonial clothes to answer our questions. We sort of rushed through it because we had to make a schedule but if I were to go again, I would be more leisurely. It is a good way to learn more about how our country was formed including the heroics of Benedict Arnold that most of us only think of as a traitor. You can also hike throughout the park.

If you get the chance a Trip to Sequoia National Park, take it there is a peace in the mountains you don’t get anywhere else. If youare in Visalia the Sequoia Shuttle runs from there for a low Price that gives you a roundtrip ride to the park and includes the entrance Fee. Once in the park there is a Free shuttle Service to the different areas. To stand and look up at one of the Giant Seguoia Trees is a very humbly act. You will never forget this trip. I suggest you go soon the cost into the Park may increase in the near future. Enjoy it!!!!

Sequoia and Kings are a great set of nearly identical national parks. Sequoia is certainly the more busy of both parks due to sites like Tunnel Log, General Sherman Tree and Moro Rock. Kings is much more quiet and in my opinion, more scenic. The entrance fee at either park, which includes both parks for $30 per car (all passengers included). If you have an annual or lifetime NPS pass, the entrance fee is waived for all passengers in a car. The Generals Highway is a very curvy, two line road which is extremely crowded on the Sequoia side in the summer time, especially a holiday weekend. The King's side is much more smooth and flowing. Best bet is to arrive early and enjoy the entire day there.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: The park is a little run down, and the speeders whom just want to fly through; the sheriff, or park rangers could of made some real money, so they don't have to charge that $30.00 just to come in. Park was really disappointing in the fact that a lot of the trees have died off, and not many places to look, at without all the construction. I realize there has to be upkeep, but the roads are not even a scratch on Yosemite. The sole reason for the travel to the park, was to see the mighty Sequoia trees, but nature has its dealings with the beetles and fires according to the visiting center on the way out. Wouldn't do it again. Think the General Sherman tree was a disappointment, only because people just crawl all over it and its taken a beating. It seemed like the two parks as other have mentioned are two major differences. But that is why you visit them.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: Made a special trip just to see these trees. At first we were disappointed because we were expecting huge trees at the beginning of the park, but you are actually starting along route 198 from Three Rivers entrance and saw amazing views of the mountains and small trees. There is a $30 entrance fee for all cars, but if you're a U.S. citizen and a senior you can get in for $10 (and get a National Park pass for free entry into other National Parks, too).
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: We visited in June and because it had snowed a little the night before the ranger told us that we needed to go back into town and rent $36 chains. By the time we waited in line again to get in, the roads were barely wet, no snow or ice. Ridiculous.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: Sequoia National Park is beautiful! The largest tree in the world by volume, General Sherman is there. We stayed in Visalia and took the shuttle bus ($7.50, need reservations) into the park. No need to spend time a fuel looking for a parking space. Then there are
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: This place was amazing! I am not a fan of snow or hiking but so glad we went. If you are going in the winter months save yourself the trouble and rent the snow chains before you get to the gate. Otherwise, you are sent back down with a list of places that rents them- I think it was $30 for 24 hours. Lots of places to pull over for photo shoots and no snow until you got further up the mountain.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: A wonderful weekend in Sequoia Nat Park and King's Canyon. One of the fine uses of all those tax dollars. Make sure your car is in tip-top shape and filled with gas...no stations. The roads are long, steep, and curvy. The scenery is fabulous but the key sights are not to be missed. The General Sherman Tree area is breath taking. Crystal Cave is worth the visit for its 1.5 million year historical formation. Both are tiring trecks from the parking areas, but just walk slowly. There is a tram area available for Sherman but not for the cave. The cave is always about 50 degrees but a coat is not really needed. Apply for a lifetime US Parks card for free entry ($10 if 62+) or pay $30 per car load. $16/adult to see the cave. $8 kids. There are picnic areas so it is good to pack some eats. Plan on a weekend stay, it is a lot to do in one day.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: $30 entry fee, good for a week. Stopped at Foothills Visitor a Center- small but adequate. Knowledgable staff, good exhibits. Park was very crowded, and some people just can't and probably shouldn't drive the tight and winding roads- be advised and stay on the lookout around every curve! Patrons also have a hard time understanding barriers/fences and can't seem to stay on the designated paths/trails. Nor can they find trash cans...so frustrating to see what is happening to our NPs....nonetheless, the scenery is beautiful, the climate very favorable in August! Be prepared to wait in line to take photos in front of the General Sherman tree, stop at the Giant Forest Museum and Beetle Rock. Sadly, the forest fires and smog keep you from being able to see out very far. We would have liked to have hiked a few trails but the crowds and limited parking made it difficult to plan and maneuver. We went out the Big Stump exit at Kings Canyon without seeing the General Grant tree.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: I recently visited the Sequoia National Park on a business trip. This place is so vast and massive that you could spend days here! We wanted to see the General Sherman Tree - the tallest tree in the world. We were staying outside of Visalia, CA. I would recommend staying there for hotels/restaurants as it's the biggest city near the park and has other things to do. It's about a 45 minute drive to the park from Visalia. If you buy a parking pass it's $30 for a vehicle, otherwise, it's $15 per person. Once into the park it took another 45 minutes or so to make it to the General Sherman Tree trail. It was quite a site to see. Along the way it's very winding roads, so if you are one faint of the heart or tend to get car sick, I definitely recommend some dramamine prior. Since it's 7,000 above altitude, it dropped in temp about 20 degrees to a very comfortable 74. There are great look out points along the way and lots of trails once you arrive. I would plan on at least 4 to 4.5 hours if you are planning to visit for a half day.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: We stayed in Visalia and made the drive up to Sequoia from there, we took the Fresno route to Kings Canyon. The road to Sequoia is a long windy road and you might want to make sure you have plenty of gas, because the hills and the curves can drink it up pretty fast. If you are Seniors invest in the National Park Senior admission card, $10, good for life for the purchaser with ID and at all parks and for everyone in the car. There are several pull overs so other cars can pass you or you can get out and check out the view. We loved the FREE shuttle buses that took you from one area of the park to others in Sequoia. Some of those roads are barely a lane and a half wide so it makes for some interesting maneuvering when you meet an oncoming car and was even hard for the shuttle drivers. We are not hikers, we are walkers and there are nice paths to get around on. The climb to Moro rock is worth all the heavy breathing, red face, and effort. That rock is so prominent on your drive up to the park, we were thrilled to climb it to the top. We did the easy way, climbed until we were tired, took a rest, let people pass us, and then continued on. Stunning views as you climb up and once you are on top - WOW!. For the hikers, there may be a trail that leads to the top by other than the stairs as two hikers arrived at the top on a very different edge of the rock than the stairs led to. The Sequoias are the stars, hard to imagine trees that are so old, so big, have withstood innumerable forest fires, and are there for us to see in all their glory. Talk about feeling insignificant standing by one of these giants. Try to catch one of the ranger talks, the one we heard was a show and tell about the Sequoia pine cones, what it takes for them open and the seed generation process. To get to Kings Canyon you drive through the Sequoia National Forest. We tried to see most of the suggested things for Kings Canyon including Raging River and Grizzly Falls which we almost missed. We had to turn around and go back but it worth it. The Zumwalt meadow is a nice little walk across a river, but it was rather buggy but were were there toward the end of the day and Muir Rock at Roads End was inspiring considering all Muir has done for the parks. There is a lot of driving in these two parks but worth it to see such such great examples of nature at its best - mostly undisturbed and its original state. There is a lot to see and do. I have covered our high points. From hairpin turns, to vistas that reveal several mountain tops, to the incredible rock formations and and the giant trees - it is awe inspiring and memory making!
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: About an hour from Fresno but well worth it to see these monster trees. Pictures do not describe the beauty and size. 30 dollars per car to get in but totally worth it.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: We spent the bigger part of one day in Sequoia National Park primarily driving the Giant's Highway. The trees are amazing, incredible, awesome and unbelievable. So was the traffic on Memorial Day weekend. You can leave your car at the main parking lot and then ride their various shuttles down different routes, or you can drive it yourself. Heads up - it is a long, curvy slow drive on the entrance nearest to Three Rivers. You feel like you will never get there, but it is worth it! Cost was $30 for our car to enter and that covers you for up to 7 days.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: Though I had seen the giants at Yosemite, this was my first trip this park. I did make the mistake of going to the Sequoia National Monument first. Do not make this mistake. That place is good for camping and other activities as well a hiking trails. However there are no giants to be seen. The park has a $30 entry fee - which is steep for what you get. The views of the giants are amazing. They are all accessible easily with a short hike. Fitting these trees into a single photo frame when you are standing close is almost impossible. Best to take pictures from some of the vista points. Due to the driving and access a full day should be planned for a visit.
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: Feeling so small among the giant trees was a surreal and spiritual experience. Hiking in the Giant Forest is my favorite national park experience and was a bucket list item. Photos don't do justice to the majesty of this place. Would love to come back multiple times!!
park: Sequoia and Kings Canyon National Parks

text: The south unit is easily accessible from the interstate. It is only a little over a mile from exit 32. Park entrance fee is $25 per car, and is good for 7 days. The park is open 24 hours a day throughout the year. You will need at least a half day to see the park via the scenic loop drive of 30+ miles.

I went in mid July. The campground Cottonwood was full each night I was there. I did come early in the morning and got the last of two spots . I was surprised how busy it was. The drive through the park is great. You see prairie dogs and hundreds of them. You see some bison but not as many as expected. I only saw two. You see about 7 wild horses. Beautiful place. It costs $20 to get into the park but the pass lasts for 6 days and for both North and South units. Camping is $14 per night. I did not do a reservation but would again. I saw a campground near the south unit that is a state park and saw that is was nearly empty. Probably would stay there instead of the busy cottonwood campground. There is a nice visitor center where you can see and walk in Teddy's cabin. You can view a film and the rangers give talks. Lots of trails in the park that you can hike.

This is a beautiful park. There is camping and hiking, but the easiest thing to do is probably the ~ two hour loop in your car. It is 20$ per car, which we paid at the visitor's center at the entrance. We saw amazing badlands, some prairie dog towns, as well as horse and bison on the way. There's no down side to this one....

It's hard to believe it only costs $10 per carload to view the spectacular 36 mile scenic loop. Make sure to take your time - it took us about 3 hours to complete this journey. There's several places to pull over and view the gorgeous colors and topography of the rolling hills. Animals abound here - although we only saw two single buffalo, there's hundreds in the park. Wild horses were everywhere, as were prairie dogs. As is common with animals, timing is everything. If we would have had more time we would have done the loop again. Be sure to visit this gorgeous piece of Americana - you will be glad you did.

We had been told that the Grand Tetons were beautiful, but our drive through was breathtaking, with the snow covered mountains, buffalo walking down the street, unbelievable trees with glistening water here and there. I would love to bring my dad someday, as this is one area of WY that he has not visited. We were fortunate to come off season, so no crowds. Many opportunities to pull over to take photos and just gaze at the gorgeous scenery. The fact that we had purchased a lifetime Sr. Pass made it all the better!

I highly recommend this place to anyone who loves nature, in here you will enjoy it to the fullest, we ride the shuttle boat at Jenny Lake and went to Inspiration point and hidden falls Beautiful!! The lake is huge and clear water, residents are very kind people and make you feel welcome every time. If you are in the Yellowstone area buy the two park ticket for $50 and it will save you $10 to entry Teton Park. Drive around go to the highest point and have the camera ready to take many pictures!

This was our second time visiting and our first time going completely through the Teton forest. So glad we decided to spend the extra time because in my opinion, the Tetons are more beautiful than Yellowstone any day. We loved our time spent riding down every backroad and seeing so many grand sites along the way. We bought the tickets going in to Yellowstone also ,so we paid $50 for both for a 7 day pass to enter and leave. There's no postcard to really catch the breathtaking beauty of the Tetons.

It's just incredible and breathtaking at any time of the year! The grandeur of the rugged peaks, the setting of the open meadows teeming with elk in winter or sightings of Big Horn Sheep, moose, antelope,and bear in Spring and summer. The Snake River winds through the valley and hiking and biking trails are everywhere. It's a place you must see for yourself and a place you won't want to leave. The drives through Togwatee Pass and Moran Junction are simply stunning, as well as the drive north into the south gate of Yellowstone. Put this at the top of your bucket list and book your hotel or resort stay in advance for better pricing and availability. It's a very popular summer Mecca because of the beautiful flowers, green hills, cool dry air and tons of things to do.

Yes the tetons are majestic and powerful...BUT I was being charged to travel through my own county! TWICE! I refused to pay another $30 on top of the $30 I had payed to get through the first time. I was only passing through to get to a music festival on the Idaho side. On the way back to Cody...They told me to pay another $30 or turn back and go to the west gate entrance. What!? They had a white car with federal government plates watching me as I turned around. They thought I was going to run through without paying. Uh Muh Gosh...Trust me, I wanted to. It was only 3 days since I bought the first entrance pass. Usually good for 7 days. Now Grand Teton National Forest is not accepting Yellowstone National Park passes. Use to be one pass for all.....B.S. I can't even traverse through my own back yard freely!

It cost me $50 for both parks. We did go to a few attractions, but only really enjoyed one. The hike to the hidden falls by Jenny Lake, but wasn't worth the extra $20. I do live in Utah so I'm not impressed by trees. Seen no large wildlife.

Put this on your bucket list!! This is an absolute must see. I have traveled extensively and have seen many beautiful places before but this place is absolutely glorious!!! I can't remember ever seeing a more beautiful landscape with so many outdoor activities, or animals. If you're on a budget camp, bring your own food, and drink instant coffee if you have to (we did), just get here. There are so many trails for biking, hiking or walking on that you could stay here for weeks and not hit every trail. This place is amazing. Bring pepper spray and a camera because there is so much wildlife, including bears, you're not going to want to miss that perfect picture. There are campgrounds in abundance so no need to worry about a place to sleep, we slept in the van at a campground off the beaten path. I think it's $30 entrance fee for the park unless you're 100%disabled then you get a free national park pass if you bring proof of your disability.
Nothing to dislike. Had $$$ to spend and they provide the absolute best there is to offer. Eddie is the best guide I've ever encountered! Great place!!!!

First of all, the $5 a person is so not worth it. I think they would be better suited to go on donations. The fort itself (a rebuild) is small with a few rooms. There were supposed to be actors telling you about life in the fort. What we found were a group of teenagers hiding in the kitchen bashing their manager and gossiping. When someone walked in, they would stop and just stare at you until you felt uncomfortable and left. A grandfather was going through telling his granddaughter all about the fort instead of the employees. The demonstrations were spaced far apart, so far that you wouldn't want to wait around for one. However, the grounds are beautiful and it is interesting to think that you are walking in the footsteps of Lewis and Clark and their company. The trails were easy and short, perfect for stretching your legs after a day of driving. The fort, well, it left much to be desired.
park: The Lewis And Clark National And State Historical Parks

text: We visited the Lewis and Clark National and State Historical Parks on the 100th anniversary of the National Park Service in August 2016. At Fort Clatsop, they had special events throughout the day. Admission was also free.
park: The Lewis And Clark National And State Historical Parks

text: We have been Lewis & Clark groupies for a long time now, visiting the museum at the Arch at St. Lewis and incorporating their route west as we travel each summer. This year was our chance to see the "end" of their journey; the mouth of the Columbia River, the Pacific Ocean, Cape Disappointment and Fort Clatsop. We spent most of the day soaking up the atmosphere of what is there today and imagining what it must have been like for Lewis and Clark. There is a short movie in the museum and a engaging display of numerous Lewis & Clark items. They truly were the "Corps of Discovery"! You need to buy a parking pass to park on the Washington side at the Interpretive center, 10.00 and the entry fee is 5.00 per person. On the Oregon side, no parking pass required and they accepted our National Park Pass to enter. We felt the parking pass was excessive due to the fact we were there only to do the center, not camping, fishing or hiking. I would recommend the Parks to everyone.
park: The Lewis And Clark National And State Historical Parks

text: Well worth the stop, good museum and very interesting to see restoration of Ft Clatsop. Now that I am back home, I am reading a book about the entire trip. The book is made very real after this visit. We used our Senior Pass to by-pass the entry fee, love that pass.
park: The Lewis And Clark National And State Historical Parks

text: Went to the National Historic Park at Fort Clatsop. The museum displays were interesting, and the recreated fort 100 feet from the building even more so. Lewis and Clark and their Corps of Discovery stayed there in early 1806. We walked the 200 feet to the canoe landing area, and there was a trail that continued on and looked inviting. This location had a particularly good gift shop, too, with quite a few recreations of the equipment Lewis and Clark used. The entry fees were very reasonable, since kids were free and adults were $3 each. Very pleasant wooded location and we were glad we stopped there.
park: The Lewis And Clark National And State Historical Parks

text: First, the $3 admission fee was well worth it. There is a museum to walk through telling a bit about the journey that Lewis and Clark made. With your paid admission, you also get a brochure full of interesting information and pictures. You then walk to a reproduction of the fort the crew wintered in. Period dressed docents were very educated and seemed to enjoy sharing. The park ranger we spent time talking with on the trail was fun to talk to and felt like a cool new friend. Most of the trails were paved or board paths. There was no food on the site, but there were picnic tables available.
park: The Lewis And Clark National And State Historical Parks

text: I've explored Astoria a couple of times, but decided this time to cross the bridge into Washington for a drive. I happened upon the Cape Disappointment loop, and loved the access to beautiful hikes and the very informative Interpretive Center. A great way to spend a day, or a few hours. Note: in May 2016 it cost $10 for a day parking pass and $5 to tour the Interpretive Center -- well worth it, in my book.
park: The Lewis And Clark National And State Historical Parks

text: Enjoyed a visit to "Fort Clatsop", JAN 2017, the winter encampment for the Lewis & Clark Corps of Discovery from December 1805 to March 1806. The log "Fort Clatsop", nestled in the woods, is a replica, similar to an original structure used by the Corps of Discovery. Very nice informative visitor center/museum & gift store. NPS Staff is helpful. Movies are shown. I used a National Park Senior Pass for entrance to the Park. Interesting History!!!
park: The Lewis And Clark National And State Historical Parks

text: From an indoor water tide pool to an tall outlook over the Channel Islands, Ventura Harbor and beaches, this is a great place to visit. There are two movies that are helicopter views of the islands along with narration by Kevin Costner (who I heard is from Ventura). Outside there is a nature area with plants from the islands identified by placards - even poison oak.
park: The Robert J. Lagomarsino Visitor Center at Channel Islands National Park

text: After exploring the cowboy town of Medora we visited this National Park (South) with it's fantastic scenery, wildlife & photo stops along the paved 36 mile park loop. The pace was easy - fellow visitors were friendly and mostly patient with many stops/pull-offs to view the amazing sights. Took about 2 hours to do the loop but really could spend the entire day or more if exploring all opportunities. We again enjoyed our National Parks Pass for entrance fee. Remember to make a stop at the visitor center/gift shop - lots of neat stuff. Highly recommend this NP stop.

If you want to see the park, it's best to get up at sunrise or go just before sunset. During the hottest part of the day, animals are laying down away from the roadway. The park is open 24-7, though no one is there to take payment all the time. Be sure to view the visitor center and watch the film. We did the ranger tour of the Maltest Cross Cabin and found it very interesting. We saw herds of buffalo, who pay no attention to cars. They were laying in the roadway and nursing calves while we waited. We also saw herds of wild horses, prairie dogs and a few hawks.

We spent two days exploring TRNP - one day seeing the South Unit plus the Painted Canyon area and the second day in the North Unit. We spent the night after the first day in Medora at Badlands Motel and the night after the second day in Watford City at the Roosevelt Inn. We saw more wildlife in the South Unit (wild horses, bison, prairie dogs and mule deer). In the North Unit, we only saw one lone male bison, but we enjoyed the solitude of the North Unit. The Painted Canyon area was the most crowded of the three areas, since it is right off the interstate and it is free. For the other areas, the cost is $25 for a 7 day pass, which is good for both North and South Units. Compared to other large National Parks we have been to (Glacier, Yellowstone, Smoky Mountain, Grand Canyon, the Utah parks), we found TRNP even at the height of summer season to be refreshingly uncrowded. In the South Unit, late in the afternoon, we cautiously followed a male bison walking on the yellow line about a mile on the Scenic Loop Drive and not one car came from the other way the entire time and only two cars came up from behind us. In Yellowstone, this would have caused a huge bison jam with 30 cars in each direction, tourists running from their cars with cameras and three park rangers trying to keep them safe. Other than in the Visitor Centers, we saw no park rangers while in the park. Take some snacks and lots of water, even if you are just driving around and don't plan to be hiking, as there are few facilities beyond the visitor centers. You can fill up water at the campgrounds and we found one pit toilet on the Scenic Loop Drive in the South Unit. The Visitor Center at Painted Canyon has a small store and a few displays, bathrooms, and water. The Visitor Center at the South Unit has a film (we recommend), several exhibits, Roosevelt's Maltese Cross cabin, and a gift shop along with restrooms and water. The North Unit Visitor Center is just a trailer - good to stop and ask any questions, get your NP passport stamped or get a map, but not much else other than porta potties. It was very hot and very dry the two days we visited in late July; luckily, there was an almost constant breeze. We were a family of four with a 10 and 13 year old, so we mostly did the overlooks and the drives with a few walks. Unfortunately, there aren't many short hikes in either unit. We did the Painted Canyon Trail, which starts near the picnic pavilions at the opposite end of the parking lot from the Painted Canyon Visitor Center. This is a well marked loop that is 0.9 miles if you stay on the main trail, but you can make it longer by taking some of the side paths (we were on it for a little over an hour, because we did take several side paths). You start at the top of a cliff and work your way down to the canyon floor - so this is steep at the end and the beginning, but fairly flat in between, unless you choose to clamber up one of the rocky areas once down to the floor. Take water and wear a hat and sunscreen, as it can be dusty and there isn't much shade. In the South Unit, we drove the 36 mile Scenic Loop drive with several stops for wildlife and overlooks and we also took a few short walks and this took us 4 hours. The short trail to the old East Entrance Station is very flat and goes through a prairie dog town. Buck Hill is not really a trail, but a very steep walkway with several stairs to a great overlook (you are seeing the other side of the Painted Canyon from the Painted Canyon Visitors Center). The Biocourt Trial is also very short; takes you out to a point where you are looking down into a canyon. Wind Canyon is a quick loop that takes you to a point to see a bend in the Little Missouri River. In the North Unit, we drove the Scenic Drive (14 miles out and 14 miles back) mid-day and spent about 4 hours. We walked the Caprock Coulee Nature Trail (1.6 miles out and back) - there are brochures at the trail head that tell you about the things you see on the hike. Some of this trail was shaded, but most is not, so take water with you. We also did the Little Mo Nature Trail, but found this one not very interesting and can't really recommend it. We did enjoy going down to the river near the entrance to the Juniper campground (the beginning of the South Achenbach Trail) and wading in the river/mud (it is really muddy, so plan footware accordingly) and looking at all the animal tracks. There is a nice picnic area with restrooms (but no water spigot that we could find) near the Juniper campground, too. In the North Unit, you are mostly on the floor of the badlands, looking up at the formations. In the South Unit, you are on top of the badlands, looking down -- so there is a difference in the two units from that perspective.

How can you rate a National Park any less? I have yet to be disappointed at a National Park because they are all so unique, different and offer a vast amount of beautiful sceneries. Theodore Roosevelt Nat. Park felt quite frankly, in the middle of nowhere and that is what made it fun and beautiful. Bison roamed all throughout the park and we were right up close and personal with them. We drove around the park for hours and stopped frequently to view wildlife and to look at the views. We entered from Medora and spent about 3 hours in the park, not including any long stops or hikes. I always find excitement in seeing a new Nat. Park so I loved it. I don't know that I'll ever be back again, but I'm glad that I was able to visit. I believe admission to the park is $30? I can't quite remember but I remember it was one of the more expensive ones that I've been to. Take your camera, pack a lunch and enjoy the sights even if you're just passing through!!!

My advice is to see the Southern Unit to see about 450 bison. We think we saw upwards of 600. Herds are everywhere and will block many of the roadways. We went late to see more animals and I mean 7:00-7:30 pm. We saw the most animals during the evening when it's cooler. We saw deer, prong horn, feral horses, prairie dogs, and a badger. Ancillary to the wildlife is the excellent painted desert and beautiful mountains of green. $25 per car entrance fee. Visitor's Center opens at 8 a.m.

We camped right across from the Medora Musical location. It was a very nice campground with hot and cold showers and restroom that were very clean. Affordable ($25) per night for a tent site and even though it was 104 degrees, we had a shady campsite which helped keep it cooler. There are lots of things to do in the nearby Medora town. Very quaint town and a very quiet campground.

The park pass is a bit expensive ($25) but it is unlimited ins and outs for 7 days, both the northern and the southern units, and for as many people as you have in your vehicle. The drive around the southern unit took us 2 or 3 hours (I didn't look at my watch when we started), because you drive slowly and you stop often. It is common for wild horses or buffalo to wander into the road, and you have to stop and wait for them to pass. Don't be in a hurry....it should be a leisure event. Beautiful terrain, beautiful animals, MUST SEE.
Well kept, fairly expensive at $25, but amazing landscapes to look at with lots of wildlife to see if you're lucky.

A portion of this park has been incorporated into a rest stop on I94 West. It is a very easy in and out stop that just must be done. It gives an overlook of the painted canyons in North Dakota's Bad Lands. Passing this by is just a mistake.

Was in Bismarck for a wedding, drove 2 hours west and enjoyed seeing the different scenery. We stopped by Painted Canyon visitor center on the way in for our first look and a 30 min hike then did the 36 mile scenic drive and saw tons of prairie dogs, wild horses, and bison. Lots of overlooks and paths (we didn't do any walking though). I thought it was worth the drive, but it's no Yosemite or anything. And be aware that the park charged $20 before we did the 36 mile loop.

First let me say that we were thrilled to enter for free! We were there on the anniversary weekend so we didn't have to pay the insane entry fee of fifteen dollars per motorcycle. The National Park fees have gotten out of hand and at fifteen dollars per person we probably would have skipped seeing this natural wonder and that would have been a shame. It was a very nice ride with lots to see. The visitors center is informative and has a lot of memorabilia as well. Much like the Badlands of South Dakota it has Prairie Dogs and Bison living on and roaming free on the land. It was well worth the price we paid. It takes about ninety minutes to see it if you make stops for photo ops along the 36 mile loop. There are numerous turnouts along the way.

It costs about $20 to get into the park per vehicle, but considering how this amount helps pay for the maintenance of this beautiful park, fork it over. Unless you're planning to hike in one of the many trails, take your time driving around the park. It only takes about an hour to an hour and a half including stops at scenic spots and lookouts, so relax and enjoy the drive. The colorful rugged terrain is a sight to behold. Each lookout offers a slightly different view of the Badlands, one more colorful than the other, so be sure to stop and enjoy each lookout that offers beautiful panoramic views. I saw about 4 bisons nearby and a herd from a distance by the water's edge. Wild horses roam freely, and there were a ton of prairie dogs running around. All in all, the Park was well-worth a visit, good for a day's worth of activity.

We had a great visit here. We drove through the beautiful park and saw a lot of Prairie Dogs, bison and horses. We saw several bison at very close range. We had to stop our car a couple of times to let the bison and horses get across the road. There were several areas for small hikes that my granddaughter and her dad walked. The Badlands of North Dakota are beautiful and much different than the Badlands in South Dakota. We were so happy that we made the effort to see this beautiful park. I am so glad that Roosevelt thought ahead and helped to make this available to everyone. If you are a senior and you plan on visiting national parks and monuments obtaining a Park Pass for $10 is well worth it. Don't miss this Park if you are in the area.
Prices to go through the park are very reasonable - $20 per car and it is valid for 7 days just keep the receipt - $10 for senior citizens and free for military-

I always love driving threw the park. Mornings are my favorite time to go to see bison. It's the 100th anniversary for national parks. If you are travel with someone 62 or older they can get a life time pass for $10 for the car to use.

The scenery here is spectacular....the badlands and rock formations are amazing. We went through late in the afternoon....around 3. Started at the visitor center with a 27 minute historical perspective of the Park development. Then we went through the parks main loop....scenery was amazing and we saw lots of wildlife. Prairie dogs, wild horses and Buffalo...no antelope or deer this time. Entry is $20 a car....but if you have your National Park membership or senior pass...it is free! So glad we did this.

You have to pay $20 to enter the park. We stopped at the visitor center first and enjoyed watching a biography of TR. The museum was very informative and interesting (and free and cool). Don't forget to check out TR's cabin behind the visitor center. We only drove from the Medora entrance up to the Badlands overlook and back again. That was enough for our kids. Unfortunately, it was too hot to do any hiking, but we saw lots of wildlife. The North Dakota Badlands are very beautiful and colorful. They remind me of the Grand Canyon.
I drove up to Theodore Roosevelt National Park from Spearfish, SD last week. It was $20 to enter the park. The pass was good for 7 days.

It says it's $20 to enter per car but no one was at the gate. The park is open 24/7 and there are campsites available. Just driving through the park is gorgeous,me were there at sunset which made it even more dramatic. We saw buffalo and prairie dogs and countless birds.

We tent camped Site 51 for one night. Reserved and Prepaid. Best way. It was full when we arrived. Quite with convenient access to toilets. Easy check in and out with prepayment. Beautiful mountain scenery. 15 minutes drive from park entrance to campground.

We love the National Parks! I had an afternoon to kill in Dickinson so made the short drive to this beautiful place. So glad I did! The speed limit is slow so just relax and enjoy the drive. There may be wildlife on the road. There are cyclists, motorcycles, hikers. SLOW DOWN and enjoy the beautiful scenery. The 36 mile loop will take at least a couple hours. There are many pullouts. Get out of the car and enjoy the vistas and views. Walk down a trail or two, or three. Many, many hiking options. Have a picnic. Just sit quietly and watch the hundreds of prairie dogs do whatever it is they do. Listen to them "talk" to each other. See bison, beautiful wild horses and more. Pay attention and be aware of your surroundings and if you're lucky you might even see a rattlesnake or two. Take plenty of water. And one more important note, I recall only one restroom available on the drive. It's near the beginning at a campsite not too far beyond where you go over the freeway after leaving the entrance/visitor center. They were clean and well maintained. Also great picnic sites here in the trees.

What an amazing badlands experience! I guarantee you that you will see some wildlife. Visitors have the option of driving a loop through the park to see the scenery or staying over to camp/hike. Admission is $20/car for the week and camping is $17/night (toilets, sinks, and drinkable water but no showers). Be aware that ticks are common and rattlesnakes are a likelihood. Hike with a good map because trail markings can be poor, but your efforts will be rewarded.

The park is beautiful and quiet, even when there are a lot of tourists about. We enjoyed watching the prairie dogs barking at one another, and seeing the wild horses. They have a great video in the interpretive center that you should make time to see. The park is well-maintained and the staff is friendly. There are National Park Passport stamps here if you are into that like me. =)

Roosevelt National Park is fun to see, lots of wildlife. We saw Bison, Deer, Feral Horses, Prairie Dogs galore. We camped in the Southern Loop, which was very convenient. $14/night & woke up with Bison in our site! Great experience. Fun to see Roosevelt's Cabin behind the Visitor's Center.

The best thing about the park was the wildlife. Buffalo along side the road, wild horses, lots of deer, prairie dogs. We spent a night in the campground. There was no wood available at the campground so we had to buy it from the store for $5 for bundle of 9 small pieces. There were toilets and a cold water faucet at the campground, but no host, staff or any other amenities.

This was our first visit to the Medora area. It is beautiful. My college aged daughter and I decided do some hiking while our "boys" golfed at Bully Pulpit. The park entrance fee was $20.00 which was good for a week. The park rangers at the South Visit Visitor center were very helpful in helping us pick an adequate trail of about 5 miles round trip.

Right off I-95 -- although it costs $20 per carload, you shouldn't skip it. You can drive through in about 1.5 hours -- but there are plenty of lovely places to stop, hike and take in the views. Also, the little town of Medora is a great stop and is adorable!

This was an unexpected gem located right near the North Dakota/Montana border. From the free roaming animals to the beautiful badlands, this park has some great scenery. We were able to cover the entire scenic loop road in about 2-1/2 hours with plenty of stops throughout. We also got to see a ton of prairie dogs, wild horses and a Bison strolling down the road. Cost was $20 for a week pass and the park was very empty during our visit. Highly recommended if your traveling near or through the area. You can see some of the park from the interstate but and the includes the wonderful Painted canyon which is a must.

Visited this park because of its connection to presidential history. Knowledgeable guides and park staff were welcoming. The park's proximity to the town's business district makes it easy to walk in (and save the $20 admission fee for cars) if all you are interested in is TR's cabin. However, the drive is also beautiful and lucky travelers may even spot the buffalo herd of 200+ animals.

We drove to Medora which looks like the cutest little town but wasn't too active when we visited. I bet it's packed in the summertime! The backdrop to this cute city is the NP. Wow, what a setting. We went in and talked to some of the rangers who were so nice and knowledgeable and posed for pictures with my 9 month old, even let her wear a hat and inducted her into the JR ranger program. We did the scenic drive and it was a very rainy overcast cold day but we still saw LOTS of bison, prarie dogs, and wild horses. The views were beautiful and glad we went in May because I bet the roads are just packed in the summer. It felt like we had the place to ourselves. I would love to go back and visit again some day. It's just worth the $20 park entrance fee!

This was a beautiful place to see. There is an interpretive center contain memorabilia related to the park. If you have a National Park Passport cancelation book, you can have it stamped here. The center displays memorabilia on Roosevelt and explains how his experience in ND encouraged him to strive for the presidency. His Maltese Cross Cabin also sits behind the center.
