When we drove through the park, there were two bison along the side of the road and fields of adorable prairie dogs.

If you want to see some amazing wildlife, this is the place! WARNING: do not enter the park to do the driving tour without a FULL TANK of gas! I almost made this mistake the first time I visited, not realizing how many times we would stop to view/photograph the abundant wildlife this park contains while driving along the 36 mile loop around the parks 70,000+ acres. There are prairie dog towns that span acres, a large herd of free roaming bison, eagles, and don't forget the wild mustangs, just to name a few of the rare and beautiful animals that can be found here. Elk and antelope are also common, as well as big horn sheep. I have even had the fortune to see a beautiful mountain lion in this park. Charge up your camera and clear your memory cards. Bicycling this park with kids would be a delightful treat, and there are dozens of trails leading up to amazing lookout spots.

We toured the South unit of Theodore Roosevelt National Park and the scenery was stunning. Be sure and do all the short little hikes along the 32 mile loop through the park. There are great views from all of them. We were able to see buffalo, wild horses and prairie dogs. The people at the visitor center were very helpful and the short movie was worth taking the time to see. If you are going to be hiking, be sure and take plenty of water as there is no where to get any once you leave the visitor center. It's $10.00 per car to get into the park. If you are just taking the drive around the loop, you will probably only need a couple hours. We spent 4 hours here, but we took in all the little trails and spent some time at the end of each one. The town of Medora at the entrance to the park was a neat little town with shops, restaurants, trail rides and a great view from anywhere you chose to sit. It was fun to just meander through and talk to other tourists. The only negative was the unfriendly clerks at almost every store which was quite surprising for a tourist town. The Badlands in both South and North Dakota are awesome, but they are truly different. South Dakota has the craggy rocky peaks and North Dakota has more rolling hills with a lot of vegetation. Once again the beauty of God's creation was front and center as we drove and hiked our way through this park.

The park has beautiful scenery but a limited amount of wildlife. The park loop drive is a great way to spend a couple of hours. We enjoyed the campground. The spaces are mostly shaded and well separated. Water and restrooms are available. Showers and RV dump are not available. A dump can be found in town for $5.

The campground is beautiful and we enjoyed the three day weekend. There are no showers but flush toilets & potable water. We tent camped and while we were away from our site one afternoon, & upon our arrival another vehicle was parked on our site & put up their tent. Our pole was clearly marked & stated paid with the three nights & our one picnic table, tent & grill was all set up. We got the host to our site & then the intruders drove up-the host told them they had to leave. Upon putting their tent down-they cursed at us & told us "now we can invite our friends". The campground had empty sites yet they wanted to piggyback & get not pay $10 for a night.Same thing happened the next day. We were very sad that people are doing this in this national park. the host told us 20% of people do not pay their way!

We visited the south unit, the north unit and the painted canyon in our two-day visit to the area. The charge was $10 per car and I would have paid $100 to see the south unit. We saw beautiful scenery and so many animals I lost count. At one point we were about 6 feet away from a bison. Of course, we were in our car. There were numerous wild horses as well. What a national treasure and so much less crowded than Yellowstone.

This is one of those savor the moment kinds of trips. For a $10 per carload entry fee, you can spend literally the entire day exploring and viewing spectacular scenery and wildlife. The main drive is a 36 mile loop that should take a minimum of two hours if you just drive it. More if you enjoy some of the relatively easy hiking trails that gets you off the main road. Regardless of how much time you actually spend, you're going to see some wonderful sights. It's going to be relatively slow going because there's tons of cars taking their time so it's best not to be in a hurry. It's not crowded in the Yellowstone crowded and there are plenty of turn-outs so it's extremely pleasant. You'll see tons of prairie dogs, hopefully a lot of buffalo (although we only saw two!), wild horses, and hopefully other critters. Even if you don't see a ton of animals, the scenery is worth the drive. If you have time, do the drive twice, especially if you can do it later in the afternoon. Just make sure you visit it - it is DEFINITELY worth it!!!

This is the way National Parks used to be -- special places preserved for their national beauty, without any crowds, shuttles, or fast food restaurants. We visited the southern section of the park, which straddles I-94, and stayed in the Cottonwood campground where we had a very private campsite near the river (cost was only $5 with our national park pass). Next morning we drove the park's 36-mile loop, where we saw wild horses, buffalo, and surprisingly beautiful scenery. They call it "badlands", but this area is quite green and much more attractive than the Badlands we're familiar with in South Dakota. The park's visitor center is small but nice, and we were glad we stopped by.

The rock formations would inspire any sculpter to marvel at such forms with the beautiful coloring swirling throughout. Saw many bison & wild horses. Cottomwood Campground is quiet & scenic with Golden Age pass just cost $5. It is dry camping. Very glad we visited Roosevelt.
$10 bucks gets your car load in. 32 mile loop through some great scenery. You have a chance to see wild horses and buffalo. Great hiking spots, some as short as a 1/3 of a mile.

It was awesome! We camped out in a tent in the south campgrounds. We were right on the buffalo trail and heard them come by the tent in the middle of the night and then back in the a.m. The scenery is beautiful. The campgrounds well-maintained and monitored. No showers, but you can get a shower in town at the Amble Inn connected to the Book Store for $6 a person if they a room available!! Great experience!

I had never heard of Theodore Roosevelt before and was expecting it to resemble the rest of the Midwest: flat, rolling plains and, at times, blustery winds. While the winds were still blustery, the terrain was far from flat; it was broken and colorful, with strange rock formations jutting up and massive buttes arrayed in splashes of yellow, orange, and red. In short, it was exactly what you would picture the Wild West looking like. There is a small fee to enter the park ($10 per vehicle per week, plus other rates depending on how long you wanted to stay), but the 24-mile loop was easily driven and quite scenic. The ranger at the gate told us that the South Unit (in Medora, ND) had around 350 head of bison. Still, I didn't really expect to see any. We drove for about 30 minutes before we encountered any wildlife (not counting prairie dogs - they're everywhere), but the experience was unforgettable! Feral horse herds walked right up to the car, and pretty soon we were surrounded by herds of bison, so close you could reach out and touch them! It was fabulous! There were a number of hiking trails that wound through the park, as well, that afford a more intimate view of the scenery and wildlife. I'm not sure when the best time of day is to experience the park, but we went close to evening, around 7pm MDT.

This is a nice hike/walk, it takes roughly 2.5 hours if you go all the way to the end, including time for a break. Be aware that you need a parking pass and there is nowhere at the park to buy one. We purchased ours at Safeway in Fountain Hills ($6); I imagine there are other places you can purchase them. If you are hungry there is a nice little restaurant at Saguaro Lake, simply make a left when leaving the park and the Saguaro Lake exit is less than a mile down the road on the left. You do not need a pass to park in the parking lot near the restaurant; if you decide to drive along the Lake then you can use the same pass you used at Butcher Jones. The restaurant is simple but good.

We headed out to Apache Junction to visit the Goldfield Ghost Town, but saw on our map that it was on the main road which loops through the forest. So we decided to take a scenic drive. It was gorgeous! A narrow two lane road with lots of switchbacks, so it is a slow drive. All the better to enjoy the views - which were stunning. This is also the land of 1000's of saguaro cacti. We went in April and many wildflowers were in bloom, but I got the sense that even 1-2 weeks later into early May the desert would have been even more colorfully spectacular. We didn't go farther than Canyon Lake due to time restrictions. Canyon Lake was just a beauty. Feel free to park for a minutes and dip your toes in the water. The biggest disappointment was that the roads and pull offs were strewn with litter and trash. Visitors should be ashamed of themselves. The Park Service needs to get some volunteers (boy and girl scout troops come to mind since I lead a troop of 20 girls) and get this place cleaned up. I wish we would have had time even to make it up to Tortilla Flats which I heard was breathtaking.
Diamond Point lies within the Tonto National Forrest, about 30 minutes east of Payson, Az.

This place is amazingly well preserved and the views from the top are incredible. It is not to terribly hard to hike it. The path is very nice and there are plenty of places to stop and rest if you need too and most of them are in some shade. BRING WATER! The lower dweling is self guided and you can bring your dog with you on the trail they just cant go the last 40 feet into the dwelling. No problem if you can take turns with another person to hang on to your dogs leash or tie them to the rail... BRING WTER FOR YOUR DOG! At 9am and 60 degrees it was still really warm feeling with the bright sun. The views are incredible from the top of the trail. I belive it is about 700ft up there. The dwellings are very nicely preserved and there is a lot of information in the visitors center. There is a fee but if you have the America The Beautiful Pass it is good for this site.

We were on a road trip to Apache Indian Reservation and had decided a side trip to check out the cave dwellings in Tonto National Monument would be good before we drove to Camp Verde. We drove on 87 north towards Payson, turned right on State Highway 188 heading southeast and continued 39 miles to Tonto National Monument on the right.

I didn't intend to stop here, and in fact I didn't even know that it existed. But seeing the sign while driving from Globe up to Payson, Arizona, I decided to stop. I've never been to any cliff dwellings, and I know this is not as famous, extensive, nor as well preserved as some of the more famous ones, but I enjoyed it completely. I was there first thing in the morning, and in fact I was at the chain barrier across the path before the ranger (who was friendly and knowledgeable - thank you Sally), and I was very happy the day wasn't too hot. This would not be a great place to visit on a hot day, or a hot afternoon. I think it was in the low-80s when I was there, and that's about as warm as I would want it. Make sure you take A LOT of water and wear good shoes, although the path to the dwelling is paved. Because it faces east, I'd also suggest a morning visit for best views into the cliff/cave. I only went to the lower cliff dwelling, but I can't wait to go back another time and walk the 1.5 miles to the upper cliff dwellings. I truly enjoyed this place.

Great view of the surrounding area once you take the 10 minute hike to the top. As all the dwellings of the region, there is virtually no confirmed historical info on what happened to the people who originally occupied this location. Nice spot while driving the Apache Trail. I would recommend the stop. $5 a person for entry.

Don't bother comparing this place to national parks such as Mesa Verde. While much smaller in scale, the cliff dwelling ruins at Tonto provides into other historic people who sought to build these fascinating dwellings. One thing for sure, you are likely to find no crowds at Tonto and even may have the place to yourself. While I definitely appreciated learning about the Salado culture that lived here from around 1250 to 1450, I very much enjoyed the vigorous walk up to the lower ruin and gazing upon the beautiful views of the canyon, Roosevelt Lake, and numerous Saguaro cacti. The approximately 1 mile roundtrip walk to the lower cliff dwelling is on a paved trail that rises approximately 350 feet. There are several benches to sit and take a break on the way up. Folks of moderate excercise ability should be able to accomplish the trip up and back in about an hour. There are Rangers at the ruins who can answer your questions that you may have. The walk to the upper cliff dwelling ruin (which is about twice the size of the lower ruin) is about 3-4 hours roundtrip and is only conducted via ranger-led tours November to April (primarily on the weekends and you should reserve a spot on this trip). Entry cost to walk up to the ruins is $5 a person. Overall, I enjoyed the NM, even though the ruins (lower) are small; but the drive here from Phoenix is beautiful and the walk up to the lower ruins is nice and scenic.

Just east of Phoenix at Tonto National Monument are some of the best preserved cliff dwellings in the Southwest. As I've come to expect of the staff of our national parks and monuments, the eagerness to answer questions will only encourage you to visit other sites. Be sure to pull out your Passport and get it stamped. This site is a winner!

Nifty little sight to visit. 20-min paced path to the lower cliff dwellings. Great for kids. Got there in the nick of time before 4:00pm n a Satuday. Late afternoon is superior for picture taking because the sun shines down onto the Roosevelt Lake valley area. The age 20-something tourguide interpreter "Davis" at the top was very genuine, friendly, and eager to inform. What a pleasant find . . . and it was completely uncrowded. Nice tiny visitor's center. The fee for the pathway is just a few dollars, we'll worth it.

This monument is a great addition to your stop when driving the Apache Junction Trail. Not only will you learn something about the 14th century cliff dwellings here (one is open to visitors year-round and the other is by guided tour and only on the cool months) and their builders, the Salado people, but you’ll also have a fantastic view of the Theodore Roosevelt Lake with Saguaro cacti on the foreground. It’s a good idea to watch a short video about the monument. Although the trail to Lower Cliff Dwelling is paved, it’ll be a somewhat of a challenge for those people with disability. There’s an entrance fee to get in; “free” if you have the America the Beautiful Pass.

Half mile hike with 350ft elevation gain up to the lower ruins. Can walk in and around a majority of the lower ruins. The path to the ruins contains a variety of labeled cacti, which was sort of interesting. There is a ranger stationed there to answer questions and no doubt guard against vandalism. Upper ones are guide tour only, and only offered at certain times (not running the day I was there) – disappointing. Reasonably priced at $3/adult, this was a nice stop to stretch the legs, but was not a highlight of my trip to Arizona.

We couldn't wait to climb to the lower ruins. As others have said- you need reservations to climb with a ranger to the upper ruins. But the lower ruin climb is very challenging for us seniors! (We got in free using our National Park Senior Passes). The path is paved and there are rest areas. Once you get to the top the view is spectacular! You can walk around in the ruins and see the actual rooms the people inhabited centuries ago. A ranger was on site to answer questions. Take some water with you as they advise. There is a good informational video in the visitor's center. We also enjoyed our picnic lunch and then drove to the nearby Roosevelt Dam.
About a mile or two south of Roosevelt Lake, off Hwy 188, between Payson & Globe, AZ.

Operated by National Park Service. See at www.nps.gov . If you're taking the Apache Trail, this attraction is about 4 mile South on route 188. Overlooking Roosevelt Lake and about one mile off the highway, it's worth at least the drive to the parking lot to view the cliff dwellings even if you don't feel ready for the uphill hike.. Only one half mile, but gains 350 foot in elevation. Well paved trail and modern visitor center with facilities, only $3 admission. Two sets of ruins, the upper requires reservation for a ranger guided tour and only goes off twice a day. Visit in the morning for better view and photos as the site faces East. Set amongst the cactus and hills of the Tonto National Forest,

This is a must do when in Southern Arizona! I read a review and it stated we would not be disappointed and they were right! Totally worth the money! ($5 PP) This mission is well preserved and there is a little garden and some out buildings to look at too. You will be given a guide book to use and all attractions are numbered so it is very easy to follow. Bring a water bottle and they do have a refill spot on the grounds so that you can stay hydrated. So much history in Southern Arizona. This National Park is slightly south of the Tubac Arts District. Just follow the signs!

This national park is not too far from Tucson. The entire property is very well preserved, and well worth the $5 per person. The church is just a ruin these days, but if you close your eyes and use your imagination, you can recreate how this place was when people lived here. The gardens are very nice, as well as the orchard. Everything is well-explained and the museum has some good exhibits. A must see when visiting southern Arizona.

The tour guide was knowledgable and the history behind the missions/settlement was fascinating. Hard to believe some things survived for hundreds of years. It's great for history buffs and while there is walking, it's easy and benches to rest if needed. And for $5 the tour is a steal!!!

Interesting. Easy to take the self guided tour and read about the history at the various spots indicated on the map. Helpful park ranger - remember to by your Golden Eagle pass if oner 62 yrs old. Currently $10, soon to be $80!

This park protects a historic mission. It's not a large area and can easily be seen in a few hours. Open 9:00am-5:00pm daily. Admission is $5, but they also accept NPS access passes. At the entrance, you can get a brochure for a self-guided tour or register for a ranger-led tour or nature walk (45 minutes, time varies so check website or call ahead if interested). Wide paved walkways lead around the grounds to the mission church (early 1800s) and other support buildings from the settlement, plus the gardens and orchard. It is not a long distance to walk, maybe half-mile total, and there are benches for resting. On weekends there are cultural demonstrations such as tortilla making or basket weaving. There is a small museum and gift/book store in the visitor center. Avoid visiting in summer months if possible as it will be very hot. Note that pets are not allowed. If you want more of a hike, you can walk the historic Anza Trail along the Santa Cruz River between Tumacacori and Tubac Presidio about 3 miles to the north. Wheelchair access at Tumacacori is very good, but the Anza Trail is a dirt footpath.

Tumacacori is a not-to-be missed place to visit in Southern Arizona. The docents are extremely knowledgeable and make the history of this place come alive. Seniors over 62 who have the Senior Pass are free with two others in the party--the best deal available.
Hey got to love it. Arizona National Park day! Nice park. Clean. Set up nice! Plenty of information to immerse one self in! Friendly staff! Usual entry is $5.

The Mission San Cayetano de Tumacacori and the Mission Los Santos Angeles de Guevavi were originally established in 1691 by Father Kino in nearby locations in the Santa Cruz River valley making them the oldest Jesuit sites in Arizona. Approximately sixty years later and only after the 1751 Pima Native American rebellion against colonial forces was the Mission San Cayetano de Tumacacori rebuilt in the 1750’s in its current location and renamed San Jose de Tumacacori. The San Jose de Tumacacori Mission is well preserved and you are able to walk through many areas including the inside of the Mission, the cemetery, the orchard, the garden and other outlying ruins on a self guided tour. Well worth seeing for the nominal $5.00 per person admission price.

This is a national park so you seniors, over 62 should have you pass and get in easily. If not you can buy your senior lifetime pass to national parks for $10. Friendly staff willing to help out and give a loaner guide book. Small but informative book store greets you. Then you take a self guided, with your book, tour of the grounds. You really feel as though you are back in 1750's. This mission is very rustic. Take your time walking around and read your guide book in numerical order. After walking the grounds is a very nice and well done small museum. Look for the description of the origin or tortilla. A little trivia never hurts any body.

If this mission could talk it would have amazing stories to tell about the people who worshipped and lived there. Don't miss the museum that gives you the history behind your walking tour. If you do not have a Parks Pass, there is a fee to get in. The fee is how the mission continues to be preserved. Something to think about: how did the Priest manage to survive each day in the scorching Arizon heat, wearing his wool robe? Take time to learn and wonder what life was like.

We visited Tumacacori on a day trip to Tubac. We had already seen San Xavier Del Bac Mission in Tucson, so it was interesting to see another, related mission and get a slightly different perspective. Tumacacori is one a few remaining missions in Arizona, and for the entrance price of $5, provides a good overview. There are a few buildings to walk through as well as a small museum attached to the visitor's center. The crumbling mission is the highlight, however. The park is a good place to visit with kids since most of it is outside. Our 15-month-old hates being in the stroller, but will tolerate a lot if he can be outside.

Easy to miss, not well advertised and just off I19 about 3km from Tubac, south of Tucson. The first mission built in Arizona offers a little history and a nice walking experience. They offered limited tours and, I think, you have to make reservations. But you can walk around by yourself and they have signs and give you a booklet to read as you walk along. Then you return it when you're done. Takes a little over an hour to visit but very interesting. The fee is $5.00 but they honor the National Parks Membership.

Having driven past the Tumacacori exit on Highway 19 too many times we decided that we had to stop. What a beautiful, peaceful, and pleasant surprise! We were greeted upon entry by a volunteer, paid the $5.00 fee per person, and within minutes were able to take a private docent tour of the property and grounds. Our volunteer docent Bob Perry (a former history teacher) gave us a most memorable experience, explaining the founding of the Mission, the various challenges that the Mission experienced, and the various areas in the expansive grounds. The rich history of Jesuit Father Kino and his followers was exemplified in the museum with dioramas showing how the chapel looked at the Mission's peak. It is worth a couple of hours to quietly sit and enjoy the beauty of the area, the mission, and think what it was like at the time of the Mission's founding.

When traveling through this area, you should definitely make this a stop if you have time. They offer guided tours, but we were on a tight schedule and bought the guide book for $1.00, which was a great bargain. Although there is much remaining of the mission, you have to use your imagination a little to understand what it would have looked like during the 1600-1700's when the mission was active. Although it isn't as well intact (no elaborate church interiors remain), the history is quite fascinating. A walk through the cemetery in the back is a somber reminder of the hard times of the people that made this their home.

Unlike the Mission San Xavier del Bac, Tumacacori is essentially a partially restored mission/church built in the 1750’s. And despite the fact that there’s not much to see inside the mission church (beautiful wood-beam ceiling though), the structure itself, along with the funerary tower, supply/storage shelter, and the nunnery/living area, is quite beautiful. Be sure to make a stop and look at the excellent exhibit (with diorama, information plaques, models, and artifacts of items used at the time) at the visitor center. There’s an entrance fee to visit the park; “free” if you have the America the Beautiful Pass. You can either take a guided-tour, or borrow a brochure that explains the various structures in this small park and explore on your own. Also, this is a handicapped accessible park.

Comfortable Shoes are a must on the excursion. Plan on doing a lot of walking while you are visiting.The fee is $3.00 per person, there is a discount for Military. Try the homemade tortillas with beans and salsa. Take the trail that leads down to the river....simply "breath taking". We really enjoyed seeing this piece of our Arizona History!

We were staying at Santa Rita Lodge for take pictures of Hummingbirds when we noticed the Tumacacori Mission a little ways away. This mission has great photo opportunities. It is either $3 or $5 each to go in unless you have your National Park pass which lets you in along with 3 others. There is a lot of history here, heat, indian attacks, hardships for the monks. We spent about 2 hours here since we enjoy taking pictures.

A waitress mentioned this historical park while eating breakfast one morning at the Esplendor Resort in Rio Rico. I might not have found it otherwise. Located just off the interstate, it's an intriguing property with fascinating history. Park preservationists were at work restoring the exterior walls of the beautiful Chapel. A woman was cooking fresh tortillas over an open fire in the courtyard. (bring a few extra dollars to tip! : ) The Park employees were very friendly. There's opportunity for composing photographs everywhere you look. I stayed just a couple of hours, reading the informational guides, taking photos, and contemplating what life must have been like at that time. You may want to stay longer. If you enjoy the history of the southwest, don't miss this!

We were down south of Tucson to specifically check out this beautiful mission. We went on President's Day and the park service was having a free admission day, but the $3 per person would have been worth it. Lovely people working the desk, we were there in time for a brief tour that starts at 11am. The guide gave us lots of information about Father Kino and the start of the mission. After that, we went on a self guided tour, with a very informative booklet of the grounds. Interesting points were described in detail in the booklet with corresponding numbers. The church was begun in 1800 and so much went on there, many people living and working on the beautiful property. Nice, easy walk through the grounds to the kiln where they made the bricks, the cemetery, the orchard. Fresh tortillas made for you, fill it with salsa and beans, no charge. You should go.

Amazing place to explore early Southwestern/Mexican colonial ruins. It was fascinating to see the blend of European and native cultures in how the buildings were designed and used. The museum itself is quality and for only $3 it is well worth the visit. There are not a lot of buildings in the western United States that are from the 1600's so this is a rare treat to explore.

Tumacacori is on the 'must see' list of historic sites in southern AZ. Although abandoned long ago, it is still in remarkably good shape, a testimony to the skill of the native builders centuries ago. This is an easy tour, with a well-marked and annotated guide and well worth the stop. Admission is modest (free with a Golden Eagle Pass) and there are a number of unusual places close by. This is well worth a visit.

The Park Service has done a great job of attempting to preserve this old mission. The self guide the rangers give you, helps you understand just how thins were in the 1700's and what the missionaries attempted to accomplish. It is sure worth the $3.00 entry fee. When we were there restoration is continuing. Check it out

We have been in the area many times and had never stopped before. Actually we made stopping a priority this trip. My wife acquired one of those National Park Passport books ($10) where you put in an ink stamp at every park you visit so National Parks have become a must and that is a good thing. We are revisiting many parks and definitely seeing others in quest of those stamps. Quite fun actually. (How do you spell obsession?)
Entrance fee $3

We didn't expect too much when we stopped here on our way home to NM, but we were pleasantly surprised by the things we saw. Not only is there the mission church with unfinished bell tower, but there are large grounds to explore. More recently, where the mission garden used to be, they have planted heritage trees, much like the fruit trees that would have been there when the mission was operational. There is also a small museum well worth walking through. We were there Easter morning and a lady was outside the Visitor Center making torillas, which was a plus. They offered a booklet to use (but return) so one can guide oneself, and that was worth it. Otherwise, it is hard to know how and when the various buildings, etc. were used. There are more preserved mission churches, but this is a nice place to stop. They also have a small museum store. There is a cost for admission, unless you have a Golden Age Pass -- something well worth the $10 that we paid years ago.

We missed the guided tour of the site, but were able to find our way around on our own just fine. I would recommend purchasing a $1 guidebook, available in the gift shop. The site is not very large and can easily be covered in an hour, depending on how long you want to spend examining the details of the ruined church.
This National Historic Park is a well preserved piece of our nation's history. There is a minimal fee, (we were free with our free 'National Park Pass' for 60+ citizens).

Located south of Tucson close to the Mexican border. The $5 admission is valid for a week, though it's unlikely you'll be back again within the week. The mission is not in use anymore. The grounds and the mission building make for a nice stroll. Lots of birds on the grounds, so bring binoculars if you are into it.

There is basically a monument to honor those who fought in this battle. Parking is limited to 2 or 3 cars on the side of the street. It will only take about 5 minutes to view. If you want to stamp your Passbook, you will need to go to the Tupelo Visitor Center on Natchez Trace Parkway

This short auto tour is a beautiful drive with a lot of history about the logging days in the great smoky mountains. A gravel road it is well maintained and an easy drive in any type of vehicle. It follows the old railroad path along the creek side. It is a great place to stop for a picnic. Pick up the $1 brochure before you start. It gives great information about the area and there are roadside markers that tell you about the railroad and villages.
park: Upper Tremont Road in Great Smoky Mountains National Park

text: Be sure to purchase the audio driving tour cd at the park headquarters. It costs $15.00 but it makes the visit to Valley Forge a lot more memorable since it contains a lot of historical information that is not available by other means.

"It's not that the soldiers were rag-tag or inexperienced. Valley Forge is where the Continental Army was created as a professional force." This was a frequent comment by the tour guides and docents on the tour of the park. (I STRONGLY suggest the $17 per person trolley tour, which is 90 minutes and a great overview of what you might want to visit more during your stay.) The shadows of the soldiers were almost palpable, with the monuments to the various state militias and the officers that were involved in the winter over of 1777-78. There is only one authentic artifact: Washington's residence, with the reproduction spring house where he would have wine and shad (a fish he favored) kept cool. I remember visiting the park before it became part of the National Park System in 1976. It's not just that I appreciate history more. The historical interpretation of the park is far more visceral and immediate, even for a Philadelphia native, to learn why nearby towns are called Wayne (Gen. Anthony) and King of Prussia (see "Gen." Von Steuben). SEPTA even runs a bus route to the Visitor's Center.
We enjoyed our visit to Valley Forge National Historic Park where I got my National Parks Passport stamped again.

I took the trolley tour. Tour was $17.50 per person. We bought our tickets in the visitor center and left at 11a.m. Tour lasted 90 minutes and it had 2 stops. The first one Muhlenberg brigade and the second one Washington headquarters. The first stop lasted 15 minutes and the second one around 20 minutes. The trolley was very informative. It dropped us off at visitor center.

Visited in the winter and still had a great experience. Admission is free to the park and museum. Would recommend that when you visit plan staying at least three hours to be able to enjoy all the sites scattered throughout the park. Also there are chapels along the roadside that I would recommend visiting. All the family can enjoy this destination whether it is for the scenery of the history!

At a convention for the week, and finally got out early one day so that we could visit the Park. We amazed that it was free to visit. The Visitor's Center have nice displays, and the requisite gift shop, where we traded dollars for those take-home items :) We followed the Encampment Drive around the area, and visited the Arch, midway through. The visit to Washington's Chapel was beautiful, made more so because we were there at dusk and the lights had been turned on, and the doors still open. We also made our way back to the Arch to photograph it in it's lighted glory. What a treat that was. This is a place that every American should visit.

Many visitors don't realize that this was a winter encampment for Washington and not a battlefield. There are $15/hr bike rentals with an 8 mile paved loop trail and a small visitor center and museum. The best parts that I like are the wooded trail hikes over Mt Misery and Mt Joy that most visitors never see. It's great for kids so make sure to ask a ranger for directions. Check the visitor center for daily ranger talks.

We first went to the Visitors Center to get the Junior Ranger packets for the kids, we then decided to get the $14.95 auto tour cd, which seemed like the best option. The trolley tour looked neat but seemed too much for a family of four, and it was quite muggy that day so traveling to each stop in an air-conditioned auto sounded much better. We took the entire tour, got out and walked around many times, then returned to the Visitor Center so the girls could get their Junior Ranger badges. The NPS tries to get children involved so much - it is great to take kids to any NPS park - they love the idea of getting a badge for learning.

This place might be perfect if you would like to see the park by riding bike with family. We were not prepared for a bike ride or walk. One good option in the park is you can drive around by your own vehicle. There are paid guided trolley tour available. I did not feel it is worth taking that ride. Charging $16/adult, $8.50/Child.

We stopped here on our return from Philadelphia to Maryland. It got us off I-95, and we had said for many years that this was a Nat. Park we should visit. The options for touring that day were: 1) A 40 minutes walking tour with a ranger to a main site. (free); 2) a Trolley tour with a narrator (about $16/person); 3) a self guided tour by car along the marked route with either a CD ($15 in gift shop) or with a cell phone by calling in to a pre-assigned number at different stops on the tour (free unless you have phone charges). There was also a bike rental ($25/day) if you want to bike the various trails within the park. We could observe many people who brought or rented bikes enjoying the park.
The park has a very nice visitor center. They also have a trolley tour that is also well worth it with a very good guide. The trolley tour is $16.50, but the park overall is free.

We visited here are what seemed like the hottest day of the year! Do not do what we did! It was overwhelmingly hot and there is little to no shade. It actually takes many hours to complete all the stops so start early or you won't finish before the place closes. We first stope at the visitors center and purchase a self guided tour of the whole park for $15 on CD. We popped it in and followed the instructions and made a good time of it. Bring food and water with you because here is nothing along the way.

We arrived at the park around 1:30 pm and had missed the 1pm trolley tour, however walked around the visitor center reading about the encampment and checking out the artifacts and letters they have on display. I bought my souvenirs and we headed out around 2:30 pm to drive the park route past all the monuments and various stops along the tour. The CD tour costs $14.95 if you want to purchase and listen to it as you drive along or you can use your cell phone when you get out of the car and get the code off the information posts they have around. We didn't do either but we did not stop at every point and still spent another 2 hours in the park. We were out of time and had to get dinner and the rental car in for drop off but wish we had planned a full day. So much to see & didn't have time to see Washington's church towards the end of the drive but looked beautiful when we drove by. We did take time to see his house and walk through it which was cool. There is a bike trail that will take you all through the park as well and you can rent bikes in the parking lot if you do not travel with yours. The trolley tour sounded like fun but we just didn't have enough time to take the 3 o'clock one which was a special 2 hour tour.

Got here well after lunch on a hot August day. The visitor's center is very nice and we decided since it was so late to take a trolly tour. We bought $15 tickets for the 4pm tour (they have them every 2 hours, I think) and began our visit. All the information is presented in ways that children can understand but that adults can appreciate. The introductory movie is well done. After about an hour it was time for our tour: we were the only ones on the tour. We had a personal tour of Valley Forge! Our tour guide and driver were very kind and knowledgeable. We enjoyed the stops and the Rangers at each place, some of whom were dressed in period costume. The tour took until almost 6 pm. We highly recommend the trolly tour, even if there are others on it. The tour guide said that the later tours are less crowded. The trolly tour was worth every penny.
Expensive, but plenty to do. We did the driving tour with CD for $15- was excellent. FYI--for those people who do not like mountains or driving on windy, high roads, you may want to avoid it!

This is a must see. We were short on time and were only able to do the CD audio tour. This is the best way to see the park if you have time constraints. The cd is sold at the visitors center. Well worth the $15 and you can see it in the comfort of your car. Be sure to stop at the places of interest and take pictures. The history it gives you and the sites are more than you get from reading each of the info plaques. The scenery is beautiful and the park rangers are helpful if you get lost which is easy to do if you don't follow the CDs directions.

Since there was 9 of us, including 3 children, we elected to buy the audio cd for $14.95 and be able to stop only at the places we wanted to and learn about the history with the cd. What a beautiful park! The rolling hills, with canons and huts was fascinating for the kids. We walked through a couple of the huts where the soldiers would have slept and they were amazed that the soldiers would have slept on straw! We also saw people giving a tour that were dressed in period costumes. I did not realize how many women were also at Valley Forge. Very interesting! The Washington Memorial Chapel was beautiful, the stained glass windows and the architecture inside is not something you see much anymore. Very intricate and detailed. The cd brought it all to life and we learned a great deal about the history of our country. You can learn more in the visitors center also. There is a short movie and lots of artifacts on display there. Definitely worth the drive.

If you plan to visit the Visitor's Center, you will park a couple of blocks' walk away, although handicapped parking and visitor drop off is at the front entrance to the building. Bicycles can be rented (or bring your own) and the fees were $15 per hour for adult or $25 for an entire day, with bikes due back to the rental trailer by 5pm. Reduced rates were in effect for children and helmets were made available. Trails are paved and are shared by joggers, walkers, Scout troops, hikers, families with strollers, and horse riders, although it appeared the latter stuck to the grass more than the paved pathways. If you elect to walk, hike, bike or ride, be sure to bring a hat, sunscreen, good walking shoes, and possibly an umbrella for the heat.

We took the audio tour. Just purchase a CD at the visitors center and then follow the directions given. The narrator gives you the story of Valley Forge as you make 9 stops around the tour. Expect to take several hours to complete the tour and give yourself a chance to get out at each point of interest. It is definitely worth the $15 for the audio guide. We thoroughly enjoyed visiting and getting a close up look at an important piece of history.

We really enjoyed our two days at Valley Forge National Historical Park. We had to split it up because the trolley tours were only running on the weekends. The museum was kind of lackluster, not as good as Gettysburg, but we enjoyed the history of the events that took place there and the hardships faced by its inhabitants. They had letters written by some of the soldiers, even George Washington! Humbling, to say the least. As I said, we did the trolley tour (about $17.00 per person), which was nicely handled. I wished it stopped at the arch and the chapel, but it did not. Washington's headquarters was interesting and definitely worth the price. The museum is free by the way, the Encampment Store which is located within has many nice items for sale. If you're looking for something to do in the King Of Prussia, spend the day at Valley Forge. Wish we would have done the car tour and seen some more of the park.

We stopped by on a whim to break up a 6hr car trip. So glad we did! 11, 9, and 7 yr old all commented that it far exceeded their expectation. We opted not for trolley ($17pp). We did the great intro movie in the visitors center then drove the 10mi loop. We used the audio prompts available by mobile phone (free). Stopped by the soldiers huts, the national arch, and Washington's headquarters. We all got a good history lesson and a great boost of patriotic pride.

This is a nice piece of history. It is the place of encampment for Washington and his troops during winter 1777-1778. No battles were fought here but this is where troops were properly trained and lessons in perseverance were learned. Valley Forge is easy to get to from the highway and entry is free. We arrived around noon and went to the visitor center. Be sure to ask where the kiosk is located where you can enter an ancestor's name to see if he was at Valley Forge. We purchased the self-tour cd for $16 (I would recommend this) and then we watched the free short video about Valley Forge and the Revolution and then walked with a Ranger to a few stops for about 1/2 hour. We took a break and drove to King of Prussia for a quick lunch (a few miles away) and then came back to start the self-tour. We ended up driving around the park until 5:30 p.m. and we didn't even get out to see everything. Washington's headquarters was at a good spot for us to stretch our legs after driving around for a while. This is a beautiful, peaceful park where it seems locals come to take advantage of the great spot to picnic or exercise. We did Gettysburg and Valley Forge in the same week and it is interesting to compare the two. Gettysburg is more hustle and bustle while this is more serene. Both equally nice. In retrospect, we should have stayed in King of Prussia afterwards because this was an all day event for us and that area looks nice and new with plenty of restaurants, hotels and a mall. An overall great visit to Valley Forge.

We spent a lot of time at Valley Forge since it was of special interest to my boyfriend. As it was August and the weather was hot, we opted for buying the vehicle CD (about $15) and driving the park and stopping at the sites instead of one of the bus tours. The CD was quite informative and gave exact directions as long as you followed the 15 mph speed it suggested. We were ahead or behind on it but got back on track by pausing or sitting in the car a few minutes. There can be a lot of walking involved if you get out at each stop to walk around. Most areas are pretty pedestrian friendly. I happen to have asthma, so walking back up the hill to the parking area would have been asking for an attack if I had been alone, however, my boyfriend walked to the top parking area and brought the car down to pick me up. There is a cute little gift shop where you can get a hotdog and drink behind Washington Memorial Chapel, but otherwise, refreshments are pretty sparse until you leave the park. There is a covered bridge on the route that I suggest you cross and see some of the homes on that road, go as far as the park sign and turn around to come back. Some of them were used as headquarters and are not on the main cd tour but can be seen on the park service map (which you should get at the visitors center from a ranger). Overall, it was a very nice park. Most areas with buildings close at 5 or 6pm, so when we arrived on Fri and went to the park, we only had a short time to explore before things closed, but did a quick tour and went back on Monday to spend the day. It was nice knowing where things were before the deep exploration on Monday.

We were going to spend July 4th weekend with family. Being a history buff, I talked my husband into this side trip prior to the family time. We did the auto tour with 2 chihauhaus after a 10 hour drive from NC. The park is very dog friendly, the Park Rangers were super nice. The really nice thing about the auto tour was the we were in our car, with AC and our dogs. It was easy to stop at the locations, with or without the dogs, walk and do a little photography. The CD was very easy to use. A person can go as fast or as slow as they want. We also saw trolley tours and horse back tours, but they were not an option with the chi-chi dogs. I also started my National Park Passport Project with this visit.

Valley Forge National Historical Park is a very informative and interesting place to spend a few hrs. The visitor center has a lot of pieces of history to view and interesting facts to learn. There is also a Re-Enactment of the Battle certain times of the year that is fun to watch. The volunteers are very knowledgeable of the history of the battle and the surrounding area. Walking through George Washington headquarters was really neat and the grounds are beautiful. If it is raining, you can stay in your car and drive around seeing most of the park without getting out. I wish I had had more time to explore but the park was closing at 5pm. It was also very windy and cold, snowy at times because it was winter but I enjoyed it all the same. Hope to go back to the area some time in the summer. The King of Prussia mall which is the largest mall in the US is withing a few miles of the park offering 40 different restaurants and many shops from Bloomingdales to Sears, and a Costco.

We went to Valley Forge National Park to kill a few hours with a walk and a look at the sites. We decided to rent bikes. There is a well marked 5 mile trail for bikes, families with strollers, walkers, & runners. The bikes were $10 an hour and excellent quality, easy to rent. We decided to go off the beaten path. Our 5 miles turned into 15 as we kept making left turns to see what was down that path into the woods. We ended up discovering wonderful 200 year old houses & farms, maintained by the park, and completely off the beaten path. I understand why the Park does not advertise these beauties, they are not set up for tourists, but if you love old houses and the feeling of being in a place that hasn't changed in 200 years try foraging through the woods to find these spots! There are trail maps,(for when you go off the 5 mile trail), that are NOT well marked, but they do generally tell you where these spots are. We went on a glorious fall day and spent 4 hours getting a great workout.

This was our first visit and will not be our last for sure. What an amazing part of history. The park itself, even on a rainy day had reenactors onsite in the encampments and buildings to give background and answer questions. Photographs are permitted everywhere in every building ( something very uncommon anymore at historic sites due to restrictions on flash or insurance issues). The park tourguides themselves were also on hand and very knowledgable and animated in their presentations. The drive tour is free and you can access info at each stop via cellphone. Or you can purchase a more detailed driveguide via cd for about $15. Very similar to Gettysburg. Their is also plenty of areas for cycling walking running picnicking and a host of other outdoor activities. Washington chapel is on the tour but is not part of the NPS and the church charges a $2 admission fee..well worth the small donation. The architecture is fantastic and the folks providing info about the church know their stuff. Even in the pouring rain ( which it did for most of our visit) you can still enjoy the entire area. A trolley tour of 90 min is also available for a fee of $16 for adults and $12 for children. But check as prices can change.

With navigation we found the visitors center difficult to find. We arrived just after 3:00 on a Saturday so we bought tickets for the last trolley tour at 4:00 then asked for a place to have a late lunch. We were told the nearby snack shop closed at 2:00 so we were directed to a small place not owned by the park behind the nearby Washington Memorial Chapel. It was cute, full of souvenirs and home made goodies. The lady there was happy to tell us about the church as we ate our hot dogs. We made it back just in time to hear a man speaking about events in Valley Forge, much of which I had no idea. It was very educational. There are many displays in the visitors center which we didn't have much time to look at. The tour was great, there was even men dressed in period clothing who gave a gun demonstration. Very interesting. I took many pictures I will try to post later. I would say the tour was very much worth the price of $15. But i would only reccommend it for older children since there is alot of sitting and listening and no seat belts. It was a great day, but next time we will be sure to go earlier, eat before we go or pack a nice lunch, there are plenty of places for a picnic. We plan to go back in the fall when the scenery will most surely be breathtaking. Visit their website for info and coupons before you go! The park is free, shuttles are free too if you don't feel up to the tour.

Visitors center is the place to start. Great displays. Film tells the story to get you started exploring the park. Interactive display to find your patriot that served at Valley Forge. We bought the CD tour packet for $14.99. Took is turn by turn thur the park. You can go fast or slow and stop and start the tour to your own pace. Allows time to get out and explore. Explains every aspect of the park. Free. National treasure. If you are going to be out In the grassy area during warm weather months use an insect repellent and check for ticks. One person in our group picked one up and found it later in the day.

This lush hunk of real estate was finally brought into the National Park system almost two hundred years after George Washington chose it as a strategic location That was following the 9/11 battle with the British at Brandywine. Then in a less inspired version of Washington planning - this time DC not the General - a broke federal agency in 2011 allowed Toll Brothers to buy a chunk of open land in the middle of the park. Then it arranged to buy it all back two years later. Toll Brothers wants to thank Congress for the $5M profit it made. (Does that make you feel warm & fuzzy, taxpayer?)

If you are interested in history, visit this site. Staff are very knowledgeable. The trolley tour was excellent and not expensive (about $15). The tour lasts about 90 minutes. You can walk or drive the same route. Audio tapes are available to purchase that guide you through the park. I did not realize that no battle was fought here. It was Washington's winter encampment. Lots of interesting facts to be learned

If you are thinking of visiting here, read some of the reviews here, check out the Web Site and you will find some options include paying $15.00 to take the trolley tours, driving yourself and calling the phone #s posted at each stop, renting or bringing a bike or walking. Entrance to the park itself is FREE.
Drive the Encampment Tour... worth it. Lots of joggers and cyclists around. Nat'l Parks are America's hidden treasure...visit them when you can! (Annual Pass is a huge plus)

We stopped at the visitors center first--#1 on the tour map. Small gift shop, very small snack shop (drinks and chips etc), and an area with informational signs and pictures. A fair amount of period pieces to check out, like the cooking gear, and the muskets they used. You can pick up a map of the area which indicates 10 different sites to check out. There is a short movie, but our timing was off so we skipped it. You can jump on the bus/trolley (I believe there was a fee), ride your own/rent a bike, walk, or drive your car. Walkers/bikers--lots of hills!! Only stops 2 and 5 were interesting to us--#2 a series of log cabins (reproductions) that you could look into, one you can enter. #5 Washington Headquarters and Train Depot. HQ was cool--no hands on stuff though. Train depot just had more info placards and pictures--still being developed I guess. Feel free to ask questions of the characters, they were very knowledgeable and good with the kids. The rest of the stops were just drive-bys of arches, cabins, and statues of famous people from the time. Expect to walk a fair amount regardless of what method you choose to tour the site--bring water and comfortable shoes!

My wife and I recently traveled to Phiadelphia for an October weekend. We spent an enjoyable 5 - 6 hours at Valley Forge National Historical Park, which is only a 30- minute drive from the Philadelphia airport. It was a crisp fall day; the leaves were turning. The day began gray and rainy, but eventually the sun came out. We started at the Visitors Center which has a well-done museum containing artifacts from the site, and exhibits portraying the life of the soldiers during their encampent at Valley Forge during the winter of there. We also viewed a 15 minute video that was at best, average. There are lots of walking trails, and we took advantage of a loop trail that is actually paved and winds its way around the park. The loop trail is about 5 miles and winds its way through woods (we spotted a deer), across fields, and around the main parade grounds where the soldiers were trained by Von Steuben. There were no battles at the site, but it was an important staging ground for the Continental Army during the bitter winter of 1777-78. The Continental Army gave bonuses of $12 to the soldiers who could complete their log cabins in the shortest amount of time. At first we were disappointed because other than some log cabins -- most of which appeared to be reproductions of the originals -- there wasn't a lot to see. We were ready to leave but then decided to find the house at the park that was George Washington's headquarters. That was the highlight of the visit. The house was built sometime in the 18th century; much of it is restored, but there are some original parts of the house. Gen. Washington rented it from its owner. The park service guide did a wonderful job telling us about the house. If you go to Valley Forge, don't miss George Washington's headquarters. If you have young chidren, they will enjoy the "reenactors" who are dressed in 18th century military uniforms. Guided bus tours of the site are available for a fee. This is worth a visit if you have any interest in the Revolutionary War.

Visited Valley Forge National Historical Park on a cool, breezy fall-like mid-September weekend. What a wonderful experience! We were lucky to emerge from the informational film just as a terrific park ranger named Peter was about to lead a tour (about 1/4 mile). The tour was excellent, as Peter led us to the beautiful ridge overlooking the Great Valley and brilliantly told all about what happened at Valley Forge during the Revolutionary War. Costumed interpreters then demonstrated how to load and fire muskets and how to bake bread and pie in the outdoor brick ovens in the camp. We then returned to the Visitor's Center to get the map for the self-guided tour and drove through the lovely park. Two great stops were the Memorial Arch and Washington's Headquarters. There are several spots to see and explore the 12-men cabins which the Continental Army built for shelter. However, the drive through the park was exquisite, with deer and other wildlife and very picturesque scenery, including a covered bridge and views across the Schuykull River. There were tons of people just enjoying the park, walking and riding bikes along the paths and trails. Altogether, a perfect late summer afternoon. We were lucky to have been in the park when so much was going on. (I have been to the park previously when things were very quiet.)

Trolley tours were a bit expensive ($17 per adult) so we opted for using our car and the cel phone explanations. Beautifully kept grounds, lots of places to stop and examine different parts of the park. Visitor Center has a small cafe (vending machine but places to sit), exhibits, and tourism information as well as the usual gift shop and NPS passport stamps. Informative movie explaining significance. Easy to follow directions, and we'll be back because we didn't see everything. Perhaps next time we'll spring for the trolley tour. Easy on and off highway.

Entry fee of $8 per person, no charge with the NPS Senior Pass. You should be prepared for a steep walk down and back on a narrow path to get up close to the cliff dwellings. Recommend watching the short video in the visitor center before touring. Impressive site that we have never heard of before, glad we made the effort to visit.

Even today with concrete steps and paved pathways access to and from the canyon it is not easy for some, considering the 7,000' elevation to start from. There is also a National Park entrance fee, but free with a National Parks or Seniors Pass card. There is a small museum and gift shop on the top mesa. Due to breathing difficulties we opted not to walk too far into the canyon, but did walk the paved rim trail. We did get good views on both, but couldn't examine the dwellings up close.

The hike down the loop had stairs going down quite a ways then paved trail back to the beginning of the stairs. I hadnt hiked in months, paced myself slowly coming back up and was fine with a few quick air breaks. Worth the hike to see a lot of ruins on the other side of the canyon. Trail did not go to the bottom just to eye level. You see ruins as soon as you step outside the visitor center. Access Pass made this free. Plenty of rooms to see right on the path also. Really beautiful rock area too! Informative center
I was here with my family during a family reunion in Arizona. I used my National Parks Pass and got four of us in.

Been here three times now (and used my Senior National Parks Pass - no admission charge for my entire party of 7). Make sure you view the continus loop film about the canyon and it''s inhabitants first. Then it's an easy 240+ steps down a winding path to the "island" and along the way one can actually see the many cave dwellings across the canyon (on this day we saw hard hat archeologists working). At the bottom you go right and it takes you on a counter clockwise trail around and through the cave dwellings with plenty of signs explaining each area as you get to view how the ancient Indian tribes lived throughout the year protected from the weather as well as their enemies. This place just amazes me everytime I visit. This time I saw a red tailed hawk soaring throughout the canyon searching for food. I will always return here with my friends visiting Flagstaff. Oh, and the Park Rangers are the nicest people around, they tell you everything you need to know about Walnut Canyon and other sights of the area. But be careful and take you time (and bring water) as you ascend the same 240+ steps back to the top. There are benches spaced appropriately for you to rest and catch your breath, remember you are at 7,000 feet above sea level!

This is an ok place, worth visiting if you visit Flagstaff. You can finish the whole trail in less than 1 hour. Entrance was $8/person. It would have been expensive if you have 4 people in your car. We chose to get the American is beautiful annual pass, which we used in other parks.

Really did not know what to expect. Hubs can't hike and we were not sure how interesting it would be just from the visitor center. We loved it! There are lots of displays and we loved the informational video. We were able to get good photos from the observation windows and bought several items in the gift shop. I was also able to get my National Park Passport book stamped and to buy the sticker stamp for this park. We were here on the fourth of July and we both agreed that it was a great choice to go see it. It brings a bit of richness to the day to learn how ancient people once lived in this land. Well worth the trip.

We spent the day hiking, fording freezing streams and enjoying the amazing scenery. As it was a Sunday and Mothers Day to boot, some of the more popular areas were somewhat crowded, but it was still worth it. Did some minor rock climbing, with a four year old, had a blast. Definitely worth the $20.00 per car admission fee.

Magnificent, truly well maintained park where you can hike down 850 feet and be inside the natural stone pueblos. Excellent signage and good short orientation video at the visitor center. Well worth the $8 each entrance fee. Important tip: do the island loop COUNTER CLOCKWISE, everyone else will go clockwise and then you have to wait for every person to explore the pueblos, go the other direction and you will have more peace and quiet and importantly, you will hike back in the shade! Look all around you and you will see hundreds of cliff dwellings. We are truly grateful that our country preserves these wonderful historic places.

Walnut Canyon was a great last minute addition to our family spring break vacation, but it deserves a place on everyone's list. Be prepared for a little exercise and take the canyon island loop trail. The paved! trail takes you down into the Canyon to get in close with the canyon cliff wall dwellings. Much of the trail has railings, but be prepared for several areas without. Walnut Canyon is a stop that should not be missed. $8 per adult entry.

About 20 minutes outside of south Flagstaff, this was very much worth the drive and the $ 8 admission fee. Very interesting and scenic. It is a workout if you go down the Island Trail (and in my opinion there’s no reason to go there if you don’t take this trail!). There was a volunteer ranger that was full of information and his love of his job was evident in his love of all around him. The Native American ruins are especially interesting and unique (to em anyway). Hard for me to imagine that humans were able to eke out an exisitance in these conditions.

If you're an outdoors person, it is economical to buy the parks pass ($40) or the National Parks Pass ($80), as it covers entrance fees for all these attractions. Plus, your money will go to a noble American cause; our impressive system of National Parks. The 1m trail down and back up out of the canyon is a lot more achievable than doing the same hike at the Grand Canyon. Granted, the views aren't as spectacular, but it is very scenic, nonetheless.

Spent our day up north of Flagstaff so we decided to stop here on the way back to Scottsdale. I have a lifetime senior pass so admission is free to all National Parks and Monuments. Otherwise, general admission here is $8. Be cautious though if you are out of condition...there are over 200 steps down to the "island" and that means over 200 back up. Take your time. Visit earlier in the day, especially in the winter. We got there at 3:30 and although it's open till 5, once you get down to the island the sun is below your horizon and it looks like you are running out of daylight. it's cold here in the winter, this might be a better visit in the spring or fall. I was deep breathing walking back up the steps and the breathing in the cold air was a little bothersome. There are places to sit and rest on the way back up so take advantage and get your heartrate back down. Make sure you read the warning information, because the girl at the desk didn't really tell us that it was considered a strenuous trail. Also, if you are afraid of heights, this won't be for you. There are railings most of the way down, but some little areas do not have them. However, I do believe this is the trail to take to see the dwellings in the rocks and how the community lived over 500 years ago. Amazing that these rocks are still so preserved. It took us about 45minutes-1 hour to do this trail, but we didn't dilly dally because of the impending sundown, and the place is only open until 5p anyway.
Great National Parks Passport Stop for the kids. Easy paths through a cliffside village with a small visitors center and Jr Ranger activity.

Been in Arizona over 40 years and never knew about Walnut Canyon. There had been a controlled burning in Flagstaff the day we went so we were a bit nervous about the smoke in the air when we arrived. Actually it was a little hazy in the canyon but we didn't smell the smoke when we entered the canyon. We had purchased a lifetime annual pass for national parks ($10) when we went to Yosemite 16 years ago so there was no charge with an annual pass.

We were five with different levels of walking abilities and this was a wonderful way for all of us to learn about the history of the area. We were a bit limited on time, so three of us walked the Island loop trail while the other two watched the film, enjoyed the exhibits and browsed the gift shop. Then, we all walked the Rim Trail together. When we compared notes, we all had learned much of the same information and were thoroughly impressed with the experience. Seeing the ancient dwellings up close was fascinating. Seeing them from a distance was equally interesting. The information and images along the Island loop trail answered many of our questions and provided a tremendous amount of information to help us imagine what life must have been like living in this rustic setting. Our entry was free thanks to my father-in-laws Senior Lifetime National Parks Pass. We were staying in Sedona and in addition to visiting this site, went to Sunset Crater Volcano and Wupatki National Monument. It was doable n one day, but we made a few sacrifices.

Just a short drive out of flagstaff. National Park $8/person or use your national pass. Two trail to choose from. 20 minutes mostly flat or 45 minutes with 270 steps to climb back up. Excellent views of Walnut canyon and Hopi dwellings.

Nice experience overall. Costs $8 per person entry, but worth it in my opinion. There is a visitor center with lots of information, and 2 main trails. Would take about 2 hours. The island trail, takes you right up and into some of the cliff dwellings. The rim trail gives a nice overview. There are a lot of steps, stairs and steep inclines on the island trail so be aware, wear proper shoes and bring lots of water!

Taking it slow in traversing the elevations down onto the mountain "peninsula" where the cliff dwellings is advisable even if you don't have bad knees or heart issues. Definitely a beautiful place to explore and fun to go into the actual "homes" of the Sinagua who lived high on this geographical wonder. The trails are well maintained and steps serve to lower you into the area where needed. Don't miss this among the trio of Walnut Canyon/Sunset Crate/Wupatki ruins - best deal to see all three for only $25/car load or $5 entry per site, per person. Best to go in early morning or late afternoon in the summer due to the intensity of the sun.
We found this place on our way to Sedona from Flagstaff. This is a must to visit.The view and the history is just incredible. Entrance fee $8/person. Parking is free

We were here some years ago and were very impressed even though the Island Trail was closed due to a huge boulder that had fallen across the path. We were able to do the whole trail this time. The boulder has been modified and the trail restored. There is also on going maintenance happening during our visit. The park is very well maintained. Makes you feel good that your tax dollars are being well spent here.
Admission is $8, not bad for this one. Nice walk around, very interesting. The last flights of stairs was a little taxing, otherwise we had a nice visit.

Had no idea what we were getting into here, but it sure was amazing. 800 year old cliff dwellings built into a steep rock face cliff, by an ancient indian tribe. There's a small welcome center with movie and some history to start, and then outside to climb the stairs and follow the paths to get right into the cliff dwellings. The path is steep and coming back up, very tiring and it make you wonder how people did it 800 years ago. Very cool and a steal at $8 admission.

This was our first cliff dwelling experience. We were not disappointed. If you are a hiker they have trails that take you right up to them for a hands on experience. If not you get a very good look from tourist center. Also center has some very reasonable literature on the cliff people. there is an admission fee to national park of $10 for seniors. But that paid for my husband, me and a guest, plus gives us admission to any national park in any of the 50 states for a year.

Firstly, get there early, as the park closes at 5pm! We were 2 adults, which was $16. This is the first place I ever saw that lets you actually climb into the cliff dwellings!! The views all around this awesome area are outstanding!! You can just imagine how many Native Americans were actually living here!! There are many steps going down to the middle of the canyon, so you can really see everything!! Benches are here and there for resting along the way, and don't forget, every step is a seat!! lol If you have heart or breathing problems, there is another trail up top that still offers a wonderful view to the past, and it is wheelchair or hover round accessible!! Don't forget your water!! but they have a couple of gateraid machines if you do. AND!!! you can take your dog!! Not recommended for the senior dogs though... just saying. So, for a great day of exploration, get there by 10am, pack a picnic lunch, and head out to Walnut Canyon. It is a real hidden gem!!

Just a short drive from Flagstaff, the Canyon offers spectacular views and a pretty strenuous walk about a mile down into the canyon. There are numerous walking trail options. Very interesting history and the trails have many explanations along the way. There is a fee to enter the park of $8 for adults.

Wonderful hike through Walnut Canyon exploring cliff dwellings. For those with height phobias, the walk could be a little unnerving but trust me it was well worth it. The walk was down hill along a maintained path, so you'll be climbing up at the end. We went with an older teen and two 20 year olds (all girls) who absolutely enjoyed learning about ancient people and their lives . They really enjoyed the trail with it's amazing views. We went in August so we went in the morning before it got too hot. We were actually there when the park opened and had the place to ourselves which enhanced the overall experience. Bring plenty of water. One of our favorite experiences in Arizona!!! We used America the Beautiful Pass.

This is by far one of my favorite National Parks. We visit Arizona often, and usually stay in Flagstaff or Sedona. Walnut Canyon has an easy loop trail that is pretty level. But the real treasure is down the MANY steps into the canyon and the cliff dwellings. We were there one day when it was snowing and it was magical. It is very close to Flagstaff, and worth the drive. Take your National Park Passport to stamp it, and have the kids complete the Junior Ranger program. The hike down the stairs is a bit strenuous,but well worth it. You can always go part way down if you aren't up to going the full route.

This is rated as the #1 place to visit in the metro Flagstaff area, and was the most humbling experience we had on our trip. The cost to enter the National Park is between $5 - $8 dollars depending on the time of year. We would recommend getting a pass for all of the local National Parks (available at all of the booths in each park) to save a little money. The cost varies again pending the season. However, this was the best $8 I spent in our week visiting Flagstaff. The Hopi tribes lived in this canyon that has dropoffs of easily 1,000 feet+, lived off the land with Prickly Pear Catcus, Claret Cup Cactus, Twoneedle Pinyon, Mormon Tea, etc. The climb is strenuous for those with physical limitations. 285 steps take you down about 200 feet from where you start at 6,885 ft above sea level, and there is a paved trail (often without railing) that extends a mile around a middle mountain that you walk to see the half wall room these folk lived in. Very little privacy they had and along the way are informational signs to help one understand the life of the Hopi tribes. If you are afraid of heights, take your time, my wife did okay but stopped along the way to rest. There are places with benches among the stairs as well. The views are breath-taking as one could imagine, but the serene peace that exists was ubiquitous and soothing.

I've been to Arizona several times but have mainly visited the Big Ticket sights, e.g., Sedona, Grand Canyon and attractions near Phoenix & Tucson. I knew about Walnut Canyon National Monument, but read that it was "merely" there to exhibit ancient dwellings.
It's $5/person and the views were just fantastic. Requires a lot of stairs but it's really worth it for the legendary views.

Walnut Canyon is a terrific excursion that is just about 20 minutes from downtown Flagstaff, off of Highway 40. The canyon is gorgeous and becomes fascinating to examine when you realize that the ancient Native Americans actually had their dwellings under the overhangs and ledges and within the cliff walls. There is a $10 fee to get into the national park site.
Good for an afternoon stop off route 40. Old cliff dwellers homes in the side of the canyon. Cool history. 5$ admission
This is an awesome site. Admission price is cheap. Great place to walk! Make sure you wear good shoes and pace yourself the climb out is killer.

It's only about 10 miles outside Flagstaff and worth the drive. I have a Nat'l Park Pass so did not have to pay. Because I have been to Mesa Verde Nat'l Park I am not usually too impressed with the cliff dwellings, but this place was really worth the walk down and around the loop. Only takes about 45 minutes and can go inside of some of the dwelling ruins. Good idea to wear proper shoes and take water. I was there early before the sun was too intense and even then found it quite warm for the 300 steps on the stairs back up to the parking lot. Be on the look for views of other cliff dwellings in the canyon walls.

Decided to escape the heat in Phoenix for a few hours and took a drive up to see the "pre-Columbian" ruins at Walnut Canyon National Monument. This place is really pretty, especially after the spring rains, etc. It's also easy for the kids because it doesn't take very long to walk the short trail around "The Island". There are several short flights of stairs, though, but if you don't do too well with stairs you can take your time and enjoy the scenery. The trail itself is NOT wheelchair or stroller friendly. But the information building is wheelchair friendly. Also, no pets are allowed as this is a National Monument. The ranger station charges $5 per adult but children/teens under 16 yrs old are FREE.

We only had time to visit one monument during our trip and we are glad we choose walnut canyon. It can be a little challenging for those unfit like me. But my 5 year old did well with climbing up the stair case. Bear in mind there are no railing along the trail and the width is just around 5 foot. Make sure to hold your child's hand all the time as it can be quite dangerous for young children. For the fee of $5/ adult. It worth the visit.
Great historical place. Take water and wear comfortable clothing if walking trails. Not recommended for individuals with weak ankles or any walking limitations. Entrance fee was $5.

We were in the area visiting the Grand Canyon and stopped off at Walnut Canyon -- I'm glad we did! Walnut Canyon has some fantastic views, as well as cave dwellings. I highly recommend it for a relatively quick, but very cool place to visit. Just a note that it is a National Monument, so there is a fee to get in. We used our America The Beautiful park pass, which I highly recommend buying. It's $80, but it really came in handy at places we might otherwise not have visited.

What a great rest stop...OK, it's not a rest stop. It is actually a much better experience than just a quick stop to stretch your legs.
