Just east of Flagstaff (appx 7 miles) take exit 204 from either east or westbound travel on Interstate 40. The visitor center is just 3 miles from the freeway exit and well worth it. There is a trail along the canyon edge with some great views of the canyon. There is also a picnic area if you're packing your own food. For the adventurers out there, go through the visitor center to the path that leads down into the canyon. Numerous visitor that I passed on the trail sounded very stressed by the walk back up. Now I walked the trail in flip-flops...but then again, I'm a regular jogger. There are lots of stairs going down...just remember you have to come back up them. But if you go down, you'll see ancient cliff dwellings up close. Dwellings are all over the canyon walls. Being a national park means this attraction is not free...but at $5 per person (adult), you'll feel like you ripping them off...especially since your fee, once paid, is good for return visits for 7 days! Good thing there is a donation box for those wishing to contribute more...which most do. But seriously, you're driving down the Interstate just wasting away....why not stop for a couple of hours and get in a little exercise mixed with some history. Afterwards, I'll bet you'll be mighty glad you did. Are you up for the challenge?

Just east of Flagstaff off route 40, Walnut Canyon is great stop for a short (though strenuous) hike to see native american rock dwellings. The path is paved and narrow in several spots, but easily passable. There is a shorter rim trail and a longer one down in to the canyon with 240 steps (one way). The canyon is vast with great views along the way. There is an elevator in the visitor center that enables access to a viewing point high above the canyon. This was our first stop of the day heading east on 40. After Walnut Canyon, we visited Winslow, AZ (and stood on the corner....... took it easy, etc). A cool photo op. And from there out to the Petrified Forest. I would definitely recommend the stop at Walnut Canyon. Only $5 per adult and our 7 and 10 year old children were free. Make sure to fill your water bottles and stay hydrated.

Walnut Canyon is a very nice place to go and see the cliff dwellings and learn about ancient native american people.Admission is $5 and they close at 5, maybe later in summer. Very pretty and a lot of steps down and back up, you view the dwellings from a distance, great photo ops. The NPS staff made it clear that closing was at 5. They were not going to stay late.

The view from the visitor center is incredible. I went as far as 20-30 steps down. You can see the cliff dwellings from an accessible platform. Pack a little lunch and take the level and paved Rim trail. There is seating along the way and 2-3 spots where a platform gives great views. Take time to look at all of the walls and not just the area where the dwellings are still apparent. When you realize where all of the homes were located, this becomes a huge settlement. Worth the $5 fee by all means. Flora and fauna signs along the way.

The "Island" hike is a very cool hike through history. Not truly a hike, but certainly more than a walk. Well worth the short drive, $5 and the exertion to climb the stairs. Hard to capture in photos so you have to see it to appreciate it.

Walk down a path into the past 1000 years when this area was occupied by the Sinagua Tribe. Fantastic welcome center and $Million vistas. Down a path to the actual dwellings--walk right in and sit in them and wonder what life was like back then.

Walnut Creek is a quick drive outside of Flagstaff. It is a steep hike down through the gorge winding around various cliff dwellings. Along the way there are some rooms you can walk into for photo ops. The hike is on a well maintained trail but is strenuous, albeit short. There is a very nice visitor center with a small museum and gift shop. There are some trails outside of the gorge itself with picnic tables as well. Definitely worth the $5 entrance fee and drive to get such a close-up experience amongst the cliff dwelling.

A great experience for the whole family. We spanned ages 2 to 65 and everyone had a great time. The vista was just stand back in amazement good. The visitor's center was informative and child friendly. We bought a National Parks Passport and it has inspired us to visit more National Parks.

Walnut Canyon is an old favorite. I've been going here since I was a child, and it's changed very little. This isn't a flashy place, but one steeped in history. If you want to learn about native lifestyle, see old cliff dwellings, and spend a few hours in a beautiful location for a very small $$, then give it a try.

Just 3 miles off the main highway. Breathtaking views. Two hiking trails, one is easier along the rim and the other (the Island) trail takes about an hour. The island of cliff dwellings is 285 feet down and there are 185 stairs to climb down then back up. It is amazing how 300 Native American families lived in the cliffs of the steep canyon walls. There is a museum there, a souvenir shop, and rest rooms. The cost for adults is $5.00 per person and there is plenty of free parking.

This beautifully preserved park shows how the local indians lived some 900 years ago. The dwelling are dug into the cliffs, complete with kitchens, sleeping areas, and social areas. You are allowed to enter most of the dwelling areas, which our grandsons loved. It's easy to understand how they survived after visiting the Welcome Center and the signs along the trail. If you plan on going down into the canyon on the trail, speak with the Park Service Ranger first, it is a long way down, and even further up. Exhausting, but fun. There is also a trail around the rim if you are not up to the climb. If you are a senior, buy a National Parks Pass as you enter. It gets you free entry into all of the other National Parks and National Recreation Areas in America.

Again, uncertain about what we would find it turned out to be worth the time. The park sports a nice visitors center with interesting displays, clean restrooms and drinking water stations. While you can get guided tours there are two self guided tours that allow you to see the multitude of dwellings in this canyon. We chose the longer of the two, the Island Loop which had a 185ft decent. It navigates you around a central large rock formation that houses some ruins but also provides excellent views of the other dwellings throughout the canyon. I was amazed at the number. Unfortunately these ruins seem more picked over from visitors than those at Mesa Verde. Still at $5 per person it was worth this hike and our time.

So let me start off by saying that I went on this trek to please my husband; not too interested in history, etc. I was so surprised by how much I enjoyed this visit! Use your Federal annual pass for the $5/person entry.

Trails are mostly paved. Dwellings are not all original (have been rebuilt after being vandalized), but cool to see regardless. Small entrance fee, $5 I think. Lots of stairs at the beginning/end, so be prepared!

We regret that we were on a tight schedule and did not have the time to hike down the 220 plus stairs to the dwellings, but that gives us a reason to return. Nonetheless, we were able to see many dwellings from the visitor center and the rim trail. It is amazing how ingenious the dwellings are taken up natural niches in the cliffs. Very beautiful gorge like canyon. We used our annual National Park Pass to enter for free.

This is a must see while in flagstaff. Hubby and I came here on our first day in the area and was in awe! It was an amazing experience and only $5 per person. Recommend seeing this before the grand canyon - it really puts things into perspective! Do the "difficult" rated canyon hike! You get down by the ruins and see the amazing views.

Since we were staying in Flagstaff, Canyon du Chelly would have been a very tiring trip, so we opted for Walnut Canyon instead. From the time we arrived, it was fantastic. The ranger at the desk steered us to the senior's pass, which has already saved us almost $100.

The canyon was a favorite place to spend Sundays by the locals way back before the depression. It is right off I-40 just a few miles east of Flagstaff. The parking lot is right at the visitor's center, and it does cost $5 per person to get in. The visitor's center has some displays to explain the native dwellings, but all of them have been reconstructed so I suppose it's our idea of what they looked like, not necessarily what they did look like. The trail goes down and around a tight bend in a dry river bed and then back to the visitor center. It has concrete steps and wide flat concrete or crushed stone pathways. Be aware, the trail isn't long, only about a mile, but it has a great deal of vertical relief (280') and you are hiking at 7000'. That means you are walking down and back up a 28 story building, so leave extra time and stay within your limits. The trail along the top rim is flat and easy to walk and you see everything, just not up close. We visited on Aug 17th and were treated to a fantastic storm. We arrived at around 11:00 A.M. and had finished by 12:00 noon just as a huge storm arrived. The lightning hit in the canyon several times and the rain poured for over 45 minutes. Then it started hailing and the entire area filled with white slushy pea sized hail stones. What a hoot! I suppose it wouldn't be so great if you were out in it, but from the huge windows of the visitor center it was FANTASTIC! When the rain let up we walked to the rim and saw the flash flood in the riverbed below. Even if you don't get the weather to cooperate for you the way it did for us, you'll still love the hike. Take water and sun screen if it's sunny and dry clothes if it looks like rain.

We hiked down into the canyon, pausing to marvel at the views and the cliff dwellers homes. it was really lovely, but be prepared for a lot of steps, especially on the return (and it was very hot even at 10a.m. In July). Really fascinating, and so nice as few people were there to disturb the quiet nature of the place( a couple of loudish groups were not appreciated!) well worth a short detour outside of Flagstaff if on your way to or from other more well known canyons!It also is a bargain as costs just $5 if you don't have an annual pass.

This is not your run of the mill historic tourist attraction. While there is plenty of history to learn about at the visitor center you can take in as much or as little as you desire. The walk around the island is not a task and I recommend taking your time to step out of the real world. We met a 65 year old woman on the trail who was on her own. For a nominal $5 entrance fee you can spend hours looking at the beautiful scenery.

I had no idea this was here! Kind of blown away by the things that are hidden in the canyons here in Arizona. We had hoped to hike the Island Trail Loop but upon arrival we were informed that part of the Island Trail was closed for construction. I think it is opening up again in a couple days but will be closed on & off for the next few months for trail repaving. Anyway, regardless of that, it is still worth going to (especially for $5/person) because you can still hike down quite a big and get a better view of the ruins. The views are pretty amazing. Crazy to think about how they lived back then. You would have to be tough as nails! There's also a very tiny museum at the visitor center worth the quick walk through. There are quite a few steep stairs on the paved trail down which I can see being difficult for some people but there are quite a few benches a long the way if you need to take breaks. Also, if you bring small children, for goodness sake, keep an eye on them because you will be walking along a cliff that's easy to fall off of!
Well kept trails and education center, very friendly park rangers, close to hwy, check it out! Only $5 park fee.

If you are in the Flagstaff area and like History, don't miss this stop. Part of the National Park system, so there is a $5 per person charge unless you have the National Parks card. The canyon contains the remains of rock dwellings that you can walk DOWN 240 steps to reach. You are permitted to walk through the houses, browse, enjoy the scenery, etc. It feels like it is an additional 40 steps back to the top and they are steep. Warning, not really for anyone with arthritis or back problems, as the climb will really aggrivate the problem. There is a trail around the ranger station that is suitable for a lesser hike and viewing the canyon. Rangers on duty for questions and a small museum on site.

We drove to Walnut Canyon to get away from Phoenix and to see some colorful trees. We were not disappointed. The scenery was beautiful and the national monument was awe-inspiring. There is an admission fee of $5 a person but there was no problem in paying to help preserve a place as amazing as this one. It is a short drive up the freeway to the park and the monument is just inside. So, you can plan to spend to spend an hour or a day, depending on how much time you have to hike the trails. The canyon is deep and long with lots of wildlife. If you want to avoid the fee, you can drive to Old Walnut Creek Rd. It is not paved and has plenty of easily visible trail heads with parking for hikers To access it from US 40 take the exit for US 180 (Country Club Drive) and Old Walnut Creek Drive will be between the houses and the driving range.
Amazing canyon, nice easy hikes with strategically placed benches so you can enjoy the view and solitude. A short ride from Flagstaff. $5 per person seems reasonable.

I live in Flagstaff and have an annual pass, which I would recommend if you plan on visiting two other sites – Sunset Crater and Wupatki National Monument. Only for $24 you get an annual admission for an entire family.

You might compare this to Mesa Verde N.P even though it is a lot smaller, but it is very cute and an easy escape from downtown Flagstaff. The island trail is the better of the two trails offered. It is short, offering a hint of challenge in its 200+ stone steps up and down. But the views are intriguing every step of the way. The ruins of the Indian dwellings were easy and fun to explore. We did the whole trail easily under an hour and half. The entrance fee is a bit pricey - $5 per head rather than the usual per vehicle charges by Grand Canyon and other large national parks, but since we have the N.P annual pass, we had nothing to complain.

We didn't know much about this prior to arriving. We just saw it in our nerdy National Parks Passport book and thought we'd stop by while in Flagstaff. What an awesome surprise. We could not do the complete hike down to the bottom of the canyon because we had our dog with us, but very cool place. We will def return for the full hike next time we are in Flagstaff sans our pup.

Really a hidden gem, wonderful display area, wheelchair access with a scenic place to sit if you don't want to hike, great staff and scenic trail. Cheap, only $5 a car. We met people from all over the world.

Walnut Canyon is certainly not for the faint of heart as the paved trail and stairs down from the Visitors Center is tough. As you descend into the canyon on the Island Trail just remember the 240 steps you descend have to be conquered again as you ascend. Bring drinking water as there is none available in the canyon. Passing thru and past the 25 cliff dwellings is quite interesting. For folks with limited mobility there is the paved Rim Trail from where cliff dwellings can be seen but at a distance. This is definitely worth a stop.
Great National Park Service site. Lots of history and a great hike. If you can only do EITHER Sunset Crater or Walnut Canyou, go to Walnut Canyon. Fee is $5/person with kids under 16 free.
$5 charge per adult, nice historical displays & info, be sure to bring bottled water.

Walnut Canyon is right outside of Flagstaff, AZ and is definitely worth stopping by if you’re in the area. The entrance fee is only $5 per person, which is cheap for what you get. Outside the visitor center you're greeted with an amazing view of the canyon and the cliff dwellings that reside in the sides of the canyon. If you’re feeling up to it, you can walk to the bottom of the canyon for some even better views. The park ranger said it was 220 stairs or so to the bottom, but we counted 300+ from the visitor’s center down to the very end of the canyon trail. Easy walk down, not so easy on the way back up, so make sure you bring comfortable shoes and some water. At the very end of the canyon trail you walk right by cliff dwellings and get a much better idea of how people lived in them...it was pretty cool to see. We would highly recommend stopping here if you’re in the Flagstaff area as the canyon provides beautiful views, interesting sights, and a lot of stairs!

This is part of the National Parks and admission is free for Seniors with a National Park Pass ($10 one-time for life), otherwise a nominal fee. There are 240 steps down plus inclined walkways to the area of the dwellings. This is not for the physically impaired or for people of low endurance, the climb back up is somewhat taxing, but there are numerous rest stops with benches along the way. Be sure to take water with you and plan for 1-2 hours for the trip. Go at your own pace and take your time, no rush. The sights and history are amazing...just to see the living quarters of the natives who lived in the canyon 700 years ago is something to behold. Trying to imagine life during those times, it must have been extremely difficult; no wonder the life-span was so short. This is a very interesting park and we would definitely visit again when in the area.

We stopped here based solely on the fabulous reviews from TripAdvisor and we couldn't have been more pleased. Admission is only $5 and grants you up-close access to Indian cliff dwellings that are hundreds of years old. The hike up and down the canyon can be a bit taxing on most people but there are plenty of places to rest and take in the excellent views along the way.

Walk in the footsteps of people who lived at Walnut Canyon more than 700 years ago. Peer into their homes, cliff dwellings built deep within canyon walls. The presence of water in a dry land made the canyon rare and valuable to its early human inhabitants. Good museum before you start on trail. No charge with a National Park Pass -- Golden Age.

We took our family and our exchange student. We all loved it. The hike fun and the attraction as a site to see. Walnut canyon is something every small kid need to see. My boy is 4 and he did the hike all by his self. We packed a nice lunch and eat right at the park. The price is $5 a person in get in. Kid's under ( I think 15) where free.

The visit to Walnut Canyon was teemendous. Kids couldn't imagine making their home on the edges of cliffs. Truly remarkable, park rangers were great and even stopped to give us a brief description of what the canyon looked like millions of years ago. Kids got quoted the educaiton and excercise. A wonderful time. There is a fee, but it's only $5 per car and its good for all the local national monument parks, excluding the grand canyon.

i enjoyed this; everything is outdoors so go when weather is good else you will be disappointed; there is side trail which is handicapped acessible but does not go to the cliffside dwellings; you can step into some of the actual cliffside dwellings but it takes 185 steps but i did not find it difficult; young kids and older folks should be able to do it easily; visitor center has huge windows with fabulous views but the exhibits are below average; they show a video on various national monuments in the area upon request; entry fee is $5 per car; details on national park service website; you can spend between one to four hours visiting

On another trip to Arizona my family and I had visited some cliff dwellings and although they were quite beautifully preserved we were disapointed we could not get close to them. Walnut Canyon was not a disapointment. For 5 dollars a person you can walk around the whole canyon (about a 1 mile trip) and actually go into most of the dwellings left on the walls of the canyon. Some places are a little steep with no guard rails but this actually made it more exciting. The hike itself was not that hard and we highly recommend it.

Loved Walnut Canyon! It's a beautiful, historic site that can be experienced for $10 per car load. Hiking trails of various lengths for the experienced and inexperienced (we being inexperienced with two daughters, ages 6 and 9). If you can, take the 200+ stairs down into the canyon to get an up close look at old cliff dwellings - it's definitely worth the climb. We almost skipped this attraction because of cold and snow. I am very glad we braved the elements!

This park has many examples of cliff dwellings from about 1100 to 1250 AD. You can view some from a lookout behind the visitor center or by means of an easy paved half mile Rim Trail looking down into the canyon. There is also the Island Trail which has about 240 steps (most with railings) going down 185 feet into the canyon where you can enter the ruins (many of which had been destroyed by vandals many years ago). This is strenuous on the trip back up, especially since you are 6500 feet above sea level. There is a 20 minute video at the visitors center as well as a small museum. The center is open from 9 to 5 PM daily except Christmas. There is a $5 per person fee but you can use one of the Park passes (such as Senior) for entrance. To get to the park take I-40 to exit 204 and go south for 3 miles. Note that there are no stores or restaurants nearby so if you are going to be here for a long period you might want to bring lunch, drinks and snacks.

This was a real treat. It's about a 20 minute drive from Flagstaff, and just three miles off the highway. It's an activity you can fit into your day without it eating up a big portion of the day. Admission was just five dollars, and there was no additional fee for parking. Very fair value.

This was my last stop of the day and I have to say by far the best. Learn from my one mistake and if you plan on hiking down take water if it hadnt been for the nice couple in front of me who I had stuck with for the hike Im not a 100% sure I would have made it back up. They have two trails a loop trail and a rim trail. Hiking down into the loop trail has a lot of steps but if you can do it do it so worth it. Pay attention as you are going down to your surroundings the cliffs across the way also have ruins left in them. You cant get to them but you can see them and its crazy to image what it must have took to get to them. The going down those stairs is also easier than coming back up just remember you go down you must come back up. The rim trail is flat and paved and awesome if you just cant hike down into the canyon. This whole place is just beautiful and the day I went very quite and peaceful. There is a fee to visit this site but if you have a America the Beautiful pass ($80) worth it if visiting a lot of NPS areas Im not sure how much the fee was without that pass just that it does have a fee.

A gentleman from Evergreen Colorado that we ran into at a rest stop that was marketing Indian jewelry atop the switchbacks from Sedona up to Flagstaff, told us about Walnut Canyon. Our GPS found it for us and we had a great time. The walk down was easy, and the ruins were fascinating. The walk up we took more slowly, reading the information along the way. It is a beautiful sight and to try and imagine living here centuries ago, without modern conveniences...best $10 spent this trip. Visited 4/23/15.

Leave it to the government to mess up a national landmark. At $8 a ticket for our family of 5 this place is more expensive than the grand canyon! What a joke! Not to mention the snotty, condescending female employee who is the first person to great you after you enter the visitor center. Don't waste your money!

A most lovely venue with abundant nature's serenity. The artist, Julian Alden Weir, created beautiful pieces of art on a lovely hilltop location and left a legacy of art history and nature for all who venture there. Now under the Nat'l Park Service, a 13 minute film is shown and a self guided walk brochure is available. The volunteer docent, Richard, has an amazing collection of historical "moments" to share as well as thought provoking questions. What a credit to the visitor's experience. Art bags are supplied, freely, for visitors to set off and create their own piece using the trails, gardens, buildings or pond for inspiration. DO visit! Souvenirs for purchase in the Burlingham House. Buy a NPS Pass. Pond area not wheelchair accessible.

This National Historic Site, is an artists heaven! The farm is also part of the Nature Conservancy, and an art center. It is located in a "remote" part of south western Connecticut, driving through hills and winding treed backroads! It is indeed a jewel in the hills, with apple orchards, old farmhouses, rock walls, and secret gardens! The art center provides art materials, etc, for anyone who desires to paint! What a serene and inspiring peaceful place! It is a photographers dream! We will be coming back to this Weir Farm National park in the Fall for the foliage! Enjoyed our tour of the place immensely. A great family outing! Admission is free!

I so enjoyed this visit to the Weir Farm National Historic Site. They had a great video about the farm’s history and the rural home of J. Alden Weir who was an American Impressionist. They had activities set up so the children visitors could get a taste of painting in nature. I was able to get my National Park’s Passport Book stamped at the cancellation station.

This is the only place in Connecticut where you can purchase a Senior pass for all national parks in the country. It's a lifetime pass for ten dollars. The Historic site must be very pretty in the fall.

Simply amazing hike! If you are looking for a beautiful scenic hike with a challenge then this trail is for you. This hike is a 9 mile roundtrip day hike. Some sites list it as moderate, but It depends on your fitness level. If your like us and are one a month hikers, then this is difficult. It is not for the beginner hiker, you must be able to hike with appropriate gear and essentials for 4.5 miles in on rough, uneven, steep terrain. Ensure you arrive early for a place to park, the lot fills up quickly. And if you don't have a NW Forest Annual Pass, you can purchase one at the trailhead for $5 a day. If you are camping, you will need a special pass sold at local stores in town. You should really start early, especially in the warmer months for easier climbing at steep inclines. Plus you'll beat the crowd. This trail gets congested in the late mornings because most day hikers and campers are making their way to the pristine waters of Cholchec Lake. So for 2.2 miles from the trailhead to just past the footbridge, you will encounter foot traffic. But keep an eye out for the fork in the road and follow the signs to Stuart Lake to the right about a quarter of a mile past the bridge. It begins to get rocky and steep here so be prepared. If it has rained, it could be muddy as well ad as you cross over creeks and runoff. But once your on the Stuart Lake trail, you usually are alone encountering very few people. You will hike through thick forest, small patches of snow,open meadows, and great boulders, all along the Mountaineer Creek with rushing waterfalls. After another 2 miles Out of a thick area of tall evergreens Stuart Lake will surprise you on the left. Breathtaking and awe inspiring with snow capped mountain ranges all around. Find a high boulder for an unobstructed view. There are small paths leading to the waters edge all around the lake. Find one that suits you to sit, relax, picnic, and enjoy the view. If you've never been to Alaska or the Alps, then this hike is for you because this part of the Enchantments makes you think you are in some far off quiet place. The Alpine Lakes Forest Area just outside of Leavenworth is a great place to explore. Though we recommend a 4 wheel drive for the road to the trailhead, as it is not kept up and full of potholes and bumps. It is a dirt road that the runoff and snow melts usually goes down so it results in the washboard affect. Can get quite muddy when it rains, and is steep so don't bring your low rider. This trail is tough, but so worth the pain. Especially if you are the avid photographer looking for some gorgeous shots. Don't forget your camera.

Wow! We had no idea how amazing White Sands was going to be. I had seen pictures, and I was excited to see it in person, but the see the shear vastness of the dunes was so awesome! We didn't get there until about 2pm, but we could have spent all day. The visitor center was crazy busy, but it was a Saturday. We went ahead and bought two of the sleds they had there for sledding down the dunes. They were $14.99 and $16.99, and you could sell them back for $5/each if you wanted to. I didn't think that was too expensive, especially since the entrance fee was so low! Plus, why not support the park? ;)

My bucket list dreams just keep coming true! White Sands, NM was everything I dreamed it would be and more. White Sands has been on my bucket list for many years and it was so incredible to get to witness the splendor and beauty of these rare dunes. The pure white wave-like gypsum sand dunes are so dreamy and magical. As far as the eye can see is desert and white sands. White Sands is the largest gypsum sand dune in the world measuring at an astounding 275 miles long. Also, the sand is cold to the touch and I mean really cold. I was wearing flip flops and a sundress and then went barefoot and the sand was like pure ice! Within minutes I couldn't feel my feet anymore and grabbed my boots to put on. White Sands is sprawled across The Chihuahuan Desert that borders Mexico and New Mexico. They have different routes and view points where you can spend time in The Chihuahuan Desert and White Sands gypsum sand dunes. The gorgeous pristine white sand dunes are so massive and impressive. Here you can climb or sled down the dunes whatever is your hearts content. At White Sands National Monument they also have a gift shop and a museum with knowledgeable park rangers. The admission is only five dollars which is a steal of a lifetime. You'll want to make your way from The Chihuahuan Desert to The Heart of White Sands where you can see nothing but white sands as far as the eyes can see. I will never forget watching the sunset over White Sands, and my time spent here. I look forward to returning.

The monument was beautiful. The gift shop was exorbitantly expensive (as usual) but they have a buyback offer where you can return the sand sleds and wax and get money back. The $5 entrance fee isn’t much but it adds up.

My husband and I hiked the five mile trail and really enjoyed it. If I could do anything different I would have brought a disc sled, of my own. On this hike there were ample opportunities where one could hike up the trail and sled down. In a pinch I’d do the gift shop gig and buy one for $16 and sell it back for $5 (quite the gimmick really,)

We flew into El Paso (because it's cheaper to get a hotel room there),rented a car, then drove 1.5 hours to get to White Sands National Monument. The drive up was scenic and beautiful. We went the day after Christmas and it was pretty crowded at the gift shop. One reviewer mentioned watching the video there; there were so many people in the gift shop I never even saw where there was a video being shown! It was a 20 minute wait to purchase a sled (which I definitely recommend, because it's the most fun part of the experience of this park)! They offered new saucers for about $15 and if you're lucky and they're available, you can purchase a used one for $10. We were a party of 6, with three children and did just fine taking turns with one saucer. The park offers a buy back program, about $5 (on either new or used). The wax is about $2 new (you can also buy used, which I would recommend if available, because you won't use an entire block of it unless you plan to stay all day- about 8 hours) sledding the entire time. They also buy back used wax for 50 cents. The day we went, the weather was gorgeous; very few clouds in the sky. The sunlight is intense with the reflection from the white sand. If you burn easily, I'd recommend sunblock, even in winter. It was also quite windy and dry, so lip balm and plenty of water is a must. This time of year, it is advisable to dress in layers. On the sunny side of the dunes, it was quite nice and warm, however on the "dark" side, it'd be really cold and our feet were really cold on the cold sand. Our family walked the boardwalk and spent about 3 hours sledding down the dunes. Even though it was extremely crowded the day we went, there are so many dunes that we felt isolated enough in the spot we picked, which was nice. There are many variations to choose from as well, so you can choose a gradual, low slope for younger children, or a steep high slope for the more adventurous type. We did a little of both. It is quite exhausting on the legs, the traversing uphill repeatedly (we brought Arnica and were quite pleased with ourselves as our aches quickly dissipated)! The kids also slept really well that night! Also, I would say on sunny days, sunglasses are a must! Everyone in our group who didn't have them were wishing they did! After sledding, we hiked the Dune Life Nature Trail. There were many people sledding on the trail dunes and it's rather wide open; the noise making it difficult to see any actual wildlife. We did, however see some animal tracks in the sand. We also passed the time joking about the various human foot prints we saw. The views from the top are awe-inspiring. The trail is somewhat difficult to follow, however and we wound up not doing it completely because it took too much effort to try figure it out, when our bodies were already fatigued from sledding. We did enjoy reading the markers about the various animals, which was a nice touch (it should be noted we didn't have a hiking map, which could have been useful for hiking that trail). I read a review that said they have guided hikes at certain times, which I'd recommend. (We didn't know that was available.) There are covered picnic tables scattered throughout the sled/due areas. Also restrooms located throughout the park for convenience (they are drop toilets).

Worth getting off the highway when crossing New Mexico. Too easy to get fixed behind the windshield and drive 90 miles an hour going to Phoenix. Stop. Get of the road and walk the dunes. Awesome $oes not describe the experience.

Entry fee of $5 person, no charge with the NPS Senior Pass. Stop in the visitor center and watch the video before your tour. We took a self-guided driving tour along the Dunes Drive (16mile). It is actually white gypsum with wind driven dunes. The first half of the drive is paved and the remainder is not, just gypsum pressed and bumpy so be careful.

We arrived at the Visitor's Center around 2:00 pm on a Wednesday. There is both a gift shop and a National Park store in the Visitor's Center - you can get information about the park from the rangers at the National Park store. There are a few exhibits and a film about the park. If you want to try sledding (and we highly encourage trying it), you can purchase saucer sleds in the gift shop. Used sleds, when available, are $10 - unfortunately, there were not anymore available by the time we arrived. There are two varieties of new sleds, one for $15 and one for $17 - and there is a $5 buy back (if you make it back to the visitors center prior to closing, which we did not since we attended the enjoyable sunset walk). They usually also have sled wax for $2, but they were sold out of that on the day we were there. One hint for sledding - re-use an existing path where the sand is already packed down a bit instead of creating your own. You pay the $5 per person entrance fee at the gatehouse at the park entrance, which is after the Visitor's Center, and get the standard NPS map/brochure once you pay. The Visitor's Center is the only place that has running water - so fill up your bottles there before entering the park. Apply sunscreen and stay hydrated. There is no shade in this park. However, the gypsum sand is not hot and if you dig your toes down under the top layer, it actually feels cool due to the high water table and white color which does not absorb the sun's heat. We spent most of our day barefoot in this park as the sand feels wonderful and it is easier to walk without shoes that are constantly getting sand in them.

Absolutely phenomenal! For only $5, this is amazing! It's so unique and when u look out over the dunes it just all seems so foreign! Where else can u see white dunes with mountains in the background!? Definitely a must if you're in the area

The gypsum sand is cooler than the real sand , which makes it so much more fun even after sunrise and almost mid day . It is a beautiful national monument with a small gift shop in the visitor center as well. If you are driving south of the visitor center , make sure to take your passport or travel document because there is an immigration checkpoint on the other side of the road . We took our saucers from home , but you can also ask for them when you go to visitor center . if there are used ones on sale , you can buy them for $10 or new ones for $16 . dress light and carry water .

We drove about 3 hours out of our way to visit this place, and found it well worth the effort. Deep blue New Mexico skies set against the fine-granule sand was breathtaking. My son had a blast sliding down the hills on a snow saucer. (The gift shop sells them, so it's $20 for the saucer and wax.) Just don't throw yours into the wind, as it will break. The sand really stuck to our sun screened bodies, and was all over the car seats, but totally worth it.

The beautiful white sand takes you to another world, especially at dusk. I love sledding down the steep slopes and grilling out for a couple hours. You can buy sleds at the entrance store and return them at a lesser value. The sand is not as hot as you'd expect, but I still suggest bringing water. It's $5/ per person in the car, which I personally think is somewhat pricey. When they do not have an attendant right before they close or on holidays, you can enter the park for free.

I've traveled a lot and this was one of the most amazing places I've been. It's like nothing else. I recommend going later in the day and staying through sunset. Watching the sunset and seeing the colors change in the sky from blue to pink/purple was amazing. There is a peaceful feeling here. The moon rose making it even more amazing. There were some bluish streaks that came up and looked almost magical. I drove 7/5 hours roundtrip from Albuquerque and glad I did! Also it's very inexpensive to go in! $5.

While this location is in the middle of nowhere, it's worth the memory with the kids. We purchased sleds ($10 used) and wax($2) and got a refund for returning ($3). Go early in the morning or later in the day to handle the heat. Keep hydrated because the wind gives the illusion of staying cooler than you really are. Kids also worked on junior ranger badges. 2-3 hour visit.

This is an incredible place to visit. The landscape is just unlike any other. I highly recommend stopping at the visitor's center and asking the Park Ranger's questions. They were very helpful. I was interested in two things: sledding down the sand dunes and photographing ripples and yuccas. The PR recommended driving the loop to see how the terrain/vegetation changes - the closer to the visitor's center the more vegetation, and the farther out the larger the dunes (crests and ripples) and less to no vegetation. New and pre-owned sleds may be purchased in the store behind the visitor's center. I can't think of a compelling reason to purchase a new sled... At the end of your visit you can turn the sled in and get some dollars back...

First, stop at the bookstore to watch the movie. Next, go slide down the dunes! Make sure you buy your sleds at the Walmart in Alamogordo - they are only $5.88 compared to the ridiculous prices they charge here. Also, we didn't see any difference between using the wax and not using it so I wouldn't bother wasting the $2 at the gift shop to buy it. We had a little trouble getting going down the hills at first, but soon realized the steeper the hill the easier it is. Bring plenty of water, sunglasses, and sunscreen!

My husband & I applied and paid for early entry to White Sands Nat'l Monument. The ranger met us at the gate at 5:00am and let us in. We paid $100.00 for two hour early entrance. It was so worth it. With our head lamps, flashlight and camera we hiked along the alkaline trail. It was a calm morning. We watched the moon set behind the mountains and watched the sunrise. Our photos were amazing. We came across many animal tracks including a bobcat. We were all alone and it was so quiet. My husband & I also participated in the ranger led sunset stroll. It was pleasant and informative. We also captured some nice photographic moments on that tour. This monument is absolutely stunning!

I was eagerly looking forward to seeing this spot. Was.Not.Disappointed.... I loved every minute. To kicking off my shoes and walking up and down the dunes. Feeling the wind in my face. People enjoying the view but finding spots all to yourself. I even loved to cute picnic spots with the aluminum shades. Would love to go back again.

If you are in the area (within 3 hours) visit this National Monument. It is truly and amazing place. While you already know you are in the desert, to see these white sand dunes in the middle of the more "brown" desert is stunning. There is a very good video you can watch in the Visitor Center. Take the time to do that. It is worth it. Also, it isn't all that long. Buy a sledding saucer and a hunk of wax in the gift shop and then take a drive out into the dunes. There is a boardwalk you visit. It is only about a thousand yards long. It is elevated above the dunes. The dunes in this area are pretty small. Drive further back in to the dunes. They can get quite large. There are several spots where you can picnic and play in the dunes. We picked an area where there appeared to be people who visit the dunes often. We asked some questions about "sledding" and they gave us some good advice. It was a blast to get to ride the saucer we had purchased down the dunes. At the end of your visit you can return the saucer you purchased and get $5 back off your purchase price. So you don't have to worry about being stuck hauling a saucer back home with you.

I wasn't expecting much, how exciting could a bunch of sand be after all? I have changed my mind after visiting. The visitor center isn't huge but the staff is friendly and eager to answer questions. Don't miss the movie about the monument. It's very informative and shows breathtaking photos of the area. Usually these movies are kinda boring for little kids but this one kept the attention of several small children when we were there. This is a great day trip or worth the stop if your in the area. Oh and only $5 to get in if I remember right.

Don't expect much here. It is one of those "been there done that" type of places. You pay $5 a person to go in and drive around the loop and look at white sand dunes. Yes, they are pretty but nothing terribly amazing. If you have been to the Gulf Coast in Florida this is just about the same without the water. What could be fun is you can sled down the dunes. Fun for all ages, but really all there is to do or see. Picnic areas are available. Alright for a quick thing to see but nothing impressive and no activities or sights other than this.

White sand dunes for as far as you can see. Fun place to hike and some people bring snow sled disks to slide down the dunes. Camping is available for $3/night if you would like to pack your gear in about 1 mile. Be sure to wear sunscreen and sun glasses. After a few minutes the bright sun on the white sand really makes the eyes hurt. Very interesting place.

Went to El Paso to visit my son and daughter in-law and made the 1.5 hour trek to White Sands. This is a awesome place, amazing views, nice visitor center. Sledding down the dunes was fun but kind of expensive for the sled $20 or so but you get $5 back if you return it. Well recommended.

A beautiful unique national park with good value. $5 per person and free for under 16. It was very cool to see the gypsum dunes and the unique plant life. My daughter really enjoyed the activity book and being sworn in as a junior ranger, so be sure to stop by the ranger station before you venture into the park for this extra (and free) part of the experience. We even saw a roadrunner crossing the road a short distance from the park entrance, but that was just about the only animal we saw besides a raven and another bird. Although the experience was good it is such a trek to get to the park that I do not think I would come back unless I happened to be in Las Cruces or Alamogordo.

We had a great time at the dunes. Definitely buy your sleds at the Alamogordo Walmart for $5.88 before heading out there and make sure you are filled up with gas. There is not much out there. The sleds in the gift shop were $16.99 and you got $5 back if you turned them back in. Also take water and sunscreen, the sun is hot even when the temp is cooler. I would recommend to take a lunch, they have ample picnic tables. We hiked back toward the lakes, it was so beautiful.

Stop at the visitor center and pick up sleds for the family. If it's busy find someone returning a sled and offer them $3. No one has to stand in line and its a win win. We went twice once around 3pm (85 degrees) and again at 8am (40 degrees). Our young children loved it and could have spent more time. Bring water and sun block. The pictures we took came out great and kept my husband busy while we played in the sand.

Sledding on the dunes is so much fun and if you buy the sleds at a local walmart they are much cheaper than what the park charges from 12-18 dollars a sled. Its good to continue to drive out about 5-6 miles into the park to get the good steep dunes.

Our family (two parents and kids aged 11, 9, 8 and 4) ADORED this place. We visited in late February and the weather was perfect, about 65F. And the sand was cool, even cold in some places! I figured we'd need our sneakers to get the most out of hiking and sledding, but our kids immediately stripped off their shoes and socks and ran out onto the dunes, and I'm so glad we adults did the same. Feeling that absolutely pristine sand on your feet is truly magical and was my favorite part of being there! (Unlike even the nicest beaches, which have shells, seaweed, etc., this sand has NOTHING in it. It's like walking on sugar.) Even in winter you definitely still need a hat with a brim, water, sunscreen (I burnt the back of my neck) and above all, sunglasses, both for glare and for wind-- we even brought goggles, which some of our kids preferred. You buy sleds at the visitor center/gift shop (all one building) for around $15, and they give you a $5 rebate for returning them, so consider it a rental. (They also sell used sleds for more like $10, but these are in high demand.) Buy the wax too. (It's dirt cheap and they still rebate you for returning it.) The dunes are enormous and some have pretty sheer drops, but you can sled down these steep slopes without fear because it's sand, not ice, so it's not slippery or fast (which is why you do need the wax)-- it was a pretty mild or even slow ride for adults sometimes, though kids went faster. Climbing back up is challenging, but there's always a slower-but-easier way up by taking the farther end of the dune with less of a grade. My kids had a blast, not only sledding, but playing, digging, burying their feet, writing silly messages, and acting out scenes from various movies. As for me, I was surprised by how much I enjoyed not only sledding, but also just the vast and otherworldly landscape, the mysteriousness of it (along with the history involving space shuttles and missile testing) and the experience of wandering barefoot through all this delightfully soft sand! Does sand get all over everything? Sure-- but it's a lot easier to clean off than beach sand because it's not wet. And putting those socks and shoes back on? Well, we rinsed our feet with a little leftover canteen water and all was well. (You dry instantly; it's a desert!)

We stopped in the visitor center and purchased sleds (@ $15 each) for use on the dunes. We drove to a couple of spots and played on the dunes. Bring sunglasses because it is very bright and hard on the eyes. The sand feels like sugar and doesn't stick to you. The sand itself was also rather cool even though it was a warm day. Bathrooms are available at the visitor center and at the back of the park. Although it is not a "typical" bathroom with running water, they were clean. If you are in this part of New Mexico, make a point to spend some time here. Entrance fee was $5 per person. They also have a really nice gift shop if you like jewelry.

I am sure glad that we stopped at white sands. It is just beautiful. The sand (gypsum) feels like it is wet and very cool but it is dry. We walked out on the boardwalk on one of the stops of the drive and the temp was really cool. As soon as we drove out of the sands the temp raised. We are from MN so we have snow but this white was completely different. We could see where they plowed the road because the wind had drifted the sand. You can buy sleds to go sliding but we didn't. The cost was $5.00 per adult to drive through but there was a sign that said the booth was closed and to keep driving. This place was great! If you get the chance, go see it!

We allowed 3 hours on Dunes Drive in the afternoon (2-5 PM) so we could even attend the 4-5 PM sunset tour. Entering Dunes Drive can take a long time as there could be a long line of cars, each paying $5pp to enter.

This place exceeded all expectations! Beautiful white sands that stretch for miles and mountain vistas provide a visual that must be experienced. Wax up your plastic disc, $10 at gift shop, and slide down the dunes. Teenagers loved it but perfect for all ages.

We arrived to white sands late in the afternoon after a long drive. It did not disappoint. We only had an hour as the sun began to set and big billowy clouds started darkening and threatening to rain. We ran up and down the dunes in search of the steepest hills to slide down. The visitors center has plastic sleds for sale for $15 or $20(I can't remember which) you can return them after use for a refund of $5. They also encourage you to buy wax for the sleds for another $2-if you can come prepared with your own, you can save a little money. The dunes are unbelievably, magically beautiful and the sky unreal. It started to rain as the sun went down so we didn't have time to explore the boardwalk. It was definitely worth the trip there! Tip: bring your own bottled water and snacks as this place is out in the middle of vast nothingness. There's a cool picnic area there. It's a great place for photo ops-bring something special that would look great on a sand dune!

This place is different. They sell sleds so one can slide down the dunes. The hiking and driving trails are through the variety of dunes. It cost $5 / person to enter but worth it. Visitor centre is free & there is a gift shop on the other side of outdoor patio.
Was so much fun, came back the second day. $17 for a $5 saucer (I broke one of the three, might recommend a heavier duty if you are over 125 lbs) is a small price for the day(s) of fun. BRING WATER.

This place is a must stop if you are traveling in New Mexico. Some must dos: The sunset walk - our ranger was phenomenal! And you must go sledding!! (They sell saucers at the visitorʻs center - and you get $5 back if you return it in good condition.) And you must go barefoot - the gypsum does not get hot at all, unlike sand. (We went sledding at 11:00 am) Do it!!

This place is really Amazing and Surreal! Don't miss the sunset! We did 6.45pm free sunset walk with Ranger. It was ok but the sunset was beautiful! We have been to North Carolina OBX Jockey's Ridge Sand Dunes and loved it but White Sand is even better! Make sure you buy sand disk ($15) from the visitors center, sometimes there are used ones available for $5 less. It's well worth the money!

You drive about a 9 mile loop through some of the most dramatic scenery you can see, the largest gypsum sand dunes in the world. You can buy a sled at the gift shop and they will even buy it back from you after you try the dunes. Gift shop is fun and the visitor center staff is friendly and informative. Admission at the time we visited was $5 per person. You can simply drive through, stop to take photographs, hike, picnic, climb the dunes or sled down them.

Beautiful, slightly eerie terrain was super interesting to drive through and to walk amongst the dunes. Visited White Sands in mid-August, and temps were in the upper 80s which means being aware of hydration. No water available after passing the visitor center, so be sure to carry some with you. Our dogs enjoyed getting out of the car and walking, but quickly decided they had enough. Several of the special programs sound interesting, especially those at dusk and at night, and we'll try them out when we are in the area again. Free entrance for Senior Pass holders.

Amazing to see such spectacular cloudscapes. The clouds really stole the show for me. I went in the middle of the day so I chose not to hike although I saw others hiking. Important to note that the ranger led program is at 11am each day and that there are often ranger led programs at in the evening. If it's possible, I'd suggest visiting in the early morning or at twilight as it should be somewhat cooler then. You can sled down the dunes although some of the people I saw doing that seemed to struggle a bit as the sleds got stuck. Sleds are for sale in the gift shop for about $15 although they can be sold back at the end of the day for a nominal amount. If wager with kids, sleds are the way to go although I did see adults sans kids buying sleds too. I drove five hours to be here and didn't regret it - don't miss, especially if you're in the area!

Entrance to the park is $5 per person, and Wow! It's the most amazing place. Softest sand ever, and dunes to climb. Dogs on a leash are okay and they love it! Be sure to see this uniquely beautiful part of New Mexico.

I highly recommend this park as a place to visit while in NM. It costs $5 a person and then the ticket is good for 7 days after purchase. We were thrilled. You can drive around the dunes and there are many opportunities to pull over and walk over the sand. We were there on a Friday and it wasn't crowded at all. Such a beautiful place!

Stopped off to take a walking break. No fee with my National Parks Pass. After about 1/4 mile in the white sands become quite prominent in large dunes. Along the way there are parking lots with restrooms and walking trails. On some dunes people were sliding down on snow boards. At one stop a raised walkway with several info cards extends about a quarter mile into the dunes. Farther back the paved road turns to packed sand..one could imagine driving on a snowy road with the beauty and no danger. There is a gift shop but we had a long drive ahead of us so left. Maybe next time.

Rented a used saucer sled for $10. Wax cube was $1.99. You get $3 back when you return saucer sled. Glad we bought wax cube , others that didn't wax the sled were having difficulty sledding down the slopes. We got a sled for both kids. Very hot. Be sure to use sunscreen and bring sunglasses. The glare off the white sand is hard to deal with without sunglasses. Good informational video in visitors center. I thought it was pricey for no longer than my kids could tolerate the heat and walking back up hill in the sand everytime they went down . Lots of fun though.
We hit the visitor center first and then paid our $5 each to drive back into the sand dunes. AMAZING!!!

The guy at the visitor center was very helpful and knowledgeable. If you have a national park passport the guy behind the desk has the memorial 100yr stamp that is kept behind the desk. The others are available near the entrance. Lots of things to do and see at the visitor center. You will not pay for entry here but at the toll booth as you drive towards the booth. If you plan to visit a bunch of parks and have more than 3 people it might be economical to get a national park pass. Saves you a bunch of money. If you plan on doing the sledding they sell those at the back of the gift shop for $15. I would more recommend you catching someone on the way back in and ask to purchase them for $6 the store will give you $5 dollars back if you hand them back in (if they are new or $3 for used). The dunes itself is odd and interesting. It is truly white but it feels like plastic and not sand. It's really wierd. the sleds aren't that awesome it's more like a slowish decline than a sledding experience. Still my son and husband had fun. You can walk anywhere you like. They had additional activities after hours and treks/hikes that are guided. Sunsets here are pretty. Make sure you buy some water if you dont already have some at the shop prior to going into the parks.

Snowboarding on winter...... Sand boarding on summer. The place is so majestic .... White sand dunes that expand several miles. You will be wondering how can this place be different from adjacent areas. The place is so cool. The sand which look like and feel like refined sugar. What's amazing is that the sand is cool and never warmed up even if the temp is greater than 100. It's made of gypsum crystals that don't absorb sun heat. Love walking barefoot and see your footprints. Kids of all ages enjoying sand boarding or just rolling on the dunes. Minimal fee of $5 it's worth it. There's a lot picnic areas and restrooms around the 8 mile loop. You will also appreciate the flora and fauna in the area.

We went in the morning (and it was VERY hot) but returned in the evening for the sunset experience. A light breeze was blowing across the dunes and the heat of the day was dissipating as the sun began to set. We took lots of pictures and enjoyed the beautiful sight and experience of being there at sunset. The movie in the visitor's center and the gift shop were fun as well. The park provides valuable information about the difficulty and length of various hikes. Pay attention to the recommendations and you will enjoy your hiking experience.

Took the grand kids to white sands for a end of school year celebration. We purchased sleds at the visitor center. Word of advice make a stop by Wall Mart first and buy your sleds there. Wall Mart price 6 bucks, white sands fifteen dollars.

We went in June in the afternoon (dumb, I know) so it was super hot! Visitors center was super informative, dunes were tons of fun for us & the kids (bought sleds for $6 at the Walmart on the way...cheaper than renting). There's a pump-type wash-off station at the visitors center that our kids soaked themselves in & loved it!

White Sands is truly an amazing destination, quite unlike anywhere else. The dunes are mesmerizing and the views everywhere are sure to stir your spirit. If you want to surf the dunes, you can bring your own board/sled/disk or you can purchase a disk in the very cool gift shop. Make sure you bring a couple quarts of water per person if you're going to hike out a couple miles. Entry in to the gift shop and monument area (none dune entry) is free to the public. Entry in to the dune's area is $5 a person. If you take advantage of the opportunity to schedule a visit when there's a full moon, you'll be glad you did. The sight of it is breathtaking and quite transcendent.
Wow - this place is beautiful. It's so strange that it's breath taking. You can buy a $10 sled at the visitor center and sled down the sand if you want. We will certainly be back.

We stopped to get our National Passport Book stamped and found a very nice female ranger explain what they had there. We drove down the road to see the dunes, it was amazing until we got off road, then it was like driving over a wash board. We were afraid the vehicle was going to fall apart it was so bumpy, it shook everything. We had to turn around. It was beautiful what we saw. We are from the gulf side of Fl. So we have seen some beautiful white sandy beaches. Don't miss it, right off the highway. Prepare for a bumpy ride once you get to the marked area that says there isn't anymore paved road!

While driving down the road you can see this place from over 25miles away. It's an amazing sight. About 15minutes south of Alamogordo. I recommend you watch the 15minute video. If your gonna do some hiking take a could gallons of water with you. You can drive around, get out walk on the dunes and slide down them. They sell these disks to use to slide down for $16. buy them back from you for $5 and sell them used for $10. I was told cardboard doesn't seem to work very well. I would bet you could find one around town somewhere like Walmart.

Amazing area of white sands. You would think you were at the beach. Lots of great photography shots. You must get a disk from Walmart or ask your hotel if you can borrow one and go down a slope. They sell disk at park at inflated price. Will buy it back for $5. We gave ours to another family at the desk. Spent about 2 hours there.

Been there many times with friends and family. Huge dunes of gypsum or so called white sands. Drive around or take a tour, google ahead to find out tour times, a Ranger will tell you history, plants, insects, animals of area. Moon light tours are a hit and also have movie night which shows all plants, animals of white sands. The Park also has various activities during summer, entertainment of various sorts so google or go to their website. A gift shop in front and back has interesting and different things to buy, also can buy a sand disk, pricey 17 dollars and wax for bottom to make disk go faster on dukes. Bring water, hat, a kite for kids is a hit, bathrooms are available thru out area, so we usually park near one. Bring your guitar in evening and friends, hot, hot during day, cool in evening, have several shaded areas for picnic lunch. Bring sandals, you will get sand all over vehicle, so use mat to stand on and brush sand off feet and sandals. Bring camera, pictures come out fantastic.

If you plan on sledding at the White Sands Monument, stop at (or continue into) Alamogordo and go to the Walmart to buy your sleds. They are currently $5.88 each whereas the park charges you 14.99 for the exact same sled. Even if you get a used sled and sell it back at the end of the day, it is still cheaper to buy the Walmart sled (it is the same one they sell at the park).

A friend said, just go to a beach for white sands, why are you going to a desert? We I dunno, I want to check it out. At first I was a little disappointed til I climbed the dunes and saw the view. Just like every post card or picture Ive see. Beautiful. We bought sleds at the Alamogordo Walmart for 4.98 instead of the $15 they charge at the gift shop. We just gave it to some family on the way out so they could pass along the savings. Tough to take pics because it was so sunny you had no idea what was on your screen. We brought water, a compass and a few other survival things cuz yes, it would be very easy to get turned around if you decided to walk a bit.

We spent an afternoon at White Sands National Monument and wished we'd have had more time to explore. The park is deceptively large and it's easy to underestimate how much there is to see. There is only one road that drives into the dunes and then loops back on itself, but on each side are wide swaths of dunes that stretch into the distance. There are parking areas all around where you can leave the car to enjoy the dunes. Each of the dunes is made of fine, soft gypsum sand that looks like something from Mars. You need only park your car and climb to the other side of the nearest dune to lose sight of civilization and feel like you're exploring uncharted wilderness! There are two formal hiking trails and one boardwalk. When we were there, the shorter hiking trail was closed so we walked the boardwalk instead and it took about 20 minutes to walk to the end and back. Then we drove to the end of the road and used our plastic sleds to sled down several of the closer dunes. The park was busy and there were families on each dune all around us. After a while, we started to hike the longer trail which winds into the Alkali Flats. However, it can take up to 3 hours to hike the entire marked trail loop so we made a casual circuit and headed back to the car. I'd suggest taking your sleds on that trail because some of the largest dunes in the park are off the road on the way to the Alkali Flats. BTW, the sleds can be purchased at the gift shop ($10-17 each, as I recall, and they will buy them back for $5) or you can bring any type of rigid plastic disc yourself. The park entrance fee was $5 per person.

We loved this place. 1st thing to do is stop at the visitors center & buy a disk type sled. They have used ones for $10.00 & they buy them back for $3.00. Next, drive to the back of the park & there are higher dunes with less people. We walked in a little ways to get to some of the biggest dunes. We went barefoot because the sand is cool & shoes are just going to get in the way. The dunes can be tough to climb but they're a blast to slide down. 2 hours here was plenty of time because all the climbing really wears you out. Don't forget the sunblock & don't waste your money on the sled wax.

First off, this place is amazing! You will not likely see anything else like it anywhere else. The dunes are very soft and sandy. My kids love it. There are snow/sand sleds for sale at the visitor center for sale for $25. There is a Walmart about 20 minutes away in Alamagordo that sells the sleds for $5-6 and they're made in the USA. I bought 5 of them there for the same price as only one from the visitor center. These may be seasonal items so you might want to call the Walmart and ask first if they have them in stock. You can get wax at the visitor center to lube the sleds so they can slide down the dunes faster but I hear a simple wax candle could give the same effect. There are covered patios next to the dunes for you to sit with small charcoal grills. Take plenty of drinks and sun screen.

There's something about the desert that calms me, and White Sands was no exception. I watched a breathtaking sunset from the dunes. Highly recommended you plan your visit to include a sunset! The visitor center gift shop is a little spendy. You can buy a new sled for $17 or a used sled for a lesser cost. I got mine for $10. It is what we call a "flying saucer" back home and is the exact same kind you'd use to slide down a snowbank (so if you're from a place that experiences winter, bring the one you have tucked away in your garage and save some money!). Also, don't expect a big adrenaline rush: I think my top speed was maybe 2.0 MPH. Other tips: bring water and pay attention to where you're going! If you venture out into the sand, everything starts to look the same after a while, so please be careful not to get lost.

The dunes are a lot of fun to wonder in and around. The store at the beginning has discs to slide down the dunes with. The new discs are around $25, I think, but since they have a buy back program, they had lots of used discs for around $10.

I had been really curious about visiting this monument for some time now and while staying in Socorro for work, I took the scenic drive out to White Sands and I wasn't disappointed. For 5 dollars, I was granted entry into the site and was almost immediately greeted by the beautiful white sand dunes on both sides of the road. This attraction would be excellent for that person who just wants to relax and marvel at the wonder that is nature. There were kids sledding down the dunes, families cranking up their bbq and generally people just relaxing about the park enjoying this marvel. I came around sunset so being able to sit on a dune and watch the sun set and if you've been to New Mexico you know that their sunsets can't truly be described, now that was the icing on the cake. I would highly recommend this attraction and the free 5pm ranger tour offered is also something to do in the evening.

This place only costs $5 per person to get in, and is worth the trip. Its a couple mile drive in a circle, but the point is to get out and take a walk. Enjoy the view, bring a discus to sled, enjoy! They had plenty of parking, plenty of restroom facilities, and maps and informational plaques. Worth the trip to see.
White sand dunes with mountainous background offers a pleasant experience. Feels like you are in a completely different place after driving from Alamogordo which is just few miles away

We had a blast here. The view from the boardwalk (the first stop) is a bit deceiving as it looks like the place isn't that big and isn't that pretty. But its a good place to let the kids start climbing the hills. We rented the hard plastic sleds to go sledding down the hills - it was $15 a sled with a $5 return if you got them back before closing. We drove to the back of the road area and found an area with a large parking lot and a large hill. Climbing up the sand is a chore for sure, but it was a blast sledding down the sand! Even my 4 y.o. timid little boy had a blast and got brave enough to go down the larger hills. You do get sand everywhere and since it was cold out, we had it in our coats and our shoes. Well worth the visit, even at 46 degrees we spent about 2 hours sledding down the sand. I wish we would have had more time to do some hiking after we were done sledding. This is a great stop between Albuquerque and El Paso. Well worth the time. We plan to go again when its warmer to enjoy the sand sledding again and to do some hiking around the area.

In the middle of "nowhere" but wow what a place. All this soft bright white sand and sun surrounded by mountains... So neat and beautiful! Rent sleds at the visitor center like $10 to rent but you get $3 back when you return them... Get one sled per person don't share! Go off the beaten path for excellent steep Dunes to slide! Bring water the beating sun and walking up Dunes will wear you out! Wear sunscreen too! Sun is constant! You would only need one to two hours here.

My husband and I took our 2 grandkids, age 6 and 8 to white sands and they had a blast! I never want to forget their contagious laughing from having so much fun sliding down the sand dunes!!! They probably climbed up and slid down at least a hundred times! We bought 2 round sled discs at Big 5 sporting goods in Almagordo for just $10 each. Before Whitesands, we took them to Peter Piper Pizza for lunch, and White Sands was a hundred times more fun than Peter Piper Pizza! Admission for White Sands was only $10 so it was an economical but super enjoyable and made memories we won't forget! My husband and I actually went 2 years ago, just the two of us and have fun ourselves sliding down the hills and taking fun couple pictures! They have nice picnic areas and bbq grills. It as about a 40 minute drive back to Las Cruces where we were staying. Enjoy making your own memories there!

White Sands National Monument was yet another wonderful attraction that saw while visiting New Mexico. It is an amazing site. A few miles before you approach the actual entrance to the Monument Site, you will start seeing the sand dunes several yards from the thruway. Just the beginning of something "amazing". Once you arrive at the Visitor's Center, be sure to watch the 17 minuite movie which explains the HOW and the WHY of what you are going to see. Just can't say it enough....it is simply AMAZING. Once you have had a chance to spend some time in the center and the gift shop, you will get in you car and drive around to the back of the center and to the gate house for an amazing 8 mile ride though the White Sands dunes. (Don't forget to buy some water at the gift shop.....there is no drinkable water in the park. But there are port a potties available and also some nice picnic tables. Several miles in there is a raised walkway where you can walk over the sand and observe signage of the various plant like. It's a fun walk and the whole way with all that sand you could easily expect or at least wish the ocean was at the end. As you continue your drive the road will eventually loop back to the Visitor's center. You will see people at the top of the dune sledding down on the sand. (Note: we were there in October so it was sunny but not too hot). We were in such awe that we came back to the park about 6PM and drove back into the dunes and waited for the sunset. With the sun going down the dunes and the vetegtation looked so different in the evening light. It was AMAZING. So glad we took to time to see in at night. The Park Rangers do come around about 7:30PM to make sure everyone is out of the park. If you are a Senior Citizen, don't forget to use you Senior Park Pass...it is good at National Monuments as well as National Parks.

My husband and I visited White Sands in mid October. What a magical, wonderful place. Just as I'd read, even though the day was warm, the sand was perfectly cool to the touch. We took a tour called the "Sunset Stroll". I highly recommend this tour especially if you're short on time, as we were. You go out for about an hour with a ranger who gives an interesting and funny narrative about white sands, it's vegetation, animals and history of how it came to be. Entrance into the attraction is $5 per person. There are large dunes that you can sled ride on, but we didn't get to do that this time around. Sleds are "sold" to visitors, then when you return them, you get most of the $$ back, so it's basically a rental. Check out the website as there are various events going on there all year around. They have a full moon event that sounded particularly interesting. If you happen to be in New Mexico, try to make time for White Sands. You'll be glad you did.

White Sands is a beautiful place to visit. Plan your trip to get there in the early morning or evening as its hot! We purchased some sleds in the gift shop and they are $15. Sledding really isn't that great as its pretty slow going down the hills but still fun.

I love this. Its a great place to take your family. I wish I was in town for the stroll at night. Nature at its best. You can purchase sleds to ride down the dunes. I don't think sleds is the right word…more like large disc. Once you use them for the day they will buy them back for $5. If your in the area you must stop by. I would go back and would recommend.

What a treat to have visited White Sands during our recent trip to New Mexico. Take water before you embark on the self-guided drive, because there are no water stations in White Sands (apart from the Visitors Center). The sand itself is soft as powder and just as white. Massive dunes create an almost other-worldly feel and it was great fun to take a short hike over several of the dunes. One caveat: if you're interested in sledding down a dune, buy a used sled and save yourself $7 (you can return the sled and get back $3 of the $10 for a used sled). For whatever reason, the sled did not work on any of the dunes we tried, but that did not mar what was an otherwise fantastic excursion.

This place blows my mind. When you hike out on the dunes, you're in another world. Give yourself time to really enjoy. The Alkaline Flats trail is the only real hiking trail. Be aware it is 5 miles and the dunes are like walking on mountains of loose beach sand. That said, it is so worth the effort. Take lots of water and hike early or late if possible. A little lite snack comes in handy. Since the white sand reflects the sun up, be sure to use lots of sunscreen. Wear a hat. The Ranger walk is late afternoon and is worth planning for. Night views are amazing if you can manage it (just before closing). Few is nominal but if you're a senior, invest the $10 in a senior pass and never pay another few at a National Park or Monument the rest of your life.

Came to Alamogordo specifically for White Sands. Had a great time. Doesn't seem like it can get hot out here but it actually does. I didn't venture way out into the hiking areas. Stayed close to my car and people. Easy to get lost and turned around as the hills started to look alike. Recommend bring an ice chest with plenty of water and snacks. They have a picnic area and restrooms. BBQ grills. Price is good and not crowded. Get a bigger gift shop. Wear comfortable shoes as this is a workout. I wore flip flops due to the sand. Brought a fitted bed sheet and some old blankets for my car seats. Gift shop has a fountain to rinse your legs and feet afterwards. Nice family getaway with kids. Check with the local hotels for complimentary sleds or bring one. Overpriced in my opinion $16 and they really don't give you a lot back if you return it for cash back. Get the sled/disc at the gift shop before going into the park. I would recommend a rental option. Nice if I lived here but as a visitor and not living in a snow area I have no other use for this disc and it doesn't even say White Sands on it to be used as a souvenir. Good time. Recommend a compass, sun tan lotion, hat, baby powder to get the sand off, backpack, sunglasses, mirror in case you need to signal help. Two water bottles at min per person.
Easy stop along the way. Buy a saucer and slide down the sand. They give you $3 credit if you bring it back. Very friendly staff and good gift shop.

Although there was an entrance and what appeared to be an entrance fee, there was no one to take payment, so we drove in until we saw cars parked. When we got out, we walked away from the (not large) crowds and within 3 minutes of walking, were totally alone in this incredible desert of white sand! We stayed for about 30 minutes marveling at the epic-ness and took many many photos (including making sand angels!)

Check the schedule for Full Moon Nights which feature live music. Attracts lots of families/older folks/young people, bring your lawn chairs & coolers & snow sleds. Kids love to sled in the sand dunes while parents enjoy the music. Porta Pottys available, bring a flashlight and/or glow sticks. Beer & wine allowed, lots of rangers assure order & safety. Cost is only $3 per adult, kids are free. We go every year, highly recommend it!

It's not the beach sand us East Coasters are used to that's for sure. Went 1st to the visitor center to watch a movie regarding the formation of the sand dunes & the geography. THis is also where you go to purchase a sled & wax if you want to attempt going down the dunes. No need to buy/rent a new sled, the used ones are cheaper but both can be resold back to the gift shop for a small refund (as long as you have your receipt). The park was only $3pp to get in.
