So, this was one of those unexpected road trips where three middle-agers and one "millennial" found themselves trapped in the same car for eight hours, and while passing by White Sands National Monument someone happened to muse out loud, "Why not?" (as if being in the scorching hot desert sun in mid-August nearing lunch time is not reason enough!). With all of us in much need of levity, I was delighted to find plastic saucer sleds for sale in the nifty gift shop, $10 used and $15 new with the option to return on your way out of the park for a $3 or $5 refund, respectively. For an extra $1.99 you can purchase a square of wax which very much resembles a cube of pool chalk; the idea being that the sled will glide easier and faster if it is waxed on the bottom. This held some appeal due to a secret fear that my expanded backside would weigh down the saucer sled, resulting in an anti-climactic two-inch slide before coming to a complete stop. With our purchase of one used saucer sled, one cube of wax and four bottles of water we made our way to the entry gate and were pleased to find admission to be $3 per person and free for ages fifteen and under. I can't think of any "attraction" I've been to recently where one can gain entry so inexpensively! We snaked our way through the park, past several picnic tables and outdoor bathrooms, and finally found a perfectly secluded dune of moderate slope to try out our saucer sled. I found climbing the dune somewhat of a challenge as my calves fought against the resistance of sinking sand. Having visions of a Griswoldian experience, though, I eagerly waxed up my sled and insisted on "ladies first". To my expected disappointment, I slid about a foot before coming to a complete stop. It was real work scooching the saucer sled down to the bottom of the dune only to have to trudge back up and hand off to someone else. It was slightly reassuring that our youngest member and our thinnest member had about the same lack of success. The winner, in fact, was one of our middle-agers, a little round in the belly area, who tackled the saucer "penquin-style". He was able to slide down the dune with a fair amount of speed on his stomach and with a little bit of a running start. We spent about an hour exploring and attempting to slide before finding ourselves exhausted in the brutal heat and sun. There was a brief moment of panic when our key would not open the trunk, allowing access to our cooler and water, particularly when I noticed that we had no cell phone reception. I can see how someone might become suddenly overwhelmed with heat exhaustion, so please prepare, bring plenty of water and pay attention to your bodies! In all, we had a fun and memorable experience. It was certainly good for a few laughs. Next time, however, I might try to get ahold of some of that non-nutrative cereal varish to assist with the whole sledding endeavor.

My boyfriend and I took a day trip up here from El Paso. We got there right before sunset, took some time going down the dunes in sleds we rented from the gift shop ($10 and you get some money back when you return them, but the shop was closed when we left). Amazing photo opportunities for sunset. The weather was nice and cool at that time too!

First let's say to check the temperature and go hiking only during the cooler parts of the day. Temperatures can reach over 100 degrees. Our day it was a "mild" 88 degrees. At the Welcome Center, be sure to rent ($7 after deposit returned) a sled so you can "sled the dunes". An eight mile loop where you can choose whatever dune suits your needs. We choose the tallest we could find. We shared a sled so it was a good $7 spent. NOTE: Two different sleds for different weights. They also have trails to venture onto and a sunset walk and talk. We didn't do the walk/talk, but went back out to "our dune" and watched the sunset over the mountains. NOTE: This is vast in size. You can go anywhere you want......bring water if hiking.....park closes at 9PM so keep an eye on your time so you can get back to your car. Very enjoyable.

Didnt know much about it when we went there but this is a must see and we will return. Relatively easy to get to, there is a charge to get into the park ($3 per person) but it is worth it. Lots of fun, you can rent or purchase slides at the visitor center and you can stay all day into the evening. Have lots of bathroom facilities available and places where you can picnic or even bbq. A must visit if you are in the area.

The sand dunes were beautiful and the children had a ball sliding down them. The sand is much different from the beach. It is like powder and doesn't dust off. It was disappointing to know that the gift shop has a racket of selling sleds to slide down the dunes. You can "buy" a used one for $10 and when you are done with it they will give you $3.00 back for it. If there are no used sleds you have to purchase a new one for about $16 with a return of $5. I felt like this was a rip off. They sell these things over and over.

LOVED! We had a fantastic time sledding down the dunes. We arrived early, a little before 9, and got the last two used sleds for $10 each. We headed out to the dunes, and got quite a workout going back up after each slide down. Go early to avoid the summer heat!
This is quite interesting to see. I recommend you watch the film and then go out into the dunes and experience the gypsum field. Admission reasonable and stafff helpful. Had a great time.

Wow - this place was my favorite on our family trip to the SouthWest. Just stunning - otherworldly feeling when you drive in as the sky and sand feel like the meet a giant light box of sorts. We rented sleds (if they have used one's you can buy them for a few dollars cheaper and they'll buy them back which equates to a rental). The trick to getting the sleds to move was crating a "shoot". Go over and over the same track and create a smooth groove, lean back and you'll have a lot of fun! The white sands are like being on a beach in the Caribbean - pure and stunning. The sky was filled with billowing clouds but we were careful to wear a lot of sunscreen and you're getting the reflection from the sand as well as the sky - took some of our best photos at this location - a must visit if you're in the area.

The whole family will enjoy a day outdoors and be amazed by the vast, pure white, gypsum sand dunes of White Sands! Entrance fee is nominal at just $3/each (under 15 are free) and you can pack in your own picnic (bring the cooler & grill). Bring sleds (the round disc type work really well), a large blanket or towels, and don't forget the sunscreen! Know the weather conditions, because cold or windy days will be miserable. But, on a warm/hot day, dig your feet a few inches below the surface to feel the cool sand below! Fly a kite (no trees in sight)! Pets are allowed. Bring lots of water, sunglasses, an umbrella--and your camera! Don't stop at the first dunes you see, keep driving! It just gets better and better!

Yes it is extremely hot being surrou ded by beautiful white sand dunes but who cares! Such a wonderful experience for my family. It is absolutely beautiful and serene. Kids had a blast sliding down the dunes in the disks purchased at gift store. Totally worth the $15. Try to go early in the morning or late in the evening so the it won't be so hot.

$3.00 gets you into the monument. It is one of the most unique monuments in the United States. You can drive it in less than 45 minutes but you have to walk a dune or two and leave some footprints. The kids would have fun sledding down the dunes on sand disks. Take a tour or walk the boardwalks. Just do it.

The Trinity site is only open to tourists two days a year. It is the site of the first atomic bomb explosion in the world, and currently very safe to visit - there is more radiation emitted by a banana than this site now! The history is very rich of how the weapons developed here brought an early end to a war that would have dragged on and cost potentially millions more lives if not brought to and end by the nuclear technology developed and tested in the American Southwest. Be sure to not pick up any of the greenish bits of glass on the ground - it's called Trinitite and was created when the heat from the bomb melted the earth at the detonation site - it's a crime to remove it. There is a rock shop down the road that has a few bits they can sell legally they obtained before it was outlawed. Expect a small pebble amount to set you back around $100.

While I saw pictures before we got there, I still joked that we were paying $3/person to see sand. It was totally worth every penny. The views were stunning and I wish I had more words to describe how majestic and beautiful that $3 sand was. We didn't get "sand disks" or snow sleds as we Illinoisians call them. But we did walk barefoot in the sand and on the dunes. The sand felt so soft and amazingly wasn't hot to walk on. Bring water and sunglasses. The sun is very bright reflecting off the sand.

Sand, Sand, Sand, everywhere you look, hills and hills of sand. Was neat to see this much WHITE sand in one location not around a beach anywhere! Beautiful. You can rent sleds at the visitors center to ride down the dunes. We didn't do that but saw lots of people participating. There is a boardwalk at the fist stop on the loop that is good for older people who have trouble walking in the sand. There is shade offered on this boardwalk and seating to rest. The sand is not off limits .... you can walk anywhere on it you like. There are places along the way to park your car if you want to walk, hike, or play in the sand. There is a place to unload your horses if you brought any. The fee was $6.00 for two people. The visitors center and museum/gift shop were at the entrance to the dunes. I would recommend this park as a must see!

Took our grandchildren to see the dunes and they were fascinated and thrilled. We purchased sleds at the gift shop for them to slide down the dunes and they had a ball! You could return them to the gift shop for a $3 refund back but they were only $12.99 and we just kept them to bring home for snow in the winter. Had a great day. Bring plenty of water if the kids are sledding in hot weather. it is tiring to walk up the dunes for the short sled down and they need to stay hydrated.

Less than ten dollars for a car load, little more to rent sand sleds. Well worth it to slide down the dunes like snow tubing but warm. Get the wax they offer with the sled/discs it really helps especially for adults. If you are a shutterbug, keep you ticket and return a bit before sunset to get some really spectacular golden hour shots across the dunes.

Stopped by the White Sands and drove through. It was a very interesting stop. They have a large gift shop where you can purchase a sled to slide down the sand dunes. The sled was $16.99 + tax if you save your receipt they will buy it back from you for $5.00 if you don't want to have to try to pack it in your car. Bring sunglasses if you plan to visit. The white sand can be very blinding.

Definitely one of the most amazing places on earth. Nothing compares to the ocean of white gypsum sand going on for further than the eyes can see. Take a plastic (waxed) board to go down the large dunes. Take a cooler and grill out there. They have overnight camping for groups. You can easily spend hours there. The fee is going up a couple of dollars this October, but still definitely worth even a $10 admission.

My husband and I visited White Sands National Monument on our trip to the west. We went inside the visitors center, saw a quick film about how the "white sands" were created, etc. it was very interesting. All the animals and insects have evolved into white creatures in the white sands to ensure survival....thought that was interesting. Biggest bang for your buck....only $3 per person to get in! You can drive in for about 8 miles and as you go, there are less and less plants, leaving pure white gypsum sands...an amazing site! It feels like dry beach sand and is cool to the touch. Nature is amazing!

Large white "sand" dunes (gypsum) that are a blast to climb and slide down on one of their blue discs. Buy for $14.99 at the gift shop (they will buy it back for $5). Picnic areas abound, sunset walk about an hour before sunset.

We went in second week of March and it was a good time to be there. Temperature was not too hot or cold. $3 entry fee for adults and can use it for a week. Definitely should take a sled for rent. Sunset will be beautiful. Fun place for the kids..When it was too hot we went to the pistachio Ranch nearby and came back. There you can enjoy different flavors of pistachios..

White Sands is a most remarkable place with its white gypsum dunes that reach 100 feet in height and stay cool even in 120-degree summers. A small entry fee ($3 for adults) opens up to the public picnic ares, hiking trails and sledding runs for families and individuals. There is no water, so bring your own. Also there are only vault toilets. This is the largest and most spectacular white gypsum dune field on earth.

On this clear day we hoped the 50+ mile drive from Las Cruces would be worth it and indeed it was! The drive inside the park to the dunes is awe inspiring. We also used our Federal Parks Pass and so we didn't have to pay the $3 entry fee. We really enjoyed climbing some of the smaller dunes with our dog. It was fun seeing families out using sleds to go down the dunes. There were people out with canopies and picnics. The restrooms were very clean which is so appreciated. This is a wonderful stop on our journey!

We drove down from Ruidoso, NM about 60 minutes away. Well worth the drive. We arrived in late afternoon and quickly realized that we should have come earlier to spend more time. We arrived at 5 pm and were told that entrance fee was waived!! It was a very cloudy day and slightly wet and cool. Would have been much more fun if it were warm. Kids had a blast regardless. They loved sliding down the dunes. Rent one from the visitors center for $10 (used) and get $3 back if you return it. The larger dunes are in the back of the park.

This is the place the you definitely want to visit if you in New Mexico. It is between Ruidoso, Las Cruses area.. It will cost 3$ for each adult. You will see white sand dunes, and you will enjoy the view of miles and miles of white sand...Just like snow...

That's what my wife said. Normally cold by nature, she loved getting out there and sledding with the kids. We all had fun. TIP: You can buy the little round sleds for $10 at Kmart....so worth the money. :-)

We had a good time each sledding about 5 or 6 times down the hills. It was a holiday weekend so it was free vs. 3 dollars. You should invest in the wax to wax the bottom of the sleds if you go or it will not work.

The visitor's center and gift shop are historical adobe buildings, rich with character, and easily found right on route 70. Driving the dune loop is quite the experience as roads are frozen looking and sand is plowed like snow. Adding to the ambiance, it was 42 degrees while we were there and there was some snow mixed in the sand in spots. Light plays on the sand. it was cloudy while we were there so the dark sky made an interesting contrast. We walked some of the trails, climbed dunes, played in the sand, and enjoyed the views from this natural environment. We went out of our way to visit here in colder weather than we like and are glad we made the effort. It's worth the trip. Modest fee of $3 per. There are no hotels or campgrounds close by--st least 20-30 minutes away. We stayed in a little dumpy place in Alamogordo--it was acceptable for 2 nights, but no more.

We stopped at White Sands with our young children (age 2.5 and 5) on a road trip from Texas to California. This was a highlight of our trip, and definitely worth the stop! We rented a used toboggan (cheaper than buying a new one) at the visitor's center and were able to return it for a credit of a few dollars after we were done. The kids had so much fun on the sand dunes that it was difficult for us to get them to leave! The sand it really soft and didn't bother us when it got under our clothes and into our shoes. The scenery is gorgeous and made for some incredible photos.

My husband and I stopped by this on our way to Ruidoso and we were so happy we did! No amount of words can describe the awe and beauty of these White Sand Dunes. Just go! You won't be disappointed! Best $6 we ever spent. We got AMAZING Photos and just had a blast! You can buy/rent little sleds to go down the dunes or just enjoy the view and soak up some rays. There's a picnic area and dogs are allowed too. Just don't drive past this place without stopping to check it out. Seriously, it was amazing!

white sands national monument only costs 3 dollars per person and there is a loop you can drive through and stop along different locations within the sand dunes. There are plenty of outdoor bathroom facilities as well as some spots with tables and picnic areas.

The development of these dunes of talcom powder like sand is awesome. Get out of your car at designated spots and feel it. If you have the time for a sled down the white and snow like sand you can buy a $17.00 sled at the visitor center, they will even buy back for $5.00.

What a blast. We watched the sunset! It was the most unbelievable sight I've ever seen. It had beautiful white sands. When I posted it on Facebook everyone thought it was snow. You can buy sleds for $5 and sled the sands. It's so vast you can have a hill all to yourself.

This one is a no contest, when in Alamogordo you must see White Sands National Monument. It is amazingly beautiful, especially in the evening and it is inexpensive, $3 per adult and they allow you to sled down the dunes. You can purchase sleds at the park but the place we were staying at had sleds we could use. It was a blast!

Have you ever gone sledding on sand? I now have!!! What a neat treat to check off my bucket list. White sands is truly a unique beauty and definitely worth the drive from Albuquerque. The gift shop sells sleds, but they'll charge you 16 or so for a new one and if you bring it back they'll "buy it back" for $5 (it then becomes 'used' which they'll charge the next guy 10 with a "buy back" for $3). I just wish the gals working in the gift shop were friendlier, but it was easy to forget about their attitude once I got to the dunes and began sledding (which I definitely recommend!).

White Sands National Monument is a ‘bucket list’ place that you really ‘must do’. The dunes themselves are amazing, towering hills of white gypsum in endlessly different shapes and sizes. It’s a terrific place for climbing, hiking, picnicking, sledding/sliding and generally just having fun playing in and on the sand. This place is also a photographer’s dream -- the views of the San Andreas Mountains to the west and the Sacramento Mountains to the east are breathtaking. The vistas are simply huge beyond description, and the sunsets are spectacular. This is a magical place to visit at any time, but late afternoon is special due to the extraordinary light from the sun low on the west. Moonrise over the Sacramento’s draws bid crowds and tours by professional photographers. Early evening is even more amazing here, especially if you can stay late enough for full sunset and are fortunate enough to have clear skies (which isn’t that hard in southern New Mexico). This place is unlike anything you’ll see anywhere else, which makes the White Sands a bucket list entry for me. The monument entrance is 15 miles west of Alamogordo, New Mexico on US Highway 70; entrance fee is $3 per person (kids under 15 get in free). The drive into the dunes themselves takes about 15 minutes from the entrance, depending on how far you choose to go. There are picnic tables and outhouses in several spots along the drive. Go to www.nps.gov/whsa for hours and more information.

This place is worth the 3 1/2 hour drive from Albuquerque even if this is the only thing you come to see in this area. Brilliant white gypsum sand dunes that feel powdery soft to walk on. Went at sunset and it was so peaceful and tranquil. If you don't stop at all, the loop drive takes about 45 minutes, but you should alot at least 1/2 a day to enjoy this National Monument. It's about a 20 minute drive from Alamogordo and be aware that sometimes they have to close for a few hours when there is a missile test being conducted. Lovely picnic areas inside, but no water -- so bring your own. Entrance fee is $3 per adult, but NPS permit holders get in free if you bring your annual pass.

We brought the family here for a visit. It is amazing. There is a gift shop with a video about 15 mins long... it is good to see. Also in the gift shop be sure to get a sled. You don't have to buy a new one, get a used one for like $10. Then you can return it for like $3 when you are done. Don't bother with the wax. I bought the wax and couldn't tell much of a difference. The most important thing is to find a steep hill. We drove way to the back of the park by all of the picnic tables. There were some HUGE dunes there. We also brought a cooler with PLENTY of water (we drank a ton) and some Subway sandwiches. Kids had a blast and we got some awesome pics too. There are no services (besides bathrooms) past the giftshop/visitors center, so bring everything you need....especially water. I highly recommend you visit here.... it is worth the out-of-the way hike.

I visited WSNM with my father some years ago and decided to return, this time with my camera (I'm an amateur photographer). I arranged for an early entry one morning, which costs $50/hour per person. (This probably won't appeal to many people, but if you want to catch sunrise during the summer months, it's necessary.) This meant sending in an application along with the fee and waiting for approval. It came quickly and I was on my way. (Allow a couple of weeks for the process.)

Nice visitor center and gift shop. There is a $3 pp entrance fee that is good for 7 days. The dune drive is mostly paved but partly you drive on the gypsum. We hiked part of the Alkalai Trail at the end of the dune drive. It is so much fun to walk up and down the dunes but it is easy to get lost so make sure you don't wander out of sight of the trail markers. We saw lots of people sliding down the dunes with plastic flying saucers that can be purchased at the gift shop. Awsome place to visit.

We bought sleds at the shop when we came in- you could "rent them" for $12 for an adult sled and $10 for a kid sled, or just buy them for $17/$15 respectively, we thought that was a better deal. We also bought a sled wax chunk for $.75. There are so many beautiful, soft, white dunes out there that we were able to find our own and not see anyone else for miles around as we sled down them. They have some kind of cool retro aluminum shelters over picnic tables where we ate the lunch we brought and stayed out of the sun and sand. The only trail we did was the boardwalk trail, which was anyone accessible and the shortest hike. I'm sure some of the longer ones might have been better. We also didn't watch the movie or visit the museum, as we wanted to get out to the dunes before it got too hot. We'd been warned the sand could get very hot, but I guess we lucked out or got there early enough (we were there from about 9:30am-12pm), the sand was nice and cool and we were able to sled barefoot in August. Totally worth doing for the views at the top of the dunes alone.

We went to do the sand dunes on our way through town. We only had an hour or two to spare so we thought this would be a fun stop. We found that you have to BUY the disks to use on the dunes for $20 each and they will buy them back for $5. We decided it wasn't worth $80 for a few minutes. Everything in the gift shop was extremely high.We were going to then drive out to the dunes but there was a per person fee and you aren't allowed to get any sand so we decided to just pass on the place. Also, the bathrooms here were awful- men's and women's. The detour was a waste of time!

Love White Sands National Monument! Feels like you might be on the moon when you get away from the road. You can hike on the dunes(bring a compass) or sled down them. Water is recommended too. During the summer Full Moon nights are fun, they have a program, and watching the moon rise and illuminate the dunes is beautiful! Lots of fun!

I've loved going to White Sands since I was a little kid, but it's been a long time since I've gone. Used to be that you needed to remember to bring some cardboard with you, or grab some from a family that was leaving. Now you can buy new or used sliders at the gift shop and then return the slider at the end of your day for a small refund. Ends up being between $9-$11 if you return the slider. And don't forget that wax for .75. The more often you wax the bottom, the fast you'll go down the dunes.

Be prepared for the heat and whiteness of it all. You absolutely need sun glasses, it is blinding. Watch the little movie in the visitor center, informative (and cool). You can drive in and explore on your own at your own pace. We loved it, the teens loved it. We brought sleds with us from our rental (or you can buy from the visitor center ($15 but you can receive $5 back if you return). There's a nice little spot around the middle where they have tents/overhangs set up if you want to stop and picnic/rest. It's such a different place to visit, the gypsum sand is comfortable to walk on (not hot at all). The whole area is beautiful, so glad we visited. Where else can you visit something like this?

stuff. Roll it thru your fingers, it is so different but take none with you of course. It's about 7 miles to the end with picnic areas there so take a lunch. If you wish there are snow disks to buy at $12., get $5 back I think when you get back to the visitors center. People walk to the top of the dunes 7 miles in where you park and slide down the dunes. Looks like fun but we passed , only had the picnic. The place was almost deserted on thurs. and the weather was picture perfect. After 3 miles in the scenery changes and the sands really stand out without and of the cactus or grasses.

The sun was a blazing and skies clear and blue,,, the sand was so bright you really did NEED your sun glasses,, I saw people wandering around on the sand in bare feet, had to try it myself, it was fantastically cool,, and so soft , the texture is unlike any sand I have ever walked on,.. A tip for the older folks,, there is almost NO shade in fact I only saw small shelters from the sun in a picnic area,, wear a nice brimmed hat , and yes SUN GLASSES,, and have lots of water in the car and a bottle or two on you cos it is HOT,, we enjoyed watching the younger set walk and climb up the dunes and slide down on snow disks ( which can be purchased at the gift store for 14.99 and they(gift shop folks) buy them back for five dollars )the gift shop has some lovely things ,, this is a must see if you are in the Alamogordo NM area :-)

I remembered this from when I was a child 30 years ago. I brought my family across country to see the west. The dunes were shorter than I remembered!! My kids had a blast! If you have a round saucer you use for sledding on snow you should bring them because they are $15 each in the gift shop and of course my kids wanted to sled at the same time so we had to buy 2! They will buy them back from you for about $5 I think but we just kept them. We left when the sun was beginning to set and it was absolutely beautiful with the sun casting shadows on the dunes. We drove on to Las Cruces which is about an hour away and stayed in the Holiday Inn Las Cruces and are very happy with that decision. It was clean and comfortable and on the way to our next stop Tombstone, Az!

If you're a photographer, there are only two ways to catch sunrise. First, backpack your gear to the back country camp area. Or, pay a ranger $50 to open the gate before sunrise. Sunset shots are no problem, as the park closes well after sunset. Most people attend to sled down the dunes (sleds are available at the visitor's center). Make sure you bring water with you as the public water supply (at the visitor's center) was shut down on my most recent visit.

The scenery here is unlike anything else. The beauty of it is something everyone can appreciate whether you're just driving through or on foot exploring the dunes. This is my new favorite place to take a family vacation. We took our 9 year old daughter and her face showed sheer joy as she was sledding down the dunes. Though we only spent one day here, we made a lot of memories. I believe the best time to visit would be spring or early fall, as the sun and lack of shade can be brutal in warmer temperatures. Sunscreen, hats, extra water, and your camera are a must. This isn't a place you want to be at without these things. We purchased used sleds from the gift shop and though there is an option to sell them back to the shop for a few dollars, we chose instead to gift them to another family when we left the park. This is a place where many people from other countries travel from afar to see, it's a shame if you live in the area and do not see this at least once.

We drove to White Sands all the way from Albuquerque, and it was definitely worth the 6-hour drive. There is a neat 17-minute video introduction to White Sands (the history and the how), in the Visitors Center. For $3, you're then free to drive through and explore the monument. There are several hiking trails you can take as well as general areas where you can get out and run through or tube down the dunes. One of the trails was closed the day we visited, so we stayed along the general road. On a sunny day, the sand is especially bright, so be sure to wear sunglasses! The sand goes on for miles, and it feels so fine and cool as it passes through your fingers and between your toes. We couldn't stay for too long, but I recommend spending some hours here.
The National Parks and Monuments are all great treasures, and if you are over 60, don't neglect to get the lifetime Park Pass. Cost: $10. Covers everyone in your car. Best bargain in the USA.

We wish we would have set aside more time to explore and enjoy the park. We started at the visitors center. It was uncomfortably packed. Rangers said it was unusual. Watched the film and then took a drive thru the dunes. We stopped to scramble up some dunes and take pictures. We could have stayed for hours. April is a good time to visit. Other months may be too hot or cold. Be sure to follow all instructions. You can dehydrate, burn or get lost quickly here. Bring lots of water! Our only complaint was that the bathrooms at the visitors center were disgusting. The visitor's center is free but there is a $3 fee per person to enter the dunes area.

Unfortunately the day I visited, so did a huge wind storm. It was difficult to see any definition of the dunes or even to take photos. There was white sand everywhere, even inside the car. However, people were sledding down the slopes and having fun. The drive is easy and I found it interesting to see so much sand surrounded by so much desert-like vegetation. The wind was too strong to take the walk/hike and see the middle of the area, so I bought a postcard. There are picnic spots to use, but I had to wonder how much sand people were ingesting with their food. Difficult to predict when to go as the wind can come up anytime at all. Lovely experience though. I used my National Parks Annual Pass to gain access.

I'm so glad I stopped here to take in the amazing views! The drive out is 8 miles but that's where the tallest dunes and thus, best sledding is. You can buy sleds for $15 and they'll refund you $5 if you return them. Be warned...climbing the dunes is quite a workout at this elevation so pace yourself and bring lots of water and sunscreen. Weather was perfect in Feb but I'd imagine summer could be quite brutal. I didn't get to do any of the hikes but they looked like fun as well. Well worth the $3 admission fee! This place is a photographer's dream.

My friend and I stopped at the gift shop to buy sleds ($10/each new; $8/each used, I think) to play in the sands. Also sat and watched a 17min video on the park at the info center. There is a $3 fee/person to enter the Dunes. Dogs on leash are also welcomed. Lots of picnic areas toward the end of the loop, so bring water and food because there's none available for sale after you enter the Dunes. We had so much fun running up and sledding down the dunes. It's worth the climb to get some of the better views, but really not a bad seat in the house. I'd recommend a handkerchief to wrap around your nose/mouth if you don't want sand in those orifices. Beware: you will get sand EVERYWHERE. :) Fun for all.

For two teens and a 9 year old, most historical landmarks and such get pretty boring. We had a blast sledding on our disks down the dunes. They rent them to you for $14 but we bought ours at Big 5 Sporting Goods in Alamogordo for $10! Take a picnic lunch.

This national monument is certainly a "don't miss!" I wish we'd had more time to spend here and enjoy more of the trails throughout the area. The sand is pure white and very fine and is spectacular against the blue sky. The gift shop at the visitor center rents or sells plastic sleds to slide down the huge dunes. We brought our own and it was all kinds of fun. Cost of admission is certainly reasonable but we were admitted free with our senior pass. There is a large area for picnicking and each table is protected from the sun by a curved roof which is artistic in and of itself.

This place is amazing, and is a real bargain too - only $3 per person. You'll find miles and miles of gigantic white sand dunes to explore. I've never seen anything like this anywhere else. The sand is soft and fun to play in. You can bring or buy sleds at the gift shop to use on the massive sand dunes, which is quite an experience. It's a little like snow after a massive blizzard without the cold and wet. There are several hiking trails available, all of which I found to be worthwhile, and you can even camp out overnight if you get a permit at the visitor's center. This place greatly exceeded my expectations. If you're in the area, don't hesitate to visit; you will not regret the experience.

Passing through the area on way home from Las Cruces. Had always heard of White Sands so knew we needed to stop. What a pleasure to see the pure white sand and so well maintained. Would stop again although I have now seen it. Great little museum and very nice gift shop. Clean restrooms. A place you can see quickly or spend a day.

My son took us to White Sands for the day! September is a wonderful time to go. The kids loved climbing the dunes and sledding. I found the sledding a little disappointing, we rented 2 for $18 each, go with one and share. Great place for photographers, go in the afternoon when the shadows are great.

White Sands National monument was something I’ve never heard of but we saw it marked off on our trusty Rand McNally road map and figured it was worth a stop. Boy- are we happy we did! 8 miles of the purest white sand in the middle of a desert! Some dunes over a hundred feet high, maybe more. Families brought sleds and slid down them like snow. Feel free to get out and take pictures, climb on them, roll down them- be a big kid again!

If you visit White Sands National Monument in the summer, I strongly recommend that you spend the night in Ruidoso or Ruidoso Downs which are less than an hour away. Ruidoso is in the nearby mountains, has pine trees, and averages 20 degrees cooler temperatures. White Sands itself is unique and amazing. It is so beautiful, and I've never seen anything like it in the world. It has the largest white gypsum sand dunes in the world. The visitor center is a few miles southwest of Alamogordo. You won't miss it because there is nothing else there. The visitor center has a free 17 minute video that gives a good description of the dunes. It also has an outdoor garden of area desert plants with plaques and descriptions of those plants. I've always heard of creosote covered telephone poles, but never knew what creosote was. Creosote is one of the plants growing and described. The gift shop has plastic sleds available for kids to slide down the dunes. To get to the dunes, you must pay $3.00 per person, not per car. The older lady at the gate was extremely slow, but that is my only complaint. To get to the heart of the dunes you drive an 8 mile road. The first several miles are paved, then you drive on graded white gypsum sand. There was no problem with getting stuck in the sand. The first couple miles of sand dunes have quite a few plants growing on the dunes. The farther in you go, the fewer plants. Eventually you get to the truly white bare sand dunes. After you drive past the paved road you will see pullover areas to park your car. That's the place to get out of the car and climb some sand dunes. I'd say the average height is 30 feet or so, but some reach 60 feet, The contrast of the very white sand and the nearby blue mountains is so beautiful. Make sure to take photos. As I said, if it's summer and daylight, you won't want to stay a long time. It's hot. They do permit visitors until 10:00 PM though. Then spend the night in cool Ruidoso. If you want a longer side trip, check out Carlsbad caverns. Hope you enjoy it..

This natural phenomenon is something to behold! The largest gypsum sand dunes in the world! When you first get there, you can visit the visitor center and watch the 17 minute movie on the history and science of the dunes. The visitor center offers a wide variety of interactive displays that teach you about the dunes and the wildlife that lives there. After that, you can purchase a pass to enter the park at $3.00 per person, unless the ranger isn't there, then you just drive in. White Sands offers many little hikes throughout the 7-8 mile driving loop. You can bring your lunch and your saucer for a day of fun! The saucers are used to slide down the sand dunes, similar to snow saucers. You don't even need to wear shoes! The sand is so soft. No matter how hot it gets, the sand does not get hot, but if you're there in the winter, the ranger said to wear 2 pairs of socks, because the sand gets so cold it could go through your shoes to your feet! Pretty amazing. During the summer, White Sands hold Full Moon Nights, three nights out of the summer. We attended this, and I highly recommend it. They have a band out there playing on the natural amphitheater the dunes create. The moon comes up and illuminates the dunes. At first, everything looks blue! It's so nice being our there at night. Definitely look into this if you plan on going in the summer. We also partook of the Sunset Stroll ranger guided walk. Our ranger was very informative and had samples of natural artifacts the dunes create and are created from. This stroll lasted about an hour and you don't walk very far. Check the visitor center or website for other ranger guided tours throughout the day. Have fun!

This is such an amazing place. I live at a beach town and the dunes here were incledible. I loved driving the roads covered in sand. It looks like snow but when you step out of the car the heat kills you. It was 99 degrees. We kicked off our shoes and strolled the dunes. There are cute little covered picnic tables on the drive. Take some food with you and enjoy the beautiful views. You can rent a sled at the visitor center for $10.00. You will not want to leave!!!!

Make sure you stop by the store at the entrance and grab your discs for sliding down the sand dunes. We made the mistake of getting all the way to the middle of the dunes before we realized we needed discs. They are about $17 per disc and they will buy it back from you for $5. They are well worth the money for hours of fun. This attraction is well worth the drive. We drove in from camping in Cloudcroft. We took a bunch of teens from our church youth group. ages of sliders ranged from 11 to 46 and we all had fun. also a fee of $3/person is charged at entrance. They also have well shaded picnic tables.

white sands is amazing place, the outside is not appealing. but when you drive between sand dunes, and walk on the sand. sand surfing must for kids. kids will have a lot of fun. you can buy used "sand plate" around $10 for them.do not need to buy new one$16.99. you can return it for $5. also get wax for sand plate. because the day before it was raining, sand is not smoothing.must see this place in the area. we have annual national park pass,we do pay entrance fee.

If you plan on doing some sledding go to Big K in Alamogordo and buy a colored sledding disc for about 10$.At the park they charge 15$ a piece and if in good condition they can buy it back from ya for 5$.But do buy the wax from the parks gift shop.It WORKS!!.I applied it to ours each time after each time going down the sand hills.DO WEAR SUNGLASSES!!!~The white sand is very bright!!!~TAKE PLENTY WATER AND SUNBLOCK!!!!~The bathrooms as mentioned.GROSS!~We drove about 8-9 miles back toward the back and we looked for the tallest hills as possiable~We got us some SPEED going down it!!~The place is AWESOME views of the mountains in the back drop and sand hills for miles to see.
This place is so unique, it's worth a stop. Catch a free ranger talk and tour if timing is right. Skip the sledding - it was difficult to slide down the dunes, not worth the $$.

This was amazing to see! Miles and miles of white sand. The visitors center will sell you sleds and then buy them back at a discount but it is so worth it ! Pack a lunch make a day of it ! There are shade shelters and barbecue areas and you can sled to your heart's content. We took the sunset tour with the ranger to learn about the dunes and the wild life and found it very informative and enjoyable. Definitely worth the stop for $3.00 per person.
What a great place to go and spend a few hours! You drive down a sometimes winding road after you go through the entrance (I think the fee was $3/pp good for 1 week).

This desert national park is a true treasure. We bought sleds from a couple of people returning theirs. So you buy the sleds for 17 bucks I believe, although I think the used ones cost $10. You return them and receive $3 bucks back. We just bought ours from someone else for $5 and still saved $2. It's incredibly hot during the day to go walking or hiking or sledding - it can drain you. Consistent with desert climates, it does get chilly at night so dress in layers if you go. I recommend visiting either early morning and/or right before, during and after sunset. We particularly enjoyed the sunset views, walking deeper into the sand dunes to find better and bigger ones to sled down. Feel free to keep driving as far into the park as you can to find the untouched, cleaner dunes (less plants). The only comparable place that I've seen to White Sands are the Sossuvlei Dunes in Namibia, Southern Africa (but they are golden sands and not white). The white sand really does look like an Arctic landscape. Be sure to wear bright colors for an awesome photo-op. We took a picture of my friend jumping up in a red outfit and caught her midair- it came out phenomenal in the sea of white. You'll see some professional photo shoots also. I know they have sunset strolls, we missed arriving for that on time but I bet you learn a lot with the ranger. We just enjoyed strolling about on our own and trying to climb the dunes after sledding down. It's a workout! We also saw a cool beetle or two which was fun..it's an ethereal and unforgettable landscape. You feel like you're on another planet. Oh and they had the full moon bike ride that night too which we could not sign up for..if you're in town for that next time, you should definitely do it.

Two young children and I stayed overnight at camp site no. 1, about .7 miles from trailhead at end of February near almost full moon. Temperatures fluctuated 50 degrees between day and night. (Frost on tent in the morning; only the slightest of breeze just before dawn.) Cost about $9 total at gate for admission and camping permit. Checked in at visitor's center for assignment. Ranger very friendly and helpful. Nice small exhibits. Children wished bathrooms were more clean; they didn't like graffiti. Very little in way of sundries at gift shop. We brought one plastic disc for dunes. They sell them there but at a premium price. They also sell wax, which might have been a good purchase. Trailhead is about 8 miles from visitor's center, with large lot and vault toilet. As mentioned, the "trail" is from post to post. Easier on top of dunes; climbing can be soft and tough with weight on your back. We planned only for one overnight: brought lots of warm clothes, bags & blankets, food, stove, tent, lots of water, etc. Even for our short time in winter, I can imagine you could get burned easily. Children loved playing and a little exploring. This is Leave No Trace (pack in/pack out) camping. Actually got a phone signal from top of dunes near our camp site. Quickly warmed in morning; fun trek out; you can see road and lot from distance; saw other early morning hikers. Afterward we visited the Space Museum in Alamogordo, which we liked.

This is a bunch of natural gypsum dunes just off of I-70 between Alamogordo and Las Cruces, New Mexico. It is definitely worth a few hours of "stop and relax". There is a fee to drive into the park (unless your have a National Park Pass) but it is reasonable. There are bathrooms outside of the park entrance as well as a gift shop and visitors' center. All are well-maintained and staffed with friendly workers. It is 15 miles from Alamogordo (if you have young kids, this is a decent potty stop as Alamogordo speed limit will drop to 45 mph as you hit town).

Fascinating place to visit. Certainly a wonder of geology and the environment. Visitor center is well done with a nice video that well explains how it all came to be. And the park rangers were very helpful. Gift shop was typical -- some interesting stuff, though at high prices. Very modest collection of snacks, but sufficient, and lots of water at a reasonable price. Walking about in the sand was much fun, but the sledding is greatly overrated: The runs are very short, end on concrete-like desert floor, and that only matters if you can get the sled to travel at more than 1 mph. Rent is $17, but they will refund $5 if you return it. A bit of a ripoff in retrospect. Nonetheless the kids had fun and learned a bit about the desert and how White Sands came to exist. There are many bathrooms on the grounds. The main bathrooms were small and well worn, and they were not overly clean, but functional. There was supposed to a a $3 per person fee, but for some reason it was waived the day we were there. In all we spent about 4 hours on the site. Certainly stop here if in the area.

A visit to southern New Mexico should include a stop at one of this nation's most unusual and interesting national treasures...White Sands National Monument. Coming down out of the Mountains east of Alamogordo you can see the amazing stretch of white sands reaching out in all directions for miles. Comprising 275 square miles this amazing anomaly is interesting and a fun stop for persons of any age. The white sand is created from gypsum in the surrounding mountains as it is broken up by nature and then washed down into the valley by rains. Blown by the winds the pieces of gypsum are eventually ground by the wind and water into the finest sand-like particles and then formed into 60 foot high dunes again by the prevailing winds. A national park staff operate a small visitor center and are extremely helpful in educating visitors about the dunes and providing maps and guidance for venturing. A 15 minute narrated film show the high lights of the dunes, along with the plants and animals that make their home in the dunes. Day camping on the dunes is permitted as is "sand boarding" down from the tops of the dunes on plastic round snow discs. The sliding is exciting and fun for "kids" of all ages. The cost to enter the 16 mile round trip driving loop into the dunes is only $3 a person and you won't even have to leave the comfort of your vehicle to enjoy this incredible national treasure, unlike any other in the world!

I wasn't sure what all the excitement was about when researching this online, but after spending the day there I can see what all the fuss was about. We started off by renting sleds in the gift shop. They rent for $10 used, but if you bring them back they will refund you $3 per sled. Make sure you bring your camera, I probably snapped about 200 photos of my children sledding, rolling, and making sand angels ! The weather was perfect , high of 56 but my children's faces still got a little sunburned so make sure you bring sunscreen. I would loved to have stayed for sunset as I can only imagine how beautiful it must be. Next time I plan on camping there for the night.

We stopped here to see the white sands and this a must see on your trip through southern NM. Rent one of the sleds in the gift shop for $10 and you get $3 back when you return it. The park is 8 miles long so go to the very back for the highest dunes and find a dune that goes straight down for the best sledding. The sand is beautiful and breath taking. We spent about 1.5 hrs here and that was enough time.

I've been there twice and pkan to go again, it is absolutely gorgeous. Try to catch the sunset and also go early in the morning as well. You can purchase a used sled for $3.00 at the visitor center, and its a lot of fun. Take your time, the park is not too big. Be carefull, i almost got lost at night, its easy to just keep going nad then the suroundings look the same. Make sure you HAVE GLASSES on, its very bright, and wear sunscreen. Go in the winter, i heard the summer is too hot down there.

We loved White Sands! I am a photographer and hiker, so I was in heaven at White Sands. There are a couple of trails at White Sands to hike further into the dune field. We took the campsite trail loop and were alone on the trail. The sand dunes are easy to hike on and the trail is well marked with poles that you can see along the trail. Another day we were off trail to do some photography and got lost when we were ready to return to the car. We had made note of our location by compass before we went into the dunes, so were able to find our way back using the compass. Don't rely on your footprints to get you back if you get off trail. The park's website has information on open times, etc. You can enter the park earlier or stay later by applying for a permit a couple of weeks in advance and paying a $50 fee per each half hour of time. Highly recommended !

plan to stay and spend the day, go to walmart and buy some $5.00 sleds or bring yours from home because this place is so much fun. ( the sleds sold there are wayyyy expencive. Take the time and drive to the very back for the highest peaks. A low cost way to spend the day.

This is a great park and you stay a little while or a long time. The best part is parks in NM are just $3 a person. The price can't be beat. Driving in is just amazing and when you reach the parking area, walking in the sand is a great work out. The sand is very close to the type in Destin. Its so white that is doesn't burn your feet. Great place to visit in this area.

Go to the visitors center and watch the movie first. Good information presented well. If you want to play on the dunes, you can get a sled from the gift shop. You drive your own car out to the dunes for only $3. Stop as much as you want and walk around. It starts out a little less than spectacular, but gets better as you go out. 30 minutes If you never leave your car. Stay as long as you want and take advantage of the ranger tours, or stay for the once monthly full moon strolls.

I had heard about sledding at White Sands many years ago and have always wanted to go. My friends and I were not disappointed! Our Super 8 Motel in Alamogordo lent us three saucers and wax (which saved us about $45) and we didn't have to worry about being back at the gift shop at a specific time to sell back our saucers.

We almost always take our out-of-town guests to White Sands. When it is hot outside, we take the self-guided drive thru. If you can plan ahead, there are lots of fun activities: full moon night, evening bike rides, hot air ballons, etc. Check the website for listings. Free admission to the Monument with the National Park Senior Pass.

The dunes were unbelievably beautiful. The dunes sit at the bottom of a basin surrounded by mountains. When it rains, all the water runs down to the dunes, therefore, the sand is moist and very cool. For hikers, there are trail markers, as it would be easy to get lost. The sand is incredibly white and the dunes reshape with the wind. There are some nice picnic areas if you bring a cooler. Next time we will be there when we can take advantage of the night programs. As awesome as it was in the daylight, I can only imagine how gorgeous it is in the moonlight. If you have a National Park Pass, it would take care of your admission.

We went with friends this past week and had the BEST time! The white dunes are absolutely stunning and make you feel like you are on another planet. We bought used sleds for $10 each at the visitor center and had a blast sliding down the dunes. Just like being in the snow without the water and chill. A truly unique place to visit and definitely worth your time if you can stop by.

We bought 2 sleds in the gift shop to slide down the dunes and had a blast. Used sleds were $10 and you would get $3 back if you returned the sleds which I thought was kind of a rip off. We went to the visitor's center and watched the short movie which was the perfect lenghth for us, we had 2 small ones in our group with not much attention span. It was about 15 minutes. Everyone really enjoyed sledding down the dunes, the little ones didn't want to leave. The bad part was climbing back up to the top of the dunes to do it again, it's quite a workout!

The white sand dunes surrounded by mountains was beautiful, especially at dusk. The park rangers were very helpful and friendly, and the girl that did our sunset tour. I would recommend going in the late afternoon and taking the sunset tour, as it's not so hot. Sledding wasn't as fun as we expected (we're both in our early twenties and under 150 lbs) but the young kids around us had a blast. If at all possible, bring your own sleds as used ones are $10 and new are even more expensive. You can get a little money back if you return them. This place is definitely a must see!

Don't miss the sledding. It is GREAT!!!.. Buy the saucers at the gift shop for about 15.00. Buy the wax too.. (less than a dollar) When you go into the park, keep driving until you get to pure sand (no vegetation) and then pick a good spot. When you sled, there are a few suggestions to help.
We live in El Paso and the drive to White Sands makes for a perfect day trip. We love the covered picnic areas. Great deal for $6!!!

These sand dunes are amazing. Definitely worth it to buy a sled but much harder and you don't go as fast as sledding on snow. Sleds must be returned by 7 to get $5 buy back at gift shop. It is quite the workout to walk up the sand dunes.

Visited White Sands today with my husband and 10 year old son. We went to slide down the sand dunes. We went to the gift shop and got our plastic saucers and don't forget the wax (you go down alot faster). Also don't forget to pick up water if you don't have any. The air is very dry and it is a good workout to go up and down the hill! We spend about 1 hour and 30 minutes. You will need more time if you want to walk the trails. If you are in the area I would recommend that you stop by. The cost is $3.00 per adult to enter the park.

We visited White Sands in July and had a great time. I was traveling with my husband and 2 girls (aged 9 and 12). Everyone loved it. We bought the sleds from the gift shop (expect to pay $15 for a round plastic sled). They do have a buyback program, too. Best to bring your own.

We rode our bikes through the park and had a blast! The views are beautiful and the staff was friendly. We paid $3 a person and this enabled us to come back for the next 6 days if we wanted to. Well worth it! Bring a picnic lunch.

About an hour out of Las Cruces, NM. It was an easy drive on well maintained roads. If you are planning a visit, be sure to check their website before you go. It is located near the missile test range & the area is sometimes closed when they are doing testing. When you arrive the visitor center has a 17 min. film that has great photography although the audio had some glitches. If you have kids, or are a kid at heart, be sure to pick up a sled at the gift shop so you can go sledding down the dunes. New ones cost $14.95 & they will buy them back from you for $5 or you can buy a used one for $10 and they will buy it back for $3. Don't bother to buy the wax as the sled works fine without it. Choose a sand dune that has soft sand & it will work best. Great place to hike, take photos, & have fun. Don't forget to take some water with you because it is hot & they don't have any at the dunes. Only $3 entrance fee for anyone 16+

I was fortunate to go on an only 85 degree day with just a light breeze. Many families were there with their kids sliding down the dunes with plastic saucers. When the tarred road ends and you start riding on the hard packed gypsum sand you may not even notice a difference. I did the five mile Alkali dunes hike that starts at the end of the loop road and had a wonderful time. I would not advise that hike though with kids or for people not in shape. The plastic saucers can be rented from the rental shop to the left of the main park info area. Ask for used ones and it will save money. In March of 2012 it was $20 for a new one with $5 refunded if it was brought back.

If you want to get in the white sands part of the park (not the gift shop part) you will need cash. I wanted to buy a National Parks Pass ($80) but could only do so wh a check or cash. So I just paid the $3 fee in cash to enter the sands.

I've been going to White Sands since I was a child and now that my children are old enough to go we can't get enough. Driving from Las Cruces or Alamogordo can trick you into thinking the effort is not worth it. Get past the towns and rising out of the middle of a desert are pure white sand hills! And park admission is only $6 per adult! Really, this is the deal of the century that the whole family will enjoy. Buy a sled at the front (you can return it after and get some money back but we just kept ours), take some water and snacks/food and go crazy on the hills. Oh yeah, take sunscreen. No matter the weather you will always get a tan (or a burn) with the sun bouncing off those beautiful dunes. Then sit back and enjoy the smiles on your faces as you try to conquer the dunes! You will not regret it.

The sand dunes are beautiful. The park is huge. Even though it was busy it did not feel that way. You can get sleds at the gift shop to sled on the sand dunes. Be sure to go into the kid's room in the gift shop to check for used sleds. New sleds are $14.50 and you get $5 back if you return them with your receipt. Used sleds are $10 and you get $3 back when you return them. Steep sand dunes are best for sledding. We also hiked the Alkali Dunes trail which takes you through the dunes. They also have a Junior Ranger Program for the kids.

After the White sands missle Range. There is the White sands national monument. Run by the US National Park Services. There is a really nice gift shop at the entrance and a great book store. After visiting the main building you get to drive into the park. It is $3 per adult and kids under the age of 16 are free. Bring water and suncreen. The park consist of a drive through monumental Sand dunes. They dont seem to finish. The beauty is that the sand is powder like (gypsum) and is white. It is one of the most beautiful sights I've ever seen. There are hiking trails and the kids bought a Sled at the Gift shop and spent the afternoon sliding on the white sand dunes. I highly recommend it.

Amazing 8 mile loop road out to the middle of the whiteness - sand drifting across the road reminded me of snow drifts I am familiar with in the Midwest. I wanted to try the sledding, springing the $10 to rent a little saucer. I think it was a little overrated, although we saw lots of people doing it, since we were there on a Saturday. The sand was deep, and even on the steep hills, I just seemed to sink in instead of slide down! And then there was the walk up! It was a lot of work! Unfortunately, our stop was in the heat of the day, and finally it was just too hot to be enjoyable. Amazing place, though, never seen anything like it! Hope to go back when we come this way again, maybe in the cooler evenings!

Really a national treasure. In the middle of the desert between Las Cruces, NM and Alamogordo, NM you will find White Sands National Monument. The visitors center has a great exhibit featuring the national monument along with a short video that educates visitors on the formation of the sand dunes. Once you enter the monument, you can choose many different routes to take and pick your dune. Never very busy when we go there are covered picnic tables available with grills. The kids and adults:) alike enjoy sliding down the sand dunes in waxed bottomed (candles work) saucer sleds (approximately $10-15 at visitors center so if you have one, bring it!) Watching the sunset from the top of the dunes is amazing. Dogs are allowed but must be leashed. Alcohol is prohibited during "spring break" times (call ahead if concerned, I think during March and April) and they will check your coolers. Be prepared to have a car full of sand, no matter how hard you try it sticks on your clothes. During the summers can be very hot so recommend going early in the morning or later in the evening. Certain days of the week/month the monument offers sunset tours, etc. Check the website for more info.

Our family was visiting Ruidoso, NM for an extended weekend. One morning we took the drive to White Sands to check it out. My wife and I and our two kids (3 & 5) and another family with same age children. It truly is a magnificent sight. I believe its 300 square miles of pure white sand dunes in the valley of some mountains. Definitely go to the visitor center and watch the short video. Even our young kids enjoyed it. It is also worth buying the saucers (sleds) in the gift shop and don't forget to buy the wax there too. You will want to keep the saucer good and waxed to enjoy a fast ride down the dunes. An unwaxed saucer won't go anywhere. There are two options. You can buy new or used saucers to start and you can turn them back in after you use them for a small refund. I think a new one was about $14, and they give you $5 back if you return it. I didn't know there were used ones or I would have pick that option. Anyway, the bottom line is that this is a worth while destination where you can easily burn up several hours. You can pack a cooler with food and beverages (take lots of water) and enjoy the day. Keep in mind my visit was in September... I have know idea what the heat would be like in mid summer. Probably not as nice of a visit I would imagine. If you don't enjoy and appreciate this sight, you simple don't have an appreciation for nature and the great outdoors. Enjoy.

Awesome place to see. The most amazing sandpile you will ever see. Kids and adults both loved walking and sledding down the sand. It was about 105 out but the sand was cool to your barefeet. I wasn't really happy about how they sold/rented the sleds but it was worth it for the kids. I wanted you to "buy" a sled and then you could "return" it and get $5.00 back. Other than that, I would recommend seeing this at least twice in your life. Great photo ops everywhere.

We visited White Sands on the way home from our tour of the Southwest. Everyone was a little grumpy and on the sad side and didn't expect much when we pulled in. Boy, were we wrong! What a beautiful place! The dunes are made of white gypsum and some are over 60 feet high. We bought a sled in the gift shop for $15 and went sledding in the dune field with the kids (ages 3, 8, 10). Even our 65-year-old "granny" went sledding down the dunes and had a blast! The sand is a different consistency than beach sand so it wasn't "yucky" feeling when we had to get back into the car. Photo ops abound with this gorgeous scenery for your backdrop. This is definitely a must-see!

Living close by in Southern New Mexico makes it convenient to visit this amazing place known as White Sands. It is right off of Interstate 70 between the White Sands Missile Range and Holloman AFB in Alamagordo. We have visited a few times in the past couple of years and they have quite a bit to offer for the whole family. You will first park at the visitor center where you will find a lovely adobe gift shop and media area where they show films about how nature has created the spectacular site. As this is part of the National Park Service, you will find a wealth of information about this natural wonder. The fee for entrance is $3 per person and you have the option of walking on trails or driving the 8 mile loop around the park. We chose to drive as it was hot most days when we visited. As you enter the park itself, you will be astounded by the abundance of pure white gypsum sand that surrounds you like sand dunes on a beach. You will see nothing but white, almost like you were in a winter wonderland. Along the road you will find areas where you can pull off and walk into the dunes. There are boardwalks along the way as well and roof covered picnic tables for the family. The park service offers many educational programs throughout the year and they even give tours of the lake that creates the sand several times a year. This is just a spectacular place that the whole family should visit when in New Mexico. You will feel like you are on another planet, as there is nothing like it on this Earth!

When my husband got his 4-day pass from Ft. Bliss before heading overseas, I wasn't sure if he would want to spend an afternoon frolicking in the sand...but even he agreed that White Sands is an absolute MUST when you are in the area. It is a $3.00/person entrance fee, which is good for 7 days and includes additional activities like the Sunset Stroll we took at 5 PM. When you first arrive, the visitor's center is across the breezeway from the bathrooms and they sell postcards, magnets, and offer literature about upcoming events at the park. There is also a knowledgeable ranger on staff who can answer questions about the park. There is a short film you can watch, which was not in operation when we were there. Behind the visitor's center is the gift store where you can buy more White Sands memorabilia and purchase a large disc sled for sledding down the dunes. To buy a sled is $14.95 and they will buy it back for $5.00. There is also sled wax for sale at the counter. It's 99 cents per block and is used to wax the bottom of the sled to keep the sand from sticking to it. We did not discover any of this until we were ready to leave the park so I'm sharing it with you now to keep you from making the same mistake. The Sunset Stroll, which starts 5 miles into the park from the visitor's center is also a must. The sun turns the San Andreas/Sacramento mountains an amazing color of orange when it sets and the sands are just brilliant. The stroll is led by a park volunteer and only ventures 100 yards or so into the dunes. I did it barefoot.

We elected to drive down to Alamogordo the evening before and stay the the budget White Sands Motel. The $50 room was well worth the $$ just to get to the park before the crowds and the hot sun the next morning. We really enjoyed the 4.5 mile Alkali Flats hike. Bring a camelback and prepare to be all alone trekking up and down dunes for as far as the eyes can see! We got the most memorable pictures. Then we drove up to Cloudcroft in the mountains for a cool late lunch, and down into Carlsbad just in time to see the night flight of bats. What a perfect day!

When you least expect it, you can be most amazed. From Texas to New Mexico we had to take a different route itself in order to go to this place but in the end few extra hours were well worth it. People look for becahes with such white sands but I have never seen such pristine and clear white sand anywhere in my life. The reason is a lake nearby, however a 45 minute drive surrounded by large expanse of such pretty pious whiteness is a great and unique experience in itself. Definitely worth visiting with hardly 3$ cost per person. Maybe go early in the morning and you could feel it to be your own territory with no crowd and can get picturesque photos too.

The visitor center is nice to visit. Buy a disc to slide down the dunes. We visited Aug 25,2009 and got lucky with the heat. It was cloudy and a bit damp. You can stop in most wide places and climb around but follow the road deep into the dunes for the best dunes. It cost adults $3.00. Bring your own water,hat and sunshade. If you plan to hike deep bring a a GPS or a compass unless you incredibly lucky. This was a lot of fun and family oriented.

Amazing jewel in the middle of the desert. We drove down from Rio Rancho, NM and arrived at the park w/in 5 hours (several stops, 3 kids....). Stopped at the visitor center, the used/rental sleds were sold out so we spent $15 EACH buying a new one (probably would fetch $7 at Wal-Mart, but hey you are in the middle of no-where). Drove into the park and found what we considered to be one of the last covered picnic tables left. Recommendation, get there early so you can secure a good, covered picnic area as you need it, the Sun is brutal. Set-up camp and attached the ceremonial kite to the car (flys all day by itself as there is a constant light wind....). Had lunch, kids sledded and over all, we just had a wonderful day at WSNP. We are looking forward to our next and next and next visit back to the NP. I wish that we lived close enough to warrant a seasonal pass as we would probably go there every weekend as the opportunities to connect with the family, explore nature and just have a wonderful time are endless.

Our Photo Club spent two days at White Sands National Monument. Ranger Kathy Denton made certain we were shown the very best places for sunrise and sunset photos. For a mere $50 we were met by Ranger Terry Wilder at 5:30 AM , given quiet time to explore and get ready for the glory of sunrise. The 15 minute video gave us a good understanding of the geology of White Sands and gave us an even larger appreciation of its natural beauty and magical colors.

We arrived at the dunes at around noon time. Stopped in the gift shop to pick up a sled and headed out to the loop road. Sleds are $15, but if they are returned you get a $5 refund with your receipt. It is extremely hot during the day time, so we did a limited amount of sledding and hiking, before heading back to the hotel with the intention of returning for the sunset. We followed through with the plan, and it was amazing. We hiked out to a very large dune and took in the sunset while doing a few more runs with our sled. There was a nice breeze and the temperature was perfect. Traveling from MA to CA, this was probably one of the most memorable experiences we had on our trip. I can't believe someone rated this as "terrible".

This place was awesome. Definitely a unique experience. Half the time it looked like we were at the beach without an ocean and the other half of the time it looked like snow! We got there a little before the sunset tour. We were able to stop at the gift shop to buy a sled. The sled cost $15 and sled wax was 75c. Apparently they will buy it back for $5 but unfortunately we didn't get to do that as the gift shop closed promptly at 7. So if you go for the sunset your (7:45pm sunset last night and the tour starts an hour before) and do a little sledding there is no time to visit the gift shop after which seems kind of silly to me. You would think the shop would stay open until the park closes...at 9pm.

We hiked at the Sipsey Wilderness. There is an abundance of birds, flora and fauna. The trails were fairly easy, with multiple waterfalls. Parking lot is spacious with a $3 per vehicle charge. Trail is fairly easy to follow, but not marked. We had children 5-12 with us. There are poisonous plants along the path, so long pants are advised. There are picnic tables and in ground grills (not very clean) so you could cook out if you wanted.

We stayed for two nights in clear creek campground which was beautiful and perfectly maintained for $26/night lakeside tent camping. It's about 45 min from the ranger station in Double Springs which is a MUST for figuring out where you're headed--don't try to figure it out through the Internet alone, we tried and failed and should have just made time to go there sooner instead of wasting time. They give you up to date directions to about six different awesome, isolated waterfalls, a church built in 1850 something and a natural bridge all in the forest. You can camp primitive anywhere with a permit from the ranger station and there's a $5 primitive campground close to double springs as well (we didn't see it though). Went to Caney Creek Falls (an easy 1.5 mile hike) and Kinlock Falls (right by windy dirt road) both gorgeous but someone needs to adopt-a-waterfall and clean up Kinlock falls, apparently locals trash it. So beautiful everywhere and we didn't run into one other person anywhere outside of town or our campground--no crowding here! Lots of different kinds of mushrooms and butterflies too, and flying squirrels kept our dog up all night!
This is a fantastic National Forest campground with full hookups. We only paid $20 per night for full hookups. The restroom and shower facilities were clean.

We had not heard of this National Park, but since we were in the area decided to stop and see what it was all about. We decided to take the 75 minute Entrance tour and found it to be very interesting. This is not a beautiful cave, but has an odd formation trough out from water dripping down. Nathan did a nice job explaining the history of the cave abs the odd formations. The price is $12 per person and $6 if you have the senior National Parks Pass.

We went to the Wind cave through Custer State park and the Blackhills. Tours fill up fast. We did the Fairground tour which had a lot of steps, but worth it. Prices were cheap compared to other caves I've been too. Ranger was friendly and very informative. Take a light jacket. At a constant 53 degrees in the cave. Go early in the morning and take a cooler lunch.

We spent a full day at Wind Cave. This is probably considered a lesser-known National Park but it's a gem. The cave itself is fascinating. There are multiple tours you can take that suit all activity/ability levels. The interior is well lit with sturdy paths, stairs, and railings. The various types of crystals we saw were lovely and the 'boxwork', which is the special feature of this cave, was enchanting. But the Park is so much more than the below-ground cave. We saw lots of bison (and sat and waited for lots of bison to get off the #@$# road so we could go on) and prairie dogs. There are a number of hiking trails. We did the self-guided Nature Trail near the main Park buildings and also hiked the Rankin Ridge trail. Strongly suggest you take the trail UP the ridge and then the fire road back DOWN; better views both ways. Very glad we made it to this Park.

We thoroughly enjoyed visiting this national cave. The guided tour was well worth the $6 admission rate for seniors. TRY TO GEWT AT THE FRONT OF THE LINE!!!! There are three different tours depending on the number of stairs you want to climb. We took the middle tour and found it to be very enjoyable. The easiest is the Garden of Eden with 150 steps and 1 hour long. The second is the Natural Entrance Tour with 300 steps mostly down and 1 hr and 15 minutes. The longest one is the Fair Ground Tour with 450 steps and about 1 1/2 hrs long. The cost is the same for all three tours.

We took the fairgrounds tour at a cost of $12 per person. There are a lot of steps (mostly down), so wear some decent foot wear. This tour lasts about 90 minutes and will provide a good history of the cave. You will be able to go deep into the cave and have a chance to experience total darkness. Most of the tour is fairly open, but you have to watch your head in a couple places. Highly recommend the tour. Its worth the time and money and it is really not that strenuous.

We visited Wind Cave in late August, went on a $12 per person tour that lasted just over an hour. There are a variety of tours to match folk's walking abilities, some use the elevator both directions while others have longer distances with stairs. Pick what suits your needs! We loved the tour and thought the Ranger really brought the history and the cave to life. You see interesting rock formations, get a feel for what it must have been like to be a first explorer in the Cave plus experience the total blackness of the cave with the lights are put out very briefly. One couple left the tour right at the start, not for them I guess. This slowed things down a bit as the Ranger had to lead them out. Another couple had a 16 month old in a front pack (only kind allowed) and the poor kid just wanted to get down and move around. I would suggest leaving younger children at the surface, the walking and stairs are not too difficult but I just don't think they would enjoy it. After the tour we drove around the park a bit and went on a 4.5 mile hike in the woods and grasslands. To our surprise a bison blocked the trail at one point, a bit scary as signs indicate that they can move at 35 mph. We did a very wide loop around him and continued on.

You get a ticket as you enter the visitor's center. Price is low. You have a scheduled tour with a park ranger. We had to wait an hour. About 40 in our group. The tour is awesome. Low ceilings in the cave, about 300 stairs down, walkways are narrow, little lighting, 30 seconds they turn the lights off all together, real unique rock formations. We loved the experience. Hike was about an hour and a half.

Have been in many other Caverns, but this was my first "Cave." We have the Access Federal Pass, so there was no entrance fee (would recommend getting a yearly pass anyway, let's support the Park System!).Reservation-wise, I didn't have problems getting my Mom into the Garden of Eden tour, however she didn't like it because she felt the lighting was very poor, the walking surface was irregular, there were lots of slippery poorly illuminated steps, it was hard to understand the Tour Guid, and there were apparently areas where she felt there should be handrails or better handrails. Kid is wheelchair bound, however the Ranger staff- Ina Winter- was very accommodating and we were able to go into 2 rooms via elevator.
