It's very different than Carlsbad, and Kartchner and Colossal in AZ, I guess due to the manner it was formed- there are no stalagtites/stalagmites, drapery, bacon, etc. Wind Cave is a "tight" cave- narrow passageways, low head space and without the large "rooms" of the other Caverns. The boxwork (think that's what it ws called) was different, but not visible to me on the abbreviated tour. It was present on the G of E Tour.

Come see the cave that breathes and learn some Native history at the same time. We went for the second time last year and were amazed at all the cave formations. This cave is 20 to 30 minuets from Custer and can be reached very easily. For Fee information just go to the web site. The Drive To the cave is very nice and lets you see lots of wildlife.

After visiting Custer State Park (lots of bison) we opted for the short trip south to Wind Cave National Park. (There were some bison there, too, near the entrance.) Admission is free, but the cave tours had a reasonable fee. We chose an hour long tour which led us down (300 steps) into the cave. Our guide, Sina Eagle Bear, gave us an informative tour of the cave and its formation, as well as stories of the Lakota people and their history associated with the caves. At the conclusion of the tour, you are transported back to earth on elevators. It's a worthwhile experience.

This is a very big walking cave, no crawling. No flashlights needed but I had one that made it interesting to look down passages. It took about 60-90 min. Fourth graders get in free to national parks this year and everyone with them. Since we did 10 parks, we saved probably $200 on fees. Our ranger was informative and funny. There's another cave nearby called Jewel Cave which we wanted to see but you have to arrive early in the day. This cave is open later.

We did the cave tour with our family of four and loved it! This is a very unique cave, with lots of narrow passageways and fascinating boxwork formations. Our guide through the cave was interesting, and you could tell that she is very passionate about it, which we loved. It was very crowded earlier in the day when we came in to get our tickets, but by the last tour of the day (the one we decided to book), there were almost no crowds. As an added bonus, our son is a 4th grader and has the National Park 4th Grader Pass and we got to tour the cave for free, so if you have a 4th grader, get your pass before you go!

Went to wind cave national park yesterday and did the Garden of Eden tour of the cave. A perfect amount of time (about a hour) and info. Very interesting. The Rangers here really love their jobs as they are very friendly and helpful. Bring a lunch or they have a microwave to heat up canteen sandwiches. Prices do not gouge. Saw buffalo right up to the car as well as pronghorn antelope, prairie dogs and deer. Camping area seemed nice, didn't stay just drove through.

Lots of areas to observe prairie dogs. At first, we didn't see them, but we kept watching the area, and then we saw hundreds of them. They come up from underground to look for food. They are a lot of fun to watch. Also, the Bison. We got to see a herd of them. They are truly majestic. The Cave Tour was also great. Down 150 steps in the beginning and then down another 150 as you descend the cave. Lot of "boxwork" to observe above you throughout the tour. Cost of our tour was $12.

One can not go wrong with a National Park! Great attraction for all ages. We did the Garden of Eden cave tour ($10 per person). Very easy walk and our Ranger was very knowledgeable and fun to listen to. We also did one small hike on our own just off the visitor center that gave great views of the prairies. Not a ton of rigorous hiking like we like but good place for easier, sight seeing hikes. Lots of Bison sightings.
Entrance tour $12 per adult

Feel like a bad parent to not have taken kids there while they were growing up. This is a massive park! Geysers aplenty, lots of animals, plenty to do amidst beautiful scenery. Spent two days and only scratched the surface. Grand Geyser is more impactful than Old Faithful. Bring your camera!

My wife and I travel everywhere, but for some reason we hadn't gone to Yellowstone, well let me say this should be on everyone's list of places to visit. Start when your children are young, but old enough to appreciate this fabulous national park. The Park Service is wonderful and very helpful. Let me also say if you can pick up a copy of a book sold at the park "Yellowstone in a Day" It has I think every sight and how to get to them as well as things to do together, like near each other. It's $10. At the park. We joined Yellowstone Forever and became a supporter and one of the benefits is a discount at the stores, a tee shirt and a nice booklet. This is one of our (USA citizens) national parks and we should do whatever we can to make sure it's here forever. I won't go into each sight, but spectacular and outstanding goes a long way to describe this park and to see the animals roaming around is breathtaking. To stay in the park you need to make reservations a year in advance. We spent 4 nights and 5 days and saw a lot but you can stay much longer because you never run out of things to see and do. One of the questions do you have pictures to share, LOL I have hundreds of pictures as will yo when you're here.

We so enjoyed our two days at Yellowstone. It was not nearly enough time, but at least we got to see the highlights! The park is breathtaking! All the visitor centers are nice and clean and have really wonderful people working at them! We did some short hikes to the falls in the canyon area. Trails were great! Mostly we drove around and stopped at most of the major points of interest! Cannot believe the diversity of the land of this park - wide open pastures, snow covered mountains and rocky canyons! It's such an amazing place! Every American needs to bring their family here at least once! And you will have memories that last a lifetime! And don't forget to stop and see all the wildlife! It's unbelievable! We were so lucky to see 2 black bears and a grizzly! Plus we also saw lots of bison, elk, pronghorns, moose and even more! Hope we can return again to this American gem! Feel so blessed to see this with the ones I love!

Push the gorgeous park to the front of your "Must See" list. Do not wait! And don't be afraid to take children. We visited in July 2016 and our children were 15, 12, and 8. They all agreed it was their most favorite vacation EVER. And they are well traveled kids having visited Hawaii, Alaska, Costa Rica, Iceland and (of course) Disney World. Also, note that this was a 2 week trip, mostly unplugged from devices. In our current state of connectivity 24/7, this was truly a gift!

Entry fee of $30 per vehicle, no charge with NPS Senior Pass. This is the most scenic national park of its type. Most other national parks you are looking down at the sights and at Zion you must look up. My one recommendation would be not to visit on a weekend as the crowds are just out of control. The shuttle system helps with the traffic and emissions but creates significant parking issues causing people to park wherever they please without regards for the park property or other people. A return trip is definitely warranted but during a weekday.

Zion is incredible!! So different from many other canyons in that you start at the bottom and go up, vs. Bryce or the Grand Canyon where you are at the top and go down. Find parking early and take the shuttle into the park. You can't go wrong with any hike you choose. Plenty of shops in town rent water shoes and gear to hike the Narrows, a wonderful hike, or just a lovely walk. Our favorite hike is the Overlook, which you drive to and is right past the tunnel. $30 to take a car into the park, but worth it to support the park. Every hike has its unique and beautiful angle, but if you don't hike, it's worth going to the lodge to see the multitude of deer that gather to graze on the front lawn, many does and fawns, and sometimes a buck or two. This park should be on everyone's list at least once, and I hate to say that as it's already overcrowded, but you'd be missing something in life if you didn't go.
Zion is a beautiful national park. If you're visiting Utah and doing several national parks some advice. Purchase an annual pass at $30 entry fee per park an annual pass is just $80.

This must be on your list if you are staying anywhere close to this National Park. I would recommend going during the week as it was less crowded. Also, kids 15 and under are free. Adults were $15 each. We parked in the city and the bus came every 10-15 minutes it was free and takes you to the park where you purchase your tickets and then take a park bus to whichever trail you want to hike. We were headed to the Narrows but flooding and rain were a chance so we skipped it. The views were simply breathtaking and the kids were able to play in the water at the end of trail. Highly recommend and even for wheel chairs as there are some fully concrete trails.

JMJ Just getting here from Las Vegas was a big WOW! The switch backs along the drive were breathtaking and then you enter the Park!! The little towns surrounding the Park seemed welcoming and next time we should make this a much longer visit. The Park was crowded so we had to park right out side the gate and that is charged by the hour. We had National Park Passes so we used those and skipped the fees being charged. Everyone had to use the Trams/buses to get farther into the Park. There are 9 stops along the way where you can get on/off and see different trails to hike, or scenery to enjoy. Some of the stops have bathrooms and other services and some have very little to offer-make sure you get a map so you won't miss something. The Park Staff was sure to warn you of the dangers that can be present in the park-severe over heating, dehydration, animals, the Virgin River, and that is very important if you want to make this a good visit. Dress appropriately for the trails if you plan to hike. There is a Lodge to stay at but reservations probably Must be made in advance. Try to go when the Park isn't too busy-weekdays off season are better that the week-ends, but just try to get here! It is handicapped accessible but good luck. You'd better be strong to push wheel chairs or stroller through parts of the trails. We had small children and they had fun looking for the smaller animals on the trails.

We took the shuttle from our Lodge and the ride was free. It's better to shuttle your way to the park and ride entrance. Pay to get in,or show Golden Card and all members of the family get in free. Walk to the maze of various ages of people waiting for the next dual shuttle service again Free Ride, we took the shuttle all the up and back down,it was very hot 105 degrees afternoon

what a delightful way to spend with the grandtwins... My husband has a bad knee and one of the girls overheats -- but we chose to do the 2 mile walk at stop 9 -- to the Narrows... perfect choice. Easy walk - -much shaded. right along the river -- Everyone felt very accomplished after the exercise.... Take plenty of extra water and a small snack if you do this walk. Dont' forget to use the National Parks Passport -- we bought them and will try to catch up - -and then use for future trip planning.

How do you explain in words? The only word that came to mind at the time was "WOW"? Their are many aspects of Zion! Hiking, Climbing, Biking, Relaxing, WOW. We Don't miss driving out the east end of the park you pass thru one of the longest tunnels that I have ever been in to see the beauty of the high country in the checkerboard Mesa Area. Next time we will venture into the valley but you have to take a shuttle to do that as no cars are allowed. If you are a Senior you can get a lifetime pass for all parks for only $10.

This was the first time the family had seen mountains like this. We come from a flat coastal town, and this blew their minds. The different colors, features and shapes are amazing. We walked several trails and were really upset we could not stay for more. This is a spot we will return to and dedicate a lot more time to. We also drove the Mt Caramel Hwy which is amazing. The views and colors are astonishing. My daughter was in awe the entire time. We also stopped at the museum and spoke to the rangers and got out National Parks Passport stamped. Everyone was extremely helpful.

Our first stop was Zion. When you are in St. George you have NO idea what you are in for. Not until you start the drive No on 15 and cut east into the lower and main section of the park, do you realize the grandiosity of the landscape. You are surrounded by magnificent red rock that shoot vertically for 1000s of feet. At times its one huge slick rock and at others a collection of jagged edged rocks in attached at varying degrees. Below, is the virgin river cutting through the park surrounded by not a large variety of landscape plants and trees. Flowers are sparsely dotted along and every care must be taken not to disturb them by staying on the established paths. Every park we went to, I took photos of the different flowers, bushes and trees we saw. It's difficult to express the beauty of magnificence of what we saw - you have to see it yourself but here's the big takeaway if you are planning to visit. RENT A BIKE! You can rent a bile for 1/2 or full day, $25 or $35, respectively. Take the shuttle (bike loads on shuttle), all the way to the top to Shinawava Temple. Get off there and start your day! You will not longer be on the shuttle schedule b/c you can get on your bike and go at will. And what's even more wonderful, is that 90% is downhill. The uphill grades are manageable and even if you have to walk a few yard, big deal! You are in Zion! That's another advantage over the shuttle, you can ride at your own pace, stop and look at the scenery from the side of the road anywhere you feel like stopping! If you rely on the Shuttle, you can only get on and off at the shuttle stops and you only see what is at the stops. With a bike, you see the entire park at your pace. Park it anywhere and pick up a trail. I can't tell you have many stops we left where the shuttle line looked like it could be 100 deep. And def have a beer at stop 6 (?). It's wonderful! We actually packed our lunch in our backpack so turned off on our bikes near a spot along the river, sat on a huge tree trunk and ate listening to the river rushed by, instead of being surrounded by tourist trying to talk over each other. After lunch, we walked to a calmer spot and skipped some rocks before getting back on the bike and riding on.

A drive through park, they offer free shuttle tours to help keep the traffic down, and the shuttle is the only way to get to the trailheads. We drove this park and went on to Bryce and Red Canyon Park. If you might be going to more than one national park get the interagency pass, it is $80 a year from purchase dare and gets the whole car load in every national park.

If you are a senior +65, for sure get your lifetime pass, it's only $10.00 and good forever. It was a drizzily day so only took the River Walk Trail. Got wet but had a plastic poncho which saved the day for me. Cliffs and rocks were very shiny from the rain so it was a different look from other times I've been here. Luckily it wasn't too crowded I'm sure because of the weather so the shuttle rides were easy.
It will take some time to get through the tunnels but the scenery is well worth the wait. Very busy near Visitor Center if you can find any place to park! Get your Park Passport stamped here!

Being from Alaska, and see most of the big National Park except for the Cali ones, this is the best. I liked it better than Denali too. That's saying a lot. The one down fall, this place is so busy. I visited at the end of March and it was still packed. Couldn't imagine what summer is like. I'd suggest, early spring, or late fall. Especially if you don't like the heat. It was already 70 at the end of March. Plan ahead, and book hotels/camp sites early. Bring your piggy bank, it's very expensive. Cheapest camp sites are $30/night. You can do the main canyon in a couple days, then head up to Kolob Canyon, and Kolob Terrace. Just as pretty, but a lot less people. It was a relief to get away from the crowds.

Just some observations...get there early, we had a 45 minute wait at the entrance to get on a shuttle bus. There are two small parking lots, for $20.00 or you have to find a place along the road, or go back to Springdale and take a shuttle bus back to the visitor center. First time visitor, came in from the east entrance, very interesting going through the tunnels. If you came in through Springdale and just took the shuttle bus to the different stops and left that same way you miss some interesting stuff. I guess its always busy, we did not think in the middle of the week, in April it would be bad, so I don't think i'd like to be there in the heat of the summer with even more people, but it was certainly worth a full day.

GO NOW - the weather is beautiful, the trails are not overwhelmed with hikers - hotel rates, especially in Cedar City, are reasonable - don't wait until the summer rush when the park will be jammed with tourists - go now! Plan at least two full days - stop in the visitor center to plan your hikes and be realistic about your skill levels. All the trails are beautiful, but the most demanding ones truly are DEMANDING. Don't forget the canyons on the north side of the park. Use the shuttle system to get around - get to the park and park early. Take plenty of water, lip balm, sun screen - good hiking shoes are a must! Go now - miss the mad rush of people that will start arriving in May. Make sure you get an annual national park pass in advance - will save you a lot of $$$ in the long run.

I went to Zion with my boyfriend because we found a cheap flight to Vegas from Seattle. We are avid backpackers and were pretty anxious to have an opportunity to just get outside after a fairly rainy winter. We spent the first day driving the Zion Canyon Road and it was incredible, although visitors in the summer will need to take the park's shuttle. We had a campsite at the Watchman Campground booked online for the first night, and then we were able to get walk-up permits for a traverse that we'd been planning for a few weeks. We arranged a shuttle and dropped our car off at Lee Pass where we planned to end our traverse. We hiked from The Grotto up the West Rim Trail, where we camped at Site 9. The next day, we hiked down Wildcat Canyon Trail, picked up the Connector, and continued on the Hop Valley Trail. We camped at site 10 near Beatty Spring, which was fantastic. The third morning, we hiked to our car at Lee Pass on the La Verkin Creek Trail. Any of the sites we passed would have been great spots to stop for the night, so plan your campsite reservations based on the mileage you are comfortable with. We had perfect weather and plenty of sunshine, but there was still about 1.5 feet of snow on the Horse Pasture Plateau (a large portion of the West Rim Trail and Wildcat Canyon Trail were covered). We were prepared with microspikes although we only used them in one area. Check trail conditions when you arrive at the park.

Beautiful national park located with 2 hours of Las Vegas near St George, Utah. Spectacular scenery and abundant hiking opportunities. Restaurant and gift store on site. Plan for more than a day to take advantage of the numerous hiking trails that range from beginner to expert. Pack your own food and water and have a picnic at the top of a mountain. Pay attention to weather advisories as it can change quickly and if you are hiking in the slot, flash flooding is a concern

Located in Utah: about a two and 1/2 hour drive north of Las Vegas. This is a part of the National Park System. It has many beautiful cliffs and rock formations. Unless you are a senior citizen, on active duty military, or have purchased a national park pass: it will cost you $30.00 to enter the park for seven days. If you are on foot and hiking, they will let you enter for $15.00.

Maybe more folks choose to visit this wonderful park than those in charge thought would attend the week of Thanksgiving? Shuttle service to the 12 different stops had already been stopped for this season - except the shuttles would be operating on November 24 thru November 26th. As a result, a number of the different nature's show piece's - could not be visited as there wasn't any place to park. Parking at the different stops are very limited. While signs are posted that parking on the road ways wasn't allowed - appears no one, including me, could read the warnings. Which made part of the overall experience less than great. However; after talking to the locals, the shuttle service may not be the answer either - locals claim that standing in line to catch a shuttle (they run every 15 minutes) was like standing in line to ride an amusement ride. Even with the limited parking - still worth the time we spent exploring just one of our nation's national parks! As for pricing - it really helps if you are over 62 - you can purchase a life time pass - good at all national parks for the bargain price of $10.00 - compared to the charge of $30.00 per car - good for 7 days - on foot or bicycle cost $15.00 each. PS - the pathways are very well kept and while step at times - most were an easy walk. We walked a total 7.7 miles or 16,153 steps in our 6 hour visit. That included looking for parking places.

Scary to drive at first but you get used to it the more you do it. Lots of little pull offs to get amazing pictures. Some hiking trails, easy to hard. There are several national parks in the area if you are going to do more than one purchase the annual pass that gets you into all of them! $30 to enter National Parks the annual pass is $80.

My wife and i spent 3.5 days in Zion NP as the last of our 5-park hiking trip in Utah in October 2016. Zion has a greater number of challenging hikes (moderate + strenuous) in relation to its easy hikes, so this park offers more for the fit and hardy hiker than for the less fit one. That said, we enjoyed our time in the park. The only problem was the number of people who had less acquaintance with trail courtesy, most of whom came off tour buses that stopped at all the easy and even some of the moderate trailheads. Our advice is to avoid these folks by hiking such trails before 9:30am or after 5:00pm. After hiking over 100 miles in 5 parks, we decided it was time to find a coin laundry, since sink washing only goes so far. Our exploration of the forums for Zion/Springdale suggested there were coin laundries to be had, but where? We found Zion Canyon Laundry on the main drag. It is apparently connected to the next-door Bumbleberry Inn in some way. My wife and I used this coin laundry first thing on a Saturday morning to wash and dry our hiking clothes between days in Zion NP. Located at the Bumbleberry shuttle stop, this was only a 5-minute walk from where we were staying, so we bundled up our laundry and hiked on over. There were many commercial machines, both top-loaders and front-loaders, as well as two large commercial washers and dryers for things like sleeping bags. Only one washer was out of service while we were there and it was clearly marked. They had a change machine that handled $1, $5, $10 and $20 (!) bills. One could also buy detergent and bleach. Standard-size washers cost $1.75 per load and the dryers were $.25 for 10 minutes. The place has two sorting/folding tables and two rolling hampers to help with transport from machine to table. We met other fellow hikers doing their laundry while we were there, and there was a nice sense of camaraderie. As far as coin laundries go, this was better than most and well located. The only restriction is the total prohibition of eating, drinking, smoking --or cooking (!) while there. We weren’t quite sure how someone would be preparing food while there, but realize backcountry folks will have gas kitchen gear and suspect the owners must have encountered cooking if they decided to ban it. Clearly, a big part of hiking is handling the dust. Being able to wash our clothes made subsequent hikes in Zion much more pleasant.

The fee to enter the park is now $30, not $25 like most sites are still saying. The Watchman campground is reasonable ($20 for no power, $30 for electricity, no showers but there are bathrooms), has the stream nearby and the sites are not too close together. There are shady spots, close to half of them actually are. You are very close to the visitors center and the museum, within 5-10 min walking.

If you are a senior citizen get a park pass. They are good at all national parks and are only ten dollars. At least that is what we paid a few years ago. Worth every penny of payment. Drove thru from the Arizona side to Utah this time.

Zion was a beautiful place to visit. The rock formations were awesome. But bring some cash because they will charge you a tunnel fee of $17. The shuttle that brings you up and down the canyon is a well oiled machine going every 5 mins. It gets really crowded in late afternoon, so bring some patience. Our favorite places were the narrows and weeping walls.

Road Trip home from CA. Take the Free shuttle to 9 sites that cars are NOT allowed. At any stop, you can exit the bus and roam around the attraction. We liked the "Weeping Rock" Stop the best. You must walk up a path to get to see it, but it is worth the effort. The Court of the Patriarch's Stop was a close second. The monoliths on the road out of the Park ( if you are going East ) are overwhelmingly inspiring. We just had to pull off the road and take in the Vistas, Wow. The cost is $30 / car

We take our vacations after Labor Day. In late September, kids are back in school, but leaf peepers aren't out yet. This helps us avoid crowds and hot temperatures. However, Zion was PACKED. I had read advice to park at the visitor's center and take the shuttle. Bad advice. We wanted to visit the visitor's center, check out the exhibits and watch the film. Unfortunately, there were no parking spaces. ZERO. I spent 25 minutes driving around the lot. Every time someone left (not often) two or three cars would be waiting to take their spot. You can't park on surrounding roads either. We finally left, disappointed. Not able to take the shuttle, we were limited where we could drive. From what I could see, the park is beautiful. But don't think we got our $30 worth. My advice - park in Springdale and take the shuttle from there.

Dear Ones, Zion National Park is a beautiful place to observe the beauty that only God could have created. You will be surrounded by magnificent rock formations...MAKE SURE you see both the east and west side of the park through the tunnel...they are so very different and beautiful in their own right. The sky is such a beautiful BLUE here. You can take a shuttle bus from outside the park and then a shuttle bus inside the Park to 8 different venues for hiking or, if you are like me, just to observe the beauty. At the Lodge, you can buy food outside and delicious ice cream soft serve cones, just inside the door. There is also a restaurant in the Lodge. If I'd missed Zion National Park, when we also saw Bryce and the Grand Canyon North Rim -- I would have been disappointed -- because they are both holes (Canyons), but Zion is UP, UP, UP -- all around you. There are hikes galore and many hikers -- but, I'm not able to do that, so seeing and being surrounded by this beautiful Park was the HIGHLIGHT of our trip. Wait until you see some of my photos. We stayed at the Zion Canyon B & B -- look up that one, to see my review. It was out of this world, just a few blocks from the entrance to Zion and the same price as much lesser accommodations elsewhere. There is a $30 entrance fee for cars to all the Parks -- unless you're old like me and have a $10/lifetime pass to all the National Parks.

This is a fantastic park, with a lot of opportunities to see wildlife up close, nice shuttles to take you for the best photo ops. Plenty of both easy and strenuous hikes depending on what you can do. We did several easy trails that were not very long and enjoyed the views of the river, mountains, wildlife, and flowers along the way; it was very relaxing and enjoyable. Our room was a suite, but IMO was not worth the money we paid for it since it was not that clean and a couple of things didn't work in the room. The space in the suite was nice and would be more of a value if shared with another couple or 2. The bed was pretty comfortable and we really enjoyed watching the mule deer in the evenings from the rocking chairs on our balcony. Coffee in the room was good, fridge and microwave were pretty small, but good enough I suppose. Best part of our visit besides the encounters with wildlife was the open air tram tour that we took the evening of our arrival with our guide Jesse. Very informative, laid back tour where we got to see everything in about 60-75 min. We stopped a couple of times to take a few pictures and stretch our legs, but the great thing about the open air tram is that you can get a lot of fantastic pictures while riding in the tram! Love the tram, don't miss it! Well worth the $14 per adult (children are less). Glad we stayed in the park because of the mule deer and easy access to the lodge/shuttles, but to save money, you might consider staying just outside the park at say, the Majestic View Lodge or similar. There are several B&B's nearby also, but not sure of the prices. I highly recommend going to Zion!!

Wow what can you say but amazing and beautiful. On this trip my wife and I both agree that Zion and the Arches were our two favorites, vastly different but both offer wonderful trail walks where you can immerse yourself in nature. Zion reminds us of Yosemite a little because of the trees and trails but Zion is big enough to bring you back again. If you are of the right age to purchase a senior pass ($10.00) and you visit more than one park you can enjoy a very nice savings, we did 7 parks and saved $200.00....the shuttle service in the park is outstanding and free. You can get on and off and any stop and then get back on after you're done taking in the sights. Thank you Americas National Park systems we cannot put in words what we've seen.

Zion is located in Springdale, Utah, only 2 ½ hours northeast of Las Vegas and about 3 ½ hours northwest of Grand Canyon North Rim. It was a great stop to put in the middle of our trip to those two places. There is a $30 fee per car to enter based on how many cars you drove on your trip there or to your hotel. It is good for one week. You may drive through the part of the park that is open to through traffic with this paid receipt. This park was different for us in that you cannot drive through the section of the park that has all the trailheads. To get to those areas you must ride the park shuttle. All the shuttles are free. If you want to park at the Visitor’s Center, you may if you can get there early enough to get a spot. Otherwise, the city of Springdale has a free shuttle also that takes people to Zion National Park Visitor’s Center. It is very convenient as they run about every 5-15 minutes throughout the day and evening until about 9 p.m. We were only able to spend one full day in the park, but we were able to do a lot of trails. Emerald Pools was a beautiful trail which leads to three levels of waterfalls. The Grotto trail connects into it and we took it on the to the next shuttle stop in order not to backtrack. Weeping Rock is nice, but very steep although a short distance. A lot of people walk the Riverside Trail which leads to the Narrows. The day we were there a storm came up and prevented people from doing the Narrows trail. It is a trail IN the river. You may walk up to your waist or higher in the water. Those who take this trail are advised to start very early and have plenty of water and snacks as well as shoes suitable to walk in the water. There are several picnic areas and bathrooms scattered throughout the park. In Zion you are looking UP whereas at Grand Canyon you are looking DOWN. There are beautiful rock features and canyons here as you follow the trails up. We really enjoyed this park!

Southern Utah's natural environment is stunning. Zion is a stunning example. Just the desensitized into the canyon is better than any E Ticket ride at Disneyland. Folks who have not been in red rock, or Navajo country are likely to think that they are in a grand movie set.

Narrows was awesome. Go to Guru and get boots, sticks and socks. Worth the $20!! Get up early and take the 6 AM shuttle. This is not a hike where you want to be around thousands of others. Wait until 12 and you will be. It's so peaceful and beautiful if you go at the right time. Anything passed 10 looks like Disneyland. Plus you will wait an hour for shuttles. Trust me!! And take a nap when you get back.

We went over a weekend in July and it was super crowded. But it was worth the drive. We stayed in Kanab which was a little less crowded than Springdale but it did take longer to get to the visitor's center. It was 30 minutes to the gate and then another 30 to the visitor's center. It worked out ok for us because we took a day to drive an hour and 20 minutes to Page, Arizona to see Antelope Canyon and do a boat tour of Lake Powell. But if you are just doing Zion, I would say it is much more convenient to stay in Springdale. I think you end up paying a bit more for having such easy access to the park. I had purchased an annual park pass ($80) and it has already paid for itself with trips to Carlsbad Caverns, White Sands, Antelope Marina, and Zion.

First of all the Zion National Park entrance is in Springdale, UT and parking is wherever you can find it. There are shuttles that run up and down the main drag or you can walk and there can be crowds. Springdale is completely oriented around Zion with outfitter shops, different types of restaurants from fast to higher bistro style. Be ready for this with small back pack, plenty of water, trail mix, first aid, etc. If you are hiking the slot canyons you will need water walkers on your feet & shorts or you can rent water shoes at a shop before you hike, some people wear wet suits. Pay close attention to the warning signs posted regarding possible flash floods. The day after we were there a few EXPERIENCED slot hikers were killed because of intense thunderstorms a few miles away. The other hiking trails provide fantastic vistas and you will not regret the experience. When you're done for the day and you are making your way back to the car there are more than enough restaurants to satisfy your appetite & your thirst. Highly Recommend & would love to go back.

We visited this place by accident on the way to Las Vegas from Page AZ. Going through this national park offers the quickest route, but we have to pay the $30 park admission fee. It turned out to be money well spent as this place is amazing. The bypass road is surrounded by gigantic rocky mountains. Some offers nice hiking experience. This is truly one of the best kept secret nature wonders in the US.

I've heard great things about Zion's beauty but I was also surprised by how well run the Park is. There is one road you can take your car on and it's worth the drive. The main part of the Park is reachable by the Park's shuttle system which does a loop through the Park and you can hop out at about 9 different stops to do your own hikes. The hikes we did were very moderate and easy to walk along. Some are even wheelchair accessible. The bathrooms are clean, the Visitor Center is gorgeous and the staff is friendly and accommodating. If you plan on visiting several National Parks in a year consider getting the Annual National Park Pass for $80. The natural beauty of Zion is fabulous and the management of the Park makes the visit even better.

We parked in the big parking lot at the entrance to the park - It's a $10 fee but well worth it. You walk over a wooden bridge to enter the park and from there, it's the best shuttle system ever! They are timed to where you never have to wait more than 5-7 mins to catch the next one. We took the first one all the way to the top and then shuttle-hopped all the way down, jumping off and on at each stop. The Weeping Rock was my favorite, but the short hike up to it is quite steep. Take water bottles and fill them with spring water at various stops. Jagged red cliffs are at one end of the park while flowing waves are at the other. If possible, take the car trip the length of the park and drive through the mountain tunnel. You won't be disappointed!

The National Park Service has done a great job preparing this Park for visitors with the Visitor Center (Trip Advisor) and the Free Shuttle bus that takes you to all of the main stops along the way. Note: NPS Fee Area. They also offer an informative Jr Ranger Program. This makes it very easy to enjoy that park at your own pace and level of effort. Great work keeping this natural beauty clean for us.

Visit the Visitors Center to get the map and overview, then enjoy. The scenery is unbelievable, and your pictures will not do it justice. If you take pictures, be sure to also look at the scenery with your eyes and not just the camera. A good pair of binoculars will enhance the views that stretch for miles. Price of entry is $30 without a senior parks pass.

Zion was the first National Park on our trip. It was beautiful. The Visitor's Center had a lot of great information- there were places everywhere to fill your water bottles. I loved the fact that no matter how long the line was at the entrance, the ranger would take time to initiate " Junior Rangers" before they went in to the park. Each park has a place for them to stamp their National Park Passport- so very awesome. It was so great to see kids staring down into their hands looking at ROCKS not electronics!! A very accessible park on many trails. There were many folks in wheelchairs and with strollers.

Beautiful park. The visitor center is worth going to (it’s just inside the west entrance). It’s very well done, has lots of information outside as well as park rangers inside, a gift shop, and restrooms. There is a $30 entrance fee per car. You have to use the free park shuttles to get to any hikes. They run often and I recommend you get there for the first shuttle to avoid big crowds. Great hiking here

We took a trip here, while the entrance fee was free. Usually there is about a $30 per car fee. There is a shuttle bus that took us up the canyon. It had about 9 stops and took about thirty minutes one way. They ranked the walks and hikes in an easy to read format. It is important to note that it is in a canyon, so unless you are an experienced hiker not all the walks are top of a mountain views. All the walks we took were wonderful though! It's a great National Park. There is a place for donations at the gift shop. All the rangers seemed very nice. Oh, and we got our National Park Passport stamped!
Recommend having a NPS Access Pass since the per car cost is $30 for a 7 day pass.
Passed through the park in March 2016, very difficult to keep my eyes on the road as this is probably the most beautiful National Park I've ever been to. We will definitely be returning!

I got there by about 8 a.m. and there was parking just outside the entrance to the Park. There are about 12-15 free parking spots right above the store and theater parking lot (that one charges you $10). If you park just up the hill from the gear store, you walk down a small hill and follow the signs over the bridge to the Visitors' Center. The charge is only $15 to walk into the Park and use the shuttle service. If you are not interested in visiting the eastern part of the Park and driving out to Route 9, this is a great stress-free option. The bus will take you all the way to the riverwalk trail which leads to the beginning of the Narrows (a very challenging hike done mostly in water). After the Riverwalk trail, I went back to the shuttle and took it to the entrance to the trail to the Upper Emerald Pools (an easy to moderate hike) and after lunch I did the Watchman trail which is somewhat underwhelming, but there is a river at the foot of the Watchman where you can swim. Bring your swim suits (I did not and was resigned to rolling up my pants and wading in up to my calves). Very refreshing nonetheless.

We stayed at the La Qinta in town, and caught the shuttle each day to the entrance.$30 for two to enter, and this is for one week and good for Bryce National Park. We had asked at the information in town about the trails, and. were shown the easy ones and the length of each. We caught the shuttle to the last stop........it is paved and quite easy and beautiful.......it ends at the beginning of the hike to the narrows......too chicken to do that one, and you have to hike through the icy water.

Thanksgiving weekend is last weekend the park offers bus service throughout. The main issue is actually getting into the park with serious construction causing heavy delays. The parking lots are $20 and we found people leaving on Thanksgiving so we were able to see some of the park that afternoon. It was very warm and crowded but the beauty outweighs any of that. The second day we arrived at 7am and the lines for the buses were already long. It’s cold in am so layers are necessary. We went to stop 9 the last stop in the main park with the rest of the early birds. The hike on the river edge is beautiful but windy in the am without much sun. The next stop was weeping rock a very short steep hike up to see the rocks ooze out water. The view is spectacular from the weeping rock. The lodge stop offers sit down or quick food and we opted fir sit down at 11:30. The taco Buffett was Good plus soup and salad before afternoon hikes. There are petroglyphs and we were lucky to find them and get photos. It’s understandable the location is not noted on park maps so these beauties aren’t destroyed. Hoping that people will only take pictures if located. We stayed for sunset every night in a different spot and each was stunningly beautiful. Plan to arrive early, bring layers of clothes, snacks, and water to stay the whole day.

This park is a long drive from Salt Lake City but I'm glad I went. Spent the night three miles from the park at The Pines motel. Could have gotten a cheaper, closer and modernized room but I didn't do my homework. The canyon is awesome. Some of the best pictures I've ever taken which I owe to the bright, clear days and the vivid canyon colors. Very walkable and you can drive right up to a number of scenic lookups located all along the one main road that runs thru the park. The historic lodge at the park is a classic, ate breakfast, lunch and dinner there, a bit pricey but great wait staff. Attended an evening presentation by the park ranger about bears that was very well attended and very interesting for all ages. On site corral with twice a day trail rides, $60 for two hour ride. I would definitely visit again.

This is perhaps the most beautiful natural wonder in the U.S. The lake is ink blue in color due to its depth (19,00 feet), the deepest lake in the world. It is six miles in width in most places. The views from the rim are absolutely enthralling. There is a tortuous rim drive, which is worth taking. A 1.1 mile trail takes you down to the lake level, where you can take a boat ride for $35. You must, however, book the seat at least six months ahead. The boat ride is thrilling. The water is truly ink blue even from near. The lake is surrounded by virgin forest and rising volcanic hills. Plan on spending at least two full days exploring the area. The lake water is so clean that it is drinkable. It has enough water to give 100 gallons per person to the entire world population.

Crater Lake is one of the most beautiful natural wonders in the U.S. I have seen! The mountains are always breathtaking and to have snow in July when it is 80 degrees is so much fun! The water in the lake is the most gorgeous royal blue! Plenty to see and hike or just have a picnic lunch each day. The cabins are very nice and there are activities to do at the park each day with the rangers. Crater Lake Lodge is cozy but pricey. Dinner for 2 was $100 which is a lot when you aren't out for a fancy dinner but sightseeing. It is more about the experience and the history of the lodge. We took the boat ride on the lake and it was well worth the cost! The hike back up is strenuous just like they say. It was hard to say goodbye to this beautiful place!

Wow, what a unique experience. This monument is vast, however most people probably think about the Quarry exhibit hall. It is truly unique and well worth a visit and very inexpensive at only $10 per car at this time. Very impressive fossil experience. There are also many miles of hiking, camping, float trips, petroglyphs and other activities available for those who wish to partake. There is a hiking opportunity just outside the Quarry building on which we saw wildlife, petroglyphs and fossils out in the elements. The best advise is to start at the top at the Quarry and end the hike after .7 mile at the visitor center - it is almost all downhill the whole way. If you start below at the visitor's center be ready for some uphill hiking!

I was a little skeptical of paying $170 and missing most of the day in Key West, but I'm so glad we did. The ferry ride is about 2 1/2 hours each way, and you need to arrive around 7AM and will return at 5PM. We both brought books and read most of the way there and back. The seas were smooth, less than 1 foot, so reading might not be as fun on rougher seas. We did spend some time out on the deck, but it was hot and inside was comfortable. You have a lot of freedom to explore once you arrive at the fort. We took a self guided tour, then snorkeled most of the afternoon. The ferry serves breakfast (eggs, yogurt, bagels, cereal, pastries, yogurt) and lunch (sandwiches ham/turkey with chips and cookies). And you can buy cokes and snacks on the way, alcoholic drinks on the return. Don't miss this great experience!

This civil war era fort has a lot of history and they let you roam basically everywhere except one part of the fort where they have placed gaudy portable buildings within sight of the tour area. It looks like crap. It also seems the pace of reconstructing this fort which they let fall apart for a long time is slow. The beauty can't be matched. The tour boat people to get you here are very professional and really respect and follow the rules. It's about $170 a person to get here though.

DC for $16 a night? who can really complain? We went in April when it was self serve and only two loops were open, we stayed in loop D which was mostly for RV's. It was not easy to find a site with a nice level spot to put a large family tent. Small tents would have worked better, this campground is mostly set up for RV/campers. I wish the bathrooms were cleaned better but I just used flip flops for showering (which is normal for camping). There was only 1 shower for the entire loop, which was not too bad in April but I couldn't imagine the wait for a shower in the summer. You will have to drive to the metro (forget walking), which costs $5(greenbelt) to $10(college park) a day to park and about $7 per person round trip to ride. The drive to the station is quick and easy, only about a 5 minutes. It took about 20 to 40 minutes to ride to the mall via the metro. Grocery stores etc. are only about 1 mile away. We were rarely there during the day so as a place to sleep at night it really suited our needs. By the way, DC traffic really IS a nightmare.

Yesterday and today we had spent some time at the Hawaii Volcanoes National Park. Yesterday there was no admissions fees due to the fact that it was a national holiday where as today there was a fee of $20 to enter the park. We had arrived to the park around 4:30pm in the afternoon with a plan to see the lava flows in the Chain of Craters at night. When you drive down to the very end of the Chain of Craters there's a gated area with a turnaround and everyone parks along the shoulder on the right side so that way they may be able to walk towards the gravel roadway. While we were excited to see this natural phenomenon we did not anticipate the long walk that laid ahead. After parking the car there's roughly a 3 1/2 mile walk that's over paved and gravel roadways. At the end of the 3 1/2 mile walk you'll come to a barricade with usually a Ranger standing towards the end of the road. He will direct you to follow the rope that is staked down and runs the perimeter of the most recent lava flow. The neat thing is by the time we had arrive to that point the sun was almost setting so we Donde headlamps onto our heads which is highly recommended and make sure that you also have decent tennis shoes or boots to wear while traversing the lava flow. So while we're traveling and traversing this lava flow which took us approximately one hour to go along the perimeter of the roped off area you'll notice that the lava has a silver refinish it's very fine as well as everywhere you step it's like stepping on glass you're consistently hear the cracking of the rock or what is beneath you. Once you arrive on the other end of the lava flow they'll be another ranger directing traffic from all the visitors from the Pahoa side of the Big Island. Then you have the opportunity to block the last 100 m to the viewing area to see the lava flow flowing into the ocean. It is an incredible sight to see. Once you're done viewing the lava flow then you have a long walk back to your vehicle along the same route that you took. Recommend to all viewers that in regards to this specific lava flow I would charter a boat to see it by the ocean or come and visit through the Pahoa side of the park.

Cost $20 to enter the national park. We got there about 4:00 pm. Visitor center closes at 5:00. It's a nice center and the guides are welcoming, friendly, and knowledgeable. Well-maintained restrooms. We were only disappointed in that to get to the current eruption, you have to drive another 2 miles from the VC (not a big deal), but then have to hike 4.1 TO the eruption site. You can take a bike tour (which they said is about 45 min TO, cost is okay for the rental - $20). We did go through a breath-taking lava tube and you can go to the steam vent, as well. I'd recommend planning to spend more than 3 hours there.
very cool with a lot of neat things--visitors cernter is cool (as well as cool on those summer days) PS--get tickets online and it's worth the $1.50 cost to best plan your day!

This was side visit on my way back home from Maryland. I had heard about the flood in my history class several years prior and how devastating it was. This memorial does a great job of documenting the town's history, the flood timeline as well as showcasing artifacts relevant to the time period. I highly recommend watching the video about the flood. They give a warning about its content as the sound effects and details can be frightening to small children, so use discretion in deciding if the film is appropriate for them. The park ranger can describe the video better than I. The gift shop for the memorial is small but is adequate to pick up a memento of the memorial for your collection (shirts, postcards,etc.). The admission fee is around $4 per person to help with upkeep of the memorial. You can also take some pictures of where the dam used to be outside the window. SInce I visited during the winter and is was quite cold, I wasn't able to walk around the site too much but I still able to take plenty of pictures of the area. This memorial is located in a rural part of Pennsylvania.

Well designed park. Drive through, stop where you wish. Grazing cattle, free range, goats, sheep, horses and deer. The Johnsons are buried here with other family. Many historic buildings pertaining to President Johnson. Tour The Texas White House for $3.00. The Rangers make it very interesting. See President Johnson's plane. If you remember the 60's, this is a frozen moment in time. Even if you don't remember the time period, the history is riveting and the Pedernales River is green, flowing and so lovely. I loved this place with the warm sun, green fields, animals, history, stories and the wind. Start at visitor center and follow LBJ Ranch Tour signs. There is also the National Park Visitor Center in Johnson City. Lots to see in two locations.
park: Lyndon B. Johnson National Historical Park

text: This particular tour at Mammoth Cave is about 2 miles in length and takes about 2 hours to complete. Although one can reserve spots, you could take a chance to see if any available spots are available on the tour. This tour at this time costs $14.00 for adults. Starting at the natural entrance of the cave, the tour proceeds through a number of sections, most easily accessible for most individuals with decent mobility and is accessible for children; although, it is best for children capable of walking at least two miles. During the tour, one must be able to ascend or descend a number of steps, the most difficult being towards the end of the tour when a 150 step staircase must be ascended to bring you up to the main level of the cave. Two slightly challenging areas are the “fat man’s misery” and the “tall man’s misery” the first a section of the cave where the lower portion of the trail where your legs are is about 15 inches or so wide while the top portion is much wider. For most people it is required to go through sideways. Almost immediately after this section, one must essentially walk while lowering one’s body several inches to walk through a short span that is not very tall.

A MUST SEE FOR EVERYONE. I had never been to a cave, and I'm told the tour I went on, "The Historic Tour", is the not the most amazing one, but I was most amazed. The tour was two hours and two miles. I'm overweight and lazy, and had no problem managing the hike. Every inch of the cave tour was fascinating. I strongly recommend a small LED flashlight to shine in the cracks and corners as you go. The park lighting is just enough to see your general surroundings, but I wanted more. The tour guides don't spent a lot of time talking, the cave speaks for itself. They stop at a few significant points, but mostly they let you walk and enjoy. I would say it's a bit much for any kid who can't get around on their own. It would be an awesome adventure and memory for any eight year old. You do NOT want to carry a child through this. If you are very obese, there are a few spots that might cause embarrassment. This is a tremendous value at $12.00, but coupons for 2$ off can be found in the area hotels. It's a national park, so every dollar goes to very good use. You could call it a day after one tour and be quite fulfilled. Book ahead because I'm told the peak season often sells out early. We had a small tour on May 11.

This was the highlight of our trip to the inside passage of Alaska! We almost did not go due to the rising air fare costs and therefore did not book a flight prior to sailing with Princess cruise. However, that morning in Ketchikan we looked at each other and said we did not want to regret doing this, and it was a beautiful sunny morning! Outside the ship we spoke to a air tour broker and signed up for about $160 less (per couple) than our previous quotes. We were not disappointed, and saw what a diverse area surrounded Ketchikan. Tongass National park is big and so is Misty Fjord. I would say the sights are Yosemite X's 10, at least. I would definitely recommend Taquan Air.

This carving is HUGE! Very well run place, really impressed with the whole experience. Just wish I had more time to spend there. Parking was great, it cost $11 but is good until the end of the calendar year. They have built a parking garage into the side of the mountain!

What can we say – it is Mt Rushmore. Very cool to look up and see in person what you have seen on TV, in Hitchcock movies, in history books for all these years. We listened to a ranger talk in the Sculptor’s Studio, where they have the scale model used to eventually create this colossal sculpture. The talk did a great job of explaining how they did it, they had an actual bosun’s chair and hand winch used to get men on and off the rock face, and did a great job explaining the whole process. Carved basically with dynamite. Truly inspiring. $11 for parking, admission free.

This place was awe inspiring. Sooooo clean! We came early (8am) to take advantage of "Breakfast with the Presidents" This is done at Carvers Restaurant at the memorial. Something cool about sitting outside under the gaze of the four presidents. Price for breakfast VERY reasonable.

Don't believe people who say "don't pay the $11 to park". You do not get a very good view on the side of road. GO INTO THE MEMORIAL AND PAY THE $11. This will allow you to come back at the end of the day, when they light up Mt. Rushmore. Additionally, they do a ceremony in the evenings where they have prior military persons in the audience come to the stage to thank them for their service and to lower the flag. I'm glad I paid.

If you are traveling to South Dakota anyway, this is worth seeing. However, I would not plan a special trip to see it as the memorial is not as impressive as one would think since it is located on a rather small mountain and the faces are carved so high on the mountain that they look rather small when you see it from the road. The visitor center itself is nicely done, but in order to visit it, one must pay for $11 for parking. The parking fee is good for the rest of the year, but for folks visiting from out of state not likely to be used.

1st of all, people need to realize Mt Rushmore is nothing more than a huge sculpture. Don't set aside an entire day to see it. It is one of those things you should see up close if you are in the area. I remember seeing it when I was a kid. I don't remember there being much more than a big parking lot with lots of trees in it and a visitor's center. It was a sculpture surrounded by nature. Now they have permanently scarred the area by building all this crap around it. There are restaurants (think $9 for a plain cafeteria burger), gift shops, an amphitheater. I think they are building all the stuff around it to compensate for the fact that all it is is a sculpture. If all you want is to see the faces, save yourself the $10 "parking" fee and look at it from outside. One thing I think is an improvement are the trails that let you walk all the way up to the base of the sculpture. Other than that, it is nothing more than a big tourist trap and an embarrassment to America.

Took a quick scramble up the fairly steep Mesa Trail at Boca Negra in the western part of the park. Amazing petroglyphs, some possibly thousands of years old. Sweeping views of Albuquerque and environs, including extinct volcanic cones and that gives-you-chills wide open New Mexico sky. Just wish I'd had more time to explore more trails. A bargain at $2!

We loved Pisgah National Forest. We visited the Cradle of Forestry where we had a great hour long tour of the school and the grounds. Very cool and interesting. The highlight of Pisgah was Sliding Rock, which was beautiful and thrilling. Our kids loved it and went down multiple times. We went at 4:00 the last week of August, and since school had already started in NC there were no crowds, and no fee. (We live in Maryland where school starts one week later.) There were no lifeguards on duty so the bathrooms were locked. Previous reviewers recommended water shoes, which were critical for the slippery rocks. Our son did not have water shoes with him, so we stopped at the Walmart in Waynesville and bought $5 canvas sneakers which worked just as well. Very highly recommended. We plan to return.

We found the self guided tour to be interesting and informative. We enjoyed learning more about the history of the native culture. It was hot with very little shade. All the exhibits are outdoors. There are restrooms and water fountains but no food or drinks available and you cannot eat in the park. Best to bring bug spray and sunscreen. It was an easy trail but terrain is uneven and lava rocks get hot. It costs five dollars to park. If you park there, you can easily walk next door for incredible snorkeling. You cannot snorkel in the park.
park: Pu'uhonua O Honaunau National Historical Park

text: Yes it is November but no crowds and no traffic during our visit. Being it almost Veteran's Day What better way to celebrate than with visiting this site. Stop at the visitor center to get started. Nice indoor exhibits. The park ranger was very knowledgable and since we had time we bought the $14.00 audio tour CD. It was great narrating facts and pointing out all the sites at a nice pace. It takes about an hour but we learned so much! We have family in Philly and will leave it for their visitors to use since Valley Forge is only about 45-60 minutes from Philly. I bought a cute little log cabin ornament made literally by a "little old lady" nearby. It is rolled up paper in the shape of logs with"snow" on the roof!
We love sledding here! Bring your own or buy at the gift shop for $15
